title: A prospective, controlled trial of a pharmacy-driven alerting system to increase thromboprophylaxis rates in inpatients.
abstract: Although venous thromboembolism is an important cause of morbidity and mortality in the hospital, a significant portion of patients at risk do not take precautions known to reduce the risk of deep vein thrombosis and pulmonary embolism. The aim of this study was to determine whether a pharmacy-guided alerting system would be associated with a higher rate of adequate venous thromboembolism prevention measures compared to usual care among at-risk patients admitted to the general internal medicine ward. The study was a prospective, controlled trial set in a university-based teaching hospital. Participants were adults admitted to the general internal medicine inpatient ward between 19 June and 21 September 2006 (Monday to Friday). Their treatment included pharmacist assessment of the risk of venous thromboembolism and a pharmacist-directed warning to the treating physician. The proportion of at-risk patients who received adequate thromboprophylaxis within 36 hours of admission was recorded. In total, 140 patients were at sufficient risk for venous thromboembolism to be included. In the usual care group, prophylactic measures were requested for 49 (61%) of 80 patients at moderate to high risk. In the pharmacist alert group, 44 (73%) of 60 patients at moderate to high risk of venous thromboembolism received adequate thromboprophylaxis (P = 0.15). Although we did not observe a statistically significant difference between groups, our results are in line with previous reports suggesting that warning systems may increase the proportion of hospitalized patients who take adequate precautions to prevent venous thromboembolism.

title: The effect of clinical pharmacy service on lipid control in patients with peripheral arterial disease.
abstract: Objective Our group and others have previously identified that patients with peripheral artery disease (PAD) are significantly undertreated in terms of overall cardiovascular risk factor management, despite national guidelines to the contrary. To maximize risk factor control in our patients with PAH, we created a pharmacist-led, physician-monitored algorithmic approach to the outpatient management of lipids in patients with PAH. The aim of this study was to determine the impact of this service on lipid screening and control in patients with PAH. Methods We analyzed records of patients treated in a large, group-model, nonprofit regionally managed care system serving approximately 405,000 members. The electronic medical record provided complete examination, laboratory and pharmacy data for all patients. Pharmacy data were analyzed to identify prescriptions for lipid-lowering agents. Lipid control was assessed with fasting lipid data. Patients with confirmed PAH and no clinical coronary artery disease (CAD) were served and followed for at least 6 months between May 2003 and September 2004. Results We identified 5159 active patients with an administrative diagnosis of PAH. Of these, 1075 can be confirmed by a non-invasive arterial study. Exclusion of 384 patients with a diagnosis of CAD resulted in a cohort of 691 patients. Of these, 90 patients were admitted to the lipid service (study group), and 601 received standard care. The mean follow-up was 17.1 months. Screening fasting lipid profiles were found in 95.6% (86/90) of patients in the study group and only 66.9% (402/601) of standard-care patients (P < .0001). Low-density lipoprotein cholesterol (LDL-C) control was improved in the pharmacist-administered group, with 79.1% (68/86) LDL-C below 100 mg/dL compared to the standard care group (54.8%) [219/400]" ;" P < .0001). An LDL-C value of greater than 130 mg/dL was recorded in the treatment and control groups at 1.2% and 14.0% (56/400), respectively (P < .001). Statin use was present in 51.9% (312/601) of the control group patients and 84.4% (76/90) of the pharmacist-administered group (P < .001). Conclusions Despite the national consensus for PAH as a CAD equivalent, patients are currently under-treated for atherosclerotic risk factor modification. Launching a pharmacist-led, physician-monitored lipid service better aligns with national guidelines

title: Using peer feedback to improve hand washing and glove use among Thai healthcare workers.
abstract: Background: Without preventive practices such as Universal Precautions, healthcare workers are at significant risk for blood-borne infection, especially in areas with a high prevalence of HIV infection, such as Thailand. The aim of this study was to evaluate the effectiveness of a peer feedback program (PFP) on handwashing and wearing gloves (HW/GW) among Thai healthcare workers. Methods: Subjects (N = 91) were randomly assigned to receive PFP versus no treatment. Peer observers rated their colleagues' HW/GW compatibility during patient care using a checklist. For 1 month, the researcher published a report on the adaptive behaviors obtained from every 3-day observation. HW/GW was also assessed by the investigator by direct observation 1 month before, during the intervention, and 1 month after the intervention. Results: Baseline HW/GW ratios for the PFP and control groups were 49.2% and 61.5%, respectively. The PFP group had a significantly higher adjusted compliance rate than the control group during the intervention period (P =.0001). However, there was no significant difference in the compliance scores obtained 1 month after the intervention. Results: PFP was effective during the intervention period, but the effect was not persistent. Therefore, additional methods should be sought to promote preservation of the effect. (AJIC Am J Infect Control 2000";"28:365-9)

title: "Doctoring" Doctors and Their Families
abstract: Being selected to provide medical care to other doctors or family members not only represents professional recognition of competence by one's peers, but also represents a challenge. Many personal and psychological factors can affect physicians' medical care. Patient physicians may have difficulty with role-switching and "VIP syndrome," while treating physicians may have to deal with their own concerns and issues such as confidentiality, privacy, empathy, and the involvement of a physician relative in the care of medical family members. . Based on experience with more than 200 physician-patients and many adult physician family members, recommendations are offered for the care of these patient groups.

title: "Ethics and clinical research" revisited. A tribute to Henry K. Beecher
abstract: The doctrine of informed consent, borrowed from tort law, is not easily transplanted into therapeutic settings. The broader idea of yet-to-be-realized informed consent, which suggests that parties should decide together, should guide interactions between physicians and patients, or between researchers and subjects.

title: "First, do no harm": legal guidelines for health programs affecting 10-17 year olds who sell sex or inject drugs
abstract: INTRODUCTION: There is a strong evidence base that the stigma, discrimination and delinquency affecting key adolescent populations (KPs) aged 10-17 is intensified due to national and international legal structures based on law enforcement-based interventions related to detention. Mandatory “rehabilitation” in pending detention, incarceration and institutional placement. While there are evidence- and rights-based technical guidelines for interventions among older groups, these guidelines have yet to be adopted by international public health actors for fear that international law imposes different standards on adolescents aged 10-17 who engage in behavior such as selling sex. or injecting drugs. DISCUSSION: As required by international human rights, health, juvenile justice and child protection law, interventions among adolescent KPs aged 10-17 should not involve any arrest, prosecution or detention. It is imperative that interventions do not rely on law enforcement, but instead utilize low-threshold, voluntary services, shelter and support, and peer-based outreach whenever possible. These services must be mobile and accessible and allow alternatives to parental leave to provide life-saving support, including HIV testing, treatment and care, needle and syringe programs, opioid substitution treatment, safe abortions, antiretroviral therapy and gender-affirming care. and hormone therapy for transgender adolescents. To enable enrollment in the Services, international guidance states that informed consent and confidentiality must be provided, including waiving parental consent requirements. To remove deterrents to health practitioners and researchers from engaging with adolescent KPs aged 10-17, it is recommended that government agencies and ethics review boards exempt or waive mandatory reporting. If authorities try to unintentionally place adolescent KPs in institutions in violation of international law and guidelines, they have the right to take legal action. Legal guidelines also ensure that these adolescents have a say over their placement, have access to legal counsel to challenge conditions of detention and regular visits from peers, friends and family, and that all facilities are subject to frequent and periodic review by independent organizations, including: Community-based groups led by KPs. CONCLUSIONS: Auditing international law states that protective interventions among KPs aged 10-17 not only must include low-threshold, voluntary services, but must also "protect" adolescent KPs from harm caused by law enforcement interventions. Going forward, health practitioners should adjust programs to the principles of minimum intervention, due process and proportionality, respecting the right to health and appropriately limiting participation in juvenile justice and child protection, if any, as a last resort.

title: "How much will you get paid if I volunteer?" Suggested institutional policy on award, consent, and research
abstract: Pharmaceutical companies often ask GPs to conduct phase IV or postmarketing research on new drugs. Companies pay doctors to enroll their patients and report dosage and side-effect information. Postmarketing research involves billions of dollars in promotion and familiarization, but subjects' informed consent to it does not normally include physician reward. Improving investigators' finances while increasing the medical risks to Phase IV subjects is ethically wrong, especially if the subjects are unaware of the investigator's rewards. We propose a model policy and guideline that validates subjects' need for informed consent, researchers' need for recognition and support, and institutions' need to protect patients from undisclosed risks and relationships.

title: "Don't fix it if it's not broken
"Let Me Get You a Nicotine Patch": Nurses' Perceptions of Implementing the Smoking Cessation Guidelines for Hospitalized Veterans
abstract: Many hospitalized smokers do not receive the recommended tobacco treatment in the guideline, but little is known about inpatient nurses' perceptions of tobacco treatment. We used a sequential explanatory mixed methods design to help explain the findings of an academic elaboration intervention trial in the inpatient units of four Veterans Affairs (VA) hospitals. We surveyed 164 nurses and conducted semi-structured interviews with a purposeful sample of 33 nurses with different attitudes towards graduation counseling. Content analysis was used to inductively characterize the issues raised by the participants. The resulting themes were categorized using the knowledge-attitude-behavior framework of adherence to the guideline. Informational and attitudinal barriers included perceived lack of skill in quit counseling and skepticism about the effectiveness of quit guidelines in hospitalized veterans. Nurses also reported multiple behavioral and organizational barriers to compliance with the guideline: resistance from patients, insufficient time and resources, presence of smoking areas in VA facilities, and lack of coordination with primary care. VA hospitals should train inpatient staff on how to negotiate behavior change, integrate quit counseling into nurses' workflow, develop alternative referral mechanisms for post-discharge dropout counseling, and adopt hospital policies to promote inpatient withdrawal.

title: Evidence "rules" for assessing efficacy and effectiveness of treatments
abstract: A brief review of the "rules of evidence" for assessing the efficacy and efficacy of treatments leads to a discussion of what the future holds in the development of guidelines for randomized clinical trials (RCTs) to increase the impact of such studies. . The primary condition for increasing the impact of research seems to be discussions and interactions between researchers, clinicians, policy makers and patient advocates on the one hand, and between basic scientists and clinical researchers on the other.

title: (S)Partners for Heart Health: A school-based program to improve physical activity and nutrition to improve cardiovascular health in grade 5 students
abstract: BACKGROUND: The American Heart Association Position Statement on the Promotion of Cardiovascular Health in Public Schools encourages school-based interventions for primary prevention of cardiovascular disease (CVD) in children through prevention or reduction of risk factors, with an emphasis on creating an environment that promotes healthy food choices. and physical activity (PA). To address issues related to CVD risk factors, including obesity, in Michigan children, a multidisciplinary team of Michigan State University (MSU) faculty, clinicians, and healthcare students was formed as a "(S)partner" with elementary school physics education. Education (PE) teachers and MSU Extension staff to develop and implement an affordable, sustainable program for CVD risk factor prevention and management for 5th grade students. This (S) partnership aims to strengthen and improve the existing 5th grade PE, health and nutrition curriculum by achieving the following objectives: 1) to improve students' knowledge, attitudes, and confidence in nutrition, FA, and heart health"; 2) to increase PA and nutrition number of students reaching national recommendations; and 3) increasing the number of students with desired CVD risk factor status based on national pediatric guidelines. Secondary purposes include promoting school staff and parental support for heart health to help children achieve their goals and provide experiential learning and service to MSU healthcare professionals for academic credit. METHODS/DESIGN: This pilot effectiveness study was approved by the MSU IRB. At the beginning and end of the academic year, students undergo a CVD risk factor assessment conducted by MSU medical students and graduate students. Key intervention components include eight lesson plans (performed bimonthly) designed to promote heart-healthy eating and PA behaviors, conducted by Physical Education teachers with the assistance of MSU undergraduate dietetics and kinesiology students (Spartners). In the last 10 minutes of each class, MSU Spartners organizes small breakout/discussion groups with 5th graders. Additionally, each Spartner case manages/mentors two to three 5th graders using a web-based goal setting and tracking protocol throughout the school year. DISCUSSION: This article explains the rationale, development, and methods of the Spartners for Heart Health program. This is a multi-level intervention designed to promote heart health behaviors and prevent or manage CVD risk factors in children. We believe this will be a viable, sustainable intervention that can be disseminated and adopted by other institutions at minimal cost, by involving university students as an integral part of measurement and response teams.

title: “Value for money” : use with caution
abstract: In this issue, Owens and colleagues (1) argue that the goal of policy should be to “protect the delivery of good value interventions.” “Unintentional reductions in effective and efficient maintenance”. Cutler and colleagues (2) argued that an intervention that benefits more than costs is socially beneficial regardless of whether it increases spending or not. The American College of Physicians Clinical Guidelines Committee makes an important contribution to this policy debate by providing definitions and concepts to guide the pursuit of high-value healthcare, but its "value for money" goal raises many questions that warrant further discussion. .

title: 15 Red Herrings and 100 Apples Split: A Careful Story from the Mid-19th Century on Comparing Hospital Mortality Rates
abstract: In 1863, Florence Nightingale argued that London hospitals were dangerous, especially when compared to provincial facilities. He backed up this claim with statistics published in William Fair's General Registrar's report, which claimed that the death rates of 24 London hospitals exceeded 90%, while rural hospitals had an average mortality rate of 13%. Farr calculated mortality rates by dividing the total number of patients who died during the year by the number of inpatients in a single day. Calculated by dividing the annual number of deaths by the total number of inpatients during the year, the death rate for London hospitals was 10%. A heated debate erupted in the London medical press about how best to calculate hospital mortality rates. Critics argued that Farr did not adjust to the differences in disease severity between urban and rural hospitals, and that his figures would mislead the public. Farr and Nightingale criticized the poor quality of hospital data. This story reinforces the need to understand the methodological derivation of statistics aimed at comparing provider quality.

title: 1931 German guidelines on human experimentation
2013 ACC/AHA cholesterol treatment guideline: A paradigm shift in managing the risk of atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease
abstract: The 2013 American College of Cardiology/American Heart Association Guidelines on the Treatment of Blood Cholesterol to Reduce Atherosclerotic Cardiovascular Risk in Adults represents a major shift from previous cholesterol management guidelines. The new guidelines include data from the most comprehensive meta-analyses as well as individual randomized trials and present several major paradigm shifts, including: targeting to reduce the risk of ASCVD rather than targeting LDL-C levels, advocating the use of evidence - based on statin doses and statin as first-line therapy Use of a new risk calculator and risk cut-off point to guide initiation of therapy. These major changes have caused controversy and confusion in the medical community, with some clinicians hesitant to embrace this change. We review the evidence underlying these major changes, compare them with other major lipid guidelines, and propose an integrated approach to managing dyslipidemia to reduce the risk of atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease.

title: 2015 AAHA/AAFP pain management guidelines for dogs and cats
abstract: RATIONALE: Strong advances in pain management for pets underpinned the decision of the American Association of Animal Hospitals (AAHA) and the American Association of Feline Practitioners (AAFP) to expand the information provided in the 2007 AAHA/AAFP Pain Management Guidelines. The 2015 Guidelines summarize much of this new information and provide a distinctive review. RELATED: Pain management is at the core of veterinary practice, alleviating pain, improving patient outcomes, and increasing both quality of life and the veterinarian-client-patient relationship. These Guidelines support veterinarians in putting pain management into practice and improving patient care. APPROACHES: Management of pain requires ongoing care that includes anticipation, early intervention, and assessment of response on an individual patient basis. A team-oriented approach, including the owner, is essential to maximize the recognition, prevention and treatment of pain in animals. EVIDENCE BASE: Guidelines include both pharmacological and non-pharmacological methods for managing pain", which are as evidence-based as possible and otherwise represent an expert opinion. Behavioral changes are currently the main indicator of pain and the healing process or course of progression and recently confirmed pain Postoperative pain is largely predictable, but there is a strong body of evidence to support strategies to alleviate maladaptive and maladaptive forms. Chronic pain is dominated by degenerative joint disease (DJD). It is one of the most important and underdiagnosed diseases of cats and dogs. DJD It is ubiquitous, found in pets of all ages, and inevitably progresses over time; evidence-based strategies for management are established in dogs and emerging in cats.

title: 5As Team obesity intervention in primary care: development and evaluation of collaborative decision-making weight management tools
abstract: Despite several clinical practice guidelines, a significant gap remains in the prevention and management of obesity in primary care. To address the need to change provider behavior, a randomized controlled trial with convergent mixed methods evaluation was conducted, the 5As Team (5AsT) study. The 5AsT toolkit was developed as part of the 5AsT response. This article describes the development process and evaluation of these tools. The tools were jointly developed by the multidisciplinary research team and 5AST, which included registered nurses/nurse practitioners (n = 15), mental health professionals (n = 7) and registered dietitians (n = 7). The 5AsT intervention group is in a primary care network in Edmonton, Alberta, Canada. 5AsT tool development occurred through a need-based, iterative process of practice/practice during learning collaborative sessions of the 5AsT intervention. During tool development, feedback was received through field notes, and final vendor evaluation was done through anonymous surveys. Twelve tools were developed with 5AsT. All tools were rated 'most useful' or 'moderately useful' in primary care practice by 5AsT. Four key findings during 5AsT tool development were the need for: adaptive tools, tools to facilitate interdisciplinary practice, tools to help patients understand realistic expectations for weight loss, and collaborative decision-making tools for goal setting and relapse prevention. The 5AsT tools are essential tools of care that extend the usefulness of the 5A of the obesity management framework in clinical practice.

title: 6-PACK program to reduce fall injuries in acute hospitals: cluster randomized controlled trial
abstract: OBJECTIVE To evaluate the effect of the 6-PACK program on falls and fall injuries in acute wards. DESIGN Cluster randomized controlled trial. SET Six Australian hospitals. PARTICIPANTS All patients admitted to 24 acute services during the trial period. INTERVENTIONS Participating wards were randomly assigned to receive the nurse-led 6-PACK program or usual care for 12 months. The 6-PACK program included a fall risk tool and personalized use of one or more of six interventions: 'fall alert' sign, surveillance of patients in the bathroom, ensuring patients' walking aids are accessible, toilet regimen, low-low bed and bed/chair alarm use of. MAIN OUTCOME MEASURES Co-primary outcomes were falls and fall injuries per 1000 bed days. RESULTS During the trial, 46,245 referrals were made to 16 medical and eight surgical services. This represented 31 411 individual patients, as many were admitted more than once. Patients' characteristics and length of stay were similar in intervention and control services. The use of 6-PACK program components was higher in intervention services than in control services (incidence rate 3.05, 95% confidence interval 2.14 to 4.34"; P<0.001). A total of 1831 falls and 613 fall injuries occurred, with falling rates (incidence ratio 1.04, P<0.001). 0.78 to 1.37; P=0.796) and fall injuries (0.96, 0.72 to 1.27; "P=0.766) were similar in intervention and control services. RESULTS Following the introduction of the 6-PACK program, positive changes have occurred in fall prevention practice. However, there was no difference in fall and fall injuries between the groups. There is no high-quality evidence demonstrating the effectiveness of fall prevention interventions in acute services. There is an urgent need for new solutions to the problem of falling in the hospital. TRIAL REGISTRATION Australia New Zealand Clinical Trials Registry ACTRN12611000332921.

title: pre-post study using OncoDoc, a guideline decision support system for breast cancer management: impact on physician prescribing behavior
abstract: Guideline-based decision support systems have been developed to influence clinicians' prescribing behaviors, but have not yet been shown to increase physician compliance with routine best practices. OncoDoc is a non-automated system that provides flexibility in guide interpretation to obtain the best patient-specific recommendations at the point of care. OncoDoc is applied in the treatment of breast cancer. We tested the system in a pre-post study at the Institut Gustave Roussy in which treatment decisions for breast cancer patients were measured before and after using the system to assess the impact on physicians' prescribing behavior. After 4 months, 127 decisions were recorded. Physicians' compliance with OncoDoc was significantly improved after using the system, reaching 85.03% (p < 10(-4)). Comparison of initial and final decisions showed that doctors changed their prescriptions in 31% of cases. Clinical trial accrual rate increased 50%, but not statistically significant as it was estimated in small numbers.

title: Behavioral-Economic Perspective on Poverty
abstract: Standard theories about poverty fall into two camps. Social scientists view the behavior of the economically disadvantaged as either calculated adaptations to prevailing conditions or as the result of a unique "culture of poverty" filled with perverse values. The first camp assumes that people are highly rational, have consistent and justified beliefs, and achieve their goals effectively, without error, and without needing help. The second camp attributes to the poor a variety of psychological and attitudinal shortcomings that often mislead their views and make their choices fallible and require paternalistic guidance. We propose a third opinion. We argue that the behavior patterns of the poor can be neither perfectly calculating nor particularly perverse. Rather, in narrow margins of poverty, the poor may exhibit the same basic weaknesses and prejudices as people from other walks of life, except that the same behaviors often manifest in more pronounced ways and lead to worse outcomes. Below we show the kinds of insights that can be gained from a more behaviorally realistic analysis of the economic conditions of the poor and propose alternative policies.

title: behaviorally effective model for the training of general health professionals by a rheumatology team.
abstract: This project evaluated a model for in-service arthritis education, based in part on the principles of applied behavior analysis. Thirty-seven public health nurses (PHNs) from 10 rural areas of the Midwest received training in screening and management of patients with arthritis";" A random half of counties received public and physician information interventions designed to increase arthritis referrals to community physicians under certain circumstances. In clinical interviews with PHN patients, modest but significant increases were seen in 14 of 16 target behaviors attributable to in-service training. Physician referral rates were unaffected by either intervention, as the measured effect of arthritis was low in this older adult population. This model illustrates generalizable behavior modification guidelines that assist traditional procedures for the development of professional arthritis education.

title: case of osteomalacia, osteoporosis and hypercalcemia
A case of sarcoidosis with cryptococcal meningitis demonstrated at the Royal Graduate School of Medicine
abstract: A fatal case is told about a 30-year-old officer who served abroad.

title: A case report evaluating a large-scale health systems improvement project in an uncontrolled environment: a quality improvement initiative in KwaZulu-Natal, South Africa
abstract: Purpose New approaches are needed to assess quality improvement (QI) in large-scale public health efforts. This case report details the challenges of large-scale QI assessment and proposes solutions based on adaptive study design. Study design We used a two-row assessment method to examine a QI effort to improve delivery of HIV preventive care in public health facilities in three regions in KwaZulu-Natal, South Africa, over a 3-year period. We initially used a cluster randomized controlled trial (RCT) design. Key findings During the RCT study period, tensions arose between intervention delivery and assessment design due to the loss of randomization unit integrity over time, pressure to implement changes across randomization unit boundaries, and the use of administrative rather than functional structures for randomization. In response to this loss of design integrity, we moved to a more flexible intervention design and mixed method quasi-experimental evaluation based on both a qualitative analysis and a discontinuous time-series quantitative analysis. Conclusions Cluster RCT designs may not be optimal for evaluating complex interventions to improve implementation in uncontrolled "real world" environments. More flexible, context-sensitive assessment designs provide the data needed to evaluate efficacy, while offering a better balance between the need to adjust intervention during assessment to meet implementation challenges. Our case study involved HIV care in a resource-limited setting, but these issues likely apply to complex remedial interventions in other settings.

title: central cardiovascular risk service to improve compliance with the guideline in private primary care offices
abstract: BACKGROUND: Many major healthcare systems now employ clinical pharmacists in team-based care to assist patients and physicians with the management of cardiovascular (CV) diseases. However, small private offices often lack the resources to hire a clinical pharmacist for their office. The aim of this study was to evaluate whether a centralized, web-based CV risk service (CVRS) managed by clinical pharmacists would improve compliance with the guideline in primary care offices in rural and small communities. METHODS: This is a randomized prospective study clustered in 12 primary care offices. Medical offices were randomized to either CVRS intervention or usual care. The intervention will last 12 months and all subjects will have research visits at baseline and at 12 months. Primary outcomes will include compliance with treatment guidelines and control of key CV risk factors. Data will also be abstracted from medical records at 30 months to determine whether the effect of the intervention persists after it has been stopped. RESULTS: Subjects in this study will be enrolled until 2015 and results will be announced in 2018. This study will provide information on whether a remote, centralized CV risk service can improve compliance with the guideline in medical offices that do not have the resources to employ clinical pharmacists.

title: clinical decision support system for the prevention of venous thromboembolism: impact on physician behavior.
abstract: CONTEXT: Computer-based clinical decision support systems (CDSSs) have been promoted because of their potential to improve the quality of healthcare. However, given the limited range of clinical settings in which they are tested, such systems must be rigorously evaluated before they can be widely applied to clinical practice. OBJECTIVE: To determine whether the submission of venous thromboembolism prophylaxis guidelines using CDSS increases the proportion of appropriate clinical practice decisions. DESIGN: Time series study conducted between December 1997 and July 1999. LOCATION: Orthopedic surgery department of a teaching hospital in Paris, France. PARTICIPANTS: A total of 1971 patients who underwent orthopedic surgery. INTERVENTION: A CDSS designed to provide immediate information on the prevention of venous thromboembolism among surgical patients was integrated into daily medical practice over three 10-week intervention periods, alternating with four 10-week control periods with a 4-week washout between each period. MAIN OUTCOME MEASURE: The proportion of eligible prescriptions ordered for anticoagulation according to predetermined clinical guidelines during the intervention and control periods. RESULTS: Physicians performed 82.8% of cases (95% confidence interval [CI], 77.6%-87.1%) during the control periods and 94.9% (95% CI, 92.5%-%) of the cases during the intervention periods. 96.6) complied with the guidelines. Prescription compliance increased significantly during each intervention period (P<.001). Each time CDSS was removed, physician practice reverted to what was observed before intervention was initiated. The relative risk of inappropriate implementation decisions during intervention versus control periods was 3.8 (95% CI, 2.7–5.4). CONCLUSION: In our study, the implementation of clinical guidelines for venous thromboembolism prophylaxis through a CDSS, which is routinely used in an orthopedic surgery department and integrated into the hospital information system, changed physician behaviors and improved compliance with guidelines. JAMA. 2000";"283:2816-2821

title: Clinical trial of knowledge-based medical records
abstract: To meet the needs of primary care physicians caring for patients with HIV infection, we have developed an informed medical record to enable the online patient record to play an active role in the care process. These programs integrate online patient enrollment, rule-based decision support, and full-text information retrieval into a clinical workstation for the practicing clinician. We conducted a controlled clinical trial among physicians and nurses caring for 349 patients infected with human immunodeficiency to determine whether the use of knowledge-based medical records was associated with faster and fuller compliance with practice guidelines and improved quality of care. virus (HIV)";" 191 patients were treated by 65 physicians and nurse practitioners assigned to the intervention group, and 158 patients were treated by 61 physicians and practitioner nurses assigned to the control group. During the 18-month study period, the computer generated 303 alerts in the intervention group and 388 in the control group. The median response time of clinicians to these stimuli was 11 days in the intervention group and 52 days in the control group (PJJ0.0001, log-rank test). During the study, the computer generated 432 primary care reminders for the intervention group and 360 reminders for the control group. The median response time of clinicians to these alerts was 114 days in the intervention group and more than 500 days in the control group (PJJ0.0001, log-rank test). Of 191 patients in the intervention group, 67 (35%) had one or more hospitalizations, compared with 70 (44%) of 158 patients in the control group (stratified Wilcoxon test for initial CD4 count). There was no difference in survival between the intervention and control groups (P = 0.18, log-rank test). We concluded that our clinical workstation significantly altered physicians' behavior in their response to warnings about primary care interventions, resulting in fewer HIV-infected patients being admitted to hospital.

title: clinically integrated postgraduate education program in evidence-based medicine and a 'no intervention' program to improve disability assessments: a cluster of randomized clinical trials
abstract: BACKGROUND: Although various studies have shown that teaching KBT is effective in improving knowledge, there is currently no convincing evidence that teaching KBT also changes professional behavior in practice. Therefore, the primary aim of this study was to evaluate the effectiveness of a clinically integrated postgraduate education program in CPA on evidence-based disability assessment. METHODS AND RESULTS: In one set of randomized controlled trials, fifty-four case-based learning groups consisting of 132 physicians and 1680 patients were randomly assigned to intervention or control groups. The intervention group received a clinically integrated, postgraduate, 5-day evidence-based medical education program consisting of (home) assignments, peer teaching, interactive training in databases, lectures, and brainstorming sessions. No training was given to the control group. The primary outcome was evidence-based disability assessment, as indicated by the frequency of use of evidence of adequate quality in disability assessment reports. General CPA behavioral outcome measures are not available. Therefore, we followed the general guidelines for establishing performance indicators and set a preliminary limit for determining adequate quality as recommended for evaluating PE training. Doctors trained in CPA performed more evidence-based assessments of disability than physicians in the control group (difference in absolute ratio 9.7%, 95% CI 3.5 to 15.9). Primary outcome differences between groups remained significant after both cluster-adjusted analysis and additional sensitivity analyzes that accounted for subjects lost to follow-up. RESULTS: A CPA program has successfully enhanced the use of evidence in a non-hospital-based medical specialty. Our findings support general recommendations for using multiple training methods to change physician behavior. In addition, the professional context of the intervention was found to be very supportive, as searching databases, using and applying guidelines, and other forms of evidence were accepted as standard practice and encouraged by colleagues and management.

title: clinic-based mammography intervention targeting inner-city women.
abstract: OBJECTIVE: The aim was to evaluate the impact of a clinic-based intervention program on mammography use of urban women. DESIGN: A randomized controlled trial was conducted using the firm systems methodology. SETTING: The setting was a general internal medicine clinic at the university-affiliated county hospital serving the Seattle metropolitan area. PARTICIPANTS: Women aged 50 to 74 years who had at least one routine clinical appointment (when it was time for a mammogram) during the study period were enrolled (n = 314). INTERVENTIONS: The intervention program emphasized nursing involvement and included physician education, provider referrals, use of audio-visual and printed patient education materials, transportation assistance in the form of bus cards, pre-appointment phone or postcard reminders, and rescheduling assistance. Control firm women received usual care. MEASUREMENTS AND MAIN RESULTS: Completion of mammography within 8 weeks of clinical visits was significantly higher among intervention (49%) than in control (22%) tough women (p < .001). These effects persisted after adjusting for possible confusion based on age, race, health insurance coverage, and prior hospital experience with mammography (odds ratio 3.5: 95% confidence interval 1.9. 6.5). The intervention effect was modified based on the type of insurance coverage and previous mammography history. Process evaluation showed that bus transits and rescheduling efforts did not contribute to the observed increases in screening participation. CONCLUSIONS: A clinic-based program that includes physician education, provider referrals, patient education materials, and appointment reminders and that emphasizes nursing involvement could facilitate compliance with breast cancer screening guidelines among urban women.

title: cluster randomized controlled trial of the clinical and cost-effectiveness of a 'whole systems' self-management support model for the management of long-term conditions in primary care: trial protocol
abstract: Background Patients with long-term conditions are increasingly becoming the focus of quality improvement activities in healthcare to reduce their impact on quality of life and reduce the burden on care use. There is significant interest in the potential of self-management support to improve health and reduce use in these patient populations, but there is little consensus on the optimal model that will best provide this support. We describe the implementation and evaluation of self-management support through an evidence-based 'whole systems' model that includes patient support, training for primary care teams, and service realignment, all integrated into routine primary care. Methods The evaluation includes a large-scale, multi-site study of the implementation, efficacy, and cost-effectiveness of this model of self-administration support using a cluster of randomized controlled trials in patients with three long-term diabetes, chronic obstructive disease. lung disease (COPD) and irritable bowel syndrome (IBS). Outcome measures include health care utilization and quality of life. We describe the methods of the cluster randomized trial. Discussion If the 'whole systems' model proves to be effective and cost-effective, it will provide decision makers with a model for providing self-management support for populations with long-term conditions that can be broadly applied to maximize 'access' in all areas. larger patient population.

title: cluster randomized clinical trial to improve prescribing patterns in outpatient pediatrics.
abstract: Objectives After previously demonstrating that an electronic prescriber and decision support system improve pediatric prescribing behavior for otitis media in an academic clinical setting, we evaluated whether point-of-care presentation of the evidence could demonstrate similar effects for a wide variety of other common pediatric conditions. . Design Cluster randomized controlled trial. Setting An education clinic/clinical practice area and a primary care pediatric clinic serving a mix of rural and semi-urban patients. Participants A total of 36 providers at the training clinic/practice site and eight providers at the private primary pediatric clinic. Intervention An evidence-based messaging system that provides real-time evidence to providers based on prescribing practices for acute otitis media, allergic rhinitis, sinusitis, constipation, pharyngitis, croup, urticaria, and bronchiolitis. Outcome measures Proportion of prescriptions given in accordance with the evidence. Results The proportion of prescriptions given in accordance with the evidence increased by four percentage points after intervention, from 38% at baseline to 42%. The control group improved by one percentage point from 39% at the beginning to 40% at the end of the trial. The adjusted difference between the intervention and control groups was 8% (95% confidence interval 1%, 15%). The effectiveness of the intervention did not decrease over time. Conclusion For common pediatric outpatient conditions, a point-of-care evidence-based prescriber and decision support system has been associated with significant improvements in prescribing practice.

title: cluster randomized controlled trial aimed at implementing local quality improvement collaborations to improve general practitioners' prescribing and test ordering performance: study protocol
abstract: BACKGROUND: The use of guidelines in general practice is not optimal. Although evidence-based methods exist to improve guideline adherence, differences in physician adherence to general practice guidelines remain relatively high. The aim of this study is to transfer a quality improvement strategy to the field based on supervision, feedback, training materials and peer group discussions led by local opinion leaders. Research questions are: is the multi-pronged strategy being implemented at scale as planned?"; what is the impact on GPs' test ordering and prescribing behavior?;" and what are the costs of implementing the strategy? METHODS: To evaluate the effects, costs and feasibility of this new strategy, we are planning a multicenter cluster randomized controlled trial (RCT) with a balanced incomplete block design. Local GP groups in the south of the Netherlands already participating in pharmacotherapeutic audit meeting groups will be recruited by regional paramedics. Approximately 50 GP groups will be randomly divided into two branches. Two different sets of balanced clinical topics will be presented to these GPs. Each GP within a group will receive comparative feedback on test ordering and prescribing performance. Feedback will be discussed in the group and working agreements will be created after guidelines and barriers to change have been discussed. Data for feedback will be collected from existing and newly created databases, both initially and one year later. DISCUSSION: We are not aware of published studies on the successes and failures of GPs attempts to transfer a multifaceted strategy for test ordering and prescribing behavior to stakeholders in the field. This pragmatic work will focus on compatibility with existing infrastructure while allowing a certain degree of adaptation to local needs and routines.

title: randomized cluster trial of standard quality improvement versus patient-centered interventions to improve depression care for African Americans in primary care: study protocol NCT00243425
abstract: BACKGROUND: Several studies document disparities in care access and quality of care for African Americans. Research suggests that patient attitudes and clinician communication behaviors may contribute to these disparities. Evidence links patient-centered care to improvements in mental health outcomes";" Therefore, quality improvement interventions that increase this dimension of care are promising strategies for improving depression treatment and outcomes among African Americans. This article describes the design of the BRIDGE (Blacks Intervening for Depression and Empowering Blacks) Study. The purpose of the study was to compare the effectiveness of two interventions - a standard quality improvement program and a patient-centered quality improvement program - for African-American patients with depression. The main hypothesis is that patients in the patient-centered group will have a greater reduction in depression symptoms, higher depression remission rates, and greater improvement in mental health functioning at six, twelve, and eighteen months compared to patients in the standard group. The study also examines patients' scores on care and receiving guidelines-compliant treatment for depression. METHODS/DESIGN: A total of 36 primary care clinicians and their 132 African-American patients with major depressive disorder were enrolled in a randomized cluster study. The study uses intent-to-treat analysis to compare the effectiveness of standard quality improvement interventions (depression guidelines for clinicians and academic elaboration on disease-focused care management for their patients) and patient-centered quality improvement interventions (communication skills training to improve inclusion). It focused on decision making and management of care for clinicians, explanatory models to improve outcomes at 12-month follow-up, socio-cultural barriers, and treatment choices for their patients. CONCLUSION: The BRIDGE Study included clinicians and African-American patients working in underrepresented, underresourced community-based practices in clinical trials to improve depression care. The patient-centered and culturally targeted approach to the treatment of depression is a relatively new approach that has not been tested in most previous studies. The study will provide evidence as to whether patient-centered accommodations improve quality of care and outcomes to a greater extent than standard quality improvement strategies for African Americans with depression. TRIAL REGISTRATION: ClinicalTrials.gov NCT00243425.

title: combined call alert and web-based tool changes clinician behavior and shortens hospital stay in acute pancreatitis
abstract: OBJECTIVE: There are many clinical guidelines published for acute pancreatitis (AP). The implementation of these recommendations is variable. We hypothesized that a clinical decision support (CDS) tool would change clinician behavior and shorten hospital stay (LOS). METHODS: DESIGN/SETUP: Observational study titled AP Early Intervention (TAPER) Project. Tertiary center emergency department (ED) and hospital. PARTICIPANTS: Two consecutive samplings from patients with ICD-9 code (577.0) for AP were generated from emergency room (ED) or hospital admissions. The diagnosis of AP was made according to the conventional Atlanta criteria. There were 110 patients in the Pre-TAPER-CDS-Agent group (5/30/06-6/22/07), 110 patients presenting to the emergency department with AP according to code 976 ICD-9 (577.0), and the Post-TAPER-CDS-Agent group (5/30 /06-6/22/07) had 113 for the 907 ICD-9 code (7/14/10-5/11). INTERVENTION: Developed on 12/2008-7/14/2010, the TAPER-CDS-Tool is an intuitive web-based point-of-care tool that sends texts to emergency room clinicians about a patient with AP - seven early management advice. RESULTS: Before and after TAPER-CDS-Tool batches had similar baseline characteristics. The post-TAPER-CDS-Mediator group met two management goals more frequently than the pre-TAPER-CDS-Agent group: risk stratification (P6L/1. 0-24 hours (P=0.0003) Mean (sd) hospital LOS was significant TAPER-CDS- Shorter (4.6 (3.1) vs. 6.7 (7.0) days in the post-Tool group, P=0.0126) Multivariate analysis identified four independent variables for hospital LOS: TAPER-CDS-Tool ( P=0.0049) associated with shorter LOS and more three variables associated with long LOS: Japanese severity score (P=0.0361), permanent organ failure (P=0.0088), and local pancreatic complications (<0.0001) RESULTS: associated with TAPER-CDS-Tool changed clinician behavior and had significant financial implications The hospital shortened the working hours.

title: An approach to increasing community capacity for breast and cervical cancer screening among older Caucasian women
abstract: In the Screening of Elderly Minority Women project, the authors applied a community capacity building approach to promote breast and cervical cancer screening among older women of color. Members of informal support networks were recruited for this health promotion intervention to enable Latino and African American women to exhibit positive health behaviors. The authors describe the stages of intervention and experiences from the community. Guidelines have been set to assist researchers and practitioners in planning and implementing a community health promotion intervention with women of color.

title: A community-based approach to promoting breastfeeding in Mexico
abstract: comprehensive education strategy is offered, linking education, community education, research and mass media efforts to improve breastfeeding practices. It describes breastfeeding promotion models, an administrative system, and lessons learned during the project. It has been shown that the keys to effective breastfeeding promotion are “accurate information”, appropriate education, training and follow-up, and a supportive administrative system;” PIP: An operations research project designed to determine which intervention model was most successful in promoting breastfeeding among 585 urban women in Mexico began in 1986. Mothers in Chihuahua and both trained promoters and program supervisors train individuals or groups at Cuauhtemoc. Jalapa served as the control zone. The prevalence rate of breastfeeding in the 4 populations ranged from 64.5% to 81.3% prior to intervention and averaged 74.9% in the target group. After the intervention, the average for this group increased to 88.8%. Also, the breastfeeding prevalence rate for Jalapa dropped from 65.9-56%. In addition, while 70% of the women in the experimental group fed their babies only with breast milk during the first month, only 63.3% of the women in the control group breastfed their babies. In the following months, breastfeeding prevalence rates decreased by 13.7% and 14.7% (5 months) and 9.4% and 3.3% (6 months) in the experimental and control groups, respectively. Informal support groups for breastfeeding mothers were formed unexpectedly as a result of educational and outreach activities. The data showed that the intervention model using promoters was the most successful strategy. They also provided guidelines to researchers and other healthcare professionals interested in promoting community-based breastfeeding programs. For example, supervisors should not discourage promoters from addressing other community needs, as discouraging them could jeopardize their commitment to breastfeeding promotion. In addition, program planners should collect geographic and sociodemographic data on region and population prior to planning and response.

title: Comparison of the effects of computer and manual reminders on mental health clinical practice guideline compliance.
abstract: Objective: To evaluate the relative effectiveness of computer and manual reminder systems in the implementation of a clinical practice guideline. Design: 78 outpatients in a mental health clinic were randomly assigned to one of two reminder systems within the clinician. The CaseWalker computer system reminded clinicians when it was time to screen for mood disorder recommended by the guidelines, ensuring that the diagnosis of major depressive disorder met the criteria for the Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders, 4th edition (DSM-IV). and created a progress note. The manual system was a checklist attached to paper medical records. Criteria: The mood disorder screening rates of patients who were said to have major depressive disorder and the completeness of documents meeting the DSM-IV criteria were compared. Results: CaseWalker reported a higher screening rate for mood disorder (61 versus 86.5%, P = 0.008) and a higher rate of full documentation of the DSM-IV criteria (100 percent versus 100 percent) compared with the paper checklist. 5.6, P < 0.001). Results: Computer reminders were shown to be superior to manual reminders in improving adherence to clinical practice guidelines for depression in an outpatient mental health clinic.

title: computer-based intervention to improve the relevance of antiepileptic drug level monitoring
abstract: To improve compliance by reminding physicians when a potentially unnecessary test is requested and providing common indications for specific AED monitoring and pharmacokinetics, we designed and implemented 2 automated, computerized screens for use during antiepileptic drug (AED) test order entry. All computerized orders for inpatient serum AED levels over two 3-month periods were included in the study. During the 3-month period after the implementation of the automated response, 13% of all AED tests ordered were canceled after computerized reminders. The cancellation rate was 27% for orders that seemed overkill. For redundant orders, 4% were canceled when information on specific AED monitoring and pharmacokinetics was provided. The cancellation rate was sustained after 4 years. Despite a 19.3% increase in overall chemistry test volume, there has been a 19.5% decrease in total AED test volume since the implementation of this intervention. Nonconformity from repeated testing before pharmacological steady state was reached decreased from 54% to 14.6% of all AED orders. A simple, automated, activity-based intervention targeting a specific test order behavior effectively reduced inappropriate laboratory testing. The sustained benefit supports the idea that computerized interventions can permanently affect physician behavior. The computerized presentation of such evidence-based boundary guidelines can help narrow the gap between evidence and practice.

title: computerized handheld decision support system to improve diagnosis of pulmonary embolism: a randomized trial.
abstract: Background: Pulmonary embolism testing often differs from that recommended by evidence-based guidelines. Purpose: To evaluate the effectiveness of a handheld clinical decision support system for improving the diagnosis of suspected pulmonary embolism among patients in the emergency department. Design: Cluster randomized trial. Assignment was based on a random number table, providers were not blinded, and outcome evaluation was automated. (ClinicalTrials.gov registration number: NCT00188032) Setting: 20 emergency services in France. Patients: 1103 and 1768 consecutive outpatients with suspected pulmonary embolism. Intervention: After a pre-intervention period involving 20 centers and 1103 patients, during which providers are accustomed to input clinical data into handsets and investigators evaluate baseline tests, emergency departments are randomly assigned to enable a decision support system on devices (10 centers, 753 patients) or demonstrating validated diagnostic strategies posters and pocket cards (10 centers, 1015 patients). Measurements: Appropriateness of the diagnostic study, defined as "any test sequence" where the probability of the posttest is less than 5% or greater than 85% (primary outcome) or strict adherence to guidelines recommendations (secondary outcome); number of tests per patient (secondary outcome) Results: In both groups, the proportion of patients undergoing appropriate diagnostic tests during the trial was greater than in the pre-intervention period, but the increase was greater in the computer-based guidelines group (adjusted mean difference increase, 19.3 percentage points computer-based in favor of the guidelines [95% CI, 2.9 to 35.6 percentile points]; PÃ' = 0.023 Among patients with appropriate examinations, those in the computer-based guidelines group received slightly fewer tests than those in the paper guides group (mean tests per patient, 1.76 [SD, 0.98] vs. 2.25 [SD, 1.04];" PÃ‚ < 0.001) Limitation: The study was not designed to show a difference in the clinical outcome of patients at follow-up Conclusion: A hand-held decision support system, suspected pulmonary embolism in the emergency room improved the diagnostic decision-making process in patients with

title: computerized intervention to reduce the use of calcium channel blockers in hypertension.
abstract: Purpose To determine whether a computer-assisted reminder would change prescribing habits for the treatment of hypertension in accordance with current clinical guidelines in a general internal medicine clinic. Design Randomized experiment. Adjustment of Veterans Affairs General Internal Medicine Clinic Puget Sound Health Care System, Seattle Division. Patients/Participants Clinical providers were randomized to a control group (n=35) or intervention group (n=36). We targeted providers of patients treated for hypertension with calcium channel blockers, a class of drugs not recommended for initial therapy. Intervention An automated computer query identified eligible patients and their providers. A guide reminder has been placed on intervention providers' patient charts";" patient charts of control providers received no reminders. Measurements and main results During the 5-month study period, 346 patients were seen by 36 primary care providers in the intervention group (staff, general practitioners, residents, and academics) and 373 by 35 providers in the intervention group. control group. Intervenors switched 39 patients (11.3%) to other drugs during the study period compared to 1 patient (<1.0%) of the control providers (p<.0001). Providers stated that in patients whose treatment did not change, 23.1% had angina, 9.5% had indications other than hypertension, 13.9% had intolerable side effects in first-line therapy, and 13.9% had inadequate control in first-line therapy. 23.6% of patients without provider-specified contraindications switched from calcium channel blockers to first-line agents during the intervention period. Conclusions The use of a computerized, clinical-based intervention has improved compliance with guidelines for the treatment of primary hypertension in general and reduced the use of calcium channel blockers for the treatment of hypertension in particular.

title: computerized reminder for deep vein thrombosis prophylaxis in surgical patients
abstract: OBJECTIVE: To measure the effect of computerized reminder system on deep vein thrombosis (DVT) prophylaxis rate in surgical patients. DESIGN: A prospective trial to measure change in compliance compared to historical controls. MEASUREMENTS: LDS Hospital surgeons developed local consensus on which procedures should be DVT prophylaxis. The historical rate of prophylaxis for procedures was measured by searching the database of patient records. Next, a computerized reminder system using a specialist knowledge base and a time drive mechanism was implemented to flag surgical cases for DVT prophylaxis. A DVT reminder appeared in the OR schedule for eligible patients";" surgical staff used it as a guide for administering prophylaxis. The DVT prophylaxis rate was re-measured during the 3-month trial and compared with the pre-intervention rate. RESULTS: The pre-intervention rate of DVT prophylaxis over a 3-month period was 85.2% (785 of 921 eligible cases). During the 3 months following the introduction of the computerized reminder, compliance with DVT prophylaxis increased to 99.3% (1084 of 1092 eligible cases). The difference between background controls and study subjects was quite significant (p < 0.001). CONCLUSION: Computerized reminder is an effective method to increase the rate of DVT prophylaxis in surgical patients.

title: computerized reminder system to increase the use of preventive care for hospitalized patients
abstract: BACKGROUND Although effective in outpatient settings, computerized reminders have not been proven to increase preventive care in inpatient settings. METHODS: We conducted a randomized controlled trial to determine the effects of computerized reminders on the rates of ordering four preventive treatments for inpatients. Over an 18-month study period, a computerized system processed online information for all 6371 patients admitted to a general medicine ward (for a total of 10,065 hospitalizations) and generated preventative care reminders as appropriate. Doctors in the intervention group saw these reminders when using a computerized order entry system for inpatients. RESULTS The reminder system identified 3416 patients (53.6 percent) who were not ordered by the attending physician as eligible for preventive measures. For patients with at least one indication, computerized reminders resulted in higher adjusted order rates for pneumococcal vaccine (35.8 percent of patients in the intervention group and 0.8 percent of those in the control group, P<0.001), flu vaccine (51.4 percent). ) 1.0 percent, P<0.001), prophylactic heparin (32.2 percent versus 18.9 percent, P<0.001) and prophylactic aspirin at discharge (36.4 versus 27.6 percent, P<0.001). CONCLUSIONS Most hospitalized patients in this study were eligible for preventive measures, and computerized reminders significantly increased the rate at which such treatments were administered.

title: concept for the implementation and evaluation of the guideline "Early Diagnosis of Breast Cancer in Germany"
abstract: Systematically developed, evidence- and consensus-based guidelines are important tools for improving healthcare. The effectiveness of a guideline is not only related to its methodological quality, but also to the implementation strategy used. The following document describes the systematic development of a strategy for the implementation and evaluation of the guideline "Early Diagnosis of Breast Cancer in Germany" as part of a national project. A multifaceted systematic implementation strategy has been developed that addresses existing barriers and builds on recently implemented projects in Germany to improve the early detection and treatment of breast cancer. The aim is to provide behavioral change in physicians as health care recipients and health care providers who take part in the medical decision-making process within the scope of the guideline. It also supports organizational changes to ensure compliance with the guideline through quality assurance and quality management. A set of quality indicators have been identified for the baseline assessment of structures, provider performance and results to enable evaluation of the implementation process. Both the effectiveness of the implementation process and the effectiveness of the guideline will be measured using the same indicators for reassessment within a predetermined 18-month timeframe. The quasi-experimental design of this uncontrolled pre- and post-administration study outlined in this paper allows evaluation of clinically relevant changes using quality indicators that measure the effectiveness of the guideline at the national level.

title: controlled trial incorporating symptom data into computer-based care recommendations for managing patients with chronic heart failure.
abstract: Background Heart failure is common and associated with significant morbidity and cost, but physician adherence to treatment guidelines is sub-optimal. We conducted a randomized controlled trial to determine whether adding symptom information to evidence-based, computer-generated care recommendations could affect treatment decisions among primary care physicians caring for heart failure patients at two Veterans Affairs medical centers. Methods Physicians were randomly assigned to receive either care recommendations generated from electronic medical record data and symptom data from questionnaires sent to patients within 2 weeks of scheduled outpatient visits (intervention group) or recommendations generated solely from electronic medical record data (control group). Patients required a diagnosis of heart failure and objective evidence of left ventricular systolic dysfunction. At 6 and 12 months after enrollment, we evaluated physician compliance with heart failure guidelines and patients' New York Heart Association (NYHA) class, quality of life, satisfaction with care, hospitalizations, and outpatient visits. Results Patients in the intervention (n = 355) and control (n = 365) groups were similar at baseline. At 12 months, there was no significant difference in adherence to care recommendations between physicians in the intervention and control groups (33% vs 30%, P = 0.4). There was also no significant difference in NYHA class (P = 0.1) and quality of life measures (P > 0.1), nor was there a difference in the number of outpatient visits between intervention and control patients (6.7 vs 7.1 visits, P = 0.48). Intervention patients were more satisfied with their doctor (P = 0.02) and primary care visit (P = 0.02), but at 6 months (1.5 vs 0.7 hospitalizations, P = 0.0002) and 12 months (2.3 vs. 2.3 hospitalizations, P = 0.0002) had more all-cause hospitalizations. 1.7 hospitalizations, P = 0.05). Conclusion Adding symptom information to computer-generated care recommendations for patients with heart failure did not affect physicians' treatment decisions or improve patient outcomes.

title: controlled trial of web-based diabetes disease management.
abstract: OBJECTIVE – To test the effects of the Diabetes Disease Management Application (DMA), a web-based decision support tool developed to improve the evidence-based management of type 2 diabetes. RESEARCH DESIGN AND METHODS—We conducted a group of randomized controlled trials of 12 intervention and 14 control staff providers and 307 intervention and 291 control patients with type 2 diabetes in a hospital-based internal medicine clinic. Providers were randomly assigned from May 1998 to April 1999 to have access (interference) or not (control) DMA. DMA displays interactive patient-specific clinical data, treatment recommendations, and links to other web-based care resources. We compared patients in the intervention and control groups for changes in care processes and outcomes through intent-to-treat analysis from prior to study year to study year. RESULTS—DMA was used in 42% of scheduled patient visits. Number of LDL cholesterol tests (intervention, +0.2 tests/year"; control, +0.01 tests/year; P = 0.02) and proportions of patients who had at least one foot exam per year (intervention, +9.8%; control, -0.7%; P Levels HbA1c decreased by 0.2 in the intervention group and increased by 0.1 in the control group (P = 0.09); The proportion of patients with LDL cholesterol levels <130 mg/dl increased by 20.3% in the intervention group and 10.5% in the control group (P = 0.5). CONCLUSIONS – Web-based patient-specific decision support has the potential to improve evidence-based parameters of diabetes care.

title: 2006 cross-sectional study of the number and frequency of terms used to refer to information translation in a health literature: Tower of Babel?
abstract: The effort to put research findings into practice is growing rapidly and has acquired many competing names (eg, dissemination, reception, exploitation, translation) and contributing disciplines. The use of multiple terms across disciplines creates barriers to communication and progress in applying research findings. In a health literature review published in 2006, we attempted to create an inventory of terms describing this field and how often the authors used them. Methods We call this area information translation (KT). Terms and definitions describing the characteristics of KT were collected from the literature, the Internet, reports, textbooks, and communication with experts. We compiled a database of KT and other articles by reading 12 health journals representing multiple disciplines. All articles published in these journals in 2006 were categorized as KT or not. KT articles (all KT) were further categorized, if possible, by whether they described KT projects or practices (KT practice articles) or presented the theoretical basis, models, tools, methods or techniques of KT (KT theory articles). Accuracy was checked using double-reading. Specially designed software determined how often the terms KT were used in the titles and abstracts of the articles categorized as PT. Results A total of 2,603 articles were evaluated and 581 were identified as KT articles. Of these, 201 described KT applications and 153 included KT theory. Of the 100 collected KT terms, 46 were used in the titles or abstracts of the articles categorized as KT by the authors. For all 581 KT articles, the eight terms or term variations used by the authors were highly distinctive (p < 0.001) to separate KT and non-KT articles: implementation, adoption, quality improvement, dissemination, complex intervention (multi-finite), implementation (three word) research and complex intervention. More KT terms were associated with KT practice articles (n = 13) and KT theory articles (n = 18). Results We collected 100 terms describing KT research. The authors used 46 of them in the titles and abstracts of KT articles. About half of these differentiated between KT and non-KT articles. Therefore, the need for consolidation and the consistent use of fewer terms related to KT research are clear.

title: Formative Study of Colon Cancer Surveillance Care: Effects of Survivor Centered Interventions
abstract: Colon cancer is one of the most frequently diagnosed cancers in the United States, and the increase in survivors has highlighted the need to improve the quality of colon cancer surveillance care. Post-treatment surveillance includes follow-up care visits and testing, as well as psychosocial support and lifestyle counseling. This formative study explored individual, interpersonal, and organizational-level factors associated with adherence to surveillance care guidelines to identify modifiable factors for potential educational intervention strategies. A suitable sample of 22 survivors (12 women and 10 men) from two cancer centers were recruited after completing treatment to attend focus groups or key informative phone interviews to carefully explore their experiences and complete a short questionnaire. Content analysis was used to identify themes. The results confirmed that survivors navigate a complex surveillance care program and have a strong trust in healthcare providers who guide their follow-up care experience. Participants defined the terms "survival" and "follow" in a variety of different ways. Individual-level themes critical to survivors' experiences were having a positive attitude, trusting one's faith, and coping with fears. Interpersonal-level themes centered around interactions and communication with family and healthcare providers in follow-up care. While organizational-level factors are rarely highlighted, respondents rated office reminder systems and communication between multiple providers as valuable. Educational interventions that leverage survivors' connections with their physicians and focus on preparing survivors for what to expect in the next phase of their cancer experience can be useful in mobilizing survivors at the end of treatment to transition into the post-treatment period.

title: framework for good practice in interagency responses to cases of self-neglect
abstract: Self-neglect is probably more common than is generally thought and poses a host of difficult conceptual, identification and intervention problems for health and social care workers. These patient management issues are compounded by the lack of any evidence base for practice that nurses can draw upon when faced with managing people who neglect themselves. Nurses who work with self-neglects work in an interdisciplinary context that includes professional groups such as environmental health workers who are not normally involved in health and social care teams. In the absence of such an evidence base, a pragmatic solution has been proposed in the form of a framework for inter-agency practice. The background supporting this framework, including a research study on self-neglect and sheltering in inter-agency responses, is briefly summarized in this paper.

title: Framework to Assist Healthcare Professionals in Recommending High-Quality Practices to Support Chronic Disease Self-Management: An Explanatory Evaluation of Type 2 Diabetes Practices
abstract: BACKGROUND: This article provides an approach to assist healthcare professionals in recommending high-quality practices to support self-management of chronic diseases. Most app reviews focus on popularity, aesthetics, functionality, usability, and information quality. There is no doubt that these factors are important in choosing reliable applications that appeal to users, but behavioral theory can also be useful in matching applications to user needs. OBJECTIVE: The developed framework aims to be methodologically sound, to be able to select popular practices that include content covered by evidence-based programs, to be consistent with behavioral theory, and to adopt a patient-centered approach to tailor practices to individual patients' needs. METHODS: A single disease type 2 diabetes was chosen to demonstrate how the framework could be applied because it was considered to represent the types of strategies used in many chronic diseases. A systematic approach was developed to match practices to patients' needs, based on behavioral theory and recommendations from best practice guidelines. In March 2014, a set of search strategies was used to identify the highest-rated iPhone and Android health apps representing 29 subjects from five categories of type 2 diabetes self-management strategies. Topics are selected from published international guidelines for diabetes management. The senior author (KH) evaluated the most popular applications addressing these topics using the Behavior Theory Content Questionnaire (BTS), which is based on traditional behavioral theory. A tool to aid decision making when using apps, developed and tested with healthcare professionals for ease of use and understanding. RESULTS: A total of 14 practices were evaluated, representing all five subject categories of self-management. Total theoretical scores (BTS scores) were less than 50 on a 100-point scale for all applications. Each app received less than 50% of the possible total BTS score for all four behavioral theories and most of the 20 behavioral strategies";" however, apps scored higher than 50% of the total possible BTS score for certain strategies related to their primary focus. Our findings suggest that the treatments studied will be more effective when used in combination with therapy rather than alone. Practices were categorized by topic and basic intervention strategies. A framework has been developed to match practices to patient needs identified based on patient-centered care principles and practice categorization. The approach was well accepted and understood by an appropriate example of health practitioners. CONCLUSIONS: The presented framework can be used by healthcare practitioners to better match practices with client needs. Some applications include highly interactive strategies of behavioral theory and can increase patient engagement and efficacy of therapy when used as an adjunct.

title: French version of the Obvious Behavior Scale (OBS), which measures challenging behavior following acquired brain injury: Echelle des compportements observables (ECO)
abstract: OBJECTIVE: To develop the French version of the Open Behavior Scale (OBS) and to examine its psychometric properties. METHODS: The scale was adapted and validated according to standard guidelines for cross-cultural adaptation of questionnaires (Echelle des compportements observables";" ECO). The reliability and construct validity of the ECO were studied among 29 inpatients and outpatients with an acquired brain injury. The instruments were administered by 12 clinicians from eight rehabilitation centers and local brain injury associations. RESULTS: ECO provided behavioral profile descriptors very similar to the original scale. It showed excellent reliability and good convergent and differential validity, as reflected by the significant associations with other measures containing similar behavioral items, and the absence of meaning correlations with broader constructs such as physical and cognitive abilities. CONCLUSION: This study provides evidence that ECO behaves like the original OBS, has promising initial findings in terms of reliability and validity, and is a valuable research and clinical tool for assessing the severity and typology of compulsive behavior after an acquired brain injury. Tracing the evolution of behavior after intervention in French and bilingual communities.

title: Effects of handheld computer smoking intervention tool and physician smoking cessation counseling
abstract: OBJECTIVE: The aim of this study was to evaluate a handheld smoking cessation intervention tool designed to assist physicians in counseling patients to quit smoking. METHODS: This study used a pre/post survey design with a trial period of 4 months for the software. Study participants included 22 faculty and assistant physicians from the University of Virginia.
