Paired samples t-tests were used to assess mean differences in 4 major subscales (physician behaviour, attitudes, comfort and knowledge of counseling patients about smoking cessation). RESULTS: No statistically significant mean differences were found for physician behavior (mean increase = 0.44, P = .55) or physician attitude (mean increase = 0.44, P = .16). A statistically significant mean increase of 2.29 was observed for the physician comfort subscale (t = 3.87, df = 16, P = .001). Physicians noted greater comfort (P = .007) in counseling patients about smoking cessation and greater comfort (P = .012) in using Public Health Service Clinical Practice Guidelines. CONCLUSION: Physician comfort level in counseling patients about smoking cessation can be increased with hand-held computer software. When used in conjunction with other practice modifications, this tool has the potential to improve physician smoking cessation intervention practices.

title: mixed activity-practice cluster randomized group CBT trial for anxiety in urban schools: rationale, design, and methods
abstract: Background Schools offer a context with great potential for the implementation of psychosocial evidence-based practices. Cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT) is an evidence-based practice that has been found to be very effective in treating anxiety in a variety of community settings, including schools. Friends for Life (FRIENDS) is an effective group CBT protocol for anxiety. Unfortunately, evidence-based practices for anxiety are rarely used in under-resourced urban schools because many treatment protocols are not suitable for the urban school context or population, existing behavioral health personnel do not receive adequate training or support to allow them. school districts do not have the resources to engage in treatment faithfully or to contract external counselors. In our previous work, we adapted FRIENDS to create a more culturally sensitive, focused and applicable CBT protocol (CBT for the Treatment of Anxiety in Schools (CATS)) for anxiety disorders. Methods/design The purpose of this 5-year study was to both evaluate the effectiveness of CATS for urban public schools versus the original FRIENDS, and compare implementation strategies (instructor-train-instructor-train?+ ?ongoing consultation), 18 K-8 urban states school by conducting a three-arm, parallel group, type 2 hybrid efficacy-practice trial. We will also evaluate cost effectiveness and loyalty mediators and moderators. Ninety therapists, 18 agency supervisors and 360 children will attend. The interactive systems framework for dissemination and practice guides training and support procedures for therapists and supervisors. Discussion This study has the potential to demonstrate that agency therapists and supervisors with little or no prior exposure to evidence-based practices (EBPs) can faithfully practice an anxiety disorder EBP. Comparison of implementation strategies will provide large urban mental health systems with data to make decisions regarding the adoption of EBPs.

title: low-fat vegan diet induces more macronutrient changes, but is comparable in adherence and acceptability among individuals with type 2 diabetes to a more traditional diabetes diet.
abstract: BACKGROUND: Although therapeutic diets are critical for diabetes management, their acceptability by patients has not been largely studied. OBJECTIVE: To measure adherence and acceptability for two types of diets for diabetes. DESIGN: Controlled trial conducted between 2004 and 2006. SUBJECTS/SETTING: Individuals with type 2 diabetes in a community-based research facility (n=99). Participants were randomly assigned to either a diet that followed 2003 American Diabetes Association guidelines or a low-fat, vegan diet for 74 weeks. MAIN OUTCOME MEASURES: Attrition, adherence, dietary behavior, diet acceptability, and craving. STATISTICAL ANALYSIS: The t-tests for nutrient intake and survey scores determined between-group differences. For dietary acceptability measures, relevant samples Wilcoxon total rank test evaluated within-group changes"; independent samples compared Mann-Whitney U test diet groups. Changes in symptoms reported between groups were compared using chi(2) for independent samples. RESULTS: All participants recorded the first 22 weeks. 90% (45/50) of the American Diabetes Association guidelines diet group and 86% (42/49) of the vegan diet group participants completed 74 weeks Fat and cholesterol intakes decreased further, and carbohydrate and fiber intake was greater in the vegan group At 22 weeks, group-specific diet adherence criteria were met by 44% (22/50) members of the American Diabetes Association diet group and 67% (33/49) of vegans-group participants (P=0.019); Association guidelines diet group reported a greater increase in dietary restriction; this difference was not significant at 74 weeks. Both groups reported reduced hunger and decreased disinhibition. Survey responses rated both diets as satisfactory, with no significant differences between groups, except for ease of preparation, where 22-week ratings marginally supported the American Diabetes Association guideline group. Cravings for fatty foods were further reduced in the vegan group at 22 weeks, with no significant difference at 74 weeks. CONCLUSIONS: Despite greater impact on macronutrient intake, a low-fat, vegan diet has similar acceptability to a more traditional diabetes diet. Its acceptability does not seem to preclude its use in medical nutrition therapy.

title: Meta-analysis of the relationship between adherence to medication and mortality
abstract: OBJECTIVE To evaluate the relationship between adherence to drug therapy, including placebo, and mortality. DESIGN Meta-analysis of observational studies. DATA SOURCES Electronic databases, communication with researchers, and reviews of textbooks and engagement. Review methods Predefined criteria were used to select studies reporting mortality among participants with good and poor adherence to drug therapy. Data were extracted for the disease, drug treatment groups, methods of measuring compliance rate, definition of good adherence, and mortality rate. RESULTS Data were obtained from 21 studies (46,847 participants), including eight studies (19,633 participants) with placebo arms. Compared with poor fit, good fit was associated with a lower mortality rate (odds ratio 0.56, 95% confidence interval 0.50 to 0.63). Good adherence to placebo was associated with lower mortality (0.56, 0.43 to 0.74), as was good adherence to beneficial drug therapy (0.55, 0.49 to 0.62). Good adherence to harmful drug therapy was associated with increased mortality (2.90, 1.04 to 8.11). CONCLUSION Good adherence to drug therapy is associated with positive health outcomes. Furthermore, the observed association between good adherence to placebo and mortality supports the existence of a 'healthy adherence' effect, whereby adherence to medication may be a surrogate marker for overall healthy behavior.

title: midwifery-led in-hospital birthing center within an academic medical center: achievements and challenges
abstract: University of California San Diego Community Women's Health Program (CWHP) has emerged as a successful and sustainable coexistence model of women's health services. The cornerstone of this midwifery practice is California's only in-hospital birthing center. Located inside the medical center, this unique and physically separate birth center has been the site for more than 4000 births. It is an exceptional example of low-intervention care with 10% cesarean section and 98% breastfeeding rates. Integrating this previously independent birth center into an academic center brought with it attempts at mistrust and ineffective communication. Education, coherent leadership, and the development of multidisciplinary guidelines have helped to meet these challenges. This collaborative model provides a structure where residents learn to be respectful counselors and appreciate differences in medical practice. CWHP and the Birth Center show that through permanence and resilience, a collaborative maternity care model can evolve and positively impact not only new families but also the next generation of providers.

title: migraine management training program for primary care providers: An overview of survey and pilot study findings, lessons learned, and considerations for further research
abstract: BACKGROUND: There are five to nine million primary care office visits per year for migraine in the United States. However, migraine care in primary care is often inadequate. A previous study noted that primary care physicians (PCPs) want to have direct contact with headache specialists to improve the migraine care they provide. OBJECTIVE: We sought to further examine PCPs' knowledge of migraine management and evaluate the feasibility of a multimodal migraine training program for PCPs. METHODS: We conducted a questionnaire assessing the knowledge of PCPs about migraine. We then hosted three live training sessions and developed an email consultation service for PCPs to post any questions they have about migraine. We report both quantitative and qualitative findings. RESULTS: Twenty-one PCP completed the questionnaire. They were generally familiar with the epidemiology of migraine (mean prevalence of migraine 12.6% +/- 10.1), psychiatric comorbidities (mean prevalence of comorbid depression 24.5% +/- 16.7%, prevalence of comorbid anxiety 24.6% +/- 18.3) and evidence-based behavioral treatments . Fifty-six percent cited cognitive behavioral therapy, 78% biofeedback, and 61% relaxation therapy as evidence-based treatments. Although most were aware of the prevalence of psychiatric comorbidities, they did not routinely assess them (43% did not routinely assess anxiety, 29% did not routinely assess depression). PCPs frequently reported referrals for non-A-level evidence-based treatments: special diets (60%), acupuncture (50%), physical therapy (30%), and psychoanalysis (20%). Relaxation therapy was a treatment recommended by 40% of PCPs. Only 10% reported seeking cognitive behavioral therapy or biofeedback. 19 percent used little or no anti-migraine medications. Seventy-two percent were unaware or little aware of the American Academy of Neurology guidelines for migraine. Participation in training sessions varied (N=22 1st session, 6 2nd session, 15 3rd session). Few used the PCP email advisory service (N=4). CONCLUSIONS: While PCPs are familiar with many aspects of migraine care, there is a need and opportunity for improvement. The three live sessions were poorly attended and the email consultation service was seldom used. We provide an in-depth discussion of targeted areas for educational intervention, challenges in developing a migraine education program for PCPs, and future areas of study.

title: model for collaboration in quality improvement projects: implementing a weight-based heparin dosing nomogram in an integrated healthcare delivery system
abstract: BACKGROUND: At Aurora Health Care, an integrated practice system based in Milwaukee, a systems-level clinical quality improvement department was established in 1995 to facilitate collaboration on clinical quality improvement (QI) initiatives. COLLABORATIVE MODEL: A model was developed to use the expertise within the system and to avoid unnecessary duplication of effort and procurement was provided for the interventions of the project at the point of service delivery. It was believed that a single team could design improvement efforts or guidelines and then work with a different group of people at a more local level to implement the processes. APPLICATION OF THE MODEL TO THE HPARIN QI PROJECT: Anticoagulation with heparin is considered the mainstay of treatment for pulmonary embolism and deep vein thrombosis. However, a large gap was found between current anticoagulant practices and published best practices regarding achieving a key process measure. To reduce the overall time to achieve effective anticoagulation, a systems-level team created an intervention consisting predominantly of a pre-printed order sheet, including a weight-based heparin dosing nomogram, and an education plan for physicians and other healthcare professionals. Significant improvement was observed at all pilot sites where overall adequate anticoagulation rates increased from 73% to 95% within the first 24 hours. CONCLUSION: The system was able to standardize care in four of its five major hospitals and deliver better patient outcomes to the wider population, and then repeat the heparin project at four additional centers over a six-month period. This model has been successfully applied to other quality improvement projects.

title: modeling tool for policy analysis to support the design of efficient and effective policy responses to complex public health problems
abstract: Background In the design of public health policy, a broader understanding of risk factors for lifelong disease and a growing awareness of the social determinants of health have led to the development of broader, cross-sectoral strategies to tackle complex issues. . However, comprehensive strategies may not represent the most efficient or effective approach to reduce the burden of disease at the population level. Instead, they can move to allocate limited resources less intensively to a larger number of programs and initiatives, reducing the potential impact of investment. While analytical tools that use research evidence exist to help identify and prioritize disease risk factors for public health action, they are insufficient to support more targeted and effective policy responses to complex public health problems. Discussion This article discusses the limitations of commonly used analytical tools to support evidence-based policy decisions for complex problems. It proposes an alternative policy analysis tool that can integrate various sources of evidence and provide a platform for virtually testing policy alternatives to design efficient, effective and equitable solutions. The case of suicide prevention in Australia is presented to illustrate the limitations of existing tools to adequately inform prevention policy and discusses the usefulness of the new policy analysis tool. Summary Contrary to popular belief, a systems approach goes beyond comprehensive thinking and seeks to determine where best to target public health action and resources for optimal effect. It primarily deals with what can reasonably be excluded from prevention strategies and can be used to explore where investment can occur without adversely affecting population health (or equity). Simulation modeling used for policy analysis holds promise for being able to better operationalize research evidence to support decision making for complex problems, improve the targeting of public health policy, and provides a foundation for strengthening relationships among policymakers, stakeholders and researchers.

title: national cross-sectional study of socio-behavioral factors affecting physicians' decisions to initiate antimicrobial therapy.
abstract: OBJECTIVE: Current efforts to prevent antimicrobial resistance include limiting antimicrobial use, providing education on appropriate use, and developing better point-of-care testing, but what do doctors really think about rational prescribing and potential interventions? We sought to determine what factors may influence a physician's decision to initiate antimicrobial therapy in a patient and their views on measures to promote rational prescribing. METHODS: We conducted a nationwide, cross-sectional survey of 10,600 doctors from the medical records of all known board-certified doctors in Germany. RESULTS: Of the respondents (n = 3,492"; 33%;" including detailed analysis of non-response bias), 90% reported that they decided to start antimicrobial therapy in one patient at least once a week, and 66% decided daily. We identified correlations in one patient's decision to initiate antimicrobial therapy. Estimates were hospital physician status (odds ratio (OR) 1.29 (95% confidence interval (CI) 1.00–1.68)), male physician (OR 1.81 (95% CI 1.42–2.31)), age 50–59 years (OR) . 1.56 (95% CI 1.10-2.21)) and practice in states in the former East Germany (OR 1.60 (95% CI 1.15-2.21)). Each specialist was significantly less likely than ENTs and urologists to decide to initiate a course of antimicrobial therapy. Other predictors agreed to be on the safe side (OR 1.34 (95% CI 1.03-1.76)) believing that the quality of prescribing practice improved after continuing education from pharmaceutical companies (OR 1.43 (95% CI 1.11-1.84)) and for resistant pathogens. having failed treatment experience (OR 2.42 (95% CI 1.83-3.19)). CONCLUSIONS: Physicians in our example decide to initiate antimicrobial therapy on a patient and value intervention to support prudent use, such as continuing education, implementation guidelines and surveillance measures. Socio-behavioral factors, regional differences, gender and age deserve further research to explore relevant influencing factors and to promote rational antimicrobial prescribing.

title: new tool for assessing wandering risk in hospitalized patients
abstract: This article describes the development and implementation of a mobile screening and intervention program based on identifying hospitalized patients with impaired cognition and mobility. A mobile screening tool developed by a multidisciplinary team was associated with appropriate levels of intervention available in the electronic health record. Advanced practice nurses (APNs) validated the accuracy of screening and interventions by bedside nurses for all patients who tested positive. Of the 1,528 hospitalized patients over a 3-week period, 48 (3.1%) were positive for navigation. Patients at risk were older (age >/= 65) (66.7%), those admitted to surgical units (41.7%), Caucasian (89.6%), and males (58.3%). Thirteen (27.1%) had dementia and 45 (93.8%) had cognitive impairment. Of the patients screened positive for crawling, APNs agreed with the bedside nurses' assessment of the risk of wandering in 79.2% (38/48) of cases and 89.5% (34/38 true positives) for interventions. The two-item crawling tool and intervention could be used by bedside nurses. Further studies are needed to determine whether this tool is effective in preventing entanglement.

title: Pan-Canadian practice guideline: prevention, screening, evaluation and treatment of sleep disorders in adults with cancer
abstract: OBJECTIVE: This study aims to provide recommendations on optimal strategies and interventions for the prevention, screening, evaluation and management of cancer-related sleep disorder (insomnia and insomnia syndrome) in adult cancer populations. METHODS: A systematic search of the published health literature was conducted to identify randomized controlled trials, clinical practice guidelines, systematic reviews, and other guidance documents. The Sleep Disorder Expert Panel [consisting of nurses, psychologists, primary care physicians, oncologists, doctors specializing in sleep disorders, researchers, and guideline methodologists] reviewed, discussed, and approved the final guideline. Health professionals in Canada were asked to provide feedback through an external review process. RESULTS: Three clinical practice guidelines and 12 randomized controlled trials were identified as the evidence base. Overall, despite the paucity of evidence, the evidence and expert consensus suggest that it is important to routinely screen and evaluate adult cancer patients for sleep disorders using standard screening tools. While prevention of sleep disturbance is the desired goal, cognitive behavioral therapies are effective in improving sleep outcomes. As part of an external review of 16 healthcare providers, 81% said they accepted the recommendations in writing. CONCLUSIONS: Difficulty sleeping is a common problem in cancer populations that needs greater recognition by healthcare professionals. Prevention, screening, evaluation and treatment strategies supported by the best available evidence are critical. Suggestions for implementation and maintenance path algorithms are presented.

title: patient-initiated system for preventive health care.
abstract: Purpose To test the effectiveness of a patient-initiated, touch-sensitive computer system (TSCS) to improve screening rates for cancers of the breast, cervix, colon and rectum, and oral cavity. Design One-year, randomized, controlled trial with primary care practice as the unit of analysis. Setting Sixty primary care practices randomly selected from 329 non-educational practices in a southeastern state. Subjects A random sample of 507 TSCS users and a random sample from the medical records of 50 male and female adult patients before intervention and 50 adult patients after intervention at each administration. Interventions A registered nurse acting as a liaison officer in touch-sensitive computer system and work practices. TSCS provided patient-specific preventative service recommendations and streamlined the workflow to increase the completion of these interventions. Main Outcome Measure Average change in proportion of eligible patients undergoing screening mammography, clinical breast examination, digital rectal examination, stool occult blood test, flexible sigmoidoscopy, Papanicolaou smear and smear examination, adjusted for use of health care examination (HME) and TSCS oral cavity examination. Results We observed a significant increase in completion of mammography screening (6.6%"; P<=.05) and clinical breast examination (6.1%; P<=.01) in women aged 50 years and older who had an HME during the study year. Results Patients with HMEs are more likely to receive cancer screening; however, a computer-based system for preventive services could contribute to improving screening. Among patients without HME, TSCS users had higher rates of breast cancer screening than nonusers.

title: peer review feedback method promoting adherence to preventive care guidelines in an established ambulatory care clinic
abstract: BACKGROUND: The simple distribution of clinical practice guidelines to physicians does not change practice behavior. A low-cost, continuous peer review feedback method was used to encourage resident physicians in the outpatient clinic at Marshall University School of Medicine (Huntington, West Virginia) to comply with nine preventive care guidelines. METHODS: Preventive care guidelines were distributed and a peer review feedback program was initiated in the resident primary care practice. The frequency of resident physician use of nine preventive care services was evaluated and compared over three periods: preliminary guideline (September 1, 1993 - March 1, 1994"; 148 patients), guideline (September 1, 1994 - March 1, 1995; 148 patients), and one-year follow-up (1 September 1995 - March 1, 1996;" 150 patients). Patients in the three periods were similar in terms of age, gender, and risk of influenza and pneumococcal infection. CONCLUSIONS: During the guideline period, resident doctors provided patients with four preventive care services: tetanus toxoid vaccine, clinical breast exam, Papanicolaou smear test, and hemoccult test, significantly more frequently than during the guideline period. All services were offered significantly more frequently than during the one-year follow-up period and as frequently as during the guideline period. CONCLUSION: A low-cost, ongoing peer review feedback program significantly and permanently improves resident's compliance with clinical practice guidelines for preventive care services. However, the effectiveness of the bad review feedback method cannot be generalized to the private practice or other settings. Research on other methods should continue to promote compliance with clinical practice guidelines and influence physician behavior in general.

title: Pilot study of an interprofessional evidence-based electronic care planning tool for clients with mental health problems and addictions
abstract: BACKGROUND: The health system must develop effective solutions to the growing challenges it faces in relation to individuals with mental health disorders and addictions. The aim of this study was to evaluate the usability of an information translation system aimed at improving client-centered, evidence-based care for hospitalized schizophrenia patients and its potential impact on outcomes. METHOD: Pre-posttest design was used. The e-Volution-TREAT system was implemented in two inpatient units in a large mental health facility. 37 nurses, allied health workers and physicians from two units participated in the study. Data collection included questionnaires, semi-structured interviews and observations. Outcome data from thirty-eight consenting customers were collected from institutional records. RESULTS: Overall, staff participants were very satisfied with the functionality of the e-Volution-TREAT system. Barriers to using the system were identified by the participants regarding the work environment, insufficient staffing, equipment problems, discomfort with technology, and focusing on short-term goals rather than long-term goals. There was moderate acceptance of guidelines on social issues and low uptake of guidelines on family support and addictions. Over time, there have been significant improvements in four client outcomes, particularly aggressive behavior, depression, withdrawal, and psychosis. CONCLUSIONS: Overall, users were overall satisfied with the e-Volution-TREAT system, although users expressed difficulties with the workload that interfered with their time to use the system. It would be premature to conclude that the change in patient outcomes is related to the e-Volution-TREAT system without a randomized controlled trial with results compared to a control group. Future research should include strategies to change the context and involve clinicians in an influential position to model change.

title: population-based cross-sectional study of colorectal cancer screening practices of first-degree relatives of colorectal cancer patients.
abstract: BACKGROUND: The aim of this study was to determine the proportions and predictors of first-degree relatives (FDR) of patients with colorectal cancer (CRC) who (i) had any CRC testing and (ii) received CRC screening in accordance with CRC screening guidelines. . METHODS: Colorectal cancer patients and their FDRs were recruited through the population-based Victorian Cancer Registry in Victoria, Australia. Seven hundred and seven FDRs completed their phone call. Of these, 405 FDRs were considered asymptomatic and suitable for analysis. RESULTS: Sixty-nine percent of FDRs received any CRC test. Elderly people who were asked about a family history of CRC by a doctor before, those with first-degree relatives, private health insurance, siblings, and FDRs were significantly more likely than their peers to have had a previous CRC test. Twenty-five percent of "at or slightly above average risk" FDRs adhered to CRC screening guidelines. For this group, male FDRs and those with higher levels of education were significantly more likely to adhere to the screening recommended by the guideline. For 'moderately high risk' and 'potentially high risk' subjects, 47% and 49% followed the CRC screening guidelines, respectively. For this group, screening recommended by the guidelines was significantly more likely to occur for FDRs living in metropolitan areas, siblings, married or partnered, and those asked about a family history of CRC. RESULTS: Significant non-compliance with screening guidelines was evident among FDRs. Developed CRC screening in accordance with guidelines and effective systematic interventions are needed to increase screening rates among population groups experiencing inequality. TRIAL REGISTRATION: Australia and New Zealand Clinical Trial Registration: ACTRN12609000628246.

title: primary care nurse-led gait intervention in older adults: PACE (pedometer accelerometer consultation assessment)-Lift cluster randomized controlled trial
abstract: BACKGROUND: In older people, brisk walking can increase step count and moderate to vigorous physical activity (MVPA) at intervals >/=10 minutes as recommended in World Health Organization guidelines. Previous interventions have reported step count increases but not changes in objectively measured MVPA in older people. We evaluated whether a complex intervention delivered by a primary care nurse increased objectively measured step counts and MVPA. METHODS AND RESULTS: A total of 988, aged 60-75 years, randomly selected from three UK family practices and able to increase walking, were invited to participate in a parallel two-arm cluster randomized trial"; Randomization was done on a home basis. Two hundred - 250 households between 2011 and 2012 98 people were chosen at random." 150 people to the intervention group, 148 to the usual care control group. Intervention participants received four primary nurse physical activity (PA) counseling over 3 months, which included behavior modification techniques, pedometer step count and accelerometer PA intensity feedback, and an individual PA diary and plan. Evaluators were not blinded to group status, but statistical analyzes were performed blinded. The primary outcome is the change in average daily steps evaluated by accelerometer between baseline and 3 months, while the change at 12 months is a secondary outcome. Other secondary outcomes were weekly change in bouts of >/=10 minutes from baseline to time, accelerometer counts, and counts/minute at 3 months and 12 months in MVPA. Other outcomes were adverse events, anthropometric measures, mood, and pain. Qualitative assessments of intervention participants and practice nurses assessed the acceptability of the intervention. At 3 months, eight participants were withdrawn or followed up, with 280 (94%) providing primary outcome data. At 3 months, changes in both mean daily step counts and weekly MVPA in bouts >/= 10 minutes were significantly higher in the intervention than in the control: 1,037 (95% CI 513-1,560) steps per day and 63 (95%) CI 40- 87) minutes/week, respectively. The corresponding differences at 12 months were 609 (95% CI 104-1,115) steps/day and 40 (95% CI 17-63) minutes/week. Counts and counts/minute showed similar effects to steps and MVPA. Adverse events, anthropometry, mood, and pain were similar in the two groups. Participants and practice nurses found the intervention acceptable and enjoyable. RESULTS: The PACE-Lift trial increased both step counts and objectively measured MVPA in bouts >/=10 minutes at 3 and 12 months in 60-75 year olds and had no effect on adverse events. To our knowledge, this is the first trial to demonstrate objective MVPA increases in this age group, emphasizing the value of individualized support that includes objective PA assessment in primary care. TRIAL REGISTRATION: Controlled-Trials.com ISRCTN42122561.

title: process to develop community consensus on the diagnosis and treatment of attention deficit/hyperactivity disorder
abstract: There are great differences between the practice patterns of pediatricians and the American Academy of Pediatrics (AAP) guidelines for the assessment and treatment of children with attention deficit/hyperactivity disorder (ADHD). A few studies raise additional concerns about access to ADHD treatment for girls, blacks, and poorer individuals. Barriers can arise at many levels, including identification and referral by school staff, help-seeking behavior of parents, diagnosis by the medical provider, treatment decisions, and acceptance of treatment. Such findings confirm the importance of establishing appropriate mechanisms to ensure that children of both sexes and all socioeconomic, racial and ethnic groups receive appropriate assessment and treatment. The publication of the AAP ADHD toolkit provides resources to assist in applying ADHD guidelines in clinical practice. These resources address a number of barriers to office practice, including unfamiliarity with the Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders criteria, difficulty identifying comorbidities, and insufficient knowledge of effective coding practices. Also very important for the success of improved processes in clinical practice is community cooperation in care, especially cooperation with the education system. Such collaboration addresses other barriers to good care, such as pressure from parents and schools to prescribe stimulant prescriptions, cultural biases that may prevent schools from evaluating children for ADHD or discourage families from seeking health care, and inconsistencies in recognition and referral in schools. same system. Collaboration can also create efficiency in data collection and school-physician communication, thereby reducing the non-face-to-face (and therefore non-refundable) element of care for doctors. This article describes a process used in Guilford County, North Carolina to develop consensus among healthcare providers, educators, and child advocates on the assessment and treatment of children with ADHD symptoms. The result, a community protocol followed by school staff and community doctors for >10 years, enables communication and collaboration between educators and physicians in the evaluation and treatment of children with ADHD symptoms. This protocol has the potential to increase practice efficiency, improve practice standards for children with ADHD, and enhance children's identity in schools. Perhaps most importantly, the community process in which the protocol is developed and implemented has an educational component that increases school staff's knowledge of ADHD and its treatment, increases the likelihood that referrals are appropriate, and increases the likelihood that children will benefit from coordination. Interventions among school staff, physicians, and parents The Protocol reflects a consensus of school staff and community health care providers regarding the following: (1) “ideal ADHD assessment and management principles”; (2) a common practice in schools for children who need assessment due to inattention and classroom entry point (a team) Behavior problems, problems first arise in a health facility, behavioral health system, or school; (3) observes a protocol followed by the school system, which recognizes schools' resource limitations but meets the needs of community health care providers for the classroom, psychoeducational testing, parent and teacher behavior rating scales, and functional assessment; (4) a package of information on each child identified as needing medical evaluation; (5) a contact person or team from school to retrieve the package at each doctor's office and direct it to the appropriate clinician; ( 6) an evaluation process that investigates comorbidities and applies the appropriate diagnosis criteria; (7) evidence-based interventions; (8) follow-up processes of children after a treatment plan has been established; (9) the role of central participants (school staff, doctors, school nurses and mental health professionals) in the assessment, management and follow-up of children with attention problems; (10) forms for collecting and exchanging information at each step; (11) processes and key people for communication flow at every step; and (12) a plan to educate school and health professionals about the new processes. A reiteration of the community process initiated in Forsyth County, North Carolina in 2001, offers insights into the role of AAP ADHD guidelines in facilitating the development of a community consensus protocol. This repetition also highlights barriers to identification and orientation at the school level. The following recommendations from 2 community processes explain the role of physicians in the collaborative community care of children with ADHD symptoms. (1) Agree with the school system on the role of school staff in collecting data for children with learning and behavior problems; components to consider include (a) vision and hearing screening, (b) school/academic backgrounds, (c) by a counselor classroom observation, (d) parent and teacher behavior rating scales (eg, Vanderbilt, Conner, or Achenbach scales), (e) assessment of speech/language assessment, (f) screening intelligence test, (g) screening achievement test, (h) full intelligence and achievement testing and (i) classroom intervention trials if abbreviated tests show inconsistencies (2) Use pediatric office visits to identify children with academic or behavioral problems and signs of inattention (history or questionnaire) (3) Recruit identified children in accordance with community consensus direct to the contact person in each child's school by requesting information (4) Determine a contact person who will receive the school materials for the application. review the package and incorporate school data into clinical assessment. (6) The need for multifaceted intervention, including academic and study strategies for the classroom and home, differences between cognitive level and achievement learning or language barrier, and an individualized education plan (special education), an individualized education plan or 504 plan (classroom accommodation) consideration of designation "with other health problems" as an alternative route, behavior modification techniques for targeted behavioral problems, and drug trials as indicated. (7) Refer the patient to a mental health professional if the assessment suggests co-existing conditions. (8) Use contact forms to share diagnosis and medication information, suggested interventions, and follow-up plans with school and family. (9) Obtain required teacher and parent follow-up reports and make adjustments to therapy based on child's functioning in targeted areas. (10) Maintaining contact with school and parents, especially during transitional times (e.g., the beginning and end of the school year, school change, times of family stress, times of change in management, adolescence, and college or university admissions workforce).

title: prospective, multicenter study of a pneumonia practice guideline
abstract: OBJECTIVE: To examine the effect of length of stay practice guidelines on patient outcomes. DESIGN: A prospective, nonrandomized, interventional trial. SETTING: Six geographically distributed hospitals. PATIENTS: Two hundred and forty-two consecutive 'low-risk' patients admitted to the hospital with pneumonia. MEASUREMENTS AND RESULTS: One hundred and fifty-two patients (63%) completed the post-discharge questionnaire and were included in the analysis. Data were collected prospectively for 85 patients from the initial observation period (B) and 67 patients from the intervention period (I). During I, case managers provided physicians with patient risk information based on guideline recommendations. Adherence to guideline (B vs I: 76.5% vs 83.6%";" p=0.32) or duration of stay (B vs I: 3.5 days [95% confidence interval, 3.2 to 3.8] vs 3.6 days [ % 95 confidence interval, 3.3 to 4.0]). In addition, the intervention had no statistically significant effect on patient outcomes, care after hospital discharge, and patient satisfaction scores. CONCLUSION: Patients in this study generally had shorter lengths of stay than recommended in the practice guideline. This suggests that the external environment may have a greater impact on physician behavior and length of stay than the practice guide itself. It also demonstrates the importance of continuous evaluation of physician practice immediately before, during, and after the implementation of clinical practice guidelines.

title: protocol for the pharmacological treatment of major depression. Field testing of a potential prototype
abstract: BACKGROUND: Much attention is paid to the development of clinical practice guidelines for the management of mental health disorders. The aim of this study was to field test a prototype protocol for the pharmacological treatment of Major Depression. METHODS: The protocol consisted of four to six-week treatment phases with critical choices in therapy defined by MADRS (Montgomery Asberg Depression Rating Scale) scores. Observational data collected on the behavior of the protocol in terms of relevance, acceptability, ease of use, and efficacy. RESULTS: The efficacy of the protocol was good for patients who stayed within and three-quarters achieved remission. However, more than half of all patients dropped out of absenteeism, and the most common reasons for this were adverse events. CONCLUSION: The protocol for the treatment of Major Depression seemed relevant, easy to use, and potentially effective. LIMITATION: Issues of non-compliance by both physicians and patients posed major challenges in the design of the protocol. Such difficulties illustrate the need to field-test any proposed design, as biases regarding the performance of a protocol can be misplaced. CLINICAL FITNESS: The tested protocol represents progress towards the goal of developing optimal strategies for the use of pharmacotherapeutic agents in the treatment of depression.

title: Qualitative Assessment of Barriers and Facilitators to Implementation of the WHO Surgical Safety Checklist in Hospitals in England: Lessons from the Surgical Checklist Implementation Project
abstract: Objectives: To assess how the World Health Organization (WHO) surgical safety checklist is implemented in UK hospitals"; to identify barriers and facilitators to implementation; and more generally to draw lessons for the implementation of surgery/healthcare improvement initiatives. Background: WHO checklist, has been associated with improved surgical outcomes and teamwork, but we know little about factors influencing successful recruitment Methods: A longitudinal interview study was conducted with operating room staff on a representative sample of 10 UK hospitals between March 2010 and March 2011. Interviews were audio recorded by telephone The interviewees were asked about their experience with how the checklist was presented and the factors that hindered or helped this process. Transcripts were sent for thematic analysis. Results: A total of 119 interviews were completed. Checklist implementation was between and within hospitals. e varied widely, from preplanned/staged approaches to simply "displaying" the checklist in ORs, or for staff to feel it was imposed. Most barriers to implementation were specific to the checklist itself (for example, perceived design issues) but also included problematic integration into pre-existing processes. The most common obstacle was the resistance of senior clinicians. The facilitators outlined some positive steps that can be taken to avoid/address these barriers, such as changing the checklist, providing education/training, feeding back local data, fostering strong leadership (especially at the level of participation) and promoting accountability. Conclusions: We identified common themes that helped or hindered the introduction of the WHO checklist in the UK and translated them into recommendations to guide the implementation of remediation initiatives in surgery and the wider healthcare system.

title: qualitative study to understand the non-guided use of imaging to stage prostate cancer
abstract: BACKGROUND: Approximately half of veterans with low-risk prostate cancer receive imaging that does not comply with the guideline. Our aim was to (1) compare physician knowledge, attitudes, and practices regarding the use of imaging to stage prostate cancer, (2) patient attitudes and behaviors regarding imaging use, and (3) responses across three different responses. VA medical centers (VAMCs). METHODS: A qualitative approach was used to explore patient and provider knowledge and behavior regarding imaging use. Between September 2014 and July 2015, we conducted a total of 39 semi-structured interviews, 22 interviews with patients with newly diagnosed prostate cancer and 17 interviews with their caregivers, at three VAMCs representing the spectrum of inappropriate screening rates. After the key theoretical concepts were defined, the Theoretical Domains Framework (TDF) was chosen to explore the connections between the themes in the dataset and the existing domains within the framework. The interviews were audio-recorded, transcribed verbatim, and then coded and analyzed using Nvivo software. RESULTS: Themes from patient interviews were categorized into four TDF domains. Patients reported little interest in staging compared to disease treatment (targets), and many could not remember whether they had imaging (information). Patients tended to trust their doctors to make decisions about appropriate tests (beliefs about abilities). Some patients expressed minor concern about radiation exposure, but concern about cancer outcomes outweighed these fears (emotions). Themes from the doctor interviews were categorized into five TDF domains. Most physicians self-reported that they knew and trusted imaging guidelines (knowledge), but some still followed their own intuition due to clinical suspicion or years of experience (beliefs about abilities). Additionally, physicians reported that forensic concerns, fear of missing associated diagnoses (beliefs about outcomes), influence of frequently viewed colleagues (social influences), and viewing rates (environmental context) of the facility they practiced. CONCLUSIONS: Interviews with patients and physicians suggest that physicians are the primary (and in some cases only) decision makers in staging imaging for prostate cancer. This finding suggests that a physician-targeted intervention may be the most effective strategy to improve guideline-compliant prostate cancer imaging.

title: quality improvement intervention that addresses provider behavior as it relates to the use of CA-MRSA guidelines
abstract: OBJECTIVES AND OBJECTIVES: To evaluate the impact of a provider-focused quality improvement education intervention on appropriate prescribing for community-associated methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus infection. BACKGROUND: Patient, provider, and healthcare system factors contribute to appropriate antibiotic prescription. Ensuring appropriate prescribing is critical in reducing the burden of antibiotic resistance. Appropriate prescribing knowledge for community-associated methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus infection is the first step in shifting prescriber behavior to evidence-based recommendations. DESIGN: Quality Improvement Project. METHODS: After reviewing the best practice guidelines and implementing the Stitler Research Usage model, a short educational intervention was conducted using audio over PowerPoint. Items in the educational intervention included screening indications that focused specifically on the watch-and-wait role after culturing for simple abscesses. The intervention was administered in a non-profit, non-academic, emergency care setting, and the knowledge and practice of prescribing providers were evaluated. RESULTS: Eighteen (37.5%) of 48 medical doctors, physician assistants, and general nurse providers agreed";" Twelve (67%) of 18 participants showed increased knowledge. Forty-three percent of prescriber charts demonstrated improved practice through the use of guidelines. Of the 18 prescribers, 44% sent a total of 21 cultures for abscess. There was no difference in practice behaviors between occupational groups. CONCLUSIONS: Despite the increase in knowledge scores, this improvement in knowledge did not turn into a dramatic change in practice, although positive trends were recorded. SUITABLE FOR CLINICAL PRACTICE: This quality improvement project highlights the complexity of changing prescriber behavior and the need for ongoing interventions.

title: quantitative method for evaluating prescribing patterns using electronic health records.
abstract: BACKGROUND: Most quality indicators available for hospitals are represented by simple ratios or ratios and are limited to specific events. A generalized method applicable to various clinical events has not been developed. The aim of this study was to develop a simple method for assessing physicians' prescribing patterns for various events and their awareness of clinical practice guidelines. METHODS AND RESULTS: We developed a quantitative method called the Prescription Model in the Clinical Event Environment (PACE) that can be applied to electronic health records (EHRs). Three distinct prescription patterns (intervention, maintenance, and discontinuation) were determined based on the prescription change index (PCI), calculated by the increase or decrease in the prescribing rate after a clinical event. Hyperkalemia and Clostridium difficile associated diarrhea (CDAD) were used as exemplary cases. We calculated the PCIs of 10 drugs related to hyperkalemia, categorized them by prescription patterns, and then compared the resulting prescription patterns to known standards for the treatment of hyperkalemia. Physicians' knowledge of hyperkalemia was estimated using a questionnaire and compared with prescription pattern. CDAD prescriptions were also determined and compared with clinical knowledge. Clinical data of 1698, 348 and 1288 patients were collected from EHR data. Prescribing physicians for hyperkalemia and CDAD were in agreement with standard information. Prescription patterns correlated well with individual physicians' knowledge of hyperkalemia (kappa = 0.714). Prescribing behaviors according to event severity or clinical situation were plotted as a simple summary graph. CONCLUSION: The algorithm successfully evaluated prescribing patterns from EHR data. Prescription patterns correlated well with physicians' knowledge. We expect this algorithm to enable the quantitative determination of prescribers' adherence to clinical guidelines and be used to facilitate improved prescribing practices.

title: Randomized Clinical Study of an Adapted Lifestyle Intervention for Obese, Sedentary, Primary Care Patients
abstract: OBJECTIVE: The aim of the study was to test a specific lifestyle intervention to help obese primary care patients lose weight and increase their physical activity. METHODS: We conducted a 24-month randomized clinical trial in Rhode Island. Primary care physicians identified obese, sedentary patients who were motivated to lose weight and increase their moderate to vigorous physical activity. These patients were randomized to one of 2 experimental groups: advanced intervention (EI) or standard intervention (SI). Both groups received 3 face-to-face weight loss meetings. The advanced intervention group was also given telephone counseling sessions, individually tailored printed materials, and DVDs focusing on diet and physical activity. Active intervention took place at year 1 and in a reduced maintenance phase at year 2. 79% of the participants were women and 16% were minorities. They averaged 48.6 years of age with a mean body mass index (BMI) of 37.8 kg/m(2) and 21.2 minutes of moderate to vigorous physical activity per week. Significantly more EI participants lost 5% of their baseline weights than SI participants (group by visit, P < .001). The difference was significant at 6 months (12.9% SI vs 37.2% EI) and 12 months (47.8% vs 11.6%) during active treatment, but was no longer significant in the maintenance phase at 18 months (31.4% vs. 26.7%). or 24 months (33.3% vs. 24.6%). The EI group reported significantly more minutes of moderate to vigorous physical activity over time than the SI group (group at visit, P = 0.04). Differences in minutes per week at 6 months were 95.7 minutes for the EI group and 68.3 minutes for the SI group"; 73.7 versus 126.1 at 12 months;" At 18 months, 103.7 vs. 63.7 and at 24 months, 101.3 vs. 75.4. Similar trends were found for the percentage reaching national guidelines for absolute weight loss and physical activity. CONCLUSION: A home-based, tailored lifestyle intervention was effective in promoting weight loss and increasing moderate to vigorous physical activity in obese, sedentary primary care patients, with effects peaking at 12 months but diminishing at 24 months.

title: randomized controlled trial of a drug use review intervention for sedative hypnotic drugs.
abstract: OBJECTIVES: The review of drug use is used by both the public and private sectors to influence prescribing behavior and patient drug use. The results of past interventions sent to prescribers have been mixed. The aim was to evaluate the effect of a one-time, mail-in intervention on subsequent use of sedative hypnotic medication. METHODS: An experimental design was used. The intervention included guidelines for the use of sedative hypnotics, a prescriber profile detailing the prescribing of sedative hypnotics, and a patient profile. Clustering of patients and co-prescribers was done to avoid contamination bias and statistical problems associated with non-independent observations. Subjects were 189 Washington State Medicaid recipients who took at least one sedative hypnotic drug tablet daily for 1 year and their prescribing physician or pharmacy dispensing drug (when information about the physician was missing). RESULTS: A significant reduction in the use of targeted sedative hypnotic drugs was measured in the intervention group (-27.6%) versus the control group (-8.5%). In the intervention group, 9.4% of patients started a new prescription for a benzodiazepine not targeted by the drug use review, while no control patients had new off-target benzodiazepine use. CONCLUSIONS: The intervention produced a statistically significant reduction in targeted drug use, and the amount of reduction is likely to have reduced the risk of fractures associated with benzodiazepine use. This study adds to recent evidence that mail-in medication use review interventions can have a desirable effect on patient medication use.

title: randomized controlled trial of a comprehensive lifestyle management intervention (ELMI) following cardiac rehabilitation: study design and baseline data.
abstract: BACKGROUND: Cardiac rehabilitation programs (CRP) represent comprehensive interventions typically limited to four months. It appears that risk factors and lifestyle behaviors may deteriorate after CRP is completed. The Cardiac Rehabilitation Trial after Comprehensive Lifestyle Management Intervention (ELMI) will explore the benefits of a randomized intervention to prevent these adverse changes. METHODS: Patients with ischemic heart disease (IRD) were randomized to ELMI or usual care following a standard CRP. The ELMI program is a case-managed intervention that aims to individualize risk factor and lifestyle management based on current treatment guidelines. The program consists of cardiac rehabilitation sessions, telephone follow-up and risk factor and lifestyle counseling sessions. Health professionals work with participants using behavioral counseling and communication with participants' family physicians. Ordinary care participants return to their family doctor's care and come to the study clinic only to undergo an annual outcome assessment. The primary outcome is the change in global risk of IHD after four years. Secondary outcomes include combined cardiovascular events, healthcare use, lifestyle adherence, quality of life, and risk factors. RESULTS: 302 men and women were randomized over 28 months. This represented 29% of the total population screened. The mean age of the study participants was 64, 18% were female, 53% had a previous myocardial infarction, 73% had previous revascularization, and 20% had diabetes mellitus. The ischemic heart disease risk factors for the entire cohort were significantly improved after subjects went through previous CRPs. Major risk factors, lifestyle behaviors, and medications were similar between groups. RESULTS: This study population represents patients who have completed a standard CRP. The results of the ELMI trial will provide valuable information for the future design of CRPs.

title: Randomized Controlled Trial of IVR-Based Alcohol Brief Intervention to Promote Patient-Provider Communication in Primary Care
abstract: BACKGROUND: Brief interventions for unhealthy drinking in primary care are effective but underused. Efforts to improve short response rates through provider training and redesign of office systems have had limited impact. Our new brief intervention uses interactive voice response (IVR) to provide information and advice directly to unhealthy drinkers prior to a doctor's office visit, with the aims of promoting in-office dialogue about drinking and reducing unhealthy drinking. This automated approach is potentially scalable for broad application. OBJECTIVE: We aimed to examine the impact of the pre-visit IVR-provided brief alcohol intervention (IVR-BI) on patient-provider alcohol discussions during the visit. Design: This was a parallel group randomized controlled trial with two treatment arms: 1) IVR-BI or 2) usual care (no IVR-BI). PARTICIPANTS: In total, 1,567 patients were recruited from internal medicine and family medicine clinics affiliated with eight university medical centers. INTERVENTIONS: IVR-BI is a short automatic telephone intervention for alcohol. It has four components based on intervention steps outlined for clinicians in the National Institute on Alcohol Abuse and Alcoholism guidelines: 1) asking about alcohol use, 2) assessing alcohol use disorders, 3) advising the patient to stop or quit drinking, and 4) follow up at subsequent visits. . KEY MEASURES: Results reported by patient: patient-provider alcohol discussion at visit"; patient initiation of discussion;" and the provider's advice regarding the patient's alcohol use. KEY RESULTS: Patients randomized to IVR-BI were more likely to report talking about alcohol with their provider (52% vs. 44%, p = 0.003), bringing it up themselves (12% vs. 20%, p < 0.001) and get a recommendation (14% versus 20%, p < 0.001). Other predictors of outcome included baseline consumption, education, age, and alcohol use disorder diagnosis. CONCLUSIONS: Providing automated brief interventions to patients prior to the primary care visit encourages discussion about unhealthy drinking and increases specific professional advice on changing drinking behavior.

title: randomized controlled trial to evaluate the effectiveness of a distance learning asthma program for pediatricians.
abstract: OBJECTIVES: To assess provider acceptability of a distance learning program for pediatric asthma and to pilot test the effects of this program on physician knowledge, attitudes, and treatment practice. DESIGN: Randomized controlled trial. SETTING: Central Kentucky area in and around Louisville. PARTICIPANTS: Twenty-four pediatricians in clinical practice. interventions. A distance education program for pediatric asthma consisting of Web or CD-ROM based multimedia learning modules and two teleconference calls. OUTCOME MEASURES: Student satisfaction and change in physician asthma knowledge, attitudes, and treatment behavior at 1 to 4 months (short-term) and 6 to 8 months (long-term). RESULTS: Pediatricians graduated from medical school an average of 11.6 years ago (SD +/-8.9)";" 56% were women. On all student satisfaction items, the average score on a 5-point scale was 4.0 or higher, indicating a positive response from participants. Participants in the training group reported greater familiarity with asthma guidelines for prescribing daily inhaled corticosteroids compared to control physicians at short-term follow-up (p = .03). Participants also expressed increased confidence in drug selection for patients requiring low-dose inhaled steroids (p = .03). However, these differences were not seen in long-term follow-up. Compared with the control group, there was no significant increase in the proportion of patients receiving inhaled steroids for persistent asthma at short or long-term follow-up. RESULTS: Pediatricians using an asthma distance learning program expressed a high degree of student satisfaction. The program was associated with a temporary increase in familiarity and confidence in implementing components of asthma guidelines.

title: randomized controlled trial to improve lymph node assessment in stage II colon cancer.
abstract: HYPOTHESIS: Doctors seem to learn best from their peers, but the influence of opinion leaders on physician behavior is unclear. Because colon cancer staging is defined as inadequate in Ontario, Canada, we sought to evaluate the impact of colon cancer expert and local opinion leaders on optimizing colon cancer lymph node assessment. DESIGN, ENVIRONMENT, PARTICIPANTS: A cluster-randomized study of all hospitals in Ontario who identified a local opinion leader by intervention between January 5 and June 17, 2004. An opinion leader who specializes in colon cancer. The 21 response hospitals also received academic elaboration and a toolkit on a local opinion leader by an expert opinion leader. MAIN OUTCOME MEASURES: The mean number of lymph nodes evaluated in patients with stage II colon cancer and the proportion of cases staged with at least 12 lymph nodes before and after a standard course were evaluated. RESULTS: Patient demographics and tumor factors were similar in both groups before and after the standardized course. Lymph node assessment significantly improved (P < .001) after standardized coursework in intervention and control sites. No additional benefit of academic elaboration and provision of a toolkit in the intervention has been demonstrated. CONCLUSIONS: Personal information provided by a colon cancer expert opinion leader can promote performance on lymph node evaluation for colon cancer. Academic elaboration by a local opinion leader did not further improve lymph node evaluation.

title: Randomized outpatient trial of a decision support information technology tool.
abstract: Background Decision-support information technology is often adopted to improve clinical decision making, but is rarely rigorously evaluated. Congress mandated the consideration of Problem-Information Integrators (PKC Corp, Burlington, Vt), a proposed decision support tool for the Department of Defense's new health information network. Methods This was a randomized patient-level trial conducted in 2 military exercises. A total of 936 patients were assigned to the intervention group and 966 to usual care. Coupler was applied before routine outpatient visits. The primary outcome was quality of care as assessed by the total percentage of any of the 24 health care quality process measures (evidence-based care delivery opportunities) fulfilled. Secondary outcomes included medical resources consumed within 60 days of enrollment and patient and provider satisfaction. Outcomes There were 4639 healthcare opportunities (2374 in the Kupler group and 2265 in the usual care group), with no difference in the proportion of opportunities fulfilled (33.9% vs. 30.7%";" P = .12). Although there was a modest improvement in performance in screening/preventive measures, it was offset by lower performance in some acute care measures. Combiner patients used more lab and pharmacy resources than regular care patients (logarithmic mean difference, $71). There was no difference in patient satisfaction between the groups, and provider satisfaction was mixed. Conclusion This study does not provide strong evidence to support the usefulness of this decision support tool, but demonstrates the value of rigorous evaluation of decision support information technology.

title: random attempt at "result orders" to avoid omission errors.
abstract: Purpose: Omission errors are a common cause of system failures. Doctors often fail to order tests or treatments needed to monitor/improve the effects of other tests or treatments. The authors hypothesized that the automated, guideline-based reminders provided to physicians when writing instructions could mitigate these shortcomings. Design: The research was carried out in the general medicine inpatient ward of a state teaching hospital. Faculty and home workers from the Indiana University School of Medicine who used computer workstations to write orders were randomized to intervention and control groups. Intervention doctors typed orders for 1 out of 87 selected tests or treatments, while the computer suggested the natural orders needed to detect or ameliorate adverse reactions to trigger orders. Physicians can accept or reject these recommendations. Results: During the 6-month trial, 48 intervention physicians were provided with reminders about outcome orders and were withheld from 41 control physicians. Intervention doctors ordered result orders recommended in 46.3% of cases when they received a reminder, while control doctors agreed in 21.9% (p < 0.0001). Doctors were discriminated against in accepting suggested orders, some readily accepted and others rejected. Interventions initiated by pharmacists along with doctors in the intervention were one-third less than in the control groups. Conclusion: This study shows that physician workstations linked to a comprehensive electronic medical record can be an effective tool to reduce errors of omission and improve adherence to practice guidelines.

title: randomized trial of a computer-based intervention to reduce the use of unnecessary laboratory tests.
abstract: OBJECTIVE: To determine the effect of giving physicians computerized reminders about seemingly unnecessary clinical laboratory tests. SUBJECTS AND METHODS: We conducted a prospective randomized controlled trial involving all patients hospitalized in a large teaching hospital over a 15-week period. The intervention consisted of computerized reminders when a seemingly unnecessary test was ordered. The main outcome measures were the proportion of clinical laboratory orders canceled and the proportion of tests actually performed. RESULTS: During the study period, there were 939 apparently unnecessary laboratory tests among the 77,609 study tests ranked between the intervention (n = 5,700 patients) and control (n = 5,886 patients) groups. In the intervention group, 69% of the tests (300 out of 437) were canceled in response to reminders. Of the 137 overrides, 41% were justified by table review. In the control group, 51% of sequential redundancy tests were performed, while in the intervention group only 27% of sequential redundancy tests were performed (P < 0.001). However, the estimated annual savings in lab fees were only $35,000. This was because only 44% of the redundant tests performed were computer orders, only half of the computer orders were scanned for redundancy, and almost a third of the reminders were invalidated. RESULTS: Reminders about apparently unnecessary lab testing orders were effective when delivered. However, the overall effect was limited because many tests were performed without corresponding computer orders and many orders were not screened for redundancy.

title: randomized trial of computer-based reminders and supervision and feedback to improve HIV screening in primary care.
abstract: Despite recommendations for voluntary HIV screening, few medical centers have implemented screening programs. The aim of the study was to determine whether an intervention with computer-based reminders and feedback would increase HIV screening in the Department of Veterans Affairs (VA) healthcare system. The design of the study was a randomized controlled trial in five primary care clinics at the VA Palo Alto Health Care System. All primary care providers were eligible to participate in the study. Study interventions were computer-based reminders to either assess HIV risk behaviors or recommend HIV testing"; feedback on adherence to reminders was provided. The main outcome measure was the difference in HIV testing rates between intervention and control providers. Control group providers, pre-intervention and during the intervention period tested 1.0% (n = 67) and 1.4% (n = 106) of patients, respectively, with intervention providers 1.8% (n = 98) and 1.9% (n = 114) tested (P = 0.75). In our random sample of 753 untested patients, 204 (27%) had documented risky behaviors Providers were more likely to adhere to reminders to test rather than reminders to assess risk (11% vs. 5%, P < 0.01). Sixty-one percent of providers felt that the lack of time impeded risk assessment.As a result, HIV testing rates in primary care clinics in our setting were low. They were unaware of the high-risk behavior rates in their patient population and perceived significant barriers to testing. Low-intensity clinical reminders and feedback did not increase screening rates.

title: randomized trial of computerized reminders for blood pressure screening in primary care.
abstract: In a randomized, controlled study (N = 8,298) the authors compared three ways to encourage patients in a large family practice to have their blood pressure checked. The study from computerized medical records at a family medicine training center included patients aged 18 years and older who had not had their blood pressure measured in the previous year. In the normal care control group, 21.1% of those requiring blood pressure measurement achieved one in the trial year. A computer-generated message in an intervention group reminding the doctor to check the blood pressure of patients who come to the center for an appointment; "30.7% of the patients allocated to this group were controlled. In the second group, the nurse was contacted. and it encouraged 24.1% of those who would receive the checks to receive the checks. Sending letters to the patients in the third group achieved a 35.7% compliance rate. Cost of three interventions Physician reminder was the most cost effective, followed by letter reminder.

title: randomized trial of electronic clinical reminders to improve quality of care for diabetes and coronary artery disease.
abstract: Objective: The aim of this study was to evaluate the effect of an integrated patient-specific electronic clinical reminder system on diabetes and coronary artery disease (CAD) care and to evaluate physician attitudes towards this reminder system. Design: We enrolled 194 primary care physicians caring for 4549 patients with diabetes and 2199 patients with CAD in 20 outpatient clinics. Clinics were randomized that physicians receive evidence-based electronic reminders in their patients' electronic medical records or usual care. There were five reminders for diabetes care and four reminders for CAD care. Measures: The primary outcome was receiving recommended care for diabetes and CAD. We generated a summary result to assess the likelihood of increased adherence to general diabetes care (based on five measures) and overall CAD care (based on four measures). We surveyed doctors to assess attitudes towards the reminder system. Results: Baseline adherence to all quality measures was low. Electronic reminders increased the likelihood of recommended diabetes care (odds ratio [OR] 1.30, 95% confidence interval [CI] 1.01–1.67) and CAD (OR 1.25, 95% CI 1.01–1.55), while individual reminders were variable. A total of three nine reminders effectively increased rates of recommended care for diabetes or CAD. The majority of physicians (76%) thought that reminders improved the quality of care. Conclusion: An integrated electronic reminder system resulted in variable improvement in diabetes and CAD care. These improvements were generally limited and quality gaps remain.

title: randomized trial of the efficacy of computer-triggered drug decision support versus on-demand drug in primary care.
abstract: Objectives: Prescribing alerts generated by computerized drug decision support (CDDS) can prevent drug-related morbidity. However, the vast majority of warnings are ignored due to clinical irrelevance. The ability to customize commercial alert systems should improve physician acceptance, as the physician can choose the terms and types of drug warnings displayed. We tested the effectiveness of two approaches to customizing medication alerting to reduce the prevalence of prescribing problems: physician-requested and computer-triggered decision support. Doctors in each study condition were able to preset the levels that triggered the alerts. Design: This was a cluster trial for 3,449 patients seen over the next 6 months with 28 primary care physicians randomized to automated or on-demand CDDS in the MOXXI drug management system. Metrics: CDDS has created alerts to prescribe issues that can be customized by severity. Prescribing issues included dose errors, drug-drug, age, allergy, and disease interactions. Doctors randomized on demand enabled drug review when they thought it was clinically relevant, while physicians randomized to computer-triggered decision support displayed all alerts for electronic prescriptions based on their chosen severity level for both common and incident problems. Data from administrative requests and MOXXI were used to measure the difference in prevalence of prescribing problems at the end of follow-up. Results: During follow-up, 50% of physicians receiving computer-triggered alerts changed the alert threshold (n = 7) and 21% of doctors in the on-demand alert group changed the alert level (n = 3). In the optional group, 4,445 prescribing problems were detected, 41 (0.9%) problems were observed in the requested drug review, and prescriptions were revised in 31 (75.6%) problems. By comparison, out of 6,505 prescribing problems in the computer-triggered group, 668 (10.3%) were seen and 81 (12.1%) were revised. Most warnings were ignored because the benefit was judged to outweigh the risk, the interaction was known, or the interaction was not considered clinically significant (computer-triggered: 75.8% of 585 ignored warnings; optional: 90% of 10 ignored warnings warnings). At the end of follow-up, there was a significant reduction in therapeutic relapse problems in the computer-triggered group (odds ratio 0.55;" p = 0.02) but no difference in the overall prevalence of prescribing problems. Outcome: customization of computer-triggered alert systems rather than on-demand review more useful in detecting and solving prescribing problems, but neither approach has been effective in reducing prescribing problems. New strategies are needed to maximize the use of drug decision support systems to reduce drug-related morbidity.

title: Randomized Trial Comparing Alternative Educational Interventions to Increase Colorectal Cancer Screening in Hard-to-Reach Urban Minority Populations with Health Insurance
abstract: This randomized controlled trial evaluated different educational approaches to increase the uptake of colorectal cancer screening in a sample of primarily non-US-born urban minority individuals over 50 years of age who had health insurance and did not comply with screening guidelines. In one group, participants were sent printed educational material (n = 180)"; in the second group, participants' primary care physicians were given academic details to improve their screening referral and follow-up practices (n = 185);" in one-third, physicians received academic elaboration and participant-specific telephone training (n = 199). Overall, 21.5% (n = 121) of participants received appropriate screening within one year of randomization. There was no statistically significant dual difference between the groups in the screening rate. However, among those aged 60 and over, the elaboration plus telephone education group had a higher screening rate than the print group (27.3 vs. 7.7%, p = .02). Different types of interventions will be required to increase screening for colorectal cancer in an unscreened and shrinking population. ClinicalTrials.gov Identifier: NCT02392143.

title: real-world cascaded wedge cluster randomized practice facilitation trial to improve cardiovascular care
abstract: BACKGROUND: Facilitation of administration has been associated with significant improvements in disease prevention and quality of patient care. Using facilitation of practice, the Improving Cardiovascular Care (IDOCC) project aimed to improve the delivery of evidence-based cardiovascular care in primary care settings in a broad health region. Our aim was to assess the impact of IDOCC on adherence to care delivery processes. METHODS: A pragmatic tiered cluster randomized trial recruiting primary care providers in practices located in Eastern Ontario, Canada (ClinicalTrials.gov: NCT00574808). Participants were randomly assigned to one of three steps by region. Implementation facilitators were intended to visit practices every 3-4 (year 1 intensive) or 6-12 weeks (year 2 sustainability) to support changes in practice behavior. The primary outcome was average adherence to evidence-based care indicators measured at the patient level. Compliance was assessed by chart review of a cohort of 66 randomly selected patients per treatment at each pre-intervention year, as well as at 1 and 2 years post-intervention. RESULTS: Eighty-four practices (182 physicians) participated. The facilitators made an average of 6.6 (min: 2, max: 11) face-to-face visits in year 1 and 2.5 (min: 0 max: 10) visits in year 2. We collected tabular data from 5292 patients. After adjusting for patient and provider characteristics, there was an absolute decrease in mean adherence of 1.9% (95% confidence interval (CI): -2.9 to -0.9%) and 4.2% (95% CI: -5.7 to -2.6%). The basis for years of intense and sustainability, respectively. CONCLUSIONS: IDOCC did not improve compliance with best practice guidelines. Our results showed a small statistically significant decrease in mean agreement of questionable clinical significance. Possible reasons for this outcome include implementation difficulties, competing priorities in implementation, a broad focus on multiple chronic disease indicators, and the use of an overall compliance index. These results contradict findings from previously reported facilitation trials and highlight the complexities and challenges of translating research findings into clinical practice. TRIAL REGISTRATION: ClinicalTrials.gov NCT00574808.

title: Research Agenda for High Value Palliative Care
abstract: Palliative care has gone from being misunderstood and overlooked by many clinicians to become one of the most sought after services by healthcare systems nationwide. This is the greatest possible proof of the potential value of space. However, the field's ability to sustainably provide high-value care is paradoxically threatened by its own success, as demand rapidly outpaces the supply of palliative care professionals (1). To bridge the gap between workforce and patient need, we propose a research agenda organized around 5 key questions about the optimal organization and allocation of limited resources in private palliative care. The table presents key considerations and suggested approaches to addressing each research problem. Among the growing evidence for the potential value of private palliative care (2), we hypothesize that it is necessary to answer these questions in order to maximize value and inform much-needed policies to support this care (3).

title: Solution for Doctors: Time to Focus on the Public Health Threat of Gun Violence
Review of family intervention guidelines for pediatric acquired brain injuries
abstract: Pediatric acquired brain injury (BI) not only affects the injured child, but also greatly affects his family. Studies show that rates of caregiver and sibling psychological distress are higher after a child in the family maintains BI. Also, family functioning after BI affects the child's recovery.
