In reviewing the literature, we identified seven theoretical clinical guidelines for working with families of children and adolescents with BI. These clinical guidelines are: (1) select developmentally appropriate interventions, (2) match the intervention with the family, (3) provide advocacy, (4) provide injury education, (5) focus on family reorganization, (6) appropriately address the child's environment. and (7) provide skills training to the family and the child. Current research on family interventions for BI is reviewed in the context of these theoretical guidelines, and then empirical support for each guideline is evaluated using specific criteria for empirically supported treatments. Unfortunately, very few randomized controlled trials are available and continued research is needed to classify all clinical guidelines as "effective". Additionally, ongoing research will help inform experts about specific approaches to use when working with the family of a child with BI. Currently, clinicians and researchers can turn to existing clinical guidelines to help address the myriad of barriers that come with practicing and examining family interventions for pediatric BI.

title: review of quantitative studies of adherence to mental health clinical practice guidelines
abstract: Mental health clinical practice guidelines have proliferated, but there is little evidence of the extent to which they are actually applied in clinical practice. The purpose of this study was to find and review all peer-reviewed reports published up to 2000 that provided quantitative information on rates of adherence to specific mental health guidelines. A literature review yielded 41 related studies. These studies were of three types: 26 were cross-sectional studies conducted after the publication of the guidelines, six were conducted without any specific intervention (pre/post) before and after the publication of the guidelines, and nine included a controlled trial of a specific intervention. Only 37% were conducted in the mental health specialty sector. Adequate agreement was found in 27% of cross-sectional and before/after studies and 67% of controlled studies. Successful interventions tended to be complex, involving system redesign or additional resources. Of the 13 studies that also measured patient outcome, only six (46%) found that better outcome was associated with greater guideline adherence. Several studies have shown that after interventions were discontinued, compliance rates returned to pre-intervention levels. Thus, the evidence suggests that adherence to the guideline is not high without the specific intervention, but that specific interventions (typically those that are versatile and resource-intensive) improve compliance. However, the public health challenge is to design and implement interventions that are sustainable in general clinical practice.

title: review of the evidence for poor adherence by healthcare practitioners to standard/universal infection control measures
abstract: OBJECTIVES: Drawing on international research, the review examines: the extent to which practitioners adhere to infection control measures; relevant issues considered to be effective in compliance; what strategies have been evaluated to promote positive behavior changes among practitioners and the impact of these interventions. BACKGROUND: Internationally, standard/universal precautions (UPs) are considered fundamental to infection prevention and control and are effective in protecting practitioners and patients. However, compliance has been problematic and implementation of standard/IPs is sub-optimal globally. METHODS: Literature search using various electronic databases from 1994 to 2006, where relevant evidence was defined by the number of key terms used. Data were extracted using key headings that facilitated analysis. RESULTS: Thirty-seven studies were evaluated. Twenty-four related to measuring practitioner compliance and t' 13 studies evaluating the effect of a research intervention on compliance. In addition, other studies examining specific causes of suboptimal compliance or discussing infection control measures in general are included. CONCLUSIONS: Compliance with infection control measures is below optimal at the international level. Evidence confirms that compliance with certain aspects of the standard/IPs varies and practitioners are selective in applying recommended practices. Adaptation improves following a structured intervention," but research fails to show how long the intervention affects practitioner compliance, or whether compliance returns to the norm after a period of time. Various causes of non-compliance are discussed and recommendations for the future Relevance for clinical practice Sub-optimal compliance staff safety, patient protection Infection control teams and researchers should consider the causes of non-compliance and provide a supportive environment that assists the routine, long-term application of standard precautions.

title: review of the literature on remote monitoring technology in incentive-based interventions for health-related behavior change.
abstract: The use of technology (eg, Internet, mobile phones) is increasing to allow remote delivery of incentive interventions for health-related behavior change. To our knowledge, a systematic review of this reported literature has not yet been conducted. This report presents a systematic review of controlled trials using technology to remotely administer financial incentive interventions targeting substance use and other health behaviors published between 2004 and 2015. Alone or in combination of the following 2 objectives: (a) to monitor target behavior or (b) to provide incentives to achieve the target target. Studies also examine financial incentives (e.g., cash, coupons) for health-related behavior change, peer-reviewed publication, and the effectiveness of the incentive intervention into another situation (e.g., unconditional incentives, treat-as-usual). Of the 39 reports that met the inclusion criteria, 18 were targeted substance use, 10 targeted drug adherence or home health monitoring, and 11 targeted diet, exercise, or weight loss. All 39 (100%) studies used technology to facilitate remote monitoring of target behavior, and 26 (66.7%) studies incorporated technology into the remote delivery of incentives. Statistically significant intervention effects were reported in 71% of the studies reviewed. Overall, the results provide substantial support for the effectiveness of remotely administered incentive interventions for health-related behavior change, which have the potential to increase the cost-effectiveness and accessibility of this treatment approach. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2016 APA, all rights reserved)

title: review of the use of laboratory testing: A trigger for cost reduction and quality improvement in healthcare
abstract: BACKGROUND: Considering the role of laboratory testing as a central part of controlling healthcare expenditure, this study aims to explore the overuse of laboratory testing in Iran to pave the way for future interventions. METHODS: Inappropriate laboratory use was reviewed in a cross-sectional questionnaire through retrospective analysis of 384 medical records at a tertiary center. To pave the way for future intervention, overuse tests were divided into two categories, inappropriate and ineffective, and then analyzed. Frequency analysis was used to analyze the patient's age, gender, length of hospital stay, length of stay and diagnosis, as well as inappropriate testing and inefficient testing. RESULTS: A total of 143 (1.50%) of the tests were inefficient and were ordered due to laboratory errors such as hemolysis, insufficient sampling or absurd results. Of the tests, 2522 (26.40%) were ineligible and resulted from not meeting the medical/clinical eligibility criteria. CONCLUSION: Although inappropriate test sequencing is more frequent than inefficient testing, initial remediation strategy should focus on physicians' test ordering behavior through appropriate teaching strategies, continuous supervision and training feedback, application of health information technology tools, and application of laboratory practice guidelines (LPGs). . ) and test algorithms. For inefficient testing, it is recommended to conduct a cycle of continuous quality improvement for laboratory services and to train personnel involved in blood sampling.

title: simple intervention to improve hospital antibiotic prescription
abstract: OBJECTIVE: To evaluate changes in prescribing behavior after distribution of antibiotic guides printed on 9 x 6 cm laminated card suitable for affixing to a hospital ID card. INTERVENTION: Guidelines for appropriate antibiotic prescription for 20 common and important pediatric infections were printed on a laminated 9 x 6 cm laminated card suitable for clip-on hospital ID card and distributed to all healthcare personnel. DESIGN: We collected data from medical records for three marker conditions (tonsillitis, pneumonia, and orbital/periorbital cellulitis) in patient samples from six-month periods on either side of the month in which the cards were distributed. The prescribers were unaware of the study, and the investigators analyzed the prescriptions without knowledge of the period in which they were written. Prescriptions were graded according to appropriate antibiotic and appropriate dose selection. Data on antibiotic costs were also collected. MAIN OUTCOME MEASURES: "Proportion of cases where antibiotic choice is appropriate"; proportion of cases where antibiotic dosing is appropriate; annual costs of third-generation cephalosporins. RESULTS: Little change in prescribing practice after the introduction of cards for tonsillitis. For pneumonia, cases with appropriate choice 77% and increased appropriate dose from 48% to 81% (P = 0.001) For orbital/periorbital cellulitis, suitably selected cases increased from 19% to 78% ( P < 0.001) and appropriate dose cases increased from 30% to 51% (P = 0.11) Third generation cephalosporins had annual costs of $193,245 for pre-cards and $89,814 for postcards. This simple intervention is likely to be cost-effective and beneficial in reducing inappropriate antibiotic use.

title: simple way to improve DVT protocol compatibility
abstract: Objective: To evaluate the effect on deep vein thrombosis (DVT) protocol violations of applying a label attached to the patient's medication schedule, specifically allowing appropriate prescribing of low-dose subcutaneous heparin or thromboembolic stockings (TEDS). Design: An audit study. Setting: General Surgery Department of a District General Hospital in the UK. Method: All adult general surgery patients hospitalized on weekdays were examined. Staff were not warned about the work in advance. Patient details and risk factors for DVT were noted. Details of the DVT prophylaxis administered were recorded. In total, four separate studies were conducted: with the original protocols (I), after 1 and 3 years with the refined protocol (II, III), and finally after the introduction of the label (IV). Results: Protocol violations were defined as "acceptable" or "unacceptable". Raising awareness between Study I and II reduced acceptable violations to zero. There was no statistically significant reduction in unacceptable violations (24.1" in 80 patients; 17 in 75, II;"13 in 60, III). In Study IV, 51 patients had only 6 violations after label introduction (p<0.02). The result: Combining increased awareness with adding labels to the medication schedule reduced unacceptable violations by 63%.

title: snapshot of general practitioner attitudes, confidence levels, and self-reported pediatric asthma management practice
abstract: The prevalence of asthma is high in Australia. Previous findings have suggested that asthma management has been inadequate, particularly in primary care, and recent government attempts to improve asthma management and encourage the use of written asthma action plans (WAAPs) in general practice have been implemented. We aimed to evaluate the attitudes, confidence and self-reported practice of pediatric asthma management of a suitable sample of Australian general practitioners (GPs). A basic questionnaire was administered to GPs as part of a randomized controlled trial. General practitioners (GPs) were recruited from two areas of the Sydney metropolitan area, NSW, between 2006 and 2008. Invitations were sent to an estimated 1200 potential eligible GPs. Of the 150 (12.5%) registered general practitioners, 122 (10.2%) completed the basic questionnaire. Although 89% were aware of the Australian National Asthma Guidelines, less than 40% were familiar with the guideline recommendations. While 85.2% of them had a positive attitude towards WAAPs, only 45.1% reported that they provided them frequently. For children with frequent symptoms, 90% agreed that they should be prescribed daily inhaled corticosteroids (ICS), and 83% reported that they currently prescribe ICS to such patients. These findings illustrate gaps between GP attitudes and behaviors and highlight opportunities for intervention to improve pediatric asthma management.

title: statewide controlled trial intervention to reduce the use of unproven or ineffective breast cancer treatment
abstract: BACKGROUND: Challenged by the public, colleagues, and the Congressional Budget Office, medical specialty associations have begun to develop a "Top Five" list of expensive procedures that do not provide meaningful benefits, at least to some categories of patients for which they are generally ordered. However, it is unknown to what extent these lists affect the behavior of doctors or patients. METHODS: We are partnering with a statewide health systems consortium to examine the effectiveness of two interventions: (i) "basic" public reporting and (ii) an "advanced" intervention that increases public reporting with a smartphone-based app that provides information to providers. Just-in-time information, decision-making tools, and personalized patient education materials to support reductions in the use of eight breast cancer interventions targeted by Choosing Wisely(R) or oncology community guidelines. Our objectives are: (1) to examine whether basic public reporting reduces the use of targeted breast cancer practices in a contemporary cohort of patients with breast cancer cases in the intervention versus usual care setting in comparison situations; (2) to examine the efficacy of an enhanced intervention relative to the baseline intervention; and (3) simulating the cost savings resulting from the nationwide implementation of both interventions. DISCUSSION: The results will provide conclusive evidence of the effectiveness of a unique public reporting system that pays all ages to influence provider behavior that can easily be exported to other states and potentially major health systems. The findings will be more relevant to the ACO environment, which is expected to provide financial disincentives for ineffective or unproven care. TRIAL REGISTRATION: ClinicalTrials.gov number pending.

title: Examining the factors associated with cost and diversity in prescribing among GPs.
abstract: BACKGROUND: Improper prescribing has the potential to harm both the individual and society. Previous research has identified physician or demographic characteristics that influence prescribing variation but cannot be changed. OBJECTIVES: To identify modifiable factors associated with GP prescribing variance and cost. METHODS: Qualitative research methods were used in semi-structured taped interviews with 17 GPs in Avon, South West NHS Region, England. CONCLUSIONS: GPs viewed themselves as cautious and conservative prescribers. Prescribing decisions were often justified by the prescriber, despite conflicting clinical or cost arguments. A personally developed drug formulation was used to reduce the dilemmas potentially associated with prescribing uncertainty. The willingness to reflect on and measure prescribing habits according to established professional standards varied significantly. The absence of mechanisms for monitoring prescribing decisions, combined with the inadequate use of the community pharmacist, has resulted in ambiguous prescribing results. Some GPs have had a hard time keeping up to date professionally due to perceived time constraints. Excessive patient demand was thought to affect their prescribing, but GPs stated that they were not unduly influenced by the drug representative. CONCLUSIONS: Prescribing has a significant impact on health and budgets and still remains a controversial issue. Improved partnerships should be established between patient, doctor and pharmacist. Support through better prescribing decision monitoring and policy development and educational intervention is needed to reduce prescribing uncertainty. Newly established Primary Care Groups may need to reflect on the challenges faced by prescribers, particularly when prescribing within cash-limited budgets, to avoid mismatch between prescribing behavior and local policy development.

title: Successful experiment to reduce unnecessary laboratory use in a public hospital
abstract: series of interventions at a 228-bed general hospital provided doctors with periodic feedback on the amount of laboratory services used to treat their patients. Laboratory test estimates adjusted for case mix allowed each doctor to compare the use of laboratory tests with that of their colleagues in the same department in the same hospital. Doctors with "extreme" practice patterns ordered hundreds of more lab tests than average each year. A well-rounded training program included: 1) meetings were held about costs and unnecessary laboratory testing"; 2) physicians were given explanations of practice patterns relative to colleagues as part of both large and small departmental discussions; 3) feedback was repeated one year later; 4 ) a consensus conference created guidelines for test ordering;" and 5) a patient record sample was reviewed for compliance with the laboratory test order. A total of 37% of a test sample ordered at baseline by physicians with "extreme" administration patterns was classified as inappropriate. The intervention resulted in a reduction of 1.8 tests per patient (P = 0.0005). Eight of the nine tests individually showed reductions in use. Pay data from the destination hospital showed a statistically significant decrease in laboratory fees per patient in the quarter after program start (P = 0.02) and no evidence for change in a group of five comparison hospitals. There was no evidence of a reduction in the ranking of the baseline tests. These results demonstrate a cost-effective approach to reducing unnecessary costs that can be implemented in hospitals with integrated data systems.

title: survey of tobacco-related knowledge, attitudes, and behaviors of primary care providers in Mississippi.
abstract: RATIONALE: Compared to other regions in the USA, the prevalence of tobacco use and tobacco-related disease is high in Mississippi. This study evaluated tobacco-related knowledge, attitudes, and intervention behaviors of family physicians, dentists, and nurses in the state of Mississippi. METHODS: The Provider Attitude Questionnaire, an 85-item measure of tobacco-related knowledge, attitudes, and intervention behaviors, was mailed to all members of Mississippi's Family Medicine, Dentistry, and Nursing professional organizations (N=2043). RESULTS: More than one-third of eligible providers (n=802, 39.2%) responded. Only 24.3% had received training in tobacco cessation and 33.7% were aware of the Public Health Service clinical practice guidelines. More than 90% said their role was to prevent tobacco use"; they felt rewarded for helping patients quit;" and was disturbed and upset by the health effects of tobacco. Doctors helped more patients than nurses or dentists. Doctors and nurses reported greater self-efficacy, motivation, and readiness to treat tobacco use than dentists. Providers who received training performed more interventions and reported greater self-efficacy, preparedness, and fewer barriers than those who did not. Education was associated with greater increases in self-efficacy, preparedness and intervention behaviors for dentists than for other groups. CONCLUSIONS: Despite the high prevalence of tobacco use and tobacco-related diseases in Mississippi, primary healthcare providers in Mississippi provide unacceptably low frequency of tobacco cessation interventions compared to other regions. Education is likely to increase the frequency of intervention behaviors.

title: sustainable strategy to prevent misuse of antibiotics for acute respiratory infections
abstract: More than 50% of past antibiotic prescriptions are for outpatients with acute respiratory tract infection (ARI). Many are not needed and thus contribute to both preventable adverse events and pressures to develop bacterial resistance. Can an intervening clinical decision support system (CDSS) during electronic prescribing adjust antibiotic use according to consensus treatment guidelines for ARI? Methods This is a retrospective comparison of the pre-intervention (2002) and post-intervention (2003-2006) periods in two comprehensive health systems (intervention and control). The intervention was a CDSS targeting fluoroquinolone and azithromycin"; other antibiotics remained unrestricted. 7000 outpatient visits marked by an ARI case finding algorithm were reviewed for compliance with guidelines (antibiotic prescribed or not prescribed when warranted or not prescribed) Results 3831 patients met the case definitions for one or more ARI: pneumonia (537), bronchitis (2931), sinusitis (717), and nonspecific ARI (145) All patients with pneumonia were given antibiotics. ) rate of compliant prescribing, intervention for antibiotics targeted by CDSS region was 2.57 (95% CI?=?(1.865 to 3,540);" concordance was unchanged for other antibiotics (adjusted RR?=?1.18 (95%) CI=?(0.691 to 2.011))) Proportion of non-guaranteed prescriptions of targeted antibiotics decreased from 22% to 3% before and after intervention (p<0.0001). An intervening CDSS was added during the results e-. Antibiotics targeted for ARI during four years of misuse have almost run out of prescriptions. This intervention highlights the path to sustainable antibiotic management for outpatients with ARI.

title: systematic qualitative analysis of psychoeducational interventions for depression in cancer patients.
abstract: OBJECTIVES/OBJECTIVES: To determine whether research-based recommendations can be made on the clinical management of depression in patients with cancer. DATA SOURCES: Reports of scientific studies, qualitative or quantitative systematic reviews of scientific studies, and practice guidelines published between 1980-2000. DATA SYNTHESIS: A total of 36 pieces of evidence supported the conclusion that psychoeducational interventions benefit depressive symptoms. Evidence included two well-conducted meta-analyses and nine well-designed randomized clinical trials with large samples (N > 100). Regarding intervention content, 70% of behavioral therapy studies and 66% of counseling studies produced results supporting the hypothesis. Additionally, 58% of studies that tested behavior therapy or counseling along with cancer education yielded positive results. CONCLUSIONS: Evidence supports the conclusion that psychoeducational interventions reduce depressive symptoms in cancer patients and that behavioral therapy or counseling, alone or in combination with cancer education, is beneficial. APPLICATIONS FOR NURSING PRACTICE: Nurses can choose from a variety of educational, behavioral and counseling techniques to prevent or manage depression in their patients.

title: systematic review of clinical decision support systems for antimicrobial management: Are we failing to research these interventions appropriately?
abstract: OBJECTIVES: Clinical decision support systems (CDSS) for antimicrobial management can support clinicians in optimizing antimicrobial therapy. We reviewed all of the original literature (qualitative and quantitative) to understand the current scope of CDSS for antimicrobial management and to analyze current methods used to evaluate and report such systems. METHOD: PRISMA instructions were followed. Medline, EMBASE, HMIC Health and Management, and Global Health databases were searched between January 1, 1980 and October 31, 2015. All primary research studies describing CDSS for antimicrobial management in adults in primary or secondary care were included. Thematic synthesis was made for qualitative research. Quality was assessed using the Integrated quality Criteria for Review of Multiple Study Designs (ICROMS) criteria. CDSS reporting was evaluated against a reporting framework for behavior change intervention implementation. RESULTS: 58 original articles describing 38 independent CDSSs were included. The majority of systems target antimicrobial prescribing (29/38%; 76%), are platforms integrated with electronic medical records (28/38%; 74%), and have a rules-based infrastructure that provides decision support (29/38;"76%). In the assessment made against the response reporting framework, CDSS studies do not report consideration of the non-specialist, end-user workflow. They have a narrow focus, such as antimicrobial selection, and use surrogate outcome measures. Participation by clinicians with CDSS was poor. CONCLUSION: When designing CDSS interventions, more consideration should be given to factors that drive non-expert decision making. Future work should aim to go beyond selecting appropriate antimicrobials with clear and systematic reporting frameworks for CDSS interventions developed to address current gaps identified in reporting evidence.

title: systematic review of computer-based patient registry systems and quality of care: more randomized clinical trials or a broader approach?
abstract: OBJECTIVE: To analyze the impact of computer-based patient record systems (CBPRS) on medical practice, quality of care, and user and patient satisfaction. DATA SOURCES: Manual and electronic search of Medline, Cochrane and Embase databases. STUDY SELECTION: Selected articles published from 2000 to March 2003. CBPRS was defined as computer software designed for use by clinicians as a direct aid in clinical decision making. To be included, systems must record patient characteristics and provide online advice or specific information or reminders to clinicians during consultation. DATA DRAWING: The keywords used for the search were: electronic record, informatics record, electronic medical record, electronic patient record, patient order entry, computer-based patient system, clinical decision support systems, and evaluation. RESULTS: Twenty-six articles were selected. The use of CBPRS was perceived positively by physicians, and satisfaction studies were mostly positive. In all three studies examining this criterion, the positive effect of CBPRS on preventive care was observed. Twelve studies evaluating the impact on medical practice and compliance with guidelines have shown that positive experiences are as frequent as experiences with no benefit. Of the six studies that analyzed the effect of CBPRS on patient outcomes, none reported any benefit. RESULTS: CBPRS has increased user and patient satisfaction, which can lead to significant improvements in medical care practice. However, studies of the impact of CBPRS on patient outcomes and quality of care are inconclusive. Alternative approaches that take into account social, cultural and organizational factors may be needed to evaluate the usefulness of CBRS.

title: systematic review of education on HIV/AIDS prevention among older adults.
abstract: Through an extensive literature review, the authors of this systematic review identified 21 articles focusing on primary prevention of HIV/AIDS for adults aged 50 and over. Three major challenges in providing HIV/AIDS education to older adults include age discrimination by health professionals, older adults' reluctance to discuss sexuality, and misunderstanding of HIV risks. Clinical guidelines for social workers, nurses, and physicians have defined the importance of designing creative delivery strategies, sharing information, and assessing risk, taking into account cultural diversity. The three models of HIV/AIDS education include group education programs delivered by social workers or other health professionals, peer education models, and one-on-one early intervention models, including HIV/AIDS testing. Additional outreach and research are needed on HIV/AIDS prevention among older adults.

title: systematic review of faculty development initiatives designed to increase teaching effectiveness in medical education: BEME Guide No. 8
abstract: BACKGROUND: Preparing health professionals for teaching is considered essential to increase teaching effectiveness. Although many reports describe a variety of faculty development interventions, there is little research demonstrating their effectiveness. OBJECTIVE: "What are the effects of faculty development interventions on teachers' knowledge, attitudes and skills in medical education, and on the institutions they work for?" Synthesize the available evidence that answers the question. METHODS: The research covering the period 1980-2002 included three databases (Medline, ERIC, and EMBASE) and used the keywords: "personnel development"; in-service training; medical school; faculty training/development; continuing medical education. Manual searches were also performed. Revised articles focusing on faculty development to increase teaching effectiveness aimed at basic and clinical scientists. All study designs that included outcome data beyond participant satisfaction were accepted. 53 articles from the first 2777 abstracts met review criteria. Data were six coders using the standard BEME coding sheet adapted for our use. Two reviewers coded each study, and coding differences were resolved through discussion. Data were synthesized using Kirkpatrick's four levels of educational outcomes. Findings were grouped by type of intervention and defined by level of outcome. In addition, 8 high-quality studies were 'focused'. picture' moment was analyzed. CONCLUSIONS: Most of the interventions were aimed at practicing clinicians. All of the reports focused on improving teaching and interventions included workshops, seminar series, short courses, longitudinal programs and 'other interventions'. Study designs included 6 randomized controlled trials and 47 quasi-experimental studies, of which 31 used a pretest-posttest design. KEY POINTS: Despite methodological limitations, the faculty development literature tends to support the following conclusions: Overall satisfaction with faculty development programs was high. Participants consistently found the programs acceptable, useful, and relevant. Participants reported positive changes in attitudes towards faculty development and teaching. Participants reported increased knowledge of educational principles and gains in teaching skills. Where formal tests of knowledge have been used, significant gains have been demonstrated. Changes in teaching behavior were consistently reported by participants and were also detected by students. Changes in organizational practice and student learning were often not explored. However, reported changes included greater educational participation and the establishment of university networks. Key features of effective faculty development that contribute to effectiveness include the use of experiential learning, providing feedback, effective peer and peer relationships, well-designed interventions that follow teaching and learning principles, and the use of a variety of educational methods within a single intervention. Methodological issues: More rigorous designs and greater use of qualitative and mixed methods are required to capture the complexity of interventions. Newer performance-based assessment methods using different data sources should be explored and reliable and valid outcome measures developed. Maintaining change over time should also be considered, as should process-oriented studies comparing different faculty development strategies. CONCLUSIONS: Faculty development activities seem highly valued by participants who also report changes in learning and behavior. Despite the methodological limitations in the literature, certain program features appear to be consistently associated with effectiveness. More research is needed to explore these relationships at the individual and institutional level and document the results.

title: specific intervention to implement guideline recommendations for elderly patients with depression in primary care: a pragmatic cluster randomized trial.
abstract: Background Elderly patients with depression are underdiagnosed, undertreated and at high risk of a chronic course. General practitioners follow clinical practice guidelines to a limited extent. In the Special Practice for Chronic Diseases International research project, we tested the effectiveness of specific interventions to improve the care of patients with chronic diseases. In Norway, we examined this approach to improve adherence to six guidelines for older patients with depression, targeting healthcare professionals, patients, and administrators. Methods We conducted a cluster randomized trial in 80 Norwegian municipalities. We identified implementation determinants for the six recommendations and then made tailored interventions to address these determinants. Interventions targeted health professionals, administrators, and patients and consisted of outreach visits, a website offering advice and underlying evidence, tools for managing depression in the elderly, and other web-based resources, including a continuing medical education course for general practitioners. The primary outcome was average adherence to recommendations. Secondary outcomes were improvement in depression symptoms as measured by patients and GPs. We offered outreach visits to all GPs and practice staff in the response municipalities. We used electronic software that extracts eligible patients from lists of general practitioners. We collected data by interviewing general practitioners or by sending a questionnaire to the four patients on their list about their practice and sending a questionnaire to the patients. Results One hundred and twenty-four (14%) of 900 GPs participated in data collection, 51 in the intervention group, and 73 in the control group. We interviewed 77 GPs, 47 GPs completed the questionnaire and 134 patients answered the questionnaire. Among GPs providing data, adherence to recommendations was 1.6 percentage points higher in the intervention group than in the control group (95% CI -6 to 9). Conclusions The effectiveness of our specific intervention to implement recommendations for elderly patients with depression in primary care is uncertain due to the low response rate in data collection. However, the effect is unlikely to be large. It remains unclear how best to improve adherence to evidence-based recommendations and thus improve the quality of care for these patients. Trial registration at ClinicalTrials.gov: NCT01913236.

title: Teachable Moment Communication Process for a smoking cessation speech: a description of a group of randomized clinician-focused interventions.
abstract: BACKGROUND: Effective clinician-patient communication about health behavior change is one of the most important and most overlooked strategies for promoting health and preventing disease. Existing guidelines for specific health behavior counseling have been established and published, but have not been successfully adopted in primary care practice. Building on studies focused on establishing effective clinician strategies to promote health behavior change in primary care, we developed an intervention aimed at improving clinician communication skills to create and act upon teachable moments for smoking cessation. In this article, we describe the key features of a group of randomized trials designed to evaluate the development and implementation and effectiveness of the Teachable Moment Communication Process (TMCP) intervention. METHODS/DESIGN: This randomized group trial included thirty-one community-based primary care clinicians working in Northeast Ohio and 840 of their adult patients. Clinicians were randomly assigned to receive either the Teachable Moments Communication Process (TMCP) intervention for smoking cessation or the delayed intervention. The TMCP intervention consisted of two, 3-hour training sessions that included a didactic presentation, skill demonstration via video examples, skills practices with standard patients, and feedback from peers and instructors. For each registered clinician, 12 patients were recruited for the two time points. Pre- and post-intervention data were collected from clinicians, patients, and audio-recorded clinician-patient interactions. At baseline, the two clinician groups and their patients were similar in all demographics and practice characteristics studied. Both physician and patient recruitment targets were met and retention was 96% and 94%, respectively. DISCUSSION: Findings support the feasibility of training clinicians to use the Teachable Moments Communication Process. The next steps are to evaluate how well clinicians use these skills in their practice and the impact on patient outcomes. TRIAL REGISTRATION: ClinicalTrials.gov Identifier: NCT01575886.

title: telephone coaching intervention to improve asthma self-management behaviors
abstract: Long aware that asthma, one of the most common chronic childhood diseases, is difficult to manage, the National Asthma Education Prevention Program has developed clinical practice guidelines to assist healthcare providers, especially those in primary care. However, maintenance asthma care still does not meet national standards. Therefore, a new nurse telephone coaching intervention was tested in a randomized controlled trial to improve and support asthma self-management behaviors for parents of children aged 5 to 12 years with persistent asthma. A detailed description of the intervention is provided, along with parent satisfaction outcomes, an overview of the training used to prepare nurses, and a discussion of the challenges experienced and lessons learned.

title: International theory of bioethics: debatable and non-negotiable
abstract: previous article in this issue of the Kennedy Institute of Ethics Journal presents the argument that the position that international bioethics rests on "fundamental" or "fundamental" moral principles universally accepted in all ages and cultures collapses under "moral fundamentalism." various multicultural and postmodern critiques. This article looks at the contractual tradition of Hobbes and Locke - as reinterpreted by David Gauthier, Robert Nozick and John Rawls - as an alternative rationale for international bioethics. Drawing on the main themes of this tradition, it is argued that international bioethics can be rationally restructured as a negotiated moral order that respects cultural and individually defined areas of inconsistency. Moreover, a negotiated theory of moral order is consistent with traditional ideals of human rights, flexible enough to absorb genuine understandings of multiculturalism and postmodernism, and yet powerful enough to justify cross-cultural and trans-temporal moral judgments, including condemnation of the Nazi. Doctors in Nuremberg. This theory is also consistent with the history of the ethics of human subject experimentation and offers insights into current controversies, such as the debate over changing the consent rule for experimentation in emergency medicine and the exclusion of inexpensive treatments from certain clinical trials to prevent perinatal disease. Contamination of AIDS from the ethical standards of the sponsoring country.

title: theory-based educational intervention targeting nurses' attitudes and knowledge regarding cancer-related pain management: a study protocol of a quasi-experimental design.
abstract: OBJECTIVE: Pain is one of the most common problems in patients diagnosed with cancer. Despite the availability of effective pharmacological treatments, this group of patients often receive less than optimal treatment. Research on nurses' pain management highlights certain factors as common barriers to effective pain management, such as lack of knowledge and attitude and inadequate procedures for systematic pain assessment. However, educational interventions targeting nurses' pain management have shown promise. Further development of knowledge in this area is warranted, as cancer-related pain is known to have a negative impact on vital aspects of a patient's life and is also commonly associated with problems such as sleep, fatigue, depression, and anxiety. METHODS/DESIGN: A quasi-experimental study design will be used to explore whether the application of guidelines for systematic daily pain assessments following a theory-based educational intervention would result in an improvement in knowledge and attitude among nurses. Another aim is to investigate whether an intervention targeting nurses' behaviors will improve the pain perception of hospitalized patients. Data on nurses' knowledge and attitudes towards pain (primary outcome), patient perception of pain (secondary outcome), along with socio-demographic variables, will be collected at baseline and at four and 12 weeks following the intervention. DISCUSSION: Nursing care is recognized as an increasingly complex activity today, and "the complexity of nursing is such that it can be seen as an intrinsically complex intervention." Changing and improving clinical practice requires multiple points of attack suited to tackling complex challenges. In conclusion, we anticipate that the theory-based intervention used in our quasi-experimental study will improve care and quality of life for this patient group, as well as that evidence-based guidelines targeting the pain of this patient group will be more widely implemented. TRIAL REGISTRATION NUMBER: ClinicalTrials.gov NCT01313234.

title: Tool for Evaluating a Community's Substance Abuse Care Capacity
abstract: Evidence-based programs for substance abuse prevention and intervention are increasing. Community needs assessments and health rankings provide definitions of local behavioral health needs, but do not provide guidance to public health practitioners and policy makers on the number of programs, health care practitioners, or interventions needed in the local substance abuse care system. This article provides a new framework for measuring and evaluating the substance abuse care system in a community. Evaluation can inform resource allocation across the continuum of care to distribute interventions and care more equitably and efficiently. We conducted 2 literature searches and synthesized our findings to create a community assessment methodology and needs calculator, CAST (computation for an adequate system tool). We reviewed 212 articles to generate an inventory of the community and social correlates of behavioral health, the components of a substance abuse care system, and the numeric values for guidelines for estimating community needs. CAST produces community-specific assessments of the capacity of the components of a community substance abuse care system. CAST generates recommendations by applying social and societal determinants of health as risk coefficients to each component need estimate. CAST can assist public health practitioners in assessing and developing the capacity of community-based, substance abuse care systems. By using recommendations for component needs across the continuum of care, community leaders can use CAST to more effectively and efficiently prioritize resource allocation.

title: Sardjito and PKU Hospital, a universal precautionary education intervention for healthcare workers in Indonesia
abstract: non-randomized control trial was conducted to develop and evaluate a culturally appropriate academic elaboration intervention on universal precautions knowledge, attitude, and behavior of healthcare workers in hospitals. 55 healthcare professionals (44 nurses and 11 doctors) participated in the study. They were visited individually to discuss the principles of universal precautions as well as the impact of autopilot on business practices. Self-reported measures of knowledge and attitude were collected from each participant before and after the intervention. A nurse observer collected participants' measures of compliance with the universal precautions guidelines before and after the intervention according to a predetermined protocol. There was a significantly different level of knowledge, attitude and compliance with regard to universal precautions between the control and intervention hospital, with p=0.0007, p=0.038 and p=0.03, respectively, after the intervention. It was concluded that the academic elaboration training approach used in this study significantly improved knowledge, attitude and compliance scores.

title: Trial of AA cluster randomized decision support strategies to reduce antibiotic use in acute bronchitis
abstract: Background National quality indicators show little change in the overuse of antibiotics for uncomplicated acute bronchitis. We compared the impact of 2 decision support strategies on antibiotic treatment of uncomplicated acute bronchitis. Methods We conducted a 3-arm randomized trial among 33 primary care practices of an integrated healthcare system in central Pennsylvania. Printed decision support intervention sites (11 apps) received decision support for acute cough sickness through a print-based strategy, computer-assisted decision support intervention sites (11 apps) received decision support through an electronic medical record-based strategy, and control zones (11 apps) received a served as the control arm. Both intervention sites received feedback on clinician education and prescribing practices at check-in, as well as patient education brochures. Antibiotic prescription rates for uncomplicated acute bronchitis during the winter period following intervention initiation (October 1, 2009 to March 31, 2010) were compared with the previous 3 winter periods in a therapeutic analysis. Results Percentage of adolescents and adults prescribed antibiotics during the intervention period compared to baseline on print decision support intervention sites (80.0% to 68.3%) and computer-assisted decision support intervention sites (74.0% to 68%) 0.3) 60.7%, but slightly increased in control areas (from 72.5% to 74.3%). After controlling for patient and clinician characteristics, as well as clustering of observations by clinician and practice site, differences for intervention regions were statistically significant from control regions (P = .003 and P = .01 computer-assisted decision support intervention sites versus control regions versus printed decision support intervention sites. sites) but not among themselves (P = .67 for computer-assisted decision support intervention sites versus printed decision support intervention sites). Changes in total visits, 30-day revisit rates, and rate of diagnosed uncomplicated acute bronchitis were similar across study sites. Conclusions Implementing a decision support strategy for acute bronchitis can help reduce the overuse of antibiotics in primary care. The impact of print and computer-assisted decision support strategies for providing decision support was equivalent.

title: Adult personality and behavior abnormalities (section F 6) -- Results of the ICD-10 field trial
abstract: Personality disorders, the most important category of the F6 section, were examined in the ICD-10 field study. Overall Kappa values for the inter-interpretive reliability of the F6 section were 0.64, 0.61 for personality disorders, and 0.73 for dyssocial personality. These results are very close to the results of the DSM-III field trials. Subjective assessments of feasibility, suitability, and goodness of fit indicate good acceptance of diagnostic guidelines by clinicians. Comparison of ICD-9, DSM-III, and ICD-10 diagnoses provided broad agreement for personality disorders diagnoses, with overlapping Kappa values of 0.91 and 0.94. The acceptance and reliability of the new classification can be enhanced by a series of improvements and the planned introduction of a multi-axis system.

title: Academic details have no impact on asthma medication prescribing in Danish general practice: a 3-year randomized controlled trial with 12-month follow-up.
abstract: BACKGROUND: Educational outreach visits, especially when combined with social marketing, appear to be a promising approach to health professionals' behavior, particularly prescribing. Results from previous studies have shown a variable effect. OBJECTIVE: The aim of the study is to examine the effect of academic elaboration as a clinical guideline application method in general practice. METHODS: A cluster of randomized, controlled, blinded studies was conducted comparing the effect of an academic detail visit to the mailing distribution of a guideline for asthma medication prescribing. Half of the practices in a Danish county of 100 practices were visited once. The outcome measure was data routinely collected from all Danish pharmacies on the sale of asthma medications. Data were collected monthly 2 years before and 1 year after intervention. RESULTS: There was no effect on the way asthma medications were prescribed after the visit, neither immediately nor in the long term. CONCLUSION: We found no effect of academic elaboration as a single intervention.

title: Access to medical records for medical audit purposes
accident prevention
Accuracy of Rapid and Point-of-Care Screening Tests for Hepatitis C
Achieving change in primary care – reasons for the evidence for the practice gap: systematic reviews of reviews
abstract: Background This study is to identify, summarize and synthesize the literature on the reasons for the evidence for the practice gap for complex interventions in primary care. Design This study is a systematic review of reviews. Methods MEDLINE, EMBASE, CINAHL, Cochrane Library, and PsychINFO were searched from baseline to December 2013. Appropriate reviews addressed the reasons for the evidence for the practice gap in primary care in developed countries. Data from the included reviews were extracted and synthesized using guidelines for meta-synthesis. Results Seventy reviews met the inclusion criteria and covered a wide range of topics, eg guideline implementation, integration of new roles, technology implementation, public health and preventive medicine. None of the included articles used the term Â¡Â°whyÂ¡Â± or made any clear intention to investigate reasons. A descriptive approach was often used, and the articles included expressed Â¡Â°reasonsÂ¡Â± Â¡Â°obstacles and practical facilitatorsÂ¡Â±. We developed a four-level framework covering the external context, organisation, professionals and intervention. External contextual factors included policies, incentive structures, dominant paradigms, stakeholder engagement, advances in infrastructure and technology. Organizational factors include culture, available resources, integration with existing processes, relationships, skill mix and staff involvement. At the level of individual professionals, professional role, basic philosophy of care and competencies were important. Characteristics of the intervention that impacted implementation included evidence of benefit, ease of use, and adaptability to local conditions. We assume that the ¡Â°fitÂ¡Â± between intervention and context is critical in determining the success of the implementation. Conclusions This comprehensive review review summarizes the available information on barriers and facilitators to the implementation of various complex interventions in primary care. To maximize the uptake of complex interventions in primary care, healthcare professionals and commissioning agencies must consider the spectrum of contextual factors, while remaining aware of the dynamic nature of the context. Future work should place emphasis on defining the context and expressing the relationships among the factors described here.

title: Reaching guidelines for the treatment of depression in primary care: is physician training sufficient?
abstract: OBJECTIVES: The authors examine whether physician education has lasting effects on the treatment of depression. METHODS: Depressed primary care patients who started antidepressant treatment from primary care clinics of a staff model health care institution were studied. Quasi-experimental and pre-post comparisons of physician practices supported by patient questionnaires were used to compare caregiving and depression outcomes. The intervention consisted of extensive physician training spanning 12 months. This includes case-by-case consultations, didactics, academic elaboration (for example, clearly articulating educational and behavioral goals to each physician), and role-playing of optimal treatment. The main outcome measures were divided into two groups. Quasi-experimental examples included: (1) choice of antidepressant medication and (2) adequacy (dose and duration) of pharmacotherapy. Survey samples included: (3) follow-up intensity"; (4) physician provided educational messages on depression treatment; (5) patient satisfaction;" and (6) depression outcomes. RESULTS: No sustained training effect was consistently observed in any of the measured outcomes. CONCLUSIONS: There was no lasting improvement in depression treatment for primary care patients. However, depression treatment guidelines were obtained concurrently for intervention patients enrolled in a well-rounded collaborative care program during the training period. These results suggest that, in addition to physician education, ongoing programs of reorganized service delivery programs to support the role of the primary care physician (e.g., onsite mental health personnel, close monitoring of patient progress and compliance) are essential for the success of physician education. guide app.

title: Smoking Cessation Action in Suspected Tuberculosis (ASSIST) in Pakistan
abstract: Background: Tobacco use is responsible for most of the total disease burden from tuberculosis. Pakistan is one of the 10 countries with a high burden of both tuberculosis and tobacco use. Objective: To evaluate the efficacy of a behavioral support intervention and bupropion in achieving 6 months of continuous abstinence in adult smokers with suspected pulmonary tuberculosis. Design: Cluster randomized controlled trial. (Available Controlled Trials: ISRCTN08829879) Setting: Health centers in Jhang and Sargodha districts, Pakistan. Patients: 1955 adult smokers with suspected tuberculosis. Intervention: Health centers were randomly assigned to provide 2 short behavioral support sessions (BSS), BSS plus 7 weeks of bupropion therapy (BSS+), or usual care. Measurements: The primary endpoint was sustained abstinence 6 months after the quit date and was determined by carbon monoxide levels in patients. Secondary endpoints were point absence at 1 and 6 months. Results: Both treatments resulted in statistically significant relative risks (RRs) for abstinence compared with usual care (RR for BSS+, 8.2 [95% CI, 3.7 to 18.2]";" BSS for RR, 7.4 [CI, 3.4] to 16.4]). Equivalence between treatments could not be established. 275 of 606 patients in the BSS+ group (45.4% [CI, 41.4% to 49.4%]), 254 of 620 patients in the BSS group (41.0% [CI, 37.1% to 45.0%]), and 52 of 52 patients achieved sustained abstinence. it did. 615 (8.5% [CI, 6.4% to 10.9%]) in the usual care group. There was significant heterogeneity of program effects among clusters. Limitations: Imbalances in urban and rural rates, and inability to confirm smoking habits and adherence to bupropion therapy among treatment groups, and the inability to confirm longer-term abstinence or the effect of smoking cessation on tuberculosis outcomes. Conclusion: Behavioral support alone or in combination with bupropion is effective in quitting smokers with suspected tuberculosis. Primary Funding Source: International Development Research Center.

title: Acute viral hepatitis B becomes exacerbated after infection with the hepatitis A virus.
Acute coronary syndromes without ST segment elevation. From randomized clinical trials to consensus guidelines to clinical practice in Italy: the need to close the circle
abstract: Recent therapeutic advances in the treatment of acute ischemic heart disease have been proven in randomized clinical trials and endorsed by official practice guidelines. This rigorous approach has led to a significant reduction in mortality and morbidity across the spectrum of acute coronary syndromes (ACS). However, contemporary registries of non-ST-elevation ACS established by the cardiology community in Italy as well as the rest of Europe and the Americas have shown only limited compliance with the general indication to treat high-risk patients at an early age. Invasive approach, protected by the use of glycoprotein IIb/IIIa receptor blockers. This partial failure in the process of improving patient care can be attributed to various reasons, such as suspicion that practice guidelines may be biased due to conflicts of interest, concerns about the real-world applicability of clinical research results, and unrealistic expectations about treatment. effects and, finally, logistical and economic barriers, including the availability of laboratories and the high cost of platelet receptor blockers. While practice guidelines provide cultural support for translating clinical trial outcomes into patient care, and national and local cardiology associations can help raise awareness of the true benefits of early aggressive management in high-risk patients, healthcare administrators must remove bureaucratic barriers and resources from unproven treatments. to those clearly shown to reduce mortality and risk of re-infarction in their patients.

title: Acute fatty liver of pregnancy and diagnosis by computed tomography
abstract: A 39-year-old woman was admitted to the maternity unit at 34 weeks of gestation with complaints of nausea, vomiting and jaundice. His condition worsened and he was transported to the hospital, deeply unconscious and hypotensive. A diagnosis of acute fatty liver of pregnancy was suggested at baseline with a history of typical prodromal malaise and vomiting, and deep hypoglycemia and rapid-onset hepatic encephalopathy with only minor increases in transaminase activities. Computed tomography was performed: there was no liver or spleen enlargement, but the attenuation value on the liver showed significant fatty infiltration in the liver, making the diagnosis of acute fatty liver of pregnancy. Computed tomography is valuable in the diagnosis of liver disease in late pregnancy and this technique may become the method of choice for the investigation of acute fatty liver of pregnancy.

title: Adding evidence-based interventions to assertive community treatment: a feasibility study
abstract: OBJECTIVE: This 24-month study conducted in the Netherlands examined the feasibility of increasing the efficacy of assertive community therapy (ACT) by adding evidence-based interventions. METHODS: A total of 159 patients were randomly assigned to two ACT teams, one providing standard ACT (N585) and an ACT Plus team (N574) providing evidence-based interventions: psychoeducation, family interventions, individual placement and support, and cognitive behavioral therapy. Interventions were conducted by psychologists and nurse practitioners working independently of the ACT team. RESULTS: Only 12 (16%) of 74 patients successfully completed an intervention, although most patients were considered eligible for each of the four interventions (range 65% to 89%). Outcomes such as inpatient care use for ACT Plus and standard ACT patients did not differ significantly. CONCLUSIONS: Guidelines for the treatment of schizophrenia should consider the feasibility of providing evidence-based interventions to difficult-to-access patients.

title: Adding exercise or subtracting sitting time for glycemic control: where do we stand?
abstract: While regular structured exercise is a well-established (albeit arguably underused) cornerstone in the prevention and management of type 2 diabetes, population adherence to recommended exercise guidelines remains stubbornly low. In fact, most adults are exposed to environmental conditions (at work, driving, and at home) that not only limit their physical activity but also encourage prolonged sitting. However, recent experimental evidence suggests that reducing sitting time and taking a break may also be a useful strategy for improving glycemic control. In this issue of Diabetologia, Duvivier and colleagues report findings that suggest that reducing sitting time with standing and light-intensity activity may be a potential alternative to structured exercise to improve glycemic control in patients with type 2 diabetes. We review and discuss the findings of this study, its potential clinical implications, and a number of knowledge gaps and opportunities that could be exploited for the benefit of future research. Duvivier and colleagues' findings should encourage health practitioners, researchers, and type 2 diabetes patients to consider the full spectrum of physical activity, from sedentary behavior to structured exercise.

title: Adding motivational interventions to exercise and traditional physiotherapy: a review and meta-analysis
abstract: BACKGROUND: Undisputed epidemiological trends indicate that an increase in chronic lifestyle-related diseases will dominate mortality and morbidity in the foreseeable future. International guidelines recommend applying evidence-based approaches to drive health behavior changes. Motivational interventions to increase fitness and physical activity are by no means part of traditional physiotherapy. OBJECTIVE: To evaluate the evidence for the effectiveness of adding motivational interventions to traditional physiotherapy to increase physical activity and short- and long-term adherence to exercise prescriptions. DATA SOURCES: Literature search of PubMed, EMBASE, Scopus, CINAHL, PsychINFO, AMED and Allied Health Evidence database using keywords and topics. STUDY SELECTION: Only randomized controlled trials comparing two or more arms, focusing on motivational interventions affecting one arm exercise, and a control arm, were included. The search identified 493 titles, of which 14 studies (consisting of 1504 participants) were included. DATA DRAWING: The principal investigator extracted data that was independently reviewed by another author. Methodological quality was assessed independently by two authors using the Cochrane Risk of Bias tool and the PEDro scale. Outcomes were measured at the level of impairment, activity limitation, and participation restriction. The standardized mean difference between control and intervention groups at follow-up time points was used as the mode of analysis. I2</=50% was used as the cut-off point for acceptable heterogeneity, above which the random effects model was applied. RESULTS: Exercise attendance was measured in six studies (n=378) and results show no significant difference in exercise participation between groups (Random-effects model, standardized mean difference 0.33, 95% confidence interval -0.03 to 0.68, I2 62%). Perceived self-efficacy results were pooled from six studies (n=722) and a significant difference was found between groups in favor of interventions (Fixed effects model, standardized mean difference 0.71, 95% confidence interval 0.55 to 0.87, I2 41 %) . Results for activity limitation levels were pooled (n=550) and a significant difference was found between groups in favor of interventions (REM, standardized mean difference -0.37, 95% confidence interval -0.65 to -0.08, I( 2) 61%). LIMITATIONS: Most of the included studies were of moderate quality and four studies were of low quality. Data were collected from a wide variety of different populations and environments, increasing the diversity of study characteristics. CONCLUSIONS: Motivational interventions can help exercise adherence, have a positive effect on long-term exercise behavior, increase self-efficacy, and reduce activity restriction levels. Although all interventions show benefits, the optimal choice of theory and the most beneficial length and type of intervention have not been defined. There is a need to determine how physiotherapists are currently optimizing compliance and their current level of knowledge about motivational interventions. IMPLEMENTATIONS OF KEY FINDINGS: Results show that motivational interventions are successful for promoting healthy physical activity behavior. Physiotherapists are ideally positioned to take on this role, and motivational interventions should become part of physiotherapy practice.

title: Addressing nicotine addiction in women. The role of the midwife
abstract: Smoking is the leading preventable cause of cancer, cardiovascular disease and other premature death among women in the United States. Tobacco use accounts for 10% of perinatal mortality and is 100% preventable. Smoking is now more common in adolescent girls than boys. Women's health care providers are in an excellent position to respond to this growing epidemic. This article discusses the health consequences of smoking, as well as the social, economic and emotional effects of smoking on women and their families. The reasons why women start and continue smoking despite the known risks are investigated. The role of the midwife in the treatment of lifelong nicotine addiction in women was examined. A theoretical model based on the woman's stage of change is presented as a framework for intervention. Behavioral and pharmacological treatment recommendations are included. Opportunities are provided for professional activities for community education and advocacy for a tobacco-free society.

title: Adherence to NICE guidelines on diabetes prevention in the UK: impact on patient knowledge and perceived risk
abstract: BACKGROUND: NICE Guidelines for diabetes prevention include identification of people at risk followed by cost-effective intervention if needed. Based on risk assessment through a questionnaire and/or blood test, intervention may include a brief discussion of risk factors and a referral to preventive advice or intensive lifestyle intervention. DESIGN AND ENVIRONMENT: In this cross-sectional study, 59 subjects recruited from local GP practices were invited by letter to participate in a screening for diabetes prevention study. METHODS: After a telephone screening in which subjects were asked whether they were informed whether they were at high risk for type 2 diabetes, eligible subjects completed the Risk Perception Questionnaire for Developing Diabetes (RPS-DD), an approved diabetes risk score, and oral in a medical screening. Glucose tolerance test (OGTT) was performed. RESULTS: As measured by the Diabetes UK Risk Score, 44.1% were at high risk, 42.4% at moderate risk and 13.6% at high risk. 42% of patients were informed by a healthcare professional that they were at high risk. Those who were informed about their risks had significantly higher perceived risk scores (p<0.001), higher knowledge scores (p<0.001) and lower optimism scores (p=0.004), but they were not aware of the diet (p=0.42). and weight management (p=0.57) may play a role in diabetes prevention. CONCLUSIONS: Persons at high risk of diabetes are not informed about their risk status as recommended in NICE guidelines. There is a space for education for health workers and the public.

title: adolescent birth control
abstract: PIP: Many adolescents in the United States are at risk of an unplanned pregnancy despite advances in birth control technology and the increasing availability of birth control methods. Physicians dealing with adolescents should be familiar with the various contraceptive measures and their suitability for adolescents. A healthcare professional should also be prepared to participate in sex education and to individually counsel or refer adolescent patients when sexual problems arise. In this discussion of adolescent contraception, attention is directed to the following: reasons for not using contraception, postcoital contraception, oral contraception (contraindications, side effects, adolescent guidelines and the mini-pill (progestogen only), IUDs, diaphragms, vaginal chemical contraceptives, condoms, withdrawal or rhythm, intervention techniques, and choice of appropriate method The average adolescent experiences unprotected sex for a year or more before requesting contraception. Current evidence shows that more teenagers today are using contraception than ever before. some of them cannot use a method for various reasons. Most of the reasons reflect lack of knowledge; some reflect inaccessibility. Reasons include not knowing their fertility periods, belief that their age is protective, infrequent or unexpected sexual intercourse. The idea of being prepared for the possibility of sexual intercourse The strong feelings of guilt that the relationship evokes. Many adolescents are hesitant to seek contraceptive advice or prescriptions from private doctors for fear of moralizing and being denied their wishes. There is evidence in at least 1 study that the presence of a family planning clinic in the school is effective in reducing pregnancy rates and maintaining high attendance rates after 36 months of follow-up. Intervention techniques that can be effective include offering a highly motivated method immediately after an event (abortion, childbirth, rape) and tailoring the method to the person's lifestyle and preference. If there are no contraindications, the preferred method and a method suitable for the frequency of sexual intercourse should be given to the young person. A backup method should also be provided if the preferred method is not tolerated or has never been initiated. Frequent follow-up is essential to maximize attendance rates.

title: Adolescent overweight and obesity - how best to manage in a general practice setting
abstract: OBJECTIVE: The prevalence of overweight and obesity in adolescents continues to increase. Community level management is required as specialist services are limited. OBJECTIVE: This article outlines a management plan for overweight adolescents in general practice using a chronic care approach and follows the National Health and Medical Research Council Clinical practice guidelines for the management of overweight and obesity in children and adolescents. CONCLUSION: Overweight and obesity do not resolve spontaneously during adolescence and active intervention is required both to improve current health and well-being and to reduce the risks of early morbidity and mortality in adult life. Modest, cumulative changes in lifestyle along with modest weight loss goals are important to reduce the risk of weight rebound. Any intervention must take into account the rapid cognitive and behavioral changes of adolescence.

title: Adolescent violence prevention practices among California pediatricians
abstract: OBJECTIVE: To examine pediatricians' provision of violence prevention services for adolescent patients and to identify factors related to pediatricians' implementation of these services. DESIGN: A cross-sectional sample of California pediatricians completed a self-report questionnaire. The "Pre/Advanced" theoretical model guided the survey in identifying factors associated with pediatricians' implementation of screening and interventions to prevent adolescent violence. RESULTS: Two hundred and twenty pediatricians (54% female, 66% white, 24% Asian, 5% Latino, and 5% other) participated in the study. On average, participants screened patients for risk factors for violence related to fighting in 31%, violence at home in 39%, and carrying a gun in 29%. Participants provided their at-risk patients with violence-related interventions less than 50% of the time (on average) by performing the following interventions: written materials, follow-up appointments, disciplinary counseling or referral to a community agency, Child Protective Services, or a specialized adolescent clinic. Factors associated with violence prevention screening practices included: Positive attitudes and beliefs about violence screening, familiarity with violence prevention guidelines, use of prompts in medical records, greater perception of skills, and positive support from patients and colleagues to provide violence prevention services (R(2)=0.44 "; P<.001. Factors associated with violence prevention intervention practices included: positive attitudes and beliefs about violence screening, availability of resources, and positive support from patients and colleagues to provide violence prevention services ( R(2)=0.37;" P<. .001). CONCLUSIONS: California pediatricians do not extensively screen adolescent patients for risk factors associated with adolescent violence and do not provide interventions for adolescent patients who may be at risk of violence. Factors associated with pediatricians' implementation of violence prevention services can assist in the development of effective interventions designed to improve their delivery of these services to their adolescent patients.

title: Adoption, attainment, implementation and maintenance of behavioral and mental health assessment in primary care
abstract: OBJECTIVE: Guidelines recommend screening patients for unhealthy behaviors and mental health problems. Health risk assessments can systematically identify patient needs and trigger care. This study aims to evaluate whether primary care practices can routinely apply such assessments to routine care. METHODS: As part of the randomized clustering study, 9 different primary care practices implemented My Own Health Report (MOHR) – an electronic or paper-based health behavior and mental health assessment and feedback system paired with counseling and goal setting. We observed how apps integrate MOHR into their workflow, how much additional practice staff time they require, and what percentage of patients complete a MOHR assessment (Access). RESULTS: Most upcoming applications (60%) agreed to adopt MOHR. How they implemented the MOHR depended on their practice resources, computing capacity, and patient characteristics. Three apps sent invitations to patients to complete MOHR on the Web, 1 called patients and completed MOHR over the phone, 1 patient completed MOHR in the office on paper, and 4 staff members helped patients complete MOHR on the Web in the office. Overall, 3,591 patients were reached and 1,782 completed the MOHR (Reach = 49.6%). Reach varied according to the strategy of implementing the MOHR with higher reach when completed by staff than patients (71.2% vs. 30.2%, P < .001). No application was able to sustain the complete MOHR assessment without adaptations after study completion. Fielding MOHR increased staff and clinician time by an average of 28 minutes per visit. CONCLUSIONS: Primary care practices can implement health behavior and mental health assessments, but counseling patients effectively requires effort. Apps will need more support to implement and maintain assessments.

title: Adult education program in palliative care for nursing facility doctors: design and pilot testing
abstract: Nursing facilities (NF) are important places for the care of dying patients. There is a need for curricula that are likely to improve end-of-life care for NF physicians. To this end, an exemplary medical school palliative care curriculum was modified for experienced NF physicians. Adult learning techniques and interactions likely to change physician behavior are emphasized. Included were opinion leader involvement, monitoring with feedback, use of consensus guidelines, and other techniques for changing physician behavior. Written materials to support the course were determined. This new program has been pilot tested and developed. Initial supervision of physician practices and survey of UF staff, a half-day adult education session, and follow-up with the NF medical director are recommended. This intervention should be tested to determine whether it improves patient end-of-life care outcomes in this setting.

title: Adult respiratory distress syndrome
Developing the literature on designing supervisory and feedback interventions: identifying theory-based hypotheses
abstract: Background Check and feedback (A&F) is a common strategy to help healthcare providers put evidence into practice. Despite being studied extensively, healthcare A&F interventions remain variablely effective, with overall effect sizes not improving since 2003. Contributing to this stagnation is that most healthcare A&F interventions are largely designed from a behavioral perspective without being informed by theoretical understanding. and social sciences. To determine whether the trend could be improved, the aim of this study was to develop a list of testable, theory-informed hypotheses about how to design more effective A&F interventions. Methods Using purposive sampling, semi-structured 60-90 minute telephone interviews were conducted with experts in A&F-related theories from various fields (eg cognitive, health and organizational psychology, medical decision making, economics). Guided by detailed descriptions of A&F interventions from the healthcare literature, the interviewees described how they would approach the problem of designing improved A&F interventions. From the interviews, specific hypotheses with theory knowledge about the conditions for the effective design and delivery of A&F interventions were elicited. The resulting hypotheses were assigned to themes and theme categories in an iterative process by three independently working coders. Results We conducted 28 interviews and identified 313 theory-informed hypotheses embedded in 30 themes. The 30 themes included hypotheses about the following five categories: A&F recipient (seven themes), A&F content (ten themes), A&F's delivery process (six themes), A&F's focus on behavior (three themes). ) and other (four themes). Results We identified a set of testable, theory-informed hypotheses from a wide variety of behavioral and social sciences that suggest conditions for more effective A&F interventions. This study illustrates the breadth of perspectives on A&F from non-healthcare-specific disciplines, generating testable hypotheses for health A&F interventions. These results will serve as the basis for further work to identify research priorities among the A&F research community.

title: Advancing Patient Safety Science
abstract: Despite a decade of effort, patient safety has gradually improved, partly due to the limited evidence base for the development and widespread dissemination of successful patient safety practices. The Agency for Health Research and Quality sponsored an international group of experts in patient safety and evaluation methods to develop criteria to improve the design, evaluation and reporting of patient safety practice research.
