This article reports on the findings and recommendations of this group, including greater use of theory and logic models, more detailed descriptions of interventions and their implementation, better explanation of desired and undesirable outcomes, and better definition and measurement of context and how context affects it. interventions. Using these criteria and measuring and reporting contexts will advance the science of patient safety.

title: Advantages and Challenges of Village Doctor-Based Cognitive Behavioral Therapy for Late Life Depression in Rural China: A Qualitative Study
abstract: BACKGROUND: The provision of mental health services in rural China has been particularly limited due to a lack of qualified mental health professionals, among other disabling factors. Cognitive behavioral therapy intervention based on a village doctor may be one way to improve accessibility. The aim of this study was to explore the advantages and challenges of implementing this intervention given by trained village doctors to treat advanced age depression in rural China. METHODS: We conducted a focus group meeting with 10 village physicians, 10 individual interviews with each village doctor, and individual interviews with 19 elderly adults. The topic guides were the advantages and challenges of the intervention program from the perspective of village doctors and older adults. The interviews were audio-recorded, transcribed, coded using NVivo 8, and analyzed using thematic analysis. RESULTS: Village doctors emphasized the importance of role-playing in education and the use of didactic guides. Appropriate supervision was also an important component of the program. The benefits from the intervention for the village doctors and the elderly were positive, such that both doctors and the elderly were willing to implement/receive this intervention. Cultural and political factors (addiction and perceived policy assessment) facilitated older people's access to mental health services. Challenges included the lack of real therapy (as opposed to role playing) demonstrated in the training and the lack of a step-by-step guide based on the different types of problems encountered. Other obstacles to the successful implementation of the intervention included the time constraints of the village doctors and the presence of other people in carrying out the intervention. CONCLUSIONS: This study showed that the intervention program can be an acceptable geriatric depression intervention in rural China, if the various challenges are addressed appropriately.

title: Counseling for Patients Seeking Complementary and Alternative Medical Treatments for Cancer
abstract: Many patients with cancer use complementary and alternative medical (CAM) therapies. Physicians need authoritative information about CAM therapies to responsibly advise patients seeking these interventions. This article summarizes the available evidence on the efficacy and safety of selected CAM therapies commonly used by cancer patients. The following main categories of interventions are covered: dietary modification and supplementation, herbal products and other biological agents, acupuncture, massage, exercise and psychological and mind and body therapies. Two categories of evidence for efficacy are considered: possible effects on disease progression and survival, and possible palliative effects. When evaluating the evidence for safety, two types of risks are considered: the risk of direct side effects and the risk of interaction with conventional treatments. For each therapy, the balance of available evidence for efficacy and safety depends on whether the therapy is reasonably recommended, accepted (e.g., reduction of dietary fat in patients with well-nourished breast or prostate cancer) or discouraged (e.g., high-dose vitamin A supplementation). . This strategy allows for the development of an approach to provide responsible, evidence-based, patient-centered advice to people with cancer seeking CAM treatments.

title: Alcohol consumption and addiction in elderly patients in an urban society
Alcohol: prevention, policy and primary care interventions
abstract: BACKGROUND: Alcohol is "Australia's most socially acceptable legal drug"; however, alcohol-related harms have increased significantly over time. Promoting safer alcohol consumption should be a national health priority and a key focus for health practitioners. PURPOSE: This The purpose of the document is to discuss some of the reasons alcohol is such a popular and valuable commodity in Australia, as well as some of the common problems alcohol causes. We outline the most effective policy and treatment approaches to reduce alcohol consumption and the associated harms. Discussion: Research evidence, alcohol shows that the most effective policies to reduce alcohol consumption and related harms are those that focus on restricting the availability and accessibility of alcohol, however, such strategies are often not implemented or implemented for political and economic reasons. Screening and brief intervention, addressing problematic alcohol consumption in primary care These are effective ways of coping and can be further supported by promoting socially organized periods of abstinence.

title: Alcohol-related and non-alcoholic activity participation and enjoyment among college students: A behavioral theory of choice analysis.
abstract: Alcohol abuse by college students remains a major public health problem, and there is a need for theory-based and empirically-based models to guide prevention efforts. Behavioral choice theories assume that the decision to consume alcohol is influenced by the relative value of alcohol relative to other available activities. In this study, a sample of college student drinkers (N=108"; "56% female, 44% male) who had previously completed a mandatory alcohol intervention completed a measure of alcohol-related and non-alcoholic activity participation and pleasure. The aims of the study were to examine the effect of drinking amount and contextual variables on enjoyment from the activity, and to identify enjoyable non-alcoholic activities that take place in the evenings that students might otherwise be drinking. Overall, students found alcohol-related activities more enjoyable than non-alcoholic activities, and the amount of drinking was positively associated with enjoyment. But non-alcoholic activities such as watching movies, going to theaters or museums, going to bars or parties, hanging out with friends, dining at restaurants, and engaging in creative activities were often just as enjoyable as drinking. Non-alcoholic activities involving peers or dates were more fun than solo activities. Men were less likely to participate in non-alcoholic activities involving their peers and reported that they enjoyed non-alcoholic activities less than women. More research is needed to identify procedures for increasing participation in non-alcoholic activities and to determine whether increased participation in non-alcoholic activities reduces alcohol consumption. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2016 APA, all rights reserved)

title: Everything you need to read in other general magazines
abstract: Between 1998 and 2009, a single surgeon in France reconstructed the genitals of 2,938 women who had been mutilated or cut off when they were girls. One of the largest case series ever suggests that surgery may help at least some women with a history of female genital mutilation achieve a pain-free, acceptable sex life. Most of the women were from French-speaking West Africa, but more than 564 had undergone FGM while growing up in France. Almost all of them sought surgery to restore their female identity and autonomy above all else. All four-fifths were looking for a better sex life. All had undergone female genital mutilation, which removed or damaged the clitoris, at an average age of 6 years. One of the goals of the surgery was to reconstruct a normal clitoris. More than three-quarters (78% (2053/2613)) of women presenting for surgery had never had an orgasm. Only 866 women (29%) returned to follow-up one year after surgery. About half (414/840) reported improvement in pain. Slightly less improvement in sexual pleasure (385/834) was reported and 430 have now had orgasms. We don't know how they feel about their bodies after surgery, and future studies should include measures of validated identity, satisfaction with surgery, and global satisfaction with sex, says a linked comment (doi:10.1016/S0140)-6736(12)60636-9). Lancet2012";"doi:10.1016/S0140-6736(12)60813-7 Citicoline is currently licensed as a neuroprotector for adults with acute stroke in some countries. Animal models suggest it may protect neurons that survive near infarction and even improve repair. However, trial results in humans have been mixed and, most recently, no difference in improvement was found between citicoline-treated subjects and placebo-treated controls (odds ratio for global improvement 1.03, 95% CI 0.86 to 1.25). Treatment started within â€¦

title: Alliance not alignment: coaching strategies to improve type 2 diabetes outcomes
abstract: OBJECTIVE: To investigate strategies to improve patient outcomes in type 2 diabetes. DATA SOURCES: Literature on type 2 diabetes management, behavior change, communication, diabetes self-management, and coaching. CONCLUSIONS: Strategies currently recommended to improve patient outcomes, such as increasing provider adherence to evidence-based management guidelines, streamlining delivery systems, and promoting patient lifestyle changes through intensive education, have produced mixed results. Among the many complexities involved in managing type 2 diabetes, motivating patients to change their behavior may be the most difficult. One recommendation to improve self-management of type 2 diabetes patients is to use coaching communication in the context of behavior change in the context of the primary care encounter between nurse practitioners (NPs) and their patients. APPLICATIONS TO PRACTICE: Given the diverse implications of current strategies, coaching by NPs may provide a viable alternative to improve patient outcomes in type 2 diabetes. Coaching communication can be implemented as a free intervention during office visits. However, in order to apply this approach effectively, more formal training in applying NPs and this expected but underdeveloped NP role competence of NP students is required. NPs are asked to contribute the knowledge needed to validate the merits of coaching for their patients.

title: Alprazolam prescribing in Tasmania: a two-fold intervention designed to reduce inappropriate prescribing and concomitant opioid prescribing
abstract: OBJECTIVE: The population rate of alprazolam prescribing in Tasmania has been more than double the national rates. Serious adverse events have been observed through co-administration of opioid drugs with alprazolam. To reduce the inappropriate prescribing of alprazolam and thus reduce adverse outcomes, a two-fold intervention was designed that included family practice education and changes to prescribing regulations. The purpose of this study was to evaluate the effect of the intervention on prescribing rates. METHODS: We measured the number of alprazolam prescriptions for the year before and after the intervention. Health Insurance Commission data were used and compared with national data to enable comparisons of subsidized prescription rates for alprazolam in Tasmania. Participants were registered medical practitioners in Tasmania who were potentially prescribing alprazolam. Interventions were three GP Education Meetings in June 2007, one in each of the major Tasmania regions on evidence-based interventions for panic disorder. Changes to regulatory procedures were implemented in September 2007 to minimize the co-prescription of alprazolam with opioids. CONCLUSIONS: A reduction in alprazolam prescribing occurred in Tasmania after interventions. CONCLUSION: Education can be an effective strategy for influencing physicians' prescribing behavior. This impact is likely to increase with the adoption of stricter regulatory requirements.

title: Alternative Perspectives on the Biased Foundations of Medical Technology Evaluation
abstract: Medical technology assessment aims to improve the care of individual patients (traditional clinical practice unit) through assessment studies conducted in patient groups (traditional clinical research unit). and clinical applicability of technology evaluation studies. We identify several biased viewpoints about technology assessment that stem from the distinction between individuals and groups: a misguided emphasis on effectiveness versus effectiveness, statistical significance versus clinical significance, and objective versus subjective outcomes. In each case, we compare these alternative perspectives and speculate on their implications for health care policy.

title: American Society of Clinical Endocrinologists and American College of Endocrinology Comprehensive Clinical Practice Guidelines for the Medical Care of Obesity Patients
abstract: OBJECTIVE: The development of these guidelines is mandated by the American Association of Clinical Endocrinologists (AACE) Board of Directors and the American College of Endocrinology (ACE) Board of Trustees and is dependent on published AACE protocols for the production of standard clinical practice guidelines (CPGs). . METHODS: Recommendations are based on a rigorous review of clinical evidence with transparent inclusion of subjective factors. RESULTS: 160 specific expressions (85 [53.1%] strong [Grade A]";" 48 [30.0%] moderate [Grade B] and 11 [6.9%] weak [ 16 [10.0%] constituting a comprehensive medical care plan for obesity) Grade C] with [Class D]) based on expert opinion. There were 133 (83.1%) statements based on strong (best level of evidence [BEL] 1 = 79 [49.4%]) or moderate (BEL 2 = 54 [33.7%]) scientific evidence. There were 34 (23.6%) evidence-based grades of recommendation (AC Grade = 144) adjusted for subjective factors. Of the 1,790 reference citations used in this CPG, 524 (29.3%) were based on strong (level of evidence [EL] 1), 605 (33.8%) moderate (EL 2), and 308 (17.2%). weak (EL 3) based on scientific studies, 353 (19.7%) reviews and opinions (EL 4). CONCLUSION: Recent recommendations recognize obesity as a complex, adiposity-based chronic disease in which management targets both weight-related complications and obesity to improve overall health and quality of life. Detailed evidence-based recommendations allow for nuanced clinical decision making that addresses the real-world medical care of patients with obesity, including screening, diagnosis, evaluation, treatment selection, treatment goals, and individualization of care. The aim is to facilitate high-quality care of patients with obesity and to provide a rational, scientific approach to management that optimizes health outcomes and safety. title: American Cancer Society Colorectal Cancer Recovery Care Guidelines
abstract: Colorectal cancer (CRC) is the third most common cancer and third leading cause of cancer death in both men and women in the United States (USA) and the second leading cause of cancer deaths in men and women combined. Almost two-thirds of CRC survivors live 5 years after diagnosis. Given the recent decline in both incidence and mortality, the prevalence of CRC survivors is likely to increase dramatically in the coming decades with the increase in CRC screening rates, further advances in early detection and treatment, and the aging and growth of the US population. Survivors are at risk for a CRC recurrence, a new primary CRC, other cancers, as well as both short-term and long-term adverse effects of CRC and the methods used to treat it. CRC survivors may also have psychological, reproductive, genetic, social, and employment concerns after treatment. Communication and coordination of care between the treating oncologist and primary care clinician is critical to effectively and efficiently manage the long-term care of CRC survivors. The guidelines in this article are intended to assist primary care clinicians in providing risk-based healthcare to CRC survivors who have completed active therapy.

title: American College of Physicians Ethics Manual
abstract: Medicine, law, social values are not static. Re-examining the ethical principles of medicine and their application in new conditions is a necessary exercise. The sixth edition of the American College of Physicians (ACP) Handbook of Ethics covers emerging issues in medical ethics and reviews old issues that are still very relevant. It reflects many of the ethical tensions in medicine and seeks to shed light on how existing principles extend to emerging concerns. In addition, the Guidelines can help physicians prevent future problems by reiterating ethical principles that provide guidance in resolving past ethical problems. The guide is not a substitute for the experience and integrity of individual physicians, but can serve as a reminder of the common duties of the medical profession.

title: American Medical Society for Sports Medicine position statement: concussion in sports
abstract: UNLABELED: PURPOSE OF REPORT: black triangle right To provide a summary of evidence-based, best practices to assist physicians in the evaluation and management of sports concussion. black triangle right To identify level of evidence, knowledge gaps, and areas requiring additional research. IMPORTANCE OF AMSSM NOTICE: right black triangle Sports physicians are often involved in the care of patients with sports concussion. black triangle right Sports medicine physicians are specially trained to provide care throughout the continuum of sports concussion, from acute injury to return-to-play (RTP) decisions. black triangle right Athletes with sports concussion are ideally cared for by healthcare professionals with specific training and experience in the assessment and management of concussion. Competence should be determined by education and experience, not expertise. black triangle right This phrase is intended for sports medicine physicians, but may also assist other physicians and healthcare professionals in the care of patients with sports concussion. DEFINITION: right black triangle Concussion is defined as a traumatically induced transient impairment of brain function and involves a complex pathophysiological process. Concussion is a subset of mild traumatic brain injury (MTBI), which is usually self-limited and is on the less severe end of the brain injury spectrum. PATHOPHYSIOLOGY: right black triangle Animal and human studies support the concept of post-concussion vulnerability by showing that a second blow worsens metabolic changes within the cell before the brain recovers. black triangle on the right Experimental evidence suggests that the concussed brain is less responsive to the usual neural activation and may be vulnerable to long-term dysfunction when early cognitive or physical activity occurs before full recovery. INCIDENCE: black triangle right It is estimated that as many as 3.8 million concussions occur in the United States each year during competitive sports and recreational activities; however, as many as 50% of concussions may go unreported. black triangle right Concussions have the highest incidence in football, hockey, occurs in all sports, which is rugby, football and basketball RISK FACTORS FOR SPORTS RELATED ATTACK: black triangle right History of a concussion is associated with a higher risk of having another concussion black triangle right Greater number, severity, and duration of symptoms after a concussion, are predictors of a long-term recovery. black triangle right In sports with similar rules of play, the reported incidence of concussions is higher in female athletes than in male athletes. black triangle right Some sports, positions, and individual styles of play carry a greater risk of concussions. black triangle right Young athletes more can have a long-term recovery and result in a catastrophic injury is more prone to a concussion that accompanies it. black triangle right Pre-injury mood disorders, learning disorders, attention deficit disorders (ADD/ADHD), and migraine headaches complicate the diagnosis and treatment of a concussion. EPIDEMIC DIAGNOSIS: right black triangle Concussion remains a clinical diagnosis ideally made by a healthcare provider who knows the athlete and is knowledgeable in recognizing and assessing concussion. black triangle right Graded symptom checklists provide an objective tool for assessing the various symptoms associated with concussions while also tracking the severity of these symptoms through serial assessments. black triangle right Standard assessment tools provide a useful framework for assessing concussion, although limited validation of these assessment tools is available. SIDE EVALUATION AND MANAGEMENT: black triangle right Any athlete suspected of having a concussion should be stopped from playing and evaluated by a licensed healthcare provider trained in the assessment and management of concussions. black triangle right Recognition and initial assessment of a concussion should be guided by a symptom checklist, cognitive assessment (including orientation, past and recent memory, new learning, and concentration), balance tests, and advanced neurological physical examination. black triangle right While standardized sideline tests are a useful framework for review, the sensitivity, specificity, validity, and reliability of these tests across different age groups, cultural groups, and settings remain largely undefined. The practical benefits, with or without an individual initial test, are also largely unknown. black triangle right Balance impairment is a specific indicator of a concussion, but it is not very sensitive. The sideline balance test may differ significantly from the baseline tests due to differences in shoe/came type or surface, use of ankle bands or braces, or the presence of other lower extremity injuries. black triangle right Imaging is reserved for athletes with suspected intracerebral hemorrhage. black triangle right For an athlete diagnosed with a concussion, there is no same-day RTP. black triangle right Athletes who are suspected or diagnosed with a concussion should be monitored for worsening physical or mental condition. NEUROPSYCHOLOGICAL TEST: right black triangle Neuropsychological (NP) tests are an objective measure of brain-behavior relationships and are more sensitive to subtle cognitive impairment than clinical examination. black triangle right Most concussions can be properly managed without the use of NP testing. Black triangle right Computerized neuropsychological (CNP) testing should be interpreted by healthcare professionals trained and familiar with the test type and individual test limitations, including an informed assessment of the reliable index of change, baseline variability, and false positive and false negative rates. . black triangle right Paper and pencil NP tests can be more comprehensive, testing different areas and evaluating other conditions that may mask concussion or complicate concussion assessment. The black triangle right NP test should only be used as part of a comprehensive concussion management strategy and should not be used alone. The ideal timing, frequency, and type of black triangle right NP testing have not been determined. black triangle right In some cases, appropriately administered and interpreted NP testing provides an added value for assessing cognitive function and recovery in the management of sports concussions. black triangle right It is not known whether the use of the NP test in the management of sports concussion helps prevent repetitive concussion, catastrophic injury, or long-term complications. right black triangle Comprehensive NP assessment aids in the post-concussion management of athletes with persistent symptoms or complex courses. BACK TO CLASS: black triangle right Students will need cognitive rest and may need academic adjustments such as less workload and longer time for tests when recovering from a concussion. BACK TO PLAYING: black triangle right Concussion symptoms must be resolved before returning to exercise. black triangle right An RTP progression involves a gradual, gradual increase in physical demands, sport-specific activities, and contact risk. black triangle right If symptoms occur with activity, progress should be stopped and restarted in the previous symptom-free step. black triangle right RTP should only be performed after a concussion with medical clearance from a licensed healthcare provider trained in the evaluation and management of concussions. SHORT-TERM RISKS OF EARLY RTP: right black triangle The primary concern with Early RTP is that it shortens reaction time, resulting in an increased risk of re-concussion or other injury and prolongation of symptoms. LONG-TERM EFFECTS: black triangle right There is a growing concern that exposure to head impact and repetitive concussions contribute to long-term neurological sequelae. black triangle right Some research has suggested an association between prior concussions and chronic cognitive dysfunction. Large-scale epidemiological studies are needed to more clearly define the risk factors and causes of any long-term neurological disorder. DISQUALIFICATION FROM SPORTS: black triangle right There are no evidence-based guidelines for disqualifying/retiring an athlete from a sport after a concussion. Each case should be carefully discussed and an individualized approach should be taken to determine disqualification. EDUCATION: right black triangle More efforts are needed to educate interested parties, including athletes, parents, coaches, authorities, school administrators and healthcare providers, to improve the recognition, management and prevention of concussion. black triangle right Doctors should be prepared to provide counseling about the possible long-term consequences of a concussion and recurrent concussions. PREVENTION: right black triangle The primary prevention of some injuries may be possible through change and enforcement of rules and fair play. black triangle right Both hard (soccer, lacrosse, and hockey) and soft (soccer, rugby) helmets are best suited to prevent impact injuries (fractures, bleeding, lacerations, etc.), but have not been shown to reduce the incidence and severity. shake. black triangle right There is no current evidence that mouth guards can reduce or prevent the severity of concussions. black triangle right Secondary prevention may be possible with proper RTP management. LEGISLATION: black triangle right Legislation efforts provide a uniform standard for scholastic and non-scholastic sports organizations regarding concussion safety and management. FUTURE INSTRUCTIONS: black triangle right Additional research is needed to validate current assessment tools, delineate the role of NP testing, and improve identification of those at risk for prolonged post-concussion symptoms or other long-term complications. black triangle right Newer neuroimaging techniques or emerging technologies such as biomarkers for diagnosing concussion may provide new insights into the assessment and management of sports concussion.

title: Americans want to dilute the Declaration of Helsinki
An academic elaboration intervention to popularize physician-administered smoking cessation counseling: smoking cessation outcomes of the Physicians Counseling Smokers Project.
abstract: BACKGROUND: Little is known about the effectiveness of interventions to promote smoking cessation interventions among a population of primary care physicians. The aim of this study was to determine the effect of a population-based academic elaboration intervention on quit rates in a population-based sample of smokers. METHODS: This population-based, quasi-experimental study included representative samples of 259 primary care physicians and 4295 adult smokers. Academic elaboration intervention was administered to physicians in intervention areas over a 15-month period. Analyzes were performed on data from 2346 subjects who reported at least one doctor visit over 24 months. Multivariate regression analyzes were performed to determine the effect of intervention on self-reported smoking cessation rates and reported with adjusted odds ratios. RESULTS: Among smokers who reported a doctor visit during the study period, there was a borderline significant effect for residents in intervention areas compared to control areas (OR = 1.35"; 95% CI.99-1.83; P = 0.057). Of 819 smokers, we observed a significant effect for residents of intervention areas (OR = 1.80; 95% CI 1.16-2.75; "P = 0.008). CONCLUSION: A detailed academic intervention to improve physician-provided smoking cessation counseling is an effective strategy to popularize smoking cessation interventions among community-based practices.

title: An administrative intervention to improve the use of laboratory tests in a university hospital
abstract: BACKGROUND: Improving the relevance of test behavior and reducing the number of laboratory tests have been recognized as essential parts of quality improvement. OBJECTIVE: To evaluate the effectiveness of an administrative and short-term educational intervention aimed at reducing clinical biochemistry laboratory use. DESIGN: An analysis comparing the use of laboratory tests performed in hospitalized patients before and after intervention. SETTING: Computerized database of all laboratory tests performed at the Hadassah Ein Kerem Medical Center in Jerusalem, Israel between 1999-2003. INTERVENTION: Administrative response included limiting the frequency of available emergency laboratory tests and repeat orders. Educational measures included: discussing the misuse and consequences of laboratory tests with hospital medical staff and presenting the new restrictive policy. A feedback on the results of the intervention was sent to the wards and reviewed with senior medical staff. MAIN OUTCOME MEASURES: Change in use of hospital department and selected laboratory tests and clinical biochemistry tests (measured as rates per 100 hospital days). RESULTS: An overall reduction of 19% (95% CI: 18.8-19.2%) in laboratory testing was observed in the year post-intervention. Usage decreased significantly in the range of 14.9-43.8% across all medical departments of the hospital. During the intervention period, use of hematology tests decreased by 7.6% (P = 0.009). Statistically significant reductions were noted in the ranking of all 12 selected clinical biochemistry tests. Although total cholesterol orders decreased by 72.2%, the use of 'high volume' tests such as glucose and electrolytes decreased only modestly (7.9% and 6.9%, respectively). RESULTS: This study included all hospital health personnel and included all clinical biochemistry tests available. This fairly simple and cost-effective intervention resulted in significant reductions in clinical chemistry test orders as well as ordering of hematological blood tests.

title: An assessment of user acceptance and satisfaction with tobacco cessation automated clinical practice guidance
abstract: OBJECTIVE: To explain user acceptance and satisfaction of the Henry Ford Health System Tobacco Cessation (TUC) Automated Clinical Practice Guideline (ACPG). STUDY DESIGN: A previous study evaluated compliance with the 5 As of TUC ACPG (ask, advise, evaluate, assist and regulate) in 3 study arms. This article explains user satisfaction with TUC ACPG after implementation. METHODS: In all study arms, providers completed a questionnaire before participating in a focus group. RESULTS: All providers in the TUC arm stated that they "almost always" asked their patients about tobacco use. Providers in the TUC arm were generally satisfied with the features of the TUC ACPG, particularly the ease with which a patient was electronically referred to the Smoking Intervention Program. Barriers to use included time constraints, lack of staff, and the willingness to "exit" the program for patients in certain circumstances (for example, terminally ill patients). CONCLUSION: Because ACPGs are included in electronic medical records, it is important to obtain provider input prior to administration, to provide technology that is user-friendly and fits the clinic's workflow, and to give physicians the autonomy to opt out of the guideline. in certain clinical situations.

title: An automatic minimum retest interval reject rule reduces repetitive CRP workload and expense and influences clinician request behavior
abstract: Objectives Repeated measurements of serum C-reactive protein (CRP) on the same day or on consecutive days have limited clinical value. Minimum retest intervals are recommended to manage unnecessary retests. As not previously reported, we examined the impact of minimum retest interval test refusal on laboratory workload and expenditure and on clinician requesting behavior. Methods In a prospective study, we evaluated the impact of an automated 48-hour CRP minimum retest interval rule on inpatient and outpatient CRP workload and costs. Control data on inpatient and outpatient serum urea and electrolytes (UE) workload were collected during the study. Results Over 1 year, after the minimum retest interval rule was introduced, there was a 7.0% and 12.3% reduction in CRP requests and analyzed CRP tests, respectively, compared to the 1-year baseline period. This equated to an estimated annual reduction in revenue costs of £10500, but a cash savings of £3000 in consumables costs. There was no significant change in UE requests. Conclusions We report for the first time that automated minimum retest interval rejection rules as a standalone strategy are an inexpensive and sustainable method to reduce unnecessary repetitive CRP testing, resulting in small laboratory cash savings, more efficient use of laboratory resources, and standardization. The Minimum retest interval rejection rule of patient care pathways also changed the clinician's test requesting behavior towards more appropriate requesting.

title: An educational program influencing healthcare professionals in recommending exercise to their type 2 diabetes patients - understanding the processes: a case study from Oxfordshire, England
abstract: BACKGROUND: Increased levels of physical activity reduce the risk of premature death associated with chronic diseases such as coronary heart disease, type 2 diabetes, stroke. Despite this, most adults in the UK do not follow physical activity guidelines. Physical activity advice and signage offered to at-risk patients by primary care providers are recommended. However, training in exercise medicine is scarce, leading to insufficient knowledge of practitioners of the evidence for risk reduction and strategies for implementing effective patient behavior change. The 'Generation Games' intervention aims to increase physical activity in Oxfordshire's 50+ population. It offers a Health Professional Education Program (HPEP) that provides exercise medicine education and the introduction of Generation Games where healthcare professionals can guide patients. There is a weak evidence base on how such education translates into patient exercise behavior change. METHODS: The research aimed to generate greater understanding of how an education program could influence healthcare professionals to recommend the Generation Games and increase exercise behavior in people with type 2 diabetes. A case study method facilitated the review of routines and cultures studied - Diabetes nurses' experience was used as an example of best practice engagement with HPEP. Observation, interview and documentation were used to triangulate the data. Data analysis refined and developed themes within key theoretical frameworks. CONCLUSIONS: First, there is a lack of knowledge about the risk reduction benefits of physical activity and a belief that efforts to motivate patients to increase their physical activity are ineffective and thus create barriers to participation in HPEP. Second, nurses tasked with providing lifestyle advice to people with diabetes – who themselves lack motivational interviewing skills – find ingrained physical activity behaviors extremely difficult and therefore highly value HPEP for providing helpful tools. Third, patients who hear about Generation Games from a healthcare professional may have maladaptive expectations about how their exercise behavior might change. CONCLUSION: Exercise medicine education has the potential to improve patient care and services. For interventions like HPEP to be successful, primary care practices require a more supportive exercise medicine culture. Adequate resources are also required for patient-centered behavior change advice, education, promotion and monitoring services.

title: An educational approach to improving outcomes in acute kidney injury (AKI): report of a quality improvement project
abstract: OBJECTIVE: To evaluate the impact of a quality improvement project using a multifaceted educational intervention on how to improve the clinician's knowledge, confidence and awareness of acute kidney injury (AKI). SETTING: 2 large acute teaching hospitals in England serving a combined population of over 1.5 million. PARTICIPANTS: All secondary care clinicians working in clinical areas were targeted, with a particular focus on clinicians working in acute admissions areas. INTERVENTIONS: A versatile educational intervention consisting of traditional didactic lectures, case-based teaching in small groups, and an interactive web-based learning resource. OUTCOME MEASURES: We assessed clinicians' knowledge of AKI and self-reported clinical behavior using an interactive questionnaire before and after the educational intervention. Secondary outcome measures included clinical review of patient notes before and after intervention. RESULTS: 26% of clinicians reported that they were aware of local AKI guidelines in the pre-intervention questionnaire, compared to 64% in the follow-up questionnaire (chi&sup2";=60.2, p<0.001). Improved number of clinicians when diagnosing AKI 50% against 68% (chi²=12.1, p<0.001) and 48% versus 64% (chi²"=9.5, p=0.002) when investigating patients with AKI. Those who performed clinical audits showed a trend towards better clinical practice. RESULTS: Utilizing a multifaceted educational intervention, this quality improvement project has increased clinician awareness of AKI, as evidenced by changes in self-reported management of patients with AKI. Project elements have been sustained beyond the project duration and demonstrate the power of quality improvement projects to help initiate changes in practice. Our findings are limited by confounding factors and highlight the need to conduct formal randomized trials to determine the impact of educational interventions in the clinical setting.

title: An educational intervention reduces the rate of inappropriate echocardiograms in an inpatient service
abstract: OBJECTIVES: This study aimed to prospectively examine the impact of an appropriate use criteria (AUC)-based educational intervention on transthoracic echocardiography (TTE) order among home staff in an inpatient general internal medicine ward at an academic medical center. BACKGROUND: The AUC for TTE was developed in response to concerns about inappropriate use of TTE. To date, AUC-based educational interventions to reduce inappropriate use of TTE have not been prospectively studied. METHODS: A prospective, time-series analysis of an educational intervention was performed and then compared to TTE ordering in the same medical service during a control period. The intervention consisted of: 1) a conference to staff on the 2011 AUC for TTE"; 2) a pocket card applying the AUC to common clinical scenarios;" and 3) bi-weekly email feedback on ordering behavior. TTE rank was tracked daily throughout the response period and feedback reports were emailed at 2-week intervals. The primary outcome was the rate of unsuitable and favorable TTE ordered during the intervention period. RESULTS: 99% and 98% of all TTEs ordered during the control and study periods, respectively, could be classified using the 2011 AUC. During the study period, there was a 26% reduction in the number of TTEs ordered per day compared to the number ordered in the control period (2.9 vs. 3.9 TTE, p < 0.001). During the study period, the rate of inappropriate TTE was significantly lower (13% vs. 5%, p < 0.001) and the rate of appropriate TTE was significantly higher (84% vs. 93%, p < 0.001). RESULTS: A simple educational intervention resulted in a significant reduction in the rate of inappropriate TTE and increased the rate of appropriate TTE ordered in an inpatient academic medical service. This study provides a practical approach to use AUC to reduce the number of unsuitable TTEs. Further work is guaranteed in other application environments.

title: Efficacy trial of cognitive behavior therapy in a representative sample of outpatients with psychosis
abstract: OBJECTIVES: The efficacy of cognitive behavioral therapies (CBTp) for psychosis is sufficiently established to be included in some national treatment guidelines. However, treatment efficacy does not warrant efficacy in routine practice, where clinician expertise and patient mix may differ. Therefore, we evaluated the feasibility, acceptability, and efficacy of CBTp when offered routinely in a public mental health service. DESIGN: A prospectively selected representative sample (N=94) of patients with psychotic disorders from a geographic collection area in Melbourne, Australia were randomized to CBTp or treatment as usual. METHODS: The CBTp intervention included psychoeducation, positive symptom, and comorbid problem components. Therapists jointly negotiated goals with patients and used treatment components from a guideline. Therapeutic analyzes used data at baseline, 9 months, and 18 months. RESULTS: Measures of working alliance and customer satisfaction demonstrated excellent acceptability. Both groups improved to a similar degree on the Positive and Negative Syndrome Scales, with no advantage for the CBTp group. The most common CBTp components administered were comorbid disorders/personal problems and personalized psychoeducation"; working with ongoing symptoms was the main focus in relatively few sessions. RESULTS: The reason for the lack of advantage of the CBTp group could be due to: on positive symptoms (most recurring outcome domain for CBTp); patients were not selected nature (rather than those with distressing symptoms or clinician-directed);" or insufficient therapist expertise.

title: An electronic health record-based intervention to improve tobacco treatment in primary care: a cluster randomized controlled trial.
abstract: Background To improve the documentation and treatment of tobacco use in primary care, we developed and implemented a 3-part electronic health record development: (1) smoking status icons, (2) tobacco treatment reminders, and (3) a Tobacco Smart Form. facilitated medication ordering, fax and e-mail referral referrals. Methods We conducted a cluster randomized controlled trial of improvement in 26 primary care practices between 19 December 2006 and 30 September 2007. The primary outcome was the proportion of documented smokers who contacted a smoking cessation counselor. Secondary outcomes included coded smoking status documents and medication prescribing. Results During the 9-month study period, 132 630 patients made 315 962 visits to study practices. Codified documentation of smoking status increased from 37% to 54% (+17%) of patients in intervention practices and from 35% to 46% (+11%) of patients in control settings (P < .001 for difference in differences). Among the 9,589 patients documented to be smokers at the start of the study, more patients in the intervention practices were enrolled as non-smokers at the end of the study (1.9% vs. 5.3% in the control practices; P < 0.001). more patients contacted a cessation counselor (3.9% vs. 0.3% in control practices; P < 0.001) No longer likely to prescribe smoking cessation medication to smokers in intervention practices (2% vs. 2% in control practices;" P = .40). Conclusion This electronic health record-based intervention improved smoking status documentation and increased counseling assistance for smokers, but not cessation medication prescriptions.

title: An electronic medical record-based intervention to improve quality of care for atypical presentations of gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD) and GERD.
abstract: Background Gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD) is common in primary care but is often underdiagnosed and untreated. GERD may also present with atypical symptoms such as chronic cough and asthma, and physicians may be unaware of this picture. We aimed to implement and evaluate an intervention to improve diagnosis and treatment for GERD and atypical GERD in primary care. Methods This was a randomized controlled trial in a primary care practice using a national network of US practices (Medical Quality Improvement Consortium – MQIC) sharing the same electronic medical record (EMR). Thirteen offices with 53 providers were randomized to the EMR-based prompts and education intervention, and 14 offices with 66 providers were randomized to the control group, which included a total of more than 67,000 patients and examined outcomes of GERD diagnosis and appropriate treatment. Results In patients without GERD at baseline, new GERD diagnoses were significantly increased in the intervention group (3.1%) versus the control group (2.3%) (P<0.01). This remained significant after controlling for clustering, with a diagnosis probability of 1.33 (95% CI 1.13–1.56) for the intervention group. For patients with atypical symptoms, the probability of those in the intervention group being both diagnosed with GERD (OR 2.02, 95% CI 1.41–2.88) and treated for GERD (OR 1.40, 95% CI 1.08–“) was higher. 1.83) more than in the control group. Outcomes Diagnosis and management of GERD in primary care, particularly in patients with atypical symptoms, can be improved with the use of an EMR-based tool that includes decision support and education. However, there is significant room for improvement in the use of appropriate therapy.

title: Evaluation of opioid prescription for chronic non-malignant pain by Australian GPs.
abstract: OBJECTIVE: Our aim was to evaluate the quality of opioid analgesia prescribed by general practitioners (general practitioners, family physicians) for chronic non-malignant pain (CNMP). DESIGN: An anonymous, cross-sectional survey-based survey. LOCATION: The setting was five Australian general practice divisions (geographically based associations of general practitioners). METHODS: A questionnaire was mailed to all department members. The outcome measures were adherence to individual recommendations of locally derived CNMP practice guidelines. RESULTS: We received 404 responses (response rate 23.3%). In the previous two weeks, GPs prescribed long-term continuous opioids for CNMP for a median of 4 (+/-8.7) patients with CNMP and a median of 7.1 (+/-8.7) patients with CNMP. Guideline alignment (GLC) was poor, with no GPs always compliant with all guideline items, and only 31% used most items. GLC was highest to avoid high dosages or fast acting formulations. It was the lowest for strategies that minimized individual and public health harms, such as initiating opioids on a time-limited trial basis, using contracts, and preventing or managing abnormal behavior. GLC was positively associated with relevant education or qualifications, enrollment in the Australian Prescription Drug Monitoring Program, being an opioid substitution treatment prescriber, and female gender. CONCLUSIONS: In this study, long-term opioids were often initiated for CNMP without a quality drug use approach. Potential sequelae are inadequate treatment of pain and increased opioid-related harms. These data suggest the need for better sourcing and education in opioid management across pain and addictions.

title: Evidence-Based Guide to Writing Grant Proposals for Clinical Trials
abstract: In 1863, Florence Nightingale argued that London hospitals were dangerous, especially when compared to provincial facilities. He backed up this claim with statistics published in William Fair's General Registrar's report, which claimed that the death rates of 24 London hospitals exceeded 90%, while rural hospitals had an average mortality rate of 13%. Farr calculated mortality rates by dividing the total number of patients who died during the year by the number of inpatients in a single day. Calculated by dividing the annual number of deaths by the total number of inpatients during the year, the death rate for London hospitals was 10%. A heated debate erupted in the London medical press about how best to calculate hospital mortality rates. Critics argued that Farr did not adjust to the differences in disease severity between urban and rural hospitals, and that his figures would mislead the public. Farr and Nightingale criticized the poor quality of hospital data. This story reinforces the need to understand the methodological derivation of statistics aimed at comparing provider quality.

title: An evolving perspective on physical activity counseling by medical professionals
abstract: BACKGROUND: Physical inactivity is a modifiable risk factor for many chronic conditions and a leading cause of premature death. An increasing number of adults worldwide are not participating in adequate levels of physical activity to prevent or mitigate these adverse effects. Medical professionals have been identified as potentially potent sources of influence for those who do not meet minimum physical activity guidelines. Health professionals are respected and sources of advice are expected, and they reach a large and engaged proportion of the population. Despite this potential, health professionals do not routinely practice physical activity promotion. CONCLUSION: Medical professionals face several known barriers to promoting physical activity, including lack of time and perceived effectiveness in changing physical activity behavior in patients. In addition, the evidence for effective physical activity promotion by medical professionals is insufficient. To address these issues, new approaches to promoting physical activity are being proposed. These include collaborating with community-based physical activity behavior change interventions, preparing patients for effective brief counseling during a consultation with a medical professional, and the use of interactive behavior change technology. SUMMARY: It is important that we recognize the hidden risk of physical inactivity among patients presenting in clinical settings. Preparation for improving the patient's physical activity behaviors should begin before consultation and may include physical activity screening. Medical professionals should also identify appropriate community interventions that they can refer to physically inactive patients. Outsourcing the majority of a comprehensive physical activity intervention to community-based interventions will reduce the clinical consultation time required to address the issue with each patient. Priorities for future research include exploring ways to promote successful referrals and then participating in comprehensive community support programs to increase the physical activity levels of inactive patients. In addition, future clinical trials of physical activity interventions should be evaluated in the context of a broader outcome framework to inform a systematic assessment of broad strengths and weaknesses related not only to efficacy but also cost-effectiveness and likelihood of successful translation of interventions into clinical contexts.

title: An experimental study on the determinants of group judgments in clinical guideline development.
abstract: BACKGROUND: Clinical guidelines for improving quality of care are a familiar part of clinical practice. Formal consensus methods, such as the nominal group technique, are often used as part of guideline development, but little is known about the factors influencing the statements produced by nominal groups and their consistency with research evidence. METHODS: Cognitive behavioral therapy, behavioral therapy, brief psychodynamic interpersonal therapy, and antidepressants for irritable bowel syndrome, chronic fatigue syndrome, and chronic back pain were selected for the study. The 16 nominal groups in a factorial design allowed only GPs to be compared with mixed GPs and specialist groups, to provide a literature review without any judgment, and to ratings made in the context of realistic or ideal levels of health care resources. Participants rated fitness independently and after a facilitated meeting. Audio recordings of four group discussions were analyzed. RESULTS: Agreed with research evidence for 51% of the 192 scenarios. Agreement was more likely if the group was GP only, if a literature review was provided, or if the evidence was consistent with clinicians' beliefs. Assumptions about the level of available resources had no effect. Clinical and social cues had mixed effects, regardless of research evidence. Qualitative analysis demonstrated the modifying effect of clinical experience and beliefs about research evidence. COMMENT: Guidelines cannot be based on data alone";" Judgment is inevitable. The nominal group technique is a method of revealing and combining judgments in a transparent and structured way. It can provide important information about the levels of agreement between experts. However, the results may conflict with the published literature. If so, the reasons should be clear.

title: An experimental study on the determinants of group judgments in clinical guideline development.
abstract: Clinical guidelines for improving quality of care are a familiar part of clinical practice. Formal consensus methods, such as the nominal group technique, are often used as part of guideline development, but little is known about the factors influencing the statements produced by nominal groups and their consistency with research evidence.";" Clinical guidelines for improving quality of care are a familiar part of clinical practice. Formal consensus methods, such as the nominal group technique, are often used as part of guideline development, but little is known about the factors influencing the statements produced by nominal groups and their consistency with research evidence.

title: An empirical study of the determinants of the extent of disagreement within clinical guideline development groups.
abstract: OBJECTIVE: To assess the impact of design features and clinical and social cues on the extent of conflict among participants in the process of developing a formal consensus. METHODS: Factorial design covering 16 groups of 135 general practitioners (GPs) and 42 mental health professionals from the UK. The groups rated the relevance of four mental health interventions for three conditions (chronic back pain, irritable bowel syndrome, and chronic fatigue syndrome) in the context of a variety of clinical and social cues. Groups differed in three design features: providing a systematic literature review (versus not provided), group composition (GP vs. mixed only), and assumptions about available healthcare resources (realistic versus idealistic). Disagreement was measured using the mean absolute deviation from a group's median rating for a scenario. RESULTS: None of the design features significantly affected the degree of disagreement within the groups (all p>0.3). There was disagreement between treatments (closer consensus for cognitive behavioral therapy and behavioral therapy rather than brief psychodynamic intervention therapy and antidepressants) and cues (closer consensus for depressed patients and patients willing to try any treatment). CONCLUSION: In terms of the extent of disagreement in the groups in this study, formal consensus building was a sound technique as it did not depend on the way the results were conducted.

title: An application research agenda
abstract: In October 2006, the UK's Chief Medical Officer (CMO) asked Professor Sir John Tooke to chair a High Level Group on Clinical Efficiency in response to the 'Not Waste, I Don't Want' section in the 2005 annual report of CMOs. Public health'. The senior group made recommendations to the CMO to consider possible ways to increase clinical effectiveness in the UK's National Health Service (NHS) and to encourage clinical engagement to ensure this. The report included a brief section on the research needs that emerged in the process of writing the report, but to more fully define the relevant research agenda, Professor Sir John Tooke asked Professor Martin Eccles to convene an expert group - Clinical Efficacy Research. Agenda Group (CERAG) – to define the research agenda. CERAG's mandate was to 'further detail the research agenda for the maintenance of clinically effective practice within the (UK) National Health Service'. This editorial provides a summary of the CERAG report and recommendations.

title: An integrated framework for safety, quality and risk management: an information and incident management system based on a universal patient safety classification
abstract: More needs to be done to improve safety and quality and manage risks in healthcare. Existing processes are fragmented and there is no single comprehensive source of information on what went wrong. There is a need for an information and incident management system based on a universal patient safety classification and an integrated framework for safety, quality and risk management. The World Alliance for Patient Safety provides a platform for the development of a coherent approach";" 43 Desirable qualities for such an approach are discussed. An example of an incident management and information system serving patient safety classification is presented with a brief explanation of how and where it is currently used. Any such system is worthless unless it improves safety and quality. Four-loop learning (personal, local, national and international) is proposed, with examples of how an exemplary system has been used successfully at various levels. There is now an opportunity to "get it right" with international collaboration through the World Health Organization to develop an integrated framework that includes systems that can accommodate information from all sources, manage and monitor what goes wrong, and allow for knowledge sharing worldwide. and disseminating tools for implementing strategies that have been shown to work.

title: An integrative review investigating the decision-making factors affecting mental health nurses' use of restraint.
abstract: UNLABELED: WHAT IS KNOWN ABOUT: There is new evidence highlighting the counter-therapeutic effect of restraint use and encouraging minimization of this practice in mental health care. Mental health nurses are often the professional group that uses restraint, and it becomes critical to understand the factors that influence their decision making. To date, there are no other published articles that do a similar extensive research to review this topic. WHAT DOES THIS PAPER ADD TO CURRENT KNOWLEDGE: The eight themes that emerged were identified as factors that influenced mental health nurses' decision making on the use of restraint. Themes: "safety for all", "restriction as a necessary intervention", "restriction as a last resort", "role conflict", "maintenance of control", "staff composition", "knowledge and perception of patient behavior", and "psychological impact" '. 'Last resort' seems to be the mantra of the acceptable use of restraint, but to date there are no studies that specifically address what this concept really is. WHAT ARE APPLICATIONS FOR IMPLEMENTATION?: These findings should be considered in evaluating the use of restraint in mental health settings and evaluating appropriate strategies in place to support the transition to restraint minimization. Because the concept of 'last resort' is mentioned in many policies and guidelines internationally without a published understanding of what it means, research should prioritize it as the next critical step in efforts to minimize the restriction. INTRODUCTION: While mechanical and manual restraint may at times seem necessary as a method of institutional control in mental health settings, there is emerging literature that highlights the potential therapeutic impact of this practice for both patients and staff. Nurses are the professional group most likely to use mechanical and manual restraint methods in mental health settings. Therefore, in-depth insights are warranted to understand what factors influence nurses' decisions about restraint use. OBJECTIVE: To investigate what influences mental health nurses' decision to use restraint. METHOD: An integrative review was conducted using Cooper's framework. RESULTS: Eight emerging themes were identified: 'safety for all', 'restriction as a necessary intervention', 'restriction as a last resort', 'role conflict', 'maintaining control', 'personnel composition', 'perception of knowledge and perception'. patient behavior' and 'psychological impact'. These themes highlight how mental health nurses' decision-making is affected by interpersonal and staff factors, as well as ethical and safety responsibilities. CONCLUSION: Research is needed to better understand the 'last resort' experience and implementation in restraint use and to provide strategies to prevent restraint use in mental health settings.

title: An intervention to change clinician behavior: conceptual framework for the multicolor simplified asthma guideline reminder (MSAGR).
abstract: Clinical practice guidelines reduce diversity in healthcare as they standardize the care delivered by healthcare providers. Seventeen years after their publication, the National Asthma Education and Prevention Program (NAEPP) guidelines are considered the "gold standard" for asthma treatment, but are underused despite three revisions, the most recent in July 2007. helpful notes. This article discusses the Multicolor, Simplified Asthma Guideline Reminder (MSAGR), an algorithm schema intervention to help clinicians change their behavior to better comply with NAEPP guidelines, and explains the conceptual framework underpinning this intervention as a means of predicting better outcomes for providers and children. .

title: An investigative journalist looks at medical ethics
abstract: KIE: Campbell welcomes Britain's medical and research community and the General Medical Council (GMC) to Dr. James Sharp and Jabar Sultan. Sharp and Sultan conducted a series of highly publicized but unethical and potentially harmful experiments with private patients that were eventually brought to public attention by Campbell's report and a BBC television programme. Campbell questions why senior doctors, journal critics, and others didn't speak out against Sharp and Sultan or alert GMC, and why GMC didn't investigate researchers independently. With the increasing commercialization of British medicine, he warns, legislation is needed to establish a national regulatory body to oversee standards in the private sector.

title: An ongoing challenge: a mixed-method systematic review of interventions, barriers and facilitators to achieve optimal self-care by children and youth with type 1 diabetes in educational settings.
abstract: BACKGROUND: Type 1 diabetes is more common in young children who are usually of preschool age and enter the education system with diabetes-related support needs that develop over time. It is important that children are supported at school to best manage their diet, exercise, blood sugar monitoring and insulin regimen. Young people are self-directed at college/university. METHOD: A mixed-methods systematic review with theory knowledge to determine the effectiveness of the intervention and to synthesize the facilitators' child/parent/professional views and barriers to achieving optimal diabetes self-care and management in educational settings for children and youth aged 3-25 years. RESULTS: Eleven interventions and 55 opinion studies were included. Meta-analysis was not possible. Study focuses, broadly matched school diabetes guidance. Intervention studies were often limited to specific contexts with a high risk of bias. Opinion studies were mostly of moderate quality and shared transferable findings. Health plans and school nurse support (various types) were effective. At school, telemedicine was instrumental for individual case management. Most educational interventions to increase the knowledge and confidence of children or school staff have had significant short-term effects, but longer follow-up is needed. Children, parents and staff said they struggled with many common structural, organizational, educational and attitudinal school barriers. Aspects of school guidance were not generally implemented (for example, individual health plans). Children recognized and appreciated school staff who were trained and confident in supporting diabetes management. Research with college/university students was lacking. Campus-based college/university students support significantly improved knowledge, attitudes, and diabetes self-care. Self-management was easier for students who balanced diabetes management with student lifestyle, such as adopting strategies to manage their alcohol consumption. CONCLUSION: This new mixed-methods systematic review is the first to integrate intervention effectiveness with views of children/parents/experts mapped to school diabetes guidelines. Diabetes management can be improved overall with full implementation and control of the guideline effect. The evidence is limited in quality and there is a lack of knowledge about what works. Telemedicine and school nurse support for children between healthcare providers and schools are effective in certain contexts, but not all education systems employ onsite nurses. More innovative and sustainable solutions and sound assessments are needed. Comprehensive lifestyle approaches for college/university students warrant further development and evaluation.

title: An update on the management of a patient presenting with acute coronary syndromes without ST elevation.
abstract: More than 780,000 patients in the United States are diagnosed with acute coronary syndrome (ACS) each year. As physicians, it is our responsibility to ensure the prompt examination, diagnosis and management of these patients. After identifying the patient with ACS and confirming no ST-segment elevation MI requiring immediate revascularization, physicians should perform a study for non-ST-elevation acute coronary syndrome (NSTE-ACS). It is important to understand the latest best practice guidelines in the treatment and management of patients with NSTE-ACS with a high rate of in-hospital mortality. Physicians must integrate clinical history and examination, electrocardiogram, and laboratory findings to accurately diagnose an NSTE-ACS. Even in establishing an early invasive strategy with cardiac catheterization and percutaneous coronary intervention, early treatment with guided medical therapy is imperative. The focus of this review is to discuss appropriate strategies for the evaluation and management of patients with NSTE-ACS based on the latest ACC/AHA practice guidelines.

title: Anesthetic and other treatments for shell shock: World War I and beyond
abstract: Post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD) is an important health risk factor for military personnel serving in modern warfare. During the First World War this condition (known then as shell shock or 'neurasthenia') was such a problem that 'advanced psychiatry' was started by French doctors in 1915. Some British doctors have tried general anesthesia (ether and chloroform) as a treatment. others preferred the electrical application. In 1917 four British 'advanced psychiatric units' were established. Hospitals were established in Britain for soldiers suffering from bullet shock, including Craiglockhart War Hospital in Edinburgh (for officers); patients found to have more serious psychiatric conditions were transferred to the Royal Edinburgh Asylum. anesthetic and electrical treatments of shock shock, modified Freudian methods were gradually replaced by psychodynamic intervention. The effectiveness of 'advanced psychiatry' was controversial. In 1922 the War Office produced a report on shell shock with recommendations for the prevention of combat neurosis. However, in 1939 the Second World War This seemed to be ignored when World War II broke out. As failure rates became alarming, the term 'battle fatigue' was introduced, and then the value of preselection was recognized. Barbiturate abreaction at Maudsley Hospital in London in 1940 for rapid relief from severe anxiety and hysteria It has been advocated using IV anesthetics: Somnifaine, paraldehyde, Sodium amytal 'Pentothal narcosis' and 'drug analysis' were adopted by British and American military psychiatrists. But in 1945 medical thought gradually settled into the same approaches that seemed effective in 1918. The term PTSD was introduced in 1980. In the United Kingdom, the National Institute for Health and Clinical Excellence (NICE) recommend management guidelines (2005). Evaluation of trauma-focused Cognitive Behavioral Therapy and antidepressants.

title: Analgesia and anesthesia for neonates: study design and ethical issues
abstract: OBJECTIVE: The purpose of this article is to summarize clinical, methodological, and ethical considerations for researchers interested in designing future trials in neonatal analgesia and anesthesia and hope to encourage additional research in this area. METHODS: MEDLINE, PubMed, EMBASE, and Cochrane registry databases were searched using topics related to infant, neonatal, neonatal, analgesia, anesthesia, ethics, and study design. Cross-references and personal files were manually searched. Studies reporting original data or review articles on these topics were reviewed and critically reviewed by experts for each subject area. Data on population demographics, study characteristics, and cognitive and behavioral outcomes were systematically abstracted and synthesized and refined by group members. Data synthesis and results were reviewed by a panel of independent experts and presented to a wider audience, including clinicians, scientists, regulatory staff, and industry representatives, at the Newborn Pharmaceutical Development Initiative workshop. The recommendations were revised after extensive discussion at the workshop and among committee members. CONCLUSIONS: Designing clinical trials to explore new or already existing approaches for analgesia and anesthesia in neonates requires consideration of salient study designs and ethical issues. Conditions requiring treatment include pain/stress from invasive procedures, surgical operations, inflammatory conditions, and routine neonatal intensive care. Study design considerations should describe inclusion and exclusion criteria, a rationale for classification, confounding effects of comorbid conditions, and other clinical factors. Important ethical issues include variability between institutional review boards in examining newborns, obtaining informed consent, performing risk-benefit assessments, defining compensation or rewards for participation, safety considerations, use of placebo controls, and interpreting federal guidelines for human research. . For optimal study design, researchers must formulate well-defined study questions, select appropriate study designs, estimate drug efficacy, calculate sample size, determine duration of studies, determine pharmacokinetic and pharmacodynamic parameters, and avoid drug-drug interactions. Specific outcome measures may include scoring on pain rating scales, various biomarkers and their response patterns, process outcomes (eg, length of stay, time to extubation), medium or long-term outcomes, and safety parameters. CONCLUSIONS: Much more research is needed in this area to formulate a scientifically sound, evidence-based, and clinically useful framework for the management of anesthesia and analgesia in neonates. Newer study designs and additional ethical dilemmas can be identified with the accumulated data in this area.

title: Analysis of information submitted by clinical trial sponsors on the safety of investigational drugs
abstract: During the conduct of clinical trials in medical institutions, information on the safety of investigational drugs is provided by trial sponsors in accordance with good clinical practice guidelines. In this study, reports of clinical trials conducted at Tokyo University Hospital were reviewed, focusing on safety information provided to the Institutional Review Board (IRB). Two hundred and two reports (52 protocols) on safety information were submitted to the IRB by clinical trial sponsors between April 2000 and March 2001, 185 of which included a total of 3021 adverse event cases. Of these, 194 were decided not to be associated with a significant problem by clinical researchers/physicians and the studies continued. For 157 of these 194 reports, it was considered unnecessary to inform test subjects about report content, including adverse events. The decision on whether to make subjects aware of such content tended to depend on the causal relationship between adverse events and drug intake, as well as the predictability of adverse events. For 8 of these 194 reports, the IRB recommended that clinical investigators/physicians provide information to test subjects and/or provide detailed information about their status to the IRB. Based on these results, we suggest that it is necessary to establish a system to integrate and evaluate drug safety information to ensure safe and efficient clinical trials.

title: Angina on the Palm: randomized controlled pilot trial of Palm PDA software for referrals for cardiac testing.
abstract: OBJECTIVE Personal digital assistants (PDAs) are popular with physicians: in 2003, 33% of Canadian physicians reported using them in their practice. However, we do not know whether using a PDA changes the behavior of GPs. We examined the effectiveness of a PDA software application to help family physicians diagnose angina in patients with chest pain. DESIGN Prospective randomized controlled pilot trial using a cluster design. INSTALLATION Basic maintenance practices in the Toronto area. PARTICIPANTS Eighteen family physicians recruited from North Toronto Primary Care Research Network (Nortren) or recruited from a local hospital. INTERVENTIONS We randomized physicians to either receive a Palm PDA (including angina diagnostic software) or continue conventional therapy. Doctors prospectively recorded the care process of patients aged 30-75 years who presented with suspected angina for 7 months. MAIN OUTCOME MEASURES Has the care process of patients with suspected angina improved when their physicians had PDAs and software? The primary outcomes we looked at were frequency of cardiac stress testing orders for suspected angina and relevance of referral for cardiac stress testing at presentation and nuclear cardiology testing after cardiac stress testing. The secondary outcome was referred to cardiologists. RESULTS The software led to a more general use of cardiac stress testing (81% vs 50%). The absolute increase was 31% (P = .007, 95% confidence interval [CI] 8% to 58%). There was a trend towards more appropriate use of the stress test (48.6% with PDA and 28.6% control), an increase of 20% (P = .284, 95% CI -11.54 to 51.4%). There was also a trend towards more appropriate use of nuclear cardiology following cardiac stress testing (63.0% vs. 45.5%), with an absolute increase of 17.5% (P = .400, 95% CI -13.9% to 48.9%). Referrals to cardiologists did not increase (38.2% vs. 40.9% with PDA, P = 0.869). CONCLUSION A PDA-based software application could lead to better care for patients with suspected angina in family practice";" this finding requires confirmation in a larger study.

title: anorexia nervosa
Antibiotic prescribing in long-term care facilities: a qualitative, multidisciplinary study.
abstract: OBJECTIVES: To explore healthcare professionals' views on prescribing antibiotics in long-term care facilities (LTCFs). Using the findings to suggest intervention strategies for antimicrobial management in LTCFs. DESIGN: Qualitative semi-structured interviews were conducted. The data were analyzed with thematic content analysis. After the interviews, the emerging findings were matched with the theoretical domain framework (TDF) and the behavior modification wheel and behavior modification technique (BCT) classification were used to recommend future intervention strategies. PARTICIPANTS: Interviews were conducted with 37 healthcare professionals working at LTCFs (10 general practitioners, 4 consultants, 14 nurses, 9 pharmacists) between December 2012 and March 2013. RESULTS: The main areas emerging from TDF were: 'Knowledge', 'Environmental context and resources', 'Social influences', 'Beliefs about outcomes', 'Memory, attention and decision making'; 'Behavior regulation'. Many participants believed that antibiotic prescribing was satisfactory in their LTCF despite the lack of surveillance activities. CONCLUSIONS: Using the TDF and BCT taxonomy, this study found that antibiotic prescription in LTCFs is influenced by many social and contextual factors. The challenges of the setting and the patient population, beliefs about patient outcomes, and the failure to implement guidelines and information regarding antibiotic prescribing patterns are significant challenges that need to be addressed. Based on the study findings and the application of TDF and BCT taxonomy, we propose some practical intervention functions for antimicrobial management in LTCFs.

title: antibiotic resistance
abstract: Resistance to antibiotics is economically and physiologically costly. Controlling antibiotic resistance will require the aggressive implementation of multiple strategies. Continuous surveillance is required to monitor known antibiotic types and identify the development of other potential types. Early intervention is needed to combat the rising rate of resistance. The continued use of hygiene measures and the controlled use of antibiotics will limit the spread of antibiotic resistance. Health care providers need to monitor compliance with control measures. Hand and environmental control measures remain a critical component of staff training activities. Active management of infections with non-pharmacological treatments should be encouraged. Motivational campaigns will reinforce positive infection control behaviors. Consistent surveillance of antibiotic use will help meet the CDC directive to combat antibiotic resistance and keep the population healthy.

title: Antibiotic therapy for 12 versus 6 weeks in patients with pyogenic vertebral osteomyelitis: an open-label, non-inferior, randomized, controlled trial.
abstract: Background The duration of therapy for patients with vertebral osteomyelitis is primarily based on expert advice rather than evidence. We aimed to determine whether 6 weeks of antibiotic therapy is less than 12 weeks in patients with pyogenic vertebral osteomyelitis.";" Background The duration of therapy for patients with vertebral osteomyelitis is primarily based on expert advice rather than evidence.
