We aimed to determine whether 6 weeks of antibiotic therapy is less than 12 weeks in patients with pyogenic vertebral osteomyelitis.

title: Antimalarial prescribing patterns in public and selected parastatal hospitals in Lagos, Nigeria
abstract: OBJECTIVE: Malaria is a treatable and preventable disease and is an important public health problem in Nigeria. Chloroquine was the first-line drug in its treatment until recently in Nigeria, where Artemisinin-based Combination Therapies (ACTs) were introduced. Inappropriate prescribing, that is, not prescribing drugs according to scientific evidence-based guidelines to ensure safe, effective and economical use, is an irrational drug use behavior. The increased benefits or slowing of progression to resistance from chloroquine can be achieved by improving prescribing practice, drug quality, and patient compliance. OBJECTIVE: To identify the antimalarial prescribing pattern and evaluate rational chloroquine prescribing by prescribers at public hospitals and parastatals in Lagos State. METHODS: The study was conducted using patient prescriptions at all ten government General Hospitals under the Lagos Public Hospitals Board (now the Lagos State Health Services Commission), a parastatal hospital and an oil company clinic. One hundred prescriptions each for adults and children were systematically sampled for each month for one year (January-December 2000). When there were fewer than 100 prescriptions in a month, all available prescriptions were sampled for analysis. RESULTS: The mean number of drugs per encounter in all hospitals was 4,259 +/- 0.009. The average number of injections per encounter was 1,215 +/- 0.009. Approximately 48.5% of all prescriptions had at least one injection, while 40.9% of prescriptions had dipyrone injection. The average drug cost per encounter was N147.40 +/- 0.765. The percentage of exposure to chloroquine was 82.5%, followed by sulfadoxine-pyrimethamine 14.2%. The proportion of prescriptions with the correct chloroquine dose was 47.5%. CONCLUSION: Polypharmacy is available in all hospitals. The average number of drugs per encounter was above 4 for most hospitals. Less than half of the prescriptions had the right dose of chloroquine. This study may serve as a basis for irrational prescribing intervention.

title: Antioxidant vitamin supplement for the prevention of cardiovascular diseases
abstract: Oxidative stress, particularly oxidative modification of LDL-cholesterol, appears to be of great importance in the pathogenesis of atherosclerosis. Several observational epidemiological studies have suggested that antioxidant vitamin intake is associated with reduced cardiovascular morbidity and mortality. In addition, experimental studies on animals have shown that antioxidant vitamins slow the progression of atherosclerosis. However, prospective controlled clinical trials failed to demonstrate a benefit of antioxidant vitamin supplementation in primary or secondary prevention of cardiovascular disease. Therefore, the use of antioxidants and vitamin supplements as a preventive or therapeutic intervention cannot be recommended.

title: Antipruritic therapy in atopic eczema
abstract: Painful itching seriously affects the quality of life in patients with atopic eczema. Since the pathogenesis of pruritus is not understood, symptomatic measures are the mainstay of treatment as well as avoidance of aggravating factors. These include emollients, topical and systemic actives, and physical therapy (eg, phototherapy) adjusted to the severity of the disease. Behavioral therapy offers additional support. New treatment modalities, such as immunomodulators, immunosuppressive agents, and opiate antagonists, which are still partially in the experimental stage, are reserved for non-responders"; they are also reviewed.

title: Antipsychotic polypharmacy in schizophrenia: benefits and risks
abstract: Antipsychotic polypharmacy refers to the simultaneous prescription of more than one antipsychotic medication for a single patient. Prescribing studies in international psychiatric services have identified relatively frequent and consistent use of combined antipsychotics, often for people with established schizophrenia, with a prevalence of up to 50% in some clinical settings. A common reason for prescribing more than one antipsychotic is to achieve a greater or more rapid therapeutic response than is achieved with antipsychotic monotherapy. However, the evidence about the risks and benefits of such a strategy is unclear and is generally not considered sufficient to warrant a recommendation for its use in routine clinical practice in psychiatry. Combined antipsychotics are a major contributor to high-dose prescribing in conjunction with an increased burden of adverse events and are of limited value in helping to establish the optimal maintenance regimen for a patient. The relatively widespread use of antipsychotic polypharmacy identified in cross-sectional studies reflects not only the addition of a second antipsychotic to enhance therapeutic response, but also the use of gradual cross-titration of antipsychotic drugs as needed (mainly to treat disturbed behavior). switching from one antipsychotic to another and augmentation of clozapine with a second antipsychotic when the disease does not respond adequately to an optimized trial of clozapine. This review considers clinical trial data and other evidence for each of these pharmacological approaches. Examples of systematic, practice-based interventions designed to reduce the prevalence of antipsychotic polypharmacy were also reviewed, many of which met with only modest success. Guidelines generally agree that if combined antipsychotics are prescribed to treat resistant psychotic illness, this should happen after other evidence-based pharmacological treatments such as clozapine have been exhausted. Also, their prescription for each patient should be in an individual research context, with monitoring of clinical response and side effects, and appropriate physical health monitoring.

title: Hospital control application to nebulizer use: Example of Hotel-Dieu de France-Lebanon
abstract: PROBLEM: The aim of the study was to reduce unfair prescriptions of nebulized therapy to comply with international guidelines and reduce healthcare costs. METHODS: DESIGN: We conducted a controlled, prospective study to evaluate the impact of local guidelines aimed at improving physicians' behavior on compliance and costs of administration. BACKGROUND AND ENVIRONMENT: All departments of a university hospital: medical and surgical wards, intensive care units, emergency rooms and one-day admission units. KEY MEASURE FOR CHANGE: Reduction in the number of inappropriate nebulized therapy prescriptions. STRATEGIES FOR CHANGE: The app included two training presentations, banners in all departments, emails to all doctors and assistants, and a reassessment of the prescription one week later. RESULTS: Pre-intervention, inappropriate prescription rate was 11.9% (42/358 of nebulizer-treated patients had no indication for this treatment and 3/19 had nebulization indications but untreated)”; “post-intervention , the inappropriate prescription rate was 14.6% (15.7% of patients with no indication for treatment, but no patients with an indication for treatment and no untreated), reflecting that the intervention had no significant effect. CONCLUSION: The simple presentation of clinical guidelines did not lead to a change in medical practice. Another approach is needed to effectively improve this outcome.

title: Application of MAT-CHDSP to evaluate guideline adherence and therapy target success in secondary prevention of coronary heart disease after percutaneous coronary intervention.
abstract: OBJECTIVE: Numerous studies have documented optimal non-compliance with guideline recommendations for secondary prevention of coronary heart disease (CHD(CP)). Clinical practice guidelines (CPGs) aimed at reducing the risk of morbidity and death are continually being developed to define appropriate patient care. The Drug Evaluation Tool for CHD(SP) (MAT-CHD(SP)) was developed to assess adherence to CPGs related to drug therapy and follow-up of CHD(SP) patients. The aim of this study was to investigate whether MAT-CHD(SP) could be applied retrospectively to evaluate guideline adherence and therapy target success in secondary prevention of CHD. METHODS: We collected data from electronic medical records of all patients who underwent percutaneous coronary intervention with stent implantation (n = 300) between January and March 2008 and performed MAT-CHD(SP). We measured the time for data collection and MAT implementation, and tested reproducibility by calculating Cohen's kappa (kappa) value for interobserver and interobserver agreement. RESULTS: A total of 247 MAT applications were analyzed (intraobserver and interobserver kappa values 0.93 and 0.95), showing the overall applicability of 66% of the 4,446 MAT-CHD(SP) criteria and the high reproducibility of the MAT-CHD(SP) application. agreement, respectively). The mean time for data collection and MAT-CHD(SP) application was 11 minutes. Compliance with prescription criteria was high (>75%), but achievement of treatment goals for cholesterol and blood pressure was low (<50%). Documentation of lifestyle recommendations provided moderate (50-75%) or low compliance, as did therapy changes, in patients whose therapy goals were not met at hospital admission. CONCLUSIONS: MAT-CHD(SP) provides a tool to determine both adherence and non-adherence to CPGs related to CHD(SP) and identifies potentials for improved patient care and applicable in retrospective evaluation of CHD(SP).

title: Applying theory to develop supervisory and feedback interventions to increase adoption of evidence-based transfusion practice: an intervention development protocol
abstract: BACKGROUND: Blood transfusion controls show that approximately 20% transfusion is outside of national recommendations and guidelines. Supervision and feedback is a widely used quality improvement intervention, but the effects on clinical practice are variable and suggest potential for improvement. Behavioral theory, theoretical frameworks of behavior change, and behavior change techniques provide systematic processes for improving intervention. This work is part of a broader program of work to promote the adoption of evidence-based transfusion practice. OBJECTIVES: The objectives of this study are to design two theoretically developed control and feedback interventions";" one focuses on content, the other on delivery and explores feasibility and acceptability. METHODS: Study A (Content): A coding framework based on available evidence on audit and feedback and behavior change theory and frameworks will be developed and implemented as part of a structured content analysis to identify key components of existing feedback documents. Prototype feedback documents with enhanced content will be developed, as well as a protocol describing the principles for developing feedback content. Study B (Delivery): Individual semi-structured interviews with healthcare professionals and observations of team meetings at four hospitals will be used to identify and identify views on current monitoring and feedback practice. Interviews will be based on a subject guide developed using the Theoretical Domains Framework and the Consolidated Framework for Practice Research. Analysis of transcripts based on these frameworks will establish the evidence base for developing a protocol describing an improved intervention focused on feedback delivery. Study C (Feasibility and Acceptability): Advanced interventions will be trialled at four hospitals. Semi-structured interviews, questionnaires and observations will be used to assess feasibility and acceptability. DISCUSSION: This intervention development study reflects UK Medical Research Council guidance on the development of complex interventions, which emphasizes the importance of a solid theoretical basis for intervention design and recommends systematic evaluation of feasibility and acceptability before undertaking a full-scale evaluation of interventions. randomized trial. The study includes the specification of current practice so that, in future trials in this program, there is a clear distinction between control (usual practice) conditions and interventions to be evaluated.

title: Applying Election Architecture Principles to Understanding HIV Testing: Findings from Malawi and Zimbabwe
abstract: World Health Organization-led advances in prenatal HIV counseling in sub-Saharan Africa from 2004 to 2011 saw a parallel increase in HIV testing. We sought to determine the extent to which the use of choice architecture principles (which by default provides an opt-out) influences HIV testing uptake, above and beyond individual-level attitudes and cognitions. Population and Health Survey data collected between 2004 and 2011 from Zimbabwe (N = 1330) and Malawi (N = 4.043) countries, where more than 10% of adults are HIV-infected, were analyzed. We investigated the impact of demographic variables, forms of knowledge about HIV, stigma towards people living with HIV, attitudes towards spousal abuse, and whether HIV testing should be recommended during prenatal visits. The results showed that structural-level support was the strongest predictor of HIV testing above and beyond individual-level attitudes and cognitions, accounting for secular trends in higher testing rates. Read More: https://guilfordjournals.com/doi/abs/10.1521/aeap.2015.27.4.362

title: Behavioral economics-based approaches can help drive patients and providers to lower healthcare expenditure growth.
abstract: Policies that change the environment or context in which decisions are made and that “push” people into certain choices have been relatively overlooked in health care. This article examines the role that behavioral economics-based approaches can play in "nudge" providers and patients in ways that could slow the growth of healthcare spending. The basic insight of behavioral economics is that behavior is driven by the very fallible human brain and is heavily influenced by the environment or context in which choices are made. In policy areas such as retirement and personal savings, approaches based on behavioral economics have produced remarkable results. In healthcare, such approaches have been used in successful but limited ways, such as in the use of surgical checklists that increase patient safety and reduce costs. With healthcare spending rising at unsustainable rates, we review the role that behavioral economics-based approaches can play in providing policymakers with a potential set of new tools to slow spending growth.

title: Architectural frameworks: defining structures for the implementation of learning health systems
abstract: Background The vision to transform health systems into learning health systems (LHSs) that rapidly and consistently transform knowledge into improved health outcomes at lower cost is generating increased interest in government agencies, health care organizations, and the health research community. While current initiatives have shown that different approaches can be successful in making the LHS vision a reality, their objectives, focus and scale are too diverse to be reproduced without undue effort. Indeed, the necessary structures to effectively design and implement LHSs on a larger scale are lacking. In this paper, we propose using architectural frameworks to develop LHSs that adhere to a recognized vision while adapting to their specific organizational context. Architectural frameworks are high-level descriptions of an organization as a system";" They capture the structure of its main components at various levels, the interrelationships between these components, and the principles that guide their evolution. Because these frameworks support the analysis of LHSs and allow their results to be simulated, they act as pre-implementation decision support tools that identify potential barriers and systems improvement possibilities. Thus, they increase the chances of successful LHS deployment. Discussion We present an architectural framework for LHSs that combines the five-dimensional objectives commonly found in the LHS literature: scientific, social, technical, and ethical. The proposed architectural framework consists of six decision layers that model these dimensions. The performance layer models the objectives, scientific layer scientific dimension, organization layer social dimension, data layer and information technology layer technical dimension, ethics and security layer ethical dimension. We define the types of decisions that need to be made at each layer and determine the methods to support decision making. Conclusion In this paper, we outline a high-level architectural framework based on the conceptual and empirical LHS literature. Because the application of this architectural framework allows for a clear and critical understanding of the types of decisions that underlie LHS operations, it can guide the development and implementation of new LHSs and the evolution of existing ones. More research is needed to evaluate and improve its generalizability and methods.

title: Are non-specific application guidelines potentially harmful? A randomized comparison of the impact of non-specific and specific guidelines on physician decision making.
abstract: OBJECTIVE: To test the ability of two different clinical practice guideline formats to influence the physician's order of electrodiagnostic testing for low back pain. DATA SOURCES/STUDY DESIGN: Randomized controlled trial of the effect of practice guidelines on physician-reported test ordering behavior in response to a set of 12 clinical short stories. The data came from a random national sample of 900 US neurologists, physical medicine doctors, and general internists. INTERVENTION: Two versions of a practice guide to the use of electrodiagnostic testing (EDT) have been developed by the US Healthcare Policy and Low Back Research Panel. The two guides were similar in content but differed in the originality of their recommendations. DATA COLLECTION: The proportion of clinical histories for which EDTs were ordered for appropriate and ineligible clinical indications in each of the three physician groups were randomly assigned to receive stories only, short stories plus non-specific version of the guideline, or stories plus a specific version of the guideline. instruction. KEY FINDINGS: The response rate to the survey was 71 percent. The proportion of eligible vignettes for which EDTs were ordered averaged 77 percent for the non-guided group, 71 percent for the non-specific guide group, and 79 percent for the specific guide group (p = .002). The corresponding values for the number of EDTs ordered for ineligible vignettes are 32 percent, 32 percent, and 26 percent, respectively (p = .08). Pairwise comparisons showed that physicians who received non-specific guidelines ordered fewer EDTs for appropriate clinical vignettes than physicians who did not (p = .02). Also, compared with physicians receiving non-specific guidelines, physicians receiving specific guidelines ordered significantly more EDT (p = .0007) for appropriate vignettes and significantly less EDT (p = .04) for inappropriate vignettes. CONCLUSIONS: The clarity and clinical applicability of a guideline can be important attributes that contribute to the effectiveness of practice guidelines.

title: Are Nurses the Answer to New Primary Care Needs?
Are Psychiatric Crisis Assessment and Treatment team clinicians at the forefront of psychotherapy?
abstract: OBJECTIVE: There is limited data on psychological interventions used by Crisis Evaluation and Treatment (CAT) team clinicians, although practice guidelines mandate some of their role as providing counselling. This study aimed to catalog and categorize the types of psychotherapeutic interventions used by clinicians of a CAT team operating in a metropolitan area. METHODS: Self-report and care-episode data were collected regarding clinicians' views on the type of psychotherapeutic intervention they administered and details of what they talked to patients, and the location and duration of interventions. RESULTS: Thirty-two maintenance departments were cataloged. On average, clinicians spent 74% of their total contact time with patients engaged in psychological interventions. A wide range of strategies, drawn from a broad theoretical foundation, were used. In addition to general approaches that aid participation, interventions can be classified into the following categories: meta-strategy ('therapeutic treatment'), 'critical', 'practical', specific psychotherapeutic (cognitive-behavioral therapy (CBT) and others), and supportive. CONCLUSIONS: Clinicians viewed themselves as preoccupied with psychological interventions that drew from a broad theoretical basis most of the time in patient contact. Observational studies of what clinicians actually do and empirical investigation of their effectiveness can have implications for clinician training and supervision.

title: Have NHS national results frameworks passed their expiration date?
Are we adequately preparing the next generation of physicians to prescribe exercise as prevention and treatment? Residents express desire for more training in exercise prescription
abstract: BACKGROUND: Physical activity (PA) is an important intervention for chronic disease, but few physicians provide exercise prescriptions (EP). EP is a key component in larger strategies to reduce noncommunicable diseases (NCDs). Our aim was to evaluate the knowledge, competency and EP perspectives of Family Medicine Residents (FMRs) to help inform future curriculum development. METHODS: A 49-item cross-sectional questionnaire was administered to 396 University of British Columbia FMRs. EP knowledge, competence, attitudes/beliefs, current practices, personal physical activity levels and educational perspectives of the residents were first evaluated using a 7-point Likert scale. RESULTS: The response rate was 80.6% (319/396). After eliminating 25 that did not meet the inclusion criteria, 294 were included in the final analysis. Majority 95.6% of FMRs had EP' despite having low knowledge of Canadian PA Guidelines (mean score 1.77/4) and low proficiency in prescribing exercise as prevention (mean score 13.35/21). reported that it is important in future applications. they consider themselves "slightly inadequate" and recommend exercise to patients with chronic disease (mean score 11.26/21). FMR believes that PA is an integral part of their patients' health (98.0%), sedentary behavior is harmful (97.9%), and is responsible for discussing PA with patients (99.7%). Few FMRs (14.9%) perceived their training in EP as adequate and 91.0% wanted more. CONCLUSIONS: The FMR report EP is important, but they do not feel sufficiently prepared to provide EP. In future curriculum development, medical educators should consider residents' low knowledge, competence, perceived program support, and expressed desire for more training in exercise prescription.

title: ARIA 2016: Pathways of care applying emerging technologies for predictive medicine in rhinitis and asthma across the lifecycle
abstract: The Allergic Rhinitis and Its Impact on Asthma (ARIA) initiative started in 1999 during a World Health Organization workshop. The initial goals were (1) to propose a new classification of allergic rhinitis and (2) to promote the concept of multiple morbidity in asthma. and rhinitis and (3) develop guidelines with all stakeholders that can be used globally for all countries and populations. ARIA—disseminated and implemented in more than 70 countries around the world—now focuses on the application of emerging technologies for individualized and predictive medicine. MASK [MACVIA (Contre les Maladies Chroniques pour un Vieillissement Active)-ARIA Sentinel NetworK] uses mobile technology to develop ways of care for the treatment of rhinitis and asthma by a multidisciplinary group and by patients themselves. An app (Android and iOS) is available in 20 countries and 15 languages. It uses a visual analog scale to evaluate symptom control and work productivity, as well as a clinical decision support system. It is associated with an interoperable tablet for doctors and other healthcare professionals. The scaling strategy uses the recommendations of the European Innovation Partnership on Active and Healthy Aging. The aim of the new ARIA approach is to provide rhinitis patients with an active and healthy life, regardless of age, gender or socio-economic status, in order to reduce health and social inequalities caused by the disease.

title: Arriba: effects of an educational intervention on prescribing behavior in CVD prevention in general practice
abstract: BACKGROUND: Evidence on the effectiveness of educational interventions in prescribing behavior change in the prevention of cardiovascular disease is still insufficient. We evaluated the effects of a brief educational intervention on prescribing hydroxymethylglutaryl-CoA reductase inhibitors (statins), platelet aggregation inhibitors (IPA), and antihypertensive agents (AH). DESIGN: Clustered randomized controlled trial with continuing medical education (CME) groups of general practitioners (GPs). METHODS: Statins, IPA, and AH prescriptions were validated before study entry (BL), immediately after index consultation (IC), and at 6 months follow-up (FU). Prescribing in high-risk patients (>15% cardiovascular event risk at 10 years according to the Framingham equation) and non-prescribing in low-risk patients (</= 15%) were considered appropriate. RESULTS: Prescribing interference effect can be found only for IPA. Overall, changes in prescription over time were all directed towards higher prescription rates and persisted FU regardless of risk status and group allocation. CONCLUSIONS: Active implementation of a brief evidence-based educational intervention on global risk in CVD did not directly result in risk-adjusted changes in prescription. Research over an extended time scale will reveal whether such decision support can improve prescribing in a risk-adjusted sustainable way.

title: Articles on Diagnostic Tests: A New Series and Invitation to Writers
Evaluation of the availability of scientific journals, databases and health library services in Canadian ministries of health: a cross-sectional study.
abstract: Background Evidence-based health policy-making logically depends on timely access to research evidence. To our knowledge, there are no studies addressing the availability of peer-reviewed research in Canadian ministries of health, despite significant political and societal pressure to improve the use of the best available research evidence in public health policy and program decision-making. Objectives To assess the availability of (1) high-ranking scholarly journals in fourteen Canadian ministries of health, (2) bibliographic databases, and (3) a purpose-built sample of health library services. Methods Between May and October 2011, we conducted a cross-sectional survey among librarians employed by Canadian health ministries to gather information on the availability of scholarly journals, bibliographic databases, and health library services. Availability of scientific journals in each ministry was determined using a sample of 48 journals selected from the 2009 Journal Citation Reports (Sciences and Social Sciences Editions). The selection criteria were: health policy based on coverage grade information on subject categories and journal popularity based on impact factors. Results We found that the majority of Canadian ministries of health do not have subscription access to major journals and rely heavily on interlibrary loans. Overall, based on a sample of highly ranked scholarly journals, the availability of journals through interlibrary loan, online, and print-only subscriptions were estimated at 63%, 28%, and 3%, respectively. Health Canada had 2.3 times more magazine subscriptions than the average for state ministries. Most organizations have access to multiple discipline-specific and multi-disciplinary databases. Many organizations have access to library resources disclosed through library partnerships or consortia. Four of the fourteen Canadian ministries of health (i.e. Manitoba Health, Northwest Territories Department of Health and Social Services, Nunavut Department of Health and Social Services, and Yukon Department of Health and Social Services) failed to find a professionally managed health library setting. Conclusions There is disparity in the availability of peer-reviewed research across fourteen Canadian ministries of health. This inequality can be a problem, as each province and territory is responsible for formulating and implementing evidence-based health policies and services for the benefit of its own population.

title: Evaluation of the impact of national guidelines in the management of children hospitalized for acute bronchiolitis
abstract: BACKGROUND: Acute bronchiolitis is a common disease with annual hospitalizations amounting to $500 million. Despite the frequency of bronchiolitis, its diagnosis and treatment are variable. To address this variability, the American Academy of Pediatrics (AAP) published an evidence-based practice management guideline for bronchiolitis in 2006. OBJECTIVE: Evaluate changes in physician behavior in the management of bronchiolitis before and after the publication of the 2006 AAP bronchiolitis guideline. METHODS: A retrospective chart review was performed in two academic medical centers of children younger than 24 months old admitted to the hospital with the diagnosis of primary or secondary bronchiolitis discharge. Pre-guideline charts were collected from 2004 to 2005 and post-guideline charts from 2007 to 2008. Evaluation and therapeutic interventions before and during hospitalization were analyzed. Data were analyzed using chi-square analysis for categorical variables and Mann-Whitney test for continuous variables. RESULTS: One thousand two hundred thirty-three patients met the inclusion criteria. Diagnostic laboratory testing rates did not decline after the guideline was published. The number of chest X-rays obtained decreased from 72.9% to 66.7% after guidelines (P = 0.02). Fewer children received a trial of racemic epinephrine (17.8% vs. 12.2%, P = 0.006) or albuterol (81.6% vs. 72.6%, P < 0.0001) after guidelines, and physicians more frequently reported ineffectiveness postoperatively. They stopped albuterol. -rules period (78.9% vs. 28.6%, P < 0.0001). Corticosteroid use decreased after guidelines in children without a history of RAD or asthma (17.5% versus 26.5%, P < 0.0001). CONCLUSIONS: Modest change in physician behavior was seen in the inpatient treatment of bronchiolitis after the guidelines. Additional healthcare provider education and training is warranted to reduce unnecessary interventions and use of healthcare resources.

title: As usual evaluation of treatment provided to control groups in adjustment trials: An investigation of the use of an open-ended questionnaire to identify behavior change techniques.
abstract: OBJECTIVE: Reporting guidelines require definitions of control group support in equal detail as for interventions. However, it remains unclear how to evaluate the active ingredient of the usual treatment (TAU) given to control groups in trials (behavior modification techniques (BCTs)). The aim of this study is to pretest a method for assessing TAU in a multicenter cost-effectiveness trial of an HIV adherence intervention. DESIGN: HIV nurses (N = 21) completed a semi-structured open-ended questionnaire asking TAU about compliance counseling. The two encoders independently encoded the BCTs. MAIN OUTCOME MEASURES: The completeness and clarity of nurse responses, intercoder reliability, and the type of BCTs reported were examined. RESULTS: The clarity and completeness of nurse responses were sufficient. Twenty-three of the 26 identified BCTs could be reliably coded (mean kappa = .79";" mean agreement rate = 96%), and three BCTs scored below kappa = .60. The total number of BCTs reported per nurse ranged from 7 to 19 (Mean = 13.86, SD = 3.35). CONCLUSIONS: This study demonstrates that the TAU open-ended questionnaire is a viable and reliable tool to capture the context of active support provided to control participants in a multicenter compliance intervention trial. Significant variability was observed in the number of BCTs provided to control patients, demonstrating the importance of reliably recruiting and accurately reporting control group support.

title: Evaluation and lifestyle management of patients with obesity: clinical recommendations from systematic reviews
abstract: IMPORTANCE: Although one-third of US adults are obese, diagnosis and treatment rates for obesity remain low. Clinician involvement is vital to provide guidance and assistance to patients who are overweight or obese to address the underlying cause of many chronic diseases. OBJECTIVES: To describe current best practices for obesity assessment and lifestyle management and to demonstrate how the Updated Guidelines for Managing Overweight and Obesity in Adults (2013) are based on a systematic review of evidence supported by the National Heart, Lung, and Blood Institute (NHLBI). ) may be administered to an individual patient. EVIDENCE REVIEW: A systematic review of evidence for the Adult Guide to Managing Overweight and Obesity (2013) supports treatment recommendations in 5 areas (risk assessment, benefits of weight loss, diets for weight loss, comprehensive lifestyle intervention approaches, and bariatric surgery)"; Recommendations for fields outside of Bariatric Physicians are supported by other guidelines (for obesity, the 1998 NHLBI-sponsored obesity guidelines and those from Canadian and US professional associations such as the National Center for Health and Clinical Excellence and the American Association of Clinical Endocrinologists and the American Association of Bariatric Physicians; for physical activity recommendations , 2008 Physical Activity Guidelines for Americans); a PubMed study identified recent systematic reviews covering depression and obesity, motivational interviewing for weight management, metabolic adaptation to weight loss, and obesity pharmacotherapy step in obesity management. is to scan in terms of beziness. A medical history should be taken assessing multiple determinants of obesity, including diet and physical activity patterns, psychosocial factors, weight gain medications, and familial characteristics. Emphasizing the complications of obesity to identify patients who will benefit most from treatment is more helpful than using body mass index (calculated in Kilograms divided by height squared height) alone for treatment decisions. Guidelines (2013) recommend that clinicians offer intensive, multi-component behavioral intervention to patients who would benefit from weight loss (either with or without comorbidities BMI >/=30 or >/=25 and 1 comorbidity or risk factor). Some clinicians do this within their primary care practice; “others refer patients for these services. Weight loss is achieved by creating a negative energy balance through modification of food and physical activity behaviors. Guidelines (2013) support comprehensive lifestyle therapy with intensive intervention. Treatment is available in a clinician's office or to a registered dietitian or commercial weight Weight loss of 5% to 10% is the usual goal. Patients need not have a body mass index of less than 25 to 25. RESULTS AND RELIABILITY: Screening and evaluation of patients for obesity followed by initiation or referral of treatment primary care To achieve and maintain modest weight loss, they will address the underlying driving force of many komo rbidities and can have a major impact on the health status of patients.

title: Evaluation of a remote collaborative program for the treatment of depression in primary care
abstract: BACKGROUND: Primary care teams play an important role in the treatment of depression, whose effectiveness is enhanced when incorporated into a collaborative disease management model. OBJECTIVE: To report the results of a clinical trial conducted to test the effectiveness of a joint program supported by an electronic platform between primary care teams and specialists. MATERIALS AND METHODS: Doctors from four community hospitals belonging to the Reloncavi Health Service network recruited 81 depressed patients aged 37 to 43, 84% of whom were women. Participants were divided into an active group participating in the joint program and a control group receiving usual care, according to the Department of Health's Depression Guidelines. The main outcome was the Beck Depression Inventory (BDI-I) score at three months of intervention. RESULTS: Participants had a mean score of 29.6 (95% CI: 27.6-31.6) on the BDI-I, and 38% had a high risk of suicide. There were no statistically significant baseline differences between the active and control groups. In the intervention group, the BDI-I score changed from 30.0 (95% CI 27.0 to 32.8) to 15.3 (95% CI 11.8 to 18.8). In the control group, the score changed from 29.2 (95% CI: 26.4-31.9) to 20.8 (95% CI 16.8 to 24.7). The reduction was significantly higher in the intervention groups. CONCLUSIONS: This type of program could be useful for assisting primary care teams in remote areas of the country to improve the outcomes of depression treatment.

title: Evaluation of a pay-for-performance program in primary care designed by target users.
abstract: Background: As financial incentives have increased over the past decade to influence the behavior of healthcare professionals to improve the quality of care, evidence for pay-for-performance (P4P) is sought. The efficacy of P4P is uncertain, although some reviews have reported significant effects. Purpose: To evaluate changes in performance after a participant initiates a P4P program. Design: An observational study with pre- and post-measurement. Setting and topics: Sixty-five general practices in the south of the Netherlands. Intervention: A targeted user-designed P4P program with indicators for chronic care, prevention, practice management, and patient experience (GP [GP] functioning and organization of care). Quality indicators were calculated for each application. A maximum bonus of €6890 per 1000 patients was determined by comparing the performance of the application with a benchmark. Key outcome measures: Quality indicators for clinical care (process and outcome) and patient experience. Results: We included 60 applications. After 1 year, significant improvement in process indicators was demonstrated for all chronic conditions, ranging from +7.9% improvement for cardiovascular risk management to +11.5% for asthma. Five outcome indicators improved significantly, as well as patients' experience with the GP's functioning and care organization. There were no significant improvements in the influenza vaccination rate and uptake of cervical cancer screening. Clinical process and outcome indicators and patient experience indicators were affected by baseline measures. Smaller apps showed more improvement. Conclusions: A participatory P4P program can promote quality improvement in clinical care and improve GP functioning and organization of care and patient experiences. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2016 APA, all rights reserved)

title: Evaluation of decision support for blood test ordering in primary care. a randomized trial
abstract: BACKGROUND: Different methods have proven effective in changing the behavior of requesting blood tests in primary care. However, randomized studies comparing these methods are lacking. OBJECTIVE: To compare the effect of two versions of BloodLink, a computer-based clinical decision support system, on blood test ordering among GPs. DESIGN: Randomized trial. SETTING: 44 GP practices in Delft, Netherlands. PARTICIPANTS: 60 GPs in 44 practices using computer-based patient records in their practice. INTERVENTION: After stratification with solo practices and group practices, apps were randomly assigned to use either the BloodLink-Restricted or the BloodLink-Guideline based on the Dutch College of General Practitioners' guidelines, which initially showed a reduced test list. MEASUREMENTS: Average number of blood tests ordered per order form per application. RESULTS: GPs using BloodLink-Guideline required 20% fewer tests on average than doctors using BloodLink-Restricted (mean [+/-SD], 5.5 +/- 0.9 tests, and 6.9 +/- 1.6 tests)" ;" P = 0.003, Mann-Whitney test). CONCLUSIONS: Guidelines-based decision support is more effective in changing blood test requesting behavior than decision support based on limited initial screening of tests. Guideline-based decision support systems can be effective in reducing the number of laboratory tests required by primary care practitioners.

title: Evaluation of the effects of radiological referral and computer-based guidelines on radiological requests in two emergency departments.
abstract: OBJECTIVE: To evaluate medical emergency radiology referral practice against a set of French guidelines and to measure the effectiveness of computer-based guidelines on unnecessary medical imaging. MATERIALS AND METHODS: All radiological requests were computerized in the medical emergency departments of two French teaching hospitals. During the control periods, radiological requests were recorded, but no action was taken. During the intervention periods, on-screen reminder displays indicate appropriate recommendations. Three control and three intervention periods of 1 month each were performed. The percentage of requests that did not comply with the guidelines and variations in control and intervention periods were measured. RESULTS: The rate of requests that do not comply with the guidelines was 33Â·2% when the guidelines were ineffective, and decreased to 26Â·9% when the recommendations were active (P < 0Â·0001). Three imaging studies (chest radiographs, plain abdominal radiographs, and CT of the brain) accounted for more than 80% of all requests"; more than 50% of requests for plain abdominal radiographs did not comply with recommendations, compared to 24Â·9, respectively. Chest radiographs and computerized brain % and 15Â·8 for tomography (CT). Seven conditions accounted for 70% of ineligible radiological referrals, in which cases the knowledge of young practitioners was insufficient. CONCLUSION: The effect of our intervention simultaneously with care, tailored to the needs of individual patients when giving computer advice However, our study identified several conditions responsible for most of the unnecessary radiological demands, and we hope this result may help clinicians and radiologists develop more specific actions for these conditions.Karton, M. et al. (2002).Clinical Radiology (2002)57 , 123–128.

title: Evaluation of self-harm in an accident and emergency room - development of a pro forma to assess suicidal intent and mental status in emergency room presenters with self-harm
abstract: INTRODUCTION: The United Kingdom has one of the highest rates of self-harm in Europe, with around 400 per 100,000 people (Horrocks et al. 2002). It is responsible for 150,000 visits to the Emergency department each year and is one of the top five reasons for acute medical admissions in the UK (NICE 2002). OBJECTIVES: Objectives including self-harm method and to investigate demographic factors of patients presenting to the Emergency department with self-harm. In addition, we wanted to investigate the suicide risk factors and suicidal intention by the emergency room doctor and, when deemed necessary, refer to the psychiatry services and investigate whether a psychiatric evaluation is performed with a full mental state examination. We wanted to explore current practice regarding self-harm presentations in the ER in accordance with NICE guidelines. METHODS: Data were collected retrospectively between February and August 2009. Twenty-five sets of medical notes were randomly compiled for patients presenting to the emergency department with self-harm. Notes were reviewed for event investigation, psychiatric evaluation, risk factors for suicide, and further referral. RESULTS: 14 of 25 patients presented with an overdose. 9 had caused another form of self-harm, namely, self-tearing. A mixed presentation was found in 2 cases. Prior psychiatric history was documented in 16 cases. 11 of them had a previous history of depression or anxiety disorder", 1 was known to have bipolar mood disorder, 1 had a previous diagnosis of borderline personality disorder and 3 patients had no previous history. No previous history was documented in 9 cases. DISCUSSION : Twenty-five sets of medical notes were reviewed for individuals presenting to the emergency department with self-harm between February and August 2009. Of these, 12 were over 25 years old, 17 were female, and 8 were male. The majority of patients were of white British ethnicity. 14 had overdosed; 9 had otherwise self-harmed;" and 2 of them gave a mixed presentation. Suicidal risk factors and suicidal intent were poorly documented by mental state examination, which was undocumented in all 25 cases reviewed. Eighteen of them were deemed medically fit in the emergency room and were referred for psychiatric examination. These unfortunate findings may be a reflection of the time pressure faced by ED doctors, namely the lack of adequate training in four-hour targets and perhaps psychosocial risk assessment. With such poor documentation by emergency room doctors, a pro forma was produced that included an assessment of suicide risk factors and suicidal intent, in addition to a short version of the mental state examination. CONCLUSION: The Royal College of Psychiatrists' latest report on self-harm has raised concerns that the current level of care provided to service users, with inadequate assessments, unskilled staff and inadequate means of care, remains below the standards set in policies and guidelines (Royal College of Psychiatrists. Report CR 158). .2010). Indeed, evidence indicates that appropriate training and intervention given to A&E personnel can lead to improvements in the quality of the psychosocial assessment of patients who intentionally self-harm (Crawford et al. 1998).

title: Evaluation of the potential effect of a reminder system on reducing diagnostic errors: a quasi-experimental study.
abstract: Background Computerized decision support systems (DSS) are mainly focused on improving the diagnostic accuracy of clinicians in unusual and challenging situations. However, as diagnostic omission errors can predominantly result from incomplete studies in routine clinical practice, providing appropriate patient and context-specific reminders may result in a greater impact on patient safety. In this experimental study, a mix of easy and hard simulated cases was used to evaluate the impact of a new diagnostic reminder system (ISABEL) on the quality of clinical decisions made by clinicians of varying degrees during acute assessment. Methods Subjects of varying degrees (counselors, registrants, senior home clerks, and medical students) evaluated a balanced set of 24 simulated cases on a trial website. Subjects recorded their clinical decisions (differential diagnosis, test ordering, and treatment) for the cases before and after the systems consultation. A panel of two pediatric counselors independently provided gold standard responses for each case in which the quality of subjects' decisions was measured. The primary outcome measure was the change in the number of diagnostic omission errors (DEO). A more precise assessment of the system's impact was obtained using specific quality scores"; additional consultation time resulting from the use of KDS was also calculated. Results 76 subjects (18 counselors, 24 registrants, 19 senior housekeepers, and 15 students) completed a total of 751 cases. sections. The mean number of DEOs decreased from 5.5 to 5.0 in all subjects (repeated measures ANOVA, p < 0.001), no significant interaction with subject grade. The mean diagnostic quality score increased after system counseling (0.044; 95% confidence interval 0.032, 0.054). ISABEL reminded subjects to consider at least one clinically significant diagnosis in 1 out of 8 cases and asked them to order a major test in 1 out of 10 cases. The median extra time for DSS consultation was 1 minute (IQR: 30 seconds to 2 minutes). Conclusion The provision of patient- and context-specific reminders has the potential to reduce diagnostic deficits at all course grades for a number of cases. This study suggests a promising role for future use of reminder-based DSS in reducing diagnostic error.

title: The Relationship Between Academic Medical Center Drug Detailing Policies and Doctor Prescribing
abstract: In an effort to regulate physicians' conflicts of interest, some U.S. academic medical centers (AMCs) enacted policies restricting drug representative sales (known as detailing) to physicians between 2006 and 2012. Little is known about the impact of these policies on doctor prescribing. . The aim is to analyze the relationship between the detailed policies enacted in AMCs and the doctor's prescription of actively detailed and non-detailed drugs. Design, Setting, and Participants The study used multivariate regression analysis of difference in differences to compare changes in prescribing by physicians before and after the implementation of detailing policies in AMCs in 5 states (California, Illinois, Massachusetts, Pennsylvania, and New York). formed the intervention group with changes in prescribing by a matched control group of similar physicians who were not subject to a detailed policy. Exposures Academic medical center implementation of policies governing the pharmaceutical salesperson's visits to relevant physicians. Key Outcomes and Precautions Intra-pharmaceutical market share of prescriptions written by a single physician for detailed and non-detailed drugs in 8 drug classes (approved for lipid-lowering drugs, gastroesophageal reflux disease drugs, diabetes drugs, antihypertensive drugs, hypnotic drugs) is 10 before the implementation of monthly detailing policies. - Comparison of the 36-month period with the 12-36-month period after administration, treatment of insomnia [sleeping medications], attention-deficit/hyperactivity disorder medications, antidepressant drugs, and antipsychotic drugs), depending on data availability. Results The analysis included 16?121?483 prescriptions written by 2126 specialist physicians and 24?593 matched control group physicians in 19 intervention group AMCs between January 2006 and June 2012. The sample mean market share at the physician-drug-month level for detailed and non-detailed drugs prior to the entry into force of the policies was 19.3% and 14.2%, respectively. Exposure to an AMC detailing policy was associated with an increase in market share of 1.67 percentage points (95% CI, ?2.18 to ?1.18 points"; P?<?.001) for detailed drugs. Undetailed 0.84% percentage points ratio of drugs (95% CI, 0.54 to 1.14 points; P?<?.001) Associations were statistically significant for 6 of the 8 study drug classes for detailed drugs (lipid-lowering drugs, gastroesophageal reflux disease drugs). antihypertensive drugs, sleep aids, attention-deficit/hyperactivity disorder drugs, and antidepressant drugs) and for 9 out of 19 AMCs enforcing policies, 11 of 19 AMCs arranged salesperson gifts to doctors, restricted salesperson access to facilities, and explicitly included Enforcement mechanisms There was a significant change in prescribing for 8 of these 11 AMCs In contrast, there was a significant change in only 1 out of 8 AMCs that did not implement policy in all 3 areas e AMCs between 2006 and 2012 implementation of policies restricting pharmaceutical detailing was associated with modest but significant reductions in prescribing of detail drugs in 6 of 8 major drug classes; however, no change was seen in all AMCs enforcing policies.

title: Association between Efavirenz as Initial Treatment for HIV-1 Infection and Increased Risk of Suicidal Ideas or Suicide Attempts or Completed Suicide
abstract: Background The association between efavirenz use and suicidality is not well defined. Objective Compare time to suicide with efavirenz-containing and non-efavirenz antiretroviral regimens for initial treatment of HIV. Design Participant-level data were analyzed from four AIDS Clinical Trials Group (ACTG) antiretroviral-naive studies conducted from 2001 to 2010. In each study, participants were randomly assigned to either an efavirenz-containing (n=3241) or no efavirenz group. regimen (n=2091). Adjustment of ACTG sites"; 74% registered in the United States. Patients Antiretroviral inexperienced participants. Intervention Efavirenz and efavirenz-free regimens. Measures Suicide was defined as suicidal ideation, suicide attempt, or completed suicide. Groups were compared with a hazard ratio ( HR ) and the 95% confidence interval (CI) estimated from a Cox model classified by the study. 73% of the results were male, the median age was 37 years; 32% had documented psychiatric history or had taken psychoactive medication within 30 days of starting the study. Median follow-up was 96 weeks. The incidence of suicides per 1000 person-years was 8.08 (47 events) in the efavirenz group and 3.66 (15 events) in the efavirenz-free group, HR: 2.28 (95% CI: 1.27 to 4.10, p=0.006). The incidence of suicide attempt or completed suicide was 2.90 (17 events) and 1.22 (5 events) in the efavirenz and efavirenz-free groups, respectively, HR: 2.58 (95% CI: 0.94 to 7.06, p= 0.065). Eight suicide deaths were reported in the efavirenz group and one in the efavirenz-free group. Limitations There was no standardized questionnaire regarding suicidal ideation or attempt. Efavirenz was open-label in three of the four studies. Results Initial treatment with an efavirenz-containing antiretroviral regimen was associated with twice the risk of suicide compared to an efavirenz-free regimen. Keywords: efavirenz, suicide, suicidal ideation, suicidal behavior, HIV, adverse event, psychiatry

title: Association of a Low-Frequency Variant in HNF1A with Type 2 Diabetes in the Latino Population
abstract: Importance Latino populations have one of the highest prevalences of type 2 diabetes worldwide. Objectives To investigate the association between rare protein-coding genetic variants and the prevalence of type 2 diabetes in a large Latino population and to explore potential molecular and physiological mechanisms for the observed associations. Design, Placement and Participants Whole exome sequencing was performed on DNA samples from 3756 Mexican and US Latino individuals (1794 with type 2 diabetes and 1962 without diabetes) recruited from 1993 to 2013. Type 2 diabetes in large multiethnic datasets of 14?276 participants characterized by experimental analysis. Main Conclusion and Measures Prevalence of type 2 diabetes. Secondary outcomes included age at onset, body mass index, and effect on protein function. Results A single rare missense variant (c.1522G>A [p.E508K]) was associated with the prevalence of type 2 diabetes (odds ratio [OR], 5.48"; 95% CI, 2.83-10.61; P?=?4.4?Â ¡Ã ?10?7) in hepatocyte nuclear factor 1-Â¦Ã (HNF1A), the gene responsible for maturity-onset diabetes of the young type 3 (MODY3), this variant was found in 0.36% of participants without type 2 diabetes and 2.1% of Participants. In multiethnic replication datasets, the p.E508K variant was seen only in Latino patients (n?=?1443 with type 2 diabetes and 1673 without diabetes) and was associated with type 2 diabetes (OR, 4.16 95% CI, 1.75-9.92;"P) ?=?.0013). In experimental experiments, the HNF-1A protein encoding the p.E508K mutant showed reduced transactivation activity of its target promoter compared to a wild-type protein. In our data, carriers and non-carriers of the p.E508K mutation with type 2 diabetes did not show significant differences in the clinical features compared, including age of onset. The mean (SD) age for carriers was 45.3 (11.2) and 47.5 (11.5) for non-carriers (P?=?.49), and the mean (SD) BMI for carriers was 28.2 (5.5) and 29.3 (5.3). non-carriers (P?=?.19). Results and Relevance Using whole-exome sequencing, we identified a single low-frequency variant in the MODY3-causing gene, HNF1A, that is associated with type 2 diabetes in Latino populations and may affect protein function. This finding may have implications for screening and therapeutic modification in this population, but additional studies are needed.

title: Association of Combatant Status and Sexual Violence with Health and Mental Health Outcomes in Post-Conflict Liberia
abstract: Context Liberia's wars since 1989 have claimed tens of thousands of lives and traumatized many people mentally and physically. Objectives To assess the prevalence and impact of war-related psychosocial trauma, including information on participation in the Liberian civil wars, exposure to sexual violence, social functioning, and mental health. Design, Environment, and Participants A cross-sectional, population-based, multistage randomized cluster study of 1666 adults aged 18 and over using structured interviews and questionnaires over a 3-week period in Liberia in May 2008. Key Outcome Measures Signs of major depressive disorder (MDD) and post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD), social functioning, exposure to sexual violence, and health and mental health needs among Liberian adults who have witnessed or participated in conflicts over the past 20 years. Results In the Liberian adult householdÂ¨C-based population, 40% (95% CI [CI], 36%-45%"; n = 672/1659) met symptom criteria for MDD, 44% (95% CI, 38%) - 49%; n = 718/1661) met symptom criteria for PTSD, and 8% (95% CI, 5-10%; n = 133/1666) met criteria for social dysfunction. Thirty-three percent (549/1666) of respondents ) reported serving in the fighting forces, and 33.2% of ex-combatants (182/549) were women. Former combatants experienced higher rates of sexual violence than non-combatants: among women, 42.3% (95% CI, 35.4%) vs. 49.1) vs 9.2% (95% CI, 6.7-11.7%); among men, 32.6% (95% CI, 27.6%-37.6%) vs. 7.4% (95% CI, 4.5-10.4%) ) PTSD, MDD, and Rates of suicidal ideation symptoms were higher among ex-combatants than non-combatants and survivors of sexual violence than non-experts. Prevalence of PTSD symptoms among former female combatants who have experienced sexual violence (74%; 95% CI, 63%-84%), not exposed to sexual violence (44%; 95% CI, 33%-53%). The prevalence of PTSD symptoms among male ex-combatants who experienced sexual violence was higher (81%; 95% CI, 74-87%) than male ex-combatants who were not victims of sexual violence (46%; 95% CI, 39). Former male combatants who have experienced sexual violence also reported higher rates of depression symptoms and suicidal ideation. Both former combatants and non-combatants experienced inadequate access to healthcare (33.0% [95% CI, 22.6%-43.4%] and 30.1% [95% CI, 18.7% vs. 41.6%, respectively.) Results Ex-combatants in Liberia were not only men. Ex-combatants, both male and female, who experienced sexual violence are referred to non-combatants and other ex-combatants. had worse mental health outcomes than not been exposed to sexual violence.

title: The Relationship of Socioeconomic Position with Health Behaviors and Mortality
abstract: Context Previous studies may have underestimated the contribution of health behaviors to social inequalities in mortality because health behaviors were evaluated only at the start of the study. Purpose To examine the role of health behaviors in the relationship between socioeconomic status and mortality and to compare whether their contribution, when assessed at only 1 point in time, differs from that assessed longitudinally over the follow-up period. Design, Environment and Participants The British Whitehall II longitudinal cohort study, established in 1985, included 10308 civil servants aged 35 to 55 living in London, England. Analyzes are based on 9590 men and women followed for mortality through April 30, 2009. Socioeconomic position was originally derived from civil service employment grade (high, medium and low). Smoking, alcohol consumption, diet and physical activity were evaluated 4 times during the follow-up period. Key Outcome Measures All-cause and cause-specific death rate. Results A total of 654 participants died during the follow-up period. In analyzes adjusted for sex and year of birth, those with the lowest socioeconomic status were found to be 1.60 times more likely to die from all causes (a ratio difference of 1.94/1000 person-years) than those with the highest socioeconomic status. This association was weakened by 42% (95% confidence interval [CI], 21-94%) when the health behaviors evaluated at baseline were included in the model, and 72% (95% CI, 42-154%) when entered into the model. entered as time-dependent variables. The corresponding attenuations were 29% (95% CI, 11-54%) and 45% (95% CI, 24-79%) and 61% (95% CI, 16-425%) and 94% for cardiovascular mortality. % (95% CI, 35%–595%) for non-cancer and non-cardiovascular mortality. The difference between only baseline and repeated assessments of health behaviors is mostly due to the increased explanatory power of diet (7% to 17% for all-cause deaths, respectively), physical activity (5% to 21% for all deaths). causes death) and alcohol consumption (3% to 12% for all-cause mortality). The role of smoking, the strongest mediator, in these analyzes did not change when baseline or repeat assessments were used (from 32% to 35% for all-cause mortality). Conclusion In a public service population in London, England, there was an association between socioeconomic status and mortality, which was largely explained by adjustments for health behaviors, particularly when behaviors were repeatedly evaluated.

title: Asthma education program in Russia: educating patients
abstract: To address the recent increase in asthma morbidity and mortality in Russia, an intervention study was conducted to improve the diagnosis, treatment and prevention of asthma. US recommendations on asthma management have been adapted for use in the education of families with children with asthma in Moscow. Two hundred and fifty-two children with asthma aged 4-14 years receiving health care with their parents in eight public health clinics in Moscow were recruited to see if teaching guidelines for the management of asthma in the USA would be acceptable and effective in Russia. Children with a recent asthma attack in four of the clinics were randomly assigned to the education or control group to test whether patient education and guided asthma care would improve outcomes for patients. Both groups were offered modern drugs to see if education was required in US guidelines for getting doctors to use the drugs. Children with recent asthma attacks at the other four clinics were defined as comparison group 1 to control for the possible impact of drug availability. All children without an asthma attack at eight clinics formed comparison group 2 to see if outcomes for these children would change over time. One-year follow-up results showed significant improvement in children's and parents' asthma self-management skills in terms of asthma management among those in the education-only group. Significant increases were observed in the subgroup of children in the education group using anti-inflammatory drugs for asthma control. Children in the training group had significantly increased peak flow rates and reduced daily peak flow variability, compared with the control and comparison groups. Compared to the control group, the children had a significantly greater reduction in doctor visits by the education group. Changes in parents' and children's behavior in terms of asthma management and prevention skills, proper treatment of the disease, and access to medications are likely responsible for reducing asthma morbidity in children.

title: Attitudes towards reproduction in Latin America. Teachings from the use of modern reproductive technologies
abstract: The use of modern reproductive technology, such as in vitro fertilization and related procedures, has opened up new areas of legal, religious and public interest. Thirty years ago, the development of effective methods to control reproduction sparked a debate over whether couples had the right to enjoy sex in the absence of reproductive influence. Today, assisted reproductive technology (ART) allows couples to have children of their own without direct sex. The Catholic Church reacted to both birth control and ART, and specific instructions were given to the public, the medical profession, and legislators. In a recent survey, 88.4% of the population in Latin America claims to be Catholic";" therefore, bioethical considerations and legal implications for intervention in reproduction are strongly permeated by the moral teachings of Catholicism. In 1996, 83 medical doctors and scientists who joined the Latin American Network of Assisted Reproduction prepared a consensus document on the ethical aspects and legal implications of ART. The document contains the minimum ethical guidelines that Latin American professionals have decided to abide by even in the absence of regulations. This article examines how the medical profession, legislators, and the public respond to religious influence when faced with difficult bioethical decisions such as reproductive right.

title: Supervision and feedback as clinical practice guideline implementation strategy: a model for acute care nurse practitioners.
abstract: BACKGROUND: Putting research evidence into practice and changing provider behavior is challenging, even if the benefits are strong. Despite the availability of supportive care clinical practice guidelines (CPG), consistent integration of these principles into practice has not been achieved. Failure of dissemination strategies has been identified as a major barrier to successful implementation. A potentially effective approach to facilitating the transfer of research evidence to practice is auditing and feedback. Audit and feedback is a summary of provider performance over a period of time, with or without suggestions to improve the application. Rationale: Cancer pain is the most appropriate symptom to study when examining the impact of a control and feedback intervention. It is a common condition with significant consequences, established CPG is available, measurable results have been described and there is potential for improvement in current practice. Acute care nurses (NPs) are often responsible for supervising and directly managing symptoms such as pain and are in a good position to practice CPG and examine the effects of adherence to guidelines on patients' pain outcomes. METHODOLOGY: A systematic review of published articles, MEDLINE, Cumulative Index to Nursing and Allied Health Literature, and the Cochrane Library computerized databases, was conducted to assess the state of science on auditing and feedback as a professional practice change strategy. A behavior change model has been proposed for application to advanced nursing practice. APPLICATIONS FOR IMPLEMENTATION: Regarded as a valuable intervention to improve healthcare quality in medicine, supervision and feedback is a strategy that has not been widely studied in nursing. Although cancer pain cannot always be completely eliminated, appropriate use of available treatments can effectively reduce pain in the majority of patients. This article is a review of the literature on supervision and feedback as a professional practice change strategy and shows a model for operationalizing the intervention.

title: Supervision and feedback: implications for professional practice and health care outcomes
abstract: BACKGROUND: Supervision and feedback continue to be widely used as a strategy to improve professional practice. Given feedback that their clinical practice is inconsistent with that of their peers or accepted guidelines, it seems reasonable to ask healthcare professionals to change their practice. However, supervision and feedback have not been found to be consistently effective. OBJECTIVES: To evaluate the effects of supervision and feedback on healthcare professional practice and patient outcomes. SEARCH STRATEGY: We searched the Care Group Cochrane Register of Effective Practice and Organization and its pending file until January 2004. SELECTION CRITERIA: Objectively reported randomized audit and feedback trials (defined as any summary of clinical performance over a period of time) Professional practice as measured in a healthcare setting or health outcomes. DATA COLLECTION AND ANALYSIS: Two reviewers independently extracted data and evaluated study quality. Quantitative (meta-regression), visual and qualitative analyzes were performed. We calculated the risk difference (RD) and hazard ratio (RR) for each comparison, adjusted for baseline fit where possible, adjusted for dual outcomes, and percentage and percentage change from control group mean after intervention adjusted for baseline performance. for possible, lasting results. We explored the following factors as possible explanations for variation in the effectiveness of interventions between comparisons: type of intervention (supervision and feedback only, supervision and feedback with training sessions, or multiple interventions involving supervision and feedback), intensity of the intervention. supervision and feedback, the complexity of the intended behavior, the severity of the result, the basic compliance and quality of work. MAIN RESULTS: Thirty new studies have been added to this update, with a total of 118 studies included. The primary analysis included 88 comparisons from 72 studies that compared any intervention in which supervision and feedback were a component with those without interventions. For dual outcomes, adjusted risk difference of adherence to desired application - 0.16 (16% absolute decrease in compliance) to 0.70 (70% increase in compliance) (median = 0.05, interquartile range = 0.03 to 0.11) and the adjusted hazard ratio ranged from 0.71 to 18.3 (median = 1.08, interquartile range = 0.99 to 1.30). For sustained results, the adjusted percent change from control ranged from -0.10 (10% absolute decrease in agreement) to 0.68 (68% increase in agreement) (median = 0.16, interquartile range = 0.05 to 0.37) has changed. Low baseline adherence to recommended practice and higher intensity of supervision and feedback were associated with greater adjusted risk ratios (higher efficacy) across studies. AUTHORS' CONCLUSIONS: Supervision and feedback can be effective in improving professional practice. When effective, the effects are usually minor to moderate. The relative effectiveness of supervision and feedback is likely to be greater when baseline adherence to proposed practice is low and feedback is given more intensively.

title: Supervision of a tuberculosis contact tracing clinic
abstract: OBJECTIVE To determine the effectiveness of tuberculosis contact tracing in South Glamorgan 1987-9. DESIGN Review of contact tracing clinic records and data from the Mycobacterium Reference Unit. The practice of the clinic was compared with the 1983 British Thoracic Society recommendations. ADJUST Health authority tuberculosis control program. MAIN OUTCOME MEASURES Ratio of contacts screened, follow-up participation rates, number of secondary cases detected and quality of record keeping. RESULTS 101 index patients and 611 contacts were identified. 596 (97.5%) contacts were screened, of which 139 should not have been screened. Of the 356 contacts who required the Heaf test, 237 were tested, seven refused the test, and 112 had chest radiographs without the Heaf test. 95 people were unnecessarily tested. Unnecessary chest X-rays were performed on 87 contacts, and seven of them should have had radiographs, but they were not done. 34 people were inappropriately given follow-up appointments and seven were ignored for follow-up. Five asymptomatic contacts were diagnosed with tuberculosis, all at initial screening and in all close contacts of index patients with pulmonary disease. CONCLUSION Insufficient data, non-compliance with contact tracing guidelines, and failure to define the term highly contagious index case resulted in unnecessary screening or monitoring of many contacts. PRACTICES The efficiency of tracking contacts can be improved by specifying the ethnic origin and spillover results of the index case in the reporting form, clearly classifying contacts as proximal or causal, and clearly defining the term highly contagious.

title: Australian and New Zealand clinical practice guidelines for the treatment of depression
abstract: BACKGROUND: The Royal College of Psychiatrists of Australia and New Zealand (RANZCP) coordinates the development of clinical practice guidelines (CPGs) in psychiatry funded by the National Mental Health Strategy (Australia) and the New Zealand Department of Health. METHODS: The CPG team reviewed the treatment outcome literature, consulted practitioners and patients, and conducted meta-analyses of the outcome research. TREATMENT RECOMMENDATIONS: Establish an effective therapeutic relationship"; inform patient of condition, rationale for treatment, probability of positive response and expected time; consider patient strengths, life stressors, and supports. The choice of treatment depends on the patient's condition. clinician's skills and patient's circumstances and In moderately severe depression, all recognized antidepressants, cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT) and interpersonal psychotherapy (IPT) are equally effective, with clinicians weighing the burdens of treatment as well as benefits, including side effects and toxicity. In severe depression, antidepressant treatment should precede psychological treatment. For psychotic depression, electroconvulsive therapy (ECT) or tricyclic with an antipsychotic is equally helpful. Treatments for other subtypes are discussed. For people taking other medications or have medical conditions. e should be careful. If response to an adequate first-line therapy trial is inadequate, another evidence-based therapy should be used. Second opinions are helpful. Depression has a high recurrence rate and efforts to reduce it are crucial.

title: Author disclosure of conflict of interest in vascular surgery journals
abstract: OBJECTIVES: Advances in vascular surgery are increasingly based on technology, and the relationships between surgeons and the medical device industry can be complex. This study is intended to suggest further directions by reviewing conflict of interest (COI) disclosure on several selected technology-driven topics, including endovascular stent grafts (EV), carotid artery stenting (CAS), and peripheral artery interventions (PI) in vascular surgery journals. METHODS: The authors' COI statements were reviewed from all clinical articles on three selected topics (EV, CAS, and PI) published in 2008 and 2009 in each of the six vascular surgery journals. COI disclosure rate was evaluated as a function of journal, subject, type of article (random search, case series, case report, review, or meta-analysis), and authors' region of origin. Second, the consistency of the authors' statements was evaluated by examining articles by the same author and on the same subject. RESULTS: Six hundred and thirty-five articles from six journals were reviewed. A COI was reported in 125 (19.7%) of these articles. This ratio differed between journals (range, 3.2%-34.1%"; P < .0001). Disclosure rate did not differ between subjects (range, 12.8%-21.2%; P = .12), type of article (range, .0001). 14.7%-30%; P = .28) or region of origin (range, 0-33.3%; "P = .09). There were 116 instances where the same author wrote articles describing the same general topic. The COI expression was consistent in most of these samples (72.4%), but inconsistent in 32 cases (27.6%). The most common (P = .006) discrepancies included the same type of article in different journals (46.9%) or in the same journal (25%). CONCLUSIONS: In the vascular surgery literature, discrepancies in CO disclosure and disclosure are at least partially due to differences in journal reporting policies, while a smaller proportion of these inconsistencies are due to individual author behavior. Journals should adopt a consistent requirement for a separate COI statement describing all relevant financial arrangements.

title: Authors response: hand washing is about respecting patients
Automatic hand hygiene monitoring with and without intervention
abstract: BACKGROUND: Daily feedback from continuous automated monitoring with peer reminder intervention was used to improve compliance. Compliance rates from invasive and non-intrusive covert and overt automated inspection stages were compared with mandatory human inspections. METHODS: An automated system was installed to covertly detect hand hygiene incidents each time the alcohol-based handrub dispenser was pressed for 5 months. The open phase involved key clinicians trained to share daily rates with clinicians, set compliance goals, and nudge each other to adhere for 6 months. For the next 6 months, the intervention continued without renewal. Australian Hand Hygiene (HHA) human inspections were conducted quarterly at the time of response in accordance with World Health Organization guidelines. Percentage point (PP) differences between the compliance rates were used to determine the change. RESULTS: HCA rates for June 2014 were 85% and 87% in medical and surgical wards, respectively. These rates were 55 PPs and 38 PPs, 30% and 49% higher, respectively, than the covert automation rates in the medical and surgical service in June 2014. In the intervention phase, mean compliance in the medical ward did not change from the covert rate, while the surgical service increased to 60% with 11 PPs compared to the covert phase. On average, compliance without renewal during intervention did not change in the medical ward, while the average rate decreased by 9 PPs in the surgical ward. RESULTS: Automation has provided a unique opportunity to respond to day-to-day rates, but compliance will return to pre-intervention levels once active intervention ends or human supervisors leave service unless clinicians are committed to change.

title: Automatic Identification of Postoperative Complications in the Electronic Medical Record Using Natural Language Processing
abstract: Context Currently most automated methods for identifying patient safety incidents are based on administrative data codes";" however, free text searches of electronic medical records may represent an additional surveillance approach. Purpose To evaluate a natural language processing search approach to identify postoperative surgical complications in a comprehensive electronic medical record. Design, Environment, and Patients Cross-sectional study of 2974 patients undergoing inpatient surgical procedures at 6 Gazi Health Administration (VHA) medical centers from 1999 to 2006. Main Outcome Measures Postoperative occurrences of acute renal failure requiring dialysis, deep vein thrombosis, pulmonary embolism Sepsis, pneumonia, or myocardial infarction identified by medical record review as part of the VA Surgical Quality Improvement Program.
