To identify these complications, we determined the sensitivity and specificity of the natural language processing approach and compared its performance with patient safety indicators using discharge coding information. Results The rate of postoperative events for each sample was 2% (39 of 1924) for acute renal failure requiring dialysis, 0.7% (2327 of 18) for pulmonary embolism, 1% (29 of 2327), 7% for deep vein thrombosis. ( 61/866) for sepsis, 16% (222/1405) pneumonia and 2% (1822/35) myocardial infarction. Natural language processing correctly identified 82% (95% confidence interval [CI], 67-91%) of acute renal failure cases and 38% (95% CI, 25%-54%) for patient safety indicators . Venous thromboembolism (59%, 95% CI, 44-72% vs 46%, 95% CI, 32-60%), pneumonia (64%, 95% CI, 58-70% vs 5%, 95% CI, %) 3-9) sepsis (89%, 95% CI, 78-94% - 34%, 95% CI, 24-47%) and postoperative myocardial infarction (91%), 95% CI, 78-97%) vs % 89, 95% CI, 74-96%). Both natural language processing and patient safety indicators were highly specific for these diagnoses. Conclusion Among patients undergoing inpatient surgical procedures at VA medical centers, natural language processing analysis of electronic medical records to identify postoperative complications had higher sensitivity and lower specificity compared to patient safety indicators based on discharge coding.

title: Availability and prescription practice of anti-malarial drugs in the private healthcare sector in Yemen
abstract: INTRODUCTION: Although the Yemeni government changed its national policy to treat malaria in November 2005 from chloroquine to combination drugs in the form of artesunate + sulfadoxine-pyrimethamine (SP) as first-line and lumefantrine + artemether as second-line therapy for uncomplicated malaria, clinicians in public and private healthcare settings continued to prescribe chloroquine because their knowledge of the new treatment policy was insufficient. METHODOLOGY: A nonrandomized trial of pre- and post-evaluation of education and reporting interventions on prescription behavior and availability of antimalarial drugs among private sector clinicians and pharmacists in three provinces in Yemen was conducted. RESULTS: Private sector clinicians adherence to new national guidelines for antimalarial drugs increased from 21% in the pre-intervention period to 38% after the artesunate + SP intervention was prescribed as first-line therapy. The prescription of lumefantrine + artemether as second-line anti-malarial therapy was also increased from 18% before the intervention to 22% after the intervention. Unfortunately, the halofantrine + SP combination continued to be frequently prescribed by clinicians in Sana'a (18%). Artesunate + SP and quinine significantly increase their marketing from 8% pre-intervention to 22% post-intervention (P-value 0.001). CONCLUSIONS: The study provides evidence of the usefulness of the educational intervention on national guidelines for malaria treatment. In addition, the inclusion of private healthcare providers in reporting procedures will support the rational prescribing and availability of antimalarial drugs.

title: Current screening tools for adults suffering from bipolar affective disorder in primary care: An integrative literature review
abstract: OBJECTIVE: To evaluate the effectiveness of six tools used in primary care for screening for bipolar affective disorder (BPAD). BPAH has historically been underdiagnosed or misdiagnosed, followed by inappropriate treatment, resulting in harmful relapses, suicide, and increased risks of comorbidity. DATA SOURCES: An electronic search was conducted to identify articles in the MEDLINE, CINAHL, Cochrane Library, ERIC, National Guideline Clearinghouse, PsycINFO, Psychology and Behavioral Sciences collection, and PsycARTICLES databases. Other information was also gathered from the NIH, CDC, Healthy People 2020, Black Dog Institute, and the Center for Quality Assessment and Development for Mental Health. CONCLUSION: Evidence suggests that primary care providers are often the first and sometimes the only providers, pointing to the importance of early detection and screening for BPAH in primary care. With the use of appropriate screening tools and the implementation of recommended treatment and intervention guidelines, relapse prevention is increased and comorbidities are diagnosed more frequently, leading to an overall improved quality of life. APPLICATIONS FOR PRACTICE: Primary care practitioners play a vital role in screening appropriately for BPAH and implementing recommended treatments to increase relapse prevention and promote a healthier and more socially successful quality of life.

title: Barriers and facilitators to the implementation of multiple stroke guideline recommendations: a qualitative study
abstract: BACKGROUND: Turning evidence into practice is an important final step in the evidence-based practice process. Medical record audits can be used to examine how well practice compares to published evidence and to identify evidence-practice gaps. After providing supervisory feedback to professionals, local barriers to practice change can be identified and targeted with focused behavior change interventions. This study aimed to identify barriers and facilitators in the implementation of multiple stroke guideline recommendations in an Australian stroke unit. METHODS: A qualitative methodology was used. A sample of 28 allied health, nursing and medical professionals participated in a group or individual interview. These interviews took place after staff received audit feedback and identified areas for practice change. Upper extremity sensory impairments, mobility including sitting balance"; vision; anxiety and depression; neglect; swallowing; communication; education for stroke survivors and caregivers; advice on return to work and qualitative data themes using theoretical areas described by Michie et al. (2005) RESULTS: Six group and two individual interviews involving six disciplines were conducted. The barriers differed between disciplines. The six main barriers identified were: (1) Beliefs about individual professionals' abilities and disciplines and patient abilities (2) Positive and negative implementation of recommendations Beliefs about outcomes (3) Memory and attention to best practices (4) Required knowledge and skills to apply best practice; (5) Intention and motivation to implement best practice; and (6) Resources. Some obstacles also brought about change. For example, occupational therapists needed new knowledge and skills (a disability) to better manage sensory and neglect disorders, while physical therapists often knew how to best implement mobility rehabilitation (an enabler). CONCLUSIONS: The findings add to the existing knowledge to modify and implement the multiple guideline recommendations. Major challenges included sex education and screening for depression. Limited knowledge and skills were a common barrier. Knowledge of specific interventions was required prior to administration and to maintain treatment accuracy. Providing detailed online intervention protocols and guidelines can help clinicians overcome the knowledge barrier.

title: Barriers and Facilitators Associated with the Use of Nonsurgical Treatment in Osteoarthritis Patients in Orthopedic Practice
abstract: INTRODUCTION: International evidence-based guidelines for the management of patients with hip and knee osteoarthritis (OA) recommend starting with nonsurgical treatments (a combination) and using surgical intervention only if a patient does not respond adequately to nonsurgical treatment. treatment options. Despite these recommendations, there are strong indications that nonsurgical treatments are not optimally used in orthopedic practice. To improve the adoption of nonsurgical treatments, more information is needed on the barriers and facilitators of these treatments. Therefore, this study evaluated what barriers and facilitators are associated with the use and prescribing of different non-surgical treatments before hip and knee OA in orthopedic practice among Dutch patients and orthopedic surgeons. MATERIALS AND METHODS: We conducted two internet-based surveys among 172 orthopedic surgeons and 174 OA patients. Univariate association and multivariate regression techniques are used to identify barriers and facilitators associated with the use of nonsurgical treatments. CONCLUSIONS: Most barriers and facilitators among patients were associated with use of physical therapy, lifestyle advice, and dietary therapy. Among orthopedic surgeons, most have been associated with acetaminophen prescription, diet therapy, and physical therapy. Examples of barriers and facilitators among patients include "People around me had positive experiences with a surgery" (facilitator for education about OA) and "Advice for people around me to keep moving" (facilitator for lifestyle and dietary advice). Examples for orthopedic surgeons were "Lack of knowledge about the guideline" (barrier for lifestyle advice), "Agreements/negotiations with primary care" and "Easy communication with dietitian" (facilitators for diet therapy). Also, belief in the effectiveness of these treatments was associated with increased prescription. CONCLUSIONS: Strategies to improve the use of nonsurgical therapy in orthopedic practice should aim to change the beliefs of orthopedic surgeons, communicate with other OA care providers, and involve the patient's environment in OA treatment.

title: Barriers and facilitators to the implementation of VA home primary care in American Indian reservations: a qualitative multiple case study.
abstract: Background Veterans Health Affairs (VA) home primary care (HBPC) is an evidence-based interdisciplinary approach to non-institutional long-term care developed in urban settings to provide longitudinal care for vulnerable elderly patients. Under the mandate of a Memorandum of Understanding between the VA and the Indian Health Service (IHS) to improve access to healthcare, 14 VA medical centers (VAMCs) independently initiated plans to expand their HBPC programs to rural Native American reservations, and 12 VAMCs successfully implemented programs. The purpose of this study is to identify barriers and facilitators to implementation in rural Indigenous communities in order to inform planners and policy makers for future program expansions. Methods A qualitative comparative case study approach was used, taking each of the 14 VAMCs as a case. Telephone interviews (n = 37) were conducted with HBPC staff and clinicians participating or supervising practice, and local/regional managers, using the Consolidated Framework for Practice Research (CFIR) to inform an open-ended interview guide. Interviews were transcribed, coded, and then analyzed using CFIR domains and structures to describe and compare experiences and identify facilitators, barriers, and adaptations that co-occurred in the VAMC and HBPC programs. The results differed significantly in local contexts across the VAMC. However, the practice was typically facilitated by key individuals who were able to build trust and belief in VA healthcare among American Indian communities. The policy promoted clinical collaboration, but collaborations were often ad hoc between VA and IHS clinicians to optimize patient resources. All programs required some adaptation to address barriers such as distances in rural areas, caseloads or delays in hiring additional clinicians. VA funding opportunities have facilitated the expansion and maintenance of these programs. Conclusions Since program expansion is the responsibility of the HBPC program director, there is little sharing of lessons learned at VA facilities. Shared learning opportunities will benefit federal health agencies to expand other medical services to additional American Indian communities and other rural and underserved communities, as well as to coordinate with other healthcare organizations. The CFIR framework was an effective analytical tool for comparing programs for multiple internal and external settings.

title: Barriers and facilitators to evidence-based practice in perinatal care in the SEA-ORCHID project
abstract: RATIONALE, OBJECTIVES AND OBJECTIVES: Optimizing Reproductive and Child Health in Developing Countries The Southeast Asia (SEA-ORCHID) project aimed to improve maternal and infant health outcomes at nine hospitals in Southeast Asia by supporting evidence-based perinatal health services. . In this study, we aimed to identify and explore factors that may have acted as barriers or enablers to evidence-based practice change in each of the hospitals. METHODS: Semi-structured, face-to-face interviews were conducted with 179 nurses, midwives, and doctors from the maternal and neonatal departments in each of the nine participating Southeast Asia during the last 6 months of the intervention phase of the project. hospitals. RESULTS: The interviews identified several factors that participants believed had a significant impact on the effectiveness of the SEA-ORCHID intervention. These; knowledge, skills, hierarchy, multidisciplinary and beliefs about leadership, outcomes, resources, and the nature of behavior. The success of the SEA-ORCHID intervention in improving implementation may reflect the extent to which tailor-made strategies have been effective in overcoming these barriers. CONCLUSION: Effective interventions to align practice with the evidence rely on identifying and addressing barriers to practice change. The barriers identified in this study may be beneficial for those designing similar clinical practice improvement projects, as well as for continued efforts to improve practice at SEA-ORCHID hospitals.

title: Barriers to breast and cervical cancer screening in underserved women of the District of Columbia
abstract: OBJECTIVES: Identifying barriers to breast and cervical cancer screening services from the perspective of medically underserved women in the District of Columbia (DC) and may influence their intentions to perform breast and cervical cancer screening behaviors"; between attitudes and cervical cancer screening behaviors identify any relationship. the influence of significant others on the intended behavior;" and to determine the relationship between the site where services are offered and the intentions of underserved women to participate in browsing behavior. DESIGN: Cross-sectional, relational. SETTING: Breast and cervical cancer screening clinics in DC. EXAMPLE: 339 medically underserved adult women. METHODS: Face-to-face interviews conducted by the researcher. MAIN RESEARCH VARIABLES: Attitudes and influence of key people as well as demographic and contextual variables. Intention to have a mammogram or Pap test, or an intention to have a monthly breast self-exam (BSE). RESULTS: Intention to have a mammogram was positively associated with the influence of important people and negatively with the caregiver health professionals. Intention to have a Pap test was positively correlated with one's attitude towards the test and the influence of significant others. Intention to perform BSE was positively associated with attitude and prior performance towards BSE, and the influence of significant others. No significant relationship was observed between the intention to perform screening behaviors and demographic variables. CONCLUSIONS: Factors affecting women's attitudes towards screening and their intention to perform these behaviors include previous screening behaviors, the influence of significant other people, and relationships with health professionals. APPLICATIONS FOR NURSING PRACTICE: Oncology nurses are well placed to develop and test intervention strategies designed to increase access to and compliance with recommended screening guidelines among medically underserved. Findings from this study could potentially guide the development and evaluation of such strategies sensitive to this particular population.

title: Barriers to the implementation of preconception care guidelines as perceived by general practitioners: a qualitative study
abstract: BACKGROUND: Despite strong evidence for the benefits of preconception interventions to improve pregnancy outcomes, the giving and taking of preconception care and periconceptional folate supplementation remains low. General practitioners play a central role in providing preconception care. Understanding general practitioners' perceptions of barriers and facilitators in the delivery of prenatal care allows for more appropriate targeting of quality improvement interventions. In conclusion, the aim of this study was to examine the barriers and facilitators to the delivery and receipt of pre-pregnancy care guidelines from the perspective of general practitioners, using theoretical fields related to behavior change. METHODS: We conducted a qualitative study using focus groups of 22 GPs recruited from three regional general practice support organisations. The questions were based on the theoretical domain framework that identified 12 domains related to behavior change. General practitioners' responses were classified into predefined themes using a deductive thematic analysis process. CONCLUSIONS: Capabilities, motivations and goals, environmental context and resources, and beliefs about memory, attention, and decision making are key areas identified in the barrier analysis. Some of the perceived barriers identified by GPs are time constraints, lack of women presenting in the prepregnancy stage, multiple competing preventive priorities in the general practice setting, problems with and cost of accessing preconception care, and problems with accessing preconception care. Resources to help provide pre-pregnancy care guidelines. Perceived facilitators identified by general practitioners included the availability of preconception care checklists and patient brochures, handbooks, and waiting room posters outlining the benefits and usability of preconception care consultations. CONCLUSIONS: Our study identified some of the barriers and facilitators to the delivery and receipt of preconception care guidelines as perceived by general practitioners. Relating these barriers to a theoretical field framework provides a clearer understanding of some of the psychological aspects involved in the behavior of general practitioners towards the provision and receipt of prenatal care. Further research prioritizing these barriers and the theoretical areas with which they relate is necessary before a methodologically rigorous intervention can be designed, implemented and evaluated.

title: Barriers to Use of Breast Cancer Risk Reduction Treatments
abstract: Evidence from randomized clinical trials supports the use of tamoxifen, raloxifene, exemestane, and anastrozole to reduce the risk of invasive breast cancer, particularly in estrogen receptor-positive tumors. Revised clinical guidelines now strongly recommend that doctors recommend drugs to high-risk women to reduce their risk of breast cancer. Although only a small proportion of eligible women take risk-reducing medication, evidence suggests greater acceptance among women with atypical hyperplasia or lobular carcinoma in situ. Among physicians, barriers to prescribing risk reduction drugs include inadequate training in risk assessment, lack of reimbursement for prevention counseling, and a lack of easily accessible and user-friendly estimation tools for estimating risk/benefit profiles. Strategies to increase intake among women have focused on providing education about breast cancer risk and information that accurately conveys the risks and benefits of risk reduction drugs. Priority areas of research identified to improve the use of risk-reducing drugs are (1) the development of risk assessment tools that more accurately identify the women most likely to benefit, and (2) the identification of circulating or tissue biomarkers that can predict and monitor. and (3) a better understanding of patient-related barriers, including patients' subjective beliefs and experiences.

title: Baseline Depression Severity as a Moderator of Depression Outcomes Between Cognitive Behavioral Therapy and Pharmacotherapy: A Meta-analysis of Individual Patient Data
abstract: IMPORTANCE: Current guidelines recommend treating severe depression with pharmacotherapy. Traditional meta-analyses as well as randomized clinical trials have important limitations in testing moderators of treatment outcomes. OBJECTIVES: To conduct a systematic literature search, collect primary data from studies, and analyze baseline depression severity as a moderator of treatment outcomes between cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT) and antidepressant medication (ADM). DATA SOURCES: A total of 14902 abstracts were reviewed from an extensive literature review in PubMed, PsycINFO, EMBASE, and the Cochrane Registry of Controlled Trials from 1966 to January 1, 2014. STUDY SELECTION: Randomized clinical trials comparing CBT and ADM included patients with DSM-defined depressive disorder. DATA ATTRACTION AND SYNTHESIS: Study authors were asked to provide primary data from their research. Primary data from 16 (67%) of 24 studies identified with 1700 outpatients (794 from CBT status and 906 from ADM status) were included. Missing data loaded with multiple assignment methods. Mixed-effect models, adjusting for differences in study level, were used to examine baseline depression severity as moderators of treatment outcomes. KEY OUTCOMES AND MEASURES: Seventeen-item Hamilton Depression Rating Scale (HAM-D) and Beck Depression Inventory (BDI). RESULTS: ADM had a main effect on CBT on HAM-D (beta = -0.88"; P = .03) and a negligible trend on BDI (beta = -1.14; P = .08, statistical test for trend) , but no significant difference in response (odds ratio [OR], 1.24; P = .12) or remission (OR, 1.18; P = .22), but not a moderate reduction in depressive symptoms between CBT and ADM (beta = 0.00; P = .96) Similar results were seen using the BDI, with baseline depression severity also not reducing the probability of response (OR, 0.99; P = .77) or remission (OR, 1.00; "P = .93) between CBT and ADM. RESULTS AND RELEVANCE: Baseline depression severity did not attenuate differences between CBT and ADM on HAM-D or BDI, or in response or remission. This finding cannot be predicted to other psychotherapies, individual ADMs, or inpatients. However, researchers provide new and important evidence that is important to doctors, therapists, and patients.

title: Key feature of a randomized trial evaluating the effects of disease management programs for the prevention of recurrent ischemic stroke.
abstract: BACKGROUND: Comprehensive, long-term patient education programs designed to improve self-management can help patients better manage their medical condition. Using disease management programs (DMPs) established for each of the risk factors according to clinical practice guidelines, we evaluate their impact on stroke recurrence prevention. METHODS: This is a randomized trial conducted within 1 year from initiation in patients with ischemic stroke. Subjects in the intervention group received a 6-month DMP that included self-management training provided by a nurse and collaborative support with a primary care physician. Those in the usual care group received ordinary outpatient care. The primary endpoints were stroke recurrence and stroke death. The patients were enrolled for 2 years with 2-year follow-up plans after the 6-month training period (30 months in total). RESULTS: A total of 321 eligible subjects (mean age, 67.3 years";" female, 96 [29.9%]) were included in this study, including 21 (6.5%) subjects with transient ischemic attack. Regarding risk factors for stroke, 260 patients (81.0%) had hypertension, 249 (77.6%) dyslipidemia, 102 (31.8%) diabetes mellitus, 47 (14.6%) atrial fibrillation, and 98 (30.5%) patients. ) had chronic kidney disease. There was no significant difference between the 2 groups in terms of subject characteristics. CONCLUSIONS: This article describes the rationale, design, and key features of a randomized controlled trial to evaluate the effects of DMPs for secondary prevention of stroke. The follow-up is ongoing and will end in 2015.

title: Making friends with caregivers of people with dementia: randomized controlled trial
abstract: OBJECTIVE To evaluate the effectiveness of a voluntary sector-based friendship plan in improving the psychological well-being and quality of life of family caregivers of people with dementia. DESIGN Single-blind randomized controlled trial. SETTING Community settings in East Anglia and London. PARTICIPANTS 236 family caregivers of people with primary progressive dementia. INTERVENTION Communication with a friendly facilitator and offer to pair with a trained volunteer friend compared to no friendly facilitator contact";" all participants continued to receive "usual care". MAIN OUTCOME MEASURES Caregivers' mood (hospital anxiety and depression scale-depression) and health-related quality of life (EuroQoL) 15 months after randomisation. RESULTS Intent-to-treat analysis showed no benefit for the "access to a friendly facilitator" intervention on either the primary outcome measure or any of the secondary outcome measures. CONCLUSIONS As with many carer services, companion programs are not implemented by all carers and providing access to a companion plan is not effective in improving well-being. Trial registration CONTROLLED TRIALS Available: ISRCTN08130075.

title: Behavior change without behavior change communication: Provoking handwashing among primary school students in Bangladesh.
abstract: Behavior change communication to improve soap handwashing can be labor- and resource-intensive, but quality results are difficult to achieve. Nudges are environmental cues involved in unconscious decision-making processes to accelerate behavior change. In this proof-of-concept study, we developed an inexpensive poke kit to promote handwashing with soap after toilet use in two primary schools in rural Bangladesh. We completed direct observation of behaviors at baseline, after providing the traditional handwashing background, and over multiple time periods (1 day, 2 weeks, and 6 weeks) following targeted handwashing impulses. Additional handwashing tutorial or motivational message incomplete. Among schoolchildren, handwashing with soap was low at baseline (4%), increasing to 68% the day after the nudge was completed, and to 74% at both 2 weeks and 6 weeks post-intervention. The results suggest that nudge-based interventions have the potential to improve handwashing with soap among school-aged children in Bangladesh, and specific areas of further research are discussed.

title: Behavioral Counseling After Primary Care Alcohol Abuse Screening: A Systematic Review and Meta-analysis for the US Preventive Services Task Force
abstract: Background: Alcohol abuse, which spans the full spectrum from risky alcohol use to alcohol dependence, is the leading cause of preventable death in the United States. Objective: To evaluate the benefits and harms of behavioral counseling interventions for adolescents and adults who abuse alcohol. Data Sources: MEDLINE, EMBASE, the Cochrane Library, CINAHL, PsycINFO, International Pharmaceutical Abstracts, and reference lists of published literature (January 1985 - January 2012, limited to English-language articles). Study Selection: Controlled trials of at least 6 months with screening in primary care settings enrolled individuals with alcohol abuse identified and evaluated behavioral counseling interventions. Data Extraction: One reviewer extracted data and a second check accuracy. Two independent reviewers gave quality ratings and rated the strength of the evidence. Data Synthesis: The 23 included studies generally excluded people with alcohol dependence. The best evidence was short (10 to 15 minute) multi-contact interventions. Among adults receiving behavioral interventions, consumption decreased from baseline by 3.6 drinks/week (weighted mean difference, 3.6 drinks/week [95% CI, 2.4 to 4.8 drinks/week]"; 10 trials; 4332 participants), 12% fewer adults reported episodes of heavy drinking (risk difference, 0.12 [CI, 0.07 to 0.16]; 7 trials; 2737 participants), and 11% more adults reported drinking less alcohol than the recommended limits (risk difference, 0.11 [CI, 0.08] to 0.13]; 9 trials ;" 5973 participants) compared with control participants over 12 months (moderate strength of evidence). There was insufficient evidence to draw conclusions about accidents, injuries, or alcohol-related liver problems. Trials that enrolled young adults or college students showed less consumption and fewer heavy drinking episodes (moderate strength of evidence). Little or no evidence of harm was found. Limitations: Because control participants' behavior may have been influenced by assessments of alcohol abuse, results may be biased to zero. Also, the evidence probably does not apply to people with alcohol dependence and selective reporting may have occurred. Conclusion: Behavioral counseling interventions improve behavioral outcomes for adults who are risky drinkers. Primary Funding: Agency for Health Research and Quality.

title: Behavioral Counseling Interventions to Prevent Sexually Transmitted Infections: US Preventive Services Task Force Recommendation Statement
abstract: DESCRIPTION: New US Preventive Services Task Force (USPSTF) recommendations on behavioral counseling for adolescents and adults to prevent sexually transmitted infections (STIs). METHODS: The USPSTF reviewed the evidence on the benefits and harms of counseling. The review included studies evaluating behavioral counseling interventions conducted in primary settings, those deemed appropriate in primary care, and whether patients could be referred from primary care. RECOMMENDATIONS: The USPSTF recommends high-intensity behavioral counseling for all sexually active adolescents and adults. are at high risk for STIs. (Recommendation B) The available evidence is insufficient to assess the balance between the benefits and harms of behavioral counseling for preventing STIs in sexually inactive adolescents and adults not at high risk of STIs. (I explain).

title: Behavioral Counseling to Promote Physical Activity and Healthy Diet to Prevent Cardiovascular Disease in Adults: A Systematic Review for the US Preventive Services Task Force.
abstract: Background: Poor diet and lack of physical activity can worsen cardiovascular health, but most Americans do not meet dietary and physical activity recommendations. Objective: Counseling to help the US Preventive Services Task Force update previous recommendations by systematically reviewing physical activity or dietary trials. Data Sources: MEDLINE, PsycINFO, Cochrane Central Register of Controlled Trials (2001 - January 2010), experts and available systematic reviews. Study Selection: Two researchers independently reviewed 13 562 abstracts and 481 articles against a series of series. critically evaluated each study using a priori inclusion criteria and design-specific quality criteria. Data Extraction and Analysis: Data from 73 studies (109 articles) were summarized by one referee and checked by a second referee. Random effects meta-analyses were performed for multiple intermediate health and behavioral outcomes. Data Synthesis: Long-term observational follow-up of intensive sodium reduction counseling showed a reduction in the incidence of cardiovascular disease";" however, other direct evidence for reduction in disease morbidity is lacking. High-intensity dietary counseling resulted in changes in body mass index (adiposity) of ?0.3 to ?0.7 kg/m2 at ?1.5 mm Hg (95% CI, ?0.9 to ?2.1 mm Hg), with or without physical activity counselling. . systolic blood pressure, ?0.7 mm Hg (CI, ?0.6 to ?0.9 mm Hg), diastolic pressure ?0.17 mmol/L (CI, ?0.09 to ?0.25 mmol/L) (?6.56 mg/dL [CI, ?3.47] to ?9.65 mg/dL]) and ?0.13 mmol/L (CI, ?0.06 to ?0.21 mmol/L) (?5.02 mg/dL [CI, ?2.32 to ?8.11 mg/dL] ]) low-density lipoprotein cholesterol level. Moderate and high-intensity counseling resulted in moderate to large changes in the person's reported dietary and physical activity behaviors. Limitations: There was evidence for large statistical heterogeneity or publication bias in meta-analyses of some results. Only 11 trials followed the results after 12 months. Conclusion: Counseling to improve diet or increase physical activity changed health behaviors and was associated with minor improvements in adiposity, blood pressure and lipid levels. Primary Source of Funding: Agency for Health Research and Quality.

title: Behavioral economics and physician compensation – promises and challenges.
Behavioral programs for type 2 diabetes mellitus: a systematic review and network meta-analysis.
abstract: Background: Behavioral programs can improve outcomes for individuals with type 2 diabetes, but there is a wide variety of behavioral interventions and uncertainties about how to optimize the effectiveness of these programs. Objective: To identify factors that regulate the effectiveness of behavioral programs for adults with type 2 diabetes. Data Sources: 6 databases (1993 - January 2015), conference proceedings (2011 - 2014) and reference lists. Study Selection: Repeated screening and selection of 132 randomized, controlled studies that evaluated behavioral programs compared to habitual care, active controls, or other behavioral programs. Data Extraction: Data extracted by one reviewer and validated by another. Two reviewers independently assessed the risk of bias. Data Synthesis: Behavior programs are grouped according to program content and delivery methods. A Bayesian network meta-analysis showed that most lifestyle and diabetes self-management education and support programs (usually offering Â¡à 11 contact hours) lead to clinically significant improvements in glycemic control (Â¡¡% in hemoglobin A1c [HbA1c]). 0.4 reduction), most diabetes self-management education programs without additional supportÂ¡Âªespecially those that offer 10 or fewer contact hoursÂ¡Âª have found little benefit. Programs with higher effect sizes were delivered in person more often than through technology. Lifestyle programs led to the largest reductions in body mass index. Reductions in HbA1c seemed greater for participants with a baseline HbA1c of 7.0% or higher, adults younger than 65, and minority people (Â¡Ã subgroups with 75% non-white participants). Limitations: All studies had a moderate or high risk of bias. Subgroup analyzes were indirect and therefore exploratory. Most outcomes were reported immediately after interventions. Conclusion: Diabetes self-management training with 10 or fewer hours of contact with the birthing staff yielded little benefit. Behavioral programs seem to benefit people with suboptimal or poor glycemic control more than those with good control. Primary Source of Funding: Agency for Health Research and Quality. (PROSPERO registration number: CRD42014010515)

title: Behavioral Sexual Risk Reduction Counseling in Primary Care to Prevent Sexually Transmitted Infections: A Systematic Review for the US Preventive Services Task Force.
abstract: Background: Sexually transmitted infections (STIs) are common and preventable. Purpose: To update a previous systematic review for the US Preventive Services Task Force on the benefits and harms of sexual risk reduction counseling to prevent STIs. Data Sources: Selected databases from January 2007 to October 2013, manual searches of reference lists and gray literature, and studies from previous review. Study Selection: Fair or good quality English language trials conducted in adolescents or adults. Data Extraction: One researcher summarized the data and another controlled the abstraction. Study quality was reviewed in pairs. Data Synthesis: 31 studies were included: 16 (n = 56 110) were newly published and 15 (n = 14 214) were from previous review. Most studies targeted people at increased risk of STIs based on sociodemographic characteristics, risky sexual behavior, or a history of STIs. High-intensity (>2 hours) interventions were used in adolescents (odds ratio, 0.38 [95% CI, 0.24 to 0.60]) and adults (odds ratio, 0.70 [CI, 0.56 to 0.87]) ]) reduced the incidence of STIs. Low-intensity interventions were generally not effective in adults, but some approaches were promising. Although moderate-intensity interventions may be effective in adolescents, data were very sparse. Reported behavioral outcomes were heterogeneous and likely to show a benefit with high-intensity interventions in 6 months or less. No consistent evidence was found that sexual risk reduction counseling is harmful. Limitations: Low-risk populations and male adolescents were underrepresented. The reliability of self-reported behavioral outcomes was unknown. Conclusion: High-intensity counseling on sexual risk reduction may reduce STIs in primary care and related settings, especially in sexually active adolescents and adults at high risk of STIs. Primary Source of Funding: Agency for Health Research and Quality.

title: Behavioral Therapy with or Without Biofeedback and Pelvic Floor Electrical Stimulation for Persistent Postprostatectomy Incontinence
abstract: Context Although behavioral therapy has been shown to improve recovery after continence, no controlled trial of behavioral therapy for post-prostatectomy incontinence lasting longer than 1 year has been conducted. Purpose To evaluate the effectiveness of behavioral therapy to reduce persistent postprostatectomy incontinence and to determine whether biofeedback and pelvic floor electrical stimulation technologies increase the effectiveness of behavioral therapy. Design, Setting, and Participants A prospective randomized controlled trial conducted at a university and 2 Veterans Affairs continence clinics (2003–2008) involving 208 community-dwelling men aged 51 to 84 years with incontinence 1 to 17 years after radical prostatectomy. 1-year follow-up after active treatment. Twenty-four percent of men were African American”; 75%, white. Interventions After stratification by type and frequency of incontinence, participants were randomized to one of 3 groups: 8 weeks of behavioral therapy (pelvic floor muscle training and bladder control strategies), behavioral therapy plus in-office , dual-channel electromyograph biofeedback and daily home pelvic floor electrical stimulation at 20 Hz, current up to 100 mA (behavior plus) or delayed treatment used as control group Decreased in mean number of incontinence episodes after 8 weeks of treatment as documented in 7-day bladder diaries Results Mean incontinence episodes decreased from 28 to 13 per week (55% reduction; 95% confidence interval [CI], 44%-66% ) after behavioral therapy and from 26 to 12 (51% reduction) after behavior plus therapy; 95% CI, 37-65%) Both reductions were observed among those controls from 25 to 21 (24% reduction; 95% CI, 10-39%) (P = .001 for both treatment groups). together, treatment There was no significant difference in the reduction of incontinence between the groups (P = .69). Improvements were sustained for up to 12 months in the active treatment groups: 50% reduction in the behavioral group (95% CI, 39.8%-61.1%; 13.5% episodes per week) and 59% reductions (95% CI, 45.0%-73.1%; "9.1 episodes per week) behavior Results in the plus group (P = .32) Results In patients with incontinence after prostatectomy for at least 1 year, 8 weeks of behavioral therapy resulted in fewer episodes of incontinence compared to delayed treatment control The addition of biofeedback and pelvic floor electrical stimulation did not result in greater efficacy.

title: Behavioral treatment of obesity in primary care patients: a systematic review.
abstract: IMPORTANCE: In 2011, the Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services (CMS) approved intensive behavioral weight loss counseling for obese beneficiaries in primary care settings for approximately 14 face-to-face, 10- to 15-minute sessions over 6 months postpartum. by physicians and other CMS-defined primary care practitioners. OBJECTIVE: To conduct a systematic review of behavioral counseling for overweight and obese patients recruited from primary care, either by primary care practitioners working alone or with trained responders (eg, medical assistants, registered dietitians) or by trained responders working independently. EVIDENCE REVIEW: We sought randomized controlled trials that recruited overweight and obese patients from primary care, published in PubMed, CINAHL, and EMBASE between January 1980 and June 2014"; provided behavioral counseling (i.e. diet, exercise, and behavioral therapy) for at least 3 months , with at least 6 months of postrandomization follow-up; at least 15 participants per treatment group, including objectively measured weights; and had a comparator, an intent-to-treat analysis, and less than 30% at 1 year or less than 40% attrition at longer follow-up RESULTS: A review of 3304 abstracts yielded 12 studies including 3893 participants who met inclusion-exclusion criteria and predetermined quality ratings No studies were found in which primary care practitioners counseled following CMS guidelines.Mean 6-month weight changes from baseline in intervention groups 0, It varies between 3 kg and 6.6 kg.In the control group, the mean The ma change ranged from a 0.9 kg gain to a 2.0 kg loss. Weight loss generally decreased with longer follow-up (12-24 months) in both groups. Interventions that predicted both reduced energy intake (eg >/= 500 kcal/day) and increased physical activity (eg >/=150 min walking) with conventional behavioral therapy resulted in greater weight loss overall than non-all interventions. 3 special ingredients. In previous studies, more treatment sessions delivered in person or over the phone by trained responders were associated with a greater average weight loss and a likelihood that patients would lose 5% or more of their baseline weight. RESULTS AND RELIABILITY: Intensive behavioral counseling can result in clinically significant weight loss, but there is little research on primary care practitioners providing this type of care. Current findings suggest that a range of trained responders who provide in-person or telephone counseling may be considered for the treatment of overweight or obesity in patients encountered in primary care settings.

title: Behavior modification strategies to reduce blood pressure-related disease burden: findings from a global practice research program
abstract: BACKGROUND: The Global Alliance for Chronic Diseases includes the majority of public research funding organizations around the world. It focuses on application research to tackle the burden of chronic diseases in low- and middle-income countries and vulnerable populations in high-income countries. In the initial call for research, 15 projects focused on reducing the burden of disease associated with blood pressure were funded. In this study, we describe a reflexive mapping exercise to identify behavior change strategies undertaken in each of these projects. METHODS: Using the Wheel of Behavior Change framework, each team rated the abilities, opportunities, and motivations of the various actors who are an integral part of each project (for example, community members, non-physician health workers, and doctors in projects focused on service delivery). The teams then mapped the interventions they implemented and identified the key policy categories in which these interventions operated. Provided guidance on using the Behavior Modification Wheel to promote consistency in responses across teams. The ratings were repeatedly discussed and developed in several group meetings. RESULTS: There were marked differences in the perceived abilities, opportunities, and motivations of the various actors targeted for behavior modification strategies. Despite this diversity, there was a high degree of synergy in intervention functions, with most teams using complex interventions that included education, training, enabling, environmental restructuring, and persuasion-driven strategies. Similar policy categories were also targeted across teams, particularly in the areas of guidelines, communications/marketing and service delivery, with few teams focused on financial measures, regulation and legislation. CONCLUSIONS: The great diversity in preparedness for behavior change among the main actors in these projects suggests that, despite the similarity in approaches taken, the interventions themselves will be addressed in a variable way. The findings highlight the importance of contextual factors in driving the success and failure of research programs. Results and process evaluations from each project will build upon this exploratory work and provide a better understanding of factors that may influence magnification of response strategies.

title: Behavioral insights in healthcare
Beliefs and attitudes about breast cancer and screening practices among Arab women living in Qatar: A cross-sectional study
abstract: BACKGROUND: Despite rising breast cancer incidence and death rates, breast cancer screening (BCS) rates among women in Qatar remain low. Previous studies point to the need to better understand the many complex beliefs, values and attitudes that influence health-seeking behavior of Arab women in order to develop culturally appropriate and effective intervention strategies to address breast cancer in the Middle East. This study examines the beliefs, attitudes and BCS practices of Arabic-speaking women in Qatar. METHODS: A multicenter, cross-sectional quantitative survey was conducted in Qatar from March 2011 to July 2011 with 1,063 (87.5% response rate) Arabic speaking Qatari and non-Qatari women aged 35 years or older. Beliefs and BCS applications were estimated using chi-square tests and multivariate logistic regression analyses. Participants who met the BCS guidelines (BCS application = Yes) were compared with those who did not (BCS application = No). RESULTS: In addition to low awareness levels and low participation rates in BCS, a quarter of respondents said their doctor had talked to them about breast cancer and less than half of the women interviewed believed that breast cancer could be prevented. Women who participated in the BCS practice were more likely to have a doctor who spoke to them about breast cancer, believing that they were in good health, that the cancer could be prevented, or that the cancer could be inherited. The majority wanted to know if they had cancer and felt their health needs were met. The main reasons given for not planning BCS were lack of doctor's advice, fear and embarrassment. CONCLUSIONS: These findings suggest that a variety of channels (health care providers, media, breast cancer survivors, community leaders) should be used to create culturally appropriate breast cancer intervention programs and to create increased awareness of breast cancer, MSC and the benefits of early detection. breast cancer. Implementation of these measures will reduce breast cancer death rates among Arabic-speaking women living in the State of Qatar.

title: Beliefs about mammography screening in women presenting to the emergency department for non-urgent care
abstract: INTRODUCTION: One in 8 women in the United States will develop invasive breast cancer during their lifetime. Despite the evidence that mammography is an effective method of early detection, some vulnerable groups, such as those who use the emergency room as a medical home, do not follow mammography screening guidelines and experience different death rates from breast cancer. The aim of this study was to explore differences in beliefs about mammography screening among women presenting to the emergency department for non-urgent care and ultimately to develop interventions that promote mammography for this vulnerable population. METHODS: We investigated the relationship between the stage of readiness to adopt mammography behavior and barriers, benefits, and perceived susceptibility by applying scales of risks, benefits, and barriers to a sample of 110 women admitted to the emergency department of a public hospital for preterm labor. They were sitting in the non-urgent complaints or emergency room waiting room. We also collected sociodemographic information and readiness stage. RESULTS: Mammography compliance was approximately 60%. Most of the women who didn't follow current guidelines were considerate. Those who did not consider screening were significantly less likely to perceive themselves as at risk of developing breast cancer. Women with greater barriers to mammography benefited less from getting a mammogram. African-American women think they see less benefit from getting a mammogram. CONCLUSION: The mammography presentation was conveniently placed in the emergency room waiting room, given the suboptimal rate at which this population was screened. Beliefs about mammography differ for women and minority women at various stages of adopting mammography. Understanding these differences will allow tailoring the intervention to population in this setting. Emergency nurses are an important and sometimes the only point of health care for patients who come to the emergency room routinely. Therefore, they have a valuable opportunity to provide cancer screening promotional messages. In this setting, it is critical that nurses understand the complexity of providing this information and the need to do so.

title: Beneficial and harmful effects of enhanced feedback on physicians' clinical teaching performance
abstract: OBJECTIVE: To assess whether clinical teaching skills can be improved by providing increased student feedback to teachers. METHODS: A randomized, controlled study included 42 physicians and 39 assistants from the Indiana University School of Medicine Department of Medicine who trained 110 students in medical service rotations for one-month periods in 1994. Prior to teaching the rotations, intervention group teachers received norm-referenced, graphic summaries of instructional performances rated by students. At mid-month, intervention group teachers received students' scores, which were boosted by individualized instructional effectiveness guidelines based on the Stanford Faculty Improvement Program framework. Linear models were used to analyze the students' average scores for teaching behavior at the middle and end of the month. Independent variables included performance ratings, intervention status, teacher status, teaching experience, and interactions with baseline ratings. RESULTS: Complex interactions with core performance were found at the middle and end of the month for most instructional categories. Intervention group teachers with high baseline performance scores had higher student scores than control group teachers with similar baseline scores"; intervention group teachers with low baseline performance scores scored lower than control group teachers with comparable baseline scores. Medium or high baseline Residents with comparable baseline scores scored higher than physicians with comparable baseline scores; Assistants with low baseline scores performed similarly to GPs with comparable baseline scores. CONCLUSION: Baseline performance is important for targeting teachers most likely to benefit from enhanced student feedback. Teaching The possible deterioration in performance warrants a reconsideration of the allocation of students' scores to teachers with low baseline performance scores.

title: Benefits and Harms of Pharmacological Treatment for Female Urinary Incontinence
abstract: Background: Urinary incontinence (UI) in women adversely affects quality of life. Objective: To conduct a systematic literature review on drugs for emergency UI in women. Data Sources: MEDLINE, Cochrane Central Register of Controlled Trials, SCIRUS, and Google Scholar were searched for articles published from 1966 to November 2011. Study Selection: Randomized, controlled studies (RCTs) are reported in English. Data Extraction: Outcome rates and risk of bias were extracted using a standardized form to combine the absolute risk differences and calculate the number of attributable events per 1000 patients treated with a 95% CI. Data Synthesis: 94 RCTs were found suitable. The pooled analyzes found that, among emergency UI drugs, 130 of 1000 women treated with fesoterodine (CI, 58 to 202), with tolterodine 85 (CI, 40 to 129), with oxybutynin 114 (CI, 64 to 163) were associated with continence. proved to be restored. ), 107 with solifenacin (CI, 58 to 156) and 114 with trospium (CI, 83 to 144). Discontinuation rates due to adverse events were 31 per 1000 treated with fesoterodine (CI, 10 to 56), 63 oxybutynin (CI, 12 to 127), 18 trospium (CI, 4 to 33), and 13 solifenacin (CI, 1 to 26). The studies' inconsistent descriptions of reduction in UI and quality of life hindered evidence synthesis. Limitation: Evidence for improvements in quality of life and comparative effectiveness with drugs was limited, and evidence for the effects of race, baseline severity of UI, and comorbid conditions on treatment success was inconclusive. Conclusion: Overall, emergency UI medications showed similar minor benefits. Therapeutic choices should take into account the harm profile. Evidence on long-term adherence and safety of treatments is lacking. Primary Source of Funding: Agency for Health Research and Quality.

title: Benzodiazepines, opioids and driving: an overview of experimental research
abstract: ISSUES: Traffic accidents contribute significantly to the overall injury burden in Australia and the risk of injury is associated with the presence of drugs and/or alcohol in the driver's blood. Increasingly, some of the most commonly identified drugs include prescription drugs, the most notable of which are benzodiazepines and opioids. However, empirical research on the effects of prescription psychoactive drugs on driving behavior is scarce. APPROACH: This article provides an overview of experimental studies investigating the effects of benzodiazepines and opioids at prescribed doses on driving ability and points to future directions for research. KEY FINDINGS: There is growing epidemiological evidence linking the therapeutic use of benzodiazepines and opioids to an increased risk of accidents. However, the available experimental literature remains unclear. Limitations in study methodologies have resulted in inconsistent findings. APPLICATIONS: Limited experimental evidence is available to inform policy and guidelines regarding eligibility for driving for patients taking prescription benzodiazepines and opioids. CONCLUSION: More experimental research is needed to elucidate the effects of these drugs on driving under varying conditions and in different medical contexts. This will ensure that physicians prescribing benzodiazepines and opioids are well informed and appropriately advise patients about the risks of driving while taking these drugs.

title: Grief interventions for adults with intellectual disabilities: what works?
abstract: Examining the theoretical basis for grief and loss is just beginning for adults with intellectual disability (IB) at this time. However, as the life expectancy of individuals with identity cards increases, these adults experience more and more loss and mourning. Practitioners, especially bereavement counselors, find it increasingly critical to understand best practice principles for working with bereaved adults with disabilities in their daily work. Practitioners are also asked to guide families and caregivers in bereavement and death education. This article provides counselors and other professionals with a review of current grief intervention research for adults with intellectual disabilities. Implementation recommendations are made at three levels: informal support"; formal intervention;" and community education.

title: Best practice in the management of primary nocturnal enuresis in children: a systematic review.
abstract: OBJECTIVE: Nocturnal enuresis is the involuntary leakage of urine at night in a child of expected dry age and physical health. The prevalence of this condition in Australia is estimated at 18.9% in children aged 5 to 12 years; 19% of boys and 16% of 5-year-old girls wet the bed at least once a month. Bedwetting is more common in boys up to the age of 13, and in girls after this age. Nocturnal enuresis has a spontaneous recovery rate of approximately 14%, but up to 3% of children remain enuretic as adults. Although this condition is pathologically benign, it can have serious social and psychological repercussions for the patient, including effects on self-esteem, school achievement, parental disapproval, and even sexual activity in later life. Despite the volume of information available for enuresis management, most of the research has been done outside of Australia. Therefore, the aim of this study was to establish management guidelines for nocturnal enuresis in children specific to Australian clinical practice. CRITERIA TO INCLUDE: This review includes systematic reviews or concurrent controlled studies (randomized controlled trials (RCT), pseudo-randomized controlled trials, controlled clinical trials (CCT), interrupted time series (ITS), and pre- and post-trial controlled (CBA)) ), to examine the effectiveness of interventions for managing nocturnal enuresis in children up to 16 years of age. SEARCH STRATEGY: A systematic literature review was conducted to identify all available evidence. Cochrane and other health technology review websites were searched for available systematic reviews. The Pubmed, Embase, and CINAHL databases were searched for recent randomized controlled trials and controlled trials (1990 to 2007). The reference lists of all the articles reached for the relevant essays were searched. These reviews and guidelines were summarized and presented to an advisory panel of nurse continence consultants and clinicians to ensure compliance with Australian clinical practice. METHODOLOGICAL QUALITY: The methodological quality of all studies was assessed by two reviewers who used the JBI critical evaluation forms for the experimental studies included in the JBI-MAStARI software. This tool was used to identify all sources of bias. When there was disagreement between the two reviewers, a third reviewer made the decision. RESULTS: Seven systematic reviews, eight recent studies, and two guidelines were used in the development of these guidelines. Briefly, management recommendations include: CONCLUSIONS: Despite the high prevalence of nocturnal enuresis and the negative psychosocial sequelae that may result from this condition, management is both readily available and effective. APPLICATIONS FOR PRACTICE: The practice of managing nocturnal enuresis in children should begin with addressing any evidence of both daytime wetting and constipation. Following this, less invasive behavioral therapies should be tried. If these measures fail, the use of alarms with or without short-term desmopressin administration may be attempted. Other interventions have not yet been conclusively proven to be effective and should be carefully considered. However, it should be stressed that the vast majority of children will become continent at some future time point, with or without benefit from the interventions. APPLICATIONS FOR RESEARCH: While it is clear that some behavioral modalities, alarms and desmopressin may be effective interventions, the evidence for other treatments is less conclusive. However, the observation that even alarms and/or desmopressin do not work for all children suggests that research to determine the efficacy of other interventions (especially behavioral and complementary therapies) should be conducted in large, carefully designed RCTs.

title: Best strategies for practicing clinical pathways in an emergency room setting: study protocol for a cluster randomized controlled trial.
abstract: Background The clinical pathway is a tool that operationalizes best evidence recommendations and clinical practice guidelines in an accessible format for Â¡Â®point-of-careÂ¡Â¯ management by multidisciplinary healthcare teams in hospital settings. While high-quality, expert-developed clinical pathways have many potential benefits, their impact has been limited by variable delivery strategies and inadequate research designs. The best strategies for implementing migration pathways into hospital settings are unknown. This study will attempt to develop and comprehensively evaluate the best strategies for the effective local application of externally developed specialist clinical pathways. Design/methods We will develop a theory-based and knowledge-based, user-informed intervention strategy to implement two pediatric clinical pathways: asthma and gastroenteritis. Using a balanced incomplete block design, we will randomly select 16 community emergency departments to receive the intervention for one clinical pathway and act as controls for the alternative clinical pathway, thus conducting two clusters of randomized controlled trials to evaluate this implementation intervention. A minimization procedure will be used to randomly select sites. Response sites will receive a specific strategy to support full clinical pathway implementation. We will evaluate the effectiveness of the implementation strategy by measuring the relevant process and clinical outcomes. The primary process outcome will be the presence of an appropriately completed clinical pathway on the chart for the patients involved. Primary clinical outcomes for each clinical pathway include: “AsthmaÂ¡Âªproportion of patients with asthma appropriately treated with corticosteroids in the emergency room and at discharge”; and proportion of involved patients appropriately treated with oral rehydration therapy for GastroenteritisÂ¡ÂªData sources include chart audits, administrative databases. , environmental surveys and qualitative interviews. We will also conduct an overall process evaluation to evaluate the implementation strategy and an economic analysis to evaluate the costs and benefits of implementation. Discussion This study will contribute to the body of evidence supporting effective strategies for the implementation of clinical pathways and, ultimately, to improve clinical pathways. will reduce research gaps to practice by making the best evidence care recommendations functional through its effective use.

title: Best practice intervention for the care of self-injured patients
abstract: OBJECTIVE: To describe the development of a best practice intervention to guide nurse practitioners (NPs) caring for self-harming individuals. DATA SOURCES: Evidence on which the guideline is based includes six descriptive studies and expert clinical opinion articles. The framework for the development of the guideline is a systematic process for obtaining and analyzing the best available evidence, developing a theory-based intervention, and recommending a system for continuous evaluation of the intervention's effectiveness. RESULTS: The guide is an information sheet that includes a definition of self-injury, background of the problem, target audience and response. The three components of the intervention are: (a) the NP's self-assessment of values, beliefs, and assumptions about self-harming individuals; (b) a focused, in-depth assessment of the client; and (c) therapeutic strategies to address the emotional, social, and biological dimensions of self-injury. PRACTICES FOR PRACTICE: This Best Practice Intervention guide for the Care of Self-Injured Patients provides direction for NPs to effectively address preventable, self-harming behavior. More studies are needed to examine the effectiveness of the use of the guideline and the intervention.

title: Better drug by default
abstract: Background. American healthcare is moving to electronic doctor ordering. These computerized systems are unique in that they allow for custom order interfaces. While these systems offer great benefits, there are also potential pitfalls, as behavioral science shows that the format of electronic interfaces can affect decision making. Current research specifically examines how defaults in electronic order templates affect physicians' treatment decisions and medical errors. Methods Forty-five medical assistants completed order sets for 3 medical case studies. Participants were randomly assigned to receive order sets with either "accept" defaults (visible but unselected options) or "disable" defaults (visible and preselected options). The results compare error rates between conditions and examine the inclusion and opt-out defaults and the type and severity of the most common errors. Results. Deactivation defaults resulted in more product orders and especially increased commission errors (overorders) compared to activation defaults. However, opt-in defaults resulted in fewer orders, while also increasing omission errors. Given the severity of the errors, the default effects seem to be limited to less serious errors. Solution. The defaults used in electronic order sets influence medical treatment decisions when their impact on the patient's health is low. This model implies that doctors cognitively override wrongly assumed choices, but only up to a point, and imply tradeoffs that maximize accuracy and minimize cognitive effort. The results show that defaults for low-impact elements in spreadsheets require careful attention, as doctors are less likely to override them.

title: Better practices in collaborative mental health care: an evidence-based analysis
abstract: OBJECTIVES: To conduct a systematic review of the experimental literature to identify better practices in collaborative mental health care in the primary care setting. METHODS: A review of Canadian and international literature using Medline, PsycInfo, Embase, Cochrane Library, and other databases yielded over 900 relevant reports, of which 38 met the inclusion criteria. A systematic review and descriptive analysis is presented, along with key results and best practices. CONCLUSIONS: Successful collaboration requires preparation, time and supporting structures based on pre-existing clinical relationships. Collaborative practice probably thrives most when clinicians are together and the most effective place is familiar and not stigmatizing for patients. The degree of cooperation does not predict clinical outcome. Enhanced collaboration paired with treatment guidelines or protocols offers significant benefits over intervention alone in major depression. Systematic follow-up was a strong predictor of positive outcome in collaborative care for depression. There was no clear relationship between collaborative efforts to improve drug compliance and clinical outcomes. Collaboration alone has not been shown to provide skill transfer in PCP knowledge or behavior in the treatment of depression. Service reengineering is also required, designed to support changes in the delivery patterns of primary care providers. Enhanced patient education was part of many studies with good results. Training was usually provided by someone other than PCP. Collaborative interventions that are part of a research protocol can be difficult to sustain over the long term without ongoing funding. Consumer choice regarding treatment modality may be important in treatment participation in collaborative care (for example, having the option to choose psychotherapy versus medication). CONCLUSIONS: A body of experimental literature evaluating the impact of enhanced collaboration on patient outcomes is now available – particularly in depressive disorders. Better practices in collaborative mental health care are starting to emerge.

title: Between peer interviews and controlled trials: hospital-based neurologists' sources of information and practical knowledge in the treatment of stroke patients.
abstract: The application of evidence-based and standardized knowledge is an important foundation for coordinated and effective clinical work. A multicenter study conducted in 30 clinical neurology departments and involving 99 junior and senior registrants addressed practical knowledge of stroke management through open structured oral interviews between physicians and analyzed for guideline compliance. In addition, participants were asked to rate the usefulness of various sources of information and describe the sources of information used according to aspects of practical knowledge addressed. Relevant department managers were asked about the medical information resources available in their clinics. Physicians in almost all hospitals had access to a library and the Internet. However, departments differed in knowledge management (frequency and type of medical education, quality management, participation in research activities). According to other studies, the most frequently reported sources of information are textbooks, journals, and clinical studies. For most resources, usefulness rankings largely correspond to user behavior rankings. Both were only poor predictors of inter-physician and guideline compliance. These are more closely related to intra-departmental homogeneity of practical knowledge than to inter-departmental and guideline compliance. Intra-departmental homogeneity is enhanced through the use of up-to-date, published and evidence-based resources and up-to-date interaction with clinical colleagues. Compliance with the guideline was related to the use of databases and professional journals. Preferring colleagues from outpatient practices decreased both inter-physician and guideline compliance. There seems to be still untapped potential for intra-departmental knowledge management, such as medical education, the application and use of guidelines, and current discussions, that could improve the homogeneity and relevance of practical knowledge applied by clinicians.

title: Between control and therapy: an evolutionary concept analysis of private observation in acute psychiatric wards.
abstract: OBJECTIVE: Private surveillance is a seriously invasive and resource-intensive intervention. Scientifically conceptualizing this measure is necessary for further research and application. METHODS: Evolutionary concept analysis. CONCLUSIONS: Established antecedents, qualifications and outcomes of private observation range from control and therapy to the safety of patients and the scope of professionals. It consists of antecedents, justification (indication, evaluation, prescription), sources (internal guidelines, architectural structures, information), and context factors (security needs, personal attitudes). Attitudes identified are the area of tension between organization (quality, change of caregiver, length, location), intervention (relationship, reappraisal, transparency), as well as control and therapy. Outcomes consist of side effects (patients, nurses, resources) and conflicts (ethical dilemmas, role conflicts). CONCLUSION: Society and discipline have influenced the concept over time, and it is recommended to make a distinction between the preventive and controlling model and the therapeutic approach.

title: Between scientific practice and therapy: ethical evaluation
abstract: The development of bioscience and biotechnology over the past three decades has had a tremendous impact on medicine. New techniques have emerged and new types of treatment have emerged and continue to be used. As theories about pathogenesis and the causes of disease change, new therapeutic drugs are constantly becoming available on the market. The way new technologies and drugs are introduced increasingly includes an experimental phase in which animals and humans are used to test research results. As a rule, these experiments are carried out in accordance with the Declaration of Helsinki (WMA, Helsinki 1964, Tokyo, 1975). The guidelines of this Declaration deal with the ethical aspects of these experiments involving human subjects. Although the guides were intended to have a global import, it is still a fact that some of them are the subject of discussion in various parts of the world. They seem to have a cultural background (for example, respect for the individual) and bioscientists sometimes argue that they should be considered unscientific constraints for this reason. On the basis of a general philosophical and ethical consideration, this article will discuss how ethical principles belong to the heart of biomedicine and biology. A common interest of researchers, clinicians, patients and scientists is to consider the ethical implications of research results before any valuable information is said to have been obtained. The application of monoclonal antibodies in clinical practice can be seen as an example of this argument.

title: Beyond domestic violence screening: a systems model approach in a managed care setting
abstract: BACKGROUND: Implementation of screening guidelines for domestic violence has been challenging. The versatile "systems model" can provide an effective tool for improving domestic violence screening, identification and response in the healthcare setting. METHODS: We have developed: (1) a systems model approach that uses tools to effectively refer, assess, and report domestic violence; (2) materials to be distributed to female patients; (3) training for social work and mental health clinicians to provide family domestic violence assessment and (4) strong links to the community SETTING: A non-profit managed care facility in Richmond, California PARTICIPANTS: Employees and members of the managed care plan MAIN OUTCOME MEASURES: (1) Increased screening for domestic violence by clinicians; (2) increased awareness of the health facility as a resource for domestic violence assistance;" and (3) increased member satisfaction with the health plan's efforts to address domestic violence. RESULTS: The number of clinician referrals and self-referrals of patients to an onsite domestic violence evaluator more than doubled. The pre-intervention and post-intervention telephone survey of members seen for routine checkup showed an increase in members' recall to be asked about domestic violence. After the intervention, statistically significant increases were seen in members' perception of the health plan's impact on the health effects of domestic violence (p<0.0001) and members' satisfaction with the health plan's efforts to address this issue (p<0.0001). RESULTS: A systems model approach improved domestic violence services in a managed care health setting within 1 year and influenced clinicians' behavior and health plan members' experiences. This successful practice makes it possible to address critical research questions about the impact of a healthcare intervention for survivors of domestic violence in a managed healthcare setting.

title: Big pharma and healthcare: an insoluble conflict of interest between private enterprise and public health
abstract: landmark paper on Game Theory showed that the maximization of individual profits necessarily endangered the public good and "requires a fundamental expansion in morality" as the problem has no technical solution (1). We propose here that public health as a public good emerges as a serious example of this problem. Recent events and reports show that there is an increasing mismatch between the interests of the pharmaceutical industry and those of public health. Johnson & Johnson has illegally and effectively off-labeled Propulsid for children, despite internal documents that raise safety concerns. Death in the drug trial was described as a "trade secret". Topol wrote in Vioxx: "Unfortunately, it is clear that Merck's commercial interest has exceeded its concern over the drug's toxicity" (2). Increasingly, concerns are expressed by academics and major journal editors about the type and quality of published evidence, often biased towards the effectiveness of new products. The industry, which funds more than 80% of research, sets a research agenda driven more by marketing than clinical considerations. Intelligent statistical and epidemiological tactics help achieve desired results. The marketing budget is much more than the research budget. Mass advertising to doctors and the public is getting more and more sophisticated: ghostwriting, professional guidelines, targeting consumer groups, and manipulating the media for disease trafficking. Widespread lobbying and political ties limit the independence of regulatory agencies. The obligation to shareholders to preempt public health issues is not unique to the pharmaceutical industry. The chemical, tobacco, and food industries share similar tactics: raising doubts about safety issues, recruiting researchers, infiltrating universities, boards, the media, and legislatures. In contrast, powerful and inexpensive health promotion activities that are not adequately supported by industry because they are too cheap and not patented are markedly underutilized: behavior modification technologies (for example, cardiac rehabilitation), palliative care, and the use of older, effective and safe drugs - all of which are the industry's predecessors. can benefit from marketing and quality tools. Free market successes appear to pose insoluble challenges to social justice in public health, as the sick, the poor and the least educated are most affected.

title: Binge eating disorder in adults: a systematic review and meta-analysis
abstract: BACKGROUND: The best treatment options for binge eating disorder are unclear. OBJECTIVE: To summarize the evidence on the benefits and harms of psychological and pharmacological treatments for adults with binge eating disorder. DATA SOURCES: English publications in EMBASE, Cochrane Library, Academic OneFile, CINAHL, and ClinicalTrials.gov until 18 November 2015 and MEDLINE until 12 May 2016. STUDY SELECTION: 9 waiting-list-controlled psychological studies and 25 placebo-controlled studies = 6) treatments evaluating pharmacological (n = 19) or combination (n = 19). All were randomized trials with a low or moderate risk of bias. DATA DRAWING: 2 reviewers independently extracted research data, assessed the risk of bias, and rated the degree of evidence. DATA SYNTHESIS: Therapist-led cognitive behavioral therapy, lisdexamfetamine, and second-generation antidepressants (SGAs) reduced binge eating frequency and increased binge avoidance (relative risk, 4.95 [95% CI, 3.06 to 8.00], 2 .61 [CI, 2.04 to 3.33] and 1.67 [CI, 1.24 to 2.26] Lisdexamfetamine (mean difference [MD], -6.50 [CI, -8.82 to -4.18]) and SGAs (MD, -3.84 [CI, -6.55 to -1.13]) reduced obsessions and compulsions related to binge eating, and SGAs reduced depression symptoms (MD, -1.97 [CI, -3.67 to -0.28]). pain, gastrointestinal distress, sleep disturbance, and sympathetic nervous system stimulation occurred more frequently with lisdexamfetamine than with placebo (relative risk range, 1.63 to 4.28).Other forms of cognitive behavioral therapy and topiramate also increased abstinence and increased binge eating frequency and associated Topiramate decreased weight and increased sympathetic nervous system stimulation, and lisdexamfetamine increased weight and decreased appetite. LIMITATIONS: Most study participants were overweight or obese white women between the ages of 20 and 40. Many treatments have been studied in just one study. Outcomes were measured inconsistently between trials and were rarely evaluated after the end of treatment.
