CONCLUSION: Cognitive behavioral therapy, lisdexamfetamine, SGAs, and topiramate reduced binge eating and related psychopathology, and reduced lisdexamfetamine and topiramate weight in adults with binge eating disorder.

title: Biomedical and behavioral research in nursing homes: guidelines for ethical research
abstract: As nursing homes become increasingly important venues for biomedical and behavioral research, researchers must address ethical issues such as the increasing vulnerability and high prevalence of mental and physical disorders in the nursing home population. Obtaining valid informed consent is one of the many difficult problems faced by the researcher in the nursing home. Efforts should be made to include family and staff members, as well as nursing home residents, in reviewing the research. The benefits and burdens of research protocols should be distributed fairly, and potential conflicts of interest for staff and physicians should be minimized or potential adverse effects should be improved. Appropriate attention to these ethical concerns can facilitate research in the nursing home and continue to protect vulnerable residents. We present recommended guidelines for the ethical conduct of research in nursing homes to encourage discussion among investigators, nursing home staff and residents, residents' families, and ethicists.

title: Bipolar disorder center for Pennsylvanians: implementing an efficacy trial to improve treatment of at-risk patients
abstract: OBJECTIVE: Adolescents, the elderly, African Americans, and rural residents with bipolar disorder are less likely to be diagnosed, receive adequate treatment, stay in treatment after diagnosis, and have favorable outcomes than their middle-aged, white, urban counterparts. The Center for Bipolar Disorder for Pennsylvanians (BDCP) study is designed to address these disparities. This report highlights the methods used to recruit, screen, and enroll a cohort of difficult-to-recruit individuals with bipolar disorder. METHODS: Fields of study included three private clinics for bipolar disorder and one rural behavioral health clinic in a university setting. Work operations have been standardized and all work personnel have been trained in work procedures. Various strategies were used for recruitment. RESULTS: It was possible to apply the same assessment and screening protocol in settings regardless of whether they had a history of implementing research protocols. This protocol could also be used across the age spectrum, in urban and rural areas, and in a racially diverse cohort of participants. At four sites, 515 people with bipolar disorder were enrolled as a result of these methods (69 African Americans and 446 non-African Americans). Although clinical features at study entry did not differ appreciably between African Americans and non-African Americans, the pathways to treatment were significantly different. CONCLUSIONS: Rigorous recruitment and evaluation procedures can be successfully implemented in different settings and with different patient groups, thereby facilitating access to high-quality care for individuals who often do not receive appropriate care for bipolar disorder.

title: Books and reading: the evidence-based standard of care whose time has come
abstract: Reach and Read (ROR) is the only clinical activity used in the United States that has been systematically evaluated to support child development in primary care. The ROR intervention is simple: clinicians advise high-risk children and parents on the benefits of reading aloud as well as giving books directly at each pediatric visit of children aged 6 months to 5 years. ROR is built on a substantial evidence base for the value of reading aloud to young children. Studies evaluating ROR from different regions from subjects of different races and multiple outcome measures are consistently positive. From its first single center at Boston City Hospital in 1989 to over 4,600 clinical centers in 2010, more than 30,000 clinicians have distributed more than 6.2 million books annually to 3.9 million children in the United States. Future efforts for ROR include integrating the mental health competencies found in American Academy of Pediatrics guidelines into the ROR paradigm as part of residency and clinician training, improving quality to ensure adherence to intervention, and expanding pediatric clinician involvement in local early childhood/school readiness. community efforts. Finally, the most important future goal is for government agencies to adopt as best practice the delivery of developmentally appropriate books to high-risk families and advice on reading aloud.

title: borderline personality disorder in adolescence
abstract: Borderline personality disorder (BPD) is a common and severe mental disorder associated with severe functional impairment and a high suicide rate. BPD is often associated with other psychiatric and personality disorders, high burden on families and caregivers, continued resource use, and high treatment costs. BPD has been a controversial diagnosis in adolescents, but this is no longer confirmed. Recent evidence suggests that BPD is as reliable and valid among adolescents as it is in adults, and that adolescents with BPD may benefit from early intervention. As a result, adolescent BPD is now recognized in psychiatric classification systems and national treatment guidelines. This review aims to inform practitioners in the field of adolescent health about the nature of BPD in adolescence and the benefits of early detection and intervention. BPD diagnosis and treatment should be considered as part of routine practice in adolescent mental health to improve the well-being and long-term prognosis of these individuals.

title: Brave New EMR
Breaking new ground: challenging current asthma guidelines
abstract: BACKGROUND: Although we have international guidelines and several national guidelines for the diagnosis and management of asthma, asthma control in many children and adults is still inadequate. In this article, we review the limitations of current asthma guidelines and describe key issues and remaining questions regarding asthma guidelines specifically for use in primary care. CONCLUSION: Clinical practice guidelines based on evidence from randomized controlled trials are considered the most rigorous and accurate. Current evidence-based guidelines are predominantly written from the perspective of the patient with a clear diagnosis of asthma and do not tend to take into account the heterogeneity of asthma or take into account individual patient variations, differences in practice in response to treatment or needs. local differences in availability and cost of settings or therapies. The results of randomized controlled trials designed to determine the efficacy of treatment under ideal conditions may not be applicable to 'real world' clinical practice, where patients are not selected, follow-up is less frequent, and efficacy - treatment benefit - treatment benefit. routine clinical practice--the most relevant outcome. In addition, most guidelines view asthma in isolation rather than taking into account asthma and other factors that may affect response to asthma treatment, particularly age, allergic rhinitis, smoking, compliance, and genetic factors. Once these links are recognized, guidelines rarely offer practical recommendations for treatment in these scenarios. Finally, there is some evidence that general practitioners are not convinced of the applicability of asthma guidelines to practice settings, particularly when the authors of the guidelines work primarily in specialist practice. CONCLUSION: The development of country-specific guidelines, or ideally local guidelines, may provide more practical solutions for asthma management and may explain regional factors affecting patient selection and adherence to treatment. Pragmatic clinical trials and well-designed observational studies are needed in addition to randomized controlled trials to evaluate the real-world efficacy of treatments, and such evidence needs to be considered by the guideline authors. Finally, there is a need for practical tools to facilitate the diagnosis and assessment of asthma to supplement the treatment information provided in clinical practice guidelines for asthma, and factors responsible for poor control such as associated allergic rhinitis, limited compliance, and smoking behavior.

title: Breast cancer knowledge, attitudes, and screening behaviors among African American women: Black beauticians promoting wellness program
abstract: BACKGROUND: African American women have higher breast cancer death rates than their white counterparts. Studies suggest that this is partly due to the cancer being discovered at a later stage, emphasizing the importance of promoting early detection of breast cancer in this population. To guide the creation of a breast cancer education intervention and to help focus health-promoting efforts of other health educators and clinicians, this study explored whether a cohort of African-American women living in San Diego would demonstrate sufficient basic knowledge about breast cancer screening. and adherence to commonly recommended screening guidelines. METHODS: African American women (N = 1,055) from San Diego, California participated in a beauty salon-based survey about breast cancer knowledge, attitudes, and screening practices. The ages of the women ranged from 20 to 94 years, with a mean age of 42.20 (SD = 13.53) years. Thirty-four percent reported completing college and/or some postgraduate education and 52 percent reported having formal education after college or post-secondary education. Seventy-five percent of the sample reported working outside their home. Participating beauticians and salons were recruited through word of mouth advice from highly respected African-American community leaders. RESULTS: Salon customers reported low compliance rates with recommended breast cancer screening guidelines. Of the 1,055 participants, 31% reported doing breast self-exams every month. Of respondents aged 40 and over, 57% reported having had a clinical breast exam and 43% reported having had a mammogram in the past year. Breast cancer knowledge was associated with compliance with screening guidelines. While women acknowledged the serious health threat posed by breast cancer and the importance of early detection of breast cancer, only 30% of women reported that they were well informed about the disease. Many participants showed a lack of basic knowledge about breast cancer. The Health Belief Model assumes that access to such information is an important element in engaging in browsing behavior. CONCLUSION: Data from this study reflect the increasing need for breast cancer education for African American women. In light of the important available information on breast cancer, these data reinforce the need for more breast cancer education programs that are clearly aimed at attracting the attention of African American women.

title: Closing the gap between pragmatic intervention design and theory: using behavioral science tools to modify an existing quality improvement program to implement "Sepsis Six"
abstract: BACKGROUND: Sepsis has a 40% mortality rate and can be halved if the evidence-based "Sepsis Six" care package is administered within 1 hour. UK audit shows low enforcement rates. Interventions to improve this had minimal impact. Quality improvement programs can be further developed using theoretical frameworks (The Theoretical Domains Framework (TDF)) to replace existing interventions by identifying impacts on clinical behavior and selecting appropriate content. The purpose of this study was to demonstrate how to use this process to replace an intervention designed using plan-do-run-action (PDSA) cycles that had partial success in improving the implementation of Sepsis Six in a hospital. METHODS: The factors affecting the practice were investigated by using TDF to analyze the interviews with 34 health professionals. The nursing team that developed and facilitated the intervention used data to select changes using the Behavior Change Technique (BCT) Taxonomy (v1) and APEASE criteria: affordability, viability, effectiveness, acceptability, safety, and equity. RESULTS: Five themes were identified that impact implementation and drive response modification. These are: (1) "knowing what to do and why" (TDF covers knowledge, social/professional role and identity)";" (2) "risks and benefits" (beliefs about outcomes), belief in the effectiveness of the package that acts as a lever for administration against fear of harming patients, for example, through fluid overload acting as a barrier to practice"; (3) "cooperation" (social influences, social/professional role and identity), eg doctor/nurse conflict acting as a lever against team collaboration"; (4) "empowerment and support" (abilities, beliefs about social/professional role and identity, behavioral regulation, social influences), e.g. staff involvement in intervention development, lack of confidence to challenge peers' decisions not to act as a barrier";" (5) "staffing levels" (environmental context and resources), eg the lack of doctors preventing nighttime practice. The modified intervention included six new BCTs and consisted of two additional components (Sepsis Six training for the Hospital Coordinator at Night; a partnership agreement that supports the participation of all clinical staff and allows peer challenge) and changes to two existing components (staff training) sessions; " documents and materials). CONCLUSIONS: This study demonstrates the feasibility of TDF and BCT Taxonomy (v1) to enhance an existing quality improvement intervention. The tools are in line with the pragmatic PDSA cycle approach often used in quality improvement studies.

Methods In order to analyze the interviews with 34 health professionals, the factors affecting the practice were investigated using TDF. The nursing team that developed and facilitated the intervention used data to select changes using the Behavior Change Technique (BCT) Taxonomy (v1) and APEASE criteria: affordability, viability, effectiveness, acceptability, safety, and equity. title: Closing the science-services gap in schizophrenia care in the Netherlands: The Schizophrenia Quality Improvement Collaboration
abstract: OBJECTIVE: Most patients with schizophrenia are not treated according to evidence-based guidelines. This study examines the large-scale implementation of the National Multidisciplinary Guideline for schizophrenia in the Netherlands. DESIGN: /st> Observational, prospective study, repeated measurements. SETTING: Thirty mental health teams in different parts of the Netherlands. PARTICIPANTS: Three hundred and fifty-nine clinicians from different professional backgrounds and 1489 patients with schizophrenia. INTERVENTION(S): Six evidence-based interventions for schizophrenia were implemented in a collaborative quality improvement context: assertive community therapy (ACT) or its adapted version functional assertive community therapy (FACT), cognitive behavioral therapy, psychoeducation, family interventions, individual placement support, and pharmacotherapy. MAIN OUTCOME MEASURES: Professional performance, social functioning, and recurrence rates. RESULTS: Improved professional performance in accordance with guidelines. Increased availability of (F)ACT from 23% to 60%. Individual Placement Boost increased from 20% to 53%. Complete care plans have been established for 38% of patients, and routine outcome monitoring has been initiated on most teams. Social functioning slightly improved (HoNOS average: 6.2 to 5.6). Recurrence rates did not improve over the course of the study. CONCLUSIONS: An intensive practice program may result in better delivery of evidence-based care, increased continuity of care, and slightly better outcomes for patients with schizophrenia. More rigorous research designs should confirm these findings.

title: Physician-initiated brief smoking cessation strategies for clinical oncology settings: a trial coordinated by the Eastern Cooperative Oncology Group.
abstract: OBJECTIVE: Although tobacco use by cancer patients increases the risk of relapse, reduces the effectiveness of treatment and worsens quality of life, approximately one third of patients who smoked before diagnosis continue to smoke. The efficacy of a physician-based smoking cessation therapy was evaluated because patients had regular contact with oncologists. METHODS: Cancer patients (n = 432) were randomly assigned to either usual care or the National Institutes of Health (NIH) physician-based smoking intervention. The primary outcome was 7-day point prevalence absence at 6 and 12 months after study entry. RESULTS: There was no significant difference in dropout rates between the usual care (11.9%) and intervention (14.4%) groups at the 6-month follow-up, and there was no significant difference between the usual care (13.6%) and intervention groups. Intervention groups (13.3%) at 12-month follow-up. Patients with head and neck cancer or lung cancer who started smoking after age 16 years, initially reported using a cessation self-help guide or therapy, and quit smoking in the last 6 months were more likely to quit at 6 months. the desire to leave the foundation. Patients who smoked 15 or fewer cigarettes a day, had head and neck or lung cancer, had tried a group quit program, and showed a greater desire to quit at baseline were more likely to quit at 12 months. Finally, there was greater adherence to the NIH model for physician smoking treatment for patients in intervention compared to the usual care group. CONCLUSION: While training physicians to provide smoking cessation treatment to cancer patients may increase physician adherence to clinical practice guidelines, physicians' smoking cessation interventions do not provide significant gains in long-term cessation rates among cancer patients.

title: British Psychopharmacological Society, consensus guideline on the use of psychotropic drugs in pregnancy and the postpartum period, 2017
abstract: Decisions regarding the use of psychotropic drugs in pregnancy are an ongoing challenge for clinicians and women with mental health problems due to uncertainties about the risks of the disease itself to the mother and fetus/infant, the effectiveness of drugs in pregnancy, and risks to the fetus/infant. infant from utero exposure or through breast milk. These consensus guidelines are intended to provide pragmatic advice on these issues. These are divided into "risks of untreated disease in pregnancy, general principles of drug use in the perinatal period, benefits and harms associated with individual drugs". and recommendations for the management of certain disorders.

title: Capacity building for antiretroviral practice in South Africa: a qualitative evaluation of the PALSA PLUS nurse education program.
abstract: BACKGROUND: South Africa has recently launched a national antiretroviral treatment program. This has created an urgent need for nurse education in the practice of antiretroviral therapy (ART). The PALSA PLUS program provides guidelines and training for primary care (PHC) nurses in the management of adult pulmonary diseases and HIV/AIDS, including ART. A process assessment was conducted to document education, explore perceptions of the value of education, and compare the PALSA PLUS education approach (used in intervention areas) with the provincial education model. The evaluation was conducted in conjunction with a randomized controlled trial measuring the effects of PALSA PLUS nurse training (Trial reference number ISRCTN24820584). METHODS: Qualitative methods were used, including participant observation of the training sessions, focus group discussions, and interviews. The data were analyzed thematically. RESULTS: Nurses were highly interested in PALSA PLUS training, not only in terms of components specific to ART, but also in terms of lung health. In contrast to the one-time centralized training provided to ART nurses only in non-intervention clinics, continuing onsite training of all PHC nurses includes nurses' experience of support for their work, not only ongoing experiential learning but also supervision and emotional support, but also health care provider behavior change and for ongoing administrative review of all these infrastructure and system-level changes needed to facilitate guideline implementation. In contrast to only ART nurses, training of all PHC nurses in the use of PALSA PLUS guidelines was also perceived to facilitate the integration of AIDS care into the clinical context better. CONCLUSION: PALSA PLUS training has successfully engaged all PHC nurses with a comprehensive approach to various diseases affecting both HIV positive and negative patients. PHC nurse education for integrated systems-based interventions should be prioritized on the ART funding agenda. Education for individual provider behavior change, however, is only one aspect of ongoing system-wide interventions needed to deliver lasting improvements in patient care in the context of an overloaded and under-resourced PHC system.

title: Building clinical networks: a developmental assessment framework
abstract: Background Clinical networks are designed as an inter-organizational mechanism for planning and delivering healthcare services. With recent concerns about the effectiveness of these constructs, it is time to consider an evidence-based approach to how they can be developed and evaluated. Purpose To document an evaluation framework for clinical networks, drawing on the network evaluation literature and a 5-year study of clinical networks. Method We searched the literature in three areas: network assessment, factors that help or hinder network development, and robust methods for measuring network properties. This material was used to establish a necessary framework for effective developmental assessment. Results The architecture of the framework defines the three phases of clinical network development";" partner selection, network design and network management. At each stage, there is evidence of factors acting as facilitators and barriers to network growth. These factors can be used to measure progress through appropriate methods and tools. The framework can drive network growth and support informed decisions about progress. Conclusions For the first time, a framework with rigorous methods and tools in one place can identify factors known to influence the development of clinical networks. The target user group are internal stakeholders who need to conduct developmental assessment to inform important decisions along the development path of their network.

title: Building Statewide Infrastructure for Academic Support for Students with Mild Traumatic Brain Injury
abstract: OBJECTIVES: To focus attention on statewide capacity building to support students with mild traumatic brain injury (mTBI)/concussion. METHOD: Consensus building process with a multidisciplinary group of clinicians, researchers, policy makers, and State Department of Education staff. CONCLUSIONS: The white paper presents the group consensus on key components of a statewide educational infrastructure to support the management of students with mTBI. The nature of mTBI and the recovery process are briefly explained, particularly in relation to its effects on school learning and performance. State and local policy considerations are then highlighted to encourage the implementation of a coherent process. Five key components have been identified for establishing a statewide infrastructure for students with mTBI, including (1) definition and training of the interdisciplinary school team, (2) professional development of the school and medical communities, and (3) protocols for identification, assessment, and progress monitoring. , (4) a flexible set of intervention strategies to meet students' recovery needs, and (5) systematic protocols for active communication among medical, school, and family team members. The need for research to guide effective program implementation is emphasized. CONCLUSION: This guiding framework seeks to assist in the development of support structures to rescue students with mTBI to optimize academic outcomes. Until more evidence is found about academic regulation and other school-based support, education systems should follow current best practice guidelines.

title: Building Trust: History and Ongoing Relationships Between DSD Clinicians, Researchers, and Patient Advocacy Groups
abstract: Individuals born with differences or gender development disorders (DSD) have been marginalized by society and the health system. Standards of care in the mid-20th century relied on the fixation of the child with DSD with hormonal and surgical interventions"; this secrecy led to shame and stigma. When these children became adults and demanded access to their medical records, the understanding of the depth of secrecy led to the formation of activism groups that shook the medical community. Despite precarious beginnings, advocates, healthcare professionals, and researchers have managed to uncover changes in the standard of care. The 2006 Consensus Statement on the Management of Intersex Disorders called for a multidisciplinary approach to care and questioned the evidence for many standard procedures. A cloaking model for a patient-centered paradigm. and funding agencies are dedicating resources to identifying future research avenues on DSD. The need to address patient priorities has led to changing international standards for inclusion of patients in research design. Some of the remaining challenges were: r: Institute of Medicine findings that sexual and gender-based minorities experience poor health outcomes; to build trust between all parties;" to develop a common language and to create spaces where individuals can engage in dialogue that addresses personal experiences, research design, clinical practice and intervention strategies.

title: Cesarean birth. Summary of an NIH consensus statement
Can the court decide to participate in the research?
Can a rural community-based work-activity program make a difference for disabled workers with chronic pain?
abstract: OBJECTIVE: To evaluate the effectiveness of a multidisciplinary work-related activity program related to clinical guidelines and to improve the physical, psychological and occupational functioning of disabled workers with chronic pain. DESIGN: Uncontrolled, repeated measurements, a pilot study was conducted. SETTLEMENT: The intervention took place in a community setting in regional New South Wales. PARTICIPANTS: Participants (n = 30), mean age 41 years, had a compensable musculoskeletal injury: 60% were male, 63% had a back injury"; mean time off from work was 13 months. INTERVENTION: Cognitive-behavioral, the interdisciplinary intervention was carried out using a multi-participant provider model (a clinical psychologist and physiotherapist from separate practices working in liaison with the participant's vocational rehabilitation provider and treating physician) Groups of six participants participated half-day per week for six weeks. Outcome measures included: physical function, pain intensity, and psychological variables assessed before and after the program; and medical certification and work engagement recorded before the program and at six-month follow-up RESULTS: Significant gains in pain intensity, physical and psychological functioning, and medical certification. The mean effect size of the intervention was moderate to large (d = 0.70). There was no significant change in employment status at follow-up. CONCLUSIONS: The results of this pilot study suggest that independent, rural or community-based practitioners working collaboratively using an integrated treatment program can produce positive outcomes for injured workers with pain disabilities and achieve outcomes similar to those reported by metropolitan-based pain relief workers. clinics.

title: Can computer-generated evidence-based care recommendations improve evidence-based management of asthma and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease? A Randomly Controlled Experiment.
abstract: Aim. Translation of evidence-based guidelines into clinical practice has been inconsistent. We conducted a randomized, controlled trial of guideline-based care recommendations given to physicians as they type orders at computer workstations. Working Setting. Inner city academic general internal medicine application. Study design. Randomized, controlled trial of 246 physicians (25 percent faculty general internists, 75 percent internists) and 20 outpatient pharmacists. We enrolled 706 primary care patients with asthma or chronic obstructive pulmonary disease. Care recommendations regarding medications and monitoring were communicated to a random half of the doctors and pharmacists while typing orders or filling prescriptions using computer workstations. A 2×2 factorial randomization of practice sessions and pharmacists resulted in four patient groups: physician intervention, pharmacist intervention, both interventions, and controls. Data Extraction/Collection Methods. Compliance with guidelines and clinical activity were assessed using patients' electronic medical records. Health-related quality of life, medication adherence, and satisfaction with care were assessed using telephone questionnaires. Key Findings. During their year in the study, patients made an average of five planned primary care visits. There were no differences between groups in adherence to care recommendations, generic or condition-specific quality of life, satisfaction with physicians or pharmacists, medication adherence, emergency room visits, or hospitalizations. The doctors who received the intervention significantly increased their overall health care costs. Physicians' attitudes towards the guidelines were mixed. Results. Care recommendations shown to doctors and pharmacists at computer workstations had no effect on the delivery or outcome of care for patients with reactive respiratory disease.

title: Can handheld computers improve compliance? Pilot study of family doctors (Palm) in British Columbia
abstract: PURPOSE To examine whether Palm Prevention, a free software tool for Palm OS personal digital assistants (PDAs) that provides rapid access to patient-specific preventive guidelines at the point of care, improves compliance with five preventive measures in primary care. DESIGN Prospective intervention pilot study. SETTING Vancouver, BC and surrounding areas. PARTICIPANTS Eight general practitioners. INTERVENTIONS Each physician used Palm Prevention for five preventive measures during routine preventive health visits with 10 patients (n = 80). Charts of patients who gave consent for documentation of recommended maneuvers were reviewed. MAIN OUTCOME MEASURES Adherence rates to five evidence-based guidelines selected from Canadian and US task forces on preventive care and included in Palm Prevention. RESULTS Intervention and control physicians were similar in familiarity and use of PDAs and recruited similar patients for the study. The intervention and control groups had similar screening rates for hypertension. The intervention improved adherence to the remaining four guidelines: cervical cancer screening increased 22% (only absolute increases reported)"; hyperlipidemia screening increased 30%; colorectal cancer screening increased 27%, and prophylaxis with acetylsalicylic acid in high-risk patients increased 38% after the study. survey administered, all reported finding the software helpful and continuing to use Palm Prevention Usage statistics showed that study participants used the tool outside the trial: users entered the program between 28 and 68 unique patients during the 2-month intervention. He argues that these tools are useful in improving preventive care and facilitating the transformation of knowledge into practice, which was particularly evident with the new guidelines.

title: Can line clinicians master the conceptual complexities of dialectical behavior therapy? Evaluation of the training program of the State Ministry of Mental Health
abstract: Dialectical behavior therapy for borderline personality disorder quickly gained widespread popularity, with the development of educational initiatives by the Department of Mental Health in at least two states in the US. Efficacy data published by the treatment's creator, Marsha Linehan, and her colleagues likely explain this popularity, at least in part. However, the complexity of DBT raises a fundamental question regarding these broader applications: can clinicians from diverse backgrounds gain a common and complex understanding of treatment theory? The clinical utility of a treatment is largely based on its ease of diffusion (APA, Guideline development template: Interventions for the psychosocial aspects of mental and physical disorders. Washington, DC: Author, 1995) and in this context DBT - a complex, multifaceted approach - may appear vulnerable. This vulnerability is heightened when institutional adoption involves the collaboration of large numbers of clinicians who, despite performing a variety of roles, still need to develop a common understanding of treatment. Using a detailed review of DBT knowledge, we evaluated the conceptual mastery of 109 clinicians trained through a Government Department of Mental Health initiative. Performance in the exam is particularly associated with DBT training. Prior training or background in behavioral therapy accounted for little variability, suggesting that clinicians in different roles have acquired reasonable intellectual mastery of this complex model.

title: 'Could practice undertaken by patients be enhanced only through the application of agreed national guidelines?' an observational study
abstract: OBJECTIVE: To increase the autonomous practice time of patients in the stroke unit of a nursing home. INTERVENTION: With the help of four interventions (muscle strengthening, sitting balance and reaching, rising from chair, walking) from the evidence-based Clinical Nursing Rehabilitation Stroke Guidelines, nurses warned and coached patients. DESIGN: An observational study. In this study, the duration of administration of elderly stroke patients was compared with the time observed in our previous study in the same setting. SETTING: Rehabilitation units of a nursing home in the Netherlands. SUBJECTS: 17 frail stroke patients (8 males, 9 females) with a mean age of 75.8 (SD +/- 9) years and 17 identical subjects who participated in a previous observational study. MAIN MEASURES: Time spent on therapeutic activities was measured using the Behavioral Mapping method. RESULTS: Time spent on therapeutic activities increased significantly from 103.5 minutes measured in our previous study to 156.5 minutes in this study (Z = 2.86"; P < 0.005;" d' = 1.09) The mean Barthel Index score was 8.8 (SD +/- 4.1). Patients with greater odds were more active, resulting in a significant positive Barthel Index-therapy duration association (r = 0.73, P </= 0.001). CONCLUSIONS: Autonomous administration time increased on weekdays in older fragile comorbid stroke patients. Stimulated and challenged by nurses, patients exercise harder and harder than they can afford. As this guide was developed specifically for nurses, nurses can encourage stroke patients to contribute more to autonomous practice, thereby helping their recovery.

title: Can psychological models bridge the gap between clinical guidelines and clinicians' behavior? A randomized controlled trial of an intervention to influence dentists' intention to implement evidence-based practice.
abstract: OBJECTIVE: The delay between the publication of evidence for clinical practice and its implementation by clinicians can be decades. Research using psychological models shows that changing intention is crucial in changing behavior. This study examined an intervention (rehearsal of alternative actions) to change dentists' intention to implement evidence-based practice (EBP) for third molar (TM) management. DESIGN: Randomized controlled trial/mail. SETTING: Primary care. SUBJECTS AND METHODS: Dentists were randomly selected from the Scottish Dental Practice Board Registry, then randomly distributed to intervention or control groups, and a questionnaire was submitted. The intervention group listed management alternatives to TM extraction prior to intent to TM extraction and the control group did not. Based on psychological models to reduce the frequency of a behavior (EBP is weighted against TM subtraction), pre-listing of alternatives should reduce the intent to subtract. MAIN OUTCOME MEASURES: Intention to remove TMs. RESULTS: A total of 99 dentists - 70 Males, 29 Females"; mean age = 41.42 years (SD = 8.62) participated in the study. The intervention significantly influenced the intention to remove TMs as desired. Despite similar background and knowledge of management alternatives, participants had significantly lower subtraction intentions: control group mean (SD) = 0.39 (1.99); intervention group mean (SD) = -0.78 (1.89); mean difference (SE) = 1, 17 (0.42);" The 95% confidence interval for the difference = 0.34 to 1.99. CONCLUSION: The results suggest that this intervention, which successfully affects the proximal predictor of dental EBP-related behavior, may result in improved EBP in a service-level trial. Basing practice interventions and trial methodology on psychological models can effectively bridge the gap between clinical guidelines and practice.

title: Can we address depression in vision rehabilitation settings? Professional perspectives on barriers to integrating problem-solving therapy
abstract: OBJECTIVE: Low vision rehabilitation (LVR) is an appropriate context to integrate early, evidence-based psychological interventions, given the high prevalence of untreated depression in adults with visual impairment. This study aims to identify perceived barriers and facilitators to staff-provided telephone-based problem-solving therapy for primary care (PST-PC) offered as an integrated component of LVR. METHODS: Qualitative semi-structured interviews developed using the theoretical domain framework (TDF) and the Consolidated Framework for Practice Research (CFIR) were conducted with 21 LVR experts and a clinical psychologist involved in the presentation of the PST-PC. Obstacles and facilitators at the practitioner, client, intervention and organizational level were identified by thematic analysis using a "theoretical" approach. RESULTS: Obvious barriers were lack of role recognition for PST-PC implementers (n = 32), unmet customer expectation with PST-PC (n = 28), dissatisfaction with phone delivery (n = 27), and limited institutional awareness of PST. -PC (n = 39). Facilitating factors included a recognized need for evidence-based psychological services (n = 28), clients benefiting from early sessions (n = 38), PST-PC supporting practical skills (n = 26), and extensive PST-PC training (n). . = 36). CONCLUSIONS: PST-PC may provide an accessible early intervention for LVR patients with depressive symptoms. Ongoing practitioner education, clinical support, and screening of potential LVR patients for treatment eligibility are likely to improve delivery in this setting. Implications for rehabilitation Depression is very common among adults participating in low vision rehabilitation (LVR) programs, but few receive support. Clinical guidelines recommend the delivery of integrated care models in rehabilitation settings as early intervention for mild to moderate depressive symptoms. Integrated telephone-based problem-solving therapy (PST-PC) for primary care, provided by trained LVR practitioners, is a practical, skills-based model with the potential to increase access to early psychological intervention in LVR patients with depressive symptoms. LVR patients are generally older, have multiple co-morbidities, and significant functional disability, requiring flexibility in PST-PC delivery and specialist staff training and support in working with older and more complex clients.

title: Can we improve compliance with guidelines for the treatment of lower urinary tract infection? A simple, versatile intervention in out-of-hours services
abstract: OBJECTIVES: To improve the antimicrobial prescribing behavior of GPs in large-scale out-of-hours services for uncomplicated lower urinary tract infection (LUTI) in women aged 20-80 years, which is considered one of the most common bacterial infections in primary care. care. METHODS: A quasi-experimental design was used in two regional large-scale out-of-hours services. A simple, multifaceted intervention was proposed in one region (intervention site) over a 16-week period. We observed the diagnoses and prescriptions during the two purification periods at 5 and 17 months. The main outcome measure was the share of suitable and unsuitable prescriptions. RESULTS: The proportion of patients with LUTI ranged from 1.0% to 2.1%. The relative proportion of eligible prescriptions in the response area increased from 26.9% to 69.4%, but then decreased to 40.8%. CONCLUSIONS: A simple, versatile intervention to LUTI therapy during out-of-hours care may improve the quality of antimicrobial prescribing, although improvement may not be sustained over the long term.

title: Canadian Contraception Consensus (Chapter 1/4)
abstract: OBJECTIVE: To provide health care providers with guidelines on the use of contraception to prevent pregnancy and the promotion of healthy sexuality. CONCLUSIONS: Guidance for Canadian practitioners on general efficacy, mechanism of action, indications, contraindications, non-contraceptive benefits, side effects and risks, and initiation of the cited contraceptive methods"; family planning in the context of sexual health and general well-being; contraceptive counseling methods and in Canada cited contraceptive methods Access and availability of methods Evidence: Published literature, appropriate controlled words (eg health) and keywords (eg birth control, family planning, hormonal contraception, emergency contraception) Results with systematic reviews, randomized controlled trials/controlled clinical trials and January 1994 Limited to observational studies published in English between January 2015, updated regularly and included in guidance for June 2015. Gray (unpublished) literature includes health technology assessment and health technology institutions, clinical practice guide collections, clinical research It was determined by searching the medical records and the websites of national and international medical specialty associations. VALUES: The quality of the evidence in this document has been graded using the criteria described in the Canadian Preventive Healthcare Task Force Report (Table). Part 1: Canadian Contraception Summary Disclosures 1. Canadian women spend a significant portion of their lives at risk of unwanted pregnancy. (II-2) 2. Effective contraception is underutilized in Canada, especially among vulnerable populations. (II-2) 3. Long-acting reversible contraceptive methods, including contraceptive implants and intrauterine contraception (copper-releasing and levonorgestrel-releasing devices/systems), are the most effective reversible contraceptive methods and have the highest retention rates. (II-1) 4. Canada does not currently collect reliable data to determine the use of birth control methods, abortion rates, and the prevalence of unintended pregnancies among women of reproductive age. (II-2) 5. A universal subsidy for birth control methods provided by many of Canada's peer countries and several Canadian provinces could result in cost savings in the healthcare system. (II-2) 6. Health Canada approval processes for contraceptives have been less efficient than those of other drug approval agencies and Health Canada processes for other drug classes. (II-2) 7. It is possible and safe to provide birth control methods and family planning services by appropriately trained allied health professionals such as midwives, registered nurses, general nurses and pharmacists. (II-2) Recommendations 1. Contraceptive counseling should include discussion of typical use failure rates and the importance of consistent and correct use of the contraceptive method to prevent pregnancy. (II-2A) 2. Women seeking contraception should be counseled about the wide variety of effective methods of contraception available, including long-acting reversible methods of contraception (LARCs). LARCs are the most effective methods of reversible contraception, have high retention rates and should be considered when presenting contraceptive options to any woman of reproductive age. (II-2A) 3. Family planning counseling should include counseling on decreased fertility associated with increasing female age. (III-A) 4. Health policy that promotes a universal birth control subsidy and strategies that promote the adoption of highly effective methods as cost-saving measures that improve health and equity in health should be considered by Canadian health decision makers. (III-B) 5. Canadian health jurisdictions should consider expanding the scope of practice of other trained professionals, such as nurses, GPs, midwives and pharmacists, and promoting family planning task sharing. (II-2B) 6. The Canadian Community Health Survey should include adequate reproductive health indicators so that healthcare providers and policy makers can make appropriate decisions regarding reproductive health policies and services in Canada. (III-B) 7. Health Canada processes and policies should be reviewed to ensure that a wide range of modern contraceptives are available to Canadian women. (III-B) Chapter 2: Summary Statements of Contraceptive Care and Access 8. Although many contraceptive options are available in Canada, only a narrow range of contraceptive methods are commonly used by those of reproductive age. (II-3) 9. As the duration of intercourse is prolonged and the sexual partner is accepted as the main partner, condom use decreases, probably due to the perceived lower risk of sexually transmitted infections in this relationship. Condom use can also be significantly reduced as an undesirable outcome when an effective non-blocking method such as hormonal contraception or intrauterine contraception is initiated. (II-3) 10. Family planning counseling provides a natural transition to screening for concerns about sexual function or intimate partner violence. (III) 11. Individuals who are well-informed, knowledgeable and motivated to practice safer sex behaviors are more likely to use contraception and safer sex methods effectively and consistently. (II-2) Recommendations 8. Comprehensive family planning services, including abortion services, should be accessible to all Canadians regardless of geographic location. These services should be confidential, non-judgmental, and respectful of individuals' privacy and cultural contexts. (III-A) 9. title: Canadian Contraception Consensus (Chapter 2/4)
abstract: OBJECTIVE: To provide health care providers with guidelines on the use of contraception to prevent pregnancy and the promotion of healthy sexuality. CONCLUSIONS: Guidance for Canadian practitioners on general efficacy, mechanism of action, indications, contraindications, non-contraceptive benefits, side effects and risks, and initiation of the cited contraceptive methods"; family planning in the context of sexual health and general well-being; contraceptive counseling methods and in Canada cited contraceptive methods Access and availability of methods Evidence: Published literature, appropriate controlled words (eg health) and keywords (eg birth control, family planning, hormonal contraception, emergency contraception) Results with systematic reviews, randomized controlled trials/controlled clinical trials and January 1994 Limited to observational studies published in English between January 2015, updated regularly and included in guidance for June 2015. Gray (unpublished) literature includes health technology assessment and health technology institutions, clinical practice guide collections, clinical research It was determined by searching the medical records and the websites of national and international medical specialty associations. VALUES: The quality of the evidence in this document has been graded using the criteria described in the Canadian Preventive Healthcare Task Force Report (Table). Part 1: Canadian Contraception Summary Disclosures 1. Canadian women spend a significant portion of their lives at risk of unwanted pregnancy. (II-2) 2. Effective contraception is underutilized in Canada, especially among vulnerable populations. (II-2) 3. Long-acting reversible contraceptive methods, including contraceptive implants and intrauterine contraception (copper-releasing and levonorgestrel-releasing devices/systems), are the most effective reversible contraceptive methods and have the highest retention rates. (II-1) 4. Canada does not currently collect reliable data to determine the use of birth control methods, abortion rates, and the prevalence of unintended pregnancies among women of reproductive age. (II-2) 5. A universal subsidy for birth control methods provided by many of Canada's peer countries and several Canadian provinces could result in cost savings in the healthcare system. (II-2) 6. Health Canada approval processes for contraceptives have been less efficient than those of other drug approval agencies and Health Canada processes for other drug classes. (II-2) 7. It is possible and safe to provide birth control methods and family planning services by appropriately trained allied health professionals such as midwives, registered nurses, general nurses and pharmacists. (II-2) Recommendations 1. Contraceptive counseling should include discussion of typical use failure rates and the importance of consistent and correct use of the contraceptive method to prevent pregnancy. (II-2A) 2. Women seeking contraception should be counseled about the wide variety of effective methods of contraception available, including long-acting reversible methods of contraception (LARCs). LARCs are the most effective methods of reversible contraception, have high retention rates and should be considered when presenting contraceptive options to any woman of reproductive age. (II-2A) 3. Family planning counseling should include counseling on decreased fertility associated with increasing female age. (III-A) 4. Health policy that promotes a universal birth control subsidy and strategies that promote the adoption of highly effective methods as cost-saving measures that improve health and equity in health should be considered by Canadian health decision makers. (III-B) 5. Canadian health jurisdictions should consider expanding the scope of practice of other trained professionals, such as nurses, GPs, midwives and pharmacists, and promoting family planning task sharing. (II-2B) 6. The Canadian Community Health Survey should include adequate reproductive health indicators so that healthcare providers and policy makers can make appropriate decisions regarding reproductive health policies and services in Canada. (III-B) 7. Health Canada processes and policies should be reviewed to ensure that a wide range of modern contraceptives are available to Canadian women. (III-B) Chapter 2: Summary Statements of Contraceptive Care and Access 8. Although many contraceptive options are available in Canada, only a narrow range of contraceptive methods are commonly used by those of reproductive age. (II-3) 9. As the duration of intercourse is prolonged and the sexual partner is accepted as the main partner, condom use decreases, probably due to the perceived lower risk of sexually transmitted infections in this relationship. Condom use can also be significantly reduced as an undesirable outcome when an effective non-blocking method such as hormonal contraception or intrauterine contraception is initiated. (II-3) 10. Family planning counseling provides a natural transition to screening for concerns about sexual function or intimate partner violence. (III) 11. Individuals who are well-informed, knowledgeable and motivated to practice safer sex behaviors are more likely to use contraception and safer sex methods effectively and consistently. (II-2) Recommendations 8. Comprehensive family planning services, including abortion services, should be accessible to all Canadians regardless of geographic location. These services should be confidential, non-judgmental, and respectful of individuals' privacy and cultural contexts. (III-A) 9. (III-B) 12. (III-B) 13. (IA) 14. (III-B) 15. title: Canadian guidelines for the evidence-based treatment of tic disorders: behavioral therapy, deep brain stimulation, and transcranial magnetic stimulation
abstract: This clinical guideline provides recommendations for non-pharmacological treatments for tic disorders. We conducted a systematic literature search for clinical trials on the treatment of tics. An evidence-based review (including 30 studies) and 3 studies on behavioral interventions, 3 studies on deep brain stimulation (DBS), and 3 studies on transcranial magnetic stimulation (TMS) met our inclusion criteria. Based on this evidence, we made strong recommendations for the use of habit-reversing therapy and exposure and response prevention, preferably embedded in a supportive, psychoeducational program and with the option to combine either of these approaches with pharmacotherapy. Although there is evidence for the efficacy of DBS, the quality of this evidence is weak and the risks and burdens of the procedure are delicately balanced with the perceived benefits. Our recommendation is that this intervention continues to be considered an experimental treatment for severe, medically resistant tics with severe limitations to quality of life. We recommend that the procedure be performed only as part of research studies and by physicians who are experts in DBS programming and management of tics. There is no evidence to support the use of TMS in the treatment of tics. However, the procedure is associated with a low rate of known complications and may continue to be evaluated within research protocols. The recommendations we provide are based on current information and further work may result in future revisions.

title: Canadian study of clinical status at onset of dialysis 1998-1999: a multicenter prospective study
abstract: OBJECTIVES: The current growth in end-stage renal disease populations has led to increased efforts to understand the impact of dialysis initiation status on long-term outcomes. Our main goal was to improve the understanding of current Canadian practice of nephrology from October 1998 to December 1999. METHODS: Fifteen nephrology centers in 7 provinces participated in a prospective data collection survey. The main outcome of interest was the clinical status at dialysis initiation, determined by: residual renal function, readiness for chronic dialysis, as measured by the presence or absence of permanent peritoneal or hemodialysis access, hemoglobin, and serum albumin. Uremic symptoms at the start of dialysis were also recorded, but in some cases these symptom data were obtained retrospectively. RESULTS: Data were collected from 251 patients over 1-month periods. Patients began dialysis with an average of 3 symptoms, with calculated mean creatinine clearance levels of approximately 10 ml/min. 35% of patients who started dialysis were known to nephrologists for less than 3 months. These patients are more likely to start without permanent access and with lower hemoglobin and albumin levels. Even those known to nephrologists, only 66% had permanent access. CONCLUSIONS: Patients starting dialysis in Canada appear to do so in relative agreement with published guidelines for timing of initiation. Despite a growing awareness of kidney disease, a significant number of patients continue to start dialysis without prior intervention by a nephrologist. Clinical and laboratory parameters of those seen by nephrologists are below optimal according to current guidelines. This survey provides an important basis for future comparisons after implementation of educational strategies for referring physicians and nephrologists.

title: Cancer adolescent pathway in France between 1988 and 1997
abstract: We report an adolescent cancer pathway in France, from referral to diagnosis and treatment. All cancer cases diagnosed from 1988 to 1997 (10% of the French population) diagnosed in the nine French population-based cancer registries were included. Treatment of adolescent cancer by pediatricians was rare. Adolescents' cancer management pathway can be summarized as the first visit to the GP, referral to an adult oncologist for hematological malignancies and medical or surgical specialists for solid tumors, treatment in the adult unit, and follow-up by an adult oncologist, adult medical or surgical specialist. specialist or general practitioner. Only 9% of the 15-19 age group enter clinical trial (6% and 3%, respectively, adult and pediatric clinical trial). The inclusion rate varies by diagnosis, with higher for acute lymphoblastic leukemia (39%), non-Hodgkin lymphomas (NHL) (27%), and acute non-lymphoblastic leukemia (20%). Only 4% of adolescent cancers, particularly soft tissue sarcomas (14.9%), malignant bone tumors (13.4), central nervous system tumors (6.2%) and NHL (4.4%) are common adult/ treated in pediatric departments. Whatever the reasons for the lack of participation in clinical trials, an ideal model that requires communication and collaboration between all adult and pediatric professionals involved in adolescent cancer treatment should reduce the huge gap in accessing collaborative groups.

title: Cancer education among primary care physicians in an underserved community
abstract: INTRODUCTION: Urban minority groups, such as those living in northern Manhattan, are often underserved in cancer prevention and screening practices. Primary care physicians are in a critical position to counsel their patients on these issues and have their patients undergo screening tests. METHODS: Eighty-four primary care physicians in two intervention communities who received educational visits about cancer screening and prevention were compared with 38 doctors in a nearby community who did not receive interventions. Through pre- and post-test interviews over an 18-month period, physicians were asked about their attitudes towards breast, cervical, colorectal, and prostate, their knowledge (according to American Cancer Society guidelines), and counseling and screening possibilities. cancers. RESULTS: Comparing the two questionnaires with physicians showed no statistically significant difference in cancer prevention or screening information. However, in the posttest, intervention group physicians identified significantly fewer barriers to practice than control physicians (p<0.05). Overall, although educational visits to inner-city primary care physicians did not appear to significantly alter cancer prevention practices, there was a positive dose-response relationship among the subgroup of participants who received three or more project contacts. RESULTS: We uncovered significant changes in attitude among urban primary care physicians working in northern Manhattan due to academic elaboration. A significant pretest sensitization effect and the small numbers may have masked overall changes in cancer prevention and screening behaviors among physicians due to the intervention.

title: Cancer-related and treatment-related fatigue
abstract: Fatigue is a distressing and persistent symptom for gynecological cancer patients and survivors. Debilitating cancer-related fatigue (CRF) is produced by both the disease and its treatment. Although awareness and study of CRF have increased in recent years, consistent assessment has not been a priority in routine medical practice. The pathophysiological mechanisms that induce CRF remain unclear, and effective pharmacological interventions have yet to be determined. Based on the literature and our own research results, this review focuses on recent advances in understanding the nature and causes of CRF and several promising treatment modalities. Given the prevalence and severity of CRF in the gynecological cancer patient population, it is extremely important to establish standardized methods of fatigue measurement and management in routine clinical oncology care. However, whether CRF has an underlying inflammatory cause remains hypothetical, and although the development of such interventions will provide patients with greater symptom control, there is currently no mechanism-driven symptom intervention in clinical use. Advancing transformational and clinical fatigue research will require anatomical pathways and well-designed clinical trials focused on the development of mechanism-driven interventions based on physiological-behavioral fatigue research, the application of guidelines for experimental designs, and the discovery of biomarkers that identify high-level individuals. risk for CRF. Confirmed patient-reported outcome measures are an important component of such clinical trials. Because many subscales, one-dimensional measurements, and multidimensional measurements are available, clinicians and researchers should consider individual circumstances, good clinical practice, and research goals as guidelines for selecting the most appropriate fatigue measurement tool. In addition, education about CRF should be provided to all patients and their caregivers, as accurate and age-appropriate information about conditions such as CRF can alleviate much of the stress and anxiety caused by poor communication about this distressing condition.

title: Cardiac drug and psychotropic drug interactions: importance and recommendations
abstract: Understanding cardiac drug interactions with concurrent psychotropic prescriptions is crucial for the psychiatrist as well as the practicing cardiologist and primary care physician. There has been an explosive use of new drugs in both psychiatry and cardiology without widespread knowledge of their potential interactions. The growing trend towards multi-pharmacy, the use of psychotropic drugs by cardiologists and primary care physicians caring for cardiac patients, and the growth of an aging population pose major challenges for the practitioner. Finally, models/paradigms are needed to predict potential drug interactions - eg Cytochrome p450 schema. This article describes a method for identifying, understanding, and coding interactions between psychotropic and cardiac drugs, and a systematic approach to update this important database and specific cardiac-psychotropic drug interactions. Specifically, this article 1) details interactions, 2) considers their level of clinical significance, 3) describes the potential mechanism(s) of interactions, and 4) offers recommendations to the clinician. Because most of the original clinical trials for both cardiac drugs and psychotropic drugs did not include studies comparing these two drug areas simultaneously, their interactions are often only known in the clinical arena with their combined use, using the patient as a "guinea pig." ," and via subsequent reporting.

title: Cardiac rehabilitation and risk factor management after myocardial infarction. Clinical and economic evaluation
abstract: The increasing scarcity of available and limited health resources and the increasing demand for health services have made it imperative to consider the effectiveness and cost-effectiveness of health services such as secondary prevention of heart disease. There is substantial evidence that modifying smoking, hyperlipidemia, hypertension, and lack of physical activity, alone or in combination, is effective in reducing the number of clinical events in secondary prevention of heart disease. Economic evaluation is the comparative analysis of alternative courses of action in terms of both costs and consequences. Data generated in economic assessments of health services, such as risk factor modification for secondary prevention of heart disease, are useful in the development of clinical practice guidelines and health policies. While smoking cessation is the most cost-effective intervention for patients with documented heart disease, hyperlipidemia treatment and referral to cardiac rehabilitation are highly cost-effective per quality-adjusted life-year and relatively cost-effective per life-year saved. Risk factor management, delivered by a team of appropriately trained allied health professionals along with cardiovascular specialists and other physicians, is the cornerstone of optimal care in both primary and secondary prevention of heart disease.

title: Cardiac Rehabilitation: Unraveling the Complexity of Referral and Current Delivery Models
abstract: BACKGROUND: Evidence-based guidelines recommend strategies to reduce risk factors for secondary prevention of acute coronary syndromes, but application to and completion of programs is insufficient to make this recommendation. OBJECTIVE: In this article, we describe the complexity of factors that influence the referral and delivery of evidence-based cardiac rehabilitation (CR) programs in the Australian context and provide direction for solutions that clinicians and policy makers should consider. The Ecological Approach is used as a framework for synthesizing evidence. The approach has 5 categories, the characteristics of which can act as barriers and facilitators to the promotion and adoption of health behaviors and include (a) interpersonal factors, (b) interpersonal factors, (c) institutional factors, (d) community networks, and (e) public policy. CONCLUSIONS: Despite the context of strong evidence for efficacy, this review highlights systematic flaws in the implementation of CR, an important intervention that has been shown to improve patient outcomes and prevent cardiac events. Recommendations from this review include standardizing program delivery, improving data capture, using technological innovations and social networks to facilitate the delivery of information and support, and establishing a cohesive, coherent message through inter-agency collaboration in CR. CLINICAL APPLICATIONS: These pathways provide direction for potential solutions to improve CR uptake and secondary prevention.

title: Specialized medical and mental health care unit care compared to standard care for elderly people with cognitive impairment admitted to general hospital: randomized controlled trial (NIHR TEAM study)
abstract: OBJECTIVE To develop and evaluate a best practice model of general hospital acute medical care for elderly people with cognitive impairment. DESIGN Randomized controlled trial adapted to account for the constraints imposed by a dense acute medical admissions system. SET is the largest acute general hospital in the UK. PARTICIPANTS 600 patients over 65 years of age presenting for acute medical care were described as "confused" at admission. INTERVENTIONS Participants were randomized to a specialist medical and mental health unit designed to provide best practice care for patients with delirium or dementia or standard care (acute geriatrics or general medical services). Features of the specialist unit include "joint staffing by medical and mental health professionals"; advanced staff training in delirium, dementia and person-centered dementia care; provision of organized purposeful activity; environmental modification to meet the needs of those with cognitive impairment; prevention of delirium and a proactive and inclusive approach to family caregivers. approach MAIN OUTCOME MEASURES PRIMARY OUTCOME Number of days spent at home during 90 days after randomization SECOND RESULTS structured non-participant observations to determine patients' experience; satisfaction of family caregivers with hospital care Outcomes assessment was closed to separation when possible RESULTS Days spent at home between specialist unit and standard care groups there was no significant difference (median 51 vs 45 days, 95% confidence interval for difference -12 to 24; P=0.3 Median index hospital stay 11 days vs. 11, mortality 22% vs 25% (-9%) to 4%, readmission was 32% to specialist unit and stand For rt care groups, 35% (-10% to 5%) and nursing home new admissions 20% versus 28% (-16% to 0%), respectively. Patients returning home spent an average of 70.5 days (-6.0 to 6.5) versus 71.0 days at home. Patients in the specialist unit spent significantly more time in positive mood or engagement (68% versus 79%, 2% to 20%; P=0.03) and experienced more staff interaction that met emotional and psychological needs (per observation). median 4 to 1; P<0.001). More family caregivers were satisfied with care (83% vs. 91%, 2% to 15%; P=0.004) and severe dissatisfaction decreased (10% vs. 5%, -10% to 0%;" P =0.05) CONCLUSIONS Specialist care for patients with delirium and dementia improved patients' experience and caregiver satisfaction, but there was no convincing benefit in health status or service use.Patient experience and caregiver satisfaction may be more appropriate measures of success for frail older people. upcoming people TRIAL REGISTRATION Clinical Trials NCT01136148.

title: Caring for adults with developmental disabilities: implications of a continuing education course for primary care providers
abstract: OBJECTIVE: To evaluate the effects of an interdisciplinary, guideline-based continuing education course on measures to care for adults with developmental disabilities (DD). DESIGN: A before and after study with a control group. SETTING: Ontario. PARTICIPANTS: Forty-seven primary care providers (doctors, registered nurses and nurses). INTERVENTION: Participants either only received reference material on primary care for persons with DD (control group) or attended a continuing education course on primary care care for persons with DD in addition to receiving reference material (intervention group). MAIN OUTCOME MEASURES: Participants reported 5 key measures regarding the care of adults with DD: frequency of using guidelines, frequency of performing periodic health checkups, frequency of evaluating patients presenting with behavioral changes, level of comfort in caring for adults with DD, and regarding adults with DD basic maintenance knowledge. RESULTS: Over time, the intervention group showed significant increases in 4 of the 5 key care measures compared to the control group: frequency of use of guidelines (P < .001), frequency of evaluation of behavior change by patients (P = .03), comfort level of care for persons with DD ( P = .01) and primary care information for adults with DD (P = .01). CONCLUSION: A continuing education course in primary care of adults with DD is a useful interdisciplinary model for training healthcare professionals who provide primary care to these patients.

title: Caring for the patient in menopause: a nurse practitioner view
abstract: OBJECTIVE: To evaluate the benefits and risks of hormone therapy (HT) and other treatment options for early postmenopausal women. DATA SOURCES: Published clinical studies, selected peer-reviewed literature, and current clinical practice guidelines. CONCLUSIONS: The results of the Women's Health Initiative (WHI) studies on HT may not be directly applicable to healthy, early postmenopausal women suffering from hot flashes. HT is the most effective treatment for menopausal symptoms. The benefits of HT in relieving menopausal symptoms are likely to outweigh the risks in this population. APPLICATIONS TO PRACTICE: The results of WHI reinforce the importance of individualized care based on the woman's medical history, medical needs, and desired outcomes. Nurse practitioners can help their patients put the final results into perspective. When HT is used, nurse practitioners should consider using lower doses and reassess the need for treatment annually.

title: CD4 cell count and viral load monitoring in patients on antiretroviral therapy in Uganda: a cost-effectiveness study.
abstract: OBJECTIVE To examine the cost and cost-effectiveness of quarterly CD4 cell count and viral load monitoring in patients receiving antiretroviral therapy (ART). DESIGN Cost effectiveness study. SETTINGS A randomized trial in a home-based ART program in Tororo, Uganda. PARTICIPANTS HIV-infected individuals who are members of AIDS Support Organization and have CD4 cell count <250 µ 10(6) cells/L or World Health Organization stage 3 or 4 disease. MAIN OUTCOME MEASURES Outcomes calculated for the study period and projected beyond 15 years included costs, disability-adjusted life years (DALYs), and incremental cost-effectiveness rates (ICER"; $ per DALY avoided). Cost inputs were empirical and other sources From the study clinical inputs obtained In the baseline, we assumed that point estimates reflect true differences, even if not significant. We performed univariate and multivariate sensitivity analyzes INTERVENTIONS Three monitoring strategies: clinical monitoring and viral load measurement (clinical/CD4/viral load) with quarterly CD4 cell counts; clinical monitoring and quarterly CD4 counts (clinical/CD4);" and clinical monitoring only. RESULTS With intent to treat (ITT) outcomes per 100 people starting ART, we found that clinical/CD4 monitoring increased costs by $20,458 (£12,780, â€šâ€14,707) compared to clinical monitoring alone and prevented 117.3. DALY (ICER = $174 per DALY). Clinical/CD4/viral load monitoring adds $142,458 compared to clinical/CD4 monitoring and avoids 27.5 DALYs ($5181 per DALY). Superior ICER for clinical/CD4 monitoring is resistant to uncertainties in input values, and this strategy dominates (cheaper and more effective) when compared to clinical/CD4/viral load monitoring in a quarter of simulations. If clinical inputs are based on treated analysis starting at 90 days (after laboratory monitoring is initiated), other strategies dominate clinical/CD4/viral load monitoring. CONCLUSIONS Based on this trial, compared with clinical monitoring alone, routine CD4 cell count monitoring is much more cost-effective than adding routine viral load testing to the monitoring strategy and is more cost-effective than ART.

title: Cervical cancer screening in adolescents: an evidence-based internet training program for practice development among advanced practice nurses.
abstract: BACKGROUND: The literature reports that recent changes in cervical cancer screening guidelines vary widely in their application to clinical practice and in knowledge levels. Evidence-based screening guidelines for the prevention and early detection of cervical cancer offer healthcare providers an opportunity to improve practice patterns among female adolescents by reducing psychological distress as well as reducing healthcare costs and the morbidities associated with overscreening. OBJECTIVE: The purpose of this pilot intervention study was to determine the knowledge of advanced practice nurses (APNs) of a Web-based continuing education unit (CEU) program about current evidence-based recommendations for cervical cancer screening and their impact on their practice in practice. This article presents a process improvement project as an example of a way to disseminate updated evidence-based practice guidelines among busy healthcare providers. METHODS: This Web-based CEU program was developed, piloted, and evaluated specifically for APNs. The program addressed the level of knowledge about cervical cancer and its relationship to high-risk human papillomavirus. He also touched upon the new cervical cancer screening guidelines and their application to clinical practice. RESULTS: The results of the study showed that there are knowledge gaps among APNs about cervical cancer screening in adolescents. However, when a CEU educational intervention was provided, the knowledge levels of APNs increased and their self-reported clinical practice behavior changed according to the new cervical cancer screening guidelines. LINKING THE EVIDENCE TO PRACTICE: The provision of relevant and easily accessible up-to-date electronic content providing CEU accelerates the adoption of clinical practice guidelines, thereby reducing the potential for morbidity associated with excessive cervical cancer screening in adolescents and young women.

title: Challenges and opportunities with the introduction of next-generation long-lived insecticidal networks for malaria control: a case study from Burkina Faso
abstract: Background Decreases in malaria incidence in Africa are largely attributable to increases in malaria vector control activities", predominantly the use of long-lived insecticidal nets (LLINs). Insecticide resistance affects an increasing number of malaria-endemic countries and threatens their effectiveness. This There is a growing urgency for the implementation of alternative tools to control resistant populations. The aim of this study was to identify potential challenges and opportunities to accelerate access to next-generation LLINs in Burkina Faso, a country with high levels of virus. Insecticide resistance Methods Selection of interviewees, data an analytical framework was used to guide collection and analysis Semi-structured interviews with key information providers were conducted in Burkina Faso in April 2014 Interviews were conducted in French and English, audio recorded, transcribed and entered into NVivo 10 for data management and analysis. coded according to framework themes and d It is then analyzed to provide a definition of key points and to explain patterns in the data. Conclusions Interviewees reported that the policy architecture in Burkina Faso is characterized by a strong framework of actors that contribute to policy-making and strong national research capacity that indirectly contributes to national policy change through collaboration with internationally-led research. Financing significantly impacts the potential adoption, availability, and affordability of next-generation LLINs. This gives significant leverage to the international donors funding vector control. National decisions over which LLINs will be procured were limited to quantity and delivery dates; "The potential to combat pesticide resistance was not part of the decision-making process. Also, at the time of the study, the World Health Organization (WHO) did not have guidance on where and when next-generation LLINs can have a positive impact on malaria transmission, which means their adoption, This study shows that access to next-generation LLINs is severely compromised by the lack of global guidance.Burkina Faso, where WHO recommendations are adopted relatively quickly, with clear WHO advice and adequate funding, next-generation LLN It will be the key to speed up access to .

title: Interchangeability, trust, common sense, and validation: comprehensive suicide risk assessment
abstract: OBJECTIVE: The authors, in collaboration with NSW Health, have recently developed a comprehensive suicide risk assessment framework. This article explains the key concepts in the assessment of suicide risk by mental health professionals. METHODS: A framework was established to conduct a comprehensive suicide risk assessment from the literature, event analysis, and clinical experience. The framework went through a consultation process involving clinicians in NSW area mental health services. The aim was to provide clinicians with a standardized conceptual map for the assessment of suicide risk.
