A MEDLINE search was conducted for publications on 'suicide' and 'suicide risk assessment' from 1980 to 2002. Recommendations from on-call case studies conducted at a mental health service in the NSW region during 1999-2002 were reviewed. Lessons learned from the visit to a coroner's relatives support group for people mourning suicide also informed the development of guidelines. RESULTS: A framework has been proposed for the assessment of suicide risk. The framework encourages a reflective style of practice, encouraging clinicians to consider their assessments and limitations. Risk assessment is always done as part of a full clinical assessment and assessment of the person's current predicament and psychosocio-cultural context. The concepts of mutability, evaluation confidence, common sense, and the importance of validation are included in the framework. CONCLUSIONS: A framework can guide mental health clinicians in assessing and documenting suicide risk. The assessment of suicide risk can establish a suicide risk rating for which minimum standards of care can be mandated.

title: Changes and challenges: managing ADHD in a fast-paced world
abstract: OBJECTIVE: Attention deficit/hyperactivity disorder (ADHD) negatively affects the lives of both children and adults. Undiagnosed and untreated ADHD can have serious lifelong consequences. Research has identified diagnostic clues, neurotransmitter pathways, and psychiatric comorbidities associated with ADHD, as well as effective pharmacological, behavioral, and psychosocial interventions. Stimulant agents have been the foundation of ADHD treatment for over 50 years. The availability of new extended-release (XR or ER) and longer-acting (LA) formulations and new agents allows for wider and more personalized treatment options. The side effects of stimulants are usually mild, short-lived, and responsive to adjustments in dosage or timing. Outcomes in ADHD treatment can be improved through the use of clear treatment guidelines and tools to help clinicians implement them efficiently and effectively. The Texas Children's Drug Algorithm Project (CMAP) provides an algorithm-based system of treatment decisions that is evidence-based and easy to implement. OBJECTIVE: (1) To review the psychological components of attention, the neurotransmitter pathways associated with ADHD, and the array of therapeutic options for ADHD, with emphasis on the latest entries in therapeutic equipment; (2) discuss rare psychiatric disorders and cardiovascular side effects associated with stimulants; (3) review liability for abuse, comorbidities, and suggested approaches to these issues; and (4) review the development and use of CMAP and provide resources for its application in clinical practice. CONCLUSION: The pathophysiology of ADHD is associated with dysfunction of fronto-subcortical networks and dysregulation of dopaminergic, noradrenergic and nicotinic neurotransmitter systems. Additional effects of multiple genes and environmental influences contribute to the clinical picture. Treatment with stimulants and non-stimulants has proven effective in different subgroups, most likely with the efficacy of specific agents related to the primary neurotransmitter involved. The availability of XR, ER, LA, and transdermal stimulant formulations, as well as alternative non-stimulant agents, offer new options for pharmacotherapy of ADHD. Major concerns about the abuse liability of stimulants have been addressed by the availability of ER formulations that reduce the potentiating effects associated with short-acting preparations. Medication outcomes in ADHD can be improved with the use of evidence-based algorithms such as CMAP. The keys to success are adequate initial assessment and diagnosis, use of sustained-release products, adequate dose titration, and use of clinical rating scales with feedback from caregivers and teachers. Optimal treatment results can be achieved with appropriate pharmacotherapy along with psychosocial interventions.

title: Changes in insurance physicians' attitudes, self-efficacy, intentions, and knowledge and skills regarding depression guidelines following an implementation strategy
abstract: INTRODUCTION: An implementation strategy to improve policy adherence by insurance physicians (IPs) was developed and investigated in a randomized controlled trial. This implementation strategy included a well-rounded training program in applying guidelines for depression to a group of IPs. In this study, we report the effect of practice strategy on physicians' attitudes, intentions, self-efficacy, and knowledge and skills as behavioral determinants of guideline compliance. Any link between these self-reported behavioral markers and levels of adherence to the guideline was also identified. METHODS: Immediately before and 3 months after the implementation of the omnidirectional training, a questionnaire designed to measure behavioral determinants based on the ASE (attitude, social norm, self-efficacy) model was completed with intervention (n = 21) and control group (n = 19). The items of the questionnaire were grouped to form the scales of the ASE determinants. Internal consistency of the scales was calculated using Cronbach's alphas. Differences between groups regarding changes in ASE determinants and the relationship of these changes to improvements in guideline compliance were analyzed using analysis of covariance. RESULTS: The internal consistency of the scales of AFE predictors proved to be sufficiently reliable, with Cronbach's alphas of at least 0.70. At follow-up after 3 months, IPs given the implementation strategy showed significant improvement over control IPs for all ASE determinants investigated. Changes in knowledge and skills were only weakly associated with improvements in guideline adherence. CONCLUSION: The practice strategy developed for insurance physicians can increase their attitudes, intentions, self-efficacy, knowledge and skills while applying depression guidelines. These changes in behavioral determinants may indicate positive changes in the behavior of IPs towards the use of depression guidelines. However, only changes in knowledge and skills related to the use of the guidelines were associated with improvements in the actual performance of the IPs when applying the guidelines.

title: Changes in lifestyle habits after consulting nurse practitioners: 1-year results of the Groningen Overweight and Lifestyle study.
abstract: OBJECTIVES: The Groningen Overweight and Lifestyle (GOAL) study primarily aims to prevent weight gain in nurse practitioners (NP) guided by a standard computer software program. Understanding the effects on lifestyle habits is important, as positive changes in physical activity (PA) and diet can improve health independent of weight (loss). We examined the 1-year effects of NP lifestyle counseling on PA and diet compared with GP usual care (GP-UC). DESIGN: A randomized controlled trial. SETTING: Eleven general practice locations in the Netherlands. SUBJECTS: A total of 341 TARGET participants, at baseline and 1 year later, with overweight or obesity and hypertension or dyslipidemia, or both, who completed the FFQ and Short Questionnaire to Evaluate Health-Enhancing Physical Activity (SQUASH). RESULTS: After 1 year, the NP group spent 33 minutes more per week walking compared to the GP-UC group who spent -5 minutes per week walking (P = 0.05). There was no significant difference between the NP and GP-UC groups in the percentage of people who followed the PA guidelines. Food intake changed positively in both groups and participants followed dietary guidelines more frequently, but there was no overall difference between the NP and GP-UC groups. RESULTS: No intervention effects on PA and diet occurred in the NP group, except for an increase in walking (based on self-reported data). Positive changes in food intake were seen in both groups.

title: Changes in nurse practitioners' knowledge and behavior after a brief education on healthy eating and combined activity (HEAT) guidelines
abstract: INTRODUCTION: Primary care providers, especially pediatric nurses, are an integral force in tackling the obesity epidemic among youth. However, most nurse practitioners report low proficiency in their ability to adequately prevent and treat pediatric overweight. In response, the National Association of Pediatric Nurse Practitioners (NAPNAP) developed the evidence-based Clinical Practice Guidelines for Healthy Eating and Combined Activity (HEAT) (CPG) to improve provider behavior and effectiveness. METHOD: Thirty-five nurse practitioners attending the NAPNAP Annual Conference participated in an intensive 4-hour HEAT CPG training session. Pre- and post-training data were collected on provider knowledge, practice behaviors, and barriers to overweight prevention among youth. RESULTS: Post-training outcomes, (a) in practitioner knowledge (assessment of patient growth, family history, psychosocial functioning, nutrition, and physical activity); (b) practitioners' intent to improve behavior (i.e., use behavior change and counseling for patient and family behavior change) );" and (c) practitioners' report of increased confidence in its ability to address barriers. CONCLUSION: Study findings demonstrate preliminary support for HEAT CPG as an effective tool aimed at helping providers improve patients' ability to maintain a healthy weight. Future research is needed to confirm the effects of HEAT CPG on long-term improvements in care.

title: Changes in nursing home residents during an innovation based on gerotranscendence theory
abstract: OBJECTIVES AND OBJECTIVES: The aim of this study was to investigate how residents are affected when an intervention based on gerotranscendence theory and theory-derived guidelines is introduced in a nursing home. BACKGROUND: The idea that communication is essential in staff-calm interaction is widely accepted, both in theory and in practice, as is the idea that communicative behavior influences patient outcomes. No studies have yet focused on whether guides derived from the gerotranscendence theory of residents are affected by staff use. DESIGN: The research was exploratory in nature and used a qualitative approach. METHODS: Data were collected through interviews with residents and participant observations"; qualitative content analysis was conducted. SAMPLE SIZE: six residents. RESULTS: The research shows that many residents review and think about their lives and this direction has changed over the course of the study. Some residents' descriptions of their situation, revealed that some changes had occurred in the social life of the ward. These changes may have an effect on the intervention. this includes a holistic view that assists residents in their aging processes. The use of guidelines derived from gerotranscendence theory can help nurses promote positive aging and create a way to treat residents in a more individual way.

title: Changing acute pain management to improve patient outcomes: an educational approach
abstract: The United States Agency for Healthcare Policy and Research (AHCPR) Acute Pain Management Guidelines were written to provide a scientific basis for practice. Educational programs designed to encourage the use of guidelines can change practice in community hospitals. This article describes the development and implementation of a training program for nurses, doctors and pharmacists in six community hospitals. Describes program content that addresses the use of continuous quality improvement (CQI) teams, detailed pain histories, application of algorithms, and dose calculation"; direct and indirect outcome measures are reviewed. Six months after the program, all three experimental centers reported use of AHCPR Guidelines in practice. Nurses, reported that assessing and documenting patients' pain duration was perceived as the most important caregiver behaviors that benefit patients: In all participants' reports on activities performed regularly, the most common activity was assessing and documenting pain on a 0-10 rating scale.

title: Changing clinical behavior by making guidelines specific
abstract: The problems of mobilizing people according to evidence-based guidelines are widely recognized.1 An overview of 41 systematic reviews revealed that the most promising approach was to use a variety of interventions, including supervision and feedback, reminders, and access to training.1 Effective interventions often require complex procedures. contained and was always a supplement to the provision of guidelines. None of the studies used the simplest intervention, namely changing the wording of the guidelines. We examine the importance of precise behavioral recommendations and suggest how some existing guidelines could be improved.

title: Changing doctors' behavior: a training program to popularize a new clinical pathway for hospital management of hip fractures in elderly patients in the Lazio Region, Italy
abstract: RATIONALE AND OBJECTIVES: Concerns about patient safety have fueled interest in approaches to improve physician performance, but the dissemination of clinical guidelines and traditional continuing medical education has often failed. This study investigated the effects of an experience-based education program on the quality of care for patients with hip fractures in Lazio, Italy. METHODS: Five hospitals participated. The work consisted of the development of a clinical pathway, a preparatory phase, and the educational intervention itself; this consisted of follow-up a course, reflection on practice, and audits guided by monthly audits and analysis of patient charts. Data on the quality of care of patients with hip fractures were collected from the routine information system for the pre-intervention and post-intervention period. RESULTS: A significant increase in the proportion of patients undergoing surgery within 48 hours of admission (from 7% in 2006 to 26.4% in 2007) and a significant reduction in the average length of hospital stay (from 18.8 to 16.4 days) ) happened. . Some process indicators of quality of care were high after intervention, but non-recommended practices were still routinely used (for example, urinary catheterization in 72.2% of patients). There were differences in changes when hospitals were compared. CONCLUSION: An educational intervention that combined the dissemination of a clinical pathway with external supervision to reflect on practice was effective in promoting changes in physicians' behavior. The persistence of non-recommended practices and differences between hospitals suggest that multiple factors influence performance and the effectiveness of interventions.

title: Modifying human behavior to prevent disease: the importance of targeting automated processes.
abstract: Much of the global burden of disease is associated with behaviors (overeating, smoking, excessive alcohol consumption, and physical inactivity) that people regard as harmful to health and that persist even with undesirable consequences. To date, interventions to change such behavior have greatly encouraged people to reflect on their behavior. These approaches are often ineffective; This is in line with the observation that most human behavior is automatic, signaled by environmental stimuli, and results in actions largely unaccompanied by conscious reflection. We suggest that interventions targeting these automatic behavioral bases may be more effective. We discuss specific interventions and suggest ways to determine if and how interventions targeting automated processes can improve global efforts to prevent disease.

title: Shifting minds: Limited rationality and heuristic processes in exercise-related judgments and choices.
abstract: Theories currently used to understand, predict, and promote physical activity and exercise represent information-processing patterns of the mind. A basic assumption that supports these theories is that human judgment and decision-making are rational. Therefore, interventions derived from these models are intended to improve "data input" (for example, to provide complete, accurate and convincing information about health benefits) with the expectation that rational evaluation of these data will result in the desired behavioral "output". Given the modest effectiveness of interventions based on these models, we designed 2 experiments that tested the validity of the rationality assumption, focusing specifically on exercise-related judgments and decisions. In Experiment 1, the exercise decisions were changed by shifting them to an arbitrary anchor whose existence should have nothing to do with those judgments. In Experiment 2, the preference between a target training session and an alternative was increased only by the addition of a third "bait" exercise option. Together, these experiments demonstrate that important motivational variables, including perceived desirability of exercise, emotional attitude, intention, emotional predictions, and exercise choices can be manipulated in a predictable direction without providing any new relevant information, but by targeting only specific, good situations. characterized heuristics. These data thus provide evidence that the "limited" nature of human rationality is also manifested in judgment and decision exercises. Researchers and exercise practitioners should consider combining heuristics in dual-process theoretical models of physical activity and exercise behavior. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2016 APA, all rights reserved)

title: Changing doctor behavior to improve disease prevention
abstract: Doctors are often unable to provide nationally recommended preventive services for their patients. Taking this into account, we reviewed selected literature on changing physician behavior using the organizational structure of the "readiness for change" transtheoretical model. This model proposes that behavior develops through the stages of precontemplation, contemplation, preparation, initiation, and sustaining change. Traditional continuing medical education can influence knowledge and beliefs, but rarely results in behavior change. However, motivational strategies such as practice feedback reports and influential peers can encourage stage change. Successful interventions for physicians preparing for change often use an office system approach that targets not only physicians but also office workers and patients. We describe the strategies used by primary care physicians in a statewide randomized controlled trial to improve cancer prevention counseling and early detection, showing how readiness to change the model can guide the design and delivery of interventions. Partners for Prevention's multi-stage interventions include support from a medical responsibility bearer, a motivational videotape, a task-related office guide, graphical flowcharts, patient activation forms, practice feedback reports, a designated prevention coordinator at each practice, and regular phone calls and office is located. visits by project staff.

title: Changing doctor behavior: what does it do?
abstract: OBJECTIVES: There are a variety of interventions for guideline implementation in clinical practice, but the effects of these interventions are often unclear. We conducted a systematic review to identify effective methods of applying clinical research findings and clinical guidelines to change physician practice patterns in surgery and general practice. STUDY DESIGN: A systematic review of reviews. METHODS: We searched electronic databases (MEDLINE, EMBASE, and PubMed) for systematic reviews published in English evaluating the effectiveness of different administration methods. Two reviewers independently evaluated eligibility for inclusion and methodological quality and extracted relevant data. RESULTS: Fourteen reviews were identified covering a wide range of interventions. Intervention methods used include: supervision and feedback, computerized decision support systems, continuing medical education, financial incentives, local opinion leaders, marketing, passive dissemination of information, patient-mediated interventions, reminders, and multifaceted interventions. Active approaches, such as academic elaboration, have had greater effects than traditional passive approaches. According to the findings of the 3 reviews, 71% of the studies included in these reviews showed positive changes in physician behavior when exposed to active education methods and multifaceted interventions. CONCLUSIONS: Active forms of continuing medical education and multifaceted interventions were found to be the most effective methods for applying guidelines to general practice. In addition, active approaches to modifying physician performance have been shown to improve practice to a greater extent than traditional passive methods. More primary research is needed to evaluate the effectiveness of these methods in a surgical setting.

title: Changing physician practice behavior to measure and improve clinical outcomes
abstract: Physician practice behavior often produces poor clinical outcomes in the management of cardiovascular disease risk factors, despite effective treatments and guidelines. The behavior of 165 doctors in 2 settings (suburb and city) was examined. After collecting baseline clinical data, including systolic blood pressure and low-density lipoprotein cholesterol, a series of interventions, including academic details, were performed. Low-density lipoprotein cholesterol was reduced by 10.4% (P = .001) in suburban patients with cardiovascular disease in the intervention group and 10.5% in the enhanced intervention group (P = .001). Systolic blood pressure was reduced by 1.11% (P = .357) in the intervention group and 5.13% in the enhanced intervention group (P < .001). In urban hypertensive patients, systolic blood pressure was decreased by 5.03% (P = 0.001) and low-density lipoprotein cholesterol was decreased by 7.01% (P < 0.001). When urban and suburban data were combined, low-density lipoprotein cholesterol decreased 9.32% (P < .001) and systolic blood pressure decreased 4.00% (P < .001). Providing physicians with clinical outcomes, reviewing national guidelines, and setting expectations for modest delivery system innovations can result in significant measurable clinical improvements.

title: Changing social relationships
Part 2: A review of self-management support for (work-related) musculoskeletal pain disorders.
abstract: The format of the review on self-management interventions for chronic conditions and musculoskeletal disorders (MSDs) in this section is narrative. Systematic reviews and other relevant reviews were considered, as well as individual qualitative and quantitative research studies. Four main databases were searched for relevant peer-reviewed literature published in the last 10 years. Papers prior to this period were included in the review if the study was considered stimulating in terms of its contribution to the self-management knowledge base in the context of interest. The following terms are used as keywords and linked using Boolean operators: self-care, self-management, chronic illness, chronic illness, patient education as a subject, patient-centered care, health behavior, low back pain, and musculoskeletal disorders. As the focus of the review was working-age people, the limits applied included the English language and adults aged 15-64. Relevant gray literature and references from key authors in the field were also consulted. We did not formally assess the methodological quality of the included studies. Identified peer-reviewed studies were then conceptually examined for components of intervention that are tightly linked to the involvement of self-management and chronic conditions, particularly MSDs, and otherwise excluded. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2016 APA, all rights reserved)

title: Chapter: Behavioral economics and treatment participation.
abstract: Behavioral economics is a field that integrates the concepts of psychology and economics to explain the decision-making process of individuals. In the last few years, this field has been increasingly incorporated into healthcare settings to promote healthier lifestyles. Typically, monetary incentives are given to participants when a target behavior or goal is objectively verified. In this section, we describe this evidence-based treatment, often referred to as contingency management. This section is structured as four sections. The "Background" section reviews the historical background of incentive-based interventions in substance abuse treatment. The section "Application of Incentive-Based Intervention to Drug Targets" describes the application of these interventions to other drug targets such as vaccination, medical screenings, diabetes monitoring, physical activity, and weight loss programs. The section "Key Elements and Concepts of Incentive-Based Interventions" explains the key concepts and elements embedded in effective incentive-based interventions, and the final section discusses issues related to the implementation and dissemination of incentive programs. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2017 APA, all rights reserved)

title: Chapter: Escape from Cognitiveism: Exercise as a hedonic experience.
abstract: Establishing social relevance should be a strategic goal for exercise psychology. But progress towards this goal has been slower than anyone in this field would like. In this section, we argued that the inability to provide intervention methods that can reliably and significantly increase physical activity level may be due in part to an overly narrow meta-theoretical perspective. We have shown that all the major theories in fashion in exercise psychology in the past decades are derivatives of the same (cognitive) meta-theoretical framework. Therefore, they all exhibit a very important limitation, namely, the relative disregard for the motivational features of affective constructs such as basic affect, moods, and emotions. Research over the past 15 years has shown that the old adage "exercise makes people feel better" is false. Therefore, the main purpose of this chapter was to highlight the urgent need of the field of exercise psychology for the transition to the postcognitivist era. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2017 APA, all rights reserved)

title: Characteristics of poorly controlled Type 2 diabetes patients in Swiss primary care
abstract: BACKGROUND: Although various treatment guidelines are available for patients with type 2 diabetes, most patients do not meet the recommended goals. We aimed to characterize patients with Type 2 diabetes who missed HbA1c treatment targets from Swiss primary care and to reveal the factors associated with poorly controlled HbA1c level. METHODS: The cross-sectional study is included in the cluster randomized controlled Chronic Care for Diabetes study. Type 2 diabetes patients with at least one HbA1c measurement >/= 7.0% in the past year were recruited from Swiss primary health care services. Data evaluation included diabetes-specific and general clinical measures, treatment factors, and patient-reported outcomes. RESULTS: 326 Type 2 diabetes patients from 30 primary health care institutions with a mean age of 67.1 +/- 10.6 years participated in the study. The HbA1c findings of the patients were 7.7% +/- 1.3, systolic blood pressure was 139.1 +/- 17.6 mmHg, diastolic blood pressure was 80.9 +/- 10.5 mmHg, and low-density lipoprotein was 2.7 +/- 1.1. 93.3% of patients suffered from at least one comorbidity and were treated with 4.8 +/- 2.1 different drugs. No determinant factor was significantly associated with HbA1c in the multiple analysis, but a significant clustering effect of GPs on HbA1c could be found. CONCLUSIONS: In our sample of patients with poorly controlled Type 2 diabetes, no "bullet points" could be demonstrated that could easily be remedied by some type of intervention. There appears to be a complex interaction between diabetes control, comorbidities, GP treatment, and patients' health behaviors, especially in this subgroup of diabetes patients, who will most benefit from appropriate interventions to improve diabetes control. So far this interaction has only been poorly described and understood.

title: Features of successfully implemented telemedical applications
abstract: Background In recent years, there has been an increasing interest in the use of telemedical applications in clinical practice. Considerable effort has been put into trials and experimental services. Yet surprisingly few applications have made it past the research and development stage. The aim of this study is to investigate the characteristics of successfully applied telemedical applications. Methods An extensive telemedicine literature review was conducted to identify relevant articles. After a defined selection process, a small number of papers were identified describing the characteristics of successfully implemented telemedical applications. These articles were analyzed qualitatively based on central procedures from the Grounded Theory (GT), including condensation and categorization. The analysis resulted in a description of the features found to be important for the successful practice of telemedicine. Later, these features are discussed in the light of Science and Technology studies (STS) and the concept of 'social negotiation'. Results The routine practice of telemedicine is typically characterized by the following six features: 1) local service delivery issues are clearly articulated, 2) telemedicine is seen as a benefit, 3) telemedicine is seen as a solution to political and medical problems. problems, 4) there was cooperation between promoters and users, 5) organizational and technological arrangements issues were discussed, and 6) future operation of the service was evaluated. Conclusion Our findings support research that argues that technologies are not fixed assets that move from invention to diffusion and routine use. Rather, it is the interaction between technical and social factors that produces a particular outcome. The success of a technology depends on how this interaction is managed during the implementation process.

title: Child survival in the Third World: a functional analysis of oral rehydration therapy promotion campaigns.
abstract: PIP: Behavior analysts conducted a functional analysis of different intervention strategies used in 14 oral rehydration therapy (ORT) campaigns in 10 developing countries. Intervention researchers manipulated antecedents, behaviors, and/or outcomes to improve diarrhea management. Strategies used radio announcements, posters and pamphlets to promote behavior change. Only 2 campaigns (Thailand and Egypt) limited their interventions to these premises. Only 3 programs manipulated premises, behavior, and consequences. The 1983 campaign in Bangladesh included schooling and home visits to siblings as part of skills training and provided incentives (US$30) to trainers as a result. A 1985 project in The Gambia used health workers to teach ORT to mothers at home and handed out happy baby lottery prizes (rice, candy and soap). The skills training component of the 1984 campaign in Honduras included one-on-one training. A radio course on breastfeeding, school education for siblings, and an illustrated health care guide. The results were games and prizes on radio show calls, free calendars, key chains, t-shirts and a trip to Tegucigalpa. The only program limited to the skills training component was the 1976 campaign in South India. The training included the training of nurses to train mothers on diarrhea management. One hurdle in all campaigns was that ORT did not outwardly improve diarrhea and vomiting. Campaigns with a skills training component were more effective than those without. Behavior analysts can contribute to ORT campaigns by developing simple and effective training programs and by developing economical and effective mechanisms to evaluate the effectiveness of such campaigns.

title: Childhood autism and related conditions
Childhood Obesity Screening and Treatment Practices of Child Health Professionals
abstract: In this study, childhood obesity screening and treatment practices of physicians were evaluated. A 26-question survey was delivered to pediatric providers across Louisiana in person or by mail, email, or fax. Fifty-seven providers completed the survey, the majority in primary care clinics. Five providers met at least four of the seven clinical guidelines, but no provider met all the guidelines. 88% of providers screened for obesity, while 7% met guidelines for referring obesity patients to weight management services. Six providers presented interventions that included all recommended components (i.e. diet, physical activity, and behavioral counseling). An intervention met intensity guidelines (ie >25 hours for at least six months). Barriers to service delivery included lack of reimbursement and poor family adjustment. In order to increase the delivery of health services for children with obesity, solutions to overcome treatment barriers should be determined.

title: Childhood tonsillectomy: who is referred and what treatment options are available? Key findings from the Children's Tonsillectomy and Adenotonsillectomy Study (NESSTAC) in Northern England and Scotland
abstract: Background: Tonsillectomy is frequently performed, but there are variations in tonsillectomy rates. Clinicians use guidelines, but the complex psychosocial effects on childhood tonsillectomy include anecdotal evidence of parental enthusiasm. Studies show that engaging in preferred treatment improves outcome. Despite the enthusiasm for offering and seeking tonsil surgery, there is little evidence of effectiveness. This resulted in a randomized controlled trial to evaluate the cost-effectiveness of (adeno)tonsillectomy in children with recurrent sore throat. OBJECTIVE: To compare the characteristics of children enrolled in a randomized study with those enrolled in a parallel, nonrandomized study, and to identify trends in patient preferences for referral and treatment. DESIGN: Baseline data from a randomized controlled trial with a parallel non-randomized preference study comparing surgery to medical treatment in children aged 4-15 years with recurrent sore throat referred to five secondary otolaryngology departments in the north or west center of England Scotland . RESULTS: The centers evaluated 1546 children";" 21% were ineligible for tonsillectomy. Among older children (8-15 years), girls were significantly more likely to be referred to secondary health care. Of 1015 eligible children, 268 (28.2%) agreed to be randomized, while 461 (45.4%) accepted a parallel, nonrandomized preference trial and made a strong preference for tonsillectomy. Participants who reported hindered progress in school or had more persistent sore throat experiences were more likely to seek tonsillectomy. Referred boys were more likely than girls to opt for medical treatment. Socio-economic data showed no effect. CONCLUSION: Tonsillectomy preference reflects educational impact and recent experience rather than age or socio-economic status.

title: Kids in taxis: an opportunity for pediatricians and ER doctors to save lives?
abstract: PURPOSE: Child restraints (infant seats, child restraints and seat belts) are effective in reducing the risk of injury";" however, a pattern remains of parental non-use or misuse of safety seats. The aim of this study was to evaluate the level of knowledge and compliance of parents regarding children admitted to emergency care regarding the National Highway and Traffic Association's safety seat guidelines in private vehicles and taxis. METHODS: Two hundred and forty-two caregivers of children (age range, 2 weeks to 19 years) presenting for care to the pediatric emergency department of a city university hospital were reached to fill out an interviewer-administered questionnaire, and 225 participated. The questionnaire included questions of knowledge, attitude and behavior about protective equipment for children of various ages. RESULTS: 11 (47.8%) of 23 children 1 year old or younger were reported to use a baby seat frequently or always while getting into a private car, while 8 (22.2%) of 36 children 1 year old or younger were using a baby seat. He reported that he used it while in the baby seat. taxis (P < 0.05). It was reported that 17 (85%) of 20 children older than 8 years of age used seat belts frequently or always in private cars, whereas 10 (41.7%) of 24 children were in taxis (P < 0.01). Fifty-four (99.3%) of the 155 subjects knew the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration's recommended position for a safety seat for their children. Most parents believed in the effectiveness of child safety seats in preventing vehicle injuries and reported that they would be more likely to use safety devices if they were informed about their use in the emergency room. CONCLUSIONS: The data obtained from this study show that the use of safety seats in taxis is lower than in private cars, and this is due to the difficulty of transporting these seats to and from a taxi, rather than financial concerns or lack of knowledge about their effectiveness. Strategies should be sought to increase the availability of child safety devices in taxis. Besides the emergency room, the pediatrician's office or clinic can be a place for educational intervention for parents and caregivers about child passenger safety.

title: Children with head trauma
Children's Cognitive Performance and Selective Attention after Recent Societal Violence
abstract: Research has shown robust associations between community violence and psychopathology, but relatively little is known about how community violence can affect cognitive performance and attention. Using a quasi-experimental fixed effects design, this study estimates the effects of police-reported community violence on the performance of 359 urban children on a computerized neuropsychological task. Living near a recent violent crime showed faster but marginally less accurate task performance for the entire sample, evolutionarily adaptive "vigilant" attention patterns (i.e., less attention to positive stimuli, more attention to negative stimuli) for children who reported low attention) predicted. Trait anxiety and potentially maladaptive “avoidant” attention patterns for children with high levels of anxiety. These results suggest that community violence may directly affect children's cognitive performance and may also have differential (and potentially orthogonal) effects on distraction depending on children's biobehavioral risk levels. Implications for mental health and sociological research are discussed.

title: Chiropractic care for pediatric and adolescent Attention Deficit/Hyperactivity Disorder: A systematic review.
abstract: BACKGROUND: Psychostimulants are the first-line treatment for pediatric and adolescent ADHD/HD. Evidence shows that up to 30% of prescribed stimulant drugs do not show clinically relevant results. In addition, many children and adolescents experience the side effects of these drugs. As a result, parents are seeking alternative interventions for their children. Complementary and alternative medicine treatments for behavioral disorders such as ADHD/HD are on the rise, with 68% of parents seeking help from alternative practitioners, including chiropractors. OBJECTIVE: This review seeks to answer the question of whether chiropractic care can reduce symptoms of inattention, impulsivity, and hyperactivity for pediatric and adolescent ADHD/HD. METHODS: Electronic databases (Cochrane CENTRAL register of Controlled Trials, Cochrane Database of Systematic reviews, MEDLINE, PsycINFO, CINAHL, Scopus, ISI Web of Science, Index to Chiropractic Literature) searched up to July 2009 for English language studies for chiropractic care . and AD/HD. Inclusion and exclusion criteria were applied to selected studies. All randomized controlled trials were evaluated using the Jadad score and a checklist developed from the CONSORT (Consolidated Standards of Reporting Trials) guidelines. RESULTS: The search yielded 58 citations, 22 of which were intervention studies. Of these, only three studies were identified for the pediatric and adolescent AD/HD cohorts. Methodological quality was poor and none of the studies were eligible to use inclusion criteria. CONCLUSIONS: There is insufficient evidence to date to evaluate the effectiveness of chiropractic care for pediatric and adolescent AD/HD. Claims that chiropractic care improves pediatric and adolescent AD/HD are supported by only low levels of scientific evidence. In terms of pediatric and adolescent health, more rigorous scientific research is needed to examine the efficacy and effectiveness of chiropractic treatment if chiropractic care for ADHD/HD is to continue. RCTs of adequate size using clinically relevant outcomes and standardized measures are needed to examine the efficacy of chiropractic care with treatment-free/placebo control or standard care (pharmacological and psychosocial care) to determine whether chiropractic care is an effective alternative intervention for pediatric and adolescent. AD/HD.

title: Choosing wisely in headache medicine: The American Headache Association's list of five things doctors and patients should question
abstract: To draw attention to the tests and procedures associated with low-value care in headache medicine, the American Headache Society (AHS) has joined the American Board of Internal Medicine Foundation's Choose Wise initiative. The AHS president has appointed a temporary "Choose Wisely" task force of the AHS. The committee surveyed AHS members to develop a candidate ingredient list for the AHS "Top 5" list of low-value care in headache medicine. After going through a literature review and consensus process, a final five-item list was selected. Draft recommendations have gone through several review rounds and an external review process. The AHS Board of Directors has approved the final list of "Five Things". The five recommendations, approved by the AHS Board of Directors, are: (1) do not perform neuroimaging studies in patients with stable headaches who meet criteria for migraine; (2) do not perform computed tomography imaging for headache when magnetic resonance imaging is performed. can be used except in emergencies; (3) does not recommend surgical inactivation of migraine trigger points outside of clinical research; (4) does not prescribe opioid or butalbital-containing medications as first-line therapy for recurrent headache disorders;" and (5) does not recommend prolonged or frequent use of over-the-counter pain medications for headaches. We recommend that other treating physicians use this list when discussing care with patients.

title: Choosing wisely: The American College of Rheumatology's list of top 5 things doctors and patients should question
abstract: OBJECTIVE: We tried to create a list of 5 tests, treatments or services that are commonly used in rheumatology practice and whose necessity or value should be questioned and discussed by doctors and patients. METHODS: We used a multi-step process combining consensus methodology and literature reviews to arrive at the American College of Rheumatology (ACR) Top 5 list. Rheumatologists from various practice environments produced substances using the Delphi method. Substances with high content agreement and perceived high prevalence progressed to a survey of ACR members who make up >90% of the US rheumatology workforce. To increase the response rate, a nested random sample of 390 rheumatologists received more intensive survey follow-up. The samples were combined and weighting processes were applied to ensure generalizability. Items with high ratings were subjected to a literature review. Final items were then selected and formulated by the task force. RESULTS: One hundred and five unique items were suggested during Delphi tours and narrowed down to 22 items. A total of 1,052 rheumatologists (17% of those contacted) participated in the member-wide survey, compared with 33% of those in the nested random sample";" responder characteristics were similar in both samples. Based on survey results and available scientific evidence, 5 items (related to antinuclear antibodies, Lyme disease, magnetic resonance imaging, bone absorptiometry, and biological therapy for rheumatoid arthritis) were selected for inclusion. CONCLUSION: The ACR Top 5 list aims to stimulate debate among physicians and patients about health practices in rheumatology whose use should be questioned, and to assist rheumatologists in providing high-value care.

title: Choosing wisely: American Society of Radiation Oncology's top 5 list
abstract: OBJECTIVE: To highlight 5 interventions patients should question as part of the Choose Wisely campaign. This initiative, led by the American Board of Internal Medicine Foundation, encourages conversations between doctors and patients about treatments and tests that could be overused, unnecessary, or potentially harmful. METHODS AND MATERIALS: Potential items were initially compiled using an online questionnaire. These were then evaluated and corrected by a working group representing the American Society of Radiation Oncology (ASTRO) Councils for Clinical Affairs and Quality, Health Policy, and Government Relationships. A literature review was conducted to support the recommendation and explanation and to provide references for each item. A final list of 5 items was then selected by the ASTRO Board of Directors. CONCLUSIONS: ASTRO's 5 recommendations for the Choose Wise campaign are: (1) In women >/=50 years of age with early-stage invasive breast cancer, do not unthinkingly initiate whole-breast radiation therapy as part of breast-conservation treatment programs"; (2) active do not initiate low-risk prostate cancer treatment without discussing surveillance (3) do not routinely use extended fractionation schemes (>10 fractions) for palliation of bone metastases (4) do not routinely recommend proton beam therapy for prostate cancer outside of a prospective clinical trial or enrollment; and (5) do not routinely use intensity modulated radiation therapy to deliver whole-breast radiation therapy as part of breast shielding therapy CONCLUSIONS: The ASTRO list for the Choose Wise campaign highlights radiation oncology interventions that should be discussed among physicians and patients before initiating treatment. better quality and less costly maintenance Provides opportunities for flourishing.

title: The chronic care model and shared care in diabetes: a randomized trial of an electronic decision support system.
abstract: OBJECTIVE To evaluate the impact of a specialist telemedicine intervention to improve diabetes care using the chronic care model (CCM). PARTICIPANTS AND METHODS As part of CCM, 97 primary care physicians at 6 primary care practices in Rochester, MN referred 639 patients to onsite diabetes educators between July 1, 2001 and December 31, 2003. At initial referral, physicians were centrally randomized to receive a telemedicine intervention (evidence-based messages on expert advice and drug management for cardiovascular risk) or no intervention, blinding outcome evaluators and data analysts to group assignments. After each subsequent clinical encounter, endocrinologists reviewed a summary from the patient's electronic medical records and provided management advice and supporting evidence to the intervention physicians via email. Control physicians received periodic e-mails with general information on cardiovascular risk reduction in diabetes. Outcomes included diabetes care processes (completion of diabetes testing), outcomes (metabolic and cardiovascular risk factors, estimated risk of coronary artery disease), and patient costs (payer perspective). RESULTS During intervention, 951 (70%) of 1361 endocrinology reviews identified performance gaps and resulted in a message; primary care physicians reported that 49% of the messages were used in patient care. With a mean follow-up of 21 months, the intervention did not significantly improve metabolic outcomes or reduce the estimated risk of coronary artery disease (adjusted mean difference, -1%; 95% CI, -19% 17%) compared with control. Exposure (P=.02), but not diabetes-related costs CONCLUSION Private telemedicine did not significantly increase the value of CCM in primary care.

title: Chronic illness health risk behaviors among people with mental illness
abstract: OBJECTIVE: In people with mental illness, modifiable health risk behaviors contribute significantly to increased chronic disease morbidity and mortality. This study examined the prevalence of such behavior and the interest in changing it among community mental health service clients in Australia. METHOD: A telephone interview was conducted with Australian community mental health service clients. Participants reported engaging in four health risk behaviors: tobacco smoking, fruit and vegetable consumption, alcohol consumption, and physical activity. Participants were classified as at risk according to Australian national guidelines. At-risk participants were asked if they considered improving their health-risk behavior in the next month. The relationship between psychiatric diagnosis and risk, and the interest in improving health-risk behaviors were examined. RESULTS: The highest risk prevalence is inadequate vegetable consumption (78.3%), followed by insufficient fruit consumption (60%), smoking (50.7%), physical inactivity (46.8%), short-term alcohol risk (40%). ,3) and chronic alcohol. risk (35.3%). Most at-risk participants were considering improving their health-risk behaviors for smoking, physical inactivity, and insufficient consumption of fruits and vegetables (65.1%, 71.1%, and 53.3%, respectively). After adjusting for demographic factors, no risk-related diagnostic categories were found for any behavior. Those diagnosed with depression were more likely to be interested in quitting smoking and increasing physical activity. RESULTS: A high prevalence of risky behaviors for chronic disease health was identified, with many participants expressing an interest in improving these behaviors, regardless of diagnosis. Such findings strengthen recommendations for routine provision of preventive care by mental health clinicians for clients' chronic disease risks. TRIAL REGISTRATION: Australian New Zealand Clinical Trials Registry (ANZCTR) ACTRN12613000693729. URL: www.anzctr.org.au/.

title: Chronic inflammatory bowel disease competency network
abstract: Inflammatory bowel diseases (IBD) occur intermittently, mostly chronic diseases affect young people aged 20-30 years and affect their quality of life and socioeconomic productivity. The factors that trigger the development of IBD are not fully understood: besides environmental factors, there is clear evidence of additional genetic factors that influence disease risk and the pattern of intestinal inflammation in Crohn's disease. Pathophysiological discoveries are leading to new therapeutic opportunities being conducted in large clinical trials with the main participation of the competency network IBD. The extensive network of university and non-university hospitals and laboratories, vertical collaboration with the self-help organization DCCV and GPs across the country provides the opportunity to simultaneously define diseases from the point of view of scientist and physician. The competency network IBD therefore provides the basis for standardized integration of patient information, the development of guidelines, and the establishment of a quality management system, thus leading to improved scientific and clinical research.

title: Smoking Prevalence Among Adults with HIV Compared to the General Adult Population in the United States
abstract: Background: The adverse health effects of smoking and HIV infection are synergistic. Objective: To compare the current prevalence of smoking and smoking cessation among adults with HIV receiving medical care and adults in the general population. Design: Nationally representative cross-sectional studies. Setting: United States. Patients: 4217 adults with HIV who participated in the Medical Monitoring Project and 27,731 US adults who participated in the National Health Interview Survey in 2009. Measures: The baseline exposure was smoking. Outcomes were weighted for smoking prevalence and quit rate (former smokers vs current and current smokers combined). Results: Of the estimated 419 945 adults with HIV receiving medical care, 42.4% (95% CI, 39.7%) to 45.1% were current smokers, 20.3% (CI, 18.6% to 18.6%) 22.1% were previous smokers and 37.3% (CI, 34.9% to 39.6%) had never smoked. Compared with the US adult population, where an estimated 20.6% of adults smoked in 2009, adults with HIV were almost twice as likely to smoke (adjusted prevalence difference, 17.0 percentage points [CI, 14.0 to 20 percent, 1 point]), but less likely to quit (quit rate, 51.7% vs. 32.4%). Among adults with HIV, factors independently associated with a higher prevalence of smoking include advanced age, non-Hispanic white or non-Hispanic black race, lower education level, poverty, homelessness, incarceration, substance use, excessive alcohol use, depression, and successful was not to be. suppressed HIV viral load. Limitation: Cross-sectional design with some limitations of generalizability. Conclusion: Adults with HIV were more likely to smoke and less likely to quit smoking than the general adult population. Tobacco screening and cessation strategies are important considerations as part of routine HIV care.

title: CIOMS's placebo rule and the promotion of negligent medical practice
Civil commitment of the anorexic patient
abstract: Involuntary adherence appears to be an rarely used intervention in anorexic patients, in part because of clinicians' uncertainty about its applicability to this population. Unlike overtly suicidal patients, anorexic patients are often unable to express an intention to harm themselves, although their actions may result in serious harm. However, examination of the language of civil commitment laws shows that when anorexic patients' behavior puts their lives in danger, they will often be blamed under severe disability standards. This appears to be in line with the practice of specialists in the treatment of anorexia and practice in other countries. When patients voluntarily refuse hospitalization and their physical safety is at risk, involuntary commitment should be used as a last resort. In addition, civil commitment should probably also be limited to situations where therapeutic gain from hospitalization is likely. Many severely ill anorexic patients will lack the competence to make treatment decisions for themselves and will allow involuntary feeding and other procedures to occur as needed. Civil commitment is a tool that can be legally used in an emergency in anorexic patients.

title: Classifications in mental health
abstract: For the first time in the Ninth Review of the International Classification of Diseases (ICD-9) the section on mental disorders included short dictionary definitions for each category. A series of changes in attitudes and policies at the international and national levels, particularly the reorientation of mental health programs to include behavioral and psychosocial issues, came at an opportune time and had a positive impact on the development of proposals for the mental and spiritual chapter. Behavioral disorders in the Tenth Revision (ICD-10). This has enabled WHO to undertake an intensive and comprehensive assessment of international needs in the classification of mental disorders and, where the situation is not clear, to organize field trials to provide the empirical data necessary for problem solving. The result is a set of congruent classifications of mental and behavioral disorders based on ICD-10. The first, produced mainly as a reference tool for statistical purposes, will be included in ICD-10 with short glossary definitions as in ICD-9. Other editions will be published for clinicians practicing for research (with complete definitions, diagnostic guidelines and diagnostic criteria) (with advanced dictionary definitions followed by diagnostic guidelines); for use in the provision of services to the mentally ill; and for use in general health (primary) care. In addition, there will be a multi-axial classification of mental disorders in children to describe the clinical syndrome, resulting disability and environmental factors.Adapted to the needs of different groups working in mental health, it is hoped that these versions will lead to further improvements in communication between service delivery and caregivers.

title: Classroom-based cognitive behavioral therapy in reducing depression symptoms in high-risk adolescents: a pragmatic cluster randomized controlled trial.
abstract: OBJECTIVE To compare the effectiveness of classroom-based cognitive behavioral therapy with attention control and regular school service for adolescents at high risk of depression. DESIGN Three-arm parallel cluster randomized controlled trial. SET Eight UK secondary schools. PARTICIPANTS Adolescents aged 12-16 years (n=5030) in 8-11 school year groups. Year groups were randomly assigned to cognitive behavioral therapy, attention control, or regular school service in a 1:1:1 ratio. The allocation is balanced by school, year, number of students and classes, lesson frequency and timetable. Participants were not blinded to treatment allocation. INTERVENTIONS Cognitive behavioral therapy, attention control, and regular school service provided in classrooms to all eligible participants. MAJOR OUTCOME MEASUREMENTS Results were collected through a self-filled questionnaire administered by the researchers. The primary outcome was depression symptoms assessed at 12 months with the brief mood and emotions questionnaire among those identified at baseline as at high risk of depression. Secondary outcomes included negative thinking, self-worth, and anxiety. Analyzes were made with the intent to base and take into account the aggregated nature of the design. RESULTS 1064 (21.2%) adolescents were determined to be at high risk of depression: 392 in the classroom-based cognitive behavioral therapy arm, 374 in the attention control arm, and 298 in the normal school provisioning arm. At 12 months, the adjusted mean scores on the brief mood and emotions questionnaire did not differ from usual school service for cognitive behavioral therapy versus attention control (-0.63, 95% confidence interval -1.85 to 0.58, P=0.41) or cognitive behavioral therapy (0.97, -0.20 to 2.15, P=0.12). CONCLUSION In adolescents with depressive symptoms, outcomes were similar for attention control, usual school service, and cognitive behavioral therapy. Classroom-based cognitive behavioral therapy programs can result in increased self-awareness and reporting of depressive symptoms, but should not be undertaken without further evaluation and research. TRIAL REGISTRATION Controlled Trials Available ISRCTN19083628.

title: Clinical and cost-effectiveness of booklet-based vestibular rehabilitation for chronic dizziness in primary care: a single-blind, parallel-group, pragmatic, randomized controlled trial.
abstract: OBJECTIVE To determine the clinical and cost-effectiveness of booklet-based vestibular rehabilitation with and without telephone support compared to routine care for chronic vertigo. DESIGN Single-blind, parallel group, pragmatic, randomized controlled trial. SET 35 general practice in southern England between October 2008 and January 2011. PARTICIPANTS Head movement (patient-confirmed) in patients 18 years of age or older with chronic dizziness (mean duration > five years) and not attributable to non-vestibular causes (GP-confirmed). INTERVENTIONS Participants were randomly assigned to receive routine medical care, booklet-based vestibular rehabilitation only, or booklet-based vestibular rehabilitation with telephone support. For the booklet approach, participants were given self-management booklets that gave comprehensive advice on performing vestibular rehabilitation exercises at home every day for up to 12 weeks and using cognitive behavioral techniques to encourage positive beliefs and adherence to treatment. Participants who received telephone support were offered three short sessions of structured support from a vestibular therapist. MAIN OUTCOME MEASURES Vertigo symptom scale-short form and total health care costs related to dizziness per quality-adjusted life-year (QALY). RESULTS Of 337 randomized participants, 276 (82%) completed all clinical measures at the primary endpoint at week 12 and 263 (78%) at one-year follow-up. We analyzed clinical efficacy with intent to treat, controlling for baseline symptom scores, using analysis of covariance to compare groups after intervention. At 12 weeks, scores on the vertigo symptom scale in the telephone support group were not significantly different from those in the routine care group (adjusted mean difference -1.79 (95% CI -3.69 to 0.11), P=0.064). At one year, both intervention groups improved significantly over routine care (phone support -2.52 (-4.52 to -0.51)), P=0.014"; booklet only -2.43 (-4.27 to -0.51) cost-effectiveness acceptability curves showed that both interventions were highly cost-effective, with very low QALY values the booklet-only approach was more likely to be cost-effective, whereas the approach with additional telephone support was more likely to be QALY were more likely to be cost-effective than at Â£1200 (â€šâ¬1488;”$1932). Using the booklet approach with telephone support, five (three to 12) patients would need to be treated for one patient to report subjective improvement at one year. CONCLUSIONS Booklet-based vestibular rehabilitation for chronic vertigo is a simple and cost-effective way to improve patient-reported outcomes in primary care. TRIAL REGISTRATION ClinicalTrials.gov NCT00732797.

title: Clinical assessment of motherhood in infancy
abstract: The use of reliable and valid maternal measures can improve the ability of clinicians and researchers to identify problematic patterns that pose risks to the health of mothers and infants during the first postpartum year. A critical review of observational and self-report tools to measure components of motherhood is presented. Positive indicators of motherhood are discussed and implications for referral and intervention to problematic aspects of motherhood are suggested.

title: Clinical biochemistry close to the patient
Clinical features associated with prescribing SSRI drugs in adolescents with major unipolar depression
abstract: Unipolar major depressions (MD) occur prominently during adolescence. The National Institute for Health and Care Excellence (NICE) UK recommends psychological therapies accompanied by selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs) that are prescribed only in severe cases. Here, we attempt to determine the scope and rationale for SSRI prescribing in adolescent MD before engaging in a randomized clinical trial. Prescribing an SSRI with clinical characteristics was determined in 465 adolescent patients with MD prior to receiving a standardized psychological therapy as part of a clinical trial of improving mood with psychoanalytic and cognitive therapies (IMPACT). Overall, 88 (19%) were prescribed antidepressants prior to psychological treatment. Clinical correlations varied by gender: severity of depression in boys and self-harming behaviors in girls, respectively. Prescribing also differed between clinical trial centers. Medical practitioners view the severity of depression in boys as an indicator of antidepressant prescribing. Self-harm in girls appears to be used as a prescribing aid which is inconsistent with past and current revised UK NICE guidelines.

title: Clinical efficacy of a manual-based coping strategy program (START, STRAtegies for Relatives) in improving the mental health of caregivers of family members with dementia: a pragmatic randomized controlled trial.
abstract: OBJECTIVE To evaluate whether a manual-based coping strategy compared to usual treatment reduces symptoms of depression and anxiety in caregivers of family members with dementia. DESIGN Randomized, parallel group, superiority trial. SETTING Three mental health community services and one neurological outpatient dementia service in London and Essex, UK. PARTICIPANTS 260 caregivers of family members with dementia. INTERVENTION A manual-based coping intervention consisting of eight sessions delivered by supervised psychology graduates to caregivers of family members with dementia. The program includes psychoeducation on dementia, caregiver stress and where to get emotional support; understanding the behavior of the cared family member and behavioral management techniques; changing useless thoughts; promoting acceptance; assertive communication; relaxation; Caregivers performed these techniques at home using manual and relaxation CDs MAIN OUTCOME MEASURES Affective symptoms (hospital anxiety and depression total score) at months four and eight Secondary outcomes were depression and anxiety case-by-case on the hospital anxiety and depression scale, and both caregiver's (health status questionnaire, mood health) as well as the care-receiver's quality of life (quality of life-Alzheimer's disease) and the caregiver's potentially abusive behavior towards the care-receiver (modified conflict tactics scale) RESULTS 260 caregivers were recruited; 173 were randomized to t intervention and 87 to treatment as usual. The mean total scores on the hospital anxiety and depression scale were lower in the intervention group than in the usual treatment group over the eight-month assessment period: adjusted difference in means -1.80 points (95% confidence interval -3.29 to -0.31; "P = 0.02) and absolute difference in means - 2.0 points Caregivers in the Intervention group were less likely to have case-level depression (odds ratio 0.24, 95% confidence interval 0.07 to 0.76) and had a non-significant trend towards reduction in case-level anxiety (0.30, 0, 08 to 1.05) Caregivers' quality of life was higher in the intervention group (means difference 4.09, 95% confidence interval 0.34 to 7.83) but not for care recipients (means difference 0.59, -0.72 to -0.72) 1.89 reported less abusive behavior towards the care recipient compared to those in treatment (odds ratio 0.47, 95% confidence interval 0.18 to 1.23), but this was not significant. was effective in reducing affective symptoms and case-level depression in caregivers of family members. The quality of life of caregivers has also improved. TRIAL RECORD Existing Controlled Trials ISCTRN70017938.

title: Clinical efficacy of health visitor education in psychologically informed approaches to depression in postpartum women: a pragmatic cluster randomized trial in primary care.
abstract: PURPOSE To evaluate the benefits of two psychologically-informed interventions by health visitors to postpartum women. DESIGN Randomized prospective cluster trial by general practice with 18 months follow-up. SETTING 101 Trent, general applications in the UK. PARTICIPANTS 2749 women were assigned to intervention and 1335 women to control. INTERVENTION Health visitors (n=89 63 clusters) were trained to identify depressive symptoms between six and eight weeks postpartum using the Edinburgh postpartum depression scale (EPDS) and clinical assessment, as well as providing psychologically informed sessions based on cognitive behavioral or person-centered principles. was trained one hour a week for eight weeks. Health visitors in the control group (n=49 38 clusters) provided usual care. MAIN OUTCOME MEASURES >or=12 points at six months on the Edinburgh postpartum depression scale. Secondary outcomes were mean Edinburgh postpartum depression scale, clinical outcomes on routine assessment-outcome measure (CORE-OM), trait anxiety inventory (STAI), SF-12 and parenting stress index short form (PSI-SF) scores at six. , 12, 18 months. RESULTS 4084 eligible women consented, and 595 women had a six-week EPDS score of >or=12. Of these, 418 had EPDS scores at six weeks and six months. At 6 months, 34% (93/271) of women in the intervention group and 46% (67/147) in the control group had an EPDS score >or=12. The odds ratio for score >or=12 at six months was 0.62 for women in the intervention group compared to women in the control group (95% confidence interval 0.40 to 0.97, P=0.036). After adjusting for covariates, the odds ratio was 0.60 (0.38 to 0.95, P=0.028). At 6 months, 12.4% (234/1880) of all women in the intervention group and 16.7% (166/995) of all women in the control group had scores >or=12 (0.67, 0.51 to 0.87, P=0.003). . For all women and for women in the intervention group with a six-week EPDS score >or=12, the benefit was maintained at 12 months postpartum. Neither psychological approach had a distinct benefit over the other. CONCLUSION Training of health visitors to assess women, identify symptoms of postpartum depression, and deliver psychologically-informed sessions was clinically effective at six and 12 months postpartum compared with usual care. TRIAL REGISTRATION ISRCTN92195776.

title: Clinical global measures of dementia. Statement of the International Working Group on the Harmonization of Dementia Drug Guidelines
abstract: Below is the report of the committee working on clinical global measures for antidementia drug guidelines. The concepts in global scales, the differences between change and severity scales, the advantages and disadvantages of structured interviews, and fixation of change scores are discussed and selected current clinical global scales are defined. In addition, the committee evaluated the usefulness of global scales in clinical trials for antidementia drugs. There was consensus among the working group members on the following: (1) Clinical global scales are interview-based";" in most cases, they contain information obtained directly from patients as well as from caregivers, but may rely only on relevant information. (2) Clinicians' overall ratings aim to assess clinically significant change based on multidimensional clinical assessment and at least take into account the clinical heterogeneity of dementia by assessing cognition, behavior, and functioning. (3) There are two different types of clinical global measures: (a) interview-based global severity scales, which often include clinicians categorizing according to disease stage or severity, and (b) clinicians' interview-based global scales of change, which include: global assessment ratings of clinical change. The committee could not reach a consensus on whether global scales are required in phase II and phase III clinical trials, or whether other specific assessments, such as well-designed measures of activities of daily living, cognition, and behavior when used in appropriate combinations, are required. , rather than global as assessments of clinical relevance.

title: Clinical governance in the management of labor induction
abstract: OBJECTIVE: To determine whether the dissemination of clear guidelines developed in consensus with stakeholders for labor induction (IOL) processes reduces variability in clinical practice. DESIGN: A prospective behavior change interventional study. PLACE AND DURATION OF STUDY: The study was carried out in Karachi Aga Khan University, Department of Obstetrics and Gynecology, between January 1 - August 31, 2002. SUBJECT AND METHODS: A total of 142 women undergoing IOLs in the appropriate sample, predetermined quality assessment indicators were measured. After data collection from the first 71 women (pre-intervention group), mutually agreed guidelines for clinical practice were distributed over a period of time among counselors, assistants, and nurses. These indicators were re-measured in 71 subsequent women (post-intervention group) to assess the magnitude of residual nonconformities in these processes. RESULTS: Following behavior change interventions, counselor non-compliance and timely patient review by counselors (1.4% versus 72, p-value <0.0001), documentation of IOL indication (16.9% versus 66.2%), Assistant-dependent processes such as p-value <0.0001), induction method for IOL (56.3% vs. 28.2%, p-value 0.0001), and calculation of Bishop score before IOL (38.0% vs. 4.2, p value <0.0001) decreased significantly. CONCLUSION: The dissemination of clear guidelines developed in consensus with stakeholders significantly reduces variability in clinical practice. Our model can be used to improve quality of care in other areas of obstetric health care.

title: Clinical inertia: a common barrier to changing provider prescribing behavior
abstract: BACKGROUND: A cross-sectional content analysis within a randomized, controlled trial was conducted to gather information on providers' responses to computer prompts regarding guideline recommendations for patients with non-optimal hypertension care. METHODS: Participants were caregivers of 1,017 patients with uncontrolled hypertension on a single antihypertensive agent at Veterans Affairs primary care clinics. All reasons for action or inaction were listed within a framework to explain the variation in guideline adaptation. RESULTS: 184 negative provider responses to computer alerts included explanations not to change patient therapy";" 76 responses to the warnings were positive, meaning the provider would make a change to the antihypertensive regimen. Adverse responses were categorized as implementation inertia (66%), lack of compliance with specific guidelines (5%), patient-based factors (17%), environmental factors (10%), and lack of knowledge (2%). . Most of the 135 providers classified as practice inertia said, "Stay on current medications and I will discuss them at next visit." The median number of days to next visit was 45 days (interquartile range, 29 to 78 days). CONCLUSION: Clinical inertia was the main reason for not attempting otherwise specified treatment change in a subset of patients. A framework is provided as a classification for the classification of provider barriers.

title: Clinical Reasoning Revisited: The Distraction of Quantitative Models
abstract: More than 25 years ago, a book called Clinical Judgment defined each act of patient care as having an experimental nature. However, the "experiments", the quality of the baseline data, the taxonomic classification of phenomena, and the features of clinical reasoning. Over the last 20 years, these developments have not been as extensive as expected because many researchers working in clinical forms of clinical trials have not addressed these fundamental scientific challenges in data, classification, and reasoning. Instead, the researchers applied quantitative "models" derived from non-clinical fields, focusing on precise data, random trials, Bayes' theorem, quantitative decision analysis, and psychometric strategies for clinimetric measurement. Consequently, the main challenges of clinical judgment still generally exist for basic scientific research by research clinicians.

title: guide to clinical practice guideline development: a quality-focused approach to turning evidence into action
abstract: BACKGROUND: Guidelines turn best evidence into best practice. A well-crafted guideline supports quality by reducing healthcare variation, increasing diagnostic accuracy, promoting effective treatment, and deterring ineffective or potentially harmful interventions. Despite the large number of published guidelines, the methodology is often poorly defined and varies widely within and between organizations. OBJECTIVE: This guide describes the principles and practices that have been successfully used by the American Academy of Otolaryngology-Head and Neck Surgery to create quality-oriented, evidence-based guidelines using efficient and transparent methodology for action-ready recommendations with multidisciplinary applicability. Allowing the transition from idea to completion in 12 months, the development process highlights a logical set of key action statements supported by reinforcing text, evidence profiles, and degrees of recommendation linking action to evidence. CONCLUSIONS: As clinical practice guidelines become more prominent as a key measure of quality healthcare, organizations must develop efficient manufacturing strategies that balance rigor and pragmatism. Equally important, clinicians must be knowledgeable in understanding what guidelines are and are not, and how they are best used to improve care. The information in this guide should help clinicians and organizations achieve these goals.

title: Clinical Practice Guideline: Otitis Media with Effusion (Updated)
abstract: OBJECTIVE: This update of the 2004 guideline, jointly developed by the American Foundation for Otolaryngology-Head and Neck Surgery, the American Academy of Pediatrics, and the American Academy of Family Physicians, provides evidence-based recommendations for managing otitis media with effusion (OME). It is defined as the presence of fluid in the middle ear without signs or symptoms of an acute ear infection. Changes to the previous guideline include consumer advocates added to the update group, evidence from 4 new clinical practice guidelines, 20 new systematic reviews and 49 randomized control trials, greater emphasis on patient education and collaborative decision making, a new algorithm to clarify actionable relationships. and new and expanded recommendations for the diagnosis and management of OME. OBJECTIVE: The purpose of this multidisciplinary guide is to identify opportunities for quality improvement in OME management and to create clear and actionable recommendations for applying these opportunities in clinical practice. Specifically, the goals are to improve diagnostic accuracy, identify the children most susceptible to developmental sequelae from OME, and educate clinicians and patients about the favorable natural history of most OMEs and the clinical benefits of medical treatment (eg, steroids, antihistamines, decongestants). ). Additional goals relate to OME surveillance, hearing and language assessment, and management of OME detected by newborn screening. The target patient for the guideline is a child between 2 months and 12 years of age with OME, with or without a developmental disability or with or without underlying conditions that predispose to OME and its sequelae. The guide is aimed at all clinicians who may be able to diagnose and manage children with OME and is applicable to all settings in which OME will be identified, monitored or managed. However, this guideline does not apply to patients aged 12 years. ACTION STATEMENTS: The update group made strong recommendations for clinicians to (1) document the presence of middle ear effusion with pneumatic otoscopy when diagnosing OME in a child; (2) perform pneumatic otoscopy to evaluate OME in a child with otalgia, hearing loss, or both. ; (3) should obtain tympanometry in children with suspected OME with uncertain diagnosis after performing (or attempting) pneumatic otoscopy (4) carefully wait and manage the child with OME who is not at risk 3 months from the onset of effusion (if known) or 3 months from the date of diagnosis months (if onset is unknown);
