(5) not recommend the use of intranasal or systemic steroids in the treatment of OME; (6) recommend not using systemic antibiotics for the treatment of OME; and (7) advise against the use of antihistamines, decongestants, or both for the treatment of OME. ensure that there is an underlying sensorineural work regarding the importance of follow-up to exclude thrust loss, parents of infants with OME who failed newborn screening; (2) determine whether a child with OME is at high risk for speech, language, or learning problems from a middle ear effusion due to underlying sensory, physical, cognitive, or behavioral factors; (3) assess at-risk children for OME at the time of diagnosis of an at-risk condition and between 12 and 18 months of age (if diagnosed as at risk before this time); (4) not routinely screen children for OME who are not at risk and do not have symptoms attributable to OME, such as hearing difficulties, balance (vestibular) problems, poor school performance, behavioral problems, or ear discomfort; (5) Educate children with OME and their families about the natural history of OME, the need for follow-up and its possible sequelae; (6) an at-risk child should have an age-appropriate hearing test if OME lasts 3 months or longer OR has OME for any period of time; (7) counsel families of children with bilateral OME and documented hearing loss about the potential impact on speech and language development; (8) should reassess children with chronic OME at intervals of 3 to 6 months until the effusion resolves, significant hearing loss is detected, or structural abnormalities of the tympanic membrane or middle ear are suspected; (9) recommend tympanostomy tubes when surgery is performed for OME in a 4-year-old child" and (11) document resolution of OME, improvement in hearing, or improved quality of life when managing a child with OME.

title: Clinical practice guideline: tinnitus
abstract: OBJECTIVE: Tinnitus is the perception of sound without an external source. More than 50 million people in the United States have reported experiencing tinnitus, causing 10% to 15% of the estimated prevalence in adults. Despite the high prevalence of tinnitus and its potential significant impact on quality of life, there are no evidence-based, multidisciplinary clinical practice guidelines to assist clinicians in management. The focus of this guide is on tinnitus, which is both bothersome and persistent (lasting 6 months or longer) and often negatively impacts the patient's quality of life. The target audience of the guide is any clinician, including non-physicians interested in managing patients with tinnitus. The target patient population is limited to adults (18 years and older) with persistent and bothersome primary tinnitus. OBJECTIVE: The purpose of this guide is to provide evidence-based recommendations for clinicians managing patients with tinnitus. This guide provides clinicians with a logical framework for improving patient care and reducing the personal and social effects of persistent, bothersome tinnitus. It will discuss the selection and timing of diagnostic testing and the evaluation of patients with tinnitus, including specific referral to identify underlying treatable pathology. It will then focus on the evaluation and treatment of patients with persistent primary tinnitus, with recommendations to guide the assessment and measurement of the impact of tinnitus, and identifying the most appropriate interventions to improve the symptoms and quality of life of tinnitus patients. ACTION STATEMENTS: The development group made a strong recommendation that clinicians separate patients with bothersome tinnitus from patients with non-irritating tinnitus. The development group made a strong recommendation against performing head and neck imaging studies in patients with tinnitus, specifically to evaluate tinnitus that is not localized to 1 ear, is not pulsating, and is not associated with focal neurological abnormalities or asymmetrical hearing loss. The panel made the following recommendations: Clinicians should (a) perform a targeted history and physical examination at the initial evaluation of a patient with presumed primary tinnitus to identify conditions that, if promptly identified and managed, may resolve the tinnitus; (b) should promptly receive information unilateral, comprehensive audiological examination in patients with persistent (>/= 6 months) or hard-of-hearing tinnitus; (c) distinguish patients with recent onset of bothersome tinnitus from patients with persistent symptoms (>/= 6 months) to prioritize intervention and facilitate discussions about history and follow-up care; (d) educate patients with persistent, bothersome tinnitus on treatment strategies; (e) recommend a hearing aid evaluation for patients with persistent, bothersome tinnitus associated with documented hearing loss; and (f) permanent recommend cognitive behavioral therapy to patients with bothersome tinnitus (a) persistent, comfortable versus antidepressants, anticonvulsants, anxiolytics or intratympanic drugs for the routine treatment of patients with tinnitus; (b) ginkgo biloba, melatonin, zinc or other dietary supplements to treat patients with persistent, bothersome tinnitus; and (c) transcranial magnetic stimulation for the routine treatment of patients with persistent, bothersome tinnitus. The development group provided the following options: Clinicians can (a) receive an initial comprehensive audiological examination in patients presenting with tinnitus (regardless of laterality, duration, or perceived hearing status) and (b) recommend sound therapy to patients with persistent tinnitus, irritating tinnitus Development group made no recommendations regarding the effect of acupuncture in patients with persistent, bothersome tinnitus.

title: Clinical practice guideline: tonsillectomy in children
abstract: OBJECTIVE: Tonsillectomy is one of the most common surgical procedures in the United States, with more than 530,000 procedures performed annually in children younger than 15 years. Tonsillectomy is defined as a surgical procedure with or without adenoidectomy that cuts the peritonsillar space between the tonsil capsule and the muscle wall and completely removes it together with the tonsil capsule. Depending on the context in which it is used, it may indicate adenoidectomy versus tonsillectomy, especially in relation to sleep-disordered breathing. This guideline provides evidence-based recommendations for the pre-, intra-, and post-operative care and management of children aged 1 to 18 years who are being considered for tonsillectomy. In addition, this guide is intended for all clinicians in any setting interacting with children aged 1 to 18 years who may be candidates for tonsillectomy. OBJECTIVE: The primary purpose of this guideline is to provide evidence-based guidance to clinicians in identifying children who are best candidates for tonsillectomy. Secondary goals are to optimize the perioperative management of children undergoing tonsillectomy, to highlight the need for evaluation and intervention in special populations, to develop counseling and education for families of children considering tonsillectomy for their children, and to highlight management options for patients with modifying factors. and reduce inappropriate or unnecessary variations in maintenance. CONCLUSIONS: The panel made a strong recommendation for clinicians to administer a single intraoperative single dose of intravenous dexamethasone to children undergoing tonsillectomy. The panel made a strong recommendation against clinicians routinely administering or prescribing perioperative antibiotics to children undergoing tonsillectomy. The panel made recommendations to wait carefully for recurrent throat infection if (1) there were fewer than 7 attacks in the last 2 years, or less than 5 attacks per year in the last 2 years, or less than 3 attacks per year in the last 3 years. "; (2) evaluation of the child with recurrent throat infection who does not meet the criteria in statement 2 to modify factors that may still support tonsillectomy (including but not limited to multiple antibiotic allergy/intolerance, periodic fever, aphthous stomatitis, pharyngitis) and adenitis or peritonsillar abscess (3) asking caregivers of children with sleep-disordered breathing and tonsil hypertrophy about comorbid conditions that may improve after tonsillectomy, including growth retardation, poor school performance, enuresis, and behavioral problems; (4) abnormal who also have tonsil hypertrophy and SL Counseling caregivers about tonsillectomy as a way to improve health in children with polysomnography eep-impaired breathing; (5) counseling caregivers that sleep-disordered breathing may persist or recur after tonsillectomy and may require further treatment; (6) post-tonsillectomy pain advocating management and educating caregivers about the importance of managing and re-evaluating pain” and (7) clinicians performing tonsillectomy should determine primary and secondary posttonsillectomy bleeding rates at least annually. The panel offered options to propose. Tonsillectomy for recurrent throat infection with at least 7 episodes in the past year or at least 5 episodes per year for 2 years or at least 3 episodes per year for 3 years, with documentation in the medical record for each sore throat episode, and 1 or more of the following: temperature > 38.3 grade C, positive test for cervical adenopathy, tonsil exudate, or group A beta-hemolytic streptococcus.

title: Clinical practice guideline: Tympanostomy tubes in children
abstract: OBJECTIVE: Insertion of tympanostomy tubes is the most common outpatient surgery performed on children in the United States. Tympanostomy tubes are often placed because of persistent middle ear fluid, frequent ear infections, or ear infections that persist after antibiotic therapy. Despite the frequency of tympanostomy tube placement, there are currently no clinical practice guidelines in the United States that address specific indications for surgery. This guideline is intended for any clinician involved in the management of children aged 6 months to 12 years, with a tympanostomy tube or in any care setting, as an intervention for any type of otitis media considered for tympanostomy tubes. OBJECTIVE: The primary purpose of this clinical practice guideline is to provide clinicians with evidence-based recommendations on patient selection and surgical indications and management of tympanostomy tubes in children. The development group extensively discussed the indications for tube placement, perioperative management, care of children with permanent tubes, and outcomes of tympanostomy tube surgery. Given the lack of current published guidelines on surgical indications, the group focused on the optional, recommended, or non-advisable considerations of tube placement. Additional emphasis was placed on quality improvement opportunities, particularly in relation to joint decision making and the care of children with existing tubes. STATEMENTS TO ACTION: The development group strongly recommended that clinicians prescribe only topical antibiotic ear drops, without oral antibiotics, for children with uncomplicated acute tympanostomy tube otorrhea. The panel recommended that (1) clinicians should not insert a tympanostomy tube in children with a single episode of otitis media with effusion (OME) lasting less than 3 months; (2) clinicians should have an age-appropriate hearing test performed. If OME persists for 3 months or longer (chronic OME) or prior to surgery when a child is a candidate for tympanostomy tube placement; (3) clinicians should offer bilateral tympanostomy tube placement to children with bilateral OME for 3 months or longer (chronic EME) and documented hearing difficulties; (4) clinicians At intervals of 3 to 6 months, children with chronic OME who do not receive a tympanostomy tube until the effusion resolves should be reassessed until significant hearing loss is detected or structural abnormalities of the tympanic membrane or middle ear are suspected; Children with acute otitis media (AOM) should not insert a tympanostomy tube. Order of evaluation for r tube candidacy effusion in both ears; (6) clinicians should offer bilateral tympanostomy tube placement in children with recurrent AOM with unilateral or bilateral middle ear effusion during evaluation for tube candidacy; (7) clinicians should determine whether a child with recurrent AOM or OME of any duration is at increased risk for speech, language, or learning problems from otitis media due to major sensory, physical, cognitive, or behavioral factors; (8) during the perioperative period, clinicians should educate caregivers of children with tympanostomy tubes about the expected duration of tube function, the recommended follow-up schedule, and the detection of complications; (9) clinicians should not encourage routine, prophylactic water precautions (use of earplugs, headbands; “avoiding swimming or water sports) for children with tympanostomy tube. The development group provided the following options: (1) clinicians can perform tympanostomy tube insertion 3 months or more symptoms attributable to EME, including but not limited to vestibular problems, poor school performance, behavioral problems, ear discomfort, or poor quality of life, and (2) clinicians with long-standing unilateral or bilateral OME (chronic OME) Can perform tympanostomy tube placement in at-risk children with unilateral or bilateral OME, as reflected by a B (flat) tympanogram or persistence of effusion for 3 months or more (chronic OME).

title: Clinical practice guidelines for severe Alzheimer's disease
abstract: BACKGROUND: Although severe Alzheimer's disease (AD) represents a common, serious, and costly public health problem, several practice guidelines are available to help physicians manage the disorder. METHODS: A search was conducted in English-language medical databases from 1996 to present for articles on AD management. The focus of this review was on studies involving patients with severe disease. Studies; Subjects were evaluated considering trial design, analyzes, and results. The recommendations were based on the best available evidence. RESULTS: Severe AD can be reliably identified and diagnosed using measures of cognition, function, behavior, and global staging. Specific assessments will also include medical condition, safety considerations, and the caregiver's health status. Disease-specific management includes treatment with cholinesterase inhibitors and/or memantine. Treatment of neuropsychiatric symptoms begins with non-pharmacological behavioral and environmental approaches. Severe agitation, aggression, and psychosis, which are potentially dangerous to the patient, caregiver, and others, can be treated with atypical antipsychotics, taking into account the increased risks of cerebrovascular adverse events and mortality. All pharmacological approaches require careful monitoring and regular periodic reassessments to determine whether ongoing therapy is necessary. CONCLUSIONS: Evidence-based guidelines for the treatment of severe AD have the potential to improve patient and caregiver quality of life. More randomized controlled trials are urgently needed, specifically targeting this stage of the disease.

title: Clinical practice guidelines to improve shared decision making on assistive device use in home care: a pilot intervention study
abstract: This study examines whether clinical practice guidelines (CPG) for the introduction of assistive devices (ADs) in home care improve joint decision making about AD use and alter social-cognitive correlates. Data were collected in a quasi-experimental design intervention study. The questionnaires were obtained from 116 home nurses and home care workers and their 140 disabled clients. Significant differences between the intervention and control groups revealed that CPG practice improved the self-reported practice of home nurses and home care workers: the number of intervention methods they applied increased and the methods applied with increasing intensity. Nurses' attitudes towards introducing FHs in a joint decision-making process decreased over time in both the intervention group and the control group. Patients' reports of caregivers' practices showed little agreement with caregivers' own reports. The complexity of the CPG and a significant time investment were reported as the main barriers to engaging customers in the collaborative decision-making process through the experimental CPG. However, the CPG is committed to joint decision-making on the use of AD between formal caregivers and community-dwelling people with disabilities. The findings suggest that this CPG can structure communication between caregiver and client and support caregivers in facilitating self-determination in dealing with clients' disabilities.

title: Clinical Practice Update: Expert Review on Endoscopic Bariatric Therapies
abstract: BACKGROUND AND OBJECTIVES: Multiple endoscopic bariatric therapies (EBTs) are currently under evaluation or in clinical use in the United States. EBTs are well positioned to fill an important gap in the management of obesity and metabolic diseases. The purpose of this expert review is to update gastroenterologists about these treatments and provide practical advice on how to incorporate them into clinical practice. METHODS: The evidence reviewed in this study is a summary of an extensive search of several English-language databases and a manual review of relevant publications (including systematic reviews and meeting summaries). Best Practice Recommendation 1: EBTs should be considered in obese patients who fail to lose or maintain weight loss with lifestyle interventions. Best Practice Recommendation 2: EBTs can be used as a bridge to conventional bariatric surgery in patients with severe obesity. They can also be used as a bridge to allow for unrelated interventions (orthopedic surgery, organ transplant) that cannot be performed due to weight limitations. Best Practice Recommendation 3: Clinicians should use EBTs as part of a structured weight loss program that includes dietary intervention, exercise therapy, and behavior change during both the active weight loss phase and the long-term maintenance phase. Best Practice Recommendation 4: Before enrolling patients in a weight loss program that includes EDTs, clinicians should screen all potential EDT candidates with a comprehensive assessment for medical conditions, comorbidities, and psychosocial or behavioral patterns that contribute to their condition. Best Practice Recommendation 5: Clinicians incorporating EBTs into their clinical practice should prospectively monitor patients to capture the impact of the EBT program on weight and weight-related comorbidities and all related adverse outcomes. Poor responders should be identified and a thorough evaluation and alternative treatment recommended. Best Practice Recommendation 6: Clinicians beginning to incorporate EDTs into their clinical practice should have comprehensive knowledge of the indications, contraindications, risks, benefits, and consequences of individual EDTs, as well as practical knowledge of the risks and benefits of alternative treatments. obesity. Best Practice Recommendation 7: Institutions should establish specific guidelines for granting privileges in EBTs that are applied consistently across disciplines and that reflect the necessary knowledge and technical skill a clinician must acquire before privileges are granted to perform these procedures.

title: Clinical practice variation in reduced fetal movements
abstract: BACKGROUND: Decreased fetal movements indicate a risky pregnancy. This is present in a significant proportion of pregnancies, but both the quality of information and the quality of clinical care are variable. MATERIALS AND METHODS: All maternity units in eastern Norway and Bergen have registered all consultations for reduced fetal movements as part of the international collaborative project "Fetal Movement Intervention Evaluation" (Femina). 1200 pregnancies out of 23,933 births were analyzed. In 1043 pregnancies, the mother expressed her concern about the decrease in spontaneous fetal movements, which were included in the analysis. The results were presented with a 95% confidence interval. RESULTS: Asphyxia, death, growth retardation or preterm delivery occurred in 19.6% (16.6 - 22.6% of cases ranged from 9.1% to 26.5% Standard procedures were very diverse; Ultrasonography was used in 39.0% to 98.6% of cases and Doppler was used in 4.5% to 74.6% of cases. There was a correlation between the results and the procedures used. The risk was increased in women who waited 24 hours with reduced mobility or absence before seeking health care. 47% (42-52%) of those who were sedentary had such risky behaviors. COMMENT: Quality improvements are needed in the clinical management of affected pregnancies as well as in information for pregnant women. This can have great health benefits. We propose new guidelines for information and management.

title: Clinical practice. Later orthodontic complications caused by risk factors observed in the first years of life
abstract: Primary preventive strategies for oral health are a key public health priority. Pediatricians are in frequent contact with families during routine preventive visits during the first few years of a child's life and are in an ideal and unique position to advise parents on the prevention of oral disease in their child. Primary prevention is always recommended in very young children to promote positive outcomes in childhood and later adulthood. The knowledge acquired by pediatricians about orofacial enlargement can enhance the implementation and eventual success of a preventive program. Given the widespread lack of orthodontic knowledge among pediatricians, this article describes the most common and distinctive symptoms that often occur in the early stages of a child's development and are easily detectable by clinicians. It is difficult to define preventive strategies to prevent malocclusion due to its multifactorial origin. However, there are some recognized behaviors that should be discouraged to allow for ideal craniofacial development, and some that require early referral to the orthodontist. The following disorders are easily diagnosed by the pediatrician or parents and represent situations in which early intervention may be appropriate to prevent possible future orofacial dysfunction: Differential sucking habits, mouth breathing, and significant deviations from established norms of teeth eruption that persist after 3 years of age. When any of these conditions are observed, early referral to a pediatric dentist or orthodontist is recommended. In general, measures to prevent malocclusion should be based on providing good incentives to promote normal growth and development of the face and eliminating potential interferences that could harm these processes.

title: Clinical reminders added to echocardiography reports of patients with reduced left ventricular ejection fraction increase beta-blocker use: a randomized trial.
abstract: Background - Although ÃŸ-blockers are known to prolong survival in patients with reduced left ventricular ejection fraction, they are often underused. We hypothesized that a reminder added to the echocardiography report would increase the use of ÃŸ-blockers in patients with reduced left ventricular ejection fraction. Methods and Results - We randomized 1546 consecutive patients with a left ventricular ejection fraction <45% on echocardiography in one of 3 laboratories to use ÃŸ-blockers or no reminders. Patients were excluded from analysis if they died within 30 days of randomization (n=89), did not receive medication through the Veterans Affairs system after 30 days (n=180), or had echocardiography performed at >1 laboratory (n=6). The primary outcome was an oral ÃŸ-blocker prescription 1 to 9 months after randomization. The mean age of 1271 patients included was 69 years; 60% had a history of heart failure and 51% were receiving ÃŸ-blocker therapy during echocardiography. More patients randomized to a reminder received a later prescription of an ÃŸ-blocker (74,458 of 621) compared to those randomized to no reminder (66%, 428/650; “P=0.002).” It differs depending on location (inpatient vs. outpatient) or previous use of ÃŸ-blockers.Conclusions—A reminder added to the echocardiography report has increased the use of ÃŸ-blockers in patients with depressed left ventricular systolic function.

title: Clinical research in interventional pain management techniques: the clinician's perspective
abstract: Interventional pain management techniques are considered for patients whose pain has proven to be resistant to conventional therapy. According to evidence-based medicine (CPA) guidelines, the highest level of evidence for the efficacy and safety of a treatment is produced in high-quality randomized controlled trials and systematic reviews. A randomized controlled trial is defined as an experiment that determines the effect of an intervention on the natural course of the disease; this means that the comparative group should receive a sham intervention, a placebo in the case of interventional pain management techniques. The systematic review summarizes the results of the available information in a structured way. When randomized controlled trials are available, observational studies will generally be rejected. As new information about a treatment becomes available, the perceived value may change, thereby determining the survival time of clinical evidence. This survival time is not different based on randomized or non-randomized studies. Inclusion criteria are an important component of the randomized controlled trial and are designed to test a treatment in a homogeneous patient population. It should be emphasized that since interventional pain management techniques are mainly used in the treatment of spinal pain, there is no gold standard for diagnosis. This lack of validated standard diagnostic procedures lies at the root of different patient selection criteria, making interpretation of different randomized controlled trials and meta-analyses very difficult. In addition, extrapolation of randomized controlled trials with carefully selected patient populations to daily practice is a major problem. Randomized controlled trials of interventional pain management techniques have often proven to be inadequate; this may be attributed to the difficulty in motivating patients and referring physicians to participate in a trial where there was a 50% chance of receiving a placebo/dummy treatment for persistent pain. In addition, the validity of the sham intervention as a reflection of the natural course of the disease is questioned. It is noted that any new technique should prove to be at least equally effective as the best available treatment option, offering the possibility to compare two groups that both receive active therapy. The reference treatment may be pharmacological or a rehabilitation program (cognitive-behavioral), in which case blinding becomes a problem. It has been shown that large observational studies with a cohort or case-control design do not systematically overestimate the magnitude of associations between exposure and outcome compared with results from randomized controlled trials. There is an urgent need for guidelines for conducting prospective cohort trials that should be designed to confirm or refute anecdotal findings from retrospective studies.

title: Clinical risk management in psychiatry
abstract: This article considers suicide and violence to others, which are the most current concerns in risk management in mental health services. Most psychiatric claims managed over a twelve-year period by the Harvard Medical Institutions Risk Management Foundation included cases of suicide, attempted suicide, or violence against oneself or others.

title: Clinical risk estimation for preeclampsia in nulliparous women: model development in an international prospective cohort.
abstract: OBJECTIVES To develop a predictive model for preeclampsia for nulliparous women based on clinical risk factors and to identify a high-risk subgroup for which specialist referral may be indicated. DESIGN Prospective multicenter cohort. SETTING Five centers in Auckland, New Zealand"; Adelaide, Australia; Manchester and London, UK;" and Cork, Republic of Ireland. PARTICIPANTS 3572 nulliparous women with "healthy" singleton pregnancies from a large international study";" Data on pregnancy outcomes were available for 3529 (99%). MAIN OUTCOME MEASURE Preeclampsia defined as 140 mm Hg or diastolic blood pressure 90 mm Hg, or both, at least twice four hours apart after 20 weeks of gestation, but before onset of labor or postpartum, with proteinuria or any multisystem complication. Preterm preeclampsia was defined as women with preeclampsia who gave birth before 37(+0) gestational week. In the stepwise logistic regression, the comparison group was women without preeclampsia. RESULTS Preeclampsia developed in 186 (5.3%) of 3529 women, 47 (1.3%) with preterm preeclampsia. Clinical risk factors at 14-16 weeks of pregnancy are age, mean arterial blood pressure, body mass index (BMI), family history of preeclampsia, family history of coronary heart disease, maternal birth weight, and vaginal bleeding for at least five years. days. Factors associated with miscarriage were a single previous miscarriage with the same partner, taking at least 12 months to conceive, high fruit intake, smoking, and first trimester alcohol use. The area under the receiver operating characteristics curve (AUC) under internal verification is 0.71. Adding uterine artery Doppler indices did not improve performance (internal validation AUC 0.71). A framework for specialist referral has been developed based on preeclampsia or abnormal uterine artery Doppler waveform generated by at least 15% of a subset of women with single risk factors. Nine percent of nulliparous women are referred for expert opinion, and 21% of these develop preeclampsia. The relative risk of developing preeclampsia and preterm preeclampsia in women referred to a specialist was 5.5 and 12.2, respectively, compared with standard care. CONCLUSIONS Using the clinical phenotype, the ability to predict preeclampsia in healthy non-delivery women is moderate and requires external validation in other populations. If confirmed, it could provide a personalized clinical risk profile for nulliparous women to which biomarkers can be added. Trial registration ACTRN12607000551493.

title: Clustered randomized controlled trial of specific interventions to improve the treatment of urinary tract infections in women and sore throat.
abstract: Objective: To evaluate the effectiveness of specific interventions to implement guidelines for urinary tract infections in women and sore throat Design: Unblinded, clustered randomized pretest-posttest trial Setting:142 general practices in Norway Participants:72 urinary tract infections and 70 practices, applying guidelines for sore throat received interventions for each other and acted as controls for each other. 59 applications in the urinary tract infection group and 61 applications in the sore throat group completed the study. Outcomes were measured in 16 939 consultations for sore throat and 9887 consultations for urinary tract infection. Interventions: Interventions have been developed to overcome identified barriers to the implementation of the guidelines. The main components of personalized interventions were patient education material, computer-based decision support and reminders, an increase in the cost of phone calls, and interactive courses for GPs and practice assistants Main outcome measures: Changes in antibiotic use rates, laboratory tests, and phone calls. They were 3% less likely to take antibiotics afterward. In the intervention group, women with symptoms of urinary tract infection were 5.1% less likely to request a laboratory test. There was no significant difference between the groups in terms of other results. Among the practices included, large differences were found in rates of prescribing antibiotics, use of laboratory tests and telephone calls, and the extent of change for all three outcome measures. changing application

title: Cluster randomized trial of a versatile primary care decision support intervention for hereditary breast cancer risk.
abstract: Background. General practitioners are increasingly expected to meet the needs of patients who are concerned about the risk of hereditary breast cancer, but may lack the skills or confidence to use complex management guidelines. We have developed an evidence-based, multifaceted intervention aimed at building confidence and skills in this area. Aim. To evaluate the effectiveness of the intervention in increasing GP confidence in the management of patients concerned about the genetic risk of breast cancer. Methods Design. Cluster randomized controlled trial. Adjustment. General practices in the Grampian region of Scotland. Topics Physicians and patients they refer for genetic counseling for breast cancer risk. Main outcome measures. GPs' self-reported confidence in the four genetic-related activities"; referral rates of patients at high genetic risk; and referral patients' understanding of cancer risk factors. Results. No statistically significant difference was observed between the intervention and control arms in primary or secondary outcomes. its possible impact on the proportion of referral patients at risk could not be excluded. Only a small proportion of intervention practitioners attended the training session, were aware of, or benefited from, the software or software. Results. There was no convincing evidence of the intervention's efficacy, which is likely to suggest its use in routine practice. reflects the obstacles ahead.

title: Cluster randomized trial of a multilevel evidence-based quality improvement approach to tailor VA Patient Care Teams to the needs of female Veterans
abstract: Background The Veterans Health Administration (VA) has taken a major initiative to transform care through the implementation of Patient-Oriented Care Teams (PACTs). Based on the patient-centered medical home (PCMH) concept, PACT aims to improve access, continuity, coordination, and inclusiveness using patient-centered and patient-centered team-based care. However, how the VA should adapt PACT to meet the needs of special populations such as female Veterans (WVs) was not considered in the initial practice guideline. The WVsÂ¡Â¯ numerical minority (approximately 7Â¨C8 of users) in VA healthcare settings creates logistical challenges for providing gender-sensitive comprehensive care. The main aim of this study is to combine comprehensive primary care services and gender-specific care in gender-sensitive settings, to test an evidence-based quality improvement approach (EBQI) to adapt PACT to meet the needs of the World, thereby enabling PACT to to accelerate its success. guidelines for women (WomenÂ¡Â¯s Health (WH)-PACT). Methods/design EBQI is a systematic approach to developing a multi-level research-clinical partnership with researchers that engages senior organizational leaders and local quality improvement (QI) teams to adapt and implement new models of care in the context of prior evidence and local practice conditions. technical support, formative feedback and practical facilitation. In a 12-site randomized cluster study, we will evaluate the success of the WH-PACT model using patient, provider, staff, and practice questionnaires in addition to analyzes of secondary administrative and chart-based data. We will explore the effects of receiving WH-PACT care on the quality of chronic disease care and prevention, health status, patient satisfaction and care experience, provider experience, utilization, and costs. Using mixed methods, we will assess pre-implementation contexts"; document EBQI activities performed at participating facilities and their relationship to provider/staff and team actions/attitudes; document WH-PACT implementation; and through a combination of semi-structured interviews and monthly formative progress narratives and administrative data Examining barriers/facilitators to EBQI-supported WH-PACT implementation Discussion The absence of gender-sensitive comprehensive care has had implications for technical quality and ratings of care among WVs and may contribute to decisions about using or seeking care elsewhere under the US Affordable Care Act. We hypothesize that adapting PACT implementation through EBQI can improve care experience and quality on many levels.

title: Cluster randomized trials for pharmacy practice research
abstract: Introduction Randomized cluster trials (CRTs) are now the gold standard in healthcare research, including pharmacy-based interventions. Research on behavior, epidemiology, lifestyle changes, education programs, and health care models draws on the strengths of cluster randomized analyzes. Methodology The main feature of CRTs is the randomization unit (clusters), which can differ from the analysis unit (individual). The subject sample size and ideally the number of clusters are determined by the inter- and intra-cluster variability relationship. The correlation between participants from the same cluster is known as the intraclass correlation coefficient (ICC). In general, having more clusters with smaller ICC values will result in smaller sample sizes. When selecting clusters, stratification prior to randomization may be useful in reducing imbalances between study arms. Because it is not always possible to blind a behavioral intervention, participant recruitment methods may differ from other types of randomized trials. When to use CRTs can have implications for making "real world" decisions. CRTs are often used in non-therapeutic intervention studies (eg change in practice guidelines). The advantages of CRT design in pharmaceutical research are the prevention of contamination and the generalizability of results. A large CRT examining physician-pharmacist collaborative hypertension management is used as an example of CRT in this article. The trial, now titled Collaboration Between Pharmacists and Physicians to Improve Outcomes (CAPTION), was implemented in primary care offices in the United States for hypertensive patients. Limitations CRT design limitations include the need for large numbers of clusters, high costs, increased training, increased monitoring, and statistical complexity.

title: Cluster randomized controlled trial of computer-based decision support to select long-term anti-thrombotic therapy after acute ischemic stroke.
abstract: Background: Identifying appropriate long-term anti-thrombotic therapy following acute ischemic stroke is a challenging area where computer-based decision support can provide assistance. Objective: To evaluate the impact of a computer-based decision support system (CDSS) on prescribing practice that provides patient-specific estimates of expected ischemic and hemorrhagic vascular event rates under each potential anti-thrombotic therapy. Design: Cluster-randomized controlled trial. Methods: We recruited patients presenting for initial investigation of symptoms of ischemic stroke or TIA, excluding those with a poor prognosis or major contraindication for anticoagulation. After observing routine prescribing (6 months) at each hospital, centers were randomized for 6 months to control (routine practice observed) or intervention (practice observed while CDSS provided patient-specific information). Between control and intervention centers, we compared the risk reduction achieved with long-term anti-thrombotic therapy (estimated by CDSS) for ischemic and hemorrhagic vascular events and the proportions of subjects prescribed optimal therapy as determined by CDSS. Results: Sixteen hospitals recruited 1952 subjects. When the CDSS provided information, the mean relative risk reduction achieved with prescribing increased by 2.7 percent (95% CI -0.3 to 5.7), and the odds ratio for optimal treatment prescribed was 1.32 (0.83 to 1.80). ) was. Approximately 55% (5/9) of clinicians believed that CDSS affected their prescribing. Conclusions: Cluster-randomized trials provide excellent frameworks for evaluating new clinical management methods. Our CDSS was practical and acceptable to clinicians, but did not significantly affect prescribing practice for antithrombotic drugs after acute ischemic stroke.

title: The COACH trial: a randomized controlled trial of GP/PHC cardiovascular disease risk reduction in urban community health centers: rationale and design
abstract: BACKGROUND: Despite well-publicized guidelines on the appropriate management of cardiovascular disease (CVD) and type 2 diabetes, implementation of risk-reducing practices remains inadequate. This article describes the rationale and design of a randomized controlled clinical trial that evaluated the efficacy of a comprehensive CVD risk reduction program delivered by NP/CHW teams versus enhanced usual care in improving patient proportion. Urban community health centers achieving target levels recommended by national guidelines for lipids, blood pressure, HbA1c and prescribing appropriate drugs. METHODS: The COACH (Community Assistance and Cardiovascular Health) study was a randomized controlled trial in which patients at federally qualified community health centers were randomly assigned to one of two groups: comprehensive intensive management of CVD risk factors for one year by an NP. CHW team or an advanced routine maintenance control group. RESULTS: A total of 3899 patients were evaluated for eligibility and 525 patients were randomized. The groups were comparable at baseline for sociodemographic and clinical characteristics, except for statistically significant differences in total cholesterol and hemoglobin A1c. CONCLUSIONS: This study is a novel blend of multilevel interdisciplinary strategies to transform highly effective therapies into low-income, federally funded healthcare centers caring for patients with a disproportionate CVD burden, type 2 diabetes and uncontrolled CVD risk factors. The impact of such a community clinic-based intervention is potentially enormous.

title: Code of practice for clinical evaluation of licensed medicinal products in general practice
abstract: KIE: A code of practice for the clinical evaluation of drugs licensed by general practitioners was developed jointly by the British Medical Association, the Royal Society of General Practitioners and the British Pharmaceutical Industry Association. The new code, reproduced in full here, summarizes the reasons for the need for drug evaluations outside of hospitals"; defines the roles of pharmaceutical companies, ethics committees, and researchers; lists items that should be included in research protocols; and provides guidelines on confidentiality, publication of results, and pricing.

title: Cognitive behavioral therapy for chronic insomnia: a systematic review and meta-analysis.
abstract: Background: Cognitive behavioral therapy for insomnia (CBT-i) is now widely recommended as first-line treatment for chronic insomnia, as psychological approaches are likely to produce sustained benefits without the tolerance or risk of side effects associated with pharmacological approaches. Purpose: To determine the efficacy of CBT-i in daily measurements of night sleep in adults with chronic insomnia. Data Sources: MEDLINE, EMBASE, PsycINFO, CINAHL, the Cochrane Library, and PubMed Clinical Queries searches from baseline to March 31, 2015 were supported by manual scanning. Study Selection: Randomized, controlled trials comparing the efficacy of face-to-face, multimodal CBT-i on nighttime sleep with inactive comparators in adults with chronic insomnia. Studies of insomnia comorbid with medical, sleep, or psychiatric disorders were excluded. Data Extraction: Study characteristics, quality, and data were evaluated independently by 2 reviewers. The main outcome measures were sleep onset latency (SOL), wake after sleep onset (WASO), total sleep time (TST), and sleep efficiency (%SE). Data Synthesis: Among the 292 citations and 91 full-text articles reviewed, 20 studies (1162 participants [64% female";" mean age, 56 years]) were included. CBT-i approaches include at least 3 of the following: cognitive therapy, stimulus control, sleep restriction, sleep hygiene, and relaxation. At the post-treatment time point, SOL increased 19.03 (95% CI, 14.12 to 23.93) minutes, WASO 26.00 (CI, 15.48 to 36.52) minutes, TST 7.61 (CI, ?0.51 to 15.74) minutes, and SE increased 9.91% (CI, 8.09% to 11.73%). Changes appeared to be sustained at later time points. No adverse results were reported. Limitation: Narrow inclusion criteria limited applicability in patients with insomnia and other sleep problems, and the accuracy of the estimates at later time points was less clear. Conclusion: CBT-i is an effective treatment for adults with chronic insomnia with clinically significant effect sizes. Primary Source of Funding: None. (PROSPERO registration number: CRD42012002863)

title: Cognitive Behavioral Therapy for Post-Traumatic Stress Disorder in Women
abstract: Context The prevalence of post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD) is high among women who have served in the military, but there are no studies evaluating previous PTSD treatment in this population. Previous research suggests that cognitive behavioral therapy is an especially effective treatment for PTSD. Purpose To compare prolonged exposure, a type of cognitive behavioral therapy, with present-centered therapy, a supportive intervention for the treatment of PTSD. Design, Environment, and Participants A randomized controlled trial of female veterans (n=277) and active-duty personnel (n=7) with PTSD recruited from 9 VA medical centers, 2 VA readjustment counseling centers, and 1 military hospital since August 2002. until 2005. Intervention Participants were randomly assigned to receive either prolonged exposure (n = 141) or present-centered therapy (n = 143) delivered according to standard protocols in 10 weekly 90-minute sessions. Main Outcome Measures Posttraumatic stress disorder symptom severity was the primary outcome. Comorbid symptoms, functioning, and quality of life were secondary outcomes. Blind raters collected data before and after treatment and at 3 and 6 months of follow-up. Results Women who received long-term exposure experienced greater reductions in PTSD symptoms (effect size, 0.27"; P = .03) than women who received current centered treatment. longer met PTSD diagnostic criteria (41.0% vs. 27.8%; odds ratio). , 1.80; 95% confidence interval, 1.10-2.96; P = .01) and achieve total remission (6.9% versus 15.2%; odds ratio, 2.43; 95% confidence) range, 1.10-5.37;" P = .01). The effects were consistent over time in longitudinal analyzes, but in cross-sectional analyzes most differences occurred immediately after treatment. Conclusions Long-term exposure is an effective treatment for PTSD in female veterans and active-duty military personnel. It is possible to apply prolonged exposure in a number of clinical settings.

title: Cognitive Behavioral Therapy and Zopiclone for the Treatment of Chronic Primary Insomnia in Older Adults
abstract: Context Insomnia is a common condition in older adults and is associated with a range of adverse medical, social, and psychological outcomes. Previous research has suggested beneficial results of both psychological and pharmacological treatments, but blinded placebo-controlled studies comparing the effects of these treatments are lacking. Purpose To examine the short- and long-term clinical efficacy of cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT) and pharmacological therapy in older adults with chronic primary insomnia. Design, Setting, and Participants A randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled study of 46 adults (mean age, 60.8 y"; 22 women) with chronic primary insomnia conducted in a single university outpatient in Norway between January 2004 and December 2005. One study clinical intervention for adults and elderly patients CBT (sleep hygiene, sleep restriction, stimulus control, cognitive therapy, and relaxation; n = 18), sleep medication (zopiclone 7.5 mg each night; n = 16), or placebo medication (n = 12) ) Total treatment duration was 6 weeks and 2 active treatments followed at 6 months Main Outcome Measures Outpatient clinical polysomnographic data and sleep diaries were used to determine total awakening time, total sleep time, sleep efficiency, and slowing Wave sleep at all 3 assessment points (using polysomnography only) Results CBT resulted in better short- and long-term outcomes compared to zopiclone in 3 out of 4 outcome measures. For most outcomes, zopiclone was not different from placebo. Participants taking the zopiclone increased their sleep efficiency from 81.4% pre-treatment to 90.1% at 6-month follow-up, compared with a decrease from 82.3% to 81.9% in the zopiclone group. Participants in the CBT group spent much more time in slow-wave sleep (stages 3 and 4) and were less awake during the night than the other groups. Total sleep duration was similar in all 3 groups; “At 6 months, patients receiving CBT had better sleep efficiency using polysomnography than those receiving zopiclone. Conclusion These results suggest that CBT-based interventions are superior to zopiclone therapy in both the short and long term. Period management of insomnia in adults.

title: Cognitive bias 2: barriers and strategies to change
abstract: In a supplementary article, we suggested that cognitive bias is a necessary skill in developing sound clinical reasoning to reduce the incidence of diagnostic failure. We examined the origins of cognitive biases and some suggested mechanisms for how bias reduction processes might work. In this article, we first outline a general scheme of how cognitive change occurs and the constraints that can be applied. We review various individual factors, many of which are self-biased and may be a barrier to change. We will then examine major strategies developed in the social sciences and medicine to achieve cognitive and affective bias, including the concept of important coercive functions. The abundance and rich diversity of approaches available in the literature and in individual clinical areas illustrate the inherent difficulties in achieving cognitive change, as well as the need for such interventions. Persistent cognitive bias is arguably the most important characteristic of the critical thinker and well-calibrated mind. We outline three groups of proposed prospective interventions: educational strategies, workplace strategies, and coercion functions. We emphasize the importance of environmental and contextual influences on the quality of individual decision-making and the need to address factors known to decalibrate the decision maker. We also emphasize the importance of introducing these concepts at undergraduate level in medical education and the natural development of critical thinking education.

title: Cognitive bias removal via sparklines in clinical data screens
abstract: Sparklines, which are built-in contextual infographics, can help reduce diagnostic errors by highlighting trends in data, simplifying cognitive tasks, and providing context for decision making. Examples applied to heparin-induced thrombocytopenia, cardiac catheterization, and pediatric viral disease illustrate the concept. Sparklines are ideal where limited representations of textual data make interpretation difficult, the chart helps interpret the data, and the chart guides decision making.

title: Cognitive-behavioral therapy for insomnia in cancer patients
abstract: Sleep-wake disorders, particularly insomnia, are among the most common and distressing symptoms experienced by cancer patients. As a result of extensive interdisciplinary research conducted since 2000, cognitive-behavioral therapy is now considered standard care for the treatment of insomnia in the general population and has also been promoted as "likely to be effective" in the Oncology Nursing Association Putting Evidence. Evidence weight category to the app. Cognitive-behavioral therapy is a multicomponent psychological and behavioral therapy designed to eliminate persistent factors of insomnia. The most commonly used strategies are stimulus control, sleep restriction and relaxation therapies, paradoxical intention, sleep hygiene, and cognitive restructuring. Although this insomnia treatment recommendation was well publicized, the nursing literature has not effectively translated the theories and principles of cognitive-behavioral therapy into practical guidelines or considerations for use by oncology staff nurses and advanced practitioners. This article attempts to unravel the mystery of cognitive-behavioral therapy and provide a basis for nurses at different levels of practice to evaluate and potentially present this promising insomnia intervention.

title: Cognitive-Behavioral Therapy for Panic Disorder, Imipramine, or Combination
abstract: Context Panic disorder (PD) can be treated with medications, psychosocial intervention, or both, but the relative and combined effects have not been objectively evaluated. The aim is to evaluate whether drug and psychosocial therapies for PD are each more effective than placebo, whether one treatment is more effective than the other, and whether the combined treatment is more effective than either treatment alone. Design and Adjustment Randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled clinical trial conducted in 4 anxiety research clinics from May 1991 to April 1998. Patients A total of 312 Parkinson's patients were included in the analysis. Interventions Patients received imipramine up to 300 mg/day only (n=83); cognitive-behavioral therapy (CBT) only (n=77); placebo only (n=24); CBT plus imipramine (n=65) or CBT plus placebo (n=63) Patients were treated weekly for 3 months (acute phase), then responders were seen monthly for 6 months (maintenance phase) and then followed for 6 months after discontinuation of treatment. Treatment response based on Panic Disorder Severity Scale (PDSS) and Clinical Global Impression Scale (CGI) by treatment group Results Both imipramine and CBT were significantly superior to placebo for the acute treatment phase (response) as assessed by PDSS Intent-to-Treat [ITT] analysis The rates for CGI were 45.8%, 48.7% and 21.7%, respectively; P=.05 and P=.03), but were not significantly different for CGI (48.2% vs 53.9% after 6 months of maintenance, imipramine and CBT were significantly higher than placebo). r for both PDSS (response rates 37.8%, 39.5%, and 13.0%, respectively); P=.02) and CGI (37.8%, 42.1% and 13.0%, respectively). Among responders, imipramine produced a higher quality response. The acute response rate for combined therapy was 60.3% for PDSS and 64.1% for CGI; none were significantly different from the other groups. The 6-month maintenance response rate for combined therapy was 57.1% for PDSS (P=.04 versus CBT alone and P=.03 versus imipramine alone) and 56.3% for CGI (P=.03' alone). against imipramine), but not significantly better than CBT plus placebo in both analyses. Six months after treatment discontinuation, CGI response rates in the ITT analysis were 41.0% for CBT plus placebo, 31.9% for CBT alone, 19.7% for imipramine alone, 13% for placebo, and 26.3% for CBT with imipramine. Results Combining imipramine and CBT seemed to provide a limited advantage acutely, but a more significant advantage at the end of maintenance. Each treatment worked well immediately after treatment and during maintenance;" CBT appeared durable at follow-up.

title: Collaborative care for depressed patients with chronic medical conditions: a randomized trial in Puerto Rico.
abstract: OBJECTIVE: This study examined whether a collaborative care model for depression would improve clinical and functional outcomes for depressed patients with chronic general medical conditions in primary care settings in Puerto Rico. METHODS: A total of 179 primary care patients with major depression and chronic general medical conditions were randomly assigned to receive either collaborative care or usual care. The collaborative care intervention included enhanced collaboration between physicians, mental health professionals, and care administrators paired with depression-specific treatment guidelines, patient education, and follow-up. In usual care, study staff informed the patient and provider of the diagnosis and encouraged patients to discuss treatment options with their providers. Depression severity was assessed with the Hopkins Symptom Checklist";" Social functioning was assessed with the 36-item Short Form. RESULTS: Compared with usual care, collaborative care significantly reduced depressive symptoms and improved social functioning within six months of randomization. The integration of collaborative care into primary care practices has significantly increased the use of mental health services by depressed patients. CONCLUSIONS: Collaborative care significantly improved clinical symptoms and functional status of depressed patients with chronic general medical conditions treated for depression in primary care settings in Puerto Rico. These findings highlight the promise of the collaborative care model to strengthen the relationship between mental health and primary care services in Puerto Rico.

title: Collaborative management to achieve treatment guidelines. Impact on depression in primary care
abstract: OBJECTIVE: To compare the efficacy of a multifaceted intervention in primary care with the efficacy of primary care physician "as usual" in patients with depression. Design: A randomized controlled trial among primary care patients with major or minor depression. PATIENTS: A total of 217 primary care patients who were deemed depressed by primary care physicians and willing to take antidepressant medication over a 12-month period were randomized, 91 meeting criteria for major depression and 126 for minor depression. INTERVENTIONS: Intervention patients received increased intensity and frequency of visits during the first 4 to 6 weeks of treatment (visits 1 and 3 with a primary care physician, visits 2 and 4 with a psychiatrist) and continued monitoring of adherence to medication regimens during continuation. and maintenance stages of treatment. Patient education at these visits was videotaped and supplemented with written materials. MAIN OUTCOME MEASURES: Primary outcome measures included short-term (30 days) and long-term (90 days) antidepressant medication use at guideline dosage levels, satisfaction with overall care for depression and antidepressant medication, and reduction in depressive symptoms. RESULTS: In patients with major depression, the intervention group had greater adherence to an adequate dose of antidepressant medication for 90 days or more than usual maintenance controls (75.5% vs. 50.0%"; P < .01), the quality of care they received for depression was good. to excellent (93.0% vs. 75.0%; P < .03) and were more likely to rate antidepressant medications as greatly helpful (88.1% vs. 63.3%; P < .3) .01 Percentage of intervention patients with major depression Seventy-four showed 50% or greater improvement (P < .01) on the Symptom Checklist-90 Depressive Symptom Scale compared to 43.8% of controls, and intervention patients also had significantly greater reductions in depression severity over time compared with controls (P < .01). .004) In patients with minor depression, the intervention group showed significantly greater adherence to adequate-dose antidepressant medication for 90 days or more than controls (79.7% vs. 3%; P < .001) and more frequently Additionally, antidepressant medications were assessed as being highly helpful (81.8% vs. 61.4%; “P < .02). However, there was no significant difference in percentage between the intervention and control groups. Percentage of patients who were satisfied with the care they received for depression (94.4% vs. 89.3%), who experienced a 50% or greater reduction in depressive symptoms, or a reduction in depressive symptoms over time. Collaborative management, intensive patient education, and monitoring of ongoing antidepressant medication refills by a primary care physician and a consulting psychiatrist improved adherence to antidepressant regimens in patients with major and minor depression Improved satisfaction with care and resulted in more favorable depressive outcomes Outcomes in patients with major but not minor depression .

title: Collaborative practice development for childhood obesity in rural clinics: Healthy Nutrition Active Living Telehealth Practice Community (HEALTH COP)
abstract: This study evaluated the impact of participation in a virtual quality improvement (QI) learning network on adherence to clinical guidelines for the prevention of childhood obesity in rural clinics. A total of 7 primary care clinics in rural California that belong to the Healthy Eating Active Life TeleHealth Practice Community and 288 children seen for good child care at these clinics participated in this prospective observational pre-post study. Clinics participated in a virtual QI learning network for 9 months to apply best practices and exchange improvement strategies. After the intervention, the weight assessment and the documentation of the consultation increased significantly. Children who received care from the clinicians who pioneered the implementation of the intervention in their clinics showed significant improvements in nutrition and physical activity. Virtual QI learning networks in geographically dispersed clinics can significantly increase clinicians' adherence to childhood obesity guidelines and improve access to recommended care for rural and underserved children.

title: Collective action for implementation: a realistic assessment of institutional collaboration in healthcare.
abstract: Background Research It is increasingly suggested that translation gaps can be eliminated or narrowed by bringing users and producers closer together, a theory largely untested. This document reports on a national study to fill the gap in the evidence on conditions, processes and outcomes related to cooperation and implementation. Methods A longitudinal realistic assessment using multiple qualitative method case studies was conducted with the three Collaborations for Leadership in Applied Health Research in Care (UK). Data were collected through four rounds of theory development, refinement, and testing. More than 200 participants participated in semi-structured interviews, non-participant observations of events and meetings, and stakeholder engagement. The combined inductive and deductive data analysis process focused on proposition refinement and iterative testing over rounds of data collection. Conclusions The quality of existing relationships between higher education and local health care and views on whether implementation is a joint action created a path dependency. When the app was perceived to be decommissioned and lack of organizational connections, this resulted in a focus on knowledge generation and transfer rather than co-production. CollaborationÂ¡Â¯ architectures were inefficient as they did not facilitate connectivity and emphasized professional and epistemic boundaries. More distributed leadership was associated with greater participation potential. The creation of roles that span borders was the most visible investment in practice, and trusted people in these roles resulted in cross-border work, facilitation and direct influences. The academic-practice distinction emerged strongly as a context for motivation to engage, because Â¡Â®that for me Â¡Â¯ resulted in varying levels of engagement along a collaborative-collaboration continuum. Learning within and between collaborations was disorganized due to the attention given to assessment. Results These collaborations did not emerge from a vacuum and needed time to learn and develop. Their lifecycle began with their position on collaboration, knowledge and application. More effective initiatives in collective action in practice can be determined by the deliberate alignment of a number of features, including key relationships, vision, values, structures and processes, and views on collaboration and the nature of practice.

title: Colonoscopy recruitment for high-risk individuals with a family history of colorectal neoplasia: A multicenter randomized counseling trial against standardized information.
abstract: OBJECTIVE: Colonoscopic screening is recommended before the age of 60 in first-degree relatives of patients diagnosed with colorectal cancer (CRC) or colorectal adenomatous polyp (CAP). This has the potential to reduce CRC-related morbidity and mortality, but uptake is currently insufficient. METHODS: The purpose of the study was to compare the effectiveness of standardized information with a nurse-led specific intervention designed to encourage the uptake of colonoscopy screening by siblings of patients with CRC or CAP. A randomized controlled trial was performed. Digestive surgeons and gastroenterologists recruited index patients who developed CRC or CAP before age 60. All index patients received standard screening information for siblings in accordance with current guidelines. Centrally computerized randomization of index patients resulted in all siblings being allocated to the same group, intervention, or control. The specific intervention primarily targeted the index patient to help them relay information to their siblings. The nurse then provided siblings specific information based on their responses to a self-questionnaire investigating health behaviors derived from psychosocial prevention models. The siblings were then given a personalized information leaflet to give to their regular doctor. The primary endpoint was the rate of documented colonoscopy performed in siblings within 1 year of diagnosis of the index patient. Intent-to-treat analysis included siblings who declined to participate in the study. Statistical analysis was adjusted for intra-familial correlation. RESULTS: A total of 304 siblings of 125 index patients, 160 in the intervention group and 144 in the control group, were included. Colonoscopy uptake rate among siblings was 56.3% in the intervention group and 35.4% in the control group (P = 0.0027). The rates after excluding rejections were 69.2% and 37.0% (P < 0.0001). More lesions were detected in the intervention group (1 invasive cancer and 5 advanced adenomas versus 11 advanced adenomas"; "P = 0.022). CONCLUSIONS: This study demonstrates the efficacy of a nurse-led private intervention designed to encourage the uptake of colonoscopy screening by siblings of patients diagnosed with CRC or CAP before age 60. Such specialized interventions, including physicians, should help reduce CRC-related deaths.

title: Combined Diet and Physical Activity Promotion Programs to Prevent Type 2 Diabetes in People at Increased Risk: A Systematic Review for the Community Preventive Services Task Force.
abstract: Background: Trials have demonstrated the effectiveness of strict diet and physical activity enhancement programs to reduce the incidence of diabetes and improve glycemic measures in adults at high risk of type 2 diabetes. Objective: To evaluate diet and physical activity improvement programs for people at high risk of type 2 diabetes, primarily to reduce diabetes risk and reduce body weight and glycemia. Data Sources: MEDLINE, Cochrane Central Register of Controlled Trials, CAB Abstracts, Global Health, and Ovid Health-STAR 1991 to February 27, 2015 without language restrictions. Study Selection: Eight researchers searched articles for single group or comparative studies of at least 2 sessions of combined diet and physical activity enhancement programs for at least 3 months in participants at high risk for type 2 diabetes. Data Extraction: 7 investigators extracted data on study design"; participant, intervention, and outcome descriptions;" and outcomes and the quality of the evaluated study. Data Synthesis: 53 studies (30 diet and physical activity enhancement programs and usual care, 13 more intensive and less intensive programs, and 13 single programs) evaluated 66 programs. Reduced incidence of type 2 diabetes (hazard ratio [RR], 0.59 [95% CI, 0.52 to 0.66]) (16 studies), reduced body weight compared with usual maintenance, diet, and physical activity promotion programs ( net change, -2.2% [ CI, -2.9% to -1.4%]) (24 studies) and fasting blood glucose level (net change, -0.12 mmol/L [-2.2 mg/dL] [CI, -0.20] to -0.05 mmol/L {-3.6] -0.9 mg/ dL}]) (17 studies) and other cardiometabolic risk factors. Evidence for clinical events was limited. More intense programs were more effective. Limitations: The wide variety in diet and physical activity enhancement programs limited the identification of the characteristics most relevant to activity. Clinical outcomes and evidence in children were scarce. Conclusion: Combined diet and physical activity enhancement programs are effective in reducing the incidence of diabetes and improving cardiometabolic risk factors in people at high risk. More intensive programs are more effective.

title: Combining intensive nurse counseling or brief GP advice with varenicline for smoking cessation in primary care: a study protocol of a pragmatic randomized controlled trial.
abstract: INTRODUCTION: Combining behavioral support and pharmacotherapy is most effective in smoking cessation and is recommended in clinical guidelines. Although GP help to quit smoking can be effective, dissemination of clinical practice guidelines and efforts to develop skills has not led to the routine provision of smoking cessation advice among GPs. Intensive counseling from the practice nurse can contribute to better smoking cessation rates in primary care. However, the effectiveness of intensive counseling by a GP versus the usual care of a GP in combination with varenicline is still unknown. MATERIALS AND METHODS: (a) intensive individual counseling by a practice nurse and (b) brief advice by a GP both groups received 12 weeks of open-label varenicline. At least 272 adult smokers per day recruited and treated in a routine primary care setting Primary outcome was defined as prolonged abstinence from weeks 9 to 26, biochemically confirmed by exhaled carbon monoxide Data were analyzed blindly on the goal-to-treat principle and associated with smoking status at follow-up Participants with missing data were counted as smokers.Secondary outcomes included: one-year long-term abstinence, short-term incremental cost-effectiveness, medication adherence, and key determinants of successful smoking cessation.CONCLUSION: This study was intensive practice nurse combined with varenicline in real-life conditions. effectiveness, cost-effectiveness and potential impact of counseling This is the first study to provide scientific evidence about its mechanisms. This article describes the methodology of the essay and discusses the pragmatic and/or illustrative design aspects. TRIAL REGISTRATION: Dutch Trial Registry NTR3067.

title: Comfort First: evaluation of a procedural pain management program for children with cancer
abstract: BACKGROUND: The Comfort First Program (CFP) provides children and their caregivers with an early procedural pain management intervention to reduce procedural pain and distress. This study evaluated whether CFP was achieving its goals and effectively implementing the Royal Australasian College of Physicians pediatric pain management guidelines. METHODS: The study was conducted as a single-site cross-sectional control. One hundred and thirty-five patients (mean age 7.7 years) treated at the Children's Cancer Center Day Oncology Unit at the Royal Children's Hospital Melbourne were observed. Procedural aspects related to treatment room, caregiver and staff behavior, child distress, and use of pharmacological and non-pharmacological interventions were recorded using a control tool developed for the study. RESULTS: The procedure room was regularly quiet and prepared before the child entered. The median processing time was 8 minutes. The median transaction wait time was 54 minutes. At least one caregiver was typically present during procedures. Comfort First (CF) clinicians were more likely to engage in procedures with a significantly distressed child. Carers, nurses, and CF clinicians generally displayed comfort-promoting behaviors. Topical anesthetic was used regularly. Non-pharmacological supplements were often used, especially for distraction. Patients under 8 years of age were significantly more likely to receive non-pharmacological support and have a caregiver and CF clinician. Age is an important predictor of distress, with higher rates of distress in younger children. RESULTS: CFP was found to effectively implement procedural pain guidelines. Regular supervision is recommended to ensure compliance with pain management standards.

title: Coping with compulsive behavior: a cluster randomized controlled trial on the effects of a multidisciplinary care program for compulsive behavior in dementia.
abstract: OBJECTIVES: The Compulsive Behavior care program was developed using existing guidelines and models for managing challenging behaviors in dementia in nursing homes. It was hypothesized that the use of a maintenance program would lead to a reduction in compulsive behaviors and psychoactive drug prescribing, without an increase in restraint use. DESIGN: A randomized controlled trial was conducted using a stepped wedge design to implement the maintenance program and evaluate effects. Compulsive behavior and psychoactive drug assessment was performed every 4 months in all participating units, followed by a program of care in a group of 3 to 4 units. A total of 6 evaluations were made over 20 months. SETTING: Seventeen dementia special care units of different nursing homes. PARTICIPANTS: A total of 659 residents of the special care unit for dementia. All residents with dementia in the unit were included. The units are assigned by the random allocation software to 1 of 5 groups with different starting points for the implementation of the maintenance program. INTERVENTION: A program of care consisting of a variety of assessment procedures and tools that provide a multidisciplinary approach and structure the process of managing challenging behaviors in dementia. MEASUREMENTS: Compulsive behavior was measured using the Cohen-Mansfield Agitation Inventory (CMAI) and Neuropsychiatry Inventory. Research assistants (blind to the unit's response status) interviewed nurses in the units about compulsive behavior. Data on psychoactive drugs and restrictions were taken from their built-in charts. RESULTS: A total of 2292 assessments (1126 control measures, 1166 intervention measures) including 659 residents were performed. The group of residents who remained in the intervention condition differed significantly in CMAI change scores between consecutive assessments compared with the group in the control condition [-2.4 CMAI score, 95% confidence interval (CI) -4.3 to -0.6]. No significant effect was found for the control to intervention group compared to the remaining group in the control group (0.0 CMAI score, 95% CI -2.3 to 2.4). Significant effects on 5 of the 12 Neuropsychiatric Inventory items and use of antipsychotics (odd ratio 0.54, 95% CI 0.37-0.80) and antidepressants (odd ratio 0.65, 95% CI 0.44-0.94) found. No effect on the use of restrictions was observed. RESULTS: The Influenza on Challenging behavior program was able to reduce some compulsive behavior patterns and the use of psychoactive drugs.

title: Communication with pediatricians: developing social work practice in primary care
abstract: While social work models of interdisciplinary collaboration suggest that communication is important, the research literature on social worker-physician collaboration rarely addresses working with pediatricians or practices outside the hospital setting. A cross-sectional questionnaire was sent to a stratified random sample of social workers to assess their communication satisfaction with pediatricians. The study found that social workers in health settings were more satisfied than those in mental health settings. The implications of this finding for the development of collaborative, collaborative care models are discussed.

title: Communication style and exercise compliance (CONNECT) in physiotherapy: A set of randomized controlled trials to test a theory-based intervention to increase patients with chronic low back pain adherence to physiotherapists' advice: study rationale, design and methods
abstract: BACKGROUND: Physical activity and exercise therapy are among accepted clinical rehabilitation guidelines and are recommended self-management strategies for chronic low back pain. However, many back pain sufferers do not follow their physical therapist's advice. Poor patient compliance can reduce the effectiveness of referrals and home rehabilitation exercises. According to self-determination theory, support from health care practitioners can promote patients' autonomous motivation and longer-term behavioral persistence (eg, following physical therapists' recommendations). The aim of this study was to evaluate the effect of an intervention designed to increase physiotherapists' autonomy-supportive communication on patients with low back pain adherence to physical activity and exercise therapy recommendations. METHODS/DESIGN: This will be a single-blind, randomized, controlled trial. Outpatient physiotherapy centers (N = 12) (population = 1.25 million) in Dublin, Ireland will be randomly assigned to either the experimental or control arm using a computer generated algorithm. Physiotherapists in the experimental arm (two hospitals and four primary care clinics) will participate in eight hours of communication skills training. Training will include brochures, workbooks, video examples, role playing and discussion designed to teach physiotherapists how to communicate in a way that encourages autonomous patient motivation. Physiotherapists in the waiting list control arm (two hospitals and four primary care clinics) will not receive this training. Participants with chronic low back pain (N = 292) will complete assessments at baseline and at 1 week, 4 weeks, 12 weeks, and 24 weeks after their first physiotherapy appointment. Primary outcomes will include low back pain, function and well-being, as well as following physiotherapy recommendations. Participants will be blinded to treatment allocation as they will not be informed whether their physiotherapist has received communication skills training. Results evaluators will also be blinded. We will use linear mixed modeling to test for arm differences in both mean levels and rates of change of outcome variables. We will use structural equation modeling, including hypothetical mediation effects, to examine the change process. DISCUSSION: This trial will be the first to test the effect of a self-determination theory-based communication skills training program for physiotherapists on low back pain patients' compliance with rehabilitation advice.

title: Community occupational therapy for elderly patients with dementia and their caregivers: a cost-effectiveness study
