abstract: OBJECTIVE To evaluate the cost-effectiveness of community-based occupational therapy compared with usual care in elderly patients with dementia and their caregivers from a societal perspective. DESIGN Cost-effectiveness study as well as a single-blind randomized controlled trial. AYAR The memory clinic, the day clinic of the geriatrics department and the participants' homes. Patients > or = 135 patients aged > or =65 years with mild to moderate dementia living in the community and their primary caregivers. INTERVENTION 10 sessions of occupational therapy over five weeks, including cognitive and behavioral interventions, to educate patients in the use of aids to compensate for cognitive decline and to educate caregivers in coping behaviors and supervision. MAIN OUTCOME MEASURES Incremental cost-effectiveness ratio, expressed as the difference in average total care costs per successful treatment three months after randomization (ie, a combined patient and caregiver outcome measure of clinically relevant improvement on process, performance, and proficiency scales). Bootstrap methods used to determine confidence intervals for these measures. RESULTS The cost of intervention was 1183 euros (£848, US$1738) per patient and primary care unit per three months (95% confidence interval: €1128 (£808, US$1657) to 1239 euros (£888, US$1820). The cost of visits to general practitioners and hospital doctors was the same in both groups, but overall average costs were €1748 (£1279, $2621) lower in the intervention group and the main cost savings were in informal care.A significant 36% increase in successful cure rates at three months. The number of patients required to be treated for successful treatment at three months was 2.8 (2.7 to 2.9) CONCLUSIONS Community occupational therapy intervention for patients with dementia and their caregivers is successful and cost-effective, especially in terms of informal care delivery.

title: Community Outreach and Cardiovascular Health (COACH) Trial: a randomized, controlled trial of nurse practitioner/public health worker cardiovascular disease risk reduction in urban community health centers
abstract: BACKGROUND: Despite well-publicized guidelines on the appropriate management of cardiovascular disease and type 2 diabetes, implementation of risk-reducing practices remains inadequate. This report presents the results of a randomized, controlled clinical trial evaluating the efficacy of a comprehensive cardiovascular disease risk reduction program delivered by NP/CHW teams, assessing lipids, blood pressure, glycated hemoglobin (HbA1c), and patients in urban community health centers. patient perceptions of the quality of chronic disease care. METHODS AND RESULTS: A total of 525 patients were randomly assigned to NP/CHW (n= 261) or EUC (n= 261) with documented cardiovascular disease, type 2 diabetes, hypercholesterolemia or hypertension, and LDL cholesterol, blood pressure, or HbA1c levels exceeding targets set by national guidelines. 264) groups. The NP/CHW intervention included aggressive pharmacological management and special education and behavioral counseling for lifestyle change and problem solving to address barriers to compliance and control. Compared with EUC, patients in the NP/CHW group had significantly greater 12-month improvement in total cholesterol (difference, 19.7 mg/dL), LDL cholesterol (difference, 15.9 mg/dL), triglycerides (difference, 16.3 mg/dL). . Perceptions of systolic blood pressure (difference, 6.2 mm Hg), diastolic blood pressure (difference, 3.1 mm Hg), HbA1c (difference, 0.5%), and quality of chronic disease care (difference, 1.2 points) . CONCLUSIONS: An intervention by an NP/CHW team using individualized treatment regimens based on targeted therapy algorithms may be an effective approach to improve risk factor status and perceptions of chronic disease care in high-risk patients.

title: Community-based care for the management of type 2 diabetes: an evidence-based analysis.
abstract: UNLABELED: In June 2008, the Medical Counseling Secretariat began work on the Diabetes Strategy Evidence Project, an evidence-based review of the literature surrounding strategies for successful management and treatment of diabetes. This project came about when the Health System Strategy Division at the Ministry of Health and Long-Term Care later asked the secretariat to provide a demonstrative platform for the Ministry's newly published Diabetes Strategy. After an initial review of the strategy and consultation with experts, the Secretariat identified five key areas where evidence was needed. Evidence-based analyzes were prepared for each of these five areas: insulin pumps, behavioral interventions, bariatric surgery, home remote monitoring, and community-based care. For each area, an economic analysis is completed where appropriate and described in a separate report. To review these topics in the Diabetes Strategy Evidence series, please visit the Medical Counseling Secretariat Web site, http://www.health.gov.on .ca/english/providers/program/mas/mas_about.html,DIABETS STRATEGY EVIDENCE PLATFORM: Evidence-Based Summary of Analysis Continuous Subcutaneous Insulin Infusion Pumps for Type 1 and Type 2 Adult Diabetes: An Evidence-Based Analysis Care: An Evidence-Based Analysis Remote Monitoring for Type 2 Diabetes: An Evidence-Based Analysis Ontario Diabetes Practice Economic Model (ODEM) to Determine the Cost-Effectiveness and Budgetary Impact of Selected Type 2 Diabetes Interventions in Ontario To determine the effectiveness of specialized multidisciplinary community care for the management of type 2 diabetes. CLINICAL NEED: TARGET POPULATION AND STATUS Diabetes (ie diabetes mellitus) is a highly common chronic metabolic disorder that interferes with the body's ability to produce or use insulin effectively. The majority (90%) of diabetic patients have type 2 diabetes. (1) Based on the UK Prospective Diabetes Study (UKPDS), intensive blood glucose and blood pressure control significantly reduces the risk of microvascular and macrovascular complications in people with type 2 diabetes. While many studies have documented that patients generally do not meet the glycemic control targets set by national and international guidelines, factors associated with glycemic control are less well studied, one of which is the caregiver(s). Multidisciplinary approaches to care may be particularly important for diabetes management. According to the Canadian Diabetes Association (CDA) guidelines, the diabetes health care team should be multifaceted and interdisciplinary. Currently in Ontario, the core diabetes healthcare team consists of at least one family practitioner and/or diabetes specialist and diabetes educators (registered nurse and registered dietitian). Increasing the role of allied health professionals in diabetes care and collaborating with doctors can be a more cost-effective option for diabetes management. Several systematic reviews and meta-analyses have examined multidisciplinary care programs, but these have been either limited to a specific component of multidisciplinary care (eg, intensive education programs) or conducted as part of a broader disease management program that is not all. multidisciplinary in nature. Most reviews do not clearly define the intervention(s) of interest, making evaluation of such multidisciplinary community programs difficult. EVIDENCE-BASED ANALYSIS METHODS: RESEARCH QUESTIONS: What is the evidence for the effectiveness of specialized multidisciplinary community care for the management of type 2 diabetes compared to normal, provided by at least one registered nurse, registered dietitian, and physician (primary care and/or specialist)? care? [Hereinafter referred to as Model 1] What is the evidence for the effectiveness of specialized multidisciplinary community care provided by at least one pharmacist and primary care physician for the management of type 2 diabetes compared to usual care? [Hereinafter referred to as Model 2]. CRITERIA FOR ADDITION: Full English-language reports published between January 1, 2000 and September 28, 2008 Randomized controlled trials (RCTs), systematic reviews, and meta-analyses Adult population with type 2 diabetes (>/=18 years old) Total sample size >/=30 Define specialized multidisciplinary community care, defined as outpatient-based care provided by at least two health care disciplines (at least one must be a diabetes specialist) with integrated communication between care providers. care (defined as the provision of health care by non-diabetes expert(s), such as primary care providers"; may include referral to other health care professionals/services as needed)>/=6-month follow-up EXCLUSION CRITERIA: different diabetes-related outcomes cannot be abstracted Predominantly home-based OUTCOMES OF INTEREST: The primary results of this review are in glycosylated hemoglobin (rHbA1c) levels and systolic blood pressure (SBP). A literature review was conducted using the Nursing & Allied Health Literature (CINAHL), Cochrane Library, and International Agency for Health Technology Assessment (INAHTA) for studies published between January 1, 2000, and September 28, 2008. Abstracts were reviewed by a single referee and met eligibility criteria. Full-text paper for studies that meet les were obtained. Reference lists were also reviewed for any additional relevant studies not identified through the search. Articles of unknown relevance were reviewed by a second clinical epidemiologist, then by a group of epidemiologists until consensus was reached. The quality of evidence was assessed as high, moderate, low, or very low according to the GRADE methodology. Given the high clinical heterogeneity of articles meeting the inclusion criteria, specific models of care currently supported in Ontario, care models widely reported in the literature, as well as specialized multidisciplinary community care, were examined. Recommendations from an Expert Advisory Panel Meeting held on January 21, 2009. SUMMARY OF FINDINGS: In the initial search, 2,116 unique citations were identified that met the eligibility criteria of 22 RCT trials and nine published systematic reviews. Of these, five studies focused on care provided by at least one nurse, dietitian, and physician (primary care and/or specialist) care model (Model 1; see Table ES 1), while three focused on care provided by at least one nurse. a pharmacist and primary care physician (Model 2; see Table ES 2) Based on moderate-quality evidence, the specialized multidisciplinary community care Model 2 showed a statistically and clinically significant reduction in HbA1c compared to regular care. This pattern in SBP is uncertain compared to usual care based on very low quality evidence Specialized multidisciplinary community care Model 2 showed a statistically and clinically significant reduction in both HbA1c (based on high quality evidence) and HbA1c with usual care Compared to 7.13 mm Hg SBP (moderate-quality evidence-based) t clinical vs. community clinical Table ES1: Summary of Meta-Analysis Results of the Effects of the Multidisciplinary Care Model 1OutcomeEffect estimation(95%CI)Heterogeneity I(2)(p- value)GRADEGlycosylated Hemoglobin (HbA1c [%])-1.00 [-1.27, - 0.73]% (p=0.37) Medium Quality Subgroup: Medium-High Quality -0.91 [-1.19, -0.62]0% (p= 0.74)Systolic Blood Pressure (mm Hg) -2.04 [-13.80, 9.72 ]89% (p=0.002) Very low quality*Mean change from baseline to follow-up between intervention and control groups Table ES2: Summary of Results of Meta-Analysis of the Effects of the Multidisciplinary Care Model 2 OutcomesEffect Estimation(95%CI) Heterogeneity I( 2)(p-value)GRADEGlycosylated Hemoglobin (HbA1c [%])-1.05 [-1.57, -0.52]0% (p=0.75)High QualitySystolic Blood Pressure (mm Hg)-7.13 [-11.78, - 2.48]46% (p=0.17) Moderate quality*Mean change from baseline to follow-up between intervention and control groups.

title: Community-based knowledge transfer and exchange: helping community-based organizations connect research to action
abstract: Background Community-based organizations (CBOs) are important stakeholders in health systems and are increasingly required to use research evidence to inform advocacy, program planning and service delivery efforts. CBOs are increasingly turning to community-based research (CBR), given its participatory focus and emphasis on connecting research to action. To further facilitate the use of research evidence by CBOs, we have developed a strategy for community-based knowledge transfer and exchange (KTE) that helps CBOs more effectively connect research evidence to action. We developed the strategy as follows: Outlining the key characteristics of CBOs and why they are important stakeholders in health systems; By defining the concepts and methods for CBR and KTE; By comparing the CBR's efforts to link research evidence to action with those discussed in this section. Using the RIT literature and comparison to develop a framework for community-based RIT that builds on both the strengths of CBR and existing RIT frameworks Discussion We find that CBR is particularly effective in fostering a climate for using research evidence and generating relevant research evidence. However, CBOs are not always engaged in activities to connect research evidence to action or evaluate these efforts on a larger scale. Therefore, our community-based RIT strategy focuses on: an expanded model of 'connection' and exchange' (i.e. asking questions together). and manufacturers and users of researchers involved in the response process); Producing and disseminating systematic reviews addressing issues of interest to CBOs; Developing a large-scale evidence service consisting of both "push" efforts and efforts to facilitate the "pull" emphasizing actionable messages in a user-friendly manner from systematic reviews of the community and rigorous assessments of efforts to connect research evidence to action. The use of research evidence for CBO advocacy, program planning, and service delivery efforts can be better facilitated and continually improved through continuous assessments of its impact.

title: Community-based primary care: improving and evaluating diabetes management
abstract: The morbidity and mortality associated with diabetes make diabetes a prime target for quality improvement research. Quality differences and race/gender disparities persist in this patient population, which requires sustainable improvement in the clinical management of diabetes. The authors of this study aimed to (1) provide a population perspective on diabetes management and (2) strengthen evidence-based clinical guidelines through a Web-based education module. The project also aimed to gain insight into working remotely with a community. rural physicians This longitudinal pre-intervention study included 18 internists and included 3 point medical record data abstraction over 24 months. A Web-based training module was introduced after basic data abstraction. This module included sections on clinical training, practice tools, and self-assessment. The results showed sustained improvement in most clinical outcomes, demonstrating the effectiveness of using Web-based environments to strengthen clinical guidelines and change physician behavior.

title: Community-Administered Trauma Therapy for Former Child Soldiers in Northern Uganda
abstract: Context Psychological rehabilitation of former child soldiers and their successful reintegration into post-conflict society are current challenges. Despite the high rates of deterioration, there are no randomized controlled trials examining the feasibility and effectiveness of mental health interventions for former child soldiers. Purpose To evaluate the effectiveness of a community-based intervention targeting post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD) symptoms in individuals with previous abduction. Design, Environment and Participants Randomized controlled trial of 85 former child soldiers with PTSD from a population-based survey of 1113 Northern Ugandans aged 12 to 25 years, conducted in IDP camps between November 2007 and October 2009. Participants were randomized into one of 3 groups: narrative exposure therapy (n = 29), an academic completion program with supportive counseling elements (n = 28), or a waiting list (n = 28). PTSD symptoms and feelings of guilt related to the trauma were measured using the Clinician-Administered PTSD Scale. Relevant sections of the mini International Neuropsychiatric Interview were used to assess depression and suicide risk, and a locally adapted scale was used to measure perceived stigma. PTSD, depression, and related symptoms of impairment were assessed before treatment and at 3 months, 6 months, and 12 months after intervention. Intervention Therapies were delivered directly in the communities in 8 sessions by trained local lay therapists. Key Outcome Measures Change in PTSD severity assessed over the 1-year period after treatment. Secondary outcome measures were symptoms of depression, severity of suicidal ideation, feelings of guilt, and perceived stigma. Results PTSD symptom severity (range, 0-148) improved significantly more in the narrative exposure therapy group than in the academic catch-up (mean variation difference, ?14.06 [95% confidence interval, ?27.19 - ?0.92]) and the waiting group. -list (mean variation difference, ?13.04 [95% confidence interval, ?26.79 to 0.72]) groups. Time contrast analyzes of treatment interaction of a mixed effects model on PTSD symptom change over time revealed the superiority of narrative exposure therapy compared with academic capture (F1,234.1 = 5.21, P = .02) and waiting. listing (F1,228.3 = 5.28, P = .02). Narrative exposure therapy produced a larger in-treatment effect size (Cohen d = 1.80) than academic catch (d = 0.83) and waiting list (d = 0.81). Conclusion Among former Ugandan child soldiers, short-term trauma-focused treatment resulted in greater reductions in PTSD symptoms compared with either an academic completion program including supportive counseling or being placed on a waiting list.

title: Community-wide Cardiovascular Disease Prevention Programs and Health Outcomes in a Rural District, 1970-2010
abstract: Significance Few comprehensive cardiovascular risk reduction programs have sustained community-wide interventions for more than 10 years, particularly in rural, low-income communities, and have demonstrated the impact of risk factor improvements on reductions in morbidity and mortality. Purpose To document the health outcomes associated with an integrated, comprehensive cardiovascular risk reduction program in Franklin County, Maine, a low-income rural community. Design, Environment, and Participants Forty-year observational study involving residents of Franklin County, Maine, a rural, low-income population of 22-444 people in 1970, based on the previous decade and comparing Franklin County with other counties of Maine and other Maine counties. status averages. Interventions Community-wide programs targeting hypertension, cholesterol and smoking, as well as diet and physical activity, sponsored by multiple community organizations, including local hospitals and clinicians. Key Outcomes and Measures Resident involvement"; detection, treatment, and control of hypertension and hyperlipidemia; smoking cessation rates; hospitalization rates from 1994 to 2006 adjusted for median household income; and 1970 to 2010 adjusted for household income and age Death rates up to. Results More than 150,000 individual county resident contacts occurred over 40 years. Over time, relevant health indicators improved as cardiovascular risk factor programs were added. Hypertension control had an absolute increase of 24.7% (95% CI, 21.6%- 27.7% ) from 1975 to 1978 from 18.3% to 43.0%; then, high cholesterol control from 1986 to 2010 28.5% (95% CI, 25.3-31.6%) absolute ratios increased from 0.4% to 28.9%, from 48.5% to 69.5%, better than status averages (observed?-?expected [O?-?E], 11.3%; 95% CI , 5.5-17.7%; P?<?.001), 1996- These differences disappeared when Maine's overall dropout rate increased in 2000. 1994-2006 (O?-?E, -17 evictions/1000 residents; 95% CI -20.1 to -13.9; P?<?.001). Franklin was the only Maine county to have a consistently lower adjusted death rate than predicted in the 1970-1989 and 1990-2010 time periods (O?-?E, -60.4 deaths/100,000; 95% CI, -97.9 to -22.8; P? <?.001 and -41.6/100?000; 95% CI, -77.3 to -5.8;"P?=?.005, respectively). Changes to improve population health of a Maine county over 40 years, compared with the rest of the state It has been associated with reductions in hospitalizations and death rates. Such programs have been shown to other U.S. county populations, particularly rural ones and other parts of the world.

title: Comparative Benefits and Harms of Second Generation Antidepressants in the Treatment of Major Depressive Disorder
abstract: Background: Second-generation antidepressants dominate the management of major depressive disorder (MDD), but the evidence for the comparative benefits and harms of these agents is conflicting. Objective: To compare the benefits and harms of second-generation antidepressants for treating MDD in adults. Data Sources: Reference lists of English studies and related review articles and gray literature from 1980 to August 2011 from PubMed, Embase, the Cochrane Library, PsycINFO, and International Pharmaceutical Abstracts. Study Selection: 2 independent reviewers, least Harm 6-week period to evaluate efficacy and observational studies with at least 1000 participants to evaluate Data Extraction: Reviewers summarized data on study design and conduct, participants and interventions, and outcomes and rated study quality. A senior reviewer checked and approved the extracted data and quality ratings. Data Synthesis: Meta-analyses of response to treatment on specific scales and mixed treatment comparisons and weighted mean differences were performed to rate depression. Based on 234 studies, no clinically significant differences in efficacy or efficacy were found for the treatment of acute, continuation, and maintenance stages of MDD. There were no differences in efficacy in patients with comorbid symptoms or in subgroups based on age, gender, ethnicity, or comorbid conditions. Individual drugs differed in some measures of onset of action, adverse events, and health-related quality of life. Limitations: Most trials were conducted in highly selected populations. Publication bias can affect the estimates of some comparisons. Mixed therapy comparisons cannot definitively exclude differences in efficacy. Evidence within subgroups was limited. Conclusion: The available evidence does not warrant the recommendation of a particular second-generation antidepressant based on differences in efficacy. When choosing a drug, differences in onset of action and side effects can be taken into account.

title: Comparative Benefits and Harms of Second-Generation Antidepressants: Background Paper for the American College of Physicians
abstract: Background: Second-generation antidepressants dominate the management of major depressive disorder, dysthymia, and subsyndromal depression. Evidence about comparative benefits and harms is still accumulating. Objective: To compare the benefits and harms of second generation antidepressants (bupropion, citalopram, duloxetine, escitalopram, fluoxetine, fluvoxamine, mirtazapine, nefazodone, paroxetine, sertraline, trazodone) and for the treatment of depressive disorders in adults. Data Sources: MEDLINE, EMBASE, PsychLit, Cochrane Central Register of Controlled Trials, and International Pharmaceutical Abstracts, 1980 to April 2007, limited to articles in English. Reference lists of relevant review articles were manually searched and the Center for Drug Evaluation and Research database was searched to identify unpublished studies. Study Selection: Abstracts and full-text articles were independently reviewed by 2 people. A minimum of 155 good or fair quality double-blind, placebo-controlled, or head-to-head randomized, controlled studies of at least 6 weeks were included, along with six previous good or fair quality systematic reviews or meta-analyses. duration. For harms, 35 observational studies with at least 100 participants and at least 12 weeks of follow-up were also included. Data Extraction: Using a standard protocol, the researchers provided details on study design and quality, funding, settings, patients, and results. Data Synthesis: If data were adequate, meta-analyses of one-to-one studies were performed to determine the relative benefit of response to treatment and weighted mean differences in specific depression rating scales. If insufficient evidence was available, adjusted indirect comparisons were made using meta-regressions and network meta-analyses. Second-generation antidepressants did not differ significantly in efficacy or efficacy for the treatment of major depressive disorder on the basis of 203 studies, although the incidence of specific adverse events and onset of effect differed. Evidence, comparative efficacy, efficacy, or harms of these agents for the treatment of dysthymia and subsyndromal depression Limitation: Adjusted indirect comparisons have methodological limitations and cannot definitively rule out differences in efficacy. Conclusion: There is available evidence. Does not warrant preference for one second-generation antidepressant over another on the basis of differences in efficacy and efficacy. The differences may be related to the choice of a drug.

title: Comparative effectiveness of additional physician communication training and supervision-feedback to improve cancer screening for patients with limited health literacy
abstract: BACKGROUND: We designed a continuing medical education (CME) program to teach primary care physicians (PCP) how to engage in cancer risk communication and joint decision-making with patients with limited health literacy (HL). OBJECTIVE: In addition to supervision-feedback, we evaluated whether training of PCPs improves communication behaviors and increases cancer screening in patients with limited HL more than simply providing clinical performance feedback. DESIGN: A four-year cluster randomized controlled trial. PARTICIPANTS: 168 patients with 18 delayed PCP and limited HL for colorectal/breast/cervical cancer screening. INTERVENTIONS: Communication intervention PCPs received skills training that included standardized patient (SP) feedback on counseling behaviors. All PCPs underwent semi-annual chart checks of patients' screening status for up to 24 months and received a two-year performance feedback report. MAIN MEASURES: PCPs experienced three unannounced SP encounters in which SPs rated their PCP communication behavior. We examined group-to-group differences in changes in CP ratings and changes in patients' knowledge of cancer screening guidelines over 12 months, and changes in patient cancer screening rates over 24 months. At follow-up, communication intervention PCPs scored higher in overall communication about cancer risks and co-decision-making about colorectal cancer screening compared to PCPs that received performance feedback only. Screening rates increased among PCP patients in both groups; however, there was no difference in screening rates between the groups, except for mammography. The communication intervention did not improve the patient's cancer screening knowledge. CONCLUSION: Compared with supervision and feedback alone, PCP, including communication training, increases patient-centered counseling behaviors, but does not increase cancer screening in patients with limited HL. Larger studies should be conducted to determine whether the lack of change in cancer screening is due to the clinical/patient sample size or the ineffectiveness of communication education to change outcomes.

title: Comparative efficacy and tolerability of 15 antipsychotic drugs in schizophrenia: a multiple therapy meta-analysis
abstract: Background The question of which antipsychotic drug should be preferred for the treatment of schizophrenia is controversial, and traditional pairwise meta-analyses cannot provide a hierarchy based on randomized evidence. We aimed to combine the available evidence to establish hierarchies of comparative efficacy, risk of all-cause discontinuation, and significant side effects of antipsychotic drugs.";" Background The question of which antipsychotic drug should be preferred for the treatment of schizophrenia is controversial, and traditional pairwise meta-analyses cannot provide a hierarchy based on randomized evidence. We aimed to combine the available evidence to establish hierarchies of comparative efficacy, all-cause discontinuation risk, and significant adverse effects of antipsychotic drugs.

title: Comparative effectiveness of interventions to improve hand hygiene in the hospital: systematic review and network meta-analysis
abstract: PURPOSE To evaluate the relative effectiveness of the World Health Organization 2005 campaign (WHO-5) and other interventions to promote hand hygiene among healthcare workers in hospital settings and to summarize information on the use of resources. DESIGN Systematic review and network meta-analysis. DATA SOURCES Medline, Embase, CINAHL, NHS Economic Review Database, NHS Review and Dissemination Center, Cochrane Library and EPOC registry (December 2009 - February 2014)"; studies selected with the same search terms in previous systematic reviews (1980- 2009). REVIEW METHODS Included. The studies included were randomized controlled trials, non-randomized trials, controlled pre-post trials, and discontinuous time series studies that implemented an intervention to improve hand hygiene compliance among healthcare workers in hospital settings and measured compliance or appropriate surrogates.The studies met predefined quality inclusion criteria. When not using analytical methods, primary data were reanalyzed. Random effects and network meta-analyses were performed in studies that reported direct observation of hand hygiene compliance, given that they were considered sufficiently homogeneous in terms of interventions, and participants did not understand information about the resources needed for the intervention. were removed and graded into three levels. RESULTS Of the 3639 studies collected, 41 met the inclusion criteria (six randomized controlled trials, 32 discontinuous time series, one nonrandomized study, and two controlled pre-post studies). A meta-analysis of two randomized controlled trials showed that the addition of goal setting to the WHO-5 was associated with improved adherence (pooled odds ratio 1.35, 95% confidence interval 1.04 to 1.76; I(2)=81%). Of the 22 pairwise comparisons from interrupted time series, 18 showed incremental increases in hand hygiene compliance, and all but four tended to increase compliance after intervention. The network meta-analysis pointed to significant uncertainty in the relative effectiveness of interventions, but still provided evidence that WHO-5 is effective and that compliance can be further improved by adding interventions, including goal setting, reward incentives, and accountability. Nineteen studies reported clinical outcomes; data from these were consistent with clinically significant reductions in infection rates from improved hand hygiene for some, but not all, major nosocomial pathogens. Reported costs of interventions range from $225 to $4669 (146-£3035; “â€šâ¬204-â€šâ¬4229) per 1000 bed-days. CONCLUSION WHO-5 is effective in increasing adherence in healthcare workers. Goal setting, reward incentives and adding accountability strategies can lead to further improvement. Reporting of the resources required for such interventions is insufficient.

title: Comparison of the cost effects of two quality strategies to improve test sequencing in primary care: a randomized trial
abstract: OBJECTIVE: To identify the costs and cost reductions of an innovative strategy aimed at improving primary care physicians' test ordering routines compared to a traditional strategy. Design: Multicenter randomized controlled trial with randomization at the local primary care physician group level. SETTING: Primary care: local groups of primary care physicians with diagnostic centers in five Dutch regions. STUDY PARTICIPANTS: Twenty-seven existing local primary care physician groups, including 194 primary care physicians. INTERVENTION: The test sequencing strategy was systematically developed and combined feedback, training on guidelines, and small group quality improvement sessions. At regular quality meetings in local groups, primary care physicians discussed each other's testing behavior, linked it to guidelines, and made individual and/or group plans for change. Thirteen groups participated in all of the strategies (full response arm), while 14 groups received feedback only (feedback arm). MAIN OUTCOME MEASURE: Operating costs, development costs, and research costs were calculated every 6 months per primary care physician for response time. Average costs of tests ordered per primary care physician at 6 months were assessed at baseline and at follow-up. RESULTS: The cost of the new strategy was 702.00 and the cost of the feedback strategy was 58.00. When operating costs were included only, the cost of the intervention was found to be 554.70 compared to 17.10 per primary care physician at 6 months in the feedback arm. Excluding opportunity costs for the time spent by doctors, the intervention was found to cost 92.70 per doctor at 6 months in the full intervention arm. The mean cost reduction achieved by physicians in this arm by reducing unnecessary testing was 144 greater per physician at 6 months than physicians in the feedback arm (P = 0.048). CONCLUSION: Based on our findings, including the expected non-monetary benefits, we propose more long-term impact and cost-effect studies on the implementation of the quality strategy.

title: Comparison of staff effectiveness with home staff training in an intervention to improve hypertension management
abstract: OBJECTIVE: To determine whether the resident physician can be as effective as the faculty opinion leader in changing physicians' compliance with the hypertension practice guideline. METHODS: Sequential charts were reviewed for patients with routinely occurring uncontrolled or new-onset hypertension over a two-week period at a general internal medicine clinic associated with the internal medicine residency program. Next, 23 providers were randomly assigned to an academic intervention to administer a hypertension practice guideline led by a single second-class resident instructor (RI), and 21 providers were assigned to the same intervention led by a single internist (SI). Interest in hypertension. The intervention included academic elaboration, graphic control with feedback, and behavior reinforcement. Six weeks later, the chart audit was repeated to assess the change in practice patterns among UR-taught providers compared with those taught by SI. RESULTS: Overall, management according to practice guidelines increased from 32% (51/157) to 45% (56/123) (p < .01) after intervention. This change was driven by the improvement in care from the SI-led intervention by service providers: 28% (17/60) to 57% (26/46) (p < .003). Providers of the UR-led intervention showed no improvement: 35% (34/97) to 39% (30/77) (p = NS). CONCLUSIONS: This intervention was effective in improving providers' compliance with a hypertension practice guideline, but only when administered by a faculty opinion leader. An assistant trainer using the same format was unable to change the behavior of the providers.

title: Comparison of strategies to reduce rates of methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus in surgical patients: a controlled multicenter intervention trial.
abstract: Objective To compare the impact of two strategies (improved hand hygiene versus methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA) screening and decolonization) alone and in combination on MRSA rates in surgical wards. Design Prospective, controlled, interventional cohort study with 6-month baseline, 12-month intervention, and 6-month washout phases. It establishes 33 surgical services of 10 hospitals in nine countries in Europe and Israel. Participants All patients admitted to registered services for more than 24 hours. Interventions The two strategies compared were (1) promotion of improved hand hygiene and (2) universal MRSA screening with contact precautions and decolonization of MRSA carriers (intranasal mupirocin and chlorhexidine bath). Four hospitals were assigned to each intervention, and two hospitals combined both strategies using targeted MRSA screening. Outcome measures are monthly MRSA clinical culture rates per 100 susceptible patients (primary outcome) and MRSA infections per 100 referrals (secondary outcome). Planned subgroup analysis was performed for clean surgical wards. Results After adjusting for clustering and possible confounders, neither strategy was associated with significant changes in MRSA rates when used alone. Combining both strategies was associated with a 12% reduction per month in the proportion of MRSA clinical cultures (adjusted incidence rate rates (aIRR) 0.88, 95% CI 0.79 to 0.98). In clean surgery wards, strategy 2 (MRSA screening, contact precautions, and decolonization) was used to identify MRSA clinical cultures (15% monthly reduction, aIRR 0.85, 95% CI 0.74 to 0.97) and MRSA infections (17% monthly reduction, AIRR 0.83%, monthly). 95 CI 0.69 to 0.99). Conclusions In surgical wards with a relatively low prevalence of MRSA, a combination of improved standard and MRSA-specific infection control approaches was required to reduce MRSA rates. The application of single interventions was not effective except in clean surgery wards, where MRSA screening was associated with contact precautions and decolonization with significant reductions in MRSA clinical culture and infection rates.

title: Comparison of the instructional effectiveness of internet-based CME with live interactive CME workshops: a randomized controlled trial.
abstract: CONTEXT: Despite evidence that various continuing medical education (CME) techniques can support physician behavior change, there are no randomized studies comparing performance outcomes using documented approaches for physicians participating in internet-based CME versus physicians participating in a live CME intervention. be effective. OBJECTIVE: To determine whether Internet-based CME can produce changes in physician knowledge and behaviors that have an impact on patient care comparable to those produced through live, small-group, interactive CME. DESIGN, ENVIRONMENT AND PARTICIPANTS: Randomized controlled trial conducted from August 2001 to July 2002. Participants were 97 primary care physicians selected from 21 practice sites in Houston, Texas, including 7 community health centers and 14 private group practices. A control group of 18 doctors from the same sites did not receive any intervention. INTERVENTIONS: Physicians were randomly assigned to either an Internet-based CME intervention that could be completed in multiple sessions over 2 weeks or a single live, small group, interactive CME workshop. Both included similarly versatile teaching approaches that have been shown to be effective in live environments. Content is based on the National Institutes of Health National Cholesterol Education Program--Adult Treatment Panel III guidelines. KEY OUTCOME MEASURES: Information was evaluated immediately before, immediately after, and 12 weeks after intervention. Percentage of high-risk patients receiving appropriate lipid panel screening and pharmacotherapeutic treatment according to guidelines were documented by chart audits performed over a 5-month period prior to intervention and over a 5-month period post-intervention. RESULTS: Both interventions produced similar and significant immediate and 12-week knowledge gains, representing large increases in the percentage of correct items (pretest to posttest: 31.0% [95% confidence interval {CI}, 27.0-35.0%)"; 12 weeks: 36.4% [95% CI, 32.2%–40.6%]; P or = 93%), without significant post-intervention change. However, the Internet-based intervention was associated with a significant increase in the percentage of high-risk patients treated with pharmacotherapeutics according to guidelines (pre-intervention, 85.3%; post-intervention, 90.3%; “P = .04). CONCLUSIONS: Properly designed, evidence-based online CME can produce objectively measured behavioral changes as well as sustained gains in knowledge comparable to or superior to those from effective live events.

title: Comparison of three methods of recalling patients for flu vaccine.
abstract: Immunization rates remain low, despite recommendations to support annual flu shots for people 65 and older. A few studies have evaluated the effect of sending reminders by mail, but few have compared alternative ways of reminding patients to receive the vaccine. In a randomized study of 939 patients aged 65 years and older in four family practice between October 23 and December 31, 1984, we compared three ways of reminding elderly patients of the vaccine: personal reminder by doctor, reminder by phone nurse, and reminder by letter. Vaccination rates for the three groups were 22.9%, 37% and 35.1%, respectively. No reminder was given to the control group and the rate was 9.8%. Some patients could not be reached by phone, and some did not see the doctor within the specified time. The rate of vaccination in patients with whom the nurse actually came into contact was 43.5%";" The proportion of patients the doctor actually saw was 45.1%. Overall, the nurse's phone reminder was the most effective, and with a salary of $16 an hour or less, it would also be the most cost-effective. Reminders used in this study were automatically generated from a computerized medical record system. The study demonstrates how a computerized system can be used to identify patients who need preventive procedures.

title: Competence network "community acquired pneumonia" (CAPNETZ). First interim report
abstract: Community-acquired pneumonia (CAP) is a disease with high morbidity and mortality in Germany. However, there are no reliable data on the spectrum and resistance of pathogens, the course of the disease, evidence-based treatment guidelines, and pathogen-host interactions. The German Ministry of Education and Research recognized these shortcomings and therefore decided to fund CAPNETZ, a competence network for community-acquired pneumonia. On the one hand, CAPNETZ integrates components of clinical and basic research (horizontal network) as well as health research and supports collaboration between GPs, community hospitals and universities (vertical network). Since October 2002, 1547 patients with CAP have been included in the network. Initial results suggest that new observations in terms of symptoms, the spectrum of pathogens involved, and treatment modalities will influence the formulation of new guidelines for the management of community-acquired pneumonia.

title: Competence development in new registered nurse graduates: closing the gap between education and practice
abstract: The gap between the practice training of new registered nurse graduates and the actual practice requirements of new registered nurses has long been a recognized reality in nursing. This article describes the development of an intervention from the academic side of the gap to improve the competence of undergraduate nursing students. The intervention is notable because it was developed collaboratively between academia and practice. The three-pronged intervention includes the development of learning modules based on the top 10 of high-risk, high-volume patient conditions; development of faculty and staff trainers in instructional strategies to increase competence development; and product sharing with 84 nursing schools in Texas.

title: Complementary therapy in allergic rhinitis
abstract: The term complementary/alternative medicine (CAM) refers to therapeutic and diagnostic approaches that differ from traditional allopathic medicine. CAM may encompass homeopathy, acupuncture, phytotherapy, antioxidant therapy, and numerous holistic or behavioral techniques. Allergists and physicians of all disciplines are confronted with patients using CAM treatments, making it imperative that they become familiar with the scientific literature surrounding them. Given the high prevalence of allergic diseases and the associated costs of CAM treatments, evidence of CAM treatments is needed to establish appropriate guidelines for their use. The efficacy of CAM modalities should be established by randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled studies, including monitoring for adverse effects. Of all the CAM treatments studied to treat allergic rhinitis, some herbal therapies and antioxidants show a trend towards some clinical efficacy. Researchers have yet to determine how to integrate these CAM modalities into the overall treatment paradigm of allergic rhinitis.

title: Complex pharmaceutical care intervention in pulmonary care: Part A. Process and professional satisfaction of pharmacists
abstract: OBJECTIVE: In the IPMP study (Interventions to the Principle of Pulmonary Drug Profiles), specific pharmaceutical care interventions were provided to pulmonary patients selected for use of drugs different from the Dutch guidelines. The aim was to solve drug-related problems and improve patients' drug use. This article describes the pharmaceutical care process and describes the care package, tailored to the individual problems of patients in the intervention arm of a randomized controlled trial. METHODS: After preselection of patients with the aid of the algorithmic IPMP computing device, trained Dutch community pharmacists conducted structured consultations with patients in the intervention arm (ages 13-70) to identify behaviors and specific problems with their medication. Based on this identification process, a specific intervention was created that could include one or more of the six pharmaceutical care modules. The modules are clustered into clusters that describe the entire program of care provided to a patient. If necessary, pharmacists consulted patients' doctors to improve the prescribed treatment. After the interventions, drug changes were evaluated with the patients. The prescribed drug and refill rate were monitored on the pharmacy computer for 1 year. All activities and results were extensively monitored and documented. MAIN OUTCOME MEASURE: Process description, ie the number of pharmaceutical care modules provided and drug changes. Pharmacists satisfaction. RESULTS: Specific interventions were provided to 199 patients at risk of inappropriate drug therapy. Performed and documented in all 813 pharmaceutical care modules and clustered in four different programs. In addition to the education and motivation to adhere to prescribed medication for all 199 patients, a medication change was recommended in 124 cases. Patients and doctors agreed on a change in 94 cases. In 58 of 64 cases, a device change was agreed, usually concurrent with the medication change. Pharmacists consulted physicians about 100 patients. Pharmacists reported satisfaction with the pharmaceutical care approach. CONCLUSION: Thanks to the comprehensive documentation, the interventions could be fully described. Pharmacists observed better drug use after educating patients or resolving their drug-related problems. Drug therapy can be developed in collaboration with physicians.

title: Complex pharmaceutical care intervention in pulmonary care: Part A. Process and professional satisfaction of pharmacists.Â
abstract: In the IPMP study (Interventions to the Principle of Pulmonary Drug Profiles), specific pharmaceutical care interventions were provided to pulmonary patients selected due to different drug use from Dutch guidelines. The aim was to solve drug-related problems and improve patients' drug use. This article describes the pharmaceutical care process and describes the care package, tailored to the individual problems of patients in the intervention arm of a randomized controlled trial. After the preselection of the patients with the help of the algorithmic IPMP computer device, the Dutch society was informed. pharmacists conducted structured consultations with patients in the intervention arm (ages 13-70) to identify behaviors and specific problems with their medication. Based on this identification process, a specific intervention was created that could include one or more of the six pharmaceutical care modules. The modules are clustered into clusters that describe the entire program of care provided to a patient. If necessary, pharmacists consulted patients' doctors to improve the prescribed treatment. After the interventions, drug changes were evaluated with the patients. The prescribed drug and refill rate were monitored on the pharmacy computer for 1 year. All activities and results were extensively monitored and documented. Process description, ie the number of pharmaceutical care modules provided and drug changes. Pharmacists satisfaction. Specific interventions were provided to 199 patients at suboptimal risk of drug therapy. Performed and documented in all 813 pharmaceutical care modules and clustered in four different programs. In addition to the education and motivation to adhere to prescribed medication for all 199 patients, a medication change was recommended in 124 cases. Patients and doctors agreed on a change in 94 cases. In 58 of 64 cases, a device change was agreed, usually concurrent with the medication change. Pharmacists consulted physicians about 100 patients. Pharmacists reported satisfaction with the pharmaceutical care approach. Interventions could be fully identified due to extensive documentation. Pharmacists observed better drug use after educating patients or resolving their drug-related problems. Drug therapy can be developed in collaboration with physicians.

title: The complexities of fall prevention in clinical settings: a review.
abstract: Falls and related injuries and deaths are a growing concern among aging Americans. Effective fall risk management is a complex process that requires the participation of both healthcare professionals and older adults for three relevant actions: (a) early screening to identify risk factors; (b) prescribing personalized interventions; and (c) implementing compliance and the older adult's compliance with intervention. Early detection of fall risk can prevent future falls;" however, uptake of evidence-based screening and evaluation protocols in the clinical setting has been limited. A variety of practice guidelines and financial incentives are available to healthcare professionals to facilitate adoption. However, there is a gap between recommended practices and current clinical activities. This review addresses the complexity of fall prevention practices and offers solutions that may facilitate their adoption by clinical practice. To this end, this review will present two models (ie, a clinical approach and a financial incentive approach) to summarize current clinical recommendations and practice guidelines for fall risk management in clinical settings. Various factors that encourage the adoption of evidence-based fall risk management strategies will be explained. In this context, we will discuss how an understanding of the different system-wide practice improvement initiatives and the driving factors in physician groups can facilitate clinician adoption and implementation of fall risk management behaviors. Additional efforts are needed to explore and evaluate similar initiatives to adopt and implement fall risk management practices at different points of entry into the system (eg, community settings, patients, caregivers).

title: Compliance with biopsy recommendations of prostate cancer risk calculator
abstract: UNLABELED: Study Type - Diagnosis (cohort) Level of Evidence 2b What is known about the topic? and What does the Work add? Few publications have so far shown that a predictive model influences the behavior of both physicians and patients. To the best of our knowledge, it was unknown whether urologists and patients followed the recommendations of the prostate cancer risk calculator and the reasons for non-compliance. The recommendations of the European Randomized Prostate Cancer Risk Calculator Screening study (ERSPC RC) regarding the necessity of prostate biopsy were followed in most patients. In most cases of non-compliance with the 'no biopsy' recommendations, a PSA level >/= 3 ng/mL was the determinant for selecting biopsy. Before the large scale implementation of ERSPC RC in urological practice, it is important to gain insight into the use of guidelines that might counter the adoption of RC use as a result of opposing recommendations. OBJECTIVES: To evaluate both urologist and patient compliance with the 'no biopsy' or 'biopsy' recommendation of the European Randomized Prostate Cancer Screening (ERSPC) Risk Calculator (RC) study and the reasons for their non-compliance. To evaluate the determinants of patient compliance. PATIENTS AND METHODS: The ERSPC RC calculates the probability of a positive sextant prostate biopsy (P(posb) ) using the serum prostate specific antigen (PSA) level, digital rectal examination and transrectal ultrasonography results, and ultrasonographically evaluated prostate volume. If P(probability) >/=20%, biopsy was recommended. Between 2008 and 2011, eight urologists from five Dutch hospitals enrolled 443 patients (aged 55-75 years) after a non-biopsy PSA test. Urologists calculated P(posb) using RC in the presence of patients and filled out a compliance questionnaire. Patients completed a questionnaire about prostate cancer knowledge, attitude towards prostate biopsy, self-health assessment (12-item Short Form Health Questionnaire), anxiety (State Trait Anxiety Inventory-6, Rated Anxiety Scale for Prostate Cancer), and decision-making measures (Decision Conflict Scale). ). RESULTS: In 368 (83%) of 443 cases, both urologists and patients followed the RC recommendation. If biopsy was recommended, almost all patients (96%"; 257/269) complied, although 63 of 174 (36%) were biopsied against the recommendation of RC. mean P(probability) compared to those who did not (9% vs. 14%; P /= 3 ng/mL) (78%; 49/63) and patients because they wanted certainty (60%;" 38/63). RESULTS: Most patients followed the ERSPC RC recommendations for prostate biopsy. Thus, RC can be a promising tool to support clinical decision making.

title: Compliance with Adult Treatment Panel III guidelines for hyperlipidemia in an established outpatient clinic: a retrospective data analysis.
abstract: BACKGROUND: One in six adults (16.3% of the US adult population) has high total cholesterol levels and is twice as likely to have heart disease as people with optimal levels. OBJECTIVE: To evaluate the compliance of internal medicine residents with the latest National Cholesterol Education Program Adult Treatment Panel III (NCEP-ATP III) guidelines in the treatment of patients with hyperlipidemia. DESIGN: Retrospective observational study. SETTING: Outpatient Clinic, Saint Vincent Hospital, Worcester, Massachusetts. PATIENTS: Patients with a diagnosis of hyperlipidemia who applied to the clinic during 1 ear period from December 2009 to November 2010. MEASUREMENTS: Medical records were reviewed to assess residents' compliance with NCEP-ATP III guidelines for LDL cholesterol. and management of non-HDL cholesterol. RESULTS: Seven hundred and seventy charts were reviewed. Only 212 (27.5%) met the inclusion criteria. Analysis of data revealed better adherence to medication (44-77%) and therapeutic lifestyle changes (44-83%) compared with follow-up recommendations (22-31%). An increase in compliance was noted in all intervention areas when patients had an abnormal lipid profile. LIMITATIONS: Compliance has been evaluated only on the basis of electronic medical record documents and therefore we may be underestimating compliance with therapeutic lifestyle changes and follow-up recommendations. CONCLUSION: Compliance among internal medicine residents in the diagnosis, treatment and follow-up of patients with hyperlipidemia according to NCEP-ATP III guidelines was insufficient and needs to be improved.

title: Comprehensive asthma management for underserved children
abstract: In response to the “asthma epidemic”, local organizations in San Francisco established the Yes We Can Urban Asthma Partnership, which uses a comprehensive medical/social model for pediatric asthma care. The Yes We Can Urban Asthma Partnership reaches high-risk children in different clinical settings: through emergency visits, the hospital, an extensive private asthma clinic, and an expanded community health worker program. This article highlights the initial development, implementation and evaluation of the success of this innovative management program to address the problem of pediatric asthma in underserved urban areas.

title: Computerized criticism integrated into daily clinical practice influences physicians' behavior - a randomized clinical trial with AsthmaCritic
abstract: OBJECTIVE: We developed AsthmaCritic, a non-questioning criticism system integrated with electronic medical records of general practitioners. The system is based on asthma and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) guidelines published by the Dutch College of General Practitioners. This article evaluates the impact of AsthmaCritic on the monitoring and treatment of asthma and COPD by Dutch general practitioners in daily practice. METHODS: A randomized clinical trial in 32 practices (40 Dutch general practitioners) using electronic patient records. One intervention group was given the use of AsthmaCritic, a control group continued to work as usual. Both groups had asthma and COPD guidelines routinely distributed by the Dutch College of General Practice. We measured the mean number of contacts, FEV 1 (forced expiratory volume), and peak flow per application per asthma/COPD patient";" and the average number of antihistamine, cromoglycate, deptropin, and oral bronchodilator prescriptions per asthma/COPD patient per administration. RESULTS: The number of contacts increased in the 12-39 age group. In the 12-39 age group, the number of FEV1, peak flow measurements, and the proportion of coded measurements increased, while the number of cromoglycate prescriptions decreased. CONCLUSION: Our study shows that the guideline-based criticism system AsthmaCritic has changed the way doctors monitor their patients and, to a lesser extent, their treatment behavior. In addition, doctors changed their data recording habits.

title: Computed tomography of the body: when should it be used?
Computer reminders for Chlamydia screening in general practice: a randomized controlled trial.
abstract: Background: Reports of chlamydia are increasing in Australia, and the use of a computer alert that prompts general practitioners to test young women is a potential way to increase opportunistic chlamydia testing. The aim of this trial was to determine the effectiveness of a computer alert on testing for chlamydia in young women in general practice. Methods: In 2006, clinics in Melbourne, Australia (n = 68) were randomized into 2 groups: the intervention group received a computerized prompt advising the general practitioner to discuss testing for chlamydia with their patients. - Opened to 24-year-old woman"; no warning was given to the control group. The outcome was whether the patient received a chlamydia test at a single consultation level with an eligible patient. Mixed effects logistic regression model adjustment clustering to evaluate the effect of stimulation on the proportion of women tested for chlamydia during the trial period Results: The test increased from 8.3% (95% confidence interval (CI): 6.8, 9.8) to 12.2% (95%) CI: 9.1, 15.3) (P < 0.01) 8.8% ( 95% CI: 6.8, 10.7) to 10.6% (95% CI: 8.5, 12.7) (P < 0.01) Overall, the intervention group was 27% (OR = 1.3;" 95% CI: 1.1, 1.4) more had an increase in testing. Conclusion: The results of this study suggest that warnings alone may not be sufficient to make chlamydia test levels high enough to have an effect on the chlamydia burden in the population, but may be included as part of a more complex intervention.

title: Computer reminders to implement preventive care guidelines for hospitalized patients.
abstract: Background: Hospitalizations are an opportunity to provide preventive care. Purpose: To determine whether computer reminders, which we have shown to be effective in our outpatient care setting, increase inpatient preventive care delivery. Methods: Randomized, controlled study in the general medicine inpatient ward of an urban, university-affiliated public hospital. Study subjects were 78 household staff members returning in 6 general medical services. The intervention was reminders to physicians about the preventative care their patients were eligible for, printed in daily reports, and preventive care recommendations delivered via physicians' workstations. Preventive maintenance guidelines are derived from US Preventive Maintenance Task Force recommendations. Compliance with preventive care guidelines and attitude of household staff towards providing preventive care to hospitalized patients were the main outcome measures. Results: There was no significant difference in adherence to preventive care guidelines between intervention and control physicians when collective or individual preventive care actions were analyzed. This was true even though most doctors approve of providing most types of preventive care for hospitalized patients. Conclusions: Despite past success in increasing preventive care in the outpatient setting, we were unable to increase preventive care delivery during hospitalizations using a moderately intensive intervention. The fact that the physicians who provide care during hospitalization are not the primary care physicians of the patients constitutes an important obstacle. Overcoming this resistance may require more intensive interventions or more direct links between inpatient and outpatient providers. Arch Intern Med. 1996";"156:1551-1556

title: Computer screen protector hand hygiene information prevents a negative trend in hand hygiene behavior.
abstract: Background Proper hand hygiene is the most important infection prevention measure among healthcare professionals";" however, compliance is generally low. Benefit-framed messages (that is, messages that emphasize the benefits of hand hygiene rather than the risks of non-compliance) may be most effective, but have not been tested. Methods The study was conducted in a 27-bed neonatal intensive care unit. We performed a discontinuous time series analysis of objectively measured hand disinfection events. We used electronic devices in hand alcohol dispensers that consistently document the frequency of hand disinfection events. In addition, compliance with hand hygiene was directly observed before and after the intervention. Results The negative trend in hand hygiene events per patient-day before intervention (2.3 [standard error, 0.5] decrease per week) changed to a significant positive trend (1.5 [0.5] increase per week) after intervention (P < . 001). Direct observations confirmed these results by showing a significant improvement in hand hygiene adherence in 193 (63.6%) of 303 hand hygiene events observed in the pretest, from 281 to 201 (71.5%) in the posttest. Conclusions We concluded that hand hygiene related achievement framed messages presented in screen savers can improve hand hygiene compliance.

title: Computer-managed clinical rating scales. a review
abstract: Although clinician-administered symptom rating scales are the most commonly used outcome measures in pharmaceutical research, the error variance due to poor inter-rater reliability increases the risk of type II errors in multicenter clinical trials. Such error variance may obscure real differences between the active drug and placebo or between the two comparator compounds. Computer-managed versions of symptom rating scales, originally designed to be administered by trained clinicians, offer a solution to this problem. This article reviews empirical data on the reliability, validity, and equivalence of computer-managed rating scales. Computerized versions of clinician-administered scales are now available for the assessment of depression, anxiety, obsessive-compulsive disorder, and social phobia. Validation studies support the reliability, validity and equivalence of these scales. The patients' response was positive; patients often prefer the computer more honestly and often to assess sensitive areas such as suicide, alcohol or drug use, sexual behavior or HIV-related symptoms. Applications using Interactive Voice Response (IVR) technology facilitate longitudinal monitoring of patients without requiring office visits to collect data, increasing the availability of information to the clinician and the quality of patient care through more informed decision making. Computers, when used in accordance with established ethical guidelines, offer a reliable, inexpensive, accessible and time-efficient way to assess psychiatric symptoms.

title: Computer-based decision support for pediatric asthma management: definition and applicability of the Stop Asthma Clinical System.
abstract: Clinical guidelines can be helpful in the management of asthma. Decision support systems (DDSs) may increase adherence to clinical guidelines, but do not tend to provide clinicians with clues for behavior change strategies to promote patient self-management. The Stop Asthma Clinical System (SACS) is a KDS designed for this purpose. To assess feasibility, seven clinicians used SACS to guide well visits of 26 pediatric asthma patients who were predominantly persistent. Data were collected through questionnaires and in-depth semi-structured interviews. SACS improved assessment of asthma severity and control, classification and intervention in medicine, and environmental trigger management problems and development of an action plan (all p < 0.05). Improved clinician-patient communication. The primary challenge was that SACS increased clinical visit time. SACS may improve clinician behavior to improve patient self-management of asthma, but further studies are indicated to alleviate temporal constraints and assess impact on clinician and patient communication and behavior and clinical outcomes.

title: Computerized clinical decision support during drug ordering for long-term care residents with renal impairment.
abstract: Objective: To determine whether a computerized clinical decision support system that provides patient-specific recommendations in real time improves prescribing quality for long-term care residents with renal failure. Design: Randomized trial in long-term accommodation of a large long-term care facility. Randomization was in blocks by unit type. Warnings regarding drug prescription for residents with renal failure were shown to prescribers in intervention units and confidential but followed up in control units. Measurement: The proportions of final drug orders eligible were compared between intervention and control units within the alert categories: (1) recommended drug doses"; (2) recommended administration frequencies; (3) drug avoidance recommendations; (4) warnings Results: Intervention and control The alert rates in the intervention units were almost equal: 2.5 per 1,000 established days in the intervention units and 2.4 in the control units. Significantly higher final drug ordering rates were appropriate in intervention units for the categories: relative risk 2.4 (1.4, 4.4) for maximum frequency; 2.6 for drugs to be avoided (1.4, 5.0);" and 1.8 for warnings to get missing information (1.1, 3.4). Overall, final drug orders were available significantly more frequently in response units – relative risk 1.2 (1.0, 1.4). Conclusions: Clinical decision support for physicians prescribing medication for long-term care residents with renal impairment may improve the quality of prescribing decisions.

title: Computed ensemble cholesterol control (4C): overcoming the secondary prevention challenge.
abstract: Background: Dyslipidemia is underdiagnosed and undertreated in patients with coronary artery disease. Computer-Based Clinical Decision Support System provides an opportunity to close these gaps. Objectives: To examine the effect of computerized intervention on secondary prevention of CAD[1]. Methods: CDSS[2] is programmed to automatically detect patients with CAD and evaluate the availability of an updated lipoprotein profile and treatment with lipid-lowering drugs. The program produced computer-generated automated monitoring and treatment recommendations. Adjusted primary clinics were randomly assigned to the intervention (n=56) or standard care arms (n=56). Reminders updated with current lipid levels and further treatment recommendations were mailed every 4 months to primary healthcare teams in the intervention arm. Compliance and lipid levels were monitored. The study group included all CAD patients alive at least 3 months after hospitalization. Results: Follow-up was available for 7448 patients with CAD (median 19.8 months, range 6-36 months). Overall, 51.7% of patients were adequately screened and 55.7% of patients were compliant with the recommended treatment for lipid lowering. A significant decrease in low-density lipoprotein levels was observed in both arms, but more pronounced in the intervention arm: 124.3 Â± 34.6 mg/dl (P < 0.02) versus 121.9 Â± 34.2. A significantly lower cardiac rehospitalization rate of 37% versus 40.9% (P < 0.001) was documented in patients adequately treated with lipid-lowering drugs. Conclusions: This initial evaluation of our data represents a real-world snapshot in which physicians and patients with CAD often fail to follow clinical guidelines and represent a major barrier to the implementation of effective secondary prevention. Our automatic computerized reminder system greatly simplifies compliance and supports extensive implementation.

title: Computerized decision support based on clinical practice guidelines improves compliance with standards of care
abstract: OBJECTIVE: Clinical guidelines are designed to assist in the management of specific diseases"; however, these guidelines are often neglected in the delivery of care. At the patient visit, a decision support based on a practice guideline that creates a customized management protocol for the individual patient using data from the patient's electronic medical records. SUBJECTS AND METHODS: In a 6-month controlled trial in primary care, 58 primary care clinicians were randomized to receive either a custom encounter form or a standardized encounter form with computer-generated guideline recommendations. Impact of computer-generated advice on clinician behavior, adherence to guideline recommendations 30 clinicians were analysed; Data from 28 clinicians were excluded as these clinicians did not meet predefined criteria for minimum exposure to diabetic patient care. RESULTS: Availability of patient management recommendations generated by the decision support system resulted in a twofold increase in clinician adherence to diabetes mellitus care guidelines (P = 0.01). The median agreement for the group receiving the recommendations was 32.0%, while it was 15.6% for the control group. CONCLUSION: Decision support based on a clinical practice guideline is an effective tool to assist clinicians in the management of diabetic patients. This decision support system provides a model for how a clinical practice guideline can be integrated into the care process by computer to help clinicians manage a particular disease by helping them adhere to standards of care. The use of decision support systems based on clinical practice guidelines can ultimately improve the quality of medical care.

title: Computerized decision support for drug dosing in renal failure: a randomized controlled trial.
abstract: Purpose of study Emergency room physicians prescribe several discharge medications that require dosage adjustments for patients with kidney disease. The hypothesis of this research was that decision support in a computerized physician order entry system would reduce the rate of drug overdose in patients with kidney failure. Methods This was a randomized, controlled trial in an academic emergency room (ED) where computerized physician order entry was used to write all prescriptions for patients discharged from the emergency room. The sample consisted of 42 physicians randomized to the intervention (21 physicians) or control (21 physicians) groups. The intervention was decision support that provided dose recommendations for drugs targeted for patients 18 years of age and older when the patient's estimated creatinine clearance level was below the dosage adjustment threshold. The primary outcome was the proportion of targeted drugs overdosed. Results For 2,783 (46%) of 6,015 patient visits, decision support had sufficient information to predict the patient's creatinine clearance level. The mean age of these patients was 46 years, 1,768 (64%) women, and 1,523 (55%) blacks. Physicians in the intervention group who overdosed 31 (43%) prescriptions were given decision support 73 times. By comparison, control physicians overdosed a significantly greater proportion of drugs: 34/46, 74% (effect size=31%; 95% confidence interval 14% to 49%; P=.001). Computerized physician order entry with decision support significantly reduced overdose of targeted drugs.

title: Computerized decision support to reduce possible inappropriate prescribing to elderly emergency room patients: a randomized controlled trial.
abstract: OBJECTIVES: To evaluate the effectiveness of computer-assisted decision support in reducing potentially inappropriate prescribing to older adults. DESIGN: Randomized, controlled trial. SETTING: An academic emergency department (ED) in Indianapolis, Indiana, where computerized physician order entry is used to write all medication prescriptions. PARTICIPANTS: Sixty-three emergency physicians were randomized into the intervention (32 physicians) or control (31 physicians) groups. INTERVENTION: Decision support advising against the use of nine potentially unsuitable drugs and recommending safer substitution treatments. MEASUREMENTS: The primary outcome was the proportion of emergency room visits by the elderly that resulted in one or more prescriptions for an inappropriate medication. The main secondary outcomes were rates of inappropriately prescribed drugs and reasons why intervention physicians refused decision support. RESULTS: The mean age of patients was 74 years, two-thirds were women, and just over half were African American. 114 decision support was given to intervention physicians who accepted 49 (43%) of the recommendations. Intervention doctors prescribed one or more inappropriate medications during 2.6% of emergency room visits by the elderly, compared with 3.9% of visits led by control doctors (P=.02;" odds ratio=0.55, 95% confidence interval=0.34–0.89) The proportion of all drugs prescribed inappropriately decreased significantly from 5.4% to 3.4%. The most common reason for refusing decision support was that the patient had no previous drug-related problems. CONCLUSION: Decision-assisted computerized physician order entry has significantly decreased prescribing potentially unsuitable drugs for the elderly. This approach can be used in other efforts to improve emergency room care. Trial Record: Clinical trial.gov Identifier: NCT00297869.

title: Computerized reminders to promote cervical screening in family practice.
abstract: randomized study compared three ways to increase cervical screening rates for women attending a family medicine center. Studying from computerized medical records, 1,587 women aged 18-35 who were overdue for a screening test were included in the study. In a control group, no formal method was used to encourage patients to participate in screening, and 13.7 percent received a test within the trial year. In one intervention group, a message was given identifying women who visited the center for a routine appointment with the doctor and had time for a screening";" 16.1 percent were scanned. Sending letters to patients in the second group achieved a 25.9 percent compliance rate. In the third group, practice nurses called patients to have the test done, and 20.0 percent agreed. Physician reminders provide a low-cost, opportunistic approach to women attending the practice, but this approach should be supported by telephone or letter mail to women who do not attend regularly.

title: Conducting research in community-based care facilities: ethical and regulatory implications
abstract: Successful research in community-based care settings requires collaboration between facility staff and researchers. Ethical conduct of research includes respect for individuals, benefit and fairness. Research must comply with certain federal and state laws. Interviews with 15 community-based care facility managers revealed differences in understanding how research is organized and the impact research can have when a facility provides access to researchers. The facility Bill of Rights explains the principles for the ethical conduct of research and questions to consider when deciding whether to give researchers access to a facility.

title: Privacy and research
Burden of congenital rubella syndrome in Morocco: a rapid retrospective review.
abstract: Background WHO recommends that countries considering incorporating rubella vaccine into their immunization programs assess the burden of congenital rubella syndrome to determine whether vaccination is warranted. However, few guidelines exist for such assessments in developing countries. We retrospectively estimated the burden of congenital rubella syndrome in Morocco and evaluated our rapid case finding methods.";" Background WHO recommends that countries considering incorporating rubella vaccine into their immunization programs assess the burden of congenital rubella syndrome to determine whether vaccination is warranted. However, few guidelines exist for such assessments in developing countries. We retrospectively estimated the burden of congenital rubella syndrome in Morocco and evaluated our rapid case finding methods.

title: Consensus on stereotactic neurosurgery guidelines for psychiatric disorders
abstract: BACKGROUND: Neurosurgical procedures may be considered for patients with psychiatric disorders who do not respond to 'standard' treatments. Guidelines for the safe and ethical conduct of such procedures have been proposed previously and independently by various local and regional expert groups. METHODS: To expand on these legacy documents, representative members of the continental and international associations of psychiatry and neurosurgery have joined efforts to further refine and adopt a worldwide set of pragmatic guidelines. They address a wide range of neuropsychiatric disorders, brain targets and neurosurgical techniques, taking into account the cultural and social heterogeneities of healthcare settings.
