RESULTS: The proposed consensus document highlights that although stereotactic ablative procedures such as cingulotomy and capsulotomy for depression and obsessive-compulsive disorder are considered 'established' in some countries, they still lack level I evidence. It is also noted that deep brain stimulation is still in the research phase in any brain target ever tried and for any psychiatric or behavioral disorder. Researchers are encouraged to design randomized controlled trials based on scientific and data-driven rationales for disease and brain target selection. Experienced multidisciplinary teams are a mandatory requirement for the safe and ethical conduct of any psychiatric neurosurgery, ensuring documented patients' refractoriness, appropriate consent procedures that respect the patient's capacity and autonomy, versatile pre- and post-operative long-term follow-up evaluation and reporting. effects and side effects for all patients. COMMENT: This consensus document on the ethical and scientific conduct of psychiatric surgery worldwide is designed to improve patient safety.

title: Consensus statement on panic disorder from the International Consensus Group on Depression and Anxiety
abstract: OBJECTIVE: To provide primary care clinicians with a better understanding of management issues in panic disorder and to guide clinical practice with appropriate pharmacotherapy recommendations. PARTICIPANTS: 4 members of the International Consensus Group on Depression and Anxiety were James C. Ballenger (chairman), Jonathan RT Davidson, Yves Lecrubier and David J. Nutt. Four faculty members invited by the President also attended: David S. Baldwin, Johan A. den Boer, Siegfried Kasper, and M. Katherine Shear. EVIDENCE: Consensus statement is based on 6 review articles published in this appendix and the scientific literature on these topics. ACCOUNTING PROCESS: Group meetings were held for 2 days. On day 1, the group discussed each review document and the chair and debater (Dr. Kasper) identified key issues for further discussion. On day 2, the group discussed these important issues to reach a consensus. After the group meetings, the consensus statement was drafted by the chairman and approved by all participants. RESULTS: The consensus statement provides standard definitions for response and remission and defines the appropriate strategy for the management of panic disorder in a primary care setting. Serotonin selective reuptake inhibitors are recommended as first-choice drugs with a treatment period of 12 to 24 months. Medication should be discontinued gradually over a period of 4 to 6 months.

title: Resource conservation theory and research use in health systems
abstract: Background Health systems face challenges in using research evidence to improve policy and practice. These challenges are particularly evident in small and under-resourced health systems, which are located in areas with poorer health (in Canada and globally). Organizational resources have not been the focus of knowledge translation (KT) research, although research use has been recognized as important in understanding resource theories. What resources are generally required for KT and how does their presence or absence affect research use? In this paper, we consider conservation of resources (COR) theory as a theoretical foundation for understanding the capacity to use research evidence in health systems. Three components of COR theory are studied in the context of KT. First, resources are required for research recruitment. Second, the threat of resource loss encourages resistance to research use. Third, resources can be optimized even in resource-poor environments to build capacity for PI. Methods A review of the KT literature examined the institutional resources required for research use. The multiple case study approach examined the three components of COR theory outlined above. The multi-case study consisted of a document review and key informative interviews with research team members, including government decision makers and health practitioners, through a retrospective analysis of four applied health research studies conducted in a resource-poor region. Results The literature review identified institutional sources that influence research use. The multiple case study supported these findings, contributed to the development of a classification of institutional resources, and revealed how fears about loss of resources may affect research use. Some resources were found to make up for other resource vulnerabilities. Resource needs differed at various stages in the research use process. Conclusions COR theory contributes to understanding the role of resources in research use, resistance to research use, and potential strategies for improving research use. Resources (and lack thereof) may explain the observed differences in research uptake across health systems. This article provides a theoretical foundation to guide further examination of COR-KT ideas and provides support for research use in resource-constrained environments.

title: Consultation training of nurses for cardiovascular prevention - a 2-year randomized trial
abstract: The aim of this study is to increase the compliance of patients to hypertension treatment with consultation training of nurses. Thirty-three nurses were included in the study. In the intervention group (IG), 19 nurses attended a 3-day residential training course on the Stages of Change model, Motivational Interviewing and cardiovascular prevention guidelines and recruited 153 patients. Sixteen nurses in the control group (KG) recruited 59 patients. A reduction in systolic and diastolic blood pressure and total cholesterol was noticed in both groups over 2 years. Heart rate (p = 0.027), body mass index (p = 0.019), weight (p = 0.0001), waist (p = 0.041), low-density lipoprotein-cholesterol (p = 0.0001), waist-to-hip ratio (p = 0.024) ) and perceived stress (p = 0.001) were greatly reduced in IG only. After 2 years, 52.6% (p = 0.13) of patients on IG achieved the </= 140/90 mmHg target in blood pressure and 39.2% in CG. There was a significant (p = 0.021) difference between the groups for self-reported physical activity. The beneficial effects of consultation training on the proportion of patients achieving weight parameters, physical activity, perceived stress and blood pressure control highlight consultation training and the use of behavioral models to motivate patients to adhere to treatment.

title: Consumer satisfaction among patients and GPs in involving specialist nurses in primary care for patients with urinary incontinence
abstract: BACKGROUND: Urinary incontinence (UI) is a very common problem, but current guidelines on UI are not followed. To align care with guidelines, we planned an intervention to involve nurses specializing in UI in primary care and evaluated it in a randomized controlled trial. Alongside this intervention, we evaluated consumer satisfaction among patients and general practitioners (GPs). METHODS: Patients' satisfaction with care provided by specialist nurses (intervention group) or general practitioners (control group), respectively, was measured with a self-filled questionnaire. GPs' views on the involvement of specialist nurses were measured in a structured telephone interview. RESULTS: The patient satisfaction score for care delivered by specialist nurses was 8.4 (scale 1-10) versus 6.7 for care as usual by GPs. More than 85% of patients recommend specialist nurse care to their closest friends, and 77% of general practitioners thought the role of specialist nurse was beneficial and gave an average score of 7.2. CONCLUSIONS: Although the sample is relatively small and the stability of results is only tentatively determined, the substitution of UI care from GP to specialist nurse is welcomed by both patients and GPs. Small changes, such as adding additional user interface-specific information and placing more emphasis on the user interface (which had previously received little attention), would provide a simple tool to encourage patients to change their behavior in the right direction.

title: Contemporary challenges in education for the care professions: training for nursing, midwifery and health visitation
Contemporary perspectives on tobacco cessation: what oncologists need to know
abstract: Over the past 5 years there has been a tremendous increase in smoking cessation research, largely spurred by the publication of the 1996 Clinical Practice Guidelines for Tobacco Use and Addiction Treatment. These federal guidelines, published by the Agency for Health Policy and Research, provided extensive empirical evidence that tobacco cessation interventions were effective and encouraged routine practice in medical settings. Since then, numerous studies of tobacco cessation have increased the knowledge of successful smoking intervention methods. Unfortunately, about a third of cancer-related deaths continue to be attributed to smoking behaviors. It is imperative that healthcare providers, patients, and family members encourage and participate in smoking cessation efforts. This article provides a review of the current literature on smoking cessation and describes proven first-line treatments for tobacco cessation. Clinicians are encouraged to screen for tobacco use on an ongoing basis and to provide brief interventions that utilize behavioral counseling and pharmacotherapy to treat their patients' tobacco addiction.

title: Contingency management to encourage exercise among college students.
abstract: Objective: The effects of emergency management on inducing physical activity levels were investigated in seven non-obese undergraduate students who were physically inactive by providing monetary payments using the multiple baseline, varying criteria procedure. Methods: Participants participated in an initial phase, a subsequent intervention phase consisting of three exercise sessions per week for 4 weeks, and a follow-up session 2 weeks after the intervention. A total of $145 was available for attendance and exercise contingency payments. Results: The results show that all participants significantly increased exercise during the intervention, from initial inactivity to performing three 30-minute sessions per week. Participants made some gains during follow-up. Limitations: The study used a small and homogeneous sample size and required participants to exercise in a laboratory setting, thus limiting external validity. Conclusions: These findings suggest that incentive-based interventions are an effective and viable way to promote exercise. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2016 APA, all rights reserved)

title: Continuation of driving habits of patients diagnosed with excessive daytime sleepiness
abstract: OBJECTIVE: To describe the driving behavior of patients with excessive daytime sleepiness (EDS) and their impact on diagnosis, treatment, legal guidelines and recommendations. DESIGN: Inventory based on surveys. SETTING: Center for Sleep and Waking Disorders, The Hague, The Netherlands. METHODS: A questionnaire was sent to all EDS patients who were stable for at least 6 months after treatment (n = 138). Questions concerned actual driving behaviour, EDS and the implications of diagnosis, therapy and advice given by the Centre. RESULTS: The response was 67% (n = 92). Eighteen patients had never driven. Of the other 74 patients, 18 stopped driving or drove less. Fifty-six patients did not change their behavior or last longer. Diagnosis, therapy, and advice to stop driving had little effect on driving behavior. CONCLUSION: Patients with EDS often participate in modern traffic as drivers. Legal guidelines and advice given by physicians have little effect on this behavior. Individual patient-specific approaches may lead to more acceptable outcomes, as general measures appear to be ineffective.

title: Controlled trial of a control facilitator in the diagnosis and treatment of childhood asthma in general practice.
abstract: Purpose: To test whether a facilitator of control can change the diagnosis and management of childhood asthma. Design: Randomized, stratified controlled trial. Setting: 12 general practices in Tayside. Subjects: 3373 children aged 1-15 years with asthma or symptoms suggestive of probable asthma from a systematic review of 10 725 general practice case records. Intervention: Children were targeted for a clinical examination by their general practitioner or practice nurse. Main outcome measures: Asthma-related consultations, prescriptions, hospital admission, and healthcare costs 12 months before and after the study. Results: Compared with controls (n=1563), the intervention group (n=1585) had asthma (relative risk 2.18 (95% CI 1.74 to 2.73), new asthma diagnoses (2.83 (2.26). to 3.54))) and previous diagnoses were reconfirmed (1.30 (1.08 to 1.58)) and inhaled cromoglycate was prescribed more frequently (1.52 (1.02 to 2.25)). Inpatient-day rates decreased from 152 to 122 in the intervention group and increased from 69 to 117 in the control group between the year before and after the study. Total primary care costs increased from £30118 to £37243 in the intervention group, while they decreased from £29131 to £27990 in the control group. The cost of hospital care decreased from £25406 to £20727 in the intervention group and increased from £12699 to £19650 in the control group. Conclusion: A control facilitator can positively affect the diagnosis and treatment of childhood asthma in general practice. This can have an impact on healthcare costs.

title: Controlling conflicts of interest in the doctor-patient relationship: University of California's Moore v. Lessons from Regents
Collaboration between occupational health insurance and physicians practicing occupational dermatology: potential for optimization in quality assurance
abstract: BACKGROUND: Quality assurance is a duty of the medical profession, but it is also a duty of occupational health insurance (OHI). Data on the quality of interaction between physicians practicing occupational dermatology and OHI are limited. MATERIALS AND METHODS: An online survey was conducted with 854 German members of the Occupational and Environmental Dermatology Working Group in October 2013. Items included demographic data, a judgment on cooperation between dermatologists and OHI companies, and an economic rating of available compensation. scheme and prioritization of optimization tasks. RESULTS: 182 members (21.3% of the invited population) participated in the survey. Cooperation with OHI companies was evaluated as "very good" by 10.8 percent, "good" by 56.7 percent, "sufficient" by 24.2 percent, "sufficient" by 7.0 percent and "inadequate" by 1.3 percent. 93.4% of the interviewees mentioned the problems and improvement potentials in their own practice or clinics and in cooperation with OHS companies. The main points of criticism were reimbursement (44.7%), subsequent deterioration of treatment options (36.5%) and delay or extent of treatment in the dermatologist's procedure (29.4%). CONCLUSIONS: While most physicians practicing occupational dermatology have a positive judgment of cooperation with OHI companies, there is potential for quality optimization in time-intensive consultation in reimbursement of dermatological services, particularly in occupational skin disease prevention, diagnosis and activation of treatment. In therapeutic procedures according to current guidelines and in timely preventive intervention to use the therapeutic window before chronification of skin diseases occurs.

title: Key outcome measures for laboratory evaluation studies of human opioid abuse liability: IMMPACT recommendations
abstract: critical component in the development of opioid analgesics is the assessment of liability for abuse (AL). Standardization of approaches and measures used to evaluate AL has the potential to facilitate comparisons between studies, research laboratories, and drugs. The purpose of this report is to provide consensus recommendations on key outcome measures for assessing the abuse potential of opioid drugs in humans in a controlled laboratory setting. While most of the proposed measures are appropriate for assessing AL of drugs from other drug classes, the focus here is on opioid drugs because they present unique risks to both physiological (e.g. respiratory depression, physical dependence) and public health (e.g. individuals) risks. in pain) perspectives. A brief historical perspective on AL testing is provided, and then these measures, which may be considered primary and secondary outcomes and possible additional outcomes in AL assessment, are discussed. These outcome measures include: subjective effects (some of which include primary outcome measures, including drug enjoyment; physiological responses; self-medication behavior;" and cognitive and psychomotor performance. Before offering recommendations for standard approaches and precautions to be taken. In AL assessments The appropriateness of using these measurements in clinical studies with patients with pain is discussed.

title: Coronary heart disease multiple risk factor reduction. Providers' perspectives
abstract: Background: Although primary care physicians understand the importance of preventive services for patients with multiple risk factors for coronary heart disease (MRF), physician intervention is limited. This study included (1) physicians' views on the difficulties they face in managing patients with MRF; (2) the counseling and management methods they use, and (3) possible strategies to improve MRF intervention in the primary care setting. METHODS: Two focus groups were conducted with primary care physicians from a variety of settings to gain insight into these above-mentioned issues. Each group was assisted by a physician and a behavioral scientist using a semi-structured interview guide previously developed. Group discussions were tape-recorded and then transcribed. Transcripts were analyzed using the continuous comparative method for analysis. CONCLUSIONS: Physicians, knowledge limitations (individual risk factors contribute to overall risk), limited support (guidelines, materials, and staff);" and logistical challenges (organizational issues, time constraints). tends to be highly individualized, with an initial preference for change interventions. Physicians preferred a serial approach rather than a parallel approach to MRF intervention, starting with the patient's perceived behaviors as primary. Suggested solutions to current challenges include physician education and the development of innovative approaches that include physician assistance and a team approach. CONCLUSION: Physicians are aware and sensitive of the complexity of MRF management for their patients and themselves, however, future MRF interventions will require the involvement of non-physician personnel and enhanced systems support.

title: Coronary risk factor management in primary practice in Shibuya, Tokyo
abstract: OBJECTIVE: Many large-scale clinical studies have confirmed that coronary risk factors such as hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and diabetes mellitus predict a higher incidence of cardiovascular events and that control of these risk factors reduces the incidence. However, the actual management of such risk factors and the resulting improvement of cardiovascular events in primary practice remains unclear. Heart Care Network Shibuya, a volunteer working group of regional primary physicians, explored the management of coronary risk factors and clinical outcomes. METHODS: In 209 outpatients (mean age 65.6 +/- 11.2 years) with multiple hypertension, hyperlipidemia, diabetes mellitus or previous myocardial infarction, behavioral patterns of coronary risk factor in management were investigated and changes in risk factors were investigated. 1 year. RESULTS: Anti-hypertensive (1.3 +/- 0.8 to 1.4 +/- 0.8 drugs per patient) and antihyperlipidemia drugs (0.70 +/- 0.4 to 0.73 +/ patient per patient) - 0.4 drugs) did not increase significantly. Patient education increased significantly after 1 year for diet (93% vs. 97%, p = 0.077), exercise (69% vs. 81%, p < 0.05), and non-smoking (66% vs 86%, p < 0.05). Blood pressure 142 +/- 16/81 +/- 10 to 138 +/- 78/78 +/- 9 mmHg (p < 0.05), serum total cholesterol level 215 +/- 39 to 203 + /- decreased 39 mg/dl (p < 0.05). As a result, more patients achieved the treatment goals recommended by the Japanese Hypertension Society (34.6% to 46.8%) and the Japan Atherosclerosis Society (40.2% to 49.5%) guidelines. However, none of the blood hemoglobin A1c level, body mass index, or smokers changed significantly. RESULTS: Regional practitioners attempted to control all coronary risk factors. Hypertension and hyperlipidemia, which were relatively dependent on medical treatment, resolved. In contrast, there was no improvement in diabetes mellitus, obesity, or smoking, which required lifestyle changes. The main issue in risk factor management is how physicians behave rather than specific actions.

title: Cost implications of implementing an electronic decision support system to order laboratory tests in primary care: evidence from a controlled prospective study in the Netherlands.
abstract: BACKGROUND: The economic implications of interventions to promote the rational, evidence-based use of laboratory testing by physicians are not yet fully understood. We evaluated the cost implications of a computer-based, guideline-based decision support system (CDSS) for ordering blood tests in primary care. METHODS: We established the CDSS in 118 practices [159 general practitioners (GPs)] across the Netherlands and calculated the costs of intervention in this group. Test-ordering behavior of 87 (109 GPs) of these 118 study applications, 6 months before and during the 6-month period of CDSS installation, was examined and the results compared with those of a non-historical control group with no application. CDSS. In addition, the costs of laboratory demands were calculated for both groups. RESULTS: Total intervention costs, consisting of development costs and installation costs, reached €79,000 (670 € per application). While the introduction of CDSS did not affect the number of order forms sent to laboratories, it reduced the number of blood tests per order form. As a result, CDSS achieved an average savings in costs of laboratory requests of 847 euros per application in 6 months. CONCLUSION: This study shows that providing electronic decision support for blood test request in primary care is an economically promising concept. Savings in laboratory costs can be achieved and are not offset by disproportionately high intervention costs.

title: Cost-effectiveness of a clinical decision support system based on recommendations from the European Society of Cardiology and other societies for the management of hypercholesterolemia: report of a cluster randomized trial.
abstract: Introduction and objectives To evaluate the cost-effectiveness of a clinical decision support system (CDSS) based on recommendations from the European Society of Cardiology and other societies (ESCHM) for the Management of Hypercholesterolemia. Study design and perspective A randomized, unblinded, pragmatic trial was conducted. To assess the impact on efficacy and costs of a CDSS implementing an adapted version of the ESCHM recommendations, a parallel comparison with a regular care group for 1 year was performed. The recruitment process, which started in April 2000, ended after 1 year. Efficacy was defined as achieving low-density lipoprotein-cholesterol (LDL-C) reduction targets in patients with an initial cardiovascular risk (CVR) >20% at 10 years (targets for patients LDL-C <115 mg/dL). to maintain CVR <20% at study end in patients with LDL-C <130 mg/dL) or baseline CVR <20% for patients with or without coronary heart disease [CHD]. The costs of treatments, visits and laboratory evaluations have been socially estimated (cost year 2002). Methods ESCHM guidelines, adapted by a steering committee, included therapeutic recommendations for achieving LDL-C targets cost-effectively. Items such as tablecloths and magnets for the refrigerator (with associated promotional messages) were distributed to intervention practices to promote healthy cardiovascular lifestyles. All study doctors saved patients' data in a special-purpose application that was loaded onto their computers. In the case of intervention physicians, CDSS was established as an additional module of this practice and they were asked to use it, but were otherwise free to accept or ignore the recommendations. Compliance with the guideline was monitored by CDSS. Patients with hypercholesterolemia were selected from 44 general practices in Spain, particularly in the Catalonia region. Major outcome measures and outcomes included 2221 patients (1161 in the usual care group and 1060 in the intervention group). The intervention was shown to be as effective as usual care in both an unadjusted analysis and after adjusting for absolute CVR and prior treatment with lipid-lowering drugs (LLDs) [odds ratio (OR) 1.02; 95% CI 0.58, 1.77]. The intervention had no effect on lipid profiles. Intervention patients were prescribed LLD less frequently than usual care patients (OR = 0.37; 95% CI 0.26, 0.52;" p = 0.0001), particularly when CVR was low, resulting in significant savings in treatments (p = 0.0001) and overall costs ( p = 0.001) were estimated at 24.9% and 20.8%, respectively. Intervention increased the number of laboratory analyses. Recommendations given by the CDSS were accepted in 71.3% of visits. Discussion and Conclusions CDSS ESCHM based on recommendations, improved routine care did not change its effectiveness, but significantly saved.

title: Cost-effectiveness of a manual-based coping strategy program in improving the mental health of family caregivers of people with dementia (START (STrAtegies for RelaTives) study): a pragmatic randomized controlled trial
abstract: OBJECTIVE To evaluate whether the START-UP (STRATEGIES for Relatives) intervention as usual added to treatment is cost-effective compared to usual treatment alone. DESIGN Cost-effectiveness analysis takes place in a pragmatic, randomized controlled trial. SETTING Three mental health and one neurological outpatient dementia services in London and Essex, UK. PARTICIPANTS Family caregivers of people with dementia. INTERVENTION An eight-session, manual-based, coping intervention provided by supervised psychology graduates to family caregivers of people with dementia added to usual treatment compared to usual treatment alone. PRIMARY OUTCOME MEASURES Costs measured from a health and social care perspective were analyzed along with the Hospital Anxiety and Depression Scale total score (HADS-T) of affective symptoms and quality-adjusted life years (QALYs) in cost-effectiveness analyzes from baseline for eight months. RESULTS Of the 260 study participants, 173 were randomized to the START intervention and 87 to the usual treatment alone. Mean HADS-T scores were lower in the intervention group than in the usual treatment group over the 8-month evaluation period (mean difference -1.79 (95% CI -3.32 to -0.33)), indicating better outcomes associated with the START intervention. There was a small improvement in health-related quality of life as measured by QALYs (0.03 (-0.01 to 0.08)). Costs were not different between the intervention and usual treatment groups (£252 (-28 to 565 higher for the START group). Cost-effectiveness calculations show that START has a better chance of being cost-effective compared to usual treatment alone at a payment threshold of €30,000 per QALY earned. demonstrated greater than 99% and a high probability of cost-effectiveness over HADS- Measure T. RESULTS The manual-based coping intervention START, when added to treatment as usual, had both outcome measures (emotional symptoms for family caregivers and caregiver-based QALY' s) was cost-effective compared to usual treatment alone, with reference to TRIAL REGISTRATION ISCTRN 70017938.

title: Cost-effectiveness of strategies to combat neuropsychiatric conditions in sub-Saharan Africa and South East Asia: a mathematical modeling study.
abstract: OBJECTIVE To evaluate the comparative costs and effects of interventions to combat five neuropsychiatric conditions (schizophrenia, bipolar disorder, depression, epilepsy and heavy alcohol use). DESIGN Cost effectiveness analysis based on an epidemiological model. ENVIRONMENT Two epidemiologically defined subregions of the world: countries with very high adult and high child mortality rates in sub-Saharan Africa (AfrE) and countries with high adult and high child mortality rates in Southeast Asia (SearD). DATA SOURCES Published studies , cost databases MAIN OUTCOME MEASURES Cost per capita and cost per disability adjusted life year (DALY) avoided, expressed in international dollars ($Int) for 2005. , cost-effectiveness values differed by two orders of magnitude (for a healthy life year gained Int100-250 to Int10,000-25,000) In both subregions, inpatient treatment of schizophrenia with newer antipsychotic drugs was the most costly and least costly strategy Most cost-effective strategies for population-based alcohol control in the African subregion, while in the South East Asian subregion The most cost-effective intervention in the region was drug treatment of epilepsy in primary care. The cumulative cost per person of the cost-effective intervention set was estimated to be $4.90-5.70. This package includes interventions for epilepsy (former first-line antiepileptic drugs); depression (newer antidepressants and psychosocial therapy generally produced); bipolar disorder (the mood stabilizer drug lithium); schizophrenia (neuroleptic antipsychotic drugs and psychosocial treatment) and heavy alcohol use (increased taxation and enforcement, reduced access and advertising bans in the African subregion and brief advice to heavy drinkers in primary care). Resources for cost-effective intervention strategies will increase health gain, save money, and help expand much-needed services for neuropsychiatric conditions in low-resource settings.

title: Cost-effectiveness of strategies to combat vision and hearing loss in sub-Saharan Africa and South East Asia: a mathematical modeling study
abstract: OBJECTIVE To determine the relative costs, effects, and cost-effectiveness of selected interventions to control cataracts, trachoma, refractive errors, hearing loss, meningitis, and chronic otitis media. DESIGN Cost-effectiveness analysis or combined strategies to control vision and hearing loss through a lifetime population model. DETERMINATION Two World Health Organization subregions of the world where vision and hearing loss are the major burden: Sub-Saharan Africa and South East Asia. DATA SOURCES Biological and behavioral parameters from clinical and observational studies and population-based studies. Intervention effects and resource inputs based on published reports, expert opinion, and the WHO-CHOICE database. MAIN OUTCOME MEASURES Disability adjusted cost per life year (DALY) avoided, expressed in international dollars ($Int) for 2005. CONCLUSIONS Treatment of chronic otitis media, extracapsular cataract surgery, trichiasis surgery, treatment of meningitis, and annual screening of school-aged children for refractive error are among the most cost-effective interventions to control hearing and vision impairment, preventing cost <$Int285 per DALY in both regions. Screening both school-aged children (yearly) and adults (every five years) for hearing loss avoided hearing loss costs of approximately $1,000 per DALY. These interventions can be considered highly cost effective. Mass treatment with azithromycin to control trachoma may be considered cost-effective in Africa, but not in the South East Asian subregion. CONCLUSIONS Vision and hearing impairment control interventions are generally cost-effective. To decide whether substantial investment in these interventions is warranted, this finding must be evaluated in relation to the economic attractiveness of other existing or new interventions in health.

title: Cost-effectiveness of a nurse-based intervention (AIMS) to improve adherence among HIV-infected patients: design of a multicenter randomized controlled trial.
abstract: Background Non-adherence to HIV therapy can have a negative impact on patients' treatment success rates, quality of life, contagiousness, and life expectancy. Several compliance interventions have shown positive effects on compliance and/or virological outcomes. The theory and evidence-based Adherence Improvement Self-Management Strategy (AIMS) is an intervention shown in a randomized controlled trial to improve rates of adherence and viral suppression. However, evidence for cost-effectiveness is lacking. Following a recent review that suggested that cost-effectiveness assessments of compliance interventions for chronic diseases are rare and that the methodology for such assessments is not adequately described in the literature, this article presents the study protocol for a multicenter study evaluating efficacy and cost. -efficacy of AIMS among a heterogeneous patient sample. Methods/design The study uses a multicenter randomized controlled trial design to compare AIMS intervention with usual care from a societal perspective. This RCT includes an empirical and model-based economic assessment. A planned number of 230 HIV-infected patients were randomized to either AIMS or usual care. Relevant outcomes include changes in compliance, plasma viral load, quality of life, and community costs. The time horizon for empirical economic evaluation is 12-15 months. Costs and impacts are estimated over a lifetime horizon for model-based economic assessment. Discussion The current multicenter RCT is designed to provide robust methodological evidence on the effectiveness and cost-effectiveness of a nurse-based counseling intervention (AIMS) to support treatment adherence in a large and heterogeneous sample of HIV-infected patients in the Netherlands. The purpose of the present article is to describe the trial protocol in sufficient detail to allow the quality of the study design to be fully evaluated. If proven to be cost-effective, it is anticipated that AIMS could contribute to improved evidence-based counseling guidelines for HIV nurses and other healthcare professionals.

title: Cost-effectiveness of alternative strategies for the initial medical management of acute coronary syndrome without ST elevation: systematic review and decision-analytical modeling.
abstract: OBJECTIVES: To identify and prioritize key areas of clinical uncertainty regarding the medical management of non-ST elevation acute coronary syndrome (ACS) in current UK practice. DATA SOURCES: Electronic databases. Consultations with clinical consultants. Postal survey of cardiologists. REVIEW METHODS: Potential areas with significant uncertainty were identified and 'decision issues' were prioritized. A systematic literature review was performed using standard methods. The decision model created consisted of a short-term phase applying the results of the systematic review and a long-term phase incorporating relevant information from an observational study in the UK to estimate estimated costs and effects. Sensitivity analyzes were performed to examine the dependence of the results on the main parameters using alternative data sources. The expected value of information analysis is performed to estimate the expected value of perfect information associated with the decision problem. This provided an upper bound on the monetary value associated with additional research in the area. RESULTS: Seven current areas of clinical uncertainty (decision problems) were identified in the drug treatment of patients with unstable angina. The agents involved were clopidogrel, low molecular weight heparin, hirudin, and intravenous glycoprotein antagonists (GPAs). Twelve published clinical guidelines for unstable angina or ACS without ST elevation were identified, but few included recommendations regarding the stated decision problems. The postal survey by clinicians showed that the greatest disagreement is for the use of small molecule GPAs, and the greatest uncertainty exists for decisions regarding the use of abciximab (a large molecule GPA). Overall, decision issues regarding the GPA class of drugs were considered the highest priority for further study. Selected articles describing the clinical efficacy of the treatment were divided into three groups, each representing an alternative strategy. The strategy, which included the use of GPAs as part of the initial medical management of all non-ST-elevation ACS, was the most appropriate choice, with an incremental cost-effectiveness ratio (ICER) of 5738 pounds per quality-adjusted life-year (QALY) by comparison. without using GPAs. Stochastic analysis has shown that if healthcare is willing to pay £10,000 per additional QALY, the probability of this strategy being cost-effective is around 82%, rising to 95% at the £50,000 threshold per QALY. A sensitivity analysis that included an additional strategy of using GPAs as part of initial medical management only in certain high-risk patients (as defined by age, ST depression, or diabetes) showed that this additional strategy was more cost-effective with an ICER. 3996 pounds per QALY compared to no treatment with GPA. The value of information analysis suggested that it is of significant value in additional research to reduce the level of uncertainty in the optimal decision. At a threshold of £10,000 per QALY, the maximum potential value of such research in the baseline was calculated at £12.7 million per year for the UK as a whole. Given the greater uncertainty in sensitivity analyzes, including clopidogrel, this figure has been increased to approximately 50 million pounds. CONCLUSIONS: This study recommends the use of GPAs in all ACS patients without ST elevation as part of their initial medical therapy. Sensitivity analysis showed that almost all benefits could be realized by treating high-risk patients alone. Further clarification of the optimum role of GPAs in the UK NHS depends on the availability of more high-quality observational and trial data. The value of information analysis derived from the model suggests that a relatively large investment in this type of research may be beneficial. Further research should focus on characterizing patients who benefit most from GPAs as part of medical management, comparing GPAs with clopidogrel as an adjunct to standard therapy, and follow-up cohort studies of cost and consequences of high risk. has explored for several years how the decisions of non-ST-elevation ACS and clinicians combine a normative evidence-based decision model with their personal behavioral perspectives.

title: Cost-effectiveness of cognitive-behavioral therapy in addition to pharmacotherapy for treatment-resistant depression in primary care: economic evaluation of the CoBalT Trial.
abstract: BACKGROUND: Treating depression is expensive, but providing ineffective treatment is more expensive. This is the case for many patients who do not respond to antidepressant medications. OBJECTIVES: To evaluate the cost-effectiveness of cognitive-behavioral therapy (CBT) and usual care for primary care patients with treatment-resistant depression compared to usual care alone. METHODS: Economic evaluation at 12 months with a randomized controlled trial. Cost-effectiveness was assessed using a cost-outcome framework that compared cost to the health and social care provider, patients, and community across a range of outcomes. Cost-benefit analysis comparing health and social care costs with quality-adjusted life years (QALYs). RESULTS: The average CBT cost per participant was £910. The difference in QALY gain between the groups was 0.057, which is equivalent to staying healthy 21 days per year. The increased cost-effectiveness ratio was £14 911 (representing 74% probability that the intervention will be cost-effective at the National Institutes for Health and Care Excellence threshold of £20,000 per QALY). Loss of earnings and productivity costs were significant, but there was no evidence of a difference between the intervention and control groups. CONCLUSIONS: Adding CBT to usual care in patients who do not respond to antidepressants is cost-effective. Primary care physicians should therefore be encouraged to refer such individuals to CBT.

title: Cost-effectiveness of guideline-approved treatments for low back pain: a systematic review.
abstract: Healthcare costs for low back pain (LBP) are skyrocketing. Therefore, it is important to provide effective and cost-effective treatments. The purpose of this systematic review was to investigate the cost-effectiveness of guideline-approved treatments for LBP. We searched nine clinical and economic electronic databases and reference lists of relevant systematic reviews and included studies for appropriate studies. Randomized controlled trials investigating LBP treatments approved by the American College of Physicians and the American Pain Society, as well as economic evaluations conducted, were included. Two independent reviewers scanned the search results and extracted the data. The data extracted included the type and perspective of economic evaluation, treatment comparators, and the relative cost-effectiveness of treatment comparators. Twenty-six studies were included. Most studies have found that interdisciplinary rehabilitation, exercise, acupuncture, spinal manipulation, or cognitive-behavioral therapy are cost-effective in people with subacute or chronic LBP. Massage alone was unlikely to be cost-effective. There were inconsistent results on the cost-effectiveness of the recommendations, insufficient evidence on spinal manipulation for people with acute LBP, and no evidence on the cost-effectiveness of medications, yoga, or relaxation. This review found evidence supporting the cost-effectiveness of guideline-approved treatments of interdisciplinary rehabilitation, exercise, acupuncture, spinal manipulation, and cognitive-behavioral therapy for subacute or chronic LBP. There is little or inconsistent evidence for other treatments approved in the guideline.

title: Cost-Effectiveness of HIV Pre-exposure Prevention for Injecting Drug Users in the United States
abstract: Background: The overall population health benefits and costs of HIV pre-exposure prophylaxis (PrEP) for injecting drug users (PWID) in the United States are uncertain. Objective: To evaluate the cost-effectiveness and optimal application conditions of PrEP for PWID. Design: Empirically calibrated dynamic partition model. Data Sources: Published literature and expert opinion. Target Population: Adult USA PWID. Time Horizon: 20 years and lifetime. Intervention: PrEP only, frequent scan PrEP (PrEP+screen), and PrEP+ Providing enhanced antiretroviral therapy (ART) for screen-infected individuals (PrEP+screen+ART). All scenarios are evaluated at 25%. Outcome Measures: Infections prevented, deaths avoided, change in HIV prevalence, reduced costs (in 2015 USD), reduced quality-adjusted life years (QALYs), and increased cost-effectiveness rates. Results of the Baseline Analysis: PrEP+screen+ART dominates other strategies by preventing 26700 infections and reducing the HIV prevalence among EYKs by 14% compared to the status quo. Receiving these benefits is $253 000 per QALY earned. At current drug prices, total expenditures for PrEP+screen+ART could be up to $44 billion over 20 years. Results of Sensitivity Analysis: The cost-effectiveness of the intervention is linear in the annual cost of PrEP and depends on PrEP drug adherence. , risks of individual transmission, and HIV prevalence in the community. Limitation: Data on risk stratification and attainable PrEP efficacy levels for the US EYP are limited. Conclusion: PrEP, which includes frequent screening and prompt treatment for those infected, can reduce the HIV burden among PMUs and provide health benefits for the US population benefits for all, but remains an expensive intervention at current drug prices, both in absolute terms and in terms of cost per QALY earned.

title: Cost-Effectiveness of Practice-Initiated Quality Improvement for Depression
abstract: Context Depression is the leading cause of disability worldwide, but cure rates in primary care are low. Purpose To determine the cost-effectiveness of 2 quality improvement (QI) interventions to improve depression treatment in primary care from a societal perspective and their impact on patient employment. Randomized controlled trial conducted at Design Group level between June 1996 and July 1999. Establishes forty-six primary care clinics in 6 community-based managed care organizations. Participants One hundred and eighty-one primary care clinicians and 1356 patients with positive screening results for current depression. Interventions Matched practices were randomly assigned to 1 of 2 QI interventions to provide routine care (n = 443 patients) or to provide training to practice leaders and nurses, advanced education and assessment resources, and nurses for medication follow-up (QI-meds). patient) or trained local psychotherapists (QI-therapy; n = 489) Practices can flexibly implement interventions that do not determine treatment type Key Outcome Measures Total health care costs, quality-adjusted costs per life-year (QALY), days with depression burden and more than 24 months of employment compared between usual care and 2 interventions Compared to usual care, average healthcare costs for QI-meds increased by $419 (11%) (P = .35 ) and $485 (13%) for QI treatment (P = .28); estimated costs per QALY earned were between $15,331 and $36,467 for QI drugs and $9478 to $21,478 for QI treatment;" and patients with depression burden had 25 (P = .19) and 47 (P = .01) fewer days and were employed 17.9 (P = .07) and 20.9 (P = .03) more days during the study period. Results The societal cost-effectiveness of practice-initiated QI efforts for depression is comparable to that of accepted medical interventions. Intervention effects on employment may be of particular interest to employers and other stakeholders.

title: Costs associated with implementing a computer-assisted clinical decision support system for antenatal and maternity care: a case study of Kassena-Nankana region of northern Ghana.
abstract: OBJECTIVE: This study analyzed the cost of implementing a computer-assisted Clinical Decision Support System (CDSS) in selected healthcare centers in Ghana. METHODS: A descriptive cross-sectional study was conducted in the Kassena-Nankana region (KND). CDSS was deployed in selected health centers in the CND as an intervention to manage patients attending antenatal clinics and maternity wards. CDSS users were mostly trained nurses. The activities and associated costs involved in implementing the CDSS (pre-intervention and response) were collected for the period 2009-2013 from the provider perspective. The components approach was used for cost analysis. Costs are grouped into personnel, training, overheads (recurring costs) and equipment costs (capital costs). We calculated the cost by annualizing the cost of capital to represent the financial cost and annualizing the cost of capital to represent the economic cost. RESULTS: Twenty-two trained CDSS users (at least 2 users per health center) participated in the study. Between April 2012 and March 2013, users managed 5,595 antenatal patients and 872 maternity worker clients using CDSS. We observed a reduction in the rate of complications during childbirth (10.74% pre-intervention vs. 9.64% post-intervention) and a reduction in the number of maternal deaths (4 pre-intervention deaths vs. 1 post-intervention death). The overall financial cost of implementing CDSS was US$23,316, approximately US$1,060 per trained CDSS user. 48% (US$11,272) of the total implementation cost was pre-intervention cost and 52% (US$12,044) of the intervention cost. Equipment costs account for the largest portion of the financial cost: 34% (US$7,917). Considering the economic cost, the total implementation cost is US$17,128, which is 26.5% lower than the financial cost. CONCLUSIONS: The study provides useful information in the implementation of CDSS in healthcare settings to increase healthcare professionals' adherence to practice guidelines and to make sound decisions to improve maternal health care.

title: Can clinical surveillance improve the diagnosis of pulmonary tuberculosis in Cuba, Peru and Bolivia?
abstract: OBJECTIVES: To evaluate the effectiveness of clinical surveillance in improving the quality of diagnostic care provided to patients with suspected tuberculosis";" and understanding the contextual factors that hinder or facilitate its success. METHODS: Twenty-six health centers in Cuba, Peru and Bolivia were recruited. Clinical supervision was initiated to improve diagnostic care for patients presenting with suspected TB. The standards were based on WHO and TB program guidelines on the appropriate use of microscopy, culture and radiological investigations. At least two audit cycles have been completed in 2 years. Improvement was determined by comparing performance between the two six-month periods before and after the intervention. Qualitative methods were used to identify the factors that facilitate and limit the contextual factors that affect the change in the clinical behavior of health professionals after the start of the clinical audit. RESULTS: We found significant improvement in 11 out of 13 criteria in Cuba, 2 out of 6 criteria in Bolivia, and 2 out of 5 criteria in Peru. Of the 24 inspection criteria in all three countries, 12 met the agreed standards. Barriers to quality improvement included conflicting goals for clinicians and TB programs, poor coordination within the health system, and patients' attitudes towards disease. CONCLUSIONS: Clinical supervision can provide improvements in the quality of clinical care in resource-poor settings. It is likely to be more effective if integrated and supported with native TB programs. We recommend that you develop and evaluate an integrated quality improvement model, including clinical audit.

title: Counseling African Americans to Control Hypertension (CAATCH) trial: a multi-level intervention to improve blood pressure control in hypertensive blacks.
abstract: Despite strong evidence of effective interventions targeting blood pressure (BP) control, there is little evidence to translate these approaches into routine clinical practice in the care of hypertensive blacks. The aim of this study was to evaluate the efficacy of a multilevel, multicomponent, evidence-based intervention compared with usual care in improving BP control among hypertensive blacks receiving care in community health centers. Primary outcomes are BP control rate at 12 months and maintenance of intervention 1 year after trial. Secondary outcomes are within-patient change in BP from baseline to 12 months and the cost-effectiveness of the intervention. Counseling African Americans to Control Hypertension (CAATCH) is a randomized clinical trial with 2 conditions: intervention condition and usual care. Thirty community health centers were randomly assigned to either the intervention condition group (n=15) or the usual care group (n=15). The intervention consists of 3 components targeting patients (interactive computerized hypertension education, monthly behavioral counseling on home blood pressure monitoring and lifestyle change) and 2 components targeting physicians (monthly case tours based on the Joint National Committee for Prevention, Detection, Evaluation and Treatment). High Blood Pressure guidelines, chart control and providing feedback on clinical performance and patients' home BP readings). All results are evaluated at quarterly study visits for 1 year. A chart review is conducted every 24 months to assess the maintenance of the intervention effects and the sustainability of the response. Poor BP control is one of the main causes of the death gap between blacks and whites. The findings from this study, if successful, will provide the salient information needed to translate and expand evidence-based interventions targeting BP control for this high-risk population into clinical practice.

title: Counseling African Americans to Control Hypertension: cluster randomized clinical trial main effects
abstract: BACKGROUND: Data on the implementation of evidence-based multilevel interventions targeting blood pressure (BP) control in hypertensive blacks receiving care in low-resource primary care settings are limited. METHODS AND RESULTS: Counseling African Americans to Control Hypertension was a cluster randomized clinical trial in which 30 community health centers were randomly assigned to either the intervention condition (IC) or usual care (UC). Patients at IC centers received patient education, home BP monitoring, and monthly lifestyle counseling, while physicians participated in monthly hypertension case tours and received feedback on their patients' home BP readings and chart audits. Printed patient education material and hypertension treatment guidelines were provided to patients and physicians at UC sites, respectively. The primary outcome was BP control, and secondary outcomes were the mean changes in systolic and diastolic BP at 12 months evaluated with the automated BP device. A total of 1059 patients (mean age, 56 years”; 28% male, 59% obese and 36% with diabetes mellitus) were enrolled. The BP control ratio was similar in both groups (IC=49.3% vs UC=44.5%). ; Odds ratio, 1.21 [95% confidence interval, 0.90–1.63]; P=0.21 In prespecified subgroup analyzes, intervention was associated with greater BP control in patients without diabetes mellitus (IC=54.0% vs. UC=44.7%; odds ratio). , 1.45 [confidence interval, 1.02-2.06]) and small-scale community health centers (IC=51.1% vs. UC=39.6;" odds ratio, 1.45 [confidence interval, 1, 04-2.45]). CONCLUSIONS: A practice-based, multi-component intervention was no better than UC at improving BP control among hypertensive blacks. Future research on the application of behavioral modification strategies for hypertension control in low-resource settings should focus on the development of more efficient and tailored interventions in this high-risk population. CLINICAL TRIAL REGISTRATION URL: http://www.clinicaltrials.gov. Unique identifier: NCT00233220.

title: Building a sustainable, professional inter-team training program: preliminary results
abstract: OBJECTIVES/OBJECTIVES: The purpose of this program evaluation was to explore whether the incorporation of intentional learning concepts through the use of simulated patient scenarios to teach interprofessional collaboration skills to a healthcare team in an acute care hospital unit would improve hospital resuscitation response. the first 5 minutes on that unit. DESIGN/SETUP: This was a pilot program evaluation using a unit-based, clinical nurse practitioner in the implementation of an interprofessional training program involving simulation in the acute medical setting in a large tertiary care hospital. EXAMPLE: Eighty-four personnel participated in 17 simulations. The sample included first-year internists, registered nurses, respiratory therapists, and patient care technicians. METHODS: This was a program evaluation using the TeamSTEPPS Perceptions of Teamwork Questionnaire (T-TPQ) (Classroom slides: TeamSTEPPS fundamentals"; http://www.ahrq.gov/professionals/education/curriculum-tools/teamstepps/instructo r/ Essentials /slessentials.html#s3) to assess participants' perceptions of teamwork during pre-simulation/postsimulation sessions. Expected intervention behaviors were collected through observations of participants in simulations and compared with American Heart Association guidelines (Circulation 2010;122:S685 -S670, S235-S337). RESULTS: Fifty-three participants completed their average scores in the leadership category of T-PS before and after T-TPQ From TPQ pretest (median, 2.167) to T-TPQ posttest (median, 2.566) decreased significantly (P = .003) Only 35% of defibrillated groups during ventricular fibrillation simulation scenario This, and only 1 group, delivered this shock within the American Heart Association recommended 2 minute timeframe (Circulation 2010;"122:S235-S337). CONCLUSION: A single resuscitation simulation was not a sufficient dose of intervention for staff to improve the resuscitation process. After staff repeats the program many times, a longitudinal study should be conducted to determine the effectiveness of the program. APPLICATIONS: A unit-based quality improvement simulation training program can help improve staff first 5-minute response and resuscitation skills by increasing the frequency of unit-based training overseen by the unit's clinical nurse specialist.

title: Creating ICU spaces for safe communication: a video reflex ethnographic study
abstract: Background The built environment in acute care settings is a new focus in patient safety research, with few studies focusing primarily on the design of ward environments and the location and selection of material objects such as lighting fixtures and handwash sinks. Methods We report an intrusive video-reflective ethnographic (VRE) study investigating how clinicians use the built environment to provide safe communication in the intensive care unit (ICU) of a metropolitan Sydney hospital. We conducted 40 semi-structured interviews, 5-week observations and four reflective focus groups with a total of 87 participants (including medical, nursing, allied health and office staff). Results We found that the accessibility of staff and patients in the open spaces of the ICU is both a safety feature and a security risk, that secure communication flow is possible and also allows for potentially unsafe interruptions. Staff managed outages by creating temporary protected areas, using physical cues such as curtains, tapes and signs, as well as behavioral cues, movement, and the development of policies that restrict activity in certain areas while maintaining a safe degree of accessibility. In addition, clinicians were able to use the VRE method to gain insight into their practice and problems and develop meaningful solutions for other problem areas. Results Intensive care personnel provide secure communication in their wards by creating both 'attached' and 'protected' temporary spaces. The flexibility of these "soft" strategies is particularly well suited to the fast-paced clinical context of intensive care.

title: Crisis response: The person-to-person emergency handbook., 4th ed.
abstract: It provides a framework for providing immediate problem-solving assistance to people in crisis. As a handbook, it offers basic information as well as methods adapted to specific conditions. The book is designed for caregivers whose work includes regular or occasional crisis response efforts. The techniques are argued to be applicable in crisis centres, hotlines, Internet-based services, victim assistance programs, college counseling centres, hospitals, schools, prisons, children's and youth programs, and other social work agencies. Users of the concepts include counselors, social workers, psychologists, nurses, doctors, clergy, prison officers, probation and probation officers, and lay volunteers. Each chapter ends with study questions. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2016 APA, all rights reserved)

title: Addressing the influence of antenatal providers on discussions of intimate partner violence
abstract: BACKGROUND: Intimate partner violence (IPV) during pregnancy poses a significant health risk to the mother and developing fetus. Practice guidelines recommend that antenatal providers screen and counsel their patients for IPV, but many doctors express reluctance or discomfort with such discussions. The Health in Pregnancy (HIP) computer program is designed to enhance the counseling of prenatal care providers on behavioral risks. METHODS: English-speaking women aged 18 years or older, less than 26 weeks pregnant, and receiving prenatal care at one of five San Francisco-area clinics were randomized into parallel groups in a controlled study (data from June 2006 to present “ ;” analyzed June 2007). Participants reporting one or more risks were randomized to intervention or control in stratified blocks. Providers received summary "signal sheets" warning their patients of the risk(s) and recommending counseling statements. RESULTS: Thirteen percent (37/286) of the sample reported present IPV. Provider cue resulted in 85% of the IPV-intervention group reporting meetings with their provider, compared to 23.5% of the control group (p<0.001). CONCLUSIONS: IPV discussions were strongly influenced by cue providers. The provider tip is an effective and convenient addition to routine risk counseling in antenatal care.

title: Cultivating a culture of learning in general practice: an educational intervention
abstract: BACKGROUND: Increasing challenges are faced in primary care, including the rise in chronic diseases and their management in the community. This document describes an educational initiative developed to help local general practitioners (GPs) and primary care teams manage chronic conditions and address referral behavior. The aim of this study is to evaluate the initiative through research of the experiences of the participants and providers. METHODS: Various methods were used to collect data for evaluation. These included feedback from participants in the form of workshop evaluation questionnaires, semi-structured interviews from both participants and presenters, and focus groups with participants. RESULTS: After the analysis of the data, five themes were identified in all the methods used. This article focuses on the main themes of 'practice change' and 'referral behavior' as they relate to the specific aims and objectives of the initiative. The data showed that participants identified actual changes in practice, including changes in individual practice and prescribing behavior, as well as in community health care delivery, following their participation in the educational initiative. The changes identified in referral behavior were evident in feedback from both participants and presenters in the secondary care. Participants noted proposed changes, including an expected reduction in dermatology referrals with better management of the conditions in primary care, and greater awareness of the indications for early referral. The use of guidelines was identified to aid referral decisions, and the content and information requested from referral letters was also an important area. CONCLUSION: Evaluation of this educational initiative identified changes in practice in primary care and shows how educational interventions can support and enhance future developments in primary care.

title: Culturally adapted interventions for chronic diseases targeting Korean Americans: a systematic review.
abstract: OBJECTIVE: Because little is known about promising interventions to prevent and control chronic diseases in Korean Americans, we conducted a systematic literature review to explore: (1) theoretical frameworks and strategies used in interventions targeting Korean Americans"; (2) these interventions; " and (3) the extent of their success in engaging Korean participants and improving their health. DESIGN: PubMed, PsycInfo, and Web of Science were searched to identify primary research articles that evaluated interventions to prevent or control chronic disease, tailored to Korean Americans and published from 1980 to 2011, following PRISMA guidelines. Of the 238 articles identified, the 16 unique intervention tests describing 21 articles met the inclusion criteria. These interventions targeted cancer (10), hypertension (2), diabetes (1), mental health (1), quitting tobacco (1), and general health (1). CONCLUSIONS: All included studies have been published since 2000 and reflect the relatively recent establishment of intervention research with Korean Americans. All 16 programs delivered linguistically appropriate messages and training. The 11 programs that achieved significant intervention effects provided or coordinated social support from culturally relevant and well-trained health workers, nurses, or family members during an intervention and/or follow-up period. CONCLUSIONS: Culturally compatible and linguistically appropriate messages and education may not be sufficient to prevent or control chronic diseases among immigrant Korean Americans. Culturally sensitive and committed social support must be provided to accelerate behavioral changes and maintain the effectiveness of interventions.

title: Current management of transitional feeding problems in preterm neonates born in Queensland, Australia.
abstract: BACKGROUND: Many premature newborns have difficulty establishing suckling-feeding proficiency in the weeks following birth. Ineffective management of transitional nutritional problems may result in patient complications and contribute to prolonged hospital stay. OBJECTIVES: Given that many neonatal hospices differ in their neonatal nutrition management practices, the purpose of this study was to explore and document the level of routine support and intervention currently provided for preterm neonates with transitional feeding problems across various level II (special) care) nurseries (SCNs) in Queensland, Australia. METHODS: A questionnaire was sent to all Queensland SCNs (n=36) in 2005. The questionnaire included a series of closed-choice and short-answer questions designed to gain insight into current practices for managing transitional feeding problems in preterm neonates from each SCN. Results were confirmed during a follow-up phone interview. RESULTS: Responses were obtained from 29 SCNs (80.6%). None of these nurseries reported having any formal, written policy regarding the management of transitional feeding problems in preterm neonates. Wide variations have been reported regarding the suction-feeding assessments and interventions used by staff at the various SCNs. Of the 29 nurseries, 4 (13.8%) reported using checklists or assessments to assess readiness to suckle, and 5 (17.2%) reported using pulse oximetry to assess tolerance of sucking attempts. Eighteen SCNs (62.1%) reported offering some form of active intervention to assist newborns with transitional feeding problems; The most common intervention techniques were reported as non-nutritive sucking during tube feeding, pre-feeding oral stimulation, and active step-by-step sucking feedings. Twenty-two SCNs (75.4%) reported having access to a lactation consultant to assist mothers with breastfeeding problems. CONCLUSIONS: Differences have been reported in the routine management of transitional feeding problems in preterm neonates at various Queensland SCNs. It is suggested that evidence-based guidelines need to be developed, and to do this, more research work is needed to identify current best practice and answer the remaining questions.

title: Current models and future directions in the treatment of insomnia
abstract: BACKGROUND: Despite the high prevalence and high burden associated with chronic insomnia, it is largely unrecognized and often undertreated by physicians. METHODS: The literature on recent trials of pharmacological and non-pharmacological agents for insomnia, as well as barriers to both acute and chronic treatment of insomnia, is reviewed. CONCLUSIONS: Barriers to appropriate treatment of the condition include the US Food and Drug Administration's outdated insomnia management guidelines that contribute to restrictions on longer prescribing of hypnotic agents"; lack of research demonstrating the benefit of treating insomnia; and tolerance and tolerance of long-term use of hypnotic agents. Fears of lack of longer-term, randomized, controlled, double-blind trials of available agents used to treat insomnia as well as withdrawal effects CONCLUSIONS: There is evidence that improved sleep can improve outcome in some medical and psychiatric disorders Both behavioral and pharmacological treatments in chronic insomnia In addition, a recent 6-month, randomized, controlled trial has shown that at least one agent may be safe and effective with longer-term use.

title: Restricting lab test ordering in a managed care environment through a computerized order form redesign
abstract: OBJECTIVE: To increase the appropriate use of blood tests for folic acid and vitamin B12 required by primary care physicians in an Israeli managed care facility through a computerized redesign of the order form. STUDY DESIGN: Pre-intervention. METHODS: The new version of the computerized order form is available. Usage patterns were calculated for the previously grouped vitamin B12, folic acid and ferritin tests. Patterns of concomitant use for hemoglobin and iron tests were considered as controls. RESULTS: Tests ordered for 3 targets decreased from 31% to 41% in the month before the intervention, and from 36% to 53% in the following month. Negligible changes in usage patterns were observed in controls (-2% to 3%) in the post-intervention period. CONCLUSIONS: A simple reconfiguration of a computerized order form significantly reduced the number of laboratory tests that were unnecessary or suspected to be unnecessary. When excessive use of laboratory resources is suspected, managers should evaluate the efficiency of the organization's current ordering procedures before implementing resource-intensive interventions.

title: Cutaneous malignant lymphomas: 2006 update
abstract: Cutaneous lymphomas represent a unique group of lymphomas and are the second most common extranodal lymphoma. As with other neoplasms, the pathogenesis is mainly based on the gradual accumulation of mutations of suppressor genes and oncogenes caused by genetic, environmental or infectious factors. Diagnostic work includes clinical, histological, imaging, and hematological studies, and in many cases, immunohistochemical and molecular biological analysis. The current WHO/EORTC classification of cutaneous lymphomas distinguishes "mature T-cell and NK-cell lymphomas", "mature B-cell lymphomas" and "immature hematopoietic malignancies", their variants and subgroups. It complies with the WHO classification for hematopoietic and lymphoid tissue neoplasms and respects the organ-specific characteristics of primary cutaneous lymphomas. The assignment of the various types of cutaneous lymphomas to prognostic categories (pre-lymphomatous "abortive" disorders"; definitive malignant lymphomas of low-grade malignancy; "definite malignant lymphomas of high-grade malignancy) provides and permits basic information on biological behavior. Appropriate planning of topical or systemic and aggressive or non-aggressive therapeutic strategy. Besides the classical treatment options, there are new and "experimental" strategies whose efficacy needs to be investigated in clinical trials.

title: Daily co-trimoxazole prophylaxis in severely immunocompromised HIV-infected adults in Africa initiated on combination antiretroviral therapy: an observational analysis of the DART cohort.
abstract: Background Co-trimoxazole prophylaxis may reduce mortality from untreated HIV infection in Africa"; it is unclear whether benefits occur alongside combination antiretroviral therapy (ART). We estimated the effect of prophylaxis after initiation of ART in adults. HIV infection in Africa;" It is unclear whether benefits occur alongside combination antiretroviral therapy (ART). We estimated the effect of prophylaxis after initiation of ART in adults.

title: Decision aid for patients considering total knee arthroplasty with preference report for surgeons: a pilot randomized controlled trial
abstract: BACKGROUND: A preference report for surgeons to evaluate the feasibility and potential efficacy of patient decision assistance (PtDA) for patients and to reduce waiting times and improve decision quality when considering total knee replacement in patients with osteoarthritis. METHODS: A prospective two-arm pilot randomized controlled trial. Patients with osteoarthritis were eligible if they understood English and were referred for surgical consultation about the first total knee arthroplasty at a Canadian orthopedic joint evaluation clinic. Patients were randomized to PtDA intervention or usual training. The intervention was an osteoarthritis PtDA for patients and a one-page preference report for their surgeons outlining patients' clinical and decision data. The main feasibility outcomes were recruitment and survey completion rates"; preliminary efficacy results were wait times and decision quality. RESULTS: Of 180 patients eligible for surgical consultation, 142 (79%) were recruited and randomized to PtDA intervention (n = 71) or normal. education (n = 71) Data collection yielded a 93% questionnaire completion rate with less than 1% missing items. After one year 13% of patients remained on the surgical waiting list out of the waiting list (censored using survival analysis techniques ) were 33.4 weeks (n = 69, 95% CI: 26.0, 41.4) for the PtDA group and 33.0 weeks for usual training (n = 71, 95% CI: 26.1, 39.9). Patients exposed to PtDA were informed As a result, it had higher decision quality (71% vs. 47%; p <0.0001) and that the quality decision was an informed choice that was consistent with option outcomes values (56.4% vs. 25.0%; p < 0.001). CONCLUSIONS: Recruitment of patients with osteoarthritis was possible considering surgery and data collection. Follow-up should be increased to two years, as some patients remain on the surgical waiting list after one year. Patients exposed to PtDA achieved higher decision quality compared to those with normal training, but there was no difference in waiting for surgery. TRIAL REGISTRATION: ClinicalTrials.Gov NCT00743951.

title: Decision making in the surgical management of chronic low back pain: performance of prognostic tests to select patients for lumbar spinal fusion.
abstract: Chronic low back pain (CLBP) is one of the main causes of disability in the western world, which places a huge economic burden on society. A specific underlying anatomical cause for CLBP has not yet been identified. Imaging usually reveals degenerative signs of one or more lumbar motion segments, disc or facet joints. However, these findings can also be seen in asymptomatic individuals. It has been suggested that pain in degenerated discs may result from the growth of nerve fibers into tears or clefts of the annulus fibrosus or nucleus pulposus, and from reported high levels of proinflammatory mediators. Since this so-called discogenic pain is often exacerbated by mechanical loading, the concept of relieving pain with spinal fusion was developed to stabilize a painful spinal segment. Lumbar spinal fusion is indeed beneficial for some patients, but outcomes are highly variable and difficult to predict for the individual patient. To identify CLBP patients who would benefit from fusion, many surgeons rely on tests that are supposed to predict the outcome of spinal fusion. The three most commonly used prognostic tests in daily practice are lumbosacral orthosis immobilization, provocative discography, and trial immobilization with temporary external transpedicular fixation. Knowing the role and value of these prognostic tests for CLBP patients in clinical practice is essential in targeting consensus on indications for lumbar fusion and improving patient selection and outcomes. The overall objectives of this thesis were: 1) to evaluate whether there is consensus among spine surgeons on the use and evaluation of prognostic tests for lumbar spinal fusion"; 2) to confirm whether a thoracolumbosacral orthosis (TLSO) actually minimizes lumbosacral motion; 3) a TLSO To confirm whether CLBP can predict the clinical outcome of fusion for CLBP; 4) to evaluate whether provocative discography of adjacent segments does indeed predict long-term clinical outcome fusion; 5) there is a need for routine antibiotic prophylaxis to determine the incidence and occurrence of discitis after discography; 6) transient to evaluate whether external transpedicular fixation (TETF) would help predict the outcome of spinal fusion; 7) To determine the prognostic accuracy of the tests most commonly used in clinical practice to predict the outcome of fusion for CLBP. The results of a national survey among spine surgeons in the Netherlands are presented in Study I. Surgeons were asked about their views on prognostic factors and the use of predictive tests for lumbar fusion in CLBP patients. Interpretations were compared with findings from the current literature. The survey revealed a significant lack of uniformity in the use and evaluation of predictive tests. Prognostic factors known from the literature have also not been consistently included in the decision-making processes of surgeons. This heterogeneity in strategy is most likely due to the lack of solid scientific evidence for available predictive tests, and it has been concluded that there is currently insufficient consensus among Dutch spine surgeons to establish national guidelines for surgical decision-making in CLBP. In Study II, the putative working mechanism of a pantaloon pattern (ie, minimization of lumbosacral joint mobility) was examined. In patients admitted for a temporary external transpedicular fixation test (TETF), infrared light markers were rigidly affixed to the protruding ends of Steinman pins fixed at the two spinal level. In this way, the three-dimensional motion between these levels can be analyzed opto-electronically. During dynamic test conditions such as walking, a cast with or without unilateral hip fixation did not significantly reduce lumbosacral joint motion. Although not proven with solid scientific support, lumbosacral orthoses or pantaloon molds are often used in daily practice as an indicator of the result of fusion. A systematic review of the literature, supplemented by a prospective cohort study, was performed to assess the value of the pantaloon pattern in surgical decision making (Study III). It turned out that only in CLBP patients who had not had prior spinal surgery, a pantaloon cast test that significantly reduced pain revealed a positive outcome of lumbar fusion compared to conservative treatment. The test is of no value in patients who have had previous spinal surgery. It is believed by many spine surgeons that provocative discography, unlike plain radiographs or magnetic resonance imaging, is a physiological test that can truly determine whether a disc is painful and whether it is related to the patient's pain syndrome, regardless of disc morphology. It has been suggested that in order to achieve a successful clinical outcome of lumbar fusion, suspected discs should be painful and adjacent control discs should not cause pain in provocative discography. Therefore, a cohort of patients for whom the decision to perform a lumbar fusion was based on the external fixation (TETF) study was retrospectively analyzed in Study IV. Only the preoperative discography results of the levels adjacent to the fusion were compared with the clinical results after spinal fusion. In this selected group of patients, the discographic status of discs adjacent to the lumbar fusion appeared to have no effect on clinical outcome. The most feared complication of lumbar discography is discitis.
