Although its incidence is low, it is a serious complication for a diagnostic procedure and prevention with the use of prophylactic antibiotics is advocated. When searching clinical guidelines, the risk of discitis after discography was assessed in Study V through a systematic literature review and a cohort of 200 consecutive patients. In the absence of prophylactic antibiotics, the overall incidence of discitis after discography was 0.25%. To prove that antibiotics will actually prevent discitis, a randomized trial of 9,000 patients will be needed to reach significance. Considering the possible side effects of antibiotics, it was concluded that the routine use of prophylactic antibiotics in lumbar discography is not indicated. In Study VI, the medium- and long-term outcomes of external fixation (TETF) as a test for predicting the clinical outcome of lumbar fusion were examined in a group of back pain patients with doubts about the indication for surgery. The test included a placebo trial in which patients were unaware of whether the lumbar segmental levels were stable or dynamic. Using strict and objective pain reduction criteria on a visual analog scale, the TETF test failed to predict the clinical outcome of fusion in this selected group of patients. Pin tract infection and nerve root irritation have been noted as complications of this invasive test. It was concluded that TETF is not recommended as a complementary tool in surgical decision making in patients with chronic low back pain whose fusion indication is doubtful. In Study VII, a systematic literature review was conducted regarding the prognostic accuracy of tests currently used in clinical practice that are presumed to predict the outcome of lumbar spinal fusion for CLBP. Tests of interest were magnetic resonance imaging (MRI), TLSO immobilization, TETF, provocative discography, and facet joint infiltration. Only 10 studies can be selected that report on three different index tests (discography, TLSO immobilization, and TETF) that actually report on test qualifiers such as sensitivity, specificity, and likelihood ratios. The accuracy of all prognostic tests appeared to be low; this confirmed that in many clinical applications patients are programmed for fusion based on tests with poor accuracy or unknown at best. As the overall methodological quality of the included studies was low, higher quality studies would be needed that would include patients who tested positive for fusion as well as patients who tested negative. It was concluded that the best evidence at this time does not support the use of any prognostic test in clinical practice. No patient group with low back pain for whom spinal fusion was a safe and effective treatment could be identified. There are many studies in the literature reporting that cognitive behavioral therapy or intensive exercise programs have similar treatment outcomes to spinal fusion, but with significantly less complications, morbidity, and cost. These tests should not be recommended for surgical decision making in standard care, as the findings of the current thesis show that currently used tests do not improve fusion outcomes with better patient selection. Also, spinal fusion should not be recommended as a standard treatment for chronic low back pain. The causation of non-specific spinal pain is complex and CLBP should not be viewed as a diagnosis but as a symptom in patients with different stages of impairment and disability. Patients should be evaluated in a multidisciplinary setting or Spine Center according to the biopsychosocial model, which aims to identify underlying psychosocial factors as well as biological factors. Treatment should be carried out gradually, starting with the least invasive treatment. The current approach of CLBP with an emphasis on self-management and empowerment is recommended so that patients receive an active course of treatment to prevent long-term disability and chronicity.

title: Declaration of Helsinki
abstract: Recommendations to guide physicians in biomedical research involving human subjects.

title: Decree announcing the Medical Ethics Rules dated 17 May 1993 and numbered 93-1155.
Default options in the ICU: widely used but poorly understood
abstract: Purpose of review Default options significantly influence the behavior of decision makers and can serve as effective decision support tools in the ICU. Their use in medicine has increased in order to increase efficiency, reduce errors and take advantage of the potential of health technology. Recent findings Defaults often lag behind predicted effects when used in intensive care settings as quality improvement interventions. Studies reporting the use of defaults are often limited to variations in relative impact between sites. Pre-application experiments and long-term follow-up studies are lacking. Summary ICU defaults can either help or harm patients and clinical efficiency, depending on their form and use. When creating and encountering defaults, providers should be aware of their powerful and complex impact on decision making. Additional considerations are needed on the appropriate establishment of healthcare defaults and their intended and unintended consequences. Keywords: behavioral economics, choice behavior, communication, intensive care, decision making

title: The default settings of the computerized doctor order entry system determine ordering habits.
abstract: Background: Computerized physician order entry (CPOE) systems are rapidly ubiquitous, and order groups ("order sets") that allow easy order entry are a common feature. This provides a streamlined mechanism for viewing, modifying and placing related order groups. This often serves as the electronic equivalent of a request for expertise. A feature of these order sets is that certain orders can be preset as "preselected" or "open by default" each time the order set is used, while others are "optional" or "closed by default". usually the option is to “deselect” tests that are set as default in a particular case. While it may seem intuitive that defaults in an order set are generally accepted, additional work is required to understand the impact of these "default" settings in an order set on ordering habits. This study set out to measure the effect of changing the default settings of an order set. Methods: For the purpose of quality improvement, order sets for transfusions were recently reviewed and modified to improve outcome tracking. Initially, the default setting for post-transfusion hematocrit and platelet count rankings was changed from "optional" to "preselected". The default settings for the platelet count were then changed back to "optional", allowing a natural experiment. Examine the impact of default choices of an order set on clinician ordering habits. Results: Post-transfusion hematocrit values were ordered for 8.3% of red cell transfusions when the default order set selection was "off" and 57.4% of transfusions when the default order set selection was "preselected" (P < 0.0001). Post-transfusion platelet count was ordered for 7.0% of platelet transfusions when the initial default order set selection was “optional”, increased to 59.4% when the default was changed to “preselected” (P < 0.0001), and then Reduced to 7.5. %. when the default selection is returned as "optional". Post-transfusion platelet count rates during the two 'on-demand' periods: 7.0% versus 7.5% - were not statistically different (P = 0.620). Discussion: The default settings in CPOE order sets can significantly affect the physician's choice of laboratory tests. All stakeholders, including clinicians and pathologists, should be carefully considered when creating default settings for order sets.

title: Defensive Medicine Among High-Risk Specialists in a Volatile Malpractice Environment
abstract: Context How often physicians change their clinical behavior due to the threat of malpractice liability, so-called defensive medicine, and the consequences of these changes are central questions in the ongoing debate on medical malpractice reform. Purpose To examine the prevalence and characteristics of defensive medicine among physicians working in high-responsibility specialties during a period of significant instability in the malpractice environment. Design, Environment, and Participants Mail survey of physicians in 6 specialties (emergency medicine, general surgery, orthopedic surgery, neurosurgery, obstetrics/gynecology, and radiology) at high risk of litigation in Pennsylvania in May 2003. Key Outcome Measures defensive medicine or any specialty that reports changes in scope of practice and characteristics of defensive medicine (assurance and avoidance behaviour). Results A total of 824 physicians (65%) completed the survey. Almost all (93%) reported using defensive medicine. “Assurance behavior” such as ordering tests, performing diagnostic procedures, and referring patients for consultation was very common (92%). Among defensive medicine practitioners who detail their most recent defensive actions, 43% reported using imaging technology in clinically unnecessary situations. Avoidance of procedures and patients thought to increase the likelihood of litigation was also common. Forty-two percent of respondents reported that they had taken steps to restrict their practice in the past 3 years, including eliminating procedures prone to complications such as trauma surgery and avoiding patients with complex medical problems or perceived as defendants. Advocacy practices were strongly associated with respondents' lack of confidence in their liability insurance and the perceived burden of insurance premiums. Conclusion Defensive medicine is prevalent among physicians in Pennsylvania who pay the most for liability insurance, with potentially serious implications for cost, access, and quality of care, both technical and interpersonal.

title: Defining optimal therapy with cholinesterase inhibitors in Alzheimer's disease
abstract: Despite a growing understanding that Alzheimer's disease (AD) represents a global public health and social care crisis, diagnosis is often slow and many patients still receive no treatment at all. Most of those treated stay below the recommended doses. The International Global Declaration on Alzheimer's Disease promotes awareness and understanding of AD by emphasizing the importance of optimal treatment. However, the definition of "optimal treatment" is vague. Since cholinesterase inhibitors became available nearly 20 years ago, clinicians have developed various protocols based on clinical experience. This review considers what is optimal for various aspects of cholinesterase inhibitor therapy, taking into account initiation strategies, dosages, modes of administration (eg, oral and transdermal), and duration of treatment. Regardless of the management approach, individuals with AD, their families and caregivers have the right to timely diagnosis and access to the best available treatment.

title: Good childcare delivery: a look through the door
abstract: OBJECTIVE: To describe the delivery of good childcare and its components", to compare this presentation with recommendations from Bright Futures and to compare good childcare provision for children with special health care needs with that for non-special needs children. METHODS: During a 10-week period, 2 medical students observed and documented characteristics of good childcare visits by general pediatricians and intermediate pediatric providers. Parents completed a demographic questionnaire and a screening device for children with special health care needs. RESULTS: 43 pediatricians and 9 pediatricians with a total of patients aged 0 to 19 years. 483 visits were observed by the intermediate provider.The adjusted average visit time was 20.3 minutes and 38.9% of visits started with an open-ended question about parent/child concerns 7.2 health checkup/expected guidance issues were covered per visit. addressed 42% - recommended age specific right Mindfulness control/ stimulant guidance topics. Topics covered less frequently than recommended included family support, parental health, behavior/discipline, physical activity, media screen time, risk reduction/substance use, adolescence/gender, social peer interactions, and violence. Shorter visits were associated with asking about parent/child concerns and addressing greater proportions of recommended checkup/expectancy guidance. Well-child care visits with children with special health care needs were 36% longer than with children without special needs, addressing a similar number of age-specific health checks/predictive guidance. More time was spent with children with special health care needs addressing health surveillance/expected guidance issues, other conditions (often chronic conditions), and testing, prescriptions and referrals. CONCLUSIONS: Using direct observation of visits with pediatric clinicians, we found that soliciting parent/child concerns occurred less frequently than recommended. Less than half of the recommended visit-specific health check/expectancy guidance issues were addressed, and there was little agreement with some of the Bright Futures age group-specific recommendations. In particular, both raising patient/parent concerns and greater adherence to health checkup/expected guidance recommendations were associated with shorter visits. Well-child care visits with children with special health care needs were longer than with children without special needs; “More time was spent on a similar number of health monitoring/expectation guidance issues, as well as chronic conditions.

title: Demand management for planned maintenance: a realistic synthesis.
abstract: Â The task of matching changing demand with available capacity is one of the key challenges in all large-scale service industries. It is a particularly urgent concern in modern healthcare systems as growing demand (aging population, availability of new treatments, increasing patient knowledge, etc.) is faced with stagnant supply (capacity and funding constraints on staff and services, etc.). As a result, a very broad portfolio of demand management strategies has been developed, based on quite different assumptions about the source of the problem and solutions. This report provides an important review of the effectiveness of key strategies designed to alleviate demand pressures in planned maintenance. The study begins with an overview of key ideas about the formation of problems of demand and capacity for health services. Many different diagnoses have been uncovered: fluctuating demand meets fixed capacity"; territorial protection between different providers; social rather than clinical pressures on referral decisions; self-driving diagnostic cascades; supplier-driven demand; demographic pressures on treatment; and informed patient and demand after-demand imbalance. We conducted a review of the key ideas (programme theories) underlying interventions designed to address them. We discovered that there was no close fit between the problems claimed and the solutions advocated. Strategic decision making, organizational re-engineering, procedural changes, and behavior change levels When mapping reform ideas, the program We also noted the tendency for 'whole-system' theories of Includes a realistic synthesis: referral management centers (RMCs); employing general practitioners (GPwSIs) with special interests at the interface between primary and secondary care; GP direct access to clinical tests; and shipping instructions. In any case, we encountered a checkered pattern of success and failure. The primary literature is replete with descriptions of unexpected problems and undesirable effects. These programs 'work' only under very limited conditions. To give brief examples, we have found that the success of RMCs is highly dependent on the balance of control in their governance structures; GPwSIs affect demand only after close negotiations on the agreed and intermediate state mix; significant efficiencies are created mainly by direct GP access to tests when there are low diagnostic yields and high 'exclusion' rates, and referral guidelines are more likely to work when implemented by staff responsible for their creation. The report concludes that it is not a 'preferred intervention' capable of outperforming others. Instead, the review found many, varied, hard-won, local and adaptable solutions. Whatever the starting point, success in demand management depends on synchronizing a complex set of strategic elements. organizational, procedural and motivational changes The final section offers practitioners some guidance on how to 'think' about all the interdependencies that balance demand and capacity. The different local contexts in which mixed methods are used will be valuable for understanding the processes by which such interventions take place. ounce adapted to local conditions. There is also space for further evidence synthesis. Substitution theory is ubiquitous in health and social care and would be valuable to determine a realistic synthesis to compare the fortunes of different practitioners (eg nurses/doctors, dentists/dental care practitioners, radiologists/radiographers, etc.) placed across different professional boundaries. contexts and mechanisms in which substitution, support or short-circuiting occurs. National Institutes of Health Research Health Services and Delivery Research program.

title: Dementia care management: Going new avenues in outpatient dementia care in a GP-based randomized controlled intervention trial
abstract: BACKGROUND: The increasing prevalence of dementia is a major challenge for the German healthcare system. The Delphi-MV study ("Dementia: life and person-centered assistance in Mecklenburg-West Pomerania") aims to implement and evaluate an innovative helper support system for people living at home with dementia (PwDs) and their caregivers. METHODS: Delphi-MV is a GP-based cluster randomized controlled intervention trial. Delphi-Intervention aims to provide "optimal care" by integrating multi-professional and multi-modal strategies to customize and optimize dementia treatment within the framework of the established health and social service system. Intervention is carried out in people's homes by Dementia Care Managers (DCMs) - nurses with special training for dementia. Based on German guidelines for evidence-based diagnosis and treatment of dementia, a comprehensive set of 95 intervention modules - the "DelpHi-Standard" - has been defined. Each module consists of predefined trigger conditions, a subsequent response task, and at least one criterion for completion. The intervention begins with a comprehensive assessment of the care situation, needs and resources. DCM develops and implements an intervention plan tailored to individual circumstances in close collaboration with the GP. EXPECTED RESULTS AND RESULTS: We expect statistically significant differences in primary outcomes (quality of life, behavioral and psychological symptoms of dementia, pharmacotherapy, caregiver burden) between the control and intervention group. The results may provide evidence for the efficacy and effectiveness of dementia care management according to the "Delphi-Standard" - prerequisites for the application of this concept to routine health care.

title: Depression
The design and dissemination of HAREKET! Weight Management Program for Veterans
abstract: BACKGROUND: Practitioners at the Veterans Health Administration (VHA) made comprehensive weight management a high priority in early 2001. PROGRAM DESIGN: MOVE! The Veterans' Weight Management Program was developed based on guidelines published by the National Institutes of Health and other organizations. Program feasibility was tested at 17 VHA sites and the program was developed during early implementation throughout 2005. EXPANDING: MOVE! It was distributed nationally in January 2006. Local program coordinators and physician champions were identified and provided with toolkits, online training, marketing materials and ongoing field support. ASSESSMENT: MOVE! It is practiced in almost all VHA medical centers. More than 100,000 patients by June 2008 MOVE! During more than 500,000 visits. An assessment based on an established framework is ongoing. CONCLUSION: MOVE! It is an example of translating research into large-scale practice. It has the potential to reduce the burden of disease from obesity and related conditions.

title: Design and evaluation of a computer reminder system to improve the prescribing behavior of GPs
abstract: OBJECTIVE: To evaluate the implementation of a decision support system with reactive computer reminders to improve drug prescribing behavior. METHODS: A clustered RCT with incomplete block design was conducted in the south of the Netherlands: 25 GPs received reminders about antibiotic and asthma/COPD prescriptions, 28 GPs received reminders about cholesterol prescriptions. Prescribing guides were integrated into the family physician information system established in the GP practices of the intervention group. While the computer program was in use, a reminder appeared if the GP deviated from the guidelines during prescribing. PRIMARY OUTCOME: Prescribing according to guidelines as a percentage of total prescriptions for a given drug. In addition, an assessment was made of the user-friendliness of the CRS in GP practice through questionnaires and interviews. RESULTS: Analyzes are currently underway. Preliminary results show that the CRS study supports our expectations. Overall, there appears to be a decrease in the number of prescriptions based on computerized guidelines for not prescribing certain drugs. Final analysis will be done as soon as possible. In general, the Computer Reminder System was perceived as stable and user-friendly. CONCLUSION: We have created a stable and user-friendly Computer Reminder System adjusted to the needs and demands of GPs. Preliminary results on the effectiveness of the system show that the implementation of a Computer Reminder System with reactive reminders improves drug prescribing behavior.

title: Education design and implementation to improve pediatric overweight management
abstract: INTRODUCTION: Clinicians report low proficiency in treating overweight children and using behavioral management strategies. This article documents the design and implementation of a training program to develop clinicians' skills in the assessment and behavioral management of pediatric overweight. METHODS: Two one-hour CME courses were designed using published guidelines, research findings, and expert committee recommendations. Training was delivered to clinicians of a managed care pediatrics department using new screening and counseling tools and interactive exercises. Questionnaires and focus groups were conducted 3 and 6 months after the intervention to examine the clinician's attitudes and practices regarding screening and counseling tools. CONCLUSIONS: Post-intervention, most clinicians agree that clinical practice guidelines (Pediatric Obesity Practice Resource) and percentage BMI for age provide useful information for clinical practice. Clinicians have reported increased use of recommended screening tools and changes in office practices to implement these tools. They made recommendations to improve the ease of use of the tools and to overcome perceived clinician and/or patient barriers. CONCLUSION: The provision of a concise, cost-effective, versatile training and counseling tool was perceived as aiding clinical practice. Useful lessons were learned about tool design and ways to put tools into practice. Training the entire healthcare team is advantageous for adopting new tools and practices.

title: Design and methods of the Echo WISELY (Scenarios Unsuitable for Echocardiography Will Significantly Reduce) study: A researcher-blind, randomized controlled trial of training and feedback intervention to reduce inappropriate echocardiograms.
abstract: BACKGROUND: Eligible use criteria (AUC) for transthoracic echocardiography (TTE) were developed to address concerns about inappropriate use of TTE. A previous pilot study suggests that a training and feedback intervention could reduce inappropriate TTEs desired by doctors in training. It is unknown whether such an intervention would be effective when targeting specialist physicians in a variety of clinical settings. OBJECTIVES: The purpose of this international, multicenter study was to evaluate the hypothesis that an AUC-based education and feedback intervention would reduce the rate of inappropriate echocardiograms requested by outpatients. METHODS: An ongoing multicenter, researcher-blind, randomized controlled trial in Canada and the United States will enroll cardiologists and primary care physicians working in an outpatient setting. The intervention arm will be provided with (1) a course summarizing the latest available evidence highlighting the AUC and appropriate use of TTE, (2) access to the American Society of Echocardiography mobile phone app, and (3) individualized emailed monthly summarizing feedback reports. TTE order behavior, including information about ineligible TTEs and brief descriptions of the ineligible assignment. The control group will receive no training in the appropriate use of TTE and will not order TTEs as usual practice. CONCLUSIONS: The Echo WISELY (Inappropriate Scenarios for Echocardiography RCT Will Significantly Reduce in One Training) study is the first multicenter randomized study of an AUC-based educational intervention. The study will examine whether an education and feedback intervention can reduce the rate of inappropriate TTE ordered by outpatient cardiologists and primary care physicians (www.clinicaltrials.gov identifier NCT02038101).

title: Design factors for the success or failure of guided decision support systems: a hypothesis involving case complexity.
abstract: Computer-based decision support systems (CDSSs) are currently mostly reminder systems. However, the effectiveness of such systems in changing physician behavior is not always observed. We assume that this approach is appropriate for simple clinical cases when doctors think they know how to prescribe and do not need help. Conversely, discretionary approaches that allow flexibility in the interpretation of patient conditions are more appropriate for more complex cases, such as chronic disease management. ASTI is a CDSS that works in two modes, a crit mode that works as a reminder-based system, and a user-initiated referral mode. Using a clinical case complexity score, a pre/post intervention trial was conducted with 10 GP and 15 hypertensive patient cases. Preliminary results tend to show that reminder-based interaction is appropriate for simple cases and that as clinical situations become complex, physicians are willing to use optional systems, complementing both modes.

title: Designing organizations with high credibility in healthcare
abstract: To improve safety performance, many healthcare organizations have tried to emulate high-reliability organizations from industries such as nuclear power, chemical processing, and military operations. We outline high reliability design principles for healthcare organizations, including both formal structures and informal practices that complement them. buildings. An organizational structure and implementation phase model is used to illustrate the typical challenges and design possibilities at each stage, moving from local autonomy to formal controls, open inquiry and deep self-understanding. We suggest how organizations can use the concepts and examples presented to increase their capacity to self-design for security and reliability.

title: Design of the Balance@Work project: systematic development, evaluation and implementation of an occupational health guide aimed at preventing weight gain among employees
abstract: BACKGROUND: Occupational health professionals can play an important role in preventive health promotion activities for workers. However, due to the lack of information, evidence and practice-based methods and strategies, interventions have not been implemented by occupational physicians until today. The aim of the Balance@Work project is to develop, evaluate and implement an occupational health guide to prevent weight gain among employees. METHODS: Following the Dutch Society of Occupational Medicine's guideline development protocol and Intervention Mapping protocol, the guideline was developed based on the literature, discussions with relevant stakeholders, and consensus among an expert group. The guide consists of an individual and an environmental component. The individual component includes recommendations for occupational physicians on how to promote physical activity and healthy eating behavior based on motivational interviewing principles. The environmental component includes an obesogenic environmental assessment tool. The guideline was evaluated in a randomized controlled trial among 20 occupational physicians. Occupational physicians in the intervention group apply the guideline to eligible workers for 6 months. Occupational physicians in the control group provide care as usual. Measurements are performed at baseline and then at 6, 12, and 18 months. Primary outcome measures include waist circumference, daily physical activity, and dietary behavior. Secondary outcome measures include sedentary behavior, predictors of behavior change, body weight and body mass index, cardiovascular disease risk profile, and quality of life. In addition, efficiency, absenteeism and cost-effectiveness are evaluated. CONCLUSION: Improving employees' daily physical activities and dietary behaviors can prevent weight gain and, in turn, improve employee health, increase productivity, and reduce absenteeism. After an impact and process assessment, the guideline will be revised and published after authorization. Along with a few practice aids, the published guide will be widely distributed by the Dutch Association for Occupational Medicine. TRIAL REGISTRATION: ISRCTN73545254/NTR1190.

title: Design, implementation and evaluation of an information translation intervention to increase organ donation after cardiovascular death in Canada: a study protocol.
abstract: Background The scarcity of transplantable organs is a global problem. There are two types of organ donation: living and dying. Organ donation of the deceased may occur after neurological determination of death (NDD) or cardio-circulatory death. Post-cardiocirculatory death (DCD) donation is responsible for the largest increases in deceased organ donation worldwide. However, differences in DCD usage exist in Canada and around the world. The reasons for these inconsistencies are largely unknown. The aim of this study is to develop, implement and evaluate a theory-based information translation intervention to provide practical guidance on how to increase the number of DCD organ donors without reducing the number of standard NDD donors. Methods We will use a three-stage hybrid method. In step one, we will conduct semi-structured interviews informed by the Theoretical Domains Framework to identify and describe stakeholders' beliefs and attitudes about DCD and their perceptions of the multilevel factors influencing DCD. We will identify: determinants of the evidence-practice gap"; specific behavioral changes and/or process changes needed to increase DCD; specific clinicians or organizations that need behavior change (eg, provincial donors)"; and specific targets for interventions. In a second step, we will develop a theory-based knowledge translation intervention that encompasses behavior modification techniques to overcome identified barriers and enhance those that enable DCD, using the principles of intervention mapping. In a third step, we will make the intervention available to hospitals in 10 Canadian provinces and evaluate its effectiveness using a multiple discontinuous time series design. Discussion We will take a behavioral approach to identify and test new, theory-based and ethically acceptable information translation strategies to increase the number of available DCD organ donors in Canada. If successful, this study will eventually lead to more transplants and reduce patient morbidity and mortality at the population level.

title: Designing a patient-centered personal health record to promote preventive care
abstract: BACKGROUND: Evidence-based preventive services offer significant health benefits, but Americans receive only half of the care specified. Various government and private community policy initiatives are promoting the adoption of information technologies, such as personal health records, to involve patients in their care, but current systems may not exploit the technology's full potential. METHODS: Using a model previously described to make information technology more patient-centered, we developed an interactive preventive health record (IPHR) designed to engage patients more deeply in preventive care and health promotion. We recruited 14 core care practices to introduce IPHR to all adult patients and sought practice and patient input in its design to ensure usability, specificity, and generalizability of IPHR. Input included patient usability testing, practice workflow observations, learning collaborations, and patient feedback. Use of IPHR was measured using practice appointment and IPHR databases. RESULTS: Emerging from this process, IPHR creates personalized patient recommendations based on guidelines from the US Preventive Services Task Force and other organizations. Extracts clinical data from applications' electronic medical records and retrieves health risk assessment information from patients. The clinical content is translated and explained in ordinary language. Recommendations review the benefits and uncertainties of services and possible actions for patients and clinicians. Recommendations include self-management tools, risk calculators, decision aids, and community resources selected to suit the patient's clinical circumstances. Within six months, practices encouraged 14.4% of patients to use IPHR (ranging from 1.5% to 28.3% in 14 practices). Applications have successfully incorporated IPHR into the workflow, using it to prepare patients for visits, increase health behavior counseling, annotate test results, automatically issue patient reminders for delayed services, notify clinicians about required services, and formulate personalized prevention plans. CONCLUSIONS: IPHR demonstrates that a patient-centered personal health record that interfaces with the electronic medical record can provide patients with a high level of personalized guidance and can be successfully adopted by intensive primary care practices. More work and improvement is needed to make information systems even more patient-centred and to demonstrate their impact on care. TRIAL REGISTRATION: Clinicaltrials.gov identifier: NCT00589173.

title: Designing a valid randomized pragmatic primary care practice trial: my own medical report (MOHR) project
abstract: Background There is an urgent need for greater attention to patient-centered health behavior and psychosocial issues and practical tools, study designs, and clinical and policy implications in primary care. Our goal is to design a scientifically rigorous and valid pragmatic trial to test whether primary care practices can systematically apply the collection of patient-reported information, and to provide patients with the necessary advice, goal setting, and counseling in response. Methods This manuscript reports on the iterative design of the My Own Health Report (MOHR), a cluster randomized delayed intervention trial. Nine couples of various primary care practices will be randomized to either early or delayed intervention after four months. The intervention includes the MOHR assessment addressing 10 areas of Â¨C health behaviors and psychosocial issues, followed by providing necessary counseling and support for patients presenting for health or chronic care. As a pragmatic participatory trial, stakeholder groups, including practice partners and patients, were included throughout the study design to take local resources and characteristics into account. Participatory tasks include determining the content of the MOHR assessment, improving the study design, providing input to outcome measures, and designing the implementation workflow. Study outcomes include intervention access (percentage of patients offered and completing the MOHR assessment), effectiveness (patients reporting being asked about issues, setting change targets, and receiving assistance in implementing early and delayed intervention), contextual factors affecting outcomes, and intervention costs. . Discussion The MOHR study demonstrates how a participatory design can be used to promote the consistent collection and use of patient-reported health behaviors and psychosocial assessments in a wide range of primary care settings. While pragmatic in nature, the study design would allow valid comparisons to answer the research question posed, and the findings can be generalized to a range of primary care settings. According to the pragmatic explanatory continuity indicator summary (PRECIS) framework, the study design is significantly more pragmatic than other published studies. The methods and findings should be of interest to researchers, practitioners, and policy makers seeking to make healthcare more patient-centered and relevant.

title: Detection and management of alcohol use disorders influenced by non-clinical factors in German primary care
abstract: OBJECTIVES: The primary aim was to evaluate the proportion of patients identified and correctly referred in German primary care. The secondary aim was to identify patient and practitioner characteristics that predict detection and correct referral. METHODS: In this clustered cross-sectional survey in German primary care, 3003 consecutive patients were invited to participate and asked to complete a standard health questionnaire. Then, problematic alcohol consumption was screened using the Alcohol Use Disorders Identification Test. Physicians recorded their assessment of the presence of any alcohol use disorder and documented the course of treatment for all patients identified for 3 months. RESULTS: Correctly identified problem drinkers were 38.6% in a per-protocol analysis and 33.6% using the worst-case scenario. Physicians' referral behavior was in line with current practice guidelines in 64.6% of documented cases and 27.0% in the worst-case scenario. Several patient (eg, gender, age) and practitioner characteristics (eg, age) can be identified that affect the diagnosis and referral of patients. CONCLUSIONS: There is a clear need to increase specialized diagnostic and therapeutic skills so that general practitioners can identify and apply secondary prevention. Further research should focus on the potential implications of applying these diagnostic and management tools.

title: Detection of lymphocytotoxic antibodies in relatives of patients with type I diabetes
abstract: Lymphocytotoxic antibody concentrations were measured in serum samples from 19 patients recently diagnosed with type I diabetes and 43 healthy relatives (33 relatives and 10 unrelated). The specificity of the reaction was tested at 15°C and 37°C against T lymphocytes and purified helper/inducer and cytotoxic/repressor subsets. Concentrations of lymphocytotoxic antibodies in each of the three test groups were significantly higher than in controls (type I patients, p<0.005; consanguineous relatives, p<0.001; and unrelated relatives, p<0.002). The frequency of detection of antibodies was also higher in each of the study groups (p less than 0.01, p less than 0.01, and p less than 0.05, respectively). Cytotoxicity affected both subgroups at 15 degrees C, but only cytotoxic/suppressor cells at 37 degrees C. Findings of lymphocytotoxic antibodies in healthy relatives of type I diabetics, regardless of consanguinity, suggest that an environmental agent such as a virus is at least partially responsible. for this lymphocytotoxic effect. Furthermore, residual cytotoxic/suppressor cell killing at 37°C may explain the suppressor cell defect observed in these patients.

title: Determinants of university students' health promoting lifestyles
abstract: This descriptive study of 151 college students in Boston, Massachusetts was conducted using the Health Supporting Lifestyle Profile (HPLP) to determine their relationship to perceived health status, gender, grade point averages, and health and non-health majors with health-promoting lifestyles. ) II, according to Pender's model. Students' perceived health status significantly predicted total HPLP II, exercise, stress management, and spiritual growth. College women performed significantly better nutrition, interpersonal relationships, health responsibility, and total HPLP II than men. The entire sample scored lower than any previously studied group in stress management. Male students, students reporting poor health, and all students are targeted for intervention and research in their missing areas. Guidelines for nursing practice are derived from the HPLP II questionnaire. These clinically relevant findings can guide nurse practitioners in intervening in college students' health awareness and practice.

title: Determinants of successful clinical networks: conceptual framework and study protocol
abstract: Background Clinical networks are increasingly seen as an important strategy for enhancing evidence-based practice and improving care models, but success is variable and the characteristics of high-impact networks are uncertain. This study takes advantage of the variability in the functioning and outcomes of networks supported by the Australian New South Wales (NSW) Agency for Clinical Innovation's non-mandatory clinical network model to explore the factors that contribute to the success of clinical networks. Methods/Design The purpose of this retrospective study was to examine the relationship between external support, organizational and program factors, and indicators of success among 19 clinical networks over a three-year period (2006-2008). Results (health impact, system impact, programs implemented, participation, user perception and financial leverage) and explanatory factors will be collected using a web-based questionnaire, interviews, and record review. An independent panel of experts will make judgments about the impact or extent of each network's initiatives on health and system impacts. The expert panel's ratings will be the result used in multivariate analyses. Following the rating of network success, a qualitative study will be conducted to provide a more in-depth examination of the most successful networks. Discussion This is the first study to combine quantitative and qualitative methods to examine the factors that contribute to the success of clinical networks, and more generally, it is the largest study of clinical networks performed. Adapting expert panel methods to rate the effects of networks is the methodological novelty of this study. The proposed project will identify conditions that should be created or promoted by agencies developing clinical networks and will be used immediately in formulating strategies and programs to maximize the effectiveness of these networks.

title: Developing a managed clinical network in palliative care: a realistic assessment
abstract: BACKGROUND: Achieving evidence-based practice is at the forefront of the international practice development agenda. Therefore, it is imperative that robust evaluation methodologies are in place to examine new approaches to service development. OBJECTIVES: This article reflects the benefits and challenges of realistic assessment design in establishing a new managed clinical network (MCN) approach to implementing a guideline for the care of individuals with cancer-related pain. DESIGN AND METHODS: There were three assessment points examining three versions of the MCN approach to care. At each stage, steps were taken to identify the context, mechanisms, and consequences associated with the model version under consideration. Findings from patient-centered case studies fed realistic assessment interviews with the management group. SETTING: A rural primary care setting in Scotland. PARTICIPANTS: Three elderly men, their families, and doctors and nurses providing direct care, along with 13 members of the network management group. CONCLUSIONS: The research highlighted the level of practitioner effort required to introduce the MCN approach to care. Progress was much slower than expected, frustrated at times by inexperience in change management and unfamiliarity with leading practice development projects and supporting practitioner learning. Problems with the age appropriateness of the evidence base for the care of the fragile elderly were also evident. The occupational group that experienced the most role changes are regional nurses and community pharmacists. CONCLUSION: The collaborative approach fueled by the realistic assessment framework was found particularly helpful and there was consensus that assessment became an integral part of the intervention itself. There were a number of methodological difficulties and the need to limit the depth of 'realistic resolution'. However, as a formative approach in the complex world of interdisciplinary practice development, realistic assessment has proven to be a valuable design.

title: Development of a pain assessment tool for use by nurses in an adult intensive care unit
abstract: Critically ill patients are particularly vulnerable to pain, citing this as the second largest intensive care stressor. Pain has also been identified as a complicating factor in critical illness. Despite this, pain management is not often seen as a priority by the intensive care team. Effective management can only be achieved with accurate pain assessment. However, this is difficult in critically ill patients as patients are often unable to communicate verbally due to the presence of endotracheal/tracheostomy tubes, sedation and paralyzing agents. Therefore, nurses rely on behavioral and physiological indicators to determine the presence of pain. However, since these occur in situations and situations that are not related to pain, a systematic, objective assessment tool is needed. Such a tool, consisting of a numerical and verbal rating scale, to facilitate documentation and auditing has been developed as a result of ongoing adjustment and evaluation. The tool scores the patient's pain by combining behavioral and physiological indicators and is used in conjunction with the Glasgow Coma Score and the modified Sheffield Sedation Scale to obtain a comprehensive neurological assessment. As movement and intervention may exacerbate pain, assessment is done at rest and during procedures such as aspiration and manual handling. A flowchart and clinical guideline are also provided as an aid to pain assessment and management. Although pre-assessment demonstrated the efficacy of the tool as a tool to predict and record pain levels in individual patients, it was clear that there was no change in the way pain was managed. To address this issue, nurses' understanding of pain management was determined and teaching sessions were conducted to increase the pain management profile in the unit.

title: Developing science of clinical utility in fieldwork strategies in diagnostic classification systems for ICD-11 mental and behavioral disorders
abstract: The World Health Organization (WHO) Department of Mental Health and Substance Abuse has developed a systematic program of field studies to evaluate and improve the clinical utility of diagnostic guidelines for mental and behavioral disorders recommended in the Eleventh Revision of the International Classification of Diseases. Related Health Issues (ICD-11). The clinical utility of diagnostic classification, its function as the interface between health encounters and health information, and the ICD-11 disease burden of mental disorders globally in 194 member states of WHO, including the United States. This article describes WHO's efforts to develop a science of clinical utility regarding one of the two main classification systems for mental disorders. We provide rationale and methodologies for an integrated and complementary set of fieldwork strategies, including major international surveys, formative field studies of the structure of clinicians conceptualizing mental disorders, case-controlled field studies using experimental methodologies to evaluate the impact of recommendations. Changes to diagnostic guidelines for clinicians' diagnostic decision making and ecological application field studies of clinical utility in global settings where the guidelines will ultimately be applied. The results of these studies have already been used in making decisions about the structure and content of ICD-11. If clinical utility is indeed among the highest goals of diagnostic systems for mental disorders, as the developers routinely claim, future revision efforts should continue to build on those efforts. (PsycINFO Database Record

title: Develop an intervention to encourage youth participation in asthma review consultations with practice nurses
abstract: OBJECTIVE: This article is the report of a study to develop an evidence-based pre-consultation guide for youth to use before an asthma review with a practice nurse. BACKGROUND: The participation of young people aged 13-19 in consultations with health professionals may be limited due to lack of opportunity to learn appropriate skills in tripartite consultations. Evidence-based interventions have been developed to encourage adult participation in consultations, but the needs of young people have not been specifically addressed. DESIGN: Guideline-informed multi-method design for the development of complex interventions. METHODS: A preliminary consultation guide for young people was developed in 2007 by applying a model of health behavior change, developing criteria by an expert panel, and consulting young people using a nominal group technique. RESULTS: The concepts of the Health Action Process Approach model were applied to the development of criteria supporting pre-consultation guidance. In the nominal groups, young people agreed that they had different needs than other children and adults. There was consensus that the pre-consultation guide should include disease-specific information, realistic photographs rather than Clip Art, consistent fonts, bullet points and colours, short vocabulary, and mature language. The evidence-based guide included statements and sample questions written by young people. CONCLUSION: Young people's views can contribute to the development of interventions designed to promote communication in consultations with nurses. This approach has the potential to be used to develop interventions in primary and secondary care in a variety of long-term conditions.

title: Developing guidelines for community child health personnel and examining referral pathways and outcomes of care in supporting emotionally and behaviorally disturbed children
abstract: The East Sussex Public Health Commissioners had asked if referral guidelines were needed to ensure that children of their greatest concern received support from the Child and Adolescent Mental Health Services (CAMHS). Community pediatric health doctors and nurses recorded all contacts with children with emotional and behavioral difficulties (EBD) over a one-month period. Data on the emergence of difficulties and ways of intervention were recorded. The same children were reviewed five months later and outcome was measured by clinical assessment and support offered. The study showed that child health staff managed cases both through single counseling sessions and through planned ongoing support. In addition, the use of the three-stage route recommended by the Ministry of Health was demonstrated. Analysis of the recorded data was used to identify referral routes and provide guidance on the characteristics of children who should be referred to CAMHS.

title: Developing guidelines for smoking cessation interventions for pregnant adolescents
abstract: More than 400,000 deaths per year in the United States are attributed to exposure to active and passive tobacco smoke. The Healthy People 2000 goals aim to reduce tobacco use in high-risk populations such as teenagers and pregnant women. This article describes health professionals' guidelines for smoking cessation when working with pregnant adolescents and young mothers who smoke.";" PIP: This article examines key components of smoking cessation and health promotion interventions for pregnant and parenting adolescents. It also explains health professionals' guidelines for smoking cessation when working with pregnant adolescents and young mothers who smoke. Both pregnancy and tobacco use are increasing among adolescents in the United States. The evidence clearly shows that smoking among pregnant adolescents is even higher than the national rate. Among pregnant teens, such a habit presents an immediate risk to the fetus, as well as a broad risk for the teen to form established smoking habits. Quitting smoking during pregnancy can have a profound effect on reducing infant mortality. For this purpose, it is suggested that health professionals can have a positive impact on the health of mothers, babies and children by encouraging and supporting the efforts of young mothers to quit smoking. The practitioner is in a special position to provide this counseling during health surveillance visits. Overall, the intervention guidelines presented in this article can be used for school-based clinics with pregnant students and are easily implemented in private practice or hospital-based clinics.

title: Developing internet-based health interventions: a guide for public health researchers and practitioners
abstract: BACKGROUND: Researchers and practitioners interested in developing online health interventions often rely on Web-based and print resources to guide them through the online intervention development process. While useful for understanding many aspects of website development best practices, what is missing from these resources are concrete examples of online intervention development experiences for health practices from the perspective of those conducting online health interventions. OBJECTIVE: This study aims to serve as a series of case studies in the development of online health interventions to provide insights to researchers and practitioners considering technology-based interventional or programmatic approaches. METHODS: A convenient sample of six study coordinators and five principal investigators at a large US-based land-grant university was interviewed about the process of developing online interventions in the areas of alcohol policy, adolescent health, medication adherence, and human immunodeficiency virus prevention. in transgender people and men who have sex with men. Respondents were asked questions that comprehensively covered each of the four phases of the User-Centered Design Process Map from the US Department of Health and Human Services' Research-Based Web Design and Usability Guidelines. The interviews were audio recorded and transcribed. Qualitative codes were developed for all transcripts using line-by-line open coding, and all transcripts were independently coded by at least 2 authors. Differences between encoders were resolved by discussion. RESULTS: We identified the following seven themes: (1) hire a strong (or at least the right) research team, (2) take the time to plan before starting the design process, (3) recognize that vendors and researchers have different values, goals, and language, (4) develop a detailed contract, (5) document all decisions and development activities, (6) use a content management system, and (7) allow extra time to test and debug your response. Each of these areas is discussed in detail with supporting citations from the principal investigators and study coordinators. CONCLUSIONS: Consideration should be given to the values held by members of each participating organization involved in the development of the online intervention or program, as well as the goals sought to be achieved by the website. These defined values and goals should initiate a frank and open discussion about the scope of work, budget, and other needs from each organization's point of view. Because of the complexity of developing online interventions, researchers and practitioners should be familiar with the process and how this process may differ from the development and implementation of face-to-face interventions or programs. To assist with this, the response team should consider expanding the team to include specialists in computer science or learning technologies, as well as leveraging the institutional resources that will be needed for successful completion of the project. Finally, we explain the balance between the funds available for online intervention or program development and the complexity of the project.

title: Developing leadership capacity for guideline use: a pilot cluster randomized control trial
abstract: IMPORTANCE: The importance of leadership in influencing nurses' use of clinical guidelines is well documented. However, little is known about how to develop and evaluate leadership interventions for guideline use. OBJECTIVE: The aim of this study was to pilot a leadership intervention designed to influence nurses' use of guideline recommendations when caring for patients with diabetic foot ulcers in home care nursing. This article reports the feasibility of implementing the study protocol, research findings on nursing process outcomes, and leadership behaviors. METHODS: A mixed methods pilot study was conducted with only a post-cluster randomized controlled trial and descriptive qualitative interviews. Four units were randomized to either control or experimental groups. Clinical and management leadership teams participated in a 12-week leadership intervention (workshop, teleconferences). Participants received summarized chart audit data, set goals for change, and created a team leadership action. Criteria for assessing the feasibility of the protocol include: design, response, precautions, and data collection procedures. For the experiment, chart controls compared differences in nursing process outcomes. PRIMARY RESULT: 8-item nursing assessment score. Secondary outcome: 5-item nursing care score based on change goals set by intervention participants. Qualitative interviews identified leadership behaviors that influenced guide use. CONCLUSIONS: Conducting this pilot demonstrated that some aspects of the study protocol were viable, while others needed further development. Trial findings observed no significant difference in primary outcome. A significant increase in the 5-item score selected by the intervention participants was observed (p = 0.02). In the experimental group, mostly relationship-oriented leadership behaviors, supervision and feedback and reminders were defined as leadership strategies. CONCLUSIONS: The findings suggest that a leadership intervention has the potential to affect nurses' use of guideline recommendations, but more work is needed to improve the intervention and outcome measures. A classification of leadership behaviors has been proposed to inform future research.

title: Development of quality measures for emergency room management of pediatric suicidal behaviors
abstract: OBJECTIVE: Given the public health importance of suicidal behaviors and the corresponding gap in the performance measurement literature, we sought to identify key candidate process indicators (quality of care measures) and structural measures (organizational resources and characteristics) important to the emergency department. ED) management of pediatric suicidal behaviors. METHODS: We reviewed nationally approved guidelines and published studies to create an inventory of precautions. We then surveyed specialist pediatric emergency clinicians to assess the level of agreement on the relevance (with patient care) and variability (between hospitals) of 42 candidate process indicators and whether 10 hospital and regional structural measures influence these processes. RESULTS: Twenty-three clinicians from 14 pediatric tertiary hospitals responded (93% of hospitals were contacted). Candidate process indicators identified as both most relevant to patient care (>/=87% agree or strongly agree) and most variable between hospitals (>/=78% agree or strongly agree)"waiting time for medical evaluation"; referral to crisis intervention employee/program ; mental health, psychosocial, or risk assessment requested; any inpatient admission; inpatient psychiatric admission; post-discharge treatment plan; waiting time for first follow-up appointment; follow-up and type of follow-up received. and regional structural measures (>/= %) 87 accepted or strongly accepted) type of specialist personnel and specialist personnel available in the emergency room or emergency department; regional policies, protocols, or procedures; and inpatient psychiatry services. CONCLUSIONS: This study evaluated candidate performance measures for emergency room management of pediatric suicidal behaviors. 9 candidate process indicators (including triage, evaluation, admission, discharge and follow-up) and 4 hospitals and regional structural measures deserve further development.

title: Developing team leadership to facilitate guide use: planning and evaluating a 3-month response strategy
abstract: BACKGROUND: Research identifies leadership as important to use. Yet interventions to develop current and future leaders for this purpose are not well understood. OBJECTIVE: To describe the planning and evaluation of a leadership intervention to facilitate nurses' use of guideline recommendations for diabetic foot ulcers in home health care. METHOD: Planning the intervention involved a synthesis of theory and research (qualitative interviews and table checks). One workshop and three follow-up teleconferences at two facilities were given to nurse managers and clinical leaders (n=15) in charge of 180 staff nurses. The evaluation included workshop questionnaires and interviews. RESULTS: The highest scoring intervention components (four-point scale) were: setting target indicators (mean 3.7) and developing a team leadership action plan (mean 3.5). The pre-workshop barriers assessment scored the lowest (average 2.9). Three months later, participants reported that their leadership performance had changed as a result of the intervention, they interacted more with staff and were clear about their implementation goals. CONCLUSIONS AND PRACTICES FOR NURSING MANAGEMENT: Creating a team leadership action plan to operationalize leadership behaviors can help provide evidence-based care. Accessing clinical data and understanding team leadership knowledge and skills prior to formal training will assist nursing management in tailoring intervention strategies to identify needs and gaps.

title: Development of protocol to assess health foundation engagement with 'quality initiative' - an urgent approach
abstract: In 2004 the UK charity The Health Foundation established the 'Connecting with the Quality Initiative' to explore and evaluate the benefits of clinician involvement in quality improvement in health care. Eight projects were commissioned, run by professional organizations or expert societies in various fields of acute care. A developmental approach to the initiative was adopted, accompanied by a two-level evaluation: eight project self-assessments and a relevant external evaluation. This article describes how the external evaluation protocol was developed. Challenges faced included large differences between and within projects (approach, scope and context, and understanding of quality improvement), the need to support project teams in their self-assessment while maintaining the required objectivity, and the challenge of assessment. the moving target created by the developmental approach adopted in the initiative. An initial period of developing the evaluation protocol has proven invaluable in helping us explore these issues.

title: Development and implementation of a medical oncology quality improvement tool for a regional community oncology network: Fox Chase Cancer Center Partners initiative
abstract: Fox Chase Cancer Center Partners (FCCCP) is a community hospital/academic partnership of 25 hospitals in the Delaware Valley. Originally created in 1986, the FCCCP promotes quality community cancer care through education, quality assurance, and access to clinical trial research. An important aspect of quality assurance is the annual medical oncology audit, which benchmarks quality indicators and guidelines and provides a roadmap for quality improvement initiatives in the community oncology clinical office setting. Each year, the FCCCP team and Associate Medical Oncologists create disease site- and stage-specific indicators based on the National Comprehensive Cancer Network (NCCN) Clinical Practice Guidelines in Oncology. Compliance with multiple indicators is assessed on 20 charts from each community application. A report for each FCCCP medical oncology practice summarizes documentation, screening recommendations, new drug use, and research trends in a particular disease region. Descriptive statistics reflect indicators met, number of new cases per year, number of disease site cases from tumor registry information, and clinical trial accrual total. Training and documentation tools are provided to physicians and oncology office nursing staff. The FCCCP Clinical Operations Team, made up of medical oncologists and oncology certified nurses, has conducted quality audits in medical oncology offices for 7 years using indicators derived from the NCCN. Successful audits involving gastric, colorectal and breast cancer have been the focus of recent reviews. For the 2005 stage II/III breast cancer assessment, the mean agreement per parameter was 88%, and 15 of 16 treatments had mean agreement above 80%. A large-scale quality assurance audit can be conducted in a community cancer partner network. Recent assessment of localized breast cancer demonstrates a high level of compliance with guidelines and identifies areas of focused education. The partnership between academic and community oncologists produces a quality review process that is broadly applicable and adaptable to changing medical knowledge.

title: Development and implementation of a program to assess medical patients' need for venous thromboembolism prophylaxis
abstract: Aim. Describes the development and implementation of a program to assess medical patients' need for venous thromboembolism (VTE) prophylaxis. Summary. The departments of pharmacy services, medicine, and information services at Hartford Hospital collaborated to create a program to improve VTE prophylaxis in medical patients. After evaluating compliance with baseline VTE prophylaxis, departments developed an intervention consisting of a message to be displayed to providers using the institution's computerized prescriber-order-entry (CPOE) system as a reminder to assess the current patient for VTE risk factors. and the need for VTE prophylaxis. The message was displayed when a patient met predefined criteria for VTE risk factors. The message would not continue to be displayed when there is an active order for mechanical or pharmacological VTE prophylaxis in the patient's drug profile. Comprehensive training on the program was provided to hospital staff, pharmacists, physicians, nurse practitioners, physician assistants, and nurses. The program was implemented on a pilot medical floor in March 2007. A retrospective table review was conducted using the risk assessment tool developed to measure the impact of the program. The compliance rate for VTE prophylaxis after administration was 93% compared to 49% at pre-administration of the program (p < 0.001). Before the program, only 25% of patients with contraindications to pharmacological therapy received mechanical prophylaxis, compared to 100% after program implementation. Solution. The use of message alerts through a CPOE system and an interdisciplinary team approach to assess patients' risk of VTE have been shown to improve the use of VTE prophylaxis in medical patients.

title: Development and implementation of non-pharmacological protocols for the management of Alzheimer's disease patients and their families in a multiethnic primary care setting.
abstract: OBJECTIVE: Most patients with dementia and their families are cared for in primary care clinics. These clinics are rarely designed to provide the necessary comprehensive care. The purpose of this article is to describe non-pharmacological protocols for the management of Alzheimer's disease patients and their families implemented as part of a multi-faceted care management intervention program in a multiethnic primary care clinic. DESIGN AND METHODS: The non-pharmacological component for the integrated collaborative care program was developed based on literature review and previous clinical experience. Care is coordinated by a geriatric nurse who meets with patients, their families, and primary care physicians. Non-pharmacological protocols included general educational guidelines on Alzheimer's disease. Special protocols have also been developed to treat common behavioral disorders associated with Alzheimer's disease. An important component of the intervention is a monthly psychoeducational support group for caregivers. RESULTS: The intervention was well received by patients, families, and doctors. About half of the treatment group attended the support group regularly. APPLICATIONS: The integration of behavioral interventions and team care in the primary care setting has been successful.

title: Developing and testing a care-based intervention for older adults with heart failure
abstract: The clinical and cost burdens of heart failure (HF) continue to increase, creating an urgent need for cost-effective interventions to improve health outcomes. This article describes the development and testing of a care-based nursing intervention for older adults with advanced HF who have recently been discharged from acute care. The development process and components of the intervention are presented. A methodology for testing the intervention is also introduced. Through a progressive development process that includes research, this intervention can be refined and used to guide clinicians, administrators and policy makers in providing high-quality care for older adults with HF.

title: Developing a behavior change intervention: a case study on the practical application of theory
abstract: BACKGROUND: The use of theory in the practice of complex interventions is widely recommended. To improve self-management support for people with osteoarthritis (OA) in primary care, a complex trial intervention needed to be implemented in the Managing Osteoarthritis in Consultations (MOSAICS) trial. One component of the trial intervention was the delivery of an enhanced consultation for patients with OA by general practitioners (GPs). The purpose of our case study is to describe the systematic selection and use of theory to develop a behavior change intervention to implement the GP presentation of enhanced consultation. METHODS: Four theoretical models/frameworks guided the development of behavior change intervention: i) applying a model of change to guide the overall approach, ii) The Theoretical Domains Framework (TDF) to identify relevant determinants of change, iii) a model to address identified determinants of behavior change and iv) principles of adult learning. Methods and measures were identified to assess the impact of the behavior change intervention. RESULTS: Behavior change intervention presented GPs with a well-defined proposition for change"; addressed seven TDF domains (eg, knowledge, skills, motivation, and goals); ten behavior change techniques (eg, persuasive communication);" and delivered in workshops that value the expertise and professional values of GPs. Using a mix of interactive and didactic sessions, the workshops were facilitated by opinion leaders and used 'contextual communication skills training'. The methods and measures chosen to evaluate the behavior change intervention included: satisfaction assessment from workshops, GP intent to practice report, and assessment of GPs video-recorded consultations with patients with OA. CONCLUSIONS: A stepwise approach to the development of a behavior change intervention using theoretical frameworks to identify determinants of change matched with behavior change techniques has allowed for the systematic and theory-based development of an intervention designed by GPs to enhance consultations for: patients with OA. The success of the behavior change intervention in practice will be evaluated in the context of the MOSAICS research as a whole and will inform the level of practice and understanding of patient outcomes in the trial.

title: Development of a complex intervention for secondary prevention of coronary heart disease in primary care using the UK Medical Research Council framework
abstract: OBJECTIVE: To apply the UK Medical Research Council (MRC) framework for the development and evaluation of trials of complex interventions for a primary care intervention to promote secondary prevention of coronary heart disease. STUDY DESIGN: Intervention development case report. METHODS: First, the literature on secondary prevention and lifestyle change was reviewed. Second, a preliminary intervention was modeled based on literature findings and focus group discussions with patients (n = 23) and staff (n = 29) from 4 general practices. Participants' experiences and attitudes towards key intervention components were investigated. Third, the pre-intervention was pilot-tested in 4 general applications. After delivery of the pilot intervention, practitioners evaluated the training sessions and qualitative data on their intervention experience were collected using semi-structured interviews with staff (n = 10) and patient focus groups (n = 17). RESULTS: The literature review identified 3 intervention components: a structured recall system, practitioner education, and patient information. Initial qualitative data identified variations in recall system design, training requirements (drug prescribing, facilitating behavior change), and information available to prospective study participants. Identifying the detailed structures within the intervention components clarified how the intervention could be tailored to the individual practice, practitioner, and patient needs while maintaining the theoretical functions of the components. Findings from the pilot phase informed further modeling of the intervention, reducing administrative time, increasing the practical content of training, and omitting unhelpful patient information. CONCLUSION: Implementation of the MRC framework helped determine the feasibility and development of a complex intervention for primary care research.

title: Development of a complex intervention to promote appropriate prescribing and drug intensification in poorly controlled type 2 diabetes mellitus in Irish general practice
abstract: Background Poorly controlled type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM) can be viewed as failure to meet recommended targets for the management of key risk factors, including glycemic control, blood pressure and lipids. Poor control of risk factors is associated with significant morbidity, mortality, and healthcare costs. When noted, failure to intensify drugs for patients with poor control of T2DM is referred to as clinical inertia and is a contributing factor to poor control of T2DM. We aimed to develop a complex theory and evidence-based intervention to improve appropriate prescribing and drug concentration in poorly controlled T2DM in Irish general practice. Methods Used the first phase of the Medical Research Council Framework to develop and evaluate complex interventions. To identify the available evidence, we conducted a systematic review to examine the effectiveness of interventions targeting patients with poorly controlled T2DM in community settings. The Behavior Modification Wheel theoretical approach was used to identify appropriate intervention functions. Workshops, simulation, collaborations with academic partners, and physician observations were used to operationalize response functions and design elements of the complex response. Conclusions Our systematic review highlighted that professional-based interventions, potentially through clinical decision support systems, could address poorly controlled T2DM. Appropriate intensification of anti-glycemic and cardiovascular medications by general practitioners (GPs) for adults with poorly controlled T2DM was identified as a key behavior to address clinical inertia. Psychological ability was the key driver of behavior that needed to be changed, and he proposed five key intervention functions (education, training, activation, environmental restructuring, and encouragement) and nine key behavior modification techniques that are operationalized in a complex response. The intervention has three components: (a) training program/academic elaboration of the target GPs, (b) a remote discovery tool to help GPs identify patients with poor T2DM control in their practice, and (c) a web-based clinical decision support system. Conclusions This article describes a multifaceted process that includes a thorough theoretical understanding of the predictors of behavior that results in the design of a complex intervention to promote the search for available evidence and the application of evidence-based guidelines in adverse situations through appropriate prescribing and drug intensification. controlled T2DM

title: Development of a minimization tool for the allocation of a hospital-level performance improvement intervention to reduce waiting times in Ontario emergency departments
abstract: Background Rigorous evaluation of an intervention requires that its allocation be neutral with respect to the confounders; this is particularly difficult in complex, system-wide health interventions. We developed a short survey tool to identify factors for a minimization algorithm for the allocation of a hospital. Leveled intervention to reduce ED wait times in Ontario, Canada Methods Potential confounding factors affecting the success of the intervention were identified by literature review and grouped according to stages of change specific to the healthcare setting. International multidisciplinary (clinical, administrative, decision) constructive, management) panel evaluated these factors in a two-stage modified delphi and nominal group process based on four areas: readiness for change, evidence base, face validity, and clarity of definition. The panel narrowed the list to 12 in the first round of polls. survey, experts scored each factor according to four areas; summary scores and consensus discussion resulted in the final selection and measurement of four hospital-level factors to be used in the minimization algorithm: improved patient flow as a hospital's leadership priority; physicians' openness to organizational change; “efficiency of bed management” and physician incentives that support the goal of change.
