Conclusion We have developed a simple tool designed to collect data from senior hospital managers on factors that may influence the success of a hospital patient flow improvement intervention. A minimization algorithm will ensure balanced allocation of the intervention for these factors in research hospitals.

title: Development of a tool to measure clinical competence in occupational therapy: a pilot study?
abstract: Clinical competence is often defined as a combination of knowledge, skills and professional behavior. It is generally assessed using written tests, direct observation, chart audits, customer satisfaction surveys, and supervisor ratings. This article describes the development and evaluation of a chart-evoked recall (CSR) measure that combines schedule control and clinician interview methods to assess the clinical competence of practicing occupational therapists. The CSR tool was developed using the Canadian Guidelines for Client-Centered Practice and draws on global competence areas: theory use, assessment, program planning, intervention, discharge planning, follow-up, program evaluation, clinical reasoning, and professional behavior. This pilot study involved two independent evaluators/interviewers evaluating twelve occupational therapy clinicians on two occasions, using a random client case/registration sample at a time. in various application environments as a global measure of on-the-job performance.

title: Development of an exercise program for older adults: pre-exercise testing, exercise prescription and program maintenance
abstract: Health care practitioners have the technical skills, contact frequency, and reliability with older adults to use exercise as a health-promoting and disease-preventing intervention. This article provides the clinician with information on how to develop an exercise program specifically for older adults. The health promotion and disease prevention outcomes of exercise in older adults are also reviewed, including a description of the three phases of exercise programming for older adults. Phase one is labeled pre-exercise testing and discusses assessment protocols for aerobic capacity, body composition, flexibility, and strength. Guidelines for who should and should not exercise were also examined. The second stage of exercise programming is exercise prescription. An explanation of how to develop a beginner's training and guidelines on how to set goals based on the initial pre-exercise test are provided. Program maintenance is the third stage";" this includes recommendations for designing an exercise program that improves program compliance, reduces attrition, and prevents repetition of non-exercise behaviors.

title: Development of an ICF-based clinical practice guideline for the evaluation of function in head and neck cancer
abstract: BACKGROUND: Functional outcome following head and neck cancer is not regularly evaluated in a standardized manner in clinical practice. Clinical trials evaluating functional outcome apply many different tools. Therefore, results are not always comparable and have limited clinical implications. The purpose of this study was to describe, interdisciplinary evaluation and recommendation of functional outcome tools for use in clinical practice and clinical trials in patients with HNC. MATERIAL: The preparatory work produced a shortlist of outcome tools based on predetermined criteria. An interdisciplinary group of experts evaluated these tools and decided which ones could be recommended for use in 3 fields of application: screening, therapy evaluation/planning, and clinical trials. Health professionals who made the decision included physicians (ENT and maxillofacial surgeons, radiotherapists, oncologists), medical psychologists, speech and language therapists, physiotherapists, and social workers. RESULTS: 98 instruments were presented at the consensus conference. In total, 21 participants suggested a set of key measures to assess impairment in 6 functional areas for each of the 3 practice areas: follow-up treatment monitoring, pain, swallowing, voice/speech, other organic problems, and psychosocial problems. CONCLUSION: A multiprofessional pool of experts discussed and accepted recommendations for the use of functional outcome tools in clinical practice and/or research. Re-recommended instruments are now available for use in clinical routine.

title: Development of clinical practice guidelines for the nursing care of persons exposed to percutaneous coronary interventions: Australian and New Zealand collaboration.
abstract: OBJECTIVE: This article describes the development of nursing practice guidelines for percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI). BACKGROUND: Clinical practice guidelines (CPGs) supporting PCI nursing care are limited. METHOD: Health and medical practice development guidelines of the National Health and Medical Research Council (NH&MRC) were used for the guideline development process. A panel of experts (clinicians and consumers) attended a consensus conference to review the available evidence. Then, the opinions of the nurses were determined through an online questionnaire. This was followed by a modified Delphi method used to develop a set of draft guides over two rounds. RESULTS: 41 participants (39 cardiovascular nurses and 2 consumer representatives) attended the consensus conference. Eight additional members joined the panel for modified Delphi tours, with 27 participants completing the online survey. The final guidance document consisted of 75 recommendations. Approval was then sought from the most important cardiovascular organizations in Australia and New Zealand. DISCUSSION/CONCLUSION: Inconclusive evidence precludes definitive recommendations. Therefore, consultation and consensus are essential in developing guidelines for achieving standardized nursing care and monitoring outcomes. PRACTICES FOR PRACTICE: Nurses play a crucial role in PCI care, but there are currently limited guidelines to inform practice. This article describes the method that developed clinical practice guidelines and achieved consensus.

title: Development of geriatric competencies for emergency medicine residents using an expert consensus process
abstract: BACKGROUND: The rate of emergency department (ED) visits for elderly patients exceeds all age groups except infants. The aging population will increase elderly emergency room patient use to between 35% and 60% of all visits. Older patients may have complex clinical presentations and may be resource intensive. Evidence suggests that emergency physicians are unable to provide consistent high-quality care for elderly emergency room patients, resulting in poor clinical outcomes. OBJECTIVES: The goal was to develop a consensus document called "Geriatric Competencies for Emergency Medicine Assistants" by designated specialists. This is the minimum set of behaviorally-based performance standards that all residents should be able to demonstrate by completing their specialist training. METHODS: This consensus-based process used an inductive, qualitative, multi-stage method to determine the minimum geriatric competencies required by emergency medicine (EM) residents. Face validity and reliability assessments were used throughout the project. RESULTS: In Phase I, participants (n=363) identified 12 domains and 300 potential competencies. In Phase II, a panel of experts (n=24) aggregated Phase I responses, resulting in eight domains and 72 competencies. III. In Phase 1, the expert panel narrowed the qualifications down to 26. IV. Analysis of face validity and reliability yielded 100% consensus for eight domains and 26 competencies. Areas identified, atypical presentation of disease; trauma, including falls; cognitive and behavioral disorders; emergency response changes; medication management; care transitions; pain management and palliative care;" and the impact of comorbid conditions. CONCLUSIONS: Geriatric Qualifications for EM Residents is a consensus document that can form the basis of assessment for EM residency curricula and to meet the demands of our aging population.

title: Development, implementation and evaluation of a pharmacy-based model of asthma care
abstract: BACKGROUND Pharmacists are uniquely placed in the healthcare system to address critical issues in the management of asthma in the community. Several programs have demonstrated the benefits of a pharmacist-led asthma care program”, although such a program has not been previously evaluated in Australia. OBJECTIVE To measure the impact of a specific asthma service delivered through community pharmacies from an objective patient clinical, humanistic, and economic outcome METHODS 52 intervention patients and asthmatics A parallel-controlled design was used in which 50 control patients were recruited at 2 separate locations In the intervention area, pharmacists were trained and an asthma care model was implemented with 3 follow-ups Upstream visits over 6 months This model was evaluated based on clinical, humane, and economic outcomes compared between and within groups RESULTS 2.6 Â± 0.5 to 1.6 Â± 0.7 (mean Â± SD;" p < 0.001) in asthma severity in the intervention group versus 2.3 Â± 0.7 to 2.4 Â± 0.5. In the intervention group, peak flow indices increased from 82.7% ± 8.2% at baseline to 87.4% ± 8.9% (p < 0.001) at the last visit, with a significant reduction in the defined daily dose of albuterol used by. patients ranged from 374.8 Â± 314.8 Âµg at baseline to 198.4 Â± 196.9 Âµg at last visit (p < 0.015). There was a statistically significant improvement in perceived asthma control and asthma knowledge scores in the intervention group compared to the control group between baseline and last visit. Based on overall severity reduction, savings of $132.84 (AU) per patient per year in drug costs and $100,801.20 for the entire group were demonstrated. CONCLUSIONS Based on the results of this study, it appears that a specialized model of asthma care offers community pharmacists an opportunity to contribute to improving asthma management in the Australian community.

title: Diabetes in rural towns: effectiveness of continuing education and feedback for healthcare providers in changing diabetes outcomes at the community level: protocol for a cluster randomized controlled trial.
abstract: OBJECTIVE: Type 2 diabetes is one of the fastest growing chronic diseases internationally. Health complications associated with type 2 diabetes can be prevented, delayed or improved through early detection and effective management. This research primarily aims to examine the impact of a web-based educational intervention on diabetes care provided by rural general practitioners (GPs) and subsequent patient outcomes. A population-level approach is used for outcome assessment, through de-identified pathology records for the entire city. METHODS/DESIGN: The study uses a set of randomized controlled trials with rural populations as the unit of analysis. Towns from four Australian states were selected and matched based on factors such as rurality, population size, proportion of the population that are Indigenous Australians, and socio-economic status. Eleven town pairs from the two states were eligible for the trial, and one town from each pair was randomized to the experimental group. Training on diabetes care best practices through an online active learning module, access to targeted and expert advice via an online request form, and town-based performance feedback on diabetes monitoring and outcomes to GPs in cities allocated to the experimental group. The package is delivered via repeated direct mail. DISCUSSION: The benefits of the results of the study are explained along with the difficulties and limitations of the methodology. TRIAL REGISTRATION: Australia New Zealand Clinical Trials Registry: ACTRN12611000553976.

title: Diabetes mellitus -- resistant obesity
Diabetes nurse case management and motivational interviewing for change (DYNAMIC): Study design and key features in a Chronic Care Model for Type 2 diabetes
abstract: BACKGROUND: Despite the evidence that diabetes is costly and devastating, the health system is poorly equipped to meet the challenges of chronic disease care. The Penn State Institute of Diabetes and Obesity is evaluating a type 2 DM management model that includes nurse case management (NCM) and motivational interviewing (MI) to promote behavior change. The primary care intervention is designed to improve patients' self-care and reduce clinical inertia through provider use of standard clinical guidelines to achieve better diabetes outcomes. METHODS: This RCT tests the efficacy of an enhanced NCM intervention on patient outcomes with type 2 DM (n=549) mediated by changes in self-care behavior and diabetes management. Outcomes include: (a) impact on clinical parameters such as HbA1c (<7), BP (<130/80) and LDL (<100), depression scores and weight; (b) process measures such as complication screening; (c) patient psychological and behavioral outcomes as measured by emotional distress (PAID), diabetes-specific quality of life (ADDQoL), patient satisfaction (DTSQ), self-care activities (SDSCA), and (d) physician satisfaction and cost-effectiveness of the intervention. RESULTS: Baseline includes (mean) age=58; BMI=34.4; 57% female;" 47% Caucasian and 39% Hispanic. Patients had elevated HbA1c (8.4), BP (137/77), and LDL (114). Overall, patients were depressed (CES-D=21.6) and had an extremely negative life (ADDQoL=-1.58) We believe that enhanced NCM will both improve self-care and reduce emotional distress in patients with diabetes. If proven effective, improved NCM may be translated into other chronic diseases.

title: Diabetes Translation Research: Where Are We and Where Do We Want To Be?
abstract: Translation research turns existing knowledge into useful measures for daily clinical and public health practice. We review progress in diabetes translation research and identify future challenges and opportunities in this area. Several promising interventions exist to optimize the delivery of effective diabetes treatments. Most of these interventions should be tested more formally, alone or in combination, in larger randomized or quasi-experimental practical trials using outcomes of particular interest to patients (eg, patient satisfaction and quality of life) and policy makers (eg, cost). and cost effectiveness). The long-term consequences (such as morbidity, mortality, quality of life, and costs) of strategies aimed at improving diabetes care should be evaluated. Translation research also needs to include ways to examine complex systems of care. The challenges and opportunities presented by translation research are enormous.

title: Diagnosis and treatment of attention deficit hyperactivity disorder (ADHD)
abstract: PURPOSE: The purpose of this NIH Consensus Statement is to inform the biomedical research and clinical practice communities about the results of the NIH Consensus Development Conference on the Diagnosis and Treatment of Attention Deficit Hyperactivity Disorder (ADHD). The disclosure provides the latest information on effective treatments for ADHD and presents the conclusions and recommendations of the consensus panel on these issues. Additionally, the statement identifies areas of study that deserve further research. Upon completion of this educational activity, the reader should have a clear working clinical knowledge of the latest in this topic. The clinician target audience for this statement includes, but is not limited to, psychiatrists, family physicians, pediatricians, internists, neurologist psychologists, and behavioral medicine professionals. PARTICIPANTS: Participants were a non-Federal, non-advocacy, 13-member panel representing the fields of psychology, psychiatry, neurology, pediatrics, epidemiology, biostatistics, education, and the public. In addition, 31 experts from the same fields presented data to the panel and a conference audience of 1215 people. EVIDENCE: Literature was searched on Medline and a comprehensive reference bibliography was provided to the panel and conference audience. Experts prepared summaries with relevant quotations from the literature. Scientific evidence was prioritized over clinical anecdotal experience. CONSENT PROCESS: By answering predefined questions, the panel developed its conclusions based on scientific evidence and scientific literature presented in the open forum. The panel created a draft statement, which was read in full and circulated to experts and audiences for comment. Subsequently, the panel resolved conflicting recommendations and issued a revised paper at the end of the conference. The panel finalized the revisions a few weeks after the conference. The draft paper was made available on the World Wide Web soon after its publication at the conference and has been updated with the panel's latest revisions. CONCLUSIONS: Attention deficit hyperactivity disorder or ADHD is a commonly diagnosed childhood behavioral disorder and represents a costly major public health problem. Children with ADHD have marked impairments and may experience long-term adverse effects on academic performance, professional success, and social-emotional development that have a profound impact on individuals, families, schools, and society. Despite progress in the assessment, diagnosis, and treatment of ADHD, this disorder and its treatment, particularly the use of psychostimulants for both short-term and long-term management, remains controversial. Although there is no independent diagnostic test for ADHD, there is evidence to support the validity of the disorder. More research is needed on the dimensional aspects of ADHD and the comorbid (co-existing) conditions present in both its childhood and adult forms. Studies involving randomized clinical trials (primarily of short duration, approximately three months) demonstrated the effectiveness of stimulants and psychosocial treatments for alleviating ADHD symptoms and associated aggression, and demonstrated that stimulants are more effective than psychosocial therapies in treating these symptoms. Due to the lack of consistent improvement beyond baseline symptoms and the paucity of long-term studies (beyond 14 months), longer-term studies with drugs and behavioral modalities and their combinations are needed. Although trials are ongoing, definitive recommendations for long-term treatment cannot be made at this time. There is wide variation among communities and physicians in the use of psychostimulants, suggesting that there is no consensus on which ADHD patients should be treated with psychostimulants. (SELF

title: Diagnosis of pulmonary embolism
Diagnostic Evaluation of Imaging Emphasized Low Back Pain
abstract: Objective: To review the clinical information and the evidence for the diagnostic accuracy of imaging for patients with low back pain in primary care. Data Source: MEDLINE search (January 1966 - September 2001) examination of patients with low back pain for clinical and radiographic accuracy articles and reviews. Study Selection: Authors reviewed abstracts and selected articles for review based on a combined judgment. Data on clinical examination were primarily based on recent systematic reviews"; data on imaging tests were primarily based on original articles. Data Extraction: Diagnostic results were drawn by one or the other author. The quality of methods was informally evaluated. Major potential biases were identified, but quantitative data extraction or No scoring was performed. Data Synthesis: No formal meta-analysis was used because of heterogeneity in diagnostic hardware and software, gold standards, and patient selection methods and the small number of studies. magnetic resonance imaging (0.83 to 0.93) and radionuclide scanning (0.74 to 0.93) 0.98) for the highest;" Specificity was highest for magnetic resonance imaging (0.9 to 0.97) and radiography (0.95 to 0.99). Magnetic resonance imaging was the most sensitive (0.96) and specific (0.92) test for infection. The sensitivity and specificity of magnetic resonance imaging for herniated discs was slightly higher than for computed tomography but very similar for diagnosing spinal stenosis. Conclusions: The data suggest a diagnostic strategy similar to the 1994 Agency for Health Care Policy and Research guidelines. Symptomatic treatment without imaging is appropriate for adults younger than 50 years of age with no signs or symptoms of systemic disease. Plain radiography and simple laboratory tests can almost completely rule out underlying systemic diseases in patients aged 50 years or older or whose findings suggest systemic disease. Further imaging should be reserved for patients considering surgery or with a strong suspicion of systemic disease.

title: Dietary treatment of hypercholesterolemia: Do dietitians do it better? A Randomly Controlled Trial
abstract: OBJECTIVE: Current guidelines of the National Cholesterol Education Program (NCEP) recommend initial dietary counseling by physicians for most patients with hypercholesterolemia";" Referral to a registered dietitian and lipid-lowering medications are recommended only for patients who remain hypercholesterolemic. We evaluated the increased value of detailed nutritional counseling by dietitians when added to general nutritional advice provided by physicians. SUBJECTS AND METHODS: Hypercholesterolemic patients identified during a cholesterol screening project were randomly assigned to receive dietary counseling by a physician only (70 patients) or by a physician and a registered dietitian (66 patients). Patients were observed for 1 year to determine compliance with NCEP guidelines. RESULTS: At 3 months, the mean (+/- SD) decrease in serum low-density lipoprotein (LDL) cholesterol was 7% +/- 11% in the physician group and 12% +/- 10% in the dietitian. group (P < 0.004). A 10% or more reduction in LDL cholesterol was observed in 25 patients (36%) in the physician group and 43 patients (65%) in the dietitian group (P<0.001). Only 40 (29%) of patients in both groups achieved their NCEP target goals at 3 months. Most of these were low-risk patients with a 160 mg/dL LDL cholesterol target target. At 12 months, both groups lost about half of the beneficial effects on LDL cholesterol levels, and the difference between the two groups narrowed. CONCLUSIONS: The short-term reduction in LDL cholesterol level obtained after counseling by dietitians is superior to that achieved by physicians. However, long-term adaptation remains insufficient. For patients at high risk, a more aggressive dietary approach and possibly earlier administration of lipid-lowering drugs should be considered.

title: Different indications, warnings and precautions and contraindications for the same drug - an international comparison of prescribing information for commonly used psychiatric drugs
abstract: OBJECTIVE: We aim to obtain an internationally valid data set to increase the prescription safety of psychiatric drugs. METHODS: We conducted an in-depth analysis of the compliance of prescribing information for 10 key psychiatric drugs in four major drug markets regarding indications, warnings and precautions, and contraindications. RESULTS: Average 71.4% +/- 30.3% of all indicated indications, 59.5% +/- 17.1% of all potential warnings and precautions, and 70.1% +/- 24% of all valid contraindications, Individual prescribing information covering 4. CONCLUSION: This significant variation in key prescribing information between countries highlights the need for better international cooperation and standardization of prescribing information.

title: Distinguishing normal speech fluency from stuttering in children
abstract: The concept of stuttering means that a speech pattern is not fluent or hesitant. It is reported that the incidence is 1% worldwide and it is more common in men than women (3:1). Theories of causation are briefly described, including genetic predisposition and neurological factors. In the process of acquiring speaking skills, preschoolers normally go through the transitional stage of speech fluency. This fact can hinder recognition of early stuttering behavior, be emotionally painful for the child, and hinder his psychological development. The healthcare provider is in a key position to provide early diagnosis and intervention to the child presenting with early stuttering. In order to do this, the healthcare provider must have the knowledge and skills to distinguish normal developmental fluency from early stuttering. Factors that differentiate these speech patterns are identified, along with guidelines for referral. Current treatment methods used by speech pathologists are described. Practical interventions that can be offered to parents to increase the child's speech fluency and reduce speaker anxiety are summarized.

title: Challenges in implementing a mental health guide: an exploratory study using psychological theory.
abstract: BACKGROUND: Evaluations of interventions to improve the implementation of guidelines have failed to produce a clear pattern of outcomes that supports a particular method. Although practice depends on clinicians and managers changing various behaviors, psychological theories of behavior and behavior change are rarely used to try to understand the challenges in practice or to develop interventions to overcome them. OBJECTIVES: This study applied psychological theory to examine explanations of difficulties in practice. He used a theoretical framework derived from an interdisciplinary consensus study to code the interviews across 11 theoretical domains. The focus of the study was the Schizophrenia guideline recommendation of the National Institute for Health and Clinical Excellence that family intervention should be offered to families of patients with schizophrenia. METHODS: Participants were recruited from community mental health teams” from three UK National Health Service (NHS) Foundations; 20 members (social workers, nurses, team managers, psychologists and psychiatrists) participated. Semi-structured interviews were audio-recorded and Interview questions covered in theoretical areas and addressed the respondents' knowledge, attitudes, and opinions about the guideline. Two researchers independently coded the transcript sections related to each theoretical area from each interview. A score of 1 indicated that the transcript sections related to the area did not appear to include a description of difficulties in applying family therapy guidelines. Similarly, 0.5 points indicates probable difficulties and 0 points definite difficulties. RESULTS: Coding of respondents' answers to questions about 'beliefs about outcomes', 'social/professional role and identity' and 'motivation', factors related to these domains creating difficulty show that the probability is low n produced the three highest overall scores. in practice. 'Environmental context and resources' was the lowest rated, while 'Emotion' was the second lowest rated, suggesting that these are probably areas where intervention should be considered. The two main resources identified as problems were time and education. The emotions that appeared to potentially influence the family therapy offering were self-doubt and fear. CONCLUSION: This exploratory work illustrates an approach to developing a theoretical understanding of implementation challenges.

title: Digitization of drugs: artifact, architecture and time
The Dimension of Time in Disease: An Objective View
Disability Associated with Psychiatric Comorbidity and Health Condition in Bosnian Refugees Living in Croatia
abstract: Context The relationship between psychiatric symptoms and disability in refugees exposed to mass violence is unknown. Purpose To determine whether risk factors such as demography, trauma, health status and psychiatric illness are associated with disability in Bosnian refugees. Design, Environment and Participants A 1996 cross-sectional study of Bosnian adults living in a camp set up by the Croatian government near the city of Varadin. One adult 18 years of age or older was randomly selected from 573 camp families"; 534 (93%) agreed to participate (mean age, 50 years; 41% male). Main Outcome Measures Culturally validated measures for depression and PTSD (ptsd ) included the Hopkins Symptom Checklist 25 and the Harvard Trauma Questionnaire, respectively. Measures of disability included the Medical Outcomes Study Short Form 20, a physical functioning scale based on World Health Organization criteria, and self-reports of socioeconomic activity, physical energy, and perceived health status. Results Participants reported a mean (sd) 6.5 (4.7) unrepeated trauma event, 18% (n=95) experienced 1 or more torture event 55.2% reported no psychiatric symptoms, 39.2% and 26.3% reported symptoms meeting dsm-iv criteria for depression and psd, respectively; 20.6% reported concomitant symptoms for both disorders. In total, 25.5% reported disability. Concomitant symptoms for sta were associated with an increased risk of disability compared with asymptomatic refugees (unadjusted odds ratio [OR], 5.02; 95% confidence interval Â¦Ã–, 3.05-8.26; adjusted or, 2.06;" 95% ci, 1.10-3.86). Advanced age, cumulative trauma, and chronic medical illness were also associated with disability. Results In a population of Bosnian refugees who had recently fled the war in Bosnia and Herzegovina, psychiatric comorbidities, age, trauma and was associated with disability, independent of the effects of health status.

title: Distinctive patterns of human immunodeficiency virus risk in healthy young adults
abstract: Previous research has questioned the effectiveness of current methods for identifying individuals at high risk for contracting and transmitting human immunodeficiency virus and other sexually transmitted diseases. Therefore, new approaches are needed to provide these individuals with risk reduction strategies. We review our research on sexual decision-making by young adults using theories and methods from the social and cognitive sciences. Four condom use patterns and associated risk and belief levels were determined. These models offer value in targeting intervention strategies to individuals at different risk levels. The findings also imply that the monogamous population may be at higher risk for infection than they realize. Primary care physicians are the first line of contact for many individuals in the healthcare system and may be in the best position to screen individuals at risk. Given the time demands and other barriers, there is a need for easy-to-use, evidence-based guidelines for this type of screening. We recommend such guidelines for primary care physicians to use in determining an individual's risk, and from these guidelines personalized intervention strategies can be developed.

title: Dismissal of professional employees: protection against dismissal for actions within professional ethics
Withdrawal of cholinesterase inhibitors: results of a survey of Canadian dementia experts
abstract: BACKGROUND: Cholinesterase inhibitors (ChEIs) are increasingly used for longer periods of time, even in patients with severe Alzheimer's disease. Practices can vary widely as there is little data available to help clinicians decide when it is safe and appropriate to discontinue ChEIs after prolonged use. METHODS: An internet-based survey was conducted with Canadian dementia specialists (geriatric psychiatrists, neurologists, geriatricians) involved in clinical trial studies. Recommendations for discontinuing ChEI were determined based on responses to questions about patient/caregiver preference, administrative considerations, efficacy, and adverse events. RESULTS: There was a reasonable consensus that ChEIs should be discontinued based on patient and caregiver preference and in the presence of serious bothersome adverse events. There was much less consensus on issues of effectiveness—especially what the larger-than-expected decline was. There was a general reluctance to rely on any single measure of cognition, function, and/or behavior, and in particular, the MMSE appeared to be useless in deciding whether to continue. CONCLUSION: Recommendations for discontinuation of ChEIs after prolonged use derived from a survey of dementia specialists are presented. Ideally, clinical practice guidelines based on controlled release trials are needed.

title: Discussing randomized clinical trials of cancer therapy: Evaluation of the Cancer Research UK education program
abstract: OBJECTIVE: To evaluate an educational intervention aimed at improving communication among healthcare professionals about randomized clinical trials with cancer patients. DESIGN: Before and after the evaluation of the training program. SETTING: Members of the National Cancer Research Network, Scottish Trials Network and Cancer Research Network Wales. PARTICIPANTS: 101 healthcare professionals (33 clinicians and 68 research nurses). INTERVENTION: Four module arms delivered by a trained facilitator using interactive exercises and videotapes covering the general topics of discussion of randomized clinical trials with patients, problems specific to adjuvant trials, trials in which palliation is the goal, and trials in which patients strongly prefer a treatment. MAIN OUTCOME MEASURES: Before and after the intervention, participants were videotaped discussing an experiment with an actor portraying a patient. These consultations were evaluated for the availability of information required by good clinical practice guidelines. Player patients made an assessment after each interview. Participants reported their self-confidence about key aspects of the essay discussion. RESULTS: Analysis of video-recorded consultations, significant communication after intervention such as significantly more participants explaining randomization (69 vs. 81, odds ratio 2.33, P = 0.033), checking patients' understanding (11 vs. 31, odds ratio 3.22). demonstrated the behavior. , P = 0.002) and standard treatment (73 vs 88, odds ratio 4.75, P = 0.005) and side effects (69 vs 85, odds ratio 3.29, P = 0.006). Participants' self-confidence increased significantly in all domains (P < 0.001). Player patients' ratings of participants' communication showed significant improvements for the 12/15 core item. CONCLUSION: This 8-hour intensive intervention significantly improved participants' confidence and competence when communicating about randomized clinical trials.

title: Discussion of sexual risk behavior in HIV care is rare and appears to be ineffective: a mixed-methods study
abstract: Consensus guidelines in HIV care require clinicians to provide a brief sexual risk behavioral intervention at each visit. Research based on participant reports finds this to occur rarely, but studies based on direct observation of clinical encounters are lacking. We conducted a mixed-method study using audio recordings of 116 routine outpatient visits by 58 different patients with HIV in five different practices. Transcripts of visits were coded and analyzed using a quantitative system. We also made a qualitative analysis of the dialogue sections in which sexually risky behaviors came to the fore. The sexual risk behavior discussion took place over 10 visits and was generally fairly short-lived. Important counseling on sexual risk reduction was given in two visits";" the other two contained important discussions that were not explicitly directed at the patient's changing behavior. At seven additional visits, clues emerged suggesting a need or opportunity for such a discussion that doctors did not follow. Interactions related to sexual risk had less patient involvement than interactions related to other health behaviors. Physicians rarely provide sexual risk reduction counseling in HIV care, even when specific indications are available.

title: Digestive system diseases. Jaundice
Dissemination of effectiveness and outcome research
abstract: Efficacy and outcome research aims to improve patients' health outcomes by improving the quality of health care they receive. The dissemination of the findings of such studies is a necessary step in this process. This article reviews what is known about the design and dissemination of effective information packages for healthcare providers (primarily doctors) where effectiveness is meant to promote behavior change for practitioners that leads to better patient care. Research information about practice is communicated to providers through the publication of results from randomized clinical trials, dissemination of consensus recommendations, the development and use of computer-based aids in clinical decision making, and the provision of continuing medical education. Each of these areas provides numerous examples of the extremely modest behavioral response that can be expected from the mere provision of information. The literature also offers some principles that may increase the chances of success, including the desirability of techniques involving face-to-face interaction, encouraging active student participation, repetition of the message, and making recommendations clear and relevant to clinical practice. benefit from opinion leaders and peer influence. Little fundamental research has been done on providers' motivations and actual decision-making processes. Research aimed at advancing the behavioral science of providers can also provide new insights into effective dissemination strategies.

title: Dissemination of Evidence-Based Antipsychotic Prescribing Guidelines to Nursing Homes: A Cluster Randomized Study
abstract: OBJECTIVES: To evaluate the effectiveness of efforts to translate and disseminate evidence-based guidelines on atypical antipsychotic use to nursing homes (NHs). DESIGN: Three-arm, cluster randomized trial. SET: NH's. PARTICIPANTS: NHs in the state of Connecticut. MEASUREMENTS: Evidence-based guidelines for atypical antipsychotic prescribing were translated into a toolkit targeting NH stakeholders, and 42 NHs were recruited and randomized to one of three toolkit dissemination strategies: toolkit delivery by mail (minimum density); quarterly inspection and toolkit delivery by mail. and feedback reports on facility-level antipsychotic prescribing (moderate intensity);" and face-to-face toolkit delivery that includes academic elaboration, on-site behavioral management training, and quarterly audit and feedback reports (high-intensity). Results were evaluated using the Reach, Effectiveness, Adoption, Implementation, Maintenance (RE-AIM) framework. RESULTS: The toolkit of leadership of 30% (7/23) of low-density NHs, 54% (19/35) of medium-density NHs, and 82% (18/22) of high-density NHs reflected awareness, adoption, and implementation of the intervention. . The highest levels of use and knowledge among direct care personnel were reported in high-density NHs. Antipsychotic prescribing levels fell over the study period, but there were no statistically significant differences between study arms or secular trends. CONCLUSION: RE-AIM indicators show some success in dissemination of the toolkit and differences in access, adoption and practice according to the dissemination strategy, but no measurable effect on antipsychotic prescribing trends. More information may need to be provided to external stakeholders such as psychiatric counselors and hospitals to influence antipsychotic prescribing for NH residents.

title: Do decision support systems affect the difference in prescription?
abstract: BACKGROUND: Translating scientific evidence into daily practice is problematic. Any intervention strategy using educational and/or guiding strategies aimed at changing behavior has evolved, but has only been partially successful. This article focuses on (computerized) decision support systems (DSSs). KDSs interfere with physicians' daily routines, as opposed to interventions aimed at influencing knowledge to change behavior. We examined whether general practitioners (GPs) prescribe according to recommendations given by DSS and whether there is less variation in prescription when DSS is used. METHODS: Data were used from the Second Dutch National Survey of General Practice (DNSGP2) collected in 2001. A total of 82 diagnoses, 749811 contacts, 133 doctors and 85 practices were included in the analyses. General practitioners using DSS daily were compared with general practitioners not using DSS. Multilevel analyzes were used to analyze the data. Two outcome measures were chosen: whether the prescription complied with the DSS recommendation and the Herfindahl-Hirschman Index (HHI), a concentration measure. CONCLUSIONS: GPs who use DSS daily write more prescriptions than GPs who do not use DSS, according to the recommendations given in DSS. Contrary to our expectation, there was no significant difference between HHIs for both groups: variation in prescription was comparable. CONCLUSION: We examined the use of a DSS for drug prescribing in general practice in the Netherlands. DSS is based on guidelines developed by the Dutch College of General Practitioners and implemented in GPs' Electronic Medical Systems. GPs using DSS write prescriptions more frequently based on the recommendations given in DSS than GPs not using DSS. However, this finding does not mean that variation is lower";" The variation is the same for GPs using and not using DSS. The conclusions of the study are that DSSs can be used to apply guidelines, but variation should not be expected to be limited.

title: Do Health Reforms Affect Health Professionals' Cost Awareness? Results of a Nationwide Study in the Balkans
abstract: BACKGROUND: Serbia, the largest market in the Western Balkans, has entered the socioeconomic transition with a significant lag compared to most of Eastern Europe. Health system reform efforts have been bold over the past 15 years, but their results have been inconsistent in several areas. The two waves of global recession that hit the Balkan economies were ultimately reflected in the health care finances. Serious difficulties have become real in providing citizens with accessible medical care. A large part of the intolerable expenses actually belong to the various laboratory and imaging diagnostic procedures demanded by physicians with overt drug prescription. Therefore, a large national survey was conducted at all levels of the health system hierarchy to discern the ability of cost containment strategies to reshape clinician mindsets and decision-making in practice. OBJECTIVES: To evaluate the judgments of health professionals about the economic consequences of prescribed medical interventions and their response to policy measures aimed at raising cost awareness. STUDY DESIGN: Cross-sectional study. METHODS: A nationwide cross-sectional survey was conducted from January 2010 to April 2013, before and after policy action, through the hierarchy of medical facilities in various geographic regions. In the middle of the observed period, the National Health Insurance Fund (RFZO) took serious cost containment measures. Independently, pharmacoeconomic guidelines targeting prescribers were distributed. Management in large hospitals and community pharmacies had to restrict access to high-budget medical care. The Economic Awareness Questionnaire of Healthcare Professionals-29 (EAHPQ-29) developed in Serbian was used in face-to-face interviews. The survey documented clinician's attitudes on: Clinical Decision Making Between Alternative-Interventions (CDMAI), Quality of Health Care (QHC), and Cost Containment Policy (CCP). The authors randomly and anonymously recruited 2000 healthcare professionals and provided a total of 1487 responses"; after missing questionnaires were eliminated, 649 participants were evaluated before the policy intervention and 651 after. RESULTS: Dentists (1.195+/-0.560) had a higher CDMAI score. The surgical group had a higher overall EAHPQ-29 score, CCP score, and CDMAI score compared to the internist group (1.017+/-0.453). Policy intervention had a statistically significant negative effect on the QHC score (F=4.958 ; df=1; " p=0.027). Policy interventions had no significant impact on professional behavior and judgment in relation to CDMAI, CCP, and overall EAHPQ-29 scores. CONCLUSION: Although cost savings were enforced in practice, their impact on clinical decision making was modest. Clinicians' perceptions of the quality of medical care were explained less effectively because of the severely limited resources allocated to providers. This pioneering effort in the Balkans demonstrates the inadequacy of current policies to broaden clinicians' cost awareness.

title: Do information brokers facilitate the implementation of stroke guidance in clinical practice?
abstract: BACKGROUND: The implementation of clinical practice guidelines in rehabilitation practice is often cumbersome and incomplete. One intervention to improve the implementation of the guidelines is the knowledge transfer program built around the activities of a knowledge broker (KB). This study explores the use of KBs to implement guideline recommendations for post-stroke intensive therapy and physical activity in 22 stroke patients. Units in hospitals and rehabilitation centers in the Netherlands. METHODS/DESIGN: This study includes a pre-intervention uncontrolled design and mixed methods process evaluation and a quantitative evaluation. Enterprising nurses and therapists from each stroke unit will be recruited and trained as KB. KB will work on its team for one year to implement the guideline recommendations. A questionnaire will be administered to patients, healthcare professionals, and BPs at baseline (T0) and one year later (T1) to assess the effectiveness of BP. In addition, semi-structured interviews will be held with 5 KB in T1. The primary outcome of this implementation project will be support for healthcare professionals to exercise and be physically active for patients, as reported by patients and healthcare professionals themselves. The support immediately after the intervention is compared to the support at the beginning of the intervention. Additionally, we will explore the impact of health professionals' socio-demographic characteristics and determinants (intention, attitude, subjective norm, and perceived) identified in the Planned Behavior Theory. behavioral control) is about the change of supportive behaviors of health professionals. Finally, PDs will fill out a questionnaire about their psychological and social demographics and the organizational conditions required for health care improvement, such as time, workforce, sponsorship and support from management. DISCUSSION: With this study, we will have an idea about when and why information brokers are effective. We will also identify predictors of which healthcare professionals are likely to change their behavior. This study will guide how to apply the guidelines and help improve stroke rehabilitation services.

title: Do nurses have a different physical health profile? A systematic review of experimental and observational studies on nurses' physical health.
abstract: OBJECTIVE: To systematically review the evidence on nurses' health. OBJECTIVE: Nurses are one of the most important resources of a health system. They are exposed to biological, socio-economic, cultural and health system factors that determine their health. Although mental and physical health problems seem to be common among nurses, the literature is often contradictory. The literature on nurses' health styles, health behaviors and health perceptions is also not clear. DESIGN: A systematic review of experimental and observational studies on nurses' health. METHODS: Forty-three databases were searched. 2692 references identified as potential areas of interest";" 187 studies were included. Only results from studies on physical health are presented. No meta-analysis was possible. The Scottish Interuniversity Guidelines Network system was used to rank the evidence. CONCLUSIONS: Nurses were at greater risk of musculoskeletal injury and more prone to blood-borne pathogen infections than other healthcare workers. They had a higher risk of breast cancer than other female healthcare professionals. Nurses in hospitals were more at risk of tuberculosis. Overall, there was no risk of excess cancer, Hodgkin's disease, stomach, colon, rectum, pancreatic, ovarian, kidney, brain, or thyroid cancer, or lymphosarcoma. They have a higher prevalence of occupational allergies than office workers. DISCUSSION: Nurses suffer more from musculoskeletal disorders in accordance with the nature of the nursing job. Especially if they work in lung, medical or Human Immunodeficiency Virus services, they are at higher risk of contracting tuberculosis, which can result from repeated contact with infected patients. Nurses are also more prone to blood-borne pathogen infections, which can be explained by exposure while working. The susceptibility to occupational allergies can be explained by exposure to a range of chemicals. RELATED TO CLINICAL PRACTICE: It is not possible to develop specific occupational health programs without sound knowledge of nurses' health.

title: Do pediatricians apply the 2009 NASPGHAN-ESPGHAN guidelines for the diagnosis and treatment of gastroesophageal reflux after receiving training?
abstract: BACKGROUND: According to a recent study, the 2009 North American Pediatric Gastroenterology, Hepatology and Nutrition-European Society for Pediatric Gastroenterology, Hepatology and Nutrition guidelines for gastroesophageal reflux are not adequately followed by European primary care pediatricians. The main issue that emerged from the survey was the unnecessary prescription of acid-suppressing drugs, especially in infants. There was no investigation into its causes. The primary aim of this study was to evaluate the applicability of the guidelines in European primary care pediatricians with specific training. METHODS: One hundred pediatricians who participated in the previous survey agreed to participate and were randomly divided into 2 groups: one group trained on guidelines via an online podcast and the other group trained via a summary. During the following 3 months, each pediatrician involved was asked to register each consecutive infant, child, or adolescent with obscene reflux symptoms. Pediatricians filled out a report on diagnosis and treatment options for each registered patient. RESULTS: A total of 382 patients (boys/girls 186/196, infants/children/adolescents 194/123/65) were enrolled by pediatricians. Infants with unexplained crying and/or distressed behavior who were given proton pump inhibitors were 3.7% (P < 0.05) compared to 45.2% of pre-training survey data. Infants with uncomplicated recurrent regurgitation and vomiting who were prescribed proton pump inhibitors were 4.5% versus 37.1% of baseline survey data (P < 0.05). The overall proportion of children managed in full compliance with guidelines was 46.1% after education compared to 1.8% before education (P < 0.05). There was no significant difference between pediatricians from the podcast and synopsis group. CONCLUSIONS: The North American Society of Pediatric Gastroenterology, Hepatology and Nutrition-European Society of Pediatric Gastroenterology, Hepatology and Nutrition gastroesophageal reflux guidelines currently have good applicability, although poorly followed by European primary care pediatricians. Simple, inexpensive training has been proven by pediatricians to be effective in increasing compliance. The increase in compliance clearly supports the role of continuing medical education through simple educational tools and subsequent practice evaluation.

title: Does polypillary lifestyle lead to neglect of risk factors? Findings from an individual participant data meta-analysis among 3140 patients at high risk of cardiovascular disease
abstract: OBJECTIVE: The aim of this study was to investigate whether polypill-based care for cardiovascular disease (CVD) prevention is associated with a change in lifestyle risk factors compared with usual care in patients with CVD or high estimated cardiovascular risk. METHODS: We performed a meta-analysis of individual participant data from three studies involving patients from Australia, England, India, Ireland, the Netherlands and New Zealand, comparing a strategy using a polypill containing aspirin, statins and antihypertensive therapy with regular care. those at high risk for a previous CVD event or initial event. The analyzes looked for any differential effects on anthropometric measures and the person's reported lifestyle behaviors. RESULTS: Among 3140 patients (75% male, mean age 62 years and 76% with prior CVD event), there was no difference in lifestyle risk factors for those randomized to polypill-based therapy compared to usual care for a median of 15 months, either all combined. among participants or within a number of subgroups. Also, narrow confidence intervals (CIs) excluded any significant effects";" for example, differences between groups in body mass index were -0.1 (95% CI -0.2 to 0.1) kg/m(2), duration of moderate-intensity physical activity per week was -2 (-26 to 23) minutes, and the proportion was 16% for smokers at the end of the trial. versus 17% (RR 0.98, 0.84 to 1.15). CONCLUSION: This analysis addresses the concern that polypill-based care may lead to neglect of lifestyle risk factors, at least in high-risk patients. Maximally effective preventive approaches should address lifestyle factors alongside pharmaceutical interventions, as recommended by major international guidelines.

title: Documentation-based clinical decision support to improve antibiotic prescribing for acute respiratory infections in primary care: a cluster randomized controlled trial.
abstract: Background and purpose Clinical guidelines do not recommend prescribing antibiotics for many acute respiratory tract infections (ARI), especially for appropriate non-antibiotic diagnoses. Electronic health record (EHR)-based clinical decision support has the potential to improve antibiotic prescribing for ARIs. Methods We randomly assigned 27 primary care clinics to receive or provide usual care – the EHR-integrated, documentation-based clinical decision support system – the ARI Smart Form – for the care of patients with ARI. The primary outcome was the rate of prescribing antibiotics for ARIs in an interventional analysis based on administrative diagnoses. Results During the intervention period, patients made 21 961 ARI visits to study clinics. Intervention clinicians used the ARI Smart Form in 6% of 11 954 ARI visits. The rate of prescribing antibiotics in intervention clinics was 43% versus 39% in control clinics (odds ratio (OR), 0.8"; 95% confidence interval (CI), adjusted for clustering by clinic 0.6_1.2). Antibiotic prescribing rate for appropriate ARI diagnoses was 54% in intervention clinics and 59% in control clinics (OR, 0.8; 95% CI, 0.5_1.3). (OR, 0.9; 95% CI, 0.6_1.4) When the ARI Smart Form was used, the rate of antibiotic prescribing was 49% based on diagnoses entered in the form, overall, 88% for antibiotic-appropriate diagnoses and 27% for non-antibiotic appropriate diagnoses. In one analysis used, the ARI Smart Form was associated with a lower rate of antibiotic prescribing for acute bronchitis (OR, 0.5; 95% CI, 0.3_0.8). Results The ARI Smart Form neither reduced overall antibiotic prescription nor significantly improved the appropriateness of antibiotic prescribing for ARIs, but it is not widely used. When using the ARI Smart Form, it can improve diagnostic accuracy and reduce the prescription of antibiotics for certain diagnoses compared to administrative diagnoses.

title: Does collaborative development and dissemination of multidisciplinary guidelines improve prescribing behavior: a pre/post study and randomized trial with concurrent control group
abstract: BACKGROUND: It is difficult to maintain control over prescribing behavior in general practice. The aim of this study was to evaluate the effects of the dissemination strategy of multidisciplinary guidelines on the volume of drug prescribing. METHODS: The study included two designs, a quasi-experimental pre/post study with a concurrent control group, and a randomized GP sample within the intervention group. The intervention area with 53 GPs was compared with a randomly selected control group of 54 GPs in the south and center of the Netherlands. In addition, a randomization was performed in the intervention group to create two arms, with 27 GPs more heavily involved in the development of the guideline and 26 GPs in the control group. A multidisciplinary committee developed prescription guidelines. These guidelines were then distributed to all GPs in the intervention area. Additional effects were examined in the subgroup study, in which GPs were invited to participate more intensively in the guideline development procedure. The guidelines included 14 recommendations on antibiotics, asthma/COPD medications, and cholesterol medications. The main outcome measures were prescription data over a three-year period (one year before and 2 years after guideline release) and rate of change from recommendations. RESULTS: Significant short-term improvements were seen for one recommendation: mupirocin. Long-term changes in cholesterol drug prescriptions have been found. No additional changes were seen in the subgroup for the randomized controlled trial. Family physicians did not accept the invitation to participate. CONCLUSION: The dissemination of multidisciplinary guidelines developed in a region does not have a clear impact on prescribing behavior, although GPs and specialists are more heavily involved in their development. It seems that more effort is needed to bring about change.

title: Does the collaborative development and dissemination of multidisciplinary guidelines improve prescribing behavior: a pre/post study and a randomized trial with concurrent control group.
abstract: Background It is difficult to maintain control over prescribing behavior in general practices. The aim of this study was to evaluate the effects of the dissemination strategy of multidisciplinary guidelines on the volume of drug prescribing. Methods The study included two designs, a quasi-experimental pre/post study with a concurrent control group, and a randomized GP sample within the intervention group. The intervention area with 53 GPs was compared with a randomly selected control group of 54 GPs in the south and center of the Netherlands. In addition, a randomization was performed in the intervention group to create two arms, with 27 GPs more heavily involved in the development of the guideline and 26 GPs in the control group. A multidisciplinary committee developed prescription guidelines. These guidelines were then distributed to all GPs in the intervention area. Additional effects were examined in the subgroup study, in which GPs were invited to participate more intensively in the guideline development procedure. The guidelines included 14 recommendations on antibiotics, asthma/COPD medications, and cholesterol medications. The main outcome measures were prescription data over a three-year period (one year before and 2 years after guideline release) and rate of change from recommendations. Results Significant short-term improvements were seen for one recommendation: mupirocin. Long-term changes in cholesterol drug prescriptions have been found. No additional changes were seen in the subgroup for the randomized controlled trial. Family physicians did not accept the invitation to participate. Conclusion The dissemination of multidisciplinary guidelines developed within a region has not had a clear impact on prescribing behavior, although GPs and specialists are more heavily involved in their development. It seems that more effort is needed to bring about change.

title: Does methadone maintenance therapy based on new national guidelines work in primary care?
abstract: BACKGROUND: General practitioners (GPs) are being encouraged to treat more drug users, but there are few studies demonstrating the effectiveness of primary care treatment. OBJECTIVE: To determine whether patients continue methadone maintenance therapy for one year in a modern British primary care setting with prescribing protocols based on new national guidelines, using objective outcome measures to determine if they can achieve harm reduction results similar to those shown in other settings. available. STUDY DESIGN: Longitudinal cohort study. SETTING: Primary Care Clinic for Drug Addiction, Sheffield. METHODS: The intervention consisted of a methadone maintenance therapy provided by GPs with prescribing protocols based on 1999 national guidelines. The first 96 consenting patients were included in the treatment";" Completed 65 studies. Outcomes were current drug use, HIV risk-taking behavior, social functioning, criminal activity, and mental and physical health, supported by urinalysis and criminal record data. RESULTS: Heroin use frequency ranged from 3.02 episodes per day (standard deviation [SD] = 1.73), mean 0.22 episodes per day (SD = 0.54), (chi 2 = 79.48, degrees of freedom [df] ] = 2, P < 0.001), confirmed by urinalysis. The average number of convictions and strikes for all offenses was reduced by 62% (z = 3,378, P < 0.001). HIV risk-taking behavior, social functioning, and physical and psychological well-being all showed significant improvements. CONCLUSION: Patients who continue methadone maintenance therapy in primary care for one year can generally achieve a range of harm reduction outcomes similar to those shown in studies in other higher-structured programs.

title: Does Publication Bias Inflate the Apparent Effectiveness of Psychological Treatment for Major Depressive Disorder? A Systematic Review and Meta-Analysis of US National Health Funded Research Institutes
abstract: BACKGROUND: The efficacy of antidepressant drugs has been shown to be empirically overestimated due to publication bias, but this has been statistically excluded only for the psychological treatment of depression. We directly evaluated the extent of study publication bias in studies examining the effectiveness of psychological treatment for depression. METHODS AND RESULTS: We identified US National Institutes of Health grants awarded during 1972–2008 to fund randomized clinical trials comparing psychological treatment with control conditions or other treatments in patients diagnosed with major depressive disorder and determined whether these grants led to publications. . For unpublished studies, data were requested from researchers and included in meta-analyses. Thirteen (23.6%) of the 55 funded grants that started trials did not result in publication and the other two never started. Between comparisons with control conditions, adding unpublished studies (Hedges' g = 0.20"; CI95% -0.11~0.51; k = 6) to published studies (g = 0.52; 0.37~0.68; k = 20) reduced the psychotherapy effect size score (g = 0.39;" 0.08~0.70) estimate 25%. Furthermore, because outcome reporting bias cannot be quantified, these findings may overestimate the "true" effect of psychological treatment for depression. CONCLUSION: The effectiveness of psychological interventions for depression has been exaggerated in the published literature, just as in pharmacotherapy. Both are effective, but not to the extent suggested by the published literature. Funding organizations and journals should archive both original protocols and raw data from treatment trials to allow detection and correction of outcome reporting bias. Clinicians, guideline developers, and decision-makers should be aware that the published literature overestimates the effects of dominant treatments for depression.

title: Does screening and intervention for multiple health-compromising behavioral and mental health disorders among young people presenting to primary health care improve health outcomes? a systematic review
abstract: AIM: Adolescence and young adulthood are important developmental periods. Screening for health-threatening behaviors and mental health disorders during routine primary care visits has the potential to help clinicians identify areas of concern and provide appropriate interventions. The purpose of this systematic review is to explore whether screening and subsequent interventions for multiple health-compromising behaviors and mental health disorders in primary care settings improve youth health outcomes. METHODS: Using the Preferred Reporting Items for Systematic Reviews and Meta-Analysis (PRISMA) guidelines, a literature search was conducted using search terms representing four thematic concepts in the Medline, PsycINFO, Scopus, and Cochrane Library databases (Prospero registration number CRD4201305828): primary care, youth, screening and mental health and health-compromising behavior. To be eligible for inclusion, studies: "include a measure of health outcome; include at least 75% of participants under the age of 25; use a screening tool that assesses multiple health domains;" and should be conducted in a primary care setting. The risk of bias was assessed using the Quality Rating Scale. RESULTS: Of the 5051 identified articles, nine studies met the inclusion criteria and were reviewed: two randomized controlled trials (RCTs), one pilot RCT, two clustered RCTs, one randomized study with multiple intervention groups and no control group, one cluster RCT with two active arms. , a longitudinal study and a preliminary study. Seven studies, including two RCTs and one clustered RCT, found positive changes in substance use, diet, sexual health or risky sexual behavior, alcohol-related risk behavior, social stress, stress management, helmet use, sleep, and exercise. One of only two studies reporting harms reported that increased alcohol use was an adverse health outcome. CONCLUSIONS: There is some evidence that the use of youth screening and intervention for mental health disorders or health-compromising behaviors in clinical settings improves health outcomes. Along with other evidence that teens value discussing health risks with their providers, these discussions should be part of teens' routine primary care. More quality studies are needed to strengthen this evidence.

title: Does shared care help treat depression?
abstract: INTRODUCTION: Shared or Collaborative Care in the treatment of depression is an evidence-based intervention that has been shown to be more effective than the usual general Practitioner in the treatment of depression, but is not yet Government policy in the UK. We aimed to bring together all the studies conducted up to mid-2009 in one place to show the evidence that joint collaborative care has significant advantages in both depression outcomes and cost benefits. Adoption of this approach in the UK and n Europe. METHODS: We conducted a literature review using PUBMED to identify and describe all trials, systematic reviews, and Metaanalyses conducted on shared care up to mid-2009. In the late 1990s he engaged in development and work activities in Luton. We excluded articles describing trials that have not yet been performed and instead focused on reported trials. CONCLUSIONS: Numerous recent studies have shown shared care in the treatment of depression, which includes the training of General Practitioners in the treatment of depression and the provision of a Nurse in Primary Care or another professional to perform psychotherapy. education ensures compliance with drug therapy and can provide psychotherapy, leading to both improved treatment outcomes and increased physician and patient satisfaction, and also provides some cost-benefits despite somewhat increased immediate costs. This is true in both adult and adolescent patients, whereas depression improves in diabetic patients, although there is no improvement in glycemic control. The joint care intervention remains beneficial in patients with persistent depressive symptoms, but in such cases a longer input will be required. Patients with sub-threshold depression would not see as much benefit, and patients expressed greater satisfaction when psychological interventions were offered. It is also a condition in which collaborative or shared care is effective in treating depression in the elderly. This has also been demonstrated in studies of elderly patients, the poorer, those with suicidal ideation, as well as Ethnic Minorities, who also suffer from multiple health conditions, arthritis, diabetes, anxiety and PTSD. CONCLUSION: The results described above are mostly based on studies conducted in the USA, but similar studies have been reported from the UK and are consistent with the service experience in Luton that we have described. Based on these results, it is seen that collaborative care, shared with primary and secondary health care doctors (General Practitioners and Psychiatrists) as part of a single team, with the help of affiliated mental health practitioners in primary care, but with easy access to health services, is important. Second-line care is an efficient way to optimize depression treatment. In the UK, however, it has not yet been possible to develop such a service for the entire population. This is because in the UK General Practice is managed by Primary Care Trusts and Secondary Care, including Psychiatry, by Mental Health Trusts. This has prompted the National Institute of Health and Clinical Excellence, and indeed local care commissioners, to focus on the Cascading Model for depression treatment; A key issue is access to secondary care (or referral) and discharge back to primary care. focuses on facilitating (or keeping doors on) these processes, rather than focusing on truly optimizing the outcomes of care with a group of Mental Health professionals. CONCLUSION: Evidence advocates the development of collaborative care between primary and secondary care for the treatment of Depression. This will require common medication guidelines in both Primary and Secondary Care, easy access for Practitioners to get advice about patients from Psychiatrists, and the use of Mental Health Professionals to provide patients with psychoeducation, adherence support and psychotherapy. . To achieve this, services may need to be restructured to allow easy communication between professionals.

title: Does therapeutic writing help people with long-term conditions? Systematic review, realistic synthesis and economic considerations
abstract: BACKGROUND: Writing therapy to improve physical or mental health can take many forms. The most researched model of therapeutic writing (TW) is unfacilitated, individual expressive writing (written emotional disclosure). Streamlined writing activities are less explored. DATA SOURCES: Databases searched from baseline to March 2013 (updated January 2015), including MEDLINE, EMBASE, PsycINFO, Linguistics and Language Behavior Abstracts, Allied and Complementary Medicine Database, and Cumulative Index to Nursing and Allied Health Literature. REVIEW METHODS: Four TW practitioners provided expert advice. Working procedures were conducted by a reviewer and checked for a second. Randomized controlled trials (RCTs) and nonrandomized comparative studies were included. Quality was assessed using the Cochrane risk of bias tool. Non-facilitated and facilitated TW studies are analyzed separately under the chapter titles International Classification of Diseases, Tenth Revision. Meta-analyses were performed using RevMan version 5.2.6 where available (RevMan 2012, The Cochrane Collaboration, The Nordic Cochrane Centre, Copenhagen, Denmark). Costs were estimated from the UK NHS perspective and three cost-outcome case studies were prepared. Realist synthesis followed the Realist and Meta-narrative Synthesis of Evidence: Emerging Standards guidelines. OBJECTIVES: To review the clinical efficacy and cost-effectiveness of TW for individuals with long-term conditions (LTCs) compared to any paper or other controls, reporting any relevant clinical results. Carrying out a realistic synthesis to understand how and for whom TW can work. RESULTS: From 14,658 unique citations, 284 full-text articles were reviewed and 64 studies (59 RCTs) were included in the final efficacy reviews. Five studies that facilitated TW were reviewed", which were highly heterogeneous with unclear or high risk of bias, but suggested that facilitated TW interventions may be beneficial in individual LTCs. Non-facilitated significant typing was reviewed in 59 studies of variable or unreported quality. Overall, very Little or no evidence of any benefit in the following conditions (number of studies): human immunodeficiency virus (six), breast cancer (eight), gynecological and genitourinary cancers (five), mental health (five), asthma (four) ); psoriasis (three) and chronic pain (four) There was a reduction in disease severity in inflammatory arthropathies (six) [n = 191, standardized mean difference (SMD) -0.61, 95% confidence interval (CI) -0.96 to - 0.26] short term in a meta-analysis of four studies No or sparse or inconsistent data for all other LTCs Unfacilitated emotional writing, short (n = 1563, SMD -0.06, 95% CI -0.29 to 0.17, forward significant heterogeneity) or long-term (n = 778, SMD -0.04 95% CI -0.18 to 0.18) depression. 0.10, small heterogeneity) follow-up or anxiety, physiological or biomarker-based outcomes. One study reported cost, no study reported cost-effectiveness, and 12 studies reported resource utilization,” and the meta-analysis suggested that drug use decreased but had no effect on health center visits. Estimated intervention costs were low, but there was insufficient evidence to judge cost. -efficacy Realistic synthesis findings suggested that facilitated TW is a complex intervention and group interaction contributes to perceived benefit. It was not clear from the available data who could benefit most from facilitated TW. CONCLUSIONS: Overall, there is little evidence to support the therapeutic efficacy or cost-effectiveness of unfacilitated meaningful writing interventions in people with LTCs. More research focusing on facilitated TW in people with LTCs may be informative. : This work is registered as PROSPERO CRD420120033. 43. FUNDING: National Institute of Health Research Health Technology Assessment program.

title: Dominant inheritance of intracranial berry aneurysm
Dressings for venous leg ulcers: systematic review and meta-analysis
abstract: OBJECTIVE To review the evidence for the efficacy of dressings applied to venous leg ulcers. DESIGN Systematic review and meta-analysis. DATA SOURCES Manual search of journals and electronic databases, conference proceedings, and bibliographies through April 2006"; contacts with dressing manufacturers for unpublished studies. STUDIES REVIEWED All randomized controlled trials evaluating dressings for venous leg ulcers were eligible for inclusion. Data from eligible studies , extracted and summarized independently by two reviewers using a data extraction sheet Methodological quality assessed independently by two reviewers RESULTS Search strategy identified 254 studies, 42 of which met inclusion criteria Hydrocolloids were no more effective than simple low-adhesive dressings used under compression (eight trials; 'relative risk for healing with hydrocolloid 1.02, 95% confidence interval 0.83 to 1.28). For other comparisons, insufficient evidence was available to allow firm conclusions to be drawn. None of the dressing comparisons showed evidence that a particular class of dressing healed more ulcers. There were some differences between dressings in subjective outcome measures and ulcer healing rates. The results were not affected by the size or quality of the studies or the randomization unit. Insufficient data were available to allow conclusions about the relative cost-effectiveness of different dressings. CONCLUSIONS The type of dressing applied under compression has not been shown to affect ulcer healing. The results of the meta-analysis showed that application of hydrocolloid dressings under compression provided no benefit in terms of ulcer healing compared to application of simple low-adhesive dressings. No firm recommendation can be made as to which type of dressing is the most cost-effective. Decisions about which dressing to apply should be based on the local costs of dressings and the preferences of the practitioner or patient.

title: Driving simulators for occupational therapy screening, assessment and intervention
abstract: Simulation technology provides reliable, objective and repeatable performance measures of operational (for example, avoiding a collision) or tactical (for example, lane maintenance) driver behavior. Many occupational therapy researchers and others use driving simulators to test various applications in different populations. A growing body of literature provides support for the relationships between simulated driving and real road driving. One limitation of simulator technology is the occurrence of simulator disease, but management strategies exist to reduce or mitigate its onset. Based on the literature review and a consensus process, five consensus statements are presented to support the use of driving simulation technology among occupational therapy practitioners. Evidence suggests that occupational therapy practitioners can use driving simulators to identify underlying impairments in driving performance, identify driving errors in at-risk drivers; can distinguish the driving performance of disabled and healthy control groups; alleviates the onset of roadworks and simulator sickness. Much progress has been made among occupational therapy researchers and practitioners in the use of driving simulation technology; however, empirical support is needed to further justify the use of driving simulators in clinical practice settings as a valid, reliable, clinically useful and cost-effective tool for driving assessment and intervention.

title: Pharmaceutical formulas in hospitals
Medication and patient rights
abstract: Challenging a hypersensitive patient with a potentially harmful drug is crucial to the advancement of medical knowledge. However, it does not always serve the interests of a particular patient. In order to protect the interests of an individual patient, one should avoid challenge unless it is vital to the health of a particular patient at the time and has no substitute. All aspects of patient rights require the establishment of limitations and guidelines for the re-admission procedure. An approach that will bring physicians closer to a solution and protect the patient from uncontrolled decisions and unnecessary risks is recommended.

title: Medication use and the role of patients and prescribers
abstract: Research methods need to be expanded to move towards rational drug use in any national or local setting. Both the public and private sectors should be addressed. In the second, the pharmacists, the audience, can be studied using an imaginary customer. Drug knowledge, an important factor influencing prescribing, has rarely been scientifically evaluated. However, experimental studies using group randomization are possible even in developing countries. The focus of drug research should be on individuals as individuals, and health and wellness should be at the forefront.
