The combination of qualitative and quantitative methods will help us achieve rational drug use that is culturally acceptable, economically viable, and pharmacologically sound."; PIP: In an effort to improve rational drug use in local or national settings, particularly in developing countries, the behavior of prescribers and users is the most It is the subject of little research. The effectiveness of drugs depends on a complex set of factors related to prescribing and purchasing status. One issue that needs to be examined is the information provided to prescribers by drug advertisers and detailers. A shortcoming that has been addressed by an international network of prescribers. In many countries, drugs The biggest outlet for pharmacies is private sector pharmacies, where drugs are often dispensed without a prescription. A simple and inexpensive way to study prescription behavior is to use phantom trackers to track case management of specific conditions such as infant diarrhea There are many factors involved in the prescription ;" The process should be studied with an epidemiological approach, namely through identification, analysis, intervention and evaluation. Standardized treatment programs, essential drug lists, treatment guidelines, and targeted intervention should be overseen by local therapeutic committees. Pharmaceutical information should also be evaluated scientifically with the same analytical principles. The experimental method of group randomization is recommended as a viable choice for developing countries. In this technique, groups of doctors are observed or interviewed and quantitative outcome data are collected. The behavior of individual users is best studied from a case study perspective, combining anthropological and biomedical approaches. An example of a challenge with this approach is the possible use of shorter courses of antibiotic therapy to reduce the risk of developing resistant organisms.

title: MEDICINE system that increases the adherence of Chinese surgeons to antibiotic use guidelines in the perioperative period
abstract: OBJECTIVE: The irrational use of antimicrobial agents to prevent postoperative SSIs is a common phenomenon in China, resulting in greater bacterial resistance, higher nosocomial infection rates, and the extra costs of antimicrobial agents. The aim of this study was to evaluate the effect of the Rational Drug Use Guidelines System (DRUGS) on the surgeon's antimicrobial agent prescribing behavior. METHODS: Ten common surgical operations including 1543 cases (778 cases using paper-based guidelines and 765 cases using MEDICINE) were selected and demographic and clinical data were collected. Selected operations are thyroid resection, breast mass resection, myomectomy etc. includes. Evaluation criteria were antibiotic administration categories, starting dose, duration of administration, length of stay, antibiotic costs, SSIs, and drug adverse events (ADRs). . RESULTS: Antimicrobial agents were mostly administered 0.5 to 2 hours before the incision, 656 patients (85.75%) were treated with MEDICINE and 256 (32.90%) patients were treated with paper-based guidelines according to the protocol. For clean wound incision, 547 patients (91.62%) were within 24 hours of discontinuing antibiotics when paper-based guidelines were used, while 91 patients (14.79%) were using DRUGS. A total of 19 types of antibiotics were used in 1543 cases. Piperacillin and sulbactam sodium, cefatiamidine and cefoperazone took the first three places in the frequency list. After the intervention, the frequency list was changed to cefazolin, cefatiamidine, and cefoperazone. Mean length of stay in hospital was (7.00+/-4.31)d with paper-based guidelines and (2.54+/-1.57)d with DRUGS, respectively. The average cost of antibiotics in paper-based guidelines was yen(3481.36+/-2584.46) and MEDICINES and yen(1693.39+/-1478.27), respectively. However, there was no significant difference in the incidence of CAE and ADR between the two groups. CONCLUSION: In this study, the increased availability of antibiotic guidelines along with DRUGS during drug ordering was associated with greater surgeon adherence to guidelines.

title: Lasting improvements in prostate cancer screening from online interval training in a randomized controlled trial
abstract: CONTEXT: Prostate-specific antigen (PSA) screening for prostate cancer is frequently performed in violation of clinical practice guidelines. BACKGROUND: It has been hypothesized that an email-based intervention called "interval education" could reduce clinicians' inappropriate screening for prostate cancer. DESIGN: The study was conducted as an RCT. SETTING/PARTICIPANTS: The study included 95 primary care clinicians at eight Veterans Affairs medical centers from January 2007 to February 2009. Intervention: Participants were divided into two cohorts: interval training clinicians received four isomorphic cycles of nine emails (zero) over 36 weeks. two e-mails a week), control clinicians did not receive any intervention. Each email presented a clinical scenario and asked if it was appropriate to have a PSA test. Participants received feedback immediately after submitting their responses. MAIN OUTCOME MEASURES: The primary outcome was the number and percentage of inappropriate PSA screening tests ordered. Inappropriate testing was defined as the use of PSA for prostate cancer screening in patients >76 or <40 years of age. The suitability of the screening was divided into two according to the age of the patient at the time of screening. Patients undergoing PSA testing for non-screening reasons were excluded using a validated protocol. Adjusted logistic regression for patient clustering was performed by the clinician. Analyzes were made in 2009. RESULTS: Clinicians who received interval training emails during the intervention period (Weeks 1-36) requested significantly fewer inappropriate PSA screening tests than control clinicians (14.2% versus 10.5%, p=0.041). During the 72-week period following the intervention (Wks 37–108), interval training clinicians continued to order fewer inappropriate tests compared to controls (7.8% and 13.1%, p=0.011, respectively), resulting in a relative inappropriateness of 40%. represents the decrease. scanning. CONCLUSIONS: Interval education permanently improves clinicians' prostate cancer screening behaviors and represents a promising new methodology for improving patient care across healthcare systems.

title: Dynamic distribution of happiness in a major social network: longitudinal analysis over 20 years in the Framingham Heart Study
abstract: OBJECTIVES To assess whether happiness spreads from person to person and whether happiness niches are formed in social networks. DESIGN Longitudinal social network analysis. SET The Framingham Heart Study social network. PARTICIPANTS 4739 people were followed from 1983 to 2003. MAIN OUTCOME MEASURES Happiness measured on a validated four-item scale";" broad features of social networks and their various social ties. RESULTS Clusters of happy and unhappy people can be seen in the network, and the relationship between people's happiness extends to three degrees (for example, a friend's friend's friend's). People who are surrounded by many happy people and are central to waxing are more likely to be happy in the future. Longitudinal statistical models suggest that clusters of happiness arise not simply from people's tendency to associate with similar individuals, but from the spread of happiness. A friend who lives within a mile (about 1.6 km) and is happy increases a person's probability of being happy by 25% (95% confidence interval 1 to 57%). Similar effects are seen in spouses living in the same household (8%, 0.2% to 16%), siblings living within a mile (14%, 1% to 28%), and next-door neighbors (34%, 7% to 70%). No effects are seen among co-workers. The impact diminishes with time and geographic separation. RESULTS People's happiness depends on the happiness of others they depend on. This provides further justification for viewing happiness, like health, as a collective phenomenon.

title: Dyslipidemia in primary care -- prevalence, recognition, treatment and control: data from the German Metabolic and Cardiovascular Risk Project (GEMCAS)
abstract: BACKGROUND: Current guidelines from the European Society of Cardiology (ESC) define low thresholds for the diagnosis of dyslipidemia using total cholesterol (TC) and LDL-cholesterol (LDL-C) to guide treatment. Although primarily a prevention tool, its thresholds are difficult to meet in clinical practice, especially in primary care. METHODS: We determined the prevalence, diagnosis, treatment, and control rates of dyslipidemia in a nationwide study of 1,511 primary care physicians and 35,869 patients. The diagnosis of dyslipidemia was based on TC and LDL-C. Basic descriptive statistics and prevalence rates and 95% confidence intervals were calculated. RESULTS: Dyslipidemia was quite common in primary care (76% overall). 48.6% of male patients and 39.9% of female patients with dyslipidemia were diagnosed by doctors. However, lifestyle intervention controlled dyslipidemia in only 10% of patients. A higher proportion (34.1% of men and 26.7% of women) were controlled while receiving pharmacotherapy. The chances of being diagnosed and subsequently controlled with pharmacotherapy were higher in men (PRR 1.15"; 95% CI 1.12-1.17), in patients with concomitant cardiovascular risk factors, in patients with hypertension (PRR 1.20; 95% CI 1.05-1.37) and cardiovascular about the disease (PRR 1.46; 95% CI 1.29-1.64), previous myocardial infarction (PRR 1.32; 95% CI 1.19-1.47), and previous myocardial infarction if patients know or know they are hypertensive (PRR 1.18; 95% CI 1.04-1.34) ( PRR 1.17;"95% CI 1.23-1.53). CONCLUSION: The thresholds of ESC seem difficult to meet. A simple call for more aggressive treatment or higher patient compliance is apparently not enough to increase the proportion of controlled patients. Transitioning to a multifactorial treatment that considers lifestyle interventions and pharmacotherapy to reduce weight and lipids may be the only way forward in a population where just being normal is not strictly ideal.

title: Early administration of aspirin in patients treated with alteplase for acute ischemic stroke: a randomized controlled trial.
abstract: Background Thrombolysis with intravenous alteplase is the only approved therapy for acute ischemic stroke. After recanalization by alteplase, reocclusion occurs in 14-34% of patients, probably due to platelet activation. Early administration of antiplatelet therapy after alteplase can reduce the risk of reocclusion and improve outcome. We compared the effects of early addition of intravenous aspirin to alteplase with standard alteplase without aspirin.";" Background Thrombolysis with intravenous alteplase is the only approved therapy for acute ischemic stroke. After recanalization by alteplase, reocclusion occurs in 14-34% of patients, probably due to platelet activation. Early administration of antiplatelet therapy after alteplase can reduce the risk of reocclusion and improve outcome. We compared the effects of early addition of intravenous aspirin to alteplase with standard alteplase without aspirin.

title: Early coverage, access, use, and health implications of affordable care law medicaid expansions: A quasi-experimental study.
abstract: Background In 2014, only 26 states and DC chose to apply Affordable Care Act (ACA) Medicaid expansions for low-income adults. Purpose To estimate whether State Medicaid expansions are associated with changes in insurance coverage, access to and benefit from health care, and self-reported health. Design Comparison of results before and after expansions in states that did and did not expand Medicaid. Identification of U.S. Respondents In the 2010Â¨C2014 National Health Interview Surveys, 19Â¨C64-year-olds with a family income below 138% of the Federal Poverty Level. Metrics Health insurance coverage (private, Medicaid, uninsured); health insurance better than last year; visits with GPs and specialists; hospitalizations and emergency room visits; medical care missed or delayed; source of usual care; diagnosis of diabetes, high cholesterol, and hypertension, self-reported health status, and depression Outcomes In the second half of 2014, low-income adults in enlargement states experienced increases in health insurance (7.4 percentage points; 95% CI, ?11.3 to ?3.4) and Medicaid. (10.5 percentage points; 95% CI, 6.5 to 14.5) coverage and improved quality of insurance coverage compared to one year ago (7.1 percentage points; 95% CI, 2.7 to 11.5) Medicaid Medicaid expansions, increased visits to physicians in general practice (6.6 percentage points; 95% CI, 1.3 to 12.0), overnight hospital stays (2.4 percentage points; 95% CI, 0, 0, 0, 0, 6) compared to adults in states that did not expand . 7 to 4.2) and meats (5.2 percentage points; 95% CI, 2 .4 to 8.1) and high cholesterol (5.7 percentage points); 95% CI, 2.0 to 9.4); changes in other results were not statistically significant. Limitations The observational study may be sensitive to unmeasured confounders; based on self-reported data;" limited post-ACA time frame provides information on short-term changes only. Results ACA Medicaid expansions, higher insurance coverage rates, improved coverage quality, greater utilization of some health care services, and higher chronic chronic disease for low-income adults health conditions diagnosis rates.

title: Early detection and intervention evaluation for people at risk for psychosis: a multisite randomized controlled trial.
abstract: OBJECTIVE To determine whether cognitive therapy is effective in preventing the worsening of psychotic symptoms experienced when young people who are thought to be at risk for serious conditions such as schizophrenia seek help. DESIGN Multisite single-blind randomized controlled trial. SET A variety of services at five UK sites. PARTICIPANTS 288 participants aged 14-35 years (mean 20.74, SD 4.34 years) at high risk of psychosis: 144 were assigned to cognitive therapy plus mental status monitoring and 144 to mental status monitoring only. Participants were followed for a minimum of 12 months and a maximum of 24 months. INTERVENTION Cognitive therapy (up to 26 (mean 9.1) sessions over six months) plus mental status monitoring compared to mental status monitoring alone. MAIN OUTCOME MEASURES The primary outcome is scores for the comprehensive assessment of mental states at risk (CAARMS), which provides a dual pass to the psychosis score and provides ordinal scores for severity of psychotic symptoms and distress. Secondary outcomes included emotional dysfunction and quality of life. RESULTS Transition to intent-to-treat psychosis was analyzed using discrete-time survival models. Overall, the crossover prevalence was lower than expected (23/288";" 8%), with no significant difference between the two groups (proportional odds ratio 0.73, 95% confidence interval 0.32 to 1.68). Changes in the severity of symptoms and distress and secondary outcomes were analyzed using random effects regression (analysis of covariance) adjusted for region and baseline symptoms. Distress from psychotic symptoms was not different (estimated difference -3.00 at 12 months, 95% confidence interval -6.95 to 0.94), but their severity was significantly reduced in the group assigned to cognitive therapy (predicted -3.67, -6.71 to - 12 months group effect size). 0.64, P=0.018). RESULTS Cognitive therapy plus monitoring did not significantly reduce transition to psychosis or symptom-related distress, but did reduce the severity of psychotic symptoms in young people at high risk. Most participants in both groups improved over time. The results have important implications for the concept of mental state at risk. TRIAL REGISTRATION Controlled Trials Available ISRCTN56283883.

title: Early detection of autism spectrum disorders: screening between 12 and 24 months
abstract: OBJECTIVE: The purpose of this article is to provide information to nurse practitioners (NPs) about screening for autism spectrum disorders (ASDs) in children 12 to 24 months old. Appropriate referrals and recommendations for initiating early intervention (EI) are also provided. DATA SOURCES: A review of the published literature on ASD. CONCLUSIONS: Children with ASD exhibit impaired social interaction, deficiencies in verbal and nonverbal communication, and repetitive, limited, and stereotyped patterns of behavior or interest. Research shows that these children benefit from starting intense emotional intelligence as soon as possible. APPLICATIONS FOR IMPLEMENTATION: Early diagnosis ensures that children with suspected ASD are evaluated by specialists and included in treatment programs as soon as possible. Because of the importance of early diagnosis of ASD, it is crucial that NPs use built-in screening tools to maximize time and increase reliability of assessment.

title: Early photography, goiter and James Inglis
Early education in combating patient obesity: a systematic review of nurse education.
abstract: OBJECTIVE: This systematic review aims to identify studies evaluating obesity-related educational interventions in undergraduate nursing education and to investigate the effectiveness of interventions. BACKGROUND: Obesity is a leading global problem and nurses have an increasing role in weight management with patients. The literature has described a variety of theory-based behavior modification techniques that have successfully aided weight management in patients. Therefore, educating nurses in behavior modification techniques related to obesity is appropriate in preparing them for their future professional roles. However, the effectiveness of these educational interventions has yet to be evaluated. METHODS: Center for Review and Dissemination guidelines informed this systematic review. Four databases were systematically searched and articles were evaluated according to inclusion criteria. Data extraction and quality assessment forms were developed and completed to identify salient features in the articles. RESULTS: Eight studies met inclusion criteria. Only two, one of which was a randomized controlled trial, included both baseline and outcome measures. In addition, only one study included a clearly defined behavior modification technique. Interventions were performed by a range of methods, but quality assessment showed that all of the studies had poor methodologies and were at high risk of bias. CONCLUSIONS: Studies in this research area are sparse and methodologically inconsistent. Therefore, it is not possible to identify effective educational interventions for weight management for nursing students. APPLICATIONS: More robust research is needed to explore how nurses can be trained to facilitate weight management. Greater transparency in definitions of intervention, particularly what behavior modification techniques are taught, will allow for replication and appropriate evaluation. Until then, it was unknown whether current teaching adequately equips nurses to manage obese and overweight patients.

title: Early treatment of migraine attacks with triptans: a strategy to improve outcomes and patient satisfaction?
abstract: Treating migraine attacks early with triptans may be more effective than late administration of triptans. However, in published studies, the definition of 'early' has varied (in terms of time, pain intensity, or presence of allodynia) or is unclear. Therefore, clear clinical indications have not been established. Appropriately designed essays to address this issue remain a priority. Early treatment with triptans can also have disadvantages, such as the inadvertent treatment of tension-type headaches and the danger of drug overuse. Currently, only migraine sufferers with rapid worsening of pain, a high recurrence rate of pain, and clinical signs of allodynia should be encouraged to take triptans as soon as possible. This recommendation implies a requirement for patient education and the need to carefully tailor treatment to individual needs.

title: Eating disorders in children and adolescents: pharmacological treatments
abstract: Anorexia nervosa and bulimia nervosa are present in childhood, often begin in adolescence, and can result in serious medical and psychiatric sequelae that impede physical, emotional, and behavioral development. Although we use the same Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders-Version 4 [DSM-IV] definitions to diagnose eating disorders in children, adolescents, and adults, these disorders may be expressed slightly differently in younger populations, requiring evaluation and treatment procedures. tailored to their developmental needs. In recent years, significant progress has been made in our understanding of treatments for eating disorders in adults, and especially pharmacological treatments for these disorders. Multiple double-blind, placebo-controlled studies have documented the short-term effectiveness of antidepressant medications in bulimia nervosa. While the benefit of pharmacological treatments for the acute treatment of anorexia nervosa is less clear, recent evidence suggests a role for the drug in preventing relapse. Most drug trials for eating disorders have been conducted with adults, and the literature on the pharmacological treatment of children and adolescents with these disorders is very limited. This review article summarizes the current literature on the role of medication in the treatment of anorexia nervosa and bulimia nervosa, with particular emphasis on studies conducted in child and adolescent populations.

title: Eating disorders in the context of preconception care: knowledge, attitudes and clinical practice of fertility specialists
abstract: OBJECTIVE(S): To measure fertility specialists' knowledge, clinical practice, and training needs on eating disorders. DESIGN: Cross-sectional study. SETTINGS: Fertility clinics. PARTICIPANTS: Eighty Australian and New Zealand fertility specialists who are members of the Australian Fertility Association. INTERVENTION(S): None. MAIN RESULT MEASURES: Responses to an anonymously completed online questionnaire. CONCLUSION(s): Approximately 54% of physicians correctly defined the body mass index for anorexia nervosa, and 30% identified menstrual disturbances for anorexia, while 63.8% of physicians incorrectly described maladaptive weight control behaviors as binge eating disorder. identified as a feature. While clinicians (83.7%) agreed that it is important to screen for eating disorders during pre-pregnancy assessments, 35% were routinely screened for eating disorders and 8.8% stated that their clinics had clinical practice guidelines for the management of eating disorders. A small percentage of the participants (13.8%) felt satisfied with their level of university education in eating disorders, 37.5% of physicians were confident in their ability to recognize eating disorder symptoms, and 96.2% stated that further education and clinical guidelines were needed. Knowledge and clinical practice of eating disorders in most of the items examined did not differ by physician's gender or years of clinical experience working as a fertility specialist. CONCLUSION(s): It is important to have knowledge about eating disorders in the context of fertility treatment. This study highlights the uncertainty among fertility specialists in identifying characteristics of eating disorders. The findings point to the importance of further education and training, including the development of specific clinical guidelines for fertility health care providers.

title: Economic analyzes of the Be Fit Be Well program: a weight loss program for community health centers
abstract: BACKGROUND: The US Preventive Services Task Force has published new guidelines on obesity, encouraging primary care physicians to provide intensive, multi-component behavioral interventions to obese patients. However, there are very few real-world studies of weight loss in non-academic primary care settings, and even fewer in largely racial/ethnic minority, low-income samples. OBJECTIVE: To evaluate the recruitment, intervention, and repeat costs of a 2-year, moderate-intensity weight loss and blood pressure control intervention. DESIGN: A comprehensive cost analysis associated with a weight loss and hypertension management program delivered at three community health centers as part of a pragmatic randomized trial was conducted. PARTICIPANTS: Three hundred and sixty-five high-risk, low-income, inner-city, minority (71% Black/African-American and 13% Hispanic) patients who were both hypertensive and obese. MAIN MEASURES: Measures included total recruitment costs and intervention costs, cost per participant, and incremental costs per unit reduction in weight and blood pressure. KEY RESULTS: Recruitment and intervention costs for the 2-year program were calculated as $2,359 per participant. Compared with the control intervention, the cost per additional kilogram lost was $2,204/kg and for blood pressure $621/mmHg. Sensitivity analyzes show that if the program is presented to a larger sample and minor changes are made, the cost per participant can be reduced to the level of many commercially available products. RESULTS: The costs associated with the Be Fit Be Well program were found to be significantly more expensive than many commercially available products and much higher than what the Centers for Medicare and Medicaid paid physicians for obesity counseling. However, given the serious and costly health consequences associated with obesity in high-risk, multimorbid, and socioeconomically disadvantaged patients, the resources needed to provide interventions such as those described here may still prove cost-effective in terms of producing long-term behavior change.

title: Economic evaluation of implementation strategies in health care
abstract: Economic considerations can inform decisions about the allocation and efficiency of resources to implementation strategies clearly designed to inform care providers and patients about the best available research evidence and improve its use in their practice. These strategies are becoming increasingly popular in healthcare, particularly in light of growing concerns about the quality of care and the limits of resources. However, such concerns have scarcely motivated health officials and other decision-makers to spend money on some form of economic evaluation in their evaluation of implementation strategies. This editorial discusses the importance of economic evaluation in the context of applied science, particularly how these analyzes can be most effectively incorporated into decision-making regarding implementation strategies.

title: The economic implications of evidence-based prescribing for hypertension: Could better care cost less?
abstract: Context Deviation from evidence-based guidelines in the treatment of hypertension is common, but the economic impact has not been fully studied. Inadequate prescribing patterns contribute to high drug costs for older patients and the difficulty in providing affordable prescription drug benefits for older Americans. Objective To calculate potential savings from the health care payer perspective as a result of increased adherence to evidence-based recommendations for managing hypertension in patients older than 65 years. Design Comparative analysis of prescription drugs and potential regimens recommended by evidence-based guidelines tailored to each patient's medical history, calculating the costs of both actual and evidence-based regimens. Environment and Patients A total of 133,624 patients in 2001 who were treated for hypertension and enrolled in a large government pharmaceutical assistance program that provides prescription drug insurance for the elderly. Key Outcome Measure Cost difference between drugs actually prescribed and regimens recommended by evidence-based guidelines. Results The patients surveyed filled more than 2.05 million antihypertensive drug prescriptions in 2001 at an annual program cost of $48.5 million ($363 per patient). We identified 815 316 prescriptions (40%) in which an alternative regimen seemed more appropriate based on evidence-based recommendations. Such changes would have reduced the cost to payers by $11.6 million (about a quarter of the program spending on antihypertensive drugs) in 2001 and would have been more clinically relevant overall. Replacing calcium channel blockers resulted in the greatest potential savings. Using pricing limits similar to those in the Medicaid program could have resulted in even greater potential savings of $20.5 million (42% of program costs). Conclusions Adherence to evidence-based prescribing guidelines for hypertension can result in significant savings in prescription costs for elderly patients with hypertension, which will save approximately $1.2 billion nationally. Identifying similar areas where prescribing could be improved will be critical to the affordability of prescription drug benefit programs.

title: Editorial: Paroxysmal tachycardia in children
Editorial: research guidelines
Educational and organizational interventions to improve depression management in primary care: a systematic review.
abstract: CONTEXT: Depression is common in primary care, but is often overlooked or poorly managed. A number of organizational and educational strategies have been proposed to improve depression management. The clinical efficacy and cost-effectiveness of these strategies have yet to be systematically reviewed. OBJECTIVE: To systematically evaluate the effectiveness of organizational and educational interventions to improve depression management in primary care. DATA SOURCES: We searched electronic medical and psychological databases from inception to March 2003 (MEDLINE, PsycLIT, EMBASE, CINAHL, Cochrane Controlled Trials Register, United Kingdom National Health Service Economic Assessments Database, Cochrane Depression Anxiety and Neurosis Group register and Cochrane Influential Professional and Organizational Change Group expert registration)"; corresponded with authors;" and the reference lists used. The search terms were related to depression, primary health care, and all guidelines and organizational and educational interventions. STUDY SELECTION: We selected 36 studies, including 29 randomized controlled trials and non-randomized controlled clinical trials, 5 pre- and post-controlled trials, and 2 interrupted time series studies. Results regarding the management and outcomes of depression were investigated. DATA DRAWING: Methodological details and conclusions were drawn and checked by 2 reviewers. Where possible, summary relative risks were calculated from the original data and attempts were made to correct for unit of analysis error. DATA SYNTHESIS: A narrative synthesis has been made. Twenty-one studies were found with positive results. Effective strategies for improving patient outcomes are often those with complex interventions that include clinician training, the enhanced role of the nurse (nurse case management), and a higher degree of integration (counsel-linkage) between primary and secondary care. Telephone medication counseling by practice nurses or trained counselors was also effective. Simple guide application and training strategies were often ineffective. CONCLUSIONS: There is significant potential to improve depression management in primary care. Commonly used guidelines and training strategies are likely to be ineffective. Applying the findings from this research will require substantial investment in primary health care and a major shift in the organization and delivery of care.

title: Educational Intervention on Hepatitis B Vaccination Knowledge and Performance of Primary Care Assistants in Patients with Diabetes Mellitus
abstract: OBJECTIVES: Although guidelines recommend hepatitis B virus (HBV) immunization for adults with diabetes mellitus (DM), vaccination rates remain low. Our aim was to evaluate the knowledge and practices related to HBV and to evaluate the effectiveness of a versatile education program. METHODS: Primary care residents (n = 244) at three academic institutions were surveyed about various aspects of HBV. Residents in a training program were then randomly assigned to a training intervention (E) (n = 20) and a control group (C) (n = 19). Group E received periodic email reminders with a focused didactic lesson and immediate feedback. We compared the knowledge scores before and after the intervention. Chart inspections were carried out to assess the behavior of residents. RESULTS: A total of 103 people (42%) responded to the survey. The survey showed that residents lacked the necessary knowledge and risk assessment skills regarding HBV in patients with DM. In the controlled trial of intervention E, both groups had similar baseline knowledge scores. Group E showed a significant increase (65%";" P < 0.001) in knowledge scores immediately after intervention, from a mean of 29% at baseline to 70% (P < 0.001) maintained 6 months after intervention. In group C, 6-month post-intervention scores were not different from baseline (38% vs. 29%). No significant difference was observed in documentation skills. CONCLUSIONS: A combined education program was effective in increasing knowledge about HBV and vaccination in DM, but had limited impact on physician practice. More work is needed, including system changes with educational initiatives to improve clinical practice.

title: Educational interventions for general practitioners to identify and manage depression as a suicide risk factor in youth: a systematic review and meta-analysis protocol.
abstract: BACKGROUND: Suicide is a major public health problem and is the second leading cause of death in young adults globally. Globally, there are 164,000 suicides per year among young people under the age of 25. Depression is a strong risk factor for suicide. Evidence shows that 45% of those who complete suicide, including young adults, contacted their general practitioner rather than a mental health professional one month before their death. More evidence suggests that risk factors or early warning signs of suicide in young people go unnoticed and untreated by GPs. Healthcare-based suicide prevention interventions targeting general practitioners are designed to increase the detection of at-risk youth. The rationale for this type of intervention is that early identification of individuals at risk and improved clinical management will reduce morbidity and mortality. This systematic review will synthesize the evidence for the effectiveness of education interventions for general practitioners in identifying and managing depression as a suicide risk factor in youth. METHODS/DESIGN: We will conduct a systematic review and meta-analysis following the guidelines of the Cochrane Handbook for Systematic Reviews of Interventions and adhere to the reporting guidelines of the Preferred Reporting Items for Systematic Reviews and Meta-Analysis (PRISMA) reporting recommendations. Electronic databases will be systematically searched for randomized controlled trials and quasi-experimental studies investigating the efficacy of general practitioner interventions in identifying and managing depression as a suicide risk factor in youth compared with any intervention, no intervention, usual care or waiting. list. Gray literature will be searched by scanning trial records. Only studies published in English will be included. No date restrictions will be applied. Two authors will independently screen titles and abstracts of potential studies. The primary outcome is the identification and management of depression. Secondary outcomes were suicidal ideation, suicide attempts, intentional self-harm, knowledge of suicide risk factors and suicidal-related behaviors, attitudes toward suicide risk and suicidal-related behaviors, confidence in coping with suicide risk factors, and suicidal-related behaviors. CONCLUSION: Our study will inform the development of future educational interventions and provide evidence of feasibility and acceptability to help general practitioners identify and manage suicidal behavior in youth. SYSTEMATIC EXAMINATION REGISTRATION: PROSPPERO registration number: CRD42014009110.

title: Educational interventions to improve the prescribing and dispensing of antibiotics: a systematic review.
abstract: OBJECTIVE: Excessive and inappropriate use of antibiotics contributes to the increase of antibiotic resistance, which is an important public health problem. Strategies should be developed to improve antibiotic prescribing. Our aim is to review educational programs aimed at improving antibiotic prescribing by physicians and/or antibiotic delivery by pharmacists in both primary care and hospital settings. METHODS: We conducted a critical systematic search and review of the relevant literature published between January 2001 and December 2011 on educational programs aimed at improving antibiotic prescribing and dispensing practices in primary care and hospital settings. RESULTS: We identified 78 studies for analysis, 47 in primary care and 31 in hospital settings. Studies have reported mostly positive results, although they vary widely in design. Outcomes measured in the studies reviewed were adherence to guidelines, total or both of antibiotics prescribed, attitudes and behaviors related to antibiotic prescribing, and quality of pharmacy practice regarding antibiotics. Twenty-nine (62%) studies in primary care and twenty-four (78%) in a hospital setting reported positive outcomes for all measured outcomes”; fourteen (30%) studies in primary care and six (20%) in a hospital setting reported positive outcomes for some outcomes and for others, outcomes that were not statistically affected by the intervention; only four studies in primary care and one study in a hospital setting did not report significant post-intervention improvements for all outcomes. Behavioral changes related to antibiotic prescribing and improvement in the quality of pharmacy practice were observed in four studies and one study, respectively. CONCLUSION: The results indicate that antibiotic use can be improved with educational interventions, mostly multifaceted interventions.

title: Educational visitation and hypnotic prescribing in general practice
abstract: Public concern about prescribing hypnosedative drugs (mostly benzodiazepines) has led to a trial of a controlled educational intervention by general practitioners (GPs) to promote rational prescribing. This article describes the training intervention and process evaluation. In urban and rural New South Wales, 137 GPs were visited during office hours by a GP or pharmacist trained in communication skills. Materials available to GPs included a booklet of relaxation tapes and problem-focused management guides. The interview had three phases: alignment was achieved, then educational material was presented, and finally, the visitor sought physician approval to review five patients on long-term benzodiazepines. Visits were well received. Various measures have been created to reflect doctors' motivations and interests in non-drug therapy";" There was almost no relationship between any of these process measures and trial outcome: a change in prescribing behavior. Self-assessment of benzodiazepine prescribing greatly underestimated actual self-reported prescribing events. We interpret this as a reminder that we don't always do what we want to do and that we don't always do what we think we are doing.

title: The effect of computerized body mass index system on diagnosis and treatment of adult obesity.
abstract: Background: In obese adults, doctors often fail to detect obesity and prescribe treatment for it. We sought to determine whether requesting a computerized body mass index (BMI) chart would increase the likelihood that family physicians would refer patients for obesity diagnosis and treatment for obesity. Methods: A total of 846 obese patients from 37 family physicians were randomly assigned to either have a patient's BMI chart request placed in their electronic medical record (intervention group) or not have a BMI request in the registry (comparison group). . We then reviewed patient medical records for evidence of an obesity diagnosis and referral for specific obesity treatments. We also measured whether the presence of comorbidity in obese patients affects the likelihood of diagnosis and treatment by physicians. Results: Obese patients of physicians who had a BMI chart request in their medical record were significantly more likely to be diagnosed with obesity than obese patients from physicians who did not request a BMI chart (16.6% vs 10.7%";" P= .016). Patients of physicians who were given a BMI chart prompt were more likely to receive referrals for diet therapy (14.0% vs. 7.3%, P=0.002) and exercise (12.1%) than patients from doctors who did not receive a chart prompt. 7.1% versus P=.016). Of the obesity comorbidities, only obstructive sleep apnea (OSA) predicted that one patient was diagnosed with obesity (OR=.49, 95% CI=0.281, 0.869, P=.014). Conclusions: The inclusion of a computerized BMI chart prompt has increased the likelihood that doctors will diagnose obesity in obese patients and refer them to treatment.

title: Effect of minimal pharmacy intervention in improving adherence to asthma guidelines.
abstract: Purpose To examine the effectiveness of a minimal intervention strategy for improving compliance with pediatric asthma guidelines. Design and setting A group of pharmacists was encouraged to discuss key aspects of asthma management with their GPs they normally work with. Compliance with guidelines was assessed by examining prescriptions for children with asthma. We compared the treatment of children enrolled in participating pharmacies (intervention group) with a control group (reference group) enrolled in other non-participating pharmacies and the results of a previous study. Key outcome measures Number of children not using short-acting betamimetics, not using inhaled corticosteroids while using long-acting betamimetics, and having more than one type of inhaler. Results The number of children without short-acting betamimetics was significantly lower in the intervention group (176/1447 vs. 534/3527"; p<0.01), and fewer children did not have inhaled corticosteroids despite using long-acting betamimetics (6/219 versus 41). /477; p=0.03) The number of children with more than one type of inhaler was equal in both groups (5.1%), but significantly lower than in this previous study (239/3217 versus 119/2311; "p<0.01). Conclusions Pharmacists' assistance in compliance with pediatric asthma guidelines is helpful. Pharmacists should be actively involved in the care of children with asthma.

title: Effect of Web-Based Guided Self-Help Intervention on the Prevention of Major Depression in Adults with Sub-threshold Depression
abstract: Significance Evidence-based treatments for major depressive disorder (MDD) are not very successful in improving functional and health outcomes. Attention has increasingly focused on the prevention of MDD. Objective To evaluate the effectiveness of a web-based guided self-help intervention for the prevention of MDD. Design, Environment, and Participants A two-group randomized clinical trial conducted between March 1, 2013 and March 4, 2015. Participants were recruited through a statutory health insurance company (ie co-employer funded insurance) larger than the general population in Germany. employee contributions). Participants consisted of 406 self-selected adults with sub-threshold depression (Central Epidemiological Studies Center Depression Scale score Â¡Ã 16, no current MDD according to the Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders [Fourth Edition, Text Revision] criteria). Interventions All participants had unrestricted access to usual care (primary care clinician visits) or either a web-based guided self-help intervention (cognitive-behavioral and problem-solving therapy assisted by an online trainer"; n?= ?202) or a web-based psychoeducation program ( n?=?204) Main Outcomes and Measures The primary outcome was the time of onset of MDD during a 12-month follow-up period in the intervention group compared to the control blind diagnostic assessors using telephone-administered Structured Clinical Interview for DSM-IV Axis Disorders at 6 and 12 months follow-up. and included time to previous evaluation. Outcomes Among 406 randomized patients (mean age, 45 years; 73.9% female), 335 (82%) completed phone follow-up at 12 months Fifty-five participants in the intervention group (%) 27) experienced MDD, 84 participants in the control group (41%) Cox regression analyzes baseline for control depressive symptom severity at 12-month follow-up 0.59 It revealed a hazard ratio of (95% CI, 0.42-0.82; “P?=?.002). The number required to treat to prevent 1 new case of MDD was 5.9 (95% CI, 3.9-14.6). Outcomes and Relevance Among patients with sub-threshold depression, use of a web-based guided self-help intervention compared with enhanced usual care reduced the incidence of MDD over 12 months. More research is needed to understand whether the effects can be generalized to both initial depression onset and depression relapse, as well as efficacy without the use of an online trainer.

title: The effect of an education program (PEGASE) on cardiovascular risk in hypercholesterolemic patients
abstract: BACKGROUND: Many studies have demonstrated that there is a gap between guidelines for the prevention of cardiovascular disease (CVD) and their application in clinical practice. OBJECTIVE: The PEGASE education program is designed to improve the management of patients at high CVD risk. METHODS: In a multicenter study conducted in France between 2001 and 2004, 96 participating physicians were randomized into a "trained" group containing 398 "trained" patients and an "untrained" group containing 242 "untrained" patients. “trained” patients. Trained patients received six hospital-based training sessions, four collective and two individual. Framingham score, smoking, lipid levels, glycemia, blood pressure, dietary intake and medication adherence and quality of life at baseline (M0) and 6. The primary endpoint of the study was the efficacy of the PEGASE program in reducing global CVD risk in high-risk patients RESULTS: Framingham score was calculated for 473 patients Framingham score was M6 vs. M0 (13.0 +/- 8.21' in the trained group) e 13.6 +/- 8.48, d = -0.658, p = 0.016) but significantly improved in the untrained group (12.5 +/- 8.19) vs. 12.4 +/- 7.81, d = +0.064, p = 0.836)";" the mean change between the two groups did not reach significance. Quality of life, LDL-c level, and diet scores improved only in the "educated" group. RESULTS: Although the global assessment by Framingham score was not significantly different between groups, the PEGASE training program risk for CVD f improved its actors. Aiming to meet the needs and expectations of patients and physicians, this program was easily implemented in all hospital centers.

title: Effect of an outpatient antimicrobial management intervention on broad-spectrum antibiotic prescribing by primary care pediatricians: a randomized trial.
abstract: Importance Antimicrobial management programs have been effective for inpatients, often prescribing supervision and feedback. However, most antimicrobial uses occur in outpatients with acute respiratory infections (ARTIs). Purpose To evaluate the impact of an antimicrobial management intervention on antibiotic prescribing for outpatient pediatric patients. Design Cluster, randomized trial of outpatient antimicrobial management comparing prescribing between intervention and control practices using a common electronic health record. After excluding children with chronic medical conditions, antibiotic allergies, and pre-existing antibiotics, we estimated prescribing rates for targeted PLUS standardized for age, gender, race, and insurance from 20 months before to 12 months after intervention (October 2008-June 2011) . ). Setting and Participants Network of 25 pediatric primary care practices in Pennsylvania and New Jersey”; 18 practices (162 clinicians) participated. Interventions One 1-hour onsite clinician training session (June 2010), followed by a 1-year personalized, quarterly supervision and bacterial and viral Feedback on prescribing for PLUS or usual practice Major Outcomes and Measures Rates of prescribing broad-spectrum (non-rule) antibiotics for bacterial PLUS and viral PLUS during 1 year after intervention Outcomes Broad-spectrum antibiotic prescribing among intervention practices % decreased from 26.8% to 14.3% (absolute difference, 12.5%) and in controls from 28.4% to 22.6% (absolute difference, 5.8%) (difference of differences [DOD], 6.7%; P = .01 for differences Children with pneumonia Non-guideline prescribing decreased from 15.7% to 4.2% among intervention practices, compared to 17.1% in controls (DOD, 10.7%; P < .001) and for acute s 38.9% in intervention practices. from 18.8% v e inusitis from 40.0% to 33.9% in controls (DOD, 14.0%; P = .12). Illegal prescribing was uncommon at baseline, and streptococcal pharyngitis (intervention, 4.4% to 3.4%; control, 5.6% to 3.5%; DOD, -1.1%; P = .82) and changed little for viral infections (intervention). , from 7.9% to 7.7%; control, 6.4% to 4.5%; DOD, -1.7%;" P = .93. Outcomes and Relevance In this large pediatric primary care network, clinician education was combined with supervision and feedback, compared with better adherence to prescribing guidelines for common bacterial PLUS in usual practice and intervention, viral did not affect the prescribing of antibiotics for infections. Future studies should examine the drivers of these effects, as well as the generalizability, sustainability, and clinical outcomes of outpatient antimicrobial stewardship.

title: The effect of anemia and cardiovascular disease on surgical mortality and morbidity
abstract: Guidelines on hemoglobin thresholds for blood transfusion in surgical patients are presented. However, there is insufficient evidence of hemoglobin concentrations at which the risk of death or serious morbidity begins to rise and transfusion is indicated. Guidelines on hemoglobin thresholds for blood transfusion in surgical patients are presented. However, there is insufficient evidence about hemoglobin concentrations at which the risk of death or serious morbidity begins to rise and transfusion is indicated.

title: The effect of peer review, supervision, and feedback on general practitioners' prescribing and test ordering performance: a cluster-randomized controlled trial.
abstract: BACKGROUND: Most worldwide research focuses on controlling costs and better compliance with guidelines in healthcare. Research focused on professional behavior is usually conducted in a well-controlled research environment. In this study, a large-scale application of a peer review strategy was tested on both test ordering and prescribing behavior in primary care in the normal quality improvement setting. METHODS: We planned a cluster of RCTs in primary care existing local quality improvement collaborations (LQICs). The study lasted from January 2008 to January 2011. LQICs were randomly assigned to one of the two trial arms, and each arm received the same supervisory intervention and feedback along with peer review. Five different clinical subjects were presented in both arms and served as a blind control for the other arm. Differences in test ordering rates and prescribing rates between both arms were analyzed in an intent-to-post analysis and a per-protocol analysis. RESULTS: Twenty-one LQIC groups participated in the trial, including 197 GPs working in 88 practices. Treatment-directed analysis showed no difference in changes in test rank or prescribing performance between the intervention and control groups. Per-protocol analysis showed positive results for half of the clinical subjects. The increase in total tests ordered was 3% in the intervention arm and 15% in the control arm. For prescribing, the increase in prescriptions was 20% in the intervention arm and 66% in the control group. It was observed that the groups with the highest initial test order and prescription volume showed the greatest improvements. CONCLUSIONS: Our study demonstrates that results from previous studies cannot be confirmed by our attempt to implement the strategy in the field. We did not see a decrease in the volumes of tests ordered or drugs prescribed, but rather a lesser increase. In the Netherlands, it has proven impossible to implement supervision and feedback and peer review in primary care. TRIAL REGISTRATION: This trial was registered in the Dutch trial register on 7 August 2007 with the number ISRCTN40008171.

title: The effect of supervision and feedback and reminder messages on primary care radiology referrals: a randomized trial.
abstract: Background Radiological tests are often used by general practitioners (GPs). These tests can be overused and contribute little to clinical management. In accordance with the UK Royal College of Radiologists guidelines on lumbar spine and knee radiographs, we aimed to evaluate two methods for reducing GP demands for radiological testing. Methods We evaluated supervision and feedback and educational reminder messages across six radiology departments and the 244 general practices they serve. The study was a pre- and post-pragmatic cluster randomized controlled trial with a 2Â·2 factorial design. A random subset of GP patients' records were reviewed for compliance with guidelines. The main outcome measure was the number of radiograph requests per 1000 patients per year. The analysis was therapeutic. Results The effect of educational reminder messages (ie change in post-intervention request rate) was -1Â·53 (95% CI -2Â·5 to -0Â·57) and -1Â·61 absolute change for the lumbar spine. For (-2Â·6 to -0Â·62) knee radiographs, both are about 20% relative reduction. The effect of supervision and feedback was an absolute change from 0Â·04 (-0Â·95 to 1Â·03) to -0Â·07 (-1Â·3 to 0Â·9) for the lumbar spine, both relative reductions. is about 1%. The agreement between the groups did not differ significantly. Interpretation 6-month feedback of audit data is ineffective, but the routine addition of educational reminder messages to radiographs is effective and does not affect the quality of referrals. Any radiology department that handles primary care referrals can do well with this intervention.

title: The Effect of Behavior Change on the Outcome in Early-Mid-stage Chronic Kidney Disease: A Cluster-Randomized Study
abstract: OBJECTIVES: Thanks to recent changes in our understanding of the underlying cause of chronic kidney disease (CKD), the importance of lifestyle modification to prevent the progression of kidney dysfunction and its complications has become clear. In addition, effective collaboration between general practitioners (general practitioners) and nephrologists is essential to provide a better system of care for the treatment of CKD. In this cluster randomized study, we examined the impact of behavior change on the outcome of early to mid-stage CKD. DESIGN: Stratified open cluster randomized trial. SETTING: A total of 489 GPs belonging to 49 local medical societies (clusters) in Japan. PARTICIPANTS: A total of 2,379 patients (1195 in group A (standard intervention) and 1,184 in group B (advanced intervention)) aged 40 to 74 years, with CKD and under consultation with general practitioners. INTERVENTION: All patients were managed according to current CKD guidelines. Group B clusters received three additional interventions: patients were given both an educational intervention for lifestyle change and a CKD status letter that sought to prevent withdrawal from treatment, and group B GPs received datasheets to facilitate reducing the gap between target and practice. MAIN OUTCOME MEASURE: The primary outcome measures were 1) the rate of non-adherence to patients' acceptance of continued medical follow-up, 2) the rate of collaboration between GPs and nephrologists, and 3) the progression of CKD. RESULTS: The rate of intermittent clinical visits was significantly lower in group B (16.2% in group A and 11.5% in group B, p = 0.01). Significantly higher referral and co-treatment rates were observed in Group B (p<0.01). The mean rate of eGFR deterioration tended to be lower in group B (group A: 2.6+/-5.8 ml/min/1.73 m2/year, group B: 2.4+/- 5.1 ml/ min/1.73 m2/year, p = 0.07). In subjects with stage 3 CKD (group A: 2.4+/-5.9 ml/min/1.73 m2/year, group B: 1.9+/-4.4 ml/min/1.73 m2/year, p = 0.03). CONCLUSION: Our care system significantly reduced behavior change of CKD patients, i.e. discontinuous clinical visits, and resulted in significantly higher referral and co-treatment rates of both GPs and nephrologists, resulting in delayed CKD progression, especially in patients. with proteinuric Stage 3 CKD. TRIAL REGISTRATION: University Hospital Medical Information Network clinical trials registry UMIN000001159.

title: The Effect of Behavioral Interventions on Improper Antibiotic Prescription Among Primary Care Practices: A Randomized Clinical Study
abstract: IMPORTANCE: Behavioral science-based interventions can reduce inappropriate antibiotic prescribing. OBJECTIVE: To evaluate the effects of behavioral interventions and inappropriate (not in accordance with guidelines) antibiotic prescribing rates during outpatient visits for acute respiratory infections. DESIGN, ENVIRONMENT, AND PARTICIPANTS: A cluster randomized clinical trial conducted among 47 primary care practices in Boston and Los Angeles. Participants were 248 registered clinicians randomized to receive 0, 1, 2, or 3 interventions over 18 months. All clinicians received training in enrollment antibiotic prescribing guidelines. Interventions began between 1 November 2011 and 1 October 2012. The tracking of the most recently started sites ended on April 1, 2014. Adult patients with comorbidities and concomitant infections were excluded. INTERVENTIONS: Three behavioral interventions administered alone or in combination: proposed alternatives offered electronic order sets recommending non-antibiotic treatments"; responsible justification encouraged clinicians to enter free-text rationales for prescribing antibiotics in patients' electronic health records; peer comparison, sent emails comparing prescribing rates with "top performers" (those with the lowest rates of inappropriate prescribing). Rates of prescribing antibiotics up to 18 months, adjusting the effects of each intervention for co-occurring interventions and pre-intervention trends, with random effects for practice and clinicians. 14,753 visits for infections (mean patient age, 47 years; 69% women) and 16,959 visits (mean patient age, 48 years; 67% women) during the intervention period. Mean antibiotic prescribing rates ranged from 24.1% at the start of the intervention to 13.1% (absolute difference, -11.0%) at the 18th month of intervention, and from 22.1% (absolute difference, -16.0%) for control treatments. decreased to 6.1% (difference) for suggested alternatives. in differences, -5.0% [95% CI, -7.8% to 0.1%]; P = .66 for differences in orbitals); for responsible reason (difference in differences) from 23.2% to 5.2% (absolute difference, -18.1%), -7.0% [95% CI, -9.1% to -2.9%]; P < .001); and 19.9% to 3.7% (absolute difference, -16.3%) for peer comparison (difference in differences, -5.2%) [95% CI, -6.9% to -1.6%];" P < .001). there were no significant interactions (neither synergy nor intervention). Identifier: NCT01454947.

title: The Impact of Clinical Decision-Support Systems: a systematic review
abstract: BACKGROUND: Despite increasing emphasis on the role of clinical decision support systems (CDSSs) to improve care and reduce costs, there is no evidence to support widespread use. OBJECTIVE: Clinical outcomes, healthcare processes, workload and efficiency, patient satisfaction, cost and provider usage and implementation of CDSSs. DATA SOURCES: MEDLINE, CINAHL, PsycINFO and Web of Science until January 2011. STUDY SELECTION: Researchers independently swept reports to identify English-language randomized trials of electronic CDSSs applied in clinical settings"; used by providers to aid point-of-care decision-making and reported clinical, healthcare process, workload, relationship-centered, economic or provider use outcomes DATA DRAWING: Investigators extracted data about study design, participant characteristics, interventions, outcomes, and quality. DATA SYNTHESIS: 148 randomized, controlled trials were included. A total of 1 28 (86%) health care process measures, 29 (20%) evaluated clinical outcomes and 22 (15%) evaluated measured costs Both commercial and locally developed CDSSs improved health care process measures related to the delivery of preventive services (n= 25; odds ratio) [OR], 1.42 [95% CI, 1.27 to 1.58]), ordering clinical trials (n= 20; OR, 1.72) [CI, 1.47 to 2.00]) v e prescribing treatments (n= 46; "OR, 1.57 [CI, 1.35 to 1.82]). Few studies measuring potential adverse outcomes or side effects. LIMITATIONS: Studies, interventions, populations, settings, and results Publication bias and selective reporting cannot be excluded. CONCLUSION: Both commercial and locally developed CDSSs are effective in improving health care process measures in different settings, but not clinical, economic, workload, and efficiency. Evidence for outcomes is insufficient. The review expands knowledge in the field by demonstrating the benefits of CDSSs outside of experienced academic centres.

title: Impact of computer-assisted implementation of European Best Practice Guidelines on commitment and goal achievement: ORAMA results.
abstract: Background: The success of guidelines largely depends on their effective implementation and adoption in clinical practice. The Optimal Renal Anemia Management Assessment (ORAMA) study investigated the impact of the European Best Practice Guidelines (EBPG) on patient outcomes. Methods: ORAMA was a prospective, international, multicenter, cluster randomized study. Fifty-three centers in eight European countries enrolled patients with stage V chronic kidney disease receiving chronic dialysis treatment. Patients were either anemic (hemoglobin [Hb] <11 g/dL [110 g/L]) or were treated with erythropoiesis stimulating agents and/or iron supplementation. Centers were randomized into two groups with or without access to a computerized clinical decision support (CDS) system. In a post hoc analysis, patients were further subdivided into whether or not investigators adhered to EBPG, regardless of CDS use. The primary endpoint was the proportion of patients with Hb >11 g/dL (110 g/L) reflecting hematological targets in the revised EPBG. Results: In this population of 599 dialysis patients, hematological targets did not differ in the presence or absence of a CDS system. While the width of the distribution curves remained unchanged, there was an overall shift towards improved patient distribution by Hb categories. The proportion of patients with Hb >11 g/dL (110 g/L) was higher among adherents (79% and 84% with or without CDS, respectively) than among those without (59% and 57%, respectively). Conclusions: ORAMA is the first international study to show that adherence to EBPG improves the acquisition of anemia indices. Availability of a CDS system did not affect anemia management.

title: The effect of computerized evidence-based guidelines on the management of asthma and angina in adults in primary care: a cluster randomized controlled trial.
abstract: Summary Objective: To evaluate the use of a computerized support system in decision-making for the implementation of evidence-based clinical guidelines for the treatment of asthma and angina in adults in primary care. Design: Before and after a pragmatic cluster randomized controlled trial using a two-by-two incomplete block design. Setting: 60 general practices in north east England. Participants: GPs and nurse practitioners involved in the study practices, and patients aged 18 years or older with angina or asthma. Key outcome measures: Adherence to guidelines based on review of case notes and patient-reported generic and case-specific outcome measures. Results: The computerized decision support system had no significant impact on consultation rates, the course of care measures (including prescribing), or patient-reported outcomes for both conditions. The usage levels of the software were low. Conclusions: Computed evidence-based guidelines for the management of asthma or angina in adults in primary care had no effect. This was probably due to low usage of the software, even though the system was as optimized as technically possible. While the technical issues of producing a system that fully supports chronic disease management have been resolved, the challenge remains of integrating systems into clinical encounters where intensive practitioners manage patients with complex, multiple conditions.

title: Effect of daily aspirin on long-term risk of cancer-related death: analysis of individual patient data from randomized trials.
abstract: Treatment with daily aspirin for 5 years or more reduces the risk of subsequent colorectal cancer. Several lines of evidence suggest that aspirin may also reduce the risk of other cancers, particularly of the gastrointestinal tract, but no human evidence. We examined cancer-related deaths during and after randomized trials of daily aspirin versus control originally performed for the prevention of vascular events. Treatment with daily aspirin for 5 years or more reduces the risk of subsequent colorectal cancer. Several lines of evidence suggest that aspirin may also reduce the risk of other cancers, particularly of the gastrointestinal tract, but no human evidence. We examined cancer-related deaths during and after randomized trials of daily aspirin versus baseline control for the prevention of vascular events.

title: The impact of exercise referral plans in primary care on improving physical activity and health outcomes: systematic review and meta-analysis
abstract: OBJECTIVE To evaluate the impact of exercise referral plans on physical activity and health outcomes. Design Systematic review and meta-analysis. DATA SOURCES Medline, Embase, PsycINFO, Cochrane Library, ISI Web of Science, SPORTDiscus and trial records through October 2009. We also checked the working references. Study selection Design: randomized controlled trials or non-randomized controlled (cluster or individual) studies published in peer review journals. POPULATION sedentary individuals, with or without a medical diagnosis. Exercise referral schemes are defined as: open referrals by primary health care professionals to third-party service providers to increase physical activity or exercise, physical activity, or individualized exercise programs, and initial evaluation and monitoring throughout programs. Comparators: usual care, non-intervention or alternative exercise referral plans. RESULTS Eight randomized controlled trials comparing exercise referral schemes with usual care (six trials), alternative physical activity intervention (two), and an exercise referral scheme plus a self-determination theory intervention (one) met inclusion criteria. Compared with usual care, follow-up data for exercise referral schemes showed an increased number of participants performing at least 90-150 minutes of moderate-intensity physical activity per week (added relative risk 1.16, 95% CI 1.03 to 1.30) and a reduced level of depression (aggregated standardized risk). mean difference -0.82, -1.28 to -0.35). Evidence for a difference between groups in moderate or vigorous-intensity physical activity or other health outcomes was inconsistent at follow-up. We did not find any difference in outcomes between the exercise referral schemes and the other two comparator groups. None of the included studies reported individual outcomes in individuals with specific medical diagnoses. Significant heterogeneity in the nature and quality of exercise referral plans between studies may have contributed to the inconsistency in the outcome findings. Conclusions Significant uncertainties remain about the effectiveness of exercise referral plans to increase indicators of physical activity, fitness or health, or the efficient use of resources for sedentary people with or without a medical diagnosis.

title: Effect of Financial Incentives on Lipid Levels of Physicians, Patients, or Both
abstract: Significance Financial incentives for physicians or patients are increasingly used, but their effectiveness has not been fully established. Purpose To determine whether physician financial incentives, patient incentives, or joint physician and patient incentives are more effective than control in reducing low-density lipoprotein cholesterol (LDL-C) levels in patients at high cardiovascular risk. Design, Setting, and Participants A four-group, multicenter, cluster randomized clinical trial with 12-month interventions conducted in 3 primary care settings in the Northeastern United States between 2011 and 2014. Three hundred and forty eligible primary care physicians (PCPs) were enrolled from a pool of 421 people. Of the 25 to 627 potentially eligible patients of these PCPs, 1503 were enrolled. Patients aged 18 to 80 years with a 10-year Framingham Risk Score (FRS) 20% or higher, coronary artery disease equivalents LDL-C levels 120 mg/dL or higher, or FRS 140 mg/dL or higher LDL-C 10% to 20% with levels. Investigators were blind to the study group, but participants were not. Interventions Primary care physicians were randomly assigned to control, physician incentives, patient incentives, or shared physician-patient incentives. Physicians in the physician incentives group were eligible to receive up to $1024 per registered patient who met their LDL-C targets. Patients in the patient incentive group were eligible for the same amount distributed through daily lotteries based on medication adherence. Physicians and patients in the shared incentives group shared these incentives. Physicians and patients in the control group received no results-related incentives, but all patient participants received up to $355 each for trial participation. Main Results and Measures Change in LDL-C level at 12 months. Results Patients in the shared physician-patient incentives group had a mean reduction in LDL-C of 33.6 mg/dL (95% CI, 30.1-37.1"; baseline, 160.1 mg/dL; 12 months, 126.4 mg/dL). achieved a mean reduction in physician incentives of 27.9 mg/dL (95% CI, 24.9-31.0; baseline, 159.9 mg/dL; 12 months, 132.0 mg/dL); a mean reduction of 25.1 mg/dL in patient incentives (% 95 CI, 21.6-28.5; baseline, 160.6 mg/dL; 12 months, 135.5 mg/dL) and those in the control group had a mean reduction of 25.1 mg/dL (95% CI, 21.7-28.5; baseline, 161.5 mg/dL; 12 months, 136.4 mg/dL; P?<?.001 for comparison of all 4 groups) Only patients in the shared doctor-patient incentive group achieved statistically different reductions in LDL-C than the control group (8.5 mg/dL; 95%) GA, 3.8-13.3;"P?=?.002). Outcomes and Relevance In primary care, shared financial incentives for physicians and patients, but not just incentives for physicians or patients, resulted in a statistically significant difference in LDL-C levels at 12 months. However, this reduction was modest and more information is needed to understand whether this approach represents good value.

title: The effect of financial incentives on physicians, patients, or both on lipid levels: A randomized clinical trial.
abstract: Importance: Financial incentives for physicians or patients are increasingly used, but their effectiveness has not been fully established. Objective: To determine whether physician financial incentives, patient incentives, or joint physician and patient incentives are more effective than control in reducing low-density lipoprotein cholesterol (LDL-C) levels in patients at high cardiovascular risk. Design, Setting, and Participants: A four-group, multicenter, cluster randomized clinical trial with 12-month interventions conducted in 3 primary care settings between 2011 and 2014 in the northeastern United States. Three hundred and forty eligible primary care physicians (PCPs) were enrolled from a pool of 421 people. Of the 25 627 potentially eligible patients for these PCPs, 1503 were enrolled. Patients aged 18 to 80 years with a 10-year Framingham Risk Score (FRS) 20% or higher, coronary artery disease equivalents LDL-C levels 120 mg/dL or higher, or FRS 140 mg/dL or higher LDL-C 10% to 20% with levels. Investigators were blind to the study group, but participants were not. Interventions: Primary care physicians are randomly assigned for control, physician incentives, patient incentives, or shared doctor-patient incentives. Physicians in the physician incentives group were eligible to receive up to $1024 per registered patient who met their LDL-C targets. Patients in the patient incentive group were eligible for the same amount distributed through daily lotteries based on medication adherence. Physicians and patients in the shared incentives group shared these incentives. Physicians and patients in the control group received no results-related incentives, but all patient participants received up to $355 each for trial participation. Main Results and Measures: Change in LDL-C level at 12 months. Results: Only patients in the shared doctor-patient incentives group achieved reductions in LDL-C levels that were statistically different from those in the control group (8.5mg/dL"; 95% CI, 3.8-13.3; "P = .002). For comparison of all 4 groups, P < .001. Outcomes and Relevance: In primary care, shared financial incentives for physicians and patients, but not incentives for physicians or patients, resulted in a statistically significant difference in LDL-C levels at 12 months. However, this reduction was modest and more information is needed to understand whether this approach represents good value. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2016 APA, all rights reserved)

title: Effect of improving depression care on pain and functional outcomes in older adults with arthritis: a randomized controlled trial.
abstract: Context Depression and arthritis are disabling and common health problems later in life. Depression is also a risk factor for poor health outcomes among arthritis patients. Objective To determine whether increasing care for depression improves pain and functional outcomes in older adults with depression and arthritis. Design, Environment, and Participants Preplanned subgroup analyzes of Improving Access to Mood Promoting Collaborative Treatment (IMPACT), a randomized controlled trial of 1801 depressed older adults (Â¡Ã 60 years) performed in 18 primary care clinics from 8 healthcare institutions July Care organizations in 5 states in the United States from 1999 to August 2001. A total of 1001 (56%) reported coexistence of arthritis at baseline. Intervention Antidepressant medications and/or 6 to 8 sessions of psychotherapy (Primary Care Problem Solving Treatment). Main Outcome Measures Depression, pain intensity (0 to 10 scale), interference with daily activities due to arthritis (0 to 10 scale), general health status, and overall quality of life outcomes assessed at baseline, 3, 6, and 12 months. Results In addition to reduction in depressive symptoms, the intervention group had lower mean (SE) scores for pain intensity (5.62 [0.16] vs. 6.15 [0.16]"; difference between groups, ?0.53 ; 95%) compared to the usual care group at 12 months. confidence interval [CI], ?0.92 - ?0.14; P = .009), interference with daily activities due to arthritis (4.40 [0.18] vs. 4.99 [0.17]); difference between groups, ?0.59; 95% CI , ?1.00 to ?0.19 ; P = .004) and interference with daily activities due to pain (2.92 [0.07] vs 3.17 [0.07]; between-group difference, ?0.26; 95% CI, ?0.41 to ?0.10; "P = .002). At 12 months, overall health and quality of life also improved among intervention patients compared to control patients. Conclusions In a large and diverse population of older adults with arthritis (mostly osteoarthritis) and concomitant depression, the benefits of improved depression treatment went beyond reduced depressive symptoms and included improved functional status and quality of life as well as reduced pain.

title: Effect of renin-angiotensin system inhibitors and other antihypertensive drugs on renal outcomes: systematic review and meta-analysis
abstract: Background A consensus has emerged that angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitors and angiotensin-II receptor blockers (ARBs) have specific renoprotective effects. The guidelines state that these are the drugs of choice for the treatment of hypertension in patients with kidney disease. We tried to determine the extent to which this consensus was supported by the available evidence.";" Background A consensus has emerged that angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitors and angiotensin-II receptor blockers (ARBs) have specific renoprotective effects. The guidelines state that these are the drugs of choice for the treatment of hypertension in patients with kidney disease. We sought to determine the extent to which this consensus is supported by the available evidence.

title: The impact of integrated care for patient-listed patients with chronic low back pain: an economic evaluation alongside a randomized controlled trial.
abstract: OBJECTIVE: To evaluate the cost-effectiveness, cost-benefit, and cost-benefit of an integrated care program compared to usual care for patients on the list of patients with chronic low back pain. DESIGN: Economic evaluation as well as a randomized controlled trial with 12-month follow-up. SETTING: Primary care (10 physiotherapy practices, one occupational health service, one occupational therapy practice) and secondary care (five hospitals) in the Netherlands 2005-9. PARTICIPANTS: 134 adults aged 18-65 years listed for chronic low back pain: 66 were randomized to integrated care and 68 to usual care. INTERVENTIONS: Integrated care consisted of a workplace intervention based on participatory ergonomics with the participation of a supervisor and a graded activity program based on cognitive behavioral principles. Normal care was provided by general practitioners and occupational physicians according to Dutch guidelines. MAIN OUTCOME MEASURES: The primary outcome was time to return to sustainable work. The secondary outcome was quality-adjusted life years (QALYs) as measured using EuroQol. RESULTS: Total costs in the integrated care group (£13165, £13600) were significantly lower than in the regular care group (£18475, £13616). Cost-effectiveness planes and acceptability curves demonstrated that integrated care is cost-effective compared to regular care for return to work and QALYs earned. Cost-benefit analyzes showed that every pound1 invested in integrated care would return an estimated £26. The net societal benefit of integrated care compared to regular care was 5744 pounds. CONCLUSIONS: Implementation of an integrated care program for the listed chronic low back pain patients has great potential to significantly reduce societal costs, increase the effectiveness of care, improve quality of life and improve function on a large scale. Therefore, integrated care has huge gains for both patients and society as well as employers.
