title: The effect of interactive group discussion among physicians to promote rational prescribing
abstract: This study evaluated the impact of an educational intervention (interactive group discussion) on the prescribing behavior of 51 general physicians in northwest Tabriz. Prescriptions were analyzed pre-intervention and post-intervention (control and intervention groups) using a proforma containing 8 correct prescribing indicators. The mean number of drugs per prescription before the intervention was 3.82. The percentages of antibiotic, corticosteroid and injection prescriptions were 40.8%, 25.9% and 58.0%, respectively. Following the intervention, there were slight but non-significant changes in indicators in both the intervention and control groups compared to pre-intervention results.

title: Effect of intervention aimed at increasing physical activity, reducing sedentary behavior and increasing fruit and vegetable consumption in children: an active school-based cluster randomized controlled trial for Life Year 5 (AFLY5).
abstract: OBJECTIVE To investigate the effectiveness of a school-based intervention to increase physical activity, reduce sedentary behavior, and increase fruit and vegetable consumption in children. DESIGN Cluster randomized controlled trial. SETTING 60 primary schools in the southwest of England. PARTICIPANTS Primary school children at 4th year (8-9 years) of school at recruitment and baseline assessment, 5th year at intervention, and 5th year at follow-up assessment (9-10 years). INTERVENTION The Active Lifelong Year 5 (AFLY5) intervention consisted of teacher education, tutoring and child-parent interactive homework plans, all required materials for lessons and homework, and school newsletters and written materials for parents. The intervention took place in the children's 5th academic year (9-10 years). Schools allocated to control received standard instruction. MAIN OUTCOME MEASURES Predetermined primary outcomes were accelerometer-assessed minutes of moderate to vigorous physical activity per day, accelerometer-assessed minutes of sedentary behavior per day, and daily fruit and vegetable serving consumption. RESULTS 60 schools with more than 2221 children were recruited";" Valid data were available for fruit and vegetable consumption for 2121 children, for accelerometer-assessed physical activity and sedentary behavior for 1252 children, and secondary outcomes for 1825 to 2212 children for the main analyses. None of the three primary outcomes differed between children in schools allocated to the AFLY5 intervention and children allocated to the control group. The difference between the averages between the intervention group and the control group was -1.35 (95% confidence interval -5.29 to 2.59) minutes per day for moderate to vigorous physical activity, -0.11 (-9.71 to 9.49) minutes per day for sedentary behavior, and fruit and vegetable consumption. 0.08 (-0.12 to 0.28) servings per day for The intervention was effective for three out of nine of the secondary outcomes after considering multiple tests: time spent watching screens on weekends (-21 (-37 to -4) minutes per day), self-reported servings. daily snacks (-0.22 (-0.38 to -0.05)) and daily high-energy drink servings (-0.26 (-0.43 to -0.10)) were reduced. Results from a series of sensitivity analyzes and per-protocol analyzes testing different assumptions about missing data yielded similar results. CONCLUSION Findings show that the AFLY5 school-based intervention is not effective in increasing physical activity levels, reducing sedentary behaviors, and increasing fruit and vegetable consumption in primary school children. Change in these activities may require more intense behavioral interventions with children or upstream interventions at the family and community level as well as at the school setting level. These findings have implications for researchers, policy makers, public health practitioners, and physicians involved in health promotion, policy making, and commissioning services. Trial registration Available Controlled Trials ISRCTN50133740.

title: The effect of offering different levels of support and free nicotine replacement therapy via the British national quit hotline: randomized controlled trial.
abstract: OBJECTIVE To compare the effects of free nicotine replacement therapy or proactive telephone counseling in addition to standard smoking cessation support offered through a telephone cessation hotline. DESIGN Parallel group, 2 Ã 2-factor, randomized controlled trial. SET National drop line, UK. PARTICIPANTS 2591 non-pregnant smokers aged 16 years or older who called the quit line between February 2009 and February 2010 and agreed to set a quit date: 648 each with standard support, proactive support or nicotine replacement therapy. were randomized to support, and 647 were randomized to standard support with nicotine replacement therapy. INTERVENTIONS In addition to standard support, two interventions were offered: six weeks of nicotine replacement therapy, free and proactive counseling sessions provided (repeated phone calls from cessation counselors and interaction with them). MAIN OUTCOME MEASURES The primary outcome was self-reported smoking cessation six months or more after the quit date. The secondary outcome was cessation confirmed by exhaled carbon monoxide measured at six or more months. RESULTS At 6 months, 17.7% (n = 229) of those who received nicotine replacement therapy reported smoking cessation, while 20.1% (n = 261) did not recommend such therapy (odds ratio 0.85, 95% confidence interval 0.70 to 1.04) and 18.2%. Compared to 19.6 (n = 254), % (n = 236) of proactive counselors offered standard support (0.91, 0.75 to 1.11). Data confirmed by carbon monoxide readings only changed the findings for nicotine replacement therapy; smoking cessation was confirmed in 6.6% (85/1295) of those who received nicotine replacement therapy, compared with 9.4% (122/1296) for whom no such treatment was recommended (0.67, 0.50 versus 0.90). CONCLUSIONS Offering free nicotine replacement therapy or additional (proactive) counseling to standard helpline support had no additional effect on smoking cessation. TRIAL REGISTRATION ClinicalTrials.gov NCT00775944.

title: The impact of patient-specific ratings on angina research decisions versus conventional guidelines: Relevance of Referral and Investigation in the Angina (ARIA) Study
abstract: BACKGROUND: Conventional guidelines have limited effect in changing physicians' testing order. We sought to determine the effect of patient-specific ratings on appropriate angina research versus conventional guidelines. METHODS: Randomized controlled trial in which 145 physicians with patient-specific ratings (online prompt indicating whether certain vignettes were deemed appropriate or inappropriate for research, with access to detailed information on how ratings were derived) and 147 physicians received conventional guidelines from the American Heart Association and Europe Society of Cardiology. Physicians provided recommendations on 12 Web-based patient vignettes prior to these interventions and 12 vignettes thereafter. The result was the proportion of appropriate research decisions defined by the 2 independent expert panels. RESULTS: Exercise electrocardiography decisions were more appropriate with patient-specific ratings (819/1491 [55%]) compared to conventional guidelines (648/1488 [44%]) (odds ratio [OR], 1.57"; 95% confidence interval [CI], 1.36–1.82). The effect was stronger for 1009/1576 [64%] [OR, 2.24; 95% CI, 1.90] with conventional guidelines compared to patient-specific ratings with angiography (1274/1595 [80%] -2.62]) Intra-arm comparisons confirmed no effect of conventional guidelines, but patient-specific ratings significantly altered physicians' decisions regarding appropriate recommendations for exercise electrocardiography (55% vs. 42%; OR, 2.62; 95% CI, 2.14–3.22) and angiography. for (65% versus 80%; OR, 2.10; "95% CI, 1.79-2.47). These effects were robust for vignetting characteristics, including physician specialty (cardiologists and GPs) and old age, female gender, and non-white race/ethnicity. CONCLUSION: Patient-specific ratings, unlike traditional guidelines, have changed physician testing behavior and have the potential to reduce practice variations and increase appropriate research use.

title: The effect of doctor's advice and patient compliance on colorectal cancer test rates.
abstract: This study investigated (1) patient characteristics associated with physician recommendation and patient adherence to colorectal cancer (CRC) screening, and (2) the combined impact of recommendation and compliance on broadly defined CRC testing. Data are from the 1999 MA BRFSS and a callback survey of 869 BRFSS participants aged 50 and over. Logistic regression was used to determine the correlations between recommendation, adherence, and testing. Patient-physician factors were positively associated with advice, adherence, and testing. Inadequate health insurance was negatively associated with recommendation (OR = 0.45, 95% CI = 0.27-0.78%) and testing (OR = 0.64, 95% CI = 0.38--1.1) . Men were not more likely to be recommended (OR = 1.1, 95% CI = 0.78--1.5), but were more likely to comply (OR = 1.9, 95% CI = 1.2-2.0) and be tested (OR = 1.4, 95%). CI = 1.0–1.9). There were gender differences in the recommendation when considering health and risk factor measures. Research is needed to understand the differences in advice and commitment. More encouragement and follow-up may be required for groups less likely to be affiliated.

title: The effect of self-efficacy and social support on adherence to antihypertensive drugs
abstract: STUDY OBJECTIVE: To determine the relationship between poor adjustment and self-efficacy or social support after pharmacist intervention. DESIGN: Post-hoc analysis of data from two randomized controlled trials of physician-pharmacist collaborative interventions (6 and 9 months, respectively) to improve blood pressure control. SETTING: Eleven primary care clinics affiliated with the university. PATIENTS: 584 patients (aged 21-85 years) with uncontrolled primary hypertension"; 296 were in the intervention group and 288 in the control group. Intervention group MEASUREMENTS AND MAIN RESULTS: Social support and self-efficacy questionnaires were administered at baseline and at study end visits. control group (p =0.0053) but not in the intervention group, but both groups had higher adherence to baseline. There were small but significant improvements in self-efficacy (p<0.04) and social support (p<0.05).Scores in the intervention group but not the control group at the end of the study Social support and, to a lesser extent, self-efficacy improved as a function of study duration, regardless of whether the patient received the intervention (6 months intervention versus 9 months). group (129.7/76.6 mm Hg) compared to the control group (140.8/78.9 mm Hg; p<0.0001 for systolic, p=0.032 for diastolic). Self-efficacy significantly improved in the intervention group at the end of support and Pharmacist intervention Medication adherence correlated with self-efficacy although drug adherence did not improve significantly in the intervention group Function of study participation time suggests that participation in a research study may have a positive effect on these measures. Social support, self-efficacy Although changes in efficacy and adherence to medication were modest, when the intervention group was compared with the control group, these findings showed that changes in medication adherence, self-efficacy, or social support did not affect blood pressure outcomes in these studies.

title: The effect of telecare management on pain and depression in cancer patients: a randomized trial.
abstract: Context Pain and depression are two of the most common and treatable symptoms of cancer, but they often go unnoticed, under-treated, or both. Purpose To determine whether centralized telephone-based care management combined with automated symptom monitoring can improve depression and pain in patients with cancer. Design, Setting, and Patients Randomized controlled trial conducted in 16 community-based urban and rural oncology practices included in the Indiana Cancer Pain and Depression (INCPAD) study. Recruitment took place from March 2006 to August 2008, and follow-up ended in August 2009. The participating patients had depression (Patient Health Questionnaire-9 score Â¡Ã 10), cancer-related pain (Brief Pain Inventory [BPI] worst pain score Â). ¡Ã 6) or both. Intervention 202 patients randomly assigned to receive intervention and 203 patients to receive usual care were stratified by symptom type. Patients in the intervention group received centralized telecare management by a team of nurse-physician specialists combined with automated home-based symptom monitoring with interactive audio recording or the Internet. Main Outcome Measures Blind assessment for depression (20-item Hopkins Symptom Checklist [HSCL-20]) and pain (BPI) severity at baseline and at months 1, 3, 6, and 12. Results Of the 405 participants in the study, 131 had depression only, 96 had pain only, and 178 had both depression and pain. Of the 274 patients with pain, 137 patients in the intervention group had greater improvements in BPI pain severity during the 12 months of the trial, whether measured as a continuous severity score or as a categorical pain response (Â¡× 30% reduction in BPI). more than 137 patients in the usual care group (P < .001 for both). Similarly, out of 309 patients with depression, 154 patients in the intervention group were compared to 155 patients in the usual care group (both), whether measured as sustained severity score or as a categorical depression response (Â± 50 % reduction in HSCL) during the 12 months of the trial. for P < .001). Standardized effect sizes for between-group differences at 3 and 12 months were 0.67 (95% CI, 0.33-1.02) and 0.39 (95% CI, 0.01-0.77) and 0.42 (95% CI, 0.16-0.69) for pain. and 0.41 (95% CI, 0.08-0.72) for depression. Conclusion Centralized telecare management combined with automated symptom monitoring resulted in better pain and depression outcomes in cancer patients receiving care in geographically dispersed urban and rural oncology practices.

title: The effect of telehealth on quality of life and psychological outcomes over 12 months (Whole System Demonstrator telehealth survey study): a nested study of patient-reported outcomes in a pragmatic cluster randomized controlled trial.
abstract: OBJECTIVE To evaluate the effect of second generation home-based telehealth for 12 months on health-related quality of life, anxiety and depressive symptoms in patients with long-term conditions. DESIGN A study of patient-reported outcomes (Whole System Demonstrator telehealth survey"; baseline n=1573) was intertwined in a pragmatic cluster randomized telehealth trial (Whole System Demonstrator telehealth trial, n=3230). Randomization unit and telehealth usual Compared with care Data collected at baseline, four months (short-term), and 12 months (long-term) Primary objective of analyzes tested treatment efficacy, multilevel models controlled for clustering by general practice, and a set of covariates at all three time points Analyzes were performed for 759 participants who completed the survey measures (full case cohort) and 1201 participants who completed the baseline assessment plus at least one other assessment (current case cohort). Participants were included. primary and secondary care through general practices, specialist nurses and hospital clinics with integrated integrated health and social care systems. PARTICIPANTS Patients with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), diabetes, or heart failure enrolled in the study between May 2008 and December 2009. MAIN OUTCOME MEASURES General, health-related quality of life (assessed by physical and mental health component scores of SF-12 and EQ-5D), anxiety (assessed by the six-item Brief State-Trait Anxiety Inventory), and depressive symptoms (10-item Center for Epidemiological Studies) assessed by the Depression Scale). RESULTS For treatment analyses, differences between treatment groups were small and not significant for all outcomes in the complete case (0.480 à€°Â¤ P â€°Â¤ 0.904) or the current case (0.181 µ). ¢â€°Â¤ P â€°Â¤ 0.905) cohorts. The magnitude of the differences between the trial arms did not reach the trial, defined as the minimal clinically significant difference (0.3 standardized mean difference) for any outcome at four or 12 months. Per-protocol analyzes replicated primary analyses; main effect of trial arm (telehealth v usual care) was not significant for any outcome (full case group 0.273 â€°Â¤ P â€°Â¤ 0.761;" current case group 0.145 â€â€ °Â¤ P â€° Â¤ 0.696) RESULTS Second-generation, home-based telehealth Demonstrative Assessment implemented on All Systems was not effective or effective compared to usual care alone. Telehealth did not improve quality of life or psychological outcomes. For patients with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, diabetes, or heart failure for 12 months The findings show that concerns about the potentially harmful effects of telehealth are unfounded for most patients. TRIAL REGISTRATION ISRCTN43002091.

title: The effect of telephone communication on subsequent suicide attempts in patients discharged from the emergency department: a randomized controlled trial.
abstract: OBJECTIVE To determine the effects of communicating with patients by telephone for one year, one month or three months after discharge from the emergency room for intentional self-poisoning, compared with usual treatment. DESIGN Multicenter, randomized controlled trial. SETTING 13 emergency services in the north of France. PARTICIPANTS 605 people who deliberately attempted to commit suicide by poisoning themselves were discharged from the emergency room. INTERVENTION The intervention consisted of contacting patients by phone who had attempted suicide one month or three months after discharge from the emergency department to assess the success of the proposed treatment or to adjust the treatment. Control patients were treated as usual and in most cases referred back to their GP. MAIN OUTCOME MEASURES Primary outcome measures were the proportion of participants who attempted suicide again, the number of deaths by suicide, and the 13-month follow-up losses. Secondary outcome measures were the types and number of health care contacts. RESULTS On a treatment basis, the three groups did not differ significantly in subsequent suicide attempts, deaths by suicide, or loss of follow-up: contact at one month (23% intervention (23% (34/147) vs controls 30% (93)/312), difference 7%, % 95 confidence interval - 2% to 15%, three months (25% (36/146) v 30%, difference 5%, - 4% to 14%. Participants contacted at one month were less likely to report having attempted suicide again at follow-up (12% vs. 22% in control group, difference 10%, 2% to 18%). CONCLUSION Contacting people by phone one month after being discharged from the emergency room for intentional self-poisoning may help reduce the number of suicide attempts within a year.

title: Impact of education on adoption of cancer prevention nutrition activities by primary care practice: results of a randomized controlled trial.
abstract: OBJECTIVE: The National Cancer Institute (NCI) has developed a guideline to guide primary care practices in structuring office environments and routine visits to improve nutritional screening, advice/referral and follow-up for cancer prevention. Adoption of the handbook's recommendations by primary care practices was assessed by examining two strategies: physician training on how to implement the guide's recommendations, and simple mailing of the guide. This article reports the results of a randomized controlled trial to evaluate the effectiveness of these two strategies. Design: A three-arm, randomized, controlled trial. SETTING: Independent primary care physician practice in Pennsylvania and New Jersey. INTERVENTION: Each study application was randomly assigned to one of three groups. Training group practices were invited to send a member from their chosen practice to a 3-hour "instructor-train" workshop, with only the manual group practices mailed the nutrition guide and nothing sent to the control group practices. intervene. For training group practices, training was provided in the four main components of the nutrition guideline: how to organize the office environment to support cancer prevention nutrition-related activities"; how to screen patient compliance with NCI dietary guidelines; how to provide dietary advice /Reference;" and how to implement a patient tracking system to support patients to make changes in their nutritional behavior. MEASUREMENTS: The primary results of the study were obtained from two assessment tools. The observation tool documented the tools and procedures recommended by the dietary guidelines and adopted in patient charts and in the office setting. The face-to-face structured interview evaluated self-reported nutrition-related activities by physicians and staff, reflecting the recommendations of the dietary guidelines. Data from these two tools were used to generate four compliance scores corresponding to the following areas: office organization, nutritional screening, nutritional advice/referral, and patient follow-up. KEY RESULTS: Adoption of the handbook's recommendations was highest among practices in the training group, as reflected by higher engagement scores. They organized their offices (P = .005) and screened their patients for their eating habits (P = .046) (P = .046), significantly closer to the recommendations of the nutritional guideline compared to practices in the manual group alone. However, despite being the highest in terms of compliance, education group practices only adhered to the guidelines' recommendations on nutrition advice/referral at 54.9%, and 28.5% to recommendations on office organization, 23.5% to nutritional screening recommendations, and 14.6% to Patient follow-up recommendations. . CONCLUSIONS: Basic care practices exposed to the nutritional guideline in a training session adopted more than the recommendations of the guideline. Specifically, practices invited to the training were more likely to conduct nutritional screening and structure their office environments to be conducive to providing nutrition-related services for cancer prevention. The effect of education was moderate and not statistically significant for nutritional advice/referral or patient follow-up, which is important in achieving long-term dietary changes in patients. Low overall scores of commitment to nutrition-related activities indicate that there is much room for improvement among practices in the training group.

title: Effect of number and relocation of alcohol-based handrub dispensers on use in a general inpatient medical unit.
abstract: To assess the effects on hand hygiene performance, we sequentially increased the number of wall-mounted alcohol-based hand scrubs in a small medical unit. Above a certain point, adding more dispensers did not increase hand hygiene frequency, which seemed to be affected by location rather than total number of dispensers.

title: The impact of written and computerized decision support aids for the US Healthcare Policy and Research depression guidelines in the evaluation of hypothetical clinical scenarios.
abstract: Aim.The purpose of this study was to compare the effects of written and computerized decision support aids (DSA) based on depression guidelines from the U.S. Agency for Healthcare Policy and Research. Methods. Fifty-six internists were randomized to evaluate clinical scenarios without DSA after initial evaluation of scenarios with a written or computerized DSA. Pairwise differences between assisted and unassisted scores were determined for diagnostic accuracy, treatment choice, severity and subtype classification, antipsychotic use, and mental health consultations. Results. Diagnostic accuracy decreased from 64% to 73% with written DSA and from 67% to 64% with computerized scanning (P = 0.0065). Residents using computerized DSA (vs DSA) requested fewer consultations (65% vs. 52%, P = 0.028). In post hoc analysis, written DSA increased sensitivity (66% vs 89%, P < 0.001) and computerized DSA improved specificity (66% vs 86%, P = 0.0020), but decreased sensitivity (67% vs 49%, P = 0.0020). 0.011). Conclusions. A written DSA improved diagnostic accuracy, while a computerized DSA did not. However, computerized DSA improved specificity and reduced mental health consultations.

title: The impact of a formalized care approach in hospital workforce assessment units on birth outcomes: an international, randomized controlled trial.
abstract: OBJECTIVE To determine whether a complex nursing and midwifery intervention in hospital birth assessment units would increase the likelihood of spontaneous vaginal delivery and improve other maternal and neonatal outcomes. DESIGN Multicenter, randomized controlled trial with hospital-based prognostic classification. SET 20 North American and UK hospitals. PARTICIPANTS 5002 women who gave birth who experienced contractions but did not deliver actively”; 2501 were allocated to structured care and 2501 to ordinary care. Main outcome of a formal approach to assessment and interventions of maternal emotional status, pain and fetal position MAIN OUTCOME MEASURES Primary outcome was spontaneous vaginal delivery Other outcomes Among these were intrapartum interventions, women's views on their care, and maternal and fetal health indicators at the time of delivery 6-8 weeks after hospital stay and discharge RESULTS Outcome data were available for 4996 women Spontaneous vaginal delivery rate 64.0% in the structured care group (n=1597 ) and 61.3% (n=1533) in usual care group (odds ratio 1.12, 95% confidence interval 0.96 to 1.27) Fewer women (n=403, 19.5%) allocated to structured care, staff helpfulness, those allocated to usual care ( n=544, 26.4%, odds ratio 0.67, 98.75% confidence interval 0.50 to 0.85. Number of women allocated to structured care (n=23 3, 11.3%) compared to regular care leavers (n=407, 19.7%) disappointed by staff attention; "Odds ratio 0.51, 98.75% confidence interval 0.32 to 0.70 None of the other results met predetermined levels of statistical significance CONCLUSION A structured approach to care in hospital workforce assessment units increased satisfaction with care and suggested a modest increase in the probability of spontaneous vaginal delivery More to reinforce the intervention." overstudy TRIAL REGISTRATION Controlled Trials Available ISRCTN16315180.

title: The impact of payment to primary care providers for performance on maternal and child health services in Rwanda: an impact assessment
abstract: Background Evidence on best practices is urgently needed to accelerate progress towards achieving the MDGs. We evaluated the impact of healthcare providers' performance-based pay (pay for performance"; P4P) on the use and quality of child and maternal care services in healthcare facilities in Rwanda. We evaluated the impact of healthcare providers' performance-based pay (pay for performance; "P4P) on the use and quality of child and maternal care services in healthcare facilities in Rwanda. .

title: Effective weight management practice: a review of lifestyle intervention evidence.
abstract: OBJECTIVES: Despite the existence of guidelines for obesity management, uncertainty remains about which interventions encompass effective implementation. This uncertainty can be a barrier for busy healthcare professionals who do not have the time and expertise to fully evaluate the huge amount of literature published each year on obesity management. Therefore, the aims of this review were to synthesize the available evidence, identify the most effective and promising practices for adult obesity management using an established methodology, and present this information according to its quality. EVIDENCE GATHERING: This synthesis review has been conducted since January 2009. A detailed search of the relevant databases was carried out up to September 2010. The most effective and promising practices were identified through systematic reviews (with/without meta-analysis) using the Canadian Best Practice Initiative Methodology Background Paper. ) as the most rigorous methodology (level 1) to develop recommendations considered to be most effective, and non-systematic reviews (level 2) to develop recommendations considered most promising. The literature was reviewed and classified at these two levels of rigor and supplemented by primary studies to further refine the recommendations. RESULTS: Evidence from systematic reviews and meta-analyses was classified into three intervention themes or context areas where more specific, most effective, and/or promising practice recommendations could be placed. These intervention themes were (1) targeted multicomponent interventions for weight management, (2) dietary manipulation strategies, and (3) delivery of weight management interventions, including the roles of healthcare professionals and delivery method. Each theme was accompanied by specific recommendations. CONCLUSIONS: This review highlights the long-term value of multi-component interventions and strengthens the role of healthcare professionals. The findings will help inform evidence-based practice for health care practitioners involved in obesity management and prevention.

title: Effectiveness and cost-effectiveness of cardiovascular disease prevention in all populations: a modeling study
abstract: OBJECTIVE To estimate the potential cost-effectiveness of a population-wide risk factor reduction program aimed at preventing cardiovascular disease. DESIGN Economic modeling analysis. SET England and Wales. Population The entire population. The Spreadsheet Model Model to measure reductions in cardiovascular disease over ten years, assuming that the benefits apply consistently to men and women of all ages and risk groups. MAIN OUTCOME MEASURES Prevented cardiovascular events, quality-adjusted life years gained, and savings in health care costs for a given activity"; estimates of how much it would be worth to achieve a particular outcome. RESULTS A program covering the entire population of England and Wales (approximately 50 million people ) would reduce cardiovascular events by just 1%, saving at least Ã‚Â 30 million (â€š34 million; “$48 million) per year without additional intervention in healthcare. . Reducing the average cholesterol concentrations or blood pressure levels in the population by 5% (as already achieved with similar interventions in some other countries) would save at least £80 million to £100 million annually. Legislation or other measures to reduce dietary salt intake by 3g per day (average daily intake of about 8.5g) would prevent around 30,000 cardiovascular events with a savings of at least £40m per year. Legislation that would reduce industrial trans fatty acid intake by around 0.5% of total energy content could save around 570,000 life years and save NHS worth at least £230m per year. CONCLUSIONS Any intervention that achieves a modest population-wide reduction in any major cardiovascular risk factor will not only improve health but also result in clear cost savings for the NHS. Given the conservative assumptions used in this model, the real benefits will likely be greater.

title: Efficacy and cost-effectiveness of an exposure-based return-to-work program for patients on sick leave for common mental disorders: design of a cluster randomized controlled trial.
abstract: BACKGROUND: To reduce sick leave time and loss of productivity due to common mental disorders (CMDs), we have developed a return-to-work program to be provided by occupational physicians (OPs) based on in vivo (RTW) exposure principles. -E program). This study evaluates the effectiveness and cost-effectiveness of this program by comparing it with the usual care (CAU). The three research questions we have are: 1) Is an RTW-E program more effective at reducing sick leave for employees with common mental illnesses than usual care? 2) Is an RTW-E program more effective in reducing sick leave for employees with anxiety disorders than for employees with other common mental disorders? 3) From a societal perspective, is an RTW-E program cost-effective compared to usual care? METHODS/DESIGN: This study was designed as a pragmatic cluster randomized controlled trial with one-year follow-up and randomization at the OPs level. We targeted 60 OPs to include 200 patients. Patients in the intervention group received the RTW-E program. Patients in the control group received care as usual. Eligible patients were on sick leave for at least two weeks and no longer than eight weeks due to pervasive mental disorders. As primary outcome measures, we calculated the time to full return to work and the duration of sick leave. Secondary outcome measures were time to partial return to work, prevalence of sick leave at 3, 6, 9, and 12-month follow-ups, and scores for distress, anxiety, depression, somatization, and fatigue symptoms"; perceived work conditions; self-efficacy for return to work; coping behavior; avoidance behavior; patient satisfaction;" and business adaptations. As process criteria, we used intervention compliance indices in the intervention group and employee-manager communication in both groups. Economic costs were calculated from a societal perspective. Total costs consisted of healthcare consuming costs, sick leave and lost production costs due to reduced productivity, and out-of-pocket costs for patients to travel to their OP. DISCUSSION: Results will be published in 2009. The strengths and weaknesses of the study protocol are discussed. TRIAL REGISTRATION: ISRCTN72643128.

title: Efficacy and cost-effectiveness of knowledge transfer and behavior change interventions in patients with type 2 diabetes mellitus - INDICA study: a cluster randomized controlled trial
abstract: Background Type 2 diabetes mellitus is a chronic disease whose health consequences are related to decision-making regarding patients and healthcare professionals. The Diabetes Intervention study in the Canary Islands (INDICA study) aims to evaluate the effectiveness and cost-effectiveness of educational interventions supported by new technology decision tools for type 2 diabetes patients and primary care workers in the Canary Islands. Methods/design The INDICA trial is an open, population-based, multicenter, clinical-controlled trial randomized by clusters to one of three interventions or usual care. The setting is primary care where doctors and nurses are invited to participate. Patients diagnosed with diabetes, 18Â¨C65 years old and using mobile phones regularly were randomly selected. Patients with serious comorbidities were excluded from the study. Clusters are primary health care practices that have adequate professionals and appropriate locations to provide the response. The calculated sample size was 2,300 patients. Patients in Group 1 receive an eight-session training group program every 3 months, led by trained nurses and monitored via diaries, a web-based platform, and dedicated semi-automatic SMS for ongoing support. Primary care workers in Group 2 receive a short training program that includes a decision support tool embedded in electronic clinical records and a monthly patient feedback report to update their diabetes information. Group 3 receives a combination of interventions for patients and professionals. The primary endpoint is change in HbA1c within 2 years. Secondary endpoints were cardiovascular risk factors, macrovascular and microvascular diabetes complications, quality of life, psychological outcomes, diabetes knowledge, and healthcare use. Data are collected from interviews, questionnaires, clinical examinations and records. Generalized linear mixed models with repeated time measurements will be used to analyze changes in results. From a healthcare perspective, the cost-effectiveness analysis includes direct medical costs per quality-adjusted life-year gained and the Markov model for two periods, an Â¡Â®per-trialÂ¡Â¯ period and a lifetime. Deterministic and probabilistic sensitivity analyzes are planned. Discussion This ongoing trial aims to enable the implementation of evidence-based programs in the clinical setting for chronic patients.

title: Efficiency and efficiency under competition: the Cochrane test
Efficacy of a behavioral intervention to prevent excessive weight gain in infancy (The Baby Milk Trial): study protocol for a randomized controlled trial.
abstract: BACKGROUND: Infancy is a period of rapid growth and habit formation and can therefore be a critical period for obesity prevention. Excess weight gain in infancy is associated with later obesity, and formula-fed infants are more likely to gain excess weight compared to breast-fed infants. The primary trial outcome is a change in weight standard deviation score from birth to 1 year. METHODS/DESIGN: We will enroll 650 to 700 formula-fed parents in a single (evaluator) blind, parallel group, individually randomized controlled trial within 14 weeks of the birth of their infant. The focus of the intervention is the caregiver (usually the mother) and the primary outcome is the infant. The intervention group will receive behavioral intervention aimed at reducing formula milk intake, promoting responsive feeding and healthy weaning, and preventing excessive weight gain in infancy. The intervention is based on Social Cognitive Theory and action planning ('implementation intentions'). It consists of three components: (1) a motivational component to strengthen parents' motivation to follow Baby Milk feeding guidelines, (2) an action planning component to help turn motivation into action, and (3) a coping planning component to assist parents in dealing with difficult situations. . It will be delivered by trained facilitators (research nurses) for 6 months in three face-to-face, two telephone and written materials. The control group will have the same number of contacts as the facilitators and general nutritional issues will be discussed. Anthropometric results will be measured at baseline, 6 months and 12 months following standard operating procedures by trained research personnel blinded to group allocation. Validated questionnaires will assess milk intake, temperament, appetite, sleep, maternal quality of life, and maternal psychological factors. A 4-day food diary will be completed in 8 months. DISCUSSION: The results of the research will help inform infant feeding guidelines and understand the links between infant feeding, behavior, appetite and growth. TRIAL REGISTRATION: ISRTCN20814693 . Registration date is January 13, 2011.

title: Efficacy of a combined strategy to improve therapeutic adherence and degree of control in patients with hypercholesterolemia: a randomized clinical trial.
abstract: BACKGROUND: Cholesterol values remain above guideline levels in patients with hypercholesterolemia. One of the factors limiting the achievement of goals in such patients is therapeutic non-compliance. The aim of this study was to evaluate the efficacy of an intervention designed to improve control of hypercholesterolemic patients, consisting of a combined strategy that included the delivery of printed information, compliance-to-treat check cards, and the sending of text messages as complementary measures. support of intervention in the GP practice. METHODS/DESIGN: A randomized parallel group clinical trial will be conducted in family medicine outpatient facilities of eight health centers in three Autonomous Regions of Spain (Comunidades Autonomas), involving a total of 358 subjects aged 18 years and over. hypercholesterolemia. Printed material informing patients in the intervention group about the disease and its management, cell phone text messages with guide summaries, reminders of upcoming appointments and/or self-report cards to check compliance with new appointment arrangements and recommendations in case of absence. Both groups - intervention and control - will receive routine recommendations from their physicians in accordance with current European clinical practice guidelines for hypercholesterolemia and cardiovascular risk management. Regarding the measurements to be made, the main variable is the proportion of subjects achieving the target low-density lipoprotein cholesterol levels over a 24-month follow-up period. Secondary variables are: adherence to lifestyle recommendations and adherence to medication"; change in lipid profiles and cardiovascular risk levels; outlook for cardiovascular events; physical activity; food consumption; smoking habit; anthropometric measures; blood pressure; health problems; use of hypolipidemic agents; sociological -demographic data; beliefs and expectations regarding preventive recommendations; and degree of satisfaction with the combined strategy. DISCUSSION: If this intervention proves effective, a recommendation may be published regarding the application of this combined strategy to subjects with hypercholesterolaemia. It is a simple, relatively inexpensive intervention. TRIAL REGISTRATION: ClinicalTrials.gov : NCT02314663.

title: The effectiveness of a potential physician self-monitoring transfusion monitoring system.
abstract: BACKGROUND: The aim of this study was to search for a more effective transfusion monitoring system than the existing retrospective peer review system. STUDY DESIGN AND METHODS: This study used a study-control, pre-intervention, and post-intervention design to evaluate the effectiveness of a functioning physician trainee self-supervision transfusion monitoring system without the direct involvement of transfusion service physicians. This research also evaluated the effectiveness of giving doctors a note with transfusion guidelines. Three process indicators were used to assess physician behavior at various stages of the blood ordering process: 1) the number of crossmatches ordered per referral, 2) the transfusion-to-crossmatch rate, and 3) the number of blood units returned to the patient. laboratory after physician self-examination. The study used two outcome indicators to reflect overall blood usage: 1) the percentage of patients transfused with red blood cells and 2) the number of blood units transfused per recipient per month. CONCLUSIONS: Physician-candidate self-regulation system implemented in the research hospital did not reverse physician transfusion decisions, and a grading process with transfusion guidelines to physicians in the control hospital did not reduce blood use. However, a temporary reduction in blood use was observed in the study hospital. CONCLUSION: The decline was hypothesized to be due to a Hawthorne effect, in which the observed behavior was influenced by the subject's awareness of the research study.

title: The effectiveness of academic elaboration for optimizing family physicians' drug prescribing behaviors
abstract: OBJECTIVE: To synthesize available information on the effectiveness and magnitude of effect of Academic Detailing (AD) as a stand-alone intervention in changing the drug prescribing behavior of Family Physicians (APs) in primary care settings. METHODS: A search of the MEDLINE, EMBASE, CENTRAL, and Web of Science databases of all English-language articles was conducted between January 1983 and July 2010. We manually searched bibliographies of articles from the electronic search to identify additional studies. Inclusion criteria were: full-length articles describing the original trial"; randomized controlled trial (RCT) or observational study design with a control group; AD studies for ADs, AD as an independent intervention; drug prescription as target behavior. Data extraction independently by two reviewers The outcomes evaluated were: the difference in relative change in prescription rate between the intervention and control groups; the difference in absolute change in prescription rate between the intervention and control groups; and the effect size calculated as the standardized mean difference RESULTS: Including 11 RCTs and 4 observational studies Five RCTS reported results demonstrating efficacy, while 2 RCTs reported a positive effect on some of the target drugs. Two observational studies found AS effective and 2 not. The median difference in relative change between studies reviewed was for RCTs 21% (43.75% interquartile range) and observational work 9% for malaria (8.5% interquartile range). Among the studies reviewed, the median effect size was -0.09 (interquartile range 2.73). CONCLUSION: This systematic review shows that AD can be effective in optimizing drug prescription by APs. Although variable, the magnitude of the effect was moderate in most studies. This systematic review also provides evidence supporting the use of AD as a strategy to promote evidence-based prescribing of drugs or incorporation of clinical guidelines into clinical practice. This article is open for POST PUBLIC REVIEW. Registered readers (see "For Readers") can comment by clicking SUMMARY on the issue's table of contents.

title: The effectiveness of voice reminder in hand hygiene compliance
abstract: Multimodal interventions aim to improve HCWs' adherence to hand hygiene guidelines. Visitors are not primarily targeted, but can spread epidemic infections. Effective interventions that increase visitor adherence to hand hygiene guidelines are needed to prevent the transmission of epidemic infections to and from healthcare settings. Methods An audible hand hygiene reminder triggered by an electronic motion sensor was placed at the hospital ward entrances. An 8-month pre-intervention and post-intervention study was conducted to measure the compliance of hospital visitors and staff with hand hygiene guidelines. Results Overall hand hygiene compliance increased from 7.6% to 49.9% (P < .001). Engagement of visitors and non-clinical staff immediately increased from 10.6% to 63.7% and from 5.3% to 34.8%, respectively (P < .001). Engagement of doctors, nurses, and physiotherapists increased from 4.5% to 38.3%, from 5.4% to 43.4%, and from 8.7% to 49.5%, respectively (P < .001). Improved cohesion between visitors and clinical staff (P < .001), but not among non-clinical staff (P = .341). Results Electronic motion sensor – immediately triggered the audible reminder and significantly improved and maintained hospital visitors and clinic staff greater adherence to hand hygiene guidelines. It is an effective addition to multimodal hand hygiene interventions and can help control epidemic infections.

title: Effectiveness of an electronic medical record clinical quality alert prepared with offline data analysis
Efficacy of an information technology intervention to improve prophylactic antibacterial use in the postoperative period.
abstract: 2005 report from the Centers for Background Medicare and Medicaid Services and the Centers for Disease Control's Surgical Infection Prevention program showed that only 41% of prophylactic antibacterials were properly stopped within 24 hours of the end of surgery. Electronic order sets have shown promise as a way to integrate guidance information with electronic order entry systems and facilitate safer, more effective maintenance. Purpose The aim was to examine the efficacy of a computer-based antibacterial ordering in increasing the proportion of patients discontinued from antibacterial wound prophylaxis within the appropriate time frame. Design The authors performed a quasi-experimental discontinuous time series analysis over an 8-month study period with the implementation of a computer-based ordering system designed to prevent overtime of surgical prophylaxis antibacterials. Measurement The primary outcome was the proportion of surgeries using antibacterials that were discontinued in the appropriate time frame. In addition, we evaluated the percentage of surgeries with documentation of infection after application of the electronic intervention among surgeries where the prescriber indicated that the cause of antibacterial therapy was therapy. Results Computer-based order intervention significantly improved the rate of surgeries from 38.8% to 55.7% (p<0.001) with timely discontinuation of antibacterials in the intervention hospital, while the control hospital remained at 56-57% (p=0.006) treatment difference between controlled and controlled hospitals). After intervention administration, the prevalence of infection documented in the chart was only 14% in surgeries where the prescriber indicated treatment as the cause of antibacterial therapy. Results A computer-based electronic order set intervention increased the timely discontinuation of postoperative antibacterials.

title: Efficacy of an Intervention to Improve Occupational Physicians' Guidelines on Duration of Illness Absence in Workers with Pervasive Mental Disorder: A Cluster-Randomized Controlled Trial
abstract: Purpose Evidence-based guidelines in occupational health care improve the quality of care and can reduce sick leave time. However, compliance by occupational physicians (OPs) with the guideline is limited. Based on the literature on guideline implementation, an intervention was developed that has been shown to effectively improve self-reported compliance in OPs. The aim of this study was to evaluate whether this intervention leads to earlier return to work (RTW) in workers with generalized mental disorder (CMD). Methods In a two-armed cluster randomized controlled trial, 66 OPs were randomized. The study included 3379 workers, of whom 1493 were in the intervention group and 1886 in the control group. Outcomes were: time to full RTW, time to first RTW, and total disease-free hours. Cox regression analyzes and generalized linear mixed model analyzes were used for evaluations. Results Among the 3228 workers with CMD, the median time to RTW was 154 days. There was no significant difference in full RTW (time) between the intervention and control group HR 0.96 (95% CI 0.81-1.15) or the initial RTW HR 0.96 (95% CI 0.80-1.15). The mean total disease-free hours were 478 hours in the intervention group and 483 hours in the control group. Results Intervention to increase OPs adherence to guidelines did not lead to earlier RTW in workers with CMDs who were guided by OPs. Possible explanations are remaining external barriers to guide use, and this perceived guideline compliance may not represent actual guideline compliance and improved maintenance. Path registration: ISRCTN86605310.

title: Effectiveness of brief training in cognitive behavioral therapy techniques for palliative care practitioners
abstract: We define CBT techniques training for 20 palliative care practitioners as the equivalent of 12 days of instruction plus skills development supervision over a six-month period. Audio recordings of trainees' interactions with patients during their regular practice were rated using a specially designed 'Cognitive First Aid' rating scale (CFARS). CFARS was highly internally consistent (Cronbach's Alpha 0.93) and inter-rater reliability was high. Trainees showed significant gain in CBT skills proficiency over six months (p=0.001). After the initial training, half of the trainees were randomly selected not to continue with the supervision";" When the measured CBT skills were reassessed six months later, as self-reported confidence decreased, those who continued to be supervised gained more skills and maintained their confidence (p=0.007). Palliative care practitioners can be trained in CBT skills with a simple and short training course and a supportive, skills development supervision. These skills are in line with national guidelines for providing psychological support to patients in all stages of cancer. Supervision is necessary to ensure skills are maintained and the confidence to use them.

title: Efficacy of Cholinesterase Inhibitors and Memantine in the Treatment of Dementia: Evidence Review for a Clinical Practice Guideline
abstract: Background: 5 US Food and Drug AdministrationÂ¨The effectiveness of approved pharmacological treatments for dementias in providing clinically meaningful improvements is unclear. Purpose: To review the evidence for the efficacy of cholinesterase inhibitors (donepezil, galantamine, rivastigmine, and tacrine) and the neuropeptide-modifying agent memantine, particularly in providing clinically significant improvements in cognitive, general function, behavior, and quality of life. patients with dementia. Data Sources: Cochrane Central Register of Controlled Trials, MEDLINE, PREMEDLINE, EMBASE, Allied and Complementary Medicine Database, CINAHL, AgeLine, and PsycINFO from January 1986 to November 2006. Study Selection: Randomized, controlled studies in English were included in the review. have evaluated pharmacological agents for adults with a diagnosis of dementia, have not used a crossover design, and have a quality score of at least 3 on the Jadad scale. Data Extraction: Data were extracted on study characteristics and outcomes, including adverse events. Effect sizes were calculated and data were combined when appropriate. Data Synthesis: 96 publications representing 59 unique studies were eligible for this review. Both cholinesterase inhibitors and memantine had consistent effects in cognition and overall assessment, but summary estimates showed small effect sizes. Outcomes in the behavioral and quality of life domains were evaluated less frequently and showed less consistent effects. Most studies were of short duration (6 months), which limited their ability to detect a delay in the onset or progression of dementia. Three studies directly compared different cholinesterase inhibitors and found no differences in cognition and behavior. Limitations: Limitations of current studies include only inclusion of patients with short-term, mild to moderate Alzheimer's disease, poor reporting of adverse events, lack of clear definitions for statistical significance, limited evaluation of behavior and quality of life outcomes, and limited direct comparison of different treatments. Conclusions: Treatment of dementia with cholinesterase inhibitors and memantine may result in statistically significant but clinically marginal improvement in cognition measures and overall assessment of dementia.

title: The effectiveness of collaborative care for older adults with Alzheimer's disease in primary care: a randomized controlled trial.
abstract: CONTEXT: Most older adults with dementia will be cared for by primary care physicians, but the primary care practice setting presents significant challenges for providing quality care. OBJECTIVE: To test the effectiveness of a collaborative care model to improve the quality of care for patients with Alzheimer's disease. DESIGN, ENVIRONMENT, AND PATIENTS: Controlled clinical trial in 153 older adults with Alzheimer's disease and their caregivers who were randomized by physician to receive joint care management (n = 84) or enhanced usual care (n = 69) in primary care settings within 2 January 2002 U.S. university affiliated healthcare systems until August 2004. Eligible patients (identified through screening or medical record) met diagnostic criteria for Alzheimer's disease and had a self-identified caregiver. INTERVENTION: Intervention patients received 1 year of care management by an interdisciplinary team led by an advanced practice nurse who worked with the patient's family caregiver and integrated with primary care. The team used standard protocols to initiate treatment and identify, monitor and treat behavioral and psychological symptoms of dementia, emphasizing non-drug management. MAIN OUTCOME MEASURES: Neuropsychiatric Inventory (NPI) administered at baseline and at 6, 12, and 18 months. Secondary outcomes included the Cornell Scale of Depression in Dementia (CSDD), cognition, activities of daily living, resource use, and the caregiver's severity of depression. RESULTS: 89% of intervention patients initiated by caregiver reports triggered at least 1 protocol for behavioral and psychological symptoms of dementia, with a mean of 4 per patient out of a total of 8 possible protocols. Intervention patients were more likely to take cholinesterase inhibitors (79.8% vs 55.1%; P = .002) and antidepressants (45.2% vs 27.5%; P = .03). Significantly less behavioral and Intervention caregivers reported significant improvements in distress as measured by caregiver based on overall NPI score at 12 months (mean difference, -5.6; P = .01) and 18 months (mean difference, -5.4; P = .01). NPI at 12 months;" At 18 months, caregivers showed improvement in depression as measured by the Patient Health Questionnaire-9. No group differences were found in CSDD, cognition, activities of daily living, or rates of hospitalization, nursing home placement, or mortality. RESULTS: Collaborative care for the treatment of Alzheimer's disease resulted in a significant improvement in the quality of care and behavioral and psychological symptoms of dementia among primary care patients and their caregivers. These improvements were achieved without significantly increasing the use of antipsychotics or sedative-hypnotics. TRIAL REGISTRATION: Clinicaltrials.gov Identifier: NCT00246896.

title: The effectiveness of computer-assisted instruction in increasing the rate of behaviors related to universal precautions.
abstract: Background: While widespread non-compliance with universal measures was well established, an experimental study was designed to compare the proportion of behaviors related to universal measures among nurses who participated in computer assisted education. This study also investigated the relationship between rates of behavior related to universal precautions and demographic and experiential characteristics of subjects and occupational blood exposure history. Methods: Data were collected using a questionnaire to obtain information on subjects' demographic and experiential characteristics and occupational blood exposure history. The Universal Measures Assessment Tool was used to collect data on the rates of behaviors related to universal precautions in two groups of registered nurses, with 30 subjects per group. Results: The null hypothesis was rejected using analysis of variance. The intervention used in this study increased behaviors related to universal precautions. Multiple regression was used to analyze the research question and none of the variables were significant. Forty (67.8%) subjects reported a needle prick or cut caused by a needle or cutter that was actually or potentially contaminated with blood or body fluids. From these exposures, one patient was known to be HIV antibody positive. Conclusion: There is a need for iterative studies using computer-assisted instructional interventions, as well as studies aiming to explore other potentially effective interventions.

title: Effectiveness of diabetes and hypertension management by rural primary health care workers (Behvarz workers) in Iran: a nationally representative observational study.
abstract: Background Noncommunicable diseases and risk factors are leading causes of disease burden in Iran and other middle-income countries. There is little evidence as to whether the primary health care system can effectively manage noncommunicable diseases and population-level risk factors. Our aim was to examine the effectiveness of the primary health care system (Behvarz system) in rural Iran in the management of diabetes and hypertension and to assess whether the effects depend on the number of health care workers in the community."; "Background Noncommunicable diseases and risk factors lead to disease burden in Iran and other middle-income countries. are the reasons. There is little evidence as to whether the primary health care system can effectively manage noncommunicable diseases and population-level risk factors. Our aim was to examine the effectiveness of the primary health care system (Behvarz system) in rural Iran in the management of diabetes and hypertension and to evaluate whether the effects depend on the number of health workers in the community.

title: The effectiveness of eye protection in the metalworking industry
The effectiveness of guided care given by occupational physicians on the return to work of workers with generalized mental disorders: a cluster-randomized controlled research design.
abstract: BACKGROUND: Illness absenteeism due to common mental disorders (such as depression, anxiety disorder, adjustment disorder) is a problem in many Western countries. Long-term sickness absence entails significant societal and financial costs. For workers with pervasive mental disorders, sickness absence costs are much higher than medical costs. In the Netherlands, a practice guide has been developed that supports an enabling approach of the occupational physician to ensure faster return to work by increasing the problem-solving capacity of employees, particularly in relation to work environments. Studies on this guideline show that there is a promising relationship between adherence to the guideline and shortening of sick leave, but at the same time, occupational physicians adhere to the guideline at a minimal level. Therefore, this study evaluates the impact of guide-based care on the full return to work of workers who are listed ill due to common mental disorders. METHODS/DESIGN: This is a two-arm, cluster randomized controlled trial with occupational physician-level randomization. For one year, occupational physicians in the intervention group receive innovative training to improve their guidance-based care, while occupational physicians in the control group provide care as usual. A total of 232 workers, who were listed for common mental disorders and were counseled by the participating workplace physicians, will be included in the study. Data are collected through the occupational health service registry system and through questionnaires at baseline and at 3, 6 and 12 months. The primary result is time to full return to work. Secondary outcomes were partial return to work, total sick leave days, symptoms, and workability. Personal and job characteristics are prognostic measures. Additional measures include coping, self-efficacy, relapse, personal experiences, satisfaction with occupational physician consultations and supervisor contact, supervisor's experiences and behaviors, and extent of guideline compliance. DISCUSSION: If the results show that guided care actually leads to a faster and more sustainable return to work, this study will contribute to lower personal, societal and financial costs. TRIAL REGISTRATION: ISRCTN86605310.

title: Efficacy of medical nutrition therapy provided by dietitians in the management of non-insulin-dependent diabetes mellitus: a randomized controlled clinical trial.
abstract: Objective To evaluate the impact of dietitian-provided medical nutrition therapy (MNT) on medical and clinical outcomes for adults with non-insulin-dependent diabetes mellitus (NIDDM) and compare MNT administered according to practice guidelines nutritional care (PGC) versus basic nutritional care (BC) administered to MNT. Design A prospective, randomized, controlled clinical trial of two levels of MNT on metabolic control in people newly diagnosed with or currently receiving NIDDM was conducted at diabetes centers in three states (Minnesota, Florida, and Colorado). BC consisted of a single visit with a dietitian"; PGC included an initial visit with a dietitian followed by two visits during the first 6 weeks of the study period. Data were collected at study entry and at 3 and 6 months. Subjects Results 179 men aged 38 to 76 years and reported for female: 85 randomly assigned to BC and 94 to PGC This represents 72% of 247 enrolled subjects Defined as a nonrandom comparison group Outcomes Fasting plasma glucose among medical outcome measures (ABG), glycosylated hemoglobin (HbA1c), and serum lipid levels included clinical outcomes Weight, body mass index, waist-to-hip ratio, and medical changes Treatment Statistical analyzes Initial analysis of discrete variables was performed using Yates-corrected ?2 statistic Initial analysis of continuous variables were performed by analysis of variance, analyzed by paired t-test, and comparisons between groups were made using test for independent groups. was analyzed. Results at 6 months resulted in significant improvements in blood glucose control as indicated by PGC, FPG and HbA1c levels and BC resulted in significant improvements in HbA1c level. Participants assigned to the PGC group had an average FPG level of 10.5% lower than baseline at 6 months, and those in the BC group had a 5.3% lower value. Among subjects with diabetes for more than 6 months, those who received PGC had significantly better HbA1c at 3 months compared to those who received BC. The comparison group showed no improvement in glycemic control over the comparable 6 months. PGC subjects had significant improvements in cholesterol values at 6 months, and subjects in both the PGC and BC groups had significant weight loss. Results MNT provided by dietitians resulted in significant improvements in medical and clinical outcomes in both the BC and PGC groups and is beneficial for people with NIDDM. People with diabetes duration longer than 6 months tended to do better with PGC than with BC. Due to the increasing trend in glucose levels after 3 months, continued MNT by dietitians is important for long-term metabolic control. J Am Diet Assoc. 1995;" 95:1009-1017.

title: Effectiveness of Motivational Interviewing in improving lipid levels in patients with dyslipidemia supported by general practitioners: The Dislip-EM study protocol
abstract: BACKGROUND: The non-pharmacological approach to cholesterol control in patients with hyperlipidemia is based on the support of a healthy diet and physical activity. Therefore, it is essential to identify the most effective approach to helping patients change their habits. Many efforts have been made to explain changes in or adherence to certain health behaviors. Such efforts have resulted in the development of theories that have been applied in prevention campaigns and include brief advice and counselling. In this context, Motivational Interviewing has proven effective in changing health behaviors in certain situations. However, more robust evidence is needed on the effectiveness of Motivational Interviewing in the treatment of chronic pathologies such as dyslipidemia in patients supported by general practitioners. This article describes a protocol to evaluate the efficacy of MI compared to general practice to improve lipid level control in patients with dyslipidemia, assisted by a general practitioner (short recommendation). METHODS/DESIGN: An open, two-arm parallel, multicenter, cluster, controlled, randomized, clinical trial will be conducted. A total of 48-50 general practitioners from 35 public primary care centers in Spain will be randomly selected and recruited to 436 patients with dyslipidemia. They will perform an intervention based on the Motivational Interview or the usual brief advice. Follow-up will be done at 2, 4, 8 and 12 months after the initial assessment. Primary outcomes are lipid levels (total cholesterol, HDL cholesterol, LDL cholesterol, triglycerides) and cardiovascular risk. The study will evaluate the degree of diet and physical activity improvement, weight loss in overweight patients, and adherence to treatment guidelines. DISCUSSION: Motivational interviewing skills constitute the primary strategies that GPs use to treat their patients. Having techniques that are affordable, simple, effective and feasible is essential for primary care professionals to help their patients change their lifestyles and improve their health. This study will provide scientific evidence about the effectiveness of Motivational interviewing and will be conducted under strict control over the data collected, ensuring that therapeutic integrity is maintained. TRIAL REGISTRATION: ClinicalTrials.gov (NCT01282190).

title: The effectiveness of motivational interviewing in patients with dyslipidemia: a randomized cluster trial.
abstract: OBJECTIVE: It is known that it is difficult for people to change their habits. It is crucial to identify the most effective approach that general practitioners (GPs) should use to help their patients change their unhealthy habits. The aim of this study was to evaluate the efficacy of a Motivational Interview-based multifactor intervention performed by GPs to increase lipid levels in patients with dyslipidemia compared to standard care. METHODS: A multicenter, controlled, randomized, cluster, two parallel-arm trial with 12-month follow-up conducted in 25 community health centers in Spain. 38 general practitioners and 227 primary care patients with uncontrolled dyslipidemia were included in the study. GPs conducted an intervention based on Motivational Interviewing (MI) or standard practice. Lipid levels were measured and the degree of control analyzed according to the criteria of clinical guidelines. RESULTS: 107 of them were assigned to the Experimental Group (EG) and 120 of them to the Control Group (KG). There was an overall improvement in total cholesterol levels (Mean Difference -MD- = -19.60"; 95% CI: -15.33 at -23.87 mg/dl; p < 0.001), LDL-cholesterol levels (MD = -13.78; 95%) CI: -9.77 at -17.79 mg/dl; p < 0.001) and triglycerides (MD = -19.14; CI 95 %: -11.29 at -26.99 mg/dl; p < 0.001) There was no difference between the two groups. however, when we evaluated the degree of lipid control by combining the parameters cholesterol <200 mg/dl and LDL-cholesterol <130 mg/dl, a higher percentage of patients achieved target values in EG compared to CG (13.1% vs. 13.1%). 5.0%; adjusted OR = 5.77, 95% CI: 1.67-19.91 CONCLUSION: A Motivational Interview-based approach by Primary Care physicians targeting patients with dyslipidemia resulted in a significant reduction in all lipid parameters, cardiovascular risk, weight reduction, and reduction of adherence to a Mediterranean diet. compliance, similar to that obtained with the usual intervention and superior combined lipid control in pa ratio achieve their goals and level of physical exercise. TRIAL REGISTRATION: the trial is registered on ClinicalTrials.gov (NCT01282190 ;" January 21, 2011).

title: The effectiveness of multicomponent interventions in primary health care to promote sustained smoking cessation in adults: a systematic review.
abstract: OBJECTIVE: The purpose of this review is to evaluate multicomponent/complex primary care (PC) interventions for their effectiveness in sustained smoking cessation by adult smokers. Design: A systematic review of randomized and non-randomized controlled trials was conducted. ELIGIBILITY CRITERIA FOR INCLUDED STUDIES: Selected studies met the following criteria: effects of a multicomponent/complex intervention (with 2 or more intervention components) in achieving at least 6 months abstinence in adult smokers visiting a PC, biochemical confirmation of abstinence, therapeutic intent analysis and results are published in English/Spanish. METHODS: We followed the PRISMA statement to report review. We searched the following data sources: MEDLINE, Web of Science, Scopus (from inception to February 2014), 3 major journals, and a tobacco research bulletin. Scottish Interuniversity Guidelines Network checklists were used to assess methodological quality. Data selection, evaluation, and extraction were performed independently using a paired review approach. Due to the heterogeneity of interventions in the included studies, a meta-analysis was not performed. RESULTS: Nine studies were selected from 1147 references identified (10,204 participants, follow-up up to 48 months, acceptable methodological quality). The methodologies used were mostly individual or group sessions, phone calls, brochures or smoking cessation kits, medicines and economic incentives for doctors, and free medicines for smokers. Complex interventions yielded long-term sustained abstinence ranging from 7% to 40%. Behavioral interventions were effective and had a dose-response effect. Both nicotine replacement and bupropion therapy were safe and effective with no differences observed. CONCLUSIONS: Multicomponent/complex interventions in PC are effective and safe, appearing to provide longer-term sustained smoking cessation success than usual care and counseling alone. The selected studies were heterogeneous and some suffered significant losses in follow-up. Our results suggest that smoking interventions should include multiple components and vigorous patient monitoring is required to maximize outcomes.

title: The effectiveness of nursing interventions in people with personality disorders
abstract: BACKGROUND: Nurses often provide care to people with personality disorders on a daily basis. As a result, it is important to determine how effective nursing interventions are in terms of both general management and more specific therapeutic approaches in patients with personality disorders. These are also current political and professional topics of discussion. However, the crucial question for planners, providers, and service brokers is: What research evidence is there about effectiveness? There is also a need to determine that more research is needed to evaluate programs for managing or changing behaviors. OBJECTIVE: The purpose of this article is to report a systematic review of the literature on the effectiveness of nursing interventions in people with personality disorders, whether administered by nurses or with other health professionals. METHOD: The review was conducted according to the UK National Health Service Center Review and Dissemination guidelines. Literature was identified from electronic database searches, footnote tracking, manual search of journals, and contact with authors of studies. A narrative synthesis was made regarding the study design, the participants, and the type of intervention. RESULTS: Eighteen separate studies were included in the review: four randomized controlled trials, four non-randomized controlled trials, seven before and after studies, and three case studies. CONCLUSIONS: There is a weak evidence base as to what constitutes effective nursing intervention in persons with personality disorders. The evidence from intervention studies in mixed disciplines is stronger than from nursing intervention studies alone. Intervention studies based on psychological approaches show greater improvements in outcomes than nursing management studies.

title: Efficacy of pharmacist care in patients with reactive respiratory disease: a randomized controlled trial.
abstract: Context It is unknown whether patient outcomes are enhanced by effective pharmacist-patient interactions. Purpose To evaluate the effectiveness of a pharmaceutical care program for patients with asthma or chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD). Design, Environment, and Participants Randomized controlled trial conducted in 36 community pharmacies in Indianapolis, India. From July 1998 to December 1999, we enrolled 1113 participants with active COPD or asthma. Outcomes were evaluated in 947 (85.1%) participants at 6 months and 898. (80.7%) at 12 months. Interventions Pharmaceutical care program (n = 447) provides pharmacists with the latest patient-specific clinical data (peak expiratory flow rates [PEFRs], emergency room [ED] visits, hospitalizations, and medication adherence), education, customized patient education materials, and implementation of the Program. resources to facilitate. The PEFR monitoring control group (n = 363) received a peak flowmeter, instructions on its use, and monthly calls to elicit PEFRs. However, PEFR data were not provided to the pharmacist. Patients in the usual care group (n = 303) were neither given peak flowmeters nor instructed on their use"; PEFR rates were not revealed during monthly phone calls. Pharmacists in both control groups received a training session but received no component of the pharmaceutical care intervention Main Outcome Precautions Peak expiratory flow rates, respiratory emergency room or hospital visits, health-related quality of life (HRQOL), medication adherence, and patient satisfaction Outcomes At 12 months, patients who received pharmaceutical care had significantly higher peak flow rates than the usual care group (P = .02), but not from PEFR monitoring controls (P = .28). (odds ratio, 2.16; 95% confidence interval, 1.76-2.63; "P<.001). Patients receiving pharmaceutical care were more satisfied with their pharmacists than the usual care group (P = .03) and the PEFR monitoring group (P = .001), and were more satisfied with health care than the normal care group at only 6 months (P = .01). Despite ample opportunities to implement the program, pharmacists only accessed patient-specific data about half the time and documented actions about half the time records were accessed. Results This pharmaceutical maintenance program increased patients' PEFRs compared to usual care, but provided little benefit compared with peak flow monitoring alone. Pharmaceutical care has increased patient satisfaction but has also increased the amount of respiratory medical care sought.

title: The effectiveness of physical therapy in patients with neck pain: an individualized approach using a clinical decision-making algorithm.
abstract: Objective: The aim of this study was to determine the efficacy of an individualized physical therapy intervention in the treatment of neck pain based on a clinical reasoning algorithm. The efficacy of treatment was examined by assessing changes in deterioration, physical performance, and disability in response to intervention. Design: A treatment group of 30 patients with neck pain completed physical therapy therapy. The eligibility control group was formed by a cohort of 27 individuals with neck pain who did not receive treatment for various reasons. There was no significant difference between groups in demographic data and initial test scores of outcome measures. A quasi-experimental, non-equivalent, pretest-posttest control group design was used. A physical therapist administered an eclectic intervention to the treatment group based on a clinical decision-making algorithm. Treatment outcome measures included the following five dependent variables: cervical range of motion, numerical pain rating, timed-weighted overhead endurance, supine capital flexion endurance test, and Patient-Specific Functional Scale. Both the treatment and control groups completed baseline and follow-up examinations with an average of 4 weeks between tests. Results: Five mixed analyzes of variance with follow-up tests showed a significant difference for all outcome measures in the treatment group compared with the control group. After an average of 4 weeks of physical therapy intervention, patients in the treatment group showed statistically significant increases in cervical range of motion, reductions in pain, increases in measures of physical performance, and decreases in disability level. The control group showed no difference in all five outcome variables between baseline and follow-up test scores. Conclusions: This study described algorithmic-based clinical reasoning strategies to evaluate and treat patients with cervical pain.
