The algorithm can help clinicians classify patients with cervical pain according to clinical models and provides model-specific guidelines for physical therapy interventions. An organized and specific physical therapy program was effective in improving the condition of patients with neck pain.

title: Efficacy of physiotherapy exercise after knee arthroplasty for osteoarthritis: systematic review and meta-analysis of randomized controlled trials
abstract: OBJECTIVE To evaluate the effectiveness of physiotherapy exercise after elective primary total knee arthroplasty in patients with osteoarthritis. DESIGN Systematic review. DATA SOURCES Database searches: AMED, CINAHL, Embase, King's Fund, Medline, Cochrane library (Cochrane reviews, central registry of Cochrane controlled trials, DARE), PEDro, Ministry of Health national research registry. Hand searches: Journal of Physiotherapy, Physical Therapy, Bone and Joint Surgery (British) Conference Proceedings. Methods of review Randomized controlled trials were reviewed if they included a physiotherapy exercise intervention compared to normal or standard physiotherapy care, or if they compared two types of exercise physiotherapy interventions that met review criteria after hospital discharge after elective primary total knee arthroplasty for osteoarthritis. RESULT MEASURES Functional activities of daily living, walking, quality of life, muscle strength and range of motion in the knee joint. Trial quality was evaluated extensively. Narrative synthesis plus meta-analyses with fixed effects models, weighted mean differences, standardized effect sizes and heterogeneity tests. RESULTS Six studies were identified, five of which were eligible for inclusion in meta-analyses. Three to four months after surgery, there was a small to medium standardized effect size (0.33, 95% confidence interval 0.07 to 0.58) in favor of functional exercise for function. Three to four months post-surgery, there were small to moderately weighted mean differences of 2.9 (0.61 to 5.2) for joint range of motion and 1.66 (-1 to 4.3) for quality of life. The benefits of treatment were not apparent at a leap year. CONCLUSIONS Post-discharge interventions that include physiotherapy and functional exercises provide short-term benefit after elective primary total knee arthroplasty. The effect sizes are small to moderate and have no long-term benefit.

title: The effectiveness of provider incentives for anemia reduction in rural China: a cluster randomized trial.
abstract: OBJECTIVES To test the effect of provider performance fee for reducing anemia in rural China. DESIGN A randomized cluster trial of information, subsidies, and incentives for school principals to reduce anemia among their students. Enumerators and study participants were not informed of the task force assignment. SETTINGS 72 randomly selected rural primary schools in northwest China. PARTICIPANTS 3553 fourth and fifth grade students aged 9-11. All fourth and fifth grade students in the sample schools participated in the study. INTERVENTIONS Sample schools were randomly assigned to a control group or one of three treatment arms without any intervention: (a) an information arm from which principals receive information about anemia; (b) a subsidy arm from which principals receive information, and unconditional subsidies; and (c) an incentive arm where principals receive information, subsidies and financial incentives to reduce anemia among students. Twenty-seven schools were assigned to the control arm (1816 students at baseline, 1623 at endpoint), 15 knowledge arms (659 students at baseline, 596 at endpoint), 15 (726 students at baseline) subsidy. , 667 at endpoint) and 15 incentive arms (743 students at baseline, 667 students at endpoint). MAIN OUTCOME MEASURES Student hemoglobin concentrations. RESULTS The average student hemoglobin concentration was 1.5 g/L (95% CI -1.1 to 4.1) in knowledge schools, 0.8 g/L (-1.8 to 3.3) in subsidized schools, and increased by 2.4 g/L (0 to 4.9) in encouragement compared to the control group of schools. This increase in hemoglobin corresponded to a 24% reduction in the prevalence of anemia (Hb <115 g/L) in foster schools. Interactions with pre-existing incentives for principals to achieve good academic performance led to significantly greater gains in the knowledge and incentive arms: when combined with incentives for good academic performance, the associated effects on student hemoglobin concentration were 9.8 g/L (4.1 to 15.5). greater in knowledge schools and 8.6 g/L (2.1 to 15.1) greater in incentive schools. RESULTS Financial incentives for health promotion were moderately effective. Understanding interactions with other motives and pre-existing incentives is crucial. TRIAL REGISTRATION NUMBER ISRCTN76158086.

title: Efficacy of screening and brief alcohol intervention in primary care (SIPS trial): pragmatic cluster randomized controlled trial
abstract: OBJECTIVE To evaluate the effectiveness of different brief intervention strategies in reducing hazardous or harmful smoking in primary care. The hypothesis was that more intense intervention would lead to a greater reduction in hazardous or harmful drinking. DESIGN Pragmatic cluster randomized controlled trial. LOCATION Primary care practices in the north east and south east of England and in London. PARTICIPANTS Of the 3562 patients aged 18 years and older who routinely present to primary care, 2991 (84.0%) were eligible to enter the study: 900 (30.1%) were screened positive for hazardous or noxious drinking, and 756 (84.0%) received a brief intervention. The sample was predominantly male (62%) and white (92%), and 34% were current smokers. INTERVENTIONS Treatments were randomized to three interventions, each based on the previous one: a patient information leaflet control group, five minutes of structured brief advice, and 20 minutes of brief lifestyle counselling. Delivery of the patient brochure and brief advice took place immediately after screening and brief lifestyle counseling at a subsequent consultation. MAIN OUTCOME MEASURES The primary outcome was patient self-reported hazardous or harmful drinking status, as measured by the six-month alcohol use disorders identification test (AUDITING). A negative AUDIT result (score < 8) indicated nonhazardous or nonharmful drinking. Secondary outcomes were a negative AUDIT result at 12 months, experience of alcohol-related problems (alcohol problems questionnaire), healthcare (EQ-5D), service use, and patients' motivation to change their drinking behavior (readiness for change). modified preparation chart. RESULTS Patient follow-up rates were 83% (n=644) at 6 months and 79% (n=617) at 12 months. At both time points, an intent to treat analysis found no significant difference in CONDITION negative status between the three interventions. Compared to the patient information leaflet group, the odds ratio of having a negative AUDIT result for brief advice is 0.85 (95% confidence interval 0.52 to 1.39) and 0.78 (0.48 to 1.25) for brief lifestyle counselling. was. One per-protocol analysis confirmed these findings. RESULTS All patients received simple feedback on the scan results. However, beyond this entry, evidence was lacking that compared to the patient information leaflet, brief advice or brief lifestyle counseling provides significant additional benefit in reducing hazardous or harmful drinking. TRIAL REGISTRATION Controlled Trials Available ISRCTN06145674.

title: Efficacy of depression screening and treatment in outpatients
abstract: OBJECTIVE: To determine the effectiveness of depression screening and treatment in poor outpatients admitted to resident physicians. Design: Two-group randomized study (N = 33 interventions, N = 28 usual care) with baseline, 6-month, and 12-month outcome measures. SETTING: Internal Medicine Specialization Clinic. PATIENTS: Clinical patients over 18 years of age who were positive for depression on the PRIME-MD during their visit to their resident doctor. Patients do not seek treatment or care for any emotional problems. All patients were either enrolled in Medicaid or had an income below the poverty line. INTERVENTION: Resident physicians are trained to follow AHCPR (AHRQ"; "Agency for Health Research and Quality) guidelines for the diagnosis and treatment of depression in the primary care setting. For intervention group patients, a screening nurse advised residents about positive screen, outlined a standard protocol for them, and attempted to organize behavioral care. Before meeting with the resident, the patients in the usual care group were provided with the scan results by the screening nurse and advised to seek care for their symptoms. MAIN RESULTS: Results for the primary outcome of depression symptoms as measured by the Beck Depression Inventory (BDI) showed that the intervention was successful in reducing symptoms relative to normal care (difference = -4.9 BDI score, P =.05, 95% confidence interval [CI], -9.8 to -0.005 effect size = -0.41). During the 12-month follow-up, 70% of intervention patients were treated for depression (91% of them with antidepressants), while 15% of usual care patients were treated with antidepressants for depression. Depression was noted in another 18% of the usual care group, but no treatment was identified. BDI differences between the intervention and control groups were similar at the 6- and 12-month measurements. Quality of life and costs were also measured, but differences between groups in this regard were not significant. CONCLUSION: Depression screening and treatment by resident doctors has been successful in reducing symptoms compared to usual care in a poor population. Nearly twice as many intervention patients as usual-care controls showed a significant reduction in depression-related symptoms (10 BDI points).

title: Effectiveness of strategies to disseminate and implement clinical guidelines for the management of impacted and unerupted third molars in primary dental care, a set of randomized controlled trials
abstract: OBJECTIVE: To investigate the effectiveness and cost-effectiveness of different guideline implementation strategies using the Scottish Inter-University Guidelines Network (SIGN) Guideline 42 "Management of unearthed and impacted third molars" (published 2000). DESIGN: A pragmatic cluster RCT (2x2 factorial design). SUBJECTS: Sixty-three dental practices across Scotland. The clinical records of all patients aged 16-24 years during the two, four month periods in 1999 (pre-intervention) and 2000 (post-intervention) were searched by a clinical investigator blinded to the intervention group. Data were also collected on the costs of interventions. INTERVENTIONS: 1. The group received a copy of the SIGN 42 Manual and had the opportunity to attend a postgraduate training course (PGEC). In addition, group 2 received supervision and feedback (A and F). Group 3 received a computer assisted learning (CAL) package. Group 4 received A and F and CALs. MAIN OUTCOME MEASURE: Proportion of patients whose treatment complied with the guideline. RESULTS: A and F versus A versus F versus weighted t-test (P=0.62) and CAL versus CAL (P=0.76) were not statistically significant. Considering the efficiency results (no difference), the cost effectiveness calculation became a cost minimization calculation. The minimal cost intervention in the trial consisted of providing general dentists (GDPs) with guidelines and the option to attend PGEC courses. Routine data later made available showed a Scotland-wide decline prior to data collection. CONCLUSION: In an environment of unexpectedly high pre-intervention compliance, neither CAL nor A and F increased dentists' adherence to the SIGN guideline compared to mailing the guideline and the opportunity to attend a graduate course. The cost of the CAL arm of the trial was higher than the A and F arm. More work is needed to understand the behavior of dental professionals in response to guideline implementation strategies.

title: Efficacy of thigh-length graduated compression stockings to reduce the risk of deep vein thrombosis after stroke (CLOTS trial 1): a multicenter, randomized controlled trial.
abstract: BackgroundDeep vein thrombosis (DVT) and pulmonary embolism are common after stroke. In small trials of patients undergoing surgery, graduated compression stockings (GCS) reduce the risk of DVT. National stroke guidelines based on these studies recommend their use in stroke patients despite insufficient evidence. We evaluated the efficacy of thigh-length GCS to reduce post-stroke DVT.";" BackgroundDeep vein thrombosis (DVT) and pulmonary embolism are common after stroke. In small trials of patients undergoing surgery, graduated compression stockings (GCS) reduce the risk of DVT. National stroke guidelines based on these studies recommend their use in stroke patients despite insufficient evidence. We evaluated the efficacy of thigh-length GCS to reduce post-stroke DVT.

title: Efficacy of community pharmacist visits for patients with heart failure: HeartMed randomized controlled trial.
abstract: OBJECTIVE To test whether a drug review and symptom self-management and lifestyle advice intervention by community pharmacists can reduce hospitalizations or mortality in heart failure patients. DESIGN Randomized controlled trial. ADJUST Home intervention in heart failure patients. PARTICIPANTS 293 patients (149 interventions, 144 controls) diagnosed with heart failure were included after emergency admission. INTERVENTION Two home visits by one of 17 community pharmacists within two and eight weeks of discharge. Pharmacists review medications and provide symptom self-management and lifestyle advice. Controls received usual care. MAIN OUTCOME MEASURES The primary outcome was total hospital readmissions at six months. Secondary outcomes included mortality and quality of life (living with Minnesota heart failure questionnaire and EQ-5D). RESULTS Primary outcome data were available for 291 participants (99%). 136 (91%) intervention patients received one or two visits. There were 134 admissions in the intervention group compared to 112 in the control group (odds ratio=1.15, 95% confidence interval 0.89 to 1.48"; P=0.28, Poisson model). Compared with 24 controls, 30 intervention patients died (hazard ratio=1.18). 0.69 to 2.03; P=0.54.EQ-5D scores favored the intervention group, whereas Minnesota survey scores living with heart failure favored controls, with no difference being statistically significant.CONCLUSION This community pharmacist intervention was comparable in trials of specialist nurse-led interventions in heart failure. Given that heart failure accounts for 5% of hospitalizations, these results pose a challenge for policy makers who lack specialist service and hope that skilled community pharmacists can deliver the same benefits.TRIAL REGISTRATION NUMBER ISRCTN59427925.

title: The effects of a behavior-independent financial incentive on GPs' prescribing behavior
abstract: RATIONALE AND OBJECTIVES: It is difficult to maintain control over prescribing behavior in general practice. The aim of this study was to evaluate the initial effects of a behavior-independent financial incentive on the volume of drug prescribing by GPs. DESIGN: 2-Year Controlled Before After study with response zone and simultaneous control zone. SETTING AND PARTICIPANTS: GPs in two regions of the Netherlands (n = 119 and n = 118). INTERVENTION: Financial incentive to prescribe according to local guidelines for certain drugs or categories of drugs. The financial incentive consisted of a non-recurring, behavior-independent allowance. MAIN OUTCOME MEASURE: Change in the number of prescriptions for the 10 targeted drugs or drug groups. RESULTS: Significant changes were seen in only three types of antibiotics and recommended stomach medications. In almost all cases, the effects were transient. CONCLUSION: Behavior-independent financial incentives can be helpful in changing GPs' prescribing behavior, but their effects are small-scale and temporary.

title: Effects of a clinician referral and exercise program for men who have completed active treatment for prostate cancer: A multicenter cluster randomized controlled trial (ENGAGE)
abstract: OBJECTIVE: The aim of this study was to determine the effectiveness of a clinician referral and exercise program in improving exercise levels and quality of life in men with prostate cancer. METHODS: This was a multicenter cluster randomized controlled trial of 15 clinicians in Melbourne, Australia: 8 clinicians were randomized to refer eligible participants (n = 54) to a 12-week exercise program that included 2 supervised gym sessions and 1 home-based session. . weeks and 7 clinicians were randomized to follow usual care (n = 93). The primary outcome was self-reported physical activity"; secondary outcomes were quality of life, anxiety, and depression symptoms. confidence interval [CI], 0.09–0.82; P = .010) but not for combined moderate and vigorous exercise levels (effect size: d , 0.08; 95% CI, -0.28 to 0.45; P = .48), also observed to meet exercise guidelines (>/=150 min/week; odds ratio, 3.9; 95% CI, 1.9-7.8; P = .002 ); positive intervention effects were observed in the intervention group for cognitive functioning (effect size: d, 0.34; 95% CI, -0.02 to 0.70; P = .06) and symptoms of depression (effect size: d, -0.35; 95% CI, - 0.71 to 0.02;"P = .06). Eighty percent of the participants reported that the clinician's referral influenced their decision to participate in the exercise program. RESULTS: Clinician referral and 12-week exercise program significantly improved vigorous exercise levels and had a positive impact on mental health outcomes for men living with prostate cancer. More research is needed to determine the sustainability of the exercise program and its generalizability to other cancer populations.

title: Effects of a fixed combination of perindopril and indapamide on macrovascular and microvascular outcomes in patients with type 2 diabetes (ADVANCE study): a randomized controlled trial.
abstract: BackgroundBlood pressure is an important determinant of the risks of macrovascular and microvascular complications of type 2 diabetes, and guidelines recommend intensive lowering of blood pressure for diabetic patients with hypertension. We evaluated the effects of routine administration of an angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitor-diuretic combination on serious vascular events in patients with diabetes, regardless of baseline blood pressure levels or use of other blood pressure-lowering drugs. BackgroundBlood pressure is an important determinant of the risks of macrovascular and microvascular complications of type 2 diabetes, and guidelines recommend intensive lowering of blood pressure for diabetic patients with hypertension. We evaluated the effects of routine administration of an angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitor-diuretic combination on serious vascular events in patients with diabetes, regardless of baseline blood pressure levels or use of other blood pressure-lowering drugs.

title: Effects of a multifaceted intervention on cardiovascular risk factors in high-risk hypertensive patients: the ESCAPE trial, a pragmatic cluster randomized trial in general practice.
abstract: BACKGROUND: Several observational studies in hypertensive patients have shown a gap between the therapeutic goals recommended in the guidelines and those achieved in daily practice. The ESCAPE trial aimed to determine whether a multifaceted intervention focused on general practitioners (GPs) would significantly increase the proportion of hypertensive patients at high risk in primary prevention who achieve all their recommended therapeutic goals. METHODS: A pragmatic cluster randomized trial involving 257 GPs randomized by site. General practitioners in the intervention group were given a one-day training session and were provided with an electronic blood pressure monitor and a short advisory leaflet. Along with usual follow-up, they focused on a consultation on hypertension and other cardiovascular risk factors every six months for two years. They also received feedback on their patients' clinical and biological parameters at baseline and at one year. The main outcome measures were quality of life and change in the proportion of patients who achieved all their therapeutic goals and each individual therapeutic goal at two years. RESULTS: 1,832 high-risk hypertensive patients were included. After two years, the proportion of patients achieving all their therapeutic goals increased significantly in both groups, but was significantly greater in the intervention group: OR (ratio ratio) 1.89 (95% confidence interval (CI) 1.09 to 3.27, P = 0.02). Significantly more patients achieved their blood pressure goals in the intervention group compared to the usual care group: OR 2.03 (95% CI 1.44 to 2.88, P < 0.0001). Systolic and diastolic blood pressures were significantly reduced in the intervention group compared to the usual care group by 4.8 mmHg and 1.9 mmHg, respectively (P < 0.0001 for both). There was no significant difference in physical and mental quality of life between the groups. CONCLUSION: An easy-to-administer, multifaceted intervention targeting GPs only significantly increased the proportion of high-risk hypertensive patients achieving their recommended therapeutic goals in primary prevention. TRIAL REGISTRATION: This trial is registered under ClinicalTrials.gov, NCT00348855.

title: Effects of a Short Course of Eszopiclone on Persistent Positive Airway Pressure Adhesion
abstract: Background: Adherence to short-term continuous positive airway pressure (CPAP) may predict long-term use. Unfortunately, initial CPAP intolerance may result in poor adherence or discontinuation of therapy. Objective: To determine whether a short-term eszopiclone at the start of treatment improves long-term CPAP compliance more than placebo in adults with obstructive sleep apnea. Design: Parallel randomized, placebo-controlled trial from March 2007 to December 2008. Randomization, which is stored and stored centrally by pharmacy staff, was computer generated using fixed blocks of 10. Referring physicians, researchers, and patients were blinded to treatment assignment until after final data. gathered. (ClinicalTrials.gov registration number: NCT00612157) Setting: Academic sleep disorder center. Patients: 160 adults (mean age, 45.7 years [SD, 7.3]"; mean apneaâ‚¬Â¡Â°hypopnea index, 36.9 events/hour [SD , 23]) newly diagnosed obstructive sleep apnea initiating CPAP. Intervention : Eszopiclone, 3 mg (n? = 76) or matched placebo (n? = 78) for the first 14 nights of CPAP Measures: CPAP use was measured. CPAP compliance (primary outcome) and CPAP discontinuation rate and symptoms Improvements (secondary outcomes) were compared. Follow-up at 1, 3, and 6 months was completed by 150, 136, and 120 patients, respectively. Results: Patients in the esopiclone group performed CPAP 20.8% more nights (95% CI, 7.2% vs. 34.4%; P? = 0.003), 1.3 hours more per night (CI, 0.4 to 2.2 hours; P? = 0.005) for all nights, and 1.1 hours more per night of CPAP use ( CI, 0.2 to 2.1 hours; P ? = 0.019. 3) times higher in the placebo group Adverse effects were reported in 7.1% of patients and did not differ between groups. treated and frequently followed-up There was severe obstructive sleep apnea; “results may not be generalizable to different settings. CPAP and reasons for discontinuation were not evaluated. Conclusion: A short course of eszopiclone during the first 2 weeks of CPAP compared with placebo improved adherence and resulted in fewer patients discontinuing treatment. Primary Funding Source: Sepracor.

title: Effects of an automated electronic reminder on changing antiplatelet drug prescribing behavior among Italian GPs in diabetic patients: an intervention trial.
abstract: OBJECTIVE – To evaluate whether an electronic reminder integrated into a routine computer system increases antiplatelet drug use for diabetic patients among Italian general practitioners (GPs). RESEARCH DESIGN AND METHODS – A randomized controlled trial was conducted among 300 GPs and their patients selected from the Health Search Database. Among these, 150 GPs (intervention group) received instructions to activate an electronic reminder and a letter summarizing the beneficial effects of antiplatelet drugs in diabetic patients with at least one additional cardiovascular risk factor (“high risk”), while another 150 GPs (control group) only received the letter. The electronic reminder, integrated into a standard software system for the management of daily clinical practice, was displayed when each participating GP opened the medical records of diabetic patients age = 30. Only high-risk diabetes patients were included in the analysis. Patients who received two or more prescriptions at baseline and during follow-up were considered antiplatelet therapy. RESULTS-- We selected 15,343 high-risk diabetes patients, including 7,313 practitioners of the control group and 8,030 practitioners of the intervention group. Overall, 1,672 patients (22.9%) in the control group and 1,886 (23.5%) in the intervention group received antiplatelet drugs at baseline (P = NS). At the end of follow-up, the number of patients treated in the intervention group increased significantly compared to the control group (odds ratio 1.99, 95% CI 1.79–2.22). The effect of the electronic reminder was more relevant among patients with one or more cardiovascular risk factors but no prior cardiovascular disease (CVD) compared with those with CVD. CONCLUSIONS—These findings provide evidence for the impact of electronic reminders in influencing GPs' prescriptive behavior.

title: Effects of an evidence service on community-based AIDS service organizations' use of research evidence: A protocol for a randomized controlled trial.
abstract: Background To support the use of research evidence by community-based organizations (CBOs), we have developed 'Synthesized HIV/AIDS Research Evidence (SHARE),' an evidence service for those working in the HIV industry. SHARE consists of several components: an online searchable database of systematic reviews of HIV (retrievable based on a classification of topics related to HIV/AIDS and clear text search); periodic email updates; access to user-friendly summaries;" and peer fitness assessments. Our aim is to evaluate whether this 'full service' evidence service increases the use of research evidence by CBOs compared to a 'self-service' evidence service. Methods/design We will conduct a two-arm randomized controlled trial (RCT) with a follow-up qualitative process study to further explore the findings. All CBOs affiliated with the Canadian AIDS Society (n = 120) will be invited to participate and will be randomly selected to receive either the 'full service' version or the 'self-service' version (a list of relevant systematic reviews with links) of SHARE. To records in PubMed and worksheets that help CBOs find and use research evidence using a simple randomization design. All management and staff from each organization will be given access to the SHARE version to which their organization is allocated. The trial period will be 10 months (two-month baseline, six-month intervention period, and two-month transition period), the primary outcome measure will be the average number of logins/months/organizations (average Each organization) between the start and the end of the intervention period. The secondary outcome will be the intention to use research evidence as measured by a questionnaire administered to one key decision maker from each organization. For the qualitative study, a key institutional decision maker from 15 organizations in each trial arm (n = 30) will be purposively sampled. One-on-one semi-structured interviews over the phone will be conducted over the phone about their views and experiences with the evidence service they have received, how helpful it has been in their work, why it was helpful (or not helpful), what aspects were most helpful. and the least helpful and suggestions for why and next steps. Discussion To our knowledge, this will be the first RCT to evaluate the effects of an evidence service specifically designed to support CBOs in finding and using research evidence.

title: The effects of an evidence service on health system policymakers' use of research evidence: A protocol for a randomized controlled trial.
abstract: Background Health system policy makers need timely access to synthesized research evidence to inform the policy-making process. No effort to address this need has been evaluated using an experimental quantitative design. We have developed an evidence service that takes inputs from Health Systems Evidence, a database of policy reviews. Reviews are (a) categorized by subject and type of review; (b) studies conducted are coded by last year searches and countries included studies are conducted; (c) rated for quality; and (d) linked to available user-friendly summaries, scientific summaries and full-text reports. Our aim is to evaluate whether a "full-service" evidence service increases the use of research evidence synthesized by policy analysts and consultants at the Ontario Ministry of Health and Long-Term Care (MOHLTC) compared to a "self-service" evidence service. service. Methods/design We will conduct a two-arm randomized controlled trial (RCT) with a follow-up qualitative process study to further explore the findings. For the RCT, all policy analysts and policy advisors (n = 168) within a single division of MOHLTC will be invited to participate. Using a tiered randomization design, participants will be randomly selected to receive either the "full-service" evidence service (database access, monthly email alerts, and full-text article availability) or the "self-service" evidence service (database access). only). The probationary period will be ten months (two-month baseline, six-month intervention period, and two-month transitional period). The primary result will be the average number of site visits/month/users between the starting point and the end of the response period. The secondary outcome will be the participants' intention to use research evidence. For qualitative research, 15 participants from each trial arm (n = 30) will be purposefully sampled. One-on-one semi-structured interviews over the phone will be conducted over the phone about their views and experiences with the evidence service they have received, how helpful it has been in their work, why it was helpful (or not helpful), what aspects were most helpful. and the least helpful and suggestions for why and next steps. Discussion To the best of our knowledge, this will be the first RCT to evaluate the effects of an evidence service specifically designed to support health system policymakers in finding and using research evidence.

title: Effects of computer reminders for the flu shot on morbidity during flu epidemics.
abstract: To examine the effects of computer-generated reminders for the flu shot of patients at high risk of lung disease during the winter months, we selected 4555 such patients from a population of 15,000 adults who participated in a three-year randomized trial of preventative care reminders. Physicians who received the reminders vaccinated eligible patients twice as often as control physicians (P = 0.0001). There was a linear increase in incidence of influenza in our region over the three winters studied (from 1,000 to 33,451 to 71,075 cases per year) and we modeled the percentage of patients hospitalized, emergency room visit with chest radiography, and blood drawn. Gas detections as a logistic function of this increase. The difference in linear trends between patients in the intervention group (reminders from physicians) and patients in the control group was significant for emergency department visits (P < 0.05), hospitalizations (P < 0.01), and blood gas determinations ( P < 0.001). ). The most likely explanation for the difference is the greater use of influenza vaccine in the intervention group.

title: Effects of computer reminders on complications of peripheral venous catheters and nurses' adherence to a guideline in pediatric care - a cluster randomized trial
abstract: BACKGROUND: Reminder systems in electronic patient records (EPR) have been proven to affect both the behavior of healthcare professionals and patient outcomes. The purpose of this cluster randomized study was to investigate the effects of implementing a clinical practice guideline (CPG) in the form of reminders integrated into EPRs for peripheral venous catheters (PVCs) in pediatric care, on PVC-related complications and registered health issues. nurses (RNs) declared their adherence to the guideline. An additional aim was to examine the relationship between contextual factors and outcomes of the intervention. METHODS: The study included 12 inpatient units in a pediatric university hospital. Reminders included PVC selection, hygiene, maintenance and daily inspection of the PVC site. The primary outcome was documented signs and symptoms of PVC-related complications on removal from the EPR. The secondary outcome was RNs adherence to a PVC guideline, collected through a questionnaire that also included RNs' perceived working context, as measured by the Alberta Context Tool. The units were divided into two layers according to the formation of the PVCs. A simple blind draw from each stratum randomized six units to the control and intervention groups, respectively. Units were not blind. The intervention group included 626 PVCs at baseline and 618 post-intervention, and the control group included 724 PVCs at baseline and 674 post-intervention. The RNs included at baseline were 212 (65.4%) and 208 (71.5%) post-intervention. RESULTS: No significant effect of computer reminders on PVC-related complications or RNs compliance with guideline recommendations was found. The baseline and post-intervention complication rates were 40.6% (95% CI 36.7-44.5) and 41.9% (95% CI 38.0-45.8) and 40.3% (95% CI 36.8-44.0) for the intervention group. ) and 46.9% (95% CI 43.1-50.7) for the control. Overall, the RNs' self-rated work context ranged from moderately low to moderately high, suggesting that conditions were less optimal for successful implementation to occur. CONCLUSIONS: Reminders may have benefited from accompanying a specific intervention targeting specific barriers, such as low frequency of recorded causes of removal, low adherence to daily inspection of PVC sites, and lack of regular feedback to RNs. TRIAL REGISTRATION: Current Controlled Trials ISRCTN44819426.

title: Implications of computerized guidelines for managing heart disease in primary care
abstract: BACKGROUND: Electronic information systems have been proposed as a way to reduce medical errors of commission (doing the wrong thing) and negligence (not providing specified care). OBJECTIVE: To evaluate the effects of computer-based cardiac care recommendations. DESIGN: A randomized controlled trial targeting primary care physicians and pharmacists. SUBJECTS: A total of 706 outpatients with heart failure and/or ischemic heart disease. INTERVENTIONS: Evidence-based cardiac care recommendations, approved by a panel of local cardiologists and general internists, were demonstrated to physicians and pharmacists when dealing with enrolled patients. MEASUREMENTS: Compliance with care recommendations, general and situation-specific quality of life, acute exacerbations of heart diseases, drug compliance, health care costs, satisfaction with care, and physicians' attitudes towards guidelines. RESULTS: Subjects were followed for 1 year, during which 3,419 primary care visits were made, and 2,609 individual cardiac care recommendations were eligible. The intervention had no effect on physician compliance with care recommendations (23% for intervention patients and 22% for controls). There were no intervention-control differences in quality of life, medication adherence, healthcare utilization, costs, or satisfaction with care. Physicians viewed the guidelines as providing useful information but limiting their application and not helping with decision-making for individual patients. CONCLUSIONS: Care recommendations generated by an advanced electronic medical record system failed to improve compliance with accepted practice guidelines or outcomes for patients with heart disease. Future studies should weigh the benefits and costs of different (and perhaps more brutal) methods of influencing clinician behavior.

title: The effects of general practitioner training and family support services on the care of dementia patients living at home-results of a controlled cluster-randomized study
abstract: BACKGROUND: More than 90% of people with dementia are cared for by their general practitioner, who is committed to diagnosis, treatment and advice of support services. OBJECTIVE: To test whether specific training of general practitioners is changing the care of people with dementia through caregiver counseling and systematic recommendations from support groups. METHODS: 129 GPs enrolled 390 dementia patients and their informal caregivers in a prospective, three-arm cluster randomized 2-year study. Usual care making up Arm A was recommended by GPs in Arms B and C support groups, and caregiver counseling (one year after baseline in Arm B, initially in Arm C). General practitioners received branch-specific training. Diagnostic and therapeutic behaviors of physicians were recorded at baseline. Informal caregivers were questioned about using support services after 2 years. CONCLUSIONS: The diagnostic behaviors of general practitioners are in accordance with the relevant guidelines. The procedure performed in newly diagnosed patients is not different from previously diagnosed patients, except for the rate of referral to a specialist. About one-third of newly diagnosed dementia patients are given an anti-dementia medication. Use of support groups and counseling increased five and fourfold, respectively. Except for home care and institutional short-term nursing, utilization of other support services remained low (< 10%). CONCLUSION: Trained general practitioners generally act according to the guidelines for the diagnosis of dementia and partially according to the guidelines regarding the recommended drug therapy. Informal recommendations of support services for caregivers by the general practitioner are successful. They cause a significant increase in the rate of use of the recommended services compared to offers not recommended by the general practitioner. TRIAL REGISTRATION: ISRCTN68329593.

title: Effects of interactive voice response self-monitoring on natural resolution of drinking problems: Use and behavioral economic factors.
abstract: Purpose: Most problem drinkers do not seek help and many get better on their own. A randomized controlled trial evaluated whether self-monitoring of the supportive interactive voice response (IVR) facilitates such "natural" solutions. Based on behavioral economics, it has been assumed that the effects on drinking outcomes vary with the baseline "time horizon" of drinkers, reflecting preferences among goods of different value available at different lags and their IVR use. Methods: Recently resolved, untreated problem drinkers were randomized to a 24-week IVR self-monitoring program (n = 87) or an assessment-only control condition (n = 98). Baseline interviews evaluated outcome predictors, including behavioral economic measures of reward preferences (deferral discount, alcohol versus pre-resolution monetary allowance, and savings). Six-month outcomes were categorized as definitive abstinence, resolved non-fasting, unresolved, or incomplete. Complier mean causal effects (CACE) models examined the self-monitoring effects of IVR. Results: IVR self-monitoring compliant subjects (>=70% scheduled search completed) were older and had greater pre-resolution drinking control and lower discount than ineligible subjects (<70%). A CACE model interaction showed that observed adherents with shorter time horizons in the IVR group (expressed by greater pre-resolution expenditure on alcohol rather than savings) were more likely to achieve moderate solutions than predicted adherents in the control group with shorter time horizons. and with all those who don't. The intent-to-treat analytical models showed no effect on IVR. More balanced spending for savings versus alcohol estimated moderation in both approaches. Conclusions: IVR interventions should consider factors that influence IVR use and drinking outcomes, including individual behavioral economic variables. CACE models provide tools for evaluating interventions that include extended participation. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2016 APA, all rights reserved)

title: Effects of treatment of depression and low perceived social support in clinical events after myocardial infarction: Enhancing Recovery in Coronary Heart Disease Patients (ENRICHD) randomized trial.
abstract: It was determined whether treatment of depression and low perceived social support (LPSS) with cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT) and supplementation with a selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor (SSRI) antidepressant when indicated reduced mortality and recurrent infarction in patients enrolled within 28 days of myocardial. infarction (MI). A randomized clinical trial was conducted in 2481 MI patients. LPSS was determined by the ENRICHD Social Support Tool (ESSI). The random allocation was usual medical care or CBT-based psychosocial intervention. CBT was initiated a median 17 days after index MI, plus group therapy where available, SSRI' for patients who scored higher than 24 on the Hamilton Depression Rating Scale or had less than 50% reduction in Beck Depression Inventory scores after 5 together with 's. weeks. Improvement in psychosocial outcomes at 6 months supported treatment: mean change in HRSD score, -10.1 in the depression and psychosocial intervention group versus -8.4" in the depression and usual care group;" The mean change in ESSI score was 5.1 in the LPSS and psychosocial intervention group versus 3.4 in the LPSS and usual care group. After a mean follow-up of 29 months, there was no significant difference in event-free survival between usual care and psychosocial intervention.

title: Efficacy and safety of corticosteroid injections and other injections for the management of tendinopathy: a systematic review of randomized controlled trials.
abstract: There are several evidence-based treatment guidelines for background tendinopathy. We conducted a systematic review of randomized trials to determine clinical efficacy and risk of adverse events for injectable therapy. There are several evidence-based treatment guidelines for background tendinopathy. We conducted a systematic review of randomized trials to determine clinical efficacy and risk of adverse events for injectable therapy.

title: Efficacy and safety of sucrose for procedural pain relief in preterm and term neonates
abstract: BACKGROUND: Premature and acutely ill neonates hospitalized in the neonatal intensive care unit undergo a number of frequently invasive and painful procedures aimed at improving outcomes. Although several studies have been developed to determine the efficacy of sucrose for managing procedural pain in preterm and acutely ill neonates, they often lack methodological rigor and have not provided clinicians with clear practice guidelines. OBJECTIVES: To compare the efficacy and safety of three interventions for relieving procedural pain associated with heel spears in preterm and term neonates and to explore the impact of contextual factors on pain responses, including gender, disease severity, and prior painful procedures. METHODS: In a randomized controlled trial, 190 newborns were classified by gestational age and then randomized to receive (a) sucrose and non-nutritive sucking (n = 64), (b) sucrose alone (n = 62), or (c) sterile water. was done. and non-nutritive sucking (control) (n = 64) to assess efficacy (pain response measured using the Premature Infant Pain Profile) (Stevens, Johnson, Petryshen, & Taddio, 1996) and safety (adverse effects) after a scheduled heel lance (n = 64) in the first week of life . Stratification was used to control for the effects of age on the pain response. RESULTS: There were significant differences in pain response between treatment groups (F = 22.49, p < .001), with the lowest mean Premature Infant Pain Profile scores in the sucrose and non-nutritive sucking group. The efficacy of sucrose following a heel spear was not affected by disease severity, postpartum age, or the number of painful procedures. Intervention group and gender explained 12% of the variance in Premature Infant Pain Profile scores. Few adverse events occurred (n = 6) and none of them required medical or nursing intervention. CONCLUSIONS: The combination of sucrose and non-nutritive suction is the most effective intervention for sole heel spears. Research is needed on the effects of gestational age on the efficacy and safety of repeated doses of sucrose.

title: Efficacy and safety of very early mobilization within 24 hours of stroke onset (AVERT): a randomized controlled trial.
abstract: Background Early mobilization after stroke is thought to contribute to the effects of stroke unit care", but the intervention is poorly defined and not supported by strong evidence. We aimed to compare the efficacy of frequent, high-dose, very early mobilization with usual care after stroke.; Background Early mobilization after stroke in the stroke unit Although the intervention is not well defined and not supported by strong evidence, we aimed to compare the efficacy of frequent, high-dose, very early mobilization with usual post-stroke care.

title: The effectiveness of cognitive and behavioral psychotherapy administered by primary care psychologists in patients with mixed anxiety-depressive disorder: a research protocol.
abstract: BACKGROUND: Contrary to the recommendations of clinical practice guidelines, the most common treatment for anxiety and depressive disorders in primary care is pharmacological. The aim of this study was to evaluate the effectiveness of cognitive-behavioral psychological intervention applied by primary care psychologists in patients with mixed anxiety-depressive disorder compared to usual care. METHODS/DESIGN: This is an open-label, multicenter, randomized, controlled study with two parallel groups. A random sample of 246 patients with mild-to-moderate mixed anxiety-depressive disorder will be drawn from the target population in the lists of 41 primary care physicians. Patients will be randomly assigned to an intervention group that will receive standard cognitive-behavioral therapy combined with usual care by psychologists, or a control group to receive usual care alone. The cognitive-behavioral therapy intervention consists of eight individual 60-minute face-to-face sessions conducted over eight consecutive weeks. A follow-up session will be conducted by telephone 6 months after the intervention for reinforcement or referral as needed. The primary outcome variable will be the change in Short Form-36 General Health Questionnaire scores. We will also measure the change in frequency and intensity of anxiety symptoms (State-Trait Anxiety Inventory) and depression (Beck Depression Inventory) at baseline and after 3, 6, and 12 months. Additionally, we will collect information about drug use and healthcare. DISCUSSION: The aim of this study was to evaluate the effectiveness of primary care-based cognitive-behavioral psychological intervention in patients with mixed anxiety-depressive disorder. International scientific evidence has shown the need for psychologists in primary care. But given the differences between health policies and health services, it is important to test the impact of these psychological interventions in our geographic setting. TRIAL REGISTRATION: NCT01907035 (July 22, 2013).

title: Efficacy of a nurse-led email reminder program to reduce cardiovascular prevention risk in hypertensive patients: a randomized controlled trial.
abstract: BACKGROUND: Many strategies have been evaluated to improve the prevention and control of cardiovascular (CVD) risk factors. Nursing telephone and tele-counseling individualized lifestyle education programs have been found to improve blood pressure control and adherence to lifestyle recommendations. This study tested the effectiveness of a nurse-led reminder program via email (NRP-e) for improving CVD risk factors among hypertensive adults. METHODS: All participants underwent the usual CVD prevention and a guideline-based training program. Subjects in the NRP-e group also received weekly email alerts and phone calls from a nurse care manager for 6 months. The emails included a reminder program of the need to adhere to a healthy lifestyle based on current guidelines. Follow-up visits were planned at 1, 3, and 6 months after enrollment"; performed as a randomization center, and blood samples evaluated in a single laboratory. RESULTS: The final sample consisted of 98 (control) and 100 (NRP-e) subjects (mean age 59.0 +/- 14.5 years;" 51.0% male). After 6 months, the following CVD risk factors improved significantly in both groups: body mass index, alcohol and fruit consumption, smoking, adherence to treatment schedule, systolic and diastolic blood pressure, fasting blood glucose, low-density lipoproteins (LDL), and total cholesterol, triglycerides and physical activity. However, in the NRP-e group, the prevalence of various at-risk behaviors or conditions was significantly reduced compared to the control group: obesity (-16%), low fruit consumption (-24%), uncontrolled hypertension (-61%), LDL (- 56) and total cholesterol (-40%). RESULTS: NRP-e improved a number of CVD risk factors. The program was low in cost, required only <20 minutes per day on average in addition to normal practice, and may merit further consideration for inclusion in existing care management approaches.

title: Effectiveness of a self-help handbook in enhancing resilience in caregivers of adults with depression in Thailand.
abstract: Caring for a person with a mental illness can have negative effects on caregivers"; however, little is known about how best to help such caregivers. The purpose of this study was to examine the effectiveness of cognitive behavioral therapy-guided self-help with depression compared to caregivers who received only routine support. handbook on building resilience in caregivers of individuals.Following CONSORT guidelines, a randomized controlled trial was conducted with 54 caregivers dedicated to parallel intervention (self-help guide) (n = 27) or control (standard support) (n = 27) groups. Flexibility was assessed at baseline, posttest (week 8), and follow-up (week 12).Treatment analyzes were performed.Repeated measures ANOVA showed a significant difference between the three time points showing a large effect in endurance scores between the intervention and control groups pairwise comparisons, between the beginning and the end of resilience. showed that they were significantly different. between testing and baseline and follow-up, but not between post-test and follow-up. Overall, the intervention group had slightly greater increases in resilience over time than the control group," but the time-group interaction was not significant. Guided self-help is helpful in enhancing caregivers' resilience and can be used in addition by mental health nurses and other clinicians to caregivers. limited support provided.

title: The effectiveness of evidence-based clinical decision support in primary care
abstract: Significance There is consensus that incorporating clinical decision support into electronic health records will improve quality of care, control costs and reduce overtreatment, but this potential has not yet been demonstrated in clinical trials. Purpose To evaluate the impact of a specialized evidence-based clinical decision support tool on the management of respiratory infections and the effectiveness of integrating evidence at the point of care. Design, Environment, and Participants In a randomized clinical trial, we applied 2 well-validated integrated clinical prediction rules, namely the Walsh rule for streptococcal pharyngitis and the Heckerling rule for pneumonia. Interventions and Key Outcomes and Measures The intervention group had access to the integrated clinical prediction rule tool and chose to complete risk score calculators, order medication, and generate progress notes to aid complex point-of-care decision making. Results The intervention group completed the integrated clinical prediction rule tool in 57.5% of visits. Providers in the intervention group were significantly less likely to order antibiotics than the control group (age-adjusted relative risk, 0.74"; 95% CI, 0.60-0.92). The absolute risk of intervention was 9.2% and the number of treatments required was 10.8. were significantly less likely to request rapid streptococcal tests compared to the group (relative risk, 0.75; 95% CI, 0.58-0.97; "P?=?.03). Results and Relevance The integrated clinical prediction rule process for integrating complex evidence-based clinical decision reporting tools is essential for national initiatives such as Meaningful Use.

title: Efficacy of standardized manual therapy and home exercise program for chronic rotator cuff disease: randomized, placebo-controlled trial.
abstract: OBJECTIVE To investigate the effectiveness of a manual therapy and exercise therapy program compared to placebo therapy given by physical therapists for people with chronic rotator cuff disease. DESIGN Randomized, participant and single evaluator blinded, placebo-controlled study. SETTING Melbourne metropolitan area, Victoria, Australia. PARTICIPANTS 120 participants with chronic (>3 months) rotator cuff disease recruited from medical practitioners and the community. INTERVENTIONS Active treatment consisted of a manual therapy and home exercise program"; it included placebo therapy, inactive ultrasound therapy, and an inert gel application. Participants in both groups received 10 sessions of individual standard therapy over 10 weeks. During the following 12 weeks, the active group home continued exercise program and placebo group did not receive treatment MAIN OUTCOME MEASURES Primary outcomes, pain and function as measured by shoulder pain and disability index, mean pain with movement measured on an 11-point numerical rating scale, and participants' perceived global rating of overall change RESULTS 112 (93%) participants 22 completed the weekly trial. At 11 weeks, there was no difference between groups for change in shoulder pain and disability index (3.6, 95% confidence interval -2.1 to 9.4) or change in pain (0.7, -0.1 to 1.5);" Both groups showed significant improvements. More participants in the active group reported a successful outcome (defined as "much better"), although the difference was not statistically significant: 42% (24/57) of active participants and 30% (18/61) of placebo participants ( relative risk 1.43, 0.87 to 2.34). The active group had significantly greater improvement in shoulder pain and disability index than the placebo group at 22 weeks (group difference 7.1, from 0.3 to 13.9%), but there was no significant difference between groups for change in pain (0.9, -0.03 to 0.03 to 1.7). or for the percentage of participants reporting a successful treatment outcome (relative risk 1.39, 0.94 to 2.03). Several secondary outcomes favored the active group, including shoulder pain and disability index function score, muscle strength, activity intervention, and quality of life. CONCLUSION A standardized manual therapy and home exercise program did not provide additional immediate benefits for pain and function compared to a realistic placebo treatment controlling therapist contact in middle-aged to older adults with chronic rotator cuff disease. However, greater improvements were seen at follow-up, particularly in shoulder function and strength, suggesting that benefits take longer to appear with active treatment. TRIAL REGISTRATION Clinical trials NCT00415441.

title: Effectiveness of guidelines and training program: an educational process for diagnosing low back pain
abstract: BACKGROUND: The National Health Plan of Italy included low back pain (LBP) among the pathologies for which clinical guidelines should be established and disseminated. A change in the clinical behavior of doctors requires forms of intervention whose efficacy is not fully known. OBJECTIVES: This study proposes to evaluate the effectiveness of a multifaceted intervention, including training materials, lectures, workshops, and local consensus processes, to change the clinical treatment of General Practitioners (GPs) LBP. METHODS: Changes in diagnostic capacity were assessed through a controlled (before/after) trial based on the frequency of aetiological diagnoses of LBP, testing of clinical knowledge with multiple choice tests, and priorities given in facing treatment problems of LBP. three groups of general practitioners who voluntarily participated in the study. RESULTS: A statistically significant increase in diagnostic capacity (frequency of definitive answers in the multiple choice test) was obtained. There has also been a shift in priorities from diagnosis as the primary concern prior to intervention to communicating with the patient in facing issues in LBP treatment. CONCLUSIONS: In the Italian context, the study also confirms the effectiveness of a multifaceted intervention based on an educational process aimed at changing the GP's clinical behavior relative to the LBP.

title: EHRA research network surveys: 6 years of EP wires effectiveness
abstract: Clinical practice should follow guidelines and recommendations based mostly on the results of controlled studies conducted in selected populations and in specific conditions, whereas clinical practice may be influenced by factors different from controlled scientific studies. Therefore, the real-world setting is better appreciated by observational registries that enroll patients for longer periods of time. However, this can be difficult, expensive and time consuming. In 2009, the Scientific Initiatives Committee of the European Heart Rhythm Society (EHRA) initiated a series of research covering controversial issues in clinical electrophysiology (EP). With this in mind, an EHRA EP research network has been created that includes EP centers in Europe and distributes questionnaires on 'hot topic' among them. This review focuses on increasing participation in surveys and the research needs and expectations of the European EP community.

title: Electronic alerts to prevent venous thromboembolism in hospitalized patients
abstract: BACKGROUND Prophylaxis against deep vein thrombosis in hospitalized patients is not used adequately. We hypothesized that the use of a computer alerting program to induce prophylaxis could reduce the incidence of deep vein thrombosis in high-risk hospitalized patients. METHODS We developed a computer program linked to a patient database to identify consecutive hospitalized patients at risk for deep vein thrombosis in the absence of prophylaxis. The program used medical record numbers to randomly assign 1255 eligible patients to an intervention group where the responsible physician was warned of a patient's risk of deep vein thrombosis, and 1251 patients to a control group where no warning was given. The physician had to accept the warning and could then stop or order prophylaxis including graduated compression stockings, pneumatic compression boots, unfractionated heparin, low molecular weight heparin, or warfarin. The primary endpoint was clinically diagnosed, objectively confirmed deep vein thrombosis or pulmonary embolism at 90 days. RESULTS More patients in the intervention group than the control group received either mechanical prophylaxis (10.0 percent versus 1.5 percent, P<0.001) or pharmacological prophylaxis (23.6 percent versus 13.0 percent, P<0.001). The primary endpoint occurred in 61 patients (4.9 percent) in the intervention group and 103 patients (8.2 percent) in the control group”; Kaplan-Meier estimated the probability of surviving deep vein thrombosis or pulmonary embolism 94.1 percent at 90 days, respectively. (95 percent confidence interval, 92.5 to 95.4 percent) and 90.6 percent (95 percent confidence interval, 88.7 to 92.2 percent) (P<0.001) Computer warning reduced risk of deep vein thrombosis or 41 percent pulmonary embolism (hazard ratio) at 90 days , 0.59; 95 percent confidence interval, 0.43 to 0.81;" P=0.001). CONCLUSIONS A computer alerting program institution has increased physicians' use of prophylaxis and significantly reduced rates of deep vein thrombosis and pulmonary embolism in hospitalized at-risk patients.

title: Electronic alerts against optional decision support to improve dyslipidemia treatment: a cluster randomized controlled trial.
abstract: BACKGROUND: Indirect evidence shows that alerting users with clinical decision support systems changes behavior rather than requiring users to actively initiate the system. However, there are no randomized studies comparing these methods in a clinical setting. We examined the effect of both stimulus and optional decision support on the screening and treatment of dyslipidemia based on the guidelines of the Dutch College of General Practitioners. METHODS AND RESULTS: In a clustered randomized study design, 38 Dutch general practitioners (77 physicians) and 87,886 patients (39,433 men aged 18 to 70 years and 48,453 women aged 18 to 75 years) using the ELIAS electronic health record participated. Each application is designated to receive alerts, optional support, or non-interference. We measured the percentage of patients screened and treated after 12 months of follow-up. In the alert group, 65% of patients requiring screening were screened (relative risk vs. control = 1.76"; 95% confidence interval, 1.41 to 2.20), compared to 35% of patients in the discretionary group (relative risk vs. control = 1.28; 95%). confidence interval, 0.98 to 1.68) and 25% of patients in the control group In the Alert group, 66% of patients requiring treatment were cured (relative risk = 1.40 compared to control; 95% confidence interval, 1.15 to 1.70 ) in the optional group compared with 40 (relative risk with control=1.19; 95% confidence interval, 0.94 to 1.50) and 36% of patients in the control group. CONCLUSIONS: The alert version of clinical decision support systems significantly improved screening and treatment performance for dyslipidemia by general practitioners.

title: Electronic antibiotic management – reduced consumption of broad-spectrum antibiotics using a computerized antimicrobial approval system in a hospital setting.
abstract: Objectives Antibiotic management is important, but the ideal strategy for management in a hospital setting is unknown. A practical, sustainable and transferable strategy is needed. This study evaluates the impact of a new computerized antimicrobial approval system on antibiotic prescribing behavior in a hospital. The effects on drug consumption, antibiotic resistance patterns of local bacteria and patient outcomes were monitored. Methods The study was conducted at a tertiary referral teaching hospital in Melbourne, Australia. The system was commissioned in January 2005 and guided the use of 28 restricted antimicrobials. Data were collected over 7 years: 5 years before and 2 years after distribution. Reception of the system was evaluated using a built-in audit trail. Drug use was prospectively monitored using pharmacy data (as defined daily doses per 1000 bed-days) and analyzed by time series analysis with segmental linear regression. Antibiograms of local bacteria were evaluated prospectively. In-hospital mortality and length of stay have also been reported in patients with gram-negative bacteremia. Results Between 250 and 300 confirmations per month were recorded during 2006. Third and fourth generation cephalosporins (+0.52, -0.05, -0.39"; P < 0.01), glycopeptides (+0.27, -0.53; P = 0.09), carbapenems (+0.12, -0.24; P = 0.21), aminoglycosides (+ 0.15, -0.27; P < 0.01) and quinolones (+0.76, +0.11; "P = 0.08) decreased after deployment, whereas Extended-spectrum penicillin use increased. Trends in increased susceptibility to methicillin of Staphylococcusaureus and increased susceptibility of Pseudomonas spp. Many antibiotics have been found. No increase in adverse outcomes was observed in patients with gram-negative bacteremia. Results The system has been successfully adopted and significant changes in antimicrobial use have been demonstrated.

title: Electronic e-isotretinoin prescription chart: increasing physicians' adherence to isotretinoin prescribing guidelines
abstract: Oral isotretinoin is a highly effective treatment for resistant nodulocystic acne. However, it can be associated with serious side effects such as teratogenicity and hepatitis. Inadequate cumulative dose may also result in decreased therapeutic efficacy and higher disease relapse. A preliminary audit had previously revealed poor and inconsistent adherence by doctors to local isotretinoin prescribing guidelines. Key areas and reasons for non-compliance were identified to achieve greater than 90% compliance with isotretinoin guidelines for all acne patients prescribed systemic isotretinoin at the Singapore National Skin Center. A specially designed 'one-stop' electronic isotretinoin chart has become available within the electronic medical records (EMR) system to address key safety areas";" that is, informed consent, pregnancy testing, baseline laboratory tests, and automated calculation of cumulative and target isotretinoin doses. Physician compliance with prescribing guidelines improved from a baseline of 50-60% to over 90% (range 95-100%) over 30 months post-intervention. The e-isotretinoin chart has resulted in a significant improvement in physicians' adherence to isotretinoin prescribing guidelines and highlights the utility of EMR technology in influencing safe prescribing behavior among physicians.

title: Electronic health record decision support and quality of care for children with ADHD.
abstract: OBJECTIVE: The aim of this study was to evaluate the impact of electronic health record (EHR) decision support on physician management and documentation of care for children with attention deficit/hyperactivity disorder (ADHD). METHODS: This study included 79 general pediatricians caring for 412 children aged 5 to 18 years and previously diagnosed with ADHD in 12 pediatric primary care settings using the same EHR. We conducted a cluster randomized trial of EHR-based decision support that included (1) clinician reminders to assess ADHD symptoms every 3 to 6 months, and (2) an ADHD note template with structured fields for symptoms, treatment efficacy, and side effects. The main outcome measures were (1) the proportion of children visited during the 6-month study period in which ADHD was assessed, and (2) the quality of documentation of the ADHD assessment. Generalized prediction equations were used by providers to control clustering. RESULTS: Children in intervention areas were more likely to visit during the study period when their ADHD was assessed. The ADHD template was used in 32% of visits where patients were specifically scheduled for ADHD assessment, and its use was associated with better documentation of symptoms, treatment efficacy, and treatment side effects. CONCLUSIONS: EHR-based decision support increased the likelihood that children with ADHD would receive care and visits to manage the condition. A better understanding of decision support and how to optimize provider usage of templates can drive further improvements in maintenance.

title: Electronic health record feedback to improve antibiotic prescription for acute respiratory infections
abstract: Objective: To examine whether the Acute Respiratory Infection (ARI) Quality Board, an electronic health record (EHR)-based feedback system, changes antibiotic prescription. Study Design: Cluster randomized controlled trial. Methods: We randomly assigned 27 primary care applications to receive the ARI Quality Dashboard or usual care. The primary outcome was the rate of prescribing interventional antibiotics for ARI visits. We also compared antibiotic prescribing between ARI Quality Dashboard users and nonusers. Results: Difference between intervention and control treatments for antibiotic prescribing (47% vs. = .68) or antibiotic-naïve ARI visits (38% vs 40%; P = .70) 72 (28%) out of 258 intervention clinicians used the ARI Quality Control Panel at least once. lower overall rate of ARI antibiotic prescribing (42% vs 50% for nonusers; P = .02) This difference is due to fewer antibiotics being prescribed for antibiotic-ineligible ARIs (32% vs. 43%; P = 0.004) ) non-streptococcal pharyngitis (31% vs. 41%; P = .01) and non-specific upper respiratory tract infections (including 19% vs. 34%; P = .01) Results: The ARI Quality Indicator Table provides an overview of antibiotic prescribing. was not associated with change For ARIs, although used, it was associated with improved antibiotic prescribing. EHR-based quality reporting will not improve care in the absence of other changes in primary care practice. (Am J Manag Care. 2010;"16(Feature No. 12):e311-e319)

title: Electronic health record-based decision support to improve asthma care: a cluster randomized trial.
abstract: OBJECTIVE: Asthma remains one of the most common chronic diseases of childhood, affecting _x0001_6 million US children. Although National Asthma Education Prevention Program guidelines exist and are widely accepted, previous studies have shown poor clinician adherence in various populations. We sought to determine whether clinical decision support (CDS) embedded in an electronic health record (EHR) would improve clinician adherence to national asthma guidelines in the primary care setting. METHODS: We conducted a prospective cluster randomized study in 12 primary care centers over a 1-year period. Applications are tiered for analysis based on whether the site is urban or suburban. Children 0 to 18 years of age with persistent asthma are defined by the International Classification of Diseases, Ninth Revision codes for asthma. 6 intervention-implementation sites had CDS alerts embedded in the EHR. Outcomes of interest were the proportion of children with at least 1 prescription for controller medication, an updated asthma care plan, and office-based spirometry performance. RESULTS: Increases in the number of prescriptions for control drugs were 6% more over time (P .006) in intervention urban practices and 3% more for spirometry (P .04). Completion of a current asthma care plan improved by 14% (P .03) and spirometry by 6% (P .003) in suburban practice with the intervention. CONCLUSION: In our study, a clustering randomized trial design improved clinician adherence to National Asthma Education Prevention Program guidelines, CDS in EHR, point-of-care. Pediatrics 2010;"125:e770–e777

title: Electronic health records for intervention research: a cluster randomized trial to reduce antibiotic prescribing in primary care (eCRT Trial)
abstract: OBJECTIVE This study aimed to implement a point-of-care cluster randomized trial using electronic health records. We evaluated the effectiveness of electronically provided decision support tools in reducing the prescribing of antibiotics for respiratory tract infections in primary care. METHODS: Family practices from England and Scotland participating in the Clinical Practice Research Data Link (CPRD) were included in the study"; 53 family practices allocated to intervention and 51 practices allocated to usual care. Patients aged 18 to 59 years consulted for respiratory tract Infections were appropriate Intervention accessed during consultations performed via remotely established computer-provided decision support tools Control practices provided usual care The primary outcome was the proportion of consultations for respiratory infections with a prescribed antibiotic based on electronic health records. Family medicine-specific ratios were included in a cluster-level analysis RESULTS Data Analyzed for 603,409 patients: 317,717 in intervention settings and 285,692 in control settings, use of the Intervention varied between practices but was less than expected, rate of antibiotic prescription consultations 1.85% (95% CI, 0.10-3.59%, P = 0, 038) and the rate of prescribing antibiotics for respiratory tract infections (9.69%; 95% CI, 0.75%-18.63%, fewer prescriptions per 1000 patient-years, P = .034). There was no adverse event. CONCLUSIONS Randomized cluster trials can be implemented efficiently in large samples from routine care settings using primary care electronic health records. Future studies should develop and test multicomponent methods for remotely delivered intervention.

title: The electronic human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) clinical reminder system increases adherence to practice guidelines among the University of Washington HIV working group.
abstract: We performed a prospective study on an electronic clinical reminder system in an academic medical center-based human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) specialty clinic. Published performance indicators were used to examine compliance with HIV practice guidelines before and after administration for 1204 patients. More than 90% of patients received CD4 cell count and HIV type 1 (HIV-1) RNA level monitoring every 3-6 months during both time periods, and 80% of patients with CD4 cell counts <350 cells/mm3 as low as <350 cells/mm3 received highly active antiretroviral therapy. Patients were compared to Mycobacterium avium complex (hazard ratio, 3.84"; 95% confidence interval [CI], 1.58-9.31; P =.003) from annual cervical carcinoma screening (OR, 2.09; 95% CI, 1.04–4.16; P =. 04) and Toxoplasma gondii (odds ratio [OR], 1.86; 95% CI, 1.05–3.27; P =.03) and infection to undergo serological screening for syphilis (OR, 3.71; 95% CI, 2.37-5.81;"P) <.0001). HIV clinical reminders given at the time of HIV care were associated with more timely initiation of recommended practices.

title: Electronic Laboratory Medicine order with evidence-based Layout sets in primary care (ELMO study): protocol for a cluster randomized trial
abstract: Background Laboratory testing is an important clinical action with a valuable role in screening, diagnosis, management and monitoring of diseases or treatments. However, improper laboratory test ordering is frequent, burdens healthcare costs, and negatively impacts quality of care. Improper testing can also cause false positive results and potentially lead to excessive downstream activities. Clinical decision support systems (CDSSs) have shown promising results for influencing doctors' test requesting behavior and improving compliance. Order sets, a form of CDSS in which a limited set of evidence-based tests are recommended for a number of indications, integrated into a computerized physician order entry (CPOE), have been shown to be effective but convincing in reducing the volume of laboratory tests ordered. There is no evidence that it affects compliance. The aim of this study is to evaluate the effect of order sets on the quality and quantity of laboratory test orders by physicians. We also aim to evaluate the impact of sequence sets on diagnostic error and explore the impact on downstream or cascade activities. Methods We will conduct a cluster randomized controlled trial in Belgian primary care practice. The study was powered to measure two outcomes. We will first measure the impact of our CDSS on the compliance of the lab test order. Additionally, we will measure the impact on diagnostic error. We will also explore the effects of our intervention on cascading activities due to the varying results of inappropriate testing. Discussion We designed a study that should be able to show whether CDSS for diagnostic testing not only affects eligibility, but also whether it is safe for diagnostic error. These findings will impact wider, nationwide implementation of this CDSS. Trial registry ClinicalTrials.gov, NCT02950142.

title: Electronic medical records to increase clinical treatment of tobacco addiction: a systematic review.
abstract: CONTEXT: The expanded use of electronic medical records (EMRs) may provide an opportunity to increase the use and impact of clinical guidelines to promote tobacco cessation treatment in primary care settings. The purpose of this systematic review is to evaluate the evidence for such an effect. EARNING EVIDENCE: After a systematic search of the English-language literature on the impact of EMR on smoking cessation or clinician behavior, relevant articles are summarized and findings are summarized from both observational studies and RCTs. EVIDENCE SYNTHESIS: Of the ten identified studies on PROMs and tobacco, only two RCTs were found. The addition of tobacco status as a vital marker has resulted in an increase in recommended actions in some clinical guidelines, particularly in documenting smoking status. There was insufficient evidence to quantify the effect of EMR on changes in patients' smoking behaviors. CONCLUSIONS: Although the use of EMRs to provide feedback or guide the clinical management of tobacco addiction has shown some promising results, significant additional research is needed to understand the effects of EMRs on provider and patient behavior.

title: Electronic prescribing enhances the taking of advice from clinical pharmacologists in the hospital setting.
abstract: OBJECTIVES To determine whether electronic prescribing facilitates clinical pharmacologists' advice to improve drug safety in medical inpatients. METHODS Electronic case records and prescription charts (electronic or paper) of 502 hospitalized medical wards at a large Swiss teaching hospital between January 2009 and January 2010 were reviewed by four assistants and four senior clinical pharmacologists. Drug-related problems were identified and interventions recommended. The implementation and time delays of these suggested interventions were compared between patients using paper medication charts and patients using electronic medication charts. RESULTS In 109 hospitalizations, 158 drug-related problems were identified and 145 recommendations were made, 51% of which were implemented. Applicants with an electronic prescription chart (n = 90) were found to have 2.74-fold higher rates for applying change than a paper prescription chart (n = 53) (95% confidence interval 1.2, 6.3, P = 0.018, adjusted patient, ward, or clinic) ";" for any addiction revealed by the team (follow-up for two missing cases). The time delay between making and implementing the recommendations (if any) was minimal (mean 1 day) and did not differ between the two groups. CONCLUSIONS In this hospital setting, electronic prescribing was associated with greater implementation of clinical pharmacologists' recommendations to improve drug safety.

title: Electronically distributed, computer-generated, personalized feedback improves the use of a computerized practice guide
abstract: Clinical guidelines have been developed to assist in the management of patient care";" however, these guidelines are often neglected in clinical practice.
