Computer-generated reminders improve guide usage, but these systems often do not achieve high guide usage rates. This study was designed to test the hypothesis that computer-generated, individualized feedback on adherence to care guidelines would significantly improve clinician adherence to guideline recommendations delivered through a computer-assisted management protocol. Half of 45 primary care clinicians working in a primary care clinic affiliated with an academic medical center were randomized to receive a biweekly email message consisting of a computer-generated report summarizing their response to care guide recommendations for diabetic patients seen. during the previous 2 weeks. Clinician adherence to guideline recommendations was the primary outcome measure. This study demonstrated that the intervention significantly increased clinician adherence to guideline recommendations without incurring high costs of care. The median agreement among the intervention group was 35%, while it was 6.1% among the control group (p < 0.01). Electronically distributed, computer-generated, personalized feedback on the clinician's use of care guide recommendations is an effective way to increase adherence to a care guide.

title: Email for clinical communication between healthcare professionals
abstract: BACKGROUND: Email is one of the most widely used communication methods, but its use in healthcare is still rare. Where email communication is used in healthcare, its purposes have included clinical communication between healthcare professionals, but the implications of using email in this way are not well known. We have updated a 2012 review of the use of email for two-way clinical communication between healthcare professionals. OBJECTIVES: To evaluate the effects of email for clinical communication among healthcare professionals on healthcare professional outcomes, patient outcomes, healthcare performance, and service efficiency and acceptability, compared with other forms of clinical information communication. SEARCH METHODS: We searched for: The Cochrane Consumers and Communication Review Group Specialized Register, Cochrane Central Register of Controlled Trials (CENTRAL, The Cochrane Library, Issue 9 2013), MEDLINE (OvidSP) (1946 - August 2013), EMBASE (OvidSP) ( 1974 - August 2013), PsycINFO (1967 - August 2013), CINAHL (EbscoHOST) (1982 - August 2013) and ERIC (CSA) (1965 - January 2010). We searched the gray literature: theses/thesis repositories, essay records, and Google Scholar (searched November 2013). We used additional search methods: reviewing reference lists and contacting authors. SELECTION CRITERIA: Randomized controlled trials, controlled quasi-randomized trials before and after trials, and discontinuous time series studies examining interventions where healthcare professionals use e-mail to convey clinical information in the following ways: 1) unsecured e-mail, 2) secure e-mail, or 3) web messaging. All healthcare professionals, patients, and caregivers in all settings were considered. DATA COLLECTION AND ANALYSIS: Two authors independently evaluated studies for inclusion, assessed the risk of bias of included studies, and extracted data. We contacted the study authors for additional information and reported all precautions according to the study report. MAIN RESULTS: The previous version of this review included a randomized controlled trial involving 327 patients and 159 healthcare providers at baseline. He compared an email containing patient-specific osteoporosis risk information and an email containing assessment and treatment guidelines with usual care (no email). This study was at high risk of bias for separation hiding and blanking areas. The email reminder significantly changed the actions of healthcare professionals, and professionals were more likely to provide the osteoporosis treatment recommended in the guideline (bone density measurement or osteoporosis medication or both) compared to usual care. Evidence for its effect on patient behavior or actions was inconclusive. One measure found that the electronic medical reminder message positively affected patient behavior (patients had a higher calcium intake), and the two found no difference between the two groups. The study did not evaluate health care outcomes or harms. No new work has been identified for this update. AUTHOR'S CONCLUSIONS: Only one study was identified for inclusion, providing insufficient evidence to guide clinical practice regarding the use of email for clinical communication among healthcare professionals. Future research should aim to use high-quality study designs that use the latest advances in information technology, keeping in mind the complexity of email as an intervention.

title: Email for clinical communication between healthcare professionals
abstract: BACKGROUND: Email is a popular and widely used communication method, but its use in healthcare is not routine. Where email communication is used in healthcare, its purposes have also included use for clinical communication among healthcare professionals, but the implications of using email in this way are unknown. This review evaluates the use of e-mail for two-way clinical communication among healthcare professionals. OBJECTIVES: To evaluate the impact of healthcare professionals using email to communicate clinical information on healthcare professional outcomes, patient outcomes, healthcare performance, and service efficiency and acceptability compared to other forms of clinical information communication. SEARCH METHODS: We searched for: Cochrane Consumers and Communications Review Group Expert Registry, Cochrane Central Registry of Controlled Trials (CENTRAL, The Cochrane Library, Issue 1 2010), MEDLINE (OvidSP) (1950 - January 2010), EMBASE (OvidSP) (19 1980) - January 2010), PsycINFO (1967 - January 2010), CINAHL (EbscoHOST) (1982 - February 2010) and ERIC (CSA) (1965 - January 2010). We searched the gray literature: theses/thesis repositories, essay records, and Google Scholar (searched July 2010). We used additional search methods: reviewing reference lists, contacting authors. SELECTION CRITERIA: Randomized controlled trials, quasi-randomized trials, pre- and post-controlled trials, and interventions that examine interventions where healthcare professionals use e-mail to convey clinical information and include 1) non-secure e-mail 2) secure e-mail or 3) web messaging. All healthcare professionals, patients, and caregivers in all settings were considered. DATA COLLECTION AND ANALYSIS: Two authors independently evaluated studies for inclusion, assessed the risk of bias of included studies, and extracted data. We contacted the study authors for additional information. We report all measures according to the study report. MAIN RESULTS: We included a randomized controlled trial involving 327 patients and 159 healthcare providers at baseline. He compared an email to physicians with patient-specific osteoporosis risk information and assessment and treatment guidelines with usual care (no email). This study was at high risk of bias for separation hiding and blanking areas. The email reminder significantly changed the actions of healthcare professionals, and professionals were more likely to provide the osteoporosis treatment (bone density measurement and/or osteoporosis medication) recommended in the guideline compared to normal care. Evidence for its effect on patient behaviors/actions was insufficient. One measure found that the electronic medical reminder message positively affected patient behavior: patients had higher calcium intakes, and the two found no difference between the two groups. The study did not evaluate primary care outcomes or harms. AUTHORS' CONCLUSIONS: As only one study was identified for inclusion, the results are insufficient to inform clinical practice of using email for clinical communication among healthcare professionals. Future research should use high-quality study designs that take advantage of the latest advances in information technology, considering the complexity and costs of email as an intervention.

title: Emergency mental health nursing for self-harming refugees and asylum seekers
abstract: This article describes the structure and function of emergency mental health nursing practice for self-harming refugees and asylum seekers on Temporary Protection Visas. Emergency nurses working in accident and emergency services or as part of crisis response teams will see refugees and asylum seekers at their most distressing point. This clinical article aims to support nurses in their practice when they encounter an adult asylum seeker who needs urgent mental health care. Practical strategies are highlighted to help mental health nurses assess, care for and comfort these vulnerable refugees and asylum seekers. When dealing with mental and emotional health issues, mental health nurses should work closely with asylum seekers, their support workers, and accredited interpreters and interpreters, where possible, to ensure the appropriate use of language without further isolating the refugee from appropriate services. To help strengthen the continuity and integration of mental health support for refugees and asylum seekers, well-resourced care must be experienced in a coherent and connected way. A consistent, interdisciplinary and team-oriented approach will synthesize different perspectives to shape clinical practice and create viable solutions in local situations.

title: Empowering patients or general practitioners? A randomized clinical trial to improve the quality of reproductive health care in Belgium.
abstract: BACKGROUND: Evidence-based clinical guidelines on contraceptive use were developed and distributed among all Flemish general practitioners (GPs) in Belgium. OBJECTIVES: To evaluate the effectiveness of two strategies for implementing a guideline on oral contraceptives to improve the quality of initial contraception consultation in general practice, either by empowering patients or introducing a computer decision support system (CDSS). METHODS: A random sample of 45 GPs was distributed to three study groups. One group was visited by 'empowered patients', one group's electronic medical record was supplemented with a CDSS, and one group served as a control group. Simulated patients (SPs) evaluated GPs' performance in daily practice before and after interventions using a validated 48-point checklist. RESULTS: The mean initial score of 43 GPs was 26.16 (SD = 5.76). SPs received adequate information on correct pill use, but not on factors related to pill failure and drug interaction. After intervention, the mean score of GPs was 26.39 (SD = 6.86). Only the 'empowered patient' intervention group scored significantly better (29.92 [SD = 7.11]). The computer group and control group scored lower (24.36 [SD = 6.60] and 24.82 [SD = 5.65], respectively). CONCLUSION: Developing and distributing an evidence-based guideline did not change the behavior of GPs. However, encouraging patients to participate more proactively significantly improved GPs' performance during a birth control consultation. It did not give a CDSS.

title: It seems possible to encourage post-stroke patients to be active: results of an intervention study with knowledge brokers
abstract: OBJECTIVE: Although physical activity and exercise are strongly recommended for rapid recovery for stroke patients, patients in hospitals and rehabilitation centers are not sufficiently encouraged to be physically active. In this study, we investigated the impact of information brokers (KBs), enterprising nurses, and therapists on the performance of healthcare workers (HPs) to encourage stroke inpatients to be physically active. METHODS: This multicenter intervention study used a pre-post test design. Two or three PDs were trained in each stroke unit of 12 hospitals and 10 rehabilitation centers in the Netherlands. Questionnaires were completed by patients and HPs before and after the BP intervention. The primary outcome was the incentive given by HPs to their patients to be physically active, as reported by patients and HPs. RESULTS: After KB intervention, significantly more patients (48%"; N=217) reported at least some incentive to be physically active by HPs (26%;" N=243, p<0.000). HPs (N=288) reported, on average, encouraging patients more frequently after intervention, but this difference was significant only for occupational therapists and BPs. CONCLUSIONS: Based on patient reports of HP behavior, BP-intervention appears to be effective as more patients feel encouraged to be physically active after the intervention than before. This study needs to be repeated in an experimental design to allow for causal inferences. Implications for rehabilitation As BP-intervention has been shown to increase the incentive that stroke patients feel to be physically active, we recommend that rehabilitation teams make use of information brokers (KBs). More frequent involvement of physicians, nurses, and patient families in efforts to encourage stroke patients to be physically active seems beneficial.

title: Improved application of low back pain guidelines in general practice: study protocol of a cluster randomized controlled trial.
abstract: BACKGROUND: Evidence-based clinical practice guidelines can improve treatment quality, but adoption of guideline recommendations is often incomplete and slow. New low back pain guidelines are being launched in Denmark recently. Guidelines are thought to reduce personal and public costs. The purpose of this study was to evaluate whether a complex, versatile implementation strategy of low back pain guidelines could reduce secondary care referral and improve patient outcomes compared to the usual simple implementation strategy. METHODS/DESIGN: A two-arm randomized cluster study will enroll 2,700 patients aged 18 to 65 years, from 100 general practices (clusters) and the northern Danish region. Applications are randomly allocated 1:1 to a simple or complex application strategy. Intervention practices will take a complex implementation strategy, including guideline facilitator visits, classification tools, and quality reports on low back pain management. The primary outcome is referral to secondary care. Secondary outcomes are pain, physical function, health-related quality of life, patient satisfaction with care and treatment outcomes, employment status, and sick leave. Primary and secondary outcomes are related to patient level. Evaluation of results is blind and follows the principle of treating. In addition, a process assessment will assess the degree to which intervention items were implemented as planned, and also measure changes in beliefs and behaviors among GPs and patients. DISCUSSION: This study provides information on the process and impact of an intervention to implement low back pain guidelines in general practice and will provide insight into key elements to include in future implementation strategies in general practice. TRIAL REGISTRATION: Registered on ClinicalTrials.gov as NCT01699256.

title: Physicians' adherence to antibiotic use guidelines has been enhanced through increased availability of guidelines when ordering medication in the hospital setting.
abstract: Purpose Some research has shown that physicians' access to practice guidelines when making clinical decisions can improve prescribing practices. The aim of the study was to evaluate the benefit of the intervention on physician compliance, which previously consisted of the placement of paper-based antibiotic guides in a teaching hospital's computerized physician order entry system. time to order antibiotics. Prior to the intervention, these guidelines were available in booklet form in all wards of the hospital. Methods Compliance with guidelines was assessed in 471 consecutive antibiotic orders for pneumonia, 104 immediately before intervention and 367 immediately after intervention. Evaluation criteria were: antibiotic selection according to the context of pneumonia acquisition, daily dose, planned duration of treatment. Antibiotic requests were evaluated at the beginning of antibiotic therapy. Results Intervention was followed by a significant decrease in the proportion of antibiotic orders that included at least one criterion for non-compliance with guidelines, by 51% (p?<?0.001) before intervention versus 33% after intervention, respectively. The proportion of unsuitable orders for daily antibiotic dose in the pre- and post-intervention period decreased by 12.2% and 26.9% (p?<?0.001) for planned treatment duration, 7.3% versus 18.3% (p?<?0.001), pneumonia acquisition The improvement in antibiotic selection according to the context did not reach statistical significance, 18.2% vs. 25%, respectively (p?=?0.12). Conclusion In this study, increased availability of antibiotic guidelines at the time of drug ordering, along with a periodic round of supplemental education, was associated with an increased physician compliance with these guidelines. Copyright © 2010 John Wiley & Sons, Ltd.

title: Increasing access to alcohol use disorder pharmacotherapy and treatment in primary care settings: ADaPT-PC
abstract: Only 7.8% of individuals who meet the diagnostic criteria for past alcohol use disorder (AUD) receive treatment in a given year. Most people with AUD are identified in primary care (PC) settings and referred to substance use disorders (SUD) clinics";" however, only a small proportion of those referred continue to receive treatment. Safe and effective pharmacological treatments for AUD exist, but they are rarely prescribed by PC providers. The aim of this study was to develop, implement and evaluate an intervention to integrate pharmacological AUD treatment options into PC settings. This article provides a detailed description of intervention design and evaluation components. Methods/design Three major Veteran Health Administration (VHA) facilities are participating in the response. The intervention targets stakeholder groups with specific strategies based on practice theory and prior research that has identified barriers to the implementation of AUD pharmacotherapy. Local SUD providers and primary care mental health integration (PCMHI) providers are trained to serve as local practice/clinical champions and receive external facilitation. PC providers access consultation from local and national clinical champions for case identification, educational materials, and a panel of patients with AUD in caseloads. Veterans diagnosed with AUD receive educational information in the mail just prior to a scheduled PC visit. The effectiveness of the intervention will be evaluated via a discontinuous time series with matched controls to monitor the change in AUD pharmacotherapy prescribing rates at the facility level. Following StitlerÂ¡â¯'s four-step formative assessment (FE) strategy, FE methods include (1) developmental FE (pre-practice interviews with champions, computer providers, and Veterans), (2) practice-oriented FE (participation monitoring). facilitation meetings, academic elaboration efforts by local champions, and patient dashboard use), (3) progression-oriented FE (AUD pharmacotherapy prescribing rates and referral rates to PCMHI and SUD special care), and (4) interpretive FE (post-champions and PC providers) application conversations). Analysis of FE data will be driven by the Consolidated Framework for Application Research (CFIR). Discussion If proven successful, this implementation strategy will provide a repeatable, viable and relatively low-cost method of integrating AUD treatment services into PC settings, thereby increasing access to AUD treatment.

title: Advancement of evidence-based diabetes and chronic disease control among local health departments: a multistage dissemination study with a tiered cluster randomized trial component.
abstract: Background Diabetes and prediabetes rates are increasing in the United States, significantly affecting the quality and life expectancy of those diagnosed, and placing a financial burden on society. Early death and disability can be prevented through the implementation of evidence-based programs and policies (EBPPs). Local health departments (LHDs) are uniquely positioned to implement diabetes control EBPPs because of their knowledge and focus on community-level needs, contexts and resources. However, there is a significant gap between the known diabetes control EBPPs and the actual diabetes control activities carried out by LHDs. The aim of this study was to determine how best to support the use of evidence-based public health for diabetes (and related chronic diseases) control among public health practitioners at the local level. Methods/design This article describes methods of a staggered cluster randomized trial and a two-stage study to evaluate public health information for diabetes control and dissemination strategies to increase uptake of EBPPs among LHDs. Phase 1 includes the development of measures to assess practitioner views and institutional supports for evidence-based public health, data collection using a national online survey of LHD chronic disease practitioners, and a needs assessment of factors influencing the uptake of diabetes control EBPPs among LHDs in the country. A state in the USA. Phase 2 includes conducting a cascade cluster randomized trial to evaluate the effectiveness of dissemination strategies with local-level practitioners in LHDs to increase capacity and institutional support for evidence-based diabetes prevention and control. Twelve LHDs will be selected and randomly assigned to one of three groups undergoing usual practice to receive intervention (spreading) strategies at 8-month intervals";" Intervention time for groups ranged from 8 to 24 months. Response (dissemination) strategies may include multi-day face-to-face workshops, electronic information exchange methods, technical assistance through an information broker, and organizational changes to support evidence-based public health approaches. Evaluation methods include initial questionnaires and three cross time points, abstraction of local level diabetes and chronic disease control program plans and progress reports, and social network analysis to understand the relationships and contextual issues affecting EBPP adoption.

title: Increasing mammography referral in primary care
abstract: Background. This 1-year randomized study tested the effectiveness of behavioral techniques for increasing mammography referrals by primary care physicians in small community practices. Methods. Sixty-one applications were randomly assigned to one of three conditions: (1) training control only, (2) training plus cue development using mammography chart stickers, and (3) training plus cue enhancement plus feedback and coin rewards. Quarterly chart audits of a defined sample (N= 11,716) of female patients 50 years of age and older were performed to document mammography referrals, completions, and compliance. Results. Dispatch and completion rates increased from the start to the first quarter and then gradually decreased. Overall, these rates were higher in the cuing condition than in the control condition. In contrast, compliance rates in both experimental conditions increased over the year, while remaining static in the control condition, demonstrating a strong and sustained effect for cue enhancement. Compliance increases were highest for older, non-white, second-specialty, practice-only, non-AMA physicians, no specialty training, and no board-certified physicians. Results. Graphic stickers can significantly increase the use of mammography in small community applications. These apps are an effective way to reach large numbers of older women who need mammography screening.

title: Developing the African bioethics initiative
abstract: OBJECTIVE: Medical ethics has existed since the time of Hippocrates. However, formal training in bioethics was not established until a few decades ago. Bioethics has gained a strong foothold in the health sciences in the developed world, particularly in Europe and North America. In many developing countries the situation is quite different. In most African countries, bioethics - as established and practiced in the West today - is either non-existent or primitive. DISCUSSION: Although bioethics has matured in developed and some developing countries, it is still largely "foreign" to most African countries. Several bioethics conferences have been held in parts of Africa over the past decade to raise awareness of research ethics and ensure compliance with international guidelines for research with human participants. This idea was born out of recognition of the real need for capacity building to review research ethics in Africa. It is also a required condition by external sponsors of collaborative research in Africa. The awareness and interest these conferences evoke need to be further strengthened and extended beyond research ethics to clinical practice. In general, bioethics education in schools that train doctors and other healthcare providers is the hook that anchors both research ethics and clinical ethics. SUMMARY: This paper reviews the current state of bioethics in Africa as it applies to research ethics workshops and suggests that, despite current efforts to integrate ethics into biomedical research in Africa, much remains to be done to achieve this. A more comprehensive approach to bioethics with an all-encompassing benefit is to integrate formal ethics education into health education institutions in Africa.

title: Development of developmental-behavioral surveillance and screening algorithm in children aged 5 to 5 years
abstract: OBJECTIVE: To determine whether the 2006 American Academy of Pediatrics developmental surveillance and screening algorithm is adequate or needs revision. METHODS: A comprehensive literature review was conducted to investigate a clinician's ability to conduct developmental-behavioral surveillance of children aged 0 to 5 years. CONCLUSIONS: Even when a broadband developmental screening is typical, pediatricians should refer when they confidently suspect a delay, but be much more skeptical about children who appear asymptomatic. Periodic screening improves surveillance by improving early detection and early intervention (EI) eligibility rates. However, children with relevant screens are not consistently referred to and linked to EI. After referral, about half do not qualify for EI, although they typically perform well below average and have multiple, predictive academic and psychosocial risk factors. Meanwhile, clinicians are struggling to keep track of at-risk children. CONCLUSION: Revisions are needed to optimize early detection, prevention and monitoring. More emphasis is needed on developmental-behavioral promotion and referral care coordination.

title: Improving the quality of antibiotic prescribing in primary care: a qualitative assessment of a blended learning intervention.
abstract: BACKGROUND: The Stemming the Tide of Antibiotic Resistance (STAR) Training Program aims to improve the quality of antibiotic prescribing and raise awareness of antibiotic resistance among general medical practitioners. It consists of a seven-part theory-based blended learning program that includes online reflection on clinicians' own practice, presentation of research evidence and guidelines, a practice-based seminar focusing on participants' own antibiotic prescriptions and resistance rates in externally sent urine samples. applications, communication skills training using videos of simulated patients during routine surgery, and participation in a web forum. Efficacy was evaluated in a randomized controlled trial involving 244 GPs and Nurse Practitioners and 68 general practitioners. This document reports part of the process evaluation of that trial. METHODS: Semi-structured, digitally recorded and transcribed telephone interviews with 31 purposefully sampled trial participants analyzed using thematic content analysis. RESULTS: The majority of participants reported increased awareness of antibiotic resistance, greater self-confidence in reducing antibiotic prescribing, and at least some change in consultation style and antibiotic prescribing behavior. Practical changes reported have included the adoption of a practice-wide policy of antibiotic prescription reduction. Many GPs also reported increased insight into patients' expectations, which ultimately contributed to improving the doctor-patient relationship. Components of the intervention that were claimed to have the greatest impact on changing clinician behavior were up-to-date sources of research evidence, simple and effective communication skills presented in online videos, and presentation of practice combined with and of their own antibiotic prescribing levels. an overview of local resistance data. CONCLUSION: Participants found this complex blended learning intervention acceptable and feasible and reported wide-ranging, positive changes in attitudes and clinical practice as a result of participating in the STAR Education Program. TRIAL REGISTRATION: Current Controlled Trials ISRCTN63355948.

title: Epidemiology for the inexperienced. Etiology of disease -- selection of controls
Epidemiology of Alzheimer's presenile dementia in Scotland, 1974-88
abstract: OBJECTIVE To describe the epidemiology of presenile Alzheimer's disease in Scotland from 1974 to 1988. DESIGN Retrospective review of hospital records of patients younger than 73 years old admitted to a psychiatric hospital with various dementia diagnoses. Diagnoses were classified according to the National Institute of Communication Disorders and Stroke and Alzheimer's Disease and Associated Disorders Association Criteria and Hachinski score. The completeness of the study sample was assessed by reviewing neurology outpatient and general hospital records. SET All general psychiatric hospitals in Scotland. SUBJECTS All patients aged 40-64 years with onset of dementia. MAIN OUTCOME MEASURES Possible and common Alzheimer's disease, patient's gender, age of onset. RESULTS 5874 psychiatric hospital records, 129 neurology outpatient records, and 89 records from non-psychiatry hospitals were analyzed. 317 patients met criteria for probable Alzheimer's disease, 569 patients met broad Alzheimer's disease criteria, and 267 patients met criteria for multiple infarct dementia. The minimum incidences per 100,000 population aged 40-64 years were 22.6 (95% confidence interval, 20.2 to 25.2) and 40.5 (38.9 to 42.3) per 100,000 for probable and extensive Alzheimer's disease. In the 1981 census year, the annual incidence of probable Alzheimer's disease was 1.6 (1.0 to 2.6). Women were at greater risk with probable Alzheimer's disease incidence rates of 28.2 (24.5 to 32.4 per 100,000) compared with 16.5 (13.8 to 19.8) per 100,000 for men. The incidence of one in 100,000 for multiple infarct dementia was greater in men (25.1, 23.3 to 27.1) than women (13.4, 12.1 to 14.8). CONCLUSION Female gender appears to be positively associated with the development of Alzheimer's disease before the age of 65.

title: Epilepsy and employment
For Erratum: Toward a common terminology: a simplified intervention framework for integrating and integrating evidence into health practices, systems and policies
ESHRE guideline: routine psychosocial care in infertility and medical assisted reproduction - a guide for fertility personnel
abstract: STUDY QUESTION: Based on the best available evidence in the literature, what is the optimal management of routine psychosocial care in infertility and medical assisted reproduction (MAR) clinics? SUMMARY ANSWER: Using the structured methodology of the European Society of Human Reproduction and Embryology (ESHRE) Guideline Development Guidelines, 120 recommendations were formulated answering 12 key questions regarding the optimal management of routine psychosocial care by all fertility staff. WHAT IS ALREADY KNOWN: The 2002 ESHRE Guidelines for infertility counseling has for years been a reference point for the best psychosocial care in infertility, but this guideline needed updating and did not focus on routine psychosocial care that could be delivered by all fertility staff. OPERATION, DESIGN, SIZE, DURATION: This guide has been prepared by a group of experts in the field, according to the 12-step process described in the ESHRE Guideline Development Guide. After defining the scope of the guideline and listing a set of 12 key questions in the PICO (Patient, Intervention, Comparison, and Outcome) format, extensive systematic literature search was conducted";" Evidence from articles published up to April 2014 was collected, evaluated for quality, and analyzed. A summary of the evidence was written in response to each of the key questions and used as the basis for recommendations defined by consensus within the guideline development group (GDG). During the scoping and review phase of guideline development, patient and additional clinical input were collected. PARTICIPANTS/MATERIALS, ENVIRONMENT, METHODS: The guide group, consisting of a psychologist, two medical doctors, a midwife, a patient representative, and a methodologist, met three times to discuss the evidence and agree on recommendations. MAIN RESULTS AND THE ROLE OF CHANCE WHAT THE GUIDE PROVIDES: 120 recommendations aimed at guiding fertility clinic staff in providing optimal evidence-based routine psychosocial care to patients dealing with infertility and MAR. The directive is written in two parts. The first section describes patients' preferences regarding the psychosocial care they want to receive in clinics and how this care relates to their well-being. The second part of the guide provides information on the psychosocial needs that patients experience along their treatment path (before, during and after treatment) and how fertility clinic staff can identify and address them. Needs refer to the conditions assumed to be necessary for patients to have a healthy experience in fertility treatment. Needs include behavioral (lifestyle, exercise, nutrition, and adjustment), relational (relationship with partner, family friends and wider network and work, if any), emotional (well-being, eg anxiety, depression, and quality of life), and cognitive (treatment concerns and knowledge). . LIMITATIONS, REASONS FOR CAUTION: We have identified many areas of care where solid evidence is lacking. Gaps in the evidence were addressed by formulating good practice points based on the GDG's expert opinion, but empirical validation of such recommendations is critical. LARGER IMPACT OF FINDINGS: The evidence presented in this guideline demonstrates that providing routine psychosocial care is associated with, or has the potential to, reduce stress and anxiety associated with medical procedures and improve lifestyle outcomes, fertility information, patient well-being, and adherence to treatment. . As only 45 (36.0%) of the 125 recommendations were based on high-quality evidence, the guideline group formulated recommendations to guide future research to increase the evidence.

title: Key elements of early intervention service for psychosis: expert clinicians' opinions
abstract: BACKGROUND: Early intervention teams seek to improve outcome in schizophrenia through early detection and provision of phase-specific treatments. While the number of early response teams is increasing, there is a lack of clarity on their key structural and functional elements. METHODS: A 'Delphi' study was conducted in a group of 21 UK specialist clinicians to determine how much consensus there was on key elements of early intervention teams. Using published guidelines, a starting list of 151 items from the ten categories of team structure and function was created. RESULTS: Overall, there was expert consensus on the importance of 136 (90%) of these elements. Of the agreed items, 106 (70.2%) were rated as necessary, meaning that their absence would seriously disrupt the functioning of the team. CONCLUSION: This level of consensus on the key elements makes it reasonable for UK early response teams to define a model from which a measure of fidelity can be derived.

title: Fundamentals of research ethics for healthcare professionals
abstract: Research with human subjects, whether conducted at a university or in the healthcare field, raises numerous ethical questions for healthcare professionals. As both clinicians and scientists engage in ongoing professional development in how to conduct research ethically, they need to broaden their knowledge to answer the following questions: Which ethical theories serve as the basis for ethical principles in research ethics? What ethical principles should a researcher respect when conducting research with human subjects? What does it mean to conduct research ethically? What ethical dilemmas does a researcher face while doing research? This article presents a review of ethical theories and the ethical foundations of guidelines developed and used to guide human subject research. The ethical behaviors and personal responsibility of the researcher who conducts research with human subjects in research designs and methods are discussed.

title: Establishing translational and clinical cancer research collaborations between high- and low-income countries
abstract: Associated malignancies, both communicable and non-communicable, are a growing problem in low- and middle-income countries (LMIC). Data and guidelines for cancer treatment from high-income countries (HIC) to cancer patients in the LMIC are difficult to estimate. Due to the increase in noncommunicable cancer rates, there is a growing gap between the need for evidence-based treatments for cancer control plans and current research capabilities. Surgeons often provide all surgical and medical oncology treatments to patients at LMIC for diseases such as breast, stomach, cervical and colorectal cancers. However, clinical and translational research collaborations in surgical oncology are lacking. There are several successful consortia focusing on HIV and infection-related malignancies. These collaborations can be used as examples of future surgical research efforts. The Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center-Nigeria collaboration focusing on colorectal cancer is used as an example of how to initiate a research collaboration that can build a research infrastructure and provide the data needed to create realistic treatment guidelines. The need for expanded surgical oncology research and the growing population of patients with non-infectious associated malignancies in LMIC have created a unique opportunity for surgeons to initiate and lead clinical and translational research collaborations between HIC and LMIC.

title: Ethical aerobics: ACHRE's avoidance of responsibility
abstract: The President's Advisory Committee on Human Radiation Experiments (ACHRE) was tasked with conducting a comprehensive ethical review of US government-funded radiation experiments. In these experiments, several hundred thousand people were used as experimental subjects in several thousand experiments. This article reviews ACHRE's Final Report, published in October 1995. ACHRE offered no apology or compensation to the vast majority of victims. The rationale for this decision was full of inconsistencies. When facts could not be recontextualized to mitigate the blatant abuse of government-funded researchers, ACHRE created ethical loopholes to prevent perpetrators from being prosecuted. We criticize ACHRE's recommendations through careful analysis of its own records and transcripts. We. It provides an accurate history of standards of informed consent in human subject research, in contrast to ACHRE's inconsistent history. We also present a detailed review of ACHRE's faulty risk analysis in two representative experimental groups.

title: Ethics and institutional review board issues
abstract: IRBs provide an important role in protecting research subjects/patients. Research investigators by their very nature as healthcare professionals have a potential conflict of interest";" As physicians, they are committed to promoting the well-being of individual patients, whereas as researchers they seek information that can be generalized and applied to people other than the individual patient studied. The second goal may conflict with the first. IRBs have the greatest responsibility for protecting the rights and well-being of human research subjects. While the IRB system is not perfect, conscientious IRBs reassure the public that the rights and well-being of human subjects are seriously considered by those who do not have a vested interest in the outcome of the research. By fulfilling their responsibilities, IRBs promote the protection of human subjects. IRB approval provides substantial confirmation of the scientific and ethical qualities of research and therefore offers important validation to research and research researchers. Acting in accordance with the guiding principles of the Belmont Report and within the regulatory guidelines of 45.CFR.46, IRBs seek to balance society's interests in advancing scientific knowledge and its duty to protect the rights and well-being of human subjects.

title: Ethical and legal risks associated with archival research
abstract: Mental health institutions and practitioners often allow researchers direct access to patient records for archival research purposes without the informed consent of patient-participants. Typically, these researchers have access to all information in such records as long as they agree to maintain confidentiality and remove any identifying data from subsequent research reports. Changes to the American Psychological Association's Code of Ethics (American Psychological Association, 1992) raise ethical and legal issues that need to be considered by practitioners, researchers, and facility Institutional Review Boards. This article addresses these issues and offers suggestions for alternative ways to conduct research using archival mental health records as well as changes in ethical standards.

title: Ethical complications of clinical therapeutic research on children
abstract: The usual debate by ethicists and physicians about the ethical implications of research on catastrophically ill children and the guidelines established by the Federal Government for this research is based on the application of general moral principles to problems. Whatever the merits of this approach to policy-making, it does not adequately reflect the patients' living situation and the complexity of a single regimen that is simultaneously therapeutic and research-oriented. Also, problems become more complex when there is disagreement between parents about a course of treatment. We believe that such cases are appropriately resolved by considering the degree of paternalism to be applied by the clinician-researcher.";" KIE: Much of the discussion of ethical issues in therapeutic research for children is based on the application of general moral principles to problem categories. The authors believe that this approach does not adequately address the complexity of a treatment regimen for disastrously ill children, both therapeutic and research-oriented. Using a case study to illustrate the possible complications of such a condition, they argue that medical paternalism is justified on the grounds that in therapeutic research on children, the protection of the patient's interests should come first, even if it diminishes the patient's autonomy. full autonomy.

title: Ethical considerations for research on human subjects
Ethical considerations in recruiting research subjects from hospitalized cardiovascular patient populations
abstract: Cardiovascular research nurses play an important role in ensuring that subject recruitment is done in an ethically defensible manner. However, these nurses face many ethical challenges during the research process. Relying solely on regulatory mechanisms such as institutional review board oversight and adherence to regulatory requirements does not ensure the protection of human subjects or the scientific integrity of researchers (J Law Med Ethics. 2002";"30:411-419). Therefore, this article discusses 3 additional ethical considerations associated with recruiting hospitalized cardiovascular patients for research studies. These are (a) the role of family and patient empowered "watchdogs", (b) the impact of temporary and subtle mental state changes on the approval process, and (c) the impact of conflicting patient priorities. This content is illustrated using the authors' experience in recruiting hospitalized coronary artery bypass graft surgery patients for a research study.

title: Ethical dilemmas in qualitative research: how do we respect autonomy?
abstract: This article brings to light the concept of nursing research and specifically examines the principle of 'respect for autonomy', its limitations and relevance in the field of research on human subjects during qualitative research. This article will also identify how ethical dilemmas involving respect for autonomy may develop during research, and will present a systematic method of critical ethical analysis to show that nurse researchers can resolve such issues as and when they arise. It is necessary to focus on one aspect of the research process to demonstrate the 'depth' of evaluation required to ensure that such research is of the highest quality.

title: Ethical genetic research on human subjects
abstract: Nuremberg Trials and II. Since the trial of Nazi doctors following World War II, international ethical protocols have emerged designed to protect human subjects from the atrocities of medical experimentation that was literally routine under the Nazis. Some apparent "lessons" from the Nazi era are summarized in the Declaration of Helsinki, perhaps the leading medical ethics protocol. This article argues that these protocols do not particularly assist human welfare or the protection of human rights in the field of human genetics research. The article proposes new protocols and a new approach to research ethics on human subjects.

title: Ethical issues in the management of chronic non-malignant pain
abstract: Chronic pain is a challenge for patients, families, employers, and doctors who care for these individuals. Opioids remain the mainstay of analgesic drugs for the treatment of both acute and chronic pain. Controlled-release preparations of morphine, oxycodone, fentanyl, and long-acting opioid agents such as methadone and levorphanol have been medically and ethically accepted in the treatment of chronic cancer pain. However, the continued use of these drugs in patients with non-cancer chronic pain is fiercely debated. This article attempts to reconcile the medical and ethical dilemma of using opioid drugs for non-cancer chronic pain. Increasing clinical experience in pain medicine has helped clarify the following: (1) a misunderstanding of addiction, physical dependence, and analgesic tolerance; (2) the misconception that chronic opioid therapy inevitably causes personality changes, depression, and cognitive and physical impairment. (3) lack of knowledge about the proper use of opioid analgesics with regard to titration and management of related side effects. Behavioral management of pain patients receiving chronic opioid therapy is also discussed. A protocol has been proposed for optimal patient management. Special attention is paid to the consent form, the behavioral contract, and the consequences of non-compliance. The importance of psychological evaluation before a long-term trial of opioids is emphasized to minimize future complications. Although most patients on the opioid regimen do well, special attention should be paid to patients with current addiction, past addiction history, or misuse of current opioid medication. Pharmacological and conservative interventions are usually warranted in patients with significant behavioral problems. If such strategies fail and chronic opioid therapy is deemed necessary, some treatment guidelines are offered.

title: Ethical regulations for innovative surgery: the final frontier?
abstract: BACKGROUND: Although there are general guidelines governing research with human subjects, there are no clear federal regulations governing innovative surgery. We hypothesized that US surgeons were unaware of Department of Health and Human Services regulations, rarely sought IRB review, were often opposed to external regulations of innovative surgery, and were unsure of what constituted innovation and research. These conditions, if true, would pose a significant ethical challenge and present potential harm to patients as unintentional research subjects. STUDY DESIGN: In a pilot study, we reviewed 527 issues of US surgical and medical journals, selecting 59 articles describing innovative surgery between 1992 and 2000. An anonymous questionnaire was sent to the corresponding authors from university hospitals (71%) and other facilities (29%). RESULTS: The survey was conducted between November 2000 and May 2001. Twenty-one questionnaires were returned, filled with responses, and an overall response rate of 35% was established. Fourteen authors approved of their work as research, but only six requested prior IRB review. Most of the authors (15 out of 21) did not submit their protocols to the IRB. Only seven authors mentioned the innovative nature of the procedure in the informed consent form. Seven authors claimed to be familiar with Office for Human Research Protections research and human subject definitions. Two-thirds of those surveyed said that innovative surgery would not be appropriate for government regulations to protect human subjects. CONCLUSIONS: The current system of definitions, ethical theories, and voluntary professional guidelines may be insufficient to meet the challenge of surgical innovation. Further research is recommended to examine the adequacy of existing guidelines.

title: Ethical requirements that must be met before new procedures are implemented
abstract: New approaches, both diagnostic and therapeutic, must be continually developed so that the orthopedic care of patients continues to evolve. These innovations need to be subjected to rigorous scientific study to confirm that a new approach does indeed deliver improved results. However, since the results of clinical interventions can only be studied in human subjects, these studies must not only meet scientific criteria, but also strict ethical criteria. The Declaration of Helsinki, a document prepared by the World Medical Association and first written in 1964, largely revised in 1975, and last revised in 1996, provides guidelines for such work. In addition to meeting ethical requirements, clinical researchers also face a variety of complex issues that must be addressed during the conduct of clinical research studies. One of the most difficult issues is the conflict between a doctor's concern for the well-being of his patients and the need for protocol-based trials. However enthusiastic surgeons may be about a new therapeutic approach, they must recognize that they are responsible for scientifically validating their innovative approach with a well-controlled clinical trial using valid functional outcome measures.

title: Ethical review of health promotion program evaluation proposals
abstract: Some policies specify that program evaluation falls within the realm of administrative research that does not require review by an ethics review board. We recommend that some health promotion program evaluations include at least one research element and be distinguishable from quality assurance. While American and Canadian evaluation societies provide important guidelines and standards for evaluation practitioners, processes of accountability to the public are maintained by research ethics committees. The field of health promotion is inherently fraught with challenges to existing research ethics committees. Given the paucity of published literature on the ethics of health promotion assessment or practice, the field could benefit from open discussion that a review of proposals would encourage.

title: Ethics committees and good clinical practice success
abstract: Local ethics committees (institutional review boards or similar bodies) have in recent years served as review bodies of proposed research projects (protocols overarching clinical research protocols) in (bio)medical research institutions around the world, as well as good practice (clinical) during the conduct of Research projects. Ethical principles, including laboratory and scientific) requirements, are respected and fulfilled. The current pluralism of the philosophical background upon which contemporary bioethics theories have been developed has seriously questioned the ancient Hippocratic, non-utilitarian traditions of medical ethics, which sought to encourage more utilitarian and secular approaches. Individual physicians or researchers, as well as the ethics committee itself, often face complex ethical dilemmas that must be resolved in an atmosphere of significant social, university, economic and temporal pressures, and sometimes without the helpful guidance of appropriate experts. legislation. An interesting possibility for how some of the pitfalls of the ethics review process can be overcome is a shared ethical responsibility for the research project or research protocol that most (or all) of the interested parties (principal researcher, sponsor, ethics committee, patient, "society") It has proven helpful in developing concrete deliberations of ethics committees established in Slovakia since 1991, according to the requirements of national guidelines published by the Slovak Ministry of Health.

title: Ethics committees and pediatric research: a personal perspective
abstract: Surveillance of clinical trials involving child subjects or tissue from them continues to become more formal and complex. Many physicians and pediatricians can be expected to be offered the opportunity to serve on Pediatric Institutional Ethics Committees (IECs) at some stage in their professional lives. Fearless and independent Ethics Committees have significant influence on both the design and conduct of clinical trials and the permitted research topics in which infants and children will be involved. The composition of IECs is often designed to strike a balance between genders, professional backgrounds, and institutional and non-institutional affiliations. In addition to these now well-established composition guidelines, IECs deciding on pediatric research have a pragmatic need for three extra-specific roles: in loco parentis, in loco infanti, and the special role of nursing staff. These roles and their ethical bases are defined. Furthermore, the in loco parentis role is ethnically complex, and an IEC that takes this role into account should be clear about its implications. Pediatric research projects involve not only the specific risks specific to that project, but also the more general risks inherent in any clinical research intervention attempt itself. Pediatric IECs should act in an incentive mode rather than simply being 'physician observers' and insist ab initio on publication of results as a condition of permission to conduct the research in question. A particularly effective form of ethical review is the national and international peer review that follows such publications of pediatric research. This report discusses these particular themes in the evolving context of greater oversight of pediatric research.

title: Ethics committees in Italy: a survey on the example of an oncologist
abstract: OBJECTIVES AND BACKGROUND: Physicians' mission and the purpose of clinical research can lead to a conflict between medical ethics and human rights. All recommendations, directives, and laws regarding experimental interventions require a formal protocol, approval from an ethics committee (EC), and written informed consent from potential participants. In Italy, new guidelines on the handling of applications to the EC were published in 1998. A year later, there was a sense that the new rules (i.e. decentralization and emphasis on pharmacological aspects of studies) had immediate impact among people involved in EC activities. negative. A prospective study was initiated to evaluate oncologists' views on the functioning of the Italian AT. METHODS AND STUDY DESIGN: A questionnaire was administered twice to 110 oncologists who participated in two multicenter studies. Nine questions were included regarding the following aspects: hospital-level presence of an EC, personal experience with an EC, average time required to consider proposals submitted, and level of satisfaction with the key functions of the EC. RESULTS: Responses were obtained from 93 (first questionnaire) and 69 (second questionnaire) clinicians. In both surveys, clinicians reported that they were satisfied with the scientific and ethical aspects of EC operation, but were dissatisfied with the educational activities and training as well as bureaucratic and clerical requirements. In the second survey, the average time required for evaluation after submission of a study protocol was approximately 2.4 months, and the level of dissatisfaction with some critical aspects such as bureaucracy (44%) and training activities and training (64%) was still high. . Analysis of change over time documented minor differences (-8% to +7%) in all aspects evaluated. CONCLUSIONS: Despite the limitations of this study, such as the small sample size and inherent characteristics of the Italian setting, the findings add empirical evidence regarding the functioning of local EC and the views of clinical investigators. This experience confirms that empirical studies on medical ethics are feasible and can generate useful information to facilitate the practice of EC in medicine and the lay community.

title: Innovative surgical ethics: definitions, knowledge, and attitudes of US surgeons
abstract: BACKGROUND: Innovative surgery is not clearly defined and not formally regulated by governing bodies, as is the case with drug and medical device development. This uncertain situation, and the subsequent questionable applicability of current federal guidelines for human subject research, raises ethical concern. To clarify his position, we asked US surgeons' definitions of, views, and attitudes towards innovative surgery. Surgeons were also invited to self-report information on current federal regulations guiding human subject research and guidelines for informed consent and IRB review for clinical trials. STUDY DESIGN: A group of US surgeons received a 46-item questionnaire that addressed the definition of innovative surgery versus research and practice-oriented, regulations for human subject research, the need for specific informed consent, and IRB review of surgical innovations. RESULTS: A total of 665 responses were used in the content analysis. Participants took a rather cautious stance when considering hypothetical innovative scenarios. The distinguishing features of experimentation and clinical research as modes of innovation were more clearly defined for the surgical situation. CONCLUSIONS: There are descriptive criteria that allow for previous review of surgical innovations and further investigation. Some forms of innovation clearly fall within the scope of existing regulations for human subject research";" others may not quite meet the definition but still require some additional oversight.

title: The ethics of randomized clinical trials and the 'ALARA' approach
abstract: A balanced discussion of the ethics of randomized clinical trials should not be based on a single ethical dimension, such as respect for patient autonomy. Instead, the analysis should consider four ethical principles—respect for autonomy, non-harming, beneficence, and justice—applicable to all human groups concerned. We present the ethical benefits and costs of current practice of randomized clinical trials for four groups: patients participating in clinical trials, patients not participating in trials, physicians participating, and the public. The ALARA (As Low as Reasonably Achievable) approach is then introduced and practical measures are proposed to strike a positive balance between the ethical benefits and the costs of randomized trials.

title: Research ethics regarding human subjects/patients
Research ethics with psychiatric patients: principles, issues and primary responsibilities of researchers
abstract: In this paper, some of the general issues surrounding recently published guidelines for the practice of research ethics committees are outlined, with a particular focus on the challenges that arise in research with psychiatric patients. Research departs from ordinary clinical practice with the intent to advance knowledge. Defined as such, research with psychiatric patients should be governed by the same four principles as research with other groups: knowledge, necessity, benefit, and consent. However, many acute difficulties arise by psychiatric patients in the application of these principles, particularly the principle of consent. A number of recommendations are discussed to address these challenges. Despite the value of published guidelines and the assistance available from research ethics committees, it is suggested that the primary responsibility for ensuring high standards of practice in research rests with research workers themselves.

title: EUROASPIRE III: A study on lifestyle, risk factors and use of cardioprotective drug therapies in coronary patients from 22 European countries.
abstract: OBJECTIVE: The aim of the European Action on Secondary and Primary Prevention by Intervention to Reduce Events III (EUROASPIRE III) was to define lifestyle and to determine if the Partner European Societies' guidelines on cardiovascular prevention were followed in daily clinical practice. Risk factor and therapeutic management in patients with coronary heart disease (CHD) in Europe. METHODS: The EUROASPIRE III study was conducted in 76 centers from selected geographical regions in 22 countries in Europe between 2006-2007. Consecutive patients with a clinical diagnosis of CHD were identified retrospectively, and then followed, interviewed, and examined at least 6 months after their coronary events. RESULTS: Thirteen thousand nine hundred and thirty-five medical records (27% women) were reviewed and 8966 patients were interviewed. At the interview, 17% of patients were smokers, 35% were obese and 53% were centrally obese, 56% had blood pressure >or=140/90 mmHg (>or=130/80 in diabetics), 51% had . diabetes with serum total cholesterol > or=4.5 mmol/l and 25%, fasting plasma glucose of 10% less than 6.1 mmol/l, and 35% of glycated hemoglobin A1c less than 6.5% reported the story. Cardioprotective drug use was: antiplatelets 91%"; beta blockers 80%; angiotensin converting enzyme inhibitors/angiotensin-receptor blockers 71%;" calcium channel blockers 25% and statins 78%. CONCLUSION: The EUROASPIRE III study shows that a large proportion of coronary patients do not meet lifestyle, risk factor and therapeutic goals for the prevention of cardiovascular diseases. There are wide variations in risk factor prevalences and use of cardioprotective drug therapies between countries. There is still significant potential across Europe to raise the standards of preventive care to reduce the risk of recurrent disease and death in patients with CHD.

title: EUROASPIRE IV: A European Society of Cardiology study on lifestyle, risk factor and therapeutic management of coronary patients from 24 European countries
abstract: OBJECTIVES: To determine whether the Common European Communities guidelines on cardiovascular prevention are followed in daily secondary prevention clinical practice and to describe the lifestyle, risk factors and therapeutic management of coronary patients across Europe. METHODS AND RESULTS: EUROASPIRE IV is a cross-sectional study conducted at 78 centers from 24 European countries. Patients /= 6 months later. A total of 16,426 medical records were reviewed and 7998 patients (24.4% women) were interviewed. At the time of the interview, 16.0% of the patients were smokers and 48.6% of the smokers at the time of the event were permanent smokers. 59.9% reported little physical activity"; 37.6% were obese (BMI >/= 30 kg/m(2)) and 58.2% were centrally obese (waist circumference >/= 102 cm in men or >/= 88 cm) women); 42.7% had blood pressure >/= 140/90 mmHg (>/=140/80 in people with diabetes); 80.5% had low-density lipoprotein cholesterol >/= 1.8 mmol/l and 26.8% had diabetes The cardioprotective drug was: anti-platelet 93.8%; beta blockers 82.6%; angiotensin converting enzyme inhibitors/angiotensin receptor blockers 75.1%;" and statins 85.7%. It was recommended that 50.7% of the patients participate in a cardiac rehabilitation program, and 81.3% of those recommended attended at least half of the sessions. CONCLUSION: The vast majority of coronary patients do not reach the guideline standards for secondary prevention with a high prevalence of persistent smoking, unhealthy diet, physical inactivity, and as a result, most patients are overweight or obese with a high prevalence of diabetes. Despite the reported high drug use, risk factor control is poor and there is wide variation in secondary prevention practices between centers. Less than half of coronary patients have access to cardiac prevention and rehabilitation programs. All coronary and vascular patients need a modern preventive cardiology program, appropriately adapted to the medical and cultural settings in each country, to lead healthier lifestyles, better risk factor control and compliance with cardioprotective drugs.

title: Evaluation of an educational intervention to improve asthma management in four European countries. Pharmaceutical Education Project Group
abstract: In the International Pharmaceutical Education Project, a new training program for peer doctor groups was developed and tested to improve the management of asthma patients in the Netherlands, Norway, Sweden and Slovakia. Individualized feedback on prescribing and underlying decision strategy was presented and discussed within the physicians group regarding current guidelines. The effect on efficacy and actual prescribing was tested in a parallel, randomized controlled design. The results were related to national guidelines. Overall, the program improved physicians' attitudes as well as some of their prescribing behaviors. The proportion of patients treated with inhaled corticosteroids improved significantly in the Netherlands (effect size 1.27) and the proportion of oral corticosteroid use for exacerbation treatment increased in both the Netherlands and Norway (effect sizes 1.99 and 0.87), respectively. Overall attitudes of Dutch and Norwegian physicians were also significantly improved in Slovakia, as were both knowledge (effect size 1.06) and attitudes (effect size 1.49) regarding exacerbation treatment (effect size 1.06 and 0.87, respectively). No significant improvement could be measured in Sweden. In conclusion, improvements in asthma treatment are possible with a self-learning education program in small peer groups, but effects in one healthcare setting may not occur in another healthcare setting. Possible explanatory factors may be differences in opportunities for change, including differing attitudes and experiences with guidelines, as well as continuing medical education programs and prevailing trends in prescribing behavior.

title: Evaluating informatics practices – some alternative approaches: theory, social interactionism and call for methodological pluralism
abstract: review of the evaluation literature on CDSSs shows that randomized controlled clinical trials (RCTs) are the 'gold standard' for evaluation. While this approach is excellent for examining systems or clinical performance, it is not well suited for answering questions about whether or how systems should be used. As the non-use of CDSS has been a matter of concern for several years, further assessment research designs are needed to address these issues. This article critiques RCT and experimental evaluation approaches and presents alternative evaluation approaches that address questions outside the scope of usual RCT and experimental designs. A wide variety of literature has been summarized to demonstrate the value of assessments that consider social, organizational, professional, and other contextual considerations. Many of these studies go beyond the usual measures of system performance or physicians' behavior, focusing on the 'fit' of the system with other aspects of professional and corporate life. Since there are few clear theories that inform most assessments, the article then reviews the CDSS assessments informed by social science theories. Finally, it proposes a theoretical social science basis of social interactionism. An example of such an approach is given. It includes a CDSS in psychiatry and is based on Kaplan's 4Cs that focus on communication, control, care and context. While an exemplary CDSS, the assessment approach is also useful for clinical guide application and other medical informatics applications. Similarly, while the debate is about social interactionism, the more important point is the need to broaden assessment through a variety of methods and approaches that explore social, cultural, organizational, cognitive, and other contextual concerns. Methodological pluralism and diverse research questions can increase understanding of the many implications associated with the development and dissemination of informatics applications.

title: Evaluation of the efficacy of a clinical practice change intervention in increasing the delivery of clinician preventive care in a community-based mental health care network: a study protocol of a nonrandomized, multiple baseline trial.
abstract: BACKGROUND: People with mental illness experience significant inequalities in health, including increased morbidity and mortality rates caused by potentially preventable chronic diseases. A contributing factor to this disparity is the higher prevalence of modifiable health risk behaviors such as smoking, inadequate fruit and vegetable intake, harmful alcohol consumption, and insufficient physical activity. Evidence supports the effectiveness of preventive care in reducing such risks, and guidelines recommend incorporating preventive care for such risks into routine clinical care. Although community-based mental health services represent an important potential setting for enabling people with mental illness to receive this type of care, research currently suggests that delivery is sub-optimal. A study will be conducted to evaluate the effectiveness of a clinical practice change intervention in providing routine preventive care by clinicians in community mental health settings. METHODS/DESIGN: A two-group multi-baseline design will be used to evaluate the effectiveness of a multi-strategic intervention over 12 months in increasing clinician provision of preventive care. The intervention will be administered alternately between the two groups of community mental health services to provide client assessment, brief advice, and referral to the four health risk behaviors (smoking, inadequate fruit and vegetable consumption, harmful alcohol consumption, and insufficient physical activity). . Outcomes of interest will be collected through repeated cross-sectional computer-assisted telephone interviews conducted weekly for 36 months with community mental health patients. DISCUSSION: This is the first study to evaluate the effectiveness of a very strategic clinical practice change intervention in increasing routine clinician preventive care provision for chronic disease behavioral risk factors within a community mental health services network. The results will inform future policy and practice regarding the ability of clinicians in mental health settings to improve preventive care delivery as a result of such interventions. TRIAL REGISTRATION: Australian and New Zealand Clinical Trials Registry (ANZCTR) ACTRN12613000693729.

title: Evaluating the effectiveness of educational interventions to prevent delirium
abstract: The aim of this study is to combine knowledge of how clinicians learn to prevent delirium in hospitalized patients with a review of educational interventions. The primary aim was to evaluate the effectiveness of approaches to delirium education. A detailed search was carried out in educational and medical databases. The type of intervention used was classified according to Green et al's PRECEED model using factors related to behavior change in health promotion. The effectiveness of the intervention was determined by evaluating changes in staff performance and patient outcomes. Nineteen studies of variable design and quality were identified. Studies that used a combination of preparatory, enabler, and reinforcement strategies were more often effective in producing changes in staff behavior and patient outcomes. Training and instructions used together or in combination have little effect. Results are more positive for patients when strategies are used in conjunction with training sessions to enable and reinforce changes in clinical practice.

title: Evaluation of the stage of change pattern to a cervical cancer screening intervention among Ohio Appalachian women
abstract: Cervical cancer incidence and death rates are disproportionately high among women living in Appalachia Ohio. This study used the Transtheoretical Model to examine barriers to screening before and after a lay health counselor (LHA) intervention (2005-2009) to increase cervical cancer screening rates. Ohio Appalachian women (n = 90) requiring Pap testing based on risk-appropriate guidelines were randomized to a 10-month LHA intervention and received two face-to-face visits, two phone calls, and four targeted postcards. to the participant's change phase. Findings revealed that 63% had advanced-stage movement 10 months after intervention. The most frequently reported screening barriers are time constraints, forgetting to make an appointment, and cost. Women who reported the following barriers—the doctor does not recommend testing; cannot afford testing; and fear of being embarrassed, nervous, or having a Pap test—were less likely to be in the action phase. Understanding the stages of change associated with Pap testing and the reported barriers among this underserved population encourages researchers and clinicians to can help inform this population's readiness for change and how to set realistic response goals.

title: Evaluation of the impact and impact of the computerized decision support system NHGDoc on the quality of primary care: protocol for a large-scale cluster randomized controlled trial.
abstract: BACKGROUND: Computerized decision support systems (CDSSs) are increasingly used to improve the quality of care. There is evidence of moderate to large effects from randomized controlled trials (RCTs), but no evidence of their effectiveness when implemented at the national level. In the Netherlands, the Dutch College of General Practitioners (NHG) launched its successful guide programs 30 years ago. NHGDoc, a multi-disease CDSS for general practice based on these NHG guidelines, was developed in 2006 to improve the quality of primary care. This manuscript presents a protocol for evaluating the uptake and effects of NHGDoc. METHODS: A cluster RCT will be conducted among 120 general practices in the Netherlands. Suitable generic applications will be randomly selected to receive either the regular NHGDoc decision support modules (control arm) or the regular modules, as well as an additional module on heart failure (intervention arm). The heart failure module consists of patient-specific alerts regarding the treatment of patients with heart failure. Impact assessment will focus on patient outcomes (eg hospital admissions) as well as performance indicators (eg, prescription behavior) related to the heart failure domain. In addition, a process assessment will be conducted to gain insight into barriers and facilitators affecting the uptake and impact of NHGDoc. DISCUSSION: The results of this study will provide insight into the uptake and impact of a multi-site CDSS for primary care implemented by a national guideline organization to improve the quality of primary care. While the trial focused on a specific area of care-heart failure, the results of this study will shed light on the functioning of CDSSs covering multiple disease domains for primary care, particularly as this study also investigated factors contributing to the uptake and efficacy of the system. TRIAL REGISTRATION: Clinical trials NCT01773057.

title: Evaluation of training methods to move emergency management to therapists
abstract: The effects of three increasingly intense training methods on therapist use, knowledge, and adherence to the application of emergency management (CM) with substance-addicted adolescents were evaluated. Ten public sector substance abuse or mental health provider organizations were randomized to one of three training conditions: workshop and resources (WS+), WS+ and computer-assisted education (WS+/CAT), or WS+/CAT and audit support (WS+/CAT/ SS). . Among the conditions, 161 therapists participated in the training experiences and measurements were taken at baseline and at 2-month intervals for 12 months following workshop participation. Across the training conditions, therapists reported increased CM use, knowledge, and adherence to practice over the 12-month follow-up. The findings suggest that community-based practitioners are open to adopting evidence-based treatments when access to helpful resources is provided. In addition, high-quality workshops with access to resources can increase knowledge about evidence-based treatment and increase young people's commitment to intervention at the level needed to improve outcomes.

title: Evaluation of a complex intervention to change professional behavior: Evidence-Based Access (EBOR) Trial.
abstract: OBJECTIVES: To determine the impact of a complex intervention (pharmacists' educational access visits) designed to change general practitioners' prescribing at each step of a hypothetical change pathway that leads to the final primary trial outcome of the change in prescribing. METHOD: The study was conducted at six health authorities in the north of England and six in London. We identified three steps that led to this outcome: 'general practices' who agreed to participate; GPs at each practice participating in the outreach visit by pharmacists; and how GPs' prescribing practices were affected by these visits. The results of each step were evaluated using a combination of quantitative and qualitative methods. RESULTS: Out of 102 randomly selected practices, 75 (73.5%) agreed to participate.Proportion of all physicians attending outreach meeting in small practice (ie 1-2 partners) was 6.7 (95% CI) compared with other practices (ie > 3 partners) : 4.4-23.5).Although pharmacists reported a good relationship in 100 (72%) of the initial visits and accepting management plans in 110 (79%) of these visits, they were confident that they would change the prescription in only 41% of implementation.
