Pharmacists and general practitioners' satisfaction with social assistance visits from these visits did not lead to drastic changes, and GPs' knowledge of pharmacist-promoted guidelines did not necessarily translate into changes in clinical practice. The main barriers to the implementation of the guidelines set by pharmacists at follow-up visits were organizational difficulties, GPs' skepticism about the evidence available to them, and doctors' disinterest in changing their prescribing behavior. CONCLUSIONS: While our study was limited to an afterthought rather than an advance design, it provides a pragmatic approach to understanding factors influencing the pathway for change in prescribing behavior in response to academic access visits.

title: Evaluation of a decision support system for pressure ulcer prevention and management: preliminary findings
abstract: decision support system for the prevention and management of pressure ulcers has been developed based on AHCPR guidelines and other resources. The system was applied for 21 weeks in a 20-bed clinical care unit. Fifteen nurses in this unit volunteered as intervention subjects to see if using the system would have a positive impact on their knowledge of pressure ulcers and their decision-making skills. A similar maintenance unit was used as a control. In addition, the system was evaluated by experts for its educational adequacy and by end users for their satisfaction with the system. Preliminary results show no effect on knowledge about pressure ulcers and no effect on clinical decision-making skills. The system was rated positively for teaching proficiency and positively for user satisfaction. User interviews about satisfaction supported the quantitative findings. There is a discussion of the issues of conducting experiments like this in today's clinical setting.

title: Evaluation of a dental health public health program for old age pensioners in Denmark
abstract: High priority is given to improving the oral health of the elderly in Scandinavia. In 1987 a Danish municipality established a dental health public health program for old age pensioners. All citizens aged 67 were provided with school-based preventive and curative care using guidelines and principles established for children by the Danish Municipal Dental Service. Maintenance was provided free of charge. Citizens who do not wish to receive care through the public system can do so from private dentists. Reimbursement of care received from the private system was provided by the National Health Insurance and the municipality. The purpose of this study was to evaluate the outcome of the program after three years of operation. A follow-up design was used and data were collected through interviews and clinical records. At baseline and at follow-up, 216 (71%) and 235 (77%) retirees were interviewed about their self-evaluation of dental health, dental knowledge, attitudes and behaviors, respectively. Clinical data were collected only for the elderly participating in the public program, and included 194 subjects at baseline and 187 at follow-up. These data included information about tooth loss, dental caries, periodontal health, and the presence and function of removable dentures. At follow-up, 86 percent of all participants made at least one regular visit to the dentist per year, compared to 46 percent at baseline"; 75 percent participated in the public program and 11 percent received care from private practitioners. At the end of the intervention period, fewer seniors reported signs of poor oral health or impaired prosthetic function.

title: Evaluation of the primary care diabetes treatment program under the guidance of a diabetes specialist
abstract: OBJECTIVE: An initial pilot program showed promising results in improvements in glycosylated hemoglobin (HbA(1c)), low-density lipoprotein cholesterol (LDL-C), and systolic blood pressure (SBP), prompting us to test these findings in a controlled trial. . The purpose of the Diabetes-Focused, Algorithm-Oriented Care, Intermediate Practitioner-Administered, Electronically-Managed, Treatment (DAMET-2) program clinical trial was to explore the benefits of a new program to disseminate guidance in diabetes care from a centralized center. from specialist clinics to primary care centers with access to intermediate provider services. DATA SOURCES: DAMET-2 included standard treatment algorithms and training disseminated by computer-assisted and traditional methods associated with remote medicine. Two primary care settings were selected and subjects with a diagnosis of type 2 diabetes > or =6 months, > or =18 years of age with one or more cardiovascular risk factors (defined by table review) were eligible for inclusion. For subjects in the experimental group, intermediate practitioners (N = 34) received training in American Diabetes Association treatment algorithms, made phone calls and bimonthly visits with diabetes specialists at 2- to 4-week intervals, and received treatment guidance from remote diabetes within 24 hours. experts. Weekly diabetes clinics were opened to the subjects in the experimental group. After 12 months, the last available subject data were extracted from the subjects' charts and compared with 12-month chart data from a control group (N = 101) who did not receive additional study services. RESULTS: Mean HbA(1c) values decreased by 0.46% from baseline in the active treatment group and by 0.06% in the control group"; however, the reductions in HbA(1c) did not reach statistical significance potentially due to the small sample size of the patients. . experimental group. Mean SBP values were significantly reduced in both groups; however, LDL-C was only significantly reduced in the control group, where more aggressive use of statins could be effective. APPLICATIONS FOR IMPLEMENTATION: Despite inconsistencies in risk factor reduction from the pilot program, the DAMET-2 program provided information on the importance of electronic records and provider notifications, patient compliance, prioritization of provider resources among patients by risk factor level, and access. self-management training.

title: Evaluation of a knowledge transfer plan to improve policy-making and practice in the health promotion and disease prevention environment in the French regions: a realistic study protocol
abstract: Background Evidence-based decision-making and practice is crucial in public health. However, barriers remain and they relate to evidence features, organizations and contexts. To address these major knowledge transfer (KT) issues, we need to rethink how knowledge is produced and used, improve our understanding of decision-making processes, their rationale and mechanisms, and examine the ability of public health services to integrate research findings into their own research findings. decisions and transactions. This article presents a realistic evaluation protocol for evaluating a PI scheme in prevention policy and practice at the local level in France. Methods/design This study is a comparative multiple case study using a realistic approach to evaluate a KT plan in regional health institutions (ARS) and regional non-profit organizations for health education and promotion (IREPS). mechanisms/results. The assessed KT scheme was designed for the use of six reviews of systematic reviews on the following themes: nutrition, alcohol, tobacco use, physical activity, emotional and sex life, and psychosocial skills. It combines the following activities: promoting access to and adapting scientific and usable evidence; strengthen the ability of professionals to analyze, adopt and use evidence in their practice and decision-making; facilitating the use of evidence in organizations and processes. RAMESE II reporting standards were used for realistic evaluations. Discussion The objectives of this study were to try and characterize factors related to the plan's ability to enable public health stakeholders to address the challenges of KT and integrate scientific knowledge into policy and practice. We will use the realistic approach to document the parameters of successful KT strategies in specific contexts of preventive health care in France and try to determine the transferability of such strategies.

title: Evaluation of a new individualized communication skills training intervention to improve physicians' confidence and skills in end-of-life communication
abstract: BACKGROUND: We have developed a unique personalized training program on end-of-life communication designed to be time efficient for busy young doctors working in hospital settings. OBJECTIVE: We aimed to test this short, individualized training program with subordinates to explore its acceptability, feasibility, and impact on physicians' trust, communication skills, attitudes towards psychosocial care, and burnout. DESIGN: The content of the educational intervention was informed by a systematic literature review on end-of-life communication and evidence-based clinical practice guidelines. The intervention was based on sound educational principles and included three one-hour teaching sessions over a three-week period, including two individual sessions with an expert facilitator and simulated patient/caregiver. In addition, participants were given written and audio-visual take-home learning materials. PARTICIPANTS were video-recorded with a simulated patient/caregiver with pre/post training counseling to evaluate the impact of the course on their communication behaviors. PARTICIPANTS completed pre/post-education unidentified questionnaires, including self-assessed confidence, attitudes towards psychosocial care, and the Maslach Burnout inventory. PARTICIPANTS: PARTICIPANTS consisted of 22 young doctors from a large teaching hospital in Sydney, Australia. RESULTS: All participants reported that the training was beneficial, beneficial in their communication with the patients, and that they would recommend the training to others. Participants' communication skills (in seven of the 21 specific and global communication behaviors evaluated, P=0.02 to <0.001), their confidence in communicating about relevant issues (P<0.001), their attitudes towards psychosocial care (P=0.03), and their sense of personal accomplishment (P=0.03). P=0.043). There was no overall difference in the participants' burnout levels. CONCLUSION: This intervention is promising and warrants further formal evaluation.

title: Evaluation of a physician-focused educational intervention for children receiving medical care with asthma.
abstract: BACKGROUND: The Omnibus Budget Reconciliation Act of 1990 mandated a review of drug use in response to inappropriate drug use. In the Pennsylvania Medicaid program, pediatric asthma is associated with higher healthcare utilization and cost. OBJECTIVE: To determine the effects of a physician-focused education intervention on asthma medication use and healthcare use. METHODS: The pre-intervention and post-intervention comparison design was used in children aged 5-18 years enrolled in the Pennsylvania Medicaid service fee program from July 1, 1998 to March 31, 1999 (pre-intervention) and July 1. From 1999 to 31 March 2000 (post-intervention). The intervention package included patients' medication profiles, medical history, monograph with national asthma management guidelines, and patient education materials provided to physicians. The main outcome measures are changes in asthma medication use among high users of short-acting beta(2)-agonists (SAB). RESULTS: The intervention focused on 2 asthma medication use criteria: (1) high use of responsive medications and (2) use of salmeterol without a curative medication. The intervention reduced the use of rapid-relief drugs by 26% in patients with higher use, without significant changes in long-term control drugs. Additionally, 82% of evaluated recipients showed a positive change in their use of salmeterol due to the addition of a SAB inhaler after the intervention or the discontinuation of salmeterol after the intervention. There were no significant changes in asthma-related emergency room visits or hospitalizations. CONCLUSIONS: While responding physicians agreed on the usefulness of the educational materials, the results indicate that the intervention had limited success in improving pharmacological management and had no impact on health outcomes. We believe that educational materials mailed to physicians can be effective in changing prescribing behavior";" however, a more versatile intervention may be necessary to improve health outcomes.

title: Evaluation of a specific intervention to improve overweight and obesity management in primary care: study protocol of a cluster randomized controlled trial.
abstract: BACKGROUND: In the UK around 22% of men and 24% of women are obese, with varying but alarming levels in other European countries. Obesity is a chronic condition that carries a significant health risk. National guidelines for use in the UK on the management of overweight or obese persons have been published by the National Institute for Health and Clinical Excellence (NICE, 2006). NICE recommendations for primary care teams include: "determining the extent of overweight and obesity; assessing lifestyle, comorbidities, and willingness to change; offering multi-component management of overweight and obesity; referral to external services where appropriate. implementation of these recommendations by primary care teams." METHODS/DESIGN: Study is a cluster randomized controlled trial Primary care teams will be recruited from the East Midlands of England and randomized into two study arms: 1) a set of workgroups to assist primary care teams in implementing the NICE guidelines for overweight and obesity special intervention is offered; or 2) control group in which primary care teams continue to administer usual care Primary outcome is proportion of overweight or obese patients whose primary care team complies with NICE guidelines Secondary outcomes are patients with lifestyle assessment enrollment rate, referral to external weight loss services, proportion of obese patients who lost weight during the intervention period, and mean weight change over the same period. DISCUSSION: Although often recommended, methods for tailoring implementation interventions to take into account the determinants of implementation are not well developed. This work is part of a research program aimed at developing adapted practice methods. TRIAL REGISTRATION: Current Controlled Trials ISRCTN07457585. 09/08/2013 registered. Randomization started on 30/08/2013.

title: Evaluation of a toolkit to improve cardiovascular disease screening and treatment for people with type 2 diabetes: protocol for a cluster-random pragmatic trial.
abstract: BACKGROUND: The difference between the level of care recommended by evidence-based clinical practice guidelines and the actual care given to patients in practice is well established. The Canadian Diabetes Association (CDA) established an implementation strategy to improve the implementation of the 2008 guidelines. This study will evaluate the impact of a strategy to improve cardiovascular disease (CVD) screening, prevention and treatment in people with diabetes. DESIGN: A pragmatic cluster randomization trial will be conducted to evaluate the CDA's CVD Toolkit. All family physicians in Ontario, Canada were randomly assigned to receive the Toolkit, which includes a variety of printed educational materials targeting CVD screening, prevention and treatment in spring 2009 (intervention arm) or spring 2010 (control arm). Randomization took place at the application level. Forty family physicians from each branch will be assigned to participate and the medical records of 20 diabetes patients at high risk for CVD will be retrospectively reviewed. Outcomes will be evaluated for each patient between July 2009 and March 2010. The primary outcome would be for the patient to take a statin. Secondary outcomes will include: 1) taking an angiotensin converting enzyme inhibitor or angiotensin receptor blocker, 2) various interim measurements (A1c, blood pressure, LDL-cholesterol, total-/HDL-cholesterol ratio, body mass index, and waist circumference), and 3) clinical inertia (inability to change therapy in response to an abnormal A1c, blood pressure, or cholesterol reading). The analysis will be performed using multi-level hierarchical logistic regression models to account for the clustered nature of the data. The group assignment will be a doctor-level variable. In addition, a process evaluation study with six focus groups of family physicians will assess the acceptability of the CDA Toolkit and explore the factors that contributed to any change or absence in behavior from the family physicians' perspectives. DISCUSSION: Printed educational materials for physicians have been shown to make small-to-moderate changes in patient care. The CDA's CVD Toolkit is an example of a practice guideline implementation strategy that can be distributed relatively inexpensively to a wide audience, so demonstrating its effectiveness in improving diabetes care could have important implications for guideline developers, policymakers, and clinicians.

title: Evaluation of Abnormal Mammography Results and Palpable Breast Abnormalities
abstract: Background: Since approximately 1 in 10 women with a breast mass or an abnormal mammogram result will have breast cancer, a series of decisions must be made by the primary care practitioner to diagnose or exclude breast cancer among these women. The most accurate and least invasive way to evaluate an abnormal mammogram result and a palpable breast abnormality. Data Source: MEDLINE study (January 1966 - March 2003), articles describing the accuracy of clinical examination, biopsy procedures, and radiographic examination for patients with abnormal mammography results or palpable breast abnormalities for reviews. Study Selection: Authors reviewed abstracts and selected articles that provided relevant primary data. 1) if mammography, fine-needle aspiration biopsy, or core needle biopsy was performed before definitive diagnosis; 2) if the study sample included 100 or more women; and 3) breast cancer status was determined from histopathological examination of excisional biopsy specimens, from a state cancer registry or affiliation with the Surveillance, Epidemiology and Final Results program, or from clinical follow-up of 95% or more of the study sample. Data Extraction: One researcher summarized the results. Methods were evaluated for major potential biases, but methodological scoring was not done. Data Synthesis: Odds ratios for initial screening mammography, Breast Imaging Reporting and Data System (BI-RADS) evaluation category were 0.1 for negative or benign finding and 1.2 for possibly benign finding. findings, 7 need for additional imaging evaluation, 125 suspected abnormalities and 2200 highly suggestive of malignancy. For fine-needle aspiration biopsy of an obvious lump performed by formally trained physicians, the odds ratio was infinite for malignant, 2.6 for atypical/suspect, and 0.02 for benign. When diagnostic mammography was used to evaluate a palpable lump or nonpalpable breast abnormality, the positive odds ratios were 5.6 and 9.4, and the negative odds ratios were 0.15 and 0.19, respectively. Results: Women whose screening mammography results were interpreted with suspicious abnormality or a high risk of breast cancer suggestive of malignancy high and surgical biopsy and core needle biopsy or needle localization should be performed. Women whose screening mammography results are interpreted as needing additional imaging evaluation have a moderate risk for breast cancer and should undergo diagnostic mammography or ultrasonography to decide whether to biopsy a non-palpable breast lesion. Women whose screening mammography results are interpreted as possibly benign are at low risk of breast cancer and may have a mammogram 6 months later. Fine-needle aspiration biopsy or ultrasonography is recommended as the initial diagnostic test of palpable breast abnormality to distinguish simple cysts from solid masses. Fine-needle aspiration biopsy also allows for the characterization of a solid mass. Diagnostic mammography does not help determine whether a palpable breast mass should be biopsied and should not affect the decision to perform a biopsy.

title: Evaluation of an informative brochure on AIDS/HIV infection for primary care workers in Catalonia
abstract: OBJECTIVE: To evaluate primary health care workers' understanding and acceptance of the HIV/AIDS periodic information booklet. DESIGN: Cross. SETTING: Primary care teams from the Institut Catala de la Salut. PARTICIPANTS: A random sample of 300 doctors, qualified nurses and social workers. INTERVENTION: A self-administered, anonymous survey sent by regular mail. MEASUREMENTS AND MAIN RESULTS: The questions covered the thematic areas: clinical care of people infected with HIV/AIDS and requests for diagnostic testing for infection, perception of patients' ability to promote changes in sexual behavior and drug use, provision of psychological support, and guidelines and social resources for the integration of HIV+ children in schools information about. 60% knew the broadcast. The thematic areas of greatest interest were: psychological support to affected people, HIV infection prevention in the healthcare setting, clinical advice and diagnosis. 77% received requests for diagnostic tests and 88% joined the infected. CONCLUSIONS: Despite the low response rate (50%) and relative variability between professionals and their health regions, this initial assessment allowed us to identify specific educational needs in the care and prevention of HIV/AIDS infection in primary education. improving the maintenance framework and also the delivery methods we use.

title: Evaluation of an Internet-based decision support system for the implementation of ATS/CDC guidelines for tuberculosis preventive therapy.
abstract: Preventive treatment for tuberculosis (TB) infected patients remains an important component of TB control. The American Thoracic Society and Centers for Disease Control (ATS/CDC) have developed guidelines based on PPD reactivity and pretest infection probability to guide physicians in implementing preventative therapy. Guidelines have become complex and many clinicians have difficulty applying them. The authors developed a computerized decision support system to assist clinicians in applying the ATS/CDC guidelines. Published on the World Wide Web using hypertext markup language, this tool provides patient-specific recommendations based on patient-specific information communicated by the physician. Four local TB specialists derived eight TB infection scenarios and validated the web-based tool, whose effectiveness was tested using general internal medicine assistants, by randomly dividing them into two groups. Group A (n = 12) used the web-based tool and Group B (n = 17) used pre-existing understanding of guidelines and/or written sources to identify the need for preventive treatment in case scenarios. Group A used therapy correctly in 92/96 probable cases (95.8%), Group B only used 77/136 (56.6%) cases (p < 0.001). Group A required an average of three mouse clicks and 1.5 minutes per scenario to reach their selection, and they rated the web-based tool as both intuitive and effective. These data demonstrate that a computer-based decision support system for the implementation of TB treatment guidelines can be delivered over the Internet and provide an efficient and effective resource for clinicians.

title: Computer-based clinical decision support system and evaluation of risk picture for hypertension management in primary care: randomized controlled trial.
abstract: Objectives: To investigate the impact of a computer-based clinical decision support system and a risk chart on absolute cardiovascular risk, blood pressure, and cardiovascular drug prescribing in hypertensive patients. Design: Cluster randomized controlled trial. Medium: 27 common apps on Avon. Participants: 614 patients aged 60-79 years with high blood pressure. Interventions: Patients were randomized to a computer-based clinical decision support system plus cardiovascular risk table"; cardiovascular risk table only;" or normal maintenance. Main outcome measures: Percentage of patients with five-year cardiovascular risk in each group = 10%, systolic blood pressure, diastolic blood pressure, cardiovascular drug prescription. Conclusions: Patients in the computer-based clinical decision support system and chart-only groups were no more likely to have a cardiovascular risk reduction below 10% than patients who received normal care. Patients in the computer-based clinical decision support group were 10% more likely to have cardiovascular risk than patients in the chart alone, with an odds ratio of 2.3 (95% confidence interval 1.1 to 4.8). The chart-only group had significantly lower systolic blood pressure compared to the usual care group (mean difference -4.6 mm Hg (95% confidence interval -8.4 to -0.8). Diastolic blood pressure reduction did not differ between the three groups. Two times more likely to be prescribed two classes of cardiovascular drugs and three times more likely to be prescribed three or more classes of drugs compared to results: Computer-based clinical decision support system did not provide any benefit in absolute risk reduction or blood pressure control and before use in clinical care The use of table guidelines is associated with a potentially significant reduction in systolic blood pressure.

title: Evaluation of internet-based clinical decision support systems.
abstract: Background: Science-based clinical guidelines are increasingly being used to educate physicians and improve quality of care. While individual guidelines are potentially helpful, repeated studies have shown that guidelines are ineffective in changing physician behavior. The Internet has evolved as a potentially useful tool for guideline education, dissemination and implementation because of its open standards and ability to provide concise, relevant clinical information where and when needed. Purpose: Our aim was to develop and test decision support systems (DSS) based on clinical guidelines available online for two disease models: asthma and tuberculosis (TB) preventive treatment. Methods: Using open HTML and CGI standards, we developed an acute asthma severity assessment DSS and a preventive tuberculosis treatment DSS based on the content of national guidelines accepted as standards of care. Both KDSs are posted on the Internet and work through a decision algorithm developed from parental guidelines with user-provided clinical information at the clinical point of care. We tested the effectiveness of each DSS in influencing physician decisions using clinical scenario tests. Results: We first validated the asthma algorithm by comparing asthma specialists' decisions with non-pulmonary nurses' decisions using computerized DDS. Nurses using the DSS scored the same as the specialists (88% vs 89%"; p = NS). Next, using the same scenario testing tool, we compared internists using the DSS with residents using a printed version of the National Asthma. Curriculum-2 guidelines Residents using computerized DSS scored significantly better than residents using paper-based guides (84% vs. 92%; p <0.002) Similarly, we compared residents using computerized TB DSS with residents using a printed reference Residents using computerized DSS scored significantly better (95.8% vs. 56.6% correct; "p<0.001). Conclusions: Previous work has shown that guidelines disseminated through traditional educational interventions have minimal impact on physician behavior. Although computerized DDS is effective in changing physician behavior, most of these systems are not widely available. We developed two clinical DSS based on national guidelines and published them online. Both systems improved physician compliance with national guidelines when tested in clinical scenarios. By providing information linked to the relevant activity, we expect these widely available DSSs to serve as effective educational tools to positively influence physician behavior.

title: Evaluation of studies investigating the effectiveness of pharmacists' clinical services
abstract: quantitative evaluation of randomized trials of counseling, education, and other clinical services provided by pharmacists was performed. Data sources are MEDLINE and bibliographies of published articles. Pharmacy services are categorized as patient counseling, physician counseling, both patient and physician counseling, and patient care. The conclusions drawn are measures of patient behavior, disease, symptoms, and patient knowledge. Thirty-two studies met the inclusion criteria. Pharmacists were identified as clinical pharmacists in 24 studies and community pharmacists in 2 studies. In six non-blind patient counseling studies, outcomes favored counselor patients over control patients in each study, and the effects were statistically significant in five studies (the result was medication adherence in these five studies). In the seven counseling trials for both patients and their physicians, patient outcomes were significantly better in the intervention group in six trials, four of which were single-blind. Two studies in which patients were randomized to either physician counseling or control groups yielded inconsistent results. In a study in which doctors were randomized to seek counseling from pharmacists, prescriptions in the counseling group were more likely to follow guidelines than in the control group. Four patient care attempts by pharmacists were unsuccessful. These trials have shown that counseling by pharmacists of patients and their physicians can improve patient outcomes. The evidence that counseling patients alone improves patient outcomes was good, though weak due to poor trial design.

title: Evaluation of Talking Parents, Healthy Teens, a new workplace-based parenting program to promote parent-adolescent communication about sexual health: randomized controlled trial
abstract: PURPOSE To evaluate a workplace-based parenting program (Talking Parents, Healthy Teens) designed to help parents learn to address sexual health with their adolescent children. DESIGN Randomized controlled trial (April 2002-December 2005). SETTING 13 construction sites in Southern California. PARTICIPANTS 569 parents completed the workplace baseline questionnaires, allowed confidential questionnaires to be sent to their adolescent children, and were randomized to intervention or control groups. Parents and adolescents completed follow-up questionnaires one week, three months, and nine months after the program. INTERVENTION Talking Parents, Healthy Teens, 6-10. It consists of a weekly eight-hour session on construction sites for parents of adolescent children in the first grade (approximately 11-16 years old). MAIN CONCLUSION MEASURES "Parent-adolescent communication about a list of sexual issues"; whether the parent teaches the adolescent to use condoms; ability to communicate with parent/adolescent about sex; openness of parent-adolescent communication about sex. CONCLUSIONS The differences between intervention and control are groups, parents, and adolescents. was significant for the mean number of new sexual topics they reported discussed between baseline and each follow-up (P<0.001 for each); intervention parents were less likely to discuss new topics than controls (29% versus 8%), for difference between 16% and 24% 95% confidence interval) and more likely to discuss seven or more new topics at nine months (38% versus 8%, 19% to 41%) Some differences increased after program completion: one week after the program, 18% of adolescents in the intervention group and 3% (6% to 30%) in the control group said that their parents had reviewed condom use from baseline (P<0.001), which included nine increased from 29% to 5% (13% to 36%) per month (P<0.001). Compared with controls at 9 months, parents and adolescents in the intervention group reported greater ability to communicate with each other about sex (P<0.001) and greater openness to communication about gender (P<0.001). CONCLUSIONS A workplace-based program can have significant effects on sexual health communication between parents and adolescents. TRIAL REGISTRATION Clinical Trials NCT00465010.

title: Evaluation of two school smoking education programs in normal classroom conditions
abstract: OBJECTIVES To evaluate the effectiveness of two school-based smoking education projects in delaying the onset of smoking behavior and promoting health knowledge, beliefs, and values. DESIGN Cluster, randomized controlled trial of two projects taught in normal classroom conditions. Schools, family smoking education project (FSE)", cigarette and me project (SAM); both projects in turn (FSE/SAM);" or no interference. ADJUST 39 schools in Wales and England matched in size and service area profile. SUBJECTS All first-year students in schools were included and assessed in three situations (4538 before instruction (1988), 3930 immediately after instruction (1989), 3786 (1990) at one-year follow-up). MAIN OUTCOME MEASURES Self-reported smoking behavior (supported by saliva sample) and change in related health knowledge, beliefs, and values. RESULTS There were no consistent and significant differences in smoking behavior, health knowledge, beliefs, or values between the four groups. For baseline never-smokers, the rate of never-smoker in 1990 was 74% (594/804) in the control group, 65% (455/704) in the FSE group, 70% (440/625) in the SAM group, and 69% in the FSE/SAM group ( 549/791) (chi 2adj = 6.1, df = 3, p = 0.1). Knowledge of the effects of smoking increased from an average score of 5.4 in 1988 for all groups to 6.4 in 1989 and 6.5 in 1990. CONCLUSIONS More comprehensive interventions than school health education alone will be needed to reduce youth smoking. Other measures need to be considered, including additional restrictions on access to cigarettes and the promotion of tobacco products. More research will be needed to develop effective school-based health education projects that normally need to be formally field-tested before they can become widespread.

title: Evidence-based behavioral medicine: what is it and how do we achieve it?
abstract: The goal of evidence-based medicine is ultimately to improve patient outcomes and quality of care. A systematic review of available published evidence is required to identify interventions that lead to improvements in behavior, health, and well-being. Authoritative literature reviews depend on the quality of published research and research reports. The Consolidated Standards for Reporting Trials (CONSORT) Statement (www.consort-statement.org) was developed to improve the design and reporting of interventions involving randomized clinical trials (RCTs) in medical journals. We describe 22 CONSORT guidelines and describe their application to behavioral medicine research and evidence-based practice. Additional behavioral medicine-specific guidelines (eg, adherence to treatment) are also provided. Use of these guidelines by clinicians, educators, policymakers, and researchers who design, report, and evaluate or review RCTs will strengthen research itself and accelerate efforts to apply behavioral medicine research to improve the processes and outcomes of behavioral medicine practice.

title: Evidence-based care of the elderly with suspected cognitive impairment in general practice: protocol for the IRIS cluster randomized trial.
abstract: BACKGROUND: Dementia is a common and complex condition. Evidence-based guidelines exist for the management of people with dementia in general practice";" however, detection, diagnosis, and disclosure of dementia have been identified as potential evidence-to-practice gaps. Interventions to put the guidelines into practice have had varying success. The use of theory in designing practice interventions is limited, but is advocated for its potential to provide more effective interventions and to help understand factors that change the magnitude of intervention effects across trials. This protocol describes the methods of a randomized trial testing a theory-based practice intervention that, if effective, could provide benefits for patients with dementia and their caregivers. OBJECTIVES: This trial aims to estimate the effectiveness of a theory-based intervention to increase GPs' adherence to a clinical guideline for the detection, diagnosis and management of dementia in general practice, compared to providing GPs with a medical aid. hard copy of the manual. Primary goals include testing whether the intervention is effective in increasing the percentage of patients with suspected cognitive impairment who receive care consistent with two key guidelines recommendations: ai) obtaining a formal cognitive assessment, and ii) assessing depression using a validated scale (primary outcomes Trial). METHODS: The design is a parallel set randomized trial in which sets are common applications. We aim to get 60 apps per group. Applications will be randomly allocated to intervention and control groups using restricted randomization. Detection and diagnostic behavior towards patients and GPs who meet the inclusion criteria will be determined and measured through electronic searches of medical records nine months after the start of the intervention. Practitioners in the control group will receive a hard copy of the manual. In addition to obtaining the printed manual, practitioners in the intervention group will be invited to participate in an interactive, opinion leader-led, educational face-to-face workshop. The theory-based intervention aims to address identified barriers and facilitators to the implementation of recommendations. Investigators responsible for identifying the group of patients suspected of having cognitive impairment and their detection and diagnostic results will be blinded to the group distribution. TRIAL REGISTRATION: Australia New Zealand Clinical Trials Registry: ACTRN12611001032943 (registered 28 September 2011).

title: Evidence-based guidelines for teaching the patient-centered interview
abstract: In a rare study of the effectiveness of an interview method, we previously reported on a randomized controlled trial that showed that step-by-step patient-centered interviewing training improves residents' knowledge, attitudes, and skills, and has a consistently positive effect on trained people. residents' patients. For those who want to use this evidence-based patient-centered method as a template for their own teaching, here we describe our training program for the first time and suggest that the training can be adapted for students, doctors, nurses. physician assistants and other new learners as well. The training was skill-focused and experiential, encouraged positive attitudes towards patient-centered interviewing, and used a student-centered approach with special emphasis on the teacher-soldier relationship and the assistant's self-awareness. Skills training was guided by a newly defined patient-centered interview method that described step-by-step use of certain behaviors.

title: Evidence-based guidelines for the treatment of bipolar disorder: revised third edition recommendations from the British Psychopharmacological Society.
abstract: British Psychopharmacological Society guidelines set the scope and goals of bipolar disorder treatment. The third version is clearly based on available evidence and, like previous Clinical Practice Guidelines, is offered as advice for practitioners to aid clinical decision-making: it can also serve as an information resource for patients and caregivers and aid management. Recommendations are accompanied by a more detailed review of the relevant evidence. A consensus meeting of experts on bipolar disorder and its treatment reviewed key areas and evaluated the strength of the evidence and clinical implications. The guidelines were developed after extensive feedback from these participants. The best available evidence from randomized controlled trials and, where available, observational studies using quasi-experimental designs were used to evaluate treatment options. The strength of the recommendations is explained using the GRADE approach. Guidelines cover diagnosis, clinical management, and strategies for the use of medications for the short-term management of episodes, prevention of relapse, and discontinuation of treatment. It is integrated with a consistent approach to drug use, psychoeducation, and behavior change.

title: Evidence-based health care for children: what are we missing?
abstract: With comprehensive health reform enacted, reimbursement for various health services will likely depend on the evidence to support that service. Understanding what constitutes "evidence" will have a profound impact on the scope of clinical care provided. A definition that is too narrow can have a significant impact, particularly on pediatric care: most current child health services require that a broader body of evidence be considered when developing clinical guidelines than is usually relied upon. This is especially true for care that addresses behavioral and developmental issues. The current standard for evaluating evidence uses study design as a proxy for evidence quality";" therefore, it may inadvertently exclude many important findings and not support further relevant research. The project described here provided a new, broader framework for evaluating clinical practice that should be valuable to both clinicians and policy makers.

title: Evidence-based medicine and headache patient management by general practitioners in Italy
abstract: The study explores awareness of technical terms used in evidence-based medicine (CPA) and the way it treats migraine patients in a random sample of 500 general practitioners (GPs). A mailed questionnaire included questions about GPs demographics and practice characteristics"; awareness about CPA; sources of information about migraine and CPA;" and the patient's treatment behavior. Only 27.2% of GPs agreed that clinical trials are needed to evaluate the effectiveness of treatments, and this awareness was higher in those who learned about migraine from scientific journals or continuing education courses and those who attended CPA courses. For two-thirds of GPs, disability is equivalent to disease diagnosis, and this behavior was more prevalent in those who agreed that clinical trials are necessary to evaluate the effectiveness of preventive or curative treatments for migraine and that the clinical approach to migraine requires an evaluation. Clinical efficacy is in those who treat fewer headache patients, older people, and those who do not use guidelines. The majority of GPs (93.1%) said it was important to integrate the best available evidence with clinical practice, and this behavior was significantly more frequent in those who agreed that the clinical approach to migraine required a clinical assessment of efficacy and the clinical trials were adequate. It is necessary for evaluating the effectiveness of preventive or curative treatments for migraine and for those attending courses on CPA. There is a strong need for education and continuing education programs in CPA and guidelines on headache treatments for general practitioners.

title: Evidence-based medicine and women: Do the principles and practice of CPA improve women's health?
abstract: Clinicians and policy makers around the world are embracing evidence-based medicine (CPA). The CPA's promise is to use summaries of research evidence to identify which health interventions are effective and which are not so that patients can benefit from effective interventions and be protected from those that are useless or harmful. The CPA provides a seemingly rational objective tool for deciding whether to provide an intervention on the basis of its effectiveness, which in theory leads to fair and effective health care for all. In this article, I take a closer look at these claims from a health care perspective for women, using relevant examples. I would argue that the current processes of evidence-based medicine contain some prejudice against women. These biases arise in the production of research that informs evidence-based medicine, in the methods used to analyze and synthesize evidence, and in the practice of CPA through the use of guidelines. Finally, the biomedical health model that underlies much of the medical research used by the CPA ignores the social and political context that contributes so much to women's health.

title: Evidence-based medicine. Interpreting studies and setting policy
abstract: The rise of the CPA has been accompanied by a greater awareness of its shortcomings. From the cost, length, and difficulty of performing RCTs, it is becoming increasingly apparent that studies cannot be initiated to address every question in medicine. Good evidence is often lacking in medicine. Epistomologists question the concepts of evidence and the relevance of current study designs and measurement tools to investigate salient issues of interest to patients and others regarding quality. Lack of evidence of effectiveness does not prove ineffectiveness, but in response to CPA, insurers and government often make this inference to justify their decision to withhold coverage or research support. Unbridled enthusiasm for the evidence-based practice guideline in the early 1990s was tempered by a more mature understanding of its limitations. Many practice guidelines are not well developed, and applying incorrect guidelines can cause harm. The seven-step process outlined earlier is slow, laborious, and expensive (sometimes costing hundreds of thousands of dollars). Furthermore, there is little evidence that the rigor of the methods or the guidelines themselves have a significant impact on administration behavior or patient outcomes. According to the most cynical observers, the only consistent beneficiaries of guides are payers who have used them with significant success in reducing costs, length of stay and usage rates. Even ardent proponents of the guidelines acknowledge the evidence that disseminating reviews and recommendations alone fails to motivate clinicians to increase the delivery of effective interventions and abandon ineffective ones. This lack of response has spurred a closer look at the barriers to behavior change and the design of thoughtful implementation strategies that begin with simple guidelines but go beyond. Tools such as reminder systems, fixed orders, academic elaboration, peer review and supervision, feedback, and health system changes recognize that knowing what needs to be done is only one piece of an increasingly complex puzzle. The competitive market for managed healthcare has added new economic effects on clinician behavior, but it is also fueling private sector interest in good research. Patients, clinicians, and policy makers will continue to seek better data on what works and what doesn't in medicine.

title: Examining the analytical quality of behavioral health randomized clinical trials
abstract: Adopting an evidence-based practice (EBP) policy has implications for both clinicians and researchers. In areas that have already adopted EBP, evidence-based practice guidelines are derived from systematic reviews of research evidence. Ultimately, such guides serve as tools used by practitioners. Systematic reviews of treatment efficacy and efficacy reserve their strongest endorsement for treatments supported by high-quality randomized clinical trials (RCTs). It is unknown how well the RCTs reported in behavioral science journals compare to the quality standards set in areas leading the evidence-based movement. We compared the analytical quality characteristics of all behavioral health RCTs (n = 73) published in three leading behavioral journals and two leading medical journals between January 2000 and July 2003. an acute or chronic physical illness or condition. The findings uncovered areas of weakness in the analytical aspects of the behavioral health RCTs reported in both journal sets. Weaknesses were more prominent in behavior journals. The authors make recommendations to improve the analytical quality of behavioral health RCTs to ensure that the evidence for behavioral treatments is high-weighted in systematic reviews.

title: Examining clinical judgment in an adaptive intervention design: Rapid follow-up program
abstract: Although frequently used in clinical judgment, assessment, and treatment planning, it has seldom examined its reliability, validity, or efficacy in practice settings. This study adjusted the frequency of home visits in a prevention program for aggressive-disruptive children (n = 410";" 56% minorities) to 2 types of clinical judgments: rating of parental functioning using a standardized multi-item scale and Global assessments of family service need. Stronger reliability and better concurrent and predictive validity emerged for type 1 clinical judgment than for type 2. Exploratory analyzes suggested that using parental functionality ratings to tailor treatment recommendations improved the effect of the intervention at the end of grade 3, but using more family needs assessments did not.

title: Exceptional births: home births as ethical anomalies in American obstetrics
abstract: Interest in home birth appears to be growing among American women, and most obstetricians can expect to encounter patients considering a home birth. In 2011, the American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists (ACOG) published an opinion statement aimed at guiding obstetricians in responding to such patients. In this article, I examine the ACOG statement in light of the historical and contemporary clinical realities surrounding home birth in the United States, guided by my own experience as an obstetrician in home birth and non-home birth friendly births. medical environment. Comparison with other guidelines shows that the ACOG treats home birth as an ethical exception: comparable evidence leads to dramatically different recommendations in the case of home birth and in the case of a previous attempted cesarean delivery"; and ACOG quite diverges other controversial issues involving similar ethical questions. By making information provision not only the primary but also the sole ethical responsibility of the obstetrician, the ACOG statement removes the obstetrician's responsibility to provide appropriate clinical care and to create the safest clinical environment possible for mothers who choose home birth and their newborns. What at first glance appears to be an expression of respect for women's autonomy implicitly allows behavior that unethically limits truly autonomous choices. There is no need for obstetricians to participate in home births, I think. However, our ethical duties make us (1) talented cl. (2) to maintain respectful antenatal care to women who choose home birth, (3) to provide appropriate counseling to home birth attendants. and (4) ensuring that care transfers are seamless and non-punitive.

title: Exercise advice: public health panacea for the promotion of physical activity? A critical perspective on exercise referral schemes";" their development and evaluation
abstract: This review critically explores the development, impact and evaluation of exercise referral plans (ERS) in the UK. There has been rapid expansion in the use of such ERS in leisure and primary care settings, but evidence to support their application is scarce and is predominantly limited to a randomized controlled trial (RCT) research design. As a result, understanding of exercise orientation as a 'real world' intervention has been limited. Given the increasing emphasis on evidence-based practice and clinical effectiveness, it is no longer enough for exercise referral service providers to ignore the need to evaluate programs. Guidelines for assessment provided by the National Quality Assurance Framework for Exercise Guidance are limited, so practitioners are often unsure of the best measures to use when assessing efficacy. Predominantly, exercise professionals focus on collecting physiological data but tend to ignore relevant psychological and environmental parameters. Also, there is very little UK research that follows participants over the long term to see if physical activity behavior is maintained over time. Here we describe the evidence from two ongoing large-scale (n = 1600/year) evaluation studies of exercise referral plans based in urban settlements in the northwest of England. A participatory action research framework was used for evaluation and combined multi-method research approaches for the evaluation of both ERS participants and healthcare professionals involved in intervention delivery. This framework is a suitable methodology for evaluating and developing complex interventions and includes case study, focus groups, interviews and survey questionnaires. A 12-month follow-up study of a cohort of exercise referral participants (n = 342) measuring leisure physical activity levels (Godin leisure score) at baseline (entry to exercise referral) and then at 3-month intervals was included. . Adherence to the ERS was approximately 35-45%, and older participants were more likely to complete it. Physiological changes during ERS, although statistically significant, were not large enough to convey any real health benefits to the individual's health status. Although small in scale, the physiological changes were all positive (for example, reduction in blood pressure) and, if sustained over time, could yield population-level benefits in health. Participants referred from cardiac and practice nurses had higher levels of compliance than participants referred by general practitioners. Scheme B showed that participants who adhered until the end of the ERS (12 weeks) (n = 103) were able to maintain a small increase in physical activity after 12 months (compared to 21 minutes of moderate activity/week increase). basis). In conclusion, this research suggests that the exercise referral process benefits certain segments of the population, but not necessarily all.

title: Extended HIV Screening in the United States: Impact on Clinical Outcomes, HIV Transmission and Costs
abstract: Background: An extensive literature supports expanded HIV screening in the United States. However, who will be tested and how often is debatable. Purpose: To inform the design of HIV screening programs where screening is cost-effective by determining the combination of screening frequency and HIV prevalence and incidence. Design: Cost-effectiveness analysis linking simulation models of HIV screening to published reports of HIV transmission risk, with or without antiretroviral therapy. Data Sources: Published randomized trials, observational cohorts, national cost and service use surveys, Red Book, and previous modeling results. Target Population: US populations with low to moderate HIV prevalence (0.05 to 1.0%) and annual incidence (0.0084 to 0.12%). Time Horizon: Lifetime. Perspective: Social. Interventions: One-time and increasingly frequent voluntary HIV screening of all adults using same-day rapid testing. Outcomes: HIV infections detected, secondary transmissions avoided, quality-adjusted survival, lifetime medical costs, and community cost-effectiveness reported as discounted 2004 dollars per quality-adjusted life-year (QALY) gained. Results of the Baseline Analysis: Routine HIV screening in a population of 1.0% HIV prevalence and 0.12% annual incidence, increased cost-effectiveness rates 30 800 $/QALY, under moderately favorable assumptions about the impact of HIV patient care on secondary transmission. one-time scan), $32300/QALY (scan every 5 years), and $55500/QALY (scan every 3 years). In settings with an HIV prevalence of 0.10% and an annual incidence of 0.014%, one-time screening produced cost-effectiveness rates of $60,700/QALY. Results of the Sensitivity Analysis: The cost-effectiveness of screening policies varied within a narrow range, as assumptions about the impact of screening on secondary transmission changed from positive to negative. Assuming moderate positive effects of antiretroviral therapy on transmission, cost-effectiveness rates have remained below $50,000/QALY for routine one-time HIV screening in settings where HIV prevalence is as low as 0.20% and prevalences are low at 0.45% annually. The incidence for screening every 5 years is as low as 0.0075%. Limitations: This analysis does not address the difficulty of determining the prevalence and incidence of undetected HIV infection in a given patient population. Conclusions: Routine, rapid HIV testing is recommended for all adults except in settings where there is evidence of an undiagnosed prevalence of HIV infection below 0.2%.

title: Extending the Use of Continuous Sedation to Death: Going Beyond the Last Resort for the Terminally Patient
abstract: As currently practiced, the use of continuous sedation until death (CSD) is controlled by clinicians in such a way that they may deny it an important choice in controlling patients' death processes. The ethical guidelines of the American Medical Association and the American Academy of Pain Medicine define CSD as "a last resort," and a position statement from the American Academy of Hospice and Palliative Medicine defines it as "an intervention reserved for extreme conditions." Accordingly, patients should move towards constant pain and suffering and come to the stage of last resort before the option to pursue CSD is considered. Alternatively, we present and advocate new guidance in which terminally ill patients with a life expectancy of less than six months, with decision-making abilities, can request a CSD before suffering the resistant suffering of "last resort" treatment.

title: Experience-based design: From redesigning the system around the patient to designing services with the patient
abstract: Engaging patients in the service improvement process and listening to and responding to what they have to say has played an important role in redesigning healthcare over the past five years or more. Patients and users have participated in stakeholder events, participated in exploratory talks, completed surveys, mapped healthcare processes, and even designed new hospitals with healthcare staff. However, efforts to date have not necessarily focused on the patient's experience, beyond asking what is good and what is bad. Questions were not asked to learn the details of what the experience was or should be like ("experience" differs from "attitudes"), and the information was then used systematically to design services with patients. Only the patient's knowledge of experience is unique and valuable. In this article, attention is drawn to the developing discipline of design sciences and experiential design, where the traditional view that sees the user as a passive buyer of a product or service has begun to give way to the new user view. It is an integral part of the improvement and innovation process.

title: Decision-Analysis Recommendations Against Expert Panel for Post-Discharge Coronary Angiography After Myocardial Infarction
abstract: Context Expert panels and decision analysis techniques are increasingly used to determine the appropriateness of medical interventions, but these 2 approaches use different methods to process evidence. Purpose To compare expert panel suitability ratings of coronary angiography after myocardial infarction (from hospital discharge to 12 weeks post-infarction) with the health gains and cost-effectiveness predicted by a decision-analytic model. Design Comparison of the significance of clinical variables considered in expert panel fit ratings compared to a previously published decision-analytic model. Identification of 36 clinical scenarios from the expert panel that can be simulated by the decision-analytic model. Key Outcome Measures Relevance score and fitness stratification (expert panel) and earnings in quality-adjusted life years (QALYs) and increased cost-effectiveness ratio (decision-analytical model). Results The most important clinical variables were similar across the 2 approaches, and the exercise tolerance test result exerted the greatest leverage on the strength of recommendation for angiography. Among the expert panel clinical scenarios considered appropriate for coronary angiography that could be simulated in the decision analysis model, the median (interquartile range) health gain and incremental cost-effectiveness rate were 0.59 (0.41-0.76) QALY and $27,000 ($23,000). . -$35,000 per QALY earned, respectively). Among the clinical scenarios that expert panels considered inappropriate, the corresponding medians (interquartile ranges) were 0.24 (0.19-0.34) QALYs and $54,000 ($36,000-58,000) per QALY earned. The Spearman rank correlation between fitness score and QALY attainment was 0.58 (P<.001), and the correlation between fitness score and estimated incremental cost-effectiveness rates was ?0.66 (P<.001). Results For the 36 expert panel scenarios that could be simulated by the decision-analytic model, there was moderate to good agreement between both the health gain and the increased cost-effectiveness ratio and fitness score of coronary angiography compared to no angiography during convalescence. Stage of acute myocardial infarction, but several scenarios assessed as inappropriate by the expert panel approach had cost-effectiveness rates comparable to many recommended medical interventions overall. A formal synthesis of expert judgment and decision modeling is warranted in future guideline development efforts.

title: Explaining the effects of two different strategies for promoting hand hygiene in hospital nurses: a process evaluation combined with a cluster of randomized controlled trials.
abstract: BACKGROUND: There is only limited understanding of why hand hygiene improvement strategies have succeeded or failed. It is therefore important to look inside the 'black box' of such strategies to determine which components of a strategy work well or less well. This study examined which components of the two hand hygiene improvement strategies were associated with increased hand hygiene compliance by nurses. METHODS: A process evaluation of a cluster randomized controlled trial was conducted in which a portion of the nursing wards of three hospitals in the Netherlands received a cutting-edge strategy including training, reminders, feedback and optimizing materials and facilities. ;" another section received a team and leaders-led strategy that included all elements of a state-of-the-art strategy, supported by activities aimed at strengthening social and leadership. Four sets of measures were used in this process assessment: effects on nurses' hand hygiene compliance, adherence to improvement strategies, contextual factors and nurses' experience with strategy components.Analyses of variance and multiple regression analyzes were used to investigate changes in nurses' hand hygiene compliance and thus to better understand trial effects. RESULTS: Both strategies were applied with good adherence to the protocol. Two contextual factors with changes in hand hygiene compliance was associated: a long-term hospital effect (p < 0.05) and higher hand hygiene baseline scores were associated with smaller effects (p < 0.01). i was positively associated with reports (p < 0.05). In the long run, several elements of the components of 'social influence' (ie, addressing each other about undesirable hand hygiene behavior p < 0.01) and 'leadership' (ie, ward manager holds team members responsible for hand hygiene performance p < 0.01)) in nurses' hand hygiene compliance showed a positive correlation with the changes. CONCLUSION: This study demonstrates the use of a process assessment to reveal the mechanisms underlying change in hand hygiene improvement strategies. Our study results demonstrate the added value of certain aspects of social influence and leadership in hand hygiene improvement strategies, thus providing an interpretation of the trial effects. TRIAL REGISTRATION: Study registered on ClinicalTrials.gov, file number: NCT00548015.

title: Explaining variation in GP referral rates for x-ray for back pain
abstract: BACKGROUND: Despite the availability of clinical guidelines for the treatment of low back pain (LBP), there remains large variation in referral rates by general practitioners (GPs) for lumbar spine x-ray (LSX). This study aims to explain the differences in referral rates for LSX from general practitioners' explanations of the management of patients with low back pain. METHODS: Qualitative, semi-structured interviews with 29 GPs in North East England with high and low referral rates for LSX. Thematic analysis used continuous comparative techniques. RESULTS: Common and different themes were identified between high and low LSX users. Themes that were similar in both groups included awareness of current guidelines for the use of LSX in patients with LBP and pressure from patients and institutional factors to order an LSX. Differentiating themes for the high user group included: a belief that LSX provides patients with greater reassurance than risks, pessimism about management options for LBP, and a belief that rejecting LSX will negatively impact doctor-patient relationships. Two specific distinguishing themes are covered in greater depth: GPs' awareness of their relative use of lumbar spine radiology and the perceived risks associated with LSX radiation. CONCLUSION: Despite being aware of clinical guideline recommendations, there are several key factors that differentiate GPs' accounts of high and low referral rates for LSX. Intervention efforts aimed at improving compliance with guideline recommendations on LSX use by changing primary care practitioners' ranking behavior should focus on these factors.

title: Explain the differences in prescribing costs across the UK
abstract: OBJECTIVE To derive a predictive model for national prescribing behavior in terms of key morbidity and demographic factors. DESIGN 24 demographic, morbidity, and practice factors were entered in multiple regression analysis to determine the net cost of content per patient. IDENTIFY 90 UK family health service officials for 1989. CONCLUSIONS Only two demographic factors (number of retirees and mobility of the registered population as measured by list inflation) and two disease-related factors (standardized death rates and numbers) for net content cost per patient contributed significantly to the multiple regression model. This model explains 81% of the variation in the cost of net content per registered patient among family health care authorities. The model also provided the derivation of a weighting factor of 4.6 (95% confidence interval 3.2 to 6.7) for the net content cost for elderly patients (compared to the current prescribing unit factor 3). CONCLUSIONS The model shows that changes in prescribing costs mainly reflect demand. He also argues that the current prescribing unit value of 3 for patients aged 65 and over underestimates the extra costs of prescribing for older patients.

title: Descriptive analysis of patients' motivation to quit smoking and attend smoking cessation classes
abstract: BACKGROUND AND OBJECTIVES: Significant research has evaluated the effects of smoking, the effects of exposure to secondhand smoke, the effectiveness of various social and individual interventions for smoking cessation, and the frequency with which physicians discuss smoking cessation with their patients. Few studies have addressed the barriers to physician-initiated discussion and intervention regarding smoking cessation, particularly with resident physicians treating low-income patients. Current research shows that physicians have low expectations of patients' willingness to quit, and often wait to discuss quitting with patients until the patient raises the issue. The aim of this pilot study was to determine smoking trends, willingness to quit smoking, and willingness to attend smoking cessation classes in the family medicine clinic. METHODS: The patients filled out a questionnaire revealing their demographic information, smoking behavior, presence of chronic disease, desire to quit smoking, and reasons for wanting to quit smoking. RESULTS: Higher smoking rates and lower desired quit rates were determined. However, among patients considering quitting smoking, the number of desired cessation classes is relatively high. A higher number of failed quit attempts heralded an increased likelihood of both wanting to quit and requesting dropout classes. Other determinants of completion desire and classroom participation are discussed. CONCLUSIONS: Based on current research, physicians are encouraged to follow practice guidelines, ask all patients about their smoking behavior, and assist in their efforts to quit, particularly those who have failed in the past.

title: Exploring the boundary-setting perspectives of nurses and patients in the forensic mental health setting
abstract: Limit setting is an intervention frequently used by mental health nurses. However, boundary setting is poorly conceptualized, its purpose is unclear, and there are few evidence-based guidelines to help nurses set boundaries safely and effectively. What is known is that the way nurses set boundaries affects patients' perceptions of interactions and their emotional and behavioral responses. In this qualitative study, 12 nurses and 12 patients participated in personal, semi-structured interviews aimed at exploring demarcation and suggesting principles to guide practice. The findings showed that (i) demarcation is important for safety in mental health hospitals"; (ii) it is necessary to empathically involve patients when setting boundaries (when nurses are empathetically engaged, the therapeutic relationship is more likely to be protected and respond aggressively). risk should be reduced);" and (iii) an authoritarian (fair, respectful, consistent, and knowledgeable), restraining style rather than authoritarian (supervisory and indifferent) promotes positive outcomes related to commitment, reduced likelihood of aggression, and maintenance of the therapeutic relationship. As a result, an authoritarian style is recommended rather than a restraining style characterized by empathetic responsiveness and an authoritarian interpersonal style. Illuminating the components of this style is critical for the effective training and best practices of mental health nurses and for reducing the aggressive responses that result from boundary-setting.

title: Exploring the feasibility of Conjoint Analysis as a tool to prioritize innovations for practice
abstract: Background In an age of scarce and competing priorities for implementation, choosing what to implement is a key decision point for many behavior change projects. The values and attitudes of the professionals and managers involved inevitably influence the priority given to decision options. Such values are difficult to capture reliably. Methods This article presents an approach for capturing and incorporating professional values in the prioritization of healthcare innovations under consideration. The Combined Analysis (CA) was used to measure the priorities of healthcare professionals working with women with postpartum depression at the UK Foundation for Primary Care. Rating-based CA data were collected using a questionnaire and then matched to 12 interventions considered as a way to improve the management of postpartum depression. Results Â¡Â®impact on patient careÂ¡Â¯ and Â¡Â®supporting quality of evidenceÂ¡Â¯ associated with potential innovationsÂ¡Â¯ were most influential in shaping priorities. Professionals were least impressed whether an innovation was a current national or local priority or whether current practice at the Trust met minimum standards. Sorting the 12 innovations by potential adopters' preferences revealed that Â¡Â®guided self-helpÂ¡Â¯ had the highest priority for implementation, and Â¡Â®screening questions¡Â¯ the least for postpartum depression. Given other factors (such as the availability of routine data or planned implementation activity elsewhere in the Trust), the project team chose to combine eight related treatments and apply them as a single innovation called Â¡Â®psychological therapiesÂ¡. A. Conclusions Using Unified Analysis to prioritize potential innovation implementation options is a viable way to capture stakeholder benefit and thereby increase the chances of an innovation being adopted. There are some practical hurdles to overcome, such as increased response rates to composite questionnaires, before the routine and unevaluated use of this technique.

title: Exploring the gap between knowledge and behavior: a qualitative study of clinician action following an educational intervention.
abstract: OBJECTIVE: Many medical education interventions improve clinicians' knowledge but fail to change behavior. The authors uncovered this knowledge-behavior gap through standard clinical interactions, thus allowing in-depth investigation of contributing factors. METHODS: In 2001-02, a typical evidence-based educational intervention was administered to family medicine residents in a clinical setting (early signs of autism) at the University of Toronto and change in knowledge was assessed with a multiple-choice test. After six to eight weeks, participants' relevant knowledge was documented and their clinical behavior was observed during four interactions with standardized patients. Factors causing knowledge-behavior mismatch were investigated using semi-structured interviews, which were then audio recorded, transcribed, and analyzed using grounded theory methods. RESULTS: Half of the participants showed varying degrees of knowledge-behavior gap. Eight major rationalizations (relationships, patient agenda, lack of knowledge, clinical style, means to ends, ideals, autism stigma, and system barriers) were used to justify clinical behavior choices, and the same rationalizations were used to justify opposing behavior choices. . Two conditions (level of certainty and sense of urgency) were identified that encouraged informed clinical action. CONCLUSION: The knowledge-behavior gap was uncovered and the factors reported to influence clinicians' decisions about whether or not to apply new knowledge were revealed. The fact that the same rationalizations have been used to justify opposite behaviors means that these factors may not be behavioral determinants. A sense of urgency and a level of certainty encourage informed clinical action";" focusing on these can increase the impact of training on practice.

title: Investigating the roots of undesirable security threats associated with the introduction of hospital e-prescribing systems and candidate avoidance and/or mitigation strategies: a qualitative study
abstract: Purpose Hospital electronic prescribing (e-prescribing) systems offer a wide range of patient safety benefits. However, like other hospital health information technology interventions, they can bring new risk areas. Despite recent progress in identifying these risks, the development and use of e-prescribing systems still leads to numerous undesirable consequences that can undermine improvement and threaten patient safety. These negative consequences need to be analyzed in the design, implementation and use of these systems. Therefore, we aimed to understand the roots of these reported threats and to identify candidate avoidance/mitigation strategies. Methods We analyzed a longitudinal, qualitative study of the implementation and adoption of e-prescribing systems in six UK hospitals, each conceptualized as a case study. The data included semi-structured interviews, observations of practice meetings and system usage, and a collection of related documents. We analyzed the data first within the case studies and then across the case studies. Results Our dataset included 214 interviews, 24 observations, and 18 documents. We developed a classification of factors underlying undesirable security threats: (1) suboptimal system design, including lack of support for complex drug delivery regimens, lack of effective integration between disparate systems, and lack of effective automated decision support tools; (2) improper use of systems – particularly too much reliance on the system and the introduction of workarounds;" and (3) suboptimal implementation strategies resulting from partial deployments/binary systems and lack of proper training. A set of systems and organizational strategies that can potentially prevent or mitigate these risks Conclusions Defects in the design, implementation, and use of e-prescribing systems can have unintended consequences, including security threats Hospitals and suppliers should implement short- and long-term strategies in terms of technology and organization to minimize undesirable security risks.

title: External validity of randomized controlled trials: "To whom do the results of this trial apply?"
abstract: Physicians and patients should consider relevant randomized controlled trials (RCTs) and systematic reviews when making treatment decisions. Relevance depends on external validity (or generalizability) – that is, whether the results can reasonably be applied to an identifiable group of patients in routine practice in a given clinical setting. There is concern among clinicians that external validity is often weak, particularly for some pharmaceutical industry trials; this is a perception that leads to the underutilization of effective treatments. Yet researchers, funding agencies, ethics committees, the pharmaceutical industry, medical journals, and government regulators alike ignore external validity, leaving clinicians to judge. However, reporting determinants of external validity in research publications and systematic reviews is often insufficient. This review discusses these determinants, provides a checklist for clinicians, and makes recommendations for greater consideration of external validity in the design and reporting of RCTs.

title: Facilitating patients' diabetes self-management: a primary care intervention framework
abstract: Based on pervasive office environment changes, a quality primary care framework for diabetes self-management (DSM) is offered. A review of recent DSM research and literature on (a) patients' perceptions of DSM and office visit experiences, and (b) more effective office-based DSM programs. This quality primary care framework allows nurse clinicians to more consistently assess individual patient factors and integrate them into office visits, using typically limited clinical resources to optimize DSM patient outcomes.

title: Factor Studies: Using Vignettes to Examine Professional Judgment.
abstract: Decision-making is becoming an increasingly central feature of social work practice, but there is limited research on the subject. While questions of validity and generalizability surround ethnographic and other descriptive methods, empirical methods of investigating decision making tend to be constrained by practical and ethical challenges. Here it is discussed that the factorial questionnaire addresses these methodological challenges as a research design to examine the way professionals make decisions in real life.
