In this research design, lifelike vignettes (case scenarios or paper cases) are presented to social workers or other staff members to make a judgment about a familiar type of scenario. The random factors in the vignettes, combined with the randomization of the vignette selection for each decision maker, gives the factorial survey a unique ability to investigate the influence of multiple factors in complex decisions, unlike the more common factorial experiment. The method is explained and the prospects and issues for the development of this research design to examine professional judgment in social work are discussed. The factorial questionnaire has potential as a method for rigorously examining the impact of client, family, and context factors on decisions made by social work and social care personnel. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2016 APA, all rights reserved)

title: Factors affecting the feasibility and acceptability of a practice-based educational intervention to support evidence-based prescribing: a qualitative study.
abstract: BACKGROUND: Improper and costly GP prescription is a major problem facing Primary Care Trusts. Educational access to practices, along with other measures such as supervision and feedback, has the potential to make GP prescribing more evidence-based. High GP prescribing costs are associated with GPs seeing pharmaceutical company representatives"; tend to end consultations with a prescription;" and 'try' new drugs on an 'ad hoc basis' and use this as proof of the drug's effect. To meet these and other educational needs, an educational intervention called 'reflective practice' has been developed. The design of the intervention was informed by studies that identified the prerequisites for successful behavior change in general practice. OBJECTIVES: The study investigated: (i) Is it possible for GPs to attend sessions included in the educational intervention? (ii) Is the intervention acceptable to the participants and session facilitators? (iii) What are the barriers to group training processes and how can they be overcome? METHODS: Four practices were recruited in South West England, all experiencing issues with prescribing eligibility and cost. In each of these practices, reflective practice sessions (including a videotaped scenario) were conducted and qualitative methods were used to explore the complex attitudes and behaviors of the participants. In each application, a researcher observed and recorded the sessions. At the end of the program, an example of a doctor and all the facilitators were interviewed about their experience. Recorded data were transcribed and analyzed using standard qualitative methods. RESULTS: Doctors in the largest partnerships had the most difficulty attending sessions. Elsewhere, physicians were also reluctant to get involved because of previous experience with top-down managerial interventions in prescribing quality. The facilitators came from a wide variety of professional backgrounds. While knowledge of prescription drug management issues was important, the facilitator's professional background was less important than group facilitation skills in establishing a group process that the participating GPs found satisfactory. The video-recorded scenario was found useful to set the stage for discussion. Preserving the anonymity of the GPs' responses in the early stages of the sessions was important to ensure honesty in the discussion. It was sometimes difficult to reach a consensus on the management of general conditions, partly because the use of the term 'best buy' denoted economic pressures rather than benefits to patients, and partly because GPs valued the concept of clinical autonomy. 'Reflective Practice' proved to have the potential to inform GPs of the link to be made between clinical management decisions and the evidence provided by the British National Formulary and Clinical Evidence. CONCLUSION: The study demonstrates the importance of adequately preparing practice, including providing protected time for all GPs to participate in the educational intervention. The scenarios and structure of the sessions should make the links between daily practice and published evidence of effectiveness clearer. The emphasis on cost effectiveness may be counterproductive and the broader benefits need to be emphasized. We also identified the skill profile of the facilitator role. Our study demonstrates the need for a clearer understanding of GPs' perception of clinical autonomy and how this conflicts with the goal of agreeing on practice guidelines for treatment. The intervention is now ripe for further development, perhaps by integrating it with other interventions to change professional behavior. Improved intervention should then be evaluated in a randomized controlled trial.

title: Factors associated with nursing interventions to reduce incontinence in hospitalized older adults
abstract: INTRODUCTION: The problem of incontinence in hospitalized elderly patients is rarely documented and there is little research on why nurses choose to help or not help this problem. Are the attitudes and beliefs of acute care nurses about incontinence related to the perceived opportunity to help the patient with the problem? What do hospital nurses know about causes and interventions for incontinence? METHODS: Two vignettes were created, one describing a patient with stress incontinence and the other with urge incontinence. Questions measuring the variables of the helping model were developed and nurses were asked to mark each question on a Likert-type scale while answering them. RESULTS: One hundred and fifty participants returned completed questionnaires, along with three nurse specialists. Many hospital nurses believed that incontinence was temporary and part of aging. As a group, they had a more positive attitude towards intervention for urge incontinence and believed that physician and nurse managers expected them to help the patient with urge incontinence. Respondents tended to believe that the patient was least likely to seek help. Participants were equally divided on the opportunity to provide help for stress or urge incontinence. Less than half of the nurses correctly listed the causes and interventions for stress or urge incontinence. CONCLUSION: Lack of knowledge about other clinical problems perceived as more urgent and appropriate help measures affect nurses' perceptions of the opportunity to intervene when elderly patients in the hospital have incontinence. Evaluation and intervention are essential for quality nursing care. Undergraduate nursing education and ongoing staff training on incontinence are essential for assessments and interventions to be accurate. As healthcare consumers, patients should be more educated about incontinence and choose to have the problem addressed during hospitalization. The Agency for Healthcare Policy and Research Clinical Practice Guidelines is an important recommended reference.

title: Factors Associated with Poor Mental Health of Guatemalan Refugees Living in Mexico 20 Years After the Civil Conflict
abstract: Context From 1981 to 2001, 46,000 refugees in Chiapas, Mexico, fleeing 36 years of internal conflict in Guatemala, were under the protection of the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees. Objectives To estimate the prevalence of mental illness and factors associated with poor mental health in underserved Guatemalan refugee communities in Chiapas, Mexico since 1981, and to assess the need for mental health services. Design, Environment and Participants Cross-sectional survey of 183 households representing approximately 1546 residents (adults and children) in 5 Maya refugee camps in Chiapas, November-December 2000. Main Outcome Measures Post Traumatic Stress Disorder (PTSD), anxiety symptom criteria, and depression as measured by the Harvard Trauma Questionnaire and Hopkins Symptom Checklist-25 (Hopkins-25). Results One adult (age = 16 years old) per household (n=170 participants) who agreed to participate in the analysis was included and represents an estimated 93% of households. All participants reported experiencing at least 1 traumatic event, with an average of 8.3 traumatic events per person. Twenty (11.8%) of the respondents had all symptom criteria for PTSD. Of 160 people who completed the Hopkins Symptom Checklist-25, 87 (54.4%) had anxiety symptoms and 62 (38.8%) had depression symptoms. Witnessing the disappearance of family members (adjusted odds [AOR], 4.58"; 95% confidence interval [CI], 1.35-15.50), near death (AOR, 4.19, 95% CI, 1.03-17.00), or living in the same home It was associated with PTSD symptoms in 9 to 15 subjects (AOR, 3.69; 95% CI, 1.19-11.39). A protective factor was found for lack of adequate food (AOR, 0.08; 95% CI, 0.01- 0.59) High anxiety symptoms witnessed a carnage was associated with being (AOR, 10.63; 95% CI, 4.31-26.22), injury (AOR, 3.22; 95% CI, 0.95-10.89), and experiencing 7 to 12 traumatic events (AOR, 2.67; 95% CI, 1.14-6.27). ) and 13 to 19 traumatic events (AOR, 2.26; 95% CI, 0.65-7.89) High depression symptoms were associated with being female (AOR, 3.64; 95% CI , 1.47-9.04), being widowed (AOR, 27.55; 95% CI) , 2.54-299.27), being married (AOR, 1.93; 95% CI, 0.59-6.33), witnessing loss (AOR, 2.68; 95% CI, 1.16 -6.19), experiencing 7 to 12 traumatic events (AOR, 1.57; 95% CI, 0.64-3.88)), or experiencing 13 to 19 traumatic events (AOR, 7.44; 95% CI, 2.18-25. 37). Conclusion Psychiatric illness related to human rights abuses, traumatic events, and refugee status was prevalent among Guatemalan refugees surveyed 20 years after the Guatemalan civil conflict.

title: Failure of computerized therapy recommendations to improve health outcomes in outpatients with uncomplicated hypertension: results of a randomized controlled trial.
abstract: Study Purpose. To evaluate the effects of evidence-based treatment recommendations for hypertension made to physicians and pharmacists using a comprehensive electronic medical record system. Design. The randomized controlled trial with a 2x 2-factor design of physician and pharmacist interventions resulted in four patient groups: physician intervention only, pharmacist intervention only, physician and pharmacist intervention, and neither physician nor pharmacist intervention (control). Adjustment. Academic primary care internal medicine practice. Subjects Seven hundred and twelve patients with uncomplicated hypertension. Measurements and Main Results. Recommendations were shown to physicians on computer workstations used to write outpatient orders, and to pharmacists when writing prescriptions. The primary endpoint was overall health-related quality of life. Secondary endpoints were symptom profile and side effects of antihypertensive drugs, number of emergency room visits and hospitalizations, blood pressure measurements, patient satisfaction with physicians and pharmacists, adherence to medication, and healthcare costs. In the control group, care changes were applied in line with the treatment recommendations in 26% of the patients. Adherence to the recommendations was poor in the intervention groups, with 25% of patients given treatment advice only to pharmacists, 29% of patients advised only to physicians, and 35% of patients who received treatment advice. Suggestions were made to both physicians and pharmacists (p=0.13). Differences between groups were neither statistically significant nor clinically significant for overall health-related quality of life, symptom and side-effect profiles, number of emergency room visits and hospitalizations, blood pressure measurements, fees, or medication adherence. Solution. Computer-based intervention using an advanced electronic physician order entry system failed to improve adherence to treatment recommendations or outcomes for patients with uncomplicated hypertension.

title: Fall prevention in acute care hospitals: a randomized trial.
abstract: Context Falls cause injury and death for people of all ages, but the risk of falls increases markedly with age. Hospitalization further increases risk, but there is no evidence to support short-term hospital-based fall prevention strategies to reduce patient falls. Purpose To investigate whether a fall prevention toolkit (FPTK) using health information technology (HIT) can reduce patient falls in hospitals. Ordinary care (4 units and 5104 patients) or intervention (4 units and 5160 patients) at 4 urban US hospitals conducted from January 1, 2009 to June 30, 2009. Intervention FPTK has integrated existing communication and workflow models into the HIT application. Based on a valid fall risk assessment scale completed by a nurse, the FPTK software adapted fall prevention interventions to address specific determinants of patients' fall risk. FPTK has produced short text bed posters with accompanying icons, patient education brochures and care plans, all of which convey patient-specific alerts to key stakeholders. Main Outcome Measures The primary outcome was patient reductions per 1000 patient-days adjusted for region and patient care unit. A secondary outcome was fall-related injuries. Results During the 6-month intervention period, the number of patients with falls differed between control (n = 87) and intervention (n = 67) units (P=.02). Site-adjusted drop rates were significantly higher in control units (4.18 per 1000 patient-days [95% confidence interval {CI}, 3.45-5.06]) than in intervention units (3.15 [95% CI, 2.54-3.90] per 1000 patients). -days"; P = .04). FPTC was found to be particularly effective in patients aged 65 years and older (adjusted rate difference, 2.08 [95% CI, 0.61-3.56] per 1000 patient days;" P = .003). No significant effects were noted in fall-related injuries. Conclusion The use of the fall prevention toolkit in hospital units significantly reduced the fall rate compared to normal care.

title: Requests by family members to extend physiological support after declaration of brain death: a case series analysis and recommended guidelines for clinical management.
abstract: We describe and analyze 13 cases handled by our ethics consultation service (ECS) in which families requested continuation of physiological support for loved ones after death with neurological criteria (DNC). These ethics consultations took place between 2005 and 2013. The ages of the patients ranged from 14 to 85 years. Continuous mechanical ventilation was the focal intervention that all families sought. ECS's advice and recommendations generally supported "reasonable regulation" of claims, balancing compassion for bereaved families with other ethical and moral concerns such as resource management, professional integrity, and moral distress. In what we have characterized as finite goal alignment, a "reasonable fit" strategy has proven effective in balancing stakeholder interests and goals and has led to steady progress towards a solution. When a family directly objected to the DNC statement and requested indefinite compliance, the "reasonable fit" approach gave clinicians little practical direction, and resolution required firm action, either by the family or the clinical team. Based on our analysis and reflection on these 13 cases, we propose ethically justified and practical guidelines to assist healthcare professionals, administrators and ECSs facing similar cases.

title: Family-based interventions to increase physical activity in children: a meta-analysis and realistic synthesis protocol
abstract: INTRODUCTION: Despite the relationship established between physical activity and health, data show that many children are not active enough and these levels decline by adolescence. Involving the family in interventions can increase and maintain children's physical activity levels during the critical preschool period. The synthesis of the available evidence will inform future studies, but the heterogeneity in recruited target populations, the behavior change techniques and intervention strategies used, and the quantification may require a versatile review method. Therefore, the primary aim of this study will be to synthesize the evidence from intervention studies that explicitly engage the family unit to increase children's physical activity, using an innovative dual meta-analysis and a realistic approach. METHODS AND ANALYSIS: Peer-reviewed studies, (1) including 'healthy' participants aged 5-12";" (2) have an important intervention goal to increase physical activity by involving the family; and (3) report on physical activity. Duplicate data extraction and quality assessment will be performed using a specially designed proforma and the Effective Public Health Practice Project Quality Assessment Tool, respectively. STATA software will be used to calculate effect sizes for meta-analyses and subgroup analyzes will be performed to identify moderator characteristics. Realistic syntheses will be conducted according to RAMESES quality and publication guidelines, including the development of a program theory and evidence mapping. DISCLOSURE: This review will be the first to use a traditional review framework to conduct a dual meta-analysis and realistic synthesis by examining family-engaging interventions to increase physical activity in children. Results will be disseminated through peer-reviewed publications, conferences, formal presentations to policy makers and practitioners, and informal meetings. Evidence from this synthesis will also be used to inform the development of theory-based, evidence-based interventions aimed at involving the family to increase children's physical activity levels. PROTOCOL REGISTRATION: International Candidate Register for Systematic Reviews (PROSPERO): number CRD42013005780.

title: Family member DOTS and community DOTS for tuberculosis control in Nepal: a cluster randomized controlled trial.
abstract: Background An important component of the DOTS strategy for tuberculosis control (short course chemotherapy following WHO guidelines) is direct observation of treatment. WHO technical guidelines recommend that healthcare professionals undertake this part of the strategy, but will also accept direct observation of treatment in the community”; WHO does not consider that a family member should take on this role. Supporting evidence for these recommendations is lacking. Nepal national tuberculosis program, healthcare professionals He asked us to develop and test a strategy for direct observation of therapy for the hill regions of Nepal where direct observation of therapy is not possible.We aimed to evaluate the success rates of the two DOTS strategies developed for this purpose.We aimed to evaluate the success rates of the two DOTS strategies for tuberculosis control (short course chemotherapy following WHO guidelines). component is direct observation of treatment. WHO technical guidelines recommend that healthcare professionals undertake this part of the strategy, but will also accept direct observation of treatment in the community; WHO does not consider that a family member should take on this role. There is no supporting evidence for these recommendations. Nepal national tuberculosis program has asked us to develop and test a strategy for direct observation of treatment for hill areas of Nepal where direct observation of treatment by healthcare professionals is not possible. We aimed to evaluate the success rates of two DOTS strategies developed for such areas.

title: Fast-track the design of theory-based KT interventions through a consensus process
abstract: BACKGROUND: Despite the available evidence for optimal management of spinal cord pain, poor adherence to guidelines and wide variability in healthcare persists. One of the goals of the Canadian Chiropractic Guideline Initiative is to develop and evaluate targeted theory and evidence-based interventions by chiropractors to improve the treatment of nonspecific neck pain. To systematically develop a knowledge translation (CT) intervention supported by the Theoretical Domains Framework (TDF), we investigated the factors perceived to influence the use of multimodal care to manage nonspecific neck pain and mapped behavior modification techniques to basic theory. domains. METHODS: Individual telephone interviews investigating beliefs about managing neck pain were conducted with a purposive sample of 13 chiropractors. The interview guide was based on TDF. Interviews were digitally recorded, transcribed verbatim, and analyzed by two independent assessors using thematic content analysis. A 15-member expert panel formally met to design a KT intervention. RESULTS: Nine TDF areas were identified as likely relevant. Core beliefs (and related areas of TDF) included: the impact of formal education, colleagues, and patients on clinicians (Social Influences); availability of educational material (Environmental Context and Resources); and better clinical outcomes reinforcing the use of multimodal care (Reinforcement) Facilitating factors considered important include better communication (Skills), monitoring of patients' treatment outcomes (Behavioral Adjustment), awareness, and agreement with guidelines (Knowledge);" and adapting multimodal care (Memory, Attention and Decision Processes). Clinicians reported conflicting beliefs about perceived threats to professional autonomy (Social/Professional Role and Identity) and speed of recovery from applying or ignoring practice recommendations (Beliefs About Outcomes). The expert panel mapped behavior change techniques to key theoretical areas and identified relevant KT strategies and delivery patterns to increase the use of multimodal care among chiropractors. CONCLUSIONS: A versatile KT training intervention has been developed targeting chiropractors' neck pain treatment. The KT intervention consisted of an online training webinar series, clinical stories, and a video powered by the Short Action Planning model. The intervention is designed to reflect key theoretical areas, behavior modification techniques, and intervention components. The effectiveness of the proposed intervention remains to be tested.

title: Feasibility and acceptability of two incentive-based practice strategies for mental health therapists practicing cognitive-behavioral therapy: a pilot study to inform a randomized controlled trial.
abstract: Background Drawing on our previous work indicating that therapists are not recognized or rewarded for implementing evidence-based practice, we tested the feasibility and acceptability of two incentive-based practice strategies aimed at improving therapist adherence to cognitive-behavioral therapy for youth. It is an evidence-based practice. Methods This study was conducted with therapists (n?=?11) and leaders (n?=?4) in two community mental health institutions for 6 weeks. Therapists were randomized to receive a financial or social incentive when they reached a predetermined criterion for adherence to cognitive-behavioral therapy. During the first intervention period (block 1"; 2 weeks), the therapists received an initially randomly selected reward if they met the criterion. During the second intervention period (block 2;" 2 weeks), the therapists received both rewards when they reached the criterion. . The therapists recorded 41 sessions between 15 different clients over the duration of the project. Primary outcomes included feasibility and acceptability. The feasibility was evaluated quantitatively. Fifteen semi-structured interviews were conducted with therapists and leaders to assess acceptability. The difference in therapist compliance according to conditions was examined as an exploratory result. Compliance ratings were determined using an established and validated observational coding system of cognitive-behavioral therapy. Results Both implementation strategies were feasible and acceptable; however, changes in study design will be required for the larger trial based on participant feedback. Regarding our exploratory analysis, we found a trend suggesting that financial reward may have a stronger effect on therapist commitment than social reward. Conclusions Incentive-based implementation strategies can be implemented in a practicable manner with good acceptability in community mental health institutions, although iterative piloting is necessary. Larger, fully powered trials are needed to compare the effectiveness of practice strategies to encourage and improve therapists' adherence to evidence-based practices such as cognitive-behavioral therapy.

title: Feasibility and impact of computerized clinical decision support system on investigation and initial management of new-onset chest pain: a mixed methods study.
abstract: BACKGROUND: Clinical decision support systems (CDSS) can change clinician behavior, but the factors influencing their effects are not fully understood. This study evaluates the feasibility and acceptability of a CDSS that supports diagnosis and treatment decisions in patients with suspected stable angina. METHODS: The Optimizing Intervention Angina (OMA) program includes a CDSS that guides research and medication decisions for clinicians managing patients with new-onset stable angina based on British national guidelines introduced through an educational intervention. Design and participants Mixed methods study i. A review of outcomes among patients presenting with suspected angina at three UK chest pain clinics before and after implementation of the OMA program. ii. Observations of clinical processes, interviews and a focus group with healthcare professionals at two chest pain clinics after the implementation of the OMA program. RESULTS: Medication and cardiovascular imaging studies performed within six months of presentation and their compliance with CDSS recommendations. Thematic analysis of qualitative data to understand how CDSS is used. RESULTS: Data were analyzed for 285 patients admitted to chest pain clinics: 106 before implementation of the OMA program and 179 after. 40 consultations were observed, met with 5 clinicians, and a focus group was organized after the intervention. The proportion of patients eligible for diagnostic investigation was 50% (95 CI 34-66%) of pre-OMA and 59% (95% CI 48-70%) post-OMA patients. Despite the high use of CDSS (84% of consultations), observations and interviews revealed the difficulties of data entry into CDSS and the structural and practical barriers to its use. In the majority of cases, CDSS was not used to guide real-time decision making, but was consulted only after the patient left the room. CONCLUSIONS: The OMA CDSS for the treatment of chest pain is not available in its current form. CDSS was not used to support decisions about the care of individual patients. A number of barriers to the use of CDSS have been identified, some easily circumvented, such as under-capturing cardiovascular risk, while others are more deeply embedded in current practice, such as the lack of some research or prescribing privileges for nurses.

title: Feasibility of conducting a randomized controlled telemental health study with children diagnosed with attention deficit/hyperactivity disorder in underserved populations
abstract: OBJECTIVE: Telemental health (TMH), the use of video teleconferencing to provide often personally delivered care, is increasingly being used to address inequalities in access to care. However, few studies have been conducted to demonstrate the effectiveness of TMH as a service delivery model. The Children's Attention-Deficit/Hyperactivity Disorder (ADHD) Telemental Health Treatment Trial (CATTS) is a randomized clinical trial (RCT) of TMH conducted in multiple underserved populations. This article reports the feasibility of TMH to experiment with an activity with children. METHODS: The CATTS trial used video teleconferencing to provide secure websites to provide guideline-based care and coordinate key aspects of trial implementation, such as participant recruitment and retention, response accuracy, and completion of assessments. RESULTS: The CATTS study co-involved seven communities and 150 primary care providers and enrolled 223 children aged 5.5-12.9 years. The intervention group completed an average of 5.3 of the 6.0 scheduled sessions, and 96% of the controls completed a TMH consultation. Both groups completed an average of 4.8 of the 5.0 assessments. Clinicians demonstrated high fidelity to treatment protocols. Minor technical difficulties did not hinder the provision of care. RESULTS: The CATTS study demonstrated the feasibility of conducting a TMH RCT with children living in multiple underserved communities. Telecommunications technologies can facilitate coordination of research activities between sites and clinicians. Future research should work closely with study partners to ensure that a representative study sample is referred. More trials are needed to help establish the effectiveness of TMH as a service delivery model. TRIAL REGISTRATION: http://clinicaltrials.gov/show/NCT00830700 .

title: Feasibility study of a communication and education asthma intervention for general practitioners in Australia
abstract: The Physician Asthma Care Education (PACE) program has significantly improved the asthma prescribing and communication behaviors of primary care pediatricians in the US. We tested the feasibility and acceptability of a modified PACE program with Australian general practitioners (GPs) and measured its impact on self-reported counseling behaviors in a pilot study. Recruitment took place through a local GP division. Twenty-five GPs completed two PACE Australia workshops that focused on effective communication strategies and included pediatric asthma management in line with Australian asthma guidelines. The applicability, usefulness, and perceived usefulness of the program were measured by questionnaires before and 1 month after the workshop, and an evaluation questionnaire after each workshop. GP was universally enthusiastic and supportive of the workshops. The most helpful elements they reported were communication skills, case studies, device demonstrations, and the toolkit provided. GP, perceived usefulness of key communication strategies and self-reports on their implementation and reported frequency of use increased significantly after the workshops. The PACE program shows promise in improving the way the Australian GP manages asthma consultations, particularly with regard to doctor-patient communication. The impact of the modified PACE Australia program on family medicine care processes and outcomes for children with asthma is now being measured in a randomized controlled trial.

title: Feasibility, accuracy, and clinical impact of the point-of-care Xpert MTB/RIF assay for tuberculosis in primary care settings in Africa: a multicenter, randomized, controlled trial.
abstract: Background The Xpert MTB/RIF test for tuberculosis is implemented in many countries, but there is no evidence for its application outside of laboratories, the ability to report same-day treatment decisions at the point of care, and its clinical impact on tuberculosis-related morbidity. We aimed to evaluate the feasibility, accuracy and clinical impact of point-of-care Xpert MTB/RIF testing in primary care facilities in South Africa.";" Background The Xpert MTB/RIF test for tuberculosis is implemented in many countries, but there is no evidence for its application outside of laboratories, the ability to report same-day treatment decisions at the point of care, and its clinical impact on tuberculosis-related morbidity. We aimed to evaluate the feasibility, accuracy and clinical impact of point-of-care Xpert MTB/RIF testing in primary care facilities in South Africa.

title: Feedback as a strategy to change behavior: the devil is in the details
abstract: BACKGROUND: Performance feedback is one of a number of strategies used to improve clinical practice among students and clinicians. OBJECTIVES: The aims of this document were to examine the conceptual foundations and key components for auditing and feedback strategies, to evaluate the extent to which recently published audit and feedback interventions include these components, and to propose future guidelines for feedback to improve its educational and behavioral impact. . METHODS: Based on the actionable feedback model, we examined the existence of four theoretical constructs – timeliness, individualisation, lack of punishment, and customizability – in studies published in 2009–2010 that included a feedback intervention. RESULTS: There was wide variation in the definition, implementation and outcomes of 'feedback' interventions, making comparisons between studies difficult. None of the studies we reviewed included all components of the actionable feedback model. CONCLUSIONS: Feedback interventions reported to date often do not include concepts of behavior change, even if the results are positive. This may partly explain the great diversity in approaches and outcomes of such interventions and presents great challenges to replicate any intervention. Some standardization and certainly more clarity is needed in the specific action steps taken to apply behavioral theory to practice if feedback processes are to be used and disseminated and applied widely.

title: Fibromyalgia treatment update
abstract: Purpose of Review: Fibromyalgia is a common chronic pain disorder characterized by complex symptomatology and few consistent effective treatments. The purpose of this review is to highlight the recent literature covering treatment options from April 2005 to September 2006. RECENT FINDINGS: Previous evidence suggests that care-oriented drug therapy and self-management approaches may improve symptoms, function, and well-being in this patient population. Recent studies examining the efficacy of two serotonin and norepinephrine reuptake inhibitors—duloxetine and milnacipran—and the anticonvulsant pregabalin are encouraging. Studies evaluating different forms of exercise continue to support the belief that increased physical activity is an important component of any treatment plan for the patient with fibromyalgia. Three studies were added to the understanding of adherence to treatment. Finally, three studies evaluating the effectiveness of acupuncture in the treatment of fibromyalgia showed conflicting results, but added to the information clinicians need to have meaningful conversations with patients. SUMMARY: Recent studies support the recommendation for a multimodal approach to treatment that includes individualized, evidence-based pharmacotherapy and self-administration. Treatment goals should include improving symptoms, particularly pain and sleep, and promoting positive health behaviors to improve physical function and emotional well-being.

title: Financial incentives to quit smoking during pregnancy: randomized controlled trial
abstract: PURPOSE To evaluate the effectiveness of financial incentives added to routine specialist pregnancy smoking cessation services versus routine care to help pregnant smokers quit. DESIGN Phase II therapeutic discovery single-center, individual randomized controlled parallel group superiority trial. SETTING A large medical board area with a financially deprived inner-city population in the west of Scotland, UK. PARTICIPANTS 612, NHS Greater Glasgow and Clyde, English speaking, at least 16 years old, less than 24 weeks pregnant and pregnant smokers with an exhaled carbon monoxide breath test result of 7 ppm or more. 306 women were randomized to incentives and 306 to controls. INTERVENTIONS Routine care for the control group, face-to-face meeting to quit and quit smoking, 10 weeks of free nicotine replacement therapy from pharmacy services to those who attended and set a quit date, and four weeks of support phone calls. The intervention group was offered routine care plus up to £400 shopping vouchers: £50 to attend a face-to-face appointment and set a drop off date"; then another £50 if four years later confirmed exhaled carbon monoxide after quit date weeks later ; after 12 weeks an additional "£100" for continued confirmed deprivation of exhaled carbon monoxide; a final "£200" voucher provided for confirmed exhaled carbon monoxide MAIN OUTCOME MEASURE Primary outcome, 34-38. Confirmed release of cotinine via saliva (<14.2 ng/mL) or urine (<44.7 ng/mL) at gestational week. Secondary outcomes are birth weight, engagement, and self-reported quitting at 4 weeks. RESULTS Recruitment to achieve target sample size 12 months to 15 weeks. extended to one month Follow-up continued until September 2013 Three of 306 randomized women went out of control soon after enrollment; these women did not want their data to be used, leavin g 306 intervention and 303 control group participants were analyzed with intent to treat. No harm from financial incentives has been documented. Significantly more smokers in the incentive group than the control group quit: 69 (22.5%) versus 26 (8.6%). The relative risk of not smoking at the end of pregnancy was 2.63 (95% confidence interval 1.73 to 4.01) P<0.001. The absolute risk difference was 14.0% (95% confidence interval 8.2% to 19.7%). The number to be treated (in cases where financial incentives must be offered to obtain a late pregnancy survivor) was 7.2 (95% confidence interval 5.1 to 12.2). Mean birth weight was 3140 g (SD 600 g) in the incentive group and 3120 (SD 590) g in the control group (P=0.67). CONCLUSION This phase II randomized controlled trial provides substantial evidence for the effectiveness of incentives to quit smoking during pregnancy; “As this is only a single center trial, incentives must now be tested in different types of contraception services and in different parts of the UK. TRIAL REGISTRATION Controlled Trials Available ISRCTN87508788.

title: FIRE (facilitating the application of research evidence): a study protocol
abstract: Background Research evidence supports best practice, but is not always used in healthcare. The Promoting Action on Research Practice in Healthcare (PARIHS) framework suggests that the nature of the evidence, the context in which it is used, and whether those trying to use evidence are assisted (or facilitated) influence evidence use. Urinary incontinence has a significant impact on the quality of life of older people, has a high prevalence and is a key priority in European health and social care policy. Improving continence care has the potential to improve quality of life for older people and reduce the costs associated with providing incontinence aids. Objectives This study aims to improve understanding of the contribution that facilitation can make to putting research findings into practice: to expand existing facilitation knowledge as a process to translate research evidence into practice; assessing the feasibility, effectiveness and cost-effectiveness of two different methods Facilitation models to encourage the acquisition of research evidence on continence management; assessing the impact of contextual factors on implementation processes and outcomes; and implement a proactive strategy of knowledge transfer and dissemination to disseminate study findings to the broad policy and practice community. Establishment and sample Four European countries, each with six long-term nursing care centers (24 regions in total) for persons aged 60 and over with documented urinary incontinence Methods and design Tri-arm (standard dissemination and two different treatment programmes) facilitation), embedded process and economic with evaluation. The primary outcome is compliance with continence recommendations. Secondary outcomes include the proportion of residents with incontinence, the incidence of incontinence-related dermatitis, urinary tract infections, and quality of life. Outcomes are evaluated at baseline, then at 6, 12, 18, and 24 months after the start of facilitation interventions. Detailed contextual and process data is collected through interviews with staff, residents and relatives, observations, assessment of context using the Alberta Context Tool, and documentary evidence. A realistic evaluation framework is used to develop explanatory theory about what works for whom under what circumstances.

title: The first online study of an international multidisciplinary working group (MightyMedic) on current practices in the diagnosis, treatment and follow-up of dyslipidemias.
abstract: The MightyMedic (Multidisciplinary International Hemapheresis Treatment and Contrast Group for Metabolic Disorders) Working Group was established in 2013. The main idea was to establish an international interdisciplinary network for research projects, clinical trials and educational initiatives that cross national borders. meetings, workshops, summer schools) in the field of metabolic diseases, ie hyperlipidemias and diabetes, preventive cardiology and atherosclerosis. Therapeutic apheresis, indications and techniques is a parallel research area. The group's first online survey was completed in the first half of 2014. The survey included Center 24 in Italy, Germany, Greece, England, Sweden, Japan and the USA. Relevant data were collected on current practices in the diagnosis, treatment and follow-up of dyslipidemias. The survey reported 240 subjects with hyperlipidemia and treated with lipoprotein apheresis, but a large percentage (35%) of patients who could benefit from this therapeutic option are still treated with the conventional drug approach. While only 33% of patients had a genetic molecular diagnosis, 71% of participating Centers included Lipoprotein(a) (Lp(a)) in the cardiovascular disease risk assessment. New detailed studies and prospective multicenter studies are needed to evaluate the changes caused by the impact of new treatment options as well as the impact of updated indications and strategies, aiming at the standardization of therapeutic and diagnostic approaches.

title: Early psychosis: a window of opportunity for best practices
abstract: Patients experiencing a first psychotic episode or early stages of psychosis face important diagnostic challenges for clinicians. During the presentation of first episode psychosis, it is crucial for clinicians to select the most effective treatment option because immediate intervention offers the best chance of controlling the disease. It is also important to choose the best treatment option during this period, because functional deterioration occurs most rapidly in this early period, which may alter the patient's future prognosis, the level of treatment required, and affect morbidity. Although research has shown a reduction in brain gray matter in people who develop psychosis and have symptoms of functional impairment, many patients with psychosis do not seek treatment and visit a clinician for a long time because of denial, fear of stigma, inadequacy. recognize the problem or complexity of maintenance systems. Previous studies have shown that when the psychosis is untreated, the patient outcome is worse during the course of the illness than if the psychosis was previously treated. There are a number of treatment options available for the treatment of psychosis, including the use of first-generation or second-generation antipsychotic drugs. Clinicians should keep in mind that both types of drugs are associated with certain side effects, such as tardive dyskinesia and weight gain, respectively. For both types of drugs, doses should be lower in patients with a first psychotic episode than in patients with chronic psychosis. Finally, patients may present with various comorbidities that may affect treatment, such as substance abuse. This specialist roundtable supplement will address diagnosis and choice of treatment of first-stage psychosis, as well as comorbidities associated with the condition. The use of first- or second-generation antipsychotics for the treatment of psychosis, dosing guidelines, and the antipsychotic side-effect profile will also be discussed.

title: Format change of a lab test order form affects physician behavior
abstract: OBJECTIVE: Our study was designed to find out whether a change in the physician's lab test sequence could be achieved with the simple strategy of changing the setup of a lab order form with checkbox embedded in a computerized medical record. METHODS: This prospective intervention study was conducted at Maccabi Healthcare Services, a Preferred Provider Organization that has used computerized medical records since 1992. We analyzed data from 865 primary care physicians over 3 years. In May 2005 we changed the order form and reduced the number of tests that can be ordered using a checkbox form from 51 to 26. Twenty-seven tests were removed from the form and two tests were added. The total number of laboratory test orders and the median proportion of test orders per visit to the physician during each study period were calculated for each test separately. RESULTS: The tests added to the computerized laboratory order form increased by 60.7% in the first year and by 90% in the following year. For the unchanged tests, the percentages of change in the same periods were +18.4 and 22.4%. The change for the deleted tests was -27% and -19.2% for the respective years. CONCLUSIONS: Changes in the format of laboratory test order forms can be useful in conjunction with other interventions to improve the compliance of laboratory tests by the physician, which can change the test order. A carefully constructed test order form can strengthen clinical guidelines for the performance of some preventive testing and follow-up.

title: Formative assessment of practice changes to manage depression within a Shared Care model in primary care
abstract: Purpose To explore the application and initial impact of Physician Integrated Network (PIN) mental health indicators specific to managing screening and follow-up for depression in three primary care practices with Shared Mental Health Care in Manitoba. BACKGROUND: In 2006, Manitoba Health undertook a primary care replacement initiative called PIN, which involved the development of specific mental health indicators to manage screening and follow-up for depression. These indicators were implemented in Manitoba at three PIN group enforcement sites that are also part of the Joint Mental Health Services. METHODS: The design was a non-experimental longitudinal design. A formative assessment explored the application and initial impact of mental health indicators using mixed methods (document review, questionnaire, and interview). Quantitative data were searched using descriptive and comparative statistics, and content and theme analysis of the qualitative interviews was carried out. Questionnaire responses were obtained from 32 of 36 physicians from three centers. Interviews were held with 15 providers. Results This assessment revealed service providers' perceived attitudes, knowledge, skills, and behaviors regarding recognizing and treating depression and broadened our understanding of primary care processes for managing depression in relation to the implementation of a new intervention. Depression is seen as an important problem in primary care practice that takes time for diagnosis, treatment and treatment and requires further research. The application of PIN mental health indicators was variable between sites and providers. There has been an increase in the use of indicators over time and there is a general consensus that the benefits of screening outweigh the costs";" however, the benefit of screening for depression remains unclear. Consistent with current guidelines, a question raised by the findings of this review is whether there are more effective ways of making an impact on depression in primary care than screening.

title: Promoting the application of health care research findings: a unified framework for advancing applied science
abstract: Background Many interventions found to be effective in healthcare research studies cannot be translated into meaningful patient care outcomes in more than one context. Health care researchers recognize the need to evaluate not only summative outcomes but also formative outcomes in order to assess the extent to which practice is effective in a given setting, prolonging sustainability, and promoting diffusion into other settings. Many practice theories have been published to help promote effective practice. However, they overlap significantly in the structures contained in the individual theories, and comparison of the theories reveals that each is missing the important structures contained in the other theories. Also, terminology and definitions are not consistent across theories. We describe the Consolidated Framework for Application Research (CFIR), which offers a comprehensive typology to encourage application theory development and validation of what works where and why in multiple contexts. Methods We used a snowball sampling approach to identify published theories that were evaluated to identify constructs based on the strength of conceptual or empirical support for impact on practice, consistency in definitions, agreement with our own findings, and potential for measurement. We combined constructs between published theories that had different labels but were either redundant or overlapped in definition, and we parsed constructs that combined key concepts. Outcomes CFIR consists of five main areas: response characteristics, external environment, internal environment, characteristics of the individuals involved, and the implementation process. Eight constructs related to the intervention were identified (eg, strength and quality of evidence), four constructs related to the external environment (eg, patient needs and resources), 12 constructs related to the internal environment (eg, culture, leadership involvement), five constructs related to individual characteristics were identified and eight process-related constructs were identified (eg, plan, evaluate, and reflect). We provide clear definitions for each structure. Conclusion CFIR provides a pragmatic framework for approaching the complex, interactive, multi-level, and transient states of real-world structures by embracing, consolidating, and combining fundamental structures from published application theories. It can be used to guide formative assessments and build a knowledge base of practice across multiple studies and settings.

title: Founder and Recurrent CDH1 Mutations in Families with Hereditary Diffuse Gastric Cancer
abstract: Context Hereditary disseminated gastric cancer is caused by germline mutations in the epithelial cadherin (CDH1) gene and is characterized by an increased risk for disseminated gastric cancer and lobular breast cancer. Purpose To determine whether recurrent germline CDH1 mutations result from independent mutational events or from a common ancestor. Design, Environment, and Patients Thirty-eight families diagnosed with clinically inherited diffuse gastric cancer were accrued between November 2004 and January 2006 and analyzed for CDH1 mutations as part of an ongoing study at the British Columbia Cancer Agency. Twenty-six families had at least 2 cases of gastric cancer and 1 common case of gastric cancer in a person younger than 50";" In 12 families, there was either a single case of common stomach cancer diagnosed in someone younger than 35, or multiple cases of common stomach cancer diagnosed in people older than 50. Main Outcome Criteria Classification of family members as carriers or non-carriers of CDH1 mutations. To evaluate recurrent mutations for the common ancestor, haplotype analysis was performed on 7 families from this study and 7 previously reported families with the same mutations. Results Thirteen mutations (6 new) were detected in 15 of 38 families (40% detection rate). The 1137G>A splicing mutation and the 1901C>T (A634V) missense/splicing mutation occurred in shared haplotypes in 2 families, but different haplotypes in a third family. The 2195G>A (R732Q) missense/splicing mutation occurred in 2 families with different haplotypes. The 2064-2065delTG mutation occurred in a shared haplotype in 2 families. Two families from this study plus 2 additional families carrying the novel 2398delC mutation shared a common haplotype, suggesting a founder effect. All 4 families hail from the southeast coast of Newfoundland. Due to the high incidence of lobular breast cancer, 2 branches of this family were diagnosed with hereditary breast cancer and tested for BRCA mutations. Within these 4 families, the cumulative risk for clinically detected gastric cancer in carriers of the mutation up to age 75 years was 40% (95% confidence interval [CI], 12-91%) and 63% (95% CI, 19%) for males. was. for females -99%) and female mutation carriers had a 52% (95% CI, 29-94%) risk of breast cancer. Conclusions Recurrent CDH1 mutations in families with hereditary disseminated gastric cancer result from both independent mutational events and a common ancestry. The existence of a founder mutation from Newfoundland is strongly supported.

title: Framework for direct monitoring of performance and safety in healthcare
Framework for quality improvement in pharmaceutical services -- a bridge to bridge the quality gap. Part I. Opportunity and tool
abstract: OBJECTIVE: To review the literature on quality improvement principles and methods applied to pharmacy services and to define a framework for current and future efforts in quality improvement and effective drug therapy management in pharmacy services. BACKGROUND: The Academy of Managed Care Pharmacy produced the Pharmacy Quality Indicators Catalogue in 1997, followed by the National Summary of Pharmacy Quality Measures in February 1999. In April 2002, AMCP introduced Pharmacy's Framework for Management of Drug Therapy in the 21st Century. The framework documents include a self-assessment tool detailing more than 250 specific "components" that identify tasks, behaviors, skills, functions, duties, and responsibilities that contribute to meeting client expectations for effective medication management. RESULTS: There are many opportunities for quality improvement in clinical, service, and cost outcomes associated with drug therapy management. These include "patient safety"; incidence of medical errors; adverse drug events; patient adherence to treatment; achievement of targeted goals such as blood pressure, glucose, and lipid levels; risk reduction for adverse cardiac events and osteoporotic-related fractures; patient satisfaction; risk of hospitalization or death; " and maintenance cost. Health care practitioners may experience (a) a better patient outcome at the same cost, (b) the same patient outcome at a lower cost, (c) a better patient outcome at a lower cost, or (d) a significantly better outcome at a moderately higher cost. a patient outcome. Measurement enables effective management. A framework of component factors (eg tasks) is needed to facilitate changes in key processes and critical factors that will help individual practitioners and health care systems meet client expectations for drug therapy and thereby improve these outcomes. CONCLUSIONS: Quality improvement in healthcare in the United States will be made through incremental changes based on a structure-process-result model. The structure is provided by evidence from controlled randomized trials and other scientific method-based studies of care and systems outcomes. The process part is created by applying evidence in the form of clinical practice guidelines, clinical practice models, and self-assessment tools such as the Pharmacy's Medication Management Framework. Gradual changes in structure and process will result in the desired outcome of meeting client needs for more effective drug therapy and disease management.

title: Framing options as choices or opportunities: does the framework influence decisions?
abstract: Aim. Healthcare professionals should present all options in an impartial manner, enabling patients to make informed decisions about their healthcare choices. This study examined whether the decision in the context of trial participation for cancer treatment is presented as an "opportunity" rather than the preferences of individuals with "choice" bias. Methods Self-selected healthy women (N = 124) were randomly assigned to the following decision frames: opportunity to participate in the trial (opt-in), opportunity to opt out of the trial (opt-out), and option to standardize treatment or take part in the trial (choice). The computer-based task required women to make a hypothetical choice about a real-world cancer treatment trial. The software presented the framed scenario, recorded the first choice, presented comprehensive and balanced information, monitored the participants' information use during decision making, and recorded the final decision. A post-task paper questionnaire assessed perceived risk, attitudes, subjective norm, perceived behavioral control, and satisfaction with the decision. Results. Framing affected women's immediate choices. Opportunity frames, whether to participate or to opt out, created a bias as they discouraged women from choosing standard treatment. Using the marquee avoided this bias. The opt-out opportunity framework also impacted women's perceived social norms";" women felt that others approved of the option to try. Framing bias was absent when participants had the opportunity to see detailed information about options within a patient decision aid format. There were no group differences in information acquisition and final decisions. Sixteen percent changed their first choice after receiving full information. Results. A 'choice' framework in which all treatment options are open is less likely to influence choices. Presenting complete information in a parallel, feature-based format is likely to “eliminate bias” in the decision framework. Tailoring information to initial preferences is not recommended, as preferences may change after detailed information.

title: Fraud and abuse in clinical trials
Fraud and abuse in clinical trials: does it harm patient safety?
From clinical evidence to daily practice: applying findings from a cost-effectiveness analysis for endoscopic injection therapy for upper gastrointestinal bleeding
abstract: BACKGROUND: A previous upper gastrointestinal bleeding trial showed that patients treated with recurrent injections of fibrin glue for upper gastrointestinal bleeding had significantly less rebleeding than those treated with polidocanol. OBJECTIVE: To analyze the cost and effectiveness of repetitive fibrin glue injection and to investigate whether these results change physicians' attitudes. DESIGN: A retrospective random sample of five hospitals from the previous study, aggregation of the cost description, and follow-up data on 320 patients (155 in the polidocanol group, 165 in the fibrin glue group). METHODS: An incremental cost-effectiveness analysis and comparison of results was performed using chi-square tests and Kaplan-Meier survival analysis. A survey was conducted using a questionnaire on local guidelines for the management of ulcer bleeding in five hospitals and the results were analyzed qualitatively. The measure of effectiveness is the number of rebleeds avoided. Other variables were length of hospital stay and length of stay in the intensive care unit (ICU). RESULTS: The cost of preventing one additional rebleeding with repeated fibrin sealant treatment is 14,316 +/- 4981 Euros (increased cost-effectiveness ratio). There was no significant difference in length of stay in the intensive care unit or hospital. Physicians did not change their management plan for patients with upper gastrointestinal bleeding. One survey found that other factors, such as local guidelines, attitudes towards new treatment options, and ease of use of drugs, were more important to physicians' behavior change than the outcome of a single study. CONCLUSIONS: The study was not designed to address a pharmacoeconomic question prospectively. This may lead to biased estimates of the increased cost-effectiveness ratio, as the relevant variables (eg, length of stay in the intensive care unit) cannot be reliably determined retrospectively.

title: From evidence to expertise: compliance in the topical treatment of psoriasis
abstract: Vulgar psoriasis is a chronic and intermittent inflammatory cutaneous-systemic disease. Its etiology is not fully defined and the risk of comorbidity affecting the quality of life of patients is higher. The aims of this trial were to "align the clinical practice of the pharmacological treatment of plaque psoriasis with the Guia de Practica Clinica (GPC)" and a group of Mexican dermatologists specializing in the topical treatment of psoriasis, as well as weighing the relevance and knowledge of quality of life and adherence to treatment. A Delphi questionnaire was administered to 30 specialists to explore their therapeutic behaviors and attitudes towards the evaluation of the patient. A meeting was held with a subgroup of 10 dermatologists to analyze the results. A second survey was conducted to distinguish between decisions made for topical treatment in institutional and private practice, as well as other substances not discovered in the first questionnaire. The questionnaire was answered.After analyzing the results of the questionnaire, it was clear that the data published in the Guia de Practica Clinica and the prescriptive position of the experts were consistent with regard to the topical treatment of plaque psoriasis.The use of vitamin D analogues and corticosteroids in the private practice is better. There is also consensus among physicians in private and institutional medical care regarding the attitude to drug prescriptions, although salicylic acid is widely used and is replacing corticosteroids in institutions.

title: From hypertension control to global cardiovascular risk management: an educational intervention in a clustered randomized controlled trial.
abstract: BACKGROUND: Guidelines for hypertension management recommend that treatment efforts be adjusted for global cardiovascular risk (CVR) rather than blood pressure levels alone. However, this paradigm shift has not yet reached German General Practice. We evaluated the impact of an educational outreach visit with general practitioners (GPs) and encouraged them to consider CVR in treatment decisions for patients with hypertension. METHODS: Prospective cluster randomized study involving 3443 patients with known hypertension treated by 87 GPs. Applications were randomly assigned to either complex (A) or simple (B) intervention. Both groups received a guide by mail";" Group A also received complex peer intervention supporting the global concept of CVR. Clinical data were collected at baseline and 6-9 months after intervention. The main outcome was improvement in the calculated CVR in a predefined subpopulation of patients with a high CVR (10-year mortality >/=5%) but without significant cardiovascular disease. RESULTS: The baseline follow-up CVR was 13.1% (95% CI 12.6-13.6%) (A) and 12.6% (95% CI 12.2-13.1%) (B) with group difference (A vs. A). B) 0.5% (-0.2%-1.1%), p = 0.179. The group difference was -0.05% in GP patients familiar with global CVR and 1.1% in GP patients unfamiliar with global CVR. However, this change in effect was not significant (p = 0.165). When pooled over the groups, the absolute CVR reduction from baseline was 1.0%, p < 0.001. The ICC was 0.026 (p = 0.002). Hypertension control (BP <140/90 mmHg) improved from 38.1% to 45.9% in the complex intervention group and from 35.6% to 46.5% in the simple intervention group in the same subpopulation, with adjusted follow-up control rates of 46.7% (95) % CI 40.4%-53.1% (A) and 46.9% (95% CI 40.3%-53.5% (B) and 0.99 (95% CI 0.68-1), 45) an adjusted odds ratio (A - B), p = 0.966 RESULTS: Our complex education intervention, including a clinical outreach visit, had a significant effect on the CVR of patients with hypertension who are known to be at high risk compared to a simple postal intervention. TRIAL REGISTRATION: ISRCTN44478543 .

title: The interdisciplinary integrated care of the child with autism: the fundamental role of a code of ethics
abstract: Various disciplines have come to the fore in intervention programs to address the developmental deficiencies of children with autism. These are speech pathologists, psychologists/counselors, occupational therapists/physical therapists, special education counselors, behavioral analysts, and doctors/medical staff. As the field of autism therapy moves towards a more comprehensive, holistic and interdisciplinary model, the complexity of an interdisciplinary model of service delivery can present significant challenges. The difficulty of taking this approach can lead to the creation of below-average programs. Ethical principles and language common to all contributing disciplines are discussed as appropriate integrative forces, as integration across disciplines is a requirement. An outline of these principles and a draft code of ethics are provided to provide high standards and expectations for everyone participating in such a program.

title: From protocol to practice: transforming clinical data into clinical practice
abstract: Clinicians should be prepared to treat individual patients based on evidence-based risk assessments. However, ethnic minorities, the elderly, and women were underrepresented in large-scale studies, so data to support clinical decisions for patients in these groups may be lacking. A notable example is the Framingham Heart Study, with a study population comprised of an almost homogeneous population from a small American town. Obviously, future studies should include more representative samples from these populations. Meanwhile, Adult Treatment Panel III guidelines should be applied in all areas.

title: Self-treatment from specialist care
Functional Recovery After Myocardial Infarction in Men: Independent Effects of Social Class
abstract: Background: Social class has been repeatedly associated with cardiovascular disease and death, but no studies have examined the effect of social class on recovery from myocardial infarction. In addition, few studies have simultaneously evaluated a wide array of demographic, clinical, and psychosocial factors that may affect health outcomes after myocardial infarction. Objective: To determine whether social class is independently associated with functional recovery after myocardial infarction, even after clinical control. Demographic and psychosocial factors known to affect post-infarction outcomes. Design: Analysis of prospective data from a multicenter, randomized, double-blind clinical trial. Setting: Attack Trial, including 25 hospital or clinical setting Health Insurance Plan substudies participating in Beta Blocker Heart in the United States and Canada. Patients: 2145 men aged 29 to 69 years hospitalized with acute myocardial infarction and enrolled in the Beta-Blocker Heart Attack Trial. Measurements: The primary outcome was change in the New York Heart Association. The functional class difference between baseline assessment and 12 months later was divided into improved or undeveloped (ie no change, decline in at least one category, or death). Results: Social class maintained its independent influence on improved functional status even after controlling for relevant prognostic factors. At 1 year after infarction, people from high social class were significantly more likely to have better functional status than people from low or middle social class. Some clinical, demographic, and psychosocial features were associated with improvement, but the effect of social class could not be explained by these additional features. Conclusions: Social class has a significant influence on recovery from myocardial infarction and may explain the differences in clinical outcomes.

title: Functional Somatic Syndromes
abstract: The term functional somatic syndrome has been applied to several associated syndromes characterized by symptoms, suffering, and disability rather than the tissue abnormality that can be consistently demonstrated. These syndromes include multiple chemical sensitivities, sick building syndrome, repetitive stress injury, side effects of silicone breast implants, Gulf War syndrome, chronic whiplash, chronic fatigue syndrome, irritable bowel syndrome, and fibromyalgia. Patients with functional somatic syndromes have clear and highly detailed self-diagnoses, and their symptoms are often resistant to reassurance, explanation, and standard treatment of symptoms. They share similar phenomenology, high rates of association, similar epidemiological features, and higher-than-expected prevalence of psychiatric comorbidities. Although some patients with functional somatic syndrome may eventually have discrete pathophysiological causes, their suffering is exacerbated by a self-perpetuating, self-affirming cycle in which common, endemic, somatic symptoms are incorrectly attributed to serious abnormalities. The patient's belief that he or she has a serious illness. Four psychosocial factors drive this cycle of symptom amplification: the person's belief that they have a serious illness; the expectation that the person's condition will worsen; the "sick role", including the effects of litigation and compensation; and the eerie portrayal of the situation as catastrophic and crippling. The climate surrounding functional somatic syndromes It includes sensational media coverage, deep suspicion of medical expertise and doctors, the mobilization of parties with self-interest in the status of functional somatic syndromes, litigation, and a clinical approach that overemphasizes biomedical factors and ignores psychosocial factors. exacerbates and perpetuates their distress, heightens their fears and pessimistic expectations, prolongs their disability, and reinforces patient roles.A six-step strategy for helping patients with functional somatic syndromes is presented here.

title: gastroesophageal reflux disease
abstract: Heartburn 2 or more days a week requires medical attention as patients are likely to suffer from gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD). Chronic GERD can lead to the development of complications such as erosive esophagitis, stricture formation and Barrett's esophagus, which increase the risk of esophageal adenocarcinoma. A trial with a proton pump inhibitor (PPI) is the fastest and most cost-effective way to diagnose GERD and is at least as accurate as 24-hour intraoesophageal pH monitoring. Because PPIs only bind to actively secreting proton pumps, they should be dosed 30 to 60 minutes before meals. Despite these recommendations, a recent survey of more than 1,000 US primary care physicians found that 36% of patients instructed their patients to take a PPI with or after a meal, or did not specify the timing of dosing. Patients who will respond best to surgical treatment for GERD are those who have clearly documented acid reflux with typical symptoms and respond to PPI therapy. Unfortunately, the same survey found that most doctors recommend antireflux surgery for patients for whom medical treatment has failed.

title: General practice fundraising
Information seeking strategies for general practice trainees' clinical queries encountered in daily practice
abstract: BACKGROUND: Previous research has shown that clinical inquiries are common among physicians. Data on the information-seeking behavior of general practice (GP) trainees are scarce and the numbers studied are small. OBJECTIVE: The aim of this study was to determine how often and how GP trainees seek answers to clinical questions encountered in daily clinical practice. METHODS: Third-year GP trainees kept records of all patient contacts for eight consecutive practice days. Information was obtained about patient contacts (description), clinical inquiries (frequency, type), search behavior (frequency, moment, reason for not calling, resources used, search duration), and responses (frequency, effect). Descriptive analyzes performed";" frequencies and percentages were calculated. We calculated the number of clinical queries per patient, the number of searches per query, and the number of responses per search. RESULTS: Seventy-six trainees reported 1533 clinical queries on 7300 patients with 7619 complaints [mean 0.2 queries per patient, standard deviation (SD) 0.1]. For most of the queries, trainees sought an answer (mean 0.8 per query, SD 0.2) mostly during consultation (61% of searches), and frequent responses (mean 0.8 per call, SD 0.17) reported improving clinical decision, making 26%. The most common sources were colleagues or supervisors (28%) and national GP guidelines (26%). The median duration of a call was 4 minutes (interquartile range 3). CONCLUSION: GP trainees have one clinical inquiry for every five patients. They often tried to find answers and reported that they were successful in most of the searches, especially in consultation with their superiors or colleagues and national GP guidelines.

title: General practitioner views on the determinants of test order: a theory-based qualitative approach to the development of an intervention to improve immunoglobulin demands in primary care.
abstract: BACKGROUND: Research suggests that variation in laboratory demanding patterns may indicate unnecessary test use. Demand patterns for serum immunoglobulins vary considerably among general practitioners (GPs). This study aims to explore GP's views on testing to identify determinants of behavior and to suggest appropriate intervention strategies to improve the use of immunoglobulin testing in primary care. METHODS: Qualitative semi-structured interviews were conducted with GPs requesting laboratory tests at University Hospital Cork or University Hospital Kerry in Southern Ireland. GPs were determined using the Healthcare Executive lab list of GPs in the Cork-Kerry area. A random sample of GPs (stratified according to GP claiming patterns) was generated from this list. GPs, location (urban/rural)"; length of time they were qualified;" consciously sampled according to the criteria. and application size (one-handed/group). The interviews were conducted between December 2014 and February 2015. The interviews were transcribed verbatim using NVivo 10 software and analyzed using the frame analysis method. The resulting themes were paired with the theoretical domain framework (TDF), which outlined 12 domains that could enable or inhibit behavior change. The behavior modification wheel and behavior modification technique (BCT) classification were then used to identify potential intervention strategies. RESULTS: Sixteen practitioners were interviewed (ten men and six women). The findings suggest that intervention strategies should specifically target key barriers to effective test sequencing, taking into account the context of primary care practice. Seven domains from the TDF were perceived to influence immunoglobulin test ordering behaviors and were described as 'mechanisms of change' (knowledge, environmental context and resources, social/professional role and identity, beliefs about abilities, beliefs about outcomes, memory, attention, and decision). - making processes and behavioral regulation). Using these TDF domains, seven BCTs emerged as appropriate 'intervention content' to target GPs' ordering behavior. These include how to order the test effectively (how to conduct behavior), information about GPs' use of the test (feedback on behavior), information about patient outcomes as a result of not performing the test (information about health outcomes), laboratory/consultant-based advice/education ( reliable source), modifying the test order form (reconfiguring the physical environment), providing guidelines (prompts/tips), and adding interpretative comments to the results (adding objects to the environment). These BCTs are aligned with four intervention functions: education, persuasion, environmental restructuring, and activation. CONCLUSIONS: This study effectively applied behavior modification theory to identify appropriate strategies to improve the use of immunoglobulin testing in primary care using TDF, 'behavior modification wheel' and BCT taxonomy. The identified BCTs will form the basis of a theory-based intervention to improve the use of immunoglobulin tests among GPs. Future research will include the development and evaluation of this intervention.

title: Reasons for general practitioners' failure to implement epilepsy guidelines in primary care in a randomized controlled trial (TIGER Trial)
abstract: OBJECTIVE: To explore the reasons for the failure of a randomized controlled trial to influence the application of epilepsy guidelines in primary care and to theorize about possible contexts in which guidelines will lead to changes in clinician behavior. METHODS: Qualitative study based on focus groups and a single in-depth interview. Participants included 47 primary health care professionals selected from a purposive sample of 13 urban and rural general practices. CONCLUSIONS: The main reason for the Scottish Inter-University Guideline Network epilepsy guideline not being implemented was an established model of GP behavior supported by practice staff and perceived as having little need for change. Secondly, there were perceived difficulties in implementing the guideline due to lack of knowledge of the existence and/or content of the guideline, and resource constraints and possible patient resistance. Therefore, clinicians' individual behavior was based on broader service structures and policies. CONCLUSIONS: Guidelines may be more likely to apply where there are perceived problems in current service delivery. Attempts to facilitate the implementation of guidelines may also focus on areas where the need for guidance is already perceived or where there is a deterioration in one of the key variables that maintain the role and practice of the healthcare professional. They may also be more likely where initiatives focus on a wider area than individual physician behavior and are more broadly geared towards redesigning broader systems of care delivery, involving other providers to achieve care coordination, improve patient self-management, and use information technology tools.

title: General practitioners' adoption of clinical practice guidelines: a qualitative study
abstract: OBJECTIVE: To describe the recent rapid controlled change in the uptake of locally applied, evidence-based clinical guidelines for asthma and angina in primary care. METHODS: A case study of primary care in two matched, contiguous areas in northern England, focusing on a stratified random sample of 49 general practitioners (GPs) from eight primary care groups. Data were collected from three cycles of mainly qualitative interviews conducted at six-month intervals before and after local guidelines were published and after audit data were collected. Interviews examined attitudes, awareness and impact of locally disseminated asthma and angina guidelines, and follow-up supervision. Audit data on guideline acquisition were also obtained from a parallel study. CONCLUSIONS: The rapid increase in guideline intake observed in both the intervention and control groups was not explained by individual practitioners or practice factors. The findings are attributed to GPs' awareness of evidence-based medicine policies, new healthcare institutions, and clinical governance activities of primary care groups.
