Behavior change reflects GPs' clinical decisions as well as their decisions about what to record in case notes, so findings may reflect changing perceptions about accountability rather than preferred treatment regimens. CONCLUSIONS: Guideline preparation and dissemination is best seen in the context of broader policy change. Guideline implementation studies should report data before and after and include important qualitative components to identify important contextual factors.

title: Antibiotic management by the general surgeon: Climbing the Rogers Diffusion of Innovation Curve-Forward Cohort Study
abstract: INTRODUCTION: The primary aim of this study was to determine the compliance of the general surgeon's prescribing practice with local IV-oral antibiotic guidelines. The secondary aim was to assess the impact of introducing educational antibiotic measures. The Rogers Diffusion Model of Innovation was used to investigate the adoption of antibiotic management practices. METHODS: In this prospective, cohort study, data were collected from 100 patients before and 100 after the mindfulness intervention program. The educational intervention included a) guidelines b) pre-intervention outcomes c) raising awareness about the introduction of an IV-oral antibiotic prompt form. Compliance with local guidelines was compared between pre- and post-intervention groups using the Fisher's Exact Test or the Pearson's Chi Test (SPSS Statistics V22). CONCLUSIONS: General surgeons' compliance with local IV-oral antibiotic guidelines was poor and did not improve significantly following the awareness intervention program. There was no reception of the antibiotic prompt page. 48-72. There was an increase in the number of patients switching from IV to oral antibiotics per hour and a significant increase (p < 0.05) in the number of patients with a clearly documented intention to review IV antibiotics. CONCLUSION: Antibiotic governance measures failed to inspire even the first group of innovators to use antibiotic claim pages. Educational measures appear to be effective in improving prescribing behavior and intent among an early adopter group, but this fails to reach a critical mass. To improve antibiotic management and begin the Rogers Diffusion of Innovation Curve, more needs to be done to involve general surgeons in prescribing antibiotics in a timely and reasonable manner.

title: Genetic evaluation of oocyte donors: recipient couple preferences and test outcome
abstract: OBJECTIVE: To report the preferences of recipient couples for genetic testing of oocyte donors. DESIGN: Observational report of results from a form of genetic testing options administered as part of routine care. SETTING: Special application. PATIENT(S): Recipients and oocyte donors. INTERVENTION(S): Recipient couples completed a form prior to screening of oocyte donors stating required screening and recommended tests that the couple could accept or reject. The couples were informed about the frequency of carriers, the risk and cost for their children in case of abnormal results. MAIN OUTCOME MEASURES: Percentage of couples who accepted optional testing. RESULT(s): Out of 63 couples with data from the initial test options form, 42 (67%) accepted, 21 (33%) refused the fragile X test, 34 (54%) agreed, and 29 (% 46) refused karyotyping. When asked whether they would accept additional testing of their donor if recommended by a genetic counselor, 15 (24%) stated that they would accept additional testing at any cost, 35 (56%) refused, and 13 (20%) stated. He said his decisions will depend on cost. In most cases, a history was taken by the genetic counselor or test results were obtained that influence further testing, decisions to continue, or provide important information for the child. CONCLUSION(s): Recipient couples chose to refuse tests that we sometimes recommend but do not require, despite the relatively low cost of this test compared to the total cost of the oocyte donation cycle.

title: Genetic testing for children and adolescents. Who decides?
abstract: In the future, multiple DNA-based tests are likely to be available to diagnose single gene disorders and identify predispositions to genetically affected disorders. This article focuses on the ethical, legal, and psychological implications of testing healthy children and adolescents for such disorders. The test may provide medical or psychological benefits, but may harm parent-child bonds or a child's self-concept. Clinicians may encounter situations where they must weigh the wishes of the child or adolescent against the wishes of the parents. We examine the legal background and current status of minors as health care consumers"; psychosocial research on their maturity to choose; the impact of testing on family relationships; national commissions' views on the ages of appropriate consent and fully informed consent; ethical and legal requirements for competence in children and adolescents; " and disclosure of genetic information. We provide guidelines for predictive genetic testing and counseling for children and discuss the risks and benefits of testing.

title: Genetic support for primary care practitioners - a demonstration project
abstract: Primary care practitioners need to be supported by specialist genetics services to enable them to effectively cope with the growing interest of genetics with their patients. Genetic counselors can be effective in such a role. This exploration project aimed to improve the Primary-Tertiary interface by piloting such a service to general implementation for 1 year. Special genetic education support was delivered by a genetic counselor to ten randomly selected general practices in central England over 12 months. A range of services were provided to the apps, including streamlined genetic update sessions, a responsive advice service, and referral guidelines. Service was assessed through pre- and post-intervention questionnaires and seven semi-structured interviews. This article provides a description of the development and delivery of this service and also reports the experience of a sample of participants. Respondents reported positive attitudes towards the service and said they gained knowledge and confidence, as well as recognized limitations and gaps in their current knowledge. Consistent connectivity with a specialist genetics service provided by the genetic counselor has had a positive impact throughout the project, and participants have continued to use the genetic counselor for advice and support regarding genetic patient issues since the project was completed. This is the first example of this service delivery model. More research using a larger sample and other measures of behavior change is needed to assess whether this model is being adopted on a broader basis.

title: German translation of the Suicide Patient Observation Chart (SPOC) - an application tool
abstract: Caring for suicidal inpatients is a complex and responsible task. Direct and immediate intensive care and therapeutic supervision, also known as private observation, is still recommended in guidelines (DGPPN, 2012) and is perhaps one of the most used interventions in the care of inpatient suicidal patients. It includes many variants to enhance the relationship between observer and patient. The original SPOC was developed in Sweden to improve the quality of a systematic documentation during the surveillance of suicidal patients. It is a tool that provides systematic documentation of observational behavior or apparent mood during an acute suicidal crisis, such as other possible influencing factors such as "anxious, anxious" or "sudden mood swings". In this way, the SPOC can ensure the process of systematically documenting the particular observation and improve its quality, namely who documents what and when. In addition, SPOC can facilitate better communication of the observation process to the multidisciplinary team and the patient. SPOC includes 28 items and covers 24 different observation periods. The purpose of this article is to establish the translation process from English to German SPOC version. The translation process followed a five-stage model. In the first step, the English version was translated by two native German speakers. In the second step, the first two translation results discussed by the Expert group (authors) and a new version were developed. In the third step, the first German version (two native speakers) was translated back into English. The fourth step was taken by expert groups (authors) to review the results and establish what is called a "pre-release". The final step includes proof of content validity by 52 nurses. Evidence was able to spot several misunderstandings and helped improve the tool in its final version. German-speaking nursing practice in psychiatry with translation has a tool that psychiatric nurses can use in their complex interventions to this special patient group.

title: Gestational diabetes and hypertensive disorders of pregnancy as vascular risk signals: review and grading of the evidence.
abstract: The emergence of common pregnancy-related medical disorders puts women at higher risk of developing vascular disease in the future. Systematic reviews of cohort studies show that gestational diabetes has a 7-fold increased risk for type 2 diabetes, and preeclampsia provides a 1.8-fold increased risk for type 2 diabetes and a 3.4-fold increased risk for hypertension. Gestational diabetes and hypertensive disorders of pregnancy (HDP) increase the risk of early vascular disease, but the 2-fold increased risk associated with preeclampsia can only be partially explained by the development of traditional vascular risk factors. Despite convincing evidence for gestational diabetes and HDP as vascular risk indicators, there are no published Canadian vascular prevention guidelines recognizing these postpartum women. In contrast, 2011 American Heart Association guidelines include gestational diabetes and HDP in assessments of vascular risk for cardiovascular disease in women. Studies show that the importance of monitoring vascular risk factors in these women after pregnancy is poorly understood by the women themselves and their physicians. Adoption of these health behaviors is low, although the American Diabetes Prevention Program trial showed that a prudent diet and a physically active lifestyle reduce the risk of diabetes in women with a history of gestational diabetes. Qualitative research confirms the need for specific strategies that address barriers and provide social support. More research is also needed on approaches to reduce vascular risk in women with a history of gestational diabetes and HDP. Otherwise, an early window of opportunity for chronic disease prevention in young, high-risk women will be missed.

title: Making the Most of Financial Incentives for Weight Loss
Global initiatives to improve cancer treatment in resource-limited areas: what ASCO members are doing and how you can get involved
abstract: Cancer is the leading cause of death worldwide. The 7.6 million deaths attributed to cancer in 2008 represent 13% of all deaths. It is estimated that around 30% of cancer deaths are due to the five leading behavioral and dietary risks. These include high body mass index, low fruit and vegetable intake, lack of physical activity, tobacco and alcohol use. A number of viral infections such as hepatitis B and C and HPV are responsible for about 20% of cancer deaths. About 70% of cancer deaths occurred in low- and middle-income countries. Due to the increasing number of elderly individuals and increased control of comorbidities, deaths from cancer are expected to continue to rise worldwide, with an estimated 13.1 million deaths in 2030. To meet this need, the American Society of Clinical Oncology (ASCO) is a truly international organization. More than a third of ASCO members work in more than 100 countries, representing the world's largest collection of expertise and insights into cancer treatment. More than half of ASCO's Annual Meeting attendees come from outside the United States. The Journal of Clinical Oncology is read by more than 24,000 subscribers worldwide and is available in a number of different languages. To fulfill its mission, ASCO has a number of international programs dedicated to sharing knowledge and providing the tools to assist clinicians around the world in treating their patients. These programs include mentoring and information exchange, educational initiatives, and scientific and educational meetings. This provides ample opportunity for participation in advancing cancer care worldwide.

title: Global minimum essential requirements: the path to competency-oriented medical education
abstract: With the increasing globalization of medicine and the emerging concept of the 'global physician profession', the issue of core competencies that all physicians should possess has been sharply focused. If defined, these competencies will help show what teachers must teach, what students must learn, and what educational experience all physicians must have. The 'minimum core competencies' that all graduates must have if they want to be called doctors have been determined by the International Institute of Medical Education (IIME), supported by the Chinese Medical Board of New York, through working groups of education and health policy experts. and representatives of major international medical education organizations. In the first phase of the project, seven areas were determined that define the knowledge, skills, professional behavior and ethical values that all physicians should have, regardless of where they received general medical education. Appropriate tools have been identified to assess each of the domains. In the second phase of the project, 'global minimum essential requirements' (GMER) will be experimentally implemented in a number of Chinese medical schools. The aim of the third phase will be to share with the global education community the results of this educational experiment aimed at improving the quality of medical education.

title: Global, regional and national life expectancy, all-cause mortality and cause-specific mortality for 249 causes of death, 1980-2015: A systematic analysis for the Global Burden of Disease Study 2015
abstract: Improving survival and extending lifespan for all populations requires timely and robust evidence on local mortality levels and trends. The Global Burden of Disease 2015 Study (GBD 2015) provides a comprehensive assessment of all-cause and cause-specific deaths for 249 causes in 195 countries and territories from 1980 to 2015. These results informed an in-depth study of observed and expected mortality rates. patterns based on sociodemographic measures.";" Improving survival and extending lifespan for all populations requires timely and robust evidence on local mortality levels and trends. The Global Burden of Disease 2015 Study (GBD 2015) provides a comprehensive assessment of all-cause and cause-specific deaths for 249 causes in 195 countries and territories from 1980 to 2015. These results informed an in-depth study of observed and expected mortality rates. models based on sociodemographic measures.

title: To go
GRADE Evidence-to-Decision (EtD) frameworks: a systematic and transparent approach to making well-informed healthcare choices. 2: Clinical practice guidelines
abstract: Summary points Clinicians regularly encounter situations involving two or more alternative actions. Each alternative usually has different advantages and disadvantages, including differences in effectiveness, side effects, costs, and other factors.

title: Gradual versus Sudden Quit Smoking
Group cognitive behavioral therapy for initial psychosis: who is referred, who attends, and who completes?
abstract: OBJECTIVE: Most national guidelines recommend psychological therapy for people with first-stage psychosis (FEP), but interventions that have proven effective in randomized controlled trials (RCTs) conducted in research settings are not always effectively reflected in real-world clinical settings. In a limited healthcare system, it is important to understand the system and patient barriers to participation in effective treatment. We sought to determine which patient characteristics influenced clinicians' decision to apply or not to apply for group cognitive behavioral therapy for FEP, and which characteristics were associated with referrals who attended/not participated in the program and adhered to/not adhered to the program. METHODS: Between 2006 and 2008, all confirmed cases of FEP from a defined geographic area were reviewed using the Structured Clinical Interview for the DSM-IV-TR Axis I Disorders Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders, Fourth Edition (DSM-IV) diagnoses. , Positive Symptoms Rating Scale, Negative Symptoms Rating Scale, Calgary Schizophrenia Depression Scale, and Birchwood Insight Scale. The duration of untreated psychosis was determined using the Beiser Scale. RESULTS: Of 124 people (77 men, 47 women) in the final sample, 88 (72%) were referred for cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT), 52 (59%) attended and 12 (23%) did not complete CBT . Those with higher insight into treatment need (U = 740.00, z = -2.63, P = 0.008) and those with higher levels of positive symptoms (t (120) = -3.064, P = 0.003) were more likely to be referred was higher. to CBT. Those with higher levels of education (chi(2) = 9.48, P = 0.03) and those with fewer negative symptoms, particularly regarding global attention (t (85) = 2.32, P = 0.03), were more likely to participate in and complete CBT was higher. CONCLUSION: In an early intervention service for FEP, individuals with less education, more negative symptoms, and less insight appear to experience significant barriers to successfully completing group CBT. More information for referring clinicians about the benefits of CBT for FEP can help increase referral rates. Ambitious benefits should also be considered for people at risk of leaving or not complying.

title: Group therapy for adolescents with recurrent self-harm: a randomized controlled trial with economic evaluation.
abstract: OBJECTIVE To examine the effectiveness and cost-effectiveness of group therapy in self-harm in young people. DESIGN A two-arm, single (evaluator) blind parallel randomized allocation trial of a group therapy intervention in addition to routine care compared with routine care alone. Randomization was done with minimization control for baseline frequency of self-harm, presence of conduct disorder, depressive disorder, and severity of psychosocial stress. PARTICIPANTS Adolescents aged 12-17 who have had at least two incidents of self-harm in the past 12 months. Exclusion criteria were: no English speaking, low weight anorexia nervosa, acute psychosis, significant learning difficulties (defined by the need for specialty school), current limitation in safe care. Eight child and adolescent mental health services in northwest England. INTERVENTIONS A manual-based developmental group therapy program specifically designed for self-harming adolescents, with an acute phase of six-week sessions followed by a supportive phase of weekly groups as needed. Details of routine care were collected from participating centers. MAIN OUTCOME MEASURES The primary outcome was the frequency of subsequent recurrent episodes of self-harm. Secondary outcomes were severity of subsequent self-harm, mood disturbance, suicidal ideation, and general functioning. Total costs of health, social care, education and criminal justice sector services, as well as family-related costs and productivity losses were recorded. RESULTS 183 adolescents were allocated to each arm (total n = 366). Follow-up loss was low (<4%). In all results, the trial group as a whole showed significant improvement from baseline to follow-up. On the primary outcome of self-harm frequency, the proportional odds ratio of routine care adjustment versus group treatment for relevant baseline variables was 0.99 (95% confidence interval 0.68 to 1.44, P = 0.95) and 0.88 (0.59 to 1.33, P) at 6 months. = 0.52) in 1 year. Equivalent odds ratios for severity of subsequent self-harm were 0.81 (0.54 to 1.20, P = 0.29) at 6 months and 0.94 (0.63 to 1.40, P = 0.75) at 1 year. Total 1-year costs (£21,781) in the group therapy arm were higher than for routine care (£15,372), but the difference was not significant (95% CI -1416 to 10782, P = 0.132). CONCLUSIONS The addition of this targeted group therapy program did not improve self-harm outcomes for adolescents who repeatedly self-harmed, and there was no evidence of cost-effectiveness. Outcomes to endpoint for the cohort as a whole were better than current clinical expectations. Trial registration ISRCTN 20496110.

title: Growth and nutritional risk in children with developmental delay
abstract: INTRODUCTION: Nutritional risk influences outcome in developmental delay. The main objectives were to identify the incidence and factors contributing to the growth stagnation. METHODS: Clinical data review was completed for 500 developmentally delayed patients admitted to the Early Intervention service. Data were collected using a standardized parent nutritional screening checklist before and during the initial dietary assessment. Data were compared with nutritional assessment data, GOSH and FSAI dietary guidelines. Weight category was determined using RCPCH growth and BMI charts. Statistical analysis was performed using the Statistical Package for the Social Sciences version 20 (IBM Statistics 20.0). RESULTS: The nutritional risk was determined as 48.6%. Weight categories were growth arrest (13.5%), underweight (7.7%), overweight (8.4%) and obesity (4.3%) at initial assessment. Growth arrest was correlated with age <1 (p = 0.000) and gestational age (p = 0.017), with the highest rates (3.6%) in those born at 32-36 weeks. Weight category was associated with adding solids to the 17 weeks pre-recommendation (10.1%), with ANOVA showing significance (P = 0.013). In 22.7% of those evaluated, it was observed that the nutritional risk was not sufficiently recognized by the parents. Feeding difficulties were common: 4.2% were fed enterally, 7.7% were taking prescription nutritional supplements, 29.1% (n=121) had feeding difficulties, and 13.9% (n=58) were on behavioral nutrition. was having difficulties. Iron intake did not meet the recommended intake in 20.9% (n=87) and calcium 4.5% (n=19). The prevalence of constipation was 21.6 and 11.8% required medical treatment. CONCLUSIONS: Developmental delay predisposes to nutritional deficiencies that affect outcome. Screening, evaluation and timely interventions are warranted to prevent worse developmental outcomes.

title: Adherence to guidelines in the management of stable chronic obstructive pulmonary disease
abstract: OBJECTIVE: Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) is the only leading cause of death with increasing morbidity and mortality. Clinical practice guidelines (CPGs) for optimizing pharmacotherapy for patients with COPD have been updated based on the promising results of randomized clinical trials. We examined the frequency of physician adherence to the guidelines and associated factors in clinical practice at an academic medical center. METHODS: Patients clinically admitted to outpatient clinics with a clinical diagnosis of COPD confirmed by spirometry were included. The primary outcome was that the provider adhered to the 2007 Global Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease Initiative (GOLD) guidelines. Subjects receiving a rescue inhaler (all patients) or at least one long-acting bronchodilator (stage II) or at least one long-acting bronchodilator plus one inhaled corticosteroid (stage III-IV) were categorized in accordance with the guideline. Demographics, clinical information, and provider type were recorded. Provider type was classified by both as primary care physician (PCP), pulmonologist, or co-management. RESULTS: Of the 450 subjects who met the study criteria, 246 (54.7%) received treatment in accordance with the guidelines. Age, gender, race, disease severity, and co-morbidities were not associated with compliance with the guideline. Multivariate analysis showed that patients co-managed by a PCP and pulmonologist were more likely to receive treatment in accordance with the guidelines than those managed by one or the other (Odds Ratio: 4.59";" 95% Confidence Interval: 2.92, 7.22, p < 0.001). ). CONCLUSIONS: Slightly more than half of stable COPD patients receive care in accordance with the guidelines. Co-management by a PCP and pulmonologist increases the likelihood of receiving guideline-compliant inhaler therapy.

title: Guideline practice in allied health professions: a systematic review of the literature
abstract: BACKGROUND: Clinical guidelines aim to improve the safety and quality of patient care by providing clinicians with graded recommendations based on best practice evidence. OBJECTIVE: To evaluate the effects of introducing clinical guidelines for allied health professionals and to estimate the effectiveness of guideline dissemination and implementation strategies used. METHODS: A comprehensive search of six electronic databases and the Cochrane Organization for Effective Implementation and Maintenance database was conducted up to June 2006. Randomized controlled trials, controlled clinical trials, pre- and post-controlled studies, and discontinuous time series studies were included if the intervention was aimed at applying guidelines in allied health professions. Articles were screened for relevance and their methodological quality evaluated";" data were extracted independently by two reviewers. RESULTS: Fourteen studies met the inclusion criteria. Methodological quality varied greatly, with the ratio of quality criteria ranging from 0 to 6 out of seven. In most studies, reported effects for patient and process outcomes were small and favored the intervention group. Of the 14 included studies, 10 focused on educational interventions. Six of the 14 studies used a single intervention strategy and seven used a multi-pronged implementation strategy. One study compared both single and multiple strategies. Multiple interventions were no more effective than single intervention strategies, and the effects of the same strategy differed between trials. CONCLUSIONS: There is no evidence to support an established guideline implementation strategy for allied health professionals. When applying clinical guidelines, it is important to first identify specific barriers to change using theoretical frameworks of behavior change and then develop strategies that deal with these barriers. When measuring the effectiveness of these strategies, professionals should consider the use of both patient and process outcomes and select outcomes that reflect their goals.

title: Application of the guide: what the literature does not tell us
abstract: BACKGROUND: Despite the large number of studies and literature reviews regarding the application of guidelines, it remains unclear whether and how clinical guidelines can be used to improve the quality of medical care. This study sought to find out if these studies and reviews recognized the importance of systems thinking and organizational change for practice. METHODS: A literature review was conducted for systematic reviews of guideline implementation or practice improvement studies. Each review is examined in terms of the extent to which it describes or discusses the value of system changes, organizational support, applied environmental factors, and use of a change process. RESULTS: Forty-seven quality systematic reviews were found. They largely agreed that using reminders and perhaps feedback during clinical encounters were the most effective ways to implement guidelines. However, the same reviews rarely identified these strategies as system changes, and there was little discussion of the need for institutional support or attention to the various environmental variables that could affect implementation. The change process required to introduce a new or modified delivery system received even less attention. CONCLUSION: Reviews of guideline practice trials have focused on how to change the behavior of individual clinicians. Little attention has been paid to the impact of practice systems or the organizational support of clinician behavior, the role of the practice environmental context in which change is produced, or in which change is attempted. A renewed interest in these issues can help us better understand and undertake the process of improving medical care delivery.

title: 'Overweight' guide to child health care
abstract: '5. The 'National Growth Study' shows that the percentage of overweight children in the Netherlands increased from 9-12% in 1997 to 13-15% in 2009. children to whom adapted prevention can be offered. Detection of overweight in children and intervention by Child Health Care takes place in a multidisciplinary environment that connects general practitioners, pediatricians, dietitians, teachers, physiotherapists, pedagogues and psychologists. For overweight children, a change plan is created with exercise, play outside, breakfast every day, as little sugary drinks and fast food as possible, less time in front of the TV or computer, less energy snacks. . Obese children are referred to a general practitioner or pediatrician, as recommended in the Dutch CBO guideline 'Obesity'.

title: Guideline-based early rehabilitation after myocardial infarction. A pragmatic randomized controlled trial
abstract: OBJECTIVES: To determine the effectiveness of individualized educational behavioral therapy delivered by cardiac nurses in hospital compared to usual care for patients after acute myocardial infarction. METHODS: One hundred and fourteen consecutive patients were randomized to receive the intervention or usual care. Outcome assessment was done by self-report questionnaire (Hospital Anxiety and Depression Scale and Dartmouth COOP Health Status), interview at month 1, and self-report at month 3 and 12. The primary outcome was improvement in Dartmouth COOP overall score from baseline to 3 months. RESULTS: Four patients required treatment (number required to treat [NNT] 4, 95% confidence interval [CIs] 3 to 12) to give an additional patient with improved health at 3 months. The intervention group was more confident in returning to activities 1 month after hospital discharge. Treated patients needed less treatment. CONCLUSIONS: Individualized educational behavioral therapy administered in hospital by cardiac nurses can have significant benefits. A large-scale pragmatic RCT is needed.

title: Guidelines and educational visits from community pharmacists to improve prescribing in general practice: a randomized controlled trial.
abstract: OBJECTIVES: To evaluate the effectiveness of guidelines with or without one-on-one educational outreach visits by community pharmacists in developing general practice prescription for non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs). METHODS: Cluster randomized study of 20 general practices in Avon, UK. Apps were randomly divided into three groups: control"; mailed instructions;" posted guidelines plus educational access visits. General practitioners (GPs) in the second group received two one-on-one outreach visits from community pharmacists. Changes in prescribing were measured using results from prescribing analysis and cost (PACT) data. The primary outcome measure was change in prescribing volume for ibuprofen, diclofenac, and naproxen as a percentage of total NSAID prescribing. Six secondary outcomes included other measures of prescribing quality and volume. Cost-benefit analysis was done. RESULTS: No significant differences were observed for the primary outcome measure: apps that received outreach visits only had 2.1% [95% confidence interval (CI): -0.8 to 5.0] of the three recommended NSAIDs, more than control treatments, and 1.6% predicted (95% CI: -1.4 to 4.7) more than just apps that received the instructions. After adjusting for multiple comparisons, only one secondary outcome showed a statistically significant difference between groups: the prescription rate for the five most commonly used drugs was 2.2% (95% CI: 0.9 to 3.6) higher in the education outreach group than in the others. control group. Both interventions showed a net increase in costs. CONCLUSIONS: Although initial good prescribing in participatory practice limits the capacity to improve, this trial provides no evidence that guidelines with or without educational access visits from community pharmacists lead to significant improvements in prescribing behavior.

title: Principles and psychology of medical decision-making in the treatment of depressive disorders
abstract: Guidelines aim to improve medical decision making. Guidelines seek to influence medical behavior, unlike textbooks and reviews that seek to improve medical knowledge. Scientific models of medical decision-making, such as action theory, and empirical data on the effects of guidelines suggest that guidelines do not always achieve their goals, and may even impair medical quality. The problem of guidelines in medicine is discussed with reference to depressive disorders. However, these issues apply to medicine as a whole. Therefore, whether physicians exposed to the guideline achieve better outcomes with their patients should be tested in controlled clinical trials. Only such guidelines should be named based on empirical evidence of positive effects.

title: Guidelines as rationing tools: a qualitative analysis of psychosocial patient selection criteria for cardiac procedures.
abstract: BACKGROUND: Cardiac procedure guidelines often include psychosocial criteria for selecting patients who potentially incorporate social value judgments in clinical decisions and decisions regarding the allocation of care. The purpose of this study was to explore the terms, rationales, and meanings of psychosocial patient characteristics used in cardiac procedure guidelines. METHODS: We selected English manuals published since 1990 and chapters from textbooks published since 1989. These guidelines combined multiple sources of evidence and expertise and made recommendations for patient selection for specific procedures. A multidisciplinary team of doctors and social scientists deduced passages on psychosocial criteria and developed categories and conceptual relationships to describe and interpret their content. RESULTS: Sixty-five articles met the inclusion criteria. Forty-five (69%) mentioned psychosocial criteria as an indication or contraindication for the procedure. Second, behavioral and psychological issues are divided into several categories, including relationships with significant other, financial resources, social roles, and environmental conditions. COMMENT: Psychosocial characteristics are portrayed as having 2 roles in patient selection: candidate-specific risk factors or indicators of the need for special intervention. Guidelines typically list psychosocial contraindications without explaining their specific nature or providing any justification for their use. Psychosocial considerations may help evaluate patients for cardiac procedures, but they become ethically controversial when used to restrict access. The use of psychosocial indications and contraindications can be improved by more precise definitions of the psychosocial problem in question, explanations as to why the criterion is important, and justification of the trait using a biological rationale or research evidence.

title: Guidelines for Adolescent Preventive Services: GAPS in Practice
abstract: DESIGN: Comparison of results obtained through chart control, before and after Guidelines for Adolescent Preventive Services (GAPS). SETTING: A rural hospital-based general pediatrics clinic. PARTICIPANTS: Adolescents undergoing annual examination between April 1, 1998 and March 31, 2001. A random sample of 441 medical records were reviewed. INTERVENTION: Training and use of the questionnaire in the GAPS model began in April 1998. MAIN OUTCOME MEASURES: Identifying, discussing, and referencing GAPS-related risk behavior. RESULTS: The medical records of 162 young adolescents (ages 11-15) and 279 older adolescents (16-19 years) were audited. Detection of risky behaviors increased from 19% at baseline to 95% with initial GAPS and 87% with periodic GAPS. The most common risk factor was possession of a rifle or handgun at home (young adolescents, 47% and older adolescents, 39%). The mean number of documented risk behaviors and health concerns was higher in the initial GAPS (4.8 and 1.3, respectively) than in the periodic GAPS (3.8 and 0.7) (P =.01 and .006). GAPS surveys detected lower levels of risk behavior compared with a local Youth Risk Behavior Survey. Control for gender, age and clinician, discussion of psychosocial issues increased during the study period";" however, there were significant differences among clinicians regarding the issues addressed. The GAPS-related referral rate did not change significantly. CONCLUSION: The GAPS model increases clinicians' identification and discussion of risky behaviors.

title: Guidelines for assessing postpartum issues: presenting evidence-based guidelines in Australian general practice
abstract: BACKGROUND: Postpartum morbidity is high and many GPs lack the confidence and knowledge to deal with common postpartum problems. There is a high consultation rate, but few women disclose common health issues. OBJECTIVE: The aim of this study is to increase the knowledge and skills of general practitioners in identifying and managing common health problems experienced by women in the year following birth. METHODS: A training program [Guidelines for Evaluation of Postpartum Problems (GAPP)] embedded in a large randomized community intervention study [Resources, Information and Support Program for Mothers (PRISM)], pre/post evaluation by Australian GPs working in Australia . four metropolitan and four rural communities. The program consisted of supervision, interactive workshops, role-playing and evidence-based guidelines and was assessed at baseline and at 6 months through written questionnaires and a surgical consultation with a trained simulated patient evaluator. RESULTS: A total of 68 (86%) practitioners took part in the full GAPP program. The probability of developing a GP's knowledge items ranged from 1.0 to 16, with the greatest change occurring in knowledge about the effectiveness of cognitive behavioral therapy for maternal depression. The percentage of GPs who gave false answers at baseline, who showed improved knowledge at follow-up, ranged from 22% to 100%. About half of GPs initially demonstrated excellent communication skills. More than half of the remaining GPs demonstrated greatly improved skills in detecting common postpartum problems at follow-up. At the initial simulated patient visit, 70% of GPs questioned sexual problems and none questioned the possibility of abuse, while at follow-up 94% questioned sexual problems and 51.5% facilitated the explanation of physical and emotional abuse. Anonymous feedback from GPs participating in the program showed that 89% believed the program had positively impacted their actual practice. Interestingly, GPs demonstrated greater knowledge and skill in the simulated setting than in the written questionnaire. CONCLUSION: This relatively short, well-rounded training program has helped many participants develop the knowledge and skills necessary to improve both physical and emotional health after birth. Despite being experienced clinicians and actively participating in a program on interviewing skills, half of the GPs did not facilitate disclosure of the underlying sensitive issue (abuse) during the follow-up consultation and could benefit from more in-depth training in effective communication skills.

title: Family-Centered Care Guide in Neonatal, Pediatric and Adult Intensive Care Unit
abstract: OBJECTIVE: To provide clinicians with evidence-based strategies to optimize support for critically ill families in the ICU. METHODS: We used Council of Medical Specialty Societies principles for the development of clinical guidelines as the guideline development framework. We assembled an international multidisciplinary team of 29 with expertise in guideline development, evidence analysis and family-centered care to revise the 2007 Clinical Practice Guidelines to support the family in the patient-centered intensive care unit. We conducted a scoping review of qualitative studies investigating family-centered care in the intensive care unit. Thematic analyzes were conducted to support population, intervention, comparison, and outcome question development. Patients and their families reaffirmed the importance of interventions and outcomes. We then conducted a systematic review using the Rating of Recommendations, Evaluation, Development and Evaluation methodology to make recommendations for implementation. Proposals were subjected to electronic voting with predetermined voting thresholds. No industry funding has been associated with guideline development. RESULTS: Scoping review yielded 683 qualitative studies"; 228 were used for thematic analysis and Population, Intervention, Comparison, Outcome question development. Systematic review research yielded 4,158 reports after deduplication and 76 additional studies from alerts and hand searches were added;" 238 studies met the inclusion criteria. We made 23 recommendations from moderate, low, and very low evidence on communication with family members, family presence, family support, consultations, and operational and environmental issues with ICU team members. We provide recommendations for future research and study tools to support the translation of recommendations into practice. CONCLUSIONS: This guideline describes the evidence base for best practices for family-centered care in the intensive care unit. All recommendations were weak, highlighting the relative emergence of this research area and the importance of future research to identify the most effective interventions to improve this important aspect of ICU care.

title: Guidelines for entering and staying in care and improving antiretroviral compliance for people with HIV: evidence-based recommendations from the International Association of Physicians in AIDS Care.
abstract: DESCRIPTION: After diagnosis of HIV, timely entry and retention in HIV medical care is essential to the delivery of effective antiretroviral therapy (ART). Adherence to ART is among the key determinants of successful HIV treatment outcome and is essential for minimizing the emergence of drug resistance. The International Association of Physicians in AIDS Care convened a panel to develop evidence-based recommendations for optimizing care admission and retention and adherence to ART for people with HIV. METHODS: A systematic literature search was conducted to establish a limited evidence base, with randomized, controlled trials and observational studies with comparators with at least 1 measured biological or behavioral endpoint. A total of 325 studies met the criteria. Two reviewers extracted and coded data independently from each study using a standardized data extraction form. Panel members outlined evidence-based recommendations for each method or intervention and then rated the overall quality of the evidence and the strength of each recommendation. RECOMMENDATIONS: Provides recommendations for monitoring entry and stay, interventions to improve entry and care, and monitoring and interventions to improve adherence to ART. Recommendations include ART strategies, compliance tools, education and counseling, and health system and service delivery interventions. It also covers specific topics related to pregnant women, incarcerated individuals, the homeless and marginally placed individuals, children and adolescents, and substance use and mental health disorders. Recommendations for future research in all areas are also presented.

title: Guidelines for interaction by the therapeutic team in the inpatient treatment of patients with chronic neurotic disorders
abstract: In the treatment of patients with chronic neurotic disorders, we have sought to both reduce the distress often caused by these patients in the therapeutic team (doctors, nurses, other therapists) and improve treatment outcome. Therefore, the treatment team was given three to five guidelines on how to deal with the patient, and the patient was shown with possible true statements. The guidelines aimed at a general interactive approach to the patient and did not specify specific therapeutic interventions. They were founded following the principles of Brief Therapy developed at the Mental Research Institute in Palo Alto. The results of our intervention in the treatment of ten patients are reported. The therapeutic team rated the guidelines generally positively. The therapeutic outcome has varied greatly. A comparison with a matched-pair control group showed a positive trend. Initial assessments by the prescribing team predicted eventual recovery from patients.

title: Medical treatment guidelines for stroke prevention
Apallik Syndrome / A Guide to Quality Management in Vegetative Condition
abstract: INTRODUCTION: Epidemiology in Europe shows steadily increasing numbers for apallic syndrome (AS)/vegetative state (VS) as a result of enabling high-standard home nursing for enhanced recovery, emergency services, intensive care treatment after acute brain injury and fully dependent end. - cases secondary to progressive neurological disease. The management of patients with irreversible persistent AS/VS has been the subject of continuous scientific and moral-legal debate over the past decade. METHODS: A task force on AS/VS quality management guidelines was established under the auspices of the European Federation of Neurological Societies Scientific Panel Neurotraumatology to address key issues regarding AS/VS prevalence and quality management. The collection and analysis of scientific data on class II (III) evidence from the literature and best practice-based recommendations resulting from the expertise of task force members comply with EFNS Guidance regulations. RESULTS: The overall incidence of new AS/VS full-stage cases of all etiology is 0.5-2/100,000 population per year. About one-third are traumatic and two-thirds non-traumatic. Increasing numbers have been noticed for hypoxic brain injury and progressive neurological disease. The main conceptual criticism is based on the evaluation and diagnosis of all the different stages of AS/VS based solely on behavioral findings, without knowing the precise or uniform pathogenesis or the uncertainty of clinical evaluation due to neuropathological findings and varying inclusion criteria. No specific diagnosis or specific medical treatment can be recommended for the treatment and rehabilitation of Class II or III AS. Therefore, the essential diagnosis and appropriate treatment of the clinical features of AS/VS patients with "AS complete, remission, defect, and end-stages" require more professional training and expertise for physicians and rehabilitation personnel. COMMENT: The management of AS aims at social reintegration of patients or has to guarantee humane active nursing if treatment fails. The outcome depends on the cause and duration of AS/VS as well as the age of the patient. There is no single AS/VS-specific laboratory study, regimen, or stimulant intervention to recommend to improve higher cerebral functioning. Quality management requires a minimum of 3 years of further education and permanent training to qualify for AS/VS treatment and specialization. Indispensable areas covering AS/VS institutions are required for early and long-term rehabilitation on a population basis (2/100,000/year) to accelerate functional restoration and prevent or treat complications. Nursing homes are needed for respectful humane nursing, including basal sensor-motor stimulation techniques. Passive euthanasia is considered an act of mercy by physicians in terms of stopping treatment";" however, the ethical and legal issues associated with cessation of nutrition and hydration and end-of-life discussions raise deep concerns. The guide is intended for neurologists, neurosurgeons, other physicians working with AS/VS patients, neurorehabilitation personnel, patients, relatives, and health authorities.

title: Guidelines for reporting health interventions using mobile phones: mobile health (mHealth) evidence reporting and evaluation (mERA) checklist
abstract: To improve the completeness of reporting of mobile health (mHealth) interventions, the WHO mHealth Technical Evidence Review Group developed the mHealth evidence reporting and evaluation (mERA) checklist. The development process for MERA consisted of bringing together a group of experts to recommend an appropriate approach, establishing a global expert review panel for checklist development, and pilot testing the checklist. The guiding principle for the development of these criteria is to identify, support and support the minimum set of information required to define what an mHealth intervention is (content), where it is implemented (context), and how it is implemented (technical specifications). repetition of the intervention. This document provides the resulting 16-item checklist and detailed explanation and elaboration for each item, with examples of illustrative reporting. With widespread adoption, we expect the use of these guidelines to standardize the quality of mHealth evidence reporting and indirectly improve the quality of mHealth evidence. #### Summary points Mobile technologies have the potential to bridge the systemic gaps needed to improve access to and use of healthcare services, particularly among underserved communities. Defined as the use of mobile and wireless technologies for health, mHealthâ€ aims to leverage the rapid uptake of information and communication technologies (ICT) to improve health system efficiency and health outcomes. In the last decade, global enthusiasm and development interest

title: Guidelines for the use and interpretation of assays to monitor autophagy (3rd ed.)
Guidelines for medical professions
abstract: BACKGROUND: Clinical practice guidelines aim to reduce inappropriate variation in practice and promote evidence-based healthcare delivery. OBJECTIVES: To identify and evaluate the impact of efforts to introduce clinical practice guidelines in nursing (including health visiting), midwifery, and other medical-related professions. SEARCH STRATEGY: We searched Cochrane Effective Practice and Organization of the Care Group expert registry, MEDLINE (1975 to 1996), EMBASE, Cinahl and Sigle 1996, NHS Database of Economic Assessments (1994 to 1996), DHSS-Data (1983 to 1996), Efficacy Reviews Database of Abstracts (1994 - 1996) and reference lists of articles. We also manually searched Quality at Health Care, made personal contact with content experts, and contacted libraries identified by an expert panel. SELECTION CRITERIA: Discrete time-series analyzes of randomized trials, controlled pre- and post-controlled studies, and introduction of interventions 1. Clinical guidelines plus dissemination and/or implementation strategies versus non-guidelines"; 2. Guidelines plus dissemination and/or implementation strategies versus guidelines plus alternative Standard physician care versus dissemination and/or implementation strategies and guidelines used by 3. (post hoc) medicine-related professions Participants were nurses, midwives, and other medical-related professions DATA COLLECTION AND ANALYSIS: Two reviewers independently derived data and assessed study quality. MAIN RESULTS: Eighteen studies involving more than 467 health care professionals were included.Reporting of study methods was inadequate for all studies.All but one study had nurses as the targeted professional group, one study targeted dietitians only. r included the management of hypertension, low back pain, and hyperlipidemia. Nine studies were identified for comparison 1. Three out of five studies observed improvements in at least some care process, and six out of eight studies observed improvements in care outcomes. Only one study included a formal economic assessment with uncertain findings. Three studies were identified for Comparison 2, but it was difficult to draw firm conclusions due to poor methods. Six studies were identified for Comparison 3 (post hoc). These studies generally supported the hypothesis that there is no difference between the care provided by nurses using clinical guidelines and standard physician care. REVIEWER'S CONCLUSIONS: There is some evidence that guide-based care is effective in changing the course and outcome of care provided by the medical-related professions. However, care needs to be taken when generalizing the findings to other professions and settings.

title: Guidelines for smoking management in the perioperative period
abstract: Smoking is a particularly important public health problem in the perioperative period, as it exposes patients scheduled for surgery to a 20% increased risk of hospital mortality and a 40% increased risk of major postoperative complications. In addition, current smoking increases almost all specific surgical complications. The perioperative period provides a real opportunity to quit smoking. By offering behavioral management and prescribing nicotine replacement before any planned surgical intervention, the rate of preoperative smoking cessation can be significantly increased. Preoperative smoking cessation should be routinely recommended regardless of the time of intervention, although the benefits increase with cessation time. All professionals of the care pathway (general practitioners, surgeons, anesthetists-intensity specialists, caregivers) should inform smokers of the positive effects of smoking cessation and offer them tailored management and personalized follow-up. In children, it is essential to quit parental smoking or remove the child from environmental tobacco smoke as long as possible before surgery.

title: Guidelines, editors, drug and biological paradigm shift
abstract: Private investment in biomedical research has increased over the past few decades. In many places it was hailed as the next best thing to technology itself. Many of the intellectual talents from academic institutions are absorbed into lucrative positions in the industry. Applied research finds willing collaborators in the venture-capital-funded industry, thus ensuring symbiotic growth for both. There are also significant costs involved. As academia interacts with industry, major areas of conflict of interest have emerged that apply specifically to biomedical research. These relate to disputes over patents and copyrights, hostile confrontations between academia and industry, as well as between public and private enterprise, legal entanglements, research abuses of various kinds, lobbies of oppositional media and patient advocates, and a general atmosphere of convergence of business interests. priority over patient welfare. The pharmacy image stinks due to a series of omissions and commission errors. A recent example is the suppression of negative findings about the marketing maneuvers of Bayer's Trasylol (Aprotinin) and Eli Lilly's Xigris (rhAPC). When there is a conflict between patient vulnerability and profit motives, medicine often tends towards the latter. There is also documentation that illuminates how companies often cross the line between patient well-being and profit-seeking behavior. A voluntary moratorium on drug spending is required to indulge drug prescribers. A code of conduct recently adopted by OPPI in India to limit pharmaceutical company spending on junk and junk is a welcome step. Clinical practice guidelines (CPGs) are considered important as they guide the diagnosis/treatment regimen of many medical professionals and hospitals. and makes recommendations about drugs, their dosage and selection criteria. Besides clinical trials, it is a growing area of influence by the pharmaceutical industry. For example, a relatively recent 2002 study found that approximately 60% of the 192 authors of clinical practice guidelines reported having financial ties to companies being considered drugs. There is a strong case for making CPGs based not only on effectiveness but also on cost effectiveness. The various consequences of this should be explained. Evaluation of the Guidelines The work of bodies such as Research and Evaluation (AGREE) Collaboration and the Guidelines Advisory Committee (GAC) is also worth watching closely. Even the actions of Foundations working to cure diseases have come under scrutiny. The process of creating 'Best Practices' Guidelines for interactions between the pharmaceutical industry and clinicians has already begun and could have important implications for patient care. Similarly, Good Publication Practice (GPP) for pharmaceutical companies aimed to improve the behavior of pharmaceutical companies when reporting drug trials. The rapidly increasing trend towards influence and control by industry has become a concern for many. It is so important that the Association of American Medical Colleges has published two relatively recent papers - one on "how to deal with conflicts of individual interest" in 2001 and the other on how to handle institutional conflicts in 2002. Concerned with the conduct of clinical research. AMCs), like medical education and research institutions elsewhere, must adopt tools that minimize conflicts of interest. Both medical societies and research journal editors have institutional conflicts of interest in the conduct of individual and clinical trials, and documents that address these issues are now available. The ICMJE revision requires full disclosure of the sponsor's role in research, as well as ensuring that researchers are independent of the sponsor. Responsible for the design and conduct of the trial, having independent access to all research data, and controlling all editorial and publication decisions. The findings of one study indicate that academic institutions routinely participate in clinical research that does not meet the ICMJE standards for accountability, data access, and publication control. profitability of the industry and research is giving rise to academia. The industry supports new rather than traditional treatments, regardless of what is effective. Whichever traditional therapy is supported, it's likely because the company involved has a product that has a large stake in it, remains the 'gold standard', or that the player thinks still has some 'juice' left. Industry sponsorship is mainly for potential drugs, not to try to determine if there are non-pharmacological interventions that could be equally good, if not better. In the paradigm shift to biological psychiatry, the role of industry sponsorship is not overt, but probably more pervasive than many realize, or one might think that thinking right is good for the health of the branch in the long run. protecting the interests of research subjects. Patients agree to be the subject of research not only for personal medical benefit, but also as an extension to benefit the rest of the patient population and also to advance medical research. The pharmaceutical industry is huge. However, we must also recognize that there is a fundamental difference between marketing strategies for other organizations and those for drugs. The ultimate barometer is patient well-being, and no drug that doesn't compromise it will stand the test of time. So how does it make commercial sense to market substandard products in the long run? The biggest mistake long-term players in the industry can make is trying to adopt the dark techniques of beginners. Secrecy of marketing/sales tactics, production process, other business expansion strategies and plans, anti-competitive strategies are good business tactics. However, it is crucial that confidentiality as a tactic does not specifically include reporting of research findings that are contrary to the individual's product. Farma has no choice but to make a quality product, make extensive adverse reaction profiles and only market it if it passes both tests. .Why does the drug adopt dubious tactics? The reasons are actually two: With all the restrictions, a medicine comes to the pharmacy after big investments. There are serious overheads and infrastructure costs that need to be recovered. And they have huge profit margins to protect. If they only depended on real drug discoveries, that would be taking a huge risk. Industry players need to strike the right balance between profitability and reliability. Marketing champions play their role in making a profit. In credibility ratings, researchers and paid spokespersons play their roles. Everything is ridiculous until marketing is based on credibility. When there is nothing that can be done for credibility, one thing is envisioned and marketed as one, with the calculated hope that profits can accrue, as profit making must continue indefinitely. This is what makes pharmacy adopt even questionable ways to make a profit. There are basically four types of drugs. First, drugs that work and have minimal side effects; second, drugs that work but have serious side effects; third, drugs that do not work and have minimal side effects, and fourth, drugs that work minimally but have serious side effects. It is the second and fourth types that create great difficulties for the industry. Often the industry can try to project. The fourth type is the second type to evade censorship. The biggest game of cat and mouse played by conscientious researchers is to reveal what the third and fourth are and not let the industry hunt them down as the first and second type respectively. The main game is to prevent the second kind from being projected as the first. The third kind is essentially harmless, so they attract reprimand and some fun to market them. But they escape nothing more than a smack on the knuckles. What is needed for industry captains and long-term players is this: Their main driving force is simply can produce the first type 2. accept the second type. only until you can get your hands on the first one. 3. The third type can be played occasionally to supplement profits, but never by projecting them as the first type. 4. The fourth type is the laggards, they are a real threat to credibility and therefore do not deserve any market excitement or promotion. While we find out why most drugs indulge in dubious tactics, we are guided to some interesting solutions to avoid such tactics in the least amount. Difficulties for everyone involved, even if both profit and reliability are kept intact.

title: Guideline-based indicators to measure the quality of prenatal care
abstract: RATIONALE, OBJECTIVES AND OBJECTIVES: A comprehensive measure of the quality of antenatal care is not available. A late booking or low number of checks is often used as a proxy for poor quality, leaving uncertainty about the true content of care received. To fill this gap, we reviewed two sets of clinical guidelines and developed corresponding quality indicators. METHOD: A group of clinicians and methodologists reviewed the National Institute of Clinical Excellence Clinical Guidelines on prenatal care and the list of prenatal care interventions recommended by the Research and Development Group, both based on evidence for the effectiveness of specific interventions. We identified one direction in three areas: (1) service use"; (2) screening; and (3) interventions. For each indicator, we defined: (1) eligibility, ie the characteristics of women to whom the indicator was applied; (2) the standard, i.e. the state when the goal was achieved; " and (3) moderators, ie any conditions that legitimately prevent the standard from being fulfilled. RESULTS: We developed four indicators for service usage, 25 scans and 17 interventions. For each indicator, the relevant eligibility, standard and moderator criteria are explained. While many indicators from medical charts can be evaluated retrospectively, the quality of communication with the provider, screening for sensible issues, and counseling on behaviors to avoid can only be obtained through prospective data collection. CONCLUSIONS: Quality indicators of prenatal care, complemented by measures of social position, social support, and immigrant/ethnic status, allow for careful identification of gaps in quality of care for specific groups of women.

title: Withdrawal of Antipsychotic Use in Long-Term Care (HALT): A single-arm longitudinal study aimed at reducing inappropriate antipsychotic use in long-term care residents with behavioral and psychological symptoms of dementia.
abstract: BACKGROUND: Inappropriate use of antipsychotic medications to manage Behavioral and Psychological Symptoms of Dementia (BPSD) persists despite revised guidelines and evidence of associated risks and side effects. The purpose of the Halt Antipsychotic Use in Long-Term Care (HALT) project is to identify residents of long-term care (LTC) facilities associated with antipsychotic drugs and to take an intervention to discontinue (or stop) their prescriptions and cure non-pharmacological drugs. behavior management. METHODS: LTC facilities will be recruited across Sydney, Australia. Resident inclusion criteria would be over 60 years of age, on regular antipsychotic medication and without primary psychotic illness or very severe BPSD, as measured using the Neuropsychiatric Inventory (NPI). Data collection will be done one month and one week before the start of the removal of the prescription";" and after 3, 6 and 12 months. In the pre-prescription period, care staff will be trained on how to reduce and manage BPSD using person-centered approaches, and academic elaboration will be provided to participants' general practitioners. The primary outcome measure will be the reduction of regular antipsychotic medications without the use of substitute psychotropic drugs. Secondary outcome measures would be total NPI and area scores, Cohen-Mansfield Agitation Inventory scores, and adverse events, including falls and hospitalizations. CONCLUSION: Although previous studies have identified strategies to minimize the inappropriate use of antipsychotic drugs in people with dementia living in long-term care, sustainability and prescribing culture for BPSD in aged care remain challenges. The HALT project aims to evaluate the feasibility of a multidisciplinary approach for prescribing antipsychotics in this population.

title: Leveraging the power of default options to improve healthcare
abstract: Decision makers are sometimes faced with a default choice – one that will be applied when an alternative is not actively chosen. Quality of health care can be improved by default options, such as vaccinating eligible hospitalized patients who do not refuse them. The authors argue that these options should be strategically identified and used to improve public health.

title: Hazards in the workplace
Head Start children's lifestyle behaviors, parents' weight perceptions and body mass index
abstract: This study examined lifestyle behaviors (food intake, active play, and screen time), parental perception of children's weight, and body mass index (BMI) of children enrolled in Head Start. Ninety-six parent-child duos participated. The prevalence of obesity (15.6%) was higher than the national average (10.4%)";" however, most of the parents of obese children (86.5%) do not perceive their children as obese. Regardless of BMI, food intake and active play levels generally did not meet recommended guidelines. Also, less active children were more likely to eat junk food (chi(2) = 6.24, p < or = .04). The role of pediatric nurses in counseling and referral to Head Start families is being investigated.

title: Heal yourself or heal your system: can doctors help improve medical care?
Health and nutrition education unit in a children's hospital
Health information, behavior change and decision support for patients with type 2 diabetes: developing a personalized, preference-sensitive health communication application
abstract: OBJECTIVE: Patient participation in diabetes management, such as joint decision making and patient self-management, has important effects on clinical parameters. As a precondition for active participation, patients need to be informed adequately and sensitive to preferences. Combining web-based health information for patients with additional support, Interactive Health Communication Applications (IHCA) offer the opportunity to reach large numbers of patients at low cost and provide them with high-quality information and support in time, place and learning speed. they prefer. Still, web-based interventions often suffer from high attrition. Tailoring the intervention to patients' needs and preferences should reduce attrition and therefore increase effectiveness. The aim of this study was to develop a custom IHCA that provides evidence-based, preference-sensitive content and treatment decision support to patients with type 2 diabetes. The content was developed based on a needs assessment and two evidence-based treatment guidelines. The delivery format is a conversational, tunneled design that adapts the content and tone of the dialogue to relevant patient characteristics (health literacy, attitudes towards self-care, and psychological barriers to insulin therapy). Both the content and the adaptation were revised by an interdisciplinary advisory committee. CONCLUSION: The World Wide Web has great potential for patient information and self-management interventions. Through the development and evaluation of a dedicated IHCA, we complement patients' face-to-face meetings with their healthcare practitioners and make them more productive and satisfying for both parties. The effects of the app are currently being tested in a randomized controlled trial.

title: Health literacy training for public health nurses in Fukushima: a case study of program adaptation, implementation and evaluation.
abstract: Health literacy includes not only an individual's ability to access, understand and use health information, but also the ability of healthcare providers to make health information accessible and usable. The Fukushima nuclear accident posed difficulties with the transmission of radiation-related health information. Public health nurses are the caretakers of community health in Japan and have a primary responsibility for communicating this complex information about science and risk to ordinary members of the community. A health literacy education program was designed to increase the communication skills of participating nurses with two key objectives: changing communication practices and norms among public health nurses and improving access to information for community residents. The training content included an overview of health literacy skills (including numbers), processes for evaluating written materials and visual representations, and guidelines for text improvement. The workshop was spread over two days with two-hour sessions each day. A proximal post-training assessment questionnaire was conducted, followed by a more distant monthly follow-up assessment to assess practical application of skills learned. Twenty-six nurses from Fukushima City attended the first hearing. Post-training evaluations were very positive, with 85-100% of participants agreeing on the relevance and usefulness of the workshop. During the one-month follow-up, the nurses reported applying new knowledge and skills to develop written materials. However, they faced difficulties in sharing their new skills with their colleagues and changing their work norms. Participants also faced difficulties in using graphs and explaining risks in practice. This article highlights the importance of providing health literacy training opportunities to professionals to strengthen the health system's access to accessible information and services. This program also serves as an important reference for future disaster management efforts.

title: Attitudes of healthcare professionals towards the treatment of acute diarrhea
abstract: BACKGROUND: Traveler's diarrhea is the most common health problem in international travellers and is responsible for many consultations abroad and on the way home. METHODS: A questionnaire was administered to 542 GPs, nurses, and pharmacists assessing attitudes towards the treatment and management of travel-related and non-travel-related diarrhea. CONCLUSIONS: Health professionals' attitudes towards the management of acute diarrhea vary and there are marked differences in adherence to published "good practice" guidelines and recommendations. Inconsistencies exist in stated attitudes and actual prescribing behavior towards prescribing antispasmodics and antimotility agents. CONCLUSIONS: Current treatment guidelines may be outdated. Inappropriate or delayed treatment puts the patient at a disadvantage. Limiting the use of antidiarrheal agents may prevent access to a drug that can shorten symptomatology and morbidity for those suffering from diarrhea and accelerate return to normalcy. Revision of guidelines for the management of diarrhea in adults has been delayed, as has standardization of treatment response. Educational initiatives are necessary to encourage active intervention and improved care delivery.

title: Health promotion in adolescent and young adult cancer survivors: activating compliance in a multifaceted risk profile.
abstract: With increasing cure rates of childhood cancer, the chances of nurse practitioners to encounter a large cohort of survivors in practice have increased. Various late effects programs are available";" however, funding for these programs is limited and not accessible to all patients. Primary providers can increasingly serve as a medical home for childhood cancer survivors (CCS). Understanding the inherent risks of cytotoxic therapy and the progressive consequences of late effects is vital to limit morbidity and mortality. Adolescents and young adults (AYA) who survive are particularly susceptible to making health behavior decisions that put them at risk for comorbidities. Developmentally appropriate experimentation with drug, alcohol or tobacco use and increased ultraviolet light exposure intensifies the risk of secondary malignancies and new diseases. The inadequacy of evidence-based surveillance guidelines and survivor-specific health promotion programs cumulatively widens the gap in non-compliance and misinformation. This article reviews the risk profile of CCS. It explores emerging health promotion techniques and the role of nurse practitioners in advancing health care, as well as health practices within the AFA survivor population.

title: Health systems guidance assessment – a critical interpretative synthesis
abstract: Background Health systems guidance (HSG) are systematically developed statements that assist decisions about options for addressing health system challenges, including relevant changes in health systems regulations. However, the development, evaluation, and reporting of HSG presents unique conceptual and methodological challenges regarding the various types of evidence involved, the complexity of health systems, and the preponderance of contextual factors. To fill this gap, we are conducting a research program that aims to create a tool to support HSG evaluation and to further improve HSG development and reporting. The focus of this article was to conduct a knowledge synthesis of the published and gray literature to identify quality criteria (concepts) related to this process. Methods We applied a critical interpretative synthesis (CIS) approach to knowledge synthesis that enables an iterative, flexible and dynamic analysis of various literatures to generate a candidate concept list that will form key components of the HSG tool. Using our review questions as a compass, we were able to guide the search strategy to search for articles based on their potential relevance to HSG evaluation, development and reporting. The search strategy included various electronic databases and resources, subject-specific journals, conference abstracts, research reports, book chapters, unpublished data, dissertations, and policy documents. Scanning of papers and data extraction was completed independently and in duplicate, and a narrative approach to data synthesis was applied. Results We identified 43 articles that met the eligibility criteria. No existing review on this topic was found and no HSG assessment tool was defined. More than one-third of the authors implicitly or explicitly identified the need for a high-quality tool aimed at systematically evaluating HSG and contributing to its development/reporting. We identified 30 concepts that may be relevant to the assessment of HSG and were able to group them into three meaningful areas: process principles, content and context principles. Conclusions Our study demonstrated the role that quality criteria play in the development, evaluation and reporting of HSG and demonstrated the resonance and interrelationship within and between various concepts in the three domains.

title: Health technologies for monitoring and managing diabetes: a systematic review.
abstract: BACKGROUND: The primary purpose of this review was to determine the strength of the evidence for the effectiveness of self-monitoring devices and technologies for individuals with type 1 diabetes mellitus (T1DM) or type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM) based on specific health outcomes. quantity. Self-monitoring devices included those that assist patients in managing diabetes and preventing cardiovascular complications (CVCs). A secondary aim was to explore feasibility, usability and compatibility issues among patients and providers. METHODS: Study criteria included individuals with T1DM or T2DM >or=14 years and younger (7-14 years), intervention with a self-monitoring device, evaluation of clinical outcomes with the device, English literature, and >or=10 participants. . Relevant published literature was searched from 1985 to 2008. Randomized controlled trials and observational studies were included. Data were extracted for clinical outcomes, feasibility and compliance methods, and outcomes. Selected studies were evaluated independently with an approved tool to assess methodological quality. RESULTS: Eighteen trials were selected. The dominant types of device intervention included self-monitoring of blood sugar, pedometers, and cell phone or wireless technologies. Feasibility and suitability were measured in most studies. CONCLUSIONS: Self-monitoring of blood glucose remains an effective tool for the management of diabetes. Wireless technologies can improve diabetes self-care, and pedometers are effective lifestyle change tools. The results of this review indicate the need for additional controlled trial research on current and new technologies for diabetes self-monitoring, health outcomes associated with diabetes and CVCs, and device feasibility and compatibility.

title: Health system use of risky alcohol drinkers: A secondary data analysis
abstract: OBJECTIVE: To examine the effects of at-risk alcohol use on health care use patterns and health outcomes.
