DATA SOURCES: Using the National Health Interview Survey and the Medical Expenditure Panel Survey, a total of 4449 adults (SD 15) with a mean age of 45 were grouped according to their responses to the question: "In the last year, in how many days have you had 5 or more drinks of any alcoholic beverage?" RESULTS: The three categories of participants were grouped as follows: no-risk group = 0 days 5+ drinks/day (n = 2991, 67%); low-risk group = 1-11 days 5+ drinks/day (n = 796, %) 18) and high-risk group = 12-365 days 5+ drinks/day (n = 662, 15%) Level of risky alcohol use health care use or health outcomes; high-risk alcohol drinkers were less likely to use the health system than other drinkers Rural and urban life, rural high-risk alcohol drinkers reported more emergency room visits, and all rural life groups had worse physical and risky alcohol use, defined as drinking above low-risk guidelines, affects 3 in 10 adults and Risky alcohol use plays a role in more than 60 chronic health conditions.Nurse practitioners encounter risky alcohol users in multiple practice settings Identifying all underlying conditions can be difficult, especially in rural areas alcohol problems in people living in my home;" however, identifying at-risk drinkers is essential for rapid intervention in possible progression from risky alcohol use to alcohol use disorder.

title: Hand decontamination practices of healthcare workers: compliance with recommended guidelines
abstract: OBJECTIVE: This article reports a study on handwashing/hand hygiene practices of healthcare workers from a behavioral perspective. BACKGROUND: Hospital-acquired infection poses a very real and serious threat to all hospital admissions. Pathogens are easily transmitted to the hands of healthcare workers, and hand hygiene significantly reduces this contamination. Evidence-based guidelines exist for HCWs to practice hand hygiene, but compliance is low internationally. METHODS: A quasi-experimental design with a suitable sample was used. Prejudicing, Reinforcing and Facilitating Structures in Educational Diagnosis and Evaluation Health Education Theory was used as the theoretical framework and the data were collected in 2001. Handwashing practices (behavior observation, n=314) and dispositions (attitude, (questionnaire, n=62) beliefs and knowledge of healthcare professionals to comply with hand hygiene rules were examined. Nurses, doctors, physiotherapists and nurses who directly care for patients in the study unit) care assistants participated. The interventional hand hygiene program aimed to prepare HCWs to adopt hand hygiene behavior (poster campaign and educational brochure), reinforce (feedback on pretest results), and activate behavior (providing alcohol hand rub near each patient's bed). Implementation of a multifaceted interventional behavioral hand hygiene program resulted in an overall improvement in adherence to hand hygiene guidelines (51-83%, P < 0.001), and HCWs believed that their skin condition had improved (P < 0.001). CONCLUSIONS: Efforts to improve compliance with handwashing guidelines to be effective It should be versatile. Alcoholic hand lotions (with emollients) should be provided at the bedside of each patient. The issues surrounding skin irritation by healthcare professionals need to be addressed urgently.

title: Self-reported impact of an intervention program on healthcare workers' knowledge and behavior regarding infection control
abstract: INTRODUCTION: Adherence to infection control guidelines is low and various efforts have been made to improve the performance of infection control measures by healthcare professionals. This study describes the performance and evaluation of a hospital-wide infection control program. The most important measure was the distribution of an infection control bulletin. METHODS: In the evaluation of the program, a questionnaire was administered to a randomly selected health worker to investigate the extent to which the health workers were aware of the program and whether they reported behavior change and renewed information as a result of the program. RESULTS: The intervention made it possible to reach >80% of staff in a Norwegian university hospital. Of those who actually read the Infection Control Bulletin, 92.9% reported that their knowledge was renewed and 60.6% reported a change in behavior. CONCLUSION: The intervention had a significant impact on nurses' and nurse assistants' knowledge and behavioral reports on infection control. Our study supports the importance of a long-term and multimodal approach to healthcare professionals in infection control studies. The time and resources spent preparing and distributing the Infection Control Bulletin was an effective way to reach large numbers of healthcare professionals.

title: Healthy active living: physical activity guidelines for children and adolescents
abstract: The childhood obesity epidemic is increasing globally. Although risk factors for obesity are multifactorial, most are lifestyle related and may be appropriate for intervention. These factors include the frequency, intensity, amounts and types of physical activity, as well as sedentary time and non-exercise activity thermogenesis. It is ideal for frontline health care practitioners to monitor the physical activity levels of children, adolescents and their families, evaluate lifestyle choices and offer appropriate counselling. This report provides guidelines for reducing sedentary time and increasing physical activity level in the pediatric population. Developmentally appropriate physical activity recommendations are provided for infants, toddlers, preschoolers, children and adolescents. Include advocacy strategies to promote healthy active living at the local, municipal, provincial/provincial, and federal levels.

title: Healthy Life After Cancer: a dissemination and implementation study evaluating a healthy lifestyle program delivered by telephone for cancer survivors
abstract: BACKGROUND: Given the evidence that physical activity, a healthy diet, and weight management can improve cancer outcomes and reduce the risk of chronic disease, leading cancer organizations and health authorities have endorsed relevant guidelines for cancer survivors. Despite these and growing evidence of effective lifestyle interventions, there is limited participation in survival care. METHODS/DESIGN: Healthy Living After Cancer (HLaC) is a national dissemination and practice study that will evaluate the integration of an evidence-based lifestyle intervention for cancer survivors into an existing telephone cancer information and support service provided by Australian state-based Cancer Councils. . Eligible participants (adults who have completed cancer treatment with curative intent) will receive 12 health coaching calls from Cancer Council nurses/assistant health professionals for 6 months, targeting national guidelines for physical activity, healthy eating and weight control. Using the RE-AIM assessment framework, primary outcomes are service-level indicators of program access, adoption, implementation/costs, and care, and secondary (efficacy) results for patient-reported anthropometric, behavioral, and psychosocial variables are aggregated preliminary and recently. program completion. The total participant accrual target in the four participating Cancer Councils is 900 over 3 years. DISCUSSION: The national scope of the project and broad inclusion of cancer survivors, along with an assessment of service level indicators, associated costs, and patient-reported outcomes, will provide the necessary practice-based evidence needed to inform the future allocation of resources to support wellness. among cancer survivors. TRIAL REGISTRATION: Australian and New Zealand Clinical Trials Registry (ANZCTR)--ACTRN12615000882527 (registered 24/08/2015).

title: Height, body mass index and socioeconomic status: a mendelian randomization study in the UK Biobank.
abstract: OBJECTIVE To determine whether height and body mass index (BMI) have a causal role in five measures of socioeconomic status. DESIGN Mendelian randomization study to test for causal effects of differences in height and BMI on five measures of socioeconomic status. Mendelian randomization takes advantage of the fact that genotypes are randomly assigned at the time of fertilization and thus are not confused with non-genetic factors. SET UK Biobank. PARTICIPANTS 119,669 men and women of British descent aged 37 to 73. MAIN OUTCOME MEASURES Completed full-time education, degree-level education, occupation class, annual household income, and Townsend deprivation index. RESULTS In the UK Biobank study, shorter stature and higher BMI were observationally associated with several measures of lower socioeconomic status. Associations between shorter stature and lower socioeconomic status tended to be stronger in males, and associations between high BMI and lower socioeconomic status tended to be stronger in females. For example, a BMI of 1 standard deviation (SD) higher was associated with €210 (£276"; $300; 95% confidence interval -84 to £420; P. =6 Ãƒâ€” 10(-3)) higher in men lower annual household income and annual household income in women with lower annual household income of Ã‚Â1890 (£1680 to £2100; P=6 Ãƒâ€” 10(-15)) Genetic analysis provided evidence that these associations are partially causal. Genetically determined 1 SD (6.3 cm) taller height resulted in a 0.06 (0.02 to 0.09) higher age at completing full-time education (P=0.01), 1.12 probability of working in a skilled occupation (1 .07 - 1.18) times higher (P=6 - 10(-7)) and € 1130 (£680 - £1580) higher annual household income (P=4 µ 10(-8)) Male relationships was stronger. Genetically determined 1 SD caused higher BMI (4.6 kg/m(2)) Ã€2940 (Â€) Â£1680 - £4200;” P=1 Ãƒâ€” 10(-5)) lower annual household income and 0.10 (0.04 to 0.16) SD (P=0.001) higher levels of deprivation in women only. CONCLUSIONS These data support the evidence that various aspects of a person's socioeconomic status, particularly women's BMI for income and deprivation, and height and BMI play an important partial role in determining men's height for education, income, and work class. These findings have important social and health implications and support the evidence that overweight people, especially women, are at a disadvantage and taller people, especially men, are advantageous.

title: Helicobacter pylori management: how to improve therapeutic confusion in practice
abstract: There appears to be a disconnect between current guidelines for Helicobacter pylori testing and treatment and clinical practice, including physician beliefs and actual prescribing patterns. In particular, there are markedly different approaches to primary and secondary care and country-specific differences in eradication therapy for H pylori infection. Although most doctors do not believe that H pylori causes non-ulcer dyspepsia, the majority seem to prescribe eradication. Less is known about the management of H pylori infection and gastroesophageal reflux disease, resulting in more marked differences in attitude and practice. Even in peptic ulcer disease, where most clinicians in both primary and secondary care believe that H pylori must be eradicated, there is often a breakdown in putting this belief into practice. There is also confusion about treatment regimens for H pylori eradication. Eradication regimens are less successful in practice than clinical trials. Moreover, a significant proportion of patients with peptic ulcer remain symptomatic despite treatment for ulcer diathesis, which can undermine confidence. Therapeutic confusion about what to prescribe, adverse effects limiting compliance, bacterial resistance, and socioeconomic factors can all impair therapeutic success with eradication therapy in practice. Unfortunately, it is well documented that guidelines alone have little or no effect in practice. Its publication in a journal is unlikely to lead to effective practice in primary care. Based on the available evidence, clinical behavior is likely to change when guidelines are developed by the intended peer group of clinicians, disseminated through a specific training program, and implemented by applying specific reminders, preferably during consultation. .

title: Helping doctors and patients understand health statistics
abstract: Many doctors, patients, journalists, and politicians alike do not understand what health statistics mean or inadvertently draw false conclusions. Collective statistical ignorance refers to the widespread inability to understand the meaning of numbers. For example, many citizens do not realize that higher survival rates with cancer screening do not mean longer life, or that the statement that mammography screening reduces the risk of dying from breast cancer by 25% actually means that 1 in 1000 women will die less. your disease. We present evidence that statistical literacy is (a) common to patients, journalists, and doctors"; (b) is created by the opaque framing of information, which is sometimes the unintentional result of a lack of understanding, but can also be the result of deliberate efforts to manipulate or persuade people and (c) it can have serious health consequences The causes of statistical literacy should not be attributed solely to cognitive biases but to the emotional nature of the doctor – the patient relationship and conflicts of interest in the health system. It also makes statistical literacy redundant.” So is the traditional combination of determinism (doctors looking for causes, not chances) and the illusion of certainty (patients looking for certainty when there is nothing). We show that fact sheets, Web sites, brochures, and even medical journals distributed to physicians by the pharmaceutical industry frequently report in opaque forms of evidence suggesting major benefits and minor harms of specific interventions. Without understanding the numbers involved, the public is open to political and commercial manipulation of their concerns and hopes, which undermines the goals of informed consent and shared decision-making. What can be done? We discuss the importance of teaching statistical thinking and transparent representations in primary and secondary education and medical school. But this requires early familiarization with the concept of probability and teaching children statistical literacy as the art of solving real-world problems rather than applying formulas to toy problems with coins and dice. An important prerequisite for statistical literacy is transparent risk communication. We recommend using frequency expressions instead of single event probabilities, absolute risks instead of relative risks, mortality instead of survival rates, and natural frequencies instead of conditional probabilities. There is a call for psychological research on transparent visual and digital forms of risk communication and for the training of physicians in their use. Statistical literacy is a necessary prerequisite for an educated citizenship in a technological democracy. Understanding risks and asking critical questions can also shape the emotional climate in a society so that hopes and worries can no longer be easily manipulated from the outside and citizens can develop a more informed and relaxed attitude towards their health.

title: Helping hands: a randomized cluster trial to evaluate the effectiveness of two different strategies for promoting hand hygiene in hospital nurses.
abstract: OBJECTIVE: Hand hygiene prescriptions are the most important measure in the prevention of hospital-acquired infections. However, compliance rates are often below 50% of all hand hygiene opportunities. This study aims to evaluate the short- and long-term effects of two different strategies to promote hand hygiene in hospital nurses. METHODS/DESIGN: This is a cluster randomized controlled trial with inpatient wards as the randomization unit. In this study, hand hygiene rules will be applied. Two strategies will be used to increase compliance with hand hygiene guidelines. The latest strategy is derived from the literature and includes training, reminders, feedback and targeting adequate products and facilities. The expanded strategy also includes activities aimed at influencing social influence and developing leadership in groups. The unique contribution of the extended strategy builds on relevant behavioral science theories. The extended strategy includes all the elements of the latest strategy, supported by active commitment and gaining the initiative of the ward management, modeling by informal leaders in the ward, and setting norms and goals within the team. Data will be collected at four points in time at six-month intervals. An average of 3,000 hand hygiene opportunities will be observed across approximately 900 nurses at each time point. DISCUSSION: The implementation and evaluation of an implementation strategy that also targets the social context of the teams can contribute significantly to the overall knowledge in this area. The results from our study will enable us to draw conclusions about the effects of different strategies for the implementation of hand hygiene guidelines, and based on these results we will be able to define a preferred practice strategy for hospital-based nursing. TRIAL REGISTRATION: Study registered as Clinical Trial on ClinicalTrials.gov, file number: NCT00548015.

title: Helping someone with problem drug use: a Delphi consensus study of consumers, caregivers, and clinicians
abstract: BACKGROUND: Problematic use of illicit drugs (ie drug use or addiction) is associated with significant health and social harms, highlighting the need for early intervention and health care participation. Family members, friends and colleagues play an important role in supporting and assisting individuals with problem drug use to seek professional help, but there are conflicting views on how and when this support should be offered. This document reports the development of mental health first aid guidelines for adult problem drug use to help inform community members about how they can help someone who develops problem drug use or is experiencing a drug-related crisis. METHODS: A systematic review of scientific and ordinary literature was undertaken to develop a 228-item questionnaire containing potential first aid strategies to help a person develop a drug problem or experience a drug-related crisis. Three expert panels (29 consumers, 31 caregivers and 27 clinicians) were recruited from Australia, Canada, New Zealand, the United Kingdom and the United States. Panel members independently rated items in three rounds, with strategies to agree on the importance written on the guidelines. RESULTS: The overall response rate over the three rounds was 80% (86% consumers, 81% caregivers, 74% clinicians). The 140 first aid strategies were deemed necessary or important by 80% or more of the panel members. Approved strategies provide information and advice about what problem drug use is and its consequences, how to approach a person about problem drug use, tips for effective communication, what to do if the person does not want to change their drug use, and what to do. if the person seeks (or does not want) professional help, what are the drug-affected situations and how to deal with them, how to deal with adverse reactions that lead to a medical emergency, and what to do if the person is aggressive. RESULTS: The guides provide a consensus resource for community members who want to help someone with a drug problem. It is hoped that the guidelines will lead to better support and understanding for those with problem drug use and facilitate professional help and engagement.

title: The Helsinki Declaration revision continues
Hepatic reactions associated with ketoconazole in the UK
abstract: Ketoconazole was introduced in the UK in 1981. By November 1984, the Drug Safety Committee had received 82 reports of possible drug-induced hepatotoxicity, including five deaths. Analysis of 75 cases with adequate follow-up showed that 16 cases, including three deaths, were likely related to drug therapy. Of the remainder, 48 were likely treatment-related, five were unlikely, and six could not be classified. The mean age of patients in the 16 probable cases was 57.9 years, and hepatotoxicity was more common in women. The mean duration of treatment before the onset of jaundice was 61 days. None of these well-confirmed cases occurred within the first 10 days after treatment. Results of serum liver function tests suggested hepatocellular damage in 10 (63%) of them";" the rest showed a mixed pattern. In contrast, the results of histological examination of the liver often showed evidence of cholestasis. In probable cases, the characteristics of 48 patients were similar. Allergic manifestations such as rash and eosinophilia were rare. Hepatitis was usually reversible when treatment was stopped, and the results of liver function tests returned to normal after an average of 3.1 months. In two of three deaths possibly related to ketoconazole therapy, the drug was continued after the onset of jaundice and other symptoms of hepatitis. Clinical and biochemical monitoring at regular intervals for evidence of hepatitis is recommended during prolonged therapy with ketoconazole to prevent possible serious liver damage.

title: Hepatitis (Hep-Net) qualification network
abstract: About 1 million people in Germany are affected by chronic viral hepatitis. Despite improved treatment options for the treatment of hepatitis B and C, some questions regarding the epidemiology, pathophysiology and treatment are still unclear. Vaccines against hepatitis C and D viruses are still not available. In addition, many patients and their relatives need information about the infection, the course of the disease and treatment options. Hep-Net aims to provide educational information about infection through the integration of physician practices and patient advocacy groups, and strives to provide access to qualified treatment strategies for all patients with treatment indications. After 18 months, the Hep-Net Homepage is showing more than 9000 clicks per day. Consultation hours are quite frequent, via telephone, e-mail services and numerous events in cooperation with Deutsche Leberhilfe eV. In the Hep-Net workhouse, high-standard clinical studies with the first successful results are centrally organized. In addition, key questions in the fields of epidemiology, virology and immunology are covered in collaborative research projects within the network.

title: hepatitis a
The herd: a new phenomenon affecting medical decision-making in multiple sclerosis care? Lessons learned from DIScUTIR MS
abstract: OBJECTIVE: Herd is a phenomenon in which individuals follow the behavior of others instead of making independent decisions based on their private knowledge. In multiple sclerosis (MS), a herd-like phenomenon can occur when a neurologist follows a colleague's therapeutic advice, even though this is not supported by best practice clinical guidelines. There is currently limited information available on the role of herds in medical care. The aim of this study was to determine the prevalence of herd (and associated factors) in MS management. METHODS: We conducted a study across Spain among neurologists with expertise in MS care. Participants answered questions on the management of 20 case scenarios commonly encountered in clinical practice and completed 3 questionnaires and 4 experimental paradigms based on behavioral economics. The herd experiment consisted of a case scenario of a 40-year-old woman who developed a self-limiting neurological event on subcutaneous interferon who was stable for 3 years. There were no new magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) lesions. His neurological examination and disability scores did not change. He was advised by an MS neurologist to switch from interferon to fingolimo, contrary to best practice guidelines. Multivariate logistic regression analysis was performed to evaluate herd-related factors. RESULTS: Of the 161 neurologists invited to participate, 96 completed the study (response rate: 60%). The herd was present in 75 patients (78.1%) and had a similar prevalence in MS specialists and general neurologists (68.8% vs. 82.8%"; "P=0.12). In multivariate analyses, the number of MS patients seen per week was positively associated with herd (odds ratio [OR] 1.08, 95% CI 1.01-1.14). Conversely, physician's age, gender, year of practice, practice environment, or risk preferences were not related to livestock. CONCLUSION: Swarming was a common phenomenon affecting approximately 8 out of 10 neurologists caring for MS patients. The herd can influence medical decisions and lead to worse outcomes in MS management.

title: Heterogeneity: we cannot live with it and we cannot live without it
Heterogeneous demographic and cultural profiles of Chinese-American patients not committed to colorectal cancer screening: a covert class analysis.
abstract: BACKGROUND: Colorectal cancer (CRC) is one of the leading causes of cancer death in Chinese Americans, but CRC screening rates remain low. OBJECTIVE: To better inform clinical practice to effectively promote screening, we examined subgroups of Chinese-American patients who do not follow CRC screening guidelines. METHODS: Using confidential class analysis of data from 327 participants from 18 primary care clinics, we stratified nonadherent patients by sociodemographic, screening barriers, and attitudinal and clinical factors for screening for CRC. RESULTS: The optimal latent class analysis model identified 3 distinct classes: Western healthcare class (36%), Eastern healthcare class (18%), and mixed healthcare class (46%). Western healthcare class patients were highly educated, with an average of 20 years of US residency, a high level of English proficiency, the least Eastern culture views on care, and the most exposure to physician advice, but reported that they did not have time for screening. Patients in the Eastern healthcare class were highly educated elderly and recent immigrants with the least CRC knowledge and the most Eastern cultural views. The mixed-health class patients had a low level of education, had resided in the United States for 20 years, and half had had service from their physicians for at least 3 years, but their knowledge and cultural views were similar to those of Eastern health-class patients. CONCLUSIONS: Nonadherent Chinese-American patients are heterogeneous. It is essential to have future intervention programs tailored to address specific screening beliefs and barriers for subtypes of maladaptive patients. APPLICATIONS FOR IMPLEMENTATION: Training primary care physicians to recognize patients' different demographic characteristics and healthcare beliefs can facilitate communication with patients to overcome barriers and improve screening behaviors.

title: Heterogeneous Effect of Emergency Service Expert Graphic System
abstract: STUDY OBJECTIVE: We compare the results obtained from different modules of the Emergency Service Expert Table System (occupational exposure to blood and body fluids, low back pain and fever in children). Each module of this electronic medical record provides real-time recommendations based on clinical guidelines embedded in the software. METHODS: Childhood fever, low back pain, and occupational exposure to blood and body fluids in the emergency department of a university hospital. We measured documentation quality as the percentage of key items included in the medical record and discharge instructions, the percentage of appropriate testing and treatment decisions, median fees per patient visit, physician satisfaction with pre-experiment and post-experiment surveys, and patient satisfaction based on: phone survey. RESULTS: Emergency Service Expert Graphics System improved documentation rates for all modules. The Emergency Room Specialist Table System has consistently improved the relevance of diagnostic testing and the relevance of treatment decisions for patients occupationally exposed to blood and body fluids, while also reducing median wages. For low back pain and fever in the children's modules, improvements in the suitability of testing and treatment were less consistent and did not result in a reduction in wages. Although physicians generally supported the intervention, physicians' use of the Emergency Service Specialist Table System and their satisfaction with the modules were mostly related to occupational exposure to blood and body fluids, and least to fever in children. For each referral complaint, average patient satisfaction was highest in the Emergency Service Specialist Table System stage. CONCLUSION: Delivery of guidelines via an electronic medical record with background decision support improved documentation, patient care, and patient satisfaction, although the effects were heterogeneous among complaints submission. The optimal guideline implementation strategy will likely depend on the nature of the clinical problem and the type of healthcare delivery environment. For selected problems, providing guidelines in this format over the Internet holds great promise for changing physician behavior and improving care (see http://www.needlestick.mednet.ucla.edu).

title: High-risk management guidelines for elderly suicidal patients in primary care settings
abstract: Older adults, especially older white men, are more likely to commit suicide than any other age group. Evaluation and management of suicidal ideation and behavior for the elderly is especially important to primary care physicians, as many patients visit their physicians shortly before committing suicide. In 1993, the Agency for Healthcare Policy and Research (AHCPR) published clinical practice guidelines for the treatment of depression in primary care settings. The AHCPR guidelines have provided some assistance in identifying and treating suicidal patients. However, this guideline lacked detailed and specific instructions for managing high-risk patients in the context of intervention research. Current guidelines include (1) a general approach to interacting with suicidal patients; (2) structured assessments to determine the degree of suicide risk; (3) crisis intervention strategies; Building on this previous work by defining and (4) ongoing management procedures for working with suicidal patients in primary care.

title: Historical background of changes in FDA policy regarding the review and evaluation of drugs in women
abstract: The Food and Drug Administration (FDA) has recently made two major changes to its policy for the examination and evaluation of drugs in women: (1) gender-specific analyzes of the safety and efficacy of drugs will be required as part of all new drugs. (2) it will no longer be recommended to restrict women of childbearing potential from participating in the early stages of drug trials. These changes have come as a result of continued efforts to individualize therapy, improve the safety and efficacy of drugs, and answer important questions about whether the drug development process has produced adequate information about the effects of drugs in women. In turn, these efforts are the result of a long history of changes in clinical care for women in the United States, changes in the use of women as research subjects, and shifting attitudes about the balance between protection and risks for women in clinical trials. and national movements to focus on women's health issues and transform the male-focused clinical research model. The new FDA guidelines, published in July 1993, will guide researchers in gathering valuable information about how drugs work in women and help doctors and other caregivers consider the effects of sex on health and treatment.

title: Evidence-based medicine history. Oranges, lime chloride and leeches: barriers to teaching old dogs new tricks
abstract: Knowledge translation is the process of taking evidence from research and applying it in clinical practice. In this article, I will highlight some key moments in the history of medicine to highlight the difficulties and delays in putting the evidence into practice. These historical examples have much in common with modern medical trials and quality improvement processes. I will also review the reasons for not using evidence and consider what factors make it easier to obtain evidence. Understanding these concepts will facilitate individual clinicians and institutions to change clinical behavior and provide a starting point for those wishing to implement 'new' practices, new therapies and clinical guidelines. Finally, I will present a list of criteria that clinicians may choose to consider when deciding to adopt a new practice, treatment, or concept.

title: HIV prevention in Mexican schools: prospective randomized review of intervention.
abstract: OBJECTIVE To evaluate the effects of an HIV prevention program that promotes condom use with and without emergency contraception at school on condom use and other sexual behaviors. DESIGN Cluster randomized controlled trial. SETTING 40 public high schools in the state of Morelos, Mexico. PARTICIPANTS 10 954 first year high school students. INTERVENTION Schools were randomized into one of three arms: an HIV prevention course that promotes condom use, the same course with emergency contraception as a backup, or an existing sex education course. Self-administered anonymous questionnaires were completed at baseline, four months, and 16 months. Students in intervention schools took a 30-hour course (over 15 weeks) in HIV prevention and life skills, designed in accordance with the guidelines of the joint United Nations program on HIV/AIDS. In the introduction of the contraception arm and condom, the students were given two hours of extra training on emergency contraception. MAIN OUTCOME MEASURES The primary outcome measure, condom use, was reported. Other outcomes were “sexual activity”; knowledge and attitudes about HIV and emergency contraception; and attitudes and confidence regarding condom use. RESULTS The intervention did not affect reported condom use. Both HIV knowledge in the intervention arms and knowledge of emergency contraception in the contraception arm and condom promotion increased. Reported sexual behavior was similar in the intervention arms and control group CONCLUSION A rigorously designed, implemented and evaluated HIV education course in public high schools did not reduce risk behavior, so such courses need to be redesigned and evaluated. The addition of emergency contraception did not reduce reported condom use or risky sexual behavior did not increase, but did increase the reported use of emergency contraception.

title: HIV/AIDS competency network research group presents first results
abstract: Germany's clinical HIV research efforts are underrepresented internationally. This shortcoming is primarily due to the lack of clinical trials involving patients from across the country and the absence of any national patient cohort system in Germany that could provide a basis for such clinical trials. The HIV/AIDS qualification network fills this gap by serving as a comprehensive nationwide research alliance. The creation of a patient cohort is linked to 20 projects. The success of this new structure becomes visible.

title: Home blood pressure management and improved blood pressure control: results of a randomized controlled trial.
abstract: BACKGROUND: To determine which of the 3 interventions was most effective in improving blood pressure (BP) control, we conducted a 4-arm randomized trial with 18-month follow-up at primary care clinics at the Veterans Affairs Medical Center. METHODS: Eligible patients were randomized to usual care or to one of 3 telephone-based intervention groups: (1) nurse-administered behavioral management, (2) nurse- and physician-administered medication management, or (3) a combination of both. Out of 1551 eligible patients, 593 were randomized";" 48% were African American. Intervention phone calls were triggered based on home BP values transmitted via telemonitoring devices. Behavior management included promoting health behaviors. Medication management included the adjustment of medications by a study doctor and nurse based on hypertension treatment guidelines. RESULTS: The primary outcome was change in BP control measured at 6-month intervals over 18 months. Both behavioral management and drug management alone were at 12.8% (95% confidence interval [CI], 1.6-24.1%) and 12.5% (95% CI, 1.3%) at 12 months. -23.6% showed significant improvements – but not at 18 months. In subgroup analyzes, among those with poor baseline BP control, systolic BP at 12 months was 14.8 mm Hg (95% CI, -21.8 to -7.8 mm Hg) and 8.0 mm Hg (95% CI) in the combined intervention group. , - 15.5 to -0.5 mm Hg) at 18 months based on usual care. RESULTS: Overall intervention effects were moderate, but effects were greater among individuals with poor blood pressure control at baseline. This study demonstrates the importance of identifying the individuals most likely to benefit from potentially resource-intensive programs. TRIAL REGISTRATION: Clinicaltrials.gov Identifier: NCT00237692.

title: Home health care nurses as a new channel for smoking cessation treatment: Results of the CARES project (Community-Nurse Supported Research and Smoking Education)
abstract: BACKGROUND: Clinical guidelines for smoking cessation may not be sufficient to assist some subgroups of smokers to quit. Including smoking cessation in home medical care can proactively reach high-risk smokers who do not have access to (or are unable to spontaneously quit) smoking. METHOD: Home health care nurses (N = 98) were randomly assigned to provide their patients with Enhancement of Motivation (ME"; Motivational Interview + Carbon Monoxide Feedback) or Standardized Care (AHCPR Guidelines for quitting smoking). Seventy percent of patients were available and willing to participate ( N = 273;" 54% female, mean age = 57 years, 83% Caucasian, 41% 0.05). ME reported more quit attempts and a significantly greater reduction in the number of cigarettes smoked per day at all follow-ups for 12 months after treatment (all P values < 0.05). CONCLUSIONS: Using an existing public health channel, such as home health care, to reach smokers with different motivations to quit smoking can have the potential to have a major impact on public health.

title: Hormonal breast cancer agents: implications for the primary care provider
abstract: OBJECTIVE: There are more than 2 million breast cancer survivors in the United States, making women with breast cancer the largest group of cancer survivors. The purpose of this article is to review current knowledge of survival issues in women with early-stage, estrogen-receptor-positive breast cancer and to focus on advances in hormonal therapies to reduce the risk of recurrence. DATA SOURCES: Published research studies, clinical treatment guidelines, and ongoing clinical trials. CONCLUSIONS: Innovations in antiestrogenic and estrogen modulatory therapies are an important aspect of ongoing care after primary breast cancer treatment. Primary care providers can play an important role in monitoring potential complications of antiestrogenic therapy. APPLICATIONS TO PRACTICE: This article reviews the current state of science in hormonal breast cancer agents for breast cancer survivors. With the high incidence and prevalence of breast cancer, primary care providers need to be aware of the potential short- and long-term health risks and benefits of hormonal therapies for breast cancer survivors.

title: Discontinuation of hormone therapy: Physician practices after the Women's Health Initiative
abstract: OBJECTIVE: No guidelines or randomized studies address best practices for discontinuation of hormone therapy (HT). METHODS: To explore the implications of HT cessation at Group Health and Harvard Vanguard, the large integrated healthcare systems in the Northwest and Northeast United States, we conducted a survey focusing on differences between specialties and field of study. RESULTS: The response rate to the written questionnaire (posted between December 2005 and May 2006) was 78.5% (736/928)"; this article reports the results of 483 eligible physicians. Most physicians (91%) advised to discontinue oral HT. not immediate discontinuation (8%) and most (60%) recommended reduction of both dose and days of the week. About 60% of physicians reported no experience with tape reduction. Harvard Vanguard physicians more likely to encourage discontinuation than Group Health physicians A woman is less likely to recommend continuing HT when her symptoms return after stopping HT. only 2% were based on research evidence. Physicians have approved a variety of approaches to manage symptoms after discontinuation of HT, mostly behavioral changes (44%) and increased exercise (37%), and these approaches have been endorsed by Harvard Vanguard physicians and obstetrician/gynecologists from Group Health physicians or family practitioners or internists. CONCLUSIONS: There is no standard protocol for discontinuing HT in the two health plans in the Northwest and Northeast United States. Physicians customized approaches influenced by their position, colleagues, and expertise. Research is needed to guide approaches for HT discontinuation.

title: Hospital building on the NHS. Ideas and designs II: harness and core
Hospital clinicians' sensitivity to test cost feedback: a prospective blinded controlled intervention study.
Attitudes of hospital doctors towards smoking behavior and cessation interventions for patients: A survey at an Italian Comprehensive Cancer Center.
abstract: OBJECTIVE: Tobacco control guidelines recommend that all healthcare professionals ask patients about their smoking status and give them at least minimal cessation advice. However, little data are available on the day-to-day practice of hospital clinicians working with cancer patients who smoke. In this study, the smoking habits of physicians in a comprehensive cancer center, their clinical practice in providing smoking cessation interventions to smokers, and the training they received in this area are evaluated. METHODS: A Web-based questionnaire was sent to 285 physicians. RESULTS: The survey response rate was 75%. 62%, 24%, and 14% of respondents were never-smokers, former and current non-smokers, respectively. Six percent of all responding physicians have already attended smoking cessation training, and 43% declared that they would like to receive training. Of all responding physicians, 86% asked about patients' smoking status, 50% recommended patients routinely quit smoking, and 32% rated their motivation to do so. Smoking cessation guidelines were not followed mostly due to lack of time, fear of increasing the stress of patients and lack of smoking cessation education. Of the physicians surveyed, 94% referred to the outpatient smoking cessation service, 65% referred at least one patient, 66% knew the inpatient service, and 36% requested at least one intervention in the ward. CONCLUSION: This study showed that physicians working in a leading cancer center partially complied with smoking cessation guidelines. Clinicians' smoking habits did not affect clinical practice and education in providing smoking cessation interventions to patients.

title: Research shows that household income directly affects children's development
abstract: A new report by the social policy research charity Joseph Rowntree Foundation concludes that children in low-income households have worse cognitive, socio-behavioral and health problems.1 The report says money makes a direct difference to children. not because it is associated with low income, parental education level, child-rearing attitudes, and other parental factors. Kerris Cooper and Kitty Stewart of the Ã¢â'¬Â¦ Center

title: How did formative research inform the development of a women's group intervention in rural Nepal?
abstract: The failure to reduce newborn and maternal mortality in poor countries is sometimes blamed on the lack of contextual information about care practices and care-seeking behaviour. There is a lack of information on how to translate formative research into effective interventions to improve maternal and newborn health. We describe the findings of formative research and how they have been used to inform the development of such an intervention in rural Nepal. Formative research was carried out in four parts. Part 1 included field familiarity and literature review, and chapters 2, 3, and 4 included qualitative and quantitative studies of community mapping, health care supervision, and perinatal care behaviors. Participatory approaches have been successful in reducing neonatal deaths and may be appropriate in our context. Community mapping and profiling helped define community context, and we have seen community-based organizations often try to involve Community Mobility Women Volunteers in community mobilization. He did not routinely hold monthly meetings and found them difficult to maintain without support and supervision. Most primary care staff in health facilities were on duty, but referral centers lacked doctors and nurses. Mortality estimates reflecting underreporting of deaths and coverage of hygiene and infection control strategies were low. Most women give birth at home with their mother-in-law, friends and neighbors. During perinatal illness, care was often sought from traditional healers. Cultural problems such as shyness, fear and normality restricted women's behaviors during pregnancy, childbirth and postpartum period, and decisions about their health were generally taken after communication with family and society. Formative research demonstrated the type of intervention that could be successful. It should be community based and not just for pregnant women. It should address discussions within families and provide information based on the needs of local groups and specific stakeholders such as mothers-in-laws and traditional healers. Intervention should not only acknowledge cultural constructs, but also be a forum for discussing ideas of pollution, shame and seclusion. We used these guidelines to develop a participatory, community-based women's group intervention facilitated through a community action cycle. The success of our intervention may be due to its acceptability at the community level and its sensitivity to the needs and beliefs of families and communities.

title: How Do Clinicians Prefer Cultural Competence Education? Findings from the DSM-5 Cultural Formulation Interview Field Trial
abstract: OBJECTIVE: The purpose of this study is to analyze the training methods, reasons, and relationships between demographic characteristics and method preferences that were reported to be the most and least helpful by clinicians during the DSM-5 Cultural Formulation Interview field trial. METHOD: The authors used mixed methods to analyze interviews from 75 clinicians on five continents regarding their training preferences after a standardized training session and the clinicians' initial administration of the Cultural Formulation Interview. Content analysis identified the most and least helpful training methods by reason. Bivariate and logistic regression analysis compared clinician characteristics with method preferences. CONCLUSIONS: Often, clinicians called case-based behavioral simulations the "most helpful" and video the "least helpful" training methods. Unadjusted and then country-clustered bivariate and logistic regression models found that each additional year of a clinician's age was associated with a preference for behavioral simulations: OR = 1.05 (95% CI: 1.01-1.10";" p = 0.025). CONCLUSIONS: Most clinicians preferred active behavioral simulations in cultural competence training, and this effect was most pronounced among older clinicians. Effective training is best accomplished through a combination of written instruction review, video demonstration, and behavioral simulations. Future studies may examine the impact of clinician education satisfaction on patient symptoms and quality of life.

title: How does the self-reported clinical management of patients with low back pain relate to the attitudes and beliefs of health care practitioners? A survey of UK general practitioners and physical therapists
abstract: Guidelines for the management of low back pain (LBP) have been available for many years, but adherence to them by healthcare practitioners (HCPs) is still not optimal. The aim of this study was to measure the attitudes, beliefs and reported clinical behavior of UK physical therapists (PTs) and general practitioners (GPs) about LBP and to explore the relationships between them. A cross-sectional questionnaire was conducted by mail among GPs (n=2000) and PTs (n=2000) including the Pain Attitudes and Beliefs Scale (PABT.PT) and a vignette of a patient with nonspecific LBP (NSLBP). with questions asking advice on work, activity and bed rest. Data from 1022 participants (442 GPs and 580 PTs) who had recently treated patients with LBP were analyzed. While the majority of HCPs reported that they made recommendations for the sketch patient that were broadly consistent with the guidelines recommendations, 28% reported that they would advise this patient to stay away from work. Job advice, opt-out advice with PABS.PT scores associated with higher biomedical (F(1.986)=77.5, p<0.0001) and lower behavioral (F(1.981)=31.9, p<0.001) scores was significantly associated with We have shown that the attitudes and reported practice behaviors of UK practitioners and PTs for patients with NSLBP are diverse. Many HCPs had the belief that LBP required some avoidance from activities and work. The attitudes and beliefs of these HCPs were correlated with their self-reported clinical behavior regarding work-related advice. Future studies need to explore whether approaches aimed at modifying these HCP factors can lead to better patient outcomes.

title: How many steps/day is enough? for children and adolescents
abstract: Worldwide, public health physical activity guidelines place special emphasis on the child (typically 6-11 years) and adolescent (typically 12-19 years) populations. Existing guidelines are often expressed in terms of frequency, duration, and intensity of behavior. However, the simple step output from both accelerometers and pedometers is gaining increasing credibility in research and practice as a reasonable estimate of daily ambulatory physical activity volume. Therefore, the purpose of this article is to review the available child and adolescent, objectively tracked step-definition physical activity literature to provide researchers, practitioners, and ordinary people who use accelerometers and pedometers with evidence-based translations of these public health guidelines in terms of steps. /day. In terms of normative data (ie, expected values), the updated international literature states that 1) among children, boys average 12,000 to 16,000 steps per day and girls average 10,000 to 13,000 steps per day; and, 2 18-year-olds about 8,000 to 9,000 steps/day. Controlled cadence studies for adolescents to steadily reduce their steps/days until observed show that continuous MVPA walking produces 3,300-3,500 steps in 30 minutes or 6,600-7,000 steps in 60 minutes. age) shows that a total volume of physical activity of 10,000-14,000 steps per day is associated with 60-100 minutes of MVPA. for adolescents (both boys and girls), 10,000 to 11,700 correlated to 60 miles Nuts of the reviveable MVPA. Translations of time- and intensity-based guidelines may be higher than available normative data (for example, in adolescents) and therefore more difficult to obtain (but not impossible or contraindicated). The recommendations are preliminary and more research is needed to confirm and extend values for cadences, associated velocities and MET values measured in young people; continue to accumulate normative data (expected values) for both steps/day and MVPA across ages and populations;" and, in children and adolescents, conduct longitudinal and intervention studies as needed to inform the shape of step-defined physical activity dose-response curves for various health parameters .

title: How much does the quality of childcare differ among health professionals with different training periods? An observational multi-country study
abstract: Background Countries with high child mortality rates tend to have a shortage of skilled health workers. Little conclusive evidence has been done to assess how much quality of care differs between types of healthcare workers. We compared the performance of different categories of healthcare professionals trained in Integrated Management of Childhood Diseases (IMCI).";" Background Countries with high child mortality rates tend to have a shortage of skilled health workers. Little conclusive evidence has been done to assess how much quality of care differs between types of healthcare workers. We compared the performance of different categories of healthcare professionals trained in Integrated Management of Childhood Diseases (IMCI).

title: How institutional escalation prevention potential impacts the success of implementing innovations: electronic medical records in hospitals
abstract: Background Engagement is the tendency to continue (innovation) projects even when it is clear that they will not be successful and/or will be excessively costly. The ability to stop or redirect implementation processes that do not meet an organization's expectations, anti-escalation potential (EPP) can prevent an organization from wasting time and money on failed projects. EPP consists of a set of checks and balances built into managerial practices that protect management against irrational (but very human) decisions and can limit the escalation of implementation projects. We explore whether successful implementation of electronic medical records (EMRs) is related to EPP and the organizational factors that create this relationship. Methods Structural equation modeling (SEM), using survey data from 427 doctors and 631 nurses with experience in the implementation and use of EMRs in hospitals, was applied to examine whether formal governance and organizational culture mediated the relationship between EPP and perceived added value. EMRs. Results Doctors and nurses in hospitals with more EPPs report more successful implementation of EMR (in terms of perceived added value of EMR). Formal governance mediates the relationship between EPP and implementation success. We found no evidence that an open or innovative culture explains the relationship between EPP and implementation success. Results There is a positive correlation between the level of EPP and the perceived added value of EMRs. This relationship is explained by the formal governance mechanisms of organizations. This means that management has a set of tangible tools to positively influence the success of innovation processes. However, it also means that management must be able to critically reflect on (previous) actions and decisions and be willing to change plans if EPP elements indicate that the implementation process is hindered.

title: How payment systems affect physicians' procurement behavior - an empirical study.
abstract: Understanding how physicians respond to incentives from payment plans is a central concern in health economics research. We present a controlled laboratory experiment to analyze the impact of incentives from fee-for-service and per-capita payments on doctors' medical service supply. In our experiment, physicians select the amounts of medical care for patients with different health conditions. We see that doctors offer significantly more services on a per-service basis than per person. Patients are over-serviced and under-serviced per person. However, payment incentives are not the only motivation for physicians' quantity choices, as patients' health benefits are also of great importance. We found that patients with a high (low) level of need for medical services receive more health benefits under the fee-for-service (pay per person).

title: How science thinks and practices: filling the gap in weight management interventions for adolescents
abstract: BACKGROUND: Adolescent obesity requires evidence-based treatment approaches given its long-term physical and psychosocial consequences. But research shows that there are many problems with putting scientific evidence into practice. OBJECTIVE: The aim of this study was to develop science- and practice-based recommendations for planning future adolescent weight management interventions. METHODS: (i) literature reviews on intervention studies targeting the treatment of adolescent obesity and Dutch clinical guidelines for obesity, as well as practice-based documents and gray literature on the delivery of obesity treatment and health programs for adolescents, and (ii) semi-structured treatment of adolescent obesity and use of evidence in practice. Interviews with eight clinicians and four non-clinicians working in obesity treatment, management and prevention to explore perspectives on RESULTS: After combining results from literature reviews and interviews, four issues emerged: (i) very few reports on theoretical models used in intervention studies, Dutch clinical guidelines and semi-structured interviews"; (ii) obesity in adolescents in intervention studies and Dutch clinical guidelines. (iii) inconsistency in addressing the social nature of obesity in intervention studies and Dutch clinical guidelines, and (iv) how professional responsibility should be divided is not clear from intervention studies, Dutch clinical guidelines and semi-structured interviews CONCLUSIONS: Joint action of science and practice for future interventions Future interventions should include issues related to the adolescence stage and focus more on the complex social nature of obesity Finally, practitioners can generate more practice-based evidence by starting their own practice-based research.

title: How to link causality in quality improvement: lessons learned from epidemiology
How to improve the acceptance and use of colon cancer screening recommendations by physicians and the public?
abstract: The Colorectal Cancer (CRC) screening presentation is a multidisciplinary initiative that aims to reduce the incidence and mortality from CRC without adversely affecting the health status of the participants. Adopting a public health perspective includes a commitment to ensure equity in access and sustainability of the program over time. We reviewed the available evidence on predictors of CRC screening uptake and the impact of interventions to improve screening adoption, using conceptual frameworks that define the role of determinants of preventive behaviors and the reach and target of interventions. The results of this review suggest that policy measures aimed at supporting screening delivery as well as organizational changes affecting the operational characteristics of preventive services must be implemented to allow the individual's motivation to finally materialize. To ensure coverage and equity of access and maximize the impact of the response, policies should be adopted to implement organized programs, ensuring that participation in screening and any follow-up assessment is not constrained by financial barriers. Beliefs of participants and providers may determine the response to different screening methods. To achieve the desired health effect, active monitoring of people with screening abnormalities should be implemented, supported by infrastructure changes and multidisciplinary teamwork that can ensure the sustainability of effective interventions over time. Ongoing monitoring and adoption of plans to evaluate program effectiveness represent important steps in the implementation of a successful program.

title: How are clinical practice guidelines applied in Iran?
abstract: OBJECTIVE: Evidence-based medicine will achieve results with evidence-based practice. Clinical Practice Guidelines (CPG), one of the evidence-based information products, require appropriate interventions after they are produced in order to be implemented. OBJECTIVES: The aim of this qualitative study was to identify strategies for the implementation of CPGs produced in Iran. MATERIALS AND METHODS: Purposeful snowball sampling was carried out and continued until theoretical saturation was reached. In-depth semi-structured individual interviews and Focus Group Discussion (FGD) aiming at triangulation were conducted. The thematic framework approach was used for the analysis. RESULTS: Twelve interviews were conducted with three health system policy makers and decision makers, four with experience in the production or adaptation of clinical practice, and five experts in evidence-based medicine development and education. In addition, 11 policy makers, managers and decision makers of the health system took part in OGD. Suggested interventions are classified into the following themes: Fiscal, Organizational, Regulatory and Multifaceted interventions for health professionals. CONCLUSION: The use of KPGs should be planned along with the adaptation and development process";" otherwise the time and money spent would be in vain. Admittedly, it is beyond the capacity of certain groups or a few academic centers to impose the above-mentioned interventions with the ultimate goal of sustainable behavior change in health system service providers. It requires the participation of all practitioners under the supervision and support of the Ministry of Health and Medical Education. Expanding the family medicine plan and referral system is an opportunity that should be considered as a reward.

title: How are therapeutic recommendations in clinical practice guidelines translated into guidelines for critiquing doctor's prescriptions? Methods and application of the five directives
abstract: BACKGROUND: Clinical practice guidelines give advice on what to do in a variety of medical situations, including therapeutic recommendations for drug prescribing. An effective way to computerize these recommendations is to design critical decision support systems, that is, systems that criticize physician prescriptions when they do not follow guidelines. These systems are commonly based on a list of "if conditions then criticism" rules. However, writing these rules from manuals is no simple task. The purpose of this article is to propose methods that (1) simplify the implementation of the therapeutic recommendations of guidelines in criticism systems by automatically translating structured therapeutic recommendations into a list of "if circumstances criticize" rules, and (2) can produce an appropriate outcome. Text label explaining why the doctor's prescription is not recommended. METHODS: We studied the therapeutic recommendations in five clinical practice guidelines for chronic disease related to cardiovascular risk management. We evaluated the system using a test base of more than 2000 cases. RESULTS: Algorithms are presented to automatically translate therapeutic recommendations into “if conditions criticize” rules. Eight general recommendations are also proposed";" they are independent of the guideline and can be used as default behavior to address various situations often covered in guidelines, such as reducing the dose of a poorly tolerated drug. Finally, we present models and methods for constructing a human-readable text critique. The system was successfully evaluated on a test basis. CONCLUSION: We have shown that it is possible to criticize physician prescriptions and provide clear explanations based on a structured clinical guideline. We are now planning a randomized clinical trial to evaluate the impact of the system on applications.

title: How well do clinicians follow dementia practice guidelines?
abstract: Although there are many clinical guidelines on dementia management, there are few studies on their practical application. Clinicians at six United States Department of Veterans Affairs medical centers (n = 200, 85% response rate) were surveyed to use the practices recommended in the California Working Group Guidelines for Alzheimer's Disease Management. Most providers (89% to 73%) reported routinely performing neurological examinations, taking history from caregivers, discussing diagnosis with patient's family, discussing permanent power of attorney, and making legally required notices for drivers with dementia. Nearly two-thirds of providers said they routinely perform cognitive screening exams, screen for depression, report elder abuse, and discuss care needs and decision-making with patients' families. Only half of outpatients have implemented caregiver support practices for at least half of their patients. Clinicians' choices of drugs for cognition, mood, and behavior problems were largely consistent with current practice guidelines. These results suggest possible priorities for quality improvement efforts. More research is needed to clarify the reasons for specific gaps between guidelines and practice and to identify specific targets for intervention.

title: Human experimentation and medical ethics
Human experimentation in historical and ethical perspectives
abstract: KIE: Prepared as background material for a World Health Organization/Council of International Medical Sciences Organization document, Proposed International Guidelines for Biomedical Research Involving Human Subjects (1982), this article reviews the historical aspects of human experimentation and considers several current issues. It refers to early experiments, including automated experiments by doctors"; traces the history of drug trials through the pharmacotherapeutic revolution and the thalidomide tragedy; and describes the formulation of ethical requirements during the Weimar Republic in Germany. Contemporary issues discussed, use of controls and placebos, as subjects investigators, special categories of subjects, and informed and proxy consent Text of the recommended WHO/CIOMS Guidelines has been added.

title: Human fetal tissue for medical research
Human tissue research: EORTC recommendations on practical implications
abstract: Improvement in cancer treatment is possible with the application of new treatment modalities that emerge from the knowledge and discoveries obtained from laboratory research. This is possible through international collaboration and collection of tumor tissues. The creation of the European Agency for Research and Treatment of Cancer (EORTC) Tumor Bank is a natural step in this direction by offering the opportunity to collect tumor samples from patients entering EORTC trials. The purpose of such a bank is not only to improve the diagnostic review process, but also to facilitate translational research by allowing clinicians and basic scientists to engage in close collaborations. The EORTC Tissue Research Policy was developed under the EORTC legal framework to ensure ethical and scientific review of research projects, to ensure adequate information is provided to patients, to establish procedures for the use of materials, including legal aspects, and to establish publication policies. As part of the EU TubaFrost project, EORTC will provide a common international platform for the research use of tissues, a balance between different laws and scientific progress.

title: Hypertension Improvement Project (HIP): study protocol and implementation challenges
abstract: BACKGROUND: Hypertension affects 29% of the adult US population and is a leading cause of heart disease, stroke, and kidney failure. Despite numerous effective treatments, only 53% of people with hypertension are at target blood pressure. The chronic care model proposes that blood pressure control can be achieved by improving the way patients and physicians handle patient self-care. METHODS AND DESIGN: This article describes the protocol of a 2 x 2 nested randomized controlled trial to test the separate and combined effects of a behavioral intervention for patients and a quality improvement-type intervention for physicians on systolic blood pressure. Primary care practices were randomly assigned to physician intervention or physician control condition. Physician randomization occurred at the clinical level. Physician intervention included education and performance monitoring. The training consisted of 2 internet-based modules detailing both the JNC-7 hypertension guidelines and lifestyle changes for hypertension. Performance data were collected for 18 months and feedback was given to physicians every 3 months. Patient participants in both intervention and control clinics were individually randomized to either patient intervention or usual care. The patient intervention consisted of a 6-month behavioral intervention conducted in 20 group sessions by trained responders, followed by 12-month phone calls by community health counselors. Follow-up measurements were made at 6 and 18 months. The primary outcome was the mean change in systolic blood pressure at 6 months. Secondary outcomes were the proportion of patients with diastolic blood pressure and adequate blood pressure control at 6 and 18 months. CONCLUSION: Overall, 8 treatments (4 per treatment group), 32 physicians (4" per treatment; 16 per treatment group), and 574 patients (289 controls and 285 interventions) were enrolled. The main characteristics of patients and providers and the difficulties encountered during the implementation of the study are presented. By addressing key components of the chronic care model, HIP interventions can improve blood pressure control and reduce cardiovascular disease risk in the primary care setting. The study design allows evaluation of the efficacy and cost of individual physician and patient interventions so that healthcare organizations can make informed decisions about the implementation of one or both interventions in the context of local resources. TRIAL REGISTRATION: ClinicalTrials.gov identifier NCT00201136.

title: Hypertension improvement project: random quality improvement trial for doctors and lifestyle change for patients
abstract: Despite widely publicized hypertension treatment guidelines for physicians and lifestyle recommendations for patients, blood pressure control rates remain low. We conducted a nested, 2 x 2 randomized, controlled trial of control versus physician intervention and/or control versus patient intervention in community-based primary care clinics. Physician intervention included internet-based training, self-monitoring, and quarterly feedback reports. Patient intervention included 20 group sessions per week, followed by 12 months of telephone counseling contact, and focused on weight loss, Dietary Approaches to Stop Hypertension, diet regimen, exercise, and reduced sodium intake. The primary outcome was change in systolic blood pressure at 6 months. Eight primary care practices (32 physicians) were randomized into physician intervention or control groups. Among these practices, 574 patients were randomized to patient intervention or control groups. The mean age of the patients was 60 years, 61% were female and 37% were black. Blood pressure data were available for 91% of patients at 6 months. The main effect of physician intervention on systolic blood pressure at 6 months was 0.3 mm Hg (95% CI: 1.5 to 2.2"; P=0.72), adjusted for baseline pressure. Main effect of patient intervention was 2.6 mm Hg (95% CI: 4.4 to 0.7; P=0.01 The interaction of 2 interventions was significant (P=0.03), with the greatest effect physician and patient intervention (9.7 +/- 12.7) mm Hg) Differences between treatment groups did not persist at 18 months Combined physician and patient interventions lower blood pressure; Future research should focus on improving the efficacy and sustainability of these interventions.

title: Hypertension in black patients: an update
abstract: Black individuals are at high risk for hypertension and increased morbidity, particularly from cardiovascular and renal disease. A better understanding of racial differences in hypertension in terms of risk factors, patient/physician behaviors, and treatment outcomes is key to improving race-focused care in black patients. Recent data suggest that black patients progress more rapidly from prehypertension to hypertension, emphasizing the need for early and prompt intervention. Unfortunately, adherence and persistence to antihypertensive therapy are often poor in black patients, compounded by the increased need for multidrug therapy in this patient population. Treatment strategies currently under investigation focus on methods to improve self-care behaviors and adherence to medication. As this is a constantly and rapidly evolving field of study, this article provides an update of recent findings that should be relevant and interesting to clinicians.

title: Identifying and evaluating salient physical activity beliefs of colorectal cancer survivors
abstract: BACKGROUND: Physical activity (PA) has been associated with a lower risk of disease recurrence and longer survival in colorectal cancer (CRC) survivors";" however, less than a third of CRC survivors meet PA guidelines. Interventions to promote PA in CRC survivors need to understand the most critical beliefs that influence PA behavior. OBJECTIVE: The aim of this study was to examine the strength of associations between the most common PA beliefs of CRC survivors and motivational constructs from Planned Behavior Theory (TPB) and PA behavior. INTERVENTION/METHODS: Colorectal cancer survivors (n = 600) residing in Alberta, Canada completed self-report questionnaires that assessed medical and demographic variables, PA beliefs, constructs from TPB, and PA behavior. RESULTS: Colorectal cancer survivors identified increased vitality (69.5%), family members (67.3%), and medical/health problems (8.8%) as the most common behavioral, normative, and control beliefs, respectively. All PA beliefs were significantly associated with all TPB constructs and PA. CONCLUSIONS: Physical activity interventions for CRC survivors should target multiple salient beliefs, including behavioral, normative, and control beliefs. APPLICATIONS TO PRACTICE: Insights into salient beliefs about PA in CRC survivors can guide nurses in developing successful strategies to promote PA in this population and possibly improve quality of life and possibly disease outcomes.

title: Identifying perceived pain management barriers in Iranian children: a qualitative study
abstract: Hospitalized children often receive inadequate treatment for their pain. Pediatric nurses experience these deficiencies more than other healthcare team members. This research was an attempt in the form of a phenomenological study to uncover some of the key barriers to pain management in children as perceived by nurses. Sixteen nurses were interviewed in the medical, surgical and infectious children's wards of a hospital in Iran. The data analysis was based on the Colaizzi method, which revealed three main themes in different domains: organizational barriers, limitations related to the characteristics of the child, and barriers related to the nature of the illness and its treatments. Study results demonstrated organizational limitations added to the lack of authority to administer some medical interventions, inadequate equipment and ancillary tools, and the absence of opioids as main pain control and limiting factors. Additional factors related to child characteristics such as age, temperament, behavior, expression, and gender influence the assessment and treatment of pain. The results revealed barriers identified in the real context. Some guidelines seem to be needed to achieve optimal pain management.

title: Identification, assessment and management of obesity in an academic primary health care center
abstract: OBJECTIVE: The rapidly increasing prevalence of obesity among children is one of the most challenging dilemmas facing pediatricians today. As the medical community struggles to develop effective strategies to treat this epidemic, timely identification of obesity by pediatric healthcare providers remains a crucial first step in obesity management. OBJECTIVE: A direct evaluation of the performance of pediatric clinicians in detecting and managing obesity in clinical practice has not been performed to date. The aim of this study was to determine the rates at which pediatric residents, nurses, and faculty members identify obesity in an academic primary care setting and describe the measures taken by these providers in assessing and managing obesity. DESIGN: A retrospective medical record review of all health surveillance visits for children aged 3 months to 16 years reviewed between 1 December 2001 and 28 February 2002 was performed. For children, 120% of 50 percent of height-weight was defined as obese. For children > or = 5 years of age, a body mass index >95th percentile for age and sex was defined as obese. SETTING: A large primary care practice located in a tertiary, academic, pediatric hospital serving a predominantly urban, minority (70% African American), Medical Aid insured (90%) population. PARTICIPANTS: Primary care providers, including pediatric residents, nurse practitioners, and faculty physicians. RESULTS: A total of 244 patients out of 2515 visits examined met the working definition of obesity, revealing an estimated prevalence of obesity visits of 9.7% between health surveillance visits for children aged 3 months to 16 years. This prevalence of obesity visits cannot be used to estimate the population prevalence of obesity, given the skewed distribution of visits to very young children. For all children meeting the obesity study definition, providers documented obesity in their evaluations in only 53% (129 visits) of the visits reviewed. Although the majority of tables (69%) contained a history of adequate nutrition, only 15% included a description of the child's activity level or television viewing. Physical examination revealed obesity in 39% of the cases. For children in whom obesity was identified as a problem by clinicians (129 patients), 81% of the charts included a history of adequate nutrition, while 27% included a description of the child's activity level or television viewing. Physical examination revealed obesity in 64% of the cases. Most children identified as obese by their providers received some treatment specific to their obesity, including education, screening, and specialist referral. Dietary changes were recommended for 71%, increased activity for 33%, and television viewing restriction only for 5%. Eighty-three percent of providers recommended close follow-up. Other recommendations included referral to a dietitian (22%), screening laboratory studies (13%), a food diary (9%), endocrine referral (5%), or referral to preventive cardiology (3%). The provider's definition of obesity was influenced by the patient's age and degree of obesity. Diagnosis of obesity was lowest among preschool children (31%) and highest in adolescent patients (76%). Providers who evaluated older and heavier children were also more likely to take activity histories, note obesity on physical examination, recommend activity changes, refer the patient to a nutritionist, receive screening lab studies, and recommend close follow-up monitoring. The determination of obesity and other outcome variables was not significantly affected by provider education or patient gender.
