CONCLUSIONS: Although the prevalence of childhood obesity has now reached epidemic proportions, it was underrecognized and undertreated by pediatric primary care providers in our study. Providers identified obesity as a problem for only half of the obese children examined for health checkup. The lowest obesity identification rates occurred among children <5 years of age and children with milder obesity. Identification did not evolve with additional years of pediatric training. Even for the subgroup of children defined as obese by their providers, assessment and treatment were often inconsistent with current recommendations. For example, more attention has been paid to the role of diet compared to activity in the assessment of obesity. Notably, despite the evidence linking television viewing and pediatric obesity, only a small number of providers (5%) offered a reduction in television viewing to their obese patients. This finding is alarming because obesity is known to be a multifactorial disease that responds to significant changes in both dietary and activity behaviors. Only 13% of providers requested laboratory studies as part of their recommendations. The American Academy of Pediatrics currently recommends screening for a lipid profile, total cholesterol level, and type 2 diabetes mellitus as part of the obesity assessment. Most clinicians who requested laboratory studies included thyroid function tests, which are not recommended by the American Academy of Pediatrics because the likelihood of hypothyroidism as a cause of obesity is very low. While the extent of assessment and management for children considered obese did not meet current guidelines, they were much better than patients not identified as obese by their providers. This illustrates the importance of timely identification as a critical first step in the management of obesity. The results of this study are particularly discouraging as evidence grows for the importance of early intervention in preventing the medical and psychosocial sequelae of obesity and the persistence of obesity into adulthood. This study highlights the need for increased awareness and identification of obesity in primary care, particularly among young children and those with mild obesity.

title: Identifying and reducing errors with surgical simulation
abstract: The main determinant of a patient's safety and outcome is the skill and judgment of the surgeon. While evaluating the knowledge base and decision-making process in the profession, the technical skills inherent in the profession are not. Innovative state-of-the-art simulation devices that train both surgical tasks and skills without posing risk to patients should allow the detection and analysis of errors and "near misses". Studies have validated the use of a sophisticated endoscopic sinus surgery simulator (ES3) for procedural training of residents. Evaluations are ongoing as to whether integrating a comprehensive ES3 training program into residency curricula will have long-term effects on surgical performance and patient outcomes. Using a variety of otolaryngology specialties, subjects receive mentoring training on ES3 as well as minimally invasive trainers such as MIST-VR. Technical errors are identified and measured in the simulator and intraoperatively. Through a web-based database, individual performance can be compared to a national standard. An upgraded version of ES3 will be developed to support patient-specific anatomical models. This advance will allow the effects of simulated rehearsal of patient-specific procedures (task rehearsal) to be investigated on patient outcomes and surgical errors during the actual procedure. The knowledge gained from these studies will help to use the next generation of surgical simulators that are expected to have a significant impact on patient safety.

title: Identifying barriers and facilitators for a triage, treatment, and transfer clinical intervention to manage acute stroke patients in the emergency department: a systematic review using the theoretical domains framework (TDF).
abstract: BACKGROUND: Clinical guidelines recommend that the evaluation and management of stroke patients begin early, including in the emergency services (ED). To inform the development of a targeted practice intervention in the emergency department, we conducted a systematic review of qualitative and quantitative studies to identify relevant barriers and facilitators to six key clinical behaviors in acute stroke care: appropriate triage, management of thrombolysis, monitoring and management of temperature, blood glucose levels, and swallowing difficulties. and transfer of stroke patients in the emergency department. METHODS: Any design study conducted in the emergency department that identifies barriers or facilitators based on primary data for one or more of these six clinical behaviors. Major biomedical databases (CINAHL, OVID SP EMBASE, OVID SP MEDLINE) were searched using comprehensive search strategies. Barriers and facilitators were categorized using the theoretical domain framework (TDF). The behavior modification technique (BCT) that best aligns with the strategy represented by each activator was selected for each of the activators reported using a standardized classification. RESULTS: Of the 44 identified studies, five qualitative studies and four questionnaires met the selection criteria. Most reported barriers correspond to the "environmental, context, and resources" (such as stressful working conditions or lack of resources) and "knowledge" (such as lack of guideline awareness or familiarity) areas of TDF. Most providers corresponded to the areas of "knowledge" (such as education for physicians about the calculated risk of bleeding following intravenous thrombolysis [tPA]) and "skills" (such as providing an opportunity to treat stroke cases of varying complexity). The total number of BCTs assigned was 18. The BCTs most frequently assigned to the reported activators were "focus on past achievement" and "information about health outcomes". CONCLUSIONS: Barriers and facilitators for providing key evidence-based protocols in an emergency were identified and interpreted within a relevant theoretical framework. This new knowledge has since been used to select specific BCTs to implement evidence-based care in an emergency room setting. It is recommended that findings from future similar reviews adopt a similar theoretical approach. In particular, the use of existing matrices to assist in the selection of relevant BCTs.

title: Idiopathic Pulmonary Fibrosis: Common and Emerging Hypotheses About Its Pathogenesis and Effects on Treatment
abstract: Idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis is a progressive and often fatal lung disease characterized by fibroblast proliferation and remodeling of the extracellular matrix, causing irreversible deterioration of lung architecture. Although the pathogenetic mechanisms have yet to be determined, the prevailing hypothesis is that fibrosis is triggered and preceded by a chronic inflammatory process that damages the lung and modulates lung fibrogenesis, leading to end-stage fibrotic scarring. However, there is little evidence that inflammation is evident in early disease, and it is unclear whether inflammation is related to the development of the fibrotic process. Evidence suggests that inflammation does not play a crucial role. Inflammation is not a prominent histopathological finding, and epithelial damage is sufficient to induce fibrosis in the absence of ongoing inflammation. In addition, the inflammatory response to a lung fibrogenic injury is not necessarily related to the fibrotic response. Clinical measures of inflammation do not correlate with stage or outcome, and strong anti-inflammatory therapy does not improve outcome. This review provides a growing body of evidence to suggest that idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis includes abnormal wound healing in response to multiple, microscopic regions of ongoing alveolar epithelial damage and activation associated with the formation of patchy fibroblast-myofibroblast foci that develop into fibrosis. Progress in understanding the fibrogenic mechanisms in the lung will likely enable more effective treatments.

title: If only it were: medical physics, US human radiation experiments, and the Presidential Advisory Committee's (ACHRE) Final Report
The effect of clinical decision support system in prescribing antibiotics for acute respiratory tract infections in primary care: a quasi-experimental study
abstract: Objective To evaluate the impact of a clinical decision support system (CDSS) integrated into an electronic health record (EHR) on antibiotic prescribing for acute respiratory infections (ARIs) in primary care. Materials and methods Quasi-experimental design with nine intervention applications and 61 control applications in the Implementing Partner Research Network, a network of applications all using the same EHR (Practicing Partner). Nine intervention apps were located in nine US states. The design included a baseline data collection period of 3 months (October-December 2009) and a 15-month follow-up (January 2010-March 2011) prior to the start of the intervention. The main outcome measures were prescription of antibiotics in episodes of ARI for which antibiotics were unsuitable and prescription of broad-spectrum antibiotics in all episodes of ARI. Results In adult patients, the prescription of antibiotics in ARI attacks in which antibiotics were inappropriate decreased more in intervention practices (+4.2%) than in control practices (-0.6%) (p=0.03). However, among adults, the CDSS intervention improved the prescribing of broad-spectrum antibiotics, with a 1.1% increase in control practices versus a 16.6% decrease in intervention practices (p<0.0001). A similar effect in broad-spectrum antibiotic prescribing was found in pediatric patients, with a 19.7% decrease in intervention applications versus a 0.9% increase in control applications (p<0.0001). Results A CDSS embedded in an EHR had a modest effect in changing prescribing for adults when antibiotics were not appropriate, but had a significant effect in changing the overall prescription of broad-spectrum antibiotics in pediatric and adult patients.

title: Effect of computerized clinical decision support system on reducing inappropriate antimicrobial use: a randomized controlled trial.
abstract: Objective: Many hospitals leverage antimicrobial management teams (AMTs) to improve patient care. But most of them work with minimal computer support. We evaluated the effectiveness and cost-effectiveness of a computerized clinical decision support system for the management of antimicrobial use. Design: A randomized controlled trial in adult patients hospitalized between May 10 and August 3, 2004. Antimicrobial use was managed by an existing AMT using the system in the intervention arm and without the system in the control arm. The system was developed to alert AMT of potentially inadequate antimicrobial therapy. Measures: Outcomes evaluated were hospital antimicrobial expenditure, mortality, length of hospital stay, and time spent managing antimicrobial use. Results: AMT spent approximately one hour less each day in the intervention arm compared to 359 (16%) of the 2,237 patients in the intervention arm and 180 (8%) of the 2,270 patients in the control arm. Hospital antimicrobial expenditures were $285,812 in the intervention arm and $370,006 in the control arm, resulting in savings of $84,194 (23%), or $37.64 per patient. No significant difference was observed in mortality (3.26% vs 2.95%, p = 0.55) or length of hospital stay (3.84 vs. 3.99 days, p = 0.38). Conclusion: The use of the system has facilitated antimicrobial use management, allowing AMT to treat more patients receiving inadequate antimicrobial therapy, resulting in significant time and cost savings for the hospital. This is the first study to demonstrate in a patient-controlled randomized trial that computerized clinical decision support systems can improve existing antimicrobial management programs.

title: The effect of computerized decision support system on compliance with antibiotic guidelines prescribed for urinary tract infections in emergency departments: a multicenter, prospective, pre- and post-controlled interventional study.
abstract: Objectives Urinary tract infections (UTIs) are one of the leading causes of antibiotic prescriptions in emergency departments (EDs), with half of these antibiotics being prescribed inappropriately. Our aim was to evaluate the impact of a computerized decision support system (CDSS) on compliance with guidelines on empirical antibiotic prescriptions (antibiotic and duration) for UTIs in emergency departments. Methods A multicenter, prospective, pre- and post-controlled interventional study was conducted between 19 March and 28 October 2012. All adults diagnosed with community-acquired UTI (cystitis, pyelonephritis or prostatitis) in three French Emergency Departments were included. If antibiotics and prescribed duration were in accordance with national guidelines, antibiotic therapy was considered in accordance with guidelines. Data were collected using electronic medical records. Paired tests were used when comparing periods within each ED, and global analyzes used multivariate logistic mixed models. Results Nine hundred and twelve patients were included during the 30-week study period. CDSS was used in 59% (182/307) of cases. The CDSS intervention improved compliance with antibiotic prescriptions in only one emergency room in a bivariate analysis (absolute increase +20%, P?=?0.007). Antibiotic selection was improved in multivariate analyses, but only when CDSS was used [OR?=?1.94 (95% CI 1.13--3.32)]. CDSS also changed the initial diagnosis in 23% of cases in all three emergency departments. Results CDSS only partially improved compliance with guidelines for antibiotic prescriptions in UTIs.

title: Effect of a computerized template in prescribing antibiotics for acute respiratory infections in children and adolescents.
abstract: Background. Computerized decision support (CDS) can potentially improve patient safety and guideline compliance. The authors developed an acute respiratory disease interactive template (ARI-IT) within an electronic health record (EHR) to manage pediatric ARIs and evaluated its impact on antibiotic prescribing. The methods randomized 12 applications to either receive ARI-IT or control. Antibiotic ratios among all eligible ARI diagnoses were compared between control and intervention ARI visits by clinician controlling clustering. Results. There was no difference in total antibiotic prescriptions between control and intervention clinics. Use of ARI-IT significantly reduced antibiotic prescriptions (31.7% vs. 39.9%; P = .02) and macrolides use (6.2% vs. 9.5%; P = .02) between visits compared to eligible visits. unused. Solution. The use of CDS has reduced antibiotic prescribing and macrolide prescriptions among children with ARI. However, low overall use has resulted in an ineffective intervention.

title: Impact of a multifaceted intervention on cholesterol management in primary care practice: adherence to guidelines for a heart health randomized trial.
abstract: Past Physicians' adherence to National Cholesterol Education Program clinical practice guidelines has been weak. Methods We recruited 68 primary care family and internal medicine practices"; 66 practices were randomly assigned to a study arm; 5 practices were withdrawn, resulting in 29 receiving the Third Adult Treatment Panel (ATP III) intervention and 32 an alternative therapy focusing on the Seventh. Joint National Committee Report on the Prevention, Detection, Evaluation, and Treatment of High Blood Pressure (JNC-7) ATP III providers were given a personal digital assistant providing Framingham risk scores and ATP III – recommended treatment. All practices included copies of each clinical practice guideline, received an introductory lecture, 1 performance feedback report, and 4 visits for intervention-specific academic elaboration Data were summarized in 61 practices from random samples of medical records of patients treated from June 1, 2001 to May 31, 2003 (baseline) and May 1, 2004 From April 30, 2006 (monitoring) Screening rate (primary outcome) was calculated with subsequent appropriate decision. Generalized estimation equations were used to compare results by arm, taking into account clustering of patients within treatments. Results We reviewed 5057 baseline and 3821 follow-up medical records. The screening rate for lipid levels increased from 43.6% to 49.0% (ATP III treatments) and from 40.1% to 50.8% (control treatments) (net difference, -5.3% [P = .22]). Appropriate management of lipid levels decreased slightly (73.4% to 72.3%) in ATP III treatments and more significantly (79.7% to 68.9%) in control treatments. The net change in appropriate management favored the intervention (+9.7%; 95% confidence interval [CI], 2.8-16.6% [P < .01]). Appropriate drug prescription decreased in both arms within 4 months (from 38.8% to 24.8% in ATP III applications and from 45.3% to 24.1% in control applications; net change, +7%) .2 [P = .37]) Overtreatment decreased from 6.6% to 6.6% in ATP III and increased from 4.2% to 6.4% in control treatments (net change, -4.9% [P = .01]) Results A multifactorial intervention including personal digital assistant-based decision support may improve primary care physician compliance according to ATP III guidelines.

title: The effect of a multifaceted intervention on the attitudes and behaviors of nurses and doctors towards the presence of the family during resuscitation.
abstract: Recent studies of healthcare providers' attitudes towards the presence of patients' family members during cardiopulmonary resuscitations and invasive procedures (family presence) have focused on retrospective or cross-sectional surveys of staff. Research reveals that clinicians have mixed views on the value of this practice. While guidelines have been proposed for the implementation of family presence, few reports have been published describing actual programs or effective strategies to change practice. As members of staff advocating the introduction of a homestay program in our own emergency department, we were interested in assessing the attitudes of staff members before and after the homestay program was initiated. We also wanted to see if attitudes differed between nurses and doctors. In this article, we present our experience with implementing a homestay program in the emergency department of a large academic teaching hospital.

title: The impact of a quality improvement program on the care and outcomes of children with asthma.
abstract: Purpose A learning collaboration based on the Institute for Healthcare Advancement's Breakthrough Series methodology to test a quality improvement intervention, specifically aimed at improving care and outcomes for patients with childhood asthma. Design Randomized trial in primary care applications. Adjustment Practices in greater Boston, Mass. and greater Detroit, Michigan Participants Forty-three practices with 13 878 pediatric asthmatic patients randomized to intervention and control groups. Intervention Participation in a learning collaboration project based on the Breakthrough Series methodology of continuous quality improvement. Main Outcome Measures Change from baseline in the proportion of children with persistent asthma receiving appropriate medication for asthma and the proportion of children whose parents received a written management plan for their child's asthma, as determined by telephone interviews with parents 631 children. Results No overall effect of the intervention was found after adjusting for condition, practice size, child age, gender, and in-app clustering. Conclusions This methodologically rigorous assessment of a widely used quality improvement technique did not have a significant impact on the processes or outcomes of care for children with asthma. Potential shortcomings in program implementation, project duration, sample selection, and data sources preclude a general conclusion that such an improvement program is ineffective. Additional rigorous studies should be performed under more optimal settings to evaluate the effectiveness of this method for improving care.

title: Effect of a web-based antimicrobial approval system on broad-spectrum cephalosporin use in a teaching hospital.
abstract: Objective: To achieve continuous improvement in the use of cefotaxime and ceftriaxone (CEFX) in a large teaching hospital, as measured against national antibiotic guidelines. Design and setting: Pre- and post-intervention survey of CEFX use at the Royal Melbourne Hospital, a tertiary care hospital in Melbourne, Victoria. Intervention: The web-based antimicrobial approval system based on national antibiotic guidelines was developed by a multidisciplinary team and implemented in March 2001. Main outcome measures: change in CEFX use rate (defined daily doses [DDDs] per 1000 acute bed days) 8 months pre-intervention and 15 months post-intervention";" Compliance of CEFX indication with national antibiotic guidelines before and after intervention. Results: CEFX use decreased from a mean of 38.3 DDD/1000 bed days before the intervention to 15.9, 18.7, and 21.2 DDD/1000 bed days at 1, 4, and 15 months after the intervention. Compliance with national antibiotic guidelines increased from 25% of pre-intervention courses to 51% within 5 months of intervention (P < 0.002). Gentamicin use also increased from a mean of 30.0 to 48.3 DDD/1000 bed days (P = 0.0001). Conclusion: The web-based antimicrobial approval system resulted in a sustained reduction in CEFX use over 15 months as well as increased prescription compliance with antibiotic guidelines. It has potential for linking with electronic prescribing and broader use for other drugs and research into the epidemiology of antibiotic use.

title: Impact of an educational intervention on improving prescribing by private physicians in Uganda
abstract: INTRODUCTION: Private doctors in urban Uganda treat a large percentage of common adult diseases. Improving their prescribing will not only encourage smarter drug use, but will also reduce patients' costs. Interventions to improve drug use are generally more successful when face-to-face education methods are included. OBJECTIVES: To determine the effectiveness of a face-to-face educational intervention for the treatment of acute respiratory infections (ARI), malaria and non-dysentery diarrhea by private physicians in three urban areas of Uganda. METHODS: The study used an intervention with a comparative group design to evaluate the impact of the educational intervention. A total of 108 private physicians were divided into intervention (n=30) and control (n=78) groups. Surrogate patients trained to simulate symptoms and signs of target conditions were used to collect data on physicians' medical practices and prescribing behaviors. Intervention physicians were invited to a one-day interactive training seminar facilitated by local opinion leaders, covering the principles of rational drug use and National Standard Treatment Guidelines for the treatment of target conditions. Physicians were also provided with data on key practices. RESULTS: Baseline data showed high rates of inappropriate treatment practices by both the intervention and control groups. There was almost universal use of antibiotics for ARI (over 90%), high recommended injection rates for malaria (over 30%), and high rates of polypharmacy (more than this drug per patient). After the intervention, some significant improvements in core practices were observed in the intervention group. Compared with control physicians, the intervention group had 23% reduced antibiotic prescriptions for ARI, 28% reduced use of combination products for malaria, trends towards better adherence to guidelines for ARI and malaria, and marginal reductions in drug costs. However, the overall effects of the intervention were limited, particularly on quality indicators related to history taking, adequate examination, and advice to patients. CONCLUSION: The face-to-face educational intervention resulted in some minor improvements in the basic prescribing practices of private physicians. However, an intervention that includes repeated contacts with prescribers and addresses economic considerations will be needed to achieve greater improvements. Private physicians need to be sensitized to and encouraged to use the National Standards of Treatment Guidelines, and attempts to improve their prescribing should be supported by community education.

title: The impact of clinical practice guidelines on clinicians' behavior: tonsillectomy in children
abstract: OBJECTIVE: This study was conducted to evaluate the extent to which the development and implementation of clinical practice guidelines to list children with tonsillectomy (with or without adenoidectomy) influenced the behavior of participating ENT surgeons. METHOD: A pre- and post-intervention study in which the intervention (development and dissemination of local practice guidelines) was presented sequentially to different hospitals and surgical practices. The study was conducted with 16 consultant ENT surgeons and their junior staff on 1190 children aged 0 to 14 years on trial before consulting an ENT surgeon in four ear, nose and throat surgery wards in northern England. Patients referred for throat-related problems for which tonsil surgery is a possible treatment option were included in the study. Proportion of decision made by surgeons and decisions following new guidelines. RESULTS: Of the clinical decisions listing children for tonsillectomy before locally accepted guidelines were applied, 73% (486/660) met criteria in subsequent guidelines, 15% (97/660) did not, and 12% (77/660) It was impossible to judge. The corresponding figures after intervention were 73% (386/530), 14% (73/53) and 13% (71/530), respectively. When decisions were made to break the guidelines, it was more common to list tonsillectomy when not indicated—83% (141/170)—than stopping tonsillectomy when indicated—-17% (29/170). Aspects of the guidelines violated in tonsillectomy decisions were: the child was younger than the recommended guidelines - -54% (75/141)"; there were more tonsillitis episodes than the guidelines recommended-- 22% (32/141);" and there were 'significant' symptoms not covered in the guidelines - 20% (29/141). CONCLUSIONS: Despite strong evidence to the contrary, local guidelines are formulated at a level already attained by the majority of surgeons. Therefore, guideline development and implementation has had little impact on clinical practice. The process of formulating guidelines locally was not sufficient to shift towards evidence-based practice";" The clinical choice has proven to be quite stubborn. There is a need to develop the skills of clinicians in evaluating and interpreting research evidence. Previous work has highlighted the need to explore factors influencing clinical behavior towards evidence-based practice. Our study shows that more research is needed as to why clinicians continue to follow clinical preference even when invited to base agreed local clinical policies on the evidence.

title: The Impact of Clinical Trial Results on National Trends in ÃŽÂ±-Blocker Prescribing, 1996-2002
abstract: Research on the factors influencing Context Prescribing patterns and the extent of change produced by clinical trial findings is limited. Purpose To examine changes in prescribing of α-blockers for the treatment of hypertension before and after the April 2000 publication of the early discontinuation of Adverse Antihypertensive and Lipid-Lowering Therapy to Prevent Heart Attack (ALLHAT), which included the doxazosin mesylate arm of the study. Changes in prescribing were evaluated in the context of other potential concomitant effects on drug use between 1996 and 2002, including changes in α-blocker drug prices, generic conversion, drug promotion, and competition. Design, Environment, and Patients Prescription orders for α-blockers using 2 national pharmaceutical market research reports published by IMS HEALTH have been reported in the National Prescription Audit - a computerized randomization of approximately 20,000 from 29,000 retail, independent and mail-order pharmacies and the National Disease and Therapeutic Index' It followed the patterns of bulk and discount homes and office-based physician a-blocker prescribing - a randomly stratified sample of approximately 3500 physician offices - reported in 2013. Outcome Measures Trends in physician-reported use of α-blockers and α-blockers prescribed and dispensed by US pharmacies. Results From 1996 to 1999, there were steady increases in new prescriptions for a-blockers, prescriptions given, and use of physician medication. There has been a moderate reversal in these trends following the early termination of ALLHAT and subsequent releases in the early 2000s. Between 1999 and 2002, new annual α-blocker prescription orders were 26% (5.15 million to 3.79 million), prescriptions were 22% (17.2 million to 13.4 million), and physician-reported drug use was 54% (2, decreased from 26 million to 1.03 million). While the cessation of inhibitory marketing accelerated the decline, other potential effects did not appear to have contributed significantly to this decline. Results Moderate but statistically significant reductions in the use of doxazosin and other α-blockers coincided with early termination of the ALLHAT doxazosin arm. Although physicians are responding to this new evidence, strategies to increase the impact of clinical trials on clinical practice are warranted.

title: The effect of computerized decision support on blood pressure management and control: a randomized controlled trial.
abstract: BACKGROUND We conducted a cluster of randomized controlled trials to examine the efficacy of computerized decision support (CDS) designed to improve hypertension care and outcomes in a racially diverse sample of primary care patients. METHODS We randomized 2,027 adult patients receiving hypertension care in 14 primary care practices to 18 months of their physician receiving CDS for each hypertensive patient or usual care without computerized support for the control group. We evaluated guideline-recommended drug prescription and blood pressure control levels for patients in each group and, using interaction terms, examined whether the effects of the intervention differed by patients' race/ethnicity. MEASUREMENTS AND MAIN RESULTS Blood pressure control rates were 42% at baseline and 46% at the outcome visit, with no significant difference between groups. After adjusting for patient demographics and clinical characteristics, number of previous visits, and baseline blood pressure control levels, there was no difference in outcome blood pressure control rates between intervention groups. Use of CDS to providers significantly improved drug prescribing based on Joint National Committee (JNC) guidelines compared to usual care (7% vs 5%, P?<?0.001);" the effects of the intervention remained after multivariate adjustment (odds ratio [ OR] 1.39 [CI, 1.13-1.72]) and the effects of the intervention did not differ by race and ethnicity of patients CONCLUSIONS CDS improved appropriate medication prescription with no improvement in disparities in care and overall blood pressure control. There is a need to explore other practical interventions to reduce

title: The effect of decision support in electronic medical records on lipid management in primary care.
abstract: Electronic decision support tools can help improve the management of hyperlipidemia and other chronic diseases. This study examined the impact of lipid management tools integrated into electronic medical records (EMR) in primary care practice. This randomized controlled trial was conducted in a national network of physicians using ambulatory EMR. Adult primary care physicians were randomized by the office to receive an electronic form embedded in the EMR. The form included requests for suboptimal care based on Adult Treatment Panel-III (ATP-III) guidelines, as well as reporting tools for identifying non-office visits patients with inadequate lipid management. All active patients aged 20-79 years, whose physicians participated in the study, were categorized as high, moderate, or low cardiovascular risk, and the proportion of those tested for hyperlipidemia, lipid target, and lipid-lowering drugs, if any. non-targets were measured according to ATP-III guidelines. A total of 105 physicians and 64,150 patients from 25 offices were included in the study. Outcomes improved for most measures from pre-intervention to 1 year post-intervention (November 1, 2005 - October 31, 2006). However, after controlling for confounding variables and clustering in multilevel modeling, only the current lipid test for high-risk patients was statistically better in the intervention group compared to the control group (adjusted odds ratio 15.0, P?<? 0.05). This study demonstrated little difference in the quality of lipid management after implementing an EMR-based disease management intervention in primary care settings. Future studies may need to examine more extensive interventions involving office staff in a team approach to care. (Population Health Management 2009";"12:221–226)

title: The effect of EHR-based clinical decision support on compliance with guidelines for patients on NSAIDs: a randomized controlled trial.
abstract: OBJECTIVE: Electronic health records (EHRs) with clinical decision support show promise for improving quality of care, but their implications for the management of chronic conditions are mixed. This study examined the impact of EHR-based clinical decision support on compliance with guidelines for reducing gastrointestinal complications in primary care patients using nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs). METHODS: This randomized controlled trial was conducted in a national network of primary care offices using an EHR and focused on patients taking traditional NSAIDs with a high risk of gastrointestinal complications (history of peptic ulcer disease; factors associated with concomitant use of anticoagulants). drugs [including aspirin] or corticosteroids or 75 years of age or older) Offices were randomized to receive EHR-based guidelines and alerts for high-risk patients receiving NSAIDs or usual care. was the proportion of patients who received appropriate care, defined as discontinuation of their traditional NSAID (including switching to a low-risk drug), or both. RESULTS: Participants consisted of 119 clinicians and 5,234 high-risk patients and 27 offices. patients were more likely to receive guideline care (25.4% vs. ı 22.4%, adjusted odds ratio = 1.19; 95% confidence interval, 1.01-1.42). For individual high-risk groups, patients receiving low-dose aspirin were more likely to receive guideline-compliant care with intervention than usual care (20.8% vs. 25.0%, adjusted odds ratio = 1.30; 95% confidence interval) , 1.04–1.62), but there was no significant difference for patients in other high-risk groups. CONCLUSIONS: This study showed only a small effect of EHR-based clinical decision support for high-risk patients on NSAIDs in primary care care. Increasing literature on the complexity of EHR-based clinical decision support to improve the quality of

title: The effect of environmental olfactory cues on hand hygiene behavior in a simulated hospital setting: a randomized trial.
abstract: This study investigated the effect of a fresh scent on hand hygiene compliance (HHC) rate among novice healthcare providers. In total, 165 participants studied a standardized patient, with one sample exposed to fresh fragrance (N = 79) and the other exposed to standard media (N = 86). Hand hygiene behaviors were monitored using video surveillance prior to patient contact. While the standard environmental group had 51% HHC, participants in the fresh fragrance group had an 80% higher HHC ratio (P < 0.001). These data suggest that hand hygiene behavior may be subconsciously influenced by environmental cues.

title: The effect of environmental patient education on preventive medicine practices
abstract: BACKGROUND: Research shows that provider-focused reminders alone are less effective at increasing physician compliance with prevention guidelines than combinations of patient- and provider-focused physician reminders. The effectiveness of environmental patient education (i.e. office-based videos, brochures, and posters) without individual staff or educator involvement has not been fully established. The aim of this study is to evaluate the effectiveness of environmental patient education in increasing the amount of preventive services that patients receive. METHODS: A nonrandomized controlled trial using historical controls was conducted in a model family medicine clinic at the University of New Mexico School of Medicine in Albuquerque. The study group (n = 389) included adult women who were seen at the clinic at a time when educational materials were available in the waiting area. The control group (n = 381) consisted of similarly selected patients seen in the same period of the previous year in the absence of such material. During the intervention, patients in the waiting area were provided with educational materials encouraging them to ask their doctors questions about cholesterol testing, Papanicolaou (Pap) smears, tetanus vaccinations and mammograms. For both control and study groups, physicians' preventive service orders were tracked over a 4-month follow-up period by reviewing medical records. RESULTS: Despite sufficient statistical power, there was no statistically significant change in the number of cholesterol tests, Pap smears, tetanus boosters, or mammograms ordered after the environmental patient education intervention. CONCLUSION: Environmental patient education materials were not effective in increasing the amount of preventive services provided by physicians in this study. While such interventions are inexpensive, straightforward, and well-intentioned, they may be ineffective in improving the performance of preventive services.

title: The effect of feedback and didactic sessions on the reporting behavior of upper endoscopic findings by doctors and nurses
abstract: BACKGROUND AND OBJECTIVES: Guidelines for reporting Barrett's esophageal and hiatal hernia measurements and reflux esophagitis grades have been developed to improve consistency, communication, and ultimately patient care. Our aim was to evaluate the percentage of cases where findings were reported in accordance with guidelines and to assess the impact of education and feedback on reporting behavior. METHODS: A prospective cross-sectional study design was used. Chart reviews were performed for all adult patients undergoing esophagogastroduodenoscopy in a tertiary care center over three 2-month time periods at a 12-month interval: Time 1 (March 1, 2004 to April 30, 2004), Time 2 (July 1, 2004-August 31, 2004), and Time 3 (March 1, 2005-April 30, 2005). Standardized training sessions started 2 years before Time 1. No intervention was made between Time 1 and Time 2";" Data were collected to examine secular change. Individual and group feedback and refresher sessions were given between Time 2 and Time 3. RESULTS: Five thousand six hundred and nine appropriate esophagogastroduodenoscopy were performed and 2675 of them were found to have Barrett's esophagus, hiatal hernia and/or reflux esophagitis. At baseline, measurements of Barrett's esophagus and hiatal hernia were accurately dictated as median in 67% and 86% of cases, respectively, and accounted for 100% (P < .05) and 98% (P < .01) of cases, respectively. ) rose. The Los Angeles Classification system was used in a median 100% of cases at baseline and at follow-up. CONCLUSIONS: Anonymous individual and group feedback combined with short, structured didactic training sessions significantly improves adherence to established guidelines for Barrett's esophagus and hiatal hernia reporting. Adherence to the esophagitis Los Angeles Classification System is easy to maintain once it has been successfully incorporated into clinical practice.

title: The effect of information leaflets on the behavior of patients with gastroenteritis or tonsillitis: a randomized cluster trial in French primary care.
abstract: OBJECTIVE: To evaluate the impact of four patient information leaflets on patients' behavior in primary care. Design: Clustered randomized multicenter controlled trial between November 2009 and January 2011. PARTICIPANTS: French adults and children who consulted a attending primary care physician and were diagnosed with gastroenteritis or tonsillitis. Patients were randomized to receive or not receive patient information leaflets based on cluster randomization of primary care physicians. Intervention: Adult patients or adults accompanying a child diagnosed with gastroenteritis or tonsillitis were informed about the study. Doctors in the intervention group gave patients an information leaflet about their condition. Two weeks after the consultation, patients (or their accompanying adults) answered a telephone questionnaire about their behavior and knowledge of the condition. MAIN MEASURES: Main and secondary outcomes, mean behavior and knowledge scores, respectively, were calculated from the responses to this questionnaire. RESULTS: Twenty-four physicians included 400 patients. Twelve patients (3%) were out of follow-up. In the group that received the patient information leaflet, patient behavior was closer to that recommended in the guidelines compared to the control group (mean behavior score 4.9 vs 4.2, p < 0.01). Knowledge was better for adults who received the brochure than for the control group (mean knowledge score 4.2 vs 3.6, p < 0.01). Patients who were given the leaflet had fewer visits by household members for the same symptoms (23.4% versus 56.2%, p < 0.01). CONCLUSION: Patient information leaflets given by the physician during the consultation significantly change the patient's knowledge of behavior and disease for the conditions examined, compared to patients who did not receive the leaflets.

title: The impact of the application of rapid diagnostic testing for malaria on antibiotic prescribing: an analysis of observational and randomized studies in public and private healthcare settings.
abstract: Objectives To examine the impact of the use of rapid diagnostic tests for malaria in prescribing antimicrobials, particularly antibiotics, for acute febrile illness in Africa and Asia. DesignÂ Analysis of nine preselected linked and co-designed observational and randomized studies (eight clusters or individual randomized trials and one observational study). SettingsPublic and private healthcare settings in Afghanistan, Cameroon, Ghana, Nigeria, Tanzania, and Uganda, 2007-13 .To the participants 522â€â€°480 children and adults with acute febrile illness. InterventionsÂ Rapid diagnostic tests for malaria. Main outcome measuresÂ Proportion of patients prescribed antibiotics, with positive results in trial groups that passed rapid diagnostic testing compared to controls, and patients with negative test results compared to patients. A secondary objective was to compare classes of antibiotics prescribed in different settings. Results Antibiotics were prescribed to 127—052/238—797 (53%) patients and 167 in the control groups. ¬â€°714/283â€°683 (59%) patients in the intervention groups. Antibiotics were prescribed to 40% (35–505/89–719) and 69% (39–400) of patients who tested positive for malaria. /57â €â€°080) was negative. All but one study showed a trend towards more antibiotic prescriptions in groups undergoing rapid diagnostic tests. A random effects meta-analysis of trials showed that the overall risk of prescribing antibiotics in intervention settings was 21% higher (95% confidence interval 7% to 36%). In most intervention settings, patients with negative test results received more antibiotic prescriptions than patients with positive results for all of the most commonly used classes: penicillins, trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole (an exception), tetracyclines, and metronidazole. ConclusionsÃ‚Â The introduction of rapid diagnostic testing could increase malaria use of non-targeted antibiotics to reduce unnecessary antimalarial use – a beneficial public health outcome. Prescribing antibiotics to 69% of patients when test results are negative likely represents overprescription. This includes antibiotics of various classes, including those such as metronidazole, which are rarely suitable for febrile illness in a variety of clinical, healthcare, and epidemiological settings. It is often assumed that better disease-specific diagnoses will reduce antimicrobial overuse, but they can simply shift it from one antimicrobial class to another. The current global application of malaria testing may increase non-targeted antibiotic use and should be examined.

title: Effect of Mediterranean diet education versus published leaflet on dietary habits and serum cholesterol in a population at high risk for cardiovascular disease
abstract: OBJECTIVE: To investigate the effect of intensive group training on the Mediterranean diet on dietary intake and serum total cholesterol after 16 and 52 weeks in the context of primary prevention of cardiovascular disease (CVD) compared to a brochure published with Dutch dietary guidelines. . DESIGN: Controlled comparison study of an intervention group receiving intensive group training on the Mediterranean diet and a control group of hypercholesterolemic subjects given usual care by general practitioners (GPs). LOCATION: A socioeconomically deprived area of the Netherlands with a high mortality rate from coronary heart disease (CHD). SUBJECTS: Two hundred and sixty-six hypercholesterolemic subjects with at least two other CVD risk factors. RESULTS: After 52 weeks, the intervention group reduced total and saturated fat intake more than the control group (net differences 1.8% at (95% CI 0.2-3.4) and 1.1% at (95% CI 0.4-1.9), respectively) . According to the Mediterranean diet guidelines, fish, fruit, poultry and bread intake increased more in the intervention group than in the control group. In the intervention group, fish (+100%), poultry (+28%), and bread (+6) intakes increased significantly (P < 0.05) after 1 year. The intensive program on dietary education did not lower serum cholesterol more (-3%) than the published brochure (-2%) (net difference 0.06 mmol l-1, 95% CI -0.10 to 0.22). Initially, body mass index (BMI) decreased more in the intervention group, but after 1 year the intervention and control groups gained equal weight (+1%). RESULTS: Despite beneficial changes in dietary habits in the intervention group compared with the control group, BMI increased after 1 year and total fat and saturated fat intake was still very high.

title: Impact of continuous drug lab monitoring alerts in outpatient care.
abstract: Purpose: Intermittent stimuli in electronic applications can cause 'stimulus fatigue' if they are fired too frequently or only at certain times if clinically reasonable. We evaluated the impact of seamless, real-time drug lab alerts on provider lab test order. Design: We enrolled 22 outpatient treatments in a prospective, randomized, controlled study. Clinics either used the existing system or took on-screen recommendations for basic laboratory tests when prescribing new drugs. Because the alerts were seamless, providers did not have to act on or approve the notification to complete a medication request. Measurements: Data were collected each time providers performed recommended laboratory tests within 14 days of ordering a new prescription. Results were adjusted for patient and provider characteristics and patient clustering within clinics. Results: Among the 12 clinics with 191 providers in the control group and the 10 clinics with 175 providers in the intervention group, there were a total of 3673 events for which basic laboratory testing would be recommended: 1988 events in the control group and 1685 events in the intervention group. In the control group, initial laboratories were requested for 771 (39%) of the drugs. In the intervention group, base laboratories were ordered by clinicians in 689 (41%) of cases. Overall, there was no significant association between intervention and the rate of ordering appropriate basic laboratory tests. Conclusion: We found that continuous drug laboratory monitoring alerts were not effective in improving the recommended baseline laboratory test monitoring for drugs. More work is needed to optimize compliance with non-critical recommendations.

title: Effect of pharmacist-clinician dual intervention on prescribed benzodiazepines in inmate patients: a retrospective study.
abstract: High-dose benzodiazepines (BDZs) represent an important risk factor for addiction, particularly in the prison setting. In Lyon prison, BDZs and/or opioid maintenance therapy are often prescribed to patients with mental disorders. The purpose of this retrospective study was to evaluate the impact of psychiatrist and pharmacist collaboration on reducing the dose of BDZ prescribed to inmate patients. Since 2001, clinicians and pharmacists have held monthly meetings to develop prescribing guidelines and discuss patients taking high-dose BDZ. All psychotropic drugs prescribed for each patient included in the control (before guidelines) and intervention groups were noted. The criteria used to define each patient profile included age, diagnosis (mental disorder), and concomitant treatment (opioids, antidepressants). To compare each group, the daily dose of prescribed BDZs was used as a quantitative variable and expressed as diazepam equivalents. A total of 473 patients were included, 222 in the control group and 251 in the intervention group. The two groups did not differ in terms of diagnosis. All patients (mean(CONTROL GROUP) = 46 mg diazepam equivalent vs mean(INTERVENTION GROUP) = 34 mg) and the control group had a higher daily dose of BDZ for each of the following patient categories: 'mental' impairment' (30 vs 48 mg) mg), 'no opioid therapy' (44 mg vs 31 mg), 'buprenorphine therapy' (58 mg vs. 63 mg), 'no antidepressant treatment' (41 mg vs. 29 mg) ) and 'antidepressant therapy' treatment' (53 mg vs. 38 mg). The results of this retrospective study demonstrate the positive effect of multidisciplinary intervention on reducing the prescribed daily dose of BDZ. This experience confirms the positive impact of pharmacist feedback on prescriptions and the development of treatment guidelines in collaboration with clinicians and pharmacists on improving prescribing practice in the prison setting.

title: The Effect of Physician Asthma Care Education on Patient Outcomes
abstract: OBJECTIVE: We evaluated the effectiveness of Physician Asthma Care Education, a continuing medical education program, in improving pediatricians' asthma management and communication skills and patients' use of healthcare services for asthma. METHODS: We conducted a randomized trial at 10 sites in the United States. Primary care providers are randomly selected and appointed by the site to receive the program provided by local faculty. The program included 2 interactive seminar sessions (2.5 hours each) reviewing national asthma guidelines, communication skills and core education messages. The format included short lectures, case discussions, and video modeling communication techniques. We collected information on physician communication, the child's asthma symptoms, and patients' parental perceptions of asthma healthcare use. We used multivariate regression models to identify differences between control and intervention groups. RESULTS: A total of 101 primary care providers and a random sample of 870 asthma patients participated. After 1 year, we completed phone interviews with the parents of 731 of 870 patients. Compared with control subjects, parents reported that doctors in the intervention group were more likely to question patients' concerns about asthma, encourage patients to be physically active, and set goals for successful treatment. Patients of doctors participating in the program had a greater reduction in days limited to asthma symptoms (15.6 versus 8.5), as well as a reduction in emergency asthma visits (0.30 versus 0.55 visits per year). RESULTS: The Physician Asthma Care Education program was used in a number of locations and was effective in improving parent-reported provider communication skills, number of days affected by asthma symptoms, and asthma healthcare utilization. Patients who had more frequent asthma symptoms at baseline and benefited more from healthcare were more likely to benefit from their doctor's involvement in the program.

title: Impact of regular collaboration between infectious diseases and intensive care practitioners on antimicrobial use and patient outcomes
abstract: OBJECTIVE: Antimicrobial management programs have been shown to help reduce the use of unnecessary antimicrobial agents in the hospital setting. To date, there is little data focusing on high-use areas such as the medical intensive care unit. When an infectious disease worker interacted regularly with the medical intensive care team, a prospective intervention was undertaken to assess guideline compliance, antimicrobial expenditure, and health care cost. DESIGN: A 3-month retrospective chart review was followed by a 3-month prospective intervention the following year. Two hundred and forty-six total charts were reviewed to assess generally accepted guidelines compliance, demographic characteristics, and microbiological outcomes. SETTING: Twenty-four-bed medical ICU in an 861-bed tertiary care, college teaching hospital in North Carolina. SUBJECTS: Patients receiving antibiotics in the medical intensive care unit. INTERVENTION: During the intervention period, the infectious disease specialist reviewed charts, including physician notes and microbiology data, and discussed antimicrobial use with the medical ICU team. MEASUREMENTS AND MAIN RESULTS: Antimicrobial use, duration of treatment, Acute Physiology and Chronic Health Assessment II scores, length of stay, mechanical ventilation days, and death rates were compared over the two periods. RESULTS: No statistically significant differences were noted at baseline in the two groups (ie, age, gender, race, or Acute Physiology and Chronic Health Assessment II scores). Antibiotic indications included health-related (53%) and community-acquired pneumonia (17%). Significant reductions in broad-spectrum penicillins (p=0.0080), carbapenems (p=0.0013), vancomycin (p=0.0040), and metronidazole (p=0.0004) were seen following intervention. Antimicrobial modification caused an increase in narrow-spectrum penicillins (p=0.0322). The intervention group had a significantly lower rate of treatment not following the guidelines (p<0.0001). There was a reduction in mechanical ventilation days (p=0.0053), length of stay (p=0.0188), and hospital mortality (p=0.0367). The annual calculated healthcare savings were $89,944 for early antibiotic discontinuation alone. CONCLUSION: Active communication with an infectious disease practitioner can significantly reduce medical ICU antibiotic overuse by changing or discontinuing antibiotics earlier without increasing mortality. This, in turn, can reduce health care costs, encourage exceptional training, and strengthen relationships between subspecialties.

title: Impact of WHO depression guidelines on patient care by psychiatrists: a randomized controlled trial
abstract: BACKGROUND: Scientific literature reviews aim to summarize the state of knowledge and published empirical evidence. In contrast, medical guidelines are intervention tools aimed at improving physician behavior and patient outcome. It can have positive effects as well as negative effects. Its effects should be tested by research. METHODS: In a randomized controlled trial, 103 private practice psychiatrists were provided with either the WHO depression guideline only (information group) or the WHO depression guideline and were trained in this guide for one day (intervention group) or left uninformed. (control group). They then treated a total of 497 patients based on individual clinical considerations and patients' needs. Observation of routine treatment lasted for 12 weeks. Physicians and patients documented the course of the disease and treatment, including the patient-physician interaction. RESULTS: Psychiatrists in the intervention group saw more psychosocial stressors in their patients, prescribed higher doses of medication, discontinued less, and rated the treatment outcome as better. Ratings of patient-physician interactions indicated greater strain in their relationship. RESULTS: The results show both positive and negative effects of guideline exposure, but only in the training group, not the knowledge group. Guidelines must be experimentally tested before they can be called "evidence-based". Each guide should also explain how it can or must be applied to be effective.

title: Impaired self-awareness after moderate to severe traumatic brain injury
abstract: Patients with moderate to severe traumatic brain injury (TBI) may exhibit impaired self-awareness several months or years after injury. Patients may under-report cognitive and behavioral difficulties, which are true remnants of brain damage. Increasingly, research is showing that the remnants of these disturbances in consciousness greatly influence the rehabilitation process and outcome. A new model for conceptualizing self-awareness disorders after various forms of brain injury is reviewed.

title: Nationwide implementation and adoption of electronic health records in UK secondary care: final qualitative results from prospective national evaluation in 'early adopter' hospitals
abstract: OBJECTIVES To evaluate the implementation and adoption of the NHS detailed care records service in 'early adopter' hospitals in England. DESIGN Theoretically informed, case studies based longitudinal qualitative assessment. SETTING 12 'early adopter' NHS acute hospitals and specialist care settings were studied over two and a half years. DATA SOURCES Data were collected through in-depth interviews, observations and related documents directly related to case study sites and wider national developments considered to have an impact on implementation strategy. Data were analyzed thematically, first within cases and then between cases. The dataset consists of 431 semi-structured interviews with key stakeholders, including hospital staff, developers and government stakeholders; From 590 hours of strategic meeting observations and the use of software in context; 334 sets of observation notes, researchers' field notes and notes from national conferences, 809 NHS documents and 58 regional and national documents RESULTS Implementation has progressed more slowly with a narrower scope and significantly less clinical functionality than originally planned. The national strategy has had important local consequences (summarized under five main themes). ) and wider national developments have greatly influenced implementation and adoption. More specifically, delays associated with unrealistic expectations about the capabilities of systems; the time required to build, configure, and customize the software; end users' needs for operational maintenance and training and support needed to ensure systems support provisioning. Other factors hindering progress include the changing environment of NHS policy and priorities; national conventions that have been repeatedly renegotiated; “different stages of development of various NHS care records service systems” and contractual arrangements that largely exclude NHS providers, as well as a complex communication process between different stakeholders. CONCLUSIONS The NHS Care Records Service is time-consuming and difficult to implement at “early adopter” sites, yet limited for clinicians it turned out to have no discernible benefits and no clear benefits for patients. Although our results may not be directly transferable. They shed light on the processes involved in later adopting sites, implementing major new systems, as the functions we evaluated were new and untested in the English context. The move was followed and welcomed by the NHS, but it is important that policy makers do not overlook the overall goal of an integrated interoperable solution.

title: Implementation and success of nurse telephone counseling in linguistically isolated Korean-American patients with hypertension
abstract: OBJECTIVE: Nurse telephone counseling may improve the management of chronic conditions, but the effectiveness of this approach in underserved populations is uncertain. This study evaluated the use of bilingual nurse-delivered telephone counseling in Korean Americans (PAs) participating in a community-based intervention trial to improve hypertension management. METHODS: PAs were randomized to receive 12-month hypertension-related telephone counseling that was either more intense (biweekly) or less intense (monthly). Consultation logs were kept for 360 PAs who completed their pre- and post-intervention assessments. RESULTS: The overall success rate of the intervention was 80.3%. Level of achievement was significantly influenced by mentoring dose, employment status, and years of US residency. During the 12-month counseling period, both groups improved in medication taking, alcohol consumption, and exercise, but without any significant group differences in non-smoking. CONCLUSION: Bilingual telephone counseling can reach monolingual PAs and improve hypertension management behaviors. PRACTICE PRACTICES: Bilingual nurse telephone counseling can have broad applicability, serving as an effective tool for disseminating evidence-based chronic disease management guidelines to a linguistically isolated population with limited health resources and knowledge.

title: Appropriate trajectories for implementing a health promotion program in multidisciplinary settings: managing tensions in rehabilitation care.
abstract: While the importance of assessing relevance to the Background Application is recognized, little is known about the heterogeneity of fidelity over time. This study aims to generate insights into the heterogeneity of practice fidelity trajectories of a health promotion program in multidisciplinary settings and its relationship with changes in patients' health behaviors. Methods This study used longitudinal data from the nationwide implementation of an evidence-based physical activity promotion program in Dutch rehabilitation care. Accuracy scores were calculated based on annual questionnaires completed by relevant professionals (n?=?Â¡Ã€?70). Higher fidelity scores indicate a more complete implementation of the core components of the program. A hierarchical cluster analysis was conducted on the application loyalty scores of 17 organizations at three different time points. Quantitative and qualitative data were used to explore institutional and professional differences between the identified trajectories. Regression analyzes were performed to identify differences in patient outcomes. Results Three trajectories were identified as follows: Â¡Â®stable high accuracyÂ¡Â¯ (n?=?9), Â¡Â®medium and incremental accuracyÂ¡Â¯ (n?=?6) and Â¡Â ®unstable fidelityÂ ¡Â¯ (n?=?2). Stable, high-loyalty organizations were generally smaller, started earlier, and implemented the program in a more structured way compared to moderate and thriving loyalty organizations. At the beginning and end of the implementation period, support from physicians and physiotherapists, professional appreciation, and program compliance were rated more favorably by professionals working in stable high-loyalty organizations than moderate and growing-loyalty organizations (p ?<?.05). Qualitative data showed that stable, high-fidelity organizations generally have a clear vision and strategy for program implementation. Surprisingly, trajectories were not associated with self-reported physical activity outcomes (corrected model Â¦Â?=???651.6, t(613)?=???1032, p?=?.303). Results Differences in institutional-level application fidelity trajectories did not result in patient-level outcome differences. This demonstrates that an effective application fidelity trajectory depends on the circumstances of the local organization. More specifically, achieving consistently high implementation accuracy required the management of tensions: Realizing a localized vision of change while maintaining standardized core components of the program and involving scarce doctors throughout the process. As we scale up evidence-based health promotion programs, we propose to tailor the management of practice tensions to the starting position, size, and circumstances of local organizations.

title: Implementation of a new policy results in reduced pressure ulcer frequency
abstract: OBJECTIVE: To determine the effects of a new policy on the effectiveness of pressure ulcer care. DESIGN: A series of 1-day pressure ulcer questionnaires before and after administration. SETTING: A 900-bed University Medical Center in the Netherlands. PARTICIPANTS: On the days of the survey, 657 patients were included before the application, 735 at 4 months after the application, and 755 at the 11 months after the application. INTERVENTION: Implementation of a hospital guideline for pressure ulcer care with the introduction of viscoelastic foam mattresses on the effectiveness of pressure ulcer prevention and treatment. MAIN RESULT MEASURES: Nurses' care behaviors and the frequency of pressure ulcer patients were compared before and after the application. RESULTS: Inadequate prevention decreased from 19% to 4% after 4 months and to 6% (P < 0.001) after 11 months, and undertreatment from 60% to 31% (P = 0.005). We found no significant increase in adequate care to prevent pressure ulcers when mattress use was excluded as a positive indicator for caregiving behavior. In addition, we did not find a significant difference in adequate treatment activities. Overall, we found a significant reduction in the frequency of hospital-acquired pressure ulcers from 18% to 13% (P = 0.003) after 4 months and to 11% (P < 0.001) after 11 months. CONCLUSION: The number of pressure ulcer patients in the hospital can be successfully reduced. General measures such as the introduction of adequate mattresses and prevention and treatment guidelines are promising tools in this regard.

title: Implementation of an effective intervention for high-risk women in Mexico: protocol for a multisite randomized trial with a parallel study of organizational factors.
abstract: Background Studies on the implementation of effective human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) prevention interventions are rare, but important, especially in resource-constrained settings, because they have the potential to increase the effectiveness of interventions by improving uptake and sustainability. Few studies have focused on provider and organizational factors that may affect uptake and loyalty to key intervention components. Using a hybrid design, we will examine the implementation of an effective intervention to reduce sexually transmitted infections (STIs) among female sex workers (FSWs) in 12 cities across Mexico. Our protocol will test a Â¡Â®trainer-trainÂ¡Â¯ implementation model to bring the Mujer Segura (Healthy Woman) intervention to community-based organizations (CBOs). Methods We partnered with the Mexican Foundation for Family Planning (Mexfam), a nonprofit with CBOs across Mexico. At each CBO, trained ethnographers will survey CBO staff about their organization's characteristics and attitudes towards their CBO and the implementation of evidence-based interventions (EBIs). Then, after CBO staff have collected a sample of 80 eligible FSWs and administered a standard of care, didactic intervention to 40 randomly selected women from this pool, a Mexfam staff member will be trained on the Mujer Segura intervention and then train other counselors to give birth. Mujer Segura, the remaining 40 participants to FSW. FSW participants will receive a baseline behavioral assessment and be tested for HIV and STIs (syphilis, gonorrhea and chlamydia)";" They will be reassessed six months after the intervention to measure possible intervention effects. At the same time, both qualitative and quantitative data will be collected on the implementation process, including the criteria for consultants' suitability for the intervention model. After data collection is completed in each CBO, the relative effectiveness of the Mujer Segura intervention will be analyzed and correlations between individual and institutional provider characteristics and intervention effectiveness among CBOs will be examined. Discussion This collaborative, binational research study will provide critical information on barriers and facilitating factors associated with the implementation of interventions in CBOs using the Â¡Â®train the trainerÂ¡Â¯ model. Our work builds on similar scale-up strategies that have been effective in the United States. This work has the potential to increase our knowledge of the generalizability of such strategies across health issues, national and institutional contexts.

title: Implementation of clinical guidelines through the electronic medical record: physician use, satisfaction and evaluation
abstract: CONTEXT: We developed and evaluated the Emergency Department Expert Table System (EDECS) to provide real-time guidance on low back pain in adults, fever in children, and occupational exposure to blood and body fluids in healthcare workers. clinical guidelines within the electronic medical record. OBJECTIVE: To describe the behaviors and attitudes of physicians using EDECS. DESIGN: Pre-post questionnaires were used to assess physician attitudes. Time studies of the intervention phase were observational using clocks embedded in the software. PARTICIPANTS: Emergency, pediatrics, internal medicine and family medicine residents and interns and patients with the above-mentioned complaints. MAIN OUTCOME MEASURES: Physician's use of EDECS, time spent on EDECS use, physician satisfaction and beliefs. RESULTS: Eighty-four percent of the 142 eligible physicians used EDECS at least once. Five hundred and ninety-one (75%) of 789 eligible cases were completed using EDECS. The median session duration decreased from 12 minutes for the 1st session to 5.5 minutes for the 16th and above sessions. Doctors generally agreed that care with EDECS was better than standard care, especially in terms of documentation. However, there was significant heterogeneity in belief among complaints. CONCLUSIONS: These data illuminate both the potentials of computer-assisted decision making and the need for context-specific approaches when trying to implement guidelines.

title: Implementation of clinical practice guidelines for the prevention of thromboembolism in spinal cord injury.
abstract: Background/Aims: The purpose of this study was to determine whether the publication of the “Prevention of Thromboembolism in Spinal Cord Injury” clinical practice guideline (CPG) changes patient management and whether adherence to CPG recommendations improves after a targeted delivery strategy. Methods: Data were summarized from the medical records of 1,34 and 520 patients with acute and chronic spinal cord injury (SCI), respectively, from 6 Veterans Affairs medical centers in 3 time periods: pre-release (T1), pre-administration (T2), and post-administration of CPG (T3). ). Targeted interventions were developed to address perceived provider-perceived barriers to guideline compliance, based on findings from focus groups conducted at each site. The interventions included two implementation strategies: standardized document templates/durable orders and social marketing/outreach visits. Results: Use of the specified time for pharmacological prophylaxis increased from 60% to 65% and 75% of patients with acute SCI at T1, T2 and T3, respectively (T1 vs. T2 and T2 vs. T3, respectively). for P = 0.060 and 0.041). ). Usage rates of individual pharmacological prophylaxis agents varied significantly throughout the study, with the use of low molecular weight heparin increasing from 7% at T1 to 42% at T3. On days 1 and 30 of hospitalization, physical assessments for thrombosis improved between T2 and T3. The use of prophylaxis in chronically injured patients with novel risk factors for thromboembolism increased from 16% to 31% and 34% during T1, T2 and T3 (P = 0.001 and 0.87, respectively). Results: The CPG broadcast had only a modest impact on the app. Use of structured practice further improved compliance with some CPG recommendations for thromboembolism prophylaxis. Similar implementation strategies should be considered for CPG recommendations with low adherence and high potential for morbidity and mortality.

title: Diagnostic practice in asymptomatic patients with aortic stenosis: Diagnostic practice in asymptomatic patients with a record of aortic stenosis
abstract: Often in clinical practice, some physicians refer patients with aortic stenosis for an invasive approach during the asymptomatic phase of the disease. This empirical behavior, which conflicts with the recommendations of current international clinical guidelines, is due to the perception that the prognosis of these patients is worse than if they were actually maintained. In fact, the management of asymptomatic patients with aortic stenosis is controversial, and there is no clear agreement on how to reduce the extreme clinical events associated with the presence of aortic stenosis mortality and morbidity in these patients in recent randomized clinical trials. The prevailing attention of the attending physicians is usually limited to the assessment of the severity of aortic stenosis and the appearance of symptoms, but instead it has been clearly demonstrated that the prognosis of these patients is associated with excessive left ventricular mass enlargement and increasing atherosclerosis. leads to coronary artery disease, heart failure, stroke and death. Therefore, apart from markers of faster aortic stenosis progression, many other clinical and echocardiographic variables should be considered, pooled, and used in conjunction with clinical/echocardiographic prognostic scores recently validated by several authors in clinical practice, where the vast majority of these variables apply. Guilt was not taken into account at all. The Diagnostic Practice Registry in Patients with Asymptomatic Aortic Stenosis is a prospective study designed to improve the diagnostic evaluation and prognostic classification of patients with asymptomatic aortic stenosis.

title: Implementation of evidence-based rehabilitation for nonspecific back pain and common mental health problems: a process evaluation of a nationwide initiative.
abstract: BACKGROUND: The nationwide implementation of guaranteed access to evidence-based rehabilitation was established in Sweden in 2009 by an Act of the Swedish Government. The primary purpose of the rehabilitation guarantee was to increase the rate of return to work, reduce and prevent long-term absenteeism after diagnoses of back pain and common mental health problems. This study aims to develop knowledge about the factors affecting the large-scale implementation of complex and comprehensive interventions in healthcare settings. METHODS: In the collection and analysis of the data, three different data sources such as questionnaire, interview and document were used. Data were analyzed using iterative thematic analysis. RESULTS: The following main facilitators contributed to the realization of the rehabilitation guarantee: financial incentives, project organization establishment, recruitment, in-service training and previous experience in similar projects. The barriers were: the short-term project form of the rehabilitation guarantee, the clinicians' attitudes towards return to work and their competence to work, the lack of guidelines defining treatment modalities in multimodal rehabilitation, and the lack of well-defined criteria for inclusion of patients. The documents revealed that the goal of return to work became less clear during the implementation process. Instead, care and health are more often described in documents used to disseminate information about the rehabilitation guarantee. The interim results found were: more adequate priority was given to patients in need of rehabilitation, greater readiness for future practice efforts, and overall competence and teamwork in psychotherapy, thus making it available to patient groups other than those covered by the rehabilitation guarantee. CONCLUSIONS: To facilitate the implementation of established national policy goals in clinical practice, there is a need for tools specifically aimed at changing clinicians' attitudes and behaviors regarding such goals. Our results highlight the importance of dedicating both time and adequate resources to activities and supporting the implementation process.

title: Implementation of evidence-based treatment protocols to manage fever, hyperglycemia and dysphagia in acute stroke (QASC): a cluster randomized controlled trial.
abstract: Background We evaluated patient outcomes 90 days after hospitalization for stroke following a multidisciplinary intervention targeting evidence-based management of fever, hyperglycemia, and swallowing dysfunction in acute stroke units (ASUs). Background We evaluated patient outcomes 90 days after hospitalization for stroke following a multidisciplinary intervention targeting evidence-based management of fever, hyperglycemia, and swallowing dysfunction in acute stroke units (ASUs).

title: Implementation of the Spanish version of European guidelines on cardiovascular disease prevention in primary care
abstract: BACKGROUND: Successful implementation of cardiovascular disease (CVD) prevention guidelines relies heavily on primary care physicians (PCPs) providing risk factor assessment, intervention, and patient education. The aim of this study was to determine the degree of awareness and implementation of the Spanish version of the European guidelines (CEIPC guidelines) on CVD prevention in clinical practice among PCPs. METHODS: A cross-sectional study of PCPs was conducted in Spain between January and June 2011. A random sample of 1,390 PCPs was taken and stratified by region. Data were collected through a self-administered questionnaire. RESULTS: More than half (58%) of physicians were aware of and knew the recommendations, and 62% of them claimed to use them in clinical practice, with general practitioners (without specialist accreditation) being less likely than family physicians. Most PCPs (60%) did not assess cardiovascular risk, and the limited time available to surgery was cited as the biggest obstacle (81%). The main reason for skepticism about the recommendations reported by 71% of physicians was that there were too many guidelines. Nearly half of the doctors cited a lack of education and skills as the biggest barrier to implementing lifestyle and behavior change recommendations. CONCLUSIONS: Most PCPs were aware of and knew the contents of the European directives on CVD prevention (CEIPC directives) to be adapted to Spain.
