However, only a third of PCPs used the guidelines in clinical practice and less than half of the CVD risk assessment tools used.

title: Implementation of NHLBI integrated guidelines for cardiovascular health and risk reduction in children and adolescents: rationale and study design for young hearts, strong starts, body mass index, blood pressure, and a cluster randomized trial targeting tobacco.
abstract: BACKGROUND: Cardiovascular disease (CVD) and underlying atherosclerosis begin in childhood and their presence and intensity are associated with known cardiovascular disease risk factors. Attention to risk factor control in childhood has the potential to reduce the risk of subsequent CVD. OBJECTIVE: The Young Hearts Heads Strong Study was designed to test strategies that facilitate the adoption of Integrated Guidelines for Cardiovascular Health and Risk Reduction in Children and Adolescents supported by the National Heart, Lung, and Blood Institute. This study compares guideline-based quality measures for body mass index, blood pressure, and tobacco using two strategies: standardized dissemination versus multifaceted, practice-oriented intervention. STUDY DESIGN: Two primary care research networks recruited applications and provided support for intervention and outcome assessments. Individual practices were randomly assigned to intervention or control groups using a cluster randomized design based on network connectivity, number of clinicians per practice, urban and non-urban locations, and type of practice. Because measure compliance is abstracted from the individual patient's medical records, the observation units are individual children. Randomization units are physician practices. This results in a multi-level design where patients are nested within apps. Intervention practices received toolkits and supported guide practices, including academic elaboration, an ongoing e-learning group. This project complies with the American Board of Pediatrics Maintain Certification requirements, including monthly physician self-isolation, webinars, and other elements of the trial. IMPORTANCE: This trial will provide an opportunity to demonstrate tools and strategies to improve CV prevention in children through guideline-based interventions.

title: Implementation of the Tobacco Tactics intervention versus usual care at Trinity Health community hospitals
abstract: BACKGROUND: A National Institutes of Health-sponsored study guided by the Access, Effectiveness, Adoption, Implementation, and Care (RE-AIM) practice framework compared a nurse-administered Tobacco Tactics intervention with usual care. A previous article describes the effectiveness of the Tobacco Tactics intervention. This next article provides data describing the remaining constructs of the RE-AIM framework. METHODS: This pragmatic study used a mixed methods, quasi-experimental design at five Michigan community hospitals, three of which were nurse-administered Tobacco Tactics interventions and two received usual care. Nurses and patients were surveyed before and after the intervention. Measures included access (patient participation rates, characteristics, and service uptake), adoption (nurse participation rates and characteristics), practice (pre- and post-training changes in nurses' attitudes, service delivery, barriers to practice, views on education, documentation of services, and volunteering). numbers of follow-up phone calls) and care (continuation of intervention after study ends). RESULTS: Reach: Patient participation rates were 71.5%. There were significant pre- and post-intervention increases (n = 1370, p < 0.001) in self-reported print material intake at intervention hospitals compared to no change in control areas. Adoption: All targeted units and a few non-targeted units in response hospitals joined";" 76.0% (n = 1028) of the targeted nurses and 317 additional staff attended the training, and 92.4% were highly or partially satisfied with the training. APPLICATION: Nurses in intervention hospitals reported increased availability of cessation advice, counselling, medications, worksheets and DVDs (all p < 0.05) and reduced barriers to the delivery of smoking cessation services (p < 0.001). Qualitative reviews were very positive ("user-friendly", "smoothed" or "saves time"), but problems were noted with showing patients DVD and charts in electronic medical records. Care: Nurses continued to provide the intervention after the study ended. CONCLUSIONS: Considering that nurses represent the largest group of front-line providers, this intervention that meets Joint Commission guidelines for the treatment of inpatient smokers has the potential to have broad reach and reduce smoking, morbidity and mortality among inpatient smokers. As we move towards more population-based interventions, the RE-AIM framework is a valuable guide to implementation. TRIAL REGISTRATION: ClinicalTrials.gov, NCT01309217.

title: Implementation of a clinical practice guideline for acute low back pain Evidence-based management in general practice (PRACTICE): cluster randomized controlled trial trial protocol
abstract: BACKGROUND: Evidence from reliable studies is not often applied in clinical practice. Evidence-based clinical practice guidelines are a potential tool to achieve this. A recent systematic review of implementation strategies for guideline dissemination concluded that there is a lack of evidence for effective strategies to promote guidelines adoption. Recommendations from this review and other studies have suggested the use of theory-based interventions because they may be more effective than those that do not. An evidence-based clinical practice guideline for the treatment of acute low back pain has recently been developed in Australia. This provides an opportunity to develop and test a theory-based practice intervention for a common, high-burden situation where there is an evidence-practice gap in primary care. OBJECTIVE: This study aims to test the efficacy of a theory-based intervention for the implementation of a clinical practice guideline for acute low back pain in general practice in Victoria, Australia. Specifically, our primary goals are to determine whether the intervention is effective in reducing the percentage of patients referred for plain x-rays and improving the average disability level for patients three months after consultation. METHODS/DESIGN: This study protocol details a cluster randomized controlled trial. Ninety-two general practices (clusters) comprising at least one consenting GP will be randomized to an intervention or control arm using restricted randomization. Patients 18 years of age or older visiting a participating GP for acute nonspecific low back pain of less than three months duration would be eligible for inclusion. An average of twenty-five patients per general practice will be recruited and a total of 2,300 patient participants will be provided. GPs in the control arm will gain access to the guideline using the current dissemination strategy. Practitioners in the intervention arm will be invited to participate in face-to-face workshops supported by behavioral theory. Investigators (not involved in administering the intervention), patients, outcome evaluators, and study statistician will be blinded to the group distribution.

title: Implementation of a guideline for the treatment of people with type 2 diabetes: results of a cluster randomized controlled trial (C-RCT)
abstract: BACKGROUND: Many diabetic patients in Italy still lack adequate care in general practice. We evaluated the effectiveness of different strategies for implementing an evidence-based guideline for the management of uncomplicated type 2 diabetes among General Practitioners (GPs) in the Lazio region. METHODS: Three-arm cluster randomized controlled trial with GPs as randomization units (clusters). 252 GPs were randomized to either an active strategy (training module including guideline management) or a passive extension (guideline application only) or usual care (control). Data on tests and drug prescriptions were collected by existing information systems, while data on patients came from databases of general practitioners. Process outcomes were measured at the cluster level one year after the intervention. Primary outcomes were related to the commissioning of glycosylated hemoglobin measurement and micro- and macrovascular complication assessment tests. Secondary outcomes were also calculated to assess physicians' medication prescribing behaviors. RESULTS: General practitioners identified 6395 uncomplicated type 2 patients with a high prevalence of cardiovascular risk factors. Data on baseline performance of GPs show evaluations of low rates of glycosylated hemoglobin. The results of the C-RCT analysis show that the active administration strategy was ineffective with respect to all primary outcomes (OR 1.06 [95% IC: 0.76-1.46]"; OR 1.07 [95% IC: 0.80-1.43];" OR 1.4 [%] 95 IC:0.91-2.16] Similarly, passive dissemination of guidelines had no effect CONCLUSION: GP compliance in our region was not enhanced by a structured learning program that causes behavioral changes TRIAL REGISTRATION: ISRCTN80116232.

title: Implementing a public-private model for tuberculosis treatment in urban Pakistan: lessons and experiences
abstract: LOCATION: The six towns of Karachi, Pakistan. OBJECTIVES: 1) Strengthen the capacity of general practitioners (GPs) to provide TB treatment through DOTS" and 2) Improve public-private collaboration in TB management and case reporting DESIGN: Treating TB patients through trained GPs with the support of quasi-experimental laboratory networks Study design was adopted to ensure enrollment and improve case detection rate CONCLUSIONS: The following challenges were encountered during the application of the model in urban settings: no systematic GP list was available Majority of GPs were untrained health practitioners working in slums where formally trained GPs were most needed; high the motivation of general practitioners with a patient load is very low; and access to the laboratory is difficult. In the first quarter (third quarter of 2009), 87% of 35 enrolled patients successfully completed their treatment. CONCLUSION: Public-private mix (PPM) DOTS can be implemented in Pakistani cities. However, the cost, time and effort required to set up the program are higher than in many other developing countries.

title: Applying academic details to breast cancer screening in underserved populations
abstract: BACKGROUND: African American and Hispanic women, such as those living in the North Manhattan and South Bronx neighborhoods of New York City, are often underserved in breast cancer prevention and screening practices, although they are more likely to die from breast cancer. than other women. Primary care physicians (PCPs) are critical in recommending breast cancer screening to their patients. Academic detailing is a promising strategy for improving PCP performance in recommending breast cancer screening, but little is known about the effects of academic detailing on breast cancer screening among physicians working in medically underserved areas. We evaluated the effectiveness of an advanced, multi-component academic elaboration intervention in increasing recommendations for breast cancer screening in a sample of community-based urban physicians. METHODS: Two medically underserved populations were matched and randomized to intervention and control arms. Ninety-four primary care community (ie, non-hospital-based) physicians in northern Manhattan were compared to 74 physicians in the South Bronx neighborhoods of the New York City metropolitan area. Intervention participants received doctor-directed advanced academic details using the American Cancer Society guidelines for early detection of breast cancer. No intervention was made in the control group physicians. We conducted interviews to measure primary care physicians' self-reported mammography and Clinical Breast Examination (CBE) recommendations and whether PCPs teach women to perform breast self-exams (BSE). RESULTS: Using multivariate analyses, we found a statistically significant intervention effect in recommending CME to female patients aged 40 years and older";" According to the physician's self-report, mammography and breast self-exam reports increased in both arms from baseline to follow-up. In posttesting, physician involvement in additional education programs, enhanced self-efficacy in counseling for prevention, routine use of schedule reminders, computers instead of paper-based guidance and monitoring approaches, printed patient education materials, performance goals for mammography, and increased involvement of nursing and other office staff. associated with increased browsing. CONCLUSION: We found some evidence of improved breast cancer screening practices among primary care physicians working in urban underserved communities due to improved academic background.

title: Applying Best Evidence in Smoking Cessation Treatment for Hospitalized Veterans: Results of the VA-BEST Trial
abstract: BACKGROUND: Although the U.S. Department of Veterans Affairs (VA) has promoted adherence to smoking cessation guidelines since 1997, hospitalized smokers do not receive ongoing assistance in quitting. METHODS: In a pre-guideline practice trial in inpatient medicine units of four VA hospitals, the effectiveness of a multimodal intervention (advanced academic elaboration, modification of the nursing admission template, patient education materials and referral to the dropout line, facilitation of administration, and staff feedback) changed practice behavior. Peri-charging interviews were conducted with 824 patients to assess whether nurses and physicians received the 5As (Ask, Advise, Evaluate, Help, Edit) in hospitalized smokers. RESULTS: Subjects were significantly more likely to receive each of the 5A from a nurse in the post-administration period (except for "quit advice"). More patients were assisted to quit (75% vs. 56%, adjusted odds ratio [OR] = 2.3, 95% confidence interval [CI] = 1.6, 3.1) and follow-up adjusted (23% vs. 18%, adjusted OR = 1.5, 95% CI = 1.0, 2.2) by a nurse in the post-administration period. However, unadjusted results showed no improvement at seven-day point prevalence deprivation at six-month follow-up (13.9% vs. 13.5%). Nurses' self-efficacy in quit counseling improved following guideline implementation, as measured in a survey of 166 unit nurses. CONCLUSION: A multifaceted intervention involving advanced academic elaboration is an effective strategy to improve the delivery of smoking cessation services in inpatients. More intensive interventions are needed to ensure that motivated smokers receive the treatment recommended in the guideline (including pharmacotherapy and referral to outpatient cessation counselling) to promote long-term cessation.

title: Application of clinical guidelines in the treatment of diabetes mellitus in general practice. Evaluation of effort, process, and patient outcome associated with the implementation of a computer-based decision support system
abstract: OBJECTIVES: To evaluate the application of clinical guidelines for diabetes mellitus in general practice with a specific computer-based clinical decision support system (CDSS) as part of the intervention. METHODS: Randomized study with health center as unit. General practice in Sor- and Nord-Trondelag counties in Norway, 380,000 inhabitants. There were 17 health centers with 24 doctors and 499 diabetes patients in the intervention group, and 12 health centers with 29 doctors and 535 patients in the control group. The main outcome measures were group differences in fractions of unregistered patients (process assessment) and mean group differences for the same variables (patient outcome assessment). RESULTS: There were statistically significant group differences in the fractions of patients with no smoking registration (intervention group, 82.6%"; control group 94.5%), body mass index (78.2% vs 93.0%), and patients with insufficient registration for risk estimation. myocardial infarction score (91.1% vs. 98.3%)" all over 18 months. Large center variations were shown for all variants. The only statistically significant group difference was -2.3 mm Hg (95% CI, -3.8, -0.8) in diastolic blood pressure in favor of the intervention group. Statistically insignificant differences in favor of the intervention group were HbA1c, -0.1% (95% CI, -0.4, 0.1), systolic blood pressure, -1.2 mm Hg (95% CI, -4.4, 2.0). Statistically insignificant differences in favor of the control group were smokers fractions, +3.0% (95% CI, -4.0, 10.0), body mass index, +0.3 kg/m2 (95% CI, -0.8, 1.4), risk score. +0.1 (95% CI, -5.1, 5.2) for females and +2.6 (95% CI, -14.2, 195) for males. CONCLUSIONS: In general practice, the implementation of clinical guidelines for diabetes mellitus through a CDSS and various practice-oriented procedures did not result in clinically significant changes in physician behavior or patient outcomes.

title: Application of clinical guidelines in the treatment of hypertension in general practice.
abstract: Inconsistencies between clinical guidelines and clinical practice require practical implementation strategies. This study evaluates the application of clinical guidelines for hypertension in general practice with a specific computer-based clinical decision support system (CDSS) as part of the intervention. We conducted a randomized study of general practice health centers in Norway's SÃ¸r- and Nord-TrÃ¸ndelag counties (population 380,000). A total of 17 health centers, including 24 doctors and 984 patients, were included in the intervention group. Data from 887 patients were used in the analyses. There are 12 health centers with 29 doctors and 1255 patients in the control group. Data from 1127 control patients were used in the analyses. The main outcome measures were physician behavior as measured by the registry of variables recommended in the Norwegian clinical guidelines for hypertension. The aim of the intervention was to reduce the proportion of patients without registries. However, there was no clinically significant difference between the intervention group and the control group for the fractions of patients who had no record of blood pressure (14.3% in the intervention group, 14.2% in the control group) or serum cholesterol (62.3% vs. 56.8%) over 12 months, neither for a proportion of patients with no smoking record (87.1% vs 82.9%), cardiovascular heredity (73.4% vs. 79.5%), and body mass index (81.5% vs. 89.2%) for 18 months. One or more variables required for the calculation of the myocardial infarction risk score were missing in 91.7% of patients in the intervention group and 91.9% of patients in the control group. Large center variations were shown for all variants. In general practice, the implementation of clinical guidelines in the treatment of hypertensive patients through a CDSS and various practical procedures did not result in clinically significant changes in physician behavior. Importantly, both the user-friendliness of the particular CDSS and the problems in implementing time-consuming multidimensional procedures.

title: Application of evidence-based guidelines for radiography in acute low back pain: A pilot study in the chiropractic community.
abstract: OBJECTIVE: To evaluate the ability of a systematic educational intervention strategy for patients with acute low back pain (LBP) to shift chiropractors' plain radiography ordering behavior towards evidence-based practice. DESIGN: A quasi-experimental method was used comparing pre- and post-intervention results with those of a control population. SETTING: Two communities in Southern Ontario. DATA SOURCE: Survey data on acute LBP management posted. Outcome Measures Plain radiography use rates for acute LBP based on responses to mailed questionnaires. RESULTS: After intervention, there was a 42% reduction in the need for self-report for plain radiography for uncomplicated acute LBP (P .05). CONCLUSIONS: The educational intervention strategy used in this study appeared to have an effect in reducing the perceived need for plain radiography in acute LBP.

title: Implementation of evidence-based practice: the effectiveness of a structured multi-faceted mentoring program
abstract: OBJECTIVE: This article is a report on the effectiveness of a structured multi-faceted mentoring program designed to implement evidence-based practice in a clinical research-intensive setting. BACKGROUND: Barriers to the implementation of evidence-based practice are well documented in the literature. Evidence-based practice is associated with better quality care and better patient outcomes than traditional care. However, the integration of evidence-based practice into daily clinical practice remains inconsistent, and the gap between research and bedside practice remains significant. METHODS: This quasi-experimental mixed-methods study included pre-intervention (N = 159) and post-intervention (N = 99) questionnaires administered between June 2006 and February 2007, as well as a three-focus discussion with nursing leadership and shared governance staff. The online questionnaires included measures of organizational readiness, evidence-based practice beliefs, evidence-based practice practice, job satisfaction, group cohesion and nursing, and current turnover intention. Results. Participants in the evidence-based practice mentoring program had a greater increase in perceived organizational culture and readiness for evidence-based practice and belief-based practice scores than those who did not. The qualitative findings suggest that a culture of evidence-based practice must be a priority for the participation of staff at all levels, with leadership support and the allocation of resources for the sustainability of the initiative. CONCLUSION: These findings support other studies showing that nurses' beliefs about evidence-based practice are significantly related to evidence-based practice and having a mentor leads to stronger beliefs and more practice by nurses, as well as greater group cohesion. a powerful predictor of nursing turnover rates.

title: Practice guidelines for depression on antidepressant prescribing in general practice: a quasi-experimental review.
abstract: BACKGROUND: Internationally, depression guidelines recommend a stepped-care approach, implying that antidepressant medications should not be offered as first-line therapy to patients with below-threshold or mild depression. In the Netherlands, antidepressant prescribing rates are considered high in general practice as the first line of treatment. The aim of this study was to evaluate the implementation of the guidelines for antidepressant prescribing. METHODS: A quasi-experimental study with a non-equivalent naturalistic control group and three-year follow-up was conducted in the Netherlands in a general practice setting. General Practitioners (GPs) participated in a national Quality Improvement Collaboration (QIC) focused on the implementation of a guideline-based model for a progressive care approach to depression. The model consisted of self-help and psychological treatment options for patients with milder symptoms as alternatives to antidepressants in general practice. Changes in antidepressant prescription rates of GPs were documented over a three-year period and compared to a control group of GPs selected from an ongoing network of national registries. RESULTS: There was a 23.3% (49.4%-26.1%) reduction in antidepressant prescribing rates for patients with newly diagnosed depressive symptoms in the intervention group, while there was no difference (50.3%-52.6%) in the reference group. The reduction over time was significant compared to the usual care group (OR 0.44, 95% CI: 0.21-0.92). CONCLUSIONS: An implementation program using tiered maintenance principles for the allocation of depression interventions resulted in lower rates of antidepressant prescriptions in general practice. GPs can change prescribing behavior in the context of a QIC.

title: Implementation of guidelines on the prevention of opportunistic infections in inflammatory bowel disease
abstract: INTRODUCTION: Opportunistic infections are an important safety issue in the management of patients with inflammatory bowel disease (IBD). Despite the existence of international guidelines, many gastroenterologists have not adopted routine screening and vaccination. The aim of this study was to change clinical behavior using a simple screening tool. METHODS: A screening and vaccination proforma for hepatitis B, chickenpox, Influenza, Pneumococcus, human papillomavirus, tuberculosis, hepatitis C, and HIV was provided to each participating gastroenterologist. Gastroenterologists were surveyed before and after the proforma was administered to raise awareness of vaccine recommendations and current practices. Immunity rates and the proportion of patients receiving recommended screening and vaccines were documented. RESULTS: Thirty gastroenterologists from 8 different IBD centers participated in the evaluation. A total of 919 patients were included (55% women, 65% Crohn's, 33% ulcerative colitis, 2% unspecified IBD). The introduction of Proforma increased self-reported gastroenterologist screening from 47% to 97% before and after intervention, respectively, p<0.001. After applying Proforma, hepatitis B, varicella, influenza and pneumococcal vaccines were recommended to 67%, 2.5%, 75% and 69% of the patients, respectively. Of these, 42%, 39%, 66% and 49% followed the recommendations and were vaccinated. Cervical smear was recommended in 31% and 62% of these received the recommended cervical smear. CONCLUSIONS: The implementation of a screening and vaccination proforma has significantly changed the self-reported behavior of gastroenterologists. Patient compliance with these recommendations was not optimal and suggests the need for more patient education in addition to other forms of support.

title: Application of international osteoarthritis treatment guidelines in primary care: study protocol for the SAMBA stepped wedge cluster randomized controlled trial.
abstract: Background Previous research shows that people with osteoarthritis (OA) do not receive recommended and optimal treatment. Based on international treatment recommendations and previous research for hip and knee OA, the SAMBA model for integrated OA care in Norwegian primary care was developed. The model includes patient OA training sessions led by a physical therapist (PT) and an exercise program lasting 8–12 weeks. This study aims to evaluate the effectiveness, feasibility and costs of a tailor-made strategy to implement the SAMBA model. Methods/design A cluster randomized controlled trial will be conducted in Norway in six municipalities (clusters) with a stepped wedge design that includes an impact, process and cost assessment. Municipalities will be randomly selected for the transition period from the current routine maintenance to the implementation of the SAMBA model, with a specific strategy. The specific strategy includes interactive workshops for general practitioners (GPs) and primary care PTs covering the SAMBA model for integrated OA care, educational materials, educational help visits, feedback and reminder material. Outcomes will be measured at patient, GP, and PT levels using self-report, semi-structured interviews, and record-based data. The primary outcome measure is patient-reported quality of care at 6 months follow-up (OsteoArthritis Quality Indicator questionnaire). Secondary outcomes include referrals to PT, imaging, and referrals to an orthopedic surgeon, as well as participants' treatment satisfaction, symptoms, level of physical activity, body weight, and self-reported and measured lower extremity function. Actual exposure to tailor-made implementation strategy and user experiences will be measured in a process assessment. In the economic evaluation, the difference in costs of usual OA care and the SAMBA model for integrated OA care will be compared with the difference in health outcomes and reported with an incremental cost-effectiveness ratio (ICER). Discussion The results of this study will add to current knowledge about adapted strategies aimed at improving the uptake of evidence-based OA care recommendations and improving the quality of OA care in primary care. The new knowledge can be used in national and international initiatives designed to improve the quality of OA care. Trial registration ClinicalTrials.gov NCT02333656

title: Implementation of nutritional guidelines -- the impact of systematic training for nurse nutrition practitioners
abstract: INTRODUCTION: Approximately 40% of patients admitted to hospitals are malnourished. Implementation of dietary guidelines can reduce the incidence of malnutrition and requires education and training for hospital staff. OBJECTIVE: It has been hypothesized that a training program focusing on staff behavior will increase the identification of eating difficulties, improve patients' knowledge of appropriate food choices, and increase the number of snacks eaten between meals, thereby reducing the risk of malnutrition. METHODS: Pre- and post-test design was used to evaluate the effect of the training program for nurses. The training was carried out in five modules over the course of 1 year and combined nutrition topics with topics related to practice and theories of planned change. The program was based on experiential learning theories and the look, think and act steps. The effect on patients was measured with a patient questionnaire. RESULTS: After following the guidelines, more patients discussed their eating difficulties with staff, received necessary assistance during meals, and were served food they ordered and could chew. Patients' knowledge of appropriate food choices from the menu increased, suggesting that patients' food intake improved. CONCLUSION: Our findings show that a strategy based on the principles of experiential learning theory and the step-by-step model of look, think and act facilitates the implementation of nutritional guidelines in the hospital setting.

title: Implementation of clinical guidelines using a computer graphics system. The effect on primary care of healthcare workers exposed to body fluids.
abstract: Context. “Although clinical guidelines are seen as an important mechanism for improving the quality of medical care, problems in implementation can limit their effectiveness. Few empirical data are available on the impact of computer-based systems for the implementation of clinical guidelines on the quality of care. Aim. “To determine whether real-time delivery of clinical guidelines using the electronic medical record would improve compliance with guidelines. Design. Prospective closed-open, discontinuous time series with therapeutic analysis. Adjustment. â€”University hospital emergency department. Subjects Patients were 280 healthcare professionals (50 at baseline control, 156 at intervention, and 74 at post-intervention control) who presented for initial treatment of occupational body fluid exposure, including 89% (248/280). those who continued to be punctured and 81% (208/257) were exposed to blood. The doctors consisted of assistant doctors and doctors working in the emergency room during the study. interventions. - Implementation of a computer graphics system that provides real-time information on history and recommendations for laboratory testing, treatment and regulation based on rules derived from clinical guidelines. Main Outcome Measures. “The percentage of total fees and charges attributable to quality of care, compliance with testing and treatment guidelines, and guidelines-approved activities determined by key elements documented in medical records and post-care instructions. Results. â€“Average percent documentation of 7 core items of patient history in the medical record increased from 57% at baseline to 98% at intervention (42% increase"; 95% confidence interval [CI], 34-49%) and care 11 items in post-education increased from 31% at baseline to 93% during the intervention phase (62% increase; 95% CI, 51-74%), but both dropped to baseline when the computer system was removed. increased from 63 to 83% during intervention (20% increase; 95% CI, 9-31%) but decreased to 52% when computer system was removed. guidelines increased from 83% initially to 96% during intervention (13%) increase; 95% Ci, 9-17%) and decreased to 84% after intervention, from 44% at baseline to 81% during intervention (37% increase; 95% CI, 22%-52%) after intervention decreased to 36. Average total fees per patient were $460, $384, and $373, respectively, at each stage. Results. Using a computer-based system for reduced manuals reduces overall fees while improving documentation, compliance with guidelines, and the percentage of fees spent for specified activities. Parameters returned to baseline when the computer system was removed.

title: Putting research findings into practice using clinical opinion leaders: barriers and lessons learned
abstract: BACKGROUND: An opinion-leader-led intervention to improve practice guideline medication management for patients with schizophrenia was tested at four Department of Veterans Affairs health care facilities. The concept of using evidence leaders as dissectors of research evidence and internal agents of change has been widely reported. PROJECT OVERVIEW: Each response site received an intensive, multi-component response over the course of a year. The process evaluation of the project included ongoing short surveys of doctors' attitudes and behaviors, diaries of reports from opinion leader conference calls, and interviews with opinion leaders towards the end of the implementation period. OBSTACLES OR PROBLEMS AND POSSIBLE SOLUTIONS: Several barriers or problematic issues have surfaced: (1) doctors do not always agree on who is an opinion leader”; on some sites there may not be an opinion leader; (2) on some sites formal and informal social development networks among doctors; (3) focusing on doctors only as agents of change;" and (4) how much instruction should opinion leaders be given on how attitudes and behaviors will be affected? DISCUSSION: The four main problematic issues encountered during the project offer potential solutions for addressing them.

title: Implementation of the NHS information technology programme: a qualitative study of progress in acute trusts.
abstract: OBJECTIVES To describe progress and perceived challenges in implementing the NHS information and technology (IT) program in England. DESIGN Case studies and in-depth interviews with themes identified using a framework developed from grounded theory. We interviewed staff who had been interviewed 18 months ago or staff who just started the same job. SETTING Four NHS acute hospital trusts in England. PARTICIPANTS Senior trust managers and clinicians, including senior managers, IT managers, medical managers, and nursing managers. CONCLUSIONS The interviewees unconditionally supported the objectives of the program, but they had some serious concerns. As before, implementation is hampered by local fiscal deficits, delays in implementing program-compliant patient management systems, and poor communication between Connecting for Health and local administrators. New problems arose. Local authorities cannot prioritize program implementation because of competing financial priorities and uncertainties about the program. They perceive an increased risk to patient safety associated with delays and loss of integration of program components and are dissatisfied with Select & Book (electronic reservation for primary care referrals). CONCLUSIONS We recommend that the program set realistic timelines for individual trusts and advise administrators about temporary IT systems they have to purchase due to delays beyond their control. Advice should be mindful of the need for trusts for longer-term compatibility with the program and value for money. Trusts need help prioritizing IT modernization, including, for example, the implementation of the program within the framework of performance management. These issues will still need to be addressed, even as Connecting for Health takes a different approach to local practice versus centralized standards setting. Lessons learned in the NHS are of wider relevance as health systems such as France and Australia seek to realize the potential of large-scale IT modernisation.

title: Results of stroke prevention studies: treating global risk
abstract: Clinical trials have shown that the risk of cardiovascular events can be reduced in stroke patients using blood pressure (BP) lowering and statin therapy, regardless of the presence of specific risk factors. These results suggest an alternative approach to secondary stroke prevention that focuses on global risk rather than identifying and modifying individual categorical risk factors such as hypertension, dyslipidemia, and diabetes mellitus. A risk-based approach is warranted because stroke patients are at high risk for many cardiovascular events, not just stroke, and physiological risk factors such as BP show a continuous or log-linear association with cardiovascular risk. What is necessary for the implementation of such an approach is the development of adequate risk stratification models for stroke patients. However, based on the limited available evidence, it appears that most patients with ischemic stroke or TIA are at high long-term absolute risk for a subsequent cardiovascular event and should be treated with all available risk reduction strategies.

title: Importance of characteristics and modalities of physical activity and exercise in defining cardiovascular health benefits in the general population: Recommendations from EACPR (Part I)
abstract: In the last decade, more and more evidence has accumulated that physical activity (PA) and exercise interventions are key components in primary and secondary prevention for cardiovascular disease. However, it is less clear whether which type of PA and exercise intervention (aerobic exercise, dynamic resistance exercise, or both) or characteristic of exercise (frequency, intensity, duration or duration and volume) confer greater benefits in achieving cardiovascular health. . The first in a series of three articles, this article will provide specific advice on the importance of these traits for cardiovascular health in the population at large. The guidance provided in this series of articles is addressed to medical practitioners, health practitioners, kinesiologists, physical therapists and exercise physiologists, politicians, public health policy makers, and individual members of society. Based on previous and current literature, recommendations of the European Society for Cardiovascular Prevention and Rehabilitation have been formulated regarding the type, volume and intensity of PA and exercise.

title: Improved asthma outcomes using a coordinated care approach in a large medical group.
abstract: The aim of this study was to review the development of a multidisciplinary asthma disease management program in a large medical group practice in an urban area and to evaluate the impact of the program on care and healthcare utilization processes for adults and children with asthma. The disease management intervention included the development of a patient registry, a systematic approach to assessment of asthma control using the Asthma Treatment Evaluation Questionnaire (ATAQ), case management, and physician education. An administrative database was used to review hospital admissions and emergency room (ED) visits. A medical record audit was conducted to examine recorded compliance with asthma guidelines and documentation practices. The baseline study population included 3,486 adults and children with asthma. At baseline, the ATAQ suggested that control problems were common, with 34% of adult participants losing their jobs due to asthma. ATAQ also identified several areas for improvement of care. For example, only 20% of adult participants reported having a written treatment plan. Table review and analyzes of administrative claims showed that the program had beneficial results in several areas. Medical record documentation was improved for asthma diagnosis (83.3% vs. 98.6%”; p < 0.001) and patient education (15.7% vs. 26.1%; “p < 0.001). No improvement in peak flow ownership/use, smoking cessation advice, or flu vaccine documentation. Asthma-related emergency room visits decreased from 148 per 1000 to 88 per 1000 (p < 0.001) and asthma-related hospitalizations decreased from 81 per 1000 to 37 per 1000 (p < 0.001). The results show that this program is associated with a significant reduction in hospitalization rates and emergency room use rates for asthma, as well as significant improvement in several primary care processes.

title: Improved Clinical Performance and Teamwork of Pediatric Interprofessional Resuscitation Teams with Simulation-Based Educational Intervention
abstract: OBJECTIVES: To measure the impact of a 1-day team training course for pediatric interprofessional resuscitation team members on adherence to Pediatric Advanced Life Support guidelines, team productivity, and teamwork in a simulated clinical setting. Design: Multicenter prospective interventional study. SETTING: Four tertiary care pediatric hospitals in Canada between June 2011 and January 2015. SUBJECTS: Interprofessional pediatric resuscitation teams (n = 300"; 51 teams) including specialist physicians, critical care nurses, registered nurses, and registered respiratory therapists. 1-day simulation-based team training including interactive lectures, group discussions, and four simulated reenactment scenarios course was given followed by a debrief each. First scenario of the day (PRE) was done before any team training. Last scenario of the day (POST) was the same scenario with slightly modified patient history. All scenarios were to uncover and challenge specific teamwork behaviors MEASUREMENTS AND MAIN RESULTS: The primary outcome measure was change (before and after training) ) in accordance with Pediatric Advanced Life Support guidelines, as measured by the Clinical Performance Tool. These were: 1) change in onset times of chest compressions and defibrillation; and 2) Clinical Team Teamwork performance as measured by the Work Work Scale. Correlation between Clinical Performance Tool and Clinical Teamwork Scale scores was also analyzed. Teams calculated Clinical Performance Tool scores (67.3-79.6%; p < 0.0001), time to onset of chest compressions (60.8-27.1 s; p < 0.0001), time to defibrillation (164.8-122.0 s; p < 0.0001). 0.0001) and Clinical Teamwork Scale scores (56.0-71.8; p < 0.0001). A positive correlation was found between the Clinical Performance Tool and the Clinical Teamwork Scale (R = 0.281;" p < 0.0001) RESULTS: Participation in a simulation-based team training training intervention significantly improved surrogate measures of clinical performance, time to significant clinical initiation. Tasks and teamwork during pediatric resuscitation The positive correlation between clinical and teamwork performance indicates that effective teamwork improves clinical performance of resuscitation teams.

title: Improved cardiovascular care (IDOCC) delivery through outreach facilitation: study protocol and implementation details of a cluster randomized controlled trial in primary care.
abstract: BACKGROUND: There is a need to find innovative approaches to translate best practices for chronic disease care into daily primary care practice routines. Primary care plays a crucial role in the prevention and management of cardiovascular disease. However, there is a significant care gap and many challenges exist in the implementation of evidence-based care. The Improved Delivery of Cardiovascular Care (IDOCC) project is a pragmatic trial designed to improve the delivery of evidence-based care for the prevention and management of cardiovascular disease using practical help facilitation in primary care. METHODS: The IDOCC project is a tiered cluster randomized control trial in which Practice Support Facilitators work with primary care practices to improve cardiovascular disease prevention and management for patients at highest risk. Basic care practices in a major health region in Eastern Ontario, Canada are eligible to participate. The intervention consists of regular monthly meetings with the Implementation Outreach Facilitator over a period of one to two years. Practices that begin with supervision and feedback, consensus building, and goal setting are supported in changing practice behavior by incorporating chronic care model elements. These elements include (a) evidence-based decision support for providers, (b) delivery system redesign for applications, (c) advanced self-management support tools provided to applications to assist patient engagement, and (d) applications to increase patient referral. The primary outcome is a composite score measured at the patient level to represent each practice's adherence to evidence-based guidelines for cardiovascular care. Qualitative analysis of Practicing Outreach Facilitators' written accounts of ongoing practice interactions will be made. These textual analyzes will provide further information to understand the critical factors affecting project implementation. DISCUSSION: This pragmatic, incremental, randomized controlled trial, which includes both quantitative and process assessments, demonstrates innovative ways to implement large-scale quality improvement and evidence-based approaches to care delivery. This is the first Canadian study to examine the impact of a large-scale, multifaceted cardiovascular quality improvement program in primary care. It is anticipated that through the evaluation of the IDOCC, we will demonstrate an effective, practical and sustainable way to improve the cardiovascular health of patients across Canada. TRIAL REGISTRATION: ClinicalTrials.gov: NCT00574808.

title: Reduced surgical wound infections through improved perioperative antibiotic use and use of computer decision analysis.
abstract: prospective study was conducted over a two-year period to determine whether computer-generated reminders of perioperative antibiotic use could improve prescribing habits and reduce postoperative wound infections. During the first year, baseline antibiotic use patterns and postoperative infection rates were determined. During the second year, computer-generated reminders of perioperative antibiotic use were placed in the patient's pre-operative medical records, and patterns of antibiotic use and postoperative wound infections were tracked. Hospitalized patients who underwent non-emergency surgery between June-November 1985 (3,263 patients) and June-November 1986 (3,568) were followed up for perioperative antibiotic use indications, timing of antibiotic use, and postoperative infectious complications. Perioperative antibiotic use was deemed appropriate for 1,621 (50%) patients in the 1985 sample and for 1,830 (51%) patients in the 1986 sample. Of these patients, 638 (40%) of the 1985 sample and 1,070 (58%) of the 1986 sample were given antibiotics two hours before the surgical incision (p<0.001). Overall, postoperative wound infection was detected in 28 (1.8%) of 1,621 patients in 1985, compared with 16 (0.9%) of 1,830 such patients in 1986 (p<0.03). We conclude that computer-generated reminders of perioperative antibiotic use improve prescribing habits with a concomitant reduction in postoperative wound infections.

title: Improved therapeutic monitoring with various interventions: a randomized trial.
abstract: Background Medication errors are often associated with improper selection of medications or failure to adjust laboratory parameters. Differences between guideline recommendations and the actual frequency of therapeutic laboratory monitoring are significant. This study evaluated interventions to improve laboratory monitoring at the start of drug therapy. Methods This cluster randomized trial compared 3 usual care interventions for 10 drugs in 15 primary care clinics in a health care organization with an electronic medical record system. Eligible patients identified from electronic databases had not received the recommended laboratory monitoring within 5 days of new distribution of a study drug. The interventions included an electronic medical record reminder to the prescribing healthcare professional, an automated voice message to the patient, and a pharmacy team reaching out to the patient. The primary outcome was completion of all recommended baseline laboratory monitoring. Results A total of 961 patients participated in the study. At 25 days, 95 (48.5%) of 196 patients in the electronic medical record reminder group, 177 (66.3%) of 267 patients in the automated voicemail group, and 214 (82%) of 261 patients in the pharmacy team outreach group. 0) and 53 of 237 patients (22.4%) in the usual care group completed all recommended baseline laboratory monitoring (P<.001). After adjustments, hazard ratios for completion of laboratory monitoring compared to usual care were 2.5 (95% confidence interval, 1.8-3.5) for electronic medical record reminder, 4.1 (95% confidence interval, 3, ) for automated voicemail. 0-5.6) and 6.7. For access to the pharmacy team (95% confidence interval, 4.9-9.0). Results All 3 interventions were effective in increasing laboratory monitoring when introducing new drugs in primary care. More work is needed to determine whether these interventions improve patient outcomes.

title: Improving antibiotic prescription in outpatient care: a cluster randomized intervention study using a physician surveillance network.
abstract: OBJECTIVES: To evaluate the effectiveness of practice guidelines with individual feedback on the antibiotic prescribing behavior of primary care physicians in Switzerland. METHODS: One hundred and forty general practices from a representative Swiss sentinel network of primary care physicians participated in this cluster randomized prospective intervention study. The intervention consisted of providing guidelines for the treatment of respiratory tract infections (RTIs) and uncomplicated lower urinary tract infections (UTIs) and continuous, regular feedback on individual antibiotic prescribing behavior over 2 years. The main goals were: (i) to increase the percentage of penicillin prescriptions for all RTIs treated with antibiotics; (ii) to increase the percentage of trimethoprim/sulfamethoxazole prescriptions for all uncomplicated lower UTIs treated with antibiotics; (iii) to reduce all exacerbations treated with antibiotics. Percentage of quinolone prescriptions for COPD (eCOPD) cases; and (iv) reducing the rate of sinusitis and other upper respiratory tract infections treated with antibiotics Study registered on ClinicalTrials.gov (NCT01358916) RESULTS: Prescribed for sinusitis or other upper respiratory tract infections While the percentage of antibiotics and the percentage of quinolones prescribed for eCOPD did not differ between the intervention group and the control group, there was a significant increase in the percentage of penicillin prescribed for all GIs treated with antibiotics [57% vs. 49%, OR=1.42 (95%) CI 1.08-1.89), P=0.01] and trimethoprim/sulfa for all uncomplicated lower UTIs treated with antibiotics in percentage of methoxazole prescriptions [35% versus 19%, OR in the intervention group =2.16 (95% CI 1.19-3.91), P=0.01]. CONCLUSIONS: In our setting, practice guidelines, combined with continuous individual feedback, did not reduce the rate of sinusitis and other upper respiratory tract infections treated with antibiotics, but increased the use of recommended antibiotics for respiratory infections and UTIs, as defined in the guidelines.

title: Improving hypertension management with structured physician education and feedback system: cluster randomized trial.
abstract: INTRODUCTION: We aimed to evaluate whether hypertension management led to improved blood pressure (BP) control and cardiovascular outcomes with a structured physician information program and a feedback system. METHODS: Randomized cluster (3 : 1), open, followed-up, multicenter study in Germany. While primary care physicians in the information group (IG) received detailed training on hypertension guidelines, feedback on reaching target level, and a reminder to intensify therapy after each patient visit, the observation/control group (KG) did not receive any information. such measures. A three-level mixed model was developed. Time-independent level differences between groups, group-independent changes, and non-parallel group-specific changes over time were tested. RESULTS: There were 15 041 (78.1%) hypertensive patients in IG and 4213 (21.9%) hypertensive patients in CG. At 1-year follow-up, 82.9% of patients in IG and 81.5% of patients in CG remained in the study. The guideline-focused BP target was achieved by 56.8% in the IG and 52.5% in the CG (+4.3%, P = 0.03), while the individual BP target was achieved in 57.0% in the IG and 51% in the CG (P = NS). BP control in IG was achieved on average 2 months ago. Clinical inertia, defined as the absence of drug changes despite uncontrolled BP, occurred significantly less frequently in the IG group. One-year cardiovascular outcomes did not differ between groups. CONCLUSION: Providing systematic information in conjunction with a feedback system reduces clinical inertia and improves guideline adherence. Although the rates of hypertension control achieved were higher compared to previous studies, there is still significant room for improvement.

title: Improvement of intraoperative antibiotic prophylaxis in long-term cardiac surgery with automatic alerts in the operating room
abstract: Purpose: To evaluate the effect of automatic intraoperative stimulation for redosing prophylactic antibiotics in long-term cardiac operations. Design: Randomized, controlled, assessor-blind study. Setting: University hospital. Patients: Patients undergoing cardiac surgery lasting more than 4 hours after preoperative administration of cefazolin, unless they are receiving therapeutic antibiotics during surgery. Intervention: Random assignment to an audible and visual reminder on the operating room computer console 225 minutes after preoperative administration of antibiotics (reminder group, n = 137) or control (n = 136). After 30 minutes, the circulating nurse was asked to indicate whether a follow-up dose of antibiotics was given. Results: Intraoperative redosing was better in the reminder group (93 out of 137; 68%) in the control group (55 out of 136; 40%) (adjusted odds ratio, 3.31; 95% confidence interval, 1.97 to 5.56; P < The effect of reminder was even greater compared to 6 months before the study period (129/480; 27%; P < .001), indicating some spillover effect over the control group. It decreased without recurrence for 19 of 44 patients in the reminder group The rate of surgical site infection in the reminder group (5 out of 137; 4%) was similar to that in the control group (8 out of 136; 6%; P = .42), but significantly lower than before (48/480; 10%; "P = .02). Conclusion: The use of automatic reminder system in the operating room improved adherence to perioperative antibiotic prophylaxis guidelines.

title: Improving compliance with hypertension drug prescribing guidelines: a clustered randomized controlled trial of general and patient-specific recommendations.
abstract: OBJECTIVE: To determine whether an intervention that focuses the clinician's attention on drug selection for the treatment of hypertension improves compliance between drug regimens and guidelines. STUDY DESIGN: Cluster-randomized controlled trial comparing an individualized intervention with a general guideline application in geographically diverse primary care clinics of a university-affiliated Veterans Affairs health system. METHODS: Participants were 36 physicians and nurse practitioners (16 in the general group and 20 in the individualized group) based on 4500 hypertensive patients. A general practice of guidelines for all clinicians, including guideline-based medication recommendations and education about targets for adequacy of blood pressure control, was compared to the inclusion of a printed, individualized recommendation sent to clinicians at each patient visit that indicates whether the patient is on antihypertensive medication. regimen was consistent with the guideline. We measured the change from baseline to endpoint in the proportion of clinicians whose medication adhered to the guidelines. RESULTS: The individualized intervention resulted in an improvement in guideline adherence more than twice that observed for the overall intervention (10.9% vs. 3.8%, t = 2.796, P = .008). Bootstrap analysis showed that being in the individualized group increased the probability of compliance 1.5-fold (P = .025). The proportion of patients with adequate blood pressure control increased in each study group";" however, the difference between groups was not significant. CONCLUSION: An individualized advice on drug therapy for hypertension given to the clinician at each patient visit was more effective than applying a general guideline in changing the clinician's prescribing behavior.

title: Costly Improving Treatment Adherence and Clinical Outcomes: Opportunities for Greater Use of Generics: Best Practice Recommendations from the American College of Physicians Clinical Guidelines Committee
abstract: Description: In the United States, the inconsistency between health expenditures and outcomes has fueled efforts to identify and address situations where unnecessarily expensive treatments are used when less costly, equally effective options are available. Inadequate use of generic drugs is an important example. Methods: A literature review was conducted to answer 5 questions regarding generic drugs: 1) How often are branded drugs used when a generic version is available? 2) How does the use of generic drugs affect compliance? 3) What is the evidence that brand-name and generic drugs have similar clinical effects? 4) What are the barriers to increasing the use of generic drugs? 5) What strategies can be used to promote cost savings through greater use of generic drugs? This article has been reviewed and approved by the American College of Physicians Clinical Guidelines Committee. Best Practice Recommendation: Clinicians should prescribe generics instead of more expensive brand-name drugs whenever possible.

title: Improving antibiotic prescription for adults with community-acquired pneumonia: Does a computerized decision support system achieve more than academic elaboration alone? - A time series analysis
abstract: BACKGROUND: The ideal method for promoting the adoption of clinical guidelines in hospitals is unknown. Several strategies have been proposed. This study evaluates the impact of academic elaboration and computerized decision support system (CDSS) on clinicians' prescribing behavior in patients with community-acquired pneumonia (CAP). METHODS: The management of all patients admitted to the emergency department in three consecutive time periods was evaluated";" foundation, academic elaboration and CDSS periods. The rate of empirical antibiotic prescribing consistent with recommendations was examined over time by comparing pre- and post-periods and using a discontinuous time series analysis. RESULTS: After adjusting for age, disease severity, and suspicion of aspiration, the odds ratio for compatible therapy during the academic elaboration period was OR = 2.79 [1.88, 4.14], p < 0.01, and computerized decision compared with baseline period. The duration of support compared to the academic elaboration period was OR = 1.99 [1.07, 3.69], p = 0.02. During the first months of the computerized decision support period, an improvement in antibiotic prescribing eligibility was demonstrated, which was greater than expected to occur with time and academic elaboration alone, based on estimates from a binary logistic model. CONCLUSION: The deployment of a computerized decision support system was associated with an early improvement in antibiotic prescribing practices that was greater than the changes seen in academic elaboration. The sustainability of this intervention requires further evaluation.

title: Improving antibiotic use among hospital workers: a pilot academic detailing project with a public health approach
abstract: OBJECTIVE: Inappropriate use of antibiotics is an important clinical and public health problem. We developed and implemented a pilot hospital-provided academic elaboration intervention to improve antibiotic prescribing patterns for inpatients. OBJECTIVE: To improve antibiotic prescribing models in the hospital services of an academic medical center. DESIGN, ENVIRONMENT, AND PARTICIPANTS: Hospital staff were recruited to participate in this pre- and post-intervention pilot study at Johns Hopkins Bayview Medical Center (JHBMC). Public health principles to create a conceptual framework based on behavior change theory were used in the development of the intervention. METHODS: The antibiotic prescribing patterns of 17 general practitioners working in the hospital were analyzed retrospectively. Antimicrobial prescriptions were classified as appropriate, effective but inappropriate or inappropriate. A profile was created for each hospital attendant and an academic elaboration intervention session was held. The session reviewed inappropriate prescribing practices and existing practice guidelines. After the detailing meeting, the prescribing patterns of the hospitals were followed prospectively. MAIN OUTCOME MEASURES: The main outcome measures were the proportions of inappropriately prescribed antibiotics before the intervention, during the elaboration period, and after the intervention. RESULTS: Seventeen hospital physician practitioners participated in the study. A total of 247 prescriptions were reviewed in the pre-intervention period and 129 prescriptions in the post-intervention period. Prior to academic elaboration, 43% (95% CI 37-49%) of prescriptions were appropriate and 57% (95% CI 51%-63%) were inappropriate. 74% (95% CI 65-81%) of post-intervention prescriptions were appropriate, 26% (95% CI 19-35%) were inappropriate";" P < 0.0001. CONCLUSIONS: A carefully planned and methodically executed intervention can lead to behavioral change even among busy hospital workers. The academic elaboration intervention, which included a practice-based learning component, improved the antibiotic prescribing practices of hospitals at JHBMC.

title: Improving asthma care in emergency departments: results of a multi-hospital collaborative quality initiative in rural western North Carolina.
abstract: BACKGROUND: In North Carolina, about a quarter of people with asthma go to an emergency room (ED) or emergency care center at least once a year because of an exacerbation of asthma symptoms. The Emergency Department Asthma Program was a quality improvement initiative designed to better understand the population of patients using emergency rooms to treat asthma in rural western North Carolina, and to demonstrate whether small hospital emergency departments can do this by implementing the National Asthma Education and Prevention Program treatment. Improve asthma care and reduce asthma-related emergency room visits. METHODS: Eight hospitals in western North Carolina participated in the project, which ran from November 2003 to December 2007. The response consisted of a series of individual and structured continuing medical education activities for emergency physicians and staff. In addition, patients presenting to emergency departments for asthma-related problems were selected to take a short patient questionnaire to determine their basic understanding of asthma and the barriers to asthma care; asthma staging by the treating physician; a respiratory therapist and finally, at the discretion of the treating physician, receive a complimentary pack of asthma medication before discharge, including rescue therapy with a beta-agonist and corticosteroid therapy delivered via a metered-dose inhaler. -monthly project, a total of 1,739 patients were delivered to participating emergency services for 2,481 asthma-related care episodes;"in 11% of these visits, patients received the intervention and approximately 100 emergency physicians referred patients to the program. and almost half were uninsured or covered by Medicaid. Only 20% of visits were to a primary care physician or practice. Patient intervention did not reduce the rate of repeat visits for asthma-related symptoms on days 30 and 60. LIMITATIONS: Patients enrolled in the study were in the target sample Since patients are more likely to be adults and insured, selection bias is possible.Since we did not measure the participation of emergency personnel in training sessions or their knowledge and attitudes about asthma care before and after the training program, we cannot draw conclusions about the effectiveness of the program in changing their knowledge, attitudes or behaviors. CONCLUSIONS: Many patients using the emergency department for care appear to have mild, intermittent asthma and do not identify a regular primary care source. Efforts to improve community-wide asthma care and reduce preventable exacerbations should include care provided in emergency rooms, as this may be the sole source of asthma treatment for many asthma sufferers. The project demonstrated that regional, collaborative performance improvement efforts in emergency services are possible, but there are many barriers to this approach.

title: Improving asthma-related health outcomes among low-income, multiracial, school-aged children: results of a publicity project combining continuous quality improvement and community health worker strategies.
abstract: AIM. The aim of this study was to improve asthma-related health outcomes in an ethnically and geographically diverse population of economically disadvantaged school-age children, using a team-based approach using continuous quality improvement and community health workers. PATIENTS AND METHODS. A promotional project was carried out with 7 community clinics treating _x0001_3000 children with asthma aged 5 to 18 years. The general clinical population with asthma was assessed for changes in course of care by randomized cross-sectional chart reviews at baseline and at 24 months (N 560). A subset of patients with moderate or severe persistent asthma or poorly controlled asthma (N 405) were followed longitudinally for asthma-specific clinical outcomes, satisfaction with care, and confidence in managing asthma through family interview at baseline and at 12 or 24 months. Patient-centered and process-of-care outcomes included patient/parent assessment of quality of care and confidence in self-management, asthma action plan review, and documentation of guideline-based quality of care indicators. Direct clinical outcomes included day and night symptoms, use of rescue medications, acute care and emergency room visits, hospitalizations, and school days missed. The degree of adherence to the intervention model of each clinical site was assessed and graded to examine the correlation between model fit and outcomes.

title: Improving Blood Pressure Control Through Provider Education, Provider Alerts, and Patient Education
abstract: Background: Inadequate blood pressure control is a persistent gap in quality care. Objective: To evaluate provider and patient interventions to improve blood pressure control. Design: Cluster randomized controlled trial. Setting: 2 hospital-based and 8 community-based clinics in the Veterans Affairs Tennessee Valley Health System. Patients: 1341 veterans with essential hypertension cared for by 182 providers. Eligible patients had 2 or more blood pressure readings greater than 140/90 mm Hg in a 6-month period and were using a single antihypertensive agent. Intervention: Providers caring for eligible patients were randomly assigned to receive an email with a Web-based link to the Seventh Report of the Joint National Committee for the Prevention, Detection, Evaluation, and Treatment of Hypertension (JNC 7). (provider education)"; provider education and patient-specific hypertension computerized alert (provider education and alert); or provider education, hypertension alert, and patient education with providers (patient education) where a letter is sent to patients advocating medication adherence, lifestyle change, and conversations. Measurements: Proportion of patients with systolic blood pressure less than 140 mm Hg at 6 months; intensification of antihypertensive drugs Results: Mean baseline blood pressure was 157/83 mm Hg with no difference between groups (P = 0.105) Six-month follow-up data were available for 975 patients (73%) ) Patients of providers randomly assigned to patient education had better blood pressure control (138/75 mm Hg) than the group, provider education, and alert or provider education-only groups (146/76 mm Hg and 145/78 mm Hg, respectively). systole of 140 mm Hg or less compared with those in more patients, provider education or provider education, and alert groups had an initial blood pressure (adjusted relative risk for the patient education group versus the provider education group alone, 1.31 [95% CI, 1.06 to 1.62]; "P = 0.012). Limitations: Follow-up blood pressure measurements were missing in 27% of study patients. The study failed to identify a mechanism by which patient education improved blood pressure control. Results: A multifactorial intervention that included patient education improved blood pressure control compared with provider education alone.

title: Improving blood pressure control through provider education, provider alerts, and patient education: a randomized cluster trial.
abstract: Background: Inadequate blood pressure control is a persistent gap in quality care. Objective: To evaluate provider and patient interventions to improve blood pressure control. Design: Cluster randomized controlled trial. Setting: 2 hospital-based and 8 community-based clinics in the Veterans Affairs Tennessee Valley Health System. Patients: 1341 veterans with essential hypertension cared for by 182 providers. Eligible patients had 2 or more blood pressure readings greater than 140/90 mm Hg in a 6-month period and were using a single antihypertensive agent. Intervention: Providers caring for eligible patients were randomly assigned to receive an email with a Web-based link to the Seventh Report of the Joint National Committee for the Prevention, Detection, Evaluation, and Treatment of Hypertension (JNC 7). (provider education)"; provider education and patient-specific hypertension computerized alert (provider education and alert); or provider education, hypertension alert, and patient education with providers (patient education) where a letter is sent to patients advocating medication adherence, lifestyle change, and conversations. Measurements: Proportion of patients with systolic blood pressure less than 140 mm Hg at 6 months; intensification of antihypertensive drugs Results: Mean baseline blood pressure was 157/83 mm Hg with no difference between groups (P = 0.105) Six-month follow-up data were available for 975 patients (73%) ) Patients of providers randomly assigned to patient education had better blood pressure control (138/75 mm Hg) than the group, provider education, and alert or provider education-only groups (146/76 mm Hg and 145/78 mm Hg, respectively). systole of 140 mm Hg or less compared with those in more patients, provider education or provider education, and alert groups had an initial blood pressure (adjusted relative risk for the patient education group versus the provider education group alone, 1.31 [95% CI, 1.06 to 1.62]; "P = 0.012). Limitations: Follow-up blood pressure measurements were missing in 27% of study patients. The study failed to identify a mechanism by which patient education improved blood pressure control. Results: A multifactorial intervention that included patient education improved blood pressure control compared with provider education alone.

title: Improving cardiovascular risk management: a randomized controlled trial on the impact of a decision support tool for patients and physicians.
abstract: BACKGROUND: There is a suboptimal adherence of general practitioners (GPs) and patients to cardiovascular risk-reducing interventions. General practitioners find it difficult to incorporate multiple risk factors into an accurate cardiovascular risk assessment. Additionally, communicating cardiovascular risk to patients has proven difficult. OBJECTIVES: To improve primary prevention of cardiovascular disease (CVD) in primary care by increasing patient participation in the use of a decision support tool. DESIGN: Cluster randomized trial. METHODS: Thirty-four GPs included patients (ages 40-75 years) without CVD. During the 4-hour interactive, small-group training session, GPs in the intervention group were trained to use cardiovascular risk guidelines and a decision support tool. The control group received educational materials about the guidelines on paper. Clinical performance of GPs and patients' perception of risk and self-reported lifestyles were measured at baseline and 6 months later. RESULTS: Thirty-four GPs recorded 490 consultations, of which 276 were in the intervention and 214 in the control group. After 6 months, the intervention had no significant effect on GP performance or on patients' perception of risk. It only had an effect on self-reported lifestyle, as more men in the intervention group increased their physical activity than the control group (probability ratio 3.8, 95% confidence interval 1.7-8.7). CONCLUSION: The 4-hour interactive, small-group training did not guarantee the correct application of the decision support tool and therefore failed to improve GP performance or correct patients' perception of risk. The positive effect on physical activity justifies further research into patient engagement.

title: Improving care for minority children with asthma: vocational training in public health clinics
abstract: OBJECTIVE: Recent studies have shown that discontinuation of primary care for asthma is associated with increased levels of morbidity in low-income minority children. Although effective preventative treatment is available, many African-American and Latino children receive episodic treatment for asthma that does not follow current care guidelines. We trained staff at New York City Bureau of Child Health clinics to provide ongoing, preventive care for asthma to see if access, continuity, and quality of care could be improved in pediatric clinics serving low-income children in New York. METHODS: We evaluated the effect of the intervention over a 2-year period in a controlled study of 22 clinics. Training for intervention clinic staff was based on the National Asthma Education and Prevention Program guidelines for asthma diagnosis and management and included screening to identify new cases and health education to improve family management. The intervention included strong administrative support provided by the Child Health Bureau to promote staff behavior change. We hypothesized that after intervention, clinics receiving the intervention would have an increased number of asthmatic children receiving ongoing care in clinics and staff use of new pharmacological and educational treatment modalities compared with control clinics. RESULTS: At both the first and second follow-up years, intervention clinics had greater positive changes in measures of access, continuity, and quality of care than control clinics. For second-year follow-up data these include: for access, higher proportion of new asthma patients (16/1000 vs 40/1000; P < .01); for continuity, greater percentage of asthma patients returning to treatment for 2 years at one year rank (42% vs 12%; P < .001) and greater annual frequency of scheduled visits for asthma per patient (1.85 vs. .88; P < .001) and greater percentage of patients receiving inhaled beta agonists for quality (52% vs 15%; P < .001) and inhaled anti-inflammatory drugs (25% vs 2%; P < .001) and greater percentages of parents (71%) who reported receiving patient education on 12 subjects from Bureau of Child Health physicians. vs 71%) 58%; P < .01) and nurses (61% vs 44%; "P < .05). CONCLUSION: We concluded that the intervention significantly enhanced the ability of Office of Child Health staff to identify children with asthma, involve them in ongoing care, and provide them with state-of-the-art care for asthma.

title: Improving chronic disease prevention and screening in primary care: results of BETTER pragmatic cluster randomized controlled trial
abstract: BACKGROUND: Provides most of the evidence-based chronic disease prevention and screening services offered by the primary health care system. However, there is still a gap between recommended preventive services and actual implementation. This trial (BETTER Trial) aimed to improve preventive care of heart disease, diabetes, colorectal, breast and cervical cancers and related lifestyle factors through a practice facilitation intervention identified in primary care. METHODS: Practice of Primary Care Physicians as unit of allocation and pragmatic two-way factorial cluster RCT with individual patients as unit of analysis. The setting was urban Primary Care Team practices in two Canadian provinces. Eight Primary Care Team applications were randomly assigned to receive application-level intervention or waitlist control";" 4 doctors (32 doctors) from each team were randomly assigned to receive patient-level intervention or waiting list control. Patients randomly selected from doctor lists were divided into two groups: 1) general and 2) moderate mental illness. Interventions included a versatile, evidence-based, personalized practice-level intervention with a Practice Facilitator and a patient-level intervention that included a one-hour visit with a Prevention Practitioner, where patients received a specific 'prevention prescription'. The primary outcome was the combined Summary Quality Index of 28 evidence-based chronic disease prevention and screening actions with predefined goals, expressed as the proportion of appropriate initial actions met at follow-up. Cost-effectiveness analysis was performed. RESULTS: Of 1,260 (63%) eligible patients, 789 participated. On average, patients were eligible for action at baseline of 8.96 (SD 3.2). In the adjusted analysis, control patients met 23.1% (95% CI: 19.2% to 27.1%) of the target actions, 55.6% (95% CI: 20.9% to 36.0%) compared to 28.5% (95% CI: 20.9% to 36.0%) who received the intervention. 95 CI: 49.0% to 62.1% receiving patient-level intervention and 58.9% (95% CI: 54.7% to 63.1%) receiving both practical and patient-level interventions (patient-level intervention vs. control, P < 0.001). The benefit of patient-level intervention was seen in both strata. The extra cost of the intervention was 26.43 CAN (95% CI: $16 to $44) per additional action covered. CONCLUSIONS: A Prevention Practitioner can cost-effectively improve the implementation of clinically important prevention and screening for chronic diseases.

title: Improving clinical handover between intensive care unit and general service staff at ICU discharge.
