abstract: Objective To systematically review and evaluate the effectiveness of interventions to improve the safety and efficiency of patient turnover among intensive care unit (ICU) and general service healthcare professionals discharged from the intensive care unit. Methods PubMed, CINAHL, PsycINFO, EMBASE, Web of Science, and the Cochrane Library were searched for intervention studies aimed at improving clinical transition among intensive care unit and general service health professionals, published up to June 2013. article inclusion and data analysis were predetermined and aligned with the recommendations outlined in the PRISMA guideline. Two reviewers independently extracted data (study objective, setting, population, sampling method, sample size, intervention characteristics, outcome and practice activities) and evaluated the quality of the included studies. Results Out of 6,591 citations originally drawn from six databases, we included 11 studies in this review. Six of these (55%) reported statistically significant effects. Effective interventions included liaison nurses to improve communication and coordination and coordination of care, and forms to facilitate timely, complete and accurate handover information. Effective interventions resulted in increased continuity of care (eg, reduced delay in discharge) and reduced adverse events. Inconsistent effects were observed for use of care, i.e. increased readmissions to higher care versus reduced length of stay. No statistically significant effect was found in reducing mortality. The overall methodological quality of the 11 studies reviewed was relatively low, with an average of 4.5 out of 11 points. Conclusions This review shows that liaison nurses and handover forms are promising interventions to improve the quality of patient handover between the ICU and the general ward. More robust evidence is needed on the effectiveness of interventions and supportive delivery strategies aimed at improving ICU turnover.

title: Improving adherence to immunization in older adults: results of a randomized cohort study.
abstract: OBJECTIVE: To compare three approaches to increase compliance of elderly patients with influenza and pneumococcal vaccines. DESIGN: Randomized controlled trial using three parallel group practices in a public urban teaching hospital. LOCATION: State teaching hospital. SUBJECTS: All patients 65 years of age or older (n = 1202) seen by resident physicians (n = 66) participating in three outpatient medical practices from October 1, 1989 to March 31, 1990. immunization standards. No other intervention was made in the control group. Staff in the second group provided education to patients during their visit. In the third group, the prevention team used a flowchart, provided patient education, and redefined staff roles to facilitate compliance";" for vaccines, for example, nurses can vaccinate independently of the MD intervention. MEASUREMENTS AND MAIN RESULTS: Medical records of 1202 patients seen, including 756 patients seen in both the 1988-89 and 1989-90 influenza seasons, were reviewed to determine the delivery and receipt of documented vaccines. During the intervention period (1989–90), influenza vaccines were offered significantly more frequently to prevention team patients (68.3%) than patients in the patient education (50.4%) or control (47.6%) groups (P = 0.006), with patients' prior immunization status , even after adjusting for age, sex, race and high-risk comorbidity, and level of education of physicians. Similarly, pneumococcal vaccines were recommended more frequently to previously unvaccinated prevention team patients (28.3%) than to previously unvaccinated prevention team patients (6.5%) or control (5.4%) patients (P = 0.001), even after adjusting for factors using multivariate analysis. Compliance rates did not differ between patient education and control subjects for either vaccine. Pre-intervention physician surveys documented perceived higher-than-actual compliance for both vaccines; 89.0% and 52.8% of physicians believed that they followed the influenza and pneumococcal vaccination guidelines, respectively. CONCLUSIONS: The results of this research provide strong support for organizational changes involving non-physician staff members to increase vaccination rates among older adults.

title: Improving the delivery of preventive health services with the comprehensive annotated reminder tool (CART)
abstract: OBJECTIVES: We evaluated the impact of the Comprehensive Annotated Reminder Tool (CART) on physician compliance with preventive service recommendations. STUDY DESIGN: Using a randomized pretest/posttest control group design, we assigned physicians to the CART group or control group, prospectively followed up, and evaluated adherence to guidelines. The 3 age-specific versions of the CART annotated history and physical examination form included up to 49 preventive service recommendations. POPULATION: All residents in a large family medicine residency program were studied for 1 academic year. MEASURED RESULTS: We conducted blind chart reviews to assess the appropriateness of preventive services provided by physicians before, during, and after CART's release. A completed multiple-choice test before and after the use of CART forms that assess knowledge. RESULTS: When CART was used, the appropriateness of the physician's preventive behaviors increased by 21% in total. Appropriateness of history, physical examination and laboratory interventions increased by 33%. When CART was removed, physician behavior returned to baseline (P < or = .0025 for 16 of 20 interventions). No significant difference was observed in the control group over time. Knowledge increased for all physicians over the study period (P < or = .005), but there was no significant difference between the treatment and control groups (P = .608). CONCLUSIONS: Use of CART significantly improved physician performance in the appropriate delivery of preventive care.

title: Improving Depression Care with Online Learning Collaboration
abstract: Depression is the leading cause of disability worldwide, and many internists diagnose and treat depression. This study aimed to examine the effect of a practice improvement intervention in screening and managing patients with depression in primary care. This preliminary study design included an intervention that included a physician practice questionnaire designed to capture what physicians believed they were doing in practice, a chart audit tool to capture what physicians actually did in practice, and an evidence-based education program. application development coaching conference calls that support online toolkit and group learning. Upon completion of the intervention, participants increasingly used the Patient Health Questionnaire-9 to detect, diagnose, and measure treatment success for depression, and reported increased use of guidelines and team-based care. While there are barriers to improving depression care, this study suggests that evidence-based quality improvement programs can positively impact practice.

title: Improving diabetes care: multicomponent strategies to reduce cardiovascular disease risk for people with diabetes in South Asia - CARRS multicenter translation trial
abstract: OBJECTIVES: Cardiovascular disease (CVD) is the leading cause of morbidity and mortality in people with diabetes in South Asia. The CARRS Translation Trial tests the efficacy, cost-effectiveness and sustainability of a clinical-based multi-component CVD risk reduction intervention among people with diabetes in India and Pakistan. METHODS: We randomly selected 1146 adults with diabetes from 10 urban clinics recruited by physicians to receive usual care or an integrated multi-component CVD risk reduction intervention. The intervention includes electronic health record management, decision support alerts to the healthcare team, and support from a care coordinator to actively facilitate patient and provider adherence to evidence-based guidelines. The primary outcome is a combination of multiple CVD risk factor control (blood sugar and blood pressure or cholesterol or all three). Other outcomes include control of individual CVD risk factors, process and patient-centered measures, cost-effectiveness, and acceptability/feasibility. CONCLUSION: The CARRS Translation Trial is testing a low-cost diabetes care delivery model in urban South Asia to enable comprehensive cardio-metabolic disease case management in high-risk patients (clinicaltrials.gov number: NCT012123228).

title: Improving physicians' prescribing behavior by reflecting on guidelines and prescription feedback: a randomized controlled trial
abstract: BACKGROUND: It is difficult to put research findings into clinical practice with guidelines or prescription feedback. OBJECTIVE: To examine the impact on prescribing quality through the combined intervention of deriving quality criteria using individual feedback and guideline recommendations in peer review groups. METHODS: 199 GPs in 32 groups were randomized to attend peer review meetings on asthma or urinary tract infections. Antiasthmatic medication and antibiotic dispensing by participating physicians during the year preceding the intervention period formed the basis for prescription feedback. Intervention feedback is designed to describe the treatment given in relation to recommendations in national guidelines. Based on these recommendations, physicians in each group agreed on quality criteria for their own treatment of related diseases. Comparing the prescription feedback with their own quality criteria gave each doctor the ratio of acceptable and unacceptable treatments. MAIN OUTCOME MEASURE: Difference in prescribing behavior between the year before the intervention and the year after. RESULTS: Prior to intervention, the mean proportions of acceptably treated asthma patients in the asthma group and urinary tract infection (control) group were 28% and 27%, respectively. The average proportion of acceptably treated patients in the asthma group increased by 6% compared to the control group";" This difference was statistically significant. The mean rates of acceptable pre-intervention urinary tract infection treatments in the urinary tract infection group and the asthma (control) group were 12% for both groups, up 13% in the urinary tract infection group compared to the control group. Based on pre-intervention mean values, this represented a 21% improvement in treatment in the asthma group and 108% in the urinary tract infection group. CONCLUSIONS: Deriving quality criteria for prescribing by discussing guideline recommendations gave physicians a basis for evaluating their treatment for individual patients as acceptable or unacceptable. Along with feedback on their own prescriptions, they learned what they were doing right and wrong. This provided a foundation for improvement, and the process thus initiated resulted in doctors providing better quality patient care.

title: Improving empirical antibiotic selection using computer decision support.
abstract: Background: Physicians often need to initiate antibiotic therapy before the results of bacterial cultures and antibiotic susceptibility tests are available. We have developed and evaluated a computerized antibiotic counselor to assist physicians in choosing the appropriate empirical antibiotic. Methods: We used a two-stage randomized study to compare antibiotics recommended by the antibiotic counselor with 482 associated antibiotic susceptibility results and physician-ordered concomitant antibiotics. Antibiotics ordered by randomized physicians were then compared between crossover periods of antibiotic consultant use. Results: The antibiotic counselor recommended an antibiotic regimen to which all isolated pathogens were susceptible in 453 (94%) of 482 culture results, while physicians ordered an antibiotic regimen to which all isolated pathogens were susceptible for 369 culture results (77%). ) (P<.001). Doctors who prescribed antibiotics to which all pathogens are susceptible did so on average 21 hours after culture samples were collected. Physicians ordered appropriate antibiotics within 12 hours of culture retrieval significantly more frequently than when using the antibiotic counsellor (P<.035). In addition, 88% of physicians stated that they would recommend the program to other physicians, 85% felt that the program improved their antibiotic selection, and 81% felt that using the program improved patient care. Conclusions: Information from computer-based medical records can be used to help physicians improve empirical antibiotic selection for infections.(Arch Intern Med. 1994";"154:878-884)

title: Improving empirical antibiotic therapy using TREAT, a computerized decision support system: a cluster randomized trial.
abstract: Background: Appropriate antibiotic therapy reduces mortality, while unnecessary therapy is associated with antibiotic resistance. We established a computerized decision support system for antibiotic therapy (TREAT) targeting these outcomes. Methods: Prospective cohort study comparing TREAT advice to physician therapy, followed by a cluster randomized trial using TREAT (intervention) services using antibiotic monitoring (control) without TREAT. We included patients suspected of harboring bacterial infections in three hospitals (Israel, Germany, and Italy). The primary outcome was evaluated among patients with appropriate antibiotic therapy, microbiologically documented infections (MDI). Length of hospital stay, adverse events, mortality (interventional study), and antibiotic costs (both studies), costs related to future antibiotic resistance were compared among all patients included. Results: Among 1203 patients included in the cohort study (with 350 MDI), TREAT prescribed appropriate empirical antibiotic therapy significantly more often than physicians (57% versus 70%, P < 0.001), quasi-doctors using fewer broad-spectrum antibiotics cost . The randomized study included 2326 patients, 570 of whom had MDI. The rate of appropriate empirical antibiotic therapy was higher in control wards compared to intervention [64% vs. 73%, odds ratio (OR): 1.48, 95% confidence interval (CI): 0.95–2.29, goal of treatment, location-adjusted, and clustering] . For patients treated according to TREAT's recommendation on intervention wards, the difference from controls was highly significant (OR: 3.40, 95% CI: 2.25–5.14). Length of hospital stay, costs related to future resistance, and total antibiotic costs were lower in intervention than in control services. Conclusions: TREAT reduced antibiotic costs and the use of broad-spectrum antibiotic therapy while improving the rate of appropriate empirical antibiotic therapy.

title: Improving empirical antibiotic therapy using TREAT, a computerized decision support system: a cluster randomized trial.
abstract: Background: Appropriate antibiotic therapy reduces mortality, while unnecessary therapy is associated with antibiotic resistance. We established a computerized decision support system for antibiotic therapy (TREAT) targeting these outcomes. Methods: Prospective cohort study comparing TREAT advice to physician therapy, followed by a cluster randomized trial using TREAT (intervention) services using antibiotic monitoring (control) without TREAT. We included patients suspected of harboring bacterial infections in three hospitals (Israel, Germany, and Italy). The primary outcome was evaluated among patients with appropriate antibiotic therapy, microbiologically documented infections (MDI). Length of hospital stay, adverse events, mortality (interventional study), and antibiotic costs (both studies), costs related to future antibiotic resistance were compared among all patients included. Results: Among 1203 patients included in the cohort study (with 350 MDI), TREAT prescribed appropriate empirical antibiotic therapy significantly more often than physicians (57% versus 70%, P < 0.001), quasi-doctors using fewer broad-spectrum antibiotics cost . The randomized study included 2326 patients, 570 of whom had MDI. The rate of appropriate empirical antibiotic therapy was higher in control wards compared to intervention [64% vs. 73%, odds ratio (OR): 1.48, 95% confidence interval (CI): 0.95–2.29, goal of treatment, location-adjusted, and clustering] . For patients treated according to TREAT's recommendation on intervention wards, the difference from controls was highly significant (OR: 3.40, 95% CI: 2.25–5.14). Length of hospital stay, costs related to future resistance, and total antibiotic costs were lower in intervention than in control services. Conclusions: TREAT reduced antibiotic costs and the use of broad-spectrum antibiotic therapy while improving the rate of appropriate empirical antibiotic therapy.

title: Improving feedback on young doctors' prescribing errors: a mixed-method evaluation of a quality improvement project.
abstract: History Prescribing errors occur in up to 15% of inpatient drug orders in the UK. However, junior doctors report insufficient feedback on errors. One barrier to feedback is that individual prescribers are often not clearly identified in prescribing documents. Goal To reduce prescribing errors in a UK hospital by improving feedback on prescribing errors. Interventions Using plan-do-run-action cycles, we developed three linked interventions: (1) "name stamps" for junior physicians who are encouraged to clearly stamp or write their names when prescribing; (2) to support pharmacists in providing feedback to physicians on individual prescribing errors and (3) biweekly prescribing advice emails addressing a common and/or serious error Implementation and evaluation Interventions were initiated at a hospital site in August 2013 and served as a secondary control Process criteria , included the percentage of inpatient drug orders named by junior doctors, and included junior doctors' and pharmacists' perceptions of available feedback (assessed using quantitative preliminary surveys and post-questionnaires and qualitative focus groups), and erroneous writing by junior doctors between August and December 2013. was the prevalence of drug orders. Results Percentage The proportion of drug orders named by young doctors increased from about 10% to 50%. Survey responses revealed a significant improvement in the perceptions of pharmacists, but no significant change for physicians. Focus group findings suggested increased physician involvement with safe prescribing. Discrete time series analysis showed no difference in weekly prescribing error rates between baseline and intervention periods compared with the control region. Conclusion Findings suggest improved experiences with feedback. However, attempts to achieve a measurable reduction in prescribing errors are likely to require a multifaceted approach that should be part of the feedback.

title: Improving guideline compliance: a randomized trial evaluating strategies to increase beta-blocker use in heart failure.
abstract: Background—Dissemination of clinical practice guidelines has generally not been accompanied by desired improvements in guideline adherence. This study evaluated interventions for the implementation of a new practice guideline advocating the use of ÃŸ-blockers in heart failure patients. Methods and Results—This was a randomized controlled trial involving heart failure patients (n=169) with ejection fraction =45% and no contraindications to ÃŸ-blockers. Patients' primary providers were randomized to 1 of 3 interventions in a stratified design: (1) control: provider training"; (2) provider and patient statement: computerized provider reminders and patient letters advocating ÃŸ-blockers;" and (3) nurse facilitator: supervised nurse to initiate and titrate ÃŸ-blockers. The primary outcome, the proportion of patients initiated or upgraded to ÃŸ-blockers and analyzed for therapeutic purposes, was achieved in 67% (36 of 54) patients in the facilitating nurse group, compared to 16% (10). 64) in provider/patient reporting and 27% (14 out of 51) in control groups (P<0.001 for comparisons between the facilitating nurse group and both other groups). At study end (median follow-up, 12 months), the proportion of patients receiving target doses of α-blockers was highest in the nurse facilitator (43%) group (2%) compared to the control (10%) and provider/patient reporting groups (P<0.001). There was no difference between the groups in terms of adverse events. Conclusions – The use of a facilitating nurse was a successful approach to administer ÃŸ-blocker guidelines in heart failure patients. The use of provider education, clinical reminders, and patient education in this setting was of limited value.

title: Improving nurses' hand hygiene behavior using action planning: a pilot study in the intensive care unit and surgical ward.
abstract: Compliance with hand hygiene guidelines by hospital doctors and nurses is universally low, and strong social science intervention methods are needed to increase compliance. One method is the creation of implementation intentions (or action planning) in which concrete 'what if' plans are formulated to relate an environmental cue to the performance of an intended behavioral action. This pilot study investigated the feasibility and effects of action planning on hand hygiene behavior (HHB) of nurses in the intensive care unit and surgical ward of a university teaching hospital. A pre-post test design was used and 17 nurses were invited to participate. A trained researcher observed nurses' HHB before and three weeks after the intervention for which action plans were formulated. Frequencies were calculated and logistic regression analysis was performed to evaluate changes in HHB. Of the 17 participants, 10 (seven in the surgical ward, three in the intensive care) had complete data and were included in the analyses. A total of 283 potential moments for hand hygiene were identified, 142 in the surgical ward and 141 in the intensive care unit. HHB increased from 9.3% at baseline to 25.4% after intervention (odds ratio: 3.3"; confidence interval: 1.7-6.5;" P<0.001). Although this is a small-scale study, the results hold promise for the use of action planning to improve nurses' HHB in the short term. Action planning has shown success in closing the intent-behavior gap in other areas, and its use to improve HHB in healthcare should be further explored.

title: Improving the transition from intensive care to ward health teams with simple changes in paperwork
abstract: Medical handover has been highlighted as a critical step in patient care by the General Medical Council[1], enabling continuity of care, patient safety, and efficient multidisciplinary functioning. The handover of the doctors in the intensive care team and the service teams at the Great Western Hospital during the descent was evaluated by evaluating the discharge summaries and patient notes, and by following the discharged patients. Handover was found to exist only in a minority of patients and was not documented in any of them. Simple changes have been made to discharge paperwork in the form of a request and documentation of who is delivering the paperwork, as well as making room for patients with extraordinary handovers in the daily review pages. Initial audit findings were presented at a local meeting to remind staff of the importance of handover. These simple modifications brought the pass rates to 100% (n=12). The rates of handover documents also increased from 0% to 100%. This quality improvement project serves to demonstrate that carefully targeted, simple changes to practice in identified critical areas can produce dramatic and legally and ethically necessary results in a very short time.

title: Improving knowledge and changing behavior for guided decisions in diabetes care: a controlled intervention study of a team-based learning approach for continuing professional development of physicians.
abstract: BACKGROUND: Continuing Professional Development (CPD) courses should ideally enhance a physician's knowledge and shift professional behavior in daily practice towards a best clinical practice reference model and adherence to guidance. Compared to lectures, interactive methods such as team-based learning and case-based learning can provide sustainable information and high satisfaction among participants. We designed a case-based interactive CPD seminar on diabetes care using a team-based learning approach to assess whether it leads to behavioral change towards improving short-term knowledge and guided decisions, and how this learning approach is perceived by participants. . METHODS: Questionnaires and electronic voting system were used to evaluate the motivation, acceptance and knowledge of the volunteer participants. We also analyzed data on referral and index diagnostic testing of patients with diabetes by participating physicians over a six-month period before and after the course in comparison with a matched control group in a quasi-experimental design. RESULTS: Participants (n=103) rated interaction and team-based discussions as major drivers of enhanced learning. They also hoped that the course would change their professional behavior. Participants got an average of 43.9% correct answers before the course and 62.6% after the course (p<0.001). The rate of referral to a diabetes specialist increased by 30.8% (p<0.001). Applications for fundoscopy also decreased (8.5%, ns) in the control group. In addition, participating physicians tested their patients more frequently for microalbuminuria (7.1%, ns). CONCLUSIONS: Our team-based learning CPD approach has been highly accepted and has resulted in an increase in short-term knowledge. While significantly increasing referrals to diabetes specialists in daily practice, all other important indicators of professional behavior have changed, but not significantly.

title: Improving laboratory monitoring at the start of drug therapy in outpatient care: a randomized trial.
abstract: Background The importance of laboratory monitoring for drugs is reflected in product labeling and published guidelines, but monitoring recommendations are followed inconsistently. There is an opportunity to improve monitoring with the potential to reduce treatment complications. Methods The purpose of this randomized study was to determine whether computerized stimulation was effective in increasing the percentage of outpatients with laboratory monitoring at the start of drug therapy. Doctors and pharmacists came together to develop organization-specific guidelines for monitoring selected drugs. In collaboration with physicians, pharmacists were alerted to missing laboratory test results, incomplete tests were ordered, patients were reminded to take a test, test completion was evaluated, test results reviewed, and abnormal results managed. Eligible individuals included patients initiating treatment for any of the 15 drugs out of 400,000 health plan members. Results In the intervention group, 79.1% (n = 4076"; 95% confidence interval [CI], 78.0-80.2%) of the distributions were observed, compared to 70.2% (n = 3522;" 95% CI, 68.9-71.5%) %) in the usual care group (P<.001). For example, 78.6% (95% CI, 73.1% - 83.5%) of amiodarone was observed in the intervention group, compared with 51.4% (95% CI, 44.4% - 58.4%) in the normal care group (P<.001 ). Conclusions This study demonstrates the effectiveness of a computerized tool, as well as collaboration among healthcare professionals in increasing the percentage of patients receiving laboratory monitoring at treatment initiation. Combining data from information systems with the knowledge and skills of physicians and pharmacists can result in better patient follow-up.

title: Improving mammography recommendation: a nurse-initiated intervention
abstract: We sought to improve our compliance with screening mammography recommendations for eligible female patients seen by family medicine residents, according to American Cancer Society (ACS) guidelines, using a multi-part intervention designed to remove relevant knowledge and behavioral barriers. residents. Copies of the ACS cancer screening guidelines were posted in all examination and conference rooms and provided to all residents. The intervention, which addressed behavioral barriers, had three components: (1) identification by nursing staff of eligible women who are overdue for mammograms at the time of their arrival for care, (2) a recommendation to complete a checklist showing whether a mammogram has been performed by residents and why, and (3) primary checklist A nurse-initiated backup reminder system for patients recovering from the system. A control of 200 pre-intervention and 270 post-intervention charts showed statistically and clinically significant increases in recommended or performed mammograms. Similar statistically significant increases were found in a cohort of 111 patient tables in both pre-intervention and post-intervention controls. The results suggest that an intervention designed to remove resident barriers to compliance with screening mammography guidelines can be effective in increasing recommended mammography rates.

title: Improving drug management in multiple morbidity: Development of the Multimorbidity Collaborative Drug Review and Decision Making (PASS) intervention using the Behavior Modification Wheel.
abstract: Background: Multimorbidity, the presence of two or more chronic conditions, affects more than 60% of patients in primary care. Because of its relevance to multi-pharmacy, the development of interventions to optimize drug management in patients with multimorbidity is a priority. The Behavior Modification Wheel is a new approach to applying behavioral theory to intervention development. Here we describe how we used results from a review of previous research, our own original research and the Behavior Modification Wheel to develop an intervention to improve medication management in multimorbidity by general practitioners (GPs) within the comprehensive UK Medical Research Council. guidance on complex interventions. METHODS: Following the steps of the Behavior Modification Wheel, we conducted a systematic review and qualitative study with GPs to investigate behaviors associated with drug management in multiple morbidity. We chose one of the identified modifiable GP behaviors and conducted a focused behavioral analysis to explain why GPs engage in this behavior or not. We used behavior analysis to identify the intervention functions, behavior change techniques, and implementation plan that are most likely to influence behavioral change. CONCLUSIONS: We identified a number of modifiable GP behaviors in a systematic review and qualitative study that selected active drug investigation (rather than maintaining the passive status quo) as the target behavior. Behavioral analysis revealed GPs' abilities, opportunities, and motivations for active drug review. We created the Multi-Disease Collaborative Drug Review and Decision-Making ( MY HELP) intervention by combining the three intervention functions (influence, environmental restructuring, and incentive) thought to be most likely to influence behavior change. MY COMRADE primarily involves the technique of social support: two GPs jointly review medications given to a complex multimorbid patient. Four other behavior change techniques are included: restructuring the social environment, prompts/cues, action planning, and self-promoting. CONCLUSIONS: This is the first study to use the Behavior Modification Wheel to develop an intervention targeting multiple morbidity and validates the approach's usability and usefulness in a complex clinical care field. The systematic development of the COMPANY intervention will facilitate a comprehensive assessment of its effectiveness in the next phase of this study.

title: Improving mental health care transitions for children and youth: a protocol for the implementation and evaluation of an emergency department clinical pathway.
abstract: Background Although the emergency department (ED) is often the first point of entry for children and youth with mental health (PD) concerns, its capacity to respond to OD needs in this setting is limited. Child OD systems are typically split between multiple ministries, organizations and providers. Communication between these groups is often poor, resulting in gaps in care transitions, especially for this vulnerable population. The evidence-based Emergency Department Mental Health Clinical Pathway (EDMHCP) was established with two main goals: (1) to guide risk assessment and regulatory decision-making processes for children and youth presenting to the emergency department with MD concerns, and (2) a community of MD agencies (CMHAs). and simplified transition to tracking services with other providers. The purpose of this article is to describe our study protocol for implementing and evaluating EDMHCP. Methods/design This mixed methods healthcare research project will include implementation and evaluation of EDMHCP in four exemplary ED-CMHA pairs. The Theoretical Domains Framework will be used to develop a specific response strategy to implement the EDMHCP. A multiple baseline study design and discontinuous time series analysis will be used to determine whether EDMHCP improves healthcare utilization, medical management of MD issues, and health sector coordination. The primary process outcome will be the proportion of patients with MD-specific recommendations documented in the health record. The primary service outcome will be the proportion of patients who receive the EDMHCP recommended follow-up 24 hours or 7 days. Data sources will include qualitative interviews, health record audits, administrative databases and patient surveys. A simultaneous process assessment will be undertaken to assess the degree of application variability and fidelity between sites. Discussion This article presents a new model for measuring the effects of EDMHCP. Our development process will determine how best to implement the EDMHCP among partner organizations to enable evidence-based risk management of children and youth with OD concerns. More broadly, it will contribute to the evidence supporting clinical pathway application in new partnerships.

title: Improving opioid safety practices in primary care: protocol for the development and evaluation of a well-rounded, theory-informed pilot intervention for healthcare providers.
abstract: INTRODUCTION: In North America, drug overdose deaths are reaching unprecedented levels, largely due to the rise of prescription opioid-related deaths. Despite the development of several opioid guidelines, prescribing behaviors still contribute to poor patient outcomes and societal harm. Provider and system-level factors may hinder or facilitate the application of evidence-based guidelines";" interventions designed to address such factors are needed. METHODS AND ANALYSIS: Using applied science and behavior change theory, we planned to develop and evaluate a comprehensive Opioid Self-Assessment Package designed to increase compliance with the Canadian Opioid Guidelines among family physicians. The intervention uses practical training and self-assessment tools to provide feedback to prescribers on their current knowledge and practice, and to provide resources to improve their practice. The assessment approach uses a pretest and posttest design and includes both quantitative and qualitative methods at baseline and 6 months. We will draw a purposive sample of approximately 10 family physicians from various practice settings in Ontario who currently treat patients on long-term opioid therapy for chronic pain. Quantitative data will be analyzed using basic descriptive statistics and qualitative data will be analyzed using the Framework Method. ETHICS AND PUBLICATION: The University Health Network Research Ethics Committee approved this study. The dissemination plan includes publications, conference presentations and short stakeholder reports. This evidence-based, theory-based intervention has implications for national application of opioid quality improvement tools in primary care settings. We involve experts and end users in advisory and stakeholder roles throughout our project to increase national relevance, implementation and sustainability. Performance measures can be used as the basis for health system quality improvement indicators to monitor opioid prescription. In addition, the methods and approach used in this study can be adapted to other opioid guidelines or applied to other areas of preventive health and clinical guideline implementation processes.

title: Improving pediatric asthma outcomes in primary care: a randomized controlled trial.
abstract: OBJECTIVE: To evaluate the effectiveness of Practitioner Asthma Communication and Education (PACE) Australia, an innovative communication and pediatric asthma management program for GPs. DESIGN: Randomized controlled trial. SETTING: General practices from two regions in the Sydney metropolitan area. PARTICIPANTS: 150 GPs recruited between 2006 and 2008 and 221 children with asthma in their care. INTERVENTION: General practitioners in the intervention group participated in two 3-hour workshops focused on communication and educational strategies to facilitate quality asthma care. MAIN OUTCOME MEASURES: Patient outcomes included obtaining a written asthma action plan (WAAP), appropriate medication use, parent absences from work, and child absences from school or childcare. GP outcomes included frequency of providing a WAAP and adherence to national asthma guidelines on patient education, communication and teaching behavior, and medication use. RESULTS: More GP patients reported receiving a WAAP in the intervention group (difference, 15%"; 95% CI, 2% to 28%; adjusted P=0.046). In the intervention group, less inhaled corticosteroids were used in children with infrequent asthma symptoms. use (difference, 24%; 95% CI, -43% to -5%; P=0.03) and long-acting bronchodilators (difference, 19%; 95% CI, -34 to -5%; P=0.02) GPs in the intervention group were more confident in communicating with patients (difference 22%; 95% CI, 3% to 40%; P=0.03). A higher proportion of GPs in the intervention group reported providing WAAP more than 70% of the time (difference, 23%; 95% CI, 11% to 36%; adjusted P=0.002) and prescribing spacer devices more than 90% of the time (difference, 29%; 95% CI, 16% to 42%; adjusted P=0.02 ). RESULTS: The PACE Australia program has improved GP practice in asthma management and has led to improvements in some key patient outcomes. TRIAL REGISTRATION: Australian New Zealand Clinical Trials Registry ACTRN12607000067471.

title: Improving Patient Care Through Medical Image Perception Research
abstract: Interpretation of medical images in medical specialties is critical to patient care. Healthcare is changing as technology changes, and clinicians today are increasingly viewing medical images in a variety of settings. While access to such data is helpful, even clinicians skilled in image interpretation make mistakes. These errors may become more frequent as the clinician's working days get longer and the number of images to interpret increases. To avoid errors in medical image interpretation, we need to understand the underlying perceptual and cognitive mechanisms that guide image interpretation. We can then use what is learned to develop better training methods, automated image analysis and processing tools. We can design methods and develop practice guidelines to reduce clinician fatigue and stress, thereby improving patient care and outcomes.

title: Improve patient discharge and reduce hospital readmissions using Intervention Mapping
abstract: Background There is a growing push to reorganize the hospital discharge process to reduce preventable readmissions and costs. The purpose of this study was to provide insight into hospital discharge problems and underlying causes, and to provide an overview of solutions that guide providers and policy makers in improving hospital discharge. Methods Intervention Mapping framework was used. First, a problem analysis was conducted examining the scale, causes, and consequences of ineffective hospital discharge. The analysis was based on primary data from 26 focus group interviews and 321 individual interviews with patients and relatives and relevant hospital and community care providers. Second, improvements were identified in terms of intervention outcomes, performance goals, and change goals. Third, 220 experts were consulted and a systematic review of effective evacuation interventions was conducted to select the theory-based methods and practical strategies needed to achieve change and better performance. Conclusions Ineffective discharge is related to factors at the level of individual caregiver, patient, relationship between providers, and organizational and technical support for caregivers. By focusing on high-quality discharge information, well-coordinated care, and direct and timely communication with colleagues, providers can reduce hospital readmission rates and adverse events. Patients or their caregivers should participate in the discharge process and be informed about their health status and treatment. Evaluating whether discharge information is accurate and understood by patients and their colleagues in the community by hospital care providers are important examples of overcoming identified barriers to effective discharge. Discharge templates, medication reconciliation, liaison nurse or pharmacist, regular site visits, and education are described as effective and promising strategies to achieve desired behavioral and environmental change. Conclusions This study provides a comprehensive guiding framework for providers and policy makers to improve patient turnover from hospitals to primary care.

title: To improve the compliance of physicians with preventive medicine guidelines
abstract: Similar general medical outpatient clinics with randomly assigned patients were used to evaluate the effectiveness of a program to increase home staff compliance with preventive medicine guidelines. Two clinical trials were determined and two served as controls. At experimental clinics, age-specific checklists of all recommended preventive procedures (taken from the Canadian Task Force report on Periodic Health Examination and American Cancer Society guidelines) are included in each patient's chart. In addition, housekeepers were offered a series of weekly seminars on screening issues alongside specific advice on the checklist. Housekeepers at four clinics were tested for their knowledge and attitudes towards the preventive program before and after the intervention. The numbers of immunizations and mammograms for the four clinics and the total populations eligible for these procedures were determined. As predicted, test scores as well as mammography and immunization rates increased significantly (from 2-40 percent) at intervention clinics compared to controls. We conclude that this intervention is clearly effective in the short term. However, follow-up studies will be necessary to determine whether the desired long-term effect is achieved.

title: Improving population-based cervical cancer screening in general practice: implications of a national strategy.
abstract: OBJECTIVE: To evaluate the effects of a Dutch national prevention program for general practitioners (GPs) on adherence to institutional guidelines for effective cervical cancer screening in general practice. To identify the characteristics of general practices that determine success. DESIGN: A prospective survey with pre- and post-measurement (before and 15 months after the introduction of the national programme). ENVIRONMENT AND STUDY PARTICIPANTS: A random sample of one-third of the 4758 Dutch general practice. A general practitioner was requested to attend for each application. INTERVENTION: A national GP prevention program to improve population-based prevention of cervical cancer at the national, regional and practice level, combining various modalities for quality improvement in general practice. Outreach visitors were a key strategy in bringing about behavioral changes. MAIN OUTCOME MEASURES: Proportion of practices that follow the 10 recommendations (four guidelines) for organizing effective cervical cancer screening. RESULTS: After 15 months, all Dutch practices showed significant improvement in adherence to nine out of 10 recommendations. In particular, the two recommendations 'identify women who should be medically excluded from screening' and 'send a reminder to those who are ineligible' showed the largest absolute increases of 26% and 33%, respectively. Implementation features such as 'computerization' and 'delegation of many clinical tasks to the practice assistant' were important in increasing adherence to guidelines, as well as greater support from outreach visitors. CONCLUSION: The national program, in which various methods are used together for quality improvement, seems to be effective in improving the organization of cervical screening in general practice. Computerization and, to a lesser extent, the transfer of many clinical tasks to the practice assistant and greater support for practices have positively impacted the effectiveness of the national program.

title: Improving Prescribing Patterns for the Elderly Through Online Drug Use Review Intervention
abstract: Context." Pharmacotherapy is among the most powerful interventions to improve health outcomes in the elderly. However, systems approaches to improving pharmacy care can be an effective way to reduce inappropriate drug use, as some drugs are less suitable for elderly patients. Aim." To determine whether a computerized drug use review (DUR) database associated with a telepharmacy intervention could improve suboptimal drug use in the elderly. Design.â€” Population-based cohort design, April 1, 1996 - March 31, 1997. Setting.â€” Outpatient care. Patients.” A total of 23269 patients 65 years of age and older who received prescription drug assistance from a major pharmaceutical benefits manager in the United States over a 12-month period. Intervention.—Assessment of the prescribing provider through a computerized online database of STOP, using clear criteria to identify potentially inappropriate drug use in the elderly. Computer alerts triggered telephone calls to pharmacists trained in geriatrics, whereby the principles of geriatric pharmacology and therapeutic substitution options were discussed. Key Outcome Measures – Rate of contact with physicians and rate of change based on recommended medication regimen. Results.â€” A total of 43007 alerts were triggered. We were able to reach 3688 physicians regarding 24266 warnings (56%) out of a total of 43007 phone calls made up of the warnings. The conversion rate to a more appropriate therapeutic agent was 24% (5860), but ranged from 40% for long half-life benzodiazepines to 2% to 7% for drugs that are theoretically contraindicated by patient self-report. Except for the α-blocker exchange rate in patients with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, all exchange rates were significantly greater than the expected 2% change rate. Results.â€” Our large-scale intervention, using a system that integrates computers, pharmacists, and physicians, has improved prescribing patterns and quality of care, thus providing a population-based approach to advancing geriatric clinical pharmacology. Future research should focus on demonstrating improved health outcomes resulting from improved prescribing options for the elderly.

title: Improving quality improvement using accessible criteria for physician feedback: a randomized controlled trial.
abstract: Context Performance feedback and benchmarking, common tools for improving healthcare, are rarely studied in randomized trials. Achievable Benchmarks of Care (ABCs) are standards of excellence achieved by the best performers in a peer group and are easily and reproducibly calculated from available performance data. Purpose To evaluate the effectiveness of using achievable benchmarks to improve typical physician performance feedback and improve care. Randomized controlled trial conducted by the Design Group in December 1996 and followed up to 1998. Setting and Participants Seventy community physicians and 2978 paid-per-service Medicare patients with diabetes who are part of the Outpatient Quality of Care Project in Alabama. Intervention Physicians were randomly assigned to receive a multimodal remedial intervention, including chart review and physician-specific feedback (comparison group”; n = 35) or the same intervention plus achievable benchmark feedback (experimental group; n = 35) (1994) -1995) changes in the proportion of patients receiving the flu vaccine post-intervention (1997-1998); foot examination;" and each of 3 blood tests measuring glucose control, cholesterol level, and triglyceride level compared between the 2 groups. Results The proportion of patients vaccinated against influenza increased from 40% to 58% in the experimental group (P<.001), from 40% to 46% (P = .02) in the comparison group. Odds ratios (ORs) for patients of available comparison physicians versus comparative physicians who received appropriate care after intervention, adjusted for pre-intervention care and placement of patients with physicians, were 1.57 for influenza (95% confidence interval [CI], 1.26-1.96) vaccine, foot 1.33 (95% CI, 1.05-1.69) for the long-term glucose control measurement and 1.33 (95% CI, 1.04-1.69) for the long-term glucose control measurement. For serum cholesterol and triglycerides, the achievable comparison effect was statistically significant only after additional adjustment for physician characteristics (OR, 1.40 [95% CI, 1.08–1.82] and OR, 1.40 [95% CI, 1.09–1.79], respectively). Conclusion The use of accessible benchmarks significantly increases the effectiveness of physician performance feedback in a multimodal quality improvement intervention setting.

title: Improving the quality of delirium care in a general medical service with established interdisciplinary care: a controlled trial.
abstract: BACKGROUND: Clinical practice guidelines have been developed to improve the screening, prevention and management of delirium. OBJECTIVES: To apply delirium guidelines in general medical patients to reduce the incidence and duration of delirium and improve outcomes in delirium patients. METHODS: The practice was managed by a multidisciplinary team of clinicians and project staff in a single medical ward. Evaluation was conducted as a controlled trial in patients 65 years of age and older at risk/at risk of delirium compared to a control medical service. Interventions included risk screening, delirium detection, multidisciplinary training, ward modifications including a four-bed delirium compartment, behavior and medication protocols, and the use of nurse aide and volunteers. Primary outcome measures were incidence and duration of delirium";" secondary outcomes were length of stay, mortality, falls, and discharge goal in the insane subgroup. Process measures included ward movements, use of neuroleptics, ancillary health review, and use of delirium bay. RESULTS: Of the 206 consenting elderly medical patients, 22% were insane at presentation and 44% were at risk. No delirium case was detected. In the insane subgroup, significantly fewer intervention participants were discharged with persistent delirium (32% vs. 71%, P = 0.016), reductions in inpatient mortality (18.5% vs. 0%, P = 0.07), and falls (P = 0.07) 11 vs 22) %, P = 0.16), at the expense of a longer medical service stay (16 days vs. 8 days, P = 0.01). CONCLUSIONS: The low incidence of new delirium may reflect the established interdisciplinary care environment. The improved outcomes in the insane group, including increased length of stay in the acute department, are encouraging, although costly to implement.

title: Improving residents' compliance with outpatient care standards: results of the VA Cooperative Study on Computerized Reminders.
abstract: Context Computerized systems that remind physicians to provide appropriate care have not been widely evaluated in large numbers of patients in multiple clinical settings. Purpose To examine whether a computerized reminder system working in multiple Veterans Affairs (VA) outpatient clinics improves resident's compliance with outpatient care standards. Design, Environment, and Participants A total of 275 resident physicians at 12 VA medical centers were randomly assigned to a reminder group (n = 132) or a control group (n = 143) in firms or half-day clinical blocks. During a 17-month study period (January 31, 1995 – June 30, 1996), residents looked after 12,989 unique patients for whom at least 1 of the studied standards of care (SOC) was applicable. Main Outcome Measures Compliance with the 13 SOCs monitored using hospital databases and encounter forms filled by residents was compared between residents in the reminder group and residents in the control group. Results The reminder group, which measures compliance as the proportion of patients who met all applicable SOC at their last visit during the study period, had statistically significantly higher compliance rates for all standards than the control group (58.8% vs 53.5%; odds ratio [OR] ], 1.24; 95% confidence interval [CI], 1.08-1.42; P = .002) and Measuring Adherence for 5 of the 13 standards reviewed separately, as the proportion of all visits at which resident provided appropriate care, the reminder group also had statistically significantly higher concordance rates for the standards than the control group (17.9% vs. 12.2%; OR, 1.57; 95% CI, 1.45-1.71; "P<.001), and 9 out of 13 standards were analyzed individually . However, the usefulness of the reminders declined over the course of the study, although the reminders remained active. Conclusions Our data shows that reminder systems installed at multiple sites can improve resident compliance to multiple SOCs. However, the benefits of such systems appear to deteriorate over time. Future research needs to explore methods to better maintain the benefits of reminders.

title: Improving smoking cessation counseling using a point-of-care health response tool (IT): from the Virginia Practice Support and Research Network (VaPSRN)
abstract: OBJECTIVE: Primary care practices are an ideal setting to reduce national smoking rates, as >70% of smokers visit their doctor annually, but smoking cessation counseling is inconsistently communicated to patients. We designed and built a new software program for handheld computers and hypothesized that it would improve clinicians' ability to provide tailored smoking cessation counseling at the point of care. METHODS: A handheld computer software program was created based on smoking cessation guidelines and an adaptation of widely accepted theories of behavior change. The instrument was evaluated using a validated pre/post questionnaire to measure the physician's smoking cessation counseling behaviors, knowledge, and comfort/self-efficacy. RESULTS: Participants were recruited from 17 physicians (mean age 41 years”; 71% male;” 5 resident physicians) from a practice-based research network. After 4 months of use in direct patient care, physicians were more likely to recommend patients to quit smoking (P = .049) and reported an increase in "5 As" use (P = .03). There was increased self-efficacy (P = .006) in counseling patients about smoking cessation and increased comfort in maintaining patients' follow-up (P = .04). CONCLUSIONS: The use of a handheld computer software tool has improved smoking cessation counseling among physicians and shows promise in translating the evidence on smoking cessation counseling into practice and educational settings.

title: Improvement of test sequencing in primary care: added value of small group quality improvement strategy compared to classical feedback only
abstract: OBJECTIVE: We wanted to evaluate the added value of small peer group quality improvement meetings compared to simple feedback as a strategy to improve test order behavior. The number of tests required by primary care physicians is increasing, and many of these tests appear unnecessary according to established, evidence-based guidelines. METHODS: 194 primary care physicians from 27 local primary care practice groups in 5 health regions (5 diagnostic centers) were enrolled. The study was a cluster randomized study with randomization at the local physician group level. We evaluated an innovative, multifaceted strategy combining written comparative feedback, group training on national guidelines, and social influence by peers in small-group quality improvement sessions. The strategy addressed 3 specific clinical issues: cardiovascular problems, upper abdominal complaints and lower abdominal complaints. The mean number of tests per physician at baseline at 6 months and the region of physicians were used as independent variables, and the mean number of tests per physician at 6 months was the dependent variable. RESULTS: The new strategy was applied in 13 primary care groups, while 14 groups received feedback only. For all 3 clinical subjects, the reduction in the average total number of tests ordered by physicians in the intervention arm was much more significant than the decrease in the average number of tests ordered by physicians in previous years (an average of 51 fewer tests per physician per half-year). feedback lever (P = .005). Five tests considered inappropriate for the clinical problem of upper abdominal complaints were reduced in the intervention arm, and physicians in the feedback arm ordered 13 more tests at 6 months (P = .002). Inter-physician variation in test sequence was further reduced in the intervention arm. CONCLUSION: Compared with distributing only comparative feedback reports to primary care physicians, the new strategy involving peer interaction and social influence improved the test ordering behavior of physicians. To be effective, feedback must be integrated into an interactive, educational environment.

title: Improving the implementation of a practice guideline for the assessment and treatment of suicidal behavior by training all staff of psychiatry departments through an e-learning powered Train-the-Trainer program: study protocol for a randomized controlled trial
abstract: BACKGROUND: A multidisciplinary practice guide for the assessment and treatment of suicidal behavior was published in the Netherlands in 2012. Publishing guidelines often fails to change professional behavior due to multiple barriers. Structured practice can improve adherence to guidelines. This article describes the design of a study that measured the impact of an e-learning powered Train-the-Trainer program aimed at training a full staff of departments in the implementation of the guideline. We assume that both professionals and departments will benefit from the program. METHOD: In a multicenter, randomized controlled trial, 43 psychiatry departments spread across 10 regional mental health institutions across the Netherlands will be clustered in pairs according to the most common diagnosis category of patients and mean duration of treatment. Pair members are randomly assigned to either the experimental or control condition. In the experimental condition, the full staff of the departments, i.e. all registered nurses, psychologists, doctors and psychiatrists (n = 532, 21 departments) will be trained in the application of the guideline in a small one-day interactive group. -Trainer program. The program is supported by a 60-minute e-learning module with video sketches of suicidal patients and additional instructions. In case of control (22 departments, 404 professionals), the manual will be distributed in the traditional way: manuals, books, conferences, internet, reviews, etc. The effectiveness of the program will be evaluated both at the level of health professionals and departments. DISCUSSION: In the implementation of a new clinical guideline, we aim to demonstrate the impact of training all personnel of the departments with an e-learning supported Train-the-Trainer program. The strengths of the study are the natural environment, the training of the full staff, the random allocation of conditions, the large scale of the study, and the willingness of both staff and management to participate in the study. TRIAL REGISTRATION: Netherlands trial registration: NTR3092.

title: Improving the appropriateness of antimicrobial use in primary care after implementation of a local antimicrobial guideline at both levels of care
abstract: Purpose This study aims to evaluate the efficacy of multiple interventions during the implementation of a guideline for improving the relevance of antimicrobial prescribing in primary care. Design This is a before/after cross-sectional study conducted in the Aljarafe Health Area (Andalusia, Spain) with a population of 368,728 assisted in 37 health centres. Subjects Subjects include patients who were prescribed antibiotics by simple random sampling (confidence level, 95%";" accuracy, 5%) during 2009 (pre-intervention phase) or 2012 (post-intervention phase) and whose infections were recorded in the electronic clinical history. Interventions This study included training sessions in primary care centers and hospital services, incorporation of the electronic manual on Healthcare Websites, and the inclusion of the Digital Health History manual as a tool to support decision making. Main conclusion The difference in appropriate antibiotic prescribing before and after interventions resulted from the study. Other variables also include age, gender, type of pharmacy, antibiotics prescribed, number of treatments per year, site of infection, and major comorbidities. Results The percentage of appropriate antibiotic prescribing increased from 36% in 2009 to 57% in 2012 (p?<?0.001). Improvement was observed in patients of all ages, of any gender, and was higher in patients of working age and patients with comorbidities. The best results were observed in the beta-lactam group and in the treatment of respiratory and skin infections. Conclusion Performing multifactorial interventions involving professionals from both care levels can be an effective strategy to improve the use of antimicrobials in primary care.

title: Improving the care of people with acute low back pain by allied health professionals (ALIGN trial): A cluster randomized trial protocol.
abstract: Background Variability between clinical practice guideline recommendations and actual clinical practice exists in many areas of health care. A 2004 systematic review examining the effectiveness of guideline implementation interventions concluded that there is a lack of evidence to support decisions about effective interventions to encourage the adoption of guidelines. In addition, the review recommended the use of theory in the development of practice interventions. A clinical practice guideline for the treatment of acute low back pain was developed in Australia (2003). Acute low back pain is a common condition, has a high burden, and there are some indications of an evidence-to-practice gap in the ancillary healthcare setting. This provides an opportunity to develop and test a theory-based practice intervention that, if effective, could have benefits for patients with this condition. Objectives This study evaluates the effectiveness of a theory-based intervention to increase compliance of allied health practitioners (physiotherapists and chiropractors in Victoria, Australia) with a clinical practice guideline for acute nonspecific low back pain (LBP) practitioners with a printed copy of the guideline. Specifically, our primary goals are to determine whether the intervention is effective in reducing the percentage of patients with acute nonspecific LBP who are referred for or received an X-ray and improve the average disability level for patients three months after initiation of therapy. acute LBP. Methods The design of the study was a cluster randomized trial. Restricted randomization was used to randomize 210 treatments (clusters) to an intervention or control group. Practitioners in the control group were given a hard copy of the manual. Practitioners in the intervention group received a theory-based intervention developed to address prospectively identified barriers to practitioner compliance with the guideline. The intervention consisted primarily of an education symposium. Patients 18 years of age or older who visit a participating practitioner for acute nonspecific LBP of less than three months duration during a two-week data collection period three months after the intervention symposium are eligible for inclusion. Sample size calculations are based on taking 15 to 40 patients per administration. Outcomes evaluators will be blind to group allocation.

title: Improving hypertension management in Kazakhstan: implications for improving clinical practice, patient behavior and health outcomes
abstract: This article presents findings from the evaluation of a strategy aimed at improving case finding and management of patients with hypertension. The study findings suggest that universal access by providers to clinical guidelines, publicly available information on hypertension risks, the promotion of annual blood pressure screening, and an outpatient medication aid package improves case finding and management. Additionally, training of service providers at the pilot facilities resulted in a significant and significant difference in patient care and health outcomes. Provider education and tools, particularly focused on effective patient counseling, have made significant contributions to case finding, patient adherence to prescription medications, reducing salt and increasing regular exercise. However, further improvement is needed to ensure patients' expected compliance with medication and lifestyle advice. In the pilot area, we compared two patient samples before and after the start of the intervention. We found an increase in the proportion of patients with blood pressure or = 160/100 mmHg. The strategy included the joint efforts of the Research Institute of Cardiology and Internal Medicine, the Karaganda Drug Information Center, the Karaganda Oblast Health Department, the Kazakhstan Family Physicians Association, the Almaty Graduate Institute of Physicians and the USAID ZdravPlus Project in Central Asia.

title: Improving the outcome of bipolar disorder with non-pharmacological strategies: the role of psychoeducation
abstract: This article discusses the effectiveness of psychoeducation and related strategies in bipolar disorders. Recently, several randomized clinical trials have demonstrated the efficacy of psychological interventions—that is, identification of prodromal symptoms, cognitive-behavioral therapy, psychoeducation, and family-focused interventions—as a prophylactic add-on to drug therapy. All these studies are presented here together with the pioneering studies in the field. There are several topics that every psychoeducational program must include in order to be useful, and these will be summarized in twelve points. Roughly, psychoeducation should include general information about bipolar illness, elements of improving compliance, teaching early detection of relapses, and lifestyle regularity. Many treatment guidelines today include psychoeducation as an important prophylactic tool. Clinicians should be aware of this and begin psychoeducation in their daily clinical practice.

title: Increasing the success of mailed letter intervention programs to influence prescribing behaviors: a review
abstract: BACKGROUND: Educational interventions have long been used as a way to influence prescribing behavior. A variety of techniques including educational mailings, academic elaboration, prescriber feedback with or without disclosing patient-identifying data, and additional patient information have been used to encourage proper prescribing habits, reduce costs, and optimize patient care. While the effects of educational intervention programs have been widely reported, little is known about the effectiveness of the various intervention techniques sent by mail. OBJECTIVE: To review the effectiveness of mail-in intervention programs and identify factors that can promote successful outcomes. METHODS: A literature search was conducted through PubMed for reports of posted intervention programs published up to May 2012. Specific search terms such as "drug use review", "medication use", "Medicaid", "prescribing feedback", "mailed doctor response" and "mailed doctor communication." Certain publications were selected for inclusion that met the following criteria: (a) evaluated printed educational materials distributed by mail, (b) took place in an outpatient setting, and (c) measured the impact of the intervention on prescribing patterns, healthcare utilization, or economics. results. Papers meeting all 3 criteria for intervention strategy, follow-up time, data source, goal of intervention, prescriber acceptance of intervention and impact on prescribing patterns, health care use, and economic outcomes are summarized. RESULTS: A total of 40 published reports on 39 unique interventions met the inclusion criteria. The majority of studies (34/39 [87.2%]) were conducted in state or federally funded programs"; only 5 programs included private insurers. All programs used </=12-month follow-up periods after final response mailing. 26' out of a total of 39 unique interventions 20 reported a positive effect on at least 1 target outcome. Programs involving a second recipient, such as pharmacists (n = 4), reported a greater effect than interventions sent to prescribers only. had a high success rate (21/25 [84.0%] and 5/14 [35.7%]); non-patient-descriptive materials also used academic elaboration. Educational material and/or prescriber feedback on multiple drug classes or disease states. programs had minimal impact on prescribing patterns (n = 4). However, targeting 1 specificity was supported by ic disease or appropriate evidence. drugs resulted in positive changes in a short time. Additionally, providing recommendations supported by widely accepted clinical guidelines or literature has also been associated with a high success rate. A subset of programs attempting to assess healthcare utilization (n=5) and economic impact (n=9) observed little change in measured outcomes. Evaluation of prescriber response forms conducted by 7 programs revealed that changes in treatment occurred in approximately 50% of prescribers who sought to accept intervention recommendations. CONCLUSIONS: A well-structured mail-in intervention program appears to have the potential to induce significant changes in prescribing patterns, although the degree of heterogeneity between articles precludes definitive conclusions. Prescribers seem open to mailed interventions," however, limited data exist to determine the relationship between acceptance and actual prescribing change. Future research should focus on identifying barriers that may prevent acceptance of recommendations from translating into changes in therapy. Additionally, future projects will consider duration of action and duration of action after the final intervention mail. longer evaluation periods to determine the potential impact on health care and economic outcomes.

title: Improving the use of early follow-up care after emergency room visits. A randomized trial
abstract: OBJECTIVE: To test the hypothesis that the appropriateness of parents' use of early follow-up care after emergency room (ED) visits can be improved with post-visit support from a nurse practitioner. DESIGN: Randomized controlled trial, single-blind. SETTING: Urban university hospital Emergency Department is connected to the primary care center of the hospital. PARTICIPANTS: Parents of 190 children younger than 8 years of age seeking emergency care for acute illnesses and receiving outpatient care with primary care center follow-up at the discretion of emergency department clinicians. INTERVENTION: Parents in the experimental group were contacted by a nurse practitioner who offered both individualized guidance on follow-up and access to a nurse for further assistance as needed. The control group received "as usual" follow-up advice during emergency room visits. MEASUREMENTS/MAIN RESULTS: In the week after ER visits, parents in the experimental group were more compliant with follow-up instructions (61% vs. 79%), were less likely to miss appointments (15% vs. 31%), and less likely to "shop" elsewhere for care (2% vs. 9%). Appropriateness of monitoring was assessed in a 'blind' fashion using predetermined guidelines. Inappropriate use of follow-up care was significantly reduced among experimental group subjects (10% vs. 20%). CONCLUSION: The intervention of the nurse practitioner improved the parental use of follow-up care in our sample. Overall care for episodic emergency room users can be improved with similar interventions.

title: In the warm defense of population health: doctors and antibiotic resistance
abstract: Antibiotic resistance threatens the population as a serious public health threat and costly social problem. Recent recommendations to tackle antibiotic resistance largely focus on supply-side approaches. Proposals include tampering with patent rights so that pharmaceutical companies have greater incentives to discover new antibiotics and resist overselling their newer drugs already on the market. This article argues that a primarily supply-side emphasis, unfortunately, distracts physicians from important demand-side effects. Physicians have a vital and inevitably necessary role in ensuring optimal societal access to antibiotics. Sadly, doctors' management of the supply of antibiotics was poor, and their defense of public health was lukewarm at best. Acting as a prudent representative of the antibiotic supply often appears to conflict with a physician's generally understood mandate duties, ethical obligations, and professional norms; all of which traditionally emphasize the individual health paradigm as opposed to community health responsibilities. Meanwhile, physicians face limited incentives to conserve antibiotics from other sources, such as malpractice liability, regulatory standards, and reimbursement systems. While multi-pronged efforts are needed to effectively combat antibiotic resistance, physician surveillance behavior should become a primary focus area. This article considers how health law and policy tools can positively change the incentives physicians face for antibiotic preservation. A clear lesson from the recent battles for managed care reform is that to have the best chance of success, interventions must respect the physician's interest in clinical autonomy and individualized medicine, even if, somewhat paradoxically, strongly encourages population health perspectives. In addition, physicians' legal and ethical obligations need to be reconceptualized in the context of antibiotics to better support gatekeeping in advocating for public health. The main recommendation is to use more financial incentives to reward physicians for complying with recommended guidelines for prescribing antibiotics. While not a panacea, further experimentation with financial incentives could provide a much-needed jump start to physicians' interest in antibiotic containment and possibly best address physicians' legitimate clinical autonomy concerns.

title: Addition of cognitive-behavioral therapy to usual care was cost effective at 1 year in treatment-resistant depression
abstract: Question Is it cost-effective to add individual cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT) to usual care in primary care patients with treatment-resistant depression? Method Design Cost-benefit analysis based on 1-year follow-up of a randomized controlled trial (CoBalT trial) from the UK National Health Service (NHS) and Personal Social Services (PSS) perspective. Identifying primary care practices in Bristol, Exeter and Glasgow, UK. Patients Â¡Ã 469 patients aged 18 to 75 years (mean age 50 years, 72% women) who had been on antidepressant medication for 6 weeks but continued to have depressive symptoms, were diagnosed with depression using the Revised Clinical Interview Schedule and a Beck Depression Inventory (BDI) )-II score Â¡Ã 14. Intervention Individual CBT, 12 to 18 hour sessions in primary care settings or similar settings, plus usual care (n = 234) or usual care alone (n = 235). Usual care may include antidepressant medications. Results Treatment response (Â¡à 50% reduction in BDI-II score)"; quality-adjusted life years (QALYs) based on EQ-5D-3L scores and quality-of-life assessments from the UK general population; costs in GBP 2010 {UK Â¡Ãª1 = $1.56}*;" and increased cost-effectiveness ratio (ICER). Costs include NHS and PSS costs from primary care registries, CBT therapist registries and patient surveys. Follow-up was 83% to 84% for clinical outcomes at 1 year and 78% for health and social care costs. Main results Addition of CBT to usual care reduced symptoms of depression and increased QALYs (Table). CBT plus regular care with 14 911 ICER (23 261) ICER per QALY earned over 12 months is more expensive than regular care alone (Table). In sensitivity analyzes using the Short Form-6 dimensions algorithm to estimate QALYs, the ICER was 29 626 (US$ 46 217). Conclusion In primary care patients with treatment-resistant depression in the UK, the addition of cognitive behavioral therapy to usual care was cost-effective at 1 year.

title: Inclusion and exclusion criteria from randomized controlled trials of psychotherapy for PTSD
abstract: OBJECTIVE: Post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD) is a common and often disabling condition. Fortunately, effective psychological treatments for PTSD are available. However, research shows that these treatments may not be used adequately in clinical practice. One reason for this underuse may be that clinicians unfairly exclude patients from these treatments based on their understanding of the exclusion criteria used in clinical trials of psychological treatments for PTSD. There is no comprehensive and up-to-date review of the inclusion and exclusion criteria used in randomized clinical trials (RCTs) of psychological treatments for PTSD. Therefore, our aim was to better understand how patients are excluded from such RCTs to provide clinicians with guidance on clinical populations likely to benefit from these treatments. METHODS: We conducted a comprehensive literature review of RCTs on psychological treatments for PTSD from January 1, 1980 to April 1, 2012. We categorized these clinical trials according to the types of psychotherapy discussed in the main guidelines for PTSD treatment and reviewed all treatments. studied in at least two RCTs (N=64, published study with 75 intervention arms, because some studies have compared two or more interventions). We summarized and tabulated information on exclusion criteria for each type of psychotherapy for PTSD. CONCLUSIONS: We identified multiple RCTs for PTSD that included cognitive behavioral therapy (n=56), eye movement desensitization and reprocessing (n=11), and group psychotherapy (n=8). The most common exclusions were psychosis, substance abuse and addiction, bipolar disorder, and suicidal ideation. Clinical trials varied in how strictly these criteria were applied.
