It is important to note that no exclusion criteria were used in all studies, and at least one study was found for each type of therapy that included patients from each of the commonly excluded groups. There is little evidence for the treatment of patients with PTSD and its four comorbidities: alcohol and substance abuse or current addiction, current psychosis, current mania, and current intentional suicidal ideation. CONCLUSIONS: Psychological treatments for PTSD have been studied in large and representative clinical populations. It seems that more liberal use of these treatments is warranted regardless of comorbidities.

title: INCOG recommendations for cognition management following traumatic brain injury, part III: executive function and self-awareness
abstract: INTRODUCTION: Traumatic brain injury (TBI) results in complex cognitive (and other) sequelae. Impairments in executive function and self-awareness are among the most characteristic neuropsychological sequelae and can have a profound impact on maintaining previous life roles. An international group of researchers and clinicians (known as INCOG) came together to develop recommendations for interventions to improve impairments in executive function and self-awareness after TBI. METHODS: The team reviewed the available literature and ensured that the recommendations were up to date. To support the implementation, the team developed decision algorithms with recommendations based on the inclusion and exclusion criteria of published trials. The team then prioritized the practice recommendations and developed audit criteria to evaluate adherence to the best practice recommendations. CONCLUSIONS: Intervention programs that include teaching metacognitive strategies for planning, problem solving, and other cognitive-executive disorders have a solid evidence base. New evidence supports the use of strategies specifically to improve reasoning skills. Significant support is available for the use of direct corrective feedback to develop self-awareness. CONCLUSIONS: There is an increasing number of scientifically well-designed studies demonstrating the effectiveness of various interventions for the correction of impairments in executive function and self-awareness after TBI.

title: Enhanced Compliance with Antibiotic Prophylaxis Guidelines to Prevent Pediatric Surgical Site Infection: Before and After the Study
abstract: OBJECTIVES: To evaluate an intervention to improve antibiotic prophylaxis (AP) guideline compliance to prevent surgical site infections in children. BACKGROUND: Although appropriate AP reduces surgical site infection and guidelines improve quality of care, it is difficult to change practice. Various barriers need to be addressed to facilitate behavior change. METHODS: A multidisciplinary task force at a children's hospital developed an evidence-based FP guideline. Later, the guideline was published in ORs and online formularies, only recommended antibiotics were available in ORs, incoming trainees received orientation, time-out antibiotic validation was included, computerized alerts were set for inappropriate postoperative prophylaxis, and surgeons received email. -Emails sent when the directive is not followed. The indication and practice of AP was documented for surgical procedures in July 2008 (pre-intervention), September 2011 (post-intervention), and April-May 2013 (follow-up). Compliance full--appropriate antibiotic, dose, timing, re-dosing, and duration” when prophylaxis is indicated; partial--appropriate medication and timing when prophylaxis is indicated; and appropriate use--full compliance, no antibiotics when prophylaxis is indicated Pre-intervention and follow-up compliance chi (2) tests. RESULTS: AP was noted in 43.9% (187/426) and 62.0% (124/200) of surgical procedures before and during follow-up Appropriate antibiotic use (51.6%-67.0%) ; P < 0.001), there were significant improvements in complete (26.2%-53.2%; P <0.001) and partial compliance (73.3-88.7%, P = 0.001), correct dosage (77.5%) -90.7%; P = 0.003), timing (83.3%-95.8%; P = 0.001), redosing (62.5%-95.8%, P = 0.003), and duration (47.1-65%) ,3;"P < 0.002). CONCLUSIONS: A versatile intervention improved adherence to a pediatric FP guideline.

title: Improving compliance with low tidal volume ventilation in the intensive care unit with two nudge-based interventions: evaluation through intervention time series analyzes
abstract: OBJECTIVES: Low tidal volume (TVe) ventilation improves outcomes in ventilated patients, and most clinicians report doing so. Unfortunately, most patients never get low TV. 'Nudges' affect decision making through subtle cognitive mechanisms and are effective in many contexts. Few studies have examined its effects on clinical decision making. We investigated the impact of 2 interventions designed using behavioral science principles on the deployment of low TVe ventilation in the intensive care unit (ICU). SETTING: University Hospitals Bristol, a 20-bed tertiary care, mixed medical and surgical ICU, admits over 1300 patients per year. PARTICIPANTS: Data were collected from 2144 patients who received more than 1 hour of controlled mechanical ventilation between October 2010 and September 2014. Patients who underwent controlled mechanical ventilation for more than 20 hours were included in the final analysis. INTERVENTIONS: (1) Default ventilator settings were adjusted to meet low TVe targets from the start of ventilation unless actively changed by a clinician. (2) A large dashboard has been placed that displays the TVs in mL/kg ideal body weight (IBW) format with warnings when the TVs are excessive. PRIMARY OUTCOME MEASURE: TVe in mL/kg IBW. RESULTS: TVe was significantly lower in the defaults group. In the panel intervention, TVe dropped faster and more after exceeding a TVe of 8 mL/kg IBW compared to controls. This effect improved with each subsequent year for 3 years. CONCLUSIONS: This study demonstrated that setting default ventilator settings and a dashboard with excessive TVe alerts can significantly affect clinical decision making. This offers a promising strategy for improving compliance with low TVe ventilation and suggests that using insights from behavioral science has the potential to improve the translation of evidence into practice.

title: Increasing the quantity and quality of seeking the best available evidence to answer clinical questions: protocol and intervention design of the MacPLUS FS Factorial Randomized Controlled Trials
abstract: Background and objectives Finding the best available evidence for clinical decisions remains difficult. With 3,000 new studies published every day, no single evidence-based source can provide all the answers or be adequately updated. McMaster Premium LiteratUre Service - Federated Search (MacPLUS FS) addresses this issue by simultaneously looking at multiple high-quality sources and displaying the results in a one-page pyramid, with the most clinically useful at the top. Still, additional logistical and educational barriers need to be addressed to improve point-of-care evidence access. This trial aims to test three innovative interventions among MacPLUS FS-registered clinicians to increase the quantity and quality of seeking the best available evidence to answer clinical questions. Methods and design Using a user-centered approach, we designed three interventions built into MacPLUS FS: (A) a web-based Clinical Question Recorder; (B) an Evidence Coach with eight short training videos; (C) an Audit, Feedback and Gamification approach to collecting evidence based on the allocation of 'badges' and 'reputation points'. We will conduct a randomized factorial controlled trial among all 904 eligible medical practitioners currently enrolled in MacPLUS. FS in hospitals affiliated with McMaster University, Canada. Graduate trainees (n = 429) and clinical faculty/staff (n = 475) will be randomized to each of the following three interventions in a factorial design (A x B x C). Usage will be recorded continuously through clinician accounts that monitor login and usage down to the level of individual keystrokes. The primary result is the monthly search rate per user over the six-month follow-up period. Secondary outcomes, measured through the Validated Impact Assessment Methodology questionnaire, include the usefulness of the answers found (meeting clinicians' information needs), use (practical application), and perceived benefit on patient outcomes. Discussion Building on effective models for point-of-care teaching, these interventions come close to acquiring evidence as a clinical skill. If effective, they can provide better access to relevant evidence across multiple top-level CPA resources in parallel, providing an opportunity to develop at a low cost for a broad audience.

title: Cholesterol-lowering drug indications: comparison of risk assessment methods
abstract: Background Recommendations for prescribing lipid-lowering drugs emphasize the importance of assessing absolute risk of coronary heart disease (CHD) based on all risk factors rather than serum cholesterol concentration alone. However, if the proposed methods for risk assessment are incorrect, the proposed prescribing will not materialise. In a series of patients referred to a lipid clinic, we compared several sets of guidelines for this type of treatment to assess the difference in the degree of CHD risk for which lipid-lowering drugs are recommended by each guideline.";" Background Recommendations for prescribing lipid-lowering drugs emphasize the importance of assessing absolute risk of coronary heart disease (CHD) based on all risk factors rather than serum cholesterol concentration alone. However, if the proposed methods for risk assessment are incorrect, the proposed prescribing will not materialise. In a series of patients referred to a lipid clinic, we compared several sets of guidelines for this type of treatment to assess the difference in the degree of CHD risk for which lipid-lowering drugs are recommended by each guideline.

title: Personalized treatment goals (RANGE) for elderly patients with type 2 diabetes using vildagliptin adjunctive or monotherapy: a 24-week, randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled study.
abstract: The Background Guidelines recommend setting individualized targets for glycemic control in elderly patients with type 2 diabetes despite the lack of evidence. We aimed to evaluate the feasibility of setting and achieving individualized goals over 24 weeks using vildagliptin versus placebo combined with traditional HbA1c reduction.";" The Background Guidelines recommend setting individualized targets for glycemic control in elderly patients with type 2 diabetes despite the lack of evidence. We aimed to evaluate the feasibility of setting and achieving individualized goals over 24 weeks using vildagliptin versus placebo combined with traditional HbA1c reduction.

title: Individuals with low back pain: How do they view physical activity?
abstract: BACKGROUND: Recent guidelines for those with acute low back pain advocate early resumption of normal activity and increased physical activity. Little is known about the relationship between low back pain and physical activity, and the impact this relationship has on promoting increased levels of physical activity in the general practice population. OBJECTIVES: We aimed to investigate the relationship between the factors affecting changes in physical activity and individuals' perception and behavior of low back pain, and the effect of these perceptions and behaviors on physical activity. METHODS: Twenty-seven sources of information were selected using a purposive sampling from a larger group of individuals who were referred by family physicians to a population-based, single-blind, randomized controlled trial (RCT) for low back problems. University of York evaluating the effectiveness and cost-effectiveness of a progressive exercise program. Fifty-four interviews were conducted with this subgroup of the RCT";" four of them were interviewed once, 19 of them twice and four of them three times. The interviews were transcribed and analyzed using manual and computer-assisted approaches. RESULTS: Physical activity was perceived as (i) activities of daily living, (ii) activities that caused shortness of breath and stopped doing, and (iii) more competitive type of activity. Avoidance of physical activity and fear of the pain returning were the two main factors directly related to the whistleblowers' backs and changes in physical activity. Although most informants strongly believed that being physically active helped relieve low back pain, these two factors hindered the increase in physical activity. CONCLUSIONS: When advocating for individuals with acute low back pain to return to or increase physical activity, it is important for clinicians to identify avoidance and/or fear of pain at the earliest stage in order to appropriately tailor advice and reassurance. If activity avoidance and fear of pain are identified, and clinicians wish to encourage patients to begin and maintain increased physical activity, they should explore fear of pain and confidence in avoiding and performing physical activities, among other factors that influence pain. physical activity.

title: Inequalities among the very poor: health care for rural children in southern Tanzania
abstract: Background Very little work has been done to assess socioeconomic disparities in health in African countries. We looked for evidence of inequalities in health care by gender and socioeconomic status for young children living in a poor rural area of southern Tanzania.";" Background Very little work has been done to assess socioeconomic disparities in health in African countries. We looked for evidence of disparities in health care by gender and socioeconomic status for young children living in a poor rural area of southern Tanzania.

title: Infectious diseases and antibiotic prescription in general practice. observational study in Sicily
abstract: Studies of drug use have shown great variation between different countries in prescribing behavior in general practice. The choice of antibiotic prescription in Italy, for example, seems to indicate a wider use of the parental antibiotic. The aim of this study is to describe the antibiotic prescribing scheme and therapeutic doses used by Sicilian general practitioners (general practitioners) and to evaluate the prescribing attitudes of family physicians towards their use. Each practitioner had to complete a questionnaire for each therapeutic intervention that ended with an antibiotic prescription over a 6-month period. Diagnosis and drugs were classified according to the International Classification of Diseases (ICD-10) and the Anatomical Therapeutic Chemical Classification (ATC), respectively. On 9,395 prescriptions administered by 76 physicians from 25 Sicilian towns, analysis showed that acute respiratory symptoms represented the most common indication (31.7%) for medical consultation, with Macrolides [such as azithromycin (8.8%) and clarithromycin (8.3%)]. , Penicillin [eg, amoxicillin (7.1%) and co-amoxiclav (8.4%)], III generation Cephalosporins [such as cefixime (5.5%) and ceftriaxone (5.1%)] represent the most widely used therapeutic groups. it does. The choice of route of administration was influenced by the age of the patients and, more importantly, by the symptoms and signs of the disease rather than the bacteria suspected of causing the disease. In conclusion, our data clearly demonstrates the lack of knowledge about antibacterial treatment guidelines among GPs in Sicily, as well as the need for independent educational training to improve antibiotic knowledge and reduce the cost of healthcare.

title: Impact of patients' direct-to-consumer advertised antidepressant demands: a randomized controlled trial.
abstract: Context Direct-to-consumer (DTC) advertising of prescription drugs in the United States is both widespread and controversial. While critics argue it leads to overprescribing, proponents argue it helps prevent the underuse of effective treatments, especially for conditions that are underrecognized or stigmatized. Purpose To determine the effects of patients' demands on Â¡Â¯ ITC on physiciansÂ¡Â¯ initial treatment decisions in patients with depressive symptoms. Design a Randomized trial using standardized patients (SPs). Six SP roles were created by crossing 2 conditions (major depression or adjustment disorder with depressed mood) with 3 request types (brand-specific, generic, or none). Establishment of Offices of primary care physicians in Sacramento, Calif"; San Francisco, Calif; and Rochester, NY, between May 2003 and May 2004. Participants One hundred and fifty-two family physicians and general internists recruited from single and group practices and health care facilities;" cooperation rates vary between 53% and 61%. Interventions SPs were randomly assigned to make 298 unannounced visits, with limited assignments due to physicians' seeing 1 SP with major depression and 1 with adjustment disorder. SPs made a brand-specific drug request, a general drug request, or no claim (control condition) in approximately one-third of visits. Key Outcome Measures Data on prescribing, mental health referral, and primary care follow-up from SP written reports, visit audio recordings, chart review, and analysis of written prescriptions and drug samples. The effects of claim type on prescribing were assessed using contingency tables and validated in generalized linear mixed models that account for clustering and adjusted for region, physician, and visit characteristics. Results Standardized patient role fidelity was excellent and physicians' suspicion that they had seen a CP was 13%. In major depression, antidepressant prescribing rates for brand-specific, general, and unwilling CPs were 53%, 76%, and 31%, respectively (P<.001). Antidepressant prescribing rates in adjustment disorder were 55%, 39%, and 10%, respectively (P<.001). The results were validated in multivariate models. Minimally acceptable initial care (any combination of an antidepressant, mental health referral, or follow-up within 2 weeks) made a general request to 98% of CPs in the major depression role, while 90% made a brand-specific request. and 56% of non-claimers (P<.001). Conclusions Patients' wishes have a profound impact on physician prescribing for major depression and adjustment disorder. Direct-to-consumer advertising can have competing effects on quality, potentially both preventing underuse and encouraging overuse.

title: Lifestyle measures with a comprehensive lifestyle intervention program in patients with coronary heart disease and its impact on five-year coronary risk
abstract: BACKGROUND: Lifestyle measures to prevent coronary heart disease (CHD) have been overshadowed by the effectiveness of drug treatments. This is especially true in the secondary prevention setting, where the benefits of lipid-lowering, anti-platelet and anti-hypertensive drugs have been highlighted in numerous trials. Lifestyle measures address several CHD risk factors simultaneously and are generally free of serious side effects. OBJECTIVES: The aim of this study was to determine whether a comprehensive lifestyle change program could positively affect diet and exercise habits in addition to smoking cessation for two years. In addition, it was tried to evaluate whether this program would positively affect the 5-year risk of CHD in the male population included in the study. Design: A total of 197 patients with proven coronary heart disease were included and randomized to a lifestyle intervention program or usual care. Follow-up was after a two-year period. METHODS: The intervention consisted of a low-fat diet, regular exercise, smoking cessation, psychosocial support, and education given by nurses for pharmacological and lifestyle measures. Usual care included routine outpatient follow-up. Both groups were given the same range of medication according to the latest guidelines. RESULTS: Patients in the lifestyle intervention group reduced their intake of saturated fat, sugar, and cholesterol (P<0.001), increased their exercise levels (P<0.01), and quit smoking (P<0.05), compared to the normal care group. A sub-analysis of the effect of the five-year calculated risk of CHD in men resulted in a relative risk reduction of 22% (9-35 confidence interval 95%). Although significant, this result should be interpreted with caution due to the method's poor statistical power and reproducibility. CONCLUSIONS: In the presence of modern drug therapies for the prevention of secondary cardiovascular disease, it remains possible through a suitable diet, exercise and smoking cessation to demonstrate an additional five-year risk for CHD in men.

title: Effects of educational interventions and negative news about calcium channel blockers in primary care prescribing of antihypertensive drugs to older people in British Columbia
abstract: Background How the dissemination of evidence is changing medical practice needs to be better understood. The debate about calcium channel blockers (CCBs) over the past 3 years has provided a natural experiment to evaluate the impact of media stories, a national warning letter, a teleconference, small group workshops, and news bulletins on primary care antihypertensive prescribing. medicines.";" Background How the dissemination of evidence is changing medical practice needs to be better understood. The debate about calcium channel blockers (CCBs) over the past 3 years has provided a natural experiment to evaluate the impact of media stories, a national warning letter, a teleconference, small group workshops, and news bulletins on primary care antihypertensive prescribing. medicines.

title: Influence of prescriber feedback and management guidelines and antibiotic prescribing: a 5-year follow-up
abstract: BACKGROUND: The extent of antibiotic use for upper respiratory tract infection (URTI) prompted a previous study of an educational intervention based on prescriber feedback and management guidelines. This study demonstrated a reduction in antibiotic prescribing for URTI and a more appropriate antibiotic choice for tonsillitis/streptococcal pharyngitis. Long-term follow-up studies of such training programs are few. OBJECTIVES: This follow-up study aimed to examine whether the reduction in antibiotic prescribing observed in the intervention group of the original study persisted after 5 years and how the prescribing behavior of GPs involved in follow-up differed from a large national scale. GP prescribing questionnaire. METHODS: An attempt was made to contact 157 general practitioners included in the original study. Of these, 121 were both built-in and currently working in public practice. Ninety-six individuals agreed to participate, and 79 of them completed a morbidity and treatment questionnaire that encountered 100 patients (response rate 65.3%). RESULTS: The intervention group (n = 37) continued their pattern of antibiotic prescribing for URTI and antibiotic selection for tonsillitis/streptococcal pharyngitis, with no significant change between completion of the original study and 5-year follow-up. The control group (n = 42) showed a downward trend in antibiotic prescribing for URTI, with no significant difference between groups at 5-year follow-up. At 5-year follow-up, both groups prescribed significantly fewer antibiotics for URTI and showed greater adherence to prescribing guidelines for tonsillitis/streptococcal pharyngitis than participants in a large national GP survey (n = 984). CONCLUSION: This study showed that prescribing behavior was maintained in the intervention group in the long term. However, the prescribing changes observed in the control group and the power limitations of the study make it unclear whether this is the result of a sustained effect of the educational intervention. The differences in both groups from the large national GP survey suggest that other influences on prescribing (such as participation in vocational training for general practice) also have a significant impact.

title: Influencing antibiotic prescribing in general practice: a trial of prescriber feedback and management guidelines.
abstract: BACKGROUND: The extent of use of antibiotics to treat upper respiratory tract infections in general practice is an area of concern due to the growing problem of bacterial resistance. Effective educational strategies are needed to promote rational prescribing. OBJECTIVE: We aimed to examine the effectiveness of prescribing feedback and management guidelines in reducing GP-prescribed antibiotics for undifferentiated upper respiratory tract infection and improving antibiotic selection for tonsillitis/streptococcal pharyngitis. The research tested a phased approach to targeting educational input to high prescribers. METHOD: General Practice trainees (n = 157) in New South Wales to a treatment group (n = 78) receiving an educational intervention on antibiotic use or an unrelated subject. Trainees completed three practice effectiveness questionnaires, each consisting of 110 consecutive patient interviews, with 6-month intervals between questionnaires. Prescriber feedback and management guidelines regarding antibiotic use for URTI and antibiotic choice for tonsillitis/streptococcal pharyngitis were provided in written form between questionnaires 1 and 2. An educational outreach visit was given to high prescribers between surveys 2 and 3. Antibiotic prescribing rate for all indications for URTI and prescribing rate of selected antibiotics for tonsillitis/streptococcal pharyngitis. RESULTS: Antibiotic prescription by the intervention group decreased from 25.0 to 23.3 to 19.7 per 100 URTI problems on three occasions, while the control group increased from 22.0 to 25.0 to 31.7 per 100 URTI problems (P = 0.002). Consistent with accepted guidelines for tonsillitis/streptococcal pharyngitis, prescribing increased over time from 55.6 to 69.8 to 73.0 per 100 problems in the intervention group but decreased from 59.6 to 57.5 to 58.5 per 100 problems in the control group (P = 0.05) . CONCLUSION: Prescribing feedback and management guidelines have been shown to affect antibiotic prescribing for URTI and antibiotic selection for tonsillitis/streptococcal pharyngitis. This study provides a model for targeting educational input to prescribers who most need to change their behavior.

title: Information technology for patient safety
abstract: Background Research on patient care has identified significant differences in the quality and safety of healthcare and significant risks of iatrogenic harm as major issues. These failures contribute to high rates of potentially preventable morbidity and mortality and the rising levels of health expenditure seen in many health systems. There have been significant advances in information technology in recent years, and there is now real potential to apply these technological advances to improve healthcare delivery universally. Of particular international interest is the use of eHealth applications. However, there is a large gap between the theoretical and experimentally proven benefits of eHealth applications. While these applications typically have the technical capability to assist professionals in healthcare delivery, insufficient attention to the socio-technical aspects of their use may result in new avoidable risks for patients. Conclusions and discussion Given the current lack of evidence on quality and safety improvements and the cost-benefits associated with introducing eHealth applications, the focus should be on implementing more mature technologies”; it is also important that eHealth applications are evaluated through a comprehensive and rigorous set of measures, ideally at all stages of the application lifecycle.

title: Informed consent in clinical trials at a general hospital in Mexico: investigators' views
abstract: In Mexico, informed consent is a legal requirement that ensures that patients invited to participate in clinical trials are provided with all the information needed to decide whether to participate in a trial protocol. To enable us to better understand the problems faced by physicians in developing countries when obtaining informed consent (IC), we examined their views on the importance of IC in clinical trials, the quantity and quality of information provided to the participant, and the circumstances in this regard. which IC is obtained. Investigators felt that IC was helpful to patients and provided information that helped the patient make decisions about participation. However, for some aspects of the research, such as drug development in general, placebo use, and the randomization process, they felt that most patients did not fully understand the information provided, citing the complexity of the information. ignorance as the main cause. Most researchers were unaware of some of the guidelines created in the Mexican General Health Law,(1) 36% admitted not completing their IC letter. Most investigators gave patients only minutes to make a decision, and 20% of ICs were obtained while the patient was in hospital. All but one researcher thought that specific training in medical ethics would be beneficial for daily clinical work.

title: Informed consent in human experiments before the Nuremberg code
abstract: The ethical issue of medical experimentation in Germany in the 1930s and 1940s was very important in the Nuremberg trials and related trials of doctors and public health officials. Those involved in the heinous crimes tried to excuse themselves by arguing that there were no clear rules governing medical research on humans in Germany at the time, and that research practices in Germany were not different from those in the allied countries. In this context, the Nuremberg law of 1947 is generally considered to be the first document to establish ethical regulations in human experimentation on the basis of informed consent. However, new research shows that ethical issues of informed consent were recognized in guidelines for human experimentation as early as the nineteenth century. These guidelines shed light on the still controversial issue of when the concepts of autonomy, informed consent, and therapeutic and non-therapeutic research were first introduced. This issue is gaining relevance in the context of current attempts to assess responsibility and liability for human abuse in the various experiments carried out in the United States, Canada, Russia and other countries since the second world war.

title: Informed consent: coronary artery bypass grafting
abstract: Coronary artery bypass graft surgery (CABG) is a well-documented procedure. Despite the increasing prevalence of percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI), surgical revascularization will continue to play an important role in patients with coronary artery disease. As demonstrated in previous clinical studies, physicians can provide patients with important information about risk-adjusted outcomes. A number of databases have been used to develop risk models to predict morbidity and mortality in patients undergoing CABG. Patients should choose between CABG and PCI according to the physicians' explanations. Major trials have demonstrated a significant survival benefit from CABG among patients at high risk of death from the disease itself, defined by severity of angina, number of diseased vessels, and left ventricular function. However, it is not clear that patients always receive accurate information about whether CABG or PCI is the more appropriate procedure. Initial informed consent should be obtained by an independent consultant using relevant guidelines.

title: Informed shared decision making supported by decision coaches for women with ductal carcinoma in situ: study protocol for a cluster randomized controlled trial.
abstract: BACKGROUND: Women with breast cancer want to be involved in treatment decision-making. The Directives affirmed the right to informed joint decision-making. However, previous research has shown that the practice of informed co-decision making is sub-optimal, due to physicians' limited resources, power imbalances between patients and physicians, and a lack of evidence-based patient information. We developed an informed co-decision-making program for women with primary ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS). The program provides decision coaching to women by specialist nurses and aims to support participation in decision making and informed choices. In this trial, an informed co-decision program will be evaluated in breast care centers. METHODS/DESIGN: A cluster randomized controlled trial will be conducted to compare an informed shared decision-making program with standard care. The program includes an evidence-based patient decision aid and training of physicians (2 hours) and specialist breast care and oncology nurses (4 days) in informed co-decision making. Sixteen certified breast care centers recruiting 192 women with primary DCIS will be included. The primary outcome is the extent to which patients are involved in co-decision making, as assessed by MAPPIN-Odyad (multifocal approach to 'sharing' in shared decision making: observer instrument pair). Secondary endpoints include sub-measures of the MAPPIN-inventory (MAPPIN-Honorse, MAPPIN-Ophysician, MAPPIN-O Patient, MAPPIN-Qnurse, MAPPIN-Q Patient, and MAPPIN-Qphysician), informed choice, decision conflict, and duration of encounters. The provision of decision coaching and evidence-based patient decision aids is expected to increase patients' participation in decision-making through informed choices and reduce decision conflicts and doctor encounter time. In addition, an accompanying process assessment will be conducted. DISCUSSION: To our knowledge, this is the first study to investigate the application of decision coaches in German breast care centers. TRIAL REGISTRATION: Available Controlled Trials ISRCTN46305518 , registration date: June 5, 2015.

title: Infrastructure for quality transformation: Measurement and reporting in veterans administration intensive care units
abstract: Background Veterans Health Administration (VA) intensive care units (ICUs) develop an infrastructure for quality improvement using information technology and recruiting leadership. Methods Setting The quality improvement program requires the participation of 183 intensive care units. The infrastructure includes measurement (electronic data extraction, analysis), quarterly web-based reporting, and implementation support of evidence-based applications. Leaders prioritize measures based on quality improvement goals. Electronic inference is manually validated against medical records, selecting hospitals with data items and measurements at the extremes (10th, 90th percentile). Results are displayed in graphical, narrative and tabular reports that are compared by type and complexity of the intensive care unit. Results VA admits 103?689Â±1156 ICU patients per year. In electronic business applications, differences in data location and the normal range of some laboratory tests affect data quality. A data management website captures data items important to ICU performance that are not available electronically. A dashboard manages excess data (quarterly reports range from 106-299 pages). More than 85% of ICU principals and nurse administrators review their reports. Leadership interest is sustained through incorporating ICU goals into executive performance engagements, identifying local improvement opportunities with analytical software, and focused reviews. Conclusion Lessons for non-VA organizations include: (1) the need for continuous data validation, (2) key involvement of leadership at multiple levels, (3) support for electronic data when key elements are not available, (4) a data item, and (5) a dashboard. good but not perfect electronic indicator for moving the app while improving its value.

title: Initiation of quality improvement activities in mental health services
abstract: In the public sector mental health care setting, accountability for quality has often been thought of as the responsibility of the individual clinician. This presents a particular challenge in promoting an organization-wide culture of quality improvement in this environment. The introduction of a systemic view of quality may encounter resistance from clinicians who are reluctant to accept that some clinical autonomy must be encompassed in more standard patterns of intervention and assessment. Services should first address the readiness of clinicians to adopt such a culture, which requires strong leadership from the managerial level. The recently diagnosed area of psychosis was chosen in a public sector mental health service as a starting point for initiating a culture of quality improvement. The end result for the organization was a positive commitment to improvement, but the journey has been long and difficult. This article describes the beginning of this ultimately rewarding journey.

title: Innovative strategy for the implementation of chronic heart failure guidelines among family physicians in different healthcare settings in Berlin
abstract: OBJECTIVES: The aim of this study was to improve drug therapy in patients with chronic heart failure (CHF). METHODS AND RESULTS: This prospective interventional pilot study was conducted with cross-sectional comparative analysis before and after intervention. Ordinary pharmacotherapy was observed for 8 months at two different outpatient settings in Berlin [11 family physicians from individual GP (IGP) practices and 12 family physicians working in a medical care center (MCC)]. Medical care centers provide a new structure for outpatient care and have recently been introduced in Germany. Subsequent intervention required implementation of heart failure guidelines via a computer-based reminder system followed by renewed cross-sectional observation of prescribing behavior for 1 year. Family physicians recruited patients, assessed CHF severity by NYHA class, and referred patients for echocardiography. The study included 190 patients in the initial phase and 209 in the intervention phase. Longitudinal follow-up was performed in 172 cases. Echocardiography was requested by 94.6% of MCC physicians and 79.9% of IGPs. Insufficient medication was observed in both settings. Guideline-based beta-blocker therapy was prescribed to 46.3% of patients (44.8% of IGPs and 48.5% of MCC-GPs). After the intervention, the prescription was improved by 12.3%. There were significant gaps in prescribing (35%) of aldosterone antagonists for severe heart failure, increasing to 44.2% after intervention. CONCLUSION: The problem of inadequate implementation of evidence-based treatment for CHF was partially overcome by using the reminder system, which provided short guide recommendations to participating physicians during the intervention phase.

title: Physician reminders versus inpatient computer-based outpatient orders to increase flu and pneumococcal vaccination rates: a randomized trial.
abstract: Context Computerized reminder systems increase influenza and pneumococcal vaccination rates, but computerized continuous order systems have not been previously described or evaluated. Purpose To determine the effects of computerized physician orders on inpatient vaccination rates compared with physician reminders. Design, Environment, and Patients A randomized trial of 3777 general medicine patients discharged from 1 of 6 study wards over a 14-month period (November 1, 1998 - December 31, 1999), comprised of 2 overlapping flu seasons in an urban public teaching hospital. Interventions The hospital's computerized physician order entry system identified inpatients eligible for influenza and pneumococcal vaccination. For patients with outpatient orders, the system automatically generated vaccine orders for nurses when the patient was discharged. For patients with reminders, the computer system provided physicians with reminders of vaccine orders during routine order entry sessions. Main Outcome Measure Vaccine application. Results During approximately 6 months of the flu season, 50% of all hospitalized patients were determined to be eligible for the flu vaccine. Twenty-two percent of hospitalized patients during the 14 months of the study were eligible for pneumococcal vaccine. Patients with interruptions received flu shots significantly more often (42%) than patients with reminders (30%) (P < .001). Outpatients received the pneumococcal vaccine (51%) significantly more frequently (51%) than reminders (31%) (P < .001). Results Computerized standing orders were more effective than computerized reminders for increasing both influenza and pneumococcal vaccine administration. Our findings suggest that computerized fixed orders should be used more widely for this purpose.

title: insomnia disease
Integrated guidance on the care of familial hypercholesterolemia from the International FH Foundation
abstract: Familial hypercholesterolemia (FH) is a congenital, predominantly inherited disease that markedly elevates plasma low-density lipoprotein (LDL) cholesterol and causes early coronary heart disease. Worldwide, there are at least 20 million people with AD, but the majority go undetected and current treatment is often inadequate. To address this major gap in coronary prevention, we present consensus-based guidance on the care of AD from an international perspective. Guidance was created from seminars and workshops held at an international symposium. Recommendations focus on the detection, diagnosis, evaluation and management of FD in adults and children and establish guidelines for clinical purposes. They also refer to best practices for cascading screening and risk reporting for FH and testing families, including the use of genetic testing. Treatment guidance is based on risk stratification, management of non-cholesterol risk factors, and the safe and effective use of LDL-lowering therapies. Recommendations are given for lipoprotein apheresis. The use of emerging therapies for FH is also contemplated. This international guide acknowledges evidence gaps, but aims to make the most of contemporary practice and technology to achieve the best outcomes for FH care. Accordingly, it should be used to inform clinical judgment and should be tailored to country-specific and local health needs and resources.

title: Integrated motivational interviewing and cognitive behavioral therapy for people with psychosis and substance abuse: a randomized controlled trial.
abstract: OBJECTIVES To evaluate the effectiveness of integrated motivational interviewing and cognitive behavioral therapy in addition to standard care in patients with psychosis and comorbid substance use problems. DESIGN A two-center, open, evaluator-blind randomized controlled trial. SET Secondary health care in the UK. PARTICIPANTS: 327 patients with a clinical diagnosis of schizophrenia, schizophreniform disorder, or schizoaffective disorder and a diagnosis of drug, alcohol, or both abuse or dependence, according to the Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders, fourth edition. INTERVENTION The intervention was integrated motivational interviewing and cognitive behavioral therapy plus standard care compared to standard care alone. The first phase of therapy - "motivating" - is about engaging the patient, then exploring and resolving ambivalence for change in substance use. The second phase - "action" - supports and facilitates change using cognitive behavioral approaches. It was administered up to 26 therapy sessions over a year. MAIN OUTCOME MEASURES The primary outcome was death or hospitalization from any cause within 12 months of treatment completion. Secondary outcomes were frequency and amount of substance use (assessed using the timeline tracking method), readiness to change, perceived negative consequences of use, ratings of psychotic symptoms, number and duration of relapses, and overall assessment of functioning and intentional self-harm at 12 and 12 years of age. 24 months with additional timeline follow-up assessments at 6 and 18 months. Analysis was done with the intent to treat and robust estimates of treatment effect were produced. RESULTS 327 participants were randomly assigned to either intervention (n=164) or treatment as usual (n=163). At 24 months, 326 (99.7%) were evaluated on primary outcome and 246 (75.2%) were evaluated on main secondary outcomes. The treatment group had no beneficial effect on hospitalizations or death at follow-up, with 23.3% (38/163) of the treatment group and 20.2% (33/163) of the deceased or admitted controls (adjusted odds ratio 1.16, 95% confidence interval). ) 0.68 to 1.99"; P=0.579. Therapy had no effect on frequency of substance use or perceived adverse outcomes of abuse, but had a statistically significant effect on the amount of substance used each day (adjusted OR' for the main substance). s 1.50 95% CI 1.08 to 2.09; P=0.016; and all items 1.48, 95% CI 1.07 to 2.05; P=0.017) Treatment had a statistically significant effect on readiness to switch use at 12 months (adjusted OR 2.05, 95%). CI 1.26 to 3.31; P=0.004), not maintained at 24 months (0.78, 95% CI 0.48 to 1.28; “P=0.320). Treatment had no effect on clinical outcomes such as relapses, psychotic symptoms, functioning, and self-harm. CONCLUSIONS For people with psychosis and substance abuse, integrated motivational interviewing and cognitive behavioral therapy do not improve outcome in terms of hospitalization, symptom outcomes, or functioning. This approach reduces the amount of substance used for at least one year after completion of treatment. TRIAL REGISTRATION Controlled Trials Available: ISRCTN14404480.

title: Integrating "Back to Sleep" suggestions into the neonatal ICU app
abstract: BACKGROUND AND OBJECTIVES: The American Academy of Pediatrics emphasizes that neonatal intensive care units should support and model sudden infant death syndrome risk reduction recommendations significantly prior to the expected discharge of the infant. Healthcare professionals are critical role models for parents, and the way they position babies in the hospital strongly influences parenting practices at home. The aims of this project were to increase the percentage of infants following safe sleep practices in the NICU before discharge and to determine whether improving adherence to these practices would affect parental behavior at home. METHODS: An algorithm detailing when to start safe sleep practices, the "Back to Sleep" crib card, training programs for nurses and parents, a crib inspection tool, and post-discharge telephone reminders were developed as quality improvement intervention strategies. RESULTS: NICU compliance with the supine position ranged from 39% to 83% (P < .001), providing a firm sleeping surface from 5% to 96% (P < .001), and removing soft objects from the bed 45%' increased from ten to 75% (P = .001). Using a post-discharge telephone questionnaire was noted to increase parental compliance with safe sleep practices from 23% to 82% (P < .001). CONCLUSIONS: Multifactorial interventions improved adherence to safe sleep practices in the NICU and at home.

title: Integrating addiction treatment into primary care using mobile health technology: protocol for a practice research study.
abstract: Background Healthcare reform in the United States is encouraging Federally Qualified Health Centers and other primary care practices to integrate addiction treatment and other behavioral health conditions into their practices. The potential for mobile health technologies to manage addiction and comorbidities such as HIV in these settings is great, but largely untested. This document describes a protocol for evaluating the application of an E-Health integrated communications technology, called Seva, delivered to primary care settings via mobile phones. Seva is an evidence-based addiction treatment and recovery support for patients and real-time caseload monitoring for clinicians. Our Methods/Design Implementation strategy uses three models of institutional change: the Program Planning Model to promote acceptance and sustainability, the NIATx quality improvement model to create a welcoming environment for change, and Rogers' diffusion of innovations research that facilitates adaptations to maximize their adoption potential. We will implement . Our asynchronous multi-base design includes three semesters Â¡Âª pretesting (concludes with four months of practice preparation), active Seva practice and maintenance Â¡Âª with phased implementation at six-month intervals between sites. The first field will serve as a pilot clinic. We will monitor the timing of intervention items and evaluate study results in all aspects of the Access, Effectiveness, Adoption, Implementation and Care framework, including impacts on clinicians, patients and practices. Our mixed-methods approach will include quantitative (eg, interrupted time-series analysis with clinical units of analysis) and qualitative (eg, staff interviews about adaptations to the implementation protocol) methods and assessment of implementation costs. Discussion If implementation is successful, the field will have proven technology that helps Federally Qualified Health Centers and affiliates provide addiction treatment and recovery support, and a proven strategy for implementing the technology. Seva also has the potential to improve key aspects of addiction treatment, such as referral and treatment processes. A mobile technology and accompanying application model for addiction treatment could provide a cost-effective way to improve the lives of patients with drug and alcohol problems.

title: Integrating evidence of patient preferences in health policy decisions: protocol of the patient-VIP study
abstract: Background Despite the strong movement towards active patient participation in health policy decisions, a systematic and explicit evaluation of the evidence from this research on patient preferences seems limited. Also, little is known about the views of various stakeholders on considering research evidence regarding patient preferences in health policy decisions. This article describes the protocol for an exploratory study of integrating research on patient preferences in health policy decisions. The study examines the extent to which research evidence regarding patient preferences is taken into account in current procedures for health policy decisions; It questions stakeholders' views on the integration of such evidence into health policy decisions and what a decision framework might be for its integration into health policy decisions. such research evidence in health policy decisions Methods/design The study is divided into three sub-studies using predominantly qualitative methods. The first sub-study is a scoping study in five European countries to explore whether and how research results on patient preferences. It is taken into account in existing procedures for scope decisions and clinical practice guideline development. The second sub-study is a qualitative study to explore stakeholder views on the possibilities of integrating evidence of patient preferences in healthcare decision-making. Netherlands The third sub-study is the development of a decision. research framework on patient preferences. The framework will consist of: a process description of the place of evidence regarding patient preferences in the decision-making process; a classification that defines the different terminologies and conceptualizations related to Â¡Â®preferencesÂ¡Â¯ and an overview of current methodologies for research The concept framework will be presented to experts and Discussion This study will raise awareness about the existence and potential value of research evidence regarding patient preferences for healthcare policy decision making and will provide insight into patient preferences and methods of researching patient preferences barriers and facilitators for the integration of such research into health policy decisions. will be useful to clinical practice guideline developers, healthcare policy makers, and patient representatives.

title: Integrative medicine in residency training: developing competence through online curriculum training
abstract: INTRODUCTION: The Specialization in Integrative Medicine (IMR) program, a 200-hour Internet-based, collaborative training initiative implemented in 8 family medicine residency programs, has shown the potential to serve as a national model for integrating integrative/complementary/integrative/complementary education. alternative medicine in postgraduate medical education. INTERVENTION: Curriculum content is designed based on a needs assessment and a set of competencies for postgraduate medical education developed following the Graduate Medical Education Accreditation Council concluding project guidelines. Content was provided through distributed online learning and onsite activities were included. A modular format that allows flexible application in different residence settings. ASSESSMENT: A MULTI MODAL ASSESSMENT IS USED TO EVALUATE THE APPLICABILITY OF THE CURRICULUM: (1) residents' curriculum assessment"; (2) residents' medical knowledge testing, self-assessment, proficiency assessment through direct observations, and reflections;" and (3) the well-being and well-being of residents through behavioral assessments. RESULTS: The class of 2011 (n = 61) had a high curriculum completion rate in year one and year two (98.7% vs. 84.2%), and course assessments on meeting objectives, clinical utility, and technology operation scored high. There was a statistically significant improvement in medical knowledge test scores for questions compatible with the content of both PGY-1 and PGY-2 courses. CONCLUSIONS: The IMR program is an advance in the national effort to make integrative medical education widely accessible to physicians and a success in terms of online education. Evaluation shows that this program is suitable for implementation and acceptable to residents despite the many pressures of residency.

title: Intensive research in the management of Hodgkin's disease
abstract: Laparotomy and splenectomy were performed in 98 patients with clinically localized Hodgkin's disease to determine the extent of microscopic spread. In 68 patients, the procedure was performed for untreated disease apparently confined above the diaphragm. Abdominal disease cannot be safely excluded on the basis of non-invasive examination at presentation. Clinical assessment of spleen disease was unreliable unless gross splenomegaly was present. Pedal lymphography was accurate in assessing para-aortic and iliac disease, but was of no value in assessing other intra-abdominal lymph node involvement, including mesenteric lymph node. Preoperatively, trephine bone marrow biopsy findings were normal in all patients, and diseased bone marrow was detected in only one patient with intraoperative Stryker-saw biopsy. Intraoperative liver disease was identified in nine patients, some of whom were asymptomatic with clinically undetectable spleen and nodal disease. Detailed clinical staging failed to detect disease in one-third of patients undergoing laparotomy. These studies suggest that an elaborate staging procedure, including laparotomy and splenectomy, remains necessary if radiotherapy is truly to remain the treatment of choice for disease localized in the lymph nodes. The value of this potentially curative treatment is significantly reduced in the understaging patient.

title: Intensive speech and language therapy in post-stroke patients with chronic aphasia: a randomized, open-label, blinded endpoint, controlled trial in a healthcare setting.
abstract: Background Treatment guidelines for Aphasia recommend intensive speech and language therapy for chronic (â€°â¥6 months) post-stroke aphasia, but large-scale, class 1 randomized controlled trials of treatment efficacy are scarce. We aimed to examine whether 3-week intensive speech and language therapy improves verbal communication in daily life situations in people with chronic aphasia after stroke under routine clinical conditions.";" Background Treatment guidelines for Aphasia recommend intensive speech and language therapy for chronic (â€°â¥6 months) post-stroke aphasia, but large-scale, class 1 randomized controlled trials of treatment efficacy are scarce. We aimed to examine whether 3-week intensive speech and language therapy improves verbal communication in daily life situations in people with chronic aphasia after stroke under routine clinical conditions.

title: Intentions and prescribing: can the theory of planned behavior explain physician behavior in the following guideline recommendations?
abstract: OBJECTIVES: Several studies have evaluated the usefulness of Planned Behavior Theory (TPB) in explaining physician behavior. This study uses TPB to explain how physicians apply the prescribing recommendations of guidelines. METHODS: We developed the questionnaire through qualitative interviews and a pilot study. A random sample of 155 general practitioners (GPs) from the UK participated in the study. Prescribing and administration data were collected from routine sources. We analyzed the data using regression methods. RESULTS: TPB explained 48% of the variation in reported intentions to follow guidelines prescribing recommendations. Attitudes and perceived controls were predictors of variation in intentions, not subjective norms. TPB belief variables significantly explained the variation in indicators of effective and efficient prescribing (14% and 12%, respectively). Normative, control, and behavioral beliefs contributed to the models. Only for effective prescribing, TPB items remained important in the presence of demographic variables. We did not find a significant relationship between intent and prescribing. RESULTS: TPB helped GPs understand prescribing behavior and intentions to apply a clinical guideline. Beliefs (eg, normative beliefs) were better predictors of behavior than composite scores for their corresponding higher-order constructs (eg, indirect subjective norm). TPB models should be tested in conjunction with random trials to test the causality assumption that change in beliefs ultimately results in change in behavior.

title: Interactions between drug representatives and doctors in education. A thematic review
abstract: OBJECTIVE: Medical school and specialty, formative years in establishing prescribing patterns. We aimed to review the literature on the extent of the pharmaceutical industry's contact with trainees, attitudes about these interactions, and their impact on trainee prescribing behavior, emphasizing potential intervention and policy-making points. DESIGN: From 1966 to May 2004, we searched MEDLINE for articles in English. All original articles, medical education, and summary reported content related to the pharmaceutical industry were included, if available. Editorials, guidelines, and policy recommendations are excluded. MEASUREMENTS AND KEY RESULTS: Contact with pharmaceutical representatives was common among residents. The majority of the trainees thought the interactions were appropriate. A minority felt that their own prescribing might be affected by contact or gifts, but were more likely to believe that others' prescriptions might be affected. Resident prescribing was associated with pharmaceutical representative visits and availability of samples. While data on the long-term effects of these interventions are limited, various policy and education interventions appear to influence established attitudes towards interactions with industry. Overall, residents reported insufficient education in this area. CONCLUSIONS: The pharmaceutical industry has a significant presence during residency training, has gained general acceptance from trainees, and appears to influence prescribing behavior. Training programs can benefit from policies and curricula that inform residents about the impact of the industry and ways to critically evaluate the information provided to them. Recommendations for local and national approaches are discussed.

title: Interactions between physicians and the pharmaceutical industry: What does the literature say?
abstract: OBJECTIVE: To determine the impact of the three types of interactions between physicians and the pharmaceutical industry – company-funded clinical trials, company-sponsored continuing medical education (CME), and information provided for physicians by pharmaceutical detailers – on clinical orientation and quality trials, content of CME courses, and physician prescriptions. typing behavior. DATA SOURCES: MEDLINE and HEALTH search for articles in English published from 1978 to 1993 supported by material from the author's personal collection. STUDY SELECTION: A total of 227 articles from MEDLINE and HEALTH research and approximately 2000 items from the author's library were initially reviewed. The following selection criteria were used: studies conducted in Australia, Canada, New Zealand, the United Kingdom, and the United States"; studies conducted after 1977; quantitative studies detailing survey methods; studies and evaluation of the direction and quality of company-funded clinical studies about the content of CME courses giving clear criteria used; and reports on outcomes of interactions indicating how outcomes were evaluated. Thirty-six studies met these criteria. DATA SHOOT: Information was extracted on five topics: physicians' attitudes towards pharmaceutical industry interactions, frequency of physicians' participation in interactions, company-funded The orientation and quality of clinical trials administered, the content of company-sponsored CME courses, and changes in physician prescribing are behavior that result from interaction. Although ra attends only occasionally, most see the details and attend company-sponsored CME courses. However, doctors don't have a very high opinion of information from detailers or company-sponsored CME events. Many doctors see pharmaceutical companies as an important source of funding for clinical trials, but they are also concerned about accepting money from that source. Company funding of clinical trials can affect the quality of trials and the type of research physicians undertake. Company-sponsored CME courses may have a commercial bias, even if conducted under guidelines designed to ensure the independence of the event. All three types of interactions affect physicians' prescribing behavior, and if information is obtained from detailers, physicians' prescribing practices become less appropriate as a result of interaction. CONCLUSION: Physicians are affected by their interactions with the pharmaceutical industry. In many cases, further research is required to determine whether such interactions lead to more or less favorable prescribing practices. CMA's guidelines on this subject should be evaluated to see if they are effective in controlling physician-industry interactions. Further action may be necessary if guidelines fail to prevent adverse effects on prescribing practices.

title: Interdisciplinary perspectives on the management of the restless infant: key strategies for better outcomes
abstract: The aims of this study were to analyze the perspectives of key sources of information with clinical expertise in the care of infants who have not settled in the first few months of life and their families regarding the changes needed to improve outcomes. The research used a purposeful selection strategy and thematic analysis of key informative interviews with 24 health professionals from 11 disciplines. Informants were selected for extensive experience in managing unsettled infants and their families. Participants confirmed the existing evidence that postnatal care is divided in Australia. All were of the view that, first, early primary care intervention for unsettled infants and their families and, second, improved interprofessional communication is vital if the burden of this problem on the infant, family and health system is to be minimized. Third, there was consensus that there were significant gaps in the knowledge base and management behavior of health professionals. Educational resources, best practice guidelines, shared assessment frameworks for primary care practitioners, and strategies to improve interprofessional communication are needed to improve health outcomes and reduce the burden of this common but complex postpartum problem.

title: Internal and external validity of clustered randomized trials: a systematic review of recent studies.
abstract: OBJECTIVES To evaluate aspects of the internal validity of recently published randomized cluster studies and to investigate reporting information useful in assessing the external validity of these trials. DESIGN Review of 34 clusters of randomized studies published in primary care in 2004 and 2005 in seven journals (British Medical Journal, British Journal of General Practice, Family Practice, Prevention Medicine, Annals of Internal Medicine, Journal of General Internal Medicine, Pediatrics). DATA SOURCES National Library of Medicine (Medline) via PubMed. DATA DRAWING To assess internal validity, we extracted data on the suitability of sample size calculations and analyzes, methods of identifying and recruiting individual participants, and blinding. To investigate reporting of information useful in assessing external validity, we extracted data on cluster relevance, inclusion and retention, cluster generalizability, and feasibility and acceptability of intervention to healthcare providers in clusters. RESULTS 21 (62%) studies included clustering in sample size calculations and in 30 (88%) analyses, nearly a quarter were potentially biased due to procedures surrounding recruitment and identification of patients; individual respondents were blinded to allocation status in 19 (56%), and outcome raters were blind in 15 (44%). Issues affecting their internal validity, such as appropriate sample size calculations and analysis, have been widely disseminated and are now better addressed by researchers. Blinding individuals who identify patients and place them in allocation status is recommended, but not always done. For internal validity in trials where individual participants are not recruited There may be fewer obstacles. External validity does not seem to have been adequately addressed in many studies, but it can be argued that it is just as important as internal validity in assessing quality as a basis for healthcare intervention.

title: International College of Rehabilitative Audiology (ICRA) recommendations for the creation of multilingual speech tests. ICRA Multilingual Speaking Tests Working Group
abstract: OBJECTIVE: To provide guidelines for the development of two types of closed set speech perception tests that can be administered and interpreted alike across languages. The guidelines cover the most commonly used digit triplet and matrix sentence tests for testing speech recognition in noise. It was developed by a working group on the Multilingual Speech Tests of the International College of Rehabilitative Audiology (ICRA). DESIGN: Recommendations are based on the research experience of members of the ICRA Working Group, as well as reviews of current evaluations of numerical triple and matrix tests. They represent the results of a consensus process. RESULTS: The resulting recommendations relate to: Test design and word choice"; Speaker characteristics; Voice recording and stimulus preparation; Noise masking; Test management;" and Test validation. RESULTS: By following these guidelines for the development of any such new tests, clinicians and researchers working in any language will be able to perform tests whose results can be compared and combined in cross-language studies.

title: Intervention in infancy: implications for autism spectrum disorders
abstract: There is a paucity of empirical research into the characteristics of successful interventions for this population, along with the scarcity of empirically approved treatments for infants and young children under 3 years of age with autism spectrum disorder (ASD). Still, early screening efforts have focused on identifying autism risk in children under age 3. To create ASD interventions for infants and young children on the basis of evidence-based characteristics, the present article presents the results of a systematic literature search and effect size analysis of effective interventions for infants and young children with other developmental disorders: those born at an early age, with or with developmental disorders. those at high risk for developmental impairments due to the presence of an associated biological or familial condition. A review of 32 controlled, high-quality experimental studies revealed that the most effective interventions routinely use a combination of four specific intervention procedures, including (1) parent involvement in the intervention, continuous parent coaching that focuses on both parent responsiveness and parent responsiveness. temporal characteristics, including cues and teaching families to provide infant interventions, (2) individualization according to each infant's developmental profile, (3) focusing on a broad range of learning goals rather than a narrow range, and (4) starting as early as risk. is detected and ensures that the intervention is more intense and long-lasting. These four characteristics of effective interventions for infants and young children with other developmental difficulties likely represent a solid foundation on which researchers and clinicians can create effective interventions for infants and young children at risk or affected by ASD.

title: Intervention development for the integration of traditional tobacco cessation interventions into routine CAM practice
abstract: BACKGROUND: Practitioners of complementary and alternative medicine (CAM) therapies are an important and growing presence in healthcare systems worldwide. A key question is whether evidence-based behavior change interventions routinely used in traditional health care can also be integrated into CAM practice to address public health priorities. Essential for successful integration are intervention approaches that are acceptable and consistent with the practice patterns and treatment approaches of different CAM practitioners – that is, they have contextual validity. Intervention development to ensure context validity was an integral part of Project CAM Reach (CAMR), a project that examines the public health potential of tobacco cessation education for chiropractors, acupuncturists, and massage therapists (CAM practitioners). This article describes the formative research conducted to achieve this goal. METHODS: Intervention development undertaken in the three CAM disciplines (chiropractic, acupuncture, massage therapy) consisted of six iterative steps: 1) exploratory key informant interviews"; 2) local CAM practitioner community survey; 3) Demonstrating current tobacco cessation curriculum with TAT practitioner physicians 4) adaptation/adaptation of existing curriculum 5) external review of adaptations 6) delivery of CAM specific curriculum to CAM practitioners with follow-up curriculum evaluation RESULTS: CAM practitioners identified barriers and facilitators to addressing tobacco use with patients/clients and saw the relevance and acceptability of intervention content Intervention development process took care of their real-world intervention concerns Comprehensive intervention appropriate to the context of each CAM discipline found unnecessary Participants and consultants from all CAM disciplines embraced the training content, broad relevance and practice across the three CAM dis its rope. All findings informed the final intervention. CONCLUSIONS: The participatory and iterative formative research process provided a context-valid intervention in real-world CAM practices: 1) it is patient/client-centered and emphasizes the practitioner's role in the healing relationship; 2) are sensitive to the different contexts of CAM practitioners' work and patient/client relationships; 3) integrates relevant best practices from the US Public Health Service Clinical Practice Guidelines for the treatment of tobacco addiction" and 4) conforms to the diverse healing philosophies, scope of practice, and practice patterns found in participating CAM practitioners. Full CAMR study to evaluate the impact of CAMR intervention on the clinical behavior of CAM practitioners continues.

title: Intervention for autistic spectrum disorders
abstract: comprehensive approach to the assessment of any child with autism must be tailored to each child and family. This premise applies to psychopharmacological interventions as well as medical treatments and special education services. Behavioral therapy, as opposed to pharmacological, is the hallmark of effective intervention for autism. Physicians caring for children with autism need to be familiar with the education law and intervention recommendations. Goals should include improved functional verbal and nonverbal communication and social skills, increased participation in developmentally appropriate activities, development of enhanced fine and gross motor skills and independent academic and organizational skills, as well as replacing problem behaviors with developmentally appropriate behaviors. Treating children with autism is difficult, but often necessary for chronic behavioral difficulties. In the absence of clear and available guidelines, we sought to use the evidence and clinical experience to propose an algorithm based on symptom clusters. Although children with autism are more sensitive to drugs at lower doses and more susceptible to side effects than other children, medical intervention can provide a significant improvement in quality of life for the child and family. Careful thought leading to accurate identification of target behaviors can appropriately guide better alternatives to the drug. Although these approaches are costly and time-consuming efforts, making such efforts is the only available way to improve potential outcomes for individuals with autism, as well as reduce lifetime societal costs for each individual.

title: Intervention mapping for the development of a strategy to implement insurance medicine guidelines for depression
abstract: BACKGROUND: This article describes the development of a strategy for implementing insurance medicine guidelines for depression. The use of guidelines aims to lead to a more transparent and uniform assessment of claimants with depressive symptoms. METHODS: The implementation strategy was developed using the Intervention Mapping (IM) method for alignment with insurance-medical practice. The ASE behavioral explanation model (Attitude, Social Impact and Self-efficacy) was used as the theoretical basis for the development study. A literature study on implementation strategies and interviews with insurance physicians were conducted to develop tools to be used with the guideline. These instruments are designed to suit the needs and working conditions of insurance physicians. Performance indicators were defined with input from insurance physicians to measure the quality of assessment and adherence to guidelines. CONCLUSIONS: This study resulted in the development of a training course to teach insurance physicians how to apply depression guidelines using the tools mentioned above. The effectiveness of this training course will be evaluated in the Randomized Controlled Trial. CONCLUSIONS: The use of IM has made it possible to develop guidance support tools adapted to insurance medical practice.

title: Interventions by Health Professionals Providing Routine Child Health Care to Reduce Child Tobacco Smoke Exposure: A Review and Meta-analysis
abstract: IMPORTANCE: Reducing children's exposure to tobacco smoke is a public health priority. The guidelines recommend that health professionals in child health settings address the issue of exposure to tobacco smoke (TSE) in children. OBJECTIVE: To determine the effectiveness of interventions by health professionals providing routine child health care in reducing TSI in children. DATA SOURCES: A secondary analysis of the 57 studies included in the 2014 Cochrane review followed by an extended search. Controlled trials (published up to June 2015) of interventions focused on reducing child TSE were identified, without any restrictions on who did the interventions. Secondary data extraction was carried out in August 2015. STUDY SELECTION: Eligible for inclusion in this review and meta-analyses that address the consequences of concern (child TSE reduction and parental smoking behaviors) regarding routine child health care provided by healthcare professionals (doctors, nurses, medical assistants, health educators, and dietitians). . DATA ATTRACTION AND SYNTHESIS: Study details and quality characteristics were derived independently by 2 authors. If outcome measures were similar enough, meta-analysis was performed using DerSimonian and Laird's random effects model. Otherwise, the results are explained narratively. MAIN RESULTS AND MEASURES: The primary outcome measure was reduction in child TSE. The secondary outcomes of interest were parental smoking cessation, parental smoking cessation, and mother's postpartum relapse prevention. RESULTS: Sixteen studies met selection criteria. A narrative analysis of 6 studies measuring child TSE showed no intervention effects relative to the comparison groups. Similarly, a meta-analysis of 9 studies measuring parental smoking cessation showed no overall intervention effect (n = 6399) (hazard ratio 1.05"; 95% CI, 0.74-1.50; P = .78). Data measuring post-smoking relapse prevention showed a significant overall intervention effect (n = 1293) (hazard ratio 1.53; 95% CI, 1.10-2.14; "P = .01). The high level of study heterogeneity likely resulted from variability in outcome measures, follow-up time, intervention strategies, and unknown intervention accuracy. RESULTS AND RELATIONSHIP: Interventions by healthcare professionals providing routine child health care can be effective in preventing relapse in maternal smoking. More research is needed to improve the effectiveness of such interventions in reducing child TSE and increasing parental smoking cessation. The findings of this meta-analysis have policy and practice implications for routine pediatric healthcare professional interventions aimed at reducing children's exposure to tobacco smoke.

title: Interventions for adolescent depression in primary care
abstract: Background: Depression in adolescents is underrecognized and undertreated despite its poor long-term consequences, including increased risk of suicide. Primary care settings may be critical places for defining depression, but little is known about the usefulness of primary care interventions. OBJECTIVE: We sought to examine the evidence for the treatment of depression in primary care settings, focusing on the evidence for psychosocial, educational, and/or supportive intervention strategies. METHODS: Available data on brief psychosocial treatments for adolescent depression in primary settings were reviewed. Given the paucity of direct studies, we also drew on the relevant literature to summarize the available evidence on whether short-term, psychosocial support from a member of the primary care team can improve depression outcomes with or without medication.
