RESULTS: We identified 37 studies on the treatment of adolescent depression in primary care. Only 4 studies have directly examined the impact of primary care-provided psychosocial interventions on adolescent depression, but they suggest that such interventions may be effective. Indirect evidence from other psychosocial/behavioral interventions, including anticipatory guidance and efforts to improve adherence, and adult depression studies also demonstrate the benefits of primary care-provided interventions alongside the impact of provider training to improve psychosocial skills. CONCLUSIONS: Given the evidence that short-term psychosocial support with or without medication improves a range of outcomes, including adolescent depression itself, there is potential for successful treatment of adolescent depression in primary care. Given the major public health challenge posed by adolescent depression, the likelihood that many depressed adolescents are unable to receive specialized services, and new guidelines for managing adolescent depression in primary care, clinicians may usefully consider initiating supportive interventions in primary care settings.

title: Interventions for thromboprophylaxis in hospitalized medical and surgical patients at risk for venous thromboembolism
abstract: OBJECTIVE: Venous thromboembolism (VTE) is the leading cause of morbidity and mortality in hospitalized patients. Numerous randomized controlled trials (RCTs) demonstrate that the use of thromboprophylaxis in hospitalized patients at risk for VTE is safe, effective, and cost-effective. Despite this, prophylactic treatments for VTE are underused. System-wide interventions to improve the use of VTE prophylaxis may be more effective than relying on the prescribing behavior of individual providers. OBJECTIVES: To evaluate the effects of interventions designed to increase the administration of thromboprophylaxis in hospitalized adult medical and surgical patients at risk for venous thromboembolism (VTE) in order to: 1. Increase in the proportion of patients receiving prophylaxis and appropriate prophylaxis 2. Reduction in the risk of symptomatic VTE3. Decreased risk of asymptomatic VTE4. The security of the intervention. SEARCH METHODS: Cochrane Peripheral Vascular Diseases Group Research Coordinator (TSC), we searched the Group's Private Registry (last searched July 2010) and the Cochrane Central Registry of Controlled Trials (CENTRAL, The Cochrane Library) 2010, Issue 3. PubMed, EMBASE, and SCOPUS databases (April 19, 2010) and reference lists of related review articles. SELECTION CRITERIA: We included all studies with interventions aimed at increasing the use of prophylaxis and/or appropriate prophylaxis in hospitalized adult patients, reducing the rate of symptomatic VTE or asymptomatic VTE. We excluded studies that simply distributed published guidelines and studies whose interventions were not clearly identified. DATA COLLECTION AND ANALYSIS: We collected the following results: proportion of patients receiving prophylaxis (RP), proportion of patients receiving appropriate prophylaxis (RAP) (primary outcomes), and outcomes such as symptomatic VTE occurrence, asymptomatic VTE, and safety bleeding. We classified the interventions as education, warnings, and multifaceted interventions. With random effects meta-analysis, we meta-analyzed RCTs and nonrandomized studies (NRS) separately and evaluated heterogeneity using I(2)statistics and subgroup analysis. Prior to analysis, we decided that if three or more studies were available for a particular intervention, the results would be aggregated. We evaluated publication bias using funnel plots and cumulative meta-analysis. MAIN RESULTS: We included a total of 55 studies. One of these data was reported as patient-days and could not be quantitatively analyzed with the others. The 54 studies (8 RCTs and 46 NRS) that remained eligible for inclusion in our quantitative synthesis enrolled a total of 78,343 participants. Among the RCTs, there was sufficient data to pool the results for a primary outcome (prophylaxis received) for the 'warning' intervention. Alerts, such as computerized reminders or stickers in patient charts, were associated with a 13% risk difference (RD) (95% confidence interval (CI) 1% to 25%), indicating an increase in the proportion of patients receiving prophylaxis. ). Among the NRS, there was sufficient data to combine both primary outcomes for each type of intervention. The pooled risk differences for prophylaxis received ranged from 8% to 17%, and for appropriate prophylaxis received, from 11% to 19%. Education and warnings were associated with statistically significant increases in prescribing appropriate prophylaxis, and multiple interventions were associated with statistically significant increases in prescribing any prophylaxis and appropriate prophylaxis. Multiple interventions had the greatest combined effects. The I(2) results showed significant statistical heterogeneity, explained in part by patient types and hospital type. A subgroup analysis showed that multifaceted interventions with a warning may be more effective at improving rates of prophylaxis and appropriate prophylaxis than those without a warning. Results for VTE and safety outcomes did not show significant benefits or harms, but most studies were insufficient to evaluate these outcomes. AUTHOR'S CONCLUSIONS: We reviewed a large number of studies applying various system-wide strategies aimed at improving thromboprophylaxis rates in many settings and patient populations. We found statistically significant improvements in prophylaxis prescription associated with alerts (RCTs) and multiple interventions (RCTs and NRS), and improvements in appropriate prophylaxis prescription in NRS with the use of education, alerts, and multiple interventions. Multifaceted interventions with a warning component may be most effective. The sources of heterogeneity shown included patient types and hospital type. The results of our review will help physicians, nurses, pharmacists, hospital administrators and policy makers make practical decisions on the local adoption of specific system-wide measures to improve the prevention of VTE, a major public health problem. We found no significant benefit for VTE results";" however, previous RCTs evaluating the efficacy of thromboprophylaxis and powering these results have demonstrated the benefit of prophylactic treatments and a favorable balance of benefit against the increased risk of bleeding events.

title: Interventions to increase patients' trust in doctors and physician groups
abstract: BACKGROUND: Trust is an essential component of the patient-doctor relationship and is associated with increased satisfaction, adherence to treatment, and continuity of care. It is unclear whether there are interventions that are known to be effective in increasing patient confidence in doctors. OBJECTIVES: To evaluate the effects of interventions aimed at increasing the patient's confidence in the doctor or a group of doctors. SEARCH STRATEGY: We searched the Cochrane Central Register of Controlled Trials (The Cochrane Library Issue 1 2003), MEDLINE(1966 - week 4 2003), EMBASE (1985 - July 2003), Health Star (1975 - July 2004), PsycINFO (1967) . July 2004), CINAHL (1982 - June 2003), LILACS (1982 - April 2003), African Trials Register (1948 - April 2003), African Health Anthology (1924 - April 2003), Dissertation Abstracts International (1861 - April 2003), and bibliographies of studies considered for inclusion. We also searched for bibliographies of studies considered for inclusion and contacted researchers active in the field. SELECTION CRITERIA: Randomized controlled trials (RCTs), controlled clinical trials, pre- and post-controlled trials, and interrupted time series studies of interventions (informative, educational, behavioral, organizational) for physicians or patients (or caregivers), where trust is assessed primary or secondary outcome. DATA COLLECTION AND ANALYSIS: Two review authors independently assessed the quality of the study and extracted data. KEY RESULTS: Three RCTs, all published in English and set in North American primary care, and involving 1916 participants were included. There was considerable heterogeneity in the aims, format and content of the interventions. A trial of an educational intervention to improve family physicians' communication behaviors (20 physicians evaluated by 414 patients) showed no effect on trust. The other two interventions were patient-focused. One investigated the effect on trust of explaining physician incentives to patients (n= 918) in a Health Care Organization (HMO) and did not show a decrease in trust. Another investigated the effect of induction visits on the confidence of new HMO members (n=564) in HMO doctors. Confidence in physicians increased after visit for some type of induction visit compared to control, group visit (confidence out of 10 (standard deviation (SD)) 8.8 (1.5) and 7.1 (2.2), difference 1.7, ( 95% confidence) range from 1.22 to 2.18)). However, there were many dropouts and the analysis was not intended to cure. AUTHORS' CONCLUSIONS: Overall, there is insufficient evidence to conclude that any intervention can increase or decrease confidence in physicians. More trials are needed to explore the impact of policy changes, guidelines, and training of specific physicians on patients' trust.

title: Interventions for migraine prophylaxis: an umbrella systematic review protocol and network meta-analysis
abstract: INTRODUCTION: Multiple interventions are effective in migraine prophylaxis. However, the comparative effectiveness of these interventions is still unclear. Therefore, the purpose of this study is to summarize the direct and indirect evidence for pharmacological and non-pharmacological interventions to prevent migraine attack. METHODS AND ANALYSIS: We will conduct an umbrella systematic review to identify appropriate randomized controlled trials (RCTs) for interventions recommended for migraine prophylaxis according to guidelines. A comprehensive literature review will be conducted in MEDLINE, EMBASE and the Cochrane library for systematic reviews to be screened for RCTs. We will describe the general information of RCTs for participants, interventions, outcome measures, comparisons, and primary findings. In addition, a network meta-analysis will be performed to determine the comparative effectiveness of treatments with a random effects model. Absolute and relative effectiveness of treatments will be ensured. Heterogeneity and inconsistency between trials will be assessed with the I(2) statistical test and Cochrane's Q test. The risk of bias will be assessed and the overall strength of the evidence will be summarized. CONCLUSION: The outcome of this network meta-analysis will provide direct and indirect evidence of treatments for migraine prophylaxis and may provide a ranking of treatments to help patients and clinicians choose the best option. TRIAL REGISTRATION NUMBER: PROSPPERO CRD42015015297.

title: Interventions that change clinician behavior: mapping the literature
Interventions to modify obstetrician behavior to promote weight-related support for obese pregnant women: a systematic review.
abstract: BACKGROUND: There has been a rapid increase in the publication of guidelines for managing obesity and weight gain in pregnancy over the past five years. Health professionals have identified many barriers to this practice area, including the need to improve communication skills, beliefs that pregnant women will have negative reactions to weight-related discussions, and a lack of weight management knowledge. This systematic review aimed to determine: the effectiveness of interventions in changing the practice of health professionals regarding maternal obesity or weight management during pregnancy”; and what behavior modification techniques and forms of intervention have been used in interventions to date. RESULTS: The search strategy included electronic databases, trial registries, and citation search. Inclusion criteria were intervention studies aimed at changing healthcare professionals' practices regarding maternal obesity or weight management. Searches identified 3,608 trials. However, no eligible completed studies were identified. A registered Canadian randomized controlled trial was identified. Trial to support compliance with gestational weight gain guidelines It includes an educational intervention for family physicians with the aim of the current focus is on changing the behavior of pregnant women. These interventions do not address multiple health professionals' barriers to maternal obesity and weight management practice. More research is needed to identify the most effective approaches to support healthcare professionals in implementing maternal obesity and weight management guidelines.

title: Interventions to improve follow-up for abnormal findings in cancer screening
abstract: The potential reduction in morbidity and mortality through cancer screening cannot be achieved without appropriate follow-up care for abnormalities detected through screening. In this article, the authors critically review the existing literature on correlations in receiving appropriate follow-up care for abnormalities detected on screening, as well as on interventions designed to increase rates of receiving follow-up care. Lessons learned identify what is known and what is unknown about factors that predict or relate to the receipt of follow-up care. Similarly, effective interventions to increase follow-up are identified and gaps identified. A conceptual model has been developed that categorizes the healthcare system in the United States into four levels: policy, practice, provider, and patient. Some patient-level factors influencing follow-up recruitment are identified, but lack of data severely limits understanding of provider, practice, and policy level correlations. Most intervention studies to increase follow-up uptake have focused on patient-level factors and have targeted the follow-up of abnormal Papanicolaou smears. There is insufficient information on the effectiveness of interventions at the provider, practice or policy level. Standard definitions of what constitutes appropriate follow-up are lacking, severely limiting the comparability of findings between studies. The validity of the various methods for obtaining outcome data has not been clearly established. More research is needed on interventions that target provider, system, and policy-level factors, particularly those focused on the follow-up of colorectal and breast abnormalities. Standardization of definitions and measures is necessary to facilitate comparisons between studies. Cancer 2004. Published by the American Cancer Society in 2004.

title: Interventions to increase hospital patient satisfaction with healthcare providers and systems: a systematic review
abstract: Background Many hospital systems seek to increase patient satisfaction, as assessed by the Hospital Consumer Assessment of Healthcare Providers and Systems (HCAHPS) surveys. A systematic review of the available experimental evidence could inform these efforts and is not yet available. Methods We conducted a systematic review of the literature by scanning electronic databases including MEDLINE and EMBASE, six databases of the Cochrane Library, and gray literature databases. We included studies involving hospital patients with interventions targeting at least one of the 11 HCAHPS domains and meeting our quality filter score on the 27-item Downs and Black coding scale. We calculated the post hoc power when appropriate. Results A total of 59 studies met the inclusion criteria, of which 44 did not meet the 50% quality filter (mean quality rating 27.8Â±10.9%). Of the 15 studies (mean quality rating 67.3Â±10.7%) that met the quality filter, 8 included the Communication with Doctors HCAHPS domain, 6 General Hospital Rating, 5 Communication with Nurses, 5 Pain Management, 5 Goal It aimed at communication. About Medications, 5 target Recommend Hospital, 3 target Hospital Environment Quiet, 3 target Hospital Environment Cleanliness, and 3 target Discharge Information. Significant HCAHPS improvements were reported with the eight interventions, but their generalizability may be limited by narrowly focused patient populations, heterogeneity of the approach, and other methodological concerns. Conclusions Although there are several studies showing some improvement in the HCAHPS score through various interventions, we conclude that more rigorous research is needed to identify effective and generalizable interventions to increase patient satisfaction.

title: Interventions to increase the use of electronic health information by health practitioners to improve clinical practice and patient outcomes
abstract: BACKGROUND: A wealth of health information is available and, if applied in clinical practice, can contribute to effective patient care. Despite the abundance of information, suboptimal care is common. Many factors influence practitioners' use of health information, and the format (electronic or other) may be one such factor. OBJECTIVES: To evaluate the effects of interventions aimed at improving or increasing health practitioners' use of electronic health information (EHI) on professional practice and patient outcomes. SEARCH METHODS: We searched The Cochrane Library (Wiley), MEDLINE (Ovid), EMBASE (Ovid), CINAHL (EBSCO) and LISA (EBSCO) up to November 2013. We contacted researchers in this field and searched the reference lists of relevant articles. . SELECTION CRITERIA: We included studies that evaluated the effects of interventions to improve or increase EHI use by healthcare practitioners on professional practice and patient outcomes. We defined EHI as information accessed from a computer. We defined 'use' as logging into the EHI. We considered any health practitioner interested in patient care. Including randomized, non-randomized and cluster randomized controlled trials (RCTs, NRCTs, CRCTs), controlled clinical trials (CCTs), interrupted time series (ITS), and controlled before and after studies (CBAs) we did. : electronic and printed health information"; EHI on different electronic devices (e.g. desktop, laptop or tablet computers, etc.; mobile / mobile phones); EHI through different user interfaces; EHI with or without an education or training component;" and EHI compared to any other type or source of information. DATA COLLECTION AND ANALYSIS: Two review authors independently extracted data and assessed the risk of bias for each study. We used GRADE to assess the quality of the included studies. Following our decision to define admissions to the EHI as a measure of professional behavior, we reassessed previously excluded studies. We reported the results in natural units. Whenever possible, we calculated and reported the median effect size (odds ratio (OR), interquartile range (IQR)). Meta-analysis was not possible due to the high heterogeneity between studies. MAIN RESULTS: We included two RCTs and four CRCTs involving 352 physicians, 48 residents, and 135 allied health practitioners. The overall risk of bias and the quality of evidence were low. One comparison was supported by three studies and three comparisons were supported by one study, but results were highly heterogeneous between the three studies. We did not find any studies supporting EHI, although there is no alternative. Given these factors, it was not possible to determine the relative effectiveness of interventions. All studies reported practitioners' use of EHI, two reported on compliance with electronic practice guidelines, and none reported on patient outcomes. One trial (139 participants) measured adherence to guideline for the electronic guide versus the printed guide, but reported no difference between groups (median OR 0.85, IQR 0.74 to 1.08). One small crossover trial (10 participants) reported increased use of clinical guidelines when mobile and fixed desktop computers were provided (mean use per shift: intervention group (IG) 3.6, standard deviation (SD) 1.7, and control group (CG) 2.0 (SD 1.9) , P-value = 0.033). One crossover trial (203 participants) reported that using a customized interface versus a generic interface had little effect on practitioners' use of EHI (mean difference in adjusted end-of-study rate: 0.77 logins/month/users, 95% confidence interval (CI) CI 0.43 to 1.11). Three studies included education or training and reported increased use of EHI by practitioners after training. AUTHORS' CONCLUSIONS: While this review suggests that EHI use increases when practitioners are provided with EHI and education or training, it provided no evidence that EHI use translates into improved clinical practice or patient outcomes. We have defined use as the activity of logging into an EHI resource, but based on our findings, use does not automatically translate into EHI practice in practice. While the use of EHI is an important component of evidence-based medicine, it alone is insufficient to improve patient care or clinical practice. For EHI to be applied in patient care, it will be necessary to understand why practitioners are reluctant to apply EHI when treating people, and to identify the most effective way(s) to reduce this reluctance.

title: Interventions to change healthcare provider adherence to asthma guidelines: a systematic review.
abstract: BACKGROUND AND OBJECTIVE: Health care provider compliance with asthma guidelines is poor. The purpose of this study was to evaluate the impact of interventions to improve healthcare providers' adherence to asthma guidelines on the healthcare process and clinical outcomes. METHODS: Data sources included Medline, Embase, Cochrane CENTRAL Register of Controlled Trials, Cumulative Index to Nursing and Allied Health Literature, Educational Resources Information Center, PsycINFO, and, through July 2012, the Research and Development Resource Base in Continuing Medical Education. Independently matched investigators evaluated study relevance. Investigators abstracted the data sequentially and independently graded the evidence. RESULTS: Sixty-eight eligible studies were classified according to intervention: decision support, organizational change, feedback and supervision, clinical pharmacy support, education only, payment for quality improvement/performance, multicomponent and information only. Half were randomized trials (n = 35). There was moderate evidence of increased supervisory drug prescriptions and clinical pharmacy support for decision support, feedback, and supervision, and low-grade evidence for institutional change and multi-component interventions. Moderate evidence supports the use of decision support and clinical pharmacy interventions to increase provision of patient self-education/asthma action plans. Moderate evidence supports the use of decision support tools to reduce ED visits, and low-grade evidence suggests no benefit for this outcome with organizational change, training only, and payment for quality improvement/performance. CONCLUSIONS: Decision support tools, feedback and supervision, and clinical pharmacy support were most likely to improve providers' adherence to asthma guidelines, as measured by health care process outcomes. There is a need to evaluate healthcare provider-targeted interventions with standardized outcomes.

title: Interventions to promote evidence-based care for children with ADHD in primary care
abstract: Attention deficit/hyperactivity disorder (ADHD) is a common behavioral disorder among children. Community-based doctors are often the primary care providers for children with ADHD. A set of consensus guidelines has been published by the American Academy of Pediatrics that provides best practice diagnostic procedures for primary care physicians. These recommendations highlight the importance of using the Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders, Fourth Edition criteria as the basis for diagnosing ADHD and conducting systematic follow-up, including the collection of parent and teacher rating scales to quantitatively assess response to treatment. Despite the widespread dissemination of these recommendations and active support for their adoption, overall compliance with the guideline is known to be poor. Two types of intervention models, ancillary service and office system modification, have been proposed to encourage the adoption of evidence-based ADHD practice in primary care settings. This article reviews the effectiveness of these intervention models and discusses the cost and sustainability of each model in relation to the feasibility of expanding the intervention.

title: Internal conflicts of interest in clinical research: need for disclosure
abstract: Protecting human subjects from researchers' conflicts of interest is critical to the integrity of clinical research. Personal financial conflicts of interest are addressed by university policies, professional society guidelines, public standards, and government regulations, but "internal conflicts of interest" - conflicts of interest found in all clinical research - have received relatively little attention. Such conflicts arise in all clinical research efforts as a result of the tension between professionals' responsibilities to their research and their patients, and both academic and financial incentives. These conflicts should be disclosed to research subjects and managed with as much care as financial conflicts of interest.

title: Introduction: Understanding and influencing multilevel factors throughout the cancer care process
abstract: While healthcare services in the United States fail to provide the care recommended in published guidelines, it is notoriously expensive. Therefore, there is a need to consider our approach to healthcare delivery. Cancer care is a good example to consider because it covers the continuum of health care issues from primary prevention to long-term survival and end-of-life care. In this monograph, we emphasize that healthcare delivery takes place in a multi-level system that includes organisations, teams and individuals. To achieve healthcare delivery that aligns with the Institute of Medicine's six quality objectives (safety, effectiveness, timeliness, efficiency, patient-centredness, and equity), we need to influence multiple levels of this multi-level system. The idea that multiple levels of contextual influence influence behavior through interdependent interactions is a well-established ecological view. This view has been used to analyze health care delivery and health inequalities. However, the experience of considering multilevel interventions in healthcare is much less robust. This monograph contains 13 chapters on expanding the research base for multilevel interventions in healthcare delivery. Topics include clinical multilevel thinking cases in health care delivery, knowledge of multilevel interventions, study design and measurement considerations, methods of combining interventions, time taken into account in assessing impacts, measuring impacts, simulations, practice multilevel thinking about health systems and inequalities, and Enforcement of the Affordable Care Act 2010. Our aim is to establish an agenda to continue multilevel intervention research not because it warrants improvement in our current approach to healthcare, but because it warrants improvement in our current approach to healthcare. The complexity of the multilevel environment in which care takes place did not provide the desired improvements in the quality of care outlined by the Institute of Medicine at the turn of the millennium.

title: Exploring breast symptoms in primary care: increasing compliance with best available recommendations
abstract: The aim of this study was to determine whether a targeted intervention could improve primary care practitioners' compliance with guidelines for the management of women with breast symptoms. One hundred and twelve practitioners from randomly selected sites across Australia prospectively supervised their research for each woman with a new breast symptom over two 12-week periods before and five months after the national guidelines were published. Between the two audits, physicians received feedback on their colleagues' practices and attended a seminar led by experts from the Royal Australasian College of Physicians and the Royal Australasian College of Surgeons in their local area. For the five recommendations, there were statistically significant improvements at the second visit, in accordance with standard Investigation of New Breast Symptom (INBS) guidelines. All this was for the investigation of breast masses. At the first audit, there were seven recommendations where practitioners already managed more than 80% of women according to the INBS, and at the second audit there were no statistically significant increases in compliance. The other six recommendations were in lower agreement with the recommendations prior to the release of the guidelines and did not improve significantly at the second audit. These tended to be for conditions that were less common and clinical findings were not consistent with other test results. We conclude that a targeted intervention improves physician compliance with best available advice for investigating women presenting in primary care with new breast symptoms. More education programs are needed to improve research on rarer symptoms and increase physicians' confidence in the results of their clinical examinations.

title: Is it possible to predict improved diabetes outcomes following diabetes self-management education: mixed methods longitudinal design.
abstract: OBJECTIVE: To predict diabetes outcomes of people participating in the Type 2 Diabetes Self-Management Education (DSME) program from baseline data. DESIGN: A mixed method longitudinal experimental study. 6 practice nurses and 2 clinical academics undertook blinded assessments of all baseline and process data to predict clinical, behavioral, and psychological outcomes at 6 months after the DSME program. SETTING: Primary care. PARTICIPANTS: -31 people with type 2 diabetes who have not had DSME before. INTERVENTION: All participants undertook the Diabetes Manual 1:1 self-directed learning 12-week DSME program supported by practice nurses trained as Diabetes Manual facilitators. OUTCOME VARIABLES: Glucose hemoglobin (HbA1c), diabetes knowledge, physical activity, waist circumference, self-efficacy, diabetes distress, anxiety, depression, demographics, change talk, and treatment satisfaction. These variables were chosen because they are known to influence self-management behavior or be influenced by a DSME program based on empirical evidence. RESULTS: Baseline and 6-month follow-up data were available for 27 participants, 13 (48%) male, 22 (82%) white British, mean age 59 years, and mean type 2 diabetes duration 9.1 years. Significant reductions were found in HbA1c t(26)=2.35, p=0.03 and diabetes distress t(26)=2.30, p=0.03 and significant increase in knowledge t(26)=-2.06, p=0.05 from baseline, and 6 months. No significant changes were found in waist circumference, physical activity, anxiety, depression, or self-efficacy. The accuracy of the estimates varied slightly between clinical academics and practice nurses, but greatly between outcome (0-100%). The median and mode accuracy of the predicted outcome was 66.67%. The accuracy of the prediction for the key outcome of HbA1c was 44.44%. Diabetes distress had the highest prediction accuracy (81.48%). RESULTS: Clinicians in this small study were unable to identify individuals most likely to achieve improvement in outcomes from DSME. DSME should be introduced to all patients with diabetes, according to guidelines.

title: Is provider type associated with cancer screening and prevention: advanced practice registered nurses, physician assistants and physicians
abstract: BACKGROUND: Physician's recommendations for cancer screening and prevention are related to patient compliance. However, time constraints, especially with increasing demand from the Affordable Care Act in the United States, can limit doctors' ability to provide all recommended preventive services. Team-based practice involving advanced practice registered nurses and physician assistants (APRN/PA) can help meet this demand. This study explores the relationship between an APRN/PA visit and receiving cancer screening and prevention recommendations consistent with guidelines. METHODS: Data from the 2010 National Health Interview Survey were analyzed by multivariate logistic regression (n = 26,716) to assess the type of provider seen and the adoption of cancer screening and prevention recommendations consistent with guidelines. RESULTS: In adjusted analyses, women who had a primary care physician (PCP) and APRN/PA or a PCP without APRN/PA in the past 12 months were more likely to comply with cervical and breast cancer screening guidelines, did not see PCP or APRN/PA (for provider type). all p < 0.0001). Men and women who saw a PCP and an APRN/PA or a PCP without an APRN/PA were more likely than men and women who did not see to receive colorectal cancer screening and advice to quit smoking and engage in physical activity consistent with the guidelines. PCP or APRN/PA (all p < 0.01 for provider type). CONCLUSIONS: Seeing a PCP alone or in combination with an APRN/PA is associated with patient receiving cancer prevention and screening recommendations consistent with guidelines. Integrating APRN/PA into primary care can help provide cancer prevention and screening services. Further intervention research efforts are needed to explore how APRN/PA can best increase cancer screening, HPV vaccination and uptake of behavioral counseling, particularly during this time of health reform.

title: Is there a gap between recommended and 'real world' practices in teen depression management? Medical file control of the application
abstract: BACKGROUND: The literature has shown that distributing guidelines alone is insufficient to ensure that guideline recommendations are incorporated into daily clinical practice. METHODS: We aimed to explore the gaps between guideline recommendations and clinical practice in the management of youth with depression by undertaking oversight of medical files in a service area public mental health service for 15 to 25 year olds in Melbourne, Australia. RESULTS: The results showed that the assessment and recording of depression severity was not systematic and consistent to enable appropriate treatment planning";" that the majority of youth (74.5%) were prescribed an antidepressant prior to an adequate trial of psychotherapy, and less than 50% were followed for improvement of depression symptoms and suicidal behaviors (35% and 30%, respectively) induced by antidepressant treatment. 92% of first-line prescriptions for antidepressant naïves aged 18 years and younger were for fluoxetine, which was encouragingly recommended. CONCLUSIONS: This research highlighted the need for targeted strategies to ensure effective implementation. These strategies may include delivery system tools that allow for systematic monitoring of symptoms of depression and adverse side effects, particularly suicidal behavior. In addition, youth-specific psychotherapy, which includes the most effective ingredients for this age group and is presented in a youth-friendly way, will assist in the effective implementation of the guidelines recommendations for participation in an adequate trial of psychotherapy prior to initiation of medication.

title: Is non-targeted outreach visit effective in primary care? A pragmatic randomized controlled trial
abstract: BACKGROUND: There is increasing evidence that clinical guidelines can lead to improvements in clinical care. However, they do not apply on their own. Outreach visits can improve prescribing behavior. METHODS: Routine methods were used to distribute guidelines for the management of Helicobacter pylori eradication in a pragmatic randomized controlled trial before and after including all common practices in a health region. Intervention practices were offered a visit and an audit by a pharmacist trained in outreach visiting techniques. Intervention was assessed using level three Prescribing Analysis and Cost (PACT) data for metronidazole and omeprazole for two 12-month periods associated with the introduction of guidelines. RESULTS: Of the 38 intervention practices, 19 accepted the outreach visit and three accepted the supervision offer. There was a significant increase in omeprazole use during the dose-unit study of 0.24 [95 percent confidence interval (CI) +0.19 to +0.29] per year, but no effect from the proposal [-0.02 (95 percent CI -0.12 to +0.08) dose units] or acceptance of a visit [-0.03 (95 percent CI -0.15 to +0.08) dose units]. Results for metronidazole were similar, with an increase in use of 0.028 (95 percent CI +0.018 to +0.038) dose units per year. The effect of the intervention was a non-significant change in prescribing dose units of -0.005 (95 percent CI -0.025 to +0.015). Accepting a visit had little effect on prescribing: a 0.003 (95 percent CI -0.021 to +0.027) dose unit change. CONCLUSIONS: The routine use of non-targeted outreach visits is probably not a valuable strategy.

title: Issues related to the protection of human research participants
abstract: Making ethical decisions regarding the protection of human research participants is often complex and fraught with uncertainty and contradictions. An awareness of the fundamental principles outlined in the Belmont Report and in federal regulations and guidelines can provide a useful framework for such decisions, but the ultimate responsibility for ensuring ethical research practices rests with the individual researcher. Ongoing dialogue and discussion about these ethical issues will provide a foundation to strengthen nursing research and practice while providing maximum protection for research participants enabling the advancement of nursing science.

title: It is not my job to motivate hand hygiene among healthcare professionals by focusing on patients.
abstract: Diseases often spread in hospitals because healthcare workers do not wash their hands. Research shows that it is important to highlight personal consequences for the actor in order to increase health and safety behaviors. However, because people (and healthcare professionals in particular) tend to be overconfident about personal immunity, the most effective messages about hand hygiene may be those that emphasize its consequences for other people. In two field experiments in a hospital, we compared the effectiveness of hand hygiene signs that emphasize personal safety (“Hand hygiene prevents you from getting sick”) or patient safety (“Hand hygiene prevents patients from getting sick”). We evaluated hand hygiene by measuring the amount of soap and hand sanitizer gel used from dispensers (Experiment 1) and by making confidential, independent observations of healthcare professionals' hand hygiene behaviors (Experiment 2). The results showed that changing a single word in messages resulted in meaningful changes in behavior: Health care professionals' hand hygiene increased significantly when the implications for patients were reminded, but not when reminded of the consequences themselves.

title: Jarvis - Levine
abstract: KIE: The Minnesota Court of Appeals ruled that, subject to the professional judgment of public hospital doctors according to mandatory guidelines, an involuntary mentally ill patient has a qualified constitutional right to refuse neuroleptic treatment in a non-emergency situation. Upholds the trial court's decision that patient Jarvis was not entitled to post-drug review, as the due process requirements for administering neuroleptic drugs were met by compliance with the involuntary drug policy set by the Minnesota Department of Public Welfare.

title: JNC-7 guidelines: still valid?
abstract: The recommendations of the Seventh Report of the Joint National Committee on the Prevention, Detection, Evaluation and Treatment of Hypertension, published in 2003 (JNC 7) are largely valid today. Targeting blood pressure (BP) in hypertensive patients is of primary importance in reducing cardiovascular risk. Antihypertensive drugs vary in their effectiveness in lowering blood pressure and may have blood pressure-independent effects on cardiovascular events, particularly as seen in preventing heart failure and stroke. Thiazide-type diuretics have been recommended as the preferred starting agents for the treatment of hypertension in most patients, and this is still an appropriate recommendation. Several other classes were initially proposed, but beta-blockers should now have less of a role in the management of uncomplicated hypertension. While a new JNC report is reassuring for practitioners and should include some changes since JNC 7, I think most of the advice still applies today.

title: JOURNAL CLUB: Estimates of Provider's Response to Clinical Decision Support: Lessons Learned from the Medicare Imaging Demonstration
abstract: OBJECTIVE: The effectiveness of imaging clinical decision support (CDS) varies. Our aim was to identify the CDS factors that contributed to the cancellation or modification of the display order. SUBJECTS AND METHODS: This pre-post study was conducted among four institutions participating in the Medicare Imaging Demonstration. Intervention was CDS at order entry for selected outpatient imaging procedures. Based on the information entered, computerized alerts notified providers whether orders were within the guidelines, whether they were appropriate, of uncertain compliance, or if they were inappropriate according to professional society guidelines. The ordering providers can override or accept the CDS. We considered actionable alerts to be alerts that could produce an immediate ordering behavior change in the ordering physician (ie, cancellation of non-compliant orders or replacement of ambiguous orders with a suggested alternative). Chi-square and logistic regression identified predictors of order cancellation or change after a warning. RESULTS: A total of 98,894 radiology orders were entered (83,114 post-intervention). In response to the warnings, providers ignored 98.9%, changed 1.1%, and canceled 0.03% of orders. Actionable alerts were 10x higher change (8.1% vs 0.7%"; p < 0.0001) or cancellation (0.2% vs. 0.2%; p < 0.02%) compared to non-actionable alerts Seven times lower cancellation or change rate of orders from institutions with pre-imaging CDS than seen at sites with newly implemented CDS (1.4% vs. 0.2%; p < 0.0001) In multivariate analysis, actionable alerts were 12 times more likely to result in order cancellation or change 7.7 times less likely to be canceled or modified with pre-existing CDS (p < 0.0001.) RESULT: Provider imaging, using results from the Medicare Imaging Demonstration project We identified potential factors associated with the CDS effect in order of magnitude; these findings may have implications for the future design of such computerized systems.

title: Judgments on the normative behavior of health professionals: An experimental study
abstract: OBJECTIVES: To explore prescriptive behavioral judgments by healthcare professionals and the general public in the UK against a proliferating background of clinical guidelines and protocols. DESIGN: A questionnaire study was used in which short scenarios describing medical practice were presented to a sample of healthcare professionals and the general public. METHODS: The healthcare sample consisted of 315 nurses, doctors and midwives from three British National Health Service (NHS) Trusts who volunteered to participate in the study. A stratified sample (N = 350) of the general public was collected through a market research organization. Three types of behavior (compliance with protocol, violation of protocol, and improvisation in non-protocol) and three types of outcomes (good, bad, bad) for the patient were manipulated in nine scenarios. Participants were asked to make judgments about (1) the inappropriateness of the behavior, (2) the possibility of taking further action, and (3) the responsibility for the outcome. CONCLUSIONS: Findings show that the care process has a greater impact on judgments about the behavior of health professionals than the outcome of that behavior. This was equally true for professional and public examples. CONCLUSION: The study has both theoretical and practical results. First, knowledge of a behavior's relationship to existing rules has a stronger influence on the behavior's consequences on responsibility attributions. Second, using clinical protocols as a way to manage risk in the NHS can backfire unless full compliance is achieved.

title: Judicial Council presents new research guidelines
Reasonable use of antibiotics for common pediatric respiratory infections
abstract: BACKGROUND: Antibiotic resistance among common respiratory infection-producing bacteria such as Streptococcus pneumoniae, Haemophilus influenzae, and Moraxella catarrhalis has become a major global public health concern. The use of antibiotics, whether medically justified for a particular disease or not, contributes to the development of resistant bacteria. To help control the growth of drug-resistant bacteria, the CDC and members of the American Academy of Pediatrics (AAP) recently published guidelines on the judicious use of antibiotics in common pediatric respiratory infections, including the common cold, otitis media, sinusitis, and tonsillitis. . This article reviews the CDC/AAP guidelines for the management of these diseases and describes the results of clinical practice studies of efforts to improve the rational use of antibiotics. CONCLUSION: The success of CDC/AAP principles in containing the increase in antimicrobial resistance depends on their application. The results of clinical practice studies show that the wise use of antimicrobial therapy in pediatric respiratory infections can be achieved through education and persistence. More widespread education and behavior change efforts are needed to reduce unnecessary antibiotic prescription and reduce the still growing problem of bacterial resistance.

title: youth working hours
Just-in-time evidence-based email 'reminders' in home health care: impact on patient outcomes
abstract: OBJECTIVE: To evaluate the impact and cost-effectiveness of two knowledge-based provider reminder interventions designed to improve self-care management and outcomes for heart failure (HF) patients. DATA SOURCES/STUDY SETTING: Interview and institution administrative data on 628 home care patients with primary HF diagnosis. STUDY DESIGN: Patients were treated by nurses randomly assigned to usual care or to one of the two intervention groups. The key response was an email to the patient's nurse highlighting six clinical recommendations specific to HF. Augmented intervention supplemented the initial nurse reminder with additional clinician and patient resources. DATA COLLECTION: Patient interviews were conducted 45 days after admission to measure self-management behaviors, HF-specific outcomes (Kansas City Cardiomyopathy Questionnaire-KCCQ), health-related quality of life (EuroQoL), and service use. KEY FINDINGS: Both interventions improved the mean KCCQ summary score (15.3 percent and 12.9 percent, respectively) over usual care (p< or =.05). Baseline intervention also gave a higher EuroQoL score than usual care (p< or =.05). Additionally, the interventions had a positive impact on drug knowledge, diet, and weight tracking. The basic intervention was more cost-effective than the augmented intervention in improving clinical outcomes. CONCLUSION: This study demonstrates the positive effect of targeting evidence-based computer reminders to home health nurses to improve patient self-care behaviors, knowledge, and clinical outcomes. It also enhances the field's limited understanding of the cost-effectiveness of the strategies chosen to translate research into practice.

title: Just-in-time evidence-based email “reminders” in home health care: impact on patient outcomes.
abstract: Aim. To evaluate the impact and cost-effectiveness of two knowledge-based provider reminder interventions designed to improve self-care management and outcomes for heart failure (HF) patients. Data Sources/Work Setup. Interviews and institutional administrative data on 628 home care patients with primary HF diagnosis. Study design. Patients were treated by nurses randomly assigned to usual care or to one of the two intervention groups. The key response was an email to the patient's nurse highlighting six clinical recommendations specific to HF. Augmented intervention supplemented the initial nurse reminder with additional clinician and patient resources. Data collecting. Patient interviews were conducted 45 days after admission to measure self-management behaviors, HF-specific outcomes (Kansas City Cardiomyopathy Questionnaire-KCCQ), health-related quality of life (EuroQoL), and service use. Key Findings. Both interventions improved the mean KCCQ summary score (15.3 percent and 12.9 percent, respectively) over usual care (p=0.05). Baseline intervention also gave a higher EuroQoL score than usual care (p=.05). Additionally, the interventions had a positive impact on drug knowledge, diet, and weight tracking. The basic intervention was more cost-effective than the augmented intervention in improving clinical outcomes. Results. This study demonstrates the positive impact of targeting evidence-based computer reminders to home health nurses in improving patient self-care behaviors, knowledge, and clinical outcomes. It also enhances the field's limited understanding of the cost-effectiveness of the strategies chosen to translate research into practice.

title: Just-in-time evidence-based email 'reminders' in home health care: impact on 'nurse practice'.
abstract: Aim. To test the effectiveness of two interventions designed to improve adoption of evidence-based practice by home health nurses caring for heart failure (HF) patients. Data Sources/Work Setup. Information on nurse practice was obtained from clinical records of patients admitted to the care of 354 working nurses at a large, urban, nonprofit home care institution between June 2000 and November 2001. Study design. The study used a randomized design with nurses assigned to usual care or one of the two intervention groups upon identification of an eligible patient. The key intervention was a one-time email reminder highlighting six clinical recommendations specific to HF. The augmented response consisted of provider prompts, patient education material, and an initial email reminder backed by clinical nurse expert support. Data collecting. At each home health visit to an eligible HF patient by a study nurse during the 45-day follow-up period, a structured chart abstraction tool was used to gather information about whether the nurse provided the care practices highlighted in the email reminder. . Key Findings. Both basic and augmented interventions have greatly increased the practice of evidence-based care based on patient registries in the areas of patient assessment and instruction on HF disease management. Although not all results were statistically significant at traditional levels, intervention effects were positive in almost all cases and effect sizes were often large. Results. The results of this randomized trial strongly support the effectiveness of just-in-time evidence-based reminders as a means of changing clinical practice among geographically dispersed home health nurses who spend most of their time in the field.

title: Safe and Smoke-Free in Children (KiSS): A randomized controlled trial of a multilevel intervention to reduce exposure to secondhand tobacco smoke in children.
abstract: BACKGROUND: Exposure to secondhand smoke (SHSe) is detrimental to children's health, but effective interventions to reduce children's SSE at home and in the car have proven difficult to implement in pediatric practice. A multilevel intervention that combines referrals from pediatric healthcare providers to behavioral counseling and pharmacological cessation aids could improve control of SHSE in pediatric populations. METHODS/DESIGN: This trial uses a randomized, two-group design with three measurement periods: pre-intervention, end-of-treatment, and 12-month follow-up. Smoking parents of children under the age of 11 are recruited from children's clinics. Clinical-level intervention involves integrating tobacco intervention guide prompts into electronic health record screens. The guidelines guide providers to ask all parents questions about child SGS, advise about the harms of SGS, and refer smokers to cessation resources. Upon receiving the clinical intervention, eligible parents are randomized to receive: (a) a 3-month telephone-based behavioral counseling intervention designed to encourage reduction of child SSH, parental smoking cessation, and navigation to access nicotine replacement therapy or cessation medication; or (b) ) an attention control nutrition education intervention. Healthcare providers and evaluators are blind to group assignments. Cotinin is used to biologically verify the child's SSH (primary outcome) and parent's dropout status. DISCUSSION: This study tests an innovative, multi-level approach to reducing child SSI. The approach is sustainable because clinics can easily integrate tobacco response alerts with "ask, recommend, and refer" guidelines into electronic health records and refer smokers to free evidence-based behavioral counseling interventions, such as government quit lines. TRIAL REGISTRATION: NCT01745393 (clinicaltrials.gov).

title: Kindergarten readiness after prematurity: Integrating health, development and behavioral functioning to optimize the educational outcomes of vulnerable children
abstract: In the last 20 years, many advances (eg, maternal steroids and surfactant) have changed the course of neonatal medicine. As a result, infants born extremely prematurely survive medical complications that were previously fatal. After discharge from the neonatal intensive care unit, preterm infants can continue to experience a range of medical and developmental challenges, and their families are faced with the daunting task of feeding a vulnerable child. Families may be referred to multiple care systems, including primary care physicians, pediatric subspecialists, and early intervention services. The ultimate goal of preterm infants is to optimize their motor, communicative, social-emotional and adaptive development, as well as to encourage their learning at home, at school and in the community. As children move to school, key indicators of their functional status include the amount of developmental, educational, habilitative and behavioral support they need to participate in learning activities with their peers. Success can be measured by whether preterm infants are ready for large group learning with their peers and the extent of support needed to make this important transition. The purpose of this review is to explain what is known about certain indicators of school readiness in preterm infants, including neurodevelopmental disorders, social-emotional skills, and social factors. We conclude this transition with guidelines for using it as an important indicator of developmental trajectories that can help us better understand risk and resilience in this vulnerable child population.

title: Knowledge, attitudes and use of low-dose computed tomography for lung cancer screening among family physicians
abstract: BACKGROUND: The results of the National Lung Screening Trial showed a 20% reduction in lung cancer mortality and a 6.7% reduction in all-cause mortality when high-risk patients were screened with low-dose computed tomography (LDCT). (CXR). The U.S. Preventive Services Task Force has issued a class B recommendation for LDCT screening, and the Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services and private insurers now cover the cost of screening under certain circumstances. The aim of this study was to evaluate knowledge, attitudes, and use of LDCT screening for lung cancer among family physicians. METHODS: A 32-item questionnaire was distributed to members of the South Carolina Academy of Family Physicians in 2015. Descriptive statistics were calculated. RESULTS: There were 101 participants, and most had incorrect information about which organizations recommended screening. Many doctors continued to recommend CXR for lung cancer screening. Most felt that LDCT scanning increased the likelihood of detecting the disease at an earlier stage (98%) and the benefits outweighed the harms (75%). Concerns included unnecessary procedures (88%), stress/anxiety (52%), and radiation exposure (50%). Most physicians in some capacity discussed the risks/benefits of screening with their patients (76%), but more than 50% reported recommending 1 or no screening in the last year. High risk for lung cancer, but referrals remain low. Screening guidelines and feedback Gaps in physician knowledge about payment exist, suggesting the need for access to more education. Development of decision aids can facilitate shared decision-making discussions about screening, and targeted interventions can improve knowledge gaps Cancer 2016;"122:2324-2331. (c) 2016 American Cancer Society.

title: Knowledge translation of research findings
abstract: Background One of the most consistent findings from clinical and healthcare research is the failure to translate research into practice and policy. As a result of these evidence-practice and policy gaps, patients are not optimally exploited by advances in healthcare and are exposed to unnecessary risks of iatrogenic harm, and healthcare systems incur unnecessary expenditures resulting in significant opportunity costs. In the last decade, there has been increasing international policy and research interest in how to reduce the evidence-practice and policy gap. In this article, we summarize current concepts and evidence to guide knowledge translation activities, defined as T2 research (transformation of new clinical knowledge into better health). We structure the article around five key questions: what should be conveyed"; to whom should research knowledge be conveyed; by whom should research knowledge be conveyed; how should research knowledge be conveyed;" and with what effect should research knowledge be transferred? Discussion We suggest that the basic unit of knowledge translation should often be current systematic reviews or other syntheses of research findings. Knowledge translators need to identify key messages for different audiences and shape them into language and information translation products that can be easily assimilated by different audiences. The relative importance of knowledge translation for different audiences will vary with the type of research, and the appropriate endpoints of knowledge translation may differ between different stakeholder groups. There are many models of planned information translation derived from different disciplinary, contextual (i.e. setting) and audience perspectives. Most suggest that planned information translation for healthcare professionals and consumers is more likely to be successful if the choice of information translation strategy is informed by an assessment of potential barriers and facilitators. While our evidence for the possible effectiveness of different strategies to overcome specific barriers is lacking, there is an important (if incomplete) evidence base to guide the selection of information translation activities targeting healthcare professionals and consumers (eg, research use by policy makers). The evidence base for the effects of different approaches to information translation targeting policy makers and senior executives is much weaker, but there are many innovative approaches warranting further evaluation.

title: Information translation of the American College of Emergency Physicians' clinical policy on syncope using computerized clinical decision support.
abstract: OBJECTIVES: To influence physician practice behavior after implementation of a computerized clinical decision support system (CDSS) based on the recommendations in the 2007 ACEP Syncope Clinical Policy. METHODS: This was a post-post intervention with a prospective cohort and retrospective controls. We performed a medical picture review of consecutive adult patients with syncope. A computerized CDSS was embedded in the emergency room information system (EDIS) that prompted physicians to explain their decision regarding imaging and admission in syncope patients based on ACEP Clinical Policy recommendations. Medical records of 410 consecutive adult patients presenting with syncope were reviewed before the application and 301 records were reviewed after the application. The primary outcomes were physician practice behavior as indicated by the acceptance rate and head computed tomography (CT) imaging rate before and after administration. RESULTS: There was a significant difference in pre- and post-intervention acceptance rates (68.1% vs. 60.5%, respectively, p = 0.036). There was no significant difference in the rate of head CT imaging before and after the intervention (39.8% vs. 43.2%, p = 0.358). There were seven doctors who saw ten or more patients before and after the intervention. A subgroup analysis of the practice behavior of these seven physicians revealed a slight significant difference in pre- and post-intervention acceptance rates (74.3% vs. 63.9%, p = 0.0495), and there was no significant difference in pre- and post-intervention head CT scan rate. -intervention (42.9% vs. 45.4%, p = 0.660). CONCLUSIONS: The introduction of an evidence-based CDSS based on ACEP Clinical Policy recommendations on syncope is associated with a change in physician practice behavior in an urban academic emergency department. This change demonstrates that emergency medicine clinical practice guideline recommendations can be incorporated into the physician workflow of an EDIS to improve the quality of practice.

title: Knowledge versus practice: the necessity of education for successful guideline implementation
abstract: This study evaluated physicians' familiarity with a practice guideline for bronchiolitis, evaluated their attitudes towards the guidelines, determined the preference of educational materials for guideline accessibility, and examined the relationship between guideline familiarity and attitudes to clinical practice behaviors. Six months after the implementation of the guideline, questionnaires were distributed to eligible physicians. The response rate was 68%. Retrospective analyzes of inhalation therapies were also performed in the three study cohorts. Most physicians surveyed in this study were aware of and used a recently introduced guideline, although the use of unproven inhalation therapies continued. Despite proven maintenance efficiency, continuing education intervention is required to sustain these gains.

title: Knowledge, attitudes, and practices surrounding breast cancer screening in educated Appalachian women
abstract: OBJECTIVE/TARGET: To determine how and what women learn about breast cancer and screening practices, and what factors affect women's breast cancer screening practices. DESIGN: Descriptive analysis of survey data collected during enrollment in a clinical trial. SETTING: Breast care center of the Mid-Atlantic academic health sciences center. EXAMPLE: 185 women in a predominantly Appalachian, purely rural state. METHODS: Participants completed the Modified Toronto Breast Self-Exam Inventory and questions about personal mammography practices at enrollment prior to randomization in a longitudinal clinical intervention study. MAIN RESEARCH VARIABLES: Women's demographics, knowledge of breast cancer screening practices, adherence to breast cancer screening guidelines, and motivation, knowledge, and practice proficiency related to breast cancer screening. RESULTS: These educated women had a lack of knowledge about breast cancer, breast cancer risk factors and screening guidelines, especially timing of breast self-examination and practice behaviors. Women who received health care and cancer screening training by healthcare providers, including advanced practice nurses, had more knowledge about breast cancer and detection practices. CONCLUSION: Women still lack information about breast cancer, breast cancer detection and personal risk factors. Additionally, some educated women in this study failed to screen for breast cancer according to current guidelines. PRACTICES FOR NURSING: Practitioners should continue to remind and update women about breast diseases, and women's cancer screening practices should be strengthened. Providers at all levels should increase their rate of clinical breast examination with physical examination. Nurses, who greatly affect women's health care, should keep their knowledge of breast disease, screening and treatment up to date.

title: KRAS and colorectal cancer: ethical and pragmatic issues impacting real-time change in oncology clinical trials and practice
abstract: Systemic therapy led to a median survival of patients with advanced colorectal cancer (CRC) almost four times longer than would be expected with the best supportive care; this is a result obtained by combining chemotherapeutic and targeted biological agents. While the latter may contain anti-epidermal growth factor receptor antibodies such as cetuximab and panitumumab, we now have strong evidence that patients whose tumors harbor mutated KRAS will not benefit from this class of substances. It took several years for the reliability and importance of the KRAS data to be acknowledged, for a variety of reasons. Timeline from the presentation and publication of small, retrospective phase II studies to widespread acceptance of the predictive value of KRAS and behavior-specific changes, modifications of ongoing national trials in advanced/metastatic CRC, changes and adjustments in national guidelines and practice models, according to labeled indications for monoclonal antibodies it was long. In this review, we discuss whether the data disclosure process regarding KRAS status and treatment of advanced CRC patients is effective in allowing timely decision regarding ongoing publicly funded clinical trials, and whether such decisions are rational and ethical. The overall goals are to highlight lessons learned in the review and adoption of new scientific data, as well as early disclosure of clinical trial results, and suggest changes to deal with similar situations in the future.

title: Laboratory test form design influences test ordering by GPs in the Netherlands
abstract: The effect of listing fewer laboratory tests on the test request form on the test ordering behavior of a group of 47 Dutch GPs was examined. The number of laboratory tests ordered by this experimental group over a 12-month period was recorded. The usual, old standard form was used by a control group of 28 GPs at a different site. After using the old standard form containing 178 tests for 5 months, the experimental group was given forms containing only 15 hematological and chemical tests plus a few urine and stool tests, making room for "others". Comparison of the experimental and control periods showed that the number of tests ordered monthly decreased by 18 in the experimental group. When the usual standard form was reintroduced, GPs quickly reverted to their old models. The results revealed that the fixed and often unsound routine influences the use of additional diagnostic procedures. Additionally, limiting and reconfiguring test order forms may break the routine, but it does not fundamentally change the logic of test ordering behavior.

title: Lack of schedule reminder effectiveness on family medicine resident JNC-VI and NCEP III guideline knowledge and attitudes
abstract: BACKGROUND: The literature shows that medical residents and general practitioners have an attitudinal-behavioral mismatch regarding the positive attitudes towards clinical practice guidelines (CPG) and their application to clinical practice models. METHODS: A pilot study was conducted to determine whether a change in a predefined CPG compliance factor (accessibility) would result in a significant increase in family medicine resident knowledge and attitude towards guidelines. The primary study intervention included inserting a summary of the Joint National Committee on the Prevention, Detection, Evaluation, and Treatment of High Blood Pressure (JNC VI) Sixth Report and the National Cholesterol Education Program Expert Panel on the Detection, Evaluation, and Treatment of Blood Pressure. Adult High Blood Cholesterol (NCEP III) CPGs in all patient (>18 years) charts for a three-month period. JNC VI and NCEP III CPGs were also distributed to each Wayne State family medicine resident, and a copy of each CPG was placed in the instructor's area of their respective clinics. Regarding CPG knowledge and attitude, the same questionnaires were administered to all residents before and after the intervention. RESULTS: Post-intervention analysis failed to show any significant difference in CPG information. A statistically significant difference was found only in the attitude question after the intervention. Barriers to CPG compliance 1) lack of CPG instruction"; 2) lack of critical evaluation capability; 3) insufficient time; 4) lack of CPG accessibility;" and 5) lack of faculty modeling. CONCLUSION: This study showed that there was no significant change in CPG knowledge after intervention and only one question reflecting attitude change. Wider established access to private clinical time, increased faculty modeling, and implementation of an electronic record/reminder system using a team-based approach are compliance factors to be considered for further research. Interpretation of CPG non-compliance would benefit from a causal matrix focused on physician knowledge, attitudes, and behavior. Recent findings in established knowledge-behavior dissonance may steer future research of physician CPG mismatch away from generalized barrier research and towards the development of information that maximizes the individual practitioner's sense of urgency and certainty.

title: Late life depression in primary care. How good are we?
abstract: OBJECTIVE: To explore the attitudes of primary care physicians towards their ability to detect and treat depression in the elderly. DESIGN: A self-administered questionnaire sent to 1,000 primary care physicians in the state of Michigan. SETTING: The questionnaire was sent to physicians practicing general internal medicine or family medicine. PARTICIPANTS: The questionnaire was sent to 500 MD and 500 DO physicians"; general internal medicine and family medicine were given equal representation. 60% (n = 604) of 1000 physicians responded, 51% (n = 309) were MDs. , % 48 (n = 295) were DOs, 41% (n = 245) were general internists and 59% (n = 359) were family physicians MEASUREMENTS AND KEY RESULTS: Despite positive attitudes towards diagnosis and treatment skills depression in the elderly, only a quarter of respondents routinely used a screening tool in practice. Forty-one percent of all physicians were unaware of depression practice guidelines. Family physicians were more confident in their treatment skills than general internists (85%). vs 50%;" chi 2 = 11.42, p < or = .003). Male physicians more frequently favored pharmacological therapy, while female physicians more frequently used counseling and exercise techniques to treat depressed older patients. Half of all doctors felt knowledgeable about community resources for treating older depressed patients. RESULTS: This survey identified several perceived needs for future targeted interventions: (1) exposure to additional Healthcare Policy and Research Institute guidance for all primary care physicians, (2) targeted counseling skills intervention for male physicians, and medication management for female physicians. and (3) additional continuing medical education intervention for general internists. In order to fully understand the nature of older depression treatment in primary care, more research is needed to link physician attitudes with follow-up behaviors.

title: Learning and behaviour., 5th ed.
abstract: This book examines how humans and animals learn and how their behavior subsequently changes. This text is designed for introductory or intermediate courses in learning, conditioning or experimental behavior analysis. Chapter 1 discusses the nature of scientific theories and experiments and compares behavioral and cognitive approaches to learning. Chapter 2 explains the theories about the learning process. Chapters 3 and 4 discuss innate behaviors and habit and examine the basic principles of classical conditioning. Chapter 5 describes more recent theoretical developments and experimental findings in this area. Chapters 6, 7 and 8 include operant conditioning and examine positive reinforcement"; reinforcement schedules; and negative reinforcement and punishment, respectively. Chapter 9 offers different views on questions such as what constitutes reinforcement and what conditions are necessary for learning to occur. Chapter 10 , takes a more comprehensive look at generalization and discrimination, and examines research on concept formation. Chapter 11 examines a wide variety of findings in the field of comparative cognition. Chapters 12 and 13 discuss learning observational and motor skills. Finally, Chapter 14, behavioral on choice. provides an overview of research (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2016 APA, all rights reserved)

title: Learning Assessment: blending quality improvement and application research methods to examine innovations in health
abstract: Background In healthcare change interventions, on-site learning about the implementation process is often lost because of the primary focus on outcome improvements. This article describes Learning Assessment, a methodological approach that blends quality improvement and application research methods to examine innovations in healthcare. Methods Learning Assessment is an approach to multi-organizational assessment. Qualitative and quantitative data are collected to make real-time assessment of implementation processes as well as to evaluate changes in context, facilitate quality improvement using worksheets, supervision and feedback, and create portable lessons. The basis of this approach are five principles: (1) "collect data to describe changes made by healthcare organizations and how changes are implemented"; (2) collect process and outcome data on healthcare organizations and research team; (3) evaluate practice, process, outcome, and portability. Multi-level contextual factors affecting (4) help healthcare organizations use data for continuous quality improvement and (5) operationalize common measurement strategies to produce portable results (1) provide a detailed understanding of the current implementation plan; (2) target audiences identify and monitor relevant process measures; (3) collect and analyze real-time quantitative and qualitative data on key contextual factors; (4) synthesize and continually share data and emerging findings with stakeholders; and (5) harmonize learning from process and outcome data. to enable and encourage primary care and behavioral s Application to a multi-site program focused on network integration demonstrates the feasibility and utility of Learning Assessment for generating real-time insights into evolving implementation processes. Conclusions Learning Evaluation produces systematic and rigorous inter-organizational findings on the implementation of innovations in health, while also increasing institutional capacity and facilitating continuous learning at individual sites, accelerating the translation of findings. Researchers evaluating change initiatives and health organizations implementing improvement initiatives can benefit from the Learning Assessment approach.

title: Learning with computer guides in general practice? A Randomly Controlled Experiment.
abstract: Background. Evidence-based guidelines are seen as an important tool to transfer scientifically produced knowledge into daily clinical practice and to provide high standards of clinical care. Despite being widely publicized, clinical guidelines so far have had limited impact on individual professional learning and changing daily medical practice. targets. Our aim was to (i) examine a potential increase in knowledge among German GPs after the implementation of web and evidence-based guidelines, and (ii) identify and analyze potential barriers to individual professional learning with computerized guidelines. Methods A prospective randomized controlled trial was conducted involving 72 GPs (21% female, 79% male). The intervention group (n = 38) had access to clinical guidelines via the internet or CD-ROM, while the control group (n = 34) did not. Both groups received a standardized two-part questionnaire. Knowledge increase was measured with 25 multiple-choice questions on four different medical topics. In addition, the reasons for using or not using the computerized guides were analyzed after access to the guides was made available to all participating physicians. Results. There was no significant increase in knowledge in the intervention group (P = 0.69). Twenty-two (58%) practitioners of the intervention group used the guidelines. Unspecified curiosity (76%) and a specific medical question (38%) were the predominant reasons for use among physicians using the guidelines. Among 'non-users', 78% cited 'lack of time' as the main reason for not using the guides. Solution. An efficient information transfer could not be achieved through computerized guides. Use, individual learning and potential application depend on adequate incentives and pragmatic aspects of clinical practice: easy and fast access.

title: left-handedness
Legal responsibility of physicians in medical research
abstract: The purpose of this article is to provide an overview in layman's language of concepts in law applicable to a research physician. The paper is divided into 2 parts. Part I deals with liability issues and standards of care. To enable the physician/researcher to recognize a potential liability situation. Part II examines insurance and related issues such as the role of the Canadian Medical Protection Association (CMPA). The document begins with a review of 2 potential categories of liability: criminal and civil tort. Next, the legal issues surrounding the consent process, which account for the majority of claims of negligence, are discussed. The research process is then discussed, highlighting the Canadian Medical Research Council Guidelines for Human Experimentation. Part II considers how research projects are financed and identifies the parties for whom coverage may be sought. Information is provided from a variety of sources offering insurance and semi-insurance protection, with particular attention to the CMPA. Each resource details the conditions necessary for its scope to be triggered. Other topics covered include those that arise when research is conducted outside of Canada and include multiple coverages.

title: Lesbian, Gay, Bisexual, and Transgender Health Inequalities: Executive Summary of a Policy Position Paper from the American College of Physicians
