abstract: In this position paper, the American College of Physicians examines the health inequalities experienced by the lesbian, gay, bisexual and transgender (LGBT) community and makes a series of recommendations to ensure equality for LGBT individuals in the healthcare system. These recommendations include improving physician understanding of how to provide culturally and clinically competent care to LGBT people, addressing environmental and social factors that may affect their mental and physical health, and supporting further research to understand their unique health needs.

title: Lessons from a randomized controlled trial designed to evaluate computer decision support software to improve asthma management
abstract: Primary purpose: To investigate whether computer decision support software used in the treatment of asthmatic patients improves clinical outcomes. Research design: Randomized controlled trial with practices each reporting 30 patients with asthma over a 6-month period. Methods and procedures: 447 patients were randomly selected from practice asthma registries managed by 17 general practices across the UK. Intervention apps did not use control apps while using software during consultations with these patients throughout the study. Main results and conclusions: Practice consultations, acute exacerbations of asthma, hospital contacts, assessment and symptoms related to medication use. A smaller proportion of patients in the intervention group initiated practice consultations for their asthma: 34 (22%) vs 111 (34%), odds ratio (OR) = 0.59, 95% confidence interval (CI) (0.37-0.95) )"; " and experienced acute asthma exacerbations: 12 (8%) vs 57 (17%), OR = 0.43, 95% CI = 0.21-0.85, six months after the introduction of computer decision support software. There were no discernible differences in reported symptoms, maintenance prescription, or use of hospital services between the two groups. Conclusion : The use of computer decision support software that implements the guidelines during patient consultations may improve clinical outcomes in patients with asthma.

title: Lessons learned from the evaluation of the UK's NHS R&D Practice Methods Programme
abstract: Background Concern over the effective use of research was a major factor behind the creation of the NHS R&D Programme in 1991. In 1994, an advisory group was formed to identify research priorities in research practice. This resulted in the Implementation Methods Program (IMP), and the commissioning group funded 36 projects. In 2000, responsibility for the program was transferred from the Brunel University Health Economics Research Group (HERG) to the National Coordinating Center for NHS Service Delivery and Organization R&D, which requested an evaluation in 2002. By then most projects had been completed. . This assessment aimed to cover: the quality of the deliverables, the lessons to be learned about the communication strategy and the deployment process, and the benefits from the projects. Methods We have adopted a wide variety of quantitative and qualitative methods. These include: documentary analysis, interviews with key actors, surveys of funded lead researchers, surveys of potential users, and table analysis. Results Quantitative evaluation of outcomes and dissemination revealed that some funded beneficial research projects with significant impact across several categories in the HERG reimbursement model, such as publications, further research, research education, impact on health policy, and clinical practice. . Qualitative findings from interviews with advisory and commissioning group members showed that practice research was a relatively unexplored field when the IMP was established. This is reflected in the understanding brought to their roles by members of advisory and commissioning groups, the way research priorities are selected and developed, and how research projects are commissioned. Ideological and methodological debates about these decisions continued among those working in this field. The need for an effective communication strategy was particularly important to the program as a whole. However, such a strategy has never been developed, making it difficult to establish the overall impact of the IMP as a program. Conclusion Our findings on the impact of funded work and the challenges faced by IMP developers have implications for the development of strategic research programs in general and for the development of more effective research in this area.

title: Letter: Mucosal ulceration in celiac disease
Leveraging insights from behavioral economics to increase the value of healthcare delivery
abstract: United States healthcare spending continues to increase at unsustainable rates. A recent move to increase price transparency has been proposed, through legislative efforts at both the state and federal levels, as a way to curb the rate of increase in spending. While this may seem like a good idea on the surface, simply informing doctors, especially interns, about prices may not achieve the kind of drastic changes in practice models that advocates expect. The way price transparency is implemented will likely play an important role in its effectiveness as an intervention. In this article, the authors review transparency efforts and assumed options from other contexts, and draw on insights from behavioral economics to provide recommendations for increasing the likelihood that price transparency will lead physicians to weigh the relative value of interventions.

title: LGB-positive cognitive-behavioral therapy for young adult gay and bisexual men: a randomized controlled trial of a transdiagnostic minority stress approach.
abstract: OBJECTIVES: We tested the preliminary efficacy of an adapted transdiagnostic cognitive-behavioral therapy to improve depression, anxiety, and co-occurring health risks (i.e., alcohol use, sexual compulsion, condomless sex) among young adult gay and bisexual men. Treatment adaptations focused on reducing minority stress processes that underlie mental health disparities related to sexual orientation. METHODS: Young gay and bisexual men (n = 63";" Age = 25.94) were randomized to emergency treatment or a 3-month waiting list. At baseline, 3-month, and 6-month assessments, participants completed self-reports on mental health and minority stress, and a past 90-day interview on risk behavior. RESULTS: Treatment versus waiting list significantly reduced depressive symptoms (b = -2.43, 95% CI: -4.90, 0.35, p < .001), alcohol use problems (b = -3.79, 95% CI: -5.94, -1.64). substantially reduced. , p < .001), sexual compulsion (b = -5.09, 95% CI: -8.78, -1.40, p < .001), and condomless sex with casual partners in the last 90 days (b = -1.09, 95%) CI: - 1.80, -0.37, p < .001) and improved condom use self-efficacy (b = 10.08, 95% CI: 3.86, 16.30, p < .001). Treatment was moderate and marginally significant according to the waiting list in anxiety symptoms (b = -2.14, 95% CI: -4.61, 0.34, p = .09) and excessive alcohol consumption in the last 90 days (b = -0.32, 95%). improved further CI: -0.71, 0.07, p = .09). The effects were generally maintained at follow-up. Minority stress processes showed minor improvements in the expected direction. CONCLUSION: This study demonstrated preliminary support for first response adapted to address the co-occurring health problems of gay and bisexual men in minority stress at the source. If found to be effective compared to standard evidence-based treatments, the treatment will have significant potential to help clinicians translate LGB-positive treatment guidelines into evidence-based practice. (PsycINFO Database Record

title: Lifestyle advice provided by primary care to prevent cardiovascular disease
abstract: BACKGROUND: The Hypertension Working Group of the Norwegian College of General Practitioners reports on this paper on behavioral advice in the prevention of cardiovascular disease. Attention is paid to hypertension. MATERIALS AND METHODS: Recommendations are primarily based on updated meta-analyses and randomized controlled trials. Hypertension is treated to prevent cardiovascular disease";" that's why we place emphasis on documentation as important endpoints. The validity of documents for general application is evaluated. We also evaluated whether certain methods or theories for behavior change could be helpful to the GP. CONCLUSIONS: The value of advice against smoking, dietary advice (increased intake of grain products, vegetables, fruit, poultry and fish), and advice on exercise is well documented and applicable in general practice. Respect for the patient's autonomy and concern for patients and their health-related habits appear to be important factors for increasing the doctor's chances of influencing patient behavior. COMMENT: The value of lifestyle advice is well documented and should play an important role in clinical strategies to prevent cardiovascular disease in high-risk patients.

title: Life-sustaining technologies and the elderly
Lifestyle counseling in primary care: long-term effects on cholesterol level
abstract: OBJECTIVE: To evaluate the long-term effectiveness of lifestyle counseling for subjects at low-to-moderate cardiovascular (CV) risk in primary care. METHODS: DESIGN: Prospective comparison of baseline and post-intervention and comparison of enrolled patients and control subjects from a large primary care database. SETTING: 94 common practices in Italy. PARTICIPANTS: All 20-70-year-old hypercholesterolemic subjects who were not eligible for statin therapy according to guidelines and were seen on 12 predetermined working days”; 713 patients; 94 GPs. INTERVENTION: Short (5-10 min.) ) educational intervention (qualitative dietary advice, walking or promoting other aerobic physical activities);" to give simple dietary advice at the discretion of the doctor. MAIN OUTCOME MEASURES: Total cholesterol level and global CV risk calculated according to the Framingham equation. RESULTS: Total cholesterol and global CV risk (10 years) were 0.31 mmol/l (p < 0.0001, 95% CI 0.23-0.40) and 1.35% (p < 0.01, %), respectively. The 95 CI was decreased from -1.73 to -0.97), after a 54-month follow-up. Registered patients showed greater reductions in total cholesterol than control patients: 2.24% (p < 0.05, 95% CI 0.58-3.91%). CONCLUSIONS: A simple, office-based, long-term lifestyle counseling program provides a small but clinically significant reduction in total cholesterol and global CV risk. This conclusion should encourage GPs to systematically offer simple, unstructured lifestyle counseling to all their patients.

title: Lifestyle interventions in primary health care: professional and organizational challenges
abstract: BACKGROUND: Interventions that support patients' efforts in lifestyle changes that reduce tobacco use, hazardous alcohol use, unhealthy dietary habits, and inadequate physical activity represent important areas of improvement for health care. Current research shows that reorienting health services towards health promotion is difficult. The aim of this study was to explore the scope of the health care professional's work with lifestyle interventions in Swedish primary care and to describe professional knowledge, attitudes and perceived organizational support for lifestyle interventions. METHODS: The study is based on a web-based cross-sectional survey of GPs, fellow doctors, residents, public health nurses, and registered nurses (n = 315) in primary care. RESULTS: Fifty-nine percent of the participants stated that lifestyle interventions were an important part of their task. The majority (77%) want to work more with their patient lifestyle. Health professionals often reported that they had extensive knowledge of lifestyle intervention methods for disease prevention. Significant differences were found between the professional groups in terms of specific knowledge and lifestyle interventions and the scope of the study. Alcohol was the least addressed lifestyle habit. Management was supportive, but there were few structures to sustain work with lifestyle interventions and the need for national guidelines was identified. RESULTS: Health professionals reported extensive knowledge and positive attitudes towards lifestyle interventions. Planning for further implementation of lifestyle interventions in primary health care should take into account information, the promotion of healthy lifestyles, and the provision of institutional support, such as national guidelines, and differences among professional groups in the scope of work and lifestyle issues.

title: Lifestyle or lifesaving drugs? Primary care and consumer opinion research on over-the-counter statins
abstract: BACKGROUND: Over-the-counter (OTC) simvastatin 10 mg was made available in the UK in July 2004 to improve primary prevention of ischemic heart disease. OBJECTIVE: To document the views of key stakeholders (general practitioners [GPs], community pharmacists and consumers) on issues related to the reclassification of simvastatin to OTC availability, highlight differences among stakeholder groups, and identify factors likely to influence consumer behavior. METHODS: A self-administered survey of GPs, community pharmacists and potentially eligible consumers was conducted 8 months after OTC simvastatin launch in the UK. Participants were asked about their awareness of the drug, their willingness to use these drugs, and their views on related management practices. RESULTS: Awareness of OTC simvastatin was high among GPs, but limited among consumers. Although OTC availability is favored by pharmacists, consumers and GPs often thought it was not a good idea. GPs and pharmacists cited increased consumer choice as the most important possible benefit";" consumers felt that the potential savings to the National Health Service were equally significant. Abuse of drugs and neglect of lifestyle risk factors were unanimously considered the most important possible risks. In contrast to the majority of pharmacists, most GPs felt that current dosing guidelines were not appropriate, but there was consensus that prolonged non-compliance would likely reduce any therapeutic benefit. Most respondents agreed that GPs should be informed if their patients were using OTC statins, but disagreed on the best way to communicate this information. CONCLUSIONS: The OTC availability of statins was not considered a popular public health intervention by consumers and GPs, as the drugs were widely perceived to be prone to abuse. However, the OTC availability was favored by pharmacists who saw it as a booster for both consumers and themselves. Key issues regarding the deployment, management and evaluation of the public health impact of this intervention remain unresolved.

title: Lifetime Prevalence of Gender-Based Violence in Women and Its Relationship with Mental Disorders and Psychosocial Functioning
abstract: Context Intimate partner physical violence, rape, sexual assault and stalking are common and co-occurring forms of gender-based violence (GBV). The relationship between these forms of abuse and lifelong mental disorder and psychosocial disability among women needs to be examined. Objectives To evaluate the association, severity and comorbidity of GBV and mental disorder, and psychosocial functioning among women. Design, Environment and Participants A cross-sectional study of 4451 women (65% response rate) aged 16 to 85 years, based on the 2007 Australian National Survey of Mental Health and Wellbeing. Main Outcomes Measures The World Health Organization's World Mental Health Survey Initiative's Unified International Diagnostic Interview version 3.0 was used to assess the lifetime prevalence of any mental disorder, anxiety, mood disorder, substance use disorder, and post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD). Lifetime trauma exposure indices were also included, including GBV, sociodemographic characteristics, economic status, family history of mental disorders, social supports, general mental and physical functioning, quality of life, and general disability. Results A total of 1218 women (27.4%) reported experiencing at least 1 type of GBV. For women exposed to 3 or 4 types of GBV (n = 139), rates of mental disorders for anxiety disorders were 77.3% (odds ratio [OR], 10.06"; 95% CI [CI], 5.85-17.30), mood disorder 52.5% (OR, 3.59; 95% CI, 2.31-5.60) for substance use disorder (OR, 5.61; 95% CI, 3.46-9.10), 56.2% (OR, 15.90; 95% CI, for PTSD) 8.32-30.20), 89.4% for any mental disorder (OR, 11.00; 95% CI, 5.46-22.17) and 34.7% (OR, 14.80; 95% CI, 6.89-31.60) for suicide attempts. with mental disorder (OR, 4.60; 95% CI, 2.93-7.22), with a higher rate of 3 or more lifetime impairments (OR, 7.79; 95% CI, 6.10-9.95), physical disability (OR, 4.00; 95% CI) , 1.82-8.82), intellectual disability (OR, 7.14; 95% CI, 2.87-17.75), impaired quality of life (OR, 2.96; 95% CI, 1.60-5.47), increase in disability days (OR, 3.14; 95% CI) , 2.43-4.05) and general disability (OR, 2.73; "95% CI, 1.99-3.75). Conclusion In a nationally representative sample of Australian women, GBV was significantly associated with mental health impairment, dysfunction and disability.

title: 'Like sugar and honey': The embedded ethics of a larval control project in Gambia
abstract: This article describes a malaria research project in The Gambia that encourages reflection on the social value of transnational research. The Larval Control Project (LCP) investigated the efficacy of a microbial insecticide to reduce vector density and ultimately clinical malaria in Gambian children. The LCP's protocol defined a clinical surveillance plan involving Rural Health Workers (VHWs) supported by project nurses. Combining insights from ethnographic fieldwork conducted at the Medical Research Council (MRC) Laboratories in Farafenni from 2005 to 2009, open-ended interviews with project nurses, and eight focus group discussions with participating mothers in October 2007, LCP's several years of research research method against the background of his activity. We found that while participants associated LCP with the clinical care it provides, they felt that collaboration between nurses and VHWs provided additional benefits. Small-scale collaborations organized around the operational functions of the trial provided the platform on which to build local capacity. While ethical guidelines highlight aspects that need to be added to experimental efforts in southern countries (for example, elaborating informed consent processes, developing community engagement strategies, or providing therapeutic access to participants after trial ends), these findings suggest a shift of attention away from ethical reinforcement. Protocols for everyday research work—embedding ethics through scientific activity—can provide a more solid basis for reinforcing the relationship between scientific rigor and societal value.

title: Limited impact of a multicenter intervention to improve quality and efficiency of pneumonia care
abstract: STUDY OBJECTIVES: To evaluate the impact of a multifactor intervention to improve quality, efficiency, and patient understanding of care for community-acquired pneumonia. DESIGN: Times series cohort study. SETTING: Four academic health centers in the New York metropolitan area. PATIENTS OR PARTICIPANTS: All consecutive adults hospitalized for pneumonia during a 5-month period before (n = 1.013) and after (n = 1.081) implementation of the inpatient quality improvement (QI) intervention. INTERVENTIONS: A multidisciplinary team of opinion leaders developed evidence-based treatment guidelines and critical pathways, held training sessions with physicians, distributed pocket reminder cards, supported standardized orders, and developed bilingual patient education materials. MEASUREMENTS AND RESULTS: The mean age was 71.4%, with 44.1% low risk, 36.8% medium risk, and 19.2% high risk. The pre-intervention and post-intervention groups were well matched for age, sex, race, hospice residence, pneumonia severity, initial presentation, and most major comorbidities. The intervention increased the use of antimicrobial therapy recommended by the guideline from 78.1% to 83.4% (p = 0.003). There was also a borderline decrease in the proportion of patients discharged before clinical stabilization from 27.0% to 23.5% (p = 0.06). However, there were no improvements in other targeted indicators, including time to first antibiotic dose, rate of taking antibiotics within 8 hours, timely switching to oral antibiotics, timely discharge, length of hospital stay, or patient education outcomes. RESULTS: This real-world QI program was able to show modest improvement in some quality indicators, but did not affect resource use or patient knowledge of their disease. Changing physician and organizational behavior in academic health centers will require the development and implementation of more intensive, systems-oriented strategies.

title: Local clinical guidelines: description and evaluation of a participatory method for their development and implementation
abstract: BACKGROUND: National guidelines rarely follow abrupt changes in clinical behavior. We present our experience of an active training method for local development and the implementation of a guideline. OBJECTIVE: To evaluate the effectiveness of a participatory method for developing local clinical guidelines. METHODS: A trial in a region of the impact of guideline development involving the active involvement of targeted buyers on subsequent relevant prescribing. It was conducted in 69 general practices, covering a population of 345,763 in the Wirral Family Healthcare Institute region (Wirral peninsula). An exemplary guide on 'hypertension in the elderly' has been developed with the method described. The main drug recommended was bendrofluazide 2.5 mg once daily. Differences in prescribed daily doses (PDD) of bendrofluazide 2.5 mg tablets per quarter per 1000 prescribing units (age-weighted population) were measured between the region of intervention and the UK as a whole. RESULTS: Comparison of intervention region with UK data shows a median difference of 122.49 PDD before guideline and 206.34 PDD after, this change is statistically significant (Mann-Whitney two-tailed P < 0.0001"; 95% CI = 36.51-104.77 Grouped regression analysis, it does not show a significant difference in slope slopes before guide production (0.89) (P = 0.35, 95% CI = -3.97-5.76), but the difference in slope slopes after (12.95) is statistically significant (P < 0.0001;" 95% CI = 8.17) -17.73. Data show that change in clinical behavior lasts for at least two years CONCLUSION: Involvement of targeted recipient GPs and local experts in the development of a guideline with an active education method as described was followed by a positive change in clinical behavior lasting at least two years.

title: Local Learning Collaborators to Improve Quality for Chronic Kidney Disease (CKD): From Four Regional Practice-based Research Networks (PBRNs)
abstract: BACKGROUND: Four practice-based research networks (PBRNs) have participated in a project to increase the dissemination of evidence-based treatment guidelines for chronic kidney disease (CKD). A multi-component organizational response deployed regionally close primary care practices in a series of facilitated meetings called local learning collaborators (LLCs). METHODS: The 2 wave strategy started with 8 applications receiving application facilitation in each PBRN and then joining an LLC. A sequential mixed method design that addresses the behavior, content, and fidelity of the intervention";" Clinicians at 2 PBRN attended the interviews and PBRN coordinators reflected on the implementation challenges. RESULTS: LLCs were formed in 3 PBRNs and 121 monthly meetings were held in 20 LLCs. Just over half of the participants were clinicians. Qualitative data show that clinicians increase priority for CKD care, improve their knowledge and skills, are satisfied with the project, and strive to improve care. Implementation challenges were encountered and sustainability concerns were raised. CONCLUSION: While PBRNs can successfully use resources to disseminate treatment guidelines and LLCs are well accepted by clinical staff, formation of LLCs was not feasible for 1 PBRN and others struggled to meet regularly and have performance data despite logistical support .

title: Long-term efficacy in prescribing two multifaceted educational interventions: results from two large-scale randomized cluster studies.
abstract: INTRODUCTION: Knowledge about the benefits and risks of drugs is an important factor influencing physicians' prescribing decisions. Outreach visits that promote independent information have proven moderately effective in changing prescribing behaviors. OBJECTIVES: To test the short- and long-term effectiveness of pharmacist-led small group meetings on general practitioners' prescribing. METHODS: Two sets of open randomized controlled trials (RCTs) were conducted in a large-scale NHS setting. We used tentative evidence-based materials taking into account a therapeutic area approach - TEA, which includes informational materials on osteoporosis or prostatic hyperplasia - and information materials on me-too drugs from 2 different classes, as well as a single-drug approach - SIDRO: barnidipine or prulifloxacin. In each study, all 115 Primary Care Groups (2.2 million population, 1737 GPs) in a Northern Italian region were randomized to educational small group meetings presenting available evidence along with drug use data and clinical scenarios. The main results were changes in the six-month prescription of targeted drugs. Longer-term outcomes (24 and 48 months) were also evaluated. RESULTS: In the TEA study, one of the four primary outcomes was reduced (alfuzosin prescription compared to tamsulosin and terazosin in benign prostatic hyperplasia: prescribing rate -8.5%, p = 0.03). Another primary outcome (risedronate prescription) showed a reduction at 24 and 48 months (-7.6%, p = 0.02" and -9.8%, p = 0.03) but not at six months (-5.1%, p = 0.36) in the SIDRO study, both primary outcomes showed a statistically significant reduction (barnidipine prescription -9.8%, p = 0.02;" prulifloxacin prescription -11.1%, p=0.04), which persisted or increased over time. COMMENT: These two clusters of RCTs demonstrated the large-scale feasibility of a complex education program in an NHS setting and the potentially relevant long-term impact on prescribing habits, particularly when focusing on a single drug. National Health systems should invest in independent drug information programs. TRIAL REGISTRATION: Controlled-Trials.com ISRCTN05866587.

title: Long-term effects of an occupational health guideline on employee body weight, cardiovascular disease risk factors, and quality of life: results of a randomized controlled trial.
abstract: OBJECTIVE: This study aims to evaluate the effectiveness of a draft occupational health guide aimed at preventing weight gain on employee weight-related outcomes, cardiovascular disease (CVD) risk factors, and quality of life. METHODS: In a cluster randomized controlled trial involving 16 occupational physicians (OPs) and 523 employees, guideline-based care was compared to usual care by OP in the Netherlands between 2009 and 2011. Guided care consists of (i) advising employers on how to assess and respond to the obesogenic work environment, (ii) conducting five face-to-face behavior change counseling sessions with employees to improve their lifestyles, and (iii) evaluating outcome and maintaining parts i and ii. . Data were collected at baseline and at 6, 12, and 18-month follow-ups. Multilevel analyzes were performed to assess the effects of the intervention. RESULTS: There was no significant difference between the intervention and control groups in terms of waist circumference [beta 1.2 cm, 95% confidence interval (95% CI) -0.6-2.9], body weight (beta 0.3 kg, 95% CI -1.0-1.6) not found. ), body mass index (beta 0.1 kg/m2 (2), 95% CI -0.3-0.5), systolic blood pressure (beta 1.7 mmHG, 95% CI -2.4-5.8), diastolic blood pressure (beta 0.3 mmHG, 95 % CI -1.0-0.6), cholesterol (beta 0 mmol/l, 95% CI -0.2-0.2), or quality of life indicators after 18 months follow-up. Stratified analyzes showed waist circumference among males (beta 2.5 cm, 95% CI 0.5-4.5) and obese intervention participants (beta 2.7 cm, 95% CI 0.6-4.7) compared to control participants. showed an increase. CONCLUSION: The draft occupational health guide was not more effective than the usual care. Therefore, the application of the guide in its current form cannot be recommended.

title: Long-term effects of asthma education given to physicians on patient satisfaction and utilization of health services.
abstract: This randomized clinical trial evaluated the long-term impact of an interactive seminar for physicians based on principles of self-regulation on clinician behavior, children's use of healthcare for asthma, and parents' views on physician performance. Seventy-four general practice pediatricians and 637 asthma patients aged 1-12 years were randomized to treatment or control. Children and parents were blind to the involvement of doctors. Data were collected through baseline and self-administered questionnaires (pediatricians), telephone interviews (parents), and medical records. The seminar focused on the development of communication and teaching skills and the use of therapeutic medical regimens for asthma, as outlined in the National Asthma Education and Prevention Program guidelines. At approximately 2 years after intervention, treatment group physicians were more likely than control physicians to use protocols to provide asthma education (odds ratio (OR) 4.9, p=0.2), to write to patients how to adjust medication when symptoms change (OR 5.7, p=0.05) and provides further guidelines for changing therapy (OR 3.8, p=0.06). Parents rated treatment group doctors higher than control doctors on five specific positive communication behaviors. Children seen by treatment group physicians had fewer hospitalizations (p=0.03), and those who used higher levels of ED at baseline had fewer subsequent emergency room visits (p=0.03). No difference was noted regarding the number of office visits. There was no significant difference between the treatment and control group physicians in terms of time spent with patients during office visits (26 versus 29 minutes) or the number of patients treated with anti-inflammatory medication. It was concluded that interactive asthma seminars for pediatricians have significant long-term benefits for asthma care.

title: Long-term reduction in adverse drug events: an evidence-based model of improvement.
abstract: OBJECTIVES: To develop and test an evidence-based model for reducing medication errors and harm in hospitalized children. METHODS: A prospective discontinuous time series study evaluating the efficacy of a multifaceted, phased intervention over 4 years in a large urban pediatric referral hospital. Safe pediatric prescribing guidelines were implemented using an evidence-based model. Key components included early clinician involvement and improved multidisciplinary communication, consensus building, interactive training, and timely data feedback using iterative Plan-Do-Run-Act cycles. The effect on medication error and harm (adverse drug events, [ADEs]) was measured using standard definitions and a multi-method approach. Potential data from volunteer reports by nursing, medical, and pharmacy staff and intensive chart review were combined. All data were reviewed by a multidisciplinary panel, including causality assessments for ADEs. RESULTS: There were 1011 patients with 6651 drug orders reviewed over 3 time periods. Total ADEs were reduced by >50% in the first year and maintained at 4 years. The greatest improvements were in potential ACEs, which decreased from 12.26 per 100 patients at baseline to 4.60 per 100 patients at 4 years (P < .05). Total medication errors decreased from 4.51 per 100 orders at baseline to 2.78 per 100 orders over 4 years (P < .05). Prescribing errors decreased by 65% from 4.07 per 100 orders initially to 2.05 orders (P < .05) over 4 years. CONCLUSIONS: A versatile, evidence-based model for safe prescribing guideline practice, with the involvement of multidisciplinary clinicians, was effective in reducing medication errors and harm in hospitalized children and achieved sustained long-term improvement.

title: Looking for gallbladder disease in the patient's iris
abstract: In alternative healthcare, iridology is used as an aid to diagnosis. The diagnosis of gallbladder disease was used to examine its validity and inter-practitioner consistency. The presence of an inflamed gallbladder containing gallstones is said to be easily recognized by certain markings on the lower lateral portion of the iris of the right eye. Stereo color slides were made from the right eye. Stereo color slides were made from the right eye of 39 patients with this disease and 39 control subjects of the same sex and age. Slides were presented in random order to five leading iridologists without additional information. The prevalence of the disease has been estimated at 56%. The median validity was 51% with 54% sensitivity and 52% specificity. These results were close to chance validity (iota = 0.03). None of the iridologists achieved high validity. The median performer consistency was 60%. This was only slightly higher than the chance consistency (kappa = 0.18). This study has shown that iridology is not a useful diagnostic aid.

title: Low-value maintenance: a tough global problem with no quick fix
Magnetic resonance imaging of the head and spine: is it effective for the clinician or patient?
abstract: OBJECTIVES To test how magnetic resonance imaging results affect clinicians' diagnosis and treatment plans for patients with cranial and spinal cord problems, and to evaluate changes in these patients' quality of life. DESIGN The DESIGN Questionnaire of patients undergoing cranial and spinal magnetic resonance imaging with questionnaires about diagnoses and intended management plans before and after imaging and quality of life questionnaires at the time of imaging and again four months later. SETTING Regional magnetic resonance imaging and spectroscopy unit. SUBJECTS "100 consecutive patients referred for cranial imaging in early 1989"; 100 similar patients referred for spinal imaging. MAIN OUTCOME MEASURES Changes and confidence of clinicians in leading diagnoses after magnetic resonance imaging; changes in intended management plans; contribution to future patient management; " changes in patients' quality of life. RESULTS Magnetic resonance imaging changed clinicians' leading diagnoses in 35 (21%) of 169 cases. Clinicians were more confident in their leading diagnosis in 90 of 167 (54%). Of 182 people, 113 (62%) had a change in the management plan. Clinicians thought that magnetic resonance imaging made a significant contribution to treatment in 119 (73%) of 162 patients. Overall, patients' quality of life did not change at the four-month evaluation. CONCLUSIONS Magnetic resonance imaging of patients with cranial and spinal problems influences clinicians' diagnosis and treatment plans, but does not alter their quality of life.

title: Maintenance Phase Efficacy of Sertraline for Chronic Depression A Randomized Controlled Trial
abstract: Context.Â¡Âª The chronic form of major depression is associated with a high prevalence and disability, but no controlled studies have examined the effect of long-term treatment on disease course and burden. Objective.Â¡Âª To determine whether maintenance therapy with sertraline hydrochloride can effectively prevent the relapse of depression in high-risk patients with chronic major depression or major depression with a previous dysthymic disorder ("double depression"). Design.Â¡Âª 76-week randomized, double-blind, parallel group study conducted between September 1993 and November 1996. Ayar.Â¡Âª Outpatient psychiatry clinics at 10 academic medical centers and 2 clinical research centers. Intervention.Â¡Âª Maintenance therapy with flexible doses of sertraline hydrochloride (n=77) or placebo (n=84) up to 200 mg. Patients.Â¡Âª A total of 161 outpatients with chronic major or double depression who responded to sertraline treatment in a 12-week, double-blind, acute-phase treatment trial and continued to achieve a satisfactory therapeutic response for the next 4 months of treatment. Key Outcome Measure.Â¡Âª Time to relapse of major depression. Results.Â¡Âª Sertraline provided significantly greater prophylaxis against relapses than placebo (5 out of 77 [6%] in the sertraline group and 19 [23%] out of 84 in the placebo group; P= for log-rank). 002 Relapse time distributions test) Clinically significant depressive symptoms reappeared in 20 (26%) of 77 patients treated with sertraline, compared with 42 (50%) of 84 patients treated with placebo (P=.001). , patients receiving placebo were 4.07 times more likely (95% CI, 1.51-10.95; "P=.005) to experience a depression relapse after adjusting for study area, type of depression, and randomization strata. Conclusions.Â¡Âª Maintenance therapy with sertraline is well tolerated and has significant efficacy in preventing relapse or reoccurrence of depression in patients with chronic depression.

title: Making comparative performance information more understandable: an empirical assessment of the impact of formats on consumer understanding
abstract: Study objectives We aimed to explore how different presentation formats affect the understanding and use of comparative performance information (CPI) among consumers. Methods An experimental design between and between subjects with manipulations of CPI presentation formats. We recruited both consumers of lower socioeconomic status (SES)/cognitive skills and consumers of higher SES/cognitive skills through an online access panel. Participants were given a fictitious CPI and completed questions on interpretation and use of information. Among subjects, (1) displaying an overall performance score (yes/no)"; (2) showing few quality indicators (5 out of 9);" and (3) displaying different types of evaluative symbols (star ratings, colored dots, and word symbols versus numbers and bar graphs). Within subjects, we tested the effect of a reduced number of healthcare providers (5 vs. 20). Data were analyzed using descriptive analysis, analyzes of variance, and paired-sample t-tests. Results A total of 902 (43%) participants participated. The display of an overall performance score and the use of colored dots and word symbols especially improved consumer understanding. More importantly, respondents provided with colored dots most frequently ranked first when compared to word symbols (76.6% correct), star ratings (70.6% correct), numbers (62.0%), and bars (54.2%). correctly selected three health care providers (84.3%). When viewing performance scores of 20 providers. Also, a reduced number of healthcare providers appeared to support consumers, for example, when 20 providers were provided, 69.5% correctly selected the top three, compared to 80.2% with five providers. Discussion Specific presentation formats have improved the consumer's understanding of CPI, most notably the use of overall performance scores, word symbols and colored dots, and fewer vendors displayed. Opinion reporting studies should use these formats to maximize impact on consumers.

title: Making Electronic Health Records Meaningful
Making research a condition of treatment: why should we sometimes allow doctors to pressure patients to participate in research?
abstract: When a patient can be offered one of many established treatments, physicians should be able to offer treatment only if the patient agrees to participate in research to determine which of the treatments is most effective. Making treatment conditional on participation in research will help researchers complete much-needed studies.

title: Making the invisible visible: a qualitative study of radiologists' values, attitudes and norms regarding radiation safety.
abstract: Audits of Swedish Radiology departments by the Swedish Radiation Safety Authority, which annually performs 5.4 million radiological examinations and 100,000 nuclear scans, revealed some safety-related shortcomings. To ensure safety in the healthcare system and to create a strong radiation protection environment for patients (and staff), there must be a strong safety culture. To understand an organization's behavior, decisions, and actions, it is important to examine its cultural values. The purpose of this study was to discuss how values, attitudes and norms influence the decisions of radiologists as well as the application of various radiation protection measures. To explore this, focus group interviews and in-depth individual interviews were conducted on a sample from a number of radiology departments in hospitals in Sweden. The results show that the core value is obtained from the patients' perspective, which focuses on the knowledge that patients come to the healthcare system for a specific reason: to discover the disease or, at best, to be declared healthy. The majority's attitudes were based on experience with aspects that the radiologist could not influence. This is often related to the increasing pressure on radiology research from clinics in various operational units. Under the concept of norms, the radiologists in the study demanded that the development of regulations and guidelines be linked to justification issues for various radiological inquiries.

title: Practices against malaria policies, a reality check from Kinshasa, the capital city of the Democratic Republic of Congo
abstract: BACKGROUND: Artemisinin-based combination therapy (ACT) is recommended following a parasitological diagnosis approved by the World Health Organization (WHO) and the Congo National Malaria Control Program (NMCP). However, the commitment and competence of all stakeholders (patients, medical professionals, governments and funders) is required to perform effective case management and ensure the "beneficial therapeutic life" of proposed drugs. The health-seeking behaviors of the patients and the practices of health professionals for malaria management were evaluated. METHODS: This was an observational study embedded in a two-stage cluster randomized questionnaire conducted at a health center (HC) in each of 12 selected health districts in the city of Kinshasa. All patients diagnosed with clinical malaria were eligible. Health-seeking behaviors were recorded in a specific questionnaire alongside the practices of health care practitioners. The latter was unaware that their applications would be evaluated. RESULTS: Six hundred and twenty-four patients, 136 (21.8%) under the age of five, were evaluated. Three hundred and thirty-five (55%) had taken medication before the current consultation (self-medication with any product or visiting another HC), 47 (14%) took antimalarial medication, and 56 (9%) hypothetically treated. . Of these, 53.6% received monotherapy with quinine, artesunate, phyto-drugs, sulfadoxine-pyrimethamine or amodiaquine. On the other hand, when clinicians were informed about the laboratory results, 39.9% of confirmed malaria cases were prescribed monotherapy. Only 285 patients (45.7%) were treated in accordance with WHO and NMCP guidelines, of which 120 (19.2%) were prescribed ACT after a positive blood smear and 165 (26.4%) after a negative result did not receive. CONCLUSION: This study demonstrates the contradiction between malaria policies in Kinshasa and the realities in the field in terms of health-seeking behaviors of patients and practices of health professionals. Consequently, poor policy compliance may contribute to the emergence and spread of antimalarial drug resistance and may also have a negative impact on the burden of the disease.

title: Malignant lymphoma competence network
abstract: The Malignant Lymphomas competence network is one of 3 oncological networks funded by the German Federal Ministry of Education and Research since 1999. The network's activities are based on the work of the German lymphoma research groups, and significant progress has been made in this network. Diagnosis and treatment of malignant lymphoma in the last few years. Based on this infrastructure, the network aims to establish a professional quality management for the diagnosis and treatment of malignant lymphomas. Key aspects of the activity include: 1. establishment of an IT-based information and communication platform, 2. a network of IT-based working groups and collaboration centers for pathology and radiotherapy, 3. epidemiological and health care-economic research, 4. research on improved and new therapeutic approaches , 5. evidence-based medicine. More information is available at http://www.lymphome.de.

title: Management for Physicians: An Annotated Bibliography of Recent Literature
abstract: As the HEALTHCARE delivery system in the United States becomes increasingly organized and bureaucratic, physicians often find themselves having to assume managerial roles. The exact nature of the physician's responsibilities can range from line management duties such as managing an emergency department, subspecialty or clinical department to more consulting activities such as quality assurance, facility design, long-term planning, staffing, serving on hospital committees. or finance. Regardless of their assigned roles and responsibilities, physicians seldom have sufficient background or skills in various management disciplines to be as effective as they would like. As concerns about healthcare costs and quality make decisions on hospitals and other healthcare facilities difficult, it will become increasingly important for physicians to become better managers and understand the opportunities and limitations of improved management.

title: Management of acute coronary syndromes at hospital discharge: do targeted educational interventions improve quality of practice?
abstract: Evidence-based guidelines exist for the management of patients with acute coronary syndrome (ACS), but compliance is lacking. The Discharge Management of Acute Coronary Syndrome project used a quality improvement approach with targeted intervention strategies and optimized: “prescribing medications recommended in the guideline”; education on lifestyle changes, including cardiac rehabilitation (CR); and communication between hospital staff, patients, and hospital staff. GPs Hospitals across Australia participated in a quality improvement cycle of inspection, feedback, response and re-inspection Interventions included training sessions, academic detailing and point-of-care reminders, and feedback on key inspection results - recommended medications, emergency department referral and management plan Documentation and communication Initially, 49 hospitals recruited 1,545 patients, and after the intervention, 45 hospitals remained active in the project and recruited 1,589 patients.Three thousand and thirty-four hospital staff attended the group in training or academic detail sessions.After the intervention, the recommended d There was a significant increase in all cover-up prescribing (69% versus 57%; p<.0001); short-acting nitrates (68% vs. 56%; p<.0001); and referral to documented CR (68% vs. 57%; "p<.0001). There have been significant increases in communication of documented discharge drug counselling, smoking cessation counseling and management plans. Cycle of targeted educational interventions used as part of quality improvement, ACS It can improve adherence to evidence-based guidelines for the management of patients with .

title: Management of Alzheimer's disease
abstract: Treatment of Alzheimer's disease is based on drug and non-drug treatments. Specific drug therapy includes acetylcholinesterase inhibitors and memantine. They show moderate efficacy to placebo for global status, cognitive impairments, need for care, and behavioral problems, but do not prevent further reduction. These treatments are not used enough. The effectiveness of psychotropic drugs (antidepressants, neuroleptics, and antipsychotic agents) in treating behavior problems is not well documented. Non-drug activities and interventions have not been adequately evaluated scientifically. These include interventions against the consequences of illness (loss of autonomy, malnutrition) and helping patients' family caregivers. Among these activities, the best appreciated and most interesting are: training programs for caregivers, home occupational therapy, and home interventions by nurses specially trained as case managers.

title: Inhaled nitric oxide-based asthma therapy as an adjunct to guideline-based therapy for city center adolescents and young adults: a randomized controlled trial.
abstract: Background Preliminary evidence for the role of exhaled nitric oxide (NO) in the management of clinical asthma is unclear. We aimed to evaluate whether measuring exhaled NO as a biomarker of airway inflammation would improve the efficacy of asthma treatment when used as an adjunct to clinical care based on asthma guidelines for city center adolescents and young adults.";" Background Preliminary evidence for the role of exhaled nitric oxide (NO) in the management of clinical asthma is unclear. We aimed to evaluate whether measuring exhaled NO as a biomarker of airway inflammation would improve the efficacy of asthma treatment when used as an adjunct to clinical care based on asthma guidelines for urban adolescents and young adults.

title: Heart failure management in primary care (Improving the Heart Failure Programme): an international survey
abstract: BackgroundHeart failure is a common condition that is usually treated in primary care. The purpose of this study was to evaluate how primary care physicians think heart failure should be managed, how they apply their knowledge, and whether there are differences in practice between countries.";" BackgroundHeart failure is a common condition that is usually treated in primary care. The aim of this study is to evaluate how primary care physicians think heart failure should be managed, how they apply their knowledge, and whether there are differences in practice between countries.

title: Hypertension management in clinical practice: perceptible qualitative differences in approaches used by clinicians
abstract: The authors recruited a group of physicians from among researchers who participated in Antihypertensive and Lipid-Lowering Therapy to Prevent Heart Attack (ALLHAT), in which more (more successful) or less (less successful) trial patients met their blood pressure (BP). ) check the targets. The authors used qualitative focus group methods to identify similarities and differences in practice behaviors. Successful and less successful physicians had similarities in their knowledge and practice behaviors regarding awareness of treatment guidelines, diagnostic approaches, use of pharmacological management, and the view that systolic BP guidelines should take into account the patient's age. However, there were discernible differences in their views on doctor-patient relationships between the two groups of physicians: physicians in the less successful group were more paternalistic towards their patients, while physicians in the more successful group were more likely to use a patient-centered clinic. Approach to BP awareness and management.

title: Obesity management in patients with type 2 diabetes in primary care
abstract: OBJECTIVES: Obesity and being overweight are the strongest risk factors, accounting for 80-90% of patients with type 2 diabetes (T2DM). The obesity epidemic is pushing the diabetes epidemic to alarming levels and primary health care is becoming an important setting for obesity management in T2DM in India. Yet many primary care providers feel ill-equipped or under-supported to address obesity in patients with diabetes. This article reviews the latest and strongest evidence-based strategies that can assist physicians in the management of obesity in patients with T2DM in primary care. MATERIALS AND METHODS: A systematic literature review of MEDLINE was conducted using the search terms Obesity, Obesity in T2DM, weight loss, and Primary Care. The websites of the American Diabetes Association, the National Institutes of Health, the National Institute for Health and Excellence (NICE), the Scottish Intercollegiate Guidance Network (SIGN), and the World Health Organization were also searched. Most studies in this area are observational in design, with few randomized controlled trials (RCTs). Articles and studies containing meta-analysis or RCT were preferred over other types. CONCLUSION AND CONCLUSION: Effective weight management treatment in T2DM patients can be applied in the primary care setting. Evidence-based individualized lifestyle and pharmacological measures supported by behavioral intervention and counseling with appropriate and informed surgical referrals have the potential to increase the success of weight management in primary care.

title: Management of Obstructive Sleep Apnea in Adults: A Clinical Practice Guide from the American College of Physicians
abstract: Description: The American College of Physicians (ACP) developed this guideline to present the evidence and provide clinical recommendations for the treatment of obstructive sleep apnea (OSA) in adults. Methods: This guide is based on published literature from 1966 to September 2010 identified using MEDLINE, the Cochrane Central Register of Controlled Trials, and the Cochrane Database of Systematic Reviews. An additional MEDLINE search identified additional articles by October 2012. Searches were limited to publications in English. Clinical outcomes evaluated for this guideline include cardiovascular disease (such as heart failure, hypertension, stroke, and myocardial infarction), type 2 diabetes, death, sleep study measures (such as the Apnea¨Kypopnea Index), cardiovascular status measurements (such as blood pressure), measures of diabetes status (such as hemoglobin A1c levels) and quality of life. This guide rates evidence and recommendations using the ACP's clinical practice guidelines rating system. Recommendation 1: The ACP recommends that all overweight and obese patients diagnosed with OSA be encouraged to lose weight. (Grade: strong recommendation"; low-quality evidence) Recommendation 2: ACP recommends continuous positive airway pressure therapy as initial therapy for patients diagnosed with OSA (Grade: strong recommendation; moderate-quality evidence) Recommendation 3: ACP recommends mandibular advancement devices As an alternative therapy to continuous positive airway pressure therapy in patients diagnosed with OSA who opt for mandibular advancement devices, or in patients with adverse effects associated with continuous positive airway pressure therapy (Grade: weak recommendation; "low quality evidence)"

title: Management of occupational therapy services for people with cognitive impairment (expression). American Occupational Therapy Association, Inc.
abstract: In summary, occupational therapy practitioners play a critical role in helping people with cognitive impairment build or lead meaningful and productive lives in their social and cultural environment. Occupational therapy practitioners effectively address a wide range of cognitive difficulties in clients of various ages and diagnoses. Intervention may be directed at the individual with cognitive impairment or those who care for or interact with them (eg, family members, significant people, employers, school staff, other healthcare professionals). Treatment involves changing the person's skills or behaviors or adapting the task and/or environment to maintain function, facilitate caregiving, reduce safety hazards, and maximize independence.

title: Management of persistent pain in the elderly patient: a clinical review.
abstract: IMPORTANCE: Persistent pain is very common, costly, and often causes disability in later life. OBJECTIVE: To identify barriers to persistent pain management among older adults and to summarize current management approaches, including pharmacological and non-pharmacological modalities; present rehabilitation approaches and highlight aspects of the patient-physician relationship that can help improve treatment outcomes. This review is for physicians seeking an age-appropriate approach to providing pain management to older adults. with the management of persistent pain in older adults to identify English peer-reviewed systematic reviews, meta-analyses, Cochrane reviews, consensus statements, and guidelines on non-cancer pain, chronic pain, persistent pain, pain management, persistent pain, and resistant pain with the elderly and the elderly. Related RESULTS: Of the 92 studies identified, 35 were evaluated pharmacologically. 57, while examining non-pharmacological modalities; the majority (n = 50) focused on older adults with osteoarthritis. This evidence base supports a phased approach with acetaminophen as first-line therapy. If treatment goals are not achieved, it is recommended to try a topical NSAID, tramadol, or both. Oral nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs are not recommended for long-term use. Given that advancing age increases the risk of side effects, careful surveillance to monitor toxicity and efficacy is critical. A multimodal approach is highly recommended, emphasizing a combination of both pharmacological and non-pharmacological treatments, including cognitive-behavioral and movement-based interventions, as well as physical and vocational rehabilitation. An integrated pain management approach is ideally achieved by developing a strong therapeutic alliance between the elderly patient and physician. RESULTS AND RELIABILITY: Treatment planning for persistent pain in later life requires a clear understanding of the patient's treatment goals and expectations, comorbidities, and cognitive and functional status, and coordinating community resources and family support whenever possible. A combination of pharmacological, non-pharmacological and rehabilitative approaches, in addition to a strong therapeutic alliance between patient and physician, is essential for setting, adjusting and achieving realistic goals of treatment.

title: Management of severe hypertension in France in 1999 and 2000: interim results of a health insurance intervention program.
abstract: OBJECTIVE: As part of a long-term public health program aimed at improving the clinical management of hypertension (HBP), French health funds conducted two nationwide surveys of affiliates that had recently been waived contributions for severe hypertension. The aim was to measure the difference between observed clinical management and benchmarking care at baseline (May 1999) and during the program (November 1999), as defined by the 1997 ANAES guidelines (National Agency for Accreditation and Health Evaluation). any change in clinical management between the two study periods, the time frame corresponding to the intervention period. METHODS: Samples of patients used in the two studies included affiliates aged 20 to 80 years who lived in France or one of its overseas territories and were recently exempted from paying co-pay (ETM) for severe hypertension (these patients were 100% reimbursed). for all maintenance related to the disorder). The assessment was based on retrospective data provided by the attending physicians. Indicators isolated to compare the two study periods were blood pressure control, recommended lifestyle changes, and prescribed medications. RESULTS: The first survey was conducted between May and November 1999 and enrolled 10,665 patients (corresponding to a weighted patient population of 50,383), the second surveyed 2,649 patients in November 2000. Study population in 1999, on average, study population in November 2000: 63.1 years +/- 0.2 versus 65.4 years +/- 0.4. Almost two out of three patients had at least one other major cardiovascular risk factor in addition to HBP (smoking, diabetes mellitus or dyslipidemia): 63.9% in 1999 and 64.4% in 2000. Approximately one in seven patients had associated coronary artery disease. : 14.1% in 1999 and 15.3% in 2000 and more than one in ten had associated cerebrovascular disease: 12.7% in 1999 and 12.2% in 2000. The 1999 group had more diabetes patients than the 2000 group: 27.5% +/- 1.0 vs 23.9% +/- 1.6. The proportion of patients with poor blood pressure control (systolic >140 mmHg or >160 mmHg in patients aged 60-80 years with isolated systolic hypertension or diastolic >90 mmHg) remained unchanged: 46.8% +/- 1.1 45.7% +/- in 1999 and 2000 1.9. If the guidelines for diabetics (blood pressure < 130/85) are followed. 85.4% of diabetic patients were poorly controlled in 1999 and 86.6% in 2000. Similarly, in hypertensive patients with renal impairment (guideline recommendations: <125/75 mmHg), 94.5% in 1999 and 96.3% in 2000 were poorly controlled. Suggested lifestyle changes (reduced salt intake, weight loss, lower alcohol consumption, increased physical activity) were not followed well in either study: less than one in four patients fully implemented the desired changes in 1999 (23.7%) but only 24% in 2000. .5 of them did. Physicians specifically specified therapeutic agents in 68.0% of patients in 1999 and 67.6% in 2000, taking into account associated diseases. 2000. CONCLUSION: Comparison of the results of two surveys conducted in 1999 and 2000 on the treatment of patients with severe hypertension did not reveal any significant differences in blood pressure. d pressure control or treatment modalities. While not questioning the value of health funding interventions, these findings illustrate how difficult it is to change clinical practice within a short period of time, particularly in a disease that includes a number of different elements that include, inter alia, individual patient behavior. To significantly improve clinical management, it will likely be necessary to maintain dialogue between medical advisers of the medecins conseils and clinicians, and to renew campaigns aimed at helping patients be more responsible.

title: Severe sepsis management in patients admitted to Asian intensive care units: a prospective cohort study.
abstract: OBJECTIVES To assess the compliance of Asian intensive care units and hospitals with the Surviving Sepsis Campaign's resuscitation and management packages. Secondary objectives were to assess the impact of compliance on mortality and the organizational characteristics of hospitals associated with higher compliance. DESIGN Prospective cohort study. SET 150 intensive care units in 16 Asian countries. PARTICIPANTS 1285 adult patients with severe sepsis were admitted to these intensive care units in July 2009. Organizational characteristics of participating centers, basic characteristics of patients, achievement of goals in resuscitation and management packs, and outcome data were recorded. KEY OUTCOME MEASURE Compliance with the Surviving Sepsis Campaign's resuscitation (six hours) and management (24 hours) packages. RESULTS Hospital mortality was 44.5% (572/1285). Compliance rates for resuscitation and management packages were 7.6% (98/1285) and 3.5% (45/1285), respectively. In logistic regression analysis, adherence to the following package goals independently predicted reductions in mortality: blood cultures (obtained on 803/1285"; 62.5%, 95% confidence interval 59.8% to 65.1%), broad-spectrum antibiotics (obtained on 821/1285) 63.9%, 61.3% to 66.5%, and central venous pressure (obtained at 345/870; 39.7%, 36.4% to 42.9%). High-income countries, university hospitals, intensive care units with an accredited fellowship program, and surgical intensive care units were more likely to comply with the resuscitation package. CONCLUSIONS While mortality from severe sepsis is high, compliance with resuscitation and treatment packages is generally poor in most of Asia. Because the centers included in this study may not be fully representative, reported success rates may overestimate the true degree of adherence to the recommended care and should be interpreted with caution. Blood cultures, antibiotics, and achievement of central venous pressure targets were independently associated with better survival.

title: Management of Stable Ischemic Heart Disease: Summary of Clinical Practice Guidelines from the American College of Physicians/American College of Cardiology Foundation/American Heart Association/American Society of Thoracic Surgery/Preventive Cardiovascular Nurses Association/Association of Thoracic Surgeons
abstract: Disclosure: The American College of Physicians (ACP) developed this guide in collaboration with the American College of Cardiology Foundation (ACCF), the American Heart Association (AHA), the American Association for Thoracic Surgery, the Society of Preventive Cardiovascular Nurses, and the Society of Thoracic Surgeons. available evidence for the management of stable, known or suspected ischemic heart disease. Methods: Literature on this topic published before November 2011 was identified using MEDLINE, Embase, Cochrane CENTRAL, PsychINFO, AMED, and SCOPUS. Searches were limited to human studies published in English. This guide ranks evidence and recommendations based on the translation of the ACCF/AHA grading system to the ACP's clinical practice guidelines grading system. Recommendations: The guide includes 48 specific recommendations that address the following topics: patient education, management of proven risk factors (dyslipidemia, hypertension, diabetes, physical activity body weight and smoking), strategies to reduce unproven risk factors, medical therapy to prevent myocardial infarction and death and revascularization and patient follow-up to relieve symptoms, alternative therapy, improve survival and symptoms.

title: Managing the Agitation Associated with Schizophrenia and Bipolar Disorder in an Emergency
abstract: INTRODUCTION: Patient agitation represents a significant challenge in the emergency room (ED), an environment in which medical personnel work under pressure dealing with a variety of medical emergencies. The potential to escalate into aggressive behavior that puts patients, staff, and others at risk makes it imperative to address agitated behavior quickly and efficiently. Time constraints and limited access to specialist psychiatric support have in the past led to a strategy of restraint and pacification "which is believed to represent the most appropriate approach"; however, it is increasingly recognized that more patient-centered approaches yield better outcomes. The purpose of this review is to raise awareness of best practices for the management of agitation in the emergency department and to evaluate the role of new pharmacological interventions in this setting. DISCUSSION: Best Practices in the Evaluation and Treatment of Agitation (BETA) guidelines address the overall management of agitation, including triage, diagnosis, interpersonal calming skills, and medication choices. Since their publication in 2012, there have been further developments in pharmacological approaches to dealing with agitation, including both new agents and new modes of administration that increase the options available for both patients and physicians. Newer modes of administration that may be useful in rapidly managing agitation include inhaled, buccal/sublingual, and intranasal formulations. To date, inhaled loxapine is the only formulation administered non-intramuscularly with a specific indication for bipolar or schizophrenia-related agitation. While noninvasive formulations require collaboration from patients, they have the potential to improve the overall patient experience, thereby enhancing future collaboration between patients and healthcare providers. CONCLUSION: Agitation management in the emergency department should include a patient-centered approach, including non-pharmacological approaches, if possible. Where pharmacological intervention is required, a collaborative approach using non-invasive drugs should be used where possible.

title: Pain management in high-risk patients in a patient-centered medical home
abstract: Chronic pain remains a major health problem despite significant advances in diagnosis, pharmacotherapy, and invasive and non-invasive interventions. The prevalence of chronic pain in the United States is staggering and continues to rise, and the personal and societal costs are not insignificant. The etiology of pain is complex, and individuals suffering from chronic pain tend to have significant medical and psychiatric comorbidities such as depression, anxiety, and in some cases, substance use disorders. There is great concern about the increasing rate of prescription opioid abuse/abuse, both for non-medical use and in patients with pain receiving chronic opioid therapy. While there is an ongoing debate about the "true" incidence of opioid abuse in the pain population, patients suffering from both pain and substance use disorders are particularly compelling. Most patients with chronic pain, including co-occurring substance use disorders, are treated in primary care. Primary care workers do not have the time, resources and training to effectively evaluate, treat and monitor these complex cases. A range of evidence and expert consensus-based treatment guidelines have been developed on opioid therapy and risk reduction, but they are underutilized in both specialty and primary care clinics. This article will discuss the use of new technologies and delivery systems for risk stratification, intervention and monitoring of patients taking painful opioids.

title: Panic attack management in emergency patients
abstract: Patients experiencing panic attacks often seek help in emergency rooms. However, it can be difficult to distinguish panic symptoms from some common medical emergencies. Also, many emergency medicine clinicians may not be equipped to effectively deal with panic attacks and related psychiatric conditions such as panic disorder and agoraphobia. Early misdiagnosis and inadequate management of panic attacks can have devastating long-term clinical and financial consequences. The purpose of this article is to provide information designed to increase the comfort and effectiveness of emergency physicians and associate professionals in coping with panic attacks. The authors provide guidelines for differential diagnosis, provide strategies for the management of acute panic and anxiety symptoms, and make recommendations for short-term postpanic clinical intervention.

title: Managing perceived conflicts of interest while enabling continuous innovation of medical technology
abstract: Many of these advanced therapies used every day in vascular interventional surgery would not exist without the ongoing collaboration between vascular surgeons and the med technology industry. The flip side of this coin is that these vital relationships create multiple roles for surgeons and must be managed appropriately. The dynamic innovation process, along with factors such as improving product delivery techniques, training, testing and clinical trials, and product support, require continuous and close collaboration between surgeons and the device industry. This unique relationship sometimes leads to a perceived conflict of interest for physicians, in part because the competing pressures arising from multiple, overlapping roles such as clinician/caregiver/researcher/innovator/client are important. To address this issue, the Advanced Medical Technology Association (AdvaMed), the nation's largest medical technology association representing medical device and diagnostic companies, has developed a Code of Ethics to guide medical technology companies in their interactions with healthcare professionals. First introduced in 1993, the AdvaMed Code encourages both industry and physicians to commit to openness and high ethical standards in the conduct of their business interactions. The AdvaMed Code addresses the many types of interactions that can occur between companies and healthcare professionals, including training, consulting engagements, provision of demonstration and evaluation units, and charitable donations. By following the Code, Companies send a strong message that treatment decisions should always be made in the best interests of the patient.

title: Management of urinary incontinence in stroke rehabilitation -- a review
abstract: OBJECTIVE: Post-stroke urinary incontinence is a common problem that affects future well-being and care for patients and their relatives. There are many therapeutic interventions available, but their effectiveness is not known in detail. The ongoing question for rehabilitation practice is how best to treat Urinary Incontinence (UI) in a way that does not endanger patients' daily lives. METHODS: The clinical trial search was conducted in PubMed, CINAHL, and the Cochrane Library, limited to German and English articles published between 1989 and April 2005. Medical, nursing, and physiotherapy interventions for the treatment of post-stroke UI were described and analyzed. RESULTS: Clinical trials were divided into process-oriented trials and trials looking at individual interventions. Process trials can be divided into three different groups with an overall success of 82-95%, 50-56% and 23-36%, respectively. Behavioral methods (caregiver-induced, patient-active, and other interventions) and medical interventions are available. The work of the most successful group includes staff training and the implementation of interventions based on an assessment procedure and a guideline. No clinical studies of individual interventions have come to the same conclusion as process-oriented studies. CONCLUSION: A multimodal approach is required to treat urinary incontinence: specific training of nurses, eg practice and acting in a problem-solving process such as the Rehabilitation Cycle, and providing care based on an assessment procedure and guidelines. It may be recommended to develop a guideline for the treatment of urinary incontinence after stroke. More research is needed on the effectiveness of individual interventions.

title: Marketing an investigational drug service
abstract: The customer survey was a useful tool for marketing the IDS. It provided guidelines for making decisions about the best use of limited human and material resources. Analyzing the results of the survey provided new priorities and directions for IDS. These results were then used with pharmacy financial and operational data to focus on areas of greatest importance to customers and the pharmacy. Physicians should not be reluctant to pursue compassionate use treatments because of the administrative program responsibilities that accompany such programs. Every patient should have the opportunity to benefit from alternative treatments under investigation. Nurses must be well-trained in order to maintain the quality of patient care and even increase it while studies are being carried out. Marketing research fulfilled its purpose of identifying service gaps and enabling us to improve our services.

title: Massachusetts General Physicians Organization's quality incentive program delivers encouraging results
abstract: Doctors are increasingly becoming salaried employees of hospitals or large groups of doctors. However, few published reports have evaluated provider-oriented quality incentive programs for salaried physicians. In 2006, the Massachusetts General Physicians Organization launched a quality incentive program for salaried physicians. Eligible physicians were given performance targets for three quality measures every six months. Incentive payments can be as much as 2 percent of a doctor's annual income. Over the thirteen six-month period, the program used 130 different quality measures. While quality of care improvements and cost reductions are difficult to calculate, anecdotal evidence points to multiple successes. For example, the program helped doctors meet many federal health information technology meaningful use criteria and generated $15.5 million in incentive payments. The program also facilitated electronic health record adoption, improved hand hygiene compliance, increased efficiency in the radiology and cancer center, and reduced emergency room use. The program showed that even small incentives based on carefully structured criteria, prioritization, and open communication can help change salaried doctors' behavior in ways that improve the quality and safety of health care and alleviate doctors' sense of administrative burden.

title: MASTERPLAN: examining the role of nurse practitioners in a multifactorial intervention to reduce cardiovascular risk in patients with chronic kidney disease.
abstract: Moderate to severe chronic kidney disease (CKD) is associated with increased cardiovascular risk. Generally, nephrologists are primarily responsible for the care of CKD patients. However, in many cases the treatment goals as formulated in the guidelines are not achieved. Adding a nurse practitioner can improve the quality of care. The Multifactor Approach and Superior Treatment Efficacy in Renal Patients Assisted by Nurse Practitioners (MASTERPLAN) study is a randomized controlled multicenter study aimed at investigating whether there is a multifactor approach to achieve treatment in patients with moderate to severe CKD (stages 3 and 4). Goals that use both a multidrug strategy and lifestyle therapy with or without the addition of a nurse practitioner will reduce cardiovascular risk and slow the decline of kidney function. Patients (n=793) were randomized to nurse care or physician care. In the nurse-care arm of the study, nurse practitioners use flowcharts to address risk factors that require medication and/or lifestyle changes. They are trained to coach patients through motivational interviewing to improve patients' self-management. At baseline, both treatment groups showed equal distributions for key variables in the study. Moreover, in only 1 patient, all of the risk factors were within the limits defined in various guidelines, emphasizing the relevance of our intervention.

title: Maternal dietary intake and physical activity habits in the postpartum period: associations with clinician advice in a sample of Australian first-time mothers.
abstract: BACKGROUND: Numerous health benefits have been associated with achieving optimal dietary and physical activity behaviors during and after pregnancy. Understanding the predictors of these behaviors is an important public health concern, but little is known about the relationships between clinician advice and dietary and physical activity behaviors in postpartum women. The aim of this study was to compare the frequency of dietary and physical activity recommendations given by clinicians during and after pregnancy and to evaluate whether this advice is related to postpartum diet and physical activity behaviors. METHODS: First-time mothers enrolled in the Melbourne InFANT Extend trial (n = 448) completed the Australian Cancer Council's Food Frequency Questionnaire three to four months after birth, which evaluated normal fruit and vegetable intake (serving/day). Total physical activity time for the previous week, time spent walking, and time spent in both moderate and vigorous activity (min/week) were assessed using the Active Australia Questionnaire.
