Advice received during and after pregnancy was assessed with separate questionnaire items asking whether a healthcare professional had discussed eating a healthy diet and being physically active. Linear and logistic regression evaluated the association of recommendations with dietary intake and physical activity. RESULTS: Overall, 8.6% of women met guidelines for combined fruit and vegetable intake. Overall, the mean total physical activity time was 350.9 +/- 281.1 min/week. Time spent walking (251.97 +/- 196.78 min/week), moderate (36.68 +/- 88.58 min/week) or vigorous activity (61.74 +/- 109.96 min/week) ) was more than time spent, and 63.2% of women meet physical activity recommendations. Most of the women reported that they received advice on healthy eating (87.1%) and physical activity (82.8%) during pregnancy. Fewer women reported receiving recommendations for healthy diet (47.5%) and physical activity (51.9%) three months after giving birth. There was no significant relationship between dietary and/or physical activity advice and maternal dietary intakes or physical activity levels. CONCLUSIONS: Recommendation for healthy eating and physical activity was received less after pregnancy than during pregnancy, but no association was observed between taking advice and behavior. More intensive approaches than advice may be required to encourage healthy eating and physical activity behaviors in new mothers. TRIAL REGISTRATION: Australian New Zealand Clinical Trials Registry (ACTRN12611000386932 13/04/2011).

title: McMaster PLUS: a clustered randomized clinical trial of an intervention to accelerate the clinical use of evidence-based information from digital libraries
abstract: Background: Doctors have trouble keeping up with new evidence from medical research. Methods: We developed the McMaster Premium LiteratUre Service (PLUS), an internet-based addition to an existing digital library, providing physicians with quality and relevance-grade medical literature appropriate to their clinical discipline. We evaluated PLUS in a clustered randomized trial of 203 participating physicians in Northern Ontario and compared the Full-Serve version (containing alerts for new articles and a cumulative database of alerts) to the Self-Service version (containing a passive guideline). evidence-based literature). Usage of the service was the primary trial endpoint. Results: Average number of library logins increased by 0.77 logins/month/user (95% CI 0.43, 1.11) in the Full Service group compared to the Self-Service group. The proportion of Full Service participants benefiting from the service in each month of the study period showed a sustained increase during the intervention period, with a relative increase of 57% (95% CI 12,123) compared to the Self-Service group. There was no difference in these rates at baseline, and following the transition of the Self-Service group to Full-Service, use of the Self-Service group became indistinguishable from that of the Full-Service group (relative difference 4.4 (95%) CI -23.7, 43.0). At the intervention and crossover periods, self-reported measures of usefulness did not differ between the 2 groups. Conclusion: A quality and relevance-rated online literature service increased the use of evidence-based resources. Information from a digital library by physicians.

title: Measures to assess practice change in medical practitioners
abstract: BACKGROUND: There is an increasing number of randomized studies and systematic reviews examining the effectiveness of interventions designed to bring about a change in clinical practice. The findings of this research are used to guide strategies to increase the uptake of evidence into clinical practice. Knowledge of the outcomes measured by these trials is vital not only for the interpretation and application of work to date, but also for informing future research in this expanding field of study and helping to collate results in systematic reviews and meta-analyses. . METHODS: The purpose of this review was to identify methods used to measure change in the clinical practice of healthcare professionals following an intervention aimed at increasing the application of evidence. All published studies (n = 228) included in a recent, comprehensive Health Technology Assessment of interventions to implement clinical practice guidelines and change clinical practice formed the sample for this study. Using a standard data extraction form, a reviewer (SH) extracted relevant information from the methods and/or results sections of the studies. CONCLUSIONS: Measures of behavior change by health practitioners are the most common, with 88.8% of studies being used as an outcome measure. Measures assessing patient-level change, true change measures, or surrogate change measures were used in 28.8% and (respectively) 36.7% of studies. The knowledge and attitudes of health practitioners were evaluated in 22.8% of the studies and organizational changes in 17.6%. CONCLUSION: Most intervention trials aimed at changing clinical practice have measured the impact of the intervention at the practitioner level, ie did the practitioner change what they do or have their knowledge and/or attitudes about this practice changed? Less than a third of the trials measured resulted in a change in the final endpoint of the patient's health status, with or without any change in practice.

title: Measuring and Monitoring Success in Compressing Morbidity
Measuring application persistence: QUERI Series
abstract: As more quality improvement programs are implemented to achieve performance gains, the need to assess their lasting impact has become increasingly evident. However, such long-term follow-up assessments in healthcare practice science are scarce, and most project papers are largely reduced to the "needs further research" section. This article examines various conceptualizations of practice sustainability, as well as behavioral and organizational factors that influence the maintenance of achievements. It highlights design highlights and draws on our own experience in measuring sustainability, framed by the rich theoretical and empirical contributions of others. In addition, suggestions were made for the design of sustainability analyzes. This article is one of a series of articles documenting application science frameworks and approaches developed by the U.S. Department of Veterans Affairs' Quality Improvement Research Initiative (QUERI).

title: Measuring the effectiveness of collaboration for quality improvement in pediatric asthma care: does the implementation of the chronic care model improve processes and outcomes of care?
abstract: Aim." To examine whether a collaboration to improve pediatric asthma care positively impacts processes and outcomes of that care. Methods.– Medical record abstractions and patient/parent interviews were used to make pre- and post-intervention comparisons of patients in 4 matched control regions and patients in 9 regions participating in the evaluation of a collaborative Breakthrough Series (BTS) for asthma care. . Setting.â€”Thirteen primary care clinics. Patients.— Three hundred and eighty-five asthmatic children receiving care in an intervention clinic and 126 asthmatic children receiving care in a control clinic (response rate = 76%). Intervention.—Three 2-day training sessions for quality improvement teams from participating sites, followed by 3 “action” periods over one year. Results.â€”Overall course of asthma care improved significantly in the intervention group but remained unchanged in the control group (change in process score +13% vs. 0%"; P < .0001). Patients in the intervention group were more likely to peak than patients in the control group. better overall health-related quality of life (scale score 80 77 versus 77; P = .05) and asthma-specific quality of life associated with treatment problems (scale score 89 versus 85; "P < .05). Results.—The intervention improved some important aspects of care processes that were previously linked to better outcomes. Patients receiving care in intervention clinics also reported higher overall and asthma-specific quality of life.

title: Measuring the effectiveness of mentoring as a knowledge translation intervention to apply empirical evidence: a systematic review.
abstract: BACKGROUND: Mentoring as a knowledge translation (KT) intervention uses social influence among healthcare professionals to increase the use of evidence in clinical practice. OBJECTIVE: To determine the effectiveness of mentoring as a KT intervention designed to increase the use of evidence by healthcare professionals in clinical practice. METHODS: A systematic review was performed using electronic databases (ie, MEDLINE, CINAHL), gray literature, and manual search. Appropriate studies have evaluated the consultation of healthcare professionals responsible for patient care to increase the application of the evidence. Mentoring, (a) a more experienced mentor than the mentee"; (b) individualized support based on the mentee's needs;" and (c) to be involved in a specified interpersonal relationship of mutual benefit, commitment and commitment. Two reviewers independently screened citations for relevance, extracted data, and quality of evaluated studies. The data were analyzed descriptively. RESULTS: From 1988 to 2012, 10 studies were eligible from 10,669 citations. Mentoring as a KT intervention has been evaluated in Canada, the USA and Australia. Exposure to mentoring improved some behavioral outcomes compared to no mentoring (one study). Compared with controls or other multi-pronged interventions, multifaceted interventions involving mentoring improved practitioners' knowledge (four out of five studies), beliefs (four out of six studies), and impact on institutional outcomes (three out of four studies). There was mixed evidence for changes in professionals' behavior and its impact on practitioners' and patients' outcomes: some outcomes improved while others showed no difference. LINKING EVIDENCE TO ACTION: Only one study evaluated the effectiveness of mentoring alone as a PT intervention and showed improvement in some behavioral outcomes. Nine other studies evaluating the effectiveness of mentoring as part of a multifaceted intervention showed mixed findings, making it difficult to determine the additive effect of mentoring. More research is needed to identify effective mentoring as a KT intervention.

title: Measuring the effects of reminders for outpatient flu vaccines at the clinical point of opportunity
abstract: OBJECTIVE: To evaluate the impact of computer-based reminders about the flu vaccine at each clinical opportunity on the behavior of individual clinicians. DESIGN: The authors conducted a four-year prospective study of clinicians' flu vaccine behavior. About half of clinicians in an internal medicine clinic used a computer-based patient record system (CPR users) that created computer-based reminders. Other clinicians used traditional paper records (PR users). MEASUREMENTS: Each non-acute visit of a patient eligible for influenza vaccination was considered an opportunity for intervention. Patients with vaccine contraindications were excluded from the study. Guideline compliance was defined as documents showing that a clinician ordered the vaccine, advised the patient about the vaccine, recommended it to a patient who refused the vaccine, or confirmed that the patient had received the vaccine elsewhere. The authors calculated the proportion of opportunities where each clinician documented action in CPR and PR user groups. RESULTS: CPR and PR user groups had different baseline compliance rates (40.1 and 27.9 percent, respectively)";" P<0.05). Both rates remained stable over an initial two-year period (P = 0.34 and P = 0.47), respectively. While compliance rates in the CPR user group increased by 78 percent from baseline (P<0.001), the rates for the PR user group did not change significantly (P = 0.18). RESULTS: Clinicians administering CPR with reminders had higher rates of documentation of compliance with influenza vaccination guidelines than those using paper records. Measures of individual clinician behavior at each clinical opportunity point can provide a precise assessment of interventions designed to improve adherence to guidelines.

title: Medical admission scheme sets to improve deep vein thrombosis prophylaxis rates and other outcomes
abstract: Preliminary results were presented as a poster at the American Medical Informatics Association Annual Meeting, Washington, DC, October 2005. After the work was completed, the CO and KD became stewards of Open Source Order Sets (OSOS), a company that created an order. Set collaborative for Canadian hospitals. OSOS had no involvement in the current study. This work has not received special funding. JF is supported by the Canadian Institutes of Health Research (CIHR) Clinician Scientist Award. We thank Barbara Stanek for her invaluable assistance in collecting health records data.

title: Medical care of type 2 diabetes in the light of international and national recommendations: a retrospective analysis.
abstract: STUDY FIELD QUESTION: Type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2Dm) is a chronic disease with great economic impact. In 2009, the Swiss Society of Endocrinology and Diabetes (SSED) published recommendations for the treatment of T2Dm. There is currently very little data on metabolic control and physician compliance with treatment guidelines in Switzerland. We aimed to explore clinical care in T2Dm in the year following the publication of the SSED recommendations. METHODS: We retrospectively analyzed the charts of all patients with T2Dm who applied to our general internal medicine clinic in 2009. Metabolic control was assessed from glycosylated hemoglobin A1c (HbA1c) levels. Antidiabetic therapy was analyzed and screening frequencies for end-organ damage were investigated. A group with newly diagnosed T2Dm was analyzed separately from patients with known T2Dm at presentation. RESULTS: The mean (+/- standard deviation) HbA1c level in patients known to have T2Dm was 7.66% +/- 1.73%. Only 44% of patients showed HbA1c levels within the target of 8.5%, with the proportion of those treated with insulin increasing from 49% at admission to 76% at discharge. Only half of the patients received a lifestyle intervention in the year prior to hospitalization or during their hospital stay. Diabetic retinopathy and nephropathy screening were performed in approximately one-third and two-thirds of patients, respectively. CONCLUSIONS: Most of the unselected T2Dm patients admitted to our hospital had inadequate metabolic control. Implementation of treatment recommendations by both general practitioners and hospitals should be improved.

title: Medical communication and technology: a video-based process study on the use of decision aids in primary care consultations.
abstract: BACKGROUND: Most research on decision-making in healthcare has focused on consultation outcomes. Less is known about the process by which clinicians and patients arrive at treatment decisions. This study aimed to quantitatively describe the behavior displayed by physicians and patients during primary care consultations when three types of decision aids were used to promote treatment decision making in a randomized controlled trial. METHODS: A video-based study in an activity trial comparing the use of paper-based guidelines (control) with two types of computer-based decision aids (implicit and explicit versions of DATS II). The treatment decision was related to warfarin anti-coagulation to reduce the risk of stroke in elderly patients with atrial fibrillation. Twenty-nine interviews were videotaped. A ten-minute consultation 'section' was sampled for detailed content analysis using existing interaction analysis protocols for verbal behavior and ethological techniques for nonverbal behavior. RESULTS: Median consultation times (quartiles) varied significantly depending on the technology used. Paper-based guides took 21 (19-26) minutes to run, 31 (16-41) minutes for the covered tool, and 44 (39-55) minutes for the open tool. At the decision point, GPs dominated speech accounting for 64% (58-66%) of all statements, and this trend was similar across all three arms of the study. Providing information for both GPs and patients was the most frequent activity for GPs and patients. , however, GPs did so at twice the rate of patients and at higher rates in consultations involving computerized decision aids. The language of the GPs was highly technical and only 7% of their speech was socio-emotional in content," which was half the socio-emotional content (15%) that patients showed. showed that both parties were actively involved in the conversation in these consultations. However, even in consultations aimed at promoting collaborative decision-making, GPs were verbally dominant and primarily acted as providers of information for patients. Additionally, computer-based decision aids, especially in the later stages, These data suggest that decision aids may not lead to more 'sharing' in treatment decision making and may take too long to negotiate for routine primary care use in their current form.

title: Medical Diagnosis Through Semiotics: Making Meaning of the Sign
abstract: Physicians are busy incorporating quantitative methods into their practice to make clinical decisions. Getting acquainted with semiotics, the doctrine of signs, can complete this project. A sign represents something. We communicate indirectly through signs, and by interpreting what the signs mean, we make sense of our world and diagnose and understand our patients. Thus, by association and inference, we turn flowers into love, Othello into envy, and staring eyes into thyrotoxicosis. Characteristically, in diagnosis, we begin with an unstable inference, test it, and ask questions that are likely to otherwise produce signs that support (or discredit) our thinking. hypothesis. In a literary sense, we unite with the author to clarify and rewrite the text"; creative interpretation is key. Diagnosis is concluded through narration, with the meaning that emerges by telling the patient's story. Diagnosis is successful only to the extent that we respect the principles and caveats of sign interpretation. The sign is both the key to the unknown and the key to the unknown. he is also a master imitator. Sign and meaning are often not the same;" meaning must be deduced. Because interpretations are subjective, they are limited by the clinician's experience and bias. Also, the contexts in which the sign appears shape its meaning and can change it completely.

title: Medical ethics in a revolutionary age
Medical research and Alzheimer's disease: a study of the perils of conducting research on the incompetent patient
abstract: Following a review of the legal issues regarding capacity and the importance of consent in the context of clinical trials involving patient groups, some of which may be inadequate, the question of how those involved in the field are solving problems is addressed. Responses from 101 Local Research Ethics Committees, 13 pharmaceutical companies, and 10 researchers working with patients with Alzheimer's Disease indicate a significant difference in approaches to legal and ethical issues, as well as some degree of conflict regarding assessment of patients' capacities. confirmation. Consequently, several aspects of the Law Commission's recent proposals in this area need further consideration and elaboration.

title: Medical research: the role and responsibilities of doctors
abstract: The General Medical Council in the UK has decided to join the multitude of organizations that have already published numerous national and international research conduct guidelines. This may have to do with the fact that the UK, through the GMC, takes research misconduct more seriously than most countries, except that GMC has developed separate guidelines in this area with the Royal College of Physicians. Therefore, the purpose of any other set of guidelines is unclear, although they will be professionally binding for physicians. Draft guidelines are open for comment until 21 June and are reprinted below.

title: Medical management of benign prostatic hyperplasia: physician and patient preferences and satisfaction.
abstract: Practice guidelines recognize the importance of patient preferences in determining the appropriate treatment of benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH). Recent literature suggests that patient and physician perspectives and satisfaction with BPH treatment management may differ," which may have an impact on clinical outcomes and patient compliance. This review will review the treatment options patients and physicians choose to manage BPH, and patient satisfaction with treatment. A Medline-based systematic review using the terms 'benign prostatic hyperplasia' + 'Patient preference/perception/satisfaction' or 'Doctor/urologist preference/perception' was conducted. Patients reported long-term disease progression relative to those who achieved short-term symptom relief, which contradicted their physician's beliefs. They prefer treatments that affect Evidence suggests that patients' views and beliefs may not always agree with the views of their doctors. Improved doctor-patient communication will help determine the best treatment option for patients with BPH and can lead to greater compliance and treatment success.

title: Medication Compromise During Care Transitions as a Patient Safety Strategy
abstract: Medication reconciliation identifies and resolves unintentional inconsistencies between patients' medication lists throughout transitions in care. The purpose of this review is to summarize the evidence on the effectiveness of hospital-based medication reconciliation interventions. Searches covered MEDLINE until November 2012 and EMBASE and the Cochrane Central Register of Controlled Trials by July 2012. Eligible studies evaluated the effects of hospital-based medication reconciliation on 30-day emergency room visits to patients or post-discharge and unintentional inconsistencies involving insignificant risks for harm to patients and readmission Two reviewers evaluated study relevance, summarized data, and evaluated study quality. Eighteen studies evaluating 20 interventions met selection criteria. Pharmacists reconciled medication in 17 of 20 interventions. Most of the unintentional inconsistencies detected were not of clinical significance. Medication consensus alone will likely not reduce post-discharge hospital use, but it may do so when combined with interventions aimed at improving care transitions.

title: Drug review and reconciliation with collaboration between pharmacist and GP and patient benefit: a systematic review.
abstract: This article systematically reviews the literature on the impact of collaboration between pharmacists and GPs and explains its impact on patient health. A systematic literature review yielded 1041 articles. After the initial review of the title and abstract, 152 articles remained. After reviewing the full text, 83 articles were included. All included articles were presented according to the following variables: (i) reference"; (ii) study design and location; (iii) inclusion criteria for patients; (iv) description of the intervention; (v) whether there was a patient interview; experience, (vi) outcome, (vii) whether HCWs have received additional training, and (viii) whether HCWs have received financial reimbursement Work together to improve patients' health Only nine studies have had difficult conditions such as (re)admissions to hospital reported results;" however, these studies all had different results that were not statistically significant. Randomized controlled trials should be able to define difficult outcomes, but large patient groups will be needed to perform such studies. Patient involvement is important for long-term success.

title: Medicine and human rights: reflections on the fiftieth anniversary of the doctors' trial
abstract: 1996 marks the fiftieth anniversary of the start of the trial of the Nazi doctors in Nuremberg, which has been variously called the "Doctors Trial" and the "Medical Trial". Besides documenting the atrocities committed by doctors and scientists during World War II, the most important contribution of the trial came to be known as the "Nuremberg Law", a forensic codification of 10 prerequisites for the moral and legal use of humans in experiments. Anniversaries give us the opportunity to reflect on the past, but they also allow us to renew our efforts to plan for the future. This article briefly explains the historical development of the Nuremberg Law, discusses its current validity and applicability using a case study example, and suggests future steps by the international community.

title: Meeting expectations: pilot review of the Solihull Approach Parenting Group
abstract: We have developed a new parenting group for conduct disorder based on the National Institutes of Health and Clinical Excellence guidelines for parenting groups and the Solihull Approach, a multi-institutional approach to improving parent-child relationship and behavior management. Our goal was to create a theoretically coherent, proven effectiveness, time efficient, accessible, manageable parenting group for parents with children from birth to 18 years old, accessible to parents with literacy difficulties, from universal to more complex issues. Community practitioners such as health visitors and school nurses are supported by a cost-effective and uncomplicated staff training model. This article describes the development of the Solihull Approach Parenting Group and the results of the first large-scale pilot evaluation. The results show an improvement in child behavior and a reduction in parental anxiety.

title: Combining regulatory, pharmaceutical industry, and US payer perspectives on improving approaches to heterogeneity of treatment effect in research and practice
abstract: Effective monitoring and management of the science of heterogeneity of treatment effect (IIT) relies on mutual understanding and collaboration of the perspectives of various stakeholders in healthcare. In this article, we compare, contrast and try to find areas of alignment between the perspectives of three such stakeholders, namely regulators, the biopharmaceutical and device industry, and US payers. First, we discuss how evidence of IIT is produced and can be improved. For drugs, much of the initial research is conducted by the pharmaceutical industry, driven by basic science but also constrained by potential markets, regulatory approval requirements, trial size considerations, and expectations of those paying for proof of value. When a drug is marketed, more evidence can be produced by combining trial data, conducting meta-analysis, and analyzing real-world results through observational research designs"; we explore how these efforts can benefit from collaboration between these stakeholders. Second, we discuss the equally important use of IIT evidence so that physicians and patients can access and benefit from information from this research. Research findings should be translated into actionable information and guidelines that can be incorporated into daily practice. Doing so requires interaction and collaboration among everyone involved, based on facilitated communication as well as further evaluation research. We present examples of various cross-industry initiatives underway in this area. Finally, we explore some of the economic aspects of IIT research as part of the drug development, marketing, and treatment process. Understanding the economic incentives available is essential to align these incentives to improve the availability and use of IIT evidence. Clear understandings of high-value goals, ways to efficiently generate and communicate information, and value propositions among regulators, pharmaceuticals, and payers can lead to "win-win" scenarios for patients, individual payers, the overall healthcare system, and the future. drug development in the production of new drugs.

title: Menopause and exercise
abstract: OBJECTIVE: Accumulating data show that regular physical exercise reduces mortality and prolongs the functional life span of men and women. This review aims to describe the current state of the medical literature on this subject. METHODS: A narrative review of the current medical literature, including randomized clinical trials and clinical guidelines addressing the health benefits of physical fitness and regular exercise in middle-aged and postmenopausal women. CONCLUSIONS: Reducing and preventing obesity and related comorbidities (hypertension, glucose intolerance, dyslipidemia and heart disease) is one of the important benefits of exercise. However, prolonged physical exercise is also associated with cancer, dementia and cognitive decline, negative mood and anxiety symptoms, and reduced rates of osteoporosis, osteopenia, falls and fractures. Beneficial physical activity includes exercise to improve cardiovascular fitness (aerobics), muscle strength (resistance), flexibility (stretching), and balance (many of the former and additional activities such as yoga). CONCLUSIONS: Given that it is clearly beneficial, inexpensive and with minimal risk, maintaining a healthy exercise regimen should be the goal of every participant to improve lifelong well-being. Clinicians should use a range of behavioral strategies to support their participants' physical fitness goals.

title: The Mental Health Connection: development and formative evaluation of a complex intervention to improve shared care for patients with long-term mental illness.
abstract: OBJECTIVES AND OBJECTIVES: This study aims to develop an intervention and related conceptual framework to develop joint care for patients with long-term mental illness and to provide a case study of the development of a complex intervention in primary care. METHODS: It included a pragmatic iterative design, a literature review and focus groups, followed by a formative assessment that included reflection, questionnaires, and interviews. General practices and relevant community mental health teams in southeast London were included. Participants included community mental health workers, psychiatrists, practice nurses, general practitioners, administrators, and local specialists with an interest in primary care mental health services. RESULTS: The shared maintenance model includes key components of enhanced communication with the development of a registry and database with review and recall systems. Local needs assessment, audit, training and guidelines are complementary components. The Mental Health Link response is a streamlined quality improvement program that aims to accelerate the development of services by bringing teams together to agree on a shared care model appropriate to local needs, skills and interests, and by supporting the development of practice. systems. CONCLUSIONS: A model for shared care should take into account the interdependencies of the components as well as the relationship to the context. The heterogeneity of primary and community care needs to be reflected in the development of complex interventions designed to enhance shared care. It is possible to develop a complex, generalizable intervention sensitive to local conditions.

title: mentally ill families. When are children insecure?
abstract: This article examines the impact of parental mental illness on children's behavior and development. Early diagnosis and intervention is very important";" The child is often disregarded, especially if the parent is not overtly abusive. Support and help with parenting can be crucial for mentally ill parents to prevent relapse and improve a child's mental health. General practitioners have a crucial role in this process.

title: Meta-analysis: Effect of Diet Counseling on Weight Loss
abstract: Background: Dietary and lifestyle change efforts are primary treatments for people who are obese or overweight. The effect of dietary counseling on long-term weight change is unclear. Objective: To perform a meta-analysis of the effect of dietary counseling compared with usual care on body mass index (BMI) over time in adults. Data Sources: Early studies (1980 to 1997) from a previously published systematic review; MEDLINE and the Cochrane Central Registry of Controlled Trials from 1997 to July 2006. time) in overweight adults reporting the effect of dietary counseling on weight. The authors included only weight loss studies with a dietary component. Data Extraction: Single reviewers performed full data extraction; at least 1 additional reviewer reviewed the data. Data Synthesis: Random-effects model meta-analyses of 46 trials of dietary counseling, with a maximum net treatment effect in 12 BMI units âˆ'1.9 (95% CI, âˆ'2.3 to âˆ'1.5) (approximately 6%). revealed. months. Meta-analysis of changes in weight (slopes) and meta-regression over time shows a change of about 0.1 BMI units per month from 3 to 12 months of active programs and a recovery of about 0.02 to 0.03 BMI units per month during the following. maintenance stages. Different analyzes suggested that calorie recommendations, frequency of support meetings, inclusion of exercise, and diabetes may be independent predictors of weight change. Limitations: Interventions, study samples, and weight changes were heterogeneous. Studies generally had moderate to poor methodological quality. They had a high rate of missing data and could not explain these losses. Meta-analytical techniques could not fully explain these limitations. Conclusions: Compared with usual care, dietary counseling interventions produce modest weight losses that diminish over time. Future studies should focus on minimizing losses, monitoring and determining which factors result in more effective weight loss.

title: Methadone substitution - a scientific review in the context of outpatient treatment in Germany
abstract: The German Betaubungsmittelverschreibungsverordnung BtmVV (drug prescription regulation), 5 part 2, 01 July 2001 commissioned the German Medical Association to develop guidelines for methadone maintenance therapy according to the latest state of medical-scientific technology. A joint commission of the German Medical Association and the National Association of Statutory Health Insurance Physicians developed guidelines for the substitution treatment of opioid addiction, which were adopted by the board of directors of the German Medical Association in March 2002 and published on May 24 in Deutsche Arzteblatt. 2002. This study is a systematic review of the scientific literature on successful treatment in general, as well as specific aspects of methadone substitution therapy considered by the guidelines of the German Medical Association. The literature has been updated to January 2004. Older randomized controlled trials and more recent quasi-experimental studies suggest methadone maintenance therapy to reduce illicit drug use, improve health status of drug users, reduce criminal behavior, and promote rehabilitation of opiate-dependent individuals. Evaluation of international studies clearly shows that beyond the diagnosis of opiate addiction, criteria for accessing substitution treatment, for example the presence of a life-threatening comorbidity, are not a prerequisite for substitution in other countries and are therefore not discussed internationally. literature. Study evidence shows that the German Medical Association's guidelines for substitution treatment of opiate addiction reflect the best evidence from scientific studies and apply it to the conditions of the German healthcare system.

title: Methodology and Reporting of Mobile Health and Smartphone Application Studies for Schizophrenia
abstract: The increasing prevalence of mobile devices among patients of all demographics has the potential to change the way we diagnose, monitor, treat and work with mental illness. As new tools and technologies emerge, clinicians and researchers are faced with an increasing array of options, both for clinical assessment through digital capture of key behavioral elements of a condition, and for intervention through formalized treatments, coaching, and other technology-assisted interventions. patient communication tools. Yet, as with any new toolkit for the assessment or treatment of a medical condition, establishing and adhering to reporting guidelines – that is, what works and under what circumstances – is an essential component of the translation research process. Here, we review the methodological strengths and weaknesses of existing studies of smartphones and wearables for schizophrenia, using the recently published World Health Organization mHealth Assessment, Reporting and Evaluation guidelines to evaluate mobile health applications. While growing evidence supports the feasibility of using mobile devices in severe mental illness, most studies to date have not adequately reported on accessibility, interoperability, costs, scalability, reproducibility, data security, usability testing, or compliance with national guidelines or regulatory regulations. Future research efforts that address these specific gaps in the literature will help improve our understanding and realize the clinical potential of these new psychiatric tools.

title: Methods of treating cognitive deficits in schizophrenia
abstract: Studies from the molecular level to the clinical level show that cognitive dysfunction is central to characterizing schizophrenia. Accordingly, there have been increasing efforts to seek effective treatments for these broad and debilitating cognitive deficits. Three general strategies have emerged in the literature to treat cognitive dysfunction in schizophrenia. Second-generation (atypical) antipsychotic drugs have received much attention, but their procognitive effects tend to be modest. Augmentation strategies originating from basic science or translation research have often been promising in small uncontrolled trials";" however, few agents have been successful in rigorously designed trials. Behavioral interventions have shown positive effects that generalize to other symptom areas and persist after the intervention, but tend to be costly and labor-intensive. Thus, although there have been some exciting developments in the treatment of cognitive dysfunction, the gains to date have been modest and the search for treatment methods continues.

title: Reminders created by microcomputer. Improving primary care physicians' compliance with mammography screening guidelines
abstract: Recent studies have documented that physicians' adherence to recommended periodic health screening increases by reminding physicians. However, these reminders are often costly to maintain and replace. This study investigates the effect of a microcomputer tickling system on the sequencing of mammograms. All women aged 40 years and older (N = 1262) who visited the outpatient clinic within a 6-month period were randomly assigned to one of two groups. For the experimental group, the date of the last mammogram ordered and recorded in the clinical database was written on the interview form created for each patient visit. No information about previous mammograms was printed for patients in the control group. Women in the experimental group were more likely to be requested for mammography during the study period (19% vs. 12%, P = .001) and, as a result, were more likely to follow mammography guidelines when the study was completed. (27% compared to 21%, P = .011). Microcomputerized data storage and retrieval systems can help increase physician interest in preventive health screening recommendations.

title: Reminders created by microcomputer. Improving the compliance of primary care physicians with mammography screening guidelines.
abstract: A study was conducted to investigate the effect of microcomputer-generated "reminders" that prompt doctors to schedule periodic mammographic scans for patients. The main reasons clinicians do not perform health screening tests such as mammograms include forgetfulness, lack of time, discomfort, and patient discomfort or rejection. The doctor's refusal to recommend a mammogram is usually due to the doctor's supervision during the patient visit. This study shows that a microcomputerized reminder system can be used to increase physicians' compliance with preventive health screening recommendations. An experimental system resulted in a 50 percent increase in mammogram ordering for a group of women over 40 who participated in the study.

title: Minimal risk, administrative firm trials, and informed consent
Minimizing errors of omission: behavioral reinforcement of heparin to prevent venous embolism: the BEHAVE study.
abstract: OBJECTIVE: To increase patient safety by increasing heparin thromboprophylaxis for medical-surgical intensive care unit patients, using a multi-method approach to evidence-based guideline development and implementation. DESIGN: A prospective longitudinal observational study. ENVIRONMENT: Medical-surgical intensive care unit. PARTICIPANTS: Multidisciplinary clinicians caring for critically ill patients in a 15-bed closed medical-surgical intensive care unit. INTERVENTIONS: Stage 1 was an initial period of 3 months during which we documented anticoagulation and mechanical thromboprophylaxis. Phase 2 was a 1-year period in which we implemented a thromboprophylaxis guideline using a) "interactive multidisciplinary training services"; b) verbal reminders to the ICU team; c) computerized daily nurse thromboprophylaxis record; d) using weekly chart feedback on adherence to the guideline to individual intensive care specialists. ;" and e) publicly displayed graphical feedback on group performance. Stage 3 was a 3-month follow-up period, during which we documented thromboprophylaxis 10 months later. In this period, the computerized daily nurse record of thromboprophylaxis was continued. MEASUREMENTS AND MAIN RESULTS: Although patients in stage 2 had higher Acute Physiology and Chronic Health Assessment II scores than patients in stages 1 and 3, ICU and hospital mortality rates were similar between stages. Rate (median % [interquartile range]) ICU patient-days heparin thromboprophylaxis in phases 1, 2, and 3, respectively, were 60.0 (0, 100), 90.9 (50, 100), and 100.0 (60, 100) (p= .01). The proportion of days of accidental omission of heparin thromboprophylaxis at stages 1, 2, and 3 (median % [interquartile range]) were 20 (0.53.8), 0 (0.6.3), and 0 (0.0). , respectively (p<.001). CONCLUSION: After the development and implementation of an evidence-based thromboprophylaxis guideline, we found significantly more patients receiving heparin thromboprophylaxis. Adherence to the guideline was maintained after 1 year. More research is needed on what are the most effective strategies for implementing patient safety interventions in the ICU.

title: Misprescribing of controlled substances: Evaluation of a professional development program
abstract: BACKGROUND: Controlled prescription drug (CPD) abuse has reached epidemic proportions in the United States. Most physicians who participate in a 3-day continuing medical education (CME) professional development program (PDP) lack training in identifying risk and managing patients who abuse CPDs. To address this issue, the authors evaluated a PDP that trains physicians to prescribe correctly, identify substance abuse, utilize screening, brief intervention and referral to treatment (SBIRT), and practice motivational interviewing (MI). METHODS: The authors conducted a program evaluation to evaluate the efficacy and impact of PDP on physicians' knowledge and prescribing behavior. RESULTS: Participants (N = 174) were typically middle-aged (mean age 53 years), male (89%), physicians (82%), and other healthcare professionals (18%). Many doctors work alone in primary health care (46%). Course assessments were completed by n = 155 (89%) participants who rated the course and presenters highly (mean 4.8/5, respectively). Physicians' knowledge scores at pre/post assessments increased significantly: pretest (Mean = 58.7, SD = 13.12) and posttest (Mean = 78.28, SD = 9.83) (t(173) = 20.06, P </= .0001 , 95% confidence interval, CI: [-21.51, -17.65]). Almost half of the respondents, n = 83/174 (48%), completed the follow-up questionnaire and 93% agreed/strongly agreed (A/SA) that they had made professional practice changes. Most respondents working with an active DEA registration (n = 57) agreed/strongly agreed that they implemented changes to align their practices with current guidelines (89%), used CPD more appropriately (87%), set up office prescribing (81%), identifying and referral to more drug addicts (80%), sharing new knowledge/experiences from the course with 25 other healthcare professionals (93%), and felt that the course positively impacted their behavior personally and professionally (90% and 96%). CONCLUSION: This is the first known study to evaluate a PDP in this population. Results showed participant satisfaction and improvement in prescriber knowledge and self-reported prescribing behaviors. However, more studies are needed to assess actual clinical practice changes, the direct impact on patient outcomes, and recidivism rates.

title: Reducing Prenatal Zika Virus Infection in the Americas
abstract: Background: Because of the risk of Zika virus infection in the United States and the links between infection and microcephaly, other serious neurological conditions and fetal death, health departments in the region have advised women to delay pregnancy. However, the effectiveness of this policy in reducing prenatal Zika virus infection has yet to be measured. Objective: To evaluate the effectiveness of pregnancy delay policies on the incidence and prevalence of prenatal Zika virus infection. Design: Vector-borne Zika virus transmission model consistent with epidemiological data from 2015 to 2016 on Zika virus infection in Colombia. Setting: Colombia, August 2015 - July 2017. Patients: Colombian population classified by sex, age, and pregnancy status. Intervention: Recommendations to delay pregnancy by 3, 6, 9, 12 or 24 months at different levels of compliance. Measurements: Weekly and cumulative incidence of prenatal infections and cases of microcephaly. Conclusions: With 50% adherence to recommendations to delay pregnancy for 9 to 24 months, the cumulative incidence of prenatal Zika virus infections is likely to decrease by 17% to 44%, while recommendations to delay pregnancy for 6 or less months are likely to increase. prenatal infections in 2% to 7%. This paradoxical exacerbation of prenatal Zika virus exposure is due to an increased risk of pregnancies shifting towards the peak of the epidemic. Limitation: Due to limited data, sexual transmission was not explicitly accounted for in the model, but was implicitly included in the overall transmission rate calibrated by observed incidence. Conclusion: Pregnancy delays can have a significant impact on reducing the incidence of microcephaly, but there is a risk of exacerbating the Zika virus epidemic if the duration is not sufficient. Latency, population cohesion, and timing of initiation of intervention should be carefully considered. Primary Funding Source: National Institutes of Health.

title: Mobile diabetes intervention study: testing a personalized therapy/behavioral communication intervention for blood glucose control
abstract: BACKGROUND: National data included glycemic control within target (A1c or =7.5%) in study groups based on PCP randomization at baseline (n=260). All study patients receive blood glucose (BG) meters and one-year test materials. Patients in the three treatment groups choose one of two mobile phone models, receive a one-year unlimited mobile phone data and service plan, sign up for a web-based individual patient portal, and receive study therapy phone software based on study assignment. Control patients receive usual care from their PCP. The primary outcome is the mean change in A1c over a 12-month intervention period. CONCLUSION: Traditional disease management methods did not provide adequate control for BG and other conditions that are important for people with diabetes. Tools to improve communication between patients and PCPs can improve patient outcomes and be rewarding for patients and doctors. This RCT is ongoing.

title: Mobile Web application for self-management of low back pain: randomized controlled trial
abstract: Background: Non-specific low back pain (NLBP) is a diagnosis for individuals with back pain without an underlying medical cause (eg, tumor, infection, fracture, herniated disc, spinal stenosis). The American College of Physicians (ACP) and the American Pain Society (APS) recommend multidisciplinary treatments for NLBP lasting longer than 4 weeks. However, this approach is impractical for many physicians, and relatively few providers offer NLBP therapy that meets common ACP-APS guidelines. OBJECTIVE: This study evaluated the effectiveness of a mobile Web intervention called "FitBack" to help users implement tailored strategies to manage and prevent NLBP events. METHODS: A total of 597 adults were recruited, screened, consented, and evaluated online at baseline, month 2 (T2), and month 4 (T3). After baseline assessments, participants were randomly divided into three groups: the FitBack intervention, the alternative care group, which received 8 emails encouraging participants to connect to six Internet resources for NLBP, and the control group. The FitBack group also received weekly email reminder prompts and emails to do reviews for 8 weeks. The control group was contacted only for evaluation. RESULTS: Users of the FitBack program showed greater improvement over the control group in each comparison of critical physical, behavioral, and worksite outcome measures at 4 months follow-up. Additionally, FitBack program users outperformed the alternative care group in current back pain, behavioral, and worksite outcomes at 4-month follow-up. For example, subjects in the control group were 1.7 times more likely to report current back pain than subjects in the FitBack group; subjects in the alternative care group were 1.6 times more likely to report current back pain at 4-month follow-up. Also, FitBack program users, patient activation, Planned A theory-based independent mobile Web intervention that tailors content to users' preferences and interests could be an effective tool in the self-management of low back pain. From a RE-AIM perspective (i.e. access, efficacy/effectiveness, adoption, relevance of practice, and maintenance), this study supports the notion that there is significant value in this type of intervention as a potentially cost-effective tool for people. supported by caregivers The results are promising, considering that it is neither integrated into a health promotion campaign, which may have provided additional support for participants. Still, more research is needed to understand how self-directed mobile Web interventions will be used over time and to understand the factors associated with continued user engagement. TRIAL REGISTRATION: Clinicaltrials.gov NCT01950091;" http://clinicaltrials.gov/ct2/show/NCT01950091 (archived by WebCite at http://www.webcitation.org/6TwZucX77).

title: Modeling eye gaze patterns in clinician-patient interaction with delayed sequential analysis
abstract: OBJECTIVE: The aim of this study was to examine whether delayed sequential analysis could be used to describe eye gaze orientation between clinicians and patients in the medical interview. This is particularly important as new technologies are applied to multi-user healthcare environments where trust is critical and nonverbal cues are an integral part of achieving trust. This method of analysis can lead to design guidelines for technologies and more effective evaluations of interventions. BACKGROUND: Nonverbal communication patterns are important aspects of clinician-patient interactions and can affect patient outcomes. METHODS: The eye gaze behaviors of clinicians and patients across 110 video-recorded medical encounters were analyzed using the delayed sequential method to identify important behavioral sequences. Latency ordinal analysis included both event-based latency and time-based latency. RESULTS: Results from the event-based delay analysis showed that the patient's gaze followed the clinician's gaze, but not the clinician's gaze. Time-based sequential analysis showed that patient responses usually occurred within 2 seconds of the clinician's initial behavior. CONCLUSION: Our data show that the clinician's outlook significantly influences the medical encounter, but the reverse is not true. APPLICATION: Findings from this research have implications for the design and modeling interactions of clinical trial systems. Similar research methods can be used to identify different behavioral patterns in clinical settings (physical layout, technology, etc.) to facilitate and evaluate clinical trial system designs.

title: Moderators of remission with interpersonal counseling or drug therapy in primary care patients with depression: a randomized controlled trial.
abstract: Background: Although depressive disorders are very common, little research has been done to guide primary care physicians in choosing treatment for patients with mild to moderate depression. OBJECTIVES: To evaluate the effectiveness of interpersonal counseling compared to selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs) in primary care settings with major depression and to identify moderators of treatment outcome. METHODS: A randomized controlled trial at nine centers (DEPICS, Australia New Zealand Clinical Trials Registration Number: ACTRN12608000479303). The primary outcome was remission of the depressive episode (defined as the 2-month Hamilton Depression Rating Scale </=7). Daily functioning was assessed using the Work and Social Adjustment Scale. Logistic regression models were used to identify moderators of treatment outcome. RESULTS: The percentage of patients achieving remission at 2 months was significantly higher in the interpersonal counseling group compared to the SSRI group (58.7% vs. 45.1%, P = 0.021). Five moderators of treatment outcome were found: severity of depression, functional impairment, anxiety comorbidity, previous depressive episodes, and smoking habit. RESULTS: We identified some patient characteristics that predicted a different outcome with pharmacological and psychological interventions. If our results are confirmed in future studies, these features will help clinicians define criteria for the first-line treatment of depression for patients' characteristics.

title: Changing the management of dyspepsia in primary care: a cluster randomized controlled educational access trial compared with passive guideline delivery.
abstract: BACKGROUND: Quality improvement initiatives in healthcare are based on the effective promotion of clinical practice guidelines. However, even well-structured guidelines have little effect unless supported by dissemination and implementation strategies. OBJECTIVE: To test the effectiveness of 'educational access' as a strategy to facilitate the acquisition of dyspepsia management guidelines in primary care. STUDY DESIGN: A pragmatic, clustered randomized controlled trial of directory entry compares educational access to mail-guide diffusion alone. SETTING: One hundred and fourteen general practices (233 GPs) in the Salford and Trafford Health authority catchment area in the northwest of England. METHOD: In July 1997, all applications were guided by mail. Intervention group practices began receiving educational access three months later. This consisted of practice-based seminars with hospital professionals where guideline recommendations were evaluated and implementation plans were formulated. The seminars were followed by 'reinforcement' visits 12 weeks later. Outcome measures were: (a) “relevance of referral” and (b) open-access upper gastrointestinal endoscopy findings; (c) costs of physician prescriptions for acid-suppressing drugs; and (d) laboratory-based use Serological testing for Helicobacter pylori Seven days before and/or after intervention. data were collected and analyzed for therapeutic purposes over the course of one month. P < 0.05); (b) the proportion of major findings on endoscopy was not significantly changed; (c) there was a greater increase in overall acid expenditure-suppressing drugs in the intervention compared to the control group (+8% vs +2%, P = 0.005) );" and (d) the median test rate per administration for H pylori in the post-intervention period was significantly higher in the intervention group (four vs. 0, P < 0.001). CONCLUSION: This study suggests that educational access may be more effective than the dissemination of passive guidelines in changing clinical behavior. It also shows that unpredictable and unpredictable results can occur.

title: Altering the prescribing behavior of angiotensin receptor blockers by selectively revoking administrative pre-authorization requirements for losartan.
abstract: OBJECTIVES To evaluate whether revoking the pre-authorization (PA) requirement (managerial pre-approval) for losartan in a healthcare organization (HMO) could reduce prescribing of more expensive angiotensin receptor blockers (ARBs). METHODS HMO physicians were informed that losartan would no longer require PA and appropriate changes were made to the electronic prescribing computer program. Monthly distribution of ARB prescriptions for new patients by drug was calculated from data obtained from electronic records before and after policy change. The proportion of patients (percentage and 95% CI) treated with losartan who met the criteria for treatment with ARBs (hypertension or heart failure in patients who developed adverse effects in response to angiotensin converting enzyme inhibitors or macroproteinuria) The canceled PA requirement was calculated. RESULTS The total number of PA requests for ARBs rose again to 651 in January 2010, down 48.6% from 961 in December 2008, the month before the policy change, to 494 the following January. increased from 15 to 16 (6.7% increase) for losartan (114% increase), from 15 to 16 (6.7% increase) for candesartan, and from 89 to 71 (20.2% decrease) for valsartan. The duration of action was about 1 year for reduced ARB demands for more expensive drugs. Only 23.3% (95% confidence interval 18.1-28.4) of patients receiving losartan met the criteria for receiving ARB. CONCLUSIONS Removing the PA requirement for this drug alone was an effective time-limited strategy to reduce prescribing of relatively expensive drugs.

title: Modular ICT-based patient empowerment framework for diabetes self-management: Design perspectives and validation results.
abstract: INTRODUCTION: It is estimated that more than 382 million people worldwide, most of whom are between the ages of 40 and 59, have diabetes. ICT can play a key role in better management of diabetes and patient empowerment. Patient empowerment largely engages patients in their healthcare processes, and disease management becomes an integral part of their daily lives. Self-management opens the possibility for patients to contribute to their own healthcare and gain more control over their illness. OBJECTIVES: The aim of our study was to investigate the impact of an ICT-based patient empowerment framework in diabetes self-management. METHODS: A modular patient empowerment framework supporting diabetes self-management was designed and implemented. The framework combines expert knowledge in the form of clinical guidelines and supports patients in identifying personalized activities based on medical advice and personal goals, and in collecting observations of daily life. The usability and usefulness of the proposed framework was evaluated in a pilot study involving 60 patients and 12 healthcare professionals. CONCLUSIONS: The study revealed that a patient empowerment approach based on self-management ICT tools was beneficial and accepted by both patients and physicians. For patients already disciplined in disease management, the piloted solution acted as a facilitator for data logging. For the rest, it served as an incentive for better adherence to disease management principles. ICT tools have encouraged many patients to be more physically active and make adjustments to their dietary habits. However, this effect proved to be tightly correlated with the subjects' sociocultural background. The study also showed that even in patient-centered self-management interventions, doctors still have a key role to play. However, acceptance of such interventions by healthcare professionals depends not only on the level of impact on their patients' disease management, but also on the level of impact on their workflow. CONCLUSIONS: It is clear that a patient empowerment approach based on self-management ICT tools is beneficial and accepted by patients and physicians. Moreover, there are clear indications that ICT frameworks such as those presented in this paper can support patients in behavioral changes and better disease management. Finally, it was realized that self-management solutions should be built around the goal of not only educating and guiding patients in disease self-management, but also helping them explore the field of decision and providing insights and explanations about their implications. own values in the decision.

title: Molecular sources of residual cardiovascular risk, clinical signals and innovative solutions: association with subclinical disease, inadequate treatment and poor compliance: implications of new evidence on optimizing cardiovascular patient outcomes.
abstract: Residual risk The continued risk of significant major cardiovascular events (MCVE) in statin-treated patients who have achieved evidence-based lipid targets remains a concern among cardiologists. Contributing factors to this ongoing risk are atherogenic non-low-density lipoprotein (LDL) particles and other risk factors, inherent characteristics of statin drugs and patient characteristics, i.e. atherogenic processes unrelated to LDL cholesterol, including genetics and behaviour. Providers, health systems, society, public policies and the environment also play a role. Large statin studies show an average 28% reduction in LDL cholesterol and a 31% reduction in relative risk, leaving a residual risk of approximately 69%. Incomplete reductions in risk and failure to ameliorate risky conditions can result in continued progression of atherosclerosis with new and recurrent lesions, remodeling, arrhythmias, readmissions, invasive procedures, and terminal disability at the original and distant culprit sites. As a result, the identification of additional agents to reduce residual risk, especially when co-administered with statin drugs, has been an ongoing search. The current model of atherosclerosis includes many steps by which the disease can progress independently of guideline defined elevations in LDL cholesterol. Differences in genetic response to statin therapy, differences in the ability of the endothelium to regenerate and repair, and differences in susceptibility to non-lipid risk factors such as tobacco smoking, hypertension, and molecular changes associated with obesity and diabetes may all pose residual risks. Numerous inflammatory and metabolic processes may also provide ultimate therapeutic targets for reducing residual risk. Classically, epidemiological and other evidence suggested that raising high-density lipoprotein (HDL) cholesterol would be cardioprotective. Low HDL cholesterol levels are still inversely correlated with MCVE when LDL cholesterol is aggressively lowered to targets. The flow capacity, or ability to remove cholesterol from macrophages, is believed to be the main antiatherogenic mechanism responsible for the reduction in MCVE, in part mediated by healthy HDL. HDL cholesterol is a complex molecule with antioxidant, anti-inflammatory, antithrombotic, antiplatelet and vasodilator properties, including protection of LDL from oxidation. HDL-associated paraoxonase-1 has a major influence on endothelial function. Also, HDL supports endothelial repair and progenitor cell health and promotes nitric oxide production. HDL from patients with cardiovascular disease, diabetes, and autoimmune disease may fail to protect and may even become proinflammatory or pro-oxidant. Mendelian randomization and other clinical studies in which raising HDL cholesterol is not beneficial suggest that high plasma levels do not necessarily reduce cardiovascular risk. These data, combined with extensive preclinical information about the functional heterogeneity of HDL, challenge the "HDL hypothesis", that is, raising HDL cholesterol by itself will reduce MCVE. After the suspected AIM-HIGH (Atherothrombosis Intervention in Metabolic Syndrome with Low HDL/High Triglycerides: Impact on Global Health Outcomes) study and withdrawal of two major cholesteryl ester transfer protein compounds, one for off-target side effects and the other for deficiency. efficacy, improvement continues for two other agents, anacetrapib and evacetrapib, both of which significantly lower LDL cholesterol. The negative but controversial trial of HPS2-THRIVE (Heart Protection Study 2-HDL Therapy to Reduce the Incidence of Vascular Events) casts further doubt on the HDL cholesterol hypothesis. The growing impression that HDL functionality, rather than abundance, is clinically important is supported by empirical evidence highlighting the conditional pleiotropic effects of HDL. Non-HDL cholesterol reflects cholesterol in all atherogenic particles containing apolipoprotein B and outperformed LDL cholesterol as a lipid marker of cardiovascular risk and future mortality. Besides including a measure of residual risk, the advantages of using non-HDL cholesterol as the primary lipid target are now convincing. A reinterpretation of data from the Treating to New Targets study suggests that better control of smoking, body weight, hypertension, and diabetes will help reduce residual risk. Although much improved, control of risk factors other than LDL cholesterol still remains inadequate due to deficiencies in compliance with guidelines and poor patient compliance. More efficient and greater use of proven simple therapies such as aspirin, beta-blockers, angiotensin converting enzyme inhibitors, and angiotensin II receptor blockers in conjunction with statin therapy may be more efficient in improving outcomes than using other complex therapies. Comprehensive, intensive, multimechanical, global and national programs using primitive, primary and secondary prevention are required to reduce the overall cardiovascular risk level.

title: Monitoring and managing the metabolic effects of antipsychotics: a randomized cluster trial of an intervention combining evidence-based quality improvement and external facilitation.
abstract: Background Treatment of psychotic disorders consists of second-generation antipsychotics associated with metabolic side effects such as overweight/obesity, diabetes, and dyslipidemia. Evidence-based clinical practice guidelines recommend timely assessment and management of these conditions", but research studies show deficiencies and delays in metabolic monitoring and management for these patients. This protocol article describes the Â¡Â®Monitoring and Management of Metabolic Side Effects project. AntipsychoticsÂ¡Â¯ tests an approach to implementing recommendations for these applications. Methods/Design This project uses a set of randomized clinical trial design to test the effectiveness of an evidence-based quality improvement plus facilitation intervention. Eligible study sites were VA. Â ¡Ã Medical Centers with 300 patients began receiving a new antipsychotic prescription within a six-month period. A total of 12 centers matched in pairs, based on scores from an organizational practice questionnaire, were then randomized in pairs to intervention or control conditions. monitoring v e includes VA staff involved in the management of treated patients. ed with antipsychotics at participating sites. The intervention includes researchers partnering with clinical stakeholders to facilitate the adaptation of local practice strategies to address barriers to metabolic side-effect monitoring and management. The Intervention includes a Design Phase (initial site visit and subsequent development of a local implementation plan); Implementation Phase (led by an experienced external facilitator)" and a Sustainability Phase. Evaluation includes developmental, application-oriented, progress-oriented and interpretative formative evaluation components as well as summative evaluation. Evaluation methods include questionnaires, collection of qualitative data from the provider and study phases Quantitative data analysis of data for all patients prescribed a new antipsychotic drug at a site for monitoring or management of metabolic adverse effects Changes in the rates of recommended monitoring and management actions in intervention and control sites will be compared using time series analyzes Discussion Improving monitoring for metabolic adverse effects of antipsychotics and these effects Promoting timely evidence-based management will lead to better patient safety and long-term outcomes when the challenges of the study arise.

title: More Informative Summaries of Papers Explaining Clinical Practice Guidelines
abstract: Recommendations are offered for the preparation of more informative summaries of articles describing clinical practice guidelines. Information on the development and content of the guidelines should be summarized in the following structure. Purpose: a brief statement of the purpose of the guideline, including the intended health issue, targeted patients, and providers, and the main reason for the development of recommendations regarding this issue for this population. Options: key practice options considered when formulating the guideline. Outcomes: significant defined as the potential consequences of administration options health and economic implications. Evidence: the methods used to collect, select, and synthesize evidence, and the history of the evidence, the most recent evidence available. Values: the individuals and methods used to assign value (relative importance) to the potential consequences of alternative practice options. Benefits, Harms, and Costs: Type and magnitude of expected main benefits, harms, and costs results from guideline implementation. Recommendations: a short and specific list of key recommendations. Governor history: results of any external review, comparison with guidelines developed by other groups, or clinical testing of guideline use. Sponsors: key individuals or groups who developed, financed or approved the guide. Summaries that adhere to these recommendations can enhance readers' ability to evaluate the applicability, importance, and validity of guidelines for specific providers, patients, and settings. More informative summaries can also encourage the use of clearer guideline development methods, more consistent reporting of guideline documents, and more appropriate use of guidelines by clinicians.

title: Mother-to-child transmission of HIV-1 infection during exclusive breastfeeding during the first 6 months of life: an intervention cohort study.
abstract: Background Although exclusive breastfeeding is better than other forms of infant feeding and is associated with improved child survival, it is rare. We evaluated the risks of HIV-1 transmission and survival rates associated with exclusive breastfeeding and other forms of infant feeding.";" Background Although exclusive breastfeeding is better than other forms of infant feeding and is associated with improved child survival, it is rare. We evaluated the risks of HIV-1 transmission and survival associated with exclusive breastfeeding and other forms of infant feeding.

title: Motivation is a crucial factor for adherence to a healthy lifestyle in people with coronary heart disease after percutaneous coronary intervention.
abstract: OBJECTIVE: To test the Adaptation Theory of People with Chronic Disease in terms of adherence to treatment in patients with coronary heart disease after percutaneous coronary intervention. BACKGROUND: More information on the concept of compliance is needed for the development of nursing interventions and nursing guidelines for patients with coronary heart disease. DESIGN: A cross-sectional, multicenter study. METHODS: This study was conducted between February and December 2013 with 416 patients with coronary heart disease 4 months after percutaneous coronary intervention. A self-reported questionnaire was used to assess their adherence to treatment. Data were analyzed using structural equation modeling. RESULTS: The theory explained 45% of adherence to a healthy lifestyle and 7% of adherence to medication. Structural equation modeling confirmed that motivation and care outcomes had the highest association with adherence to a healthy lifestyle. Responsibility was associated with drug compliance. Support from relatives, support from nurses and doctors, and motivation, cooperation, fear of complications, and sense of normalcy were associated with adjustment. CONCLUSION: Patients who were motivated to self-care and thought that the outcomes of care were important were more likely to adhere to a healthy lifestyle. Responsible patients were more likely to adhere to their medication. It is important to consider these elements as part of secondary prevention strategies in patients with coronary heart disease after percutaneous coronary intervention.

title: Motivational Enhancement Therapy with and Without Cognitive Behavioral Therapy for the Treatment of Type 1 Diabetes
abstract: Background: Although psychological problems may hinder diabetes care, the effectiveness of psychological treatments in improving diabetes outcomes is unclear. Objective: To determine whether motivational reinforcement therapy with or without cognitive behavioral therapy improves glycemic control in type 1 diabetes compared to usual care. Design: Randomized, controlled trial . Setting: 8 diabetes centers in London and Manchester, UK. Patients: 344 adult diseases with type 1 diabetes for more than 2 years, hemoglobin A1c levels between 8.2% and 15% and no complications or serious comorbidities. Intervention: Motivational reinforcement therapy (4 sessions over 2 months), motivation enhancement therapy plus cognitive behavioral therapy (12 sessions over 6 months) or usual care. Measures: 12-month change in hemoglobin A1c levels (primary outcome), hypoglycemic events, depression, quality of life, fear of hypoglycemia, diabetes self-care activities, and body mass index x (secondary results). Results: In an analysis of all randomly assigned patients, the 12-month change in hemoglobin A1c levels compared with normal care was 0.46% (95% CI, 0.81% to 0.11%) on motivational boosting therapy plus plus. 0.19% (CI, 0.53% to 0.16%) in the cognitive behavioral therapy group and the motivational reinforcement therapy group alone. There was no evidence of treatment effects on secondary outcomes. Limitations: Of the 1659 patients screened, only 507 were eligible and 344 participated. Data on primary outcome were not available for 11.3% of participants. The study design did not allow for the additive effect of cognitive behavioral therapy plus motivational enhancement therapy to be distinguished from the effect of the more intense and duration of the combined intervention compared to motivational enhancement therapy alone. Conclusion: Nurse-administered motivational enhancement therapy and cognitive behavior therapy adults with poorly controlled type 1 diabetes It is suitable for Combined therapy provides a modest 12-month improvement in hemoglobin A1c compared with normal care, but not motivational enhancement therapy alone.

title: Motivational interviewing: Helping people change., 3rd ed.
abstract: This bestselling work for professionals and students is the credible presentation of motivational interviewing (MI), a powerful approach to facilitating change. More than just an update, the third edition has been completely restructured around the new four-process MI model (engage, focus, awaken and plan). MI creators William R. Miller and Stephen Rollnick show what processes look like in practice, describe a rich range of applications, and review the growing evidence base. Infused with respect and compassion for clients, the book begins with a comprehensive overview of the MI spirit and method. Chapters on each of the four processes offer step-by-step guidance for building a strong working relationship, developing a clear focus and direction, awakening and strengthening the client's motivation for change, and formulating a concrete plan of action. Basic communication skills used in MI explained";" vignettes and interview examples vividly illustrate the "do's and don'ts" of successful practice in different contexts. Ways to build competence in MI, integrate it with other practices, and evaluate the accuracy of intervention are discussed. Key points at the end of each chapter increase the book's usefulness for teaching and professional development. The supplemental Web page (www.guilford.com/p/miller2) provides other helpful resources, including reflection questions, illustrated case material, an expanded bibliography, and glossary. Reflecting great advances in understanding and teaching mental intelligence, this book is essential reading for practitioners in mental health and health care disciplines, including addiction professionals, clinical psychologists, psychiatrists, social workers, family therapists, counselors, nurses, physicians, and health educators. Graduate students in these fields will find it an accessible, uniquely informative course text. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2016 APA, all rights reserved)

title: Motivational interviewing: Is this all our customers need?
abstract: Motivational Interviewing (MI) and its sub-branches such as Drink Control and Motivation Enhancement Therapy have become immensely popular in science and addiction treatment circles over the past decade. This article first considers the reasons for this popularity and argues that it is due to the putative cost-effectiveness, relevance of interventions in untreated populations, and the fundamental nature of addictions as motivational disorders. The article then proceeds to examine the evidence for the efficacy of MI in both treatment-seeking and treatment-seeking samples, taking into account published systematic reviews and particularly the findings of Project MATCH. The relevance of possible findings from the UK Alcohol Treatment Trial is also taken into account. The article also looks at the mechanisms of change that might explain the way MI works. The effectiveness of MI ends with a list of possible roles it can serve in therapy, the client groups it may be particularly suitable for, and the implications for which further research is needed. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2016 APA, all rights reserved)

title: Mouthwash in oral mucositis in the context of allogeneic stem cell transplantation: a qualitative study.
abstract: Background: Oral mucositis is a common side effect of allogeneic stem cell transplantation and may lead to increased morbidity, mortality, and higher costs. It also has an impact on patients' quality of life.
