In the stem cell transplant ward of a Swiss university hospital, patients are trained according to current mouthwash guidelines and their oral condition is evaluated daily. RESEARCH QUESTION: How do patients experience oral mucositis and what factors affect their regular mouth rinse behavior? METHODS: In this qualitative part of the simultaneous mixed methods research, 14 patients were interviewed using an interview guide. The data were analyzed using content analysis methods. RESULTS: The results showed that oral mucositis cannot be considered separately from disease, isolation, and care. Mucositis was only a heavy burden for patients with a serious occurrence. Other symptoms were more significant for patients with lower grade formations. The research identified motivating and debilitating factors for regular mouth rinsing, one of the most important preventive procedures. CONCLUSION: This study highlights how important it is to see oral mucositis in the context of transplantation and that knowing the motivating and inhibiting factors can help nurses in patient care. Improving patient self-management is an important consideration.

title: So Much Cheaper, Nearly Good: Cost-Effective Medical Innovation
abstract: Under conditions of scarce resources, cost-saving innovations can improve overall outcomes by allowing more efficient reallocation of resources, even if they are somewhat less effective than current options. The authors systematically reviewed all cost-benefit analyzes cited by MEDLINE from 2002 to 2007 to identify and identify medical innovations that reduce cost and quality. At least $100,000 per quality-adjusted life-year lost. Of the 2128 cost-effectiveness ratios of 887 publications, only 9 (0.4% of the total) identified 8 innovations that were considered incremental cost-effectiveness. Examples include percutaneous coronary intervention (instead of coronary artery bypass grafting) for multi-vessel coronary disease, repetitive transcranial magnetic stimulation (instead of electroconvulsive therapy) for drug-resistant major depression, watchful waiting for inguinal hernias, and hemodialyzer sterilization and reuse. On a per-patient basis, these innovations saved $122 to almost $12,000, but resulted in losses of 0.001 to 0.021 quality-adjusted life years (about 8 hours to 1 week). These findings demonstrate that increasingly low-cost innovations are rare in the medical literature.

title: Multidimensional analyzes to evaluate the relationships between physicians' treatment options and patient characteristics: an example of COPD
abstract: BACKGROUND: In some cases, practice guidelines do not provide robust evidence-based guidance on COPD treatment options, especially when large studies fail to identify subgroups of those who respond particularly well or poorly to existing medications. METHODS: This observational cross-sectional study explored the throughput of four types of multidimensional analyzes to assess associations between clinical characteristics of COPD patients and pharmacological and non-pharmacological treatments prescribed by lung specialists in a real-life context. RESULTS: A total of 2494 patients were recruited by 515 respiratory physicians. Multiple relevance analysis and hierarchical clustering identified 6 clinical subtypes and 6 treatment subgroups. Strong bidirectional associations were found between clinical subtypes and treatment subgroups in multivariate logistic regression. However, clinical subtypes were not associated with specific prescribing profiles, although the overall frequency of prescriptions for all pharmacological treatment types varied from one clinical subtype to another. Using the canonical analysis of redundancy, the rate of variation in pharmacological treatments explained by clinical features remained modest: 6.23%. This proportion was greater for the non-pharmacological components of care (14.29%). CONCLUSION: This study shows that although pharmacological treatments of COPD are quantitatively very well correlated with the clinical characteristics of patients, there is no specific patient profile that can be qualitatively associated with prescriptions. This underlines the uncertainties perceived by physicians to distinguish the relevant effects of current pharmacological treatments. The methodology applied here is useful for identifying areas of uncertainty that require further research and/or guidance clarification.

title: Multidisciplinary treatment of pediatric obesity: nutritional assessment and management
abstract: Evaluation and treatment methods for pediatric obesity are developing rapidly. Obesity, thought to result from an imbalance of caloric intake and expenditure, requires a comprehensive assessment of patient, familial, environmental, genetic, and cultural characteristics in order for clinicians to design successful interventions. Quantitative nutritional assessment of calorie intake is difficult and time consuming and should only be used in isolated settings such as a research setting or if initial approaches to management have failed. Alternatively, providers should identify dietary patterns or behaviors that are linked to obesity and are promising targets for change. Clinicians should tailor interventions taking into account patient and family motivation and readiness for change. Current guidelines recommend gradual increases in treatment plans, and multidisciplinary treatment teams are recommended for patients requiring intensive intervention. Providers at the multidisciplinary level should combine their area of expertise with that of the team to develop a comprehensive management plan. This article reviews current recommendations for the assessment and treatment of pediatric obesity with a focus on nutritional assessment as part of a multidisciplinary team.

title: Multifactorial effects and deviations on the safety and quality of drug administration in an acute medical/surgical context
abstract: BACKGROUND AND OBJECTIVES: Although many factors influence drug management, our understanding of the interaction of these factors on drug quality and safety is limited. The aim of this study was to investigate multifactorial effects on drug quality and safety in the context of a single control policy for drug administration in acute care. APPROACH: An exploratory/descriptive study using non-participant observation and follow-up interview was used to identify factors affecting drug quality and safety during drug administration episodes (n=30). Observations focused on nurses' interactions with patients during drug administration and the characteristics of the environment in which they took place. During the short semi-structured interviews with the participating nurses, the observed data were validated upon completion of the observation period. RESULTS: The findings showed that nurses developed therapeutic relationships with patients in terms of evaluating patients before administering drugs and educating patients about drugs during drug administration. Nurses experienced more frequent distraction when drugs were stored and prepared in a common medicine room according to the ward design. Nurses deviated from best practice guidelines during drug administration. APPLICATIONS: Nurses' skills and readiness to develop therapeutic relationships with patients have increased drug quality and safety, thus protecting patients from potential adverse events. Deviations from best-practice drug practice had the potential to reduce drug safety. System factors such as service design that determine drug storage areas can be easily addressed to minimize potential error. CONCLUSION: Nurses exhibited behaviors that increase the quality and safety of drug administration";" however, it was observed that the implementation standards were violated. These findings will inform future intervention studies to improve drug quality and safety.

title: Multifactorial intervention with nurse practitioners does not alter cardiovascular outcomes in patients with chronic kidney disease
abstract: Strict implementation of multi-target guidelines reduces vascular risk in diabetic patients. It is unclear whether this also applies to patients with chronic kidney disease (CKD). To assess this, the MASTERPLAN Study randomized 788 patients with CKD (estimated GFR 20-70 ml/min) to receive additional intensive nurse practitioner support (intervention group) or nephrologist care (control group). The primary endpoint was a composite of myocardial infarction, stroke, or cardiovascular death. At a mean follow-up of 4.62 years, moderate but significant reductions were found in the intervention group compared with controls in blood pressure, LDL cholesterol, anemia, proteinuria, and increased use of active vitamin D or analogues, aspirin, and statins. No differences were found in rates of smoking cessation, weight loss, sodium excretion, physical activity, or glycemic control. Intensive control did not reduce the composite endpoint rate (21.3/1000 person-years in the intervention group, 23.8/1000 person-years in the controls (hazard ratio 0.90)). No differences were found in secondary outcomes of vascular interventions, all-cause mortality, or end-stage renal disease. Thus, the addition of intensive support by nurse practitioner care in patients with CKD improved some risk factor levels but did not significantly reduce the proportion of primary or secondary endpoints.

title: Multi-level support for physical activity and healthy eating
abstract: OBJECTIVE: This article reports a study evaluating the relationship between social and community-level supports and physical activity and dietary behaviors in a low-income Latino population with multiple chronic conditions. BACKGROUND: With less physical activity and documented nutritional deficiencies than whites, Latinos in the United States represent a disproportionate share of the population with chronic diseases. This pattern of health inequality is seen in countries where there is a struggle to improve the health status of low-income, immigrant and indigenous communities. Social-ecological theories of health behavior emphasize the importance of considering social and community support for health behavior and provide a useful framework for considering ways to improve physical activity and nutrition for migrant and indigenous groups. METHOD: Here we report data from a baseline assessment of 200 patients from a health clinic serving a low-income, primarily Hispanic population in the United States. Participants enrolled in Resources for Health, a randomized controlled trial to promote multi-level support for chronic disease self-management. Measures included demographic data as well as multi-level support for self-reported physical activity, dietary behavior, and chronic disease management. The baseline data reported here were collected between February 2002 and September 2003. RESULTS: Use of multi-level supports (eg, family, individual, and healthcare provider) was statistically significantly associated with meeting physical activity guidelines and better eating behaviors. Being female and having multiple chronic conditions were also associated with better eating behavior. These variables explained 20% of the variance in dietary behavior. CONCLUSION: The results support a social-ecological approach to promoting healthy behavior in this low-income, primarily Latino sample with multiple chronic conditions. Addressing multiple levels of support for healthy behavior is important in interventions to improve physical activity and diet, and nurses may be in a particularly good position to address such issues for low-income, indigenous and immigrant patients with chronic conditions.

title: Multiple antipsychotic drug prescribing patterns
abstract: OBJECTIVE: To evaluate current prescribing practices regarding the concomitant use of antipsychotic drugs and to summarize the reasons why clinicians may prescribe >1 planned agent. METHODS: The pharmacy identified patients currently on antipsychotic therapy at William R Sharpe Jr Hospital. All patients who received >/=2 scheduled antipsychotic drugs at the same time were included in the study. Data on demographics, current drug combinations used, history of therapeutic regimens attempted, and prescriber rationale were prospectively evaluated over a 60-day period beginning 13 December 2000 and ending 10 February 2001. The prescriber's rationale for using .1 concurrent antipsychotics and other drug treatment regimens tried were compared with chart papers and published therapeutic guidelines for schizophrenia. RESULTS: During a 60-day surveillance period, 206 patients received scheduled antipsychotic drugs and 85 (41%) received at least 2 agents. Respondents to a prescriber survey (59%) indicated augmentation was the most common rationale for combination therapy";" the least likely logic was cross-titration. Survey responses also demonstrated a belief that more than half of patients treated with combinations of multiple antipsychotics had questionable therapeutic benefit. In addition, chart papers showed that most of these patients did not receive an adequate trial of monotherapy with other atypical or typical agents or clozapine prior to the combination antipsychotic regimen. Fifty-one percent of medical records did not document the rationale for concomitant therapy. CONCLUSIONS: Due to the lack of published data, the practice of using multiple antipsychotic agents is considered a gray area that requires the prescriber to have a high level of awareness in assessing efficacy and safety. Documentation of the cause, adverse events, and response to the treatment regimen is essential in providing optimal patient care.

title: Multi-screen electronic alerts to enhance venous thromboembolism prophylaxis
abstract: Venous thromboembolism (VTE) prophylaxis is often not used adequately in high-risk patients. Previously, we designed a single-screen computer alert program that identifies hospitalized patients at high risk for VTE who do not receive prophylaxis and advise their physicians to prescribe prophylaxis. While this strategy reduced the 90-day incidence of symptomatic VTE by 41%, most electronic warnings were ignored. We have now developed a series of three-screen alert computer programs designed to train physicians who initially refuse to seek prophylaxis after a single screen alert. Out of a total cohort of 880 patients, physicians responsible for 425 patients received a single electronic alert, while 455 who refused prophylaxis after the first screen received the second and third screens of the new three-screen alert. Our enhanced serial three-screen alert program generated VTE prophylaxis orders for 58.4% of 455 patients whose doctors initially refused to order prophylaxis after a single screen alert. There was no significant difference in symptomatic 90-day VTE rates between the two groups (2.8% for one screen and 2.2% for three screens, p=0.55). We conclude that our three-screen computer warning program can significantly improve prophylaxis among physicians who reject the first single-screen warning.

title: Should diabetes be a deadly disease in Africa? Examination of treatment costs
abstract: OBJECTIVE To estimate the costs of diagnosing and treating diabetes in Tanzania. DESIGN Costs were estimated from the reported and recorded experience of patients with new diabetes in 1989-90 and diabetic patients first seen in 1981-2. AYAR Muhimbili Medical Center, Dar es Salaam. SUBJECTS 464 patients (315 men and 149 women). 262 patients were diagnosed between September 1, 1989 and August 31, 1990 (group 1), and 202 patients were diagnosed between June 1, 1981 and August 31, 1982 (group 2). RESULTS The average annual direct cost of diabetes care in 1989-90 was $287 for a patient requiring insulin and $103 for a patient not requiring insulin. Purchasing insulin accounted for 68.2% ($156) of average annual outpatient costs for patients requiring insulin. For patients not requiring insulin, the cost of oral hypoglycemic drugs and the treatment of chronic complications and infections accounted for 42.5% ($29.3) and 48.8% ($33.7) of the costs, respectively. The cost of outpatient treatment of diabetic patients for the whole of Tanzania was estimated at $2.7 million, *75,128 (32.2%) of which were for insulin. The costs of doctors and nurses accounted for 0.2% of the total costs of outpatient services. Annual direct inpatient care costs were estimated at $1.25 million. About 0.2% of the Tanzanian population aged 15 and over used the equivalent of 8% of total government health expenditure of $47,4088,382. CONCLUSION Diabetes places serious pressure on the limited resources of developing countries. If African diabetic patients have to pay for their treatment, many will be unable to do so and die.

title: nationwide survey of alcohol screening and brief intervention practices at US Level I trauma centers
abstract: BACKGROUND: In 2007, the American College of Surgeons (ACS) Trauma Committee implemented the requirement that Level I trauma centers have a mechanism for identifying problem drinking patients and the capacity to provide interventions for patients who screen positive. Although landmark alcohol screening and brief intervention (SBI) mandate were expected to impact trauma practice nationwide, a literature review revealed no studies that systematically documented the pre-ACS requirement for SBI practice. STUDY DESIGN: Trauma programs at all Level I trauma centers in the USA were contacted and asked to complete a questionnaire about pre-ACS requirement trauma center SBI administration. RESULTS: One hundred and forty-eight (73%) of 204 Level I trauma centers responded to the survey. More than 70% of responding centers routinely used laboratory tests (eg, blood alcohol concentration) to screen patients for alcohol, and 39% routinely used a screening question or standard screening tool. Screen-positive patients received a formal alcohol consultation or had an informal alcohol discussion with staff about 25% of the time. RESULTS: The trial observed significant variability between Level I centers in the percentage of patients screened and the nature and extent of intervention in screening-positive patients. Following the ACS Trauma Committee requirement, future research can systematically implement and evaluate training in the delivery of evidence-based alcohol interventions and trauma center institutional capacity building for continued delivery of SBI.

title: Natural treatment for earache in children
abstract: OBJECTIVE: Otitis media is one of the most common diseases of early infancy and childhood and one of the most common reasons for children to consult a doctor. In the last 2 decades, there has been a significant increase in the diagnosis of otitis media worldwide. In the United States, 93% of all children have had at least 1 episode of acute otitis media (AOM) by age 7 years. Otalgia is the hallmark of AOM. Most affected children either complain of earache or complain of distinctive behaviors that parents interpret as indicating earache. Treating ear pain early in the course of AOM reduces both parental anxiety and child discomfort and speeds up the healing process. The aim of this study was to determine the efficacy and tolerability of naturopathic and conventional therapy in the treatment of otalgia commonly associated with AOM in children. METHODS: The study was designed as a double-blind study in an outpatient community clinic. A total of 171 children aged 5-18 years with ear pain and clinical findings due to middle ear infection were analyzed. Children were randomly assigned to be treated with Naturopathic Herbal Extract Ear Drops (NHED) or anesthetic ear drops with or without amoxicillin. At enrollment, children were assigned by computer-numbered randomization to receive NHED (content: allium sativum, verbascum thapsus, calendula flores, hypericum perfoliatum, vitamin E in lavender and olive oil), alone, 5 drops 3 times daily (group A), or with a topical anesthetic together (amethocaine and phenazone in glycerine) 5 drops 3 times a day (group B) or oral amoxicillin 80 mg/kg/day (maximum 500 mg/dose) divided into 3 doses, both NHEDs 5 drops 3 times daily (group C) or 5 drops of topical anesthetic 3 times a day (group D). A double-blind design was used and all ear drops were placed in the same bottles. Treatment was initiated by the nurse in all cases. A single physician (MS) evaluated and treated all patients included in the study and recorded all data. Presence or absence of ear pain was evaluated by visual analog scale for 3 days. Ear pain was assessed with a specially designed observation tool based on previous reports. One side of the instrument consisted of a linear numbered scale from 1 (no pain) to 10 (worst possible pain) and a corresponding color scale ranging from blue to deep red. The reverse included 5 scales of facial expression ranging from a broad smile (no pain) to a sad and crying face (worst possible pain) and a corresponding color scale from blue to deep red. RESULTS: There were no significant differences between the groups in terms of patient age or gender, fever grade, main symptoms, associated symptoms, and acute otitis media severity or laterality. Each group showed a statistically significant improvement in ear pain over 3 days. Patients given ear drops alone responded better than patients given ear drops in combination with amoxicillin. Outcomes were better in the NHED group than in the controls. However, the findings showed that the pain was mostly (80%) self-limited and could be explained simply with the passage of time. The American Academy of Otolaryngology-Head and Neck Surgery guidelines recommend topical medications as the first line of treatment for earache in the absence of systemic infection or serious underlying disease. Since there is no evidence that systemic antibiotics alone improve treatment outcome, if antibiotics do not alter the natural course of otitis media, the main goal of treatment should be to alleviate ear pain, as in this study. Alternative, naturopathic herbal extract remedies may offer many new possibilities in the treatment of AOM-related ear pain. Primary care physicians should be aware that at least 10% of their patients may have tried 1 or more forms of alternative/complementary medicine before seeking consultation. As widely reported in the medical literature, this herb, these plant extracts have the potential to meet all the requirements of suitable drugs that can be used routinely in pediatric patients, namely in vitro bacteriostatic and bactericidal activity, immunostimulation against common pathogens. ability, antioxidant activity and anti-inflammatory effects. They are also well absorbed, penetrating well into the tissue surrounding the eardrum. They have been found to increase local immunological activity. Finally, plant extracts are well tolerated (due to long elimination times), easy to administer, and less expensive than new antibiotics. There are no documented side effects. Based on our findings that the group with the most significant therapeutic effects (NHED with topical anesthetic) explained only 7.3% of total pain reduction, we suggest that sometimes the GP or pediatrician should give the human body a chance to repair. itself. However, if the physician believes there is an indication for treatment, a local treatment similar to the one used in our study may be sufficient, especially if the parents are concerned. CONCLUSION: This study suggests that a herbal extract solution may be beneficial in cases of earache caused by AOM in children where a simple waiting period of 2 to 3 days as well as active treatment is required. Concomitant antibiotic therapy does not seem to contribute.

title: Needs and opportunities in rehabilitation. Aids and the environment
Negative pressure wound management after partial diabetic foot amputation: a multicenter, randomized controlled trial.
abstract: Background Diabetic foot ulcers, especially those secondary to amputation, are very complex and difficult to treat. We investigated whether negative pressure wound therapy (NPWT) improves wound healing rate and rate after partial foot amputation in patients with diabetes. Background Diabetic foot ulcers, especially those secondary to amputation, are very complex and difficult to treat. We investigated whether negative pressure wound therapy (NPWT) improves wound healing rate and rate after partial foot amputation in patients with diabetes.

title: Neonatal end-of-life decision making: Physicians' attitudes and relationship to self-reported practices in 10 European countries
abstract: Context The ethical issues surrounding the end-of-life decision-making process for infants with an adverse prognosis are controversial. There is little empirical evidence about the attitudes and values underlying such decisions in different countries and cultures. Purpose To investigate the variability of neonatal physicians' attitudes among 10 European countries and the relationship between such attitudes and their practice of self-reported end-of-life decisions. Design and Adjustment Research was conducted in 10 European countries (France, Germany, Italy, Netherlands, Spain, Sweden, United Kingdom, Estonia, Hungary and Lithuania) in 1996-1997. Participants A total of 1391 physicians (response rate, 89%) work regularly in 142 neonatal intensive care units (NICU). Main Outcome Measures Scores on an attitude scale measuring opinions about the absolute value of life (0 points) and the value of quality of life (10 points)";" Self-report on setting limits on intensive neonatal interventions in cases of poor neurological prognosis. Results Physicians more likely to agree with statements consistent with protecting life at all costs were from Hungary (mean attitude scores, 5.2 [95% confidence interval {CI}, 4.9-5.5]), Estonia (4.9 [95% CI, 4.3-5.5]), Lithuania (5.5 [95% CI, 4.8-6.1]), and Italy (5.7 [95% CI, 5.3-6.0]) They are more likely to agree that quality should be taken into account. from the United Kingdom (attitude scores, 7.4 [95% CI, 7.1-7.7]), the Netherlands (7.3 [95% CI, 7.1-7.5]), and Sweden. ten (6.8 [95% CI, 6.4-7.3]). . Other factors associated with having a pro-quality-of-life view were being female, having no children, being Protestant or having no religious background, not viewing religion as important, and working in a very low number of NICUs. -birth weight newborns. Physicians with scores reflecting higher quality of life views were more likely to report in their practice that they set limits on intensive interventions in cases of poor neurological prognosis, with an adjusted odds ratio of 1.5 (95% CI, 1.3-). 1.7) per unit change in attitude score. Conclusion In our study, the probability of physicians reporting that they limit intensive neonatal interventions in cases with poor neurological prognosis is related to their attitudes. After adjusting for possible confounding factors, country remained the most important predictor of physicians' attitudes and practices.

title: Neurobehavioral morbidity associated with sleep-disordered breathing in children: a comprehensive review.
abstract: STUDY OBJECTIVES: To comprehensively review research on the relationship between sleep-disordered breathing (SDD) and neurobehavioral functioning in childhood. DESIGN: Qualitative and quantitative literature review. SETTING: None. PATIENTS OR PARTICIPANTS: None. INTERVENTIONS: None. MEASUREMENTS AND RESULTS: The findings of 61 studies on the relationship between childhood SDB and neurobehavioral functioning were critically evaluated and synthesized. There is strong evidence that childhood SDB is associated with deficits in behavior and emotion regulation, scholastic performance, sustained attention, selective attention, and alertness. There is also evidence that USB has minimal association with a child's typical mood, expressive language skills, visual perception, and working memory. The findings were insufficient to draw conclusions about some aspects of intelligence, memory, and executive functioning. The mechanisms by which SDB may lead to neurobehavioral morbidity are under investigation, but clinical symptoms such as chronic snoring remain the best predictors of morbidity. Short-term USB therapy outcome studies are encouraging, but long-term outcomes are unknown. Failure to treat SDB seems to put children at risk for long-term neurobehavioral deficits. CONCLUSIONS: Childhood SDB is associated with neurobehavioral morbidity. Even in the absence of a much-needed randomized clinical trial, there is strong evidence of association, consistent findings, and effect specificity when widely used guidelines for causal inference are applied. There is significant evidence that this association fits the expected temporal pattern and that SDB is a biologically plausible cause of neurobehavioral deficits. Clinicians should be alert for the coexistence of SDB symptoms and concerns about the child's academic progress, attention, arousal, or behavior or emotion regulation.

title: Neurotropic viruses and cerebral palsy: a population-based case-control study
abstract: OBJECTIVE To investigate the relationship between cerebral palsy and direct evidence of perinatal exposure to neurotropic viruses. DESIGN Population-based case-control study. AYAR Adelaide Women's and Children's Hospital Research Laboratory. PARTICIPANTS AND MAIN OUTCOME MEASURES Neonatal screening cards consisting of 443 white case patients with cerebral palsy and 883 white controls were tested for viral nucleic acids from enteroviruses and herpes viruses using the polymerase chain reaction. Herpes group A viruses included herpes simplex viruses 1 and 2 (HSV-1 and HSV-2), Epstein-Barr virus (EBV), cytomegalovirus (CMV), and human herpes virus 8 (HHV-8) and herpes group B viruses. included varicella zoster virus (VZV) and human herpes viruses 6 and 7 (HHV-6 and HHV-7). RESULTS The prevalence of viral nucleic acids was high in the control population: 39.8% of controls tested positive and the prevalence was highest in premature infants. Detection of herpes group B viral nucleic acids increased the risk of developing cerebral palsy (odds ratio 1.68, 95% confidence interval 1.09 to 2.59). CONCLUSIONS Perinatal exposure to neurotropic viruses is associated with preterm birth and cerebral palsy.

title: Never too old? Age should not be a barrier to enroll in cancer clinical trials
abstract: Across Europe and the USA, more than 60% of the total cancer incidence occurs in the elderly (> or =65 years old) population; this is a group of patients that needs special consideration when making treatment decisions due to a number of factors. Despite this, elderly patients are often underrepresented in clinical trials, so study data should be interpreted with caution, as outcomes in younger cancer patients may not always predict the typical elderly cancer patient. Reports indicate that elderly cancer patients represent approximately 22% of patients participating in phase II clinical trials. Barriers to accruing older patients to clinical trials include the lack of appropriate trials, the high burden of comorbidities, study-imposed limitations, and physician attitudes. There is a belief that elderly patients may not be able to tolerate various cancer treatments and may result in this patient population being excluded from prospective trials. However, clinical data suggest that age alone is not a sufficient reason to discontinue treatment. The lack of clinical trial data, and the associated lack of evidence-based guidelines for elderly patients, means that doctors have little to guide them, and as a result, patients may not receive optimal treatment. Because clinical trials are the primary method of assessing the efficacy and safety of adjuvant and palliative cancer therapies, trials specifically targeting the elderly cancer patient are necessary to adequately assess the risks and benefits of therapy in this vulnerable population. This review aims to assess clinical reality and clinical trial age mismatch to evaluate outcomes for older cancer patients and determine how this may be addressed. Possible reasons for the difference and the resulting clinical consequences are also taken into account.

title: New challenges in family interventions for schizophrenia
abstract: This review first summarizes the rationale and research basis supporting the development of family interventions for schizophrenia. Next, the dominant principles that guide effective family interventions for schizophrenia are presented, with key components (participation, assessment, training, communication skills training, and problem solving) shared by most family programs in schizophrenia. Next, meta-analyses demonstrating the effectiveness of family interventions in reducing relapse and rehospitalization in schizophrenia, minimum effective duration of treatment, differential benefits of single- and multi-family modalities, and mixed evidence for maintenance of treatment effects after termination are discussed. The benefits of participating in non-professional support and training programs organized by the family are then explained. Finally, three issues that deserve further study are summarized.

title: New developments in psychotherapy for schizophrenic psychoses
abstract: There is currently sufficient evidence of the effectiveness of psychotherapeutic interventions, particularly cognitive behavioral therapy, in symptom reduction and relapse prevention. Evidence-based treatment guidelines recommend this approach for routine care. A growing number of randomized clinical trials and research into the active elements of therapy characterize this field. This article presents research and clinical implications. Representing an innovative field of research, treatment strategies to reduce positive and negative symptoms are presented and discussed in terms of efficacy, treatment principles and possible future developments.

title: New drugs in anesthesia: can we afford them?
abstract: The most important challenge facing doctors today is the dilemma of providing high-quality care in a financially responsible manner. The cost can no longer be ignored. Pharmacoeconomics is an essential component of medical education. Economic considerations should be an integral part of drug development and clinical trials. Although anesthetists are concerned that the use of cheaper drugs may compromise patient outcomes and satisfaction, there is little evidence to support such concerns. This is a fertile area for future intensive research. Pharmacoeconomics is dynamic. The cost of drugs is not static, patterns of drug use are changing rapidly, and clinical practice is in constant flux. The answer to cost containment is not simply to cut, limit, delist, or simply hope for the best, but rather to manage and change the application as it adapts to changing needs. Educational programs, guidelines, departmental policies, system changes, and financial incentives can be implemented to ensure consistent and enduring adherence to the principles of pharmacoeconomics and value-based care. Some argue that national societies should establish guidelines for cost-beneficial practices. Others support physician autonomy in drug selection. Changing physician behavior is difficult. This change will happen gradually and will be the subject of many emotionally charged philosophical discussions. There will be great reluctance from patients to reject pharmacologically superior drugs solely on the basis of cost, especially since drugs are such a small fraction of the total cost. We must be careful not to make a penny of wisdom and nonsense. Drug acquisition costs are only one element in a large and complex equation. Focusing on the cost of acquiring medicine can be dangerous, or even naive if we fall into the trap of knowing the cost of everything and not the value of anything.

title: New format for printed BMJ research articles
abstract: It's been nearly 10 years since we started shortening original research articles for print BMJ readers. Now we go one step further, taking advantage of both the web and print. The full, open access version of this original article by Hollingshurst and colleagues is available online (doi:10.1136/bmj.a2656), along with our first BMJ research video and a podcast. Here are two abridged versions: a BMJ Picoâ€" a new summary of the evidence by the authors and a Shortcuts article by the BMJ. Which version would you read and use? Which would you prefer if you were the author? Please send quick replies to this article and give us your feedback as readers and researchers. Sandra Hollinghurst,1 Debbie Sharp,1 Kathleen Ballard,3 Jane Barnett,2 Angela Beattie,1 Maggie Evans,1 George Lewith,2 Karen Middleton,2 Frances Oxford,3 Fran Webley,2 Paul Little2 Study question2 What is the cost difference Alexander Efficiency between long and short courses in the technique, massage, and a general practitioner's prescription for exercise for patients with persistent back pain Response An exercise prescription and each of the six courses in the Alexander technique alone at values above €20Â 000 per quality-adjusted life year (QALY) more than 85% likely to be cost effective, but Alexander â€¦

title: New Insights on Pervasive Variable Immunodeficiency
abstract: Common variable immunodeficiency (CVI) is a heterogeneous immunodeficiency syndrome characterized by hypogammaglobulinemia, recurrent bacterial infections, and various immunological abnormalities. In addition to recurrent infections, the incidence of autoimmune disease and malignancy is high in patients with this syndrome. Because the spectrum of associated diseases is broad, patients with CVI are seen by a variety of medical professionals. This review discusses the pathogenesis, clinical manifestations, diagnosis and treatment of CVI.

title: Newly diagnosed idiopathic thrombocytopenic purpura in childhood: an observational study.
abstract: Background Diagnosis and treatment of idiopathic thrombocytopenic purpura (ITP) is primarily based on expert opinion and practice guidelines rather than evidence. We used a registry to prospectively investigate presentation features and diagnostic evaluation and management practices used for children with ITP worldwide.";" Background Diagnosis and treatment of idiopathic thrombocytopenic purpura (ITP) is primarily based on expert opinion and practice guidelines rather than evidence. We used a registry to prospectively investigate presentation features and diagnostic evaluation and management practices used for children with ITP worldwide.

title: NHMRC guidelines for clinical practice for ASD and PTSD
abstract: Dear Editor, I recently described the case of a scuba instructor suffering from acute stress disorder (ASD), a type of post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD), following the death of one of his students. The treatment described was a combination of eye movement desensitization and reprocessing (EMDR) and cognitive-behavioral therapy (CBT) exposure-based exercises. As it happened, in August the Australian Center for Post Traumatic Mental Health published Australian clinical practice guidelines for ASD and PTSD. These have been approved by the National Health and Medical Research Council (NHMRC). The treatment described in the diver injury case complies with these guidelines. NHMRC guidelines suggest that the most helpful response immediately after a traumatic event (for example, diver death or serious injury) is to offer psychological first aid. This includes providing information about traumatic stress responses, promoting self-care, and using available social support. It is recommended that the medical practitioner monitor the patient, monitor for improvement, plateau, or deterioration, and be prepared to offer assistance or appropriate referral if necessary. Guidelines recommend the use of trauma-focused psychological therapy as a first-line intervention for ASD and PTSD. EMDR, including in vivo exposure, and CBT are considered the most effective treatments. If medication is required, selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor antidepressants are considered the best option. For the benefit and convenience of patients and practitioners, the NHMRC guidelines and a comprehensive set of information guides on ASD and PTSD can be downloaded online as a pdf file from http://www.acpmh.unimelb.edu.au. An update in the Medical Journal of Australia provides traumatic stress information for medical professionals, including screening questions that can be used to identify patients suffering from ASD and PTSD. This article can be found online at http://www.mja.com.au/public/issues/187_02_160707/for10467_fm.html. Diver-specific short articles and summary pages on traumatic stress reactions, death and panic are available at http://psychdiviver.com.

title: NHS 1948-88: Less ideology, more humanity
NHS profile. Enter the men from the Control Commission. Richard Smith's interview
NICE guidance on preventing STIs and teen pregnancies
abstract: NICE has published new public health intervention guidance to stop the growing number of sexually transmitted infections, including HIV, and prevent pregnancy under 18 years of age. This article summarizes the roles of nurses in practice.

title: Unaffected by the active dissemination of the Ottawa Ankle Rules: further evidence of the need for local enforcement of enforcement guidelines
abstract: BACKGROUND: Local enforcement strategies are often required to ensure consistent adherence to clinical guidelines, but they are time consuming and expensive. The authors tested an educational intervention designed to increase the use of the Ottawa Ankle Guidelines, a widely publicized set of clinical guidelines previously shown to reduce the use of radiography for diagnosing acute ankle injuries. METHODS: The study consisted of a quasi-experimental, before and after comparative analysis. Trained experts provided 1-hour training sessions to healthcare professionals from 63 Ontario hospitals and provided resource materials on the Ottawa Ankle Rules. Participants were asked to evaluate the intervention. The authors then compared the use of ankle radiography for the periods before and after training sessions for adults with acute ankle injuries in 10 hospitals who received the educational intervention and reported no prior (n = 5) or some (n = 5) use. and already in 5 control hospitals that refused educational intervention because they were following the rules. RESULTS: Although participants gave highly favorable evaluations of the Ottawa Ankle Rules and training sessions, there was no reduction in ankle radiography use for the 10 hospitals that received the training sessions (73% before intervention and 78% after intervention, p = 0.11). In contrast, use of radiography was significantly reduced from 75% to 65% in the 5 control hospitals (p = 0.022). COMMENT: Even if a dissemination strategy is well received and includes widely accepted clinical guidelines, the impact on behavior in clinical practice may be small. In addition to wide dissemination, an active local practice strategy is required to encourage physicians to adopt clinical guidelines.

title: Nonalcoholic Fatty Liver Disease and Fibrosis in Youth Taking Psychotropic Drugs: Literature Review, Case Reports and Management
abstract: OBJECTIVE: Non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD) has become a worldwide epidemic due to the increasing prevalence of obesity. Despite its implications for youth with severe mental disorders, little has been published about this increasingly common medical comorbidity in the psychiatric literature. The objectives of this article are: 1) to provide an overview of the epidemiology and pathophysiology of NAFLD, including progression to nonalcoholic steatohepatitis (NASH); 2) to describe two clinical cases that illustrate challenges in management; and 3) to provide screening recommendations, differential diagnosis, and approaches to monitoring and intervention. METHODS: A literature review including guidelines and recommendations, case reports, and control liver histology biopsy photographs was conducted.CONCLUSIONS: NAFLD during childhood and adolescence as a precursor to NASH progresses to fibrosis in a small percentage of young people, increasing the risk of early-onset cirrhosis and The cases presented suggest that youth with serious mental health disorders who are already at greater risk for obesity and its sequelae may be at higher risk for progression to NASH due to higher rates of weight gain in addition to potentially overweight or obese status. plus your worry and changes in liver metabolism from psychotropic drugs that promote fat accumulation. CONCLUSIONS: Patients with rapid weight gain into the overweight or obese categories or who develop elevated liver transaminases that persist for 3-6 months should be screened or referred for screening by psychotropic provider clinicians for early detection, diagnosis, and association. Treatment by a pediatric gastroenterologist to reduce the risk of progression to NASH, which is reversible if early and adequate lifestyle change results in significant weight loss. Controlled studies are urgently needed on the relationships between weight gain, psychotropic drugs, ultrasound and biopsy findings, and rates of progression to NAFLD and NASH in youth taking psychotropic drugs that cause weight gain.

title: Noninvasive imaging predicts failure burden of spine with simulated osteolytic defects
abstract: BACKGROUND: Clinical treatment of lytic tumors of the spine is currently based on geometric measurements of defect. However, the mechanical behavior of a structure depends on both its material and its geometric properties. Quantitative computed tomography and dual-energy x-ray absorptiometry were explored as noninvasive tools to quantify the material and geometric properties of vertebrae with a simulated lytic defect. From these measurements, yield loads were estimated using composite beam theory. METHODS: Thirty-four fresh frozen cadaver spines were divided into functional spinal units of three vertebral bodies with two intervertebral discs at the thoracic and lumbar levels. Lytic defects of equal size were created in one of three locations: the anterior, lateral, or posterior region of the vertebra. Each spinal unit was scanned using computed tomography and dual-energy x-ray absorptiometry, and axial and bending stiffnesses were calculated from the image data. Each specimen was brought to the breaking point under combined compression and forward bending, and the axial load and bending moment at the yield point were recorded. RESULTS: Although the relative defect size was nearly constant, the measured yield loads had a wide distribution, suggesting that defect size alone is a poor predictor of failure. However, the structural stiffness measurements derived from the image correlated moderately well with the measured yield loads. Also, using composite beam theory with stiffnesses derived from quantitative computed tomography, vertebral yield loads were estimated on a one-to-one basis (fit, r(c) = 0.74). CONCLUSIONS: We show that although current clinical guidelines for estimating fracture risk are based on geometric measurements of the defect, the relative size of the defect alone does not account for variation in vertebral yield loads. However, composite beam theory analysis with stiffness measurements derived from quantitative computed tomography can be used to prospectively predict yield loads of lytically defective vertebrae. CLINICAL APPLICABILITY: Image-estimated vertebral yield loads and analytical models that approximate the loads applied to the spine during activities of daily living can be used to calculate a fracture risk factor that can be used by physicians to plan appropriate treatment or intervention.

title: Non-surgical treatment of blunt spleen injury
Nonpharmacological Treatments for Acute and Chronic Low Back Pain: A Review of Evidence for the American Pain Society/American College of Physicians Clinical Practice Guidelines
abstract: BACKGROUND: Many non-pharmacological treatments are available for the treatment of low back pain. OBJECTIVE: To evaluate the benefits and harms of acupuncture, back schools, psychological treatments, exercise therapy, functional restoration, interdisciplinary therapy, massage, physical therapies (interventional therapy, low-level) laser therapy, lumbar supports, short wave diathermy, surface heat, traction, transcutaneous electrical nerve stimulation and ultrasonography), spinal manipulation, and yoga for acute or chronic low back pain (with or without leg pain). DATA SOURCES: English studies were identified through MEDLINE (until November 2006) and Cochrane Database of Systematic Reviews (2006, Issue 4). These electronic searches were supplemented by manual searches of expert-recommended reference lists and additional citations. STUDY SELECTION: Systematic reviews and randomized trials of 1 or more previous treatments for acute or chronic low back pain (with or without leg pain) pain outcomes, back-specific function, general health status, job disability, or patient satisfaction. DATA DRAWING: We abstracted information about study design, population characteristics, interventions, outcomes, and adverse events. We used the Oxman criteria for systematic reviews and the Cochrane Review Group criteria for individual trials to rate methodological quality. DATA SYNTHESIS: We found good evidence that cognitive-behavioral therapy, exercise, spinal manipulation, and interdisciplinary rehabilitation were all moderately effective. chronic or subacute (lasting >4 weeks) low back pain. Benefits relative to placebo, sham therapy, or no treatment were an average of 10 to 20 points on a 100-point visual analog pain scale, 2 to 4 points on the Roland-Morris Disability Questionnaire, or a standard mean difference of 0.5 to 0.8. We found reasonable evidence that acupuncture, massage, yoga (Viniyoga), and functional restoration are also effective for chronic low back pain. For acute low back pain (duration <4 weeks), the only non-pharmacological treatments with evidence of efficacy are superficial heat (good evidence for moderate benefits) and spinal manipulation (moderate evidence for small to moderate benefits). Although serious harms appear to be rare, data on harms are underreported. There are no studies addressing the optimal sequencing of treatments, and methods for tailoring treatment to individual patients are still in the early stages of development. There is insufficient evidence to evaluate the effectiveness of sciatica treatments. LIMITATIONS: Our primary data source was systematic reviews. We included non-English trials only if they were included in English systematic reviews. CONCLUSIONS: Therapies with good evidence of moderate efficacy for chronic or subacute low back pain are cognitive-behavioral therapy, exercise, spinal manipulation, and interdisciplinary rehabilitation. . For acute low back pain, the only treatment with good evidence of efficacy is superficial heat.

title: Non-pharmacological management of hypertension: results of interviews with 100 GPs.
abstract: OBJECTIVE: To describe the type and level of non-pharmacological management offered by general practitioners for essential hypertension. DESIGN: An interviewer-directed open-ended questionnaire using a standard case of a 60-year-old man with essential hypertension. Seventy interviews were conducted face-to-face and 30 interviews were conducted by telephone. SETTING: Auckland general applications. SUBJECTS: A random sample of 100 Auckland general practitioners. MAIN OUTCOME MEASURES: Aspects of patients' medical history, physical examination, laboratory tests, and treatment related to non-pharmacological management. RESULTS: There was a response rate of 84%. Most GPs reported recommending non-pharmacological treatment at the initial consultation before prescribing medication. However, few offered detailed programs. Dietary therapy, restriction of alcohol consumption, and exercise were recommended by most general practitioners. Restriction of sodium intake and behavioral therapy were less popular among non-pharmacological interventions. The median number of patients' visits to the GP before medications were prescribed was five, in accordance with guidelines. The median number of days from the first visit to the prescription of drug therapy was 42 (range 2-341). The clinical advice given by the majority of the participants was in line with current guidelines on the treatment of hypertension, but the recommendations given were broad in scope. CONCLUSIONS: The results indicate that general practitioners are aware of non-pharmacological interventions for the treatment of hypertension. They reported routine use of non-pharmacological treatments early in the clinical process before considering pharmacological treatment for blood pressure lowering and other health benefits. These non-pharmacological treatments are not offered in well-defined and detailed programmes.

title: unresponsive celiac disease
Nordic Myeloma Study Group, first 15 years: scientific collaboration and improving patient care
abstract: The successes of the Nordic Myeloma Study Group (NMSG) over the first 15 years are briefly reviewed, with a discussion of the principles guiding the group's clinical trials and issues that need to be addressed in the coming years. The group has so far conducted 12 clinical trials involving more than 2,500 patients ranging from minor phase II to large randomized phase III trials. At the time of this writing, two randomized trials are underway (comparing two doses of iv pamidronate and melphalan-prednisone (MP) versus MP-thalidomide in elderly patients). The group strived for a simple organization with multiple responsibilities delegated to regional coordinators (Denmark 3, Norway 5, Sweden 5). Regarding research design, the group felt it was important that studies were based on sound scientific questions, were simple to address for participants, and included population-based, investigator-initiated, quality of life and health resources assessment as endpoints. It can be used as the basis for various scientific side projects. Like other clinical trial groups, the NMSG faces a number of challenges in the years to come. The financial situation for independent investigator-initiated research is far from satisfactory, especially with regard to the resource-consuming implementation of stricter good clinical practice rules and ethics committee requests. The NMSG has also faced increasing difficulties in recruiting patients into recent research, partly due to problems with participating physicians (lack of support, troublesome paperwork, insufficient credit for participation). Solutions to these problems are needed for industry-independent clinical research groups to survive.

title: Norepinephrine plus dobutamine versus epinephrine alone for the treatment of septic shock: a randomized trial.
abstract: Background International guidelines for the management of septic shock recommend preferring dopamine or norepinephrine to epinephrine. However, no large comparative trials have yet been conducted. We aimed to compare the efficacy and safety of norepinephrine plus dobutamine (as needed) versus epinephrine alone in septic shock.";" Background International guidelines for the management of septic shock recommend preferring dopamine or norepinephrine to epinephrine. However, no large comparative trials have yet been conducted. We aimed to compare the efficacy and safety of norepinephrine plus dobutamine (as needed) versus epinephrine alone in septic shock.

title: Normal ranges of heart rate and respiratory rate in children from birth to 18 years: a systematic review of observational studies.
abstract: Background Although heart rate and respiratory rate are routinely measured in children in acute settings, the available reference ranges are not evidence-based. We aimed to derive new percentile charts for these vital signs and compare these percentiles with existing international ranges.";" Background Although heart rate and respiratory rate are routinely measured in children in acute settings, the available reference ranges are not evidence-based. We aimed to derive new percentile charts for these vital signs and to compare these percentiles with current international ranges.

title: Nudge antibiotic prescription in line with guideline: a randomized clinical trial
abstract: IMPORTANCE: "Nudges" that influence decision making through subtle cognitive mechanisms have been shown to be highly effective in a wide variety of applications, but little experimentation has been done to improve clinical practice. OBJECTIVE: To explore the use of a behavioral "nudge" based on the principle of public commitment to promote the judicious use of antibiotics for acute respiratory infections (ARIs). DESIGN, ENVIRONMENT, AND PARTICIPANTS: Randomized clinical trial in 5 outpatient primary care clinics. A total of 954 adults visited ARI during the study period: 449 patients were treated by clinicians selected at random to the letter of commitment (335 at baseline, 114 during intervention period); 505 patients were treated by clinicians randomized to standard practice control (384 baseline, 121 INTERVENTIONS: The intervention consisted of the display of poster-size commitment letters in the examination rooms for 12 weeks. These letters, which included clinician photographs and signatures, expressed their commitment to avoid inappropriate antibiotic prescribing for ARIs. MAIN RESULTS AND PRECAUTIONS: Antibiotics during baseline and intervention periods -antibiotic prescribing rates for inappropriate ARI diagnoses adjusted for patient age, gender, and insurance status RESULTS: Baseline rates were 43.5% and 42.8% for control and poster, respectively. During the intervention period, rates of inappropriate prescribing for controls increased to 52.7% , send a letter of commitment It decreased to 33.7% in the condition that it was removed. Controlling for baseline prescribing rates, we found that the submitted letter of commitment resulted in a 19.7 absolute percent reduction in the rate of inappropriate antibiotic prescribing relative to the control (P = .02). There was no evidence of diagnostic coding change, and rates of appropriate antibiotic prescription did not decline over time. RESULTS AND SUITABILITY: Display of poster-size commitment letters in examination rooms reduced inappropriate antibiotic prescribing for ARIs. The impact of this simple, low-cost intervention is comparable in magnitude to more costly, more intensive quality improvement efforts. TRIAL REGISTRATION: Clinicaltrials.gov identifier: NCT01767064.

title: Nudge physician prescription decisions by segmenting the order set: results of a sketch-based study.
abstract: Background Health professionals are rapidly adopting electronic health records (EHRs). Within EHRs, seemingly innocuous menu design configurations can influence provider decisions for better or for worse. Purpose The aim of this study was to examine whether grouping of menu items systematically influences prescribing practices among primary care providers. Participants We surveyed 166 primary care providers in a research network in the Greater Chicago area, of which 84 responded (51% response rate). Responders and non-responders were similar across all observable dimensions, except that participants were more likely to work in an academic setting. The Design Questionnaire consisted of seven clinical histories. Each sketch described the typical signs and symptoms for acute respiratory infections, and providers selected treatments from a menu of options. For each sketch, providers are randomly assigned to one of the two menu sections. For non-antibiotic-appropriate vignettes, the treatment menu grouped prescriptions together while listing over-the-counter (OTC) drugs one by one or showing the reverse section. For antibiotic-appropriate vignettes, the treatment menu either listed narrow-spectrum antibiotics individually while grouping broad-spectrum antibiotics, or showed the reverse section. Key Precautions The main outcome was the provider's treatment choice. For short stories that were not appropriate for antibiotics, we categorized the responses as prescription drugs or over-the-counter options only. For antibiotic-appropriate vignettes, we classified the responses as broad- or narrow-spectrum antibiotics. Key Results Among the short stories, there was an 11.5 percentage point reduction in choosing aggressive treatment options (eg, broad-spectrum antibiotics) when aggressive options were grouped compared to when the same options were listed separately (95% CI: 2.9 to 20.1%). ; " p?=?.008). Results Provider treatment choice appears to be influenced by grouping of menu options, suggesting that the arrangement of EHR order sets is not an arbitrary practice. Careful creation of EHR order sets can serve as an important opportunity to improve patient care without limiting physicians' ability to prescribe what they believe is best for their patients.

title: To act prudently? The effect of reminders on antibiotic prescriptions.
abstract: Antibiotic resistance is a major and growing global health threat with significant consequences. The prudent use of antibiotics is vital to delay the spread of resistance. In this study, I use a randomized controlled trial to test the effect of reminders to primary care patients on antibiotic use. The intervention was implemented in 31 clinics during flu season in Stockholm. A two-level randomization was used, with clinical-level and individual-patient-level randomization. With reminders, antibiotic use decreased by 12.6 percent compared to control clinics. The impact is clinical, suggesting that doctors or doctor-patient interactions are affected, not individual patients. Results from a follow-up experiment also show that an effect on the interactions between doctor and patient is the primary driver of the main results. Behavioral interventions targeting these interactions have the potential to reduce antibiotic use. However, more research is needed as monitoring and adherence may also play a role.

title: Nurse-led home self-help therapy for primary care patients with chronic fatigue syndrome: randomized controlled trial.
abstract: OBJECTIVE To evaluate the efficacy of pragmatic home rehabilitation—an increasing activity program designed collaboratively by patient and therapist—and a non-directive counseling-based supportive listening approach for primary care inpatients with chronic fatigue syndrome/myalgia. encephalomyelitis or encephalitis (CFS/ME). DESIGN Single-blind, randomized, controlled trial. DETERMINATION 186 general practice in the north-west of England between February 2005 and May 2007. PARTICIPANTS 296 patients aged 18 years and older with CFS/ME (mean disease duration of seven years) were diagnosed using the Oxford criteria. INTERVENTIONS Participants were randomized as usual to pragmatic rehabilitation, supportive listening, or GP therapy. Both therapies were administered at home in 10 sessions over 18 weeks by one of three adult private general nurses who received four months of training, including supervised practice in each of the interventions. As usual, GP treatment was not restricted, except that patients were not referred to systematic psychological therapies during treatment. Main outcome measures Primary clinical outcomes were fatigue and physical functioning at the end of treatment (20 weeks) and 70 weeks after recruitment compared to usual GP therapy. Lower fatigue scores and higher physical functioning scores mean better results. RESULTS A total of 257 (87%) of the 296 patients enrolled in the study were evaluated at the primary endpoint at 70 weeks. Analysis was on a treatment basis, with robust treatment effects estimated after adjusting for missing data using probability weights. Immediately after treatment (at 20 weeks), fatigue was significantly improved in patients (n=95) allocated to pragmatic rehabilitation (effect estimation -1.18, 95% confidence interval -2.18 to -0.18"; P=0.021) but physical functioning (-0.18%, %). There was no statistically significant difference in fatigue or physicality at one year (70 weeks) after the end of treatment when compared to patients who opted out for treatment normally (n=100) 95 CI -5.88 to +5.52; P=0.950). functionality among patients treated as usual (-1.00, 95% CI -2.10 to +0.11; P=0.076 and +2.57, 95% CI 3.90 to +9.03; P=0.435). 101) had worse physical functioning than those who opted out of treatment as usual (-7.54, 95% CI -12.76 to -2.33; “P=0.005) and there was no difference in fatigue. At 70 weeks, patients allocated to supportive listening were not significantly different from those allocated to treatment-as-usual in both primary outcomes. CONCLUSIONS For patients with CFS/ME in primary care, pragmatic rehabilitation delivered by trained nurse therapists improves fatigue in the short term compared to unconstrained GP therapy as usual, but the effect is small and not statistically significant at one year follow-up. Supportive listening by trained nurse therapists is not an effective treatment for CFS/ME. Trial registration International Standard Randomized Controlled Trial Number IRCTN74156610.

title: Nurse practitioners improve quality of care in chronic kidney disease: two-year results of a randomized trial.
abstract: BACKGROUND: Chronic kidney disease (CKD) is associated with increased cardiovascular risk. Here, we evaluate whether strict implementation of multi-target guidelines with the help of nurse practitioners (NP) improves management in patients with CKD. METHODS: MASTER PLAN was a randomized controlled clinical trial conducted in nine Dutch hospitals. Patients with CKD (estimated glomerular filtration rate (eGFR) 20-70 ml/min) were randomized to receive NP support (intervention group (IG)) or physician care (control group (CG)). The patients were followed for a median of five years. The data presented is an interim analysis of risk factor control at two-year follow-up. RESULTS: 788 patients (532 M, 256 F), (393 CG, 395 IG), mean (+/-SD ) age 59 (+/-13) years, eGFR 38 (+/-15) ml/min were included . /1.73m(2), blood pressure (BP) 138 (+/-21)/80 (+/-11) mmHg. At two years, 698 patients (352 IG, 346 CG) could be analyzed. Compared with CG, IG had lower systolic (133 vs 135 mmHg"; p= 0.04) and diastolic BP (77 vs 80 mmHg; p=0.007), LDL cholesterol (2.30 vs 2.45 mmol(-1); " p = 0.03). and increased use of ACE inhibitors, statins, aspirin and vitamin D. The intervention had no effect on smoking cessation, body weight, physical activity, or sodium excretion. CONCLUSION: Risk factor management improved in both groups. However, changes in BP control, lipid management, and drug use were more pronounced in IG than in CG. Lifestyle interventions were not effective. Coaching by NPs therefore benefits the day-to-day care of CKD patients. Whether these changes translate into improvements in clinical endpoints remains to be determined.

title: Nurse-led motivational interviewing to change the lifestyle of patients with type 2 diabetes (MILD project): protocol for a cluster to implement lifestyle recommendations, randomized, controlled trial
abstract: BACKGROUND: Many patients' diabetes is managed in general practice";" Health care providers aim to promote healthy behaviors such as a healthy diet, adequate physical activity and smoking cessation. These measures can reduce insulin resistance, improve glycemic control, lipid abnormalities, and hypertension. They can also prevent cardiovascular diseases and complications of diabetes. However, professionals do not follow lifestyle counseling guidelines optimally. Motivational interviewing to change the lifestyles of patients with type 2 diabetes aims to improve diabetes care in accordance with national guidelines for lifestyle counselling. Primary care nurses will be trained in motivational interviewing embedded in structured care in general practice. The purpose of this article is to describe the design and methods of a study evaluating the effects of nurse education on patient outcomes. METHODS/DESIGN: A cluster, randomized, controlled trial of 70 overall treatments (35 treatments in the intervention arm and 35 treatments in the control arm) starting March 2007. A total of 700 patients with type 2 diabetes will be included in the study. Patients in the intervention arm will receive care from a primary care nurse who will be trained in an implementation strategy with motivational interviewing as the key component. Other components of this strategy will be educational and supportive tools for adapting the diabetes protocol to local conditions, introducing a social map for lifestyle support, and maintaining motivational interviewing. The control arm will be encouraged to maintain normal maintenance. Impact measures will be the course of care, metabolic parameters (glycosylated hemoglobin, blood pressure, and lipids), lifestyle (diet, physical activity, smoking and alcohol), health-related quality of life, and patients' willingness to change their behavior. Measurements will be made at baseline and after 14 months. DISCUSSION: The application of motivational interviewing for patients with diabetes in primary care has been studied, but to our knowledge, no other study has yet evaluated the practicality and sustainability of motivating and involving patients in daily diabetes care in general practice. If this intervention proves to be effective and cost-effective, large-scale implementation of this nurse-focused intervention will be considered and anticipated. TRIAL REGISTRATION: Current Controlled Trials ISRCTN68707773.

title: Nurse-led, telephone-based outreach to improve lipids in people with diabetes
abstract: BACKGROUND: Randomized prospective trials of resource utilization analyzes and case management interventions are needed. OBJECTIVE: To determine whether algorithm-based phone care by nurses improves lipid control in patients with diabetes. DESIGN: Prospective, randomized, controlled trial. PARTICIPANTS: Adults with diabetes at a federally funded community health center were randomly assigned to the intervention (n = 381) or usual care (n = 381) groups. INTERVENTIONS: Nurses independently initiated and titrated lipid therapy and promoted behavior change through motivational interviewing and self-management techniques. Other parameters of diabetes care were considered based on time constraints. MAIN MEASURES: The primary outcome was the proportion of patients with low-density lipoprotein (LDL) less than 100 mg/dL. Secondary outcomes included the number of hospital admissions, total hospital charges per patient, and the proportion of patients meeting other lipid, glycemic, and blood pressure guidelines. KEY RESULTS: The percentage of patients with LDL < 100 mg/dL increased from 52.0% to 58.5% in the intervention group and decreased from 55.6% to 46.7% in the control group (P < .01). The mean cost to the healthcare system per patient was less for the intervention group ($6600 vs. $9033, P = .03). Intervention patients tended to have fewer hospitalizations (P = .06). The intervention did not affect glycemic and blood pressure outcomes. CONCLUSIONS: Nurses can improve lipid control in patients with diabetes, mainly in a poor population, through telephone care using moderately complex algorithms, but a more targeted approach is warranted. Phone-based access can reduce resource usage, but more work is needed.

title: Evaluations of nurses regarding the use of CPOT 12 months after the application in the intensive care unit
abstract: BACKGROUND: Routine pain assessments with all intensive care unit (ICU) patients are strongly recommended in clinical practice guidelines. Because many ICU patients do not self-report, the Critical-Care Pain Observation Tool (CPOT) is one of two behavioral pain scales recommended for clinical use. However, there are no studies describing evaluations of its use in daily practice in the intensive care unit. OBJECTIVE: To describe nurses' assessment of feasibility, clinical relevance, and satisfaction with the use of CPOT 12 months after its application in the ICU. METHOD: A descriptive design was used. It was conducted in the medical-surgical intensive care unit of a university-affiliated setting in Greenfield Park (Quebec, Canada). A self-administered assessment questionnaire containing four sections (ie, feasibility, clinical relevance, satisfaction, and socio-demographic information) was completed by ICU nurses, all trained to use the CPOT. The questionnaires were filled in anonymously. RESULTS: A total of 38 intensive care nurses returned the completed questionnaire (63% participation rate). Regarding its applicability, the majority rated CPOT as fast to use, simple to understand and easy to complete (92-100%). Based on clinical significance, approximately 70% of ICU nurses agreed that CPOT affected their practice, but lower results (<50%) were found for effective communication of pain assessment findings with physicians and other healthcare professionals. More than 80% of intensive care nurses were satisfied with daily use. CONCLUSION: According to the evaluations of the nurses, the use of CPOT was found to be applicable and appropriate in daily practice, but it did not allow effective communication with other ICU care team members. RELATED TO CLINICAL PRACTICE: All members of the ICU care team should be trained and other practice strategies should be explored to ensure optimal adoption of a pain assessment approach that influences decision-making processes for pain management.

title: nurse salary
Nurses' representations of caring for mentally handicapped patients and perceived needs to provide quality care
abstract: OBJECTIVES AND OBJECTIVES: To explore nurses' representation in caring for people with intellectual disabilities, the intervention strategies they currently use, and identify needs to provide quality care. BACKGROUND: Nurses work in many settings and with a variety of clients. Certain customers have needs that require special approaches, for example people with intellectual disabilities. The care provided to these patients may be influenced by the representations of the nurses caring for them. DESIGN: Qualitative descriptive study. METHODS: Semi-structured interviews were conducted with 18 nurses working in hospital and community settings using thematic analysis. RESULTS: Nurses are concerned with the ability to recognize the special nature and complex needs associated with patients' mental disabilities, promote quality care by managing behavioral and communication difficulties, and also cope with the perceived lack of time and organization in the work environment. . Current strategies include trying to promote continuity of care. Participants also identified learning needs that were relational and informative in nature. CONCLUSIONS: Nurses typically appear to be mindful of providing quality care to patients with intellectual disabilities and acknowledge that there are many contextual and practical elements that need improvement to ensure the safety of these patients. RELATED TO CLINICAL PRACTICE: Nurses should be trained to accommodate and encourage findings from existing research showing that people with intellectual disabilities want to be part of their local communities. This can be facilitated by the adoption of specific guidelines, protocols and maintenance programmes. More research focusing on self-advocacy and health promotion techniques is needed to better understand the expectations of these patients and their caregivers in order to develop personalized standards of practice and reduce health education disparities for these patients.

title: Nurses' strategies to address self-care aspects related to medication adherence and symptom recognition in heart failure patients: an in-depth look.
abstract: OBJECTIVE: Despite the increasing knowledge about self-care in heart failure patients, the need for effective interventions remains. We sought to deepen the understanding of interventions used by heart failure nurses in clinical practice to improve patient compliance with medication and symptom monitoring. METHODS: A qualitative study with directed content analysis was conducted using data from a selected sample of Dutch-speaking heart failure nurses who filled out booklets containing two vignettes of medication adherence and symptom recognition. RESULTS: Nurses regularly evaluate and reassess patients before deciding on an intervention. They evaluate the basic/factual information and obstacles in a patient's behavior and try to find room for improvement in the patient's behavior. Interventions used by heart failure nurses to increase medication adherence and symptom monitoring are grouped under the themes of increasing knowledge, increasing motivation, and providing practical tools to patients. Nurses also described using technology-based tools, increased social support, alternative communication, partnership approaches, and coordination of care to improve medication adherence and symptom monitoring. CONCLUSION: Despite a strong focus on educational strategies, nurses also reported other strategies to increase patient compliance. Nurses use a variety of strategies not included in the guidelines to improve patient compliance. These interventions need to be evaluated for further applications to improve heart failure management.

title: Nursing research in the United States: protecting human subjects
abstract: In the United States, protection of the rights of human subjects in experiments has developed at three levels: professional, public, and private. At the professional level, the rules, guidelines and the Bill of Rights address issues of protecting the dignity, privacy and autonomy of individuals serving as research subjects. At the public level, regulations issued by the Food and Drug Administration and the Department of Health and Human Services have become the standard for the protection of human subjects. At the specific level, United States common law regulates the behavior of individual researchers by requiring that they act in accordance with generally accepted standards of care. As professionals, nurses should be actively involved in the formulation of public policy regarding the conduct of research and should seek to establish a research agenda that will ensure that research ethics in nursing are not questioned.

title: Nursing practice protocol standard: depression in elderly patients. NİŞE faculty
abstract: Depression is a very common but underrecognized and undertreated mental health problem among community-dwelling, medically ill, and institutionalized older adults. Untreated depression is associated with serious adverse outcomes for the elderly patient. Nurses in a variety of practice settings can reduce the negative effects of depression through early recognition, intervention, and referral of depressed patients. This article provides an overview of late-life depression, with emphasis on age-related assessment considerations, clinical decision-making, and nursing intervention strategies for older people with depression. A standard practice protocol is also provided for use by nurses in a variety of practice settings.
