title: Nursing students' beliefs about smoking, their own smoking behaviors, and use of professional tobacco treatment intervention
abstract: As the largest group of healthcare professionals, nurses are in a unique position to influence their smoking patients. They also have more contact with patients than any other provider. The purpose of this survey study is to use nursing students' beliefs about smoking, smoking behaviors, and an evidence-based tobacco treatment intervention. Only 6% of the 200 undergraduate nursing students surveyed smoked. The most common misconception about tobacco treatment was that less than 3 minutes of counseling had no effect on improving smoking cessation. Eight percent of smokers surveyed reported providing tobacco use treatment to all patients who smoked, compared to 26% of nonsmokers. Smoking-related morbidity and mortality requires consistent use of clinical practice guidelines by nursing students and professional nurses.

title: Nutrition is more important than nature in childhood obesity, study finds
abstract: A study comparing the weight of biological and adopted children with that of their parents found that lifestyles, rather than genes, are primarily responsible for children's overweight.1 Researchers and researchers from the Center for Economic Performance at the London School of Economics, in Political Science, argue that policies to influence parents' lifestyles concluded that it may help combat overweight in children. For the study, the researchers compiled 13 years of data.

title: Nutrition and Policy

Obesity assessment and treatment: Expert Committee recommendations. Office of Maternal and Child Health, the Health Resources and Services Administration, and the Department of Health and Human Services
abstract: OBJECTIVES: To develop recommendations for physicians, nurses and nutritionists to guide the assessment and treatment of overweight children and adolescents. METHODS: The Office of Maternal and Child Health, the Health Resources and Services Administration, the Department of Health and Human Services convened a committee of pediatric obesity experts to develop recommendations. CONCLUSIONS: The committee recommended that children with obesity complications who have a body mass index (BMI) greater than or equal to the 85th percentile, or with a BMI greater than or equal to the 95th percentile, with or without complications, should seek evaluation and possible treatment. . Clinicians should be aware of the manifestations of rare exogenous causes of obesity, including genetic syndromes, endocrinological diseases, and psychological disorders. They should screen for complications of obesity, including hypertension, dyslipidemias, orthopedic disorders, sleep disorders, gallbladder disease, and insulin resistance. Conditions that require consultation with a pediatric obesity specialist include pseudotumor cerebri, obesity-related sleep disorders, orthopedic problems, massive obesity, and obesity in children younger than 2 years. Recommendations for treatment evaluation included an assessment of the patient's and family's readiness to participate in a weight management program, and a focused assessment of diet and physical activity habits. The primary goal of obesity treatment should be healthy nutrition and activity. The use of weight maintenance and weight loss to achieve weight goals depends on each patient's age, baseline BMI percentage, and presence of medical complications. The committee recommended treatment that starts early, involves the family, and gradually creates lasting change. Parenting skills are the foundation of successful intervention that provides gradual, targeted activity increases and targeted reductions in high-fat, high-calorie foods. Ongoing support for families after the initial weight management program will help families maintain their new behavior. CONCLUSIONS: These recommendations provide practical guidance to pediatric clinicians evaluating and treating overweight children.

title: Observational study of telephone interviews by stroke specialists supporting community tissue plasminogen activator delivery
abstract: OBJECTIVES: Barriers to the use of intravenous (IV) tissue plasminogen activator (tPA) in ischemic stroke include the limited treatment experience of community physicians. Acute stroke care models are designed to address these limitations by providing community support. These include telephone or televideo support, with or without subsequent transfer to tertiary care centers. The authors describe the frequency, characteristics, and impact of community phone calls to a 24/7 stroke "helpline" staffed by stroke doctors at an academic stroke center using such a model. METHODS: Twelve intervention hospitals participating in Incremental Stroke Treatment through Interventional Behavior Modification Tactics (INSTINCT) were provided with a single access number ("helpline") for specialist advice on tPA use. The specialists consisted of doctors trained in stroke at an academic medical center. Helpline use was not mandated by the study protocol and patient transfer was not required. Counselors were asked to log all treatment questions in a Web-based diary. All patients discussed on the helpline and/or treated with tPA at an INSTINCT hospital underwent multilevel chart review by trained nurse coordinators. Cases were associated with recorded helpline calls based on duration of treatment and hospital first treated. Physician reviewers evaluated the suitability of tPA therapy, deviation from standard guidelines, and treatment complications (intracranial hemorrhage [ICH], systemic hemorrhage, or death). RESULTS: A total of 204 telephone lines were called on 116 patients during 27 months. 91 percent of calls were between 8 am and midnight, and 77% of questions explored eligibility for IV tPA, specifically minor stroke or stroke amelioration (26%). A total of 243 patients were treated with IV tPA in 12 intervention hospitals, 54 of which followed the hotline. Seventy-six percent of patients for whom tPA was recommended actually received tPA, while 2% of those for whom tPA was not recommended received the drug. There was no difference in protocol deviations (27.8% helpline group vs 23.8% no helpline group), incidence of symptomatic ICH (5.6% vs 7.3%), or in-hospital mortality (5.6% vs 13.2%). No medico-legal problem was reported for any case in the study. CONCLUSIONS: It is possible and safe to provide tPA decision-making support to community physicians by telephone consultation. Consultants can play a more important role than acceptance in determining tPA non-compliance. Future studies should include a real-time survey of physician providers to identify such potential qualitative benefits of a stroke helpline.

title: Oncologist Perspectives on Rare Cancer Care: A Nationwide Study
abstract: OBJECTIVE: In response to the challenges and challenges posed by rare cancers, multi-stakeholder initiatives to improve rare cancer care have been launched and several recommendations have been made by the professional community. However, they primarily reflect the views of advocates and supporters and may not represent the views of the "average" clinician or researcher. In this study, we sought to explore the perceived challenges associated with rare cancer care and potential solutions approved by oncologists. MATERIAL AND METHODS: A representative sample of 420 oncologists from 13 cancer centers participated in a nationwide survey. CONCLUSIONS: Oncologists treat patients with rare cancers, including lack of clinical practice guidelines (65.7%) and personal experience (65.2%), lack of approved treatment options (39.8%) and reimbursement issues (44.5%). faced various difficulties. . They generally supported the recent recommendations of the professional communities as well as multi-stakeholder initiatives for the development of open clinical practice guidelines (66.0%), flexible reimbursement guidelines (52.9%), and a national rare cancer registry (47.4%). However, there was only moderate approval for referrals to high-volume centers (35.5%) and promotion of off-label treatments (21.0%). CONCLUSION: Insights into the general attitudes of oncologists gained through our nationwide survey of representative samples will be helpful in improving clinical practice and public health policy in rare cancer treatment and research.

title: Oncology healthcare providers' application of the 5A brief intervention model for smoking cessation: patients' perceptions
abstract: OBJECTIVE: Health care providers (HCPs) can play an important role in promoting smoking cessation and preventing relapse. Public Health Service guidelines recommend the "5A's" short response model. The aim of this study was to examine cancer patients' perceptions of the model application of 5A by oncology HCPs. METHODS: This study included 81 breast cancer and 87 head and neck cancer patients at an NCI-designated comprehensive cancer center. Patients completed questionnaires assessing their perceptions of oncology HCPs' implementation of the brief intervention model of 5A. RESULTS: The results show partial application of the 5A model. Most patients reported that their providers asked about smoking and advised them to quit";" only half reported that their interest in quitting had been assessed, and very few reported assistance with quitting or follow-up. Administration of 5As was greater in patients seeking quit advice from their HCP. CONCLUSION: Current findings indicate that adherence to 5As should be increased in the oncology setting. PRACTICAL APPLICATIONS: Efforts to increase smoking cessation treatment provided by healthcare professionals can improve quit rates among cancer patients and ultimately translate into better long-term cancer treatment outcomes.

title: One size fits all? A mixed method evaluation of the impact of 100% single room accommodation on staff and patient experience, safety and costs.
abstract: Background and objectives There is little strong evidence for the impact of one-bedroom accommodation on healthcare quality and safety. We explore the impact of all single rooms on staff and patient experience"; safety outcomes and costs. Methods Mixed methods, "pre/post move" comparison of four nested case study wards in a single 100% single room acute hospital; two control hospitals vs. pre-post-experimental study; analysis of capital and operating costs associated with single rooms. Results Two-thirds of patients said they preferred single rooms with comfort and control that outweighed the disadvantages (feeling of isolation) felt by some. Patients were satisfied with the privacy, privacy and flexibility that single rooms provide. Staff perceived improvements (patient comfort and privacy), but single rooms were worse in terms of visibility, surveillance, teamwork, monitoring and keeping patients safe. Staff walking distances increased significantly after the move. A temporary increase in falls and medication errors in a ward was likely related to the need to adjust work patterns rather than single rooms. We found no evidence that single rooms reduce infection rates. Building a fully one-room hospital may cost 5% more with higher cleaning and cleaning costs, but the difference is marginal over time. Results Staff needed to significantly adapt their work practices and felt unprepared for new ways of working with potentially significant long-term effects on the nature of teamwork. Staff preference remained for a mix of single rooms and coves. Patients preferred single rooms.

title: One-year outcomes of surgical and nonsurgical treatments for discogenic back pain: a prospective population-based cohort study.
abstract: BACKGROUND CONTEXT: "Discogenic back pain" is controversial at baseline levels, including its clinical status, pathophysiology, diagnostic criteria, and optimal treatment. This is true despite the existence of four randomized studies comparing the effectiveness of surgical and nonsurgical treatments. One trial demonstrated the benefit of lumbar fusion compared to unstructured nonsurgical care, and the other three showed roughly similar results for lumbar surgery and structured rehabilitation. OBJECTIVE: To compare the outcomes of community-based surgical and nonsurgical treatments in patients with chronic back pain due to degeneration at the level of one or both lumbar discs. DESIGN: Prospective observational cohort study. PATIENT SAMPLE: Patients presenting with axial back pain to academic and private practice orthopedic surgeons and neurosurgeons in a large metropolitan area. OUTCOME MEASURES: Roland-Morris back injury score (primary outcome), current rating of overall pain severity on a numerical scale, measures of back and leg pain discomfort, physical function scale of short form 36 version 2 questionnaire, pain, job status, emergency room visits, hospitalization hospitalizations and subsequent surgeries. METHODS: Patients who had spine surgery within 6 months of enrollment were designated as the "surgical treatment" group and the rest as "non-surgical treatment". Results were evaluated 3, 6, 9, and 12 months after enrollment. RESULTS: We brought 495 patients with discogenic back pain to 16 surgeons' offices for initial surgical consultation. Eighty-six patients (17%) underwent surgery within 6 months of enrollment. Surgery consisted of instrumented fusion (79%), disc replacement (12%), laminectomy or discectomy (9%). Surgical patients reported more severe pain and physical disability at baseline and were more likely to have had previous surgery. Adjusting for baseline differences between groups, surgical intervention showed limited benefit over nonsurgical treatment of 5.4 points on the modified (23-point) Roland disability questionnaire (primary outcome) 1 year after enrollment. Using a combined definition of success that included 30% improvement in Roland score, 30% improvement in pain, no opioid pain medication, and study (if appropriate), the 1-year success rate was 33% for surgery and 15% for nonsurgical treatment. treatment. The rate of reoperation in the surgical group was 11%";" In the nonsurgical group, the surgical rate after treatment was determined was 6% at 12 months post enrollment. RESULTS: Although the composite success rate for both treatment groups was only fair, the surgical group showed greater improvement at 1 year compared to the non-surgical group. Results should be interpreted with caution, as results are short-term and treatment is not randomly assigned. Only 5% of nonsurgical patients received cognitive behavioral therapy. The non-surgical treatment patients received varied and often did not comply with the main guidelines.

title: Continuous provision of individual clinician performance data improves practice behavior
abstract: BACKGROUND: Clinical practice guidelines summarize the evidence from science and attempt to translate these findings into clinical practice. Widespread and consistent adoption of these guidelines into log provider practices has proven slow. METHODS: Using postoperative nausea and vomiting (PONV) prophylaxis guideline compliance as our metric, we compared the effects of continuing medical education (CME) alone (I), a single snapshot of provider compliance of CME (II), and provider ongoing reporting. compatibility data (III) without further CME. We retrospectively analyzed the guideline compliance of 23,279 anesthetics at the University of Texas MD Anderson Cancer Center. Compliance was defined as a patient with 1 risk factor for PONV who received at least 1 antiemetic, 2 risk factors for at least 2 antiemetics, and 3 risk factors who received at least 3 antiemetics. Drugs in the same class were counted as the only antiemetic administration. Propofol-based anesthetic techniques counted as taking 1 antiemetic. Patients with 0 risk factors for PONV were not included. We estimated compliance rates for each of the 4 time periods of the study by adjusting for multiple observations on the same clinician. Individual performance feedback was given every 6 months after intervention I with a refresher presentation on PONV (initiation of intervention II) and continuously quarterly during intervention III. RESULTS: Compliance rates were not significantly affected by CME (intervention I) compared to baseline behavior (54.4% vs. 54.4%, P = 0.9140). A significant improvement occurred during the time period when CME was paired with performance data (intervention II) compared with intervention I (59.2% vs. 54.4%, P = 0.0002). Compared with intervention II (intervention III), more significant improvements occurred when data were presented alone (intervention III) (65.1% vs. 59.2%, P < 0.0001). For patients with 3 risk factors, we saw significant improvement in compliance rates during intervention III (P = 0.0002). In the post hoc analysis of overtreatment, the percentage differences between baseline and time period III decreased as the number of risk factors increased. RESULTS: We observed the greatest improvement in guideline compliance with continued personal performance feedback. Provider feedback can be an effective tool to change clinical practice, but it can have unexpected consequences.

title: Online interventions for social marketing health behavior change campaigns: a meta-analysis of psychological architectures and adaptation factors.
abstract: BACKGROUND: Researchers and practitioners have developed numerous online interventions that encourage people to reduce their alcohol consumption, increase their exercise, and better manage their weight. Motivations to develop eHealth interventions may be driven by Internet access, interaction, cost-effectiveness, and studies showing that online interventions work. However, when designing appropriate online interventions for public campaigns, there are few evidence-based guidelines, classifications are difficult to apply, many studies lack impact data, and previous meta-analyses do not apply to large-scale public campaigns targeting voluntary behavior change. OBJECTIVES: This meta-analysis evaluated online intervention design features to inform the development of online campaigns, such as those used by social marketers seeking to promote voluntary health behavior change. Another goal was to increase understanding of the relationships between intervention commitment, study commitment, and behavioral outcomes. METHODS: Based on systematic review methods, a combination of 84 query terms across 5 bibliographic databases was used with additional gray literature review. This resulted in 1271 abstracts and articles"; 31 met the inclusion criteria. In total, 29 articles describing 30 interventions were included in the primary meta-analysis, and 2 additional studies qualified for concordance analysis. Using the random effects model, initial analysis, control estimated the overall effect size, including groupings by conditions and time factors. The second analysis evaluated the effects of psychological design features encoded with classifications from evidence-based behavioral medicine, persuasive technology, and other behavioral domains. was integrated into the coding framework model. Finally, the third analysis evaluated the associations between intervention compliance and behavioral outcomes. RESULTS: The overall effect of online interventions was small but statistically significant (standardized) across all studies. mean difference effect size d=0.19, 95% confidence range [CI]=0.11-0.28, P<.001, mu number of more k=30). Compared with waitlists and placebos (d=0.28, 95% CI=0.17-0.39, P<.001, k=18) the largest effect with moderate efficacy was applied from the online interventions, followed by comparison with lower technology. online interventions (d=0.16, 95% CI=0.00-0.32, P=.04, k=8),” no significant difference was found when compared to complex pressure interventions (d=-0.11, 95% CI=-0.34 to 0.12, P=.35, k=4), but online interventions offer a small impact with the advantage of lower costs and greater accessibility. Time has proven to be a critical factor, shorter interventions often lead to greater impact and greater adherence to the design, interventions most are taken from a post-theoretical approach and are goal-directed, embeds multiple impact components aimed at showing users the consequences of their behavior, helping them achieve goals, and providing normative pressure a d intervention effectiveness, despite a conflicting correlation, evidence shows that study compliance, intervention compliance, and behavioral outcomes are related CONCLUSIONS: These findings suggest that online interventions have the capacity to influence voluntary behaviors such as those routinely targeted by social marketing campaigns. shows that he has Given the high reach and low cost of online technologies, the setting may be set for increased public health campaigns that blend interpersonal online systems with mass media. Such a combination of approaches can help individuals achieve personal goals that help them improve the quality of life of citizens at the individual level and contribute to healthier societies at the state level.

title: Operations research as an applied science: definitions, challenges and research priorities
abstract: Background Operations research (OR) is the discipline of using quantitative or qualitative models to aid decision making in complex application problems. Operating room methods have been used in healthcare since the 1950s in various fields such as emergency medicine and the interface between acute and community care; hospital performance; planning and management of patient home visits; scheduling patient appointments; and many other complex application issues of an operational or logistical nature. Discussion To date, there has been limited discussion of the role that operations research should play in applied science. For OR, I detail three such roles, all of which are based on prior systems thinking: structuring implementation problems, prospective evaluation of remediation interventions, and strategic restructuring. Case studies in mental health, emergency medicine, and stroke are used to illustrate each role. I then describe the challenges of the applied operating room within applied science at the organizational, interventional, and disciplinary levels. Two main challenges are the difficulty in achieving a position of mutual understanding between practice scientists and research users and the incomplete assessment of operating room interventions. To overcome these challenges, I propose a research agenda to evaluate the applied OR through applied science, liberating the OR from the environment of specialist research and consulting, and collaborative design of models with service users. Summary Operations research is a mature discipline that has developed a substantial amount of methodologies to improve healthcare. OR, it offers application scientists the opportunity to do more systems thinking before committing resources or taking risks. OR has three roles in practice science: a tool for structuring a practice problem, a prospective assessment of practice problems, and a strategic restructuring of healthcare. The challenges faced by OR as a science of practice include limited evidence and impact assessment, limited service user involvement, lack of managerial awareness, effective communication between research users and OR modelers, and availability of health data. To advance the science, three key areas need to be focused: evaluating OR interventions, embedding OR information into healthcare, and educating OR modelers about the goals and benefits of service user engagement.

title: Physicians' opinion survey on ethical issues in medical research
abstract: total of 3622 physicians registered with the Medical Association of India were contacted by mail and asked to answer a semi-structured questionnaire on different aspects of medical ethics, with a particular focus on informed consent. Six hundred and twenty-nine physicians (17.4%) answered the questionnaire"; 86% of the respondents reported that they had no formal training in medical ethics; 49% of the study subjects received only verbal consent. Most of the respondents were concerned with public health and animal ethics. noted the appropriateness of ethics in different medical situations, although it was felt to be less important in certain areas such as research using Physicians with previous research experience who reported taking an orientation course in medical ethics were more ethically conscious. Most professionals wanted ethics to be included in their medical curriculum.

title: Opportunistic electronic reminders. Improving the performance of preventive maintenance in general practice
abstract: BACKGROUND: Preventive care is an important role for general practitioners, but opportunities for prevention are often missed. METHOD: We provided an automatic electronic record preventive maintenance reminder system for 12 preventive maintenance activities for one 10 doctor's practice. All participating patients were randomized according to the last digit of their registration number. RESULTS: Opportunistic prevention has low uptake of control";" It ranges from 1.5% (tetanus vaccine) to 27% (flu vaccine). Reminders increased this by significant but small amounts for four of the 12 activities (tetanus and pneumococcal immunization and allergy and weight registration), insignificant increases in four (mumps, measles and rubella immunization, smoking registration and cervical smear collection). and blood pressure) and significantly reduced flu vaccination and screening for diabetes and hyperlipidemia. CONCLUSION: Opportunistic electronic reminders have the potential to increase preventive maintenance in general practice.

title: Optimal matches of patient preferences for information, decision making and interpersonal behavior: evidence, models and interventions
abstract: OBJECTIVE: A comprehensive review of theoretical and empirical studies addressing the preference-matching strategy in physician-patient communication was conducted. METHODS: Searches were made on Medline, PsychINFO, InFoTrac One File Plus, Sociological Abstracts, and Dissertation Abstracts until 2004. in joint decision making; patient-physician compliance, compliance or compliance; reciprocity or reciprocity; Physician-patient relationship, control, relationship;" fit/fit between patient and physician in terms of relationship, control, or relationship. CONCLUSIONS: Findings revealed varying degrees of support for the positive effects of matching patients' preferred knowledge levels, decision control, and counseling interpersonal behaviors CONCLUSIONS: The findings justify not only continued research efforts in this area, but also expanded research efforts in this area to include proposed changes in research design and practice. evaluation strategies and match interventions that can optimize toward positive outcomes are discussed Methodological guidelines are proposed that can improve future preference matching studies of patient-physician interaction Practitioners' recent experience of patient-centered and collaborative decision-making approaches In addition to specific concentrations, patient matching assessment and adoption of intervention strategies should be considered.

title: Optimal care models for patients with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease
abstract: There is a close relationship between physiological respiration and swallowing processes in all levels of neuromotor control and peripheral function in healthy adults. Little is known about potential changes in these patterns in patients with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), but the impact of dysphagia and aspiration on the health outcomes of patients with COPD may be significant. COPD is a common comorbidity seen by swallowing clinicians in patients with head and neck cancer and neurological disorders and requires consideration during swallowing therapy. This article summarizes reports of changes in nutritional status, airway protective mechanisms, and swallowing efficiency that potentially contribute to or exacerbate a chronic and debilitating pulmonary condition. Care guidelines are given for modifying eating and swallowing behavior to optimize the COPD patient's health status. The need for controlled clinical trials to validate the impact of these care guidelines on clinical outcomes has been described.

title: Optimizing Antiretroviral Therapy (ART) for Maternal and Child Health (MCH): Rationale and Design of the MCH-ART Trial
abstract: BACKGROUND: The practice of preventing mother-to-child transmission of HIV faces significant challenges globally, particularly in the context of universal lifelong antiretroviral therapy (ART) for all HIV-infected pregnant women. METHODS: We describe the rationale and methods of the Maternal and Child Health-Antiretroviral Therapy (MCH-ART) study, an application science project examining strategies for providing HIV care and treatment to HIV-infected women and HIV-infected women who begin ART during pregnancy. RESULTS: The MCH-ART consists of 3 interrelated study designs throughout the prenatal and postnatal periods. Phase 1 is a cross-sectional evaluation of consecutive HIV-infected pregnant women seeking antenatal care”; Phase 2 is an observational cohort of all women in phase 1 who are eligible to begin ART according to local guidelines; and phase 3 is a randomized trial. In the postpartum period Strategies for the delivery of ART to lactating women from stage 2. At each stage, a series of study measurement visits takes place separately from prenatal care and ART services, with a maximum of 9 visits during the 12 months postpartum from the start of antenatal care. In-depth interviews are used to qualitatively examine issues of adherence and persistence, and the costs and cost-effectiveness of care models are examined.Separate sub-studies examine health outcomes in HIV-uninfected women and their HIV-unexposed infants, and the role of the compliance club model for long-term adjustment and retention. : MCH-ART combining observational and experimental components study offers a new approach to understanding and optimizing ART delivery for MCH.

title: Optimizing hypertension management in clinical practice
abstract: There is a clear relationship between high blood pressure (BP) and various manifestations of cardiovascular disease. Despite the large number of treatment guidelines, hypertension remains poorly controlled and only a minority of patients achieve target BP levels. Many factors, both patient- and physician-related, contribute to this poor level of hypertension control. Major determinants include the application of inappropriate treatment regimens that fail to enable patients to achieve their goals, and poor patient compliance. For example, it is widely accepted that most patients require two or more antihypertensive drugs to achieve their BP goal”; however, physicians may be reluctant to use such treatment strategies. The purpose of this review is to choose combination therapy, with particular reference to angiotensin II receptor blocker combinations. Our aim is to explore the factors that contribute to poor hypertension control rates, including the rationale, and how to overcome them.

title: Optimizing hypertension management with combination therapy: considerations for the nurse practitioner
abstract: Hypertension is a major contributor to the risk of cardiovascular disease and death, but success in achieving blood pressure (BP) control has been limited. Most patients will need 2 or more medications to control their blood pressure. Nurse practitioners play a vital role in the management of patients with hypertension and can help overcome barriers to achieving BP goals. Measures to improve therapeutic adherence include educating the patient and simplifying the medication regimen. The use of single-pill combination therapy, which reduces the pill burden, may contribute to improved drug retention and adherence. Rational combination therapy combines drugs with complementary mechanisms of action, such as a calcium channel blocker (CCB) and a renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system (RAAS) inhibitor";" it is generally more effective than monotherapy and allows lower doses of the individual ingredients to be used, which often results in better tolerability. Current guidelines support the first-line use of combination therapy in many patients. Starting treatment with an RAAS inhibitor-based combination may reduce blood pressure and cardiovascular risk and may be more effective in some patients than traditional combinations such as a beta-blocker with diuretics. Adverse events associated with any drug may compromise its therapeutic benefit. Peripheral edema is a common dose-related adverse event seen with dihydropyridine CCBs that can cause significant patient distress, reduce adherence, and lead to dose reduction or even treatment discontinuation. In most cases, peripheral edema caused by CCB can be successfully managed and CCB therapy need not be abandoned. Management strategies include non-pharmacological and pharmacological measures. Several clinical studies have shown a lower incidence of peripheral edema in patients receiving combination therapy with CCB and RAAS blocker compared to CCB monotherapy.

title: Oral contraceptives and smoking, current considerations: recommendations of a consensus panel.
abstract: In a closed meeting, members of the consensus panel considered the scientific panel's presentations and developed a set of recommendations. They summarized the clinical imperatives of identifying and educating patients who smoke, the physician's role in smoking cessation, and prescribing oral contraceptives to smokers. They also set research goals for the future. The most important recommendations are: At each visit, all patients should be asked about their smoking status, and all smokers should be encouraged and helped to quit. The decision to prescribe oral contraceptives requires a detailed personal and family history of thrombotic disease. Measurement of lipid profile with exercise and dietary intervention should be considered in smokers over 35 years of age who use or request oral contraceptives. Oral contraceptive use should be refused in patients older than 35 years of age and heavy smokers (>15 cigarettes/day). Initial data suggest that an oral contraceptive containing a very low dose of 20 micrograms of ethinyl estradiol may be safer for oral contraceptive users who smoke, even for those over 35 who are occasional smokers, but these laboratory findings require clinical validation."; "PIP: This article summarizes the activities of a conference titled "Oral Contraceptives and Smoking: Current Considerations" held in Montreal, Canada. Members of the consensus panel evaluated the presentations of the scientific panel and developed a set of recommendations. Clinical imperatives regarding the detection and education of smokers, the reverse question-mark role of physicians in smoking cessation, and OC prescriptions were given to smokers. The following recommendations were made: 1) encouraging smokers to quit smoking; 2) advising patients on the benefits of OC; also advising patients on the risks of co-smoking and OC use; and 3) 20 mcg ethinyl for women who smoke prescription for estradiol.In light of the remaining unanswered questions, the panel identified several research goals for the future.

title: Oral quinolones in hospitalized patients: evaluation of a computerized decision support intervention.
abstract: Aim. To determine whether a computerized decision support system would increase the proportion of oral quinolone antibiotic orders placed in hospitalized patients. Design. Prospective, discrete time series analysis. Adjustment. University hospital in the southeastern United States. Subjects Inpatient quinolone orders from February 1, 2001 to January 31, 2003. Intervention. On February 5, 2002, a web-based intervention was implemented as part of an existing order entry system at a university hospital. Based on the automated query of active drug and diet orders, some users who ordered intravenous quinolones were presented with a recommendation to consider choosing a drug. oral formulation. The main outcome measure. Proportion of inpatient quinolone orders for oral formulations before and after administration of the intervention. Results. During the study period, a total of 15 194 quinolones were ordered, of which 8962 (59%) were for oral forms. Oral quinolone orders rose from 4202 (56%) prior to the intervention to 4760 (62%) with no change in total orders. In time series analysis, there was an overall 5.6% increase (95% CI 2.8-8.4%"; "P < 0.001) in weekly oral quinolone orders due to the intervention, with the greatest impact on non-ICU medical units. . Results. A web-based intervention succeeded in increasing oral quinolone orders in hospitalized patients. This is one of the first studies to show a significant effect of a computerized intervention on the dosing pathway within a class of antibiotics. This model can be applied to other antibiotics or other drug classes with good oral bioavailability.

title: Oral triptans (serotonin 5-HT1B/1D agonists) in the treatment of acute migraine: meta-analysis of 53 studies
abstract: Background Triptans, selective serotonin 5-HT1B/1D agonists, are very effective acute migraine medications with a well-developed scientific rationale. Seven different triptans will soon be clinically available, necessitating evidence-based selection guidelines. Triptan trials have similar designs, facilitating meta-analysis”, which will provide a basis for the use of triptans in clinical practice. Seven different triptans will soon be clinically available, necessitating evidence-based selection guidelines. Triptan trials have similar designs and facilitate meta-analysis This will provide a basis for the use of triptans in clinical practice.

title: Orbital/Periorbital Plexiform Neurofibromas in Children with Neurofibromatosis Type 1: Multidisciplinary Recommendations for Care
abstract: SUBJECT: Children and adults with neurofibromatosis type 1 (NF1), a common autosomal dominant condition, present with a variety of ophthalmologic conditions. Plexiform neurofibromas (PNs) involving the eyelid, orbit, periorbital, and facial structures (orbital-periorbital plexiform neurofibroma [OPPN]) can cause significant vision loss in children. Equally important, OPPNs can cause significant changes in physical appearance due to proptosis, ptosis, and facial disfigurement, resulting in social embarrassment and reduced self-esteem. CLINICAL APPLICABILITY: Although NF1 is a relatively common disease for which routine ophthalmologic examinations are required, no formal recommendation exists for the clinical care of children with OPPN. While medical and surgical interventions have been reported, there are no agreed criteria for when OPPNs require treatment and which treatment works best. METHODS: The absence of a uniform outcome measure representative of visual or aesthetic sequelae complicates evidence design, as a multidisciplinary team of experts (oculofacial plastics, pediatric ophthalmology, neuro-ophthalmology, medical genetics, and neuro-oncology) guides management decisions. based studies and applicable clinical trials. CONCLUSIONS: In September 2013, a multidisciplinary task force of pediatric practitioners from tertiary care centers experienced in caring for children with OPPN convened to address the lack of clinical care guidelines for children with OPPN. CONCLUSIONS: This consensus statement provides recommendations for ophthalmological monitoring, outlines indications for treatment and upcoming biologic therapy, and discusses the challenges of performing clinical trials in this complex condition.

title: Oversight organization in GI application
abstract: BACKGROUND: Various reports have documented the inefficient use of available resources as well as inadequate compliance with surveillance recommendations. Surveillance protocols often rely on unorganized approaches, although evidence suggests that organizational issues can affect the quality of care provided. METHODS: We conducted a literature review of PubMed and Cochrane Database of Systematic Reviews for guidelines, Database of Abstracts of Effects Studies, and the Cochrane Central Registry of Controlled Trials (published 01/2000-06/2016), practice questionnaires for intervention studies to improve adherence to guidelines, patients or reporting information on the attitudes and behavior of providers. Related articles were also reviewed. Based on clinical relevance and the burden on endoscopy services, this review focused on surveillance for post-polypectomy surveillance of Barrett's esophagus, IBD, and colon adenomas. CONCLUSIONS: While current guidelines generally recognize the structure and process requirements that affect the delivery of surveillance interventions, less attention has been paid to transitions and interfaces in the maintenance process. The available evidence from practice surveys highlights the need to design institutional strategies aimed at ensuring patient participation and providers deliver timely and appropriate care. However, well-designed studies evaluating the effectiveness of certain interventions in this setting are lacking. Indirect evidence from screening settings will suggest that the implementation of automated standardized recall systems, use of clinical records, removing financial barriers, may improve eligibility for use and adherence to recommendations. CONCLUSIONS: The lack of robust evidence regarding the utility and methodology of surveillance may contribute to explaining the observed variability in providers and patients' attitudes and compliance with recommended surveillance.

title: Organization theory for dissemination and application research
abstract: Background Even under optimal internal organizational conditions, practice can be undermined by changes in the external environment of organizations such as fluctuations in funding, adjustments in contracting practices, new technology, new legislation, changes in clinical practice guidelines and recommendations, or other environmental changes. . Internal organizational conditions are increasingly reflected in implementation frameworks, but detailed explanations of how organizations' external environments affect implementation success are lacking in implementation research. Organizational theories provide practice researchers with a range of available, highly relevant and hitherto largely unused explanations of the complex interaction between organizations and their environments. In this article, we demonstrate the usefulness of organizational theories for application research. Discussion We applied four well-known organizational theories (institutional theory, transaction cost economics, probability theories, and resource dependency theory) to published descriptions of efforts to implement SafeCare, an evidence-based practice to prevent child abuse and neglect. Transaction cost economics theory explained how often uncertain processes to contract for SafeCare create inefficiencies and thus jeopardize practice among private child welfare agencies. Institutional theory explained how child welfare systems may have been motivated to implement SafeCare, as it aligns with the expectations of key stakeholders in child welfare systems' professional communities. He explained how efforts such as emergency theories, interagency collaborative teams support the implementation of SafeCare by facilitating adaptation to the internal and external contexts of child welfare agencies. Resource dependency theory (RDT) explained how inter-agency relationships supported by contracts, memoranda of understanding, and negotiations facilitate SafeCare implementation by balancing autonomy and dependence on funders and SafeCare developers. Summary In addition to the retrospective application of organizational theories shown above, we advocate the proactive use of organizational theories to design practice research. For example, implementation strategies should be chosen to minimize transaction costs, encourage and maintain harmony between organizations' dynamic internal and external contexts over time, and respond to the financial needs of organizations while simultaneously maintaining their autonomy. We describe the results of applying organizational theory in practice strategies, evaluation of practice efforts, measurement, research design, theory and practice research for practice. We also guide practice researchers to apply organizational theory.

title: Osteoporosis prevention education: behavioral theories and calcium intake
abstract: Osteoporosis is a worldwide health problem. Prevention of osteoporosis and subsequent fractures has become the goal of many health practitioners, especially dietetics. However, several prevention models have proven effective. The purpose of this project was to determine whether an educational, theory-based osteoporosis prevention program would significantly affect calcium intake. This project used a convenient sample of 42 women participating in an 8-week educational intervention, similar to a community class. The program included hands-on activities to increase self-efficacy and was based on the Health Belief Model and Theory of Rational Action (TRA). The main outcome measures were calcium intake and constructs from the Health Belief Model and TRA. Significant changes in the Health Belief Model and TRA constructs after intervention include increased perceived susceptibility to osteoporosis (P < .001), perceived benefits of increased calcium intake ( P < .001), and increased self-efficacy related to calcium intake ( P < . /=.003). ). Statistically significant regression equations were found for all calcium-related pre-intervention intentions. Post-intervention calcium intake increased significantly to 821+/-372 mg/day (P < .0001). The results of this project can be used as a guide for dietetics professionals to develop osteoporosis prevention programs for their clients.

title: Outcomes and costs of primary care surveillance and intervention for overweight or obese children: the LEAP 2 randomized controlled trial.
abstract: OBJECTIVE To determine whether detecting childhood obesity through surveillance followed by structured secondary prevention in primary care improves outcomes in overweight or slightly obese children. DESIGN Randomized controlled trial nested within a basic cross-sectional study of body mass index (BMI). Randomization and outcome measurement, but not participants, were blind to group assignments. SETTING 45 family practices (66 GPs) in Melbourne, Australia. PARTICIPANTS A BMI questionnaire was administered to 3958 children who visited their general practitioners between May 2005 and July 2006. Of these, 258 children aged 5 years 0 months and up to their 10th birthday who were overweight or obese according to the International Obesity Task Force criteria were randomized into intervention (n=139) or control (n=119) groups. Children who were very obese (UK BMI z score >or=3.0) were excluded. INTERVENTION Four standard consultations over 12 weeks aimed at change in nutrition, physical activity and sedentary behavior, supported by purpose-designed family materials. Main outcome measures The primary measure was BMI at 6 and 12 months after randomization. Secondary measures were 7-day accelerometer mean activity count/min, nutrition score from 4-day shortened food frequency diary, and child health-related quality of life. Differences were adjusted for socioeconomic status, age, gender, and baseline BMI. RESULTS Of 781 eligible children, 258 (33%) participated"; attrition was 3.1% at 6 months and 6.2% at 12 months. The adjusted mean differences for BMI at 6 and 12 months (intervention vs control) were -0.12 (95%). CI -0.40 to 0.15, P=0.4) and -0.11 (-0.45 to 0.22, P=0.5) for physical activity in counts/minute, 24 (-4 to 52, P=0.09) and 11 (- 26 to 49, P=0.6);" and 0.2 (-0.03 to 0.4, P=0.1) and 0.1 (-0.1 to 0.4, P=0.2) for the nutrition score. There was no evidence that he harmed the child. The cost of the healthcare system was significantly higher in the intervention arm. CONCLUSIONS Primary care screening followed by brief counseling did not improve BMI, physical activity or nutrition in overweight or mildly obese 5-10 year olds and would be very costly if applied universally. These findings contradict national policies in countries such as the US, UK and Australia. TRIAL REGISTRATION ISRCTN 52511065 (www.isrctn.org).

title: Results of population-based language support for slow-speaking infants aged 3 and 3 years: Let's Learn Language cluster randomized controlled trial
abstract: OBJECTIVE To identify the benefits of a low-intensity parent-toddler language development program offered to young children identified by screening at Universal Services as slow to speak. DESIGN Cluster, randomized trial nested in a population-based survey. SETTING Three local government districts in Melbourne, Australia. PARTICIPANTS Parents who attended 12-month healthy child checkups over a six-month period completed a baseline questionnaire. At 18 months, children in the 20th percentile or younger on an expressive word checklist entered the trial. INTERVENTION Maternal and child health centers (clusters) were randomly assigned to the intervention (modified "Change Maker" program at six sessions per week) or control ("care as usual") arms. MAIN OUTCOME MEASURES Primary outcome was expressive language (Preschool Language Scale-4)" at 2 and 3 years; secondary outcomes were receptive language at 2 and 3 years, vocabulary checklist raw score at 2 and 3 years, Expressive Vocabulary Test at 3 years , and Child Behavior Checklist/2 and 1.5-5 raw score at 3 years RESULTS 1217 parents completed baseline questionnaire; 20th percentile and randomized (158 interventions, 143 controls) 115 (73%) intervention parents (mean) 4.5 sessions) and reported high satisfaction with most programs. Interim results were similar at age 2 Similarly, at age 3, adjusted mean differences (intervention-control) were -2.4 for expressive language (95% confidence interval -6.2 to 1.4; P=0.21) were -0.3 (-4.2 to 3.7; P=0.90) ) for receptive language; 4.1 (-2.3 to 10.6; P=0.21) bulary checklist for vocal; -0.5 (-4.4 to 3.4; P) for Expressive Vocabulary Test =0.80); -0.1 (-1.6 to 1.4; P=0.86) for expressing behavioral problems; and -0.1 (-1.3 to 1.2;" P=0.92) for expressing behavioral problems to lify. CONCLUSION This community-based program targeting young children who speak slowly was feasible and acceptable, but there was little evidence that it improved language or behavior immediately or immediately. 3 year old TRIAL REGISTRATION Current Controlled Trials ISRCTN20953675.

title: Overdiagnosis and overtreatment as a quality problem: insights from healthcare improvement research
Overweight and obesity in pregnancy: the evidence-practice gap in staff knowledge, attitudes and practices.
abstract: BACKGROUND: Statewide (Queensland) Clinical Guidelines reflecting current best practices have recently become available for the management of pregnancy-associated obesity. However, dissemination of guidelines alone does not change practice. OBJECTIVE: To systematically assess the evidence-practice gap in the multidisciplinary management of overweight and obesity in pregnancy (ow/ob) and inform an intervention that will facilitate the translation of obesity guidelines into practice in a tertiary maternity service. MATERIALS AND METHODS: An online questionnaire available over a three-week period (May-June 2011) was distributed to obstetrics, midwives and allied health personnel. Outcomes of interest included a 15-point guideline compliance score, knowledge of guideline content, advice given, information about obesity-pregnancy-related complications, previous education, and referral patterns. RESULTS: Eighty-four staff completed the surveys (57% response rate). Widespread incompatibility with the guideline was noted. The majority (88.1%) reported overweight/obesity (ow/ob) as an important/very important general obstetric problem and most accurately identified the associated complications. However, only 32.1% were aware of existing guidelines and only half correctly defined BMI categories for ow/ob. Compliance with referral recommendations varies";" 20% of staff thought the referral was 'not their business'. CONCLUSIONS: Staff are aware of the negative consequences associated with the mother's ow/ob, although few fully comply with referral guidelines or advise in line with recommendations. These findings will be categorized using the application of scientific methodological frameworks and effective behavior change interventions will be established to facilitate the translation of this important guide into practice.

title: Oxygen therapy in hospitalized patients: impact of local guidelines
abstract: OBJECTIVE: To examine the impact of local guidelines on the behavior of nurses and health personnel to optimize oxygen use in hospitalized patients. METHODS: The study was conducted in a district training hospital. The guidelines produced recommended indications, monitoring, use of arterial blood gases (ABGs), and recommendations on when to stop oxygen therapy. The guidelines were administered to all nursing and healthcare personnel, both orally and in writing, before and after an audit examining patients' oxygen use in medical and surgical wards. RESULTS: Ninety patients were included in the pre-intervention control and 59 patients in the post-intervention study. Oxygen prescription remained unchanged compared to guidelines 30% (27/90) and 32% (19/59). Nurses administered oxygen 95% (18/19) and 70% (19/27) better (P = 0.043) and were monitored more frequently using oximetry 91% (54/59) and 69% (62/90) (P = 0.001) ) after the instructions. ABGs of patients with airway disease were checked more frequently 87% (14/16) versus 65% (15/23) at admission and after starting oxygen inhalation 68% (11/16) and 34% (8/23) . CONCLUSION: Oral and written guidelines had no effect on oxygen prescription, but improved practice of close monitoring of patients with airway disease. The nurses improved their follow-up performance both by administering oxygen according to the prescribed dose and by oximetry.

title: Postoperative pain management practices of pediatric nurses in hospital-based non-critical care settings: a narrative review.
abstract: OBJECTIVE: To investigate the postoperative pain management practices of pediatric nurses to determine the factors associated with unmanaged pediatric postoperative pain. DESIGN: Systematic search and review. DATA SOURCES: PsychInfo, CINAHL, PubMed, EMBASE and manual search. REVIEW METHODS: Included were peer-reviewed English, quantitative, qualitative, or mixed methods research articles published between 1990 and 2012 investigating the practice of pediatric postoperative pain management by registered nurses. Articles that focused on nurses' pain management practices in the recovery room in neonatal or pediatric intensive care units and/or focused on children with cognitive impairment were excluded. The search terms used were: "postoperative pain"; nurses*; pediatrics; pediatrics; children; pain assessment; non-drug*; analges*. Titles and summaries were used for initial screening. Two researchers evaluated data extraction and rigor for each. RESULTS : Included 27 studies from the first 248 citations. Most studies were descriptive and examined relationships between personal factors and nurses' pain management practices. Observational data from four articles added insights beyond what was provided in self-report studies. Two articles used experimental designs with vignettes. Data were categorized under four headings. included: pain assessment; pharmacological applications; non-pharmacological applications;" and factors affecting applications. Despite the developments in the application of analgesics in the last 20 years, the applications remain insufficient. Children's behavior appears to influence nurses' assessment of pain more than approved measures. Pain scores were not recorded in the first 24 hours after surgery in a significant proportion of children. Children receive more analgesia than necessary. However, prescription of analgesia around the clock did not guarantee administration. Nurses routinely report using several non-pharmacological strategies, but some are not evidence-based. CONCLUSIONS: The results of this review show that nurses' assessment and management of children's pain is not in line with published guidelines. The results of studies investigating factors related to nurses and children are insufficient. The research needs to examine the effect of organizational factors on nurses' pain care practices. Intervention studies are needed to identify the most effective strategies for nurses to support and improve pain care for children.

title: Pain descriptors for critically ill patients who cannot self-report
abstract: OBJECTIVE: To examine the descriptors used by nurses in two Canadian intensive care units to document the presence of pain in critically ill patients who cannot self-report. BACKGROUND: Systematic documentation of pain assessment is essential for continued communication and pain management, thereby providing better pain control, maximizing recovery, and reducing physical and psychological sequelae. METHOD: A retrospective, mixed method with observational design in two Level-III intensive care units of a quaternary academic center in Toronto, Canada. For the period 2008-2009, data were summarized through chart review guided by a reference summary of potential behavioral descriptors compiled from available behavioral pain assessment tools. RESULTS: A total of 679 narrative explanations were extracted. Behavioral descriptors (232, 34%), physiological descriptors (93, 14%) and descriptors indicating that the patient was pain free (117, 17%) were used to define the presence or absence of pain. The narratives also described analgesia administered without pain assessment descriptors (117.17%) and assessment and administration of analgesics (30.4%) prior to a known painful procedure. The themes that emerged included life-threatening treatment intervention, decision-making uncertainty, and constant vigilance. CONCLUSION: Inconsistent or unclear documentation was problematic in this example. This may reflect confusing behavior and accompanying security priorities. Developing a glossary of pain assessment descriptors in critically ill patients who cannot self-report for use with valid and reliable measures may improve documentation that facilitates appropriate analgesic management. Protocols or unit guidelines that prioritize a trial of analgesia prior to administration of sedatives can reduce decision uncertainty when patients display ambiguous behaviors such as agitation or restlessness.

title: pain in ankle
Parallel pathways to improve heart failure outcomes: evidence matters
abstract: Gaps and inequalities between heart failure education given by nurses and the performance of patients with advanced heart failure in performing self-care behaviors may be factors in clinical decompensation and unplanned healthcare consumption. Is nurse-led education delivered effectively prior to hospital discharge? Nurse leaders must understand the power of nurses' knowledge base on self-care principles and important barriers to best practice. Nurses may not be comfortable teaching patients about dry weights, meal planning, heart failure medications, or progressive activity and exercise steps. Also, clinical nurses may not have time to provide in-depth education to patients before discharge. Equally important, research is needed to learn about factors that increase patients' adherence to heart failure self-care behaviors, because adherence to the recommendations of national, evidence-based heart failure guidelines improves clinical outcomes. Therefore, nurses and patients are on parallel paths in laying the foundation for improved self-care compliance in advanced heart failure. Through research, we have found that nurses are not adequately prepared as heart failure educators and patients do not believe they can control their heart failure. In 2 educational intervention studies aimed at helping patients understand that they can control their fluid management and follow a strict daily fluid limit, patients improved clinical outcomes. Therefore, misperceptions about heart failure can be overcome with interventions that go beyond communicating "what" self-care behaviors that are recommended. Research results reflect that evidence matters! There is a need for systems and processes that will support nurses' knowledge, convenience and frequency of providing self-care training before discharge, increase the accuracy of patients' beliefs about controlling heart failure, and increase patients' willingness to self-adhere to heart failure recommended in the guideline. -care behaviors. This article describes the development of parallel pathways of nurse and patient research programs and explores the translation of findings into practice and the development of clinical translation research.

title: Parental presence during invasive procedures and resuscitation: evaluation of clinical practice change
abstract: Rationale: Parental presence during invasive procedures and/or resuscitation is a relatively underdeveloped and controversial practice. Much of the worry stems from the concern of the medical community. OBJECTIVES: To assess whether the implementation of formal practice guidelines and relevant interprofessional training improves clinicians' sense of preparedness and provides parents with comfort in presenting options during their child's procedures. METHODS: Multistage pre-post investigation of (1) clinician perceptions and (2) practice from the perspectives of clinicians and parents who have experienced the same procedure. Data were collected over 4 years from a cardiovascular and critical care program in a US children's hospital. MEASUREMENTS AND MAIN RESULTS: More than 70% of clinicians participated in the perception questionnaires (n = 782) and 538 clinicians and 274 parents participated in the practice questionnaires. After intervention, clinicians reported that parents were present during more invasive procedures and reported a higher level of comfort with the practice of providing parents with options during resuscitative events. Comfort levels were higher in clinicians who practiced skills in a simulated learning environment. In both stages, few clinicians reported that parental presence affected their technical performance (4%), therapeutic decision making (5%), or teaching skills (9%). Next, clinicians reported more active parental behavior during procedures. Parents who reported receiving information to help their children prepare for their procedures reported a higher level of procedural understanding and emotional support. CONCLUSIONS: Implementation of practice guidelines and interprofessional training had a positive impact on clinicians' perceptions and practice while providing options and support to parents during their child's invasive procedures and/or resuscitation.

title: Parental intervention in Sure Start services for children at risk of developing conduct disorder: a pragmatic randomized controlled trial.
abstract: OBJECTIVE To evaluate the effectiveness of a parenting program as a preventive intervention with parents of preschool children thought to be at risk of developing conduct disorder. DESIGN A pragmatic randomized controlled trial using a domain allocated block design. SETTING Eleven Sure Start areas in North and Wales. PARTICIPANTS 153 parents and their children aged 36-59 months from socially disadvantaged regions are at risk of behavioral disorder, which is defined by scoring over clinical cut-off in the Eyberg child behavior inventory. Participants were randomized on a 2:1 basis, 104 to intervention and 49 to waiting list (control). Eighteen (13%) of the intervention group dropped out of follow-up after six months. INTERVENTION The Webster-Stratton Incredible Years core parenting program, a 12-week group-based intervention. MAIN OUTCOME MEASURES Problematic behavior and parenting skills in children are assessed by self-reports from parents and direct observation at home. Parenting efficacy, stress, and depression self-reported by parents. Standardized and well-validated tools were used throughout. RESULTS At follow-up, most measures of parenting and problem behavior in children improved significantly in the intervention group. For the primary outcome measure, the Eyberg child behavior inventory, intent to treat analysis showed a mean difference between the groups with an effect size of 0.63 on the problem scale of 4.4 points (95% confidence interval 2.0 to 6.9, P<0.001), and 25.1 on the intensity scale with an effect size of 0.89. (14.9 to 35.2, P<0.001) mean difference. CONCLUSION This community-based study demonstrated the effectiveness of an evidence-based parenting intervention faithfully delivered by regular Sure Start staff. He has influenced policy in Wales and has taught courses for England where Sure Start programs have not been effective to date. TRIAL REGISTRATION ISRCTN46984318.

title: Parenting program for parents of children at risk of developing conduct disorder: a cost-effectiveness analysis
abstract: OBJECTIVE To investigate the cost-effectiveness of a parenting program. DESIGN A pragmatic, randomized controlled trial as well as an incremental cost-effectiveness analysis of the effectiveness of a group parenting program delivered through Sure Start in the Community. Surah AYAR starting areas in north and central Wales. PARTICIPANTS Parents of 116 children aged 36-59 months (87% of the clinical sample) are at risk of developing behavioral disorders, which are defined by scoring the clinical cut-off in the Eyberg child behavior inventory. Children were identified by health visitors and recruited by the research team. INTERVENTION Webster-Stratton Incredible Years basic parenting program or a six-month waiting list check. MAIN OUTCOME MEASURE Incremental cost per unit of improvement in the density score of the Eyberg child behavior inventory. RESULTS The bootstrapped incremental cost-effectiveness rate point estimate was £73 (EUR109, $142) per one point improvement in intensity score (95% confidence interval £42 to £140). Bringing the child with the highest intensity score below the clinical breakpoint would cost 5486 (EUR 8190, 10,666) and bringing the average child in the intervention group within the non-clinical limits would cost 1344 (EUR 2006, $2618). by intensity score (below 127). For a cap rate of £100 (EUR 149, 194) per point increase in the intensity score, the probability of the intervention being cost effective is 83.9%. The average cost per child joining the parenting group was £1934 (€2887, US$3760) for eight children and £1289 (€1924, US$2506) for 12 children, including start-up costs and materials for training group leaders. When we divided the sample into relatively mild, moderate, and severe behavioral groups based on baseline intensity scores, the intervention appeared to be more cost-effective in those at highest risk of developing conduct disorder. CONCLUSION This parenting program improves child behavior at a relatively low cost, as measured by the density score of the Eyberg inventory of child behavior, and is cost-effective compared to waiting list control. This parenting program has modest costs and strong clinical impact; this suggests that it would represent good value for money for public expenditures.

title: Parkinson's disease
Participant and study-related characteristics predictive of treatment completion and study continuation in an adolescent smoking cessation trial.
abstract: Objective: To determine which factors predict the completion and continuation of smoking cessation treatment in adolescents. Methods: In a multisite, randomized, controlled study, the effectiveness of motivational interviewing was compared with brief structured recommendations for smoking cessation and reduction in 14-18 year-old adolescents (n = 355) (55% female, 45% black, 12%). Spanish). Treatment was spread over 12 weeks with follow-up evaluations at 24 weeks. Completion of treatment was defined as the completion of all five counseling sessions. Study retention was defined as the completion of the 24-week evaluation. Participant and study variables served as predictors of treatment completion and retention. Results: In total, 79% of participants completed all five counseling sessions and the same 24% completed the weekly assessment. Black race, anticipation phase to nap, and shorter time between baseline assessment and initial counseling session were significantly associated with treatment completion. For each 7.5-day delay in starting treatment after the baseline visit, there was a 50% reduction in the probability of completing all five treatment sessions. At 24 weeks, detention was estimated by black race, younger age, more maternal education, expectations of college graduation, and structured brief advice intervention. Conclusions: High treatment completion and study retention rates can be achieved in a multi-session behavioral intervention for smoking cessation in adolescents. The findings suggest that therapy should begin immediately after the intake session to maximize treatment completion. Increasing efforts to retain older adolescents and youth with lower academic goals and lower family incomes will be important in future studies. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2017 APA, all rights reserved)

title: Participation in biomedical research: the consent process as seen by children, adolescents, young adults, and physicians
abstract: We examined the capacity of children, adolescents and young adults to accept and consent to participate in biomedical research and what physician-researchers believe is important for patients in these age groups to learn about such participation. The sample included 44 male and female subjects aged 7 to 20 who were hospitalized for treatment for pediatric cancer or obesity. Participants completed a structured interview that evaluated their knowledge of research participation using elements outlined in the federal guidelines for informed consent. Study subjects were most knowledgeable about the elements of consent assessing concrete information (for example, freedom to ask questions, relevant time elements, and benefits of participation). They were less aware of the elements of informed consent evaluating soft information (for example, the scientific versus therapeutic purpose of the study, and alternative treatments). Chronological age was not related to knowing the elements of informed consent. The strategies the subjects used to reason about participation in the study paralleled their reasoning about other physical phenomena.

title: Children's participation in clinical trials: UK, European and international legal perspectives on consent
abstract: The Declaration of Helsinki was until recently the leading international code for the conduct of clinical trials on human subjects. The Council of Europe's Convention on Human Rights and Biomedicine (1997) and ICH guidelines for Good Clinical Practice (1996) represent an important step towards further harmonization of standards in the conduct of medical experiments on human subjects. But despite emerging areas of consensus, there are still significant areas of uncertainty and disagreement. Medical practitioners participating in pediatric research in the UK are concerned about the lack of certainty in the law, particularly regarding the application of consent rules to emergency research. This article examines UK, European and International norms regarding the participation of children in medical research and compares the conditions under which consent rules may be waived under each normative regime.

title: Participatory action research in antimicrobial management: a new approach to improving antimicrobial prescribing in hospitals and long-term care facilities.
abstract: Changing the antimicrobial prescribing behavior of physicians is difficult. Although antimicrobial prescribing is determined by contextual (eg, lack of guidelines), cultural (eg, peer practice) and behavioral (eg, perceived decision-making autonomy) factors, most antimicrobial management programs do not consider these factors in their approach. This can lead to insufficient response effectiveness. We present a new approach to antimicrobial stewardship program development that addresses the relevant determinants of antimicrobial prescribing: participatory action research (PAR). PAR is a collaborative process that aims to bring about change in social situations by generating practical knowledge that is useful in local practice. It requires substantial involvement of relevant stakeholders to address the determinants of behavior under consideration and facilitate empowerment. PAR is well suited for complex problems in multidisciplinary environments, as it adapts to local needs, offering a tailored approach to improving native application. We describe how PAR can be applied to antimicrobial management and the PAR design of two ongoing multicenter antimicrobial management projects in the acute care setting and the long-term care setting, respectively.

title: Passive smoking exposure and risk of COPD among adults in China: the Guangzhou Biobank Cohort Study.
abstract: Background Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) is a leading cause of death in China, where the population is also exposed to high levels of secondhand smoke, but little is known about the effects of such exposure on COPD. We examined the association between passive smoking and COPD and respiratory symptoms in an adult Chinese population.";" Background Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) is a leading cause of death in China, where the population is also exposed to high levels of secondhand smoke, but little is known about the effects of such exposure on COPD. We examined the association between passive smoking and COPD and respiratory symptoms in an adult Chinese population.

title: The pathology of poverty: the need for quality improvement efforts to address the social determinants of health
Patient compliance with family physicians' breast cancer screening recommendations: a historical cohort study
abstract: OBJECTIVE: Breast cancer is the most common malignancy among women in Israel and routine screening is recommended for early detection. In 1997, a primary health care center, a health management organization in rural Israel, established a 1-year program in which family physicians were encouraged to remind their patients to have a breast cancer examination. This study evaluates the impact of physician intervention on patient compliance. METHODS: Family physicians from two practices were asked to discuss the importance of early breast cancer diagnosis with all eligible patients who come to the clinic for any reason, and assist in making an appointment for screening. The files of patients who received the recommendation were stamped accordingly. Upon completion of the program, physicians' files were audited and potential candidates for breast cancer screening were divided into two groups: those who received the intervention (n = 251) and those who did not (n = 187)"; "results also showed that those who went to the examination on their own initiative (n = 100) before the study (n = 100) The results were also compared with the results of a third group of patients (i.e. no intervention). A random sample of half of the patients also filled out an ad hoc questionnaire covering sociodemographic variables and the impact of doctors' intervention on their behavior. RESULTS: Patients in the intervention group showed a significantly greater change in behavior related to breast cancer screening than controls (32% vs. 13%, P = 0.001). This change was particularly evident in the group of women aged 50-74 years who received a mammogram recommendation (according to the guidelines). CONCLUSION: Although this was only a two-practice study, the results show that primary care physicians can significantly change their patients' behavior regarding regular breast examinations. The use of a specific reminder can also help the individual physician ensure that each patient is appropriately informed.

title: Patient advocacy and advance care planning in the acute hospital setting
abstract: OBJECTIVE: The aim of this study was to explain the role of patient advocacy in the Advance Care Planning (ACP-ing) process. Nurses consider prolonging the death process and protecting patients' rights as the most disturbing ethical issue with inappropriate precautions (Johnston et al. 2002). Paradoxically, ethical codes assume that nurses have the autonomy to support patients' health care choices. Advanced Directives (ADs) designed to improve end-of-life care are poorly addressed and acute hospitals are often not tailored to the small number of people they receive. The Respect for Patient Choices Program (RPCP) improves the use of AD by providing a supportive framework for ACP-ing and primarily equipping nurses as RPC consultants. Helping patients in this process requires qualities that are consistent with patient advocacy, which is the most fundamental principle of nursing, which stems from caring for others. DESIGN: Likert Scales questionnaire administered to pilot and control groups with overlapping focus groups before and six months after the intervention. Setting: Selected wards at an acute care public hospital in South Australia. SUBJECTS: Nurses in palliative care, respiratory, renal and colorectal pilot services, and hemoncology, coronary care, cardiology, and neurology/geriatric control services. RESPONSE: (RPCP) RPCP during 2004-2005 South Australian pilot. MAIN RESULTS: Institutional endorsement of ACP-ing gave nurses autonomy to become patient advocates for end-of-life care, reconciling clinical practice with ethics, and easing the distress of inappropriately prolonging the death process. RESULTS: Statistically significant survey results in the post-intervention group showed that nurses were experienced: “encouragement (84%) to enable patients to make informed choices about end-of-life treatments”; the ability to fulfill these wishes in practice (73%) and the results of providing appropriate end-of-life care. job satisfaction (67%);" compared to about half (42-55%) of participants in the pre-intervention and control groups. Focus group participants shared that it used to be difficult to advocate for patients, but now they can act legally and feel ethically comfortable with end-of-life care. CONCLUSION: The findings suggested by the patient advocacy supported by the supportive RPC environment influence the ACP-ing process. It is recommended that the RPCP be adopted and developed as an integral part of promoting quality end-of-life assurance and related job satisfaction.

title: Patient and physician reminders to promote colorectal cancer screening: a randomized controlled trial.
abstract: Background Screening reduces colorectal cancer deaths, but effective screening tests are underutilized.
