Systematic reminders to patients and physicians can increase screening rates Methods We conducted a randomized controlled trial of patient and physician reminders in 11 outpatient settings. Participants included 21,860 patients aged 50 to 80 years and 110 primary care physicians who were overdue for colorectal cancer screening. Patients were randomly assigned to receive the mail containing an educational brochure, stool occult blood test kit, and instructions for direct programming of flexible sigmoidoscopy or colonoscopy. Physicians were randomly assigned to receive electronic reminders during office visits with patients overdue for screening. The primary outcome was fecal occult blood testing, flexible sigmoidoscopy, or colonoscopy for 15 months, and the secondary outcome was detection of colorectal adenomas. Results Screening rates were higher in patients who received mail (44.0% vs 38.1%"; P < .001). The effect increased with age: +3.7% for 50 to 59 years old; +7.3% for 60 to 69 years old. and +10.1% (P = .01 for trend) for patients aged 70 to 80 years (P = .01 for trend) Screening rates were similar between patients of physicians receiving electronic reminders and the control group (41.9% vs. 40.2%; P = .47). electronic reminders tended to increase screening rates in patients with 3 or more primary care visits (59.5% versus 52.7%; P = .07). 4.9;" P = .09). Conclusions Mailed reminders to patients are an effective tool to promote colorectal cancer screening, and electronic reminders to physicians can increase screening among adults who visit primary care more frequently.

title: Patient education about cough: impact on counseling behavior of general practitioner patients
abstract: The purpose of this general practice study is to examine how the counseling behavior of patients with cough is affected when the roles and responsibilities of patients, practice nurses, and practitioners are reorganized. The effects of a rational cough practice policy on patients' counseling behavior and the provision of systematic patient education on cough were compared with patient behavior in four matched control practices across four 'mean' one-handed general practices. Behavioral changes were measured in 548 patients who presented for coughing at least twice in two consecutive autumn-winter periods. Significantly more patients in the experimental practice changed their behavior to follow practice guidelines than patients in the control practices (56% vs 30%, P less than 0.001). The proportion of patients who continued to be consulted as approved was higher among patients who received intervention (66% versus 66%, P less than 0.001). This was equally true for patients who had fewer than four coughing episodes or more than four coughing episodes. The more often patients received the training, the more effective it was. All patients who applied to the general practitioner for cough in the first autumn-winter period filled a cough diary in the second period. From this it appeared that the intervention did not cause patients to delay the consultation when they had a cough lasting longer than three weeks or had a cough with 'severe' symptoms. A rational practice policy and the provision of patient education can encourage patients to change their counseling behavior. This can result in a reduction in healthcare costs.

title: Patient education for colon cancer screening: a randomized trial of a video submitted prior to the physical exam.
abstract: BACKGROUND: Colorectal cancer screening is underutilized and primary care clinicians are obligated to provide patient education within the constraints of intensive practice. OBJECTIVE: To test the effect of an educational video sent to patients' homes prior to physical examination on colorectal cancer screening, particularly sigmoidoscopy performance. DESIGN: Randomized, controlled trial. SETTING: 5 primary care practices in central Massachusetts. PARTICIPANTS: 938 patients aged 50 to 74 years scheduled for an upcoming physical examination, with no personal history of colorectal cancer and eligible for lower endoscopy screening according to current guidelines. INTERVENTION: Participants were randomly assigned to receive usual care (n = 488) or a video about colorectal cancer, the importance of early detection, and screening options (n = 450). MEASUREMENTS: Baseline and 6-month follow-up phone evaluations were made. A dependent variable was classified from baseline as 1) sigmoidoscopy with or without other tests, 2) another test or combination of tests, or 3) no test. RESULTS: Overall screening rates were the same (55%) in the intervention and control groups. In regression modeling, intervention participants were nonsignificantly more likely to complete sigmoidoscopy, either alone or in combination with another test (odds ratio, 1.22 [95% CI, 0.88 to 1.70]). Intervention dose (at least half of the video viewed) was significantly associated with receiving sigmoidoscopy with or without another test (odds ratio, 2.81 [CI, 1.85 to 4.26]). Recruitment records showed that at least 23% of people who come for periodic health evaluations are currently screened with a lower endoscopy procedure and are therefore ineligible. LIMITATIONS: The primary care sample studied consisted primarily of middle-class white people with high initial screening rates. Results cannot be generalized to other populations. The trial was conducted at a time when increased health insurance coverage for low endoscopy procedures and public media attention was paid to colon cancer screening. CONCLUSIONS: A mailed video had no effect on the overall colorectal cancer screening rate and only modestly improved sigmoidoscopy screening rates among patients in primary care.

title: Patient Engagement Programs for the Recognition and Initial Treatment of Depression in Primary Care
abstract: Significance Encouraging primary care patients to address their depression symptoms and referral to clinicians may improve outcomes, but may also result in unnecessary treatment. Purpose To determine whether a depression engagement video (DEV) or an adapted interactive multimedia computer program (IMCP) improves initial depression care compared to a control without increasing unnecessary antidepressant prescriptions. Design, Environment, and Participants Randomized clinical trial comparing DEV, IMCP, and control among 925 adult patients treated by 135 primary care clinicians (603 patients with depression and 322 without depression, defined by the Patient Health QuestionnaireÂ¨C9 [PHQ-9] score) June It was conducted at 7 primary care clinical centers in California from 2010 to March 2012. Gender and income interventions DEV, an IMCP tailored to individual patient characteristics, and a sleep hygiene video (control). Major Outcomes and Precautions Among depressed patients, superiority assessment of composite measure of patient-reported antidepressant medication recommendation, mental health referral, or both (primary outcome); depression at 12-week follow-up as measured by PHQ-8 (secondary outcome) Among patients without depression, Non-inferiority assessment of clinician- and patient-reported antidepressant medication recommendation (primary outcomes) with a 3.5% non-inferiority margin Analyzes adjusted by cluster Results 867 of 925 eligible patients in primary analysis (depressed, 559; non-depressed, 308) Among depressed patients, primary outcome rates were 17.5% for DEV, 26% for IMCP, and 16.3% for control (DEV vs control, 1.1 [95% CI, ?6.7 to 8.9], P = .79; IMCP vs. control, 9.9 [95% CI, 1.6 to 18.2], P = .02 No effect on PHQ-8 measured depression score at 12 weeks follow-up: DEV vs control, ??0.2 (95% CI, ?1.2 to 0.8); IMCP vs control, ?0.9 (95% CI, ?0.1 to 1.9). Among patients without it, clinician-reported antidepressant prescribing in the DEV and IMCP groups was not lower than control (mean percentage point difference [PPD]: DEV vs control, ??2.2 [90% CI, ?8.0 to 3.49], P?=? .0499 for inequality; patient-reported antidepressant recommendation did not yield disparity (mean PPD: DEV - control, ?0.9 [90% CI, ?4.9 - 6.7], P?=?.23, for disparity;"IMCP - control, ?0.3 [90% CI , ?5.1 to 5.7], P?=?.16, not to be inferior) Results and Relevance A tailor-made IMCP increased clinicians' recommendations for antidepressant medication, a mental health referral, or both, but at 12, there was no evidence on mental health. The possibility of -weekly follow-up IMCP and DEV increasing patient-reported clinician recommendations for an antidepressant medication in non-depressed patients could not be excluded.

title: Patients' perceptions of risky drinking: daily and weekly low-risk guidelines and knowledge of standard drink sizes
abstract: BACKGROUND: Effective intervention for risk drinking requires clinicians and patients to know the low-risk daily and weekly guidelines and what constitutes a "standard drink." The authors assumed that most patients lacked this knowledge and that education was necessary. METHODS: After primary care visits, patients ask, "How many drinks (containing alcohol) can you safely drink in a day?" They completed anonymous exit questionnaires containing 3 Alcohol Use Disorder Identification Test-Consumption (AUDIT-C) questions. and questions about the size in ounces of a standard wine, beer, and liquor beverage. Descriptive analyzes were performed in Stata. RESULTS: Of the 1,331 participants (60% female, mean age: 49.6, SD = 17.5), 21% tested positive for risk drinking on the AUDIT-C. Only 10% of correctly estimated daily low risk limits, 9% of weekly limits are correct and half of the low risk limits estimated at or below the guidelines. Less than half of those who answered “yes” to the question “Do you know what a standard drink” was? gave correct answers for beer, wine, or liquor. Patients with screen positive were twice as likely to say they knew what a standard drink was, but only one-third gave accurate predictions. When asked about their plans for the next month regarding change in drinking behavior, 23% with AUDIT-C positive indicated that they were considering at least a change. RESULTS: Most primary care patients were diagnosed with the National Institute of Alcohol Abuse and Alcoholism (NIAAA) low Does not know the specifics of risk-drinking guidelines. Investigating patients' perceptions of low-risk guidelines and current drinking behaviors may reveal controversial inconsistencies. For risk drinkers, who do not know most of the daily and weekly low-risk guidelines or standard drink sizes, education may be vital in the intervention. Findings suggest low-risk What exactly does drinking mean? It shows that there is a need for detailed and clear social marketing and communication.

title: Patient safety research: an overview of the global evidence
abstract: Background Unsafe medical care can cause significant morbidity and mortality globally, despite uncertain estimates of the extent of the problem. To better understand the scope and nature of the problem of unsafe care, the WHO World Alliance for Patient Safety commissioned a review of the world literature on patient safety research. Methods Major patient safety issues were identified through a consultation and research process and categorized within the framework of the nature, process, and outcomes of unsafe care. Leading experts reviewed the available evidence and identified key knowledge gaps on issues in developing, transitional and developed countries. The report was reviewed by internal and external experts and improvements were made based on feedback. Results Twenty-three major patient safety issues were examined. Most evidence of the consequences of unsafe care comes from developed countries, where prevalence studies show that between 3% and 16% of hospitalized patients suffer from medical care. Data from transitional and developing countries also show significant medical harm. However, significant knowledge gaps about the structural and process factors underlying globally unsafe care make it difficult to identify solutions, especially in resource-poor environments. Interpretation Harm from medical care appears to be a significant burden for the world's population. However, most of the evidence base comes from developed countries. Understanding the scope and solutions for unsafe care for the rest of the world is a critical component of delivering safe and effective care to all citizens of the world.

title: Patient safety: the doctor's perspective
abstract: Medical errors can be defined as the failure of a planned action to be completed as intended or the use of an incorrect plan to achieve a goal. Errors, beyond their economic costs and costs in human life, cause patients to lose their trust in the health system and decrease the satisfaction of both patients and health professionals. There are many evidence-based safety-oriented behaviors and interventions that can be easily implemented, such as ultrasound-guided central venous catheter placement, prevention of catheter-related bloodstream infection, and more. The development of research on patient safety in vascular access has raised several issues that require work to provide an optimal patient safety approach. Patients are the biggest contributors to their own safety, and therefore doctors must develop a new approach to involve them in the decision-making cycle at every step of their treatment. Along this path, there are many opportunities for the patient to engage in safe behaviors and for the access team to provide these behaviors using simple strategies. The emergence of the access center based on multidisciplinary teamwork has increased the potential to improve patient safety by preventing errors in planning and performing access surgery, preventing delay in treatment of access failure, and improving communication between team members. However, significant research effort is still needed to implement the intervention with evidence-based data focused on patient safety.

title: Patient-carried card prompts versus computer-generated prompts to remind private practice physicians to take health care precautions.
abstract: Background: We compared the effectiveness of a computer-generated prompt page placed in front of patient charts to a patient-carried prompt card to remind physicians to perform selected health care items. Methods: A randomized prospective single-blind study of 28 family physicians and nine general internists was conducted in private practice offices in rural eastern North Carolina. Twenty-two physicians were randomized to the computer prompt group and 22 to the card prompt group. Four physicians in the computer group did not complete the study due to computer software problems, and three physicians did not complete the study because their limited staff could not enter patient data into the computer. Before the intervention, 20 patient files (10 male and 10 female) from each physician were inspected for influenza vaccination, stool for occult blood, pap smear, breast examinations by physicians, and mammograms. One year after the start of the intervention, rescheduling controls were performed for the above five items in 20 different patient charts for each physician. Results: There was a 7% increase in the performance of flu vaccines in the card group (24% versus 17%) compared to a 6% increase in the computer group (26% versus 20%). There was a 5% decrease in stool performance for occult blood in the card group (23% versus 28%) compared to a 1% increase in the computer group (31% versus 30%). There was an 11% decrease in pap smear performance in the card group (26% vs 15%) compared to a 3% increase in the computer group (26% vs. There was a 2% decrease (33% vs 35%) in the performance of physician-performed breast exams in the card group compared to a 3% increase in the computer group (33% vs. Finally, there was a 3% increase in the performance of mammograms in the card group (25% vs. 22%) compared to an 11% increase in the computer group (26% versus 15%). Conclusions: Our data show a greater increase in the performance of health care items in the computer assisted group. Stool performance for occult blood, pap smear, doctor-performed breast exams, and mammography increased more in the computer-assisted group than in the card group. However, there was no statistically significant difference after intervention for any of the health care items supervised for the computer group or the card group. Overall, sanitation measures were implemented in only a minority of eligible patients.(Arch Intern Med. 1994";"154:1957-1960)

title: Gout patients adapt to curative treatment when appropriately informed: a proof-of-concept observational study
abstract: INTRODUCTION: Many doctors believe that gout patients are reluctant to receive urate-lowering therapy (ULT) and blame them for poor adherence to treatment. OBJECTIVE: To test the efficacy of a complex intervention for gout delivered in an optimal setting (specialist hospital clinic) containing key elements of current guidelines, including full patient information. METHODS: Observational study of patients reporting ongoing gout attacks from primary care lists. The study included 106 participants (94 males, 12 females"; mean age 61 years). Patients received a predominantly nurse-administered intervention that included education, personalized lifestyle advice, and appropriate ULT. The predefined goal was to obtain serum uric acid ( SUA) levels after 1 year in at least 70% of participants</=360 mumol/l RESULTS: 16% of 106 participants had tophi at baseline, with a mean (SD) baseline SUA of 456 (98) micromol/l. participants agreed to co-aspiration to confirm gout, and all wished to receive an ULT. At 12 months, 92% of 106 participants achieved the therapeutic target (SUA</=360 micromoles);" 85% had SUA<300 micromol/l. Allopurinol was the most widely used ULT, requiring an average daily dose of 400mg to achieve the goal. Improvements were observed in Short Form-36 (significant for pain) after 1 year. CONCLUSION: A predominantly nurse-led intervention that includes education, lifestyle advice, and ULT can successfully achieve the recommended treatment goal in more than 9 out of 10 patients. Full disclosure and discussion of the nature of gout and treatment options and the individualization of management likely explain this success.

title: Pearls, dangers, and pitfalls in the assessment and treatment of attention-deficit/hyperactivity disorder in adolescents
abstract: PURPOSE OF REVIEW: To provide clinicians with an updated overview of key issues in the clinical assessment and management of attention-deficit/hyperactivity disorder (ADHD) in adolescents. RECENT RESULTS: The American Psychiatric Association's recently revised Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders-5 included significant changes in the diagnostic criteria for ADHD in adolescents. The American Academy of Pediatrics (AAP) also recently revised its Clinical Practice Guidelines for ADHD";" Whereas previous guidelines focused on children aged 6-12, new guidelines extend to age 17. Understanding these revised diagnostic criteria and clinical guidelines is essential for pediatricians and others dealing with adolescents. In addition to an updated review of the clinical approach to the assessment and treatment of ADHD in adolescents, recent findings regarding common comorbidities, psychosocial risks, and long-term outcomes are briefly described. SUMMARY: Diagnosis and treatment of adolescents with ADHD presents unique challenges and barriers. Clinicians need to exercise caution when evaluating a young person with recent onset symptoms suggestive of ADHD, considering other conditions that may mimic ADHD, and to screen for common comorbid conditions. In terms of the treatment of adolescents, the AAP recommends drug therapy as a first-line intervention, noting that stimulants have a much broader evidence base and larger effect size than non-stimulants. Although clinicians now have a large number of drug formulations to choose from, they also need to be alert to the potential for abuse and diversion of stimulants.

title: Pediatric Nurse Practitioner Management of Child Anxiety with an Evidence-Based COPE Program in a Rural Primary Care Clinic
abstract: INTRODUCTION: Anxiety is the most common mental health disorder in children. There is a shortage of mental health providers in many communities, and many children with anxiety do not get the evidence-based treatment they need. The aim of this pilot study was to evaluate the feasibility and effects of Creating Opportunities for Personal Empowerment (COPE), a short seven-session cognitive-behavioral skills development intervention given to anxious children by a pediatric nurse in primary care. adjustment. METHODS: Pre-experimental, single-group, pre-test and post-test design were used. RESULTS: Significant reduction in anxiety symptoms (13.88 points, SD = 17.96, 95% confidence interval [CI] = -1.13-28.89) and increased knowledge of cognitive-behavioral coping skills (Mean = 11.38, CI = 5.99-8.26, p = .00) and enhanced functionality (at school and at home). Reviews by parents and children were positive. CONCLUSION: COPE is a promising evidence-based intervention for children with birth anxiety that can be implemented by pediatric nurse practitioners in primary care.

title: Peer support for patients with type 2 diabetes: a cluster randomized controlled trial.
abstract: OBJECTIVE To test the effectiveness of peer support for patients with type 2 diabetes. DESIGN Cluster randomized controlled. DETERMINATION 20 common practices in the east of the Republic of Ireland. PARTICIPANTS 395 patients (192 in the intervention group, 203 in the control group) and 29 peer supporters with type 2 diabetes. INTERVENTION All practices brought a standard diabetes care system. The peer support intervention spanned a two-year period and included four elements: the recruitment and training of peer supporters, nine group meetings led by the peer supporters in the participant's own general practice, and a retention plan for the peer supporters. MAIN OUTCOME MEASURES HbA(1c)"; cholesterol concentration; systolic blood pressure;" and well-being score. RESULTS There was no difference between intervention and control patients at baseline. All applications and 85% (337) of the patients were followed up. At two-year follow-up, HbA(1c) (mean difference -0.08%, 95% confidence interval -0.35% to 0.18%), systolic blood pressure (-3.9 mm Hg, -8.9 to 1 ,1 mm) there was no significant difference. Hg), total cholesterol concentration (-0.03 mmol/L, -0.28 to 0.22 mmol/L), or well-being scores (-0.7, -2.3 to 0.8). In particular, systolic blood pressure (52% (87/166) >130 mm Hg) v 61% (103/169) >130 mm Hg in control), these changes were not significant. The process evaluation showed that although 18% (35) of the patients in the intervention group had never attended any group meetings, the intervention was generally performed as intended. CONCLUSIONS A group-based peer support intervention could be implemented in general practice settings, but was not effective when the intervention targeted all patients with type 2 diabetes. While there is a trend towards improving clinical outcomes, the results do not support the widespread adoption of peer support. Trial registration Available Controlled Trials ISRCTN42541690.

title: Perceptions and performance of function and physical activity in assisted living communities
abstract: OBJECTIVE: The aim of this study was to define residents' self-efficacy and outcome expectations regarding function and physical activity (PA), measure functional performance and time in CA, evaluate the fit between the resident and the environment, and in 4 different assisted living (AL) communities. assessing knowledge, beliefs, and care behaviors of nursing assistants (NAs) DESIGN: This was a descriptive study using baseline data from an ongoing intervention study, Testing the Effect of Functional Care Intervention, Res-Care-AL. four assisted living communities PARTICIPANTS: A total of 171 residents and 96 NAs consented, passed eligibility, and were included in this study MEASUREMENTS: Descriptive data were obtained from NAs and residents Resident data also included functional tasks and exercise-related self-efficacy and outcome expectations, exercise It included subjective and objective information about social support and functions for on and physical activity. NA data, self-efficacy efficacy and outcome expectations included the performance of knowledge and function-oriented care. RESULTS: Residents were mostly female, white and widowed; needed some help with activities of daily living; and engaged in very few PAs based on subjective and objective reports. NAs were mostly female and black, had more than ten years of nursing experience, strong confidence, but limited knowledge of function-oriented care, and performed this care in 76% of observed care interactions. There were no site-specific differences in beliefs, knowledge, or performance of function-oriented care among NAs. There were region-specific differences among residents in self-efficacy for functional ability; functional performance; social support from experts for exercise;" and from family, person-environment fit and PA based on subjective questionnaires. No differences were noted based on actigraphy. CONCLUSION: Those living in AL communities engage in very limited numbers of PAs and staff working in these sites. can benefit from continuing education on how to increase PA among residents and help them comply with current guidelines for PA to optimize their overall health.

title: Performance of the TREAT decision support system in an environment of low prevalence of resistant pathogens.
abstract: Objectives To evaluate a decision support system (TREAT) to guide empirical antimicrobial therapy in an environment of low prevalence of resistant pathogens. Methods A retrospective trial of TREAT was conducted at Copenhagen University Hvidovre Hospital. The patient cohort included adults with systemic inflammation and suspected community-acquired bacterial infection. Empirical antimicrobial therapy recommended by TREAT was compared with empirical antimicrobial therapy prescribed by the first attending clinician. Results Of the 171 patients enrolled in the study, 161 (65 with microbiologically documented infections) met the inclusion criteria of TREAT. Coverage achieved with TREAT was significantly higher than clinical practice (86% vs. 66%, P = 0.007). There was no significant difference in the cost of future resistance between treatments chosen by TREAT and treatments chosen by physicians. Direct expenditures for antimicrobials were higher in TREAT when patients without antimicrobial therapy were included, with no otherwise significant difference. The cost of side effects was significantly lower when TREAT was used. Conclusions The results of the study suggest that TREAT may improve the appropriateness of antimicrobial therapy and reduce the cost of side effects in areas with low prevalence of resistant pathogens, at the expense of increased antibiotic use.

title: Perioperative care map improves adherence to best practices for the morbidly obese
abstract: BACKGROUND: Morbid obesity can complicate perioperative management. Best practice guidelines have been published, but are generally followed only in bariatric patients. Little is known about physicians' awareness of and adherence to these clinical recommendations for non-bariatric operations. Our study evaluated whether an educational intervention could improve physician recognition and adherence to best practices for all surgically treated morbidly obese patients. METHODS: A map of care outlining best practices for morbidly obese patients was distributed to all surgeons and anesthetists in 4 teaching hospitals in 2013. Pre- and post-intervention questionnaires were sent to participants in 2012 and 2015 to assess changes in clinical practice. A post-intervention chart audit determined the physician's compliance with the distributed guidelines. RESULTS: In the study, 567 physicians completed the questionnaire in 2012 and 375 physicians in 2015. Statistically significant improvements were seen in the percentage of surgeons and anesthetists who reported changing the management of morbidly obese, surgically treated patients after intervention. best practices preoperatively (89% vs. 59%), intraoperatively (71% vs. 54%), post-operatively (80% vs. 57%), and overall (88% vs. 72%). to suit. Results were similar when surgeons and anesthesiologists were analyzed separately. A chart audit of 170 cases from 4 hospitals found that 167 (98%) cases adhered to best practices. CONCLUSION: After the care map distribution, the percentage of physicians who reported changing their management to comply with best practices improved significantly. These findings highlight the beneficial effect this educational intervention can have on physician behavior. Continued research is needed to evaluate the impact of this intervention on clinical outcomes.

title: Perioperative Î² blockers in patients undergoing non-cardiac surgery: a meta-analysis
abstract: Background Do the American College of Cardiology and the American Heart Association (ACC/AHA) guidelines on perioperative evaluation recommend perioperative? Blockers for non-cardiac surgery, although the results of some clinical trials do not seem to support this recommendation. Perioperative ? blockers in patients undergoing non-cardiac surgery.";" Background Do the American College of Cardiology and the American Heart Association (ACC/AHA) guidelines on perioperative evaluation recommend perioperative? Blockers for non-cardiac surgery, although the results of some clinical trials do not seem to support this recommendation. Perioperative ? blockers in patients undergoing non-cardiac surgery.

title: Person-Centered Primary Care Strategies for Evaluation and Intervention of Aggressive Behaviors in Dementia
abstract: With the increasing number of individuals affected by dementia, it is imperative that healthcare providers are knowledgeable about the most effective ways to manage neuropsychiatric symptoms such as aggression. Managing aggression can be particularly difficult because it poses a risk of harm to formal and informal caregivers, and medical intervention options are complex and context-dependent. Although there are multiple guidelines for the management of aggression in dementia in the literature, their scope is widespread and the treatments recommended are often variable, making decision making difficult for busy clinicians. Using a composite case as a model, the current article provides guidelines that guide outpatients through the steps necessary to provide effective treatment for aggression in individuals with dementia. Shifting the current focus of healthcare for aggressive dementia patients to a more human-centred approach will have a positive impact on patient care. [Journal of Gerontological Nursing, 43(2), 9-17.].

title: Pharmaceutical care in chronic kidney disease: experience at University Hospital Grenoble from 2006 to 2010
abstract: BACKGROUND: Clinical pharmacists (CPs) specifically administer laboratory test follow-up, adjust drug dosage according to guidelines, and assess cardiovascular risk factors and decline in renal function. The aim of this study is to evaluate the effect of clinical pharmacy services in outpatient nephrology clinics. METHODS: Medical history and current treatment were obtained for each patient. Each intervention was classified according to the Act-IP document of the French Society of Clinical Pharmacy. This tool contains definitions and guidelines for preventing and resolving drug-related problems (DRPs). RESULTS: From January 2008 to April 2009, 42 patients seen by SP at at least 2 visits were included in the study. We observed 350 pharmaceutical consultations and 263 interventions. Related pharmaceutical interventions: untreated indication (30%), underdose (25.9%), and overdose (18.3%). CP interventions consisted of: dose adjustment (42.2%) and treatment addition (31.9%). The main drugs involved were cardiovascular (33.1%), digestive-metabolic (28.6%) and hematopoietic (21.6%) systems. CONCLUSION: The inclusion of a CP in the treatment of chronic kidney disease (CKD) patients is essential for the identification and prevention of IIPs. In addition to the medical improvement of CKD patients, CP participates in the development of prescription recommendations and therapeutic education programs for patients. It has also proven the effectiveness of redefining the roles and practices of clinical team members in optimizing the medical care of CKD patients. In addition, the patient's admission to dialysis is delayed, which leads to a reduction in health insurance costs.

title: Pharmacoeconomic consequences of measuring and modifying hospital drug use
abstract: Drug use patterns affect hospital-based healthcare delivery in several ways. Adverse reactions to drugs (ADR) accelerate approximately 5% of admissions and adversely affect the care of approximately 20% of hospitalized patients, while prolonging inadequate drug therapy outcomes and length of hospital stay. Conversely, appropriate administration of medications can promote recovery and improve the quality of care. Well-documented examples include the prevention of deep vein thrombosis and postoperative wound infections. Accordingly, optimization of drug use represents an important quality assurance challenge in addition to determining the cost-effectiveness of healthcare delivery. Drug use review (DUR) requires all elements of the quality assurance process. In practice, therapeutically meaningful and cost-effective exercises can only be established if there is knowledge of the link between drug use patterns and clinical outcomes. These measurement processes are currently rate-limiting in quality assurance. There are several ways to measure hospital drug use. These range from readily available and relatively inexpensive quantitative methods to methods that require the availability of skilled personnel. There are a number of methods that include increasing costs and increasing resource demands, providing increased details of the information obtained. This sequence begins with pharmacy purchases, followed by pharmacy issues to specific clinical areas, prescription or treatment sheet research, clinical record review, and finally reports from trained researchers working in the clinical field. Simpler methods can provide useful information and a fruitful basis for selecting and planning definitive investigations. When a category of drug use is appropriately targeted for intervention, drug use can in many cases be replaced by planned intervention with improved clinical outcomes and reduced economic costs. Intervention strategies to change drug use can be classified as reeducational, persuasive, facilitating, and power strategies. Other models for implementing behavior change have been considered, including the influence of trained researchers and the use of online computer prescribing with interactive software with appropriate guidelines. The challenge is to achieve sustained change when interventions are implemented. Low-cost quality assurance of drug use with modest resources is possible if results-oriented activities are prioritized.

title: Pharmacological Treatment of Insomnia Disorder: An Evidence Report by the American College of Physicians for Clinical Practice Guidelines
abstract: Background: Pharmacological interventions are often prescribed for insomnia disorder. Objective: To evaluate the benefits, harms and comparative effectiveness of pharmacological treatments for adults with insomnia. Data Sources: Various electronic databases (2004Â¨CSeptember 2015), reference lists, and US Food and Drug Administration (FDA) documents. Study Selection: 35 randomized, controlled studies of at least 4 weeks duration evaluating available pharmacotherapies in the United States and reporting global or sleep outcomes; 11 long-term observational studies reporting harm information; FDA review data for non-benzodiazepine hypnotics and orexin receptor antagonists and product labels for all agents Data Extraction: Single investigator data extraction approved by a second reviewer; dual investigator assessment of risk of bias; consensus determination of strength of evidence Data Synthesis: Although absolute effect sizes for eszopiclone, zolpidem, and suvorexant were small (low to moderate severity). evidence) better short-term overall and sleep outcomes or lower power compared to placebo. Evidence was also insufficient to compare efficacy in or across ph. versus pharmacotherapy classes or behavioral therapy. Evidence of harm reported in trials was rated as insufficient or low power; Observational studies have suggested that the use of hypnotic for insomnia is associated with an increased risk of dementia, fractures, and major injuries. FDA documents reported that most pharmacotherapy had risks for cognitive and behavioral changes, including driving impairment and other side effects, and recommended dose reduction in women and older adults Limitations: Most trials were small and short-term and enrolled individuals meeting stringent criteria. Minimal significant differences in outcomes. often not identified or reported. Conclusion: Eszopiclone, zolpidem, and suvorexant may improve short-term overall and sleep outcomes for adults with insomnia, but the comparative effectiveness and long-term effectiveness of pharmacotherapies for insomnia are unknown. can cause cognitive and behavioral changes and may be associated with d Rare but serious harm. Primary Source of Funding: Agency for Health Research and Quality. (PROSPPERO: CRD4201409908)

title: Pharmacological Treatment of Low Bone Density or Osteoporosis to Prevent Fractures: A Clinical Practice Guide from the American College of Physicians
abstract: Description: The American College of Physicians (ACP) developed this guideline to present the available evidence for a variety of pharmacological treatments to prevent fractures in men and women with low bone density or osteoporosis. Methods: Published literature on this topic MEDLINE (1966 - December 2006), ACP Journal Club database, Cochrane Central Register of Controlled Trials (no date limit), Cochrane Database of Systematic Reviews (no date limit), UK National Health and Clinical Excellence Institute (no date limit) and the UK Health Technology Assessment Program (January 1998 - December 2006) websites. Searches were limited to English publications and human studies. Keywords for the search included terms for osteoporosis, osteopenia, low bone density, and drugs listed in key questions. This guide ranks evidence and recommendations according to the ACP's clinical practice guidelines grading system. Recommendation 1: ACP recommends that clinicians recommend pharmacological treatment to men and women with known osteoporosis and those who experience fragility fractures (Grade: strong recommendation"; high-quality evidence). Men and women at risk of developing osteoporosis (Grade: weak recommendation; moderate-quality evidence) Recommendation 3 : The ACP recommends that clinicians choose pharmacological treatment options for osteoporosis in men and women based on assessment of risk and benefit in individual patients (Grade: strong recommendation; "moderate-quality evidence). Recommendation 4: The ACP recommends further research to evaluate the treatment of osteoporosis in men and women.

title: Pharmacological treatment of neuropsychiatric disorders
abstract: Emotional and cognitive symptoms such as depression, mania, mood and affect lability, psychosis, impaired arousal, anxiety and irritability and aggression are common in neurological disorders. These neuropsychiatric syndromes significantly impair functionality and rehabilitation efforts. Patients with brain damage are particularly susceptible to the side effects of drugs. When appropriate guidelines are followed, psychopharmacological intervention alleviates these symptoms, accelerates rehabilitation, and prevents arousal and cognitive impairment.

title: Pharmacological treatment of bipolar disorder in children and adolescents
abstract: It is increasingly recognized that bipolar disorder often first appears during adolescence. Pre-adolescents with volatile behaviors and severe mood swings also make up a large group of patients whose difficulties may lie within the bipolar spectrum. However, the preponderance of scientific effort and clinical studies for this condition has focused on adults. This review summarizes the complexity of bipolar disorder and its diagnosis among young people. It continues to review pharmacotherapy principles, evaluate current treatment options, and highlight areas where evidence-based guidance is lacking. Recent advances have broadened the range of potential treatments for bipolar disorder. However, the differences in the phenomenology, course, and sequelae of bipolar disorder among young people warrant greater attention to the benefits and obligations of treatment for those affected by the early onset of this illness. This review aims to provide an update on a clinically important but controversial issue by summarizing current research and views on diagnostic issues and therapeutic approaches.

title: Pharmacotherapy of social anxiety disorder at the turn of the millennium
abstract: In the 21 years since CP entered diagnostic terminology, important information has been obtained about effective pharmacological and psychotherapeutic treatments. Although good evidence demonstrates the efficacy of benzodiazepines, SSRIs have emerged as first-line pharmacological therapy"; MAOIs; and anticonvulsant agents such as gabapentin and pregabalin. There is also emerging evidence for the efficacy of the new antidepressant venlafaxine, as well as the potential benefit of nefazodone and possibly bupropion. There is also optimism. However, there are many areas that require further research. There has been great excitement about the publication of the RUPP Anxiety Study, which shows the efficacy of fluvoxamine in socially phobic youth. Given that CP begins in childhood and adolescence, early intervention can prevent the sequelae of chronic CP. , more data are needed to support the use of pharmacotherapy in this age group. Further research is needed on what is required for social phobic individuals who respond well to pharmacotherapy to reach a state of complete remission. Comparative studies of different drug classes Additional research is needed to evaluate its efficacy and develop an improved ability to predict treatment response to a particular type of treatment. In addition, more research is needed on resistance to treatment. In most of the anxiety disorders examined, combining CBT with psychopharmacological treatment showed little advantage over either treatment alone. These findings may be due to methodological problems. Research is needed on how to rank treatments to maximize the benefits of combining the two types of effective treatments. Finally, many clinicians see an increasing trend in individuals who have not been treated for CP in their lifetime and are now seeking treatment in their "golden years". Current established therapies need further evaluation in this geriatric population.

title: The Pharmacy Asthma Care Program (PACP) improves outcomes for patients in the community.
abstract: Background: Despite national disease management plans, optimal asthma management remains a challenge in Australia. Community pharmacists are in an ideal position to implement new strategies aimed at ensuring that asthma treatment meets current best practice standards. The effect of the Pharmacy Asthma Care Program (PACP) on asthma control was evaluated using a multisite randomized intervention versus control repeated measures study design. Methods: Fifty Australian pharmacies were randomized into two groups: intervention pharmacies administered PACP (an ongoing cycle of assessment, goal setting, monitoring and review) to 191 patients over 6 months, while control pharmacies administered 205 control patients their usual care. Both groups administered questionnaires and performed spirometric tests at baseline and 6 months later. The main outcome measure was asthma severity/control status. Results: 186 (91%) of 205 control patients and 165 (86%) of 191 intervention patients completed the study. The intervention resulted in improved asthma control: patients who received the intervention were 2.7 times more likely to improve from "severe" to "not severe" than control patients (OR 2.68, 95% CI 1.64 to 4.37"; p< Intervention also improved adherence to preventative medication (OR 1.89, 95% CI 1.08 to 3.30; p?=?0.03), reducing the mean daily dose of reliever medication (difference -149.11 µg, 95% CI -283.87 to -14.36; p? =?0.03) in the drug profile, switching from relaxer only to a combination of inhibitor, long-acting ÃŸ agonist or no ÃŸ agonist reliever (OR 3.80, 95% CI 1.40 to 10.32; p?=?0.01), and improved scores mismatch risk (difference -0.44, 95%) CI -0.69 to -0.18; p?=?0.04), quality of life (difference -0.23, 95% CI -0.46 to 0.00; p?=?0.05), asthma knowledge (difference 1.18, 95% CI 0.73 to 1.63; p <0.01) and perceived control of asthma questionnaires (difference -1.39, 95% CI -2.44 to -0.35; "p<0.01). There was no significant change in spirometric measurements in both groups. Conclusions: A pharmacist-administered asthma care program based on national guidelines improves asthma control. The sustainability and implementation of the program within the health system continues to be explored.

title: Prescription physical activity (PAP) from the GP's perspective - a qualitative study
abstract: BACKGROUND: Prescription physical activity (PAP) is a successful intervention to increase physical activity in patients with sedentary lifestyles. The method appears to be infrequently used by general practitioners (GPs), and there is limited information available about general practitioners' attitudes towards counseling using PAP as a tool. The aim of the study was to explore and understand the meaning of prescribing physical activity from the GP perspective. METHODS: Three focus group interviews were conducted in southern Sweden with a purposive sample of 15 Swedish GPs. Participants were invited to talk about their experience using PAP. The interviews were transcribed verbatim and analyzed using qualitative content analysis. RESULTS: The analysis resulted in four categories: Tradition makes it difficult to change attitudes, Shared responsibility required, PAPs have low status and are viewed with distrust, and Lack of procedures and clear guidelines. Traditionally, GPs talk to patients about the importance of increased levels of physical activity, but do not recommend physical activity as a treatment. Physicians' education focuses on drug use. Responsibility for the physical activity level of patients is shared with other healthcare professionals, patients and the community. General practitioners express reservations about prescribing physical activity. A heavy workload is a source of frustration. PAP is viewed with distrust and considered a task of lesser value and status. Using a prescription to highlight an increased level is considered unnecessary, and GPs feel that it should be given by someone else in the healthcare system. Doubts about the outcome of the method were also expressed. CONCLUSION: There is uncertainty about the use of PAP as a treatment because physicians do not have training on non-drug methods. GPs do not view written referral as a primary task and instead turn to other professionals in the healthcare system to prescribe PAP. GPs noted the need to create routines and regulations for the method to gain credibility and become daily practice among GPs.

title: Doctor's Advice on Smoking for Adolescents: Who Gets Advice and Who Benefits The Most?
abstract: OBJECTIVE: Clinical Practice Guidelines instruct physicians to ask their patients about smoking and to advise against tobacco use. Due to the increased sensitivity of these groups to smoking, doctors are urged to deal with racial minorities and youth in particular. Research on race and doctor's recommendations against smoking has produced conflicting findings. The aim of this study is to reveal the relationships between physician communication about tobacco, race and smoking among adolescents. METHODS: This cross-sectional retrospective study investigated (1) racial differences in rates of receiving physician communication and (2) whether the association between physician communication and smoking among adolescents is governed by race. Multiple measures of smoking status were used (eg, intentions to quit, attempts to quit, quits, relapse status). We used a large (N = 5,154), predominantly African-American (82.9%) sample of grade 11 students. RESULTS: Regular smokers were more likely to be screened for smoking. African Americans were advised against tobacco more often than Caucasians. Among African Americans, nonsmokers were more likely to be both screened and recommended";" Among Caucasians, regulars were most likely screened and recommended. Overall, physician intervention was associated with greater benefits for young African Americans, including less intent to smoke, more likely to quit, and fewer relapses. CONCLUSIONS: Physician communication about smoking may be particularly promising for African-American youth by reducing health disparities due to racial differences in smoking-related mortality and morbidity. Physicians should be encouraged to screen and advise all youth about tobacco, regardless of race or smoking status.

title: Physician and patient predictors of evidence-based prescribing in heart failure: a multi-level study.
abstract: BACKGROUND: The management of patients with heart failure (HF) must take into account the variable and complex individual clinical characteristics. The use of renin angiotensin system inhibitors (RAAS-I) to target doses is recommended by the guidelines. But although little is known about physicians and patients' factors predicting compliance, it seems that physicians do not adequately follow this recommendation. METHODS: To examine the consistency of primary care (PC) physicians' knowledge of the RAAS-I and their self-perceived competence with their prescribing behaviors regarding patient-related disabilities. Cross-sectional follow-up study after a randomized trial of medical education intervention with a seven-month observation period. PC physicians (n = 37) and patients with systolic heart failure (n = 168) from practices in Baden-Württemberg. Measures included knowledge (plan-based multiple choice test), self-perceived efficacy (questionnaire about global confidence in treatment and frequency of RAAS-I use), and patient variables (age, gender, NYHA functional status, blood pressure, potassium level, kidney function). Prescribing was collected from the documentation of the trials. The target variable consisted of >/= 50% of the recommended RAAS-I dose investigated by the two-level logistic regression models. RESULTS: Patients (69% male, mean age 68.8 years) were symptomatic and objective left ventricular (NYHA II vs III/IV: 51% vs 49% and mean LVEF 33.3%) and renal (GFR/=50%) showed. Reasons for improvement in RAAS-I prescribing were patient age (OR 0.95, CI 0.92-0.99, p = 0.01), physician's general confidence in follow-up (OR 1.09, CI 1.02-1.05, p = 0.01), and NYHA class (II vs. III). /IV) (OR 0.63, CI 0.38-1.05, p = 0.08) CONCLUSIONS: A change in physician confidence as a predictor of RAAS-I dose escalation is a novel finding that may reflect the intervention effect of improved physicians. ' intention, and this may lead to new strategies to improve safe evidence-based prescribing. These should include targeting knowledge, attitudes and skills.

title: Physician and patient willingness to pay for electronic cardiovascular disease management
abstract: OBJECTIVES: Cardiovascular disease (CVD) is an important target for electronic decision support. We examined the potential sustainability of an electronic CVD management program using a discrete selection experiment (DCE). Our aim was to estimate physician and patient willingness to pay (WTP) for existing and improved programs. METHODS: Focus groups, expert input, and literature searches decided on qualifications to be evaluated for physician and patient DCEs conducted using a Web-based program. Hierarchical Bayesian analysis, estimated preference coefficients for each participant, and latent class analysis partitioned each sample. The simulations were used to estimate WTP for each of the features separately and for an advanced vascular management system. RESULTS: 144 participants (70 physicians, 74 patients) completed DCE. Overall, speed of access to updated records and monthly payments for a nurse coordinator were the main determinants of physician selection. Two distinct segments of physicians were identified – one very sensitive to the monthly subscription fee and speed of updating the tracker with new patient data, and the other very sensitive to the nurse coordinator's monthly cost and government billing incentives. Patient choices were most affected by the annual subscription cost. Estimated physician WTP was slightly above the estimated threshold for sustainability while below patient WTP. CONCLUSION: Current willingness to pay for electronic cardiovascular disease management should spur innovation to achieve economies of scale in program development, implementation and maintenance to meet sustainability thresholds.

title: Physician attitudes towards diffusion of optical spectroscopy devices for cervical cancer control: an industrial-academic collaborative study.
abstract: BACKGROUND: Optical spectroscopy has been studied for biological plausibility, technical efficacy, clinical efficacy, patient satisfaction, and cost-effectiveness. OBJECTIVE: We tried to determine the attitudes or practices of the health care provider that may prevent the spread or spread of this new technology. METHODS: Through an academic-industrial partnership, we conducted a series of focus groups to examine physicians' barriers to optical diagnosis. The study was carried out in 2 stages. First, a pilot group of 10 doctors (8 obstetrician-gynecologists and 2 family practitioners) from 8 regions of the United States was randomly selected and interviewed individually with each doctor. Physicians were presented with the results of a large trial (N = 980) testing the accuracy of a spectroscopy-based device in detecting cervical neoplasia. They were also shown a prototype of the device and given time to ask questions about the device and get answers. They were also asked to provide feedback on a questionnaire that was later revised and submitted to 3 larger focus groups (n = 13, 15 and 17 for a total of N = 45). Larger focus groups were conducted during national scientific meetings with 20 obstetrician-gynecologists and 25 primary care physicians (family practitioners and internists). CONCLUSIONS: When asked about the potential for new cervical screening technology to spread, all study groups tended to rely on established clinical guidelines from their professional community regarding the screening and diagnosis of cervical cancer. Additionally, study participants consistently agreed that real-time spectroscopy would be well received by their patients. Participants were positive about the potential of the new technology in addition to colposcopy and agreed that improved accuracy would result in reduced healthcare costs (due to reduced biopsies and reduced visits). While all participants saw the potential of real-time diagnostics, there were many perceived barriers. These barriers included changes in timing and workflow, liability, documentation, ease of use, training time, device cost, and reimbursements by third-party payers. CONCLUSIONS: There are barriers to the diffusion of optical technologies into physician practice. These will need to be addressed before cervical screening and diagnostic programs can benefit from spectroscopy-based tools for cancer control.

title: Physician behavior in pediatric chronic disease care: relationship with health outcomes and adherence to treatment.
abstract: OBJECTIVE: Physician behavior is an important but under-studied influence on child and parent adherence to medical treatment. METHOD: To address this need, research was reviewed in the following subject areas: child and adolescent perceptions of physicians' behavior in pediatric chronic disease management, parental perceptions of physicians' behavior in pediatric chronic disease management"; physicians' compliance with guidelines for pediatric chronic disease management; physicians' pediatric chronic disease management Information communication on chronic disease management; the relationship of physician behavior to adherence to treatment; and interventions to improve physicians' pediatric chronic disease management. CONCLUSIONS: Findings include inconsistencies between parent and adolescent needs and physician behavior, as well as adherence to practice guidelines that may limit children's adherence to medical treatment. However, the results of interventions designed by physicians to improve pediatric asthma management have been promising. Future research should be guided by a comprehensive model of physician behavior that takes into account contextual determinants (eg, culture and socioeconomic status) in chronic disease management, defines clinically relevant targets for intervention, and documents its impact on health outcomes. Chronic disease management approaches that involve physicians in active communication, support and decision-making processes with children with chronic diseases and their parents should be developed and evaluated.

title: Physician intervention and patient risk perception in smokers with acute respiratory disease in the emergency department
abstract: BACKGROUND: Acute Respiratory Disease is responsible for more than 12 million visits to emergency departments in the United States each year. A quarter to half of these patients are smokers. We examined the frequency of physician intervention to quit smoking in patients with acute respiratory disease in the emergency department and the effect of physician intervention on patients' perceived risk from smoking and motivation to quit. METHODS: This study was conducted in the emergency department of a large hospital in the city centre. A questionnaire was applied to adult smokers (n = 63) who presented with symptoms of acute respiratory tract disease by conducting an exit interview while in the emergency room. The frequency and extent of physician interventions for smoking were examined using Health Care Policy and Research Agency guidelines as a Model. We also evaluated the patients' perceptions of risk from smoking, the presence of other smokers at home, and the patients' motivation to quit smoking. RESULTS: Emergency room doctors gave incomplete and inconsistent interventions to smoking. While most patients reported being asked if they smoked, only half of smokers were advised to quit. Only 9% were offered help with quitting. Risk perception was generally low, but most smokers were willing to receive onsite smoking cessation counseling while in the emergency room. CONCLUSIONS: The small sample size in this study requires careful interpretation of the results. However, the findings of this study suggest that the emergency room setting may provide a unique "teachable moment" for initiating smoking cessation counseling for this high-risk population.

title: Physician involvement in the management of obesity as a primary medical condition
abstract: As the obesity epidemic escalates, an increasing number of patients present with serious comorbidities due to excess body weight. Obesity should be recognized and treated as a progressive, chronic and recurrent primary medical condition. Effective treatment of obesity has been shown to reduce cardiovascular risk factors and comorbid conditions. Physician involvement is required for medical evaluation, management, counseling and coordination of multidisciplinary obesity treatment. Obese patients who receive counseling and weight management from doctors are much more likely to receive weight management programs than those who do not. Obesity treatment guidelines and materials are available from a variety of health care providers. A comprehensive weight management program should include dietary adjustments, increased physical activity, and behavior change. Nutritional changes should take into account the energy content, composition and suitability of the diet for the individual patient. The physical activity component should be safe and practical, including aerobic activity, strength training, and increased daily lifestyle activities. Various behavioral strategies enable the patient to make lifestyle changes that will promote weight loss and management. Additional treatments may serve to support lifestyle changes in cases of severe or resistant obesity. Multidisciplinary care models vary depending on whether they are designed for an individual medical practice or as part of a larger facility's healthcare. Lifestyle changes for healthy weight management should be permanently incorporated into the patient's daily lifestyle to reduce obesity and its associated health risks. Such an intervention is necessary to slow and reverse the growing obesity epidemic.

title: Physician management of hypercholesterolemia. A randomized trial of continuing medical education
abstract: To determine the impact of continuing medical education (CME) on compliance with the National Cholesterol Education Program Expert Panel's recommendations on high serum cholesterol levels in adults, we recruited primary care physicians in 174 practices, 2 standard or intensive CMEs, and a control group. The standard CME group received a free 3-hour seminar on high serum cholesterol levels”; the intensive CME group was provided with follow-up seminars and free office supplies. After 18 months, we audited 13,099 medical records from 140 practices. Groups with continuing medical education (51% screening; There was no significant difference in high serum cholesterol screening or compliance with guidelines (P > .15) between the control group (57% compliance) and the control group (57%). ;" 37% compliance). In the prespecified subgroup of patients with hypercholesterolaemia, there was a trend towards modest benefit from continuing medical education interventions: adherence was 21% in the control group, 23% in the standard CME group, and 27% in the intensive CME group (P = .07 total). These results highlight the need for better ways to change behavior in GPs and the importance of examining the implementation of preventive health recommendations.

title: Physician reimbursement with salary or fee-for-service: impact on physician practice behavior in a randomized prospective study.
abstract: We used an established continuity clinic to prospectively compare the impact of salary and pay-per-service reimbursement on physician practice behavior. This model allowed physicians to be randomized into salary and pay-per-service groups and to decouple the effects of reimbursement from patient behavior. Physicians reimbursed for service scheduled more visits per patient than salaried doctors (3.69 visits v 2.83 visits, less than P.01) and saw their patients more often (2.70 visits v 2.21 visits, less than P.05) 9 monthly work. Almost all of this difference was that paid doctors per service saw better patients than salaried doctors (1.42 visits and .99 visits per enrolled patient, respectively, less than P.01). Judging visits according to the American Academy of Pediatrics guidelines showed that doctors who charge per service see more patients for better childcare than salaried doctors because they miss fewer recommended visits and scheduled visits that exceed these recommendations. Pay-per-service physicians also participate in a larger percentage of all visits by their patients (86.6% of visits and 78.3% of visits, less than P 0.05) and encourage less emergencies than salaried physicians. They provided good continuity of care. visits per registered patient (0.12 visits v 0.22 visits, P less than .01). Physicians' interest in private practice, as determined by career plans, was significantly associated with the total number of patients enrolled (r = .48, P less than .05) and the total number of clinical patients seen by each resident during the study (r = .40). , P less than .05).

title: Doctor's response to computer reminders.
abstract: A computerized medical record system has been designed to identify and remind the responsible clinician of clinical events that may require corrective action. These reminders significantly increased the clinician's response rate (in terms of test orders and treatment changes) to these events. Adding relevant medical literature citations to reminders did not significantly alter the clinician response rate compared to reminders alone and did not encourage physicians to read any of the cited articles kept in an immediately accessible reprint "library".

title: Physician responses to a population-level study promoting reasonable antibiotic use
abstract: OBJECTIVE: In an environment with multiple campaigns promoting rational antibiotic use in children, it is important to identify effective strategies. We evaluated physician responses to a population-level intervention for antibiotic prescribing, related practices, and perceived effectiveness. METHODS: This study was a mixed qualitative and quantitative evaluation of a randomized controlled population-wide educational intervention in 16 Massachusetts communities. Physicians in intervention communities received locally approved guidelines, group training sessions, and biweekly newsletters. Parents simultaneously received material in doctor's offices and by mail. After the intervention, we conducted a mailed physician questionnaire and individual interviews to assess the impact of the intervention. We compared survey responses for intervention and control physicians and analyzed interview transcripts to provide in-depth information on selected topics. RESULTS: Among respondents (n = 168), 91% of intervention and 4% of control physicians reported receiving intervention materials. Doctors took information from many other sources. More interventions than control physicians reported a decrease in antibiotic prescribing between 2000 and 2003 (75% versus 58%, P = .03), but there was no difference between groups in knowledge, attitudes, or behaviors that support conscious antibiotic use. Both groups were concerned about antibiotic resistance and reported space to reduce their own prescriptions. Physicians interviewed recommended frequent repetition of messages, short written material on specific topics for themselves and their patients, and mass media promotion as the most effective strategies for reducing prescribing. CONCLUSIONS: In multiple communities, an intervention to promote judicious antibiotic prescribing in physicians' offices reached its intended audience, but physicians' self-reported attitudes and practices were similar in the intervention and control populations. Campaigns that repeat short, consistent reminders to multiple stakeholder groups may be most effective in ensuring reasonable antibiotic use.

title: Doctor screening for multiple behavioral health risk factors
abstract: BACKGROUND: Screening rates for single behavioral health risk factors in primary care have been widely documented. However, such risk factors cluster in individuals and populations. This article examines the number and types of behavioral risk factors that U.S. adults report and have screened at their last routine medical exam. METHODS: The sample consisted of 16,818 adults who reported having routine checkups in the last year from the 1998 National Health Interview Survey. Participants completed questions on four behavioral risk factors (physical inactivity, overweight, smoking, risky drinking) and provider screening for behaviors related to these risk factors. RESULTS: Half of the sample (52.0%) reported having two or more of the four risk factors and more than half (59.4%) were screened for two or more risky behaviors during their last routine check-up, but 28.6% reported being screened. none. Participants who reported at least one risk factor were screened for an average of 57.7% of their own risk factors. Women, adults with lower income and education levels, and people 65 and older reported being screened for fewer risk factors. CONCLUSIONS: While guidelines for risk factor screening and intervention typically focus on single behavioral risk factors, most primary care patients have more than one and are screened for them. Behavioral risk factor screening tools and interventions should be expanded to include multiple risks. Additionally, efforts are needed to reduce significant missed opportunities for screening and to eliminate demographic differences in screening practices and accuracy.

title: Physician, heal yourself: health protection behaviors among physicians
abstract: The purpose of this article is to evaluate the need for health care intervention programs for physicians and patients. We compared physicians' (as patients) adherence to health-preserving behavior with a control patient population. An online questionnaire was sent to Texas Tech University Health Science Center (TTUHSC) medical school clinical and non-clinical basic science faculties and non-TTUHSC clinicians of the local county medical community. The questionnaire included questions about basic demographics and recent participation in regular health care strategies, including annual checkups, flu shots, colonoscopy, Pap smears, and mammograms. Logistic regressions were performed to determine whether being a physician was significantly associated with the probability of participating in the health-maintaining behavior outcomes listed above. This article shows that physicians are less likely than the general population to follow certain health care guidelines (i.e. annual checkups, colonoscopies, and mammograms). Pap smear rates did not differ between physicians and the control population, but physicians did show an increased likelihood of receiving influenza vaccine.

title: Physician-Industry Relations. Part 1: Individual Doctors
abstract: This is part 1 of a 2-part article on ethics and physician-industry relationships. Part 1 offers advice to individual doctors";" Part 2 provides advice to medical education providers and the medical professional community. Physicians and industry have a common interest in advancing medical knowledge. However, the primary ethics of the physician is to promote the interests of the patient, while the primary ethics of the industry is to promote profitability. While partnerships between physicians and industry can lead to impressive medical advances, they also create opportunities for bias and cause negative public perceptions. Many physicians and trained physicians feel that they are not affected by the commercial influence. However, recent research shows that industry hospitality and accepting gifts, even drug samples, can compromise judgments about medical information and subsequent decisions about patient care. It is up to the physician to decide whether a gift is acceptable. A very general principle is that it is ethical to accept modest gifts that enhance medical practice. It is clearly unethical to accept gifts or services that compel the physician to reciprocate. Conflicts of interest may arise from other financial ties between physicians and industry, from outside companies or from self-owned businesses. Such ties include talking or writing about a company's product, paying for participation in clinical-based research, and referrals to medical resources. All these relationships have the potential to affect the attitudes and practices of the physician. This article explores relevant ethical dilemmas and provides guidelines for ethical business dealings.

title: Doctors and the pharmaceutical industry (2001 update)
Physicians' health habits are associated with lifestyle counseling for hypertensive patients
abstract: BACKGROUND: The Seventh Report of the Joint National Committee on the Prevention, Detection, Evaluation and Treatment of Hypertension (JNC VII) recommended lifestyle interventions for all patients with high blood pressure, with or without pharmacological therapy. The aim of this study is to determine the relationship of physicians' personal habits with their attitudes and behaviors towards JNC VII lifestyle change guidelines. METHODS: One thousand primary care physicians completed DocStyles 2010, a voluntary web-based questionnaire designed to provide information on physicians' attitudes and behaviors related to a variety of health problems. RESULTS: The mean age of the respondents was 45.3, and 68% were male. Regarding physician behavior, 4.0% smoke at least once a week, 38.6% consume >/=5 cups of fruit and/or vegetables >/=5 days/week and 27.4% >/=5 days/ He was exercising for the week. When asked about the specific types of advice offered to their hypertensive patients, physicians replied that they recommend a healthy diet (92.2%) or reducing salt (96.1%) or reaching a healthy weight (94.8%). or limiting alcohol use (75.4%) or being physically active (94.4%). Collectively, 66.5% made all 5 lifestyle change recommendations. Doctors who did not smoke were more likely to recommend each lifestyle intervention to their hypertensive patients. Those who exercised at least 1 day per week were more likely to recommend limiting their alcohol use. RESULTS: Physicians who did not smoke and exercised at least 1 day per week were more likely to recommend all 5 JNC VII interventions.

title: Doctors' response to victims of domestic violence: towards a model of care
abstract: Existing domestic violence guidelines, such as those published by the AMA in 1992, continue to invite doctors to play a large role in identifying, intervening and monitoring, although they seek to relieve doctors of "the entire burden of intervention." in case of partner abuse. In this paper, we describe a limited domestic violence role for physicians who take the direction suggested by the AMA and complete sample programs. We propose to simplify and limit the role of physicians to "asking patients about abuse"; providing affirmative messages, admitting the beating is wrong and reaffirming the patient's value; documenting signs, symptoms, and explanations; and referring victims to domestic violence specialists (AVDRs) to the literature and our own experience. Based on these four missions, we show how the focus on the role of the doctor in these four tasks is consistent with the sample programs and expands the ideas of experts to address domestic violence in health care, reducing barriers to the intervention of doctors for victims; reducing unrealistic training demands for doctors by providing a realistic approach; " and complements managed care trends in contemporary health care.

title: Physicians understand consent requirements for phase I clinical trials in cognitively impaired or highly vulnerable populations
abstract: We investigated physicians' attitudes towards including patients who were unable to give informed consent or who were from a vulnerable population in clinical trials. A survey tool asked a nationwide sample of GPs whether ten hypothetical patients could be enrolled in a phase I clinical trial. The impact of demographic variables on the number of scenarios considered fully or partially acceptable was analyzed via student T-tests or analysis of variance (ANOVA) as applicable. All significant (p<0.01) variables were entered into the multiple logistic regression model. Eighty-four percent of respondents said at least one case scenario is acceptable. The majority of those conducting clinical trials (62%), those trained in clinical research ethics (78%), and those on institutional review boards (IRBs) (83%) approved at least one case scenario. Physicians have approved the inclusion of some patients in clinical trials who were unable to give informed consent or were from a vulnerable population. More effective education should be provided for GPs, residents and medical students on guidelines involving clinical research. There should also be assurance that physicians conducting clinical trials or participating in IRBs have the necessary knowledge of clinical research ethics.

title: Fixing the diagnosis in breast cancer
Service point reminders for prescribing cardiovascular medications.
abstract: OBJECTIVES: To evaluate its effectiveness in promoting prescriptions to prevent cardiovascular events and to provide physicians with evidence-based recommendations for point-of-service care, using an automated system. STUDY DESIGN: Randomized controlled trial. METHODS: Patients at risk for cardiovascular events who might benefit from angiotensin converting enzyme inhibitors or 3-hydroxy-3-methylglutaryl coenzyme A reductase inhibitors (statins) were identified from electronic data in a managed care organization and randomly assigned to 2 groups. Physicians seeing outpatients in the intervention group were faxed a page with pertinent patient data, including a recommendation to prescribe the prescribed medication. In the control group, the datasheet did not include the recommendation. Distributed prescriptions were compared between groups. RESULTS: More than 4000 visits were observed for each drug type. Angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitors or angiotensin II receptor blockers were dispensed after the first patient-physician encounter in 7.1% of visits in the intervention group and 5.7% in the control group (P = .048). No significant difference was observed for statins (intervention, 8.1% vs control, 7.7%). Data for all patient-physician encounters and for both drugs were combined in a logistic regression analysis. The odds ratio was 1.19 for a prescription given in the intervention group and 1.54 for 1 visit versus 2 or more visits. RESULTS: An automated system that provides relevant data and tailored recommendations for point-of-service care has modestly increased prescription dispensing rates. Targeting patient-provider encounters to change provider behavior is difficult";" however, even minor effects can produce clinically significant results over time.

title: Point-of-care electronic alerts: an effective way to increase compliance, demonstrate quality and improve outcome
abstract: BACKGROUND: Incentives based on quality indicators, such as the Surgical Care Improvement Project key measures (SCIP 1), encourage the consistent application of evidence-based guidelines in clinical practice. Information systems with point-of-care electronic alerts (POCEPs) can facilitate process adoption and performance comparison. We evaluated the efficacy of POCEPs on antibiotic administration rates within 60 minutes after surgical incision and outcome in a prospective observational study. METHODS: SCIP 1 compliance and the associated outcome variable (surgical site infection [SSI]) were prospectively studied over 2 consecutive 6-month periods before (A) and (B) after administration of POCEPs in a regional health system.
