The secondary analysis extended the observation to two 12-month periods (A' and B'). This was followed by a 2-year (C and D) sustainability phase. RESULTS: 19,744 procedures included 9127 and 10,617 procedures before (A) and (B) after administration of POCEPs, respectively. POCEPs increased compliance with SCIP indicators by 31% (95% CI, 30.0%-32.2%) in period B from 62% to 92% (average SSI rates for all periods were lower compared to pre-POCEP SSI rates (0.8). the lower P 95%, 0.7% and 0.5% vs 1.1%";" was associated with an absolute risk reduction of 30% and 0.4% incidence of SSI. POCEPs may be useful to modulate provider behavior and to demonstrate intraoperative quality and value.

title: Population-based interventions to reduce sexually transmitted infections, including HIV infection
abstract: AIM: Sexually transmitted infections (STIs) are common in developing countries. The World Health Organization (WHO) estimates that 340 million new cases of syphilis, gonorrhea, chlamydial infection and trichomoniasis occurred in 1999. Human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) infection is also common in developing countries. UNAIDS estimates that by December 1999, more than 95% of the 40 million people infected with HIV lived in developing countries (UNAIDS 2003). STI and HIV epidemics are linked. Similar behaviors, such as frequent unprotected sex with different partners, put people at increased risk for both infections, and there is clear evidence that traditional STIs increase the likelihood of HIV transmission. Several studies have shown a strong association between both ulcerative and non-ulcerative STIs and HIV infection (Cameron 1989, Laga 1993). There is also biological evidence that the presence of an STI increases HIV transmission and that STI treatment reduces HIV transmission (Cohen 1997, Robinson 1997). Therefore, STI control may have the potential to contribute significantly to HIV prevention. OBJECTIVES: To determine the impact of population-based STI interventions on HIV infection frequency, STI frequency, and quality of STI management. SEARCH STRATEGY: The following electronic databases were searched for relevant randomized trials or reviews: 1) MEDLINE using the search terms "sexually transmitted diseases" and "human immunodeficiency virus infection" for the years 1966 to 2003 2) Cochrane Database of Systematic Reviews, Abstracts of Efficacy Reviews Database and Cochrane Clinical Trials Register, latest issue of The Cochrane Library 3) Expert register of research maintained by the Cochrane Infectious Diseases Group. 4) EMBASE Abstracts of relevant conferences were searched and lists of all reference review articles and primary studies were searched. Finally, the authors of the included studies and other experts in the field were contacted as appropriate. SELECTION CRITERIA: Randomized controlled trials in which the randomized unit is a community or a treatment facility. Studies in which individuals were randomized were excluded. DATA COLLECTION AND ANALYSIS: Two reviewers independently applied inclusion criteria for prospective studies and any disagreements were resolved through discussion. Essays were reviewed for completeness of reports. The methodological quality of each trial was assessed by the same two reviewers using the Cochrane Infectious Diseases standard guidelines, recording details of the randomization method, blinding, use of therapeutic analysis, and the number of patients lost to follow-up. Group. MAIN RESULTS: Five trials were included. Frequency of HIV infection: In Rakai, after 3 rounds of treatment for STIs of all community members, the HIV infection case rate rate was 0.97 (95%CI 0.81 to 1.16), indicating no effect of the intervention. In Mwanza, the incidence of HIV infection in the intervention groups (enhanced syndromic management of STIs in primary care clinics) was 1.2% compared to 1.9% (OR=0.58, 95% CI 0.42-0.70) in the control groups. 38% reduction in HIV incidence in the intervention group (95%CI 15% to 55%). In the most recent study by Kamali et al., the odds ratio for behavioral intervention and STI management compared to control over HIV incidence was 1.00 (0.63–1.58, p=.98). These are consistent with Rakai data showing no effect of the intervention. Frequency of STIs: In both Mwanza and Rakai, there were no significant reductions in gonorrhea, chlamydia, urethritis, or reported STI symptoms among the intervention populations. In Rakai, the prevalence rate for syphilis was 0.8 (95%CI 0.71-0.89), trichmoniasis 0.59 (0.38-0.91) and bacterial vaginosis 0.87 (0.74-1.02) between the intervention and control groups. In Mwanza, the prevalence of serologically diagnosed syphilis in the intervention population was 5% at the end of the trial compared to 7% in the control population (adjusted to 7% at the end of the trial in the control population (adjusted relative risk 0.71 (95% CI 0.54-0). ,93.Kamali et al. had significant reductions in gonorrhea and active syphilis.The odds ratio for gonorrhea was 0.29 (0.12-0.71, p=0.016), active syphilis 0.53(0.33-0.84, p=0.016). there was a trend towards significance with intervention";" odds ratio was 1.27(1.02-1.56,p=0.036). Quality of treatment: Percentage of pharmacy residents in Lima in STI syndrome management after training, standardized simulated patients (SSPs) visiting intervention ) and 60% of SSPs who visited control pharmacies considered symptoms to be due to an STI (p=0.35), with physicians in most cases (83% intervention vs. 78% control, p=0.61). only 1.4% of SSPs visiting intervention pharmacies and only 0.7% (p=0.57) of those visiting control pharmacies were offered a recommended regimen. Similarly, only 15% and 16% of SSP visits, respectively, were any recommended medication. However, SSPs who visited intervention pharmacies were more likely to receive training and counseling (27% versus 40%, p=0.01). No partner cards or condoms were issued to any SSP. In Hlabisa, SSPs were more likely to be given recommended medications in intervention clinics following intervention targeted at primary care clinic nurses (reinforced STI syndrome management and provision of STI syndrome packages containing recommended medications, condoms, partner cards, and patient information leaflets). vs 12%, p<0.005) and more likely to manage the case correctly [correct drugs, spouse cards and condoms were given] (88% vs 50%, p<0.005). Adequate counselling (68% vs. 46%, p=0.06), having good staff attitudes (84% vs. 58%, p=0.07) and being consulted in privacy (86% vs. 92%, p= 0.4). None of the four studies had strong evidence of any effect on treatment-seeking behavior, service use, or sexual behavior. RESULTS OF STUDY: There is limited evidence from randomized controlled trials for STI control as an effective HIV prevention strategy. Improved STI treatment services have been shown to reduce the incidence of HIV in an environment characterized by an emerging HIV epidemic (low and slowly increasing prevalence) where STI treatment services are poor and STIs are highly prevalent. There is no evidence that all community members benefit significantly from their treatment. Adding the Kamali case to the available evidence supports the ineffectiveness of the data from the Rakai case. However, there are other compelling reasons to strengthen STI treatment services, and available evidence suggests that once an intervention is adopted, it can significantly improve the quality of services provided. The Kamali trial shows an increase in condom use, a marker for improved risk behaviors. More population-based randomized controlled trials testing a range of alternative STI control strategies in a variety of different settings are needed. Such trials should aim to measure a range of factors, including HIV, STI, and other biological endpoints, as well as health-seeking behavior and quality of treatment.

title: Population-based interventions to reduce sexually transmitted infections, including HIV infection
abstract: AIM: Sexually transmitted infections (STIs) are common in developing countries. The World Health Organization (WHO) estimates that 333 million new cases of syphilis, gonorrhea, chlamydial infection and trichomoniasis occurred in 1995. Human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) infection is also common in developing countries. UNAIDS estimates that by December 1999, more than 90% of the 33 million people infected with HIV lived in developing countries (UNAIDS 1999). STI and HIV epidemics are linked. Similar behaviors, such as frequent unprotected sex with different partners, put people at increased risk for both infections, and there is clear evidence that traditional STIs increase the likelihood of HIV transmission. Several studies have shown a strong association between both ulcerative and non-ulcerative STIs and HIV infection (Cameron 1989, Laga 1993), and there is biological evidence that the presence of an STI increases HIV transmission and STI treatment reduces HIV transmission (Cohen). 1997, Robinson 1997). Therefore, STI control may have the potential to contribute significantly to HIV prevention. OBJECTIVES: To determine the impact of population-based STI interventions on HIV infection frequency, STI frequency, and quality of STI management. SEARCH STRATEGY: The following electronic databases were searched for relevant randomized studies or reviews: 1) MEDLINE using the search terms sexually transmitted diseases and human immunodeficiency virus infection from 1966 to the present 2) The Cochrane Database of Systematic Review, Database of Abstracts of the Cochrane The Cochrane Clinical Trials Register in the latest issue of Efficacy Reviews and the Cochrane Library 3) Expert register of studies maintained by the Cochrane Infectious Diseases Group. 4) EMBASE Abstracts of relevant conferences were searched and reference lists of all review articles and primary studies were searched. Finally, the authors of the included studies and other experts in the field were contacted as appropriate. SELECTION CRITERIA: Randomized controlled trials in which the randomized unit is a community or a treatment facility. Studies in which individuals were randomized were excluded. DATA COLLECTION AND ANALYSIS: Two reviewers independently applied inclusion criteria to potential studies where any disagreements were resolved through discussion. Essays were reviewed for completeness of reports. The methodological quality of each trial was assessed by the same two reviewers, recording details on the randomization method, blinding, use of therapeutic analysis, and the number of patients lost to follow-up using standard guidelines from the Cochrane Infectious Diseases Group. MAIN RESULTS: Four studies were included. Frequency of HIV infection: In Rakai, the HIV infection case rate rate was 0.97 (95%CI 0.81 to 1.16) after 3 rounds of treatment for STI of all community members, indicating no effect of the intervention. In Mwanza, the incidence of HIV infection in the intervention groups (enhanced syndromic management of STIs in primary care clinics) was 1.2% compared to 1.9% (OR=0.58, 95% CI 0.42-0.70) in the control groups. 38% reduction in HIV incidence in the intervention group (95%CI 15% to 55%). Frequency of STIs: In both Mwanza and Rakai, there were no significant reductions in gonorrhea, chlamydia, urethritis, or reported STI symptoms among the intervention populations. In Rakai, the prevalence rate for syphilis was 0.8 (95%CI 0.71-0.89), trichmoniasis 0.59 (0.38-0.91) and bacterial vaginosis 0.87 (0.74-1.02) between the intervention and control groups. In Mwanza, the prevalence of serologically diagnosed syphilis in the intervention population was 5% versus 7% in the control population at the end of the trial (adjusted relative risk 0.71 (95%CI 0.54-0.93)). in Lima). , following training of pharmacy residents in STI syndrome management, 65% of standardized simulated patients (SSPs) visiting intervention intervention and 60% of SSPs visiting control pharmacies were considered to have symptoms due to an STI (p =0.35). referral to a doctor in most cases (83% intervention vs 78% control, p=0.61) Only 1.4% of drug-offering SSPs visited intervention pharmacies and only 0.7% of control pharmacies (p=0.57) offered a recommended regimen Similarly, only 15% and 16% of SSP visits were offered any recommended medication, respectively. However, SSPs who visited intervention pharmacies were more likely to receive training and counseling (27% vs 40%, p=0.01) No S SPs were given partner cards or condoms. In Hlabisa, SSPs were more likely to be given recommended medications in intervention clinics following intervention targeted at primary care clinic nurses (reinforced STI syndrome management and provision of STI syndrome packages containing recommended medications, condoms, partner cards, and patient information leaflets). against 12%, p <0.005) and more likely to manage the case correctly [correct drugs, partner cards and condoms were given] (88% vs 50%, p <0.005). Receiving adequate counseling (68% vs. 46%, p=0.06), experiencing good staff attitudes (84% vs. 58%, p=0.07) and being consulted in privacy (86% vs. 92%, p=0.4) ). There was no strong evidence of any effect on treatment-seeking behavior, service use, or sexual behavior in any of the four trials. RESULTS OF STUDY: There is limited evidence from randomized controlled trials for STI control as an effective HIV prevention strategy. Improved STI treatment services have been shown to reduce the incidence of HIV in an environment characterized by an emerging HIV epidemic (low and slowly increasing prevalence) where STI treatment services are poor and STIs are highly prevalent. There is no evidence that all community members benefit significantly from their treatment. However, there are other compelling reasons to strengthen STI treatment services, and available evidence suggests that once an intervention is adopted, it can significantly improve the quality of services provided. More population-based randomized controlled trials testing a range of alternative STI control strategies in a variety of different settings are needed. Such trials should aim to measure a range of factors, including HIV, STI, and other biological endpoints, as well as health-seeking behavior and quality of treatment.

title: Population-level intervention strategies and examples for the prevention of obesity in children
abstract: With obesity affecting approximately 12.5 million American youth, population-level interventions are indicated to help promote healthy behaviors. The purpose of this review is to provide a summary of population-level intervention strategies and specific intervention examples that illustrate ways to help prevent and control obesity in children by improving nutrition and physical activity behaviors. Information is summarized in settings where children live, learn and play (early care and education, school, community, health care, home). Intervention strategies are activities or changes aimed at promoting healthy behavior in children. These include (a) systematic reviews; (b) recommendations, guidelines, or standards based on evidence and expert consensus from non-governmental or federal agencies; and finally (c) peer-reviewed synthesis reviews. Intervention examples show how at least one of the strategies was used in a particular setting. To identify examples of interventions, we evaluated (a) peer-reviewed literature as well as (b) additional sources with research-tested and practice-based initiatives. Researchers and practitioners can use this review to find examples of research and practice-tested interventions that can be replicated in their own communities when setting priorities and promoting integration across settings and for the prevention of childhood obesity.

title: Positron emission tomography in gynecological cancer
abstract: Most positron emission tomography (PET) imaging studies in gynecological cancer are performed using (18)F-fluorodeoxyglucose (FDG). It provides valuable information in the primary staging of untreated advanced cervical cancer, in surveillance after treatment with an unexplained tumor marker (such as squamous cell carcinoma antigen [SCC-Ag]), or in the restaging of potentially treatable recurrent cervical cancer with suspicion of recurrence. . Its value in early stage resectable cervical cancer is controversial. In ovarian cancer with FDG-PET, plateau or increased abnormal serum CA 125 (>35 U/mL), localized recurrence identified by computed tomography and/or magnetic resonance imaging (CT-MRI) and applicable for locally destructive procedures (e.g. surgical , radiotherapy or radiofrequency ablation) and clinically suspected recurrent or persistent cancer that cannot be biopsied under CT guidance. The role of FDG-PET in endometrial cancer is relatively less defined in the literature due to lack of data. In our prospective study, FDG-PET combined with MRI-CT may facilitate optimal management of endometrial cancer in well-selected cases. The clinical effect was positive in 29 (48.3%) of the 60 scans, 22.2% for primary staging, 73.1% for post-treatment surveillance, and 57.1% after rescue therapy, respectively. Insufficient studies have been reported in the treatment of vulvar cancer using FDG-PET. More data is needed. Gestational trophoblastic neoplasia is quite unique in terms of biological behavior and clinical management. Our preliminary results suggest that FDG-PET is potentially useful in selected gestational trophoblastic neoplasms by providing a presensitive metastatic mapping of tumor extent, monitoring response, and localizing viable tumors after chemotherapy. Evaluation of diagnostic efficacy (sensitivity, specificity, etc.).

title: Postpartum depression and infant development
Postphlebitis syndrome after leg fractures
The potential of trans fat policies to reduce socioeconomic disparities in deaths from coronary heart disease in the UK: a cost-effectiveness modeling study.
abstract: OBJECTIVES To determine the health and equity benefits and cost-effectiveness of policies to reduce or eliminate trans fatty acids from processed foods compared to consumption remaining at the latest levels in the UK. DESIGN Epidemiological modeling study. AYAR Health economics data from the National Diet and Nutrition Survey, the Low Income Diet and Nutrition Survey, the Office for National Statistics, and other published studies PARTICIPANTS stratified by one-fifth socioeconomic status â€°Â¥25-year-old adults. INTERVENTIONS Complete ban of trans fatty acids in processed foods"; improved labeling of trans fatty acids; ban of trans fatty acids in restaurants and takeaways. MAIN OUTCOME MEASURES Deaths from coronary heart disease have been prevented or delayed; life years gained; quality-adjusted life years. Government and industry policy costs; policy savings directly resulting from reductions in healthcare, informal care and lost productivity. CONCLUSIONS A total ban of trans fatty acids in processed foods could prevent or delay approximately 7200 deaths (2.6%) from coronary heart disease between 2015-20 and reduce the disparity in deaths from coronary heart disease by approximately 3000 deaths (15%). Policies to improve labeling or simply remove trans fatty acids from restaurants/fast food could save 1800 (0.7%) and 3500 (1.3%) deaths from coronary heart disease, and reduce inequalities from 600 (3%) to 1500 (7%) deaths. rate can be reduced. , thus making them half as effective at best. The total ban would have the largest net cost savings of around £265m ($361m, $415m) excluding reformulation costs, or £64m if significant reformulation costs occur outside the normal cycle. CONCLUSIONS A regulatory policy in the UK to eliminate trans fatty acids from processed foods would be the most effective and fair policy option. Interim policies would also be helpful. However, continuing to rely on industry to voluntarily reformulate products can have negative health and economic consequences.

title: Practical clinical trials in psychopharmacology: a systematic review
abstract: Practical clinical trials (PCTs) are randomized trials under typical practice conditions to test the "real-life" benefits and risks of therapeutic interventions. Effective PCTs have been performed in cardiology, oncology, and internal medicine. Psychotropic drugs are widely and increasingly used in medical practice. This review reviews recent advances in the conduct of PCTs in psychopharmacology. January 2000 - October 2014 The MEDLINE, Scopus, and ClinicalTrials.gov databases were searched for peer-reviewed publications of PCTs with at least 100 subjects per treatment arm. Most PCTs in psychiatry evaluated mental health services or psychosocial interventions rather than specific pharmacotherapy. Of the 157 PCTs in psychiatry, 30 (19%) were in psychopharmacology, with a median of 2 publications per year and no increase during the observation period. Sample size 200 to 18.154";" only 11 studies randomized 500 or more patients. Psychopharmacology PCTs were equally likely to be funded by industry as well as public institutions. There were 10 PCT antidepressants for a total of 4206 patients (compared to at least 46 PCTs of antihypertensive drugs for a total of 208,014 patients). Some psychopharmacology PCTs have used suicidal behavior, treatment discontinuation, or mortality as the primary outcome and have produced efficacy and safety data that influence both practice guidelines and regulatory decisions. Practical clinical research can be an important source of information for clinicians, patients, regulators and policy makers, but has been used relatively less in psychopharmacology. Electronic medical records and integrated application research networks offer promising platforms for more efficient execution of PCTs.

title: Practical application of coronary revascularization heart team
Implementation changes regarding the Family Care Cooperation of the Ministry of Veterans Affairs
abstract: BACKGROUND: The Department of Veterans Affairs (VA) provides rehabilitation for veterans with moderate to severe war injuries through four regional Multiple Trauma Rehabilitation Centers (PRC). To standardize and improve the care provided to family members of these veterans, health care researchers partnered with program leaders and rehabilitation professionals to implement the collaboration to improve family quality of care. OBJECTIVE: To identify practice changes associated with the intervention of the Family Care Collaborative. DESIGN: Cross-site, mixed method evaluation. PARTICIPANTS: Rehabilitation interdisciplinary team members (n = 226) working at four participating facilities. INTERVENTIONS: Collaboratively developed and implemented a 6-month pilot, a web-based tool to standardize and promote family-centered care. RESULTS: Survey of provider perceived efficacy in family care, satisfaction with family care, and working with families"; specific practice changes at each site; provider and facilitator perceptions of collaboration; and a validated measure to predict the probability of success of the chosen intervention. KEY RESULTS: Family-centered practices and satisfaction improved at sites with lower baseline scores (P < 0.05) and were equivalent across sites after piloting. Providers initiated specific family-centered practices that usually started at one site and spread to others through collaboration. The sites standardized family education and collaboration. Providers, believed that collaboration had produced a "culture shift" from patient-centred to family-centered care, and saw the involvement of program leadership and health care researchers as crucial to success. The scores of n measures were promising. CONCLUSIONS: Collaborations that bring clinicians, program leaders and researchers together can be beneficial to foster complex change involving interdisciplinary teams.

title: Practice development: closing the research-practice divide through the appointment of a research leader
abstract: Research shows that while most clinicians recognize the importance of evidence-based practice, achieving such practice can be difficult without the right culture of support and encouragement. This article outlines a method for improving evidence-based practice. A clinical practice-based research leader reports on the evaluation of a new type of occupational therapy task and suggests that the post has the potential to bridge the research-practice divide. Based on feedback from clinicians, research output, and impact on practice, the results provide insight into the role of the research leader in contributing to and promoting the use of evidence-based practice. It is hoped that these findings can be useful to other areas considering the strategies and support needed to develop and invest in evidence-based practice.

title: Implementation Isn't Always Perfect: A Qualitative Study Explaining Why a Training Toolkit Trial Didn't Improve Quality of Care
abstract: OBJECTIVE: Diabetes is a chronic disease commonly managed by family physicians, the most common complication of which is cardiovascular disease (CVD). Clinical practice guidelines have been developed to support clinicians in the care of diabetic patients. We conducted a pragmatic cluster randomized controlled trial (RCT) of a printed educational toolkit aimed at improving CVD management in diabetes in primary care and found no effect and indeed a possibility of harm. We conducted a qualitative assessment to examine the guideline implementation strategy used in this trial and to understand its implications. This article focuses solely on qualitative findings, as the quantitative results of RCT have already been reported elsewhere. METHODS AND RESULTS: All family practices in the province of Ontario were randomly selected to receive the training toolkit in the summer of 2009 (intervention arm) or spring 2010 (control arm). A subset of 80 family physicians (representing approximately 10% of randomized and approached practices, with enrollment of 1,592 randomly selected patients with diabetes at high risk for CVD) then participated in a chart review and reflective feedback exercise on their practice versus guideline recommendations. They were asked to fill out two forms (one pre-audit and one post-audit) to understand their awareness of pre-trial guidelines, their expectations of their individual performance before the audit, and their reflection on the audit results. In addition, individual interviews were conducted with thirteen other family physicians. Textual data from interview transcripts and written comments from pre- and post-audit forms were subjected to qualitative descriptive analysis to identify common themes and patterns. The analysis revealed four main themes: impressions of the toolset, awareness was not the problem, 'not my patient', and chart control as a more effective intervention than the toolkit. Participants found neither the toolkit content nor the dissemination strategy effective, indicating that they felt they were aware of the pre-trial guidelines. However, their accounts also noted that they may have a hard time prioritizing CVD management amid competing demands for their attention. After receiving the chart inspection results, many respondents expressed surprise that they had not performed better. They reported that the audit results would be an important motivation for behavior change. CONCLUSIONS: The qualitative findings summarized in this paper provide important insights into why the intervention was not effective. They also show that physicians have undetected needs for CVD management and that schedule control serves to identify hitherto unawareness in their practice. The findings also indicate that new intervention development and delivery methods need to be explored. This is important given the high prevalence of diabetes worldwide";" Appropriate CVD management is critical to addressing disease-related morbidity and mortality.

title: Practical Feedback Interventions: 15 Tips for Optimizing the Event
abstract: Electronic app data is increasingly used to provide feedback to drive app development. However, evidence suggests that, despite decades of experience, the effects of such interventions vary widely and do not improve over time. Guidance on providing more effective feedback is available, but is distributed across a wide range of disciplines and theoretical perspectives. Through expert interviews"; systematic reviews;" and experiences with providing, evaluating and receiving practice feedback, 15 recommendations were identified that were believed to be associated with effective feedback interventions. These recommendations are intended to provide practical guidance to quality improvement professionals, information technology developers, educators, managers and practitioners receiving such interventions. Designing interventions with these recommendations in mind should improve their impact, and examining the mechanisms underlying these recommendations will advance a stagnant literature.

title: Practice guides developed by communities of expertise: the need for a critical assessment
abstract: There is growing concern about the quality, reliability, and independence of Background Practice guides. Since no information was available on the methodological quality of guidelines developed by expert associations, we conducted a survey of those published in peer-reviewed journals.";" There is growing concern about the quality, reliability, and independence of Background Practice guides. As no information was available on the methodological quality of guidelines developed by specialist associations, we conducted a survey of those published in peer-reviewed journals.

title: Practice nurses' intentions to use clinical guidelines
abstract: BACKGROUND: Evidence suggests that although nurses increasingly use clinical guidelines to provide higher quality care, there is wide variation in their adherence to them. The utility of Planned Behavior Theory (TPB) has not previously been explored in explaining this variance in community nursing. OBJECTIVE: This article reports a study whose primary aim was to examine the utility of TPB in explaining differences in nurses' intention to offer smoking cessation advice in accordance with coronary heart disease guidelines. METHODS: A cross-sectional survey was conducted using the postal questionnaire. A 52-item questionnaire was administered to 48 practice nurses in England. The questionnaire was designed to assess components of TPB and included intentions to offer smoking cessation advice, person-reported past behaviors, attitudes, subjective norms, perceived behavioral controls (PBCs), behavioral beliefs and evaluations, normative beliefs, and motivation. conforming to and controlling beliefs and judgments. RESULTS: TPB explained up to 40% of the variance in intentions to offer smoking cessation advice. Attitudes and PBCs were the most important predictors of intention. Among other elements of TPB, implicit attitudes and indirect PBCs made significant positive contributions to explaining the variance in intent. DISCUSSION: Future trials of interventions to increase practice nurses' compliance with clinical guidelines may seek to address the elements identified in this study as important factors. More studies are needed to examine the utility of TPB in predicting the behavior of practice nurses.

title: Application parameters for the non-pharmacological treatment of chronic insomnia. American Academy of Sleep Medicine report. American Academy of Sleep Medicine Standards of Practice Committee
abstract: Insomnia is the most common sleep complaint reported to doctors. Treatment traditionally includes medication. Behavioral approaches have been available for decades, but lack of physician awareness and education, difficulty in obtaining reimbursement, and questions about effectiveness have limited their use. These practice parameters review the available evidence for various non-pharmacological treatments for insomnia. The available literature was analyzed using a supplementary article providing a background review. Evidence was graded according to previously reported criteria of the American Academy of Sleep Medicine, with reference to the criteria of the American Psychological Association. Treatments considered include: stimulus control, progressive muscle relaxation, paradoxical intent, biofeedback, sleep restriction, multicomponent cognitive behavioral therapy, sleep hygiene training, imagery training, and cognitive therapy. The improved experimental design has significantly advanced the evaluation process of non-pharmacological treatments for insomnia using guidelines outlined by the American Psychological Association (APA). Recommendations for individual therapies using the American Academy of Sleep Medicine recommendation levels for each are: Stimulus Control (Standard)"; Progressive Muscle Relaxation, Paradoxical Intention, and Biological Feedback (Guidelines); Sleep Restriction and Multicomponent Cognitive Behavioral Therapy (Options);" Sleep Hygiene Training, Imagery Training, and Cognitive Therapy lacked sufficient evidence to be recommended as single treatments. The optimal duration of treatment, who should administer the treatments, long-term outcomes and safety concerns, and the impact of treatment on quality of life are questions that need future research.

title: Implementation-level effects of interventions to improve asthma care in primary care: Pediatric Asthma Care Patient Outcomes Research Team.
abstract: Aim. To evaluate the effects of (1) a physician peer leader intervention and (2) peer leaders at the practice level, with the introduction of asthma education nurses to facilitate improvement of care. And to compare the findings with previously reported patient-level results from study enrollees. Working Setting. Data on children aged 5-17 years with asthma in 40 primary care settings enrolled in the Pediatric Asthma Care Patient Outcomes Research Team (PORT) randomized trial connected to managed health care plans were included. Study design. Primary care practices were randomly assigned to one of the two care improvement arms or routine care. Automated damage data were analyzed for 12-month periods using a repeated section design. The primary outcome was evidence of at least one controller drug distributed among patients with persistent asthma. Secondary outcomes included controller distribution among all identified asthmatics, evidence of chronic controller use, and administration of oral steroids. Healthcare use outcomes included the number of outpatient visits and hospital-based events. Key Findings. The proportion of children with permanent asthma prescription controllers increased in all study arms. No effect of interventions was detected on the proportion of controllers receiving (peer leader intervention effect 0.01, 95 percent confidence interval [CI]: -0.07, 0.08";" planned care intervention effect -0.03, 95 percent CI: -0.09, 0.02). A statistical trend was seen towards an increased number of bursts of oral corticosteroids deployed in intervention practices. Significant adjusted increases in outpatient visits were seen in the first year of intervention, 0.08-0.10 visits per year for each child, but only a statistical trend in these outcomes persisted in the second year of follow-up. No differences were detected in hospital-based events. Results. This analysis showed a slight increase in outpatient asthma visits as a result of asthma care improvement interventions using automated data. The absence of a detectable effect on drug use at the practice level differs from the positive intervention effect observed in self-reported data from trial enrollees. Analysis of automated data on unregistered adds information on the impact of maintenance improvement strategies at the application level. The benefits of practice-level interventions may accrue disproportionately to a subset of research participants. The impact of such interventions may be less pronounced at the level of practices or health plans.

title: Preclinical research in Rett syndrome: laying the foundation for translational success
abstract: In September 2011, the National Institute of Neurological Disorders and Stroke (NINDS), Eunice Kennedy Shriver National Institute of Child Health and Human Development (NICHD), International Rett Syndrome Foundation (IRSF), and Rett Syndrome Research Foundation (RSRT) National Institutes of Health (NIH), The U.S. Food and Drug Administration (FDA) held a workshop that included a broad cross-section of key scientists, clinicians, and representatives from the pharmaceutical industry and private organizations. Animal studies of Rett syndrome (RTT). The aim of the workshop was to identify important knowledge gaps and propose scientific priorities and best practices for the use of animal models in the preclinical evaluation of potential new RTT therapeutics. This review summarizes the results of the workshop and extensive follow-up discussions among participants, and includes: (1) a comprehensive summary of the physiological and behavioral phenotypes of RTT mouse models to date, and areas where further phenotypic analysis is required and the use of these models for translational studies"; (2) discussion of the impact of genetic differences between mouse models and methodological differences between laboratories on the expression and analysis of phenotypic traits, respectively; and (3) definitions of standards that the community of RTT researchers can apply for rigorous preclinical study design and transparent reporting, ensuring that decisions to initiate costly clinical trials are based on reliable preclinical data. provides.

title: Pre-commitment to choosing wisely about low-value services: a staggered wedge-set randomized trial.
abstract: Background Little is known about how to deter clinicians from ordering low-value services. Our goal was to test whether clinicians could potentially reduce low-value orders to follow their future selves (i.e., pre-committed) decision support along with Choose Wisely recommendations. Methods We conducted a 12-month staggered wedge cluster randomized trial among 45 primary care physicians and advanced practice providers in six adult primary care clinics of a US community group practice. Clinicians were invited to make a prior commitment to Choose Wise Recommendations against imaging for uncomplicated low back pain. , imaging for uncomplicated headaches and unnecessary antibiotics for acute sinusitis. Pre-committed clinicians received weekly emails with 1-6 month point-of-care pre-commitment reminders, as well as patient education brochures and resources to support communication about low-value services. The primary outcome was the difference between the control and intervention percentages of patients. visits with potentially low value orders. Secondary outcomes are the differences between the control and intervention period percentages of visits with possible alternative orders, and the differences in the control and post-intervention 3-month follow-up percentages of visits with potentially low value orders. Results Intervention was not associated with a change in the percentage of visits with potentially low-value orders overall for headaches or acute sinusitis, but was associated with an overall 1.7% increase in alternative orders (p=0.01). For low back pain, the intervention was associated with a 1.2% decrease in the percentage of visits with potentially low value orders (p=0.001) and a 1.9% increase in the percentage of visits with alternative orders (p=0.007). There was no change in follow-up. Conclusion Clinician's pre-commitment to Choose Wisely recommendations was associated with a small, unsustained decline in potentially low-value orders for only one of the three targeted conditions, and there may be an increase in alternative orders.

title: Estimating adherence to physician guideline: assessment of motivators and perceived barriers.
abstract: BACKGROUND: Although clinical practice guidelines are widely accepted as 'best practices', provider compliance remains low. OBJECTIVES: To examine the relationship between service providers' behavioral intentions and compliance with practice guidelines"; to assess the impact of perceived barriers that most inhibit compliance; and to examine the ability of factors in the Physician's Guideline Compliance Model to predict adherence intention and compliance with guidelines applied at specific practice sites. METHODS: Predecessors (attitudes) Survey research methods were used to assess the effects of providers (subjective norms, past behavior, and perceived behavioral control) on providers' intention to comply with clinical practice guidelines Provider survey I was conducted at the time of guideline introduction and survey II 4 months after administration. scores reflected positive responses to the use of guidelines. Self-reported mean compliance behavior was 65%, while compliance as assessed by chart review was 54%. The variance in physicians' behavioral intentions was approx. 68 of them are explained by the variables included in the Physician Guide Adherence Model. A significant negative relationship was found between perceived barriers and self-reported behavior, but not between perceived barriers and behavior assessed by chart review. RESULTS: Some variables, particularly perceived barriers to guideline enforcement, predicted a provider's enforcement intentions and self-reported behavior. Future guideline response efforts should identify and reduce these barriers to guideline compliance prior to implementation.

title: Estimating type 2 diabetes risk in England and Wales: possible derivation and validation of the QDScore.
abstract: OBJECTIVE To develop and validate a new diabetes risk algorithm (QDScore) for 10-year estimation of the risk of acquiring diagnosed type 2 diabetes over a 10-year period in an ethnically and socioeconomically diverse population. DESIGN Prospective open cohort study using data routinely collected from 355 general practices in England and Wales to develop the score and 176 individual practices to validate the score. PARTICIPANTS 2,540 753 patients aged 25-79 in the derivation cohort, contributed to 16 436 135 person-years of observation, and 78 081 had a case diagnosis of type 2 diabetes"; confirmation cohort with 37 535 cases of type 2 diabetes OUTCOME MEASURES Risk in the derivation cohort In the final model, self-assigned ethnicity, age, sex, body mass index, smoking status, family history of diabetes, Townsend withdrawal score, treated hypertension, cardiovascular disease, and current corticosteroid use; outcome of interest was event diabetes recorded in the general practice registry. Calibration and discrimination measures were calculated in the validation cohort. RESULTS There was a four- to five-fold variation in the risk of type 2 diabetes among different ethnic groups. Compared with the white reference group, adjusted hazard rate 4.07 (95% confidence interval 3.2) for Bangladeshi women 4 to 5.11), 4.53 (3.67 to 5.59) for Bangladeshi men, 2.15 (1.84 to 2.52) and 2.54 (2.20) for Pakistani women. For Pakistani men up to 2.93. Pakistani and Bangladeshi men had significantly higher hazard ratios than Indian men. Black African men and Chinese women had an increased risk compared to the corresponding white reference group. In the validation dataset, the model explained 51.53 percent of the variation (95% confidence interval 50.90 to 52.16) for females and 48.16% (47.52 to 48.80) for males. The risk score differed well, with a D statistic of 2.11 (95% confidence interval 2.08 to 2.14) for women and 1.97 (1.95 to 2.00) for men. The model is well calibrated. RESULTS QDScore is the first risk estimation algorithm to estimate the 10-year risk of diabetes, including both social deprivation and ethnicity, based on a prospective cohort study. The algorithm does not require laboratory testing and can be used in clinical settings as well as by the general public via a simple web calculator (www.qdscore.org).

title: Hip fracture prediction in older women: a prospective study
abstract: OBJECTIVE To evaluate the relative importance of osteoporosis of os calsis, consciousness, and mobility in the risk of hip bone fracture in older women. DESIGN Prospective study of elderly women staying in residential care for two years. SETTING 21 Private or 38 local government residences for the elderly and 4 geriatric hospitals in Doncaster and Hull. SUBJECTS 1414 Women over the age of 69, standing in private or locally authorized residential or geriatric care. Those who had bilateral hip surgery were excluded from the study. MAIN OUTCOME MEASURES Broadband ultrasonic attenuation (BUA) index, Clifton assessment procedures for aging testing (for cognition) and mobility on a six-point scale, and hip fracture over the next two-year period. RESULTS 73 Women broke their hips within two years. Mean age was not significantly different from women without fracture (85.3 (SD 5.6) v 83.9 (6.3)"; p = 0.07), but mean BUA index (40.3 (19.3) v 50.9 (22.2) ) db/MH2 ) and grip score (median 19 (interquartile range 10.5-27.0) v 24 (17-30)) were significantly lower (both p less than 0.001). These variables had independent associations with hip fracture. Women with fractures had a significantly lower score for the psychomotor component of the cognitive test (4.5 (1-8) v 7 (2-10); p was less than 0.0025 and was significantly more mobile (1(1-3) v 3 ( 1-6); p less than 0.02). When we subdivided women according to high, moderate, and low scores for the BUA index and awareness testing, the high-risk group (118 women) with a low BUA index and awareness score emerged, and the fracture incidence was : 12.8%;" the incidence of fracture in the lowest risk group (136 women) with a high BUA index and cognitive score was only 1.5% (relative risk 8.4 (95% confidence) range -2.0 to 35.5]. Further analysis showed that those most at risk were, in addition, the most mobile, but women who were less active had a low incidence of fractures independent of the BUA index (1.2%, high index, v 0.9%, low index). CONCLUSIONS Older women most at risk of hip fractures are those with a low BUA index, low cognitive test score, and high mobility. Improving bone strength and awareness in older women can reduce the incidence of hip fractures.

title: Predictors of colorectal cancer screening from patients enrolled in a managed care health plan.
abstract: BACKGROUND: Despite increasing recognition of the importance of colorectal cancer (CRC) screening in reducing cancer mortality, national screening rates are low, indicating a critical need to understand the barriers and remedies to underuse of CRC screening tests. METHODS: Using results from independent cross-sectional telephone surveys with patients > 50 years of age or before (2000"; n=498) and after (2003; n=482) quality improvement intervention for CRC screening in a large managed care health plan, stool Trends and predictors of CRC screening by occult blood testing (FOBT) and/or endoscopy (flexible sigmoidoscopy/colonoscopy) were reviewed from a patient perspective RESULTS: In 2000, patient-reported screening rates within guidelines were 38% for any test, endoscopy 23 and 22% for FOBT In 2003, screening rates increased to 50% for any test, 39% for endoscopy, and 24% for FOBT. Discussing CRC with a doctor significantly increased the odds of getting screened (FOBT: odds ratio). [OR], 2.09 [95% confidence interval (95% CI), 1.47-2.96]; endoscopy: OR, 2.33 [95% CI, 1.67-3.26], and any test: OR, 2.86 [ 95% CI, 2.06- 3.96]) and notice to the CRC in general their disability reduced the probability of being screened (FOBT: OR, 0.76 [95% C] I, 0.60-0.95]; endoscopy: OR, 0.74 [95% CI, 0.60-0.92];" and any test: OR, 0.66 [95% CI, 0.54-0.80]. RESULTS: Evidence found despite increased screening rates over the 3-year period. The 2 strongest predictors of obtaining CRC screening were provider impact and patient barriers to CRC screening in general, signaling the need for multi-level interventions that target both the provider and the patient.

title: Predictors of fatigue 30 days after completing anthracycline plus taxane adjuvant chemotherapy for breast cancer.
abstract: OBJECTIVES/OBJECTIVES: To determine the predictors of fatigue 30 days after completing adjuvant chemotherapy for breast cancer and whether there is a difference between the behavioral sleep intervention and the healthy eating attention control group in predicting fatigue. DESIGN: Descriptive, exploratory, secondary analysis of a randomized clinical trial. Setting: Outpatient oncology patients in a city in the midwest USA. EXAMPLE: 96 women aged 29-83 years, 72% married, 95% white, diagnosed with stage I-IIIA breast cancer, receiving adjuvant anthracycline and taxane chemotherapy. METHODS: Participants were randomized to either a behavioral sleep intervention group or an attention control group. Participants completed data collection before and during the peak and recovery days of the first chemotherapy treatment cycle and after the last treatment. MAIN RESEARCH VARIABLES: Fatigue, circadian rhythms of activity, objective and subjective sleep-wake, and objective and subjective activity-rest. RESULTS: Predictors of fatigue were less total sleep time before treatment, higher fatigue before treatment and at peak, and less energy upon waking on recovery days. In the control group, predictors of higher fatigue were higher fatigue before treatment, higher body mass index, higher positive lymph node count, and less daytime dysfunction. For the intervention group, lower peak activity at the peak of initial treatment differently predicted fatigue. CONCLUSIONS: The results suggest that sleep intervention group participants who maintained balanced activity with sleep at the peak of initial treatment benefited most from the intervention. PRACTICES FOR NURSING: Nurses should screen for fatigue prior to initial chemotherapy treatment and at regular intervals, further evaluate poor sleep in patients reporting 4 or greater (on a 0-10 scale) fatigue, and use evidence-based guidelines for selection. appropriate interventions.

title: Predictors of provider recommendation for HPV vaccine among young adult men and women: findings from a cross-sectional survey.
abstract: Background: Although doctor's recommendation is one of the strongest predictors of human papillomavirus (HPV) vaccine, it is unclear to whom doctors recommend the vaccine. To guide intervention efforts, this study investigated predictors of participant-reported physician recommendation for HPV vaccination among young adults in the United States. METHODS: Men and women aged 18-26 (N=223) were recruited online through Craigslist, a popular classified ads website. From September 2013 to March 2014, classifieds were published in the 25 largest cities in the USA. Participants completed a questionnaire that evaluated demographic and sociopolitical characteristics, sexual history, HPV vaccination history, and whether they had received HPV vaccination recommendations from a doctor or healthcare provider. Provider. RESULTS: Fifty-three percent reported receiving a recommendation for HPV vaccine and 45% reported receiving >/=1 dose of HPV vaccine. Participants who received advice were more than 35 times more likely to receive >/=1 dose of HPV vaccine than participants who did not receive advice. Bivariate and multivariate correlations of the provider recommendation were determined. Results from the multivariate model showed that younger (18-21 years), female, and White participants with health insurance (i.e., another type such as employer-sponsored or military-sponsored) were more likely to report receiving a recommendation for HPV vaccination. . CONCLUSIONS: The results show that physician recommendation practices for HPV vaccine vary according to patient characteristics. The findings highlight the key role of the healthcare provider in promoting HPV vaccination and have important implications for future HPV vaccine interventions with young adults.

title: Preferred reporting items for systematic review and meta-analysis protocols (PRISMA-P) 2015: elaboration and explanation
abstract: Systematic review and meta-analysis protocols allow planning and documenting review methods, act as a safeguard against arbitrary decision making during review conduct, enable readers to assess the existence of selective reporting versus completed reviews, and allow duplication of effort and potentially rapid collaboration when made public. reduce. Evidence is accumulating to document the existence of excessive duplication of selective reporting and reviews on the same or similar issues, and many calls have been made for review protocols to be documented and made public. Various efforts have emerged in recent years to rectify these issues, including the development of an international registry for prospective reviews (PROSPERO) and the launch of the first open access journal dedicated to the exclusive publication of systematic review products, including protocols (BioMed Central's Systematic Reviews). . . Continuing these efforts and building on the PRISMA (Preferred Reporting Elements for Systematic Reviews and Meta-analysis) guidelines, an international group of experts has created a guideline to improve the transparency, accuracy, completeness, and frequency of documented systematic reviews and meta-analysis. protocols--PRISMA-P (for protocols) 2015. The PRISMA-P checklist contains 17 items that are considered essential and are considered minimum components of a systematic review or meta-analysis protocol. This PRISMA-P 2015 Explanation and Detailing document provides readers with a full understanding and proof of the necessity of each item, as well as a model example from an existing published protocol. This document should be read in conjunction with the PRISMA-P 2015 statement. Systematic review authors and evaluators are strongly encouraged to use PRISMA-P when preparing and evaluating review protocols.

title: Prescribing habits of GPs in choosing an empirical antibiotic regimen for lower respiratory tract infections in adults in Sicily
abstract: The survey was conducted between September 1995 and May 1996 to define prescriptive behavior among Sicilian general practitioners (GPs) when choosing an empirical antibiotic regimen for LRTIs in adult patients and to begin an educational process involving the same GPs in decisions. when following prescriptions and local guidelines. Each GP completed a questionnaire that ended with an antibiotic prescription for each therapeutic intervention. In the questionnaire, the characteristics of the patient, the diseases to be treated and drug prescription were also questioned. In order to evaluate the prescriptive behavior of the physicians regarding the patient's symptoms, the opinion of the physicians was sought about the severity assessment of the infectious disease before choosing the antibiotic treatment. Of all the upcoming Sicilian practitioners, 76 doctors from 25 Sicilian towns with a patient population of 96,630 agreed to participate. The doctors used 49 different molecules and six different combinations of the two antibiotics. The most commonly used antibacterial agents were cephalosporins (55.0%). Penicillins (11.7%), fluoroquinolones (11.4%), macrolides (10.1%), and penicillin combinations together with beta-lactamase inhibitors (7.9%) represented 41.1% of the remaining antibiotic prescriptions. The choice of route of administration was significantly influenced by the age of the patients, the symptoms and signs of the disease, and the presence of concomitant diseases rather than the bacteria suspected of causing the disease. The highly marked variation in the pattern of prescribing antibiotics for LRTIs among Sicilian GPs reflects the lack or lack of knowledge of any local or national guidelines on the management of these diseases.

title: Prescription data as a tool in pharmacotherapy supervision (I). General Evaluations
abstract: This article discusses how prescription data available from pharmacies can be used as a tool to support improving prescribing behavior. For optimal use of prescription data in pharmacotherapeutic supervision, the specific purpose of the audit meeting should be clear. Appropriate measures (quality, volume, cost of drug selection) should then be selected for the presentation and discussion of prescribing. Recommendations for adequate measures are given for the various purposes of audit meetings. For each stage of behavior change, the article explains why and how prescription data can make a useful contribution. Finally, recommendations on prerequisites for optimal use of prescription data are given. Important factors are that prescribing data adequately covers the patient population of physicians, information on the extent of represcribing is needed, and prescribing drugs for multiple indications can cause difficulties in interpreting charts. With this information in mind, prescribing feedback can be tailored to the needs of the control groups and targeted to the intervention followed.

title: Post-Occupational Exposure HIV Prophylaxis Prescription by Emergency Physicians: An Analysis on Prescription Accuracy and Compliance
abstract: We conducted a retrospective analysis of data from a prospective nPEP (Non-Occupational Post-Exposure Prophylaxis) registry based on patients consulted in an academic Emergency department located in Brussels, Belgium. Here we review 1,357 cases consulted from January 2011 to December 2013. The aim of the study is to determine whether emergency room physicians prescribe nPEP according to national guideline with support from IDS (infectious disease specialists). Because this intervention has a high cost, we wanted to confirm that treatment was properly allocated to high-risk patients. We also wanted to determine whether adherence to nPEP when prescribed by the Emergency Physician differs from literature reports. Finally, we wanted to explain the population counseling for nPEP in our center. Emergency physicians prescribed nPEP more frequently at high-risk exposures (98.6%) than at moderate-risk exposures (53.2%)";" adequate allocation of resources from a public health perspective. When nPEP was evaluated according to Belgian guidelines, prescription compliance was 98.8%. In our study, compliance with nPEP prescribed by emergency physicians was 60%. Compliance was highest in MSM (Men Who Have Sex With Men), while victims of sexual assault showed the lowest compliance. Altogether, this study demonstrates that ED physicians can safely and adequately prescribe nPEP when supported by comprehensive guidelines. Recognizing the intrinsic differences within heterogeneous populations consulted for nPEP may improve adherence to this costly public health intervention.

title: Prescription omega-3s: an overview for nurse practitioners
abstract: Nurse practitioners (NPs) often take a multidisciplinary approach when treating and educating patients. Collaboration with a registered dietitian is not uncommon when treating patients with severe hypertriglyceridemia (triglycerides [TGs] >/=500 mg/dL). Patients with severe hypertriglyceridemia should be treated and managed to normalize TG levels (TG level <150 mg/dL). Treatment for severe hypertriglyceridemia is usually 3-fold, including lifestyle changes, dietary modification, and pharmacotherapy. Therapeutic lifestyle changes are often the first step in lowering TG levels. Registered dietitians encourage a heart-healthy diet rich in fruits and vegetables. There is growing evidence to support the consumption of eicosapentaenoic acid and docosahexaenoic acid to reduce TGs. When lifestyle and dietary changes do not effectively lower TGs, NPs will recommend pharmacological therapy as the next step. A viable pharmacological option includes prescription omega-3 (P-OM3) fatty acid ethyl esters. Each 4 g/day dose of P-OM3 provides 465 mg of eicosapentaenoic acid and 375 mg of docosahexaenoic acid. Clinical trials show that P-OM3 can safely and effectively reduce TGs by 45% in patients with severe hypertriglyceridemia. Nurse practitioners play an important role in the treatment of severe hypertriglyceridemia and in educating patients about lifestyle and dietary changes that can greatly affect patients' health.

title: Pressure ulcer treatment: clinical guidelines
abstract: Like any intervention, clinical guidelines can and should be evaluated systematically. Evaluation is important as an intervention that appears to improve care may not do so in practice. In addition, the guidelines are based on practitioners' behavior change, and failing to do so can undermine potential health gains. The key areas covered here are the evaluation of the guidelines themselves and their impact on care.

title: The Prevalence of a Healthy Lifestyle Among Individuals with Cardiovascular Disease in High, Middle, and Low Income Countries The Prospective Urban Rural Epidemiology (PURE) Study
abstract: Significance Little is known about the adoption of healthy lifestyle behaviors among individuals with coronary heart disease (CHD) or stroke in communities in various countries around the world. Purpose To examine the prevalence of smoking avoidance or quitting, healthy eating and regular physical activity in individuals with CHD or stroke. Design, Setting, and Participants Prospective Urban Rural Epidemiology (PURE) was a large, prospective cohort study using an epidemiological survey of 153 996 adults aged 35 to 70 from 628 urban and rural communities in 3 high-income countries (HICs). ), 7 upper middle income countries (UMICs), 3 lower middle income countries (LMICs) and 4 low income countries (LICs) registered between January 2003 and December 2009. Main Outcome Measures Smoking status (current, former, never), exercise level (low, <600 metabolic equivalent tasks [MET]-min/week"; moderate, 600-3000 MET-min/week; high, >3000 MET- min/week) and diet (classified by the Food Frequency Questionnaire and defined using the Alternative Healthy Eating Index) Results Self-reported CHD (past event: median, 5.0 [interquartile range {IQR}, 2.0-10.0] years ago) or 7519 with stroke Among subjects (past event: median, 4.0 [IQR, 2.0-8.0] years ago), 18.5% (95% CI, 17.6-19.4%) continued to smoke; only 35.1% (95% CI, 29.6) -41.0% ) did a high level of work or leisure-related physical activity and 39.0% (95% CI, 30.0-48.7%) ate healthily; 14.3% (95% CI, 11.7-17.3%) ) did not undertake any of the 3 healthy lifestyle behaviors and 4.3% (95% CI, 3.1%-5.8%) had all 3. Overall, 52.5% (95% CI, 50%) .7-54.3% quitting smoking (by income country classification: 74.9% [95% CI, 71.1-78.6%] in HIC; 56.5% [95% CI, 53%] in UMIC , 4-58,6]; 42.6% [95] %CI, 39.6%–45.6% on LMIC] and 38.1% [95% CI, 33.1%–43.2%] on LIC). Physical activity levels increased with increasing country income, but this trend was not statistically significant. The lowest prevalence of healthy eating was in LIC (25.8%; 95% CI, 13.0-44.8%), LMIC (43.2%; "95% CI, 30.0%-57.4%), UMIC (45.1%, 95%) CI, Among a sample of patients with a CHD or stroke from countries with different income levels, healthy lifestyle behaviors were lower, whereas in poorer countries more was also at low levels.

title: Prevalence of Chlamydia trachomatis infection in women undergoing cervical smear test
abstract: OBJECTIVE To determine the prevalence of sexually transmitted diseases in patients with normal and abnormal cervical smears. DESIGN A prospective study of asymptomatic women with normal cervical smears and newly referred patients with abnormal smears presenting to their GP and colposcopy clinic. SETTING A hospital-based colposcopy clinic and an urban general practice (list size 5500) in the north-west of Glasgow. SUBJECTS 197 asymptomatic women presenting to their general practitioners for cervical smear tests and 101 randomly selected patients who came to the colposcopy clinic to search for abnormal smears. MAIN OUTCOME MEASURES Presence of various sexually transmitted infections as determined by culture and serological testing. RESULTS Six of 101 women with cytological abnormalities had existing culture-proven chlamydial infection and none had gonococcal infection";" Of 197 women with normal smears, 24 (12%) had chlamydial infection and two had gonorrhea. Serological studies for antibody specific to Chlamydia trachomatis showed that a large proportion of patients in both groups were exposed to this agent. There was no significant difference between the groups in the prevalence of any sexually transmitted disease studied. CONCLUSION Women in northwest Glasgow have a high prevalence of chlamydial infections, regardless of their cervical cytological status.

title: Prevalence of Nonpolypoid (Straight and Depressed) Colorectal Neoplasms in Asymptomatic and Symptomatic Adults
abstract: Context Colorectal cancer is the second leading cause of cancer-related death in the United States. Prevention is focused on the detection and removal of polypoid neoplasms. Data on the significance of non-polypoid colorectal neoplasms (NP-CRNs) are limited. Objectives To determine the prevalence of NP-CRNs in the Gazi hospital population and to characterize their association with colorectal cancer. Design, Environment, and Patients Cross-sectional study at a California veterans hospital with 1819 patients undergoing elective colonoscopy between July 2003 and June 2004. Main Outcome Measures Endoscopic appearance, location, size, histology, and depth of invasion of neoplasms. Results The overall prevalence of NP-CRNs was 9.35% (95% CI [95% CI], 8.05-10.78"; n=170). NP-CRN in subpopulations for screening, surveillance, and symptoms The prevalence of . 6.01% (95% CI, 4.17-8.34%, respectively n = 33) Overall prevalence of NP-CRNs with invasive carcinoma in situ or submucosal was 0.82% (95% CI, 0.46-1.36%; n) =15), prevalence in the screening population was 0.32% (95% CI, 0.04-1.17%; n = 2) Overall, NP-CRNs were more likely to have carcinomas (odds ratio, 9.78; 95%) than polypoid lesions, regardless of size. GA, 3.93-24.4), positive size-adjusted association of NP-CRNs with invasive carcinoma in situ or submucosal, screening (odd ratio, 2.01; 95% CI, 0.27-15.3) and surveillance (odds ratio, 63.7) ;" was also observed in subpopulations for 95%). CI, 9.41-431). The depressive type had the highest risk (33%). Non-polypoid colorectal neoplasms containing carcinomas were smaller in diameter than those with polypoids (mean [SD] diameter, 15.9 [10.2] mm versus 19.2 [9.6] mm, respectively). Procedure times did not change significantly compared to historical controls. Conclusion In this group of senior patients, NP-CRNs were relatively common lesions diagnosed during routine colonoscopy and had a greater association with carcinoma than polypoid neoplasms, regardless of size.

title: Prevalence of War-Related Mental Health Conditions and Relation to Displacement Status in the Post-War Jaffna Region, Sri Lanka
abstract: Context Around 2.7 million people worldwide are internally displaced each year (taking refuge in their home country's safe zones) as a result of armed conflict. Although the psychological impact of war is well documented, less is known about the mental health symptoms of forced displacement among internally displaced persons. Objectives To estimate the prevalence of the most common war-related mental health conditions, post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD), anxiety and depression symptoms in the post-war Jaffna District of Sri Lanka, and to evaluate the relationship between displacement and these conditions. Design, Environment and Participants Between July and September 2009, a cross-sectional multistage cluster sample survey was conducted among 1517 Jaffna District households that included 2 IDP camps. The response rate was 92% (1448 participants, 1409 eligible participants). Two percent (n = 80) of respondents were already displaced, 29.5% (n = 539) were recently resettled, and 68.5% (n = 790) were long-term residents. Bivariate analyzes followed by multivariate logistic regression models were performed to determine the relationship between displacement status and mental health. Main Outcome Measures PTSD, anxiety, and depression symptom criteria as measured by the Harvard Trauma Questionnaire and the Hopkins Symptom ChecklistÂ¨C25. Results The overall prevalence of PTSD, anxiety, and depression symptoms was 7.0% (95% CI [CI], 5.1-9.7%), 32.6% (95% CI, 28.5%-36.9%), and 22.2% (95% CI, %, respectively). 18.2-26.5%). Participants who were already displaced had PTSD (odds ratio [OR], 2.71"; 95% CI, 1.28-5.73), anxiety (OR, 2.91; 95% CI, 1.89-4.48), and depression (OR, 4.55; 95% CI, 2.47) -8.39) compared to long-term residents Recently resettled residents were more likely to report PTSD symptoms than long-term residents (OR, 1.96;" 95% CI, 1.11-3.47). However, after controlling for trauma exposure, displacement was no longer associated with mental health symptoms. Conclusion Among residents of the Jaffna District in Sri Lanka, the prevalence of symptoms of war-related mental health conditions was significant and significantly correlated with displacement status and exposure to underlying trauma.

title: Prevention and management of amateurism in medical faculties
abstract: Professionalism is a required competency for medical students, residents, GPs, and academic faculty. Faculty members must adhere to a code of conduct or risk discipline. The authors describe unprofessional issues in academic medicine that result in the filing of complaints or allegations of faculty malpractice, and outline strategies for early intervention and prevention. Writers, vice deans and assistant deans, and the executive director of the office of faculty affairs at a major U.S. medical school have handled many allegations of unprofessional behavior over the past decade. They provide case examples of behavior such as disrespect, inappropriate language and behavior, non-cooperation with healthcare team members, and sexual harassment/discrimination. They discuss factors that make these behaviors difficult to assess, including varying definitions of respect, different cultural norms, and false claims. The authors provide recommendations for prevention and intervention, including early detection, performance management, education about sexual harassment, and referrals to professional coaches, anger management classes, and faculty staff assistance programs.

title: Caries prevention in young children of Bangladeshi immigrant families in New York: perspectives of mothers and pediatricians
abstract: OBJECTIVE: Childhood caries is common in South Asian immigrant families. Few children go to the dentist at 12 months of age, as current guidelines recommend. The pediatric visit has significant potential to connect children to preventive care. The aim of this study was to understand the barriers and facilitators of caries prevention for young children of Bangladeshi immigrant families in New York. Qualitative data were collected as a preliminary step in the development of an oral health counseling intervention for South Asian children. BASIC DESIGN: Qualitative interviews were conducted with Bangladeshi mothers on child nutrition and prevention of oral health. Qualitative interviews were conducted with pediatricians about their caregiving experience. Data were analyzed using standard qualitative approaches. SETTING: Pediatric practices serving low-income Bangladeshi immigrants in New York. PARTICIPANTS: 26 mothers with children aged 6-24 months receiving service in five pediatric centers and 15 pediatricians providing care in these settings. RESULTS: Both mothers and pediatricians described risky feeding practices, communication problems, and lack of compliance. Oral health for young children was a low priority for some mothers. Many, however, were concerned about childhood cavities but lacked the skills or resources to reduce their risk of cavities. CONCLUSIONS: The results support our plan to develop an empowerment-based counseling intervention to address caries risk in children. Pediatric dentists should be aware of the barriers to caries prevention in this group.

title: Prevention of child abuse and neglect with a home nurse visit program: Limiting effects of domestic violence
abstract: Context Home visiting for families with young children has been promoted as an effective way to prevent child maltreatment, but few studies have examined the circumstances in which such programs achieve this goal. Purpose To investigate whether the presence of domestic violence limits the effects of home nurse visitation interventions in reducing confirmed reports of child abuse and neglect. Fifteen-year follow-up study of a randomized trial. Build a Semirural community in New York. Participants The follow-up study included 324 mothers and children of 400 socially disadvantaged pregnant women who had not had a live birth before and who were consecutively enrolled between April 1978 and September 1980. Interventions Families were randomly assigned to receive routine perinatal care (control group";" n = 184 follow-ups), routine care plus home nurse visits during pregnancy only (n = 100), or routine care plus home nurse visits during pregnancy. and by the child's second birthday (n = 116). Key Consequence Measures Number of verified reports isolated from government records and analyzed by the treatment group during the entire 15-year period in which the study child was included as the subject regardless of the perpetrator's identity, or the mother was included as the perpetrator regardless of the child's identity, and the level of domestic violence at home as measured by the Conflict Tactics Scale. Results Families who received home visits during pregnancy and infancy had significantly fewer reports of child maltreatment involving the mother as the perpetrator (P = .01) or the study child as the subject (P = .04) than families who did not receive home visits. The number of reports of maltreatment of mothers who received home visits only during pregnancy was not different from the control group. In mothers who were visited until the child's second birthday, the effect of treatment decreased as the level of domestic violence increased. Of the women who reported 28 or fewer cases of domestic violence (79% of the sample), mothers who made home visits over a 15-year period received significantly fewer reports of child maltreatment than mothers who did not receive longer-term interventions (P = .01). However, this intervention did not significantly reduce child maltreatment among mothers who reported more than 28 cases of domestic violence (21% of samples). Conclusions The existence of domestic violence may limit the effectiveness of interventions to reduce cases of child abuse and neglect.

title: Prevention of coronary heart disease and stroke with aggressive statin therapy in older adults using a team management model
abstract: OBJECTIVES: The aims of this review were to highlight recent clinical research results regarding the safety and efficacy of statin therapy in adults 65 years of age and older and to examine how nurses (NPs) and physician assistants (PAs) work with physicians. team can better serve the needs of this fastest growing subset of the US population at high risk for cardiovascular events, including stroke. DATA SOURCES: This report has been compiled through a review of the scientific literature on the safety and efficacy of statin therapy, including effects on cardiovascular, coronary, and stroke endpoints, with particular reference to clinical trial results in elderly patients. CONCLUSIONS: Recent guidelines emphasize that age alone is not a reason to stop statin therapy in older adults. However, despite the evidence highlighted in this review that suggests that older patients can derive significant benefits from statin therapy, studies have consistently shown an inverse relationship between age and treatment propensity. Often, elderly patients have multiple risk factors and many chronic comorbid conditions that complicate and hinder management in many intensive clinical practices. More comprehensive guidelines for the use of statin therapy in the elderly, including recommendations for treatment goals and developing a framework for the use of statins in stroke prevention, will assist caregivers in the management of this high-risk population. Finally, both NPs and PAs are well-trained and well-placed to manage patients with chronic stable cardiovascular disease (CVD). APPLICATIONS FOR IMPLEMENTATION: Implementing a multidisciplinary team approach to identify individuals at risk and provide them with education, counseling and effective statin therapy will aid efforts to reduce the increased risk of morbidity and mortality associated with CVD in older adults.

title: Prevention of depression in at-risk adolescents: a randomized controlled trial
abstract: Context Adolescent children of depressed parents are at a significantly higher risk of developing depressive disorders. While some smaller targeted prevention studies have found that the risk of depression can be reduced, these results have yet to be replicated and extended to large-scale, at-risk populations in different settings. Purpose To determine the effects of a group of cognitive behavioral (CB) prevention programs compared to usual care in preventing the onset of depression. Design, Setting, and Participants A multicenter randomized controlled trial of 316 adolescents (13-17 years of age) with current or pre-existing depressive disorder from August 2003 to February 2006 in 4 US cities. Adolescents had a past history. depression, present high but sub-diagnostic depressive symptoms, or both. Evaluations were made at baseline, after 8 weeks of intervention and 6 months of continuation. Intervention Adolescents were randomly assigned to a CB prevention program consisting of 8-week, 90-minute group sessions followed by 6-month follow-up sessions or were assigned alone to receive usual care. Main Outcome Measure The proportion and hazard ratio (HR) of a probable or definite depressive episode (ie, depressive symptom rating score Â¡Ã 4) for at least 2 weeks, as diagnosed by clinical interviewers. Results During post-continuation follow-up, the proportion and HR of depressive episodes were lower for those in a CB prevention program than those in normal care (21.4% vs. 32.7%"; HR, 0.63; 95% confidence interval [CI ], 0.40- 0.98) Adolescents in the CB prevention program also showed significantly greater improvement in self-reported depressive symptoms than those in usual care (coefficient, ?1.1; z = ?2.2; P = .03). CI, 2.29-15.58; P = .001) Among adolescents whose parents were not depressed at baseline, the CB prevention program was more effective than normal care in preventing the onset of depression (11.7) 40.5% vs. HR, 0.24; 95% GA, 0.11–0.50), for adolescents with a currently depressed parent, the CB prevention program was no more effective than normal care in preventing event depression (31.2% vs. 24.3%; HR , 1.43;" 95% CI, 0.76-2.67). Conclusion The CB prevention program had a significant prevention effect during the 9-month follow-up period based on both clinical diagnoses and self-reported depressive symptoms, but this effect was not evident for adolescents with a currently depressed parent.

title: Preventing falls in community-dwelling older adults: US Preventive Services Task Force advisory statement
