abstract: DESCRIPTION: Update to the 1996 US Preventive Services Task Force (USPSTF) advisory statement on counseling to prevent home and recreational injuries, including falls. METHODS: The USPSTF reviewed recent evidence on the effectiveness and harms of primary care interventions for preventing falls in community-dwelling older adults. Interventions were grouped into 5 main categories: multifactor clinical assessment (with or without direct intervention), clinical management (with or without screening), clinical education or behavioral counseling, home hazard modification, and exercise or physical therapy. RECOMMENDATIONS: The USPSTF recommends exercise or physical therapy and vitamin D supplementation to prevent falls in community-dwelling adults 65 years and older at high risk of falls. (Class B recommendation) The USPSTF does not automatically recommend performing an in-depth multifactorial risk assessment in conjunction with comprehensive management of identified risks to prevent falls in community-dwelling adults aged 65 and over because benefit is unlikely. In determining whether this service is appropriate in individual cases, patients and clinicians should consider the balance of benefits and harms based on previous falls, comorbid medical conditions, and patient values. (Class C recommendation).

title: Recommended Preventive Care (PCA)/Operative Care Advice (OCA)--classification of caries by management option
abstract: number of systems and classifications are currently used by clinicians, epidemiologists, and clinical research professionals to classify carious lesions into different grades. These systems are based on the depth of the lesion and/or the presence/absence of macroscopic cavitation. To improve the relevance and comparability of such systems in light of the growing knowledge of disease process, lesion behavior, and caries management options, the authors propose a new categorization system that distinguishes between lesions that normally require operative intervention and lesions that require operative intervention. don't do that. In the future, it is recommended that, in addition to existing conventional criteria, diagnostic systems should allow results to be expressed in terms of 1) lesions for which appropriate non-invasive Preventive Care is Recommended (PCA lesions) and 2) lesions that are operative. Care Recommended (OCA lesions). Locally acceptable subdivisions may need to be developed and adopted for certain specific applications. Adoption of this additional terminology and approach in the future will aid communication between the different groups involved in caries diagnosis and research. In addition to facilitating the dissemination of research findings, it can help "guide" researchers working on caries diagnostic methods to focus on techniques that will assist in the accurate assessment of lesion activity and behavior. Such a focus should also increase our understanding of treatment decision making and encourage the development of clinical guidelines. The ability to keep existing criteria in parallel for local and other purposes will maintain comparability with previously collected data.

title: The preventive evidence for practice (PEP) study: application of guidelines to prevent primary vascular disease in a general practice protocol for a cluster randomized controlled trial.
abstract: BACKGROUND: There are significant gaps in the implementation and adoption of evidence-based guideline recommendations for cardiovascular disease (CVD) and diabetes in Australian general practice. This study protocol describes the randomized cluster trial methodology to evaluate the efficacy of a model aimed at improving the application of these guidelines in Australian general practice, developed in collaboration between researchers, non-governmental organizations and the profession. METHODS: We hypothesize that the intervention will change the behavior of clinicians and patients resulting in improvements in the registration of lifestyle and physiological risk factors (20%) and increased adherence to guideline recommendations for: management of CVD and diabetes risk factors (up to 20 %)" and those at risk. patients' lifestyle and physiological risk factors (5%) Thirty-two common practices will be randomly selected in a 1:1 distribution to receive intervention or continue usual care after classification by state Intervention will be delivered via: small group education; preventive care audit of patient records to determine" and application facilitation visits tailored to the needs of applications. Outcome data will be drawn from electronic medical records and qualitative assessment from patient surveys and provider and patient interviews. DISCUSSION: We plan to widely disseminate study findings and directly inform implementation strategies by non-governmental organizations, including governments, professional bodies and partner organisations.

title: Preventive interventions for postpartum psychosis
abstract: BACKGROUND: Postpartum psychosis is a life-threatening condition worldwide that affects one to two out of every 1,000 new mothers. It has a sudden onset within a month after birth. Affected new mothers quickly develop overt psychosis, cognitive impairment, and erratic behavior. Factors that increase the risk of postpartum psychosis include single mothers, older women, or women with a past psychiatric history, and a family history of affective psychosis, prenatal depression, and autoimmune thyroid dysfunction. The risk of future postpartum recurrence is 25% to 57%. Preventive interventions for postpartum psychosis aim to identify women with risk factors, early recognition of possible psychosis through screening, and preventive medication. Mood stabilizers, antipsychotic medications, and hormone therapy may be helpful in preventing postpartum psychotic episodes in at-risk women. OBJECTIVES: To explore the best available evidence for interventions aimed at preventing postpartum psychosis. SEARCH METHODS: Using the Cochrane Schizophrenia Group's search strategy, we searched the Cochrane Schizophrenia Group Trials Register and the Cochrane Central Registry of Controlled Trials (CENTRAL) in October 2012. SELECTION CRITERIA: All randomized controlled trials on the prevention of postpartum psychosis. DATA COLLECTION AND ANALYSIS: Two review authors reviewed all citations to ensure reliable selection. If we had included relevant studies, we planned to assess the methodological quality of the identified studies using the criteria proposed in the Cochrane Handbook for Systematic Reviews of Detections. The two compilation authors would have independently extracted the data. For homogeneous binary data, we planned to calculate the hazard ratio (RR), the 95% confidence interval (CI), and the number needed to treat for benefit/harm (NNTB/NNTH) on a goal-to-treat basis. MAIN RESULTS: There are no studies included in this review. The electronic search produced three relevant references, among which we identified two formerly planned studies that seemed to have never started, and excluded one study because it was the report of a case series. AUTHOR CONCLUSIONS: This is not an empty review - it is a review full of unanswered questions. Despite the growing interest in women's mental health, the literature on postpartum psychosis is still very limited. Clinicians seem to have no choice but to continue their current practice, guided only by various clinical judgments. Women and their relatives at risk for postpartum psychosis are justified in being disappointed in the medical/research association. A post hoc PubMed topic (not methodology-specific) study identified mainly case series. Policy makers do not have empirical evidence on which to base their guidelines. Of course, preventive interventions for postpartum psychosis are difficult to justify with confidence without well-designed, well-conducted, and well-reported randomized studies. Current publications suggest that such work is possible and that research funders may want to make it a priority.

title: Compliance of primary care clinicians with guidelines for the management of chronic musculoskeletal pain: results from a study of the efficacy of a collaborative approach to pain
abstract: OBJECTIVE: We evaluated primary care clinician-provided guideline-based care, predictors of documented guideline-compliant care, and association with pain-related functionality as documented in patients' medical records. Patients participated in a randomized trial of collaborative care for chronic musculoskeletal pain. The intervention included patient and primary care clinician education, symptom monitoring, and feedback to clinicians by the intervention team. METHODS: To assess compliance with the evidence-based treatment guidelines on which our intervention was based, we developed the Pain Process Checklist (PPC), an 8-item chart review tool. We then reviewed the electronic medical records of 365 senior patients treated for 12 months by 42 primary care clinicians. Intervention status, demographic and clinical variables were tested as predictors of PPC scores using generalized estimation equations (GEE). GEE was also used to test whether PPC scores predicted treatment response (>/= 30% reduction in Roland-Morris Disability Questionnaire score). RESULTS: Care rates consistent with the documented guideline varied widely among PPC items; from 94% of patients addressing pain to 17% of patients using opioids whose side effects were addressed. Intervention status was unrelated to item scores, and PPC-7 totals did not differ significantly between patients receiving intervention and usual treatment (61.2%, standard error [SE] = 3.3% vs. 55.2%, SE = 2.6%, P = 0.15). In a multivariate model, higher PPC-7 scores were associated with obtaining a prescription for opioids (odds ratio [OR] = 1.07, P = 0.007) and lower PPC-7 scores were associated with patient age (10-year difference OR = 0.97, P). associated. = 0.004). Finally, intervention patients who received quantitative pain and depression assessments were less likely to respond to treatment (18% vs. 33% assessed vs. P = 0.008 vs. 13% vs. 28%, P = 0.001). CONCLUSIONS: As measured by medical record review, additional education and clinician feedback did not increase the delivery of pain care consistent with documented guidelines, and adherence to guidelines by primary care clinicians did not improve clinical outcomes in patients with chronic musculoskeletal pain.

title: Experience of primary care clinicians prescribing HIV pre-exposure prophylaxis at a specialized community health center in Boston: lessons from early adopters
abstract: INTRODUCTION: An estimated 1.2 million Americans have indications for using antiretroviral pre-exposure prophylaxis (PrEP) to prevent transmission of HIV. For many of these at-risk individuals, the best opportunity to learn about and receive information about PrEP will be during routine visits to their general primary care clinician. However, very few general clinicians have prescribed PrEP because of practical concerns about providing PrEP in primary care settings. The experience of specialist primary care clinicians prescribing PrEP can inform the feasibility of PrEP delivery by general specialists. METHODS: During January-February 2015, 35 primary care clinicians at a Boston community health center specializing in the care of sexual and gender minorities completed anonymous questionnaires about their experience and practice of PrEP service. Responses were analyzed with descriptive statistics. RESULTS AND DISCUSSION: Thirty-two clinicians (response rate=91%) completed the questionnaires. Nearly all clinicians (97%) prescribed PrEP (median 20 patients, interquartile range 11-33). Most clinicians have reported testing and risk reduction counseling practices for PrEP that comply with US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention guidelines. Clinicians noted that patients using PrEP rarely experienced drug toxicities and generally reported high compliance. However, some clinicians' practices differed from guideline recommendations, and some clinicians observed patients with increased risk behaviors. Most clinicians (79%) rated PrEP provision as easy to achieve, and 97% thought they were likely to prescribe PrEP in the future. CONCLUSIONS: In a primary care clinic specializing in HIV prevention, clinicians perceived that providing PrEP to a large number of patients was safe, feasible, and potentially effective. Efforts to involve general primary care clinicians in PrEP service may facilitate scaling up this effective intervention.

title: Basic care guidelines for consultation practices: effectiveness of computerized and paper-based versions. A cluster randomized controlled trial among newly qualified primary care physicians.
abstract: Purpose: To compare the recent impact of computerized and paper-based versions of guidelines on qualified physician consultation practices. Methods: Two-armed randomized controlled trial. Physicians were randomized to receive computerized or textbook-based versions of the same guidelines for a 4-week study period. Physicians' compliance with the guidelines for laboratory, radiological, physical and other tests, procedures, non-pharmacological and pharmacological treatments, physiotherapy, and referrals was measured by case note review. Results: 139 newly qualified doctors working in 96 primary health care centers in Finland participated in the study. Data from 4,633 patient interviews were summarized, of which 3,484 were eligible for further analysis. Physicians' compliance with guidelines was high (over 80% for laboratory use, radiology, physical examination, and referral). There was no significant difference in physician consultation practices in any of the outcomes measured between the computerized and textbook group. Conclusion: The guidelines are a useful source of information for newly qualified physicians working in primary care. However, the method of presentation of guidelines (either electronic or paper) has no influence on guideline use or impact on decisions. Other factors such as information seeking time, ease of use during consultation, updateability, production costs, and physicians' own preferences should be considered when choosing the way the guidelines are presented.

title: Primary care physicians' response to dissemination of practice guidelines
abstract: BACKGROUND: Much effort has been devoted to establishing clinical practice guidelines, but relatively few studies address dissemination issues. Unless guides are used, little is gained. This study evaluates the impact of three methods for disseminating asthma guidelines on physicians' behaviors and attitudes towards educational strategies. METHODS: Asthma guidelines were mailed to 60 physicians at three District Health Education Centers in Arkansas. Dissemination efforts on one site included a brief summary, "detailed" phone calls from doctors, and a continuing medical education conference. The second area used computer strategies and the third area used a multimedia approach that included fax messages, posters, videotapes, audio cassettes and a continuing medical education conference. A fourth site with 22 participants served as the comparison. Data were collected through mailed questionnaires, outpatient chart reviews, and physician interviews. Changes between baseline and posttest evaluations after a 4 month intervention for drug use were calculated and the use of peak flow monitoring was compared with the control group (general linear model). Regression analyzes were used to identify physician and practice factors associated with specific training techniques. RESULTS: Each region showed improvement in drug use or peak flow monitoring, but none improved in all areas. The multimedia, constant reminder approach was well received, but there was little support for computing strategies. CONCLUSIONS: Further efforts to disseminate clinical guidelines should include a variety of formats with an emphasis on concise summaries and frequent reminders. Social influence seems to play a role and will be a fertile field for further research.

title: Primary care physicians' use of lumbar spine imaging tests: implications for guidelines and practice pattern feedback
abstract: OBJECTIVE: To reduce the variability in primary care physicians' use of procedures for imaging the lumbar spine. DESIGN: Controlled intervention using clinical practice guidance and practice model feedback. STUDY EXAMPLE: 67 internists and 28 family practitioners in a large, group model HMO. MEASUREMENTS AND MAIN RESULTS: Intervention group physicians received clinical practice guidelines for low back pain, followed by three bimonthly feedback reports 4 months later on current rates of use for timber spine x-rays and computed tomography and magnetic resonance imaging scans of the lumbar spine. . Control group physicians received neither guidelines nor feedback reports. Automated radiology use data was used to compare changes in use rates and variability in use rates for intervention and control group physicians over the study period. Neither guideline alone nor guideline plus feedback was associated with a significant reduction in use rates or variability in use rates for the lumbar spine imaging procedures studied. CONCLUSIONS: Clinical practice guidelines and practice model feedback fail to meet their goals when characteristics of the practice environment and patient expectations and behavior are not defined and addressed.

title: Primary care provider attitudes are associated with smoking cessation counseling and referral.
abstract: OBJECTIVE: Most primary care providers (PCPs) approve of the importance of smoking cessation, but counseling rates are low. We evaluated the consistency of PCP's attitudes towards smoking cessation counseling and corresponding smoking cessation behaviors. DESIGN: This was a post-intervention analysis of a population-based sample from a randomized controlled group trial to improve adherence to smoking cessation guidelines. SETTING: A total of 18 VA facilities participated in the Southwest and Western United States. PARTICIPANTS: A total of 280 PCPs completed a questionnaire 12 months after the implementation of the smoking cessation quality improvement (QI) program. His patients also completed 12 (n = 1080) and 18-month (n = 924) follow-up questionnaires. INTERVENTION: The quality improvement response included local prioritization, quality improvement plan development, implementation and monitoring. MEASUREMENTS AND MAIN RESULTS: PCPs at intervention sites were more likely to counsel patients on smoking cessation (P = 0.04) but not referrals. PCP attitude towards smoking cessation counseling was strongly associated with reported counseling (P < 0.001) and referral (P = 0.01). Other relationships with counseling, perceived barrier "patients are not interested in quitting" (P = 0.01) and fewer years in practice (P = 0.03)"; other relationships with referral are specialist consultation (P < 0.0001) and perceived barrier "refer is not appropriate" (P = 0.001) (negative association) PCP attitudes were associated with higher rates of counselling, referral, and program participation CONCLUSIONS: Regardless of intervention participation, PCPs had attitudes consistent with reported smoking cessation behaviors, and more positive attitudes were more patient-reported. associated with higher rates of smoking cessation behaviour.The findings suggest that PCPs that approve smoking cessation counseling and referral may offer more treatment recommendations and have higher quit rates.

title: Primary Care Provider-Provided Smoking Cessation Interventions and Smoking Cessation Among Participants in the National Lung Screening Study
abstract: SIGNIFICANCE: The National Lung Screening Study (NLST) found a reduction in lung cancer mortality among participants screened with low-dose computed tomography and chest radiography. In February 2015, Medicare announced its decision to include annual lung screening for patients with a significant smoking history. These guidelines support smoking cessation therapy in addition to screening, but the frequency and effectiveness of clinician-administered smoking cessation interventions after lung screening are unknown. OBJECTIVE: To determine the relationship between clinician-reported 5As (issue, advise, evaluate, assist [talk about quitting or suggest or recommend smoking cessation medications] and adjust follow-up) after lung screening and smoking behavior changes. DESIGN, ENVIRONMENT, AND PARTICIPANTS: A paired case-control study of 3336 NLST participants who smoked at enrollment (cases were quitters and controls were smokers) examined participants' 5A birth rates and patterns after lung scanning and reported their smoking cessation behavior. MAIN RESULTS AND MEASURES: Prevalence of clinician-administered 5A and associated smoking cessation after lung screening. RESULTS: Delivery of 5As, 1 year after screening, was as follows: ask, 77.2%"; advise, 75.6%; evaluate, 63.4%; assist, 56.4%; and arrange follow-up, 10.4%. Demand, advice, and assessment sociodemographic were not significantly associated with quitting in multivariate models adjusted for characteristics, medical history, screening results, nicotine addiction, and motivation to quit. Assists were associated with a 40% increase in quit probability (odds ratio, 1.40; 95% CI, 1.21-1.63 ) and regulation was associated with a 46% increase in odds of quitting (odds ratio, 1.46; 95% CI, 1.19–1.79) Primary care providers for smokers participating in the NLST were associated with increased quitting; less intense interventions (ask, advise, and evaluate). However, rates of assistance and follow-up of regulation were relatively low.Our findings indicate the need for clinicians to take more active intervention steps to help screened patients quit smoking and confirms its usefulness.

title: Sensitivity of primary care providers to health risk behaviors reported by adolescent patients
abstract: OBJECTIVE: To evaluate clinicians' responsiveness to health risk behaviors reported by adolescent patients during a comprehensive clinical preventive services visit. DESIGN: Improbable sample of adolescent patients scheduled for routine physical examination. Setting: Seven clinical sites in Chicago, Ill. PARTICIPANTS: Fifteen primary care providers and 95 adolescent patients aged 11 to 18 years. INTERVENTION: Providers provided comprehensive clinical preventive services to adolescent patients using the Guidelines for Adolescent Preventive Services model. This model includes screening, guidance, physical examination and immunizations. Prior to the visit, adolescent patients completed a 52-item screening questionnaire containing a health risk behavioral profile. Responses to the screening questionnaire were discussed during the visit. MAIN OUTCOME MEASURES: Each provider's response to reported health risk behaviors was determined by comparing the adolescent patient's responses on the screening questionnaire with those reported during an adolescent debriefing about whether certain issues were discussed. Sensitivity to highly sensitive behaviors was determined by comparing the screening questionnaire and the medical record. RESULTS: On average, each adolescent patient reported 10 risk behaviors, 7 of which were discussed. The severity of the risk behavior reported, the number of reported biological health problems, and the gender of the adolescent patient were important determinants of the provider's responsiveness. The number of health-risk behaviors reported, duration of visit, professional role and gender of the provider, whether the adolescent was a recent patient, and the adolescent patient's age were unrelated to responsiveness. RESULTS: Providers addressed most of the health risk behaviors reported during a single visit, but responsiveness decreased when 3 or more biological health problems or relatively serious problems were reported. Steps can be taken to improve the responsiveness of providers.

title: Primary care, generalism, public interest: déjÃ vu? Again!
A primary care-based multidisciplinary, interdisciplinary medical education intervention for patients with systolic heart failure: lessons learned from a cluster randomized controlled trial.
abstract: BACKGROUND: Chronic (systolic) heart failure (CHF) is a common and disabling condition. Adherence to evidence-based guidelines in primary care has been shown to improve health outcomes. The aim was to explore the impact of a multidisciplinary educational intervention (Train the Trainer = TTT) on patient and performance outcomes for general practitioners (GPs). METHODS: This article presents key findings from the trial and discusses lessons learned during the implementation of the TTT trial. Primary care practices were randomly assigned to the TTT intervention or control group. 37 GPs (18 TTTs, 19 controls) were randomized, and 168 patients (91 TTTs, 77 controls) with a definitive diagnosis of CHF were enrolled. GPs in the intervention group attended four meetings that discussed clinical practice guidelines and pharmacotherapy feedback. The primary outcome was patient self-reported quality of life at seven months using the SF-36 Physical Function scale. Secondary outcomes include other SF-36 scales, Kansas City Cardiomyopathy Questionnaire (KCCQ), total mortality, heart failure hospitalizations, prescribing, depressive disorders (PHQ-9), behavior change (European Heart Failure Self-Care Behavior Scale), patient - Improving heart failure using perceived quality of care (EUROPEP) and NT-proBNP levels. An exploratory analysis was performed as recruitment targets were not met. RESULTS: Both groups had high initial success for most outcomes. At 7 months, there was no significant mean difference between groups for the primary outcome measure (-3.3, 95% CI -9.7 to 3.1, p = 0.30). The only difference in secondary outcomes regarding the prescription of aldosterone antagonists by GPs in the intervention group was significant differences between the group at follow-up (42% vs. 24%, adjusted OR = 4.0, 95% CI 1.2-13"; p = 0.02). did not change outcome or most secondary outcomes. Recruitment targets were not met and selection bias of participating GPs, as well as under-employment of practices and patients prohibit conclusive results, but CI demonstrates that intervention was not effective in this example. Lessons learned from trial conduct for future planning and conduct of confirmatory trials in primary care TRIAL REGISTRATION: ISRCTN08601529.

title: Primary care-based smoking interventions
abstract: The primary care setting is an important place to promote smoking cessation. Randomized clinical trials (RCTs) testing the effectiveness of brief smoking interventions and comprehensive programs delivered in primary care provide excellent evidence that such interventions significantly increase patients' smoking cessation rates and that the efficacy increases as the intervention dose increases. Unfortunately, despite the widespread dissemination of preventive service guidelines and positive physician attitudes towards such services, the current level of smoking cessation intervention by physicians in real-world settings is not high, making this a major research and public health concern. Interventions to increase the rate of implementation of provider-provided short smoking interventions can be broadly grouped into 'provider education', clinical systems and procedures (eg, screening and monitoring of patients); and institutional policy (eg reimbursement, coverage, performance measures). Given the significant impact primary care-based interventions have on smoking cessation, it is important to explore ways to increase their birth rates and effects.Research examples to motivate intervention questions include: What are the best incentives or combinations of incentives for physicians? What is the most effective for reminding providers to intervene? What are the strategies? How can each of these be best applied in different types of settings and systems? How can the stepped care and patient-care matching model be used? Examining factors such as reimbursement policies and benefits covered, tightly controlled It is not suitable for randomized trials. Therefore, there is a need to use quasi-experimental designs and apply qualitative strategies. These designs represent a different challenge for the research community.

title: Primary Coronary Intervention (PCI) in myocardial infarction network system in a German city (Essen)
abstract: In a German city (Essen, 490,000 people), a new network system was established in 2004 for patients with ST-elevation myocardial infarction (STEMI). This included a so-called integrated care model (IV model) with the involvement of insurance companies. In a collaborative structure between invasive and noninvasive hospitals, general practitioners and cardiologists, and emergency systems, it can be realized that every patient with STEMI will be treated with primary percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI) as soon as possible according to current guidelines. Patient characteristics (age, gender, comorbidity, medication) were comparable to other trials and registries. The primary success rate was high (96.4%). Acute in-hospital outcomes showed a low mortality (7.6%). Latency times were comparable to other recordings. Time from symptom to balloon was 239 minutes, contact time with medical balloon was 95 minutes, time from door to balloon was 60 minutes, and time from puncture to balloon was 18 minutes (median values). The STEMI mesh system in Essen demonstrates the possibility of modern treatment in patients with myocardial infarction (primary PCI) in a collaborative modality among all participants in the healthcare system.

title: Primary prevention of diabetes mellitus type 2 and cardiovascular disease using a cognitive behavioral program aimed at lifestyle changes in people at risk: Design of a randomized controlled trial.
abstract: BACKGROUND: The number of people with cardiovascular disease (CVD) and diabetes mellitus type 2 (T2DM) is increasing rapidly. This increase is largely due to lifestyle-related risk factors such as overweight, reduced physical activity and unhealthy diet. Modifying these risk factors has the potential to delay or prevent the development of T2DM and CVD. It is hypothesized that a cognitive behavioral program (CBP) focusing on motivation and self-management, especially in people at high risk for CVD and/or T2DM, will improve lifestyle behaviors and ultimately reduce their risk. Development of T2DM and CVD. METHODS: 12,000 people aged 30-50 years living in various municipalities in the semi-rural West Friesland region will receive an invitation from their GP (n = 13) to measure their waist circumference with a tape measure. Persons with abdominal obesity (male waist >/= 102 cm, female waist > or= 88 cm) will be invited to participate in the second phase of screening, blood pressure, blood sample and anthropometric measurements. T2DM and CVD risk scores will then be calculated according to the ARIC and SCORE formulas, respectively. Persons with a score indicating a high risk of developing T2DM and/or CVD will then be randomly assigned to the intervention group (n = 300) or the control group (n = 300). Participants in the intervention group will follow a targeted CBP. in changing dietary behaviors, physical activities and smoking behaviors. Counseling methods to be used are motivational interviewing (MI) and problem-solving therapy (PST), which specifically focus on intrinsic motivation for change and self-management of participants' problems. CBP will be provided by nurse practitioners trained in the participant's general practice and will consist of a maximum of six individual sessions of 30 minutes followed by 3-month reinforcement sessions over the phone. Participants in the control group will be given brochures containing health guidelines on physical activity and diet, and how to quit smoking. Primary outcome measures will be changes in T2DM and CVD risk scores. Secondary outcome measures would be changes in lifestyle behavior and cost-effectiveness and cost-benefit ratios. All relevant direct and indirect costs will be measured and a 24-month follow-up will be made. DISCUSSION: Changing behaviors is difficult, it takes time, great effort and motivation. Combining the two counseling modalities, MI and PST, followed by supportive sessions, can result in sustained behavior change. TRIAL REGISTRATION: Current Controlled Trials ISRCTN59358434.

title: Preparation of Hand Hygiene Compliance in Clinical Environments
abstract: Introduction: Effective hand hygiene is the most important procedure in the prevention of hospital-acquired infections. Traditional knowledge/education-based interventions have shown only modest benefits in adaptation. This study set out to investigate whether priming through olfactory and visual cues affects hand hygiene compliance. Methods: Randomized controlled trial in a surgical intensive care unit (SICU) at a teaching hospital in Miami, Florida. Primary outcome data included observations – a mix of healthcare professionals and service users were observed upon entering the ICU by 2 trained observers and their hand hygiene compliance was independently verified. Interventions included olfactory (clean, citrus scent) or visual lining (male or female eyes). The primary outcome measure was hand hygiene compliance (HHC), as measured by the visitor using the hand gel dispenser. Results: At the 5% level, there was substantial evidence that a clean, citrus scent significantly improved HHC (15.0% versus 46.9%, p = .0001). Compared to the control group, a significant improvement in HHC was seen when a picture of 'male eyes' was placed over the hand gel dispenser (15.0% versus 33.3%, p < .038). No significant improvement in HHC was seen when a picture of female eyes was placed in the same hand gel dispenser (15.0% vs. 10.0%, p = .626). Conclusions: This is one of the first studies to show that the preparation can affect HHC in a clinical setting. The findings suggest that priming interventions can be used to change other public health-related behaviors. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2016 APA, all rights reserved)

title: Printed educational materials: implications for professional practice and health care outcomes
abstract: BACKGROUND: Printed educational materials (PEMs) are passive dissemination strategies commonly used to improve knowledge, awareness, attitudes, skills, professional practice, and patient outcomes. They are traditionally presented in paper formats such as monographs, peer-reviewed publications, and clinical guidelines and appear to be the most commonly adopted method for disseminating information. OBJECTIVES: To determine the effectiveness of PEMs in improving process outcomes (including the behavior of healthcare professionals) and patient outcomes. To investigate whether the impact of characteristics of PEMs (e.g., source, content, format, mode of delivery, timing/frequency, complexity of targeted behavior change) influence process outcomes (including healthcare professional behavior and patient outcomes). SEARCH STRATEGY: The following electronic databases were searched up to July 2006: (a) EPOC Group Specialized Register (including database of studies pending evaluation (see 'Specialist Register' under 'Group Details')"; (b) The Cochrane Central (c) MEDLINE, EMBASE, CINAHL, and CAB Health. A recent search for MEDLINE was conducted in March 2007. SELECTION CRITERIA: We included randomized controlled trials (RCTs), controlled clinical trials (CCT), controlled pre- and post-controlled studies (CBA), and interrupted time series analyzes (ITS) evaluating the impact of printed educational materials on healthcare practitioner practice and/or patient outcomes No language restrictions Any objective measures of professional performance (ordered number of tests, prescriptions for a particular drug) or patient health outcomes (for example, blood pressure, number of cesarean sections). z re-included. DATA COLLECTION AND ANALYSIS: Four reviewers independently undertook data abstraction using a modified version of the EPOC data collection checklist. Any disputes are resolved by discussion between the referees and the arbitrators. Statistical analysis was performed by considering dual process outcomes, continuous process outcomes, patient outcome binary measures, and patient outcome continuous measures. We have presented the results for all comparisons using a standard presentation method whenever possible. We reported the median effect size for each outcome type and the median of these effect sizes across studies separately for each study. MAIN RESULTS: 23 studies were included for this review. Evidence from this review indicated that PEMs have minor beneficial effects on professional practice. RCTs comparing PEMs with no interventions observed a median absolute risk difference: +4.3% (range -8.0% to +9.6%) in categorical process outcomes (eg, x-ray requests, prescribing, and smoking cessation activities) 6 studies ) and continuous process outcomes (eg drug change, x-ray requests per administration) relative risk difference +13.6% (range -5.0% to +26.6%, 4 studies). These findings are similar to those reported for ITS studies, although significantly larger effect sizes were observed (the relative risk difference ranged from 0.07% to 31%). In contrast, the median effect size for categorical measures of patient outcome (eg screening, return to work, smoking cessation) was -4.3% (range -0.4% to -4.6%, 3 studies)). Two studies reported -10% and -20.5% deterioration in continuous patient outcome data (eg, depression score, attempts to quit smoking). Minimal differences were observed in a study comparing PEMs with training workshops. In the two studies comparing PEMs and educational outreach, there were no statistically significant differences between the groups. It was not possible to discover potential modifiers between studies. AUTHOR'S CONCLUSIONS: The results of this review show that PEMs when used alone can have a beneficial effect on process outcomes, but not on patient outcomes, compared with no intervention. Despite this wide range of effects reported for PEMs, the clinical significance of the observed effect sizes is unknown. There is not enough information on how to optimize training materials. The effectiveness of educational materials compared to other interventions is uncertain.

title: Printed educational messages fail to increase the use of thiazides as first-line medication for hypertension in primary care: a cluster randomized controlled trial [ISRCTN72772651
abstract: BACKGROUND: Evidence regarding the effectiveness of printed educational messages in contributing to increased evidence-based clinical practice is conflicting. However, these messages are filling doctor's offices to promote treatments that can reduce costs while improving patient outcomes. This study evaluated the ability of printed educational messages to promote the selection of thiazides as first-line therapy for individuals newly diagnosed with hypertension; this is a practice that is supported by good evidence and included in the guidelines and can reduce the costs of the health system. . METHODS: The study uses a pragmatic, cluster randomized controlled trial (doctor randomized by the practice group). SETTING: The setting includes all Ontario general/family physician physicians. Messages recommending the use of thiazides as first-line therapy for hypertension were mailed to each physician, along with a widely read professional newsletter. Physicians were randomly selected to receive different versions of the printed educational messages: an insert (two-page evidence-based article) and/or one of two versions of an "outsert" (a short, directive message stapled to the outside of the newsletter). One was developed without a clear theory, and the other with messages targeting factors from the theory of planned behavior or none (newsletter only, no mention of thiazides). Percentage of patients aged 65+ and newly diagnosed with hypertension who were prescribed a thiazide as the first prescribed single drug. The effect of the intervention was estimated using a logistic regression model estimated using generalized prediction equation methods to account for clustering of patients within physician practices. RESULTS: Four thousand five hundred four physicians (23,508 patients) were randomized and provided a 97% power to detect an absolute increase of 5% in thiazides prescribing. No interference effects were detected. Thiazide was prescribed to 27.6% of patients who saw a control physician, 27.4% for the insert, 26.8% of patients who saw an ophthalmologist, and 28.3% of patients who saw an insert + dentist, p = 0 ,54. CONCLUSIONS: The study failed to conclusively demonstrate any effect of the printed educational messages in prescribing thiazide diuretics for the first-line treatment of hypertension. TRIAL REGISTRATION: ISRCTN72772651.

title: Private enterprise and public interest: ethical issues in financing clinical trials
abstract: Health centres, universities and their researchers and clinicians are encouraged to raise research funding through the development of business relationships. There are positive, practical, and morally relevant arguments supporting this initiative, but this move also raises ethical issues related to potential conflicts of interest. These include conflicts between an institution or researcher's responsibilities to each other, research subjects and the public, and competing financial interests. This article examines developments and ethical challenges in research funding that may arise in the current administrative context. Provides recommendations for the development of guidelines by institutions that support researchers in their efforts to improve clinical care through the implementation of significant external funding and research.

title: Pro renata drug for inpatient psychiatric patients: time to act
abstract: Pro re nata (PRN"; "as needed") drug therapy is an archetypal mainstay for managing acute inpatient psychiatric symptoms and behaviors. This article reviews the evidence for the administration of PRN psychotropic drugs and examines evidence-based best practice, current mental health policy. and in the context of professional ethics, it recommends a standard Australian PRN management protocol. The procedures and conditions that lead to a nurse administering psychotropic medication PRN medication is broken down into five simple steps: (i) medical prescription; (ii) nurse assessment of patient indications for an intervention; (iii) nurse's assessment of therapeutic options; (iv) obtaining patient informed consent;" and (v) documenting the results of PRN administration. The literature pertaining to each step is reviewed, along with national and international professional ethics, guidelines, and patient rights documents on the care of mental health patients. Recommendations for maintenance best practices are discussed for each step. There is a lack of published evidence to support the use of PRN drugs in inpatient psychiatric patients. Nevertheless, there is published evidence that PRN drugs are associated with increased risks of morbidity, inappropriate use, may lead to the above recommended dosages or multi-pharmacy, and complicate evaluation of the efficacy of regularly scheduled drugs. Alternative non-pharmacological treatment options to PRN medication are effective and associated with fewer side effects. There are no clear national standards, operational criteria, or quality assurance regarding the use of PRN in inpatient psychiatry units. Contemporary PRN practices are largely unregulated and driven primarily by anecdotal evidence, leaving clinicians and the service vulnerable to allegations of poor accountability and misuse (intentional and unintentional) of psychotropic drugs. The development of best practice guidelines for the use of PRN management is essential.

title: Proactive asthma care in childhood: a general practice-based randomized controlled trial.
abstract: Objectives To evaluate the feasibility and effectiveness of a general practice-based, proactive asthma care system in children. Design a randomized controlled trial with cluster sampling with general practice. Identifying General practices in the northern region of the Australian Capital Territory. Participants 174 children with moderate to severe asthma who attended 24 GPs. Intervention System for structured asthma care (3+ visit plan) reminding participating families to attend GP. Main outcome measures Process measures: GP asthma consultation rates, written asthma plans, completion of 3+ visit plans"; clinical measures: emergency room visits rates for asthma, days absent from school, symptom-free days, past year above symptoms, activity during the past year Restriction and use of asthma medication during the past year Spirometric measures of lung function before and after the challenge of cold weather Outcomes Children in the intervention group had significantly more asthma-related consultations (three or more asthma-related odds ratio consultations 3.8 (95% confidence interval 1, 9 to 7.6; P = 0.0001), written asthma plans (2.2 (1.2 to 4.1); P = 0.01) and completed 3+ visit plan (24.2 (5.7 to 103.2); P = 0.0001) more than control children and Average 2.6% (1.7 to 3.5) reduction in forced expiratory volume measurements per second after cold air application; P = 0.0001) less than control children Needs to be treated for a supplement The most (benefit) number written asthma action plan was 5 (3 to 41) children. Lower emergency room attendance rates for asthma in intervention group children (odds ratio 0.4 (0.2 to 1.04); P = 0.06) and less speech-limiting wheezing (0.2 (0.1 to 0, 4); P = 0.0001) and was lower than in control children. use a spacer (2.8 (1.6 to 4.7); P = 0.0001). There was no difference in the number of days of school absence or in symptom-free days scores. Results For children with moderate to severe asthma, proactive care with active recall can be applied in the following situations: general practice and looks useful.

title: Issues with implementation of guidelines: a randomized controlled trial of consensus management of dyspepsia.
abstract: OBJECTIVE: To determine the feasibility and usefulness of developing guidelines for dyspepsia management with consensus among general practitioners (GPs) and specialists, and to evaluate GPs input on prescribing, using research, and referral. DESIGN: Randomized controlled trial of the effect of agreed consensus guidelines among family physicians and specialists on the behavior of general practitioners. SETTING: Southampton and South West Hampshire Health District, UK. SUBJECTS: Of 254 eligible GPs, 179 GPs working in 45 practices, 107 in the control group and 78 in the study group in the Southampton county. KEY MEASURES: Referral and research rates and prescribing costs for dyspepsia in the six months before and after the guidelines are implemented. RESULTS: Consensus guidelines were generated relatively easily. After their introduction, referral rates for upper gastrointestinal symptoms dropped significantly in both the study and control groups, but there were no significant changes in either group in terms of referral rates, patient selection, or use of endoscopy or radiology for research findings. No difference was observed between the control and study group in the number of substances prescribed, but in the study group, prescribing costs increased by 25% (from 2634 pounds per GP to 3215 pounds per GP), almost entirely due to the increased rate of prescribing ulcer-healing agents. CONCLUSION: It was possible to develop regional guidelines for managing dyspepsia with consensus among GPs and specialists. However, their acceptance and adoption was variable, and their measured effects on some aspects of clinical behavior were relatively weak and not necessarily associated with reduced costs or improved quality of care.

title: Proceedings of the 9th annual conference on dissemination and applied science
Proceedings of the Application Research Collaboration Association (SIRC) 2015 3rd Biennial Conference: developing productive methodologies through community partnerships and team science
Proceedings of the 8th Annual Conference on Dissemination and Application Science
Process and outcome in the National Health Service
Process evaluation of an occupational health guide aimed at preventing weight gain among workers
abstract: OBJECTIVE: To evaluate an occupational health guide process for weight gain prevention. METHODS: Quantitative data on the seven treatment items were evaluated and correlated with effects on workers' waist circumference and body weight at 6 months. RESULTS: Occupational physicians (n = 7) partially applied the guideline at the environmental level, but performed well at the individual level. Behavior change counseling was applied "to some extent". Employees (n = 274) showed high access (86%), satisfaction (7.1) and engagement rates (4.4 over 5 sessions). Significant effects were found on waist circumference (-1.5 cm to -2.1 cm) and body weight (-0.9 kg to -1.4 kg) among workers with higher engagement and satisfaction rates. CONCLUSIONS: Workplace health promotion through an occupational health manual is possible, but environmental component and behavior change counseling needs revisions before practical implementation.

title: Process evaluation of complex interventions: Medical Research Council guideline
abstract: Process evaluation is an essential part of designing and testing complex interventions. New MRC guideline provides a framework for conducting and reporting process assessment studies Attempts to tackle problems such as smoking and obesity use increasingly complex interventions. These are often described as interventions consisting of multiple components in interaction, but additional complexity dimensions include the difficulty of their implementation and the number of organizational levels they target.1 Randomized controlled trials are considered the gold standard for determining the effectiveness of interventions in the following situations. randomization can be done. However, effect sizes do not provide policymakers with information on how an intervention can be replicated in their particular context or whether trial results can be reproduced. The previous MRC guideline for evaluating complex interventions focused on randomized trials made no mention of process evaluation.2 The updated guideline recognized the value of process assessment in trials and stated that it could be used to assess the fidelity and quality of trials. 3 However, it did not provide guidance for conducting process assessment. #### Highlights In 2010, a workshop funded by the MRC Demographic Health Sciences Research Network discussed the need for guidance on process evaluation.4 There was consensus among researchers, funders, and â € ™.

title: Procrastination, Deadlines, and Performance: Self-Control with Pre-Commitment
abstract: Procrastination is very familiar to most people. People delay writing their research (we hear!), repeatedly saying they'll start their diet tomorrow, or delaying chores at home until next week. Still, people sometimes try to control their procrastination by setting deadlines for themselves. In this article, we ask three questions: (a) Are people willing to impose meaningful (i.e. costly) deadlines on themselves to overcome procrastination? (b) Are self-imposed deadlines effective in improving task performance? (c) When setting their own deadlines, do people adjust them optimally for maximum performance gains? A series of studies examining these issues empirically showed that the answer to the first two questions was "yes" and to the third question "no". People have self-control issues, they recognize them and try to control them by imposing costly deadlines on them. These deadlines help people control procrastination, but they are not as effective as some externally imposed deadlines in improving task performance.

title: Professional and social support for hysterectomy patients
abstract: This article describes a social support study for women who have had a hysterectomy and shows how the original research plans should be modified when early interviews revealed women's needs for basic information and their willingness to receive it from the researcher. The modified design allowed comparisons between a group of women who received information as part of the research interview and a second group who did not receive such assistance. Follow-up after hysterectomy at 3 months showed significant differences between the 2 groups, with the 'information group' less hostile but more critical for hospital treatment. The study also confirms the same author's previous findings regarding overall high satisfaction, health, and resumption of activities after hysterectomy. Regarding social support, it is suggested that full-time housewives especially need support from nurses due to their relative isolation from other sources of support and information. However, all interviewees would have sought more information and support from their healthcare professionals. Despite the acknowledged limitations of the study, some guidelines are offered for nurses trying to increase their level of professional and professional support for their patients.

title: Professional interventions for the management of musculoskeletal disorders for general practitioners
abstract: BACKGROUND: Musculoskeletal conditions require special management skills. Identifying interventions that are effective in equipping general practitioners (GPs) with such essential skills can mean better health outcomes for patients and lower health and societal costs. OBJECTIVES: To determine the effectiveness of professional interventions for GPs aimed at improving the management of musculoskeletal disorders in primary care. SEARCH METHODS: Cochrane Central Register of Controlled Trials (CENTRAL), 2010, Issue 2"; MEDLINE, Ovid (1950 - October 2013); EMBASE, Ovid (1980 - October 2013); CINAHL, EbscoHost (1980 - November 2013) and We performed citation reference searches using the EPOC Specialized Register. ISI Web of Knowledge and Google Scholar and manually searched selected issues of Arthritis and Rheumatism and Primary Care Clinics in Office Practice. The most recent search was in November 2013. SELECTION CRITERIA : Randomized controlled trials (RCTs), non-randomized controlled trials (NRCTs), controlled pre- and post-controlled studies (CBAs), and interrupted time series (ITS) studies of professional interventions for GPs in a community setting, musculoskeletal We aimed to improve the management (including diagnosis and treatment) of GP disorders and to report any objective measure of GP behavior, patient or economic outcomes. length, duration, density, and complexity. DATA COLLECTION AND ANALYSIS: Two review authors independently summarized all data. We calculated the risk difference (RD) and odds ratio (RR) of adherence to desired practice for dual outcomes, and the mean difference (MD) and standardized mean difference (SMD) for sustained outcomes. We investigated whether the direction of targeted behavior change affected the effectiveness of interventions. MAIN RESULTS: Thirty studies met our inclusion criteria. Out of 11 studies on osteoporosis, a meta-analysis of five studies (high-confidence evidence) showed that there was a combination of a GP alert system and a patient-directed intervention about a patient's increased risk of osteoporosis. (including patient education and a reminder to see their GP), diagnostic bone mineral density (BMD) testing, and prescribing osteoporosis medication (RR 4.44; (95% confidence interval (CI) 3.54 to 5.55; 3 studies; 3,386) for improves GP behavior (participant) and for osteoporosis medication RR 1.71 (95% CI 1.50 to 1.94; 5 studies; 4,223 participants). A meta-analysis of two studies showed that GP stimulation by itself likely improved GP behavior consistent with the osteoporosis guideline (RR 4.75 (95% CI 3.62 to 6.24; 3,047 participants)) for BMD and RR 1.52 (95% CI 1.26 to 1.84; 3,047 participants) and The addition of the patient-directed component probably did not result in a greater effect for BMD and RR 0.93 (95% CI 0.79 to 1.10) (RR 0.94 (95% CI 0.81 to 1.09; 2.995 participants));" 2,995 participants). Feedback on the total number of studies requested may have an impact on GP behavior and may result in a slight reduction in the number of tests, one of these studies adding to the radiology reports of the combination of guidelines and GP r may result in a small but sustained reduction in the number of research requests. One study out of four studies on osteoarthritis found that the use of educationally effective physicians can result in improvement in GP behavior consistent with the guideline. stered. Another study showed slight improvements in patient outcomes (pain control) after GPs trained in pain management. One study out of three studies on shoulder pain reported little or no improvement in patient outcomes (functional capacity) after GP training on shoulder pain. and injection training. One of two studies on other musculoskeletal conditions, a study on pain management, showed that there may be worse patient outcomes (pain control) after GP training on the use of validated rating scales. The remaining 12 studies have shown little in all musculoskeletal disorders. or no improvement in GP behavior and patient outcomes. The direction of the targeted behavior (i.e. increasing or decreasing a behavior) does not seem to affect the effectiveness of an intervention. Most studies did not explore the potential adverse effects of interventions, and only three studies included a cost-effectiveness analysis. Overall, there were significant methodological limitations in the nature of the evidence, and only one-third of the studies reported adequate allocation confidentiality. and blind outcome assessments. While our confidence in the combined effect estimate of interventions to improve diagnostic testing and drug prescribing in osteoporosis is high, our confidence in the effect estimates reported in the remaining studies is low. AUTHORS' CONCLUSIONS: There is good quality evidence that a GP alert system with or without patient education on osteoporosis improves guideline-consistent GP behavior and results in better diagnosis and treatment rates. Interventions such as GP reminder messages and performance-related GP feedback, combined with dissemination of the guideline, may result in minor improvements in GP behavior consistent with the guideline regarding low back pain, while GP education on osteoarthritis pain and the use of educationally effective physicians have resulted in a slight decrease in patient outcomes and behavior consistent with the guideline, respectively. can lead to recovery. However, more studies are needed to determine the effectiveness of such interventions in improving GP behavior and patient outcomes.

title: Prognosis research strategy (PROGRESS) 1: a framework for investigating clinical outcomes
abstract: Understanding and improving the prognosis of a disease or health condition is a priority in clinical research and practice. In this article, the authors present a framework of four interrelated themes in prognostic research, explain the importance of the first of these themes (understanding future outcomes in relation to current diagnostic and therapeutic practices), and offer recommendations for the field of prognosis research. In clinical medicine, the term prognosis refers to the risk of future health outcomes in people with a particular disease or health condition. Thus, prognosis research is the study of associations between future outcomes (endpoints) among people with a particular baseline health condition (baseline) to improve health (see supplemental figure on bmj.com). The study of prognosis has never been more important because more people globally are living with one or more diseases or debilitating conditions than ever before.1 Therefore, governments around the world are now increasing their attention to health care outcomes. Similarly, research funders and researchers are increasingly focusing on translating new interventions and technologies from laboratory to clinical practice and then health policy to establish and implement new high-quality standards of care and improve patient outcomes. Prognosis research findings should therefore be an integral part of exploring and evaluating new approaches to clinical decision making, health policy, and patient management. However, there is an alarming gap between the potential and actual impact of prognostic research on health. Prognosis research studies lag far behind the high standards required in other fields such as therapeutic trials and genetic epidemiology. In the PROGnosis RESEARCH Strategy (PROGRESS) series (www.progress-partnership.org), we propose a framework made up of four distinct but interrelated prognosis research themes:

title: Promising advances in neuropsychological approaches for the detection of preclinical Alzheimer's disease: a selective review.
abstract: Recently published guidelines suggest that the best time to treat individuals with Alzheimer's disease is the preclinical stage of the disease. This is a stage where individuals are defined as clinically normal but show signs of amyloidosis, neurodegeneration, and subtle cognitive/behavioral decline. While our standard cognitive tests are useful for detecting cognitive decline at the stage of mild cognitive impairment, they are not designed to detect subtle cognitive variations associated with this biomarker stage of preclinical Alzheimer's disease. However, neuropsychologists are attempting to circumvent this challenge by designing newer cognitive measures and questionnaires derived from translational efforts in neuroimaging, cognitive neuroscience, and clinical/experimental neuropsychology. This review is a selective summary of several new, potentially promising approaches under investigation to detect early cognitive evidence of preclinical Alzheimer's disease in presymptomatic individuals.

title: Promoting evidence-based psychosocial care for cancer patients
abstract: With the large number of studies showing that psychosocial care reduces distress and improves quality of life, practitioners have an obligation to treat cancer patients consistent with this evidence. While the rationale is simple, there are major challenges in achieving the goal of translating research into clinical practice. One challenge has been the nature of the evidence, with many psychosocial intervention studies characterized by poor methodological quality, the absence of eligibility criteria indicating increased distress, and minimal consideration of spillover potential. A second challenge has been to make practitioners aware of relevant evidence. Targeted dissemination efforts, such as publishing clinical practice guidelines and evidence-based recommendations and distributing intervention materials over the Internet, appear to be more effective than passive efforts at providing useful information to practitioners. Perhaps the most challenging aspect has been persuading practitioners to change their practice. An approach currently under development would allow practitioners and health care organizations to make self-assessments of the quality of their psychosocial care based on a review of medical records. Feedback that indicates the quality of care is sub-optimal is likely to motivate change, especially if the quality indicators evaluated are considered important and reliable and point to specific actions that can be taken. Using evidence to encourage changes in clinical practice represents one of the primary ways the psycho-oncology field is fully realizing its potential to positively impact the lives of people with cancer.

title: Promoting Hand Hygiene Compliance
abstract: BACKGROUND: German "Clean Hands Campaign" to promote hand hygiene among hospital staff at the Hanover Medical School (MHH, Medizinische Hochschule Hannover), known as Aktion Saubere Hande (ASH) (an adaptation of the WHO "Clean Care is Safer Care" programme) ), met with initial success. By 2013, however, compliance rates with hygienic hand disinfection in the hospital's ten intensive care units (ICUs) and two hematopoietic stem cell transplant units (HSCTU) had returned to their original levels (doctors: 48%";" nurses: 56%). The cluster randomized controlled trial of PSYGIENE was conducted to explore whether tailored interventions in ways suggested by behavioral psychology research could bring more sustainable improvements from ASH. METHODS: The "Health Action Process Approach" (HAPA) adjustment model specifies the main psychological determinants of adjustment. These determinants were assessed through questionnaires (response rates: doctors: 71%"; nurses: 63%) among healthcare workers in MHH's ICUs and ICUs, and interviews with responsible ward physicians and head nurses (100%). While 29 special behavior modification techniques were applied in trainer training sessions and feedback discussions in the six wards that constitute the intervention arm of the research, ASH trainings were provided in the control arm. RESULTS: The two groups did not differ in baseline compliance rates (intervention: 54%, control: 55% , p = 0.581) in 2013. Customized interventions resulted in improved compliance in each of the two follow-up years (2014: 64%, p<0.001;" 2015: 70%, p = 0.001), the control arm increased to 68% in 2014 (p<0.001) but decreased to 64% in 2015 (p = 0.007). Increases in compliance between 2013 and 2015 and compliance rate in 2015 were higher in the intervention arm (p<0.005). This can mainly be attributed to the behavior of nurses, as the corresponding parameters for physicians did not differ significantly between the two study arms in the stratified analysis. CONCLUSION: Specific interventions based on behavioral psychology principles led to more sustained increases in compliance with hand hygiene guidelines than ASH training sessions. This was also true for nurses and thus for hospital ward staff as a whole (ie, nurses and doctors together). More studies are needed to identify more target group-specific interventions that could improve adherence among physicians.

title: Promoting the recovery of patients with schizophrenia: discrepancy between routine practice and evidence. SIEP-DIRECT'S Project
abstract: OBJECTIVES: The aim of this study is to present the main differences between the evidence-based NICE guidelines for schizophrenia and the usual practice of Italian mental health services to promote patient recovery, as evidenced by the SIEP-DIRECT'S Project. with schizophrenia. METHODS: 41 indicators have been developed, starting with the main NICE recommendations on promoting recovery. These were tested in 19 participating Italian Departments of Mental Health (MHD) or Psychiatric Services through self-assessment of activities to promote patient recovery, in order to assess the level of adherence to recommendations. The data needed for most of the indicators were obtained from the psychiatric information system or the MHD Referral. In addition, specific studies were conducted on clinical records and representative patient samples. In addition, an assessment was requested for the 14 indicators by a section of the "multidisciplinary" or "expert" focus groups, which then awarded a score according to a defined "ad hoc" scale. CONCLUSIONS: According to the data obtained, although mental health services seem to care about the physical condition of their patients, they routinely monitor blood pressure, glycemia, etc. does not examine key parameters and collaboration with GPs is often complex or not. applied uniformly. Most psychiatrists and psychologists have basic communication skills but are not proficient in cognitive-behavioral treatments";" such treatments and any other form of structured individual psychotherapy are rarely performed and appear to have become marginal activities within the Services. In addition, family psycho-educational interventions are not used sufficiently. Services are very active in the care of patients with very problematic schizophrenia, who make up a large percentage of the patients in their care (almost a quarter on average). Special and integrated treatment plans are offered to these patients with the participation of other health services and social institutions operating in the region. The strategies implemented by the wards for pharmacological treatment in the prevention of relapses and for patients with schizophrenia with frequent crises or treatment-resistant schizophrenia are all in line with NICE recommendations. Finally, the Services promote vocational training activities and supported employment, but their results are often unsatisfactory. CONCLUSIONS: The results of the study show a picture of Italian mental health services with both light and dark areas in terms of recovery-promoting activities. The services appear to guarantee adequate pharmacological evidence-based treatments, integrated assistance and good management of patients with multiple problems. However, they have difficulties in monitoring the physical health of patients, promoting psychotherapeutic activities, including those for families, and supported employment. In addition, they still show problems in structuring and formalizing maintenance processes. They should make greater use of professional guidelines, protocols and written procedures to improve this situation.

title: Promoting screening mammography in urban settings: a randomized controlled trial of computerized reminders as a component of a program to facilitate mammography.
abstract: In a one-year randomized controlled trial, we evaluated the efficacy of a computed mammography reminder system as a component of a program to increase the use of screening mammography in three healthcare facilities (two districts) serving women in downtown Detroit, Michigan. a health department, an HMO site and two sites of a private hospital). Four thousand four hundred and one women over the age of 40 who had visited a study site in the previous year were randomly assigned to one of two treatment groups. The limited intervention (LI) included physician and staff breast cancer control education, streamlined mammography appointment scheduling procedures, and elimination of the out-of-pocket patient cost for mammography (at three out of five centres). The full intervention (FI) included all the components of the limited intervention and an additional set of "action tips". These included a mammogram reminder form added to the medical records of women with mammography appointments, aimed at increasing doctor referrals for mammography appointments, and patient reminders to increase mammography completion among referral women. During the one-year intervention period, 2,725 randomized women visited a study site. Among FI women, 6-month mammography appointment rates range from 38% to 65%, and the FI rate exceeds the LI rate in each region, with differences from 13% (95% CI, 6 to 20) to 29% (21 to 38). . The annual rate of completed mammograms among FI women increases from 43% to 64%, exceeding the LI rate by 12% (5 to 19) to 25% (16 to 34) in each region. After adjusting for age, mammography intervention effect sizes were not significantly different between the five sites. The mean increase in FI compared to LI was 18%. The computerized reminder system is effective in increasing the use of mammography in each of the study establishments, and its greatest impact is on physician referral for mammography.

title: Promoting self-management through cohesion among heart failure patients discharged from rural hospitals: a study protocol.
abstract: UNLABELED: Background Heart failure is one of the most common chronic conditions in adults, causing long-term morbidity, repeated hospitalizations, and placing a huge economic burden on the health system. Heart failure patients discharged from rural hospitals or primarily critical access hospitals have higher 30-day readmission and death rates compared to patients discharged from city hospitals. Self-management improves health outcomes and reduces readmissions for heart failure patients, but adherence to self-management guidelines is low. We propose a home post-acute care service led by advanced nurses to increase patient activation and lead to improved adherence to self-management in heart failure patients discharged from rural hospitals. Purpose This article describes the study design and research methods used to implement and evaluate the intervention. Our Method Intervention is a 12-week patient activation (Home Patient Active Care [PATCH]) to improve adherence to self-management. Patients were randomized into two parallel groups (12-week PATCH intervention + usual care versus usual care only) to evaluate the efficacy of this intervention. Results were measured at baseline, 3 and 6 months. Discussion This study aimed to examine the effectiveness of a rural theory-based, nurse-led, activation-enhancing intervention on self-management compliance in heart failure patients living in rural areas. Our expectation is to facilitate compliance with self-management behaviors in heart failure patients after discharge from provincial hospitals, and to reduce the economic burden by reducing complications and hospital readmissions. CLINICAL TRIAL REGISTRATION INFORMATION: ClinicalTrials.gov";" https://register.clinicaltrials.gov/NCT01964053.

title: Promoting the use of colorectal cancer screening tests
abstract: BACKGROUND: Colorectal cancer (CRC) screening is underutilized despite evidence that screening reduces mortality. OBJECTIVE: To evaluate the impact of an intervention targeting physicians and their patients on CRC screening rates. DESIGN: A randomized clinical trial for community physicians and their patients. PARTICIPANTS: Ninety-four community primary care physicians were randomly assigned to an intervention consisting of academic details and direct mail to patients or a control group. Patients aged between 50 and 79 in the intervention group were given a letter from their physician, a brochure on CRC screening, and a pack of stool occult blood test (FOBT) cards. MEASUREMENTS: We measured after 1 year the following: (1) FOBT in the past 2 years, (2) flexible sigmoidoscopy (SIG) or colonoscopy (COL) in the previous 5 years, and (3) any CRC scan. We report percent change from baseline in both groups. RESULTS: 9,652 patients were enrolled for 2 years, 3,732 patients for 5 years. For patients enrolled over 2 years, there was no increase in any CRC screening occurring in the intervention group (12.5% versus 12.7 increase, P=.51). Similar results were seen for any CRC screening among patients enrolled at 5 years (8.6% versus 9.7% increase, P=.45). The only outcome for which intervention was effective was on patient SIG screening rates (4.4% versus 7.4% increase, P<.01). CONCLUSION: The intervention had no effect on CRC screening rates, except for the increase in SIG rates in the intervention group. Future interventions should consider innovative approaches to increase CRC screening rates.

title: Promoting and prescribing hormone therapy after harm reporting by the Women's Health Initiative
abstract: Context Little is known about how the pharmaceutical industry responds to evidence of harm associated with its products; For example, as in the Women's Health Initiative's Estrogen Plus Progestin Trial (WHI E+P) report published in July 2002, standard-Dose Prempro did significant harm and lacked clear benefits. Purpose To examine the pharmaceutical industry's response to WHI E+P results by analyzing promotional spending for hormone therapy before and after July 2002. Design and Adjustment Nationally representative and prospectively collected longitudinal data (January 2001 - December 2003) on the prescribing and promotion of hormone therapies were obtained from IMS Health and Consumer Media Reports. Key Outcomes Measures Trends in quarterly hormone therapy prescriptions and spend on 5 types of drug promotion: samples, office-based detailing, hospital-based promotion, magazine advertisements, and direct-to-consumer advertising. Results Prior to the WHI E+P report, prescribing rates and promotional expenditure for hormone therapy were stable. In the quarter preceding the WHI E+P report (April-June 2002), 22.4 million prescriptions were dispensed for hormone therapy and $71 million was spent on promotion ($350 per year per US doctor, per year). Within 9 months of the report's publication (Q1 2003), there was a 32% reduction in hormone therapy prescriptions and a bottom point for promotional spending was reached (37% reduction levels compared to pre-WHI E+P). Spending on all promotional activities and most hormone therapy decreased. Overall, the largest decreases were in samples (36% decrease as of Q1 2003) and direct-to-consumer advertising (100% decrease). The largest reductions in promotion occurred with the standard dose of Prempro, the agent specified in the WHI E+P report (61% decrease as of Q1 2003). More recently, promotional efforts have increased, particularly for low-dose Prempro, a resurgence associated with modestly increasing prescriptions for this new agent. Conclusions Consistent with its widespread use, hormone therapy was among the most promoted drugs before the WHI E+P report. After reporting the evidence of harm from this trial, there was a significant reduction in promotional spending for hormone therapy, particularly for agents that had a direct role in the trial. In conjunction with the impact of the trial results itself and the media coverage that followed, the reduced promotion may have contributed to a significant decline in hormone therapy prescriptions.

title: Appropriate antibiotic therapy. Pharmacogenomics from penicillin
abstract: Antibiotics have always been considered one of the great discoveries of the 20th century. The use of penicillin by Flaming ushered in the golden age of antibiotics, and it is now hard to imagine the practice of medicine without antibiotics. Life-threatening infections such as meningitis, endocarditis, bacteremic pneumonia sepsis can also be fatal. Also, aggressive chemotherapy and transplant procedures would be impossible. Another real miracle is the rise of antibiotic resistance soon after the clinical use of penicillin in hospitals and communities. A few studies have shown that over-prescribed antibiotics for patients and inpatients in the community, and in some hospitals up to 50% of antibiotic use is inappropriate: the benefits of antibiotic therapy come with the risk of developing antibiotic resistance. In hospitals, infections caused by antibiotic-resistant bacteria are associated with higher mortality, morbidity, and prolonged hospital stay compared to infections caused by antibiotic-susceptible bacteria. Various strategies have been proposed to reduce cost and improve the quality of drug use.
