Education, guidelines, and evidence-based advice are considered essential elements of any program designed to influence prescribing behavior and can provide a knowledge base that will enhance and increase acceptance of management strategies. An approach to clinical practice that assists in making decisions based on evidence-based advice, clinical expertise, and candid knowledge of the individual patient's conditions, beliefs, and priorities, enhances antimicrobial management, including appropriate selection, dosing, route, and duration of antimicrobial therapy, emergence of resistance, adverse drug events It can maximize clinical improvement or prevention of infection while limiting undesirable consequences such as cost and cost. These evidence-based guidelines are not a substitute for clinical judgment and their application always requires clinical judgment. Genome studies have identified hundreds of genetic polymorphisms that are important predictors of treatment efficacy, and several trials have demonstrated the successful use of pharmacogenomic testing to reduce the incidence of hypersensitivity reactions in patients. Knowing the patient's phenotype before treatment, optimal doses and types of drugs can be prescribed to ensure better management of patients.

title: Infection prophylaxis after appendicitis surgery: current surgical practice research
abstract: Two hundred and eighty questionnaires were sent to junior surgical staff across the UK asking about the use of systemic antibiotic prophylaxis, topical antibacterial agents and surgical drainage in appendectomy. One hundred and seventy-five (63%) responses were received from 81 of the 87 hospitals included in the survey. Prophylactic systemic antibiotics were used by 78 surgeons (46%) when operating on a normal appendix, but by 168 (99%) when the organ was perforated. Most surgeons began using antibiotics prior to surgery, but proportionately fewer did when the appendix was gangrenous or perforated. Patients with severe contamination tended to receive longer courses of antibiotics, although the duration of administration varied significantly. Metronidazole was included in more than 95% of all prophylactic regimens and was often combined with other drugs when the appendix was gangrenous and perforated. Topical antibacterial agents were routinely applied to the wound by only 45 surgeons (26%), but 106 (61%) occasionally used them. Povidone-iodine was the most commonly used agent. Only 98 surgeons (56%) drained appendectomy wounds, while 135 (77%) sometimes drained the peritoneal cavity. Evidence suggests that current methods of administering systemic antibiotic prophylaxis should continue, but topical agents and surgical drainage are perhaps unnecessary once surgeons are confident of the efficacy of the systemic therapy used.

title: Prophylaxis of surgical wound sepsis
Recommended guidelines for the participation of people with dementia as research subjects
Proposed revision of the Declaration of Helsinki
Prospective comparative study of computer programs used for warfarin administration.
abstract: OBJECTIVE - To compare the effectiveness of three computerized systems currently used to aid warfarin control in outpatients with the traditional dosing method used by experienced medical personnel. METHODS - A three-system pilot randomized study was conducted in 186 patients on long-term therapy or recently started on warfarin therapy and discharged from hospital, a follow-up study in which two were randomized independently. RESULTS-- All three computerized systems appeared to provide satisfactory control compared to the conventional dosing method. Significantly better control was achieved for patients on more intensive therapy with an assigned target range of 3.0-4.5 computerized dosing programs";" medical staff undertreated such patients almost 50% of the time. CONCLUSION--Computer-based programs can aid in anticoagulant control with warfarin in the outpatient, both early and during long-term treatment. The control achieved for most patients is as good as control achieved by experienced clinicians with the traditional dosing method, but the latter tends to be very conservative when dosed to patients within the intense target range of 3.0 to 4.5 International Normalized Ratio (INR). . Computers were significantly more successful in this higher range.

title: Prospective study of quality of life before and after coronary artery bypass grafting
abstract: OBJECTIVES To measure changes in patients' perceptions of how different health conditions affect their lives and to determine the ability of preoperative variables to predict outcome after coronary artery bypass grafting. DESIGN Prospective study in which questionnaires were completed before and three months, one year, and five years after coronary artery bypass grafting. SETTING Regional cardiothoracic center. PATIENTS 100 A male patient who was the patient of two cardiothoracic surgeons and was younger than 60 years of age at the time of the operation. MAIN OUTCOME MEASURES Patients' assessment of their health status in terms of functional capacity and distress aspects according to the Nottingham health profile, and the outcome of the operation in terms of changes in symptoms, work life, and daily activities as determined by self-completed work questionnaires. in operation and three and six months later. RESULTS Interim one-year results are reported. The differences between Nottingham health profile scores at three months before and after surgery were significantly different (p less than 0.01), indicating a notable improvement in overall health and favorably at one year compared with a normal male population. Analysis of responses to the study questionnaire showed that 65 of 89 patients (73%) were employed within one year of surgery, and seven (8%) claimed they were fit to work but were unable to find employment. The proportion of patients complaining of chest pain dropped from 90% (88/98) before grafting to 19% (17/89) one year after coronary artery bypass grafting, with 91% (81/89) of patients claiming to be doing well. either completely better or definitely improved. Important positive factors influencing return to work and home activities were work before surgery, short wait for surgery, no shortness of breath, and a low physical activity score (all p less than 0.001) in the Nottingham health profile. RESULTS Improvements in general health, symptoms, and activity were evident at three months and one year after coronary artery bypass graft surgery. Interventions likely to affect outcomes include reduced waiting times for surgery"; rehabilitation interventions;" placing greater emphasis on the quality of information provided to patients, their families and the community.

title: Prospective trial of real-time electronic surveillance to accelerate the early care of severe sepsis.
abstract: Study objective An automated, real-time electronic medical record inquiry and caregiver notification system was developed and studied for its usefulness in improving sepsis care. We hypothesize that the algorithm will improve the sampling rate and timing of blood lactate and blood cultures, performance of chest radiography, and antibiotic delivery. Methods A pre- and post-prospective study with sequential enrollment examined an algorithm that automatically identifies adult patients with 2 or more systemic inflammatory response syndrome (SIRS) criteria and who accumulate 2 or more blood pressure readings equal to or less than 90 mm Hg. . stay in the emergency room (ED). In phase 1, the system collected information but did not alert caregivers. In phase 2, caregivers were informed by an alphanumeric call and a text entry into the electronic medical record of patients' potential illness, and specific recommendations were provided. Results Patients (33,460) were screened for 6 months"; 398 patients, including 184 (46%) appropriately identified as severe septic, activated the system. The algorithm had a 54% positive predictive value and 99% negative predictive value in detecting severe infection. Acute organ dysfunction The median time for patients to accumulate SIRS and blood pressure criteria was 152 minutes (interquartile range [IQR] 71 to 284 minutes), which underlines the dynamic nature of critical illness diagnosis in an emergency and underlines the need for detection algorithms to re-evaluate patients during their assessment. After administration, 2 more frequent interventions were performed, pre-admission chest X-ray (probability ratio 3.2; 95% confidence interval 1.1 to 9.5) and blood culture (odd ratio 2.9; 95% confidence interval 1.1 to 1.1) 7.7) Blood culture test only, performed significantly faster in the presence of decision support (inter-ventilation 86 minutes, IQR 31, 296 minutes; intervention median time to culture after 81 min, IQR 37, 245 min;" P=.032 by Cox proportional hazard modeling. The dominant lack of strategy has failed to detect severe septic cases before caregivers. Conclusion An automated algorithm for detecting potential sepsis has increased the frequency and timing of some emergency department interventions for severe sepsis. Future efforts need to identify patient characteristics that precede SIRS and hypotension in emergency room evaluation.

title: Protection of the rights of human subjects
abstract: There is a significant problem with the volume of human subjects research conducted by researchers who do not comply with the Belmont Report's guidelines for the protection of human subjects. There are many reasons for non-compliance and these can create dilemmas for solving this problem. However, it is important for healthcare organizations, whatever their size, to take a proactive position in addressing this problem. This article briefly described the nature, scope, and underlying dilemmas of this issue and suggested a strategy for solving the problem at the organizational level. Thanks to their professional licenses as patient advocates, nurses can and should take the lead in protecting human subject rights in any role.

title: Protection of children participating in research studies
Protection of human subjects"; informed consent;" suggested rule
pragmatic cluster randomized controlled trial protocol to reduce irrational antibiotic prescription among children with upper respiratory tract infections in rural China.
abstract: INTRODUCTION: Irrational use of antibiotics is a serious problem in China and internationally. In 2012, China's Ministry of Health issued a regulation limiting antibiotic prescriptions to <20% of all outpatient prescriptions, but no operational details on policy implementation were published. This study aims to test the efficacy of a multidimensional intervention designed to reduce antibiotic use among children (2-14 years) with acute upper respiratory tract infections in rural primary care settings in China by changing physician prescribing behaviors and educating parents. /caregivers. METHODS AND ANALYSIS: This is a pragmatic, parallel group controlled, cluster randomized superiority trial with blinded evaluation of results and data analysis and unblinded treatment. Of the two counties in Guangxi Province, 12 county hospitals will be randomized to the intervention arm and 13 to the control arm. In the control arm, the management of antibiotic prescriptions will continue through usual care through clinical consultations. In the intervention arm, a provider and patient/caregiver focused intervention will be incorporated into routine primary care practices. Provider intervention includes operational guidelines, systematic education, peer review of antibiotic prescribing, and health education to caregivers. We will also provide printed educational materials and educational videos to caregivers. The primary outcome is the proportion of all provider-issued prescriptions for upper respiratory tract infections in children aged 2-14 years containing at least one antibiotic. ETHICS AND EXPANDATION: The research received ethical approval from the Ethics Committee of the Guangxi Province Center for Disease Control and Prevention in China. Results will be disseminated through workshops, policy briefs, peer-reviewed publications, and local and international conferences. TRIAL REGISTRATION NUMBER: ISRCTN14340536";" Preliminary results.

title: Protocol for systematic review of assessment research for adults participating in the 'SMART recovery' mutual support program
abstract: INTRODUCTION: Self-Management and Recovery Training (SMART Recovery) offers an alternative to the dominant 12-step approaches to mutual aid (eg, anonymous alcoholics). While SMART Recovery's principles (eg, self-efficacy) and therapeutic approaches (eg, motivational interviewing and cognitive behavioral therapy) are evidence-based, more clarity is needed regarding direct evidence of its effectiveness as a mutual aid package. Compared to the methodologically rigorous reviews supporting the effectiveness of 12-step approaches to date, the SMART Recovery reviews have been revealing. We aim to fill this gap by providing a comprehensive overview of the evidence for SMART Improvement in adults with problem alcohol, substance and/or behavioral addictions; this includes a comment on the evaluated results, potential intermediaries, feasibility (including economic consequences), and a critical evaluation. one of the methods used. METHODS AND ANALYSIS: Methods are informed by the Cochrane Guidelines for Systematic Reviews and the Preferred Reporting Items and Meta-Analysis statement for Systematic Reviews. 6 electronic peer-reviewed and 4 gray literature databases were identified. Preliminary searches have been conducted for the SMART Recovery literature (free inclusion criteria are not limited to randomized controlled trials (RCTs), only qualitative designs are excluded). Eligible 'review' articles will be evaluated against standard criteria and checked by an independent reviewer. Searches will be rerun immediately prior to final analyzes and other studies received for inclusion. A narrative synthesis of the findings, structured around the type and content of intervention, population characteristics and outcomes, will be reported. Where possible, 'summary of findings' tables will be created for each comparison. When data are available, we will calculate a hazard ratio for the primary outcome of each trial and its 95% CI (two-divided outcomes) and/or effect size based on Cohen's formula (continuous outcomes). ETHICS AND EXPANDATION: No ethical problems are foreseen. The findings will be widely disseminated to clinicians and researchers through journal publications and conference presentations. PROSPERO REGISTRATION NUMBER: CRD42015025574.

title: Protocol for a systematic review of telephone-delivered psychosocial interventions on relapse prevention, psychiatric medication adherence, and health risk behaviors in adults with psychotic disorders.
abstract: INTRODUCTION: Individuals with psychotic illness typically have poor mental and physical health. When administered, the drug can reduce recurrence. However, despite compliance, relapse remains common and functional outcomes often remain at risk. Compatibility is also generally low. Cardiovascular-related morbidity and mortality also rise with several important modifiable health risk behaviors. Access to psychosocial interventions is therefore important, but currently limited. Telephone interventions represent a promising solution, although more clarity is needed. Accordingly, (1) relapse, (2) dependence on psychiatric medication, and/or (3) modifiable cardiovascular health risk behaviors. METHODS AND ANALYSIS: Our methods are informed by published guidelines. The review is recorded and any protocol changes are tracked. Ten electronic peer-reviewed and four gray literature databases were identified. Preliminary research was conducted for the literature on psychosocial telephone interventions targeting relapse, medication adherence, and/or health risk behaviors in adults with psychotic disorders. Articles classified as 'review' will be evaluated according to standard criteria and checked by an independent reviewer. Searches will be rerun immediately prior to final analyzes and other studies received for inclusion. A narrative synthesis structured around the type and content of intervention, population characteristics and outcomes will be reported. Where possible, 'summary of findings' tables will be created for each comparison. For the primary outcome of each trial, when data are available, we will calculate a hazard ratio and its 95% CI (paired outcomes) and/or effect size based on Cohen's formula (continuous outcomes). ETHICS AND EXPANDATION: No ethical problems are foreseen. The findings will be widely disseminated to clinicians and researchers through journal publications and conference presentations. TRIAL REGISTRATION NUMBER: PROSPPERO CRD42015025402.

title: Protocol processing system (ProtoVIEW) to support residents in the emergency room.
abstract: This article describes the design, implementation, and evaluation of a prototype protocol processing system (ProtoVIEW). ProtoVIEW provides protocol information for diagnostic and therapeutic purposes. The developed system described here is used as a research tool to investigate the impact of automated protocols on physicians' medical decision making. The initial assessment shows that the residents like to use the system and the use of the system leads to a more uniform working strategy.

title: Provider attitudes towards oral pre-exposure prophylaxis for HIV prevention among high-risk men who have sex with men in Lima, Peru
abstract: Oral pre-exposure prophylaxis (PrEP) was the first biomedical intervention to show efficacy in preventing HIV infection among men who have sex with men (MSM). Health care providers' attitudes towards PrEP will be critical in translating this finding into effective public health delivery programs. In a convenient sample of 186 healthcare providers in Peru, we evaluated knowledge, barriers, and attitudes to prescribing and monitoring HIV PrEP for high-risk MSM and trans women, the populations with the highest incidence of HIV in this setting. A total of 57.5% reported PrEP awareness and awareness was independently associated with looking at more than 50 MSMs (OR: 3.67, p<0.002). Lack of local guidelines, concerns about increasing high-risk behavior, antiretroviral drug resistance, and limited availability of antiretrovirals for HIV-infected individuals were the most common barriers to prescribing PrEP. 44.6% of all physicians said they are now more likely to prescribe oral PrEP";" Probability of prescribing if PrEP is supported by local guidelines (70.3%, p<0.001), supports further study efficacy (68.5%, p<0.001), and intermittent use is shown to be effective (62.2%, p<0.001) was higher. =0.019). If physicians cared for more than 50 MSMs, they were now more likely to prescribe PrEP (OR: 6.62, p=0.010). Infectious disease specialists were less likely to prescribe PrEP (OR: 0.10, p=0.003) than non-specialists. Successful large-scale implementation of PrEP in Peru will require focused education campaigns to raise awareness and address concerns among healthcare providers.

title: Provider detailing: an intervention to reduce prescription opioid deaths in Utah
abstract: BACKGROUND: Utah has made a multi-pronged effort to reverse the epidemic of death among patients taking prescription opioids. This article describes the provider details of the effort. METHODS: Presentations highlighting the six recommended prescribing practices were developed and presented to healthcare professionals. Participants were encouraged to use the state prescription database and complete a series of questionnaires that assessed confidence and behavior changes at 0, 1, and 6 months after presentation. Continuing medical education credits encouraged participation. RESULTS: Utah's drug-induced overdose deaths fell 14.0% in 2008 compared to 2007 after program implementation. A total of 581 physicians and many non-physician healthcare professionals were reached in 46 presentations. Monitoring surveys on the degree of adoption of application changes were completed by 366 respondents at 0 months, 82 at 1 month, and 29 at 6 months. Combined results for all three assessments reported that 60-80% of responding providers no longer prescribed long-acting opioids for acute pain or tranquilizers"; 50% using Utah's database of controlled substances during patient care and lower starting doses and Saved using slower increments. ;" and 30-50% reported receiving ECG and sleep studies in eligible patients, using patient education tools, and following Utah's prescribing guidelines. RESULTS: Provider sophistication was associated with decreases in Utah's prescription opioid death rate and improvements in provider-reported prescribing behaviors. Other concomitant interventions may have contributed to the reduction in mortality rates. The impact of this intervention was limited to short-term financing.

title: Provider training to promote the application of clinical practice guidelines
abstract: STUDY OBJECTIVES: Although interest in and publication of clinical practice guidelines has increased significantly over the past 20 years, there are concerns about their actual application. This article focuses on one strategy to encourage practice of guidelines at the clinician level: clinician education. The aims of the article are to review training strategies, to evaluate them in the context of complementary strategies carried out at organizational and clinical setting levels, and to summarize challenges and recommendations for continuing education of clinicians. METHODS: Experience and data from relevant randomized clinical trials are reviewed in an educational framework. OBSERVATIONS: Implementing clinical practice guidelines requires a variety of skills, including assessment, appropriate definition of a treatment and monitoring plan, patient follow-up, and patient counseling and training skills. Continuing education strategies should reflect the content and teaching methods best suited to the learning objectives. The pressures of today's practice place limitations on the resources available for continuing education, particularly clinician time. Institutional resources should be dedicated to establishing the complementary supportive systems necessary for improved clinician practice. In addition to physicians, training should be aimed at non-physician clinicians, office staff, and managers who are also responsible for the implementation of the guideline. CONCLUSIONS: To meet the challenges of improving clinician motivation, balancing competing demands, and treating patients with complex medical conditions within time constraints, clinical leaders need to design educational activities with leadership support, reflective evidence, using multiple strategies and teaching techniques. and engage students in skill development and problem solving.

title: Providing social norm feedback to high antibiotic prescribers in general practice: a pragmatic national randomized controlled trial.
abstract: Background Unnecessary prescribing of antibiotics contributes to antimicrobial resistance. In this trial, we aimed to reduce the unnecessary prescribing of antibiotics by GPs (GPs) in the UK. Methods In this randomized, 2?Ã—?2 factorial trial, public databases were used to identify GP practices with antibiotic prescribing rates in the top 20% for the NHS Local Area Team. Eligible applications were randomly divided into two groups (1:1) in order of computer-generated allocation, stratified by the NHS Local Area Team. Participants, not researchers, were blinded to group assignments. On 29 September 2014, each GP in the feedback intervention group was sent a letter from the UK's Chief Medical Officer and a brochure on antibiotics for use in patients. The letter noted that the practice prescribed antibiotics in more than 80% of practices in the NHS Local Area Team. General practitioners in the control group received no communication. The sample was re-randomized into two groups, and in December 2014, GP practices were either sent patient-oriented information that reduced antibiotic use or received no communication. The primary outcome measure was the proportion of antibiotic substances dispensed per 1000 weighted population, controlling for past prescriptions. The analysis was therapeutic. This trial is registered and completed with ISRCTN registration number ISRCTN32349954. Results Between September 8 and September 26, 2014, we recruited and assigned 1581 GP practices to the feedback intervention (n=791) or control (n=790) groups. Letters were sent to 3227 general practitioners in the intervention group. Between October 2014 and March 2015, the proportion of antibiotic substances dispensed per 1000 population was 126Â·98 (95% CI 125Â·68-â€“128Â·27) and 131Â·25 (130Â·33â€) in the feedback intervention group. “132Â·16) control group 4Â·27 (3Â·3”; incidence rate ratio [IRR] 0Â·967 [95% CI 0Â·957â€“0Â·977]; p<0Â· 0001), estimated 73 distributed ?406 represents fewer antibiotic items In December 2014, GP practices were reassigned to the patient-focused intervention (n=777) or control (n=804) groups Does not significantly affect the primary outcome measure between December 2014 and March 2015 (per 1000 population antibiotic items dispensed: 135Â·00 [95% CI 133Â·77–136Â·22] in the patient-focused intervention group and 98 [133Â·06–134Â·90] in the control group, IRR 1Â·01, 95% for difference between groups GA 1Â·00–1Â·02; p=0Â·105 Interpretation The high-profile messenger of social norm feedback can significantly reduce antibiotic p rewriting at low cost and at a national scale,” this result makes it a valuable addition to antimicrobial management programs.

title: Providing tapped conversations with neonatologists to mothers of infants in intensive care: randomized controlled trial
abstract: OBJECTIVE To determine whether keeping audio recordings of the conversations with a neonatologist of infant mothers in neonatal intensive care units improves information recall and psychological well-being. DESIGN Randomized, single-blind trial. SETTING Neonatal intensive care unit, North Queensland, Australia. PARTICIPANTS 200 mothers of babies are in a neonatal intensive care unit. INTERVENTIONS Audio recordings of conversations with a neonatologist given or not given (n=102) to mothers (n=98). KEY OUTCOME MEASURES At day 10 and at 4 and 12 months, recall of information, attitudes and use of tape, satisfaction with conversations, postpartum depression, anxiety, general health, and parenting stress. RESULTS 91% (n=93) of mothers in the tape group listened to the tape (once at day 10, twice at 4 months, and three times at 12 months"; range 1-10). At four months, mothers in the patch group were 75% more likely to remember all treatment-related information than mothers in the control group (59% vs 34%; "hazard ratio 1.75, 95% confidence interval 1.27 to 2.4). Six mothers, all in the control group, could not remember their speech. There was no statistically significant difference between the groups in terms of satisfaction with the conversations (10 days), postpartum depression and anxiety scores (10 days, four and 12 months), and parenting-related stress (12 months). CONCLUSION Providing voice recordings of conversations with a neonatologist to mothers of infants hospitalized in neonatal intensive care units increased their recall of information (up to four months). Recorded conversations did not affect mothers' well-being or satisfaction with the neonatologist. TRIAL REGISTRATION Australian Clinical Trials Registry 12606000478516.

title: Psychiatric experiment: history lessons
Psychoeducation: improving outcomes in bipolar disorder
abstract: BACKGROUND: A relevant paradigm shift in the treatment of bipolar disorder began a few years ago";" Important findings on the usefulness of psychological interventions clearly support the shift from a purely pharmacological therapeutic approach to a unified but hierarchical model in which pharmacotherapy plays a central role, but psychological interventions can help bridge the gap between theoretical effectiveness and "real world" effectiveness. . Here we review the effectiveness of several adjunctive psychotherapies in the maintenance treatment of bipolar patients. METHODS: A systematic review of the relevant literature was conducted using the MEDLINE and CURRENT CONTENTS databases. "Bipolar", "Psychotherapy", "Psychoeducation", "Cognitive-behavioral" and "Relapse prevention" were entered as keywords. CONCLUSIONS: Psychological treatments specifically designed for the prevention of relapse in bipolar mood disorder, together with mood stabilizers, are useful tools. Most recently published psychotherapy studies report positive results on maintenance as adjunctive therapy and efficacy in the treatment of depressive episodes. Interestingly, several groups around the world reported similar positive results and achieved very similar results";" Almost every intervention tested includes important psychoeducational elements, including both enhancing compliance and early identification of prodromal symptoms – emphasizing the importance of lifestyle regularity – and exploring patients' health beliefs and disease awareness. CONCLUSIONS: The utility of psychotherapy for improving adherence and clinical outcomes of bipolar patients is currently unquestionable and future treatment guidelines should encourage its regular use among clinicians. As clinicians, it is our greatest mission to provide our patients with the best treatment available, and this includes both evidence-based psychoeducational programs and newer pharmacological agents.

title: Psychological and Behavioral Interventions for the Management of Insomnia Disorder: An Evidence Report by the American College of Physicians for Clinical Practice Guidelines
abstract: BACKGROUND: Psychological and behavioral interventions are often used for insomnia disorder. OBJECTIVE: To evaluate the benefits and harms of psychological and behavioral interventions for insomnia in adults. DATA SOURCES: Supported by Ovid MEDLINE, Embase, Cochrane Central Register of Controlled Trials and via PsycINFO September 2015, manual search. STUDY SELECTION: Randomized, controlled trials of psychological or behavioral interventions published in English and enrolled in adults with insomnia lasting 4 or more weeks. reviewer"; dual investigative assessment of risk of bias;" Consensus determination of strength of evidence. DATA SYNTHESIS: Sixty studies with low to moderate risk of bias compared psychological and behavioral interventions with inactive controls or other psychological and behavioral interventions. Cognitive behavioral therapy for insomnia (CBT-I) generally improved post-treatment global and most sleep outcomes compared with information or waiting list controls (moderate-strength evidence). Use of CBT-I improved several sleep outcomes in older adults (low to moderate evidence). Multicomponent behavioral therapy improved several sleep outcomes in older adults (low to moderate evidence). Stimulus control improved 1 or 2 sleep outcomes (low-powered evidence). The evidence for other comparisons and harms was insufficient to draw conclusions. LIMITATIONS: The wide range of comparisons has limited the ability to aggregate the data. Trials did not always report global results, and rarely did the sender or responder analysis. Comparisons were usually groups of information or waiting lists, and publication bias was possible. CONCLUSION: The use of CBT-I improves most outcomes compared to inactive controls. Multicomponent behavioral therapy and stimulus control may improve some sleep outcomes. Other results, comparisons, and evidence for long-term efficacy were limited.

title: Psychological treatments for post-traumatic stress disorder: recommendations for the clinician based on a review of the literature
abstract: This article reviews current research data supporting the use of psychotherapy in the treatment of post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD). The authors highlight how this evidence can inform clinical choices in the treatment of PTSD and show how assumptions based on gaps in the current literature can be misleading. The authors first discuss the findings on a range of interventions commonly used in the treatment of trauma survivors or PTSD patients: critical-event stress interrogation, psychoeducation, exposure therapy, eye movement desensitization reprocessing, stress inoculation therapy, trauma management therapy, cognitive therapy, psychodynamic psychotherapy, and hypnotherapy. They also discuss a number of treatment strategies recently reviewed in PTSD, including imagery rehearsal, memory structure intervention, interpersonal psychotherapy, and dialectical behavior therapy. PTSD is associated with significant symptomatic morbidity, but desired outcomes in clinical practice typically relate to reductions in social, interpersonal, and occupational impairment. The most methodologically sound studies that typically examine cognitive or behavioral treatments show that psychotherapy helps alleviate symptom severity";" however, although these problems are often of greatest concern to patients, there is no consistent information on whether these interventions are helpful in improving other areas of impairment and related disability. Furthermore, the available evidence does not indicate when and for whom various psychotherapeutic interventions should be provided, or whether different treatment modalities can be combined or offered sequentially, as is often done in specific treatment programmes. Clinicians should keep these issues in mind when reviewing the literature on current (and future) clinical trials. Unfortunately, the available psychotherapy-based evidence for PTSD provides only limited guidance regarding clinical choices in the management of PTSD. Therefore, the authors provide some literature-based clinical guidelines for clinicians treating patients with PTSD.

title: Psychometric Analysis of the Three-Factor Eating Questionnaire-R18V2 in Adolescent and Young Adult-Old CNS Tumor Survivors
abstract: OBJECTIVE: Adolescent and young adult (FNA) central nervous system (CNS) tumor survivors are an understudied population at risk of developing adverse health outcomes such as obesity. Long-term follow-up guidelines recommend monitoring those at risk for obesity, thereby motivating the need for an eating behavior questionnaire. A shortened online version of the Three-Factor Eating Questionnaire (TFEQ-R18v2) has been developed, but its applicability to this population is not yet known. This study investigated the factor structure and reliability of the instrument in this universe. METHODS: AYA-aged CNS tumor survivors (n = 114) aged 15-39 years completed the TFEQ-R18V2 questionnaire online. Confirmatory factor analysis was used to examine the relevance of the three-factor construct (uncontrollable eating, cognitive restriction, and emotional eating [EE]) and reliability (internal consistency of TFEQ-R18v2). Relationships between the three factors and body mass index (BMI) were evaluated by linear regression. RESULTS: The theorized three-factor construct was supported in our population (RMSEA = 0.056 and CFI = 0.98) and showed good reliability (0.81-0.93 alpha). EE (beta = 0.07, 95% CI 0.02-0.13) was positively associated with BMI, while the other two subscale scores were not. CONCLUSION: The TFEQ-R18v2 device shows promise for research and clinical use among AYA-aged CNS tumor survivors. The tool could be a useful tool for researchers to develop personalized weight management strategies. It can also be a valuable tool for clinicians to monitor and facilitate referral of survivors at risk of obesity. Our results also suggest that IE in this population should be further investigated as a potential target for intervention.

title: Psychopharmacology in pregnancy
abstract: Clinicians face challenging situations when working with women who are pregnant and have a comorbid mental illness. A risk-benefit assessment is helpful when identifying possible care interventions. Psychopharmaceutical intervention is a consideration when non-pharmacological interventions are ineffective or inappropriate. Informed consent should be obtained based on known and unknown risks to the mother and fetus. The literature and case reports on the risks of drugs used for psychiatric diseases are contradictory and inconclusive. This article reviews the literature and provides clinical guidelines for antipsychotic medications, antidepressant medications, mood-stabilizing medications, and antianxiety medications.

title: Psychosocial aspects in cardiac rehabilitation: From theory to practice. A status sheet from the Cardiac Rehabilitation Division of the European Society of Cardiovascular Prevention and Rehabilitation of the European Society of Cardiology
abstract: Numerous empirical studies show that psychosocial risk factors (PSRFs) such as low socio-economic status, social isolation, stress, type D personality, depression and anxiety increase the risk of coronary heart disease (CHD) and also increase the risk of coronary heart disease. Worse health-related quality of life (HRQoL) and prognosis in patients with CHD. PSRFs may also be a barrier to lifestyle changes and treatment compliance and may alleviate the effects of cardiac rehabilitation (CR). There also appears to be a bidirectional interaction between PSRFs and the cardiovascular system. Stress, anxiety, and depression affect the cardiovascular system through immune, neuroendocrine, and behavioral pathways. In contrast, CHD and related treatments can cause distress in patients, including anxiety and depression. In clinical practice, PSRFs can be assessed with single-item screening questions, standard questionnaires, or structured clinical interviews. Psychotherapy and medication may be considered to alleviate any PSRF-related symptoms and improve HRQoL, but there is insufficient evidence of a definitive beneficial effect on cardiac endpoints. A multimodal behavioral intervention, integrated counseling for PSRFs and coping with illness should be included in comprehensive CR. Patients with clinically significant symptoms of distress should be referred for counseling or psychologically focused interventions and/or psychopharmacological treatment. Consequently, the success of CR may critically depend on the interdependence of body and mind, and this interaction needs to be reflected through the evaluation and management of PSRFs in line with sound scientific evidence by trained personnel integrated into the core CR team.

title: Pulmonary edema accelerated by nifedipine
Putting the evidence into practice: evidence-based interventions for sleep-wake disorders
abstract: Symptom management is a vital aspect of oncology nursing practice. The Oncology Nursing Association has identified nursing intervention-sensitive outcomes known as nursing-sensitive patient outcomes. This article provides information on sleep-wake disorders in cancer patients and makes recommendations for evidence-based interventions to improve patients' sleep. Sleep-wake disorders occur in 30-75% of people with cancer and adversely affect other symptoms and quality of life. Despite the frequency and severity of sleep-wake disorders, limited research has tested interventions to improve sleep-wake outcomes. While no interventions currently receive the highest recommendations for practice, some non-pharmacological interventions show initial positive findings in promoting high-quality sleep and daytime functioning. Oncology nurses can screen for sleep-wake disorders and recommend specific interventions. Four promising categories of interventions are cognitive-behavioral therapy, complementary therapies, psychoeducation and information, and exercise. Clinicians can use the Putting Evidence Into Practice (PEP) card and PEP resources at www.ons.org/outcomes to improve sleep-wake outcomes.

title: Putting prevention into practice
abstract: In primary medical care settings, disease prevention services are provided at lower rates than recommended. Also, practitioners tend to exaggerate their realization rate. There are essentially two steps in providing evidence-based preventive services: (1) knowing what the evidence is to perform various detection and response maneuvers, and (2) integrating preventive services into daily practice. The first is a scientific process and is conducted in Canada by the Canadian Task Force on Periodic Health Examination. However, after ten years of experience with evidence-based guidelines, we now know that guidelines are not enough. Integrating clinical prevention into intensive practice is a political and logistical process. This fact is best captured by the joke, "An ounce of prevention requires a pound of office system change." A number of studies have shown that continuing medical education (CME) courses and workshops for physicians are not sufficient to ensure clinical preventive services are incorporated into practice. According to Lomas, traditional CME education approaches need to be complemented by strategies that come from paradigms such as the social impact model, the innovation diffusion model, and the adult learning model. In his book "From Science to Practice," Battista draws attention to the complexity of the communication process required to spread innovation into practice. Walsh's Model of Clinical Preventive Care Systems best captures the interactive factors that mediate practitioners' intentions and actions when it comes to delivering clinical prevention services. This article reports a practical example of helping family practitioners develop a "sustainable office system in prevention" that minimizes barriers, focuses energy, and integrates clinical prevention into office routines. Key components are (i) a practice coordinator for prevention, (ii) clear clinical prevention-related job descriptions for all patient caregivers, (iii) a prevention-enhancing information management system, and (iv) a practice feedback and problem-solving strategy.

title: Qualitative data collection and analysis methods: INSTINCT trial
abstract: Patient care practices often lag behind current scientific evidence and professional guidelines. The failure of such knowledge translation (KT) efforts may reflect an inadequate assessment and management of certain barriers faced by both physicians and patients at the treatment level. Effective CC in this setting can benefit from the use of qualitative methods to identify and overcome these barriers. The qualitative methodology allows for an in-depth exploration of barriers to practice change adoption and has rarely been used in emergency medicine research. The authors describe the methodology for qualitative analysis in the INSTINCT (Increased Stroke Treatment Through Interactive Behavioral Change Tactics) trial. This includes processes for valid data collection and reliable analysis of textual data from focus group and interview transcripts. INSTINCT is a 24-hospital, randomized, controlled trial designed to evaluate a systems-based barrier assessment and interactive educational intervention to increase appropriate tissue plasminogen activator (tPA) use in ischemic stroke. Response hospitals undergo basic barrier assessment using both qualitative and quantitative (survey) techniques. Researchers obtain data on local barriers to tPA use, as well as information on local attitudes, knowledge, and beliefs regarding acute stroke treatment. Targeted groups at each site include emergency physicians, emergency nurses, neurologists, radiologists, and hospital administrators. Transcript analysis using NVivo7 with a predefined barrier taxonomy is described. This will provide both qualitative information on thrombolytic use and the importance of specific barrier types for each site. Qualitative findings then guide professional education efforts and systems interventions in treatment areas.

title: Qualitative research within trials: developing a standard operating procedure for a clinical research unit
abstract: BACKGROUND: Qualitative research methods are increasingly used in clinical research to address broader research questions than can be addressed by quantitative methods alone. These methods allow healthcare professionals, service users, and other stakeholders to contribute their insights and experience regarding the evaluation of healthcare treatments, interventions or policies and influence the design of trials. Qualitative data often contributes information that could change policy for the better or affect design. METHODS: Healthcare researchers, including trialers, clinicians and qualitative researchers, have worked collaboratively to develop a comprehensive portfolio of standard operating procedures (SOPs) for the West Wales Society for Meticulous Research in Health (WWORTH), a clinical research unit (CTU) . At Swansea University, recently enrolled with the UK Clinical Research Collaboration (UKCRC). While UKCRC requires a total of 25 SOPs from registered CTUs, WWORTH has chosen to add an additional qualitative methods SOP (QM-SOP). CONCLUSIONS: Qualitative methods SOP (QM-SOP) defines good practice in designing and implementing qualitative components of trials while providing flexibility in approach and method. Its basic principles are: qualitative researchers should contribute from the outset of studies with qualitative potential; the qualitative component should have clear objectives; and the main working publication should report on the qualitative component. CONCLUSIONS: We recommend that CTUs consider developing a QM-SOP to improve the conduct of quantitative research by adding qualitative data and analysis. We conclude that this enhances the value of quantitative research and contributes to the future development of multi-method research.

title: Quality assessment in surgical care departments: a proposal for a scoring system in terms of structure and process
abstract: Aim To create a score that can reflect and rank surgical departments according to a definition of "quality" in terms of structure and process. Methods Collaborative design of a quality score within the framework of the French clinical research project NosoQual. Feasibility and observational study in 46 surgical departments visited between November 2002 and March 2003 according to standard procedures. A bibliographic review followed by expert consultations, a field test, analysis, and a final reassessment leading to the definition of a consensus score. The results generated 138 variable scores. They were classified into seven dimensions, each representing a different aspect of quality of care in surgery. Scores were calculated for each section according to the threshold and weight attributed to each variable. The mean achievement level of scores ranged from 42% to 71% of theoretical maximums. The variability of scores on the seven dimensions was greater and significant than that expressed by the total score (coefficient of variation = 0.1). Conclusion This analytical study contributed to the design of a quality score for surgery. However, the progression of the score must continue to account for all observed barriers and meet the high requirements of the real patient safety issue.

title: Quality improvement and changes in diabetic patient outcomes in an academic nurse practitioner primary care practice
abstract: OBJECTIVE: To examine the outcomes of a range of system interventions and care in the management of patients with diabetes. DATA SOURCES: Pre-intervention and post-intervention data collected from electronic medical records. RESULTS: The sample size was smaller than expected and contributed to the lack of statistical significance in patient outcome measures from pre-intervention to post-intervention. System-level variables under the direct control of clinical staff (eg, given pneumococcal vaccine) have improved greatly. In the pre-intervention period, the percentage of "yes" responses to system-level variables ranged from 8 to 24, jumping to 16 to 95 after the intervention. APPLICATIONS FOR IMPLEMENTATION: Clearly, this project has demonstrated that system-level changes result in better care for patients";" however, they had minimal effect on patient outcome variables. Variables under the direct control of clinical staff are more easily modified while promoting change in patient behavior is difficult, which may have contributed to its insignificance in this area.

title: Improving the quality of medical records in a teaching hospital
abstract: INTRODUCTION: The aim of this study was to evaluate the quality of the MRI review before and after the quality improvement intervention in some Operative Units of "Azienda Ospedaliera Universitaria--II Universita di Napoli" (AOU-SUN)-Italy. by highlighting potential differences in the behavior of different specialists (doctors versus surgeons). METHODS: Two random samples of 660 MRs were examined. A four-stage program was developed: (1) Initial assessment of MR"; (2) Implementation of MR quality, sending a letter with the purpose of the study, results from that ward in the first step, guidelines to correctly fill out the MR; (3 ) follow-up step four months later;" (4) Comparison of data before and after distribution of guidelines using indicators of completeness of all parts of the MR, clarity of handwriting, and presence and clarity of signature. RESULTS: The main concerns were the signature of the on-call doctor (2.0% present and only 15.4% legible), the presence of the discharge letter (18.0%), and the clarity of the days of hospital stay (32.0%). ). Improvement in review quality after intervention was modest and considered primarily medical rather than surgical wards. DISCUSSION AND CONCLUSIONS: From a medical and legal point of view, the improvement was unsatisfactory as the indicators needed to reach 100% clarity and completeness. Another study is being carried out to increase the participation of health professionals so that such needs are perceived as a common goal, not just bureaucratic initiatives.

title: Quality of hospital care for children in Kazakhstan, the Republic of Moldova and Russia: systematic observational evaluation
abstract: Background Significant concerns have been raised about the quality of primary hospital care for children in developing countries, but there has been no formal assessment in the Commonwealth of Independent States applying international standards.";" Background Great concern has been expressed about the quality of primary hospital care for children in developing countries, but there has been no formal assessment in the Commonwealth of Independent States applying international standards.

title: Quality of drug advertisements in medical journals: a systematic review.
abstract: BACKGROUND: Magazine advertisements are one of the main sources of drug information to physicians. Although there are regulations and controls on drug promotion around the world, the information on drugs provided in magazine advertisements has been criticized for being of poor quality in several studies. However, no attempt has been made to systematically summarize this research group. We designed this systematic review to evaluate all studies examining the quality of pharmaceutical advertisements for prescription products in medical and pharmaceutical journals. METHODS AND RESULTS: Studies were identified by searching electronic databases, web library, search engine and examining citations (1950 - February 2006). Only articles published in English that examine the quality of information contained in drug advertisements for prescription products in medical or pharmaceutical journals are included. For each eligible article, one researcher independently extracted data on study methodology and results. The data were then reviewed by a second researcher. Any disputes are resolved by consensus. The data were analyzed descriptively. The final analysis included 24 articles. The studies examined ads from 26 countries. The number of journals reviewed in each study ranged from four to 24 journals. Various outcome measures were examined, including testimonials and claims provided in advertisements, availability of product information, adherence to codes or guidelines, and presentation of risk results. Most of the studies used convenience sampling method. Brand name, generic name and indications are usually provided. Journal articles were widely cited to support pharmaceutical claims. Less than 67% of claims were supported by a systematic review, a meta-analysis, or a randomized control trial. In studies that evaluated misleading claims, there was at least one advertisement with a misleading claim. Two studies found that less than 28% of claims were conclusive clinical claims. Most advertisements with quantitative information provided risk results as relative risk reduction. Studies were conducted in only 26 countries, and in this case the generalizability of the results is limited. CONCLUSIONS: Evidence from this review indicates that low-quality magazine advertising is a global problem. Ongoing efforts to increase education on drug promotion are crucial, as the information provided in magazine advertisements has the potential to change the prescribing behavior of physicians. The results of our review highlight the need for a global, proactive and effective regulatory system to ensure that the information provided in medical journal advertisements supports the quality use of medicines.

title: Quantitative comparison of cognitive behavioral therapy and music therapy research: a methodological best practice analysis to guide future research for adult psychiatric patients.
abstract: Although the music therapy profession is relatively young and small, it can treat diverse clinical populations and has established a diverse research base. However, although the profession has arisen from working with people diagnosed with mental illness, there is a significant lack of quantitative research on the effects of music therapy on this population. Music therapy clinicians and researchers have reported on this lack of evidence and the difficulty of conducting psychosocial research on their interventions (Choi, 1997";" Silverman, 2003a). While published studies offer recommendations for future research, no study has provided detailed recommendations for the methodology and design of rigorous high-quality randomized controlled psychiatric music therapy trials. How do other psychotherapies acquire their database, and can the music therapy field borrow from their rigorous "methodological best practices" to strengthen its literature base? Therefore, since the National Institutes of Mental Health has indicated that cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT) is the treatment of choice for evidence-based psychotherapy, aspects of this psychotherapy's literature base were analyzed. The purpose of this literature review is (a) to analyze and identify components of high-quality quantitative CBT research for adult psychiatric consumers, (b) to analyze and identify variables and other elements of quantitative psychiatric music therapy research available to adult consumers, and (c) with the mental health population. Compare the two datasets to identify the best methodological designs and variables for future quantitative music therapy research. To identify the key components of high-quality experimental research designs and the application of quantitative clinical trials, a table is included that analyzes randomized and comprehensive controlled trials involving the use of CBT for people with severe mental illness. The table also shows the same analyzed components for current quantitative psychiatric music therapy research with adult consumers, thus highlighting potential areas and elements for future research. A second table shows a range of potential dependent measures and their sources to be evaluated in future music therapy studies. A third table, which provides recommendations for future research, is derived from a synthesis of the tables and is included to guide researchers and encourage the advancement and expansion of the existing literature base. The body of the article is a discussion of literature analysis results from tables, meta-analyses, and literature reviews. It is hoped that this report will lead to the addition of future high-quality quantitative research to the psychiatric music therapy literature, thereby providing evidence-based services to as many people with mental illness as possible.

title: The pursuit of quality care and patient safety: the Singapore case
abstract: Quality of care in Singapore has witnessed a paradigm shift from the traditional focus on structural approaches to a broader multidimensional concept involving monitoring of clinical signs and medical errors. Strong political commitment and institutional capacities have been key factors in making the transition happen. What is lacking, though, is a culture of rigorous program evaluation, public participation, and patient empowerment. Despite these shortcomings, Singapore has made significant strides, and its experience can teach lessons for other smaller developing countries in the common quest for quality care and patient safety.

title: Quetiapine supplementation for depression: a dosing model in routine practice
abstract: This study investigated dosing patterns of quetiapine supplementation (QA) for major depressive disorder (MDD) in routine practice. Patients diagnosed with MDD who were taking QA with an ongoing antidepressant between January 1, 2009 and May 31, 2013 were included in this study. A total of 977 patients' electronic medical records and clinical data were reviewed for up to one year. Almost half of the patients continued their QA treatment for more than 3 months. The mean CG duration was approximately 6 months, and the mean initial and maintenance doses were 23.6 and 40.7 mg/day, respectively (range=12.5-400 mg/day). The most common adverse events observed were somnolence, followed by dry mouth and drowsiness. Our results suggest that in routine practice, actual QA doses for MDD should be lower than those used in placebo-controlled clinical trials and those recommended by a regulatory agency. Sufficiently robust and well-controlled prospective studies are needed to better understand the precise role of low-dose QA in the treatment of MDD, especially in routine practice.

title: Randomized controlled trial of a complex intervention by primary care nurses to increase walking in patients aged 60-74 years: PACE-Lift protocol (Pedometer Accelerometer Consultation Assessment - Lifting) trial
abstract: BACKGROUND: Physical activity is essential for older people to maintain physical and mental health and independence. Guidelines recommend at least 150 minutes of activity per week, with at least moderate-intensity physical activity most days. The most common physical activity of the elderly is walking, if walking is light intensity, if it is brisk, moderate intensity. Less than 20% of 65-74-year-olds in the UK report meeting the guidelines, although most do. Effective behavior modification techniques include strategies such as goal setting, self-monitoring, building self-efficacy, and relapse prevention. Primary care physical activity consultations allow for individual tailoring of recommendations. Pedometers measure step counts and accelerometers measure physical activity intensity. This protocol describes an innovative intervention to improve walking in older people using behavior modification techniques, including pedometer and accelerometer feedback as part of a primary care nurse physical activity consultation. METHODS/DESIGN: DESIGN: Randomized controlled trial with intervention and control (usual care) arms plus process and qualitative assessments. PARTICIPANTS: 300 people aged 60-74, registered in 3 general practices in Oxfordshire and Berkshire West primary care foundations, can walk outside without any restrictions to increase their physical activity. INTERVENTION: 3-month pedometer and accelerometer-based intervention supported by practice nurse physical activity consultations. Four consultations based on behavior modification techniques, physical activity diary, average daily step-by-step steps, and accelerometer feedback on physical activity intensity. Individual physical activity plans will be produced based on increased walking and other available physical activities. RESULTS: Change in mean weekly daily steps (primary outcome) and mean time spent in at least moderate-intensity physical activity (secondary outcome) at 3 months and 12 months, as assessed by accelerometry. Other outcomes include quality of life, mood, exercise self-efficacy, injuries. Qualitative assessments will explore reasons for not participating in the trial, acceptability of the intervention by patients and nurses, and factors that hinder or increase the physical activity level of the elderly. CONCLUSION: The PACE-Lift trial will determine the feasibility and efficacy of an intervention to increase physical activity among elderly primary care patients. Steps taken and anticipated challenges to minimize bias will be discussed. Word number 341. TRIAL REGISTRATION NUMBER: ISRCTN42122561.

title: Randomized controlled trial of Alexander technique classes, exercise, and massage (ATEAM) for chronic and recurrent back pain
abstract: OBJECTIVE To determine the effectiveness of the Alexander technique, massage therapy and exercise advice from the doctor (exercise prescription) courses and, together with the nurse, to provide behavioral counseling to patients with chronic or recurrent back pain. DESIGN Factorial randomized trial. SETTING 64 General applications in the UK. PARTICIPANTS 579 patients with chronic or recurrent low back pain"; 144 were randomized to normal care, 147 to massage, 144 to six Alexander technique lessons, and 144 to 24 Alexander technique lessons;" half of each of these groups were randomized to prescribe exercise. INTERVENTIONS Normal care (control), six sessions of massage, six or 24 lectures on the Alexander technique, and exercise prescription from a doctor with a nurse provided behavioral counseling. MAIN OUTCOME MEASURES Roland Morris disability score (number of activities impaired by pain) and number of days with pain. RESULTS Exercises and lessons in the Alexander technique, but not massage, remained effective at one year (compared to control Roland injury score 8.1: massage -0.58, 95% confidence interval -1.94 to 0.77, six lessons -1.40, -2.77 to -0.03) , 24 lesson -3.4, -4.76 to -2.03 and exercise -1.29, -2.25 to -0.34. Exercise after six lessons provided 72% of the effect of only 24 lessons (Roland disability score of -2.98 and -4.14, respectively). The number of days with back pain in the last four weeks was lower after classes (compared to control median 21 days: 24 lessons -18, six lessons -10, massage -7), and quality of life improved significantly. No significant damage was reported. CONCLUSIONS One-on-one lessons in the Alexander technique from registered teachers have long-term benefits for patients with chronic back pain. The six lessons followed by the exercise prescription were almost as effective as the 24 lessons. TRIAL REGISTRATION National Research Registry N0028108728.

title: Randomized controlled trial of Alexander technique classes, exercise, and massage (ATEAM) for chronic and recurrent back pain: economic evaluation.
abstract: OBJECTIVE An economic evaluation of therapeutic massage, exercise and classes in the Alexander technique for treating persistent back pain. DESIGN Cost outcomes study and cost-effectiveness analysis at 12-month follow-up of a factorial randomized controlled trial. PARTICIPANTS 579 patients with chronic or recurrent low back pain from primary care. INTERVENTIONS Six or 24 lessons in normal care (control), massage and Alexander technique. Half of each group were randomized to receive an exercise prescription from a doctor plus behavioral counseling from a nurse. MAIN OUTCOME MEASURES Costs for the NHS and participants. Comparison of costs with Roland-Morris disability score (number of activities impaired by pain), painful days, and quality-adjusted life years (QALYs). NHS costs versus QALY earnings using incremental cost-effectiveness rates and cost-effectiveness acceptability curves. RESULTS Intervention costs ranged from £30 for an exercise prescription to £596 for 24 lessons in the Alexander technique plus exercise. Healthcare costs ranged from £50 for 24 lessons in the Alexander technique to £124 for exercise. An incremental analysis of cost-effectiveness of single treatments showed that exercise offered the best value (£61 per point in disability score, £9 per additional pain-free day, £2847 per QALY gain). For the two-stage therapy, six courses combined with exercise in the Alexander technique were the best value (additional pound64 per point on disability score, pound43 per additional pain-free day, 5332 pounds per QALY gain). RESULTS In an exercise prescription and the Alexander technique alone, both six lessons were more than 85% likely to be cost effective at values above £20,000 per QALY, but the Alexander technique outperformed exercise in all outcomes. In Alexander technique classes, the combination of six lessons followed by exercises was the most effective and cost-effective option.

title: Randomized controlled trial of integrated care to reduce disability from chronic low back pain in work and private life
abstract: OBJECTIVE To evaluate the effectiveness of an integrated care program combining patient-directed and workplace-directed intervention for patients with chronic low back pain. DESIGN Population-based randomized controlled trial. ENVIRONMENT Primary care (10 physiotherapy practices, one occupational health service, one occupational therapy practice) and secondary care (five hospitals). PARTICIPANTS 134 adults aged 18-65 years were listed because of low back pain for at least 12 weeks. INTERVENTION Patients were randomly assigned to usual care (n=68) or integrated care (n=66). Integrated care consisted of a participatory ergonomics-based workplace intervention involving a supervisor and a gradual program of activities based on cognitive behavioral principles. KEY OUTCOME MEASURES The primary outcome was time off from work (work disability) due to low back pain until return to full sustainable work. Secondary outcome measures were pain intensity and functional status. RESULTS The median time to return to sustainable employment was 88 days in the integrated care group compared to 208 days in the regular care group (P=0.003). Integrated care was effective in returning to work (hazard ratio 1.9, 95% confidence interval 1.2 to 2.8, P=0.004). After 12 months, patients in the integrated care group had significantly greater improvement in functional status compared with patients in the usual care group (P=0.01). The relief of pain did not differ significantly between the groups. CONCLUSION The integrated care program has significantly reduced disability due to chronic low back pain in private and work life. Trial registration Available Controlled Trials ISRCTN28478651.

title: Randomized controlled trial of adapted strategies to implement guidelines for the management of patients with depression in general practice.
abstract: BACKGROUND: Various methods are available to implement changes in the clinical behavior of general practitioners (GPs). While passive dissemination is generally ineffective, other methods can be variably effective. Few studies have investigated the effect of adapted methods. OBJECTIVE: To determine whether methods designed to overcome barriers to change using psychological theories are more effective than dissemination alone in the implementation of depression guidelines among GPs. STUDY DESIGN: Randomized controlled trial. SETTING: Sixty general practices in the UK"; 30 GPs in the control group, 34 GPs in the intervention group. METHODS: Practitioners identified patients presenting with depression before and after the implementation of the guidelines (control group n = 192 at first data collection, n = 181 at second; first intervention group n = 210 at data collection and n = 197 in the second. The main outcome measures were: record of adherence to guideline recommendations in clinical records;" Proportion of patients with Beck Depression Inventory (BDI) score less than 11 at 16 weeks after diagnosis. RESULTS: Compared with control group Compared to the general practice group, there was an increase in the proportion of patients evaluated for suicide risk in the group of GPs in the private practice group. In the intervention group, the proportion of patients with a BDI score below 11 at 16 weeks increased. CONCLUSION: Barriers to implementation can be identified and strategies can be adapted. It points to a new approach to understanding and improving their methods.

title: Randomized controlled trial to change hospital management of unstable angina
abstract: OBJECTIVES: To examine the benefits of a guideline-based education program to improve the management of unstable angina pectoris (UAP) in hospital patients. DESIGN: Randomized controlled trial. LOCATION: 37 public hospitals across New South Wales. PATIENTS: 1,872 patients admitted with the diagnosis of UAP between February 1 and June 30, 1996 (baseline questionnaire), and 1,368 patients admitted with the same diagnosis between July 1 and December 31, 1998 (follow-up questionnaire). INTERVENTION: Training sessions led by local opinion leaders, providing guidelines from the National Health and Medical Research Council on the management of UAP, and providing feedback on local practice using data from the baseline survey. Sessions were held between March and June 1998. MAIN OUTCOME MEASURES: Use of evidence-based practice determined by medical record review. RESULTS: Beta blocker use increased in intervention and control hospitals, but the increase was significant only in the first. The use of calcium channel blockers has decreased significantly in both intervention and control hospitals. However, the variation in drug use between baseline and follow-up did not differ significantly between intervention and control hospitals. CONCLUSIONS: Despite some favorable changes in drug use for the management of UAP between 1996 and 1998, there was no evidence that a guideline-based education program was beneficial in changing management. This reaffirms the challenge of changing doctors' behavior through practice guidelines. Alternative methods should be considered to promote evidence-based practice.

title: Randomized trial of an integrated education strategy to reduce trial rates in young women with dysfunctional uterine bleeding.
abstract: OBJECTIVES: To evaluate the efficacy of an integrated training strategy to change clinician behavior and reduce the number of hysteroscopy and/or dilatation and abortions in women aged 40 years and younger with dysfunctional uterine bleeding (DUB). Design: Randomized controlled trial with six-month follow-up. ENVIRONMENT: Public teaching hospital gynecology units with 12,000-13,000 relevant procedures per year. PARTICIPANTS: Six public gynecology units consisting of 62 gynecologists or trainees randomly assigned to the intervention group - three or the control group. opinion leader and a layered algorithm and guidelines. MAIN OUTCOME MEASURES: Number of hysteroscopy and/or dilatation and abortion performed for DUB in women aged 40 years and younger, clinician behavior change, and perceived reservation rates of the procedure. RESULTS: There was no significant effect on the number of hysteroscopy and/or dilatation and curettage performed at six months, but there was an increase in evidence-based behavior. CONCLUSIONS: The evidence-based education strategy for the appropriate investigation of young women with DUB did not result in a reduction in hysteroscopy/D&C rates at six months, while resulting in clinician behavior change when applied to theoretical cases.

title: Randomized clinical trial of a customized electronic alert requiring a positive response compared to a control group receiving a commercial passive CPOE alert: NSAID-warfarin co-prescription as test case.
abstract: Background Studies examining the effectiveness of computerized decision support systems to prevent drug-drug interactions have reported modest results due to the low response of providers to automated alerts. Purpose To evaluate the increased effectiveness of a provider-required stimulus within the inpatient computerized physician order entry (CPOE) system, designed as a more powerful intervention to prevent concurrent orders of warfarin and nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs. NSAIDs). Design Randomized clinical trial of 1963 clinicians assigned to an intervention group that received a customized electronic stimulus requiring a positive response, or to a control group that received a commercially available passive stimulus as part of the CPOE. The study period was from August 2, 2006 to December 15, 2007. Measures Stimulus compliance were compared between study groups. Results The proportion of requested order responses (ie, not reordering the alert-triggering drug after firing) was lower in the intervention group (114/464 (25%) customized alert issued) compared to the control group (154/560 (28%). ) passive alerts firing). The adjusted OR for the non-conforming rank was 1.22 (95% CI 0.69 to 2.16). Outcome A customized CPOE warning requiring a provider response had no effect in reducing co-prescription of NSAIDs and warfarin beyond the commercially available passive warning received by the control group. New CPOE alerts cannot be assumed to be effective in improving prescribing, and evaluation is needed.

title: Randomized controlled clinical trial of efficacy of cognitive behavior therapy compared to usual treatment for persistent insomnia in cancer patients.
abstract: OBJECTIVE: Persistent insomnia is a common complaint in cancer survivors, but is seldom satisfactorily addressed. Adapting a validated, cost-effective intervention to cancer treatment may offer a viable solution. The aim of this study was to investigate the clinical efficacy of protocol-based cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT) for insomnia by oncology nurses. PATIENTS AND METHODS: Randomized, controlled, pragmatic, two-center study of CBT versus usual therapy (TAU) in 150 patients (103 women"; mean age, 61 years) who completed active breast, prostate, colorectal, or gynecologic cancer Study CONSORT Primary outcomes were sleep diary measures at baseline, post-treatment, and at 6-month follow-up. Secondary measures of actigraphic sleep, health-related quality of life (QOL), psychopathology, and fatigue. CBT consisted of five small group sessions over consecutive weeks after a manualized protocol. TAU represented normal clinical practice; appropriate control for clinical efficacy study. RESULTS: CBT was associated with a mean reduction in wakefulness of 55 minutes per night compared to no change in TAU. These results persisted 6 months after treatment. Difficulty initiating sleep, nocturnal sleep deprivation standardized for complaints of waking and sleep efficiency (percentage of time spent sleeping in bed) The work-relative effect sizes were large. CBT was associated with moderate to large effect sizes for five of the seven QOL outcomes, including significant reduction in daytime fatigue. There were no significant interaction effects between any of these results and baseline demographic, clinical, or sleep characteristics. CONCLUSION: CBT for insomnia can be both clinically effective and applicable in real-world practice.

title: Randomized controlled trial of a computer strategy to increase GP preventative care
abstract: BACKGROUND: Previous interventions targeting primary care practitioners with the aim of increasing preventive care delivery have shown limited effectiveness. The primary objective of this study was to evaluate the efficacy of a computerized continuing medical education program to increase rates of three screening behaviors (cholesterol, blood pressure, and cervical screening) and to identify three risky behaviors (smoking, alcohol consumption, benzodiazepine use). in general practice. METHODS: Nineteen GPs were randomly assigned to intervention or control conditions. Responders received a computerized feedback system. The intervention was performed using a touchscreen computer located in the surgery waiting area. Preventive behaviors of interest were patients' smoking, alcohol use, benzodiazepine use, and blood pressure, cholesterol, and cervical screening with the Papanicolou test. In each of the outcomes, differences in performance by group were measured at baseline and at 3-month follow-up. Generalized estimation equations and logistic regression analyzes were performed as the main analyzes. CONCLUSION: At 3-month follow-up, statistically significant differences were evident in the following outcome measures: correct classification of benzodiazepine users (z = 2.8540, P < 0.05)"; correct classification of non-benzodiazepine users (z = 2.7339, P < 0.05); dangerous or harmful alcohol drinkers correct classification (z = 2.3079, P < 0.02); blood pressure screening (z = 3.4136, P < 0.001);" and cholesterol screening (z = 6.6313, P < 0.001). CONCLUSION: A computerized performance-specific feedback system was effective in increasing some preventive maintenance services in general practice.

title: Randomized controlled trial of a computer-adapted multiple health behavior intervention in general practice: 12-month follow-up results.
abstract: BACKGROUND: Effective strategies to address the risk factors of noncommunicable diseases are needed to reduce the rising costs of healthcare. This trial tested the efficacy of a minimal intervention targeting multiple health behaviors (diet, physical activity, alcohol, and smoking) over one year in a general practice setting through the provision of personalized, computer-tailored feedback. METHODS: Patients who had been to a general practitioner in the past 6 months were recruited from 21 GPs in Brisbane, Australia. Baseline data were collected using self-reports on adherence to ten health behaviors and summarized with a health score between 0 and 10. This randomized controlled trial used a 2x2 factorial design with an arm that randomized subjects to either the intervention or control group. The other arm was either baseline feedback (single contact) or an additional assessment at 3 months with feedback (dual contact). Accordingly, 4 study groups were formed and participants were randomized blindly: A. Single-contact intervention"; B. Dual-contact intervention; C. Single-contact control and D. Double-contact control. All participants were re-evaluated. RESULTS: Of 4676 randomly selected participants 3065 completed the questionnaires at 12 months Both the single and dual contact groups improved their 10-item health scores (+0.31 and +0.49, respectively) compared to the control group results (+0.02; p< 0.01. Fish intake in the single and double contact intervention groups, consumed Improvement was observed in adherence to guidelines for dairy type, fruit and vegetable intake, and alcohol intake (p<0.01).
