Both intervention groups individually showed greater improvement than controls. Red meat intake, smoking behavior, physical activity, and health excluding body weight Interestingly, there was an improvement in reported non-smoking rates in both the intervention and control groups I (3% single contact; "4.5% dual contact). RESULTS: Low density Small but significant long-term changes in health behaviors can be achieved with a common intervention, which, when applied on a large scale, can reduce health care costs. More research is needed to better understand the mechanism by which behavior change can be sustained. TRIAL REGISTRATION: Australia New Zealand Clinical Trials Registry: ACTRN12611001213932.

title: Randomized controlled training and feedback trial for implementation of guidelines for acute low back pain
abstract: OBJECTIVE: The impact of clinical guidelines on resource use for complex conditions with significant barriers to clinician behavior change is not well studied. We report the impact of a multifaceted guideline intervention intervention on primary care clinicians' use of radiological and specialty services for the treatment of acute low back pain. DESIGN: Physician groups were randomized to receive mentoring and individual feedback supplementing patient education materials, or both or neither. Adherence to the guideline and impact on resource use were assessed during the 12-month period before and after implementation. PARTICIPANTS: Fourteen physician groups consisting of 120 primary care physicians and associate practitioners from 2 groups of model HMO practices. INTERVENTIONS: A training/supervision/feedback model was used with local peer opinion leaders in the implementation of the directive. The patient education component included written and videotaped materials on the management of low back pain. KEY RESULTS: Clinician intervention was associated with an absolute increase of 5.4% in behavior consistent with the guideline in the intervention group and a 2.7% decrease in the control group (P =.04). The patient education intervention produced no significant change in behavior consistent with the guideline, but was poorly adopted. Patient characteristics, including duration of pain, previous history of low back pain, and number of visits during the illness episode were strong predictors of service use and behavior consistent with the guideline. CONCLUSIONS: Implementation of the training and feedback-supported acute low back pain care guideline for primary care clinicians was associated with an increase in behavior consistent with the guideline. Patient education materials did not increase the effectiveness of the guideline. Implementation barriers may limit the usefulness of this approach in usual care settings.

title: Randomized controlled trial on cardiovascular risk management by practice nurses supplemented by self-monitoring in primary care
abstract: UNLABELED: BACKGROUND: Treatment goals for cardiovascular risk management are often not achieved. Specialized practice nurses are making the work of general practitioners increasingly easy, and self-monitoring devices have been developed as a counseling aid. The aim of this study is to compare standard treatment with self-monitoring-assisted standard treatment administered by clinical nurses and standard treatment without self-monitoring in terms of cardiovascular risk and separate risk factors. METHODS: At least one treatable risk factor (smoking, hypertension, lack of physical activity, or overweight) without a history of cardiovascular disease or diabetes but with a Score >/= 5% 10-year risk of cardiovascular mortality was randomized into two groups. The control group received standard treatment according to the guidelines, while the intervention group also received proactive counseling and self-monitoring (pedometer, scale, and/or blood pressure device). The effect on 179 participants after one year of treatment was analyzed. RESULTS: SCORE risk assessment decreased 1.6% (95% CI 1.0-2.2) for the control group and 1.8% (1.2-2.4) for the intervention group, with the difference between groups being 0.2% (-.6-1.1). Most risk factors tended to improve in both groups. The intervention group had higher number of visits and longer visits (4.9 (SD2.2) vs. 2.6 (SD1.5) visits p< .001 and 27 (P25 -P75:20-33) vs. 23 (P25 -P75) :19-30) min/visit p= .048). CONCLUSION: After one year of treatment by GPs, cardiovascular risk was significantly reduced in both groups. Despite the extra time investment, basing proactive counseling on self-monitoring had no additional effect. TRIAL REGISTRATION: trialregister.nl NTR2188.

title: Randomized controlled trial to evaluate the effectiveness of primary care liaison in promoting shared care for opiate users
abstract: BACKGROUND: Recent national guidelines highlight the need for all general practitioners to manage drug users within a common care plan and suggest that a primary health care liaison officer (PHCLW) can facilitate these arrangements. To determine the efficacy of a PHCLW in promoting shared care, we conducted a randomized, randomized controlled trial by group. METHODS: Primary care teams at Stockport Health Authority, North West England, were randomly assigned either to a response arm with services from a PHCLW or a control arm with standard support from the community medicine team (CDT). The proportion of CDT patients in co-care at 12 months after randomization and with a history of regular opiate abuse was compared between study arms. RESULTS: Eighteen (24.0 percent) of 75 CDT patients in the intervention arm but none of the 80 CDT patients in the control arm were on co-care at 12 months (chi2 = 9.37, df = 1, p < 0.01";" 95 percent confidence interval 8.6-39 percent) ,4). CONCLUSION: A PHCLW can significantly increase the number of CDT patients in shared care arrangements.

title: Randomized controlled trial: impact of nutritional counseling in general practice
abstract: OBJECTIVES: To investigate the effectiveness of an unstructured 15-minute educational intervention by general practitioners (GPs) on daily dietary changes among healthy adults. DESIGN: A two-arm randomized trial lasting 12 months. SETTING: Italian general practitioner services. Subjects A total of 3,186 men and women aged 18-65 years were admitted to the medical service by their general practitioner. INTERVENTIONS: The Italian Guide to Proper Nutrition, an educational intervention dating back to 1998, and a brochure on the basics of healthy eating. The aim of the main study was to provide more than 5 servings of fruits and vegetables per day. Follow-up visit every 6 months. The main outcome measures Weight, blood pressure, and the 40-item Food Frequency Questionnaire. RESULTS: The intervention group showed a slight decrease in net meat intake and a slight increase in net intake of fruit and vegetables, fish products and olive oil. Body mass index (BMI) changed only in the treatment arm [-0.41 95% confidence interval (95% CI) -0.11 to -0.53]. Net change in the intervention arm at 1 year was +1.31 (CI 0.90-4.39) for fruit and vegetables and -0.22 (-0.11 to -0.69) (portions per week) for meat. We also calculated a 'healthy eating score' reflecting adherence to recommended dietary habits. In the intervention group, the mean score at recruitment was significantly lower than the mean score at the end of follow-up (Coarse score change = 0.29"; CI 0.19-0.48). . When comparing the intervention with the control group, the difference in score from baseline to last visit was statistically significant (P < 0.001) (MANOVA adjusted for gender, BMI, education, and time). CONCLUSIONS: A brief educational intervention by GPs can result in multiple dietary changes that can lower BMI and potentially reduce the risk of chronic disease in generally healthy adults.

title: Randomized trial of online vaccination reminders in adult primary care
abstract: Online immunization reminders were implemented in an adult medical setting where all immunization history, vaccine ordering and charts were required online. Physicians were randomized to either arm in a crossover design. Each arm was shown online recommendations for vaccines specified in nationally accepted guidelines in the first or second part of the study period. The main aim of the study was to evaluate the impact of reminders on the right decisions regarding vaccine prescribing. Online reminders had the following effect on physician behavior: 1) Doctors used the app almost 3 times more often when the reminder was presented. 2) Doctors in the reminder group were 27% less likely to order vaccines in the reminder group (P-value 0.0005). 3) Compliance with guidelines for Tetanus and Hepatitis B was significantly improved in various analyzes. No such effect was found for the Pneumococcal, Measles, or Flu vaccines.

title: Randomized study of a clinical decision support system: impact on the management of children with fever without an apparent source.
abstract: Purpose: To evaluate adherence to a clinical decision support system (CDSS) for the diagnostic management of children with fever without an obvious source, and to examine the effects of CDSS implementation on the time spent in the emergency room (ED) and the number of laboratory tests. Design: CDSS was used by emergency care personnel to enroll children presenting with fever. The CDSS identified children who met the inclusion criteria (1-36 months and fever without apparent source (FWS)) and provided patient-specific diagnostic management advice. Children at high risk of serious bacterial infection were randomized to the 'intervention' (n _x0001_ 74) or 'control' (n _x0001_ 90) group. In the intervention group, the CDSS recommended that laboratory tests be ordered immediately, and in the control group, the emergency room doctor first evaluated the children and then decided to order laboratory tests. Results: Compliance with the enrollment of children with fever was 50% (683/1,399). Adherence to the recommendation to request laboratory tests was 82% (61/74). Children in the intervention group had a median (25-75th percentile) length of stay in the emergency department of 138 (104-181) minutes. The median length of stay in the emergency room in the control group was 123 (83–179) minutes. Laboratory tests were requested significantly more frequently in the intervention group (82%) than in the control group (44%, p 0.001, _x0001_2 test). Conclusion: The implementation of a CDSS for the diagnostic management of young children with fever of no apparent origin was successful in terms of adherence and adherence to CDSS recommendations, but had unexpected effects on patient outcomes in terms of length of stay in the emergency department and number of laboratory tests. Existing CDSS has been discontinued.

title: Randomized trial of model predictive control for improved anemia management
abstract: Background and targets: The variable hemoglobin (Hb) response to erythropoiesis-stimulating agents may have adverse consequences. The utility of model predictive control for drug dosing has been demonstrated previously. Design, setting, participants, and measures: This was a double-blind, randomized, controlled trial to test the model predictive control for erythropoietin dosing in ESRD patients. The trial included 60 hemodialysis patients randomized to a treatment arm (30 subjects) receiving erythropoietin doses according to computer recommendations, or to a control arm (30 subjects) receiving erythropoietin doses based on recommendations from a standard anemia management. protocol (control). Subjects were followed for 8 months, and target ratios of measured Hb within the target of 11 to 12 g/dl and outside the target of 9 to 13 g/dl were measured. The variability of the Hb level was measured by the area under the Hb curve as well as the absolute difference between the obtained Hb and the target Hb of 11.5 g/dl. Results: Model predictor control, 15 observations >13 or <9 g/dl (outliers), a mean absolute difference of 0.98 ± 0.08 g/dl and Hb between achieved Hb and 11.5 g/dl resulting in the area under the curve. 2.86 ± 1.46. The control group algorithm resulted in 30 Hb outliers (P = 0.051), producing a mean absolute difference between the obtained Hb and 11.5 g/dl, an area of 1.18 Â± 0.18 g/dl (P < 0.001 difference in variance) and below. Hb curve of 3.38 Â± 2.69 (P = 0.025 difference in variance). Conclusions: Model predictive control of erythropoietin administration improves anemia management.

title: Randomized trial of problem-based and didactic seminars to disseminate evidence-based guidelines on asthma management to primary care physicians
abstract: INTRODUCTION: This randomized controlled trial (RCT) investigated the efficacy and satisfaction of small group problem-based learning (PBL) versus a didactic lecture approach to guideline dissemination in the treatment of asthma by controlling for confounding factors common in comparative education interventions. METHODS: Places were selected as lessons or PBL using simple randomization. All participants were exposed to similar educational resources to ensure treatment equivalence. Tools included standardized program/speaker evaluation forms and a case-based questionnaire validated with a visual analog scale measuring the confidence level of responses. The second was presented immediately before and after the intervention and 3 months later. The statistician was blind to intervention groups. RESULTS: A total of 52 family physicians agreed to attend, 23 of them PBL sessions (mean 4.6 per group) and 29 didactic lecture sessions (mean 7.25). There was no significant difference between the groups in terms of knowledge gained in each test application. Participants rated the lecturer or facilitator equally as having created a positive learning environment. PBL participants rated the perceived educational value of the program as higher than course participants (4.36 vs. 3.93";" p = .04). Both groups experienced a significant increase in knowledge about asthma after the intervention. Attrition rates for the 3-month posttest were 14% for PBL participants versus 32% for course-based participants. CONCLUSION: PBL was as effective as course-based continuing medical education (CME) programs in acquiring and retaining knowledge. Further studies are warranted to explore whether the higher educational value assessment or the increase in delayed test response rate is reproducible in other RCTs that address common confounders and whether these factors influence future CME participation, changes in physician clinical behavior, or patient health outcomes.

title: Randomized trial to improve prescribing safety in ambulatory elderly patients.
abstract: OBJECTIVES: To determine whether a computerized tool that alerts pharmacists when new potentially unsuitable drugs are prescribed to patients 65 years of age and older is effective in reducing the proportion of patients prescribing these drugs. DESIGN: Prospective, randomized study. SETTING: US healthcare organization. PARTICIPANTS: All 59,680 health plan members aged 65 and over were randomized to intervention (n=29,840) or usual care (n=29,840). Pharmacists received alerts on all patients randomized to a targeted drug newly prescribed intervention. INTERVENTION: Prescription and age information was associated with alerting pharmacists when a patient aged 65 and over was newly prescribed one of 11 drugs potentially unsuitable for older people. MEASUREMENTS: Physicians and pharmacists collaborated to develop the targeted drug list, the indications for drug use where the intervention should occur, intervention guidelines and scenarios, and implement the intervention. RESULTS: During the 1-year study, 543 (1.8%) intervention group patients aged 65 years and older were newly issued prescriptions for targeted drugs, compared with 644 (2.2%) usual care group patients (P=.002). For indications of drug use in which an intervention should occur, amitriptyline (P<.001) and diazepam (P=.02) distributions were reduced. CONCLUSIONS: This study demonstrated the effectiveness of a computerized pharmacy alert system and collaboration among healthcare professionals in reducing potentially inappropriate drug dispensing in elderly patients. Combining the knowledge and skills of physicians and pharmacists with data from information systems can improve prescribing safety in patients aged 65 and over.

title: Randomized, controlled trial of the efficacy of simulation training: A 24-month follow-up study in a clinical setting.
abstract: BACKGROUND: The knowledge and skills of ICU nurses to follow evidence-based guidelines to avoid complications associated with intubation and mechanical ventilation are currently limited. We hypothesized that a single simulation training session would lead to longer-term higher skill levels among ICU nurses. MATERIAL AND METHODS: A randomized controlled trial was conducted in a 22-bed adult mixed medical-surgical intensive care unit in Finland between February 2012 and March 2014. Thirty of the initially randomized critical care nurses participated in a 24-month follow-up. -up work. Behavior and cognitive development were assessed through a validated Ventilator Pack Observation Schedule and Questionnaire at baseline and repeated 3 times during simulation and real-life clinical settings. RESULTS: After simulation training, the mean skill score increased from 46.8-58.8% of the total score at the final post-intervention measurement (Ptime < .001, Ptime x group = .040, and Pgroup = .11). The mean knowledge scores within the groups did not change significantly. The mean difference between groups in skill scores was significant only at 6 months (P = .006). RESULTS: ICU nurses' ability to adhere to evidence-based guidelines improved over time in both groups, but improvements between study groups were significantly different at only 6 months and were no longer evident 2 years after a single simulation training.

title: Rapid change in prescribing behavior at hospitals that joined the guidelines after clinical trial results of management of atherothrombosis (MATCH) with clopidogrel in high-risk patients were released
abstract: BACKGROUND AND OBJECTIVE: Despite published randomized trials and consensus guidelines, physician prescribing patterns are slowly changing. Treatment of Atherothrombosis in High-Risk Patients (MATCH) In the Get With The Guidelines (GWTG)-Stroke Program with Clopidogrel, we measure the impact on discharge prescribing patterns in patients with stroke and transient ischemic attack. METHODS: We analyzed the discharge prescribing patterns of antithrombotic drugs for patients presenting with ischemic stroke or transient ischemic attack to hospitals participating in the GWTG-Stroke between October 2002 and January 2006. Quarterly clinical information regarding publication of the MATCH trial was analyzed. The frequency of aspirin+clopidogrel prescribing after MATCH was compared with the pre-MATCH period after adjusting for patient and hospital characteristics and clustering by hospital. RESULTS: A total of 107,872 patients were discharged from 632 centers and were eligible for antithrombotic therapy. Use of aspirin+clopidogrel therapy decreased from 22.4% to 15.4% of patients after publication of MATCH (adjusted OR 0.62, 95% CI 0.56 to 0.70, P<0.0001). The quarterly analysis revealed a rapid and sustained reduction in the use of aspirin+clopidogrel therapy for the remainder of the study period. RESULTS: In the absence of MATCH-specific GWTG-Stroke interventions and prior to an American Heart Association guideline update, a rapid and sustained reduction in the frequency of aspirin+clopidogrel use was observed in ischemic stroke and transient ischemic attack after the publication of the MATCH study.

title: Rational prescribing in primary care (RaPP): economic evaluation of an intervention to improve professional practice.
abstract: Background Interventions designed to narrow the gap between research findings and clinical practice can be effective but also costly. Economic considerations are necessary to decide whether such interventions are worth the effort. We evaluated the economic implications of a tailored intervention to support the implementation of guidelines for the use of antihypertensive and cholesterol-lowering drugs. The specific intervention was evaluated in a randomized trial and was shown to significantly increase thiazide use in patients starting antihypertensive drug therapy, but with little or no effect on other outcomes. The increased use of thiazides was not expected to have an impact on health outcomes. Methods and Findings We performed cost minimization and cost-effectiveness analyzes on data from a randomized trial involving 146 general practices from two geographic regions in Norway. Each treatment was randomized to either the specific intervention (70 treatments"; 257 physicians) or the control group (69 treatments;" 244 physicians). Only patients who were started on antihypertensive drug therapy were included in the analyses. A multi-pronged intervention was designed to address identified barriers to change. Key components were an educational outreach visit with supervision and feedback, and computerized reminders. Pharmacists visited. A cost minimization framework was adopted in which intervention costs were set against declining treatment costs (mainly due to the increased use of thiazides rather than more expensive drugs). The cost-effectiveness of the intervention was estimated as the additional cost per patient initiated on thiazides. The net annual cost (cost minimization) in our study population was $53,395, corresponding to $763 per application. The additional cost per patient (cost-effectiveness) initiated on thiazides was US$454. The net annual savings in a national program are modeled after 2 years at US$761,998 or US$540 per implementation. In this scenario, savings exceeded costs in all but two of our sensitivity analyzes and cost-effectiveness was estimated at $183. Conclusions In our study, we found a significant shift towards thiazide use in prescribing antihypertensive drugs. An important reason to encourage the use of thiazides is their lower price compared to other drugs. The cost of the intervention was more than double the savings over the time frame of our study. However, we foresee modest savings over a 2-year period.

title: Rationale and Design of the Study to Evaluate the Effect of Cardiovascular Drugs Provided as Low-Cost Evidence-Based Generic Examples (SAMPLES)
abstract: BACKGROUND: Highly effective generic cardiovascular drugs are often underused, leading to increased overall drug costs and cost mismatch. OBJECTIVE: We sought to evaluate an intervention to promote appropriate generic cardiovascular drug use without creating administrative or financial barriers that could hinder essential drug use. TRIAL DESIGN: SAMPLES (Study of Evaluation of the Effect of Cardiovascular Medicines Provided as Low-Cost, Evidence-Based Generic Samples) trial is a clustered, randomized controlled trial of the effect of providing physicians with free generic hydrochlorothiazide and simvastatin for hypertensive patients. for patients with hyperlipidemia. We will randomly select 660 primary care physicians in Pennsylvania, clustered by physician practice, with or without free samples for both conditions. We will use data on filled prescriptions from a government-sponsored prescription drug assistance program to perform a therapeutic assessment of the intervention's impact on physician prescribing behavior (proportion of generic prescriptions) and patient compliance. Secondary outcomes will include physician adherence to established guidelines and overall prescription drug costs. CONCLUSION: This trial will identify the potential role of an innovative approach to promote clinically cost-effective prescribing. We will determine whether free generic samples can reduce overall drug costs as well as patient out-of-pocket costs without sacrificing efficacy, and whether this approach provides a better fit for core cardiovascular drugs. This intervention can also improve adherence to practice guidelines and improve the quality of care received. If effective, this strategy could be widely used by private insurers or government payers to promote more cost-effective and higher quality care.

title: Causes and consequences of poor adherence to standard measures by the nursing team
abstract: Standard precautions (SPs) are recommendations to prevent infection and protect healthcare workers during the delivery of care, but there is still a low level of adherence to these recommendations. Purpose To analyze the causes and consequences of poor adherence to standard precautions by maintenance personnel. Method integrative literature search, search seven databases from 2005 to 2014. Results 30 articles were selected for analysis. The reasons for proven low compliance are related to inadequate lifelong learning practices, risky behavior of employees, inadequate equipment and protective equipment supply, and inadequate working conditions. The consequences are accidents and occupational diseases. There are few intervention studies that guide professionals only. Conclusions Low adherence to standard measures is linked to individual aspects of workers, employers and educational institutions. Intervention strategies employed have shown little effectiveness by focusing solely on the employee.

title: Recall intervals for oral health in primary care patients
abstract: BACKGROUND: The frequency of dental visits and the potential effects of changing recall intervals between visits on oral health have been the subject of international debate for almost 30 years. Although recommendations regarding optimum recall intervals differ between countries and dental health systems, in many developed countries, 6-month dental exams are traditionally advocated by general dentists. OBJECTIVES: To determine the beneficial and harmful effects of different fixed recall intervals (eg 6 months vs. 12 months) for the following different types of dental examinations: a) clinical examination only"; b) clinical examination plus scale and polish; c) clinical examination plus preventive advice d ) clinical examination plus preventive advice plus scale and polish Identify relative beneficial and harmful effects in the same fixed recall interval between any of these different types of dental examination Comparing the beneficial and deleterious effects of recall intervals based on clinicians' assessment of patients' disease risk with fixed recall intervals Comparing the beneficial and harmful effects of absence/patient-guided participation (which may be symptomatic) with fixed recall intervals We searched the Cochrane Oral Health Group Trials Register, the Cochrane Central Register of Controlled Trials (CENTRAL), MEDLINE, and EMBASE. too much Authors of some articles were contacted to identify research and obtain additional information. Date of most recent searches: March 5, 2007. SELECTION CRITERIA: Trials were selected if they met the following criteria: design - random distribution of participants; participants - all children and adults undergoing dental examinations in primary care, regardless of their level of oral disease risk; interventions - recall intervals for the following different dental examinations: a) clinical examination only; b) clinical examination plus scale and polish; c) clinical examination plus preventive advice; d) clinical examination plus weighing and polishing plus preventative advice; e) recall interval/no patient-focused participation (may be symptomatic); f) clinician risk-based recall intervals; outcomes - clinical status outcomes for dental caries (mean dmft/DMFT, dmfs/DMFS scores, increased caries, filled teeth (including replacement restorations), early caries lesions stopped or reversed); periodontal disease (including but not limited to plaque, calculus, gingivitis, periodontitis, change in probing depth, level of attachment);" oral mucosa (presence or absence of mucosal lesions, potentially malignant lesions, cancerous lesions, size and stage of cancerous lesions) In addition, the following outcomes were considered when reported: other outcomes such as patient-centered outcomes, economic cost outcomes, improvements in oral health knowledge and attitudes, harms, changes in dietary habits, and other oral health-related behaviors DATA COLLECTION AND ANALYSIS: Methods, participants, interventions , outcome measures, and information on outcomes were extracted independently, in duplicate, by the two review authors. When deemed necessary and possible, authors were contacted for study design and further details data disclosure Quality assessment of included study was performed Cochrane Collaboration Statistical guidelines were followed. MAIN RESULTS: Only one study (with 188 participants) was included in this review and was considered to have a high risk of bias. This study provided limited data for dental caries outcomes (dmfs/DMFS increase) and economic cost outcomes (reported for time taken to provide examination and treatment). AUTHOR'S CONCLUSIONS: There is insufficient evidence from randomized controlled trials (RCTs) to draw any conclusions regarding the potential beneficial and harmful effects of changing the recall interval between dental exams. There is insufficient evidence to support or refute the practice of encouraging patients to attend dental examinations at 6-month intervals. To address the purposes of this review, it is important to conduct high-quality RCTs for the outcomes listed in this review.

title: Recall intervals for oral health in primary care patients
abstract: BACKGROUND: The frequency of dental visits and the potential effects of changing recall intervals between visits on oral health have been the subject of international debate for almost 30 years. Although recommendations regarding optimum recall intervals differ between countries and dental health systems, in many developed countries, 6-month dental exams are traditionally advocated by general dentists. OBJECTIVES: To determine the beneficial and harmful effects of different fixed recall intervals (eg 6 months vs. 12 months) for the following different types of dental examinations: a) clinical examination only"; b) clinical examination plus scale and polish; c) clinical examination plus preventive advice d ) clinical examination plus preventive advice plus scale and polish Identify relative beneficial and harmful effects in the same fixed recall interval between any of these different types of dental examination Comparing the beneficial and deleterious effects of recall intervals based on clinicians' assessment of patients' disease risk with fixed recall intervals Comparing the beneficial and harmful effects of absence/patient-guided participation (which may be symptomatic) with fixed recall intervals We searched the Cochrane Oral Health Group Trials Register, the Cochrane Central Register of Controlled Trials (CENTRAL), MEDLINE, and EMBASE. too much Authors of some articles were contacted to identify research and obtain additional information. Date of most recent searches: April 9, 2003. SELECTION CRITERIA: Trials were selected if they met the following criteria: design - random distribution of participants; participants - all children and adults undergoing dental examinations in primary care, regardless of their level of oral disease risk; interventions - recall intervals for the following different dental examinations: a) clinical examination only; b) clinical examination plus scale and polish; c) clinical examination plus preventive advice; d) clinical examination plus weighing and polishing plus preventative advice; e) recall interval/no patient-focused participation (may be symptomatic); f) clinician risk-based recall intervals; outcomes - clinical status outcomes for dental caries (mean dmft/DMFT, dmfs/DMFS scores, increased caries, filled teeth (including replacement restorations), early caries lesions stopped or reversed); periodontal disease (including but not limited to plaque, calculus, gingivitis, periodontitis, change in probing depth, level of attachment);" oral mucosa (presence or absence of mucosal lesions, potentially malignant lesions, cancerous lesions, size and stage of cancerous lesions) In addition, the following outcomes were considered when reported: other outcomes such as patient-centered outcomes, economic cost outcomes, improvements in oral health knowledge and attitudes, harms, changes in dietary habits, and other oral health-related behaviors DATA COLLECTION AND ANALYSIS: Methods, participants, interventions , outcome measures, and information on outcomes were extracted independently, in duplicate, by two authors. The authors were contacted for more details on study design and data when deemed necessary and possible. Description Quality assessment of the included study was carried out Cochrane Oral S The statistical data ideals of the weight group were followed. MAIN RESULTS: Only one study (with 188 participants) was included in this review and was considered to have a high risk of bias. This study provided limited data for dental caries outcomes (dmfs/DMFS increase) and economic cost outcomes (reported for time taken to provide examination and treatment). AUTHOR'S CONCLUSIONS: There is insufficient evidence from randomized controlled trials (RCTs) to draw any conclusions regarding the potential beneficial and harmful effects of changing the recall interval between dental exams. There is insufficient evidence to support or refute the practice of encouraging patients to attend dental examinations at 6-month intervals. To address the purposes of this review, it is important to conduct high-quality RCTs for the outcomes listed in this review.

title: Recent Trends in Violent Behavior of High School Students in the United States
abstract: Context Violent behaviors such as fighting and carrying weapons are associated with serious physical and psychosocial consequences for adolescents. The goal is to measure trends in non-fatal violent behavior among adolescents in the United States between 1991 and 1997. Design, Environment and Participants Nationally representative data from the 1991, 1993, 1995 and 1997 Youth Risk Behavior Surveys were analyzed to define the percentage of students. Those who engage in violent behavior in grades 9 to 12. Overall response rates for each of these years were 68%, 70%, 60% and 69%, respectively. Logistic regression analyzes were performed to evaluate the statistical significance of time trends for these variables, controlling for gender, grade, and race or ethnicity and simultaneously evaluating linear and higher-order effects. Main Consequence Measures Self-reported carrying weapons, physical combat, combat-related injuries, feeling unsafe, and damaged or stolen property. Results Between 1991 and 1997, the percentage of students engaged in physical fights decreased by 14%, from 42.5% (95% confidence interval [CI], 40.1-44.9%) to 36.6% (95% CI, 34.6%-38.6%) . "; the percentage of students injured in a physical fight decreased by 20% from 4.4% (95% CI, 3.6%-5.2%) to 3.5% (95% CI, 2.9%-4%, 1); gun carrying decreased 30%, from 26.1% (95% CI, 23.8-28.4%) to 18.3% (95% CI, 16.5-20.1%). Between 1993 and 1997, the percentage of students carrying guns decreased by 25%, 7.9% (95% CI, 6.6-9.2%) to 5.9% (95% CI, 5.1%-6.7%); 16% of students engaged in physical fights on school property; decreased from 2 to 9% (95% CI, 15.0-17.4%) to 14.8% (95% CI, 13.5-16.1%);" and the percentage of students carrying guns on school property decreased by 28% from 11.8% (95% CI, 10.4-13.2) to 8.5% (95% CI, 7.0-10.0%) fell. All these changes represent significant linear decreases. Results The decline in fighting and carrying weapons among US adolescents between 1991 and 1997 is encouraging and is consistent with decreases in homicide, non-fatal victimization, and school crime rates. Further research should explore why interpersonal violence-related behaviors are declining and what types of interventions are most effective.

title: Recommendations for community-based treatment of depression in older adults
abstract: OBJECTIVE: To present recommendations to public health and aging networks for the community-based treatment of advanced age depression. METHODS: An expert panel of mental health and public health researchers and community-based practitioners on aging convened in April 2006 to create consensus-based recommendations. When making recommendations, panelists evaluated the feasibility and relevance for community-based delivery, as well as the strength of evidence for program effectiveness from a systematic literature review of articles published up to 2005. at home or in primary care clinics. The panel recommended individual cognitive behavioral therapy. Interventions not recommended as primary treatment for advanced age depression included education and skills training, comprehensive geriatric health assessment programs, exercise, and physical rehabilitation/occupational therapy. There was insufficient evidence to make recommendations for various categories of interventions, including group psychotherapy and psychotherapies other than cognitive behavioral therapy. CONCLUSIONS: While recognizing the challenges and barriers involved, this interdisciplinary panel of experts determined that proposed interventions should be mainstreamed in public health and aging networks. Interventions that were not recommended or lacked sufficient evidence generally did not primarily treat depression and/or did not include a clinically depressed sample while attempting to establish efficacy. These interventions may provide other benefits, but they should not be assumed to effectively treat depression alone. Panelists also described primary prevention of depression as a poorly studied area. These findings should assist individual clinicians as well as public health decision makers in the delivery of population-based mental health services in a variety of community settings.

title: Multi-model sensors recommendations service for the chronically ill patient in the home environment
abstract: With the advanced technologies at hand, there are potential applications and services created around monitoring the activities of daily living (ADL) of the elderly in nursing homes. Most of the elderly in these facilities suffer from different chronic diseases such as dementia. Current technologies mainly focus on non-drug interventions and monitoring of ADL to address loss of autonomy or well-being. Monitoring and managing ADL related to cognitive behaviors for non-drug intervention is very effective in improving the condition of people with dementia. However, patients' cognitive functions can be improved if appropriate medication recommendations are given at a given time. We have previously developed Secure Wireless Sensor Network Integrated Cloud Computing for Ubiquitous-Life Care (SC(3)). SC(3) services were limited to monitoring the ADL of older people with Alzheimer's disease and providing non-drug advice to the patient. In this paper, we propose a system called Intelligent Clinical Decision Support System (CDSS) as an integral part of the SC(3) platform. With Smart CDSS, patients are provided with access to drug recommendations from specialist physicians. Physicians are provided with an interface to generate clinical information for drug recommendations and to monitor the patient's condition. As the knowledge base of Smart CDSS, clinical information generated by physicians generates recommendations for medications to the caregiver based on each patient's symptoms.

title: Recruiting hospitalized patients for research: How do participants differ from non-eligible participants?
abstract: BACKGROUND: Randomized controlled trials provide strong evidence for guidelines and interventions. Still, most of the eligible population refuses to be examined. OBJECTIVE: To identify differences between participants and eligible non-participants in (1) perceived stress, (2) self-efficacy, (3) recovery prospects, (4) discussion of advanced directions, and (5) understanding of a standard prescription label (health literacy). Design: Quasi-experimental prospective cohort study in 5 acute care hospitals. METHODS: We approached 295 hospitalized patients who were recruited for a behavioral intervention and asked them to answer 5 screening questions. We matched respondents' responses to behavioral intervention acceptance and Medicare claims and enrollment data. We used multivariate logistic regression to compare approval rates based on screening question responses. ENVIRONMENT/PATIENTS: Medicare patients paid per inpatient service. RESULTS: Patients were less likely to consent to behavioral intervention when they reported that they had low expectations of recovery when they felt that they could not control important things in their life (odds ratio [OR]: 0.35, 95% confidence interval [CI]: 0.14-0.92). (OR: 0.17, 95% CI: 0.06-0.45) or mixed with any other question (OR: 0.11, 95% CI: 0.05-0.24). Conversely, individuals who incorrectly answered the drug question were more likely to consent to the behavioral intervention (OR: 3.82, 95% CI: 1.12-13.03). There were no significant differences in the consent of patients who reported feeling overwhelmed or discussed prior care planning with family members or doctors. CONCLUSIONS: Hospitalized non-eligible participants differ in constructs related to perceived stress, recovery expectation, and health literacy. Recognition of such features can inform strategies to improve hospital response reception and representation in clinical trials.

title: Recruiting and retaining elderly patients in clinical trials: issues and strategies
abstract: Clinicians and researchers are shifting their focus to older patients to target the most effective treatments for a variety of psychiatric conditions. Clinical trials with elderly patients are required as they consume the largest number of prescription drugs. There are special challenges and considerations in designing and conducting clinical trials. The authors review the various stages of such research, including recruiting eligible patients and retaining enrollment, and make recommendations using examples from currently completed research studies that illustrate the methods found to be most successful.

title: Relapse after surgical treatment of Hidradenitis suppurativa
abstract: Six to 89 months after surgery, 82 patients treated with radical surgery (118 excisions) for resistant hidradenitis suppurativa were reviewed. Local recurrence rates varied widely by disease site, with low after axillary (3%) and perianal surgery (0%), and high after inguinoperineal (37%) and submammary excision (50%). Recurrence is due to inadequate excision or an unusually wide distribution of apocrine glands, but physical factors such as obesity, local pressure, and skin maceration played a role in a few patients. Relapse due to inadequate surgery tended to be the most troublesome. In the follow-up, 75 (91%) of the patients were satisfied with the results of their operations. A quarter of patients developed disease in a new anatomical region after surgery. Radical surgery provides good symptomatic control of severe hidradenitis suppurativa of the axilla, inguinoperineal and perianal regions, but is less satisfactory for submammary disease.

title: Redesigning the “architecture of choice” of hospital prescription charts: a mixed-methods study including in situ simulation testing.
abstract: Objectives To incorporate behavioral insights into the user-centered design of the inpatient prescription chart (Imperial Medication Chart Evaluation and Adoption Study, IDEAS chart) and to determine whether changes in the content and design of prescription charts can affect prescribing behavior and reduce prescribing errors. Design A mixed methods approach was adopted during the development phase of the project"; on-site simulation was used to evaluate the effectiveness of the newly developed IDEAS prescription chart. Establishment of a London teaching hospital. Interventions/methods (1) an exploration phase consisting of chart reviews, focus groups and collecting user insights (2 ) iterative design of the IDEAS prescription chart and finally (3) testing the final chart with prescribers using on-site simulation Results Significant differences were seen between current inpatient prescription Charts used in 15 different UK hospitals Review of 40 completed prescription charts from one hospital, illegibility and prescription demonstrated a number of common prescribing errors, including difficulty in identifying authors situ simulation testing revealed significant improvements in prescribing IDEAS chart compared to prescribing chart currently used in study hospital was taken. Include correct dose entries for medication orders in the IDEAS table (164/164 vs 166/174; p=0.0046) as well as the prescriber's printed name (163/164 vs 0/174; p<0.0001) and contact number probability was significantly higher. (137/164 - 55/174; p<0.0001). Antiinfective indication (28/28 vs 17/29; p<0.0001) and duration (26/28 vs 15/29;" p<0.0001) were more likely to be completed using the IDEAS chart. In this context, the IDEAS prescription schedule has significantly reduced a number of common prescribing errors, including dosing errors and illegibility. Positive behavior change has been seen without prior training or support, which could potentially be corrected through changes in the content and design of some of the prescription schedules. It is an Open Access article distributed under a Creative Commons Attribution Non Commercial (CC BY-NC 4.0) license that allows others to distribute, reedit, adapt, build upon this work non-commercially, and license derivative works on different terms. , provided that the original work is properly cited and the use is non-commercial. See: http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-nc/4.0/

title: Reducing the risk of cardiovascular disease in patients with diabetes: a message from the National Diabetes Education Program
abstract: OBJECTIVE: To provide nurse practitioners (NPs) a review of current practice guidelines that assist clinicians in their efforts to reduce diabetes-related morbidity and mortality and its major macrovascular complications. DATA SOURCES: This article presents data from major evidence-based studies and clinical trials that describe the extent of the problem, the rationale for risk reduction, and a patient-centered action plan for NPs to effectively manage cardiovascular risk factors in people with diabetes. CONCLUSIONS: NPs are active partners of the National Diabetes Education Program and play a key role in efforts to effectively manage cardiovascular risk factors in people with diabetes and increase their awareness of the link between diabetes and heart disease and stroke. APPLICATIONS FOR IMPLEMENTATION: The action plan to reduce cardiovascular risk in people with diabetes will help NPs implement the most effective management strategies for medical nutrition therapy, physical activity and pharmacological therapy, which are essential for patient-centered proactive management of hyperglycemia, hypertension and lipid. abnormalities

title: Reducing the amount of blood transfused: a systematic review of behavioral interventions to change physicians' transfusion practices.
abstract: BACKGROUND: Transfusion services have used a variety of techniques to reduce blood product use. Given the potential adverse effects of transfusions and the resources consumed in implementing strategies to reduce transfusions, there is a need to understand their effectiveness. Therefore, we conducted a systematic review of the literature to examine the effectiveness of behavioral interventions to reduce blood product use. METHODS: We identified all relevant articles through electronic searches of MEDLINE and EMBASE as well as manual searches of review articles and personal files. Electronic searches included articles published between January 1966 and May 2003. Searches included the terms blood transfusion, plasma exchange, guidelines, education, practice patterns, and professional practice. Outcomes of interest were the number of units transfused and the proportion of patients transfused. RESULTS: Nineteen studies examining the efficacy of single (guidelines, prospective controls, retrospectives, and reminders) or multiple interventions in reducing red blood cell, platelet, plasma, cryoprecipitate, and albumin transfusions met inclusion criteria. Eighteen studies showed a relative reduction in the number of units delivered (range, 9-77%) or the proportion of patients who received transfusions (range, 17-79%). The reported reductions were qualitatively similar for the different blood products studied. No specific intervention or combination of interventions appeared more effective in reducing use. CONCLUSIONS: Behavioral interventions, including simple interventions, appear to be effective in changing physician transfusion practices and reducing blood use. Appropriately designed clinical trials are still needed to determine the relative effectiveness of different interventions to change practice.

title: Reducing the Risk of Alcohol Use Disorder in Women
abstract: Nurses and other clinicians help women examine their lifestyle and consider changes to promote optimal health. When the question is about drinking alcohol, what advice would be appropriate? While moderate intake may be beneficial for cardiovascular and bone health, drinking more than the recommended amount increases the risk of harmful effects. This column reviews guidelines for moderate alcohol consumption for women, reviews the evaluation process, and shows a brief example of an intervention. A screening, brief intervention, and referral program (called SBIRT by the Substance Abuse and Mental Health Services Administration) should be part of the standard assessment for every woman. Ongoing assessment of alcohol consumption can help better target behavior for early intervention.

title: Reducing excessive therapeutic injection use through patient-prescriber interactive group discussions in the Kinondoni District, Dar es Salaam, Tanzania
abstract: Inappropriate prescription of injections has been reported in developing and developed countries. Previous studies in Tanzania have shown that more than 70% of patients admitted to outpatient clinics in private dispensaries receive at least one injection per consultation; this is higher than the WHO recommended 10% target. This is worrisome given the potential negative effects of using unsafe syringes to transmit HIV, hepatitis B and C, polio, and the additional economic impacts on the patient and the healthcare system. This study aimed to investigate the impact of Interaction Group Discussion on behavior change on injection prescribing practices in ten selected public dispensaries in the Kinondoni District, Dar es Salaam, Tanzania. Patient records of injection prescriptions covering the period three months prior to the study were obtained from 5 randomly selected controls and 5 randomly selected intervention sites. In each healthcare facility, mothers and prescribers were administered IGDs for one month, followed by a survey 3 months after IGD to determine the effect of IGDs. Chi-square statistical calculations were performed to compare data on the percentage of prescriptions with an injection prescribed between baseline and 3-month follow-up and that met national standard treatment guidelines (STG). The results showed no significant difference between the percentage of injectable prescriptions prescribed at baseline in state dispensaries and 3-month follow-up (P>0.05, X2 test). Prescribed injections consistent with STG were low at baseline and did not improve significantly after 3 months (P>0.05, X2 test). Comprehensive studies and sensitization of adherence to STG are recommended by prescribers.

title: Reducing ventilator-associated pneumonia rates through a staff training program
abstract: Ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP) is the most common nosocomial infection in mechanically ventilated patients and causes increased mortality, prolonged hospital stay, and costs. Preventive measures for VAP are well documented and evidence-based, but continue to be poorly implemented in most intensive care units. We conducted a pre- and post-intervention observational study to evaluate whether an educational program focusing on preventive practices for VAP could reduce the incidence. Six hundred and seventy-seven adult patients who were mechanically ventilated for >48 hours were included in the study population. An evidence-based guideline for bedside preventive practices has been developed and distributed to ICU staff. The incidence rates of VAP before and after the implementation of the training program were compared. VAP infection rates ranged from a mean of 13.2+/-1.2 in the pre-intervention period to 6.5+/-1.5/1000 device days in the post-intervention period (mean difference 6.7"; "95% CI: 2.9-10.4, P=0.02). A multidisciplinary training program for intensive care unit personnel can successfully reduce VAP incidence rates. More studies will be needed to assess the impact on broader outcome measures such as costs or mortality.

title: Reduction of lower extremity clinical abnormalities in patients with non-insulin dependent diabetes mellitus. A Randomly Controlled Trial
abstract: OBJECTIVE: To evaluate the impact of a patient, healthcare provider, and systems intervention on the prevalence of risk factors for lower extremity amputation in patients with non-insulin-dependent diabetes. DESIGN: Blind, randomized, controlled trial. SETTING: Academic general medicine practice. PARTICIPANTS: Of the 395 patients with non-insulin-dependent diabetes who underwent initial patient evaluation, 352 completed the study. INTERVENTION: The 12-month intervention was multifaceted. Patients received podiatry training and entered into a behavioral contract for their desired foot care, reinforced by phone and postcard reminders. Health care providers were provided with practice guidelines and information flowcharts on foot-related risk factors for amputation in diabetic patients. In addition, folders for intervention patients had specific descriptors that required healthcare providers to 1) ask patients to remove their shoes, 2) conduct foot exams, and 3) provide podiatry training. RESULTS: Patients receiving the intervention were less likely than control patients to have severe foot lesions (baseline prevalence, 2.9%"; odds ratio, 0.41 [95% CI, 0.16 to 1.00]; P = 0.05) and other dermatological abnormalities. were more likely to self-report podiatry behaviors, have foot exams during office visits (68% vs. 28%; P < 0.001), and receive podiatry training from healthcare providers (42% vs. 42%) 18%; P < 0.00 0.001) Physicians assigned to intervention patients were more likely to examine patients for ulcers, pulses, and abnormal dermatological conditions and refer patients to a podiatric clinic than physicians assigned to check-in (10.6% versus 5.0%);" P = 0.04). CONCLUSIONS: An intervention designed to reduce risk factors for lower extremity amputations positively affected patient self-foot care behavior and foot care provided by healthcare providers, and reduced the prevalence of lower extremity clinical disease in patients with diabetes.

title: Referral for fertility preservation counseling in female cancer patients
abstract: STUDY QUESTION: What changes can be detected in fertility preservation (FP) counseling (FPC) over time, and what are the predictors associated with referral of newly diagnosed female cancer patients aged 0-39 years to a reproductive medicine specialist for FPC? ? SUMMARY ANSWER: Although the absolute number of patients receiving FPC has increased over time, only 9.8% of all potential patients (0-39) were referred in 2011, and referral differences were found in terms of patients' age, cancer diagnosis, and healthcare provider. -related factors. WHAT IS ALREADY KNOWN: Referral rates for FPC prior to initiating gonadotoxic cancer treatment are low. Determinants associated with low referral and referral disparities have been identified in previous studies, but only scarce data are available on determinants for referral practices and FPC referral in FP(C) reimbursed environments. STUDY DESIGN, SIZE, DURATION: We conducted a retrospective observational and survey study in a Dutch university hospital. The data of all female cancer patients (2001-2013) who were given FP counseling in this center and all newly diagnosed female cancer patients aged 0-39 in the region (2009-2011) were collected. PARTICIPANTS/MATERIALS, INSTALLATION, METHODS: Data were drawn from medical records (FPC patients), cancer cases reported by the Dutch Cancer Registry (to calculate referral percentages) and referring professionals (to determine reasons for current referral behavior). KEY OUTCOMES AND ROLE OF CHANCE: A total of 9.8% of patients were referred for FPC in 2011. Patients aged 20-29 years or diagnosed with breast cancer or lymphoma were referred more frequently than patients under 20 years of age or patients diagnosed with other malignancies. The absolute number of patients receiving FPC increased over time. The healthcare provider predictors for miscarriage were not starting a discussion about fertility-related issues, not knowing where to refer a patient for FPC, and not collaborating with patient associations. LIMITATIONS, REASONS FOR CAUTION: Actual referral rates may differ slightly from our estimate as there may be patients who do not wish to receive FPC. Sporadically, patients may have been referred directly to other sites or have received ovarian transposition without FPC. By excluding skin cancer patients, we would underestimate the group of women eligible for FPC, as this group includes melanoma patients who may have received gonadotoxic therapy. WIDE IMPACT OF THE FINDINGS: The low referral rates and referral disparities reported in the current study suggest opportunities to improve referral practices. Future research should focus on the implementation and evaluation of interventions to improve referral practices, such as informational materials for patients in oncology departments, discussion prompts, or ways to increase physician and patient awareness of AP techniques and guidelines. STUDY FUNDING/COMPETITION INTERESTS: This work was supported by Radboud university medical center and Radboud Institute of Health Sciences. The authors have not declared any conflict of interest regarding this work. TRIAL REGISTRATION NUMBER: Not applicable.

title: Regeneration of peripheral nerves after injury
Regulatory and legislative security: the state of candor
Regulatory models for human embryo cloning: free market, professional guidelines and government restrictions
abstract: Both experimental and therapeutic uses of new reproductive technologies have been governed not by medical ideology that is in the best interests of patients and their children, but by market ideology of profit maximization under the guise of "reproductive freedom." In our constitutional, democratic society, government has the mandate and obligation to make and enforce reasonable arrangements to manage the new reproductive market in order to protect the interests of the public, prospective parents and their future children. The "cloning" discussion provides a useful opportunity to compare and contrast the competing regulatory models of the free market, professional guidelines, and government restrictions.

title: Rehabilitating antisocial personalities: treatment through self-management strategies
abstract: It is commonly assumed that offenders with antisocial personality disorder (ASPD) refuse psychotherapeutic intervention. Thus, some commentators argue that those with this disorder are better managed in the criminal justice system, where engagement with psychological treatment following the introduction of indefinite sentences is forcibly linked to achieving parole. In contrast, National Institute of Clinical Excellence guidelines on the management and treatment of ASPD recommend that treatment seekers should be considered for admission to specialist psychiatric hospitals. The rationale is that prison-based interventions are under-resourced and ASPD treatment is not given enough priority. The rationale is that offenders with ASPD can be rehabilitated if they are motivated. One problem, however, is that little is known about why offenders with ASPD receive treatment or what effect subsequent treatment has on their understanding. The purpose of this article is to address these unresolved issues. Based on the findings of an Economic and Social Research Council (ESRC)-funded qualitative study examining the experiences of male convicted male offenders admitted to a specialist personality disorder ward on medium security property and the medical doctors who treat them. The data are analyzed with reference to Michel Foucault's work on governmentality and strategy in power relations. Two arguments have been advanced: first, criminals with ASPD are motivated by legal coercive pressures to employ a variety of Foucault-type strategies to give a false impression of treatment progress. Second, and related treatment, does not lead to changes in self-understanding in the resistant client with ASPD. This assumes that, at least for this group, Foucault was wrong in his claim that resistant behaviors only mask the effectiveness of treatment norms over time. However, the article concludes that specialist treatment in a hospital setting may affect changes in the resistant offender's self-understanding, but completion of treatment does not result in his readmission to prison, as is usual.

title: Rehabilitation of children and adolescents
abstract: significant increase in the majority of chronic mental and physical diseases among children and adolescents has been reported in recent years. Therefore, medical child and adolescent rehabilitation plays an important role. Therefore, early diagnosis and multimodal intervention in childhood and adolescence are necessary to prevent a chronic disease course. Patient education programs have been shown to be effective in the treatment of chronic diseases. These programs mostly aim to improve adaptive behavior and disease management. Then health status and quality of life should be improved. The quality of rehabilitation programs has been improved over the past 15 years due to the implementation of the guidelines and evaluation work. However, future research should develop flexible rehabilitation programs (rehabilitation period, rehabilitation near or far from the place of residence, inpatient, partial outpatient and outpatient programs and rehabilitation chain), whose effectiveness should be proven in particular.

title: Successfully treated anxiety and fear relapse: theoretical considerations and recommendations for clinical practice.
abstract: Despite the existence of effective interventions for anxiety disorders, relapse – or return of fear – poses a significant long-term challenge for patients and clinicians. This article draws on the experimental and clinical behavioral literature, reviewing the mechanisms by which fear reversal may occur. The aim of the article was to create a list of treatment recommendations for clinicians aiming to reduce relapse in successfully treated anxiety disorders. The clinical and experimental literature on the mechanisms of regeneration, reinstatement, self-healing, and recovery is reviewed. These are linked to the clinical and experimental literature on the return of fear in successfully treated anxiety. A list of recommendations is provided to help reduce the likelihood of relapse in successfully treated anxiety. This list includes methods of use in the behavioral (exposure) treatment of anxiety disorders aimed at improving clinical outcomes. Despite a significant relapse problem in successfully treated anxiety, there are methods available to reduce the likelihood of relapse through fear return. Clinicians dealing with the treatment of anxiety disorders should pay attention to these methods to ensure optimal patient outcome.

title: The relationship between reporting completeness of health research and journal approval of reporting guidelines: systematic review.
abstract: PURPOSE To assess whether the completeness of reporting health research is relevant to journals' approval of reporting guidelines. DESIGN Systematic review. DATA SOURCES Reporting guidelines from a published systematic review and the EQUATOR Network (October 2011). Studies evaluating the completeness of reporting using a reporting guide (called "reviews") (1990 - October 2011"; additional searches in January 2012) included from searches of Medline, Embase, and the Cochrane Methodology Register or Scopus, depending on reporting English or French language assessments of included reporting guidelines are included, which provide clear guidance for reporting, describe the guidance development process, and specify the use of a consensus development process. potentially appropriate assessments, including DATA DRAWING The guides used were first scanned as titles and abstracts, and then as full-text reports. If eligibility was uncertain, review authors were contacted; When necessary, the websites of the journals were consulted for approval information. Completeness of reporting of reporting guidelines was analyzed in relation to item-by-item validation and a mean overall score when consistent with the authors' analysis. RESULTS 101 reporting guidelines included. Of the 15,249 records from the assessment search, 26 assessments were identified that evaluated the completeness of reporting on the approval of nine reporting guidelines. Of these, 13 assessments evaluating seven reporting guidelines (BMJ economic checklist, CONSORT for damages, PRISMA, QUOROM, STARD, STRICTA and STROBE) can be analyzed. Reporting guidelines were evaluated by several assessments. RESULTS (excluding CONSORT) Of the 101 health research reporting guidelines, the completeness of reporting only nine was evaluated in relation to the validation of journals. The items in the seven reporting guidelines were analyzed quantitatively, each with several assessments. There is insufficient evidence to determine the relationship between journals' approval of reporting guidelines and the completeness of reporting of published health research reports. Journal editors and researchers should consider collaborative prospective, controlled studies to provide more robust evidence. REGISTER OF SYSTEMATIC REVIEWS Not registered; "No known registry currently accepts protocols for methodological systematic reviews.

title: reminiscence therapy for dementia
abstract: BACKGROUND: Recall Therapy (RT) has been defined as a vocal or silent recollection of events in a person's life, alone or with another person or group. It usually includes group meetings, at least once a week, in which participants are encouraged to talk about past events, often supplemented by helpful tools such as photos, music, objects, and videos from the past. Consistent application of psychological therapies in dementia services is often minimal. Some of these 'therapies' have been enthusiastically received by health care practitioners in stimulating care settings. They were expected to work miracles, and their "failure" led to their not being widely used. A systematic review of the available evidence is important to determine the effectiveness of different treatments. Then, guidelines for their use can be made on the basis of solid evidence. OBJECTIVES: RT involves groups of older people talking about past events, supported by tools such as videos, pictures and archives, to communicate and reflect on their life experiences. The purpose of this review is to evaluate the effects of RT for dementia. SEARCH STRATEGY: We searched the Cochrane Controlled Trials Register, MEDLINE, PSYCHLIT, EMBASE, OMNI, BIDS, Dissertation Abstracts International, SIGLE and related articles' reference lists up to 1998 and contacted experts. We also manually searched relevant websites and the Aging and Mental Health, Gerontologist, Journal of Gerontology, Current Opinion in Psychiatry, Current Research in Britain: Social Sciences, British Psychological Society conference proceedings and Reminiscence database. SELECTION CRITERIA: Randomized controlled trials and quasi-randomized trials for RT for dementia in elderly people. DATA COLLECTION AND ANALYSIS: Two reviewers independently extracted data and evaluated research quality. MAIN RESULTS: Two studies were included in the review, but only one study with 15 participants had extractable data. The results were not statistically significant for both cognition and behavior. STUDY MANAGER's RESULTS: No firm conclusions could be drawn about the effectiveness of RT for dementia. The review highlighted the urgent need for more systematic research in the region.

title: Remission, residual symptoms, and unresponsiveness in the usual treatment of major depression in managed clinical practice
abstract: BACKGROUND: While published guidelines recommend continuing treatment for depression until complete remission of symptoms and restoration of functioning, little is known about how often remission is achieved in usual practice and what factors lead to discontinuation when treatment outcome is not optimal. METHODS: A native study design examined 1859 patients treated for DSM-III-R major depression between 1995 and 1997 in the national provider network of a managed behavioral health organization (MBHO). Symptom and disorder ratings were used by clinicians to group patients into complete remission, partial remission, and no response. Damage data were used to characterize treatment and identify comorbid medical conditions. RESULTS: Based on clinician ratings, approximately 27% to 39% of patients achieved complete remission. Medical and substance use comorbidity and hospitalization were more common in those with partial response to treatment. Only half of the patients with no treatment response received a drug trial during their treatment. Patient selection was the most common reason for discontinuing treatment, but approximately 40% of clinicians agree with patients' decisions even when symptoms do not improve. CONCLUSION: Although rates of complete remission are comparable to those in clinical trials of antidepressants, results suggest that clinicians may fail to recommend continuation and maintenance therapy in accordance with best practice guidelines, and failed therapy often does not include antidepressant drugs.

title: foot replantation
Report from the PHLS Center for Infectious Disease Surveillance
abstract: An outbreak of Legionnaires' disease was reported among vacationers returning from Yugoslavia between August and September"; there were other outbreaks of shellfish-related gastrointestinal disease; the flu received much publicity after a suggestion that an epidemic could occur in the coming winter months; and two tropical diseases were in the news, leishmaniasis and cercarial dermatitis.

title: NIH Panel Report Defining Principles of HIV Infection Treatment*
abstract: Recent research advances have led to a significantly better understanding of the biology of human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) infection and the pathogenesis of acquired immunodeficiency syndrome (AIDS). With the advent of sensitive tools to monitor HIV replication in infected individuals, the risk of disease progression and death can be accurately assessed and the efficacy of anti-HIV treatments directly determined. Also, when used appropriately, combinations of newly available, potent antiviral therapies can affect long-term suppression of detectable levels of HIV replication and counteract HIV's natural propensity to generate drug-resistant viral variants. However, as antiretroviral therapy for HIV infection has become more and more effective, it has also become increasingly complex. Familiarity with the latest research advances is necessary to ensure that new available treatments are used in a way that most effectively improves the health and prolongs the life of people infected with HIV. To enable practitioners and people infected with HIV to make the most of the rapidly accumulating new knowledge about the pathogenesis and treatment of HIV disease, the National Institutes of Health's Office of AIDS Research sponsored the NIH Panel to Define Principles of HIV Infection Treatment. This Panel was asked to describe the key scientific principles that should be used to guide the most effective use of antiretroviral therapies and viral load testing in clinical practice. Based on a detailed review of the most recent data, the panel identified eleven principles that address issues of fundamental importance for the treatment of HIV infection. These principles provide the scientific basis for specific treatment recommendations made by the Clinical Practices Panel for Treating HIV Infection, supported by the Department of Health and Human Services and the Henry J. Kaiser Family Foundation. Reports from both of these panels are presented in this publication. Together, they summarize new data and provide both the scientific basis and specific guidelines for the treatment of HIV-infected persons. This information will be of interest to healthcare providers, HIV-infected persons, HIV/AIDS educators, public health educators, public health authorities and all organizations that fund the medical care of HIV-infected persons.

title: Reproductive rights and the medical care system: an advocacy for rational health policy.
abstract: In recent times, there have been many challenges to women's reproductive rights and liberties: "court-ordered cesarean section"; criminal cases against women for prenatal child abuse; and attempts to limit midwifery, home birth, and alternative birth operations. In these cases, medicine has taken up the behavior of pregnant women or the health care has been complicit or proactive in their attempts to control their choices. A more coherent policy framework is needed to guide the role of medicine as an agent of social control, the medical restructuring of problems that are social in nature, and the practice of physicians;" PIP: Reproductive issues are highly controversial. Women's legal right to abortion continues to be questioned, women's rights are challenged by fetal rights, and there are concerns about early pregnancy, the appropriate use of reproductive technology, and the use of drugs and alcohol during pregnancy. However, little attention has been paid to the role of medicine as an agent of social control and arbiter of reproductive behavior, the medical restructuring and intervention of problems that are social in nature, or the role of equity and social justice in reproductive health care. The authors discuss these latter issues in light of historical and more recent attempts to control the behavior of pregnant women. In the absence of current reproductive health policy, the medical profession makes arbitrary decisions in individual cases that may or may not reflect the wishes of the patient or community. A more coherent policy framework and regulatory mechanisms are needed to guide physician practice. The authors discuss the issue in the context of context, key questions, social discrimination in reproductive health care, the choice of which services to provide, coercion and choice, and reproductive health policy as a solution.

title: Requiring physicians to respond to computerized reminders improves their adherence to preventive care protocols.
abstract: Purpose: To improve compatibility with computer-generated reminders to perform stool occult blood testing (FOBT), mammography, and cervical Papanicolaou (Pap) testing. Design: A six-month prospective, randomized, controlled study. Setting: Academic primary care general internal medicine practice. Subjects: Thirty-one general internal medicine faculties, 145 residents, and 5,407 patients with scheduled visits eligible for any of the three cancer screening protocols. Intervention: Primary care teams of internists and faculty received either routine computer reminders (check) or the same reminders to circle one of four responses: 1) “made/ordered today”, 2) “not applicable to this patient” ” 3) “patient declined” or 4) “next visit”. Results: Intervention physicians adhered more frequently than control physicians by combining all reminders (46% versus 38%, p=0.002), and FOBT (61% versus 49%, p=0.0007) and mammography (54%, respectively). vs 47%, p=0.036) separately with reminders, but not for cervical Pap testing (21% vs. 18%, p=0.2). Intervention assistants responded to FOBT and mammography reminders together and separately to all reminders significantly more frequently than control residents, but did not give a Pap test. There was no significant difference between intervention and control faculty, but the compliance rate for control faculty was significantly higher than the proportion of control residents for all reminders together and separately for FOBT, but not for mammography or Pap testing. The impact of the intervention was greatest for 70-year-old patients and yielded significant results for all tests combined and alone, not for residents but not faculty. Intervention physicians felt that reminders could not be implemented in 21% (due to insufficient data in patients' electronic medical records) and stated that 10% of patients refused. Conclusions: Requiring physicians to respond to computer-generated reminders improved adherence to preventive care protocols, particularly in older patients with the lowest compliance by control physicians. However, 100% compliance with cancer screening reminders will not be achieved due to missing data and patient rejection.

title: Research based on archived information and examples. Recommendations of the Committee on Ethics in Medicine of the Royal College of Physicians
abstract: In 1996 the College published Guidelines on the Practice of Ethics Committees in Medical Research, which includes Human Subjects, which includes a section on non-intrusive research (3rd ed). The recommendations published here aim to clarify the issues surrounding this category of research as it pertains to allowing the use of archived information and samples.

title: Research in the field of psychiatry
Practice-oriented research: Collaboration for Leadership in Applied Health Research and Care (CLAHRC) for Nottinghamshire, Derbyshire, Lincolnshire (NDL)
abstract: Background To address the challenge of translating from research-based evidence to routine health practices, the Collaboration for Leadership and Care in Applied Health Research (CLAHRC-NDL) for Nottinghamshire, Derbyshire and Lincolnshire was funded as one by the National Institute for Health Research. From nine CLAHRCs across the UK This article summarizes the core theory adopted by the CLAHRC-NDL and its application as a case example that can be generalized to practice outside of CLAHRC compared to alternative practice models. Discussion Traditional approaches to health research often produce evidence that is isolated from the environment for which it is intended.
