The premise of the CLAHRC-NDL model is that barriers to implementation can be overcome if knowledge is co-produced by academic and clinical service staff, taking into account the organizational context in which it will be applied. This approach is based on organizational learning theory, recognizing that change is a social and political phenomenon. Evidence is produced in real time, taking into account the entire environment in which it will be applied. To support this process, senior healthcare personnel are assigned to CLAHRC as Â¡Â®diffusion scholarsÂ¡Â¯ (DFs) to actively bridge the research practice gap as full members of both the research team and their clinical field. application. Existing communities of practice are developed and new ones encouraged around specific themes to facilitate innovation and embed change in the local health community. Our approach has been adopted by 16 clinical research studies in mental health, children and youth, primary care, and stroke rehabilitation. Summary The CLAHRC-NDL implementation model applies organizational learning theory, addressing social and situational barriers and factors that facilitate implementation, and adopting a co-production philosophy. Two key mechanisms have been used for translation of innovation: DFs to actively bridge research into the practice gap, and communities of practice to support and sustain improvements in healthcare. The model shows promising results in putting research into practice that can be transferred to other healthcare contexts.

title: Research opportunities in early childhood: Birth to 5 years old
abstract: The American Occupational Therapy Association (AOTA) Evidence-Based Practice Project has developed a chart that summarizes research opportunities on early childhood. The table provides an overview of the current state of evidence regarding interventions in occupational therapy practice and is based on systematic reviews in the AOTA Evidence-Based Practice Guidelines Series. Researchers, students and clinicians can use this information to develop innovative research to answer important questions in the field of occupational therapy.

title: Research priorities for public health nursing
abstract: The Society of Community Health Nursing Educators (ACHNE) Research Committee initiated a revision of the ACHNE Research Priorities for public health nursing practice in 2006, following those developed in 1992 and 2000. The Committee (a) reviewed public health nursing research summaries (n =485) 2000 from 7 selected nursing journals to assess progress in addressing priority; (b) defined research methods used in abstracts, health issues and health behaviors addressed, and demographics of study populations; " and (c) reviewed the research priorities of key federal funding agencies and journal editors. Overall, progress towards meeting previous priorities was modest, with a limited set of methods, topics, and examples described. The 2009 ACHNE Research Priorities for public health nursing include: (1) Population-Based Outcomes and (2) Public Health Nursing Workforce. To address these priorities, there is a need for multisite studies, clinical trials, population-based participatory research, the development and/or analysis of existing large datasets, and the development of valid and reliable methods. Collaboration between educators, researchers, and practitioners is crucial to developing a scientific evidence base for population-based nursing practice.

title: Investigation of effective approaches to cleanliness in hospitals: protocol of the REACH trial, a multisite cascade randomized trial.
abstract: Background The Study of Research into Effective Approaches to Cleaning in Hospitals (REACH) will produce evidence of the effectiveness and cost-effectiveness of a new cleaning initiative aimed at improving the environmental cleanliness of hospitals. The initiative is an environmental sanitation package consisting of five interconnected, evidence-based components (education, technique, product, inspection and communication) implemented with environmental services personnel to improve hospital sanitation practices. Methods/design The REACH trial will use a cascade randomized controlled design to test the study intervention, an environmental cleanup package, in 11 Australian hospitals. All trial hospitals will receive the intervention and act as their own controls, with analysis of the change in each hospital based on data collected during the control and intervention periods. Each site will be randomly selected to one of 11 response times in 2016 with staggered start dates and a response time of 20 to 50 weeks. All sites are completing trial at the same time in 2017. Inclusion criteria allow for a purposeful sample of both public and private hospitals with higher risk patient populations for healthcare-associated infections (HAIs). The primary outcome (target) is the number of Staphylococcus aureus bacteremia (SAB), Clostridium difficile infections (CDI), and vancomycin-resistant enterococci (VRE) infections per 10,000 bed days per month. Secondary outcomes for the primary objective include the completeness of hospital cleanliness assessed using fluorescent sign technology, the bioburden of frequently touched surfaces after cleaning, and changes in staff knowledge and attitudes regarding environmental cleanliness. A cost-effectiveness analysis will identify the second key result (second objective): the increased rate of cost-effectiveness resulting from the implementation of the cleaning package. The study uses the Action to Promote Research Practice in Healthcare (iPARIHS) framework to support the specific implementation of the environmental cleanup package at each hospital. Discussion Evidence from the REACH study will contribute to future policy and practice guidelines regarding hospital sanitation. It will be used by healthcare leaders and clinicians to inform decision-making and implementation of best practice infection prevention strategies to reduce HAIs in hospitals.

title: Responding to drug addiction in a flexible but impure way
Responding to patient-initiated humor: practice guidelines
abstract: Over the past few decades, increasing evidence has shown the beneficial effects of humor. The use of caregiver-initiated humor as an intervention in healthcare settings has both physiological and emotional benefits. However, little has been written about another very important aspect of humor, patient-initiated humor. When patients use humor to relieve feelings of stress, uncertainty, or embarrassment, they try to communicate with their caregivers. This use of humor by patients is not a way of "illuminating" the situation, but rather a way of reducing their sense of dehumanization. Humor is an interactive sharing process and an important aspect of communication. Patients will observe the caregiver for a response. A clear, accepting response shows you understand";" However, a negative or blank response may serve to isolate the patient. The guidelines discussed in this article for recognizing, interpreting, and responding to patient-initiated humor will help home care and nursing home nurses foster increased open patient/caregiver communication and create a supportive humane atmosphere for patient care.

title: Intervention with Youth's Health Risks in Primary Care: A Cluster Randomized Training Trial of Clinicians in Screening and Motivational Interviewing
abstract: OBJECTIVE: To evaluate the effectiveness of a complex intervention applying best practice guidelines recommending that clinicians screen and counsel young people for multiple psychosocial risk factors on clinicians' health risk identification and patients' risk-taking behavior compared to a didactic seminar on youth health. DESIGN: A pragmatic cluster randomized trial in which volunteer general practices are stratified by zip code advantage or disadvantage score and billing type (private, free national health, community health centre), then randomized to intervention or comparison arms using a computer-generated randomized array. Three months after the intervention, patients were recruited from all practices after consultation for the Computer Assisted Telephone Interview and followed up at three and 12 months. Investigators who recruited, consented, and interviewed patients and patients themselves were masked in assignment status"; clinicians were not. MEDIA: General practices in Victoria, Victoria, Australia. PARTICIPANTS: With at least one relevant clinician (GP or nurse) and Intervention: This complex intervention was designed using evidence-based practice in learning and change in clinician behavior and general practice systems, and included best-practice approaches to motivate change in adolescent risk-taking behaviors. The intervention included training of clinicians (nine hours) in health risk screening, use of a screening tool. and motivational interviewing; training all practice staff (receptionists and clinicians) on youth participation; providing feedback to clinicians on patients' risk data; and two practice visits and referral resources to support new screening Comparative clinicians received a didactic training The m seminar (three hours) was included in youth and health risk screening. OUTCOME MEASURES: The primary outcomes were (1) the patient's report that the clinician identified at least one of six health risk behaviors (tobacco, alcohol, and illicit drug use, sexually transmitted infection risks, STIs, unplanned pregnancy, and route risks); and (2) change in one or more of the six health risk behaviors at three months or 12 months. Secondary outcomes were probability of future visits, trust in clinician after exit interview, clinician's perception of emotional distress and fear and abuse in relationships, and emotional distress at three and 12 months. Patient acceptability of the scan tool for the intervention arm is also described. Analyzes were adjusted for practice location and billing type, patients' gender, age, and method of recruitment, and, where appropriate, past health risks. Intent-to-treat analysis approach involving multilevel multiple assessment was used for missing outcome data. RESULTS: 42 treatments were randomly assigned to the intervention or comparison arms. The two intervention practices were withdrawn post-allocation before training, leaving 19 interventions (53 clinicians, 377 patients) and 21 comparators (79 clinicians, 524 patients). 69% of patients in both the intervention (260) and comparison (360) arms completed 12 months of follow-up. Intervention clinicians discussed more health risks per patient (59.7%) than comparative clinicians (52.7%) and were therefore more likely to identify a higher proportion of youth with at least one of the six health risk behaviors (38.4% versus 26.7%). , risk difference [RD] 11.6%, Confidence Interval [CI] 2.93% to 20.3%; adjusted odds [OR] 1.7, CI 1.1 to 2.5). Patients experienced less illicit drug use (RD -6.0, CI -11 to -1.2; OR 0.52, CI 0.28 to 0.96) and a lower risk of STIs (RD -5.4, CI -11 to 0.2; OR 0.66, CI 0.46 to 0.96). ) reported ) at three months for intervention relative to the comparator arm and at 12 months for unplanned pregnancy (RD -4.4; CI -8.7 to -0.1; OR 0.40, CI 0.20 to 0.80). Health risks More abuse detection (OR 13.8, CI 1.71 to 111) There were no reports of harmful events, and the intervention arm highly accepted the youth screening tool. Better detection of risky behaviors Had insufficient impact on health outcomes Technology that enables more efficient, systematic health risk screening could allow providers to target counseling to higher-risk individuals. Requires more power to Ak confirm the health benefits. TRIAL REGISTRATION: ISRCTN.com ISRCTN16059206.

title: Response to intervention: principles and strategies for effective implementation.
abstract: Meeting a basic need, this book is the first comprehensive guide to implementing a school-wide intervention intervention (RTI) program. The book is intended to help practitioners understand and respond to No Child Left Behind and the new special education eligibility guidelines outlined at IDEIA 2004. The theoretical and empirical foundations of the approach and a clear, 10-step model for executing RTI procedures are presented. with students with learning difficulties. Special features include reproducible planning and execution worksheets and more than two dozen overhead transparency masters for use in RTI training sessions and flat binding to make copying easy. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2016 APA, all rights reserved)

title: Educator's responsibility
Results of a physician and respiratory therapist joint effort to develop the long-term metered dose inhaler technique in the pediatric asthma clinic
abstract: BACKGROUND: Despite advances in treatment, asthma remains the chronic condition most responsible for absenteeism and pediatric hospitalizations. This is especially true for inner-city children. We operate an inner-city Pediatric Asthma Adaptation and Technique (PACT) clinic where doctors and respiratory therapists collaborate to improve metered dose inhaler (MDI) technique and outcomes among children with asthma. OBJECTIVE: To determine the effectiveness of our MDI technique and strategy to improve asthma outcomes. METHODS: Children referred to the PACT clinic underwent a standardized assessment based on the National Heart, Lung, and Blood Institute's (NHLBI) Expert Panel Guidelines. Clinicians demonstrated and reinforced correct MDI technique at each visit. Demographic data, MDI-technical scores (MDI steps performed correctly";" scale 0-8), pulmonary function, and asthma severity (NHLBI classification), using a standard format that we prospectively collected at the patient's first visit (T1) and most recent visit (T2) scale: 1 = mildly intermittent to 4 = severe persistent). Statistical analyzes were performed using parametric and non-parametric tests. RESULTS: Fifteen of 60 patients admitted to the PACT clinic between 1999 and 2002 were excluded from the study due to incomplete data enrollment. The mean time from T1 to T2 was 11.8 +/- 9.5 months. At T1 and T2, mean MDI technique scores were 53% and 81%, mean overall asthma severity scores were 2.6 and 2.3, and mean overall pulmonary function severity scores were 2.4 and 2.1. MDI-technical scores improved significantly between TI and T2 (p < 0.001). Black patients had the greatest improvement in MDI technique (p < 0.001), but pulmonary function test results, overall asthma severity, and pulmonary function severity did not improve significantly. White patients significantly improved both MDI techniques (p = 0.004) and overall asthma severity scores (p = 0.005). CONCLUSION: In our PACT clinic, children with asthma showed sustained improvement in the MDI technique, and some of the patients showed improvement in respiratory function and overall asthma severity score.

title: Results that matter: Structured and unstructured self-monitoring of blood glucose in type 2 diabetes
abstract: Self-monitoring of blood glucose (SMBG) is a component of diabetes management. SMBG provides information on current glycemic status and provides the ability to receive immediate feedback on the effect of behavioral and pharmacological interventions on glucose levels. However, SMBG is only useful when the glucose information is properly understood, the data interpreted correctly, and the results prompt appropriate therapeutic actions. The International Diabetes Federation (IDF) has recently published guidelines for the use of SMBG in people with diabetes who are not insulin-treated, recommending that SMBG be used only when patients and/or clinicians have the ability and willingness to incorporate SMBG monitoring and therapy adjustment into their treatment. diabetes care plan If SMBG is used, the IDF also recommends that structured SMBG be done using defined regimens to meet individual needs. Structured SMBG can be performed as daily glucose profiles that represent daily glucose excursions. Measuring pre-meal/post-meal blood glucose (bG) levels on consecutive or alternating days ("testing in pairs") also provides effective glucose information for daily diabetes management. This article reviews recent studies that have appropriately used structured SMBG as an integral component of comprehensive diabetes management and discusses how their findings support IDF recommendations. Our goal is to help clinicians make more informed decisions about the value and utility of SMBG in diabetes management.

title: Rethinking pragmatic randomized controlled trials: introducing the "cohort multiple randomized controlled trial" design
abstract: Pragmatic trials are important for informing routine clinical practice, but current designs have shortcomings. Clare Relton and colleagues outline the design of a new "multiple randomized controlled trial" design that could help address issues associated with current approaches. The "gold standard" for determining how well an intervention is working. However, trials that aim to determine the efficacy of a treatment using a double-blind, placebo-controlled design (i.e., explanatory trials) are sometimes criticized. For example, while the design of exploratory trials results in strong internal validity—we can rely on the results of a particular trial—such trials may have limited external validity: Don't be sure we can apply the results to routine clinical practice. Pragmatic trials,12 aimed at informing healthcare decision-making in practice, have been proposed as a solution because they preserve the rigor of randomization (thus eliminating selection bias) but retain features of normal clinical practice. Implementation and interpretation of both pragmatic and explanatory randomized controlled trials are associated with significant problems. This article describes a trial design that helps address these issues - the "cohort multiple randomized controlled trial" approach. Current clinical trial designs may have shortcomings in four areas: "recruitment"; ethics; patient preferences;" and treatment comparisons. ### Recruitment Most randomized controlled trials have difficulty recruiting enough patients. For example, one study found that less than a third of the 114 multicenter, publicly funded UK studies received the original target number of patients within the time specified at baseline.3 Failure to meet the target may have implications for the power and generalizability of the study results. In addition, many clinical trials exclude hard-to-reach groups and ethnic minorities4, resulting in disparities between the “need (reference)” population and the trial population.5 6 â‚¬ ¦

title: Review of legal instruments and rules regarding medical experimentation with children
abstract: Medical research with children has been the subject of ongoing debate. The reason for the controversy is clear. As with adult research, a balance must be struck between two goals: promoting children's health through advances in scientific knowledge and protecting children's research subjects from exploitation and harm. However, due to their age and relative immaturity, children cannot protect their own interests as much as adult subjects. As they progress into adulthood, however, increased care must be taken to involve children in decisions that affect them enough to allow them to make choices that can have serious and long-term consequences.

title: Revision of the Declaration of Helsinki: a new beginning
A review of the history of Cold War research ethics
abstract: President Clinton's responsibility to the Human Radiation Experiments Advisory Committee included setting ethical and legal standards for evaluating government-sponsored radiation experiments performed during the Cold War. In this article, we will review the traditional narrative of the history of American research ethics, and then highlight and explain the importance of a number of the Committee's historical findings in connection with this disclosure. These findings include both the national defense agency's tackling legal and insurance issues related to human experimentation, and the medical profession's perspective on human experimentation in the years following the Nuremberg Medical Trials. We conclude that the Committee's work both enriches the traditional view of the history of research ethics and opens up important new areas for study.

title: Rheumatism and Arthritis: A Study of Recent American and British Literatures: (Eleventh Study of Rheumatism): Part II
Rheumatism and Arthritis: Recent American and English Literature Review: (Sixteenth Review of Rheumatism)
abstract: Since 1935, fifteen issues of Reviews of Rheumatism have been published periodically in the ANNALS OF INTERNAL TIBINE under the auspices of the American Rheumatism Society. This sixteenth issue contains an analysis of selected articles from the American and British literature on the basic and clinical aspects of connective tissue diseases from 1961 and 1962. The American Rheumatism Association (ARA), with the help of the editors of the ANNALS OF INTERNAL MEDICINE, will continue to publish – at approximately two-year intervals – an analysis of key contributions in this field, emphasizing issues of interest to clinicians. The American Rheumatic Association, in collaboration with the National Library of Medicine, is producing a recurring bibliography on rheumatic diseases on computer tape. By making use of this method of accessing the literature, "Current Bibliographic Lists in Arthritis and Rheumatism" will be prepared and made available to anyone interested in connective tissue diseases. Future Rheumatism Reviews will be prepared by a committee of the American Rheumatism Society to provide a single comprehensive analysis of both fundamental and clinical aspects in the field of rheumatology. These will be published in the journal Arthritis and Rheumatism.

title: Rheumatism and Arthritis: A Study of the Recent Years of American and English Literature: (THIRTH REVIEW OF rheumatism)
abstract: CONTENTS CHAPTER I General Incidence of Rheumatic Diseases 2 Classification of Joint and Related Structural Diseases 5 Diseases Primarily Related to Trauma 5 Arthritis Due to Specific Infectious Agents 8 Rheumatic Fever 19 Sydenham Korea 29 Rheumatoid Arthritis 30 Rheumatoid (Ankylosing) Spondylitis Joint 81 Osteoarthritis (Degenerative Arthritis) 88 CHAPTER II Back Pain and Sciatica 95 Gout and Gout Arthritis 119 The Uric Acid Problem 144 “Collagen Diseases” 149 Psoriatic Arthritis 162 Reiter's Syndrome 163 Neurotrophic Arthropathy: Charcot Joints 165 Rheumatic Purpura (Sch?nlein-Henoch) 166 Haemophilic Arthritis 168 Arthritis and Arthralgia 168 Alkaptonuria, Ochronosis and Ochronic Arthritis

title: Richard Cabot: Medical Reformer in Progress (1890-1920)
abstract: Richard Cabot's (1868-1939) decision to leave his full-time medical job in 1920 to teach social ethics illustrates some of the tensions inherent in the transformation of twentieth-century medicine from clinical practice to biomedical science. One of America's best-known doctors at the time, Cabot practiced medicine in an age where science was redefining medical practice and thought. Despite being a champion of medical science, Cabot's primary concerns were clinical and humanistic. He emphasized the importance of outpatient medicine, advocated group practice, founded hospital social work, conducted clinical epidemiological research, lobbied for preventive medicine, formed the Clinical-Pathological Conference, and wrote extensively on medical ethics. In 1912, despite Cabot's great talents, the top professorship at Harvard Medical School was given instead to David Edsall, a clinician with a more extensive basic science training. Cabot's efforts to define the physician's role in human well-being as well as the healthcare system heralded the current attempts by medicine to emphasize the patient's social context.

title: Escape from the world of hydroxyquinolines
Taking the information translation detour: Lessons learned in information translation from the Canadian Health Research Summer Institute
abstract: Background Funding the education and training of the next generation of health researchers is a key task of the Canadian Institutes of Health Research (CIHR) information translation (KT) portfolio. KT area is growing day by day";" therefore, the training and development of the next generation of KT researchers is essential. Methods Using curriculum documents, participant assessments, and self-reflection, this article describes a unique Summer Institute hosted by CIHR in Cornwall, Ontario, Canada. We outline the key aspects of a successful education initiative that can inform organizations and agencies worldwide that have an interest in or mandate for KT. Conclusions This study provides potential funders, faculty, and students with an inside look at the purpose, process, and outcomes of such educational initiatives. Conclusion National and international TC institutions, research institutions and funding agencies are encouraged to consider repeating the training model used here, as investment in TC staff will encourage the field to progress within and beyond local borders. 'To a person who has devoted his life to science, nothing gives greater happiness when the results find immediate practical application. There are no two sciences. There is science and the application of science, and the two are linked like a fruit to a tree.' Â¨C Louis Pasteur, 1871 (from Ian Graham's presentation, 2008 CIHR Summer Institute for Knowledge Translation)

title: Risk communication in clinical research: a cognitive experiment and a questionnaire
abstract: BACKGROUND: A Royal Statistical Institute Working Group recently recommended that "more numerical definitions as opposed to verbal risk definitions should be used" in initial human clinical trials. This echoed the views of many clinicians and psychologists on risk communication. As the clinical research industry rapidly expands worldwide, it is important to understand risk communication in Asian countries. METHODS: We conducted a cognitive experiment on participation in a hypothetical clinical trial of a pain medication and a survey in cancer and arthritis patients in Singapore. In part 1 of the experiment, patients were informed about the risk of adverse events in one of three formats (frequency, percentage, and verbal descriptor) and one of two sequences (least to most severe and most to least severe). They were asked if they were willing to participate. In part 2, patients were informed about risk in all three formats in the same order and asked if they were willing to participate again. Immediately afterwards, a preference survey was conducted for risk presentation methods and the use of verbal descriptors. RESULTS: Willingness to participate and possibility of change of decision were not affected by risk presentation methods. Most patients preferred the frequency format, but patients with no primary school graduate or formal education were indifferent. While patients used the verbal descriptors "very common", "common" and "very rare" in a manner similar to the European Commission Guidelines, their use of "uncommon" and "rare" descriptors differed significantly from that in the EU. CONCLUSION: In this sample of Asian cancer and arthritis patients, the risk presentation format had no effect on willingness to participate in a clinical trial. However, there is a clear preference for the frequency format. The ordinary use of verbal identifiers differed significantly from that of the EU.

title: Risk Factors for Methotrexate-Induced Lung Injury in Patients with Rheumatoid Arthritis: A Multicenter, Case-Control Study
abstract: BACKGROUND: Toxicity limits the use of methotrexate. OBJECTIVE: To determine risk factors for methotrexate-induced lung injury in patients with rheumatoid arthritis. DESIGN: Case-control study. MEDIA: One private and five academic rheumatology practices. PARTICIPANTS: Methotrexate recipients with rheumatoid arthritis with and without lung injury. MEASUREMENTS: Potential risk factors examined were sociodemographic and lifestyle characteristics, medical history, clinical and ancillary features, and characteristics of rheumatoid arthritis treatment and methotrexate treatment before methotrexate treatment. Cases of lung injury were defined according to the modified criteria of Searles and McKendry. RESULTS: Ninety-four percent of the study participants were white and 67% were women. Case patients (n = 29) were older than controls (n = 82) (61.5 vs. 54.5 years). After adjusting for other variables, the strongest predictors of lung injury were advanced age (odds ratio [OR], 5.1 [95% CI, 1.2 to 21.1]), diabetes (OR, 35.6 [CI, 1.3 to 21.1]). infinite]), was rheumatoid. pleuropulmonary involvement (OR, 7.1 [CI, 1.1 to 45.4]), previous use of disease-modifying antirheumatic drugs (OR, 5.6 [CI, 1.2 to 27.0)), and hypoalbuminemia (OR, 19.5 [CI, 3.5 to 109.7]). Previous use of disease-modifying antirheumatic drugs and hypoalbuminemia had enormous attributable risks. CONCLUSION: Knowing the risk factors that predispose patients with rheumatoid arthritis to the toxic effects of methotrexate on the lung can provide a rationale for monitoring high-risk patients and facilitate their treatment.

title: In-Hospital Heart Failure Risk Among New Users of Saxagliptin, Sitagliptin, and Other Antihyperglycemic Drugs
abstract: Background: Recent post-marketing trials have produced conflicting results regarding the risk of hospitalized heart failure (hHF) associated with dipeptidyl peptidase-4 (DPP-4) inhibitors, creating uncertainty about the safety of these antihyperglycemic agents. Purpose: To examine the relationships of hHF with saxagliptin and sitagliptin. Design: Population-based, retrospective, new user cohort study. Setting: 18 health insurance and healthcare system data partners in the U.S. Food and Drug Administration's Mini-Sentinel program. Patients: Patients 18 years of age or older with type 2 diabetes who started treatment with saxagliptin, sitagliptin, pioglitazone, second-generation sulfonylureas, or long-acting insulin products from 2006 to 2013. Measurements: Hospitalized HF defined by the International Classification of Diseases, Ninth Revision, Clinical Change codes 402.x1, 404.x1, 404.x3, and 428.xx were recorded as the main discharge diagnosis. Results: 78 553 saxagliptin users and 298 124 sitagliptin users contributed an average of 7 to 9 months of follow-up data to 1 or more paired comparisons. The risk of hHF was not higher with DPP-4 inhibitors than with other study drugs. Hazard ratios derived from the disease risk score (DRS), “Cstratified analyses, 0.83 (95% CI, 0.70 to 0.99) for saxagliptin vs. sitagliptin, 0.63 (CI, 0.47 to 0.99) for pioglitazone vs. saxagliptin. 0.85), 0.69 (CI, 0.54 to 0.99), 0.87) for sulfonylureas versus saxagliptin, and 0.61 (CI, 0.50 to 0.73) for saxagliptin versus insulin. DRS-layered hazard ratios for sitagliptin and pioglitazone It was 0.74 (CI, 0.64 to 0.85), 0.86 (CI, 0.77 to 0.95) for sitagliptin versus sulfonylureas, and 0.71 (GA, 0.64 to 0.78) for sitagliptin versus insulin.1:1 propensity scoreÂ¨Cmatched analyzes results were similar. was similar in subgroups of patients with and without cardiovascular disease and in a subgroup defined by the highest DRS decimal of 2. Limitation: Confusing now and short follow-up Conclusion: In this large cohort study, for hHF in saxagliptin or sitagliptin users compared to other selected antihyperglycemic agents a higher ri sk was not observed. Primary Source of Funding: US Food and Drug Administration.

title: Risk prevalence and screening for cancer by general practitioners
abstract: BACKGROUND: This study presents the cancer risk prevalence and screening rates of patients admitted to GPs. Conditions covered include smoking, skin cancer, Pap smears, clinical breast exams and mammography. METHODS: A cross-sectional study of 7,160 patients aged 18-75 years attending 230 GPs in a metropolitan and rural area in Queensland, Australia was used. The prevalence of risk was assessed from patients' self-reports of risk behavior and from screening prior to consultation. The details of the preventive care provided at the consultation are based on the doctors' own statements at the end of the consultation. RESULTS: 27 percent of men and 23 percent of women were smokers, with these rates being highest in younger age groups. According to national guidelines, there was no prior screening as recommended for men and women: skin cancer screening -- 66% of men, 70% of women", cervical cancer screening -- 27%, clinical breast exam -- 45%; " mammography -- 75%. These patients were thus categorized as "at risk" and the screening rates for these patients at the consultation were as follows: smokers -- 34%"; skin cancer -- 5%; cervical cancer -- 16%; mammography -- 4%;" clinical breast examination -- 8%. CONCLUSIONS: According to national guidelines, a significant number of patients admitted to general practitioners were at risk of developing cancer. Of these, only a small proportion of all groups received preventive intervention by their families at the consultation described in this study. While GPs often see their role in prevention as important, these results raise questions for future cancer prevention policies and education of GPs.

title: The cardiologist's role and interactions in a regional institutional primary prevention project
abstract: BACKGROUND: There is evidence to support policies for a population-wide approach to change risk factor distribution”, while establishing permanent primary prevention projects and recruiting the right experts is difficult. METHODS: In 1999, the Piedmont Region Administration identified risk factors in the general population, particularly disadvantaged groups. Cardiologists played a primary role in supporting the evidence project to produce based guidelines, bibliographic reviews, and disseminate coronary risk maps To promote a lifestyle counseling system with the central reference of general practice activity a main trainer group was established in each Local Health Service. As a second step, a mass media campaign was created using health advertisements in newspapers, television, public transport, bulletin boards on: nutrition, hypertension, tobacco, physical hand activity, stress; warehouses, food markets, trains and squares took place. In addition, a bulletin review has been published since January 2000 to produce key models, the most effective interventions, and recommendations for their implementation. CONCLUSIONS: New attention has been paid to general practitioners' primary prevention and counseling arguments, as well as the need for continuing education to encourage preventive action. A system has been established to identify the best channels, means of communication and the most effective messages for a healthy life. To better plan and evaluate effective interventions, a model was established to identify social differences, monitor risk factor changes and protective behaviors in the population. CONCLUSION: After more than half a century of productive public health science, there is an urgent need for State Administrations to direct health policy towards the determinants of health and create the best conditions for citizens to improve their lifestyles.

title: The role of 'external facilitation' in applying research findings: A qualitative assessment of facilitation experiences in the Veterans Health Administration.
abstract: Background Facilitation has been identified in the literature as a potentially important component of successful practice. However, it is neither well defined nor well studied. Important questions remain about the operational definition of facilitation and its relationship to other interventions, particularly when used in multifaceted implementation projects. Researchers, part of the Quality Enhancement Research Initiative (QUERI), are actively exploring a variety of approaches and processes, including facilitation, to ensure that best practices are implemented in the Veterans Health Administration healthcare system Â¨C, the largest integrated healthcare system in the United States. This document describes a systematic, retrospective assessment of practice-related facilitation experiences within QUERI, a quality improvement program developed by the U.S. Department of Veterans Affairs. Methods A post-hoc assessment was conducted through a series of semi-structured interviews to examine the concept of facilitation in several multisite QUERI practice studies. The interview process is based on a technique developed in the field of education that systematically enhances learning through experience by promoting recall and reflection on past complex activities. An iterative content analysis approach based on a set of conceptually based interview questions was used for data analysis. Findings The findings suggest that facilitation within a practice effort initiated by a central change agency is an intentional and valuable interactive problem-solving and support process that emerges in the context of an acknowledged need for improvement and a supportive interpersonal relationship. Facilitation was primarily defined as a distinct role with a potentially important set of behaviors and activities. The data also suggest that external facilitators are more likely to use or integrate other implementation interventions while fulfilling this problem-solving and supportive role. Preliminary Conclusions This assessment provides evidence that facilitation can be considered a separate implementation intervention, just as supervision and feedback, educational access or similar modalities can be considered separate interventions. Therefore, facilitation should be well defined and clearly evaluated for its perceived usefulness in multiple intervention implementation projects. In addition, researchers should better define the specific contribution of facilitation to the success of practice, with evidence and innovations in different types of projects, different types of sites, and varying levels of strength and complexity.

title: Royal College of Australian and New Zealand Psychiatrists clinical practice guidelines for the treatment of schizophrenia and related disorders
abstract: BACKGROUND: The Royal Australian and New Zealand College of Psychiatrists is coordinating the development of clinical practice guidelines (CPGs) in psychiatry funded by the National Mental Health Strategy (Australia) and the New Zealand Health Funding Authority. This article presents CPGs for schizophrenia and related disorders. In the last decade, schizophrenia has become more treatable than ever before. Next-generation drug therapies, the renaissance of psychological and psychosocial interventions, and first-generation reform within the specialist mental health system have combined to create a climate of realistic evidence-based optimism. Progressive neuroscientific advances raise the strong possibility of more definitive biologic treatments in the near future. However, this improved potential for better outcomes and quality of life for people with schizophrenia has not been realized in Australia. The efficacy-efficacy gap is wider for schizophrenia than for any other serious medical disorder. Therapeutic nihilism, inadequate provision of services and the stalling of the service reform process, low morale in specialist mental health services, lack of broad-based recovery and life support programs, and a persistent climate of stigma and consequent lack of concern for people with schizophrenia contribute to the failure to effectively treat this failure. are the reasons. These guidelines therefore address only one element in the effort to reduce the impact of schizophrenia. They distill the existing evidence base and make recommendations based on the best available information. METHODS: A comprehensive literature review (1990-2003), including all Cochrane reviews of schizophrenia and all relevant meta-analyses, was conducted and a number of current international clinical practice guidelines were consulted. A number of drafts were revised by the expert committee and developed through a binational consultation process. TREATMENT RECOMMENDATIONS: This guideline provides evidence-based recommendations for the management of schizophrenia according to the type of treatment and stage of the disease. The key features of the guidelines are: (i) Early detection and comprehensive treatment of first-episode cases is a priority, as the psychosocial and possibly biological effects of the disease can be minimized and outcomes improved. The optimistic attitude of health professionals is an important component from the onset of the disease and in all its stages. (ii) Since the course of the disease is strongly influenced by what occurs during this 'critical period', comprehensive and continuous intervention should be provided during the first 3-5 years after diagnosis. Patients should not have to 'prove chronicity' before gaining consistent access and tenure to specialist mental health services. (iii) Antipsychotic drugs are the cornerstone of treatment. These drugs have improved in quality and tolerability, but should be used more cautiously and in a targeted manner than in the past. The treatment of choice for most patients is now new antipsychotic drugs because of their superior tolerability and particularly low risk of tardive dyskinesia. This is especially true for the first-episode patient, where new agents are the first, second, and third-line choice because of superior tolerability. However, these new agents are associated with potentially serious medium- to long-term adverse events that require careful monitoring of patients. Low-dose conventional antipsychotic drugs may still have a role in a small proportion of patients with complete remission and good tolerability";" but the indicators are getting smaller and smaller. These principles are now accepted in most developed countries. (vi) Clozapine should be used early in the course when resistance to treatment with at least two antipsychotic drugs has been demonstrated. This usually means incomplete remission of positive symptomatology, but clozapine may also be considered in situations where there are widespread negative symptoms or where there is a significant or persistent risk of suicide. (v) Comprehensive psychosocial interventions should be routinely available to all patients and their families and should be allocated time to the task by appropriately trained mental health professionals. This includes family interventions, cognitive-behavioral therapy, occupational rehabilitation, and other forms of therapy, particularly for comorbid conditions such as substance abuse, depression and anxiety. (vi) The social and cultural environment of patients with schizophrenia is a necessary arena for intervention. Adequate housing, financial security, access to meaningful social roles, and the availability of social support are essential components of recovery and quality of life. (vii) Interventions should be carefully tailored to the stage and stage of the disease, gender and cultural background. (viii) The genuine involvement of consumers and relatives in the service development and supply process should be standard. (ix) Maintaining good physical health and the prevention and early treatment of serious medical illnesses have been severely neglected in the management of schizophrenia, resulting in premature death and widespread morbidity. The quality of medical care for patients with schizophrenia should be equivalent to the general population standard. (x) General practitioners (general practitioners) should always be closely involved in the care of patients with schizophrenia. However, this should truly be shared care, and the sole care of a GP with minimal or no specialist involvement, while very common, is not considered an acceptable standard of care. Optimal treatment of schizophrenia requires a multidisciplinary team approach with a centrally involved consultant psychiatrist.

title: Royal College calls for central research ethics committee
Royal College of Physicians Intercollegiate Stroke Working Group, evidence-based guidelines for secondary prevention of stroke through dietary or dietary modification
abstract: BACKGROUND: 15 million people worldwide and 110,000 people in the UK suffer a stroke each year. Having a stroke increases the risk of having another stroke. There are a number of additional known risk factors that can be modified by diet. This study aimed to systematically review essential nutrients and diets and their role in secondary prevention, as well as to provide evidence-based guidelines for use in clinical practice. The study was conducted as part of the development process of the Royal College of Physicians' (RCP) National Clinical Guidelines for Stroke (NCG) 4th edition. METHODS: The questions were created by the research team in consultation with the Virtual Stroke Group, an online professional interest group, and the RCP Intercollegiate Stroke Working Group Guideline Development Group. Nine questions covering a variety of individual foods and dietary combinations were identified and searches were performed using five electronic databases (Embase, Medline, Cumulative Index to Nursing and Allied Health Literature (CINAHL), Cochrane Library, and Web of Science) up to 31 October 2011. The quality and risk of bias of all included studies were assessed using the van Tulder criteria for randomized controlled trials (RCTs) and the Quality of Reporting of Meta-analyses (QUORUM) criteria for systematic reviews. RESULTS: 4287 abstracts were identified, 79 articles were reviewed, and 29 systematic reviews and RCTs were included to provide evidence for the secondary prevention components of the guidelines. Evidence statements, recommendations and practical considerations were developed for each question. CONCLUSIONS: This systematic review process resulted in the development of evidence-based guidelines for use in clinical practice and identified areas for further research.

title: Saccadic eye movement measurements reflect the fatigue of surgical residents
abstract: OBJECTIVE: Little is known about the effects of surgical residents' fatigue on patient safety. Using (1) measures of eye movement, (2) objective measures of laparoscopic surgical performance, and (3) subjective reports based on standardized questionnaires, we monitored the fatigue levels of surgical residents during call days. BACKGROUND: Previous attempts to investigate the effects of fatigue on surgical performance have suffered from methodological limitations, including inconsistent definitions and the lack of objective measures of fatigue and non-standard measures of surgical performance. Recent research has shown that fatigue can affect the characteristics of saccadic (rapid ballistic) eye movements in non-surgical scenarios. Here, we asked whether fatigue caused by time on duty (~24 hours) could affect saccadic measures in surgical residents. Because saccadic velocity is not under voluntary control, a saccadic velocity-based fatigue index has the potential to provide an accurate and unbiased measure of a patient's fatigue level. METHODS: Joseph Hospital and Medical Center (Phoenix, AZ) using a head-mounted video eye tracker (similar configuration to a surgical eye tracker) eye movements. far), during the performance of 3 tasks: 2 simulated laparoscopic surgical tasks (peg transfer and precision cutting) and a guided saccade task before and after the call day. Residents rated their perceived level of fatigue every 3 hours during their 24-hour shift using a standardized scale. CONCLUSIONS: Time on duty decreased saccadic speed and increased subjective fatigue, but did not affect laparoscopic performance. These results support the hypothesis that saccadic indices reflect gradual changes in fatigue. They also emphasize the complex relationship between continuity of care, patient safety, and fatigued caregivers, noting that fatigue from prolonged tenure does not necessarily result in medical error. CONCLUSIONS: Our data show for the first time that saccadic speed is a reliable indicator of subjective fatigue of healthcare professionals during prolonged employment. These findings have potential implications for the development of neuroergonomic tools for detecting fatigue among healthcare professionals and for the specification of future guidelines regarding assistant hours of duty.

title: Security risks associated with the integration of hospital health information technologies and lack of interfacing: a qualitative study of hospital electronic prescribing systems in the UK.
abstract: Background Significant amounts of money are invested in health information technology around the world. However, realizing the benefits and reducing safety risks depends heavily on interfacing to allow efficient integration of information within systems and/or information exchange between systems. As part of the English research programme, we explored the social and technical challenges of integration and interface faced by hospitals in early adopters of independent and hospital-wide multi-module integrated electronic prescribing (e-prescribing) systems. Methods We collected longitudinal qualitative data from six hospitals that we conceptualized as case studies. We conducted 173 interviews (up to three different times), 24 system usage observations and strategic meetings, 17 documents on implementation plans, and 2 full-day expert roundtable discussions with users, implementers, and software vendors. Data were analyzed thematically, first within and then between cases, utilizing perspectives surrounding knowledge infrastructures. Conclusions We observed that integration and interface issues hinder effective information transfer in both stand-alone and multi-module systems, resulting in threats to patient safety resulting from lack of timely information and duplicate data entry. On some standalone systems where users had to deal with multiple logins, interface problems arose immediately and did not subside over time. To eliminate such problems at first glance, multimodular systems appeared. However, in these systems, there was a perceived lack of data consistency between modules, resulting in difficulties in providing a comprehensive overview of the patient record, possibly due to the piecemeal implementation of modules with different functions. While it is possible to access data from some primary care systems, we found that the two-way data transfer between hospitals and primary care services was inadequate and required workarounds, giving opportunity for new errors associated with repetitive and manual transfer of information. While some advanced multimodular systems have begun to implement this functionality, it was still a request at most sites to expand e-prescribing to include modules with other clinically important information needed to support care. However, very modular systems proved difficult to interface with external systems. Conclusions The decision to purchase stand-alone systems and then interface with them, or to pursue a hospital-wide multi-modular system purchase strategy, is a crucial decision in realizing the vision of achieving a fully integrated digital record for hospitals and should be based on the clear relative trade-offs between these choices. somehow appreciated. Multi-module systems offered slightly better usability, while stand-alone systems provided greater flexibility and innovation opportunities, particularly regarding interoperability with external systems and customizability to the needs of different user groups.

title: The salivary cortisol response after a medical interview: effect of doctor communication behavior, depressive affect and alexithymia.
abstract: OBJECTIVE: To investigate whether and possibly how a medical consultation affects adrenocortical activity in patients with musculoskeletal pain with and without alexithymia. METHODS: Female patients (N = 54) recruited from a patient organization for fibromyalgia completed the Toronto Alexithymia Scale (TAS-20), and subgroups with low and high scores, respectively, were selected for inclusion. Seven doctors conducted consultations trying to change their communication according to the given guidelines. All consultations were videotaped and analyzed by the Roter Interaction Analysis System (RIAS) to assess the actual content of the consultations. CONCLUSIONS: An increase in depressive affect from pre-interview to post-interview was associated with relatively high cortisol levels 24 hours after consultation, but only in alexithymia patients. Psychosocial questions from the doctor were associated with increased depressive affect immediately after the interview, but not with cortisol responses at any time. CONCLUSION: In patients with deficient affect regulation, the increase in depressive affect after a medical interview may possibly be related to delayed effects on adrenocortical activity mediated by rumination. PRACTICE PRACTICES: Providers should be sensitive to possible affect regulation deficits in their patients.

title: Salt, hypertension and cardiovascular risk
abstract: For more than a century, salt and blood pressure have been linked. Prospective randomized clinical trials and meta-analyses have provided evidence that reducing salt intake by 100 mmol daily can reduce systolic blood pressure by 3-5 mm Hg, while diastolic blood pressure can be reduced by 1 mm Hg. The effect of salt restriction is highly dependent on individual salt sensitivity. Whether reducing salt intake will ultimately result in a reduction in cardiovascular morbidity and mortality will be determined in future studies.

title: Scanning for pleasure or digging for horror? Comparison of findings from a postal survey with findings from a focus group study
abstract: BACKGROUND: Despite increasing support for mixed-method approaches, we still have little systematic information on the results of combining surveys and focus groups. While the methodological aspects of survey questionnaires have been extensively researched, the features of focus group methodology have not been adequately studied. We suggest and discuss whether the focus group setting encourages participants to negatively exaggerate views compared to survey questionnaires. DISCUSSION: Based on a sample from our own research, in which we conducted a survey as a follow-up to a focus group study, and with reference to theoretical approaches and empirical evidence from the literature on survey respondents' behavior and small-group dynamics, the possibility that a discrepancy in findings between focus groups and survey reflects characteristics of two different research methods . Contrary to the survey, the focus group study showed that physicians generally viewed clinical guidelines negatively. We were not convinced that this difference in results was due to methodological flaws in any of the studies and instead we discussed how this difference could be the result of a general methodological phenomenon. SUMMARY: Based on studies of how survey questionnaires affect responses, it seems reasonable to argue that surveys are more likely to find exaggerated positive opinions. Conversely, there are some indications in the literature that focus groups can lead to complaints and overly negative attitudes, but this is still an open question. We suggest that these topics can be exaggerated in focus groups, although problematic issues tend to be under-reported in survey questionnaires. For example, we discuss the importance of increasing our understanding of focus group methodology by reporting interesting inconsistencies in mixed methods research. Additionally, more empirical research should be conducted on focus groups to improve the methodology and test our hypothesis.

title: School-Based Mental Health Intervention for Children Affected by Political Violence in Indonesia
abstract: Context Little is known about the effectiveness of mental health interventions for children exposed to armed conflict in low- and middle-income settings. Childhood mental health problems are difficult to address in situations of ongoing poverty and political instability. Purpose To evaluate the effectiveness of a school-based intervention designed for children exposed to conflict, delivered in a low-income setting. Design, Environment, and Participants A cluster randomized study involving 495 children (81.4% inclusion rate) with a mean (SD) age of 9.9 (1.3) attending randomly selected schools in communities affected by political violence in Poso, Indonesia. and were screened for symptoms of exposure (=1 event), post-traumatic stress disorder, and anxiety compared to a waiting-listed control group. Unblinded assessment was performed before, 1 week, and 6 months after treatment between March and December 2006. Intervention Over 5 weeks, fifteen sessions of a manual, school-based group intervention that included trauma processing activities, collaborative play, and creativity - expressive elements administered by locally trained associate professionals. We assessed psychiatric symptoms using the Main Outcome Measures Child Post-Traumatic Stress Scale, Depression Self-Assessment Scale, Self-Report for Anxiety-Related Disorders 5-item version, and Children's Hope Scale, and assessed dysfunction as treatment outcomes using standard symptom checklists. and locally developed rating scales. Results When adjusting for clustering of participants in schools, PTSD symptoms (mean change difference, 2.78"; 95% confidence interval [CI], 1.02 to 4.53) and sustained hope (mean change difference, -2.21; 95% CI, - Changes in traumatic statements (stress-related physical symptoms) (mean change difference, 0.50; 95% CI, -0.12 to 1.11) in the treatment group compared to the waiting list group, depressive symptoms (mean change difference, 0.70; 95% CI, -0.08 to 1.49), anxiety (mean change difference, 0.12; 95% CI, -0.31 to 0.56), and functionality (mean change difference, 0.52; "95% CI, -0.43 to 1.46) was not different between treatment and waiting list groups. Conclusions In this study of children in violence-affected communities, a school-based intervention reduced symptoms of post-traumatic stress and helped maintain hope, but did not reduce traumatic stress-related symptoms, depressive symptoms, anxiety symptoms, or functional impairment.

title: Screening and brief intervention for obesity in primary care: a parallel, two-arm, randomized trial.
abstract: OBJECTIVE: Obesity is a common cause of non-communicable diseases. Guidelines recommend that physicians screen and provide brief recommendations to motivate weight loss by referring to behavioral weight loss programs. But doctors rarely intervene, and no trials have been made on the subject. We conducted this trial to determine whether brief physician intervention is acceptable and effective for reducing body weight in obese patients. METHODS: In this parallel, two-arm, randomized study, patients presenting to 137 primary care physicians in England were screened for obesity. Individuals can be registered if they are at least 18 years old, have a body mass index of at least 30 kg/m2 (or at least 25 kg/m2 if of Asian ethnicity) and have a high body fat percentage. At the end of the consultation, the physician randomly assigned the participants (1:1) to one of the two 30 s interventions. Randomization was done via pre-made randomization cards placed in opaque sealed envelopes and labeled with a code representing the assignment, given to physicians to open at the time of treatment assignment. In active intervention, the doctor offered a referral to a weight management group (12 sessions of 1 hour once a week) and, if the referral was accepted, the doctor made the patient make an appointment and offered follow-up. In the control intervention, the physician advised the patient that losing weight would benefit his health. The primary outcome was weight change at 12 months in the intent-to-treat population evaluated blinded to treatment allocation. We also assessed the feelings of patients who were asked about discussing their weight when they visited their GP for other reasons. Given the nature of the intervention, we did not anticipate any adverse events in the usual sense, so the safety implications were not evaluated. This trial is registered in the ISRCTN Registry with number ISRCTN26563137. RESULTS: We screened 8,403 patients, 2728 (32%) of whom were obese, between June 4, 2013 and December 23, 2014. Of these obese patients, 2256 (83%) agreed to participate, and 1882 were eligible, enrolled, and included in the intent-to-treat analysis, with 940 in the support group and 942 in the advice group. 722 (77%) people assigned to the support intervention agreed to participate in the weight management group, and 379 (40%) of these people did, versus 82 (9%) who were assigned a referral intervention. In the entire study population, the mean weight change at 12 months was 2.43 kg with the support intervention and 1.04 kg with the advice intervention, with an adjusted difference of 1.43 kg (95% CI 0.89-1.97). Patients' responses to GPs' brief interventions were appropriate (adjusted odds ratio 0.89, 95% CI 0.75-1.07, p=0.21) or helpfulness (1.05, 0.89-1.26, p=0.54)";" overall, four (<1%) patients considered their intervention inappropriate and unhelpful, while 1530 (81%) patients considered it appropriate and beneficial. COMMENT: A behaviorally-informed, very brief, opportunistic physician-provided intervention is acceptable to patients and is an effective means of reducing the average weight of the population. FUNDING: UK National Prevention Research Initiative.

title: Screening and Intervention for Comorbid Substance Disorders, PTSD, Depression, and Suicide: A Trauma Center Questionnaire
abstract: OBJECTIVE: Few studies have examined screening and intervention procedures for comorbid substance use and mental disorders in trauma centers in the United States, but these disorders are endemic among traumatic injury survivors. In 2006, the American College of Surgeons (ACS) mandated that level I and level II trauma centers screen for alcohol use problems and that these level I centers provide brief intervention for those who screen positive. The ACS is expected to recommend best practice policy guidelines for screening for drug use problems and post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD). This study examined screening and intervention procedures for the full spectrum of comorbid mental and substance use disorders in US trauma centers. METHODS: Participants at all level I and level II trauma centers (N=518) in the United States were asked to complete a questionnaire describing screening and intervention procedures for alcohol and drug use problems, suicidality, depression, and PTSD. RESULTS: There were 391 (75%) participants. More than 80% of trauma centers are routinely screened for alcohol and drug use problems. Routine screening and intervention for suicide, depression, and PTSD were significantly less common";" in fact, only 7% of centers reported routine screening for PTSD. Consistent with ACS policy, level I centers were significantly more likely to provide alcohol intervention than level II centers. RESULTS: Alcohol screening and intervention occurred frequently in US trauma centers and appeared to respond to ACS instructions. In the future, efforts to improve clinical research and policy may improve screening and intervention procedures for the highly prevalent comorbid mental disorders.

title: Screening and interventions for overweight in children and adolescents: statement of recommendation
abstract: The US Preventive Services Task Force (USPSTF) is an independent panel of non-federal experts in prevention and primary care that systematically reviews evidence of efficacy and develops recommendations for clinical preventive services. This recommendation addresses the evidence for the accuracy of screening children and adolescents using BMI, the effectiveness of behavioral and pharmacological interventions in improving health outcomes in these children, and the potential harms of routine screening and intervention. Using the USPSTF methodology, an analytical framework with key questions was developed to guide the systematic review that underpins this recommendation. The number of overweight children and adolescents has more than doubled in the past 25 years. Excess weight during childhood and adolescence is associated with increased health risks. The USPSTF found insufficient evidence for the effectiveness of behavioral counseling or other preventive interventions with overweight children and adolescents that could be applied in primary care settings. Currently available studies are limited by factors such as small sample sizes, poor generalizability, and variable follow-up. Based on this critical gap in the evidence for efficacy, the USPSTF concluded that the evidence was insufficient to recommend for or against routine screening for overweight in children and adolescents as a means of preventing adverse health outcomes (the "I" recommendation). There are several gaps in research evidence regarding screening and interventions for overweight children and adolescents in the primary care setting. Research is needed to provide well-defined and effective approaches to medical and psychological screening in children, as well as effective clinical approaches that can be implemented by primary care clinicians for the prevention and treatment of childhood overweight.

title: Screening and Treatment of Suicide Risk Related to Primary Care: A Systematic Review for the US Preventive Services Task Force
abstract: Background: In 2009, suicide was responsible for 36897 deaths in the United States. Objective: To review the accuracy of screening tools and the efficacy and safety of screening and treatment of suicide risk in primary care populations and settings. Data Sources: MEDLINE, PsycINFO, Cochrane Central Register of Controlled Trials, and CINAHL (2002 - 17 July 2012) excerpts from MEDLINE's surveillance survey (July-December 2012) for gray literature and additional screening trials (July-December 2012). Study Selection: Primary care Fair or good quality English studies evaluating the accuracy of screening tools in or similar populations and trials of suicide prevention interventions in primary care or mental health care settings Data Extraction: One investigator summarized data and another controlled data abstraction. Two researchers rated study quality. Data Synthesis : Insufficient evidence to determine benefits of screening in primary care populations; very limited evidence found no serious harm it took. Minimal evidence, limited to high-risk populations, showed poor performance of screening tools in adolescents. Trial evidence showed that psychotherapy reduced suicide attempts in high-risk adults, but not in adolescents. Most trials were not powerful enough to detect effects on deaths. Limitation: Treatment evidence is from high-risk groups rather than screening-detected populations. Evidence for adolescents, older adults, and racial or ethnic minorities was limited. Conclusion: Primary care. Applicable screening tools may help identify some adults who are at high risk of suicide but have limited ability to detect suicide risk in adolescents. Psychotherapy may reduce suicide attempts in some high-risk adults, but effective interventions for high-risk adolescents have yet to be proven. Primary Source of Funding: Agency for Health Research and Quality.

title: Colorectal cancer screening with sigmoidoscopy only once: a feasibility study in Turin
abstract: Objectives – To evaluate the acceptability and efficacy of two bowel preparation regimens for endoscopic screening in the general population, as well as the impact of three invitation methods on compliance. Methods – 1170 subjects (men and women aged 55 to 59 years on the lists of a general practitioner (GP) sample in Turin) were randomly assigned to one of three invitation groups (A: personal letter signed by GP, with a predetermined appointment" ; B: same letter A+ supporting study by a recognized scientist; C: letter signed by study coordinator, NS) and two preparation regimens (i: an enema, two hours before home self-test, ii: pre-test Two enemas administered the night before and two hours before) A postal reminder was given to non-participants One sample of nonresponders contacted for a telephone interview by a trained nurse Written consent was obtained from all subjects tested Results – a total of 278 subjects attended for sigmoidoscope screening. only an invitation from the GP drove the high response rate (concord: A = 29.3%; B = 24.9%;" C = 26.8%). A single enema was as effective as two in obtaining satisfactory preparation for the test: the proportion of subjects invited to repeat the test was 8.1% in the single enema group and 9.6% in the group that received two enemas. Results – Compliance with this screening procedure tends to be low. A self-administered enema two hours before a sigmoidoscopy can provide satisfactory bowel preparation.

title: Colorectal cancer screening in the foreground
abstract: OBJECTIVE: The aim of this study is to evaluate primary care clinicians' knowledge, beliefs and practices regarding colorectal cancer screening. METHODS: We surveyed 77 primary care providers at six clinics in central Massachusetts to assess various factors associated with colorectal cancer screening. RESULTS: Most agreed with the guidelines for stool occult blood testing (97%) and sigmoidoscopy (87%) reported as usual practice. Although the majority (86%) recommend colonoscopy as a colorectal cancer screening test, it has rarely been reported as routine practice. In addition, 36% considered barium enema as a colorectal cancer screening option and was rarely reported as usual practice. Digital rectal exams and in-office stool occult blood testing have been widely reported as usual practice, although there is no evidence to support efficacy. However, these were often reported with a guideline-approved testing option. Although only 10% reported frequent refusal of stool occult blood test/home, 60% reported that sigmoidoscopy was performed. Frequently cited patient barriers to sigmoidoscopy compliance included fear that the procedure would cause harm, and patients' assuming that symptoms would occur if there was a problem. Health systems' perception of barriers to sigmoidoscopy was less strong. RESULTS: Most providers recommended guideline-approved colorectal cancer screening. However, patient rejection for sigmoidoscopy was common. The results suggest that multiple levels of intervention, including patient and provider education and systems strategies, can help increase prevalence.

title: Dementia Screening in Primary Care: Summary of Evidence for the US Preventive Services Task Force
abstract: BACKGROUND: Dementia is a large and growing problem but is often not diagnosed in its early stages. Screening and early treatment can reduce the pain burden of this syndrome. OBJECTIVE: To review the evidence on the benefits and harms of screening for the early treatment of dementia. DATA SOURCES: MEDLINE, PsycINFO, EMBASE, Cochrane Library, experts and bibliographies Number of reviews. STUDY SELECTION: The authors developed eight key questions representing the logical chain between screening and improved health outcomes, with eligibility criteria for acceptable evidence for each question. Acceptable evidence was obtained by searching the data sources. DATA DRAWING: Two reviewers summarized relevant information using standardized abstraction forms and graded article quality according to US Preventive Services Task Force criteria. DATA SYNTHESIS: No randomized, controlled screening studies for dementia have been completed. . Short screening tools can detect some people with early dementia (positive predictive value < or = 50%). Six to 12 months of treatment with cholinesterase inhibitors moderately slows the decline of cognitive and general clinical change scores in some patients with mild to moderate Alzheimer's disease. Function is minimally affected and less than 20% of patients stop taking cholinesterase inhibitors because of side effects. Only limited evidence suggests that any other pharmacological or non-pharmacological intervention slows decline in people with early dementia. Although intensive multi-component caregiver interventions may delay hospice placement of caregiver patients, the significance of this finding for those who do not yet have caregivers is unclear. Other potential benefits and harms of screening have not been explored. CONCLUSIONS: Screening tests can detect undiagnosed dementia. In people with mild to moderate clinically detected Alzheimer's disease, cholinesterase inhibitors are somewhat effective at slowing cognitive decline. The effect of cholinesterase inhibitors or other treatments on people with dementia detected by screening is unclear.

title: Screening for Depression in Adult Patients in Primary Care Settings: A Systematic Evidence Review
abstract: Background: In primary care settings, prevalence estimates of major depressive disorder range from 5% to 13% in all adults, with lower estimates (6% to 9%) in those older than 55 years. In 2002, the US Preventive Services Task Force (USPSTF) recommended screening adults for depression in clinical practice with systems that ensure accurate diagnosis, effective treatment, and follow-up. Objective: To provide a targeted, updated systematic review for the US Preventive Services Task Force on the benefits and harms of screening adult patients for depression in primary care, the benefits of depression treatment in older adults, and the harms of depression treatment in older adults. antidepressant drugs. Data Sources: MEDLINE, Cochrane Central Registry of Controlled Trials, Cochrane Database of Systematic Reviews, Database of Abstracts of Impact Studies, PsycINFO (1998 to 2007), expert recommendations, and bibliographies of recent systematic reviews. Study Selection: Moderate to good quality randomized clinical trials or controlled clinical trials"; systematic reviews; meta-analyses;" and large observational studies of serious adverse events and premature discontinuation of treatment due to adverse events. All studies are published in English. Data Extraction: Two researchers summarized, critically evaluated, and synthesized 33 articles that met the inclusion criteria. Data Synthesis: Nine studies of fair or good quality indicate that staff-supported primary care depression screening and care management programs, such as case management or the involvement of mental health professionals, can improve depression response and remission. There was no benefit in screening programs without staff assistance in depression care. Seven regulatory reviews or meta-analyses and 3 large cohort studies show no increased risk for suicide deaths completed with antidepressant therapy. There was an increased risk of suicidal behavior in young adults (18-29 years) who took the antidepressant, particularly paroxetine, but decreased in older adults. Limitation: The study of harms was limited to serious adverse events and primarily available systematic reviews were used. Additional studies published from 2007 to 2008 expand this review. Conclusion: Depression screening programs are unlikely to improve depression outcomes without significant staff-supported depression care support. Close monitoring of all adult patients starting antidepressant therapy, particularly those under 30 years of age, is important to ensure both safety and optimal therapy.

title: Hypertension Screening
abstract: Objective: To review the evidence on four questions for screening asymptomatic adults for arterial hypertension: Is hypertension a major health concern? Can it be detected at an early, presymptomatic stage? Is treatment available and effective? Do the benefits of screening outweigh the costs and risks? Data Description and Selection: We conducted a computational search on the MEDLARS database to identify population-based drug therapy trials for mild hypertension";" Other relevant citations are included where appropriate. Data Synthesis: We approached the first questions in our analysis with narrative analysis and argument. Estimates of therapeutic efficacy are based on previously published meta-analyses. The cost-effectiveness of screening was addressed by formal mathematical modeling of the impact of screening on various US populations. Analysis Results: Hypertension is clearly an important health problem. It can be diagnosed early and has effective treatment. Screening asymptomatic adults for hypertension is more advantageous compared to the associated risks and costs. In our estimations, screening is most cost-effective for older adults and men compared to women, and is highly sensitive to the cost of treating mild hypertension. Conclusions: We recommend screening for hypertension for all adults. We also discuss the frequency and pattern of browsing activities. When a low-cost therapy is used, the cost-effectiveness of hypertension screening compares favorably with other cardiovascular interventions.

title: Screening for postpartum depression in primary care: cost-effectiveness analysis
abstract: OBJECTIVE To evaluate the cost-effectiveness of routine screening for postpartum depression in primary care. DESIGN Cost-effectiveness analysis with a decision model of alternative screening methods for depression, including standardized postpartum depression and general depression tools. The performance of scanning tools was derived from a systematic review and bivariate meta-analysis at a range of tool cutoffs";" Estimates of other relevant parameters are derived from literature sources and relevant databases. A decision tree considered the full course of treatment from possible onset of postpartum depression through identification, treatment, and possible relapse. SETUP Primary care. PARTICIPANTS A hypothetical population of women evaluated for postpartum depression either through routine care alone or supplemented using formal identification methods six weeks after birth, as recommended in recent guidelines. MAIN OUTCOME MEASURES Costs expressed in 2006-7 prices and impact on health outcomes expressed in quality-adjusted life years (QALYs). The time horizon of the analysis was one year. CONCLUSIONS Routine administration of postpartum or general depression questionnaires did not appear to be cost-effective compared to routine care alone. The Edinburgh scale of postpartum depression (at 16 cut-off points) had an increased cost-effectiveness rate (ICER) of 41,103 pounds (45,398 euros, $67,130) per QALY compared with routine care alone. For all other strategies, ICER ranged from £49,928 to £272,463 per QALY compared to routine care alone, while the probability that no formal identification strategy would be cost-effective was 88% (59%) at the £20,000 (£30,000) cost-effectiveness threshold. per QALY. Sensitivity analysis showed that the cost of managing misidentified depression (false positive result) was a major driver of the model, while formal identification approaches did not appear to be cost-effective in any appropriate estimate of this cost.
