CONCLUSIONS Official methods of definition for postpartum depression do not appear to represent value for money for the NHS. The main determinant of cost effectiveness appears to be the potential additional costs of managing women who are incorrectly diagnosed as depressed. Official identification methods for postpartum depression do not currently meet the National Screening Committee's criteria for adopting a screening strategy as part of national health policy.

title: Screening for speech and language delay in preschool children: systematic evidence review for the US Preventive Services Task Force.
abstract: BACKGROUND: PEDIATRIC (ISSN Numbers: Edition, 0031-4005";" Online, 1098-4275). Published in the public domain by the American Academy of Pediatrics. Speech and language development is a useful indicator of a child's overall development and cognitive ability and is associated with school success. Identifying children at risk for developmental delay or related problems can lead to intervention services and family assistance at a young age where the chances of recovery are best. However, optimal methods for speech and language delay screening have not been determined, and screening has been inconsistently applied in primary care. OBJECTIVE: We sought to assess the strengths and limitations of the evidence for the effectiveness of screening and interventions for speech and language delay in preschool children to determine the balance between the benefits and adverse effects of routine primary care screening for the development of guidelines. US Preventive Services Task Force. The target population includes all children up to 5 years of age without known pre-existing conditions associated with speech and language delay, such as hearing and neurological disorders. METHODS: Studies were selected from the Medline, PsycINFO, and CINAHL databases (1966 - 19 November 2004), systematic reviews, reference lists, and experts. The evidence review included only articles published in English and accessible through libraries. Only randomized, controlled studies were considered to examine the efficacy of interventions. As long as the initial assessment occurred at any time or age after screening and/or intervention, as long as the child had 1 population =2 screening techniques, outcome measures were considered and comparisons of a single screening technique across different populations were made. missing. Fourteen randomized, controlled intervention trials of good and fair quality reported significantly improved speech and language outcomes compared with control groups. Improvement in several areas, including articulation, phonology, expressive language, receptive language, lexical acquisition, and syntax, was demonstrated among children of all age groups studied and in multiple therapeutic settings. Improvements in other functional outcomes, such as socialization skills, self-esteem, and enhanced play themes, were demonstrated in some, but not all, of the 4 studies that measured them. Overall, intervention studies were small and heterogeneous, may be subject to plateau effects, and reported short-term outcomes based on a variety of tools and measures. As a result, long-term outcomes are unknown, interventions cannot be directly compared, and their generalizability is questionable. CONCLUSIONS: The use of risk factors to guide selective screening is not supported by studies. Various aspects of screening have been poorly studied to determine optimal methods, including which instrument to use, what age to scan, and what interval is most useful. Intervention trials show improvement in some outcome measures, but results and generalizability are limited. Data are lacking to address other important issues, including the effectiveness of screening in primary care settings, the role of surveillance developed by primary care physicians prior to referral for diagnostic evaluation, the speech and nonlinguistic and long-term benefits of interventions, and the adverse effects of screening. and interventions.

title: Screening Surgeons for HIV Infection: Cost Effectiveness Analysis
abstract: AIM. To determine the cost-effectiveness of a policy to screen surgeons for human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) infection to prevent HIV transmission to patients with invasive procedures. DESIGN: Cost effectiveness analysis. RESULTS: A one-time national screening program will identify approximately 137 surgeons (range, 28 to 423 surgeons) with HIV infection and approximately 4.3 infections (range, 1.9 to 21.3 infections) and 0.9 infections in patients treated by infected surgeons. (range, 0 to 12.9 infections) with a direct cost of $8.1 million and an induced cost of about $44 million in sexual partners of infected surgeons. This results in an annual expenditure of $458,000 per life saved (range of $147,000 to $687,000 per life saved), while an annual screening program will result in expenditure of approximately $1.1 million per life saved (range, $338,000 to $1,886,000 per person). . years of life saved). If the prevalence of HIV infection in surgeons is estimated at three times our baseline estimate (an increase from 0.1% to 0.3%), annual screening would result in expenditures of approximately $741,000 per life saved. If the probability of seroconversion after a patient's exposure to a contaminated device is increased from our baseline estimate of 0.29% to 5.0%, an annual screening program would still cost more than $228,000 per life saved. CONCLUSION: To prevent HIV transmission to patients undergoing invasive procedures, surgeons' HIV screening requires expenditures per year of life saved, significantly higher than most accepted healthcare interventions. Surveillance studies of patients treated by HIV-infected surgeons should be continued to confirm that transmission of HIV to patients undergoing invasive procedures is rare.

title: Screening, isolation and decolonization strategies for the control of methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus in intensive care units: cost-effectiveness evaluation
abstract: OBJECTIVE To evaluate the cost-effectiveness of screening, isolation and decolonization strategies in the control of methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA) in intensive care units. DESIGN Economic evaluation based on a dynamic transmission model. SET England and Wales. Population The patient population in the theoretical intensive care unit. MAIN OUTCOME MEASURES Infections, deaths, costs, quality-adjusted life years (QALYs), increased cost-effectiveness rates and net monetary benefits for alternative strategies. RESULTS All decolonization strategies have improved health outcomes and reduced costs. Although universal decolonization (regardless of MRSA status) is the most cost-effective method in the short term, strategies using screening may be preferable to target MRSA carriers because of the reduced risk of selecting resistance. Among such targeted strategies, universal acceptance and weekly screening with polymerase chain reaction combined with decolonization using nasal mupirocin was the most cost-effective. This finding was robust in terms of the size of intensive care units, the prevalence of MRSA at admission, the proportion of patients classified as high-risk, and the absolute value of willingness to pay for health benefits. All strategies that used isolation but not decolonization improved health outcomes, but increased costs. When the prevalence of MRSA on admission to the ICU is 5% and the willingness to pay per QALY gained is between approximately £20,000 (â€šâ€23,000";"$32,000) to £30,000, such the best strategy is to isolate only patients at high risk of carrying MRSA. (after prior or admission identification and weekly screening for MRSA using chromogenic agar). Weekly screening using polymerase chain reaction-based MRSA detection with general admission and isolation was unlikely to be cost-effective unless the prevalence was high (10% of patients colonized with MRSA at presentation). CONCLUSIONS MRSA control strategies using decolonization are likely to provide cost savings in the ICU setting provided that resistance is absent, and if untargeted decolonization is considered unacceptable, combining universal screening with decolonization using polymerase chain reaction is likely to represent good value for money. There is insufficient evidence to support universal screening for MRSA in non-decolonization intensive care units, except in high-prevalence settings.

title: Secondary prevention after minor stroke and TIA - usual care and development of a support program
abstract: BACKGROUND: Effective methods of secondary prevention after stroke or TIA exist, but adherence to recommended evidence-based treatments is generally weak. The study aimed to determine the quality of secondary prevention in usual care and to develop a step-by-step modeled support program. METHODS: Two consecutive groups of patients with acute minor stroke or TIA on usual outpatient treatment were compared with a secondary prevention program. Risk factor control and drug compliance were evaluated at 6-month follow-up (6A-FU). Usual care consisted of detailed information on vascular risk factor targets given by primary care physicians at discharge and regular outpatient care. Four additional outpatient appointments were used in the incremental modeled support program. A combination of educational and behavioral strategies was used. RESULTS: In the observational cohort who indicated that they were open to participate in a prevention program, 168 patients (mean age 64.7 years, blood pressure at admission (BP): 155/84 mmHg) and 173 patients (mean age 67.6 years, BP: 161/84) participated in a support program mmHg) was evaluated at 6 months. According to the guidelines, the proportion of patients with BP was 50% in the usual care and 77% in the support program (p<0.01). LDL<100 mg/dl was measured at 71% vs. 62% (p = 0.12). The proportion of patients who quit smoking was 79% versus 50% (p<0.01). 89% versus 72% of patients with atrial fibrillation were using oral anticoagulation (p = 0.09). CONCLUSIONS: Risk factor control is inadequate in usual care. Secondary prevention targets were met more frequently in the supported cohort. Effects on (cerebro-)vascular recurrence rates will be evaluated in a multicenter randomized trial.

title: Selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs) and routine specialist care in adolescents with major depression with and without cognitive behavioral therapy: randomized controlled trial.
abstract: OBJECTIVE To determine whether the combination of a selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor (SSRIs) and cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT) combined with clinical care is more effective in the short term than an SSRI alone and clinical care in adolescents with moderate to severe major depression. DESIGN Pragmatic randomized controlled superiority trial. SETTING 6 outpatient clinics in Manchester and Cambridge. PARTICIPANTS 208 adolescents 11-17 years of age with moderate to severe major or probable major depression who did not respond to a brief first intervention. Adolescents with suicidal tendencies, depressive psychosis, or behavioral disorders were included. INTERVENTIONS 103 adolescents received SSRIs and routine care";" 105 received an SSRI, routine care, and CBT. The trial lasted for 12 weeks, followed by a 16-week maintenance phase. MAIN OUTCOME MEASURES Change in score (primary outcome) on National Health outcome scales for children and adolescents from baseline with 12 weeks as primary and 28 weeks as follow-up endpoint. Secondary measures were change in scores on the mood and emotions questionnaire, the revised children's depression rating scale, the children's overall rating scale, and the clinical global impression improvement scale. RESULTS Treatment effect for primary outcome at 12 weeks was -0.64 (95% confidence interval -2.54 to 1.26, P=0.50). In a longitudinal analysis, there were no differences in treatment efficacy for either the primary (mean treatment effect 0.001, -1.52 to 1.52, P=0.99) or secondary outcome measures. On average, there was a reduction in suicidal thoughts and self-harm. There was no evidence that cognitive behavioral therapy had a protective effect on suicidal ideation or action. By 28 weeks, 57% had improved a lot or very much and 20% had not. CONCLUSIONS For adolescents with moderate to severe major depression, there is no evidence that the combination of CBT plus an SSRI in the presence of routine clinical care contributes to a better outcome for 28 weeks compared to providing routine clinical care and an SSRI alone. TRIAL REGISTRATION Controlled Trials Available ISRCNT 83809224.

title: Selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors in childhood depression: a systematic review of published and unpublished data.
abstract: Background questions regarding the safety of selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs) in the treatment of depression in children prompted us to compare and contrast published and unpublished data on the risks and benefits of these drugs.";" Background questions regarding the safety of selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs) in the treatment of depression in children led us to compare and contrast published and unpublished data on the risks and benefits of these drugs.

title: Self-formulated contingent plans to change health behavior among healthcare consumers and healthcare professionals.
abstract: This is a protocol for the Cochrane Review (Intervention). The objectives are as follows: Our primary objective is to evaluate the effects of self-formulated contingent plans to change the health-related behavior of healthcare consumers and healthcare professionals. Our secondary goal is to explore whether the effects of self-formulated contingent plans are altered by (i) the form of the plan (eg, does the individual participate in its development as planned?) and (iii) the complexity of the intended behavior (eg, number of actions required; "regularity of behavior)". .

title: Self-help books for depression: How can practitioners and patients make the right choice?
abstract: BACKGROUND: Depression is a common and important public health problem that is often treated by general practitioners. The self-help approach is popular with patients, but little is known about its effectiveness. OBJECTIVE: Our primary goal was to review and update the evidence for the clinical efficacy of bibliotherapy in the treatment of depression. Our secondary aim was to determine which of these self-help materials are generally available for purchase and to examine the evidence specific to these publications. METHOD: Medline, CINAHL, EMBASE, PsycINFO, CCTR, PsiTri, and the National Research Registry were searched for randomized trials that evaluated self-help books for depression and included participants aged 16+ with a diagnosis or symptoms of depression. Clinical symptoms, quality of life, costs, or acceptability for users were required outcome measures. Papers were obtained and data extracted independently by two researchers. A meta-analysis using a random effects model was performed using the mean score and standard deviation of the Hamilton Depression Rating Scale at the endpoint of the trial. RESULTS: Eleven randomized controlled trials were identified. None met CONSORT guidelines and all were small, with the largest trial having 40 patients per group. Nine of these reviewed two recent publications, Anxiety and Depression Management (UK) and Feeling Good (US). A meta-analysis of 6 studies evaluating Feeling Good found a large treatment effect compared to delayed treatment (standardized mean difference = -1.36"; 95% confidence interval [CI] = -1.76 to -0.96). In addition to the two books evaluated in the trials, five self-help books were determined to be available and widely purchased by the public. CONCLUSION: There are many self-help books available for the treatment of depression. For the majority, there is little direct evidence for their effectiveness. There is weak evidence to suggest that bibliotherapy based on the cognitive behavioral therapy approach is helpful for some people when given some additional guidance. More studies are needed in primary care to explore the cost-effectiveness of self-help and the optimal format and presentation of materials.

title: Self-management programs for COPD: moving forward
abstract: Self-management is becoming increasingly important in the management of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD). However, there is confusion about what processes are involved, how the value of self-management should be determined, and research priorities. To gain more insight and agreement on the content, outcomes and future aspects of COPD self-management of the programmes, a group of interested researchers and physicians, all of whom have previously published on the topic and collaborated on other projects, organized a workshop. This article summarizes their initial findings. Self-management programs aim at structural behavior change to maintain treatment effects after the programs are complete. Programs should include techniques for behavior change, be personalized, take the patient's point of view into account, and vary according to the course of the patient's disease and co-morbidities. Evaluation should include process variables. This report is a step towards greater alignment in the field of self-management. To increase clarity on effectiveness, future studies should clearly define interventions, be appropriately designed and strengthened, and include results that focus more on the acquisition and application of new skills. In this way, more evidence and a better understanding of self-management programs will be obtained and the formulation of more specific guidelines on self-management will be possible.

title: Personal protective equipment use among Chinese intensive care clinicians during the 2009 H1N1 influenza pandemic
abstract: BACKGROUND: Critically ill patients with 2009 H1N1 influenza are frequently treated in intensive care units (ICUs), which poses a significant risk of hospital-acquired transmission to critical care clinicians and other patients. Despite the large body of literature and guidelines recommending infection control practices, numerous barriers to the use of personal protective equipment (PPE) in intensive care units have been identified that lead to inadequate compliance. The use of PPE among critical care clinicians has not been extensively evaluated, particularly during pandemic influenza. This study examined knowledge, attitudes and self-reported behaviors among ICU healthcare workers (HCWs) during pandemic flu and barriers to compliance with PPE use. METHODOLOGY/KEY FINDINGS: A questionnaire consisting of 36 questions was developed and mailed to all healthcare workers in 21 intensive care units in 17 provinces in China. A total of 733 doctors, nurses and other professionals were surveyed and 650 (88.7%) were included in the analysis. Fifty-six percent of the respondents reported that they had received a pandemic influenza education program before caring for H1N1 patients, while 77% reported that they had sufficient knowledge about protecting themselves and the patient. Only 18% of respondents were able to correctly identify all components of PPE, and 55% reported high compliance (>80%) with the use of PPE during patient care. In multivariate analysis, organizational factors such as 2009 H1N1 influenza vaccine, positive attitudes towards the use of PPE, availability of PPE in the ICU and patient knowledge of influenza precautions, as well as condemnation by supervisors for non-compliance were associated with high compliance, while negative attitudes towards PPE use and Violation of PPE use were independent predictors of low adherence. CONCLUSION/IMPORTANCE: Knowledge and self-reported agreement on recommended PPE use among Chinese critical care clinicians is insufficient. Perceived barriers must be addressed to bridge the important gap between perception and knowledge or behavior.

title: Self-reported and real test order behavior among primary care clinicians
abstract: To determine the accuracy of clinicians' self-reports, 38 clinicians in a university-based health care organization (HMO) practice were surveyed about thyroid function testing (TFT) models one year after the deployment of an educational intervention. The absolute difference between self-reported and actual test order rates averaged 12%";" the difference was greater than 20% in only 3 of 33 clinicians who ordered TFT for at least five patients during the study period. A strong correlation was found between the self-reported change and the true mean change in TFT order rates post-intervention (p less than 0.0001). The results show that clinicians can accurately predict usage patterns and the impact of practice guidelines, at least in certain settings.

title: Violations reported during drug administration in two children's hospitals
abstract: Content Violations of security protocols are pathways to adverse consequences that are inadequately addressed by current security efforts. This study reports self-reported violations during the medication administration process of nurses. Purpose To evaluate the extent of violations in the drug administration process among nurses. Design, setting, and participants Participants were 199 nurses from two US urban, academic, tertiary, independent pediatric hospitals working in a pediatric intensive care unit (PICU), hematology-oncology-transplant (HOT) unit, or a medical unit. surgical (Med/Surg) unit. In a cross-sectional survey, nurses were asked about routine or emergency violations in three steps of the medication administration process. Main outcome measure Self-reported violations of the three drug administration protocols were made using a seven-point 0-6 scale from "not at all" to "too much." Results Analysis of variance determined that violation reports were highest for emergencies rather than routine operations, with the highest number of HOT unit nurses, followed by PICU nurses, followed by Med/Surgical unit nurses, and the highest during patient identification followed by matching a drug. documenting an application followed by a drug administration record. There was also a significant three-way interaction between the violation situation, the step in the process, and the unit. Consequences Protocol violations occur throughout the drug administration process and their prevalence varies by hospital unit, step in the process, and violation status. More research is needed to determine whether these breaches improve or worsen security, and for those who worsen security, how to redesign the management system to reduce the need to breach protocol to perform job duties.

title: Self-study from web-based and printed guide materials. A randomized controlled trial among resident physicians
abstract: BACKGROUND: Online physician education is on the rise, but its effectiveness compared to current self-study methods is unknown. OBJECTIVE: To compare the knowledge, learning efficiency, and student satisfaction produced by the self-study of World Wide Web-based and print-based guidelines for care after acute myocardial infarction. DESIGN: Randomized, controlled trial. SETTING: 12 family medicine and internal medicine specialization programs at four universities. PARTICIPANTS: 162 assistants. INTERVENTIONS: In supervised sessions, participants were randomly assigned to study from printed materials or SAGE (Graphic Evidence Self-Study Acceleration), a Web-based training system. Both methods used the same self-assessment questions and answers and guide texts, but SAGE included hyperlinks to specific guide passages and graphic evidence animations. MEASUREMENTS: Scores on multiple choice knowledge tests, point attainment per unit of study time, and ratings on a student satisfaction scale. RESULTS: Immediate posttest scores on a 20-point scale were similar in the SAGE and control groups (median score 15.0" compared to 14.5; P>0.2), but SAGE users spent less time studying (median 38.5 minutes compared to 27.0). ; P<0.001) and therefore had higher learning efficiency (median score gain 8.6 compared to 6.7 points per hour; P = 0.04). On a scale of 5 to 20, SAGE users were more satisfied with learning (median score, 17.0 versus 15.0) After 4 to 6 months, information was equally reduced in the SAGE and control groups (median score 12.0 compared to 11.0; P = 0.12). CONCLUSIONS: Online tutorials can provide greater learning efficiency and satisfaction than printed materials, but a single self-study experience may be insufficient for long-term knowledge accumulation. More research is needed to identify instructional features that motivate further learning and retention.

title: Sertraline as monotherapy in the treatment of psychotic and non-psychotic depression
abstract: BACKGROUND: Previous studies show that selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs) are effective when used alone in the treatment of unipolar depression with psychotic features. The aim of this study is to examine the response to sertraline treatment in patients with and without psychotic features using standard criteria such as recovery and remission. METHODS: An 8-week open-label trial of sertraline was performed in inpatients with depression. Twenty-five subjects had DSM-IV major depressive disorder with psychotic features and 25 had DSM-IV major depressive disorder without psychotic features. After 1 week of open washout, all subjects were initially rated using the Hamilton Depression Rating Scale (HAM-D) and Brief Psychiatric Rating Scale (BPRS). HAM-D was administered weekly and BPRS was re-administered only at the end of the 8-week trial. The drug dose was started at 50 mg/day, increased to 100 mg/day after 1 week, and then increased to 200 mg/day if subjects were not in remission. RESULTS: Depressed patients without psychosis, remission (HAM-D score - 7"; p =.001), response (HAM-D score - 50% of baseline score; p = .011), referral to electroconvulsive therapy (HAM-D) score >/= 15;" p =.011) or change in HAM-D scores (p =.016). Baseline HAM-D score and psychosis independently predicted response, whereas baseline BPRS scores did not, regardless of whether psychotic state was entered in the analyses. CONCLUSION: Psychotic depression responds worse to sertraline alone than depression without psychosis. Psychosis is a predictor of response, independent of the degree of depression and general psychopathology. The limitations resulting from the open-label design and the differences between this study and others using the SSRI for psychotic depression are discussed.

title: Services for children with developmental coordination disorders: an assessment against best practice principles.
abstract: OBJECTIVE: The National Health Service in Scotland has published a best practice framework to support occupational therapists and physical therapists to deliver effective services to children with developmental coordination disorders (DCDs)"; however, commitment is variable. To highlight areas of development, this study is a pediatric DCD service METHODS: A UK-based partnership of researchers and clinicians conducted a qualitative study with 37 participants (N = 13 interview participants, N = 24 workshop participants) In-depth interviews and/or to match the DCD service with the NHS framework workshops were used. Identified gaps were aligned with the four key phases of the care pathway. Qualitative analysis software was used to analyze the data. RESULTS: For each phase of the pathway, key principles were identified to guide future development. These key principles relate to the NHS framework and involve family, define clear pathways and increasing children's participation. Participants identified potential strategies for service improvement, such as community-based interventions and information provision. CONCLUSION: Challenges in providing services to children with DCD include confusing service pathways and poor partnership work. Therefore, it is important for clinicians to use collaborative work strategies that promote children's participation. PRACTICES FOR REHABILITATION: There are numerous challenges associated with applying best practice principles in the provision of therapy services for children with developmental coordination disorder (DCD). It is important that AHPs look for ways to involve parents and education professionals at all stages of the care pathway to ensure optimal service delivery for the child. Addressing participation is an important issue and community-based strategies can be particularly useful as both a preventive action and an intervention approach.

title: Sex in the doctor's office
abstract: KIE: A case study explores the dilemma of a doctor who is faced with a colleague's serious violation of professional norms. A psychiatrist, Dr. Jones learns from a patient that she voluntarily had sexual intercourse with an internist and threatened to harm him if she took action against him. Although devastated and suicidal, she insists on protecting the internist and Jones must decide for himself which path to take. Shapiro, a psychiatrist, notes in his comment that Jones' actions are tied to the actions of his patient, for whom he has a duty of confidentiality. He also has moral and fraternal obligations to his colleague, which may require contacting a committee of physicians with disabilities. Morrow, a sociologist, argues that Jones must intervene morally and legally to protect patients and the integrity of the medical profession. This intervention should likely take the form of informing an agency investigating problem doctors.

title: Gender, stroke and inflammation: potential for estrogen-mediated immune protection in stroke.
abstract: Stroke is the third leading cause of death and the primary cause of disability in the developed world. Experimental and clinical data suggest that stroke is a sexually dimorphic disease and that men exhibit an enhanced intrinsic susceptibility to ischemic injury for most of their lives. The neuroprotective role of estrogen in the female brain is well known, but estrogen exposure can also be harmful, especially in older women. The mechanisms for this remain unclear. Our current understanding is based on studies examining estrogen in relation to neuronal damage, but cerebral ischemia also induces a robust sterile inflammatory response involving local and systemic immune cells. Despite estrogen's potent anti-inflammatory effects, few studies have investigated the contribution of estrogen to sex differences in the inflammatory response to stroke. This review examines the potential role of estrogen-mediated immune protection in ischemic injury. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2017 APA, all rights reserved)

title: Sexual activity and counseling in the first month after acute myocardial infarction among young adults in the United States and Spain: a prospective, observational study.
abstract: BACKGROUND: United States and European cardiovascular community guidelines recommend that physicians advise patients to resume sexual activity after acute myocardial infarction (AMI), but little is known about patients' counseling experience regarding sexual activity after AMI. METHODS AND RESULTS: The Longitudinal Variation in Recovery: The Role of Gender in Outcomes of Young AMI Patients (VIRGO) study conducted at 127 hospitals in the United States and Spain was designed, in part, to assess gender differences in baseline sexual intercourse. Activity, function and patient experience with physician consultation about sexual activity after AMI. This study used baseline and 1-month data collected from a 2:1 sample of 18- to 55-year-old women (N=2349) and men (N=1152) with AMI. The mean age was 48 years. Of those (12% of women, 19% of men) who reported discussing sexual activity with a doctor once a month after AMI, 68% were given restrictions: limiting sex (35%), taking a more passive role (26%), and/ or keep heart rate low (23%). In risk-adjusted analyzes, factors associated with not discussing sexual activity with a physician included female gender (relative risk, 1.07"; 95% confidence interval, 1.03-1.11), age (relative risk, 1.05% at 10 years; 95 confidence interval) , 1.02-1.08) and sexual inactivity at baseline (relative risk, 1.11; 95% confidence interval, 1.08-1.15) Among patients who received counseling, women in Spain were significantly more likely than women in the United States. restriction was more likely to be applied (relative risk ;" 1.36, 95% confidence interval, 1.11-1.66). CONCLUSION: Few patients reported counseling for sexual activity after AMI. Those who did were often given restrictions that were not supported by evidence or guidelines. CLINICAL TRIAL REGISTRATION URL: http://www.clinicaltrials.gov. Unique identifier: NCT00597922.

title: Sexual health curriculum in US medical schools: current educational goals
abstract: OBJECTIVE: Authors identify explicit and implicit goals that shape decisions about what medical schools teach about human sexuality. METHODS: The authors reviewed relevant journal articles, physician licensing exams, and professional body publications to identify learning objectives for human sexuality in undergraduate medical curricula. CONCLUSIONS: There is consensus on many attitudinal goals and some skills that medical students should acquire on sexual health. There is less consensus on sexual knowledge that student physicians should specialize in. Several common knowledge goals focus narrowly on the diagnosis of sexual dysfunction and disease. CONCLUSION: Model sexual health curricula, licensing exams, and guidelines from professional organizations mainly focus on the pathological aspects of sexuality. Student physicians should have a basic knowledge of healthy sexual function and be familiar with the role of practitioners in a variety of therapeutic disciplines in addressing sexual concerns and enhancing patients' sexual function and well-being. The instruction should also address ways to incorporate this important issue into time-limited interactions with patients.

title: Sexually Transmitted Diseases Among Erectile Dysfunction Drug Users: Analysis of Claims Data
abstract: Background Pharmacological treatments for erectile dysfunction (ED) have gained widespread popularity among middle-aged and older men in recent years. Increased sexual activity among users of these treatments raises concerns about sexually transmitted diseases (STDs). Purpose to examine the relationship between STDs and ED drugs. Longitudinal analysis of users and non-users of design ED drugs. Data sources from 1997 to 2006 medical and drug claims 1,410,806 male employees over 40 years of age with private insurance at 44 major companies. Results People who used emergency drugs had higher rates of STDs than nonusers even before they started Emergency drug therapy (288 v. 156 per 100,000 people per year). p. < 0.005). Adjusting for these baseline rates, users of ED drugs had higher rates of STDs in the year after their first ED drug use (OR 2.06, p < 0.05) compared with nonusers during the same period. Among users of ED drugs, STD rates were higher in the year following the first ED drug use than in the previous year (289 vs. 327 per 100,000 population per year, p < 0.05). Limitations Selection bias prevents firm conclusions from being drawn about whether the use of ED treatments directly leads to death. It causes an increase in STDs. Conclusions Compared to those who do not use emergency medicine, the rates of STDs are higher both before starting treatment and after one year. At the very least, this association suggests that men taking emergency medications may benefit from early discussions about safe sexual practices and closer monitoring for STDs. It is also possible that the availability of ED medications may increase STD rates.

title: Collaborative decision-making does not influence physicians against clinical practice guidelines
abstract: BACKGROUND: While shared decision-making (SDM) and adherence to clinical practice guidelines (CPGs) are important, some believe they are incompatible. This study investigated the interplay between physicians' intentions to engage in SDM and their intention to pursue CPGs. METHODS: To evaluate the impact of physician education in SDM on using antibiotics to treat acute respiratory infections, this study housed within a clustered randomized trial evaluated physicians' intentions to both engage in SDM and follow CPGs. A self-administered questionnaire based on the theory of planned behavior evaluated both behavioral intentions and their respective determinants (attitude, subjective norm, and perceived behavioral control) at study entry and exit. We used path analysis to explore the relationships between intentions. We performed statistical analyzes using the maximum likelihood method and the variance-covariance matrix. Goodness of fit indices included the chi-square statistic, the comparative index of fit, and the root mean square error of approximation. RESULTS: We analyzed 244 responses on entry and 236 responses on exit. In the control group, we observed that, at entry, physicians' intentions to engage in SDM (r = 0, t = 0.03) did not affect their intention to follow CPGs; however, their intention to follow CPGs (r = -0.31 t = -2.82) negatively affected their intention to join SDM. At exit, neither behavioral intention affected the other. In the experimental group, neither behavioral intention at entry affected the other;" at exit, intention to follow CPGs (r = -0.15 t = -2.02) slightly negatively affected intention to join SDM, although intention to join SDM still affected intention to use CPGs. CONCLUSION: Physicians' intention to participate in SDM does not affect their intention to adopt CPGs, even after SDM training. Physicians' intention to adopt CPGs did not have a clinically significant effect on their intention to participate in SDM. TRIAL REGISTRATION: ClinicalTrials.gov NCT01116076.

title: Researchers say short-term cognitive behavioral therapy may reduce health anxiety
abstract: Researchers claim that a short course of cognitive behavioral therapy taught by nurses with minimal training would be an effective and relatively inexpensive way to reduce health anxiety in general medical clinics. Health anxiety or hypochondriasis places a significant burden on healthcare as it leads to multiple consultations and investigations. Cognitive behavioral therapy is known to be an effective treatment for other anxiety disorders, but there is a shortage of specialist therapists and long waiting lists for treatment. The Cognitive Behavioral Therapy for Health Anxiety in Medical Patients (CHAMP) study randomized 445 people with abnormal health anxiety.

title: Should future interventional neuroradiologists be screened for mutations that impair radiation-induced DNA repair?
abstract: In our current medical practice, an increasing number of specialists have access to radiology technical platforms to perform imaging-guided procedures. Although knowledge of current guidelines and radiation protection devices is a prerequisite for radiation use, preventive measures are often more or less strictly followed, resulting in significant daily doses of radiation and large accumulated lifetime exposures. Aortic intervention, electrophysiology and especially neuro intervention can result in large doses for operators. Responders may try to rationalize their denial of exposure risks with a variety of excuses: they don't know where they left their badges (and will even guiltily admit that it's good practice to wear them all the time), for an estimated short time. procedure, significant muscle tension and spasm caused by the weight of lead aprons, reduced dexterity with lead gloves, or discomfort in wearing lead safety glasses. But their indifferent attitude is most likely due to the nature of not feeling threatened by something they can't see or feel, a culture of bravado that reinforces their commitment to the patient at all costs and their behavior.

title: Should recommendations for initiating inhaled corticosteroid therapy for mild asthma be based on symptom frequency: a post-hoc efficacy analysis of the START trial.
abstract: Background Low-dose inhaled corticosteroids (ICS) are highly effective for reducing asthma exacerbations and mortality. Conventionally, ICS therapy is recommended for patients with symptoms more than 2 days per week, but there is insufficient evidence for this criterion. We aimed to assess the validity of previous symptom-based cutoff by determining whether there was a differential response to budesonide versus placebo for severe asthma exacerbations, lung function, and asthma symptom control among subgroups defined by baseline asthma symptom frequency. Background Low-dose inhaled corticosteroids (ICS) are highly effective for reducing asthma exacerbations and mortality. Conventionally, ICS therapy is recommended for patients with symptoms more than 2 days per week, but there is insufficient evidence for this criterion. We aimed to assess the validity of prior symptom-based cutoff for starting ICS by determining whether there was a differential response to budesonide versus placebo for severe asthma exacerbations, lung function, and asthma symptom control among subgroups defined by baseline asthma symptom frequency.

title: Should women take part in clinical trials in breast cancer? Problems and some solutions
abstract: OBJECTIVE: The purpose of this review is to address issues related to women's participation in clinical trials evaluating breast cancer management and to provide some recommendations for future interventions to address identified areas of concern. METHODS: National Health and Medical Research Council (NHMRC) National Breast Cancer Center, "Clinical Trials in Breast Cancer: Should Women Participate?" hosted an international workshop on the question of We also reviewed the literature on informed participation in clinical trials identified in a broad-based survey covering Medline, PsycLIT, and HealthPlan from 1986 to 1996. with a series of questions and dilemmas. These include issues related to the conduct of research and ethical considerations; the effect of participation or non-participation in treatment; doctor's roles as clinician and researcher; informed consent process; the timing of the request for participation; and The benefits and costs of participation A number of steps have been identified that can help women decide whether to participate in clinical trials. These include providing community information about clinical trials, establishing independent commissioners and registries for clinical trials, consumer review of information, and protocols and participation in trials; reviewing the role of ethics committees; collecting data on the proportion of women currently participating in clinical trials, the reasons for their participation or refusal, and their views on the recruitment and participation process; optimal practice models trials in involving women in clinical research and encouraging continued participation; "evidence-based communication skills training" to teach clinicians the skills to adequately inform women about participation in clinical research, and research support and support by an independent agency.

title: Importance of chronic fatigue syndrome in rehabilitation medicine – status and perspectives
abstract: From a clinical perspective, chronic fatigue or fatigue appears to be an important factor in rehabilitation. But it is, above all, a phenomenon that can be defined as a function according to the International Classification of Functioning, Disability and Health (JCF) caused by chronic diseases or chronic excessive stress. The clinical and sociomedical ranking of chronic fatigue or exhaustion in terms of rehabilitation was discussed in terms of psychiatric rehabilitation, methodology, sociology and practical rehabilitation within the framework of a Workshop at the 12th Rehabilitation Science Colloquium in 2003, and implications for future research were discussed. drawn. The definition of chronic fatigue is primarily based not only on the feeling of chronic fatigue, but also on the phenomena of disturbed concentration, physical discomfort, headache and "impulse" and mood disorders. A psychiatric diagnosis associated with chronic fatigue symptoms is neurasthenia, reached according to strictly defined criteria. Depressive disorder is one of the most important differential diagnoses in this area. Examinations by GPs revealed that approximately 90% of patients diagnosed as suffering from psychovegetative disorders fully agree with the diagnosis of neurasthenia. Neurasthenia resulted in more frequent episodes of work disability than somatization disorders and other psychosomatic diagnoses. On the basis of the "IRES" scale "vital exhaustion", even drastic changes become evident in approximately 50% to 90% of patients entering rehabilitation, depending on the individual indication range. Not surprisingly, most of the pathological findings are related to patients undergoing psychosomatic rehabilitation because in such cases there is overlap with the symptoms of psychosomatic diseases. However, it is noteworthy that fatigue symptoms are observed in up to 50% of patients in somatic-oriented orthopedic rehabilitation. Preliminary studies have shown that although pathological manifestations are still abundant at follow-up examinations, these symptoms can definitively be improved within the framework of rehabilitation. Significantly severe levels of "vital exhaustion" and "occupational exhaustion" are also seen in rheumatology patients undergoing somatic rehabilitation. This is consistent with the relevant case history details by many male and female patients. Therefore, it seems necessary to tailor the rehabilitation intervention to both the psychovegetative and medical behavioral aspects of this symptom. Scientific classification of all chronic fatigue in terms of rehabilitation requires classification of relevant functions within the framework of the ICF. To this end, it will be necessary to use a systematic consensus process among experts for the assignment of relevant functions, on the one hand, to conduct patient inquiries within the scope of cross-sectional studies. This is the basis for the development of appropriate assessment tools for use in prospective studies to systematically assess the impact on functions, and in particular the impact on activities and participation.

title: Simplifying care: when will the treatment burden be too high for patients living in poverty?
Simulation training as a single intervention does not improve hand hygiene practices: A randomized controlled follow-up study
abstract: BACKGROUND: To evaluate how nurses' critical knowledge of and adherence to current care hand hygiene (HH) guidelines differed between randomly allocated intervention and control groups before and after simulation training in both the simulation setting and clinical practice during a 2-year follow-up period. It was hypothesized that after simulation training, the intervention group's knowledge of and adherence to existing HH guidelines might increase compared to a control group. METHODS: A prospective, parallel, randomized controlled trial with repeated measurements was conducted in a 22-bed adult mixed medical-surgical intensive care unit in Oulu, Finland. Thirty of the 40 ICU nurses initially randomized participated in baseline measures";" 17 of them completed all study procedures. Participants' HH compliance was observed only in high-risk contact situations before and after endotracheal aspiration events using a direct, non-participant observation method. Participants' HR knowledge was assessed at the end of each observation session. RESULTS: Overall HH compliance increased from a baseline value of 40.8% to 50.8% at the last post-intervention measurement at 24 months (P = .002). However, the linear mixed model did not detect any significant group (P = .77) or time group interactions (P = .17) between study groups after 2 years of simulation training. In addition, the simulation training did not have any effect on the participants' knowledge of HR. RESULTS: After a single simulation training session, intensive care nurses' knowledge of and adherence to current HR guidelines remained below target behavior rates.

title: Sleep disturbance in adults with cancer: a systematic review of the evidence for best practices in assessment and management for clinical practice.
abstract: Sleep disturbance is common in cancer with detrimental effects on health outcomes. Sleep problems are rarely identified or addressed in cancer practice. The purpose of this review was to determine the evidence base for the evaluation and management of cancer-related sleep disorder (insomnia and insomnia syndrome) for oncology practice. The health literature search included gray literature data sources and empirical databases from June 2004 to June 2012. The evidence was reviewed by a Canadian Sleep Specialist Panel, made up of nurses, psychologists, primary care physicians, oncologists, and doctors specializing in sleep disorders. researchers and guide methodologists to develop clinical practice recommendations for pan-Canadian use reported in a separate article. Three clinical practice guidelines and 12 randomized, controlled trials were identified as the main source of evidence. Additional guidelines and systematic reviews were also reviewed for evidence-based recommendations for the assessment and management of insomnia not necessarily in cancer. The need to routinely screen for sleep disorders has been identified, and randomized controlled trial (RCT) evidence suggests benefits of cognitive behavioral therapy for improving sleep quality in cancer. Sleep disturbance is a common problem in cancer that needs further recognition in clinical practice and future research.

title: Smoking in emergency chest pain patients: motivation to quit, risk perception, and physician intervention.
abstract: The feasibility of the emergency department (ED) as a setting for smoking interventions was studied among 159 adult patients presenting with chest pain (38% were smokers). Subjects were admitted to a 24-hour observation unit (OU) to rule out myocardial infarction. Using the AHCPR guidelines as a model, we examined the frequency and extent of physician interventions for smoking. We also evaluated patients' perceptions of risk from smoking and their motivation to quit. The results show that emergency physicians provide incomplete and inconsistent response. When most of the patients were asked whether they smoked, only half were advised to quit and very few were offered help with quitting. Nearly half of the smokers had a low perceived risk from smoking. However, more than three-quarters were willing to seek smoking cessation counseling while in the emergency room. The emergency department may be a suitable setting to initiate smoking cessation counseling for certain high-risk populations.

title: Smoking cessation activities by general practitioners and practice nurses
abstract: OBJECTIVES: To evaluate the self-reported behaviors, attitudes and knowledge of general practitioners and practice nurses about smoking cessation. DESIGN AND ENVIRONMENT: Two mail surveys" with randomized national samples of 303 GPs (survey 1) and 459 GPs (survey 2) covering England and Wales; effective response rates were 75% and 96%, respectively. RESULTS: Questionnaire 1, found that 96% of GPs agreed that the anti-smoking intervention was part of their role, and nearly all (99%) said they recorded their smoking status when patients were enrolled; 57% said they routinely updated their smoking status record, 50% 76% said they recommend smokers to quit smoking if they cannot quit. A large majority (83%) said they recommend or prescribe nicotine replacement therapy (NRT). Despite many general practitioners (86%), NRT' Thought the drugs were effective, only a minority thought they were worth the cost (47%) or needed to be on a NHS prescription (32%). There was little evidence that prior education was associated with more activity, positive attitudes, or more knowledge. Survey 2 showed that almost all practice nurses (99%) agreed that smoking intervention is part of their role, and 95% advised patients to quit at least occasionally; 71% said they advise smokers to quit most or all of the consultations. The majority (74%) said they recommend NRT to their patients. As with GPs, most nurses felt that nicotine replacement was effective (79%), but fewer (42%) felt the cost was justified and only half (53%) needed NHS prescriptions. Nurses who said they were educated about smoking cessation were more active, had a more positive attitude, and were more knowledgeable about quitting. CONCLUSION: General practitioners and practice nurses accepted the intervention. smoking was an important part of their role, and a large majority reported that they interfered with at least some smokers. This provides a promising basis for moving forward in terms of introducing new smoke. However, it is hoped that improvements can be made in terms of updating the registries and frequency of intervention and the cost-effectiveness of NRT being recognized as a life-saving intervention.

title: Smoking cessation counseling beliefs and behaviors of outpatient oncology service providers
abstract: OBJECTIVE: Many cancer patients continue to smoke after diagnosis, which increases the risk of treatment complications, reduces treatment efficacy, secondary cancers, and decreases survival. Outpatient oncology providers may not be using the "teachable moment" of a cancer diagnosis to provide smoking cessation help. PROVIDERS AND METHODS: Physicians and mid-level providers (n = 74) providing outpatient oncology services completed an online questionnaire on smoking cessation counseling behaviors, beliefs, and perceived barriers. The outpatient medical records of 120 breast, lung, head and neck, colon, prostate, and acute leukemia cancer patients were reviewed to evaluate current smoking cessation assessment and intervention documentation practices. RESULTS: Providers reported that they rate smoking widely in new patients (82.4% often or always), but rates at subsequent visits decreased for both current smokers and recent quitters. The rates of recommending patients to quit smoking were also high (86.5% often or always), but <30% of providers reported that they often or always intervene with smokers (for example, nicotine replacement therapy or other medications, self-help materials and/or references). Only 30% of providers reported that they often or always followed patients to assess quit-related progress. Few providers (18.1%) reported a high level of confidence in their ability to counsel smokers. The lack of motivation of the patients was determined as the most important obstacle to quitting smoking. CONCLUSIONS: While beliefs about providing cessation services to smokers are generally positive, few providers commonly report providing interventions beyond quit advice. Additional education and clinical-based interventions can improve adherence to tobacco cessation practice guidelines in the outpatient oncology setting.

title: Smoking cessation counseling with pregnant and postpartum women: a survey of community health center providers
abstract: OBJECTIVE: This study evaluated the performance of smoking cessation counseling steps of low-income pregnant and postpartum women and service providers receiving care in community health centers. METHODS: WIC (Special Supplementary Nutrition Program for Women, Infants, and Children) program staff, obstetricians, and pediatric clinicians at 6 community health centers were asked to complete the questionnaires. Smoking intervention practices (performance), knowledge and attitudes, and organizational facilitators were measured. Performance-related factors were investigated by analysis of variance and regression analysis. RESULTS: Performance scores differed significantly by clinic and provider type. Providers at gynecology clinics had the highest scores, while providers at pediatric clinics had the lowest scores. Nurse practitioners and nutritionists had higher scores than other providers. Clinical type, greater knowledge about smoking, older age, and perception of smoking cessation as a priority were independently associated with better counseling performance. RESULTS: Average performance scores showed room for improvement in all groups. Low scores for performance of steps beyond assessment and advice indicate that national guidelines need emphasis on assistance and follow-up steps. The providers' commitment to helping mothers quit smoking was significant.

title: Don't quit smoking from office to bedside. An evidence-based, practical approach
abstract: Smoking remains a national health crisis and is responsible for unacceptable levels of suffering, illness and death. While the situation is improving as appropriate behavioral approaches and medications are clearly identified, the barriers to effective intervention such as education, time and reimbursement remain formidable. Applying these practical points is an acquired skill that takes time. Incorporating these recommendations into daily practice ensures that your smokers have the best opportunity to quit smoking and the highest level of care.

title: Smoking cessation in family medicine: effects of a regional health education center training program
abstract: BACKGROUND AND OBJECTIVES: Many clinicians have not received adequate training in smoking cessation. We examined the effects of a tobacco education program on clinician behavior, attitudes, knowledge, and comfort with smoking cessation. METHODS: In a prospective cohort study, family medicine residents and faculty completed a pretest, followed by an educational intervention that included smoking cessation resources, motivational interviewing, and presentations on the neurobiology of addiction and pharmacotherapy. After 3 months, participants completed a post-intervention questionnaire. The results were analyzed using chi-square tests to examine the effects of training. RESULTS: Thirty-three residents and faculty completed the pre-training questionnaire and 25 completed the post-training questionnaire. After the training, participants became more familiar and comfortable with the Public Health Service Clinical Practice Guidelines (P < .0001). No significant differences were found in performance of 5 As (Ask, Advise, Evaluate, Help, and Arrange) or performance of other behaviors, including providing assistance with counseling, quit plans, resources, or pharmacotherapy. There was no improvement in knowledge of specific intervention plans or attitudes to identify and counsel smokers. CONCLUSION: A multidisciplinary tobacco education program increases the clinician's familiarity and comfort with practice guidelines and can contribute to improved care activities that promote a healthy lifestyle. Future research should explore other interventions that have the potential to change delivery patterns on a larger scale. Future studies should also evaluate the impact of educational programs on patient-centered outcomes.

title: Quitting smoking - a central role for doctors
abstract: With its ability to integrate various aspects of nicotine addiction, physicians are in a unique position to advise smokers to quit. This review provides an overview of the intervention for smokers presenting in primary care. Strategies used in smoking cessation counseling differed according to the patient's readiness to quit. For smokers who do not intend to quit, physicians should inform and sensitize patients about tobacco use and cessation, particularly by personalizing the benefits of quitting and challenging smokers' beliefs. For smokers who are maladjusted, physicians should use motivational strategies, such as discussing barriers and solutions to quitting. For smokers who are ready to quit, the physician should demonstrate strong support, help set a quit date, prescribe replacement therapy and/or pharmaceutical treatments for nicotine addiction, such as bupropion, with instructions for use, and recommend behavioral strategies to prevent relapse.

title: Smoking: Can we really make a difference?
abstract: The enormous health benefits of quitting smoking are now well known. Doctors have a vital role in motivating smokers and initiating cessation initiatives. The mainstay of the National Health Service smoking cessation strategy should be the routine provision of brief opportunistic intervention in primary care, supported by referral to a specialist smoking cessation service. There is an urgent need to significantly increase the number of smokers referred to specialist smoking cessation services and better communication channels among various agencies by general practitioners, other members of the primary care team, and those working in acute hospital trusts. The use of pharmacotherapy (nicotine replacement therapy or bupropion) in combination with behavioral support produces higher quit rates than either component alone and is the most effective way to help smokers quit. Smokers who quit smoking often relapse and therefore need help over and over again.

title: Social Status and Mortality
Societal preferences for the return of incidental findings from clinical genomic sequencing: a separate selection experiment.
abstract: BACKGROUND: A major challenge with the application of next-generation sequencing technology is the possibility of uncovering incidental genomic findings. The paucity of evidence of personal benefit for incidental findings has hampered clinical guidelines. Our aim was to estimate personal benefit for complex information from incidental genomic findings. METHODS: We used a separate selection experiment to assess participants' personal benefit for the following attributes: disease penetration, disease treatability, disease severity, carrier status, and cost. Study participants were selected from the Canadian public. We analyzed the data with a mixed logit model. RESULTS: A total of 1200 respondents completed our survey (available in English and French). Participants valued information about high penetration disorders, but expressed it as unhelpful for information on low penetration disorders. In a scenario where clinicians were reporting on high-penetration, medically treatable disorders, the average willingness to pay to receive incidental findings was $445 (95% confidence interval [CI] $322-567), but only 66% (95% CI 63%) of respondents. -71%) stated that they would prefer to receive information in this scenario. On average, participants rated a significant value ($725, 95% CI 600-$850) in having a choice of what kind of findings they would receive, including information about high penetration, treatable disorders, or high penetration. disorders with or without current treatment. The estimated uptake for this scenario was 76% (95% CI 72%-79%). COMMENT: Most participants valued inclusion of incidental findings, but personal benefit depended on the type of finding, and not all participants wanted incidental results regardless of potential health effects. These results suggest that to maximize benefit, participant-level preferences should inform the decision about whether to return random findings.

title: Adolescent Medical Association Opinion Document on Reproductive Health Care for Adolescents
abstract: PIP: This article is a revision of a 1983 position paper of the Adolescent Medical Association that includes the latest medical advances in research on adolescent sexuality, namely contraceptive compliance, the promotion of behavior change, ethnicity and pregnancy relations, and male reproductive health issues of the 1990s. There will be morbidity and mortality from sexually transmitted diseases. The issues identified will be sexual activity and adolescent pregnancies, care of young pregnant women, sexually transmitted diseases, HIV infection, male adolescent, sexual abuse in adolescents, gay and lesbian youth, interventions, reproduction of disabled and chronically ill adolescents health care and education of primary care physicians The HIV/AIDS epidemic has drawn attention to male reproductive behavior.Sexual activity varies by race/ethnic group.Delayed sexual onset needs to be examined, although condom use increases between the ages of 17-19.21% to 58% in metropolitan areas However, sexually transmitted Condom use is the lowest among the group of men at highest risk for the disease: those who have used drugs before, those who have had sex with a prostitute, and those who have 5 or more partners per year. Men's beliefs about contraception have rarely been studied. There are misconceptions about heterosexual transmission of HIV. Better screening is needed for STD detection. Fathers are more involved in prenatal care and postnatal intervention programs. 7% of children aged 18-21 have been exposed to involuntary sexual intercourse. ;" i.e. 12.7% of white women, 9% of black women, 1.9% of white men and 6.1% of black men. Risk factors for white women are separation from parents at age 16, poverty, physical and emotional limitations, Parental alcohol and smoking and drug use Sexual assault was associated with hitchhiking and alcohol and drug use in 1 study cited. Doctors need to be sensitive to this issue and search for information. Sexual needs of those who are unsure of their place or who are gay 12th graders Among women, 1% of men and 1% of women viewed themselves as mostly or completely gay or lesbian, and 10% were unsure. Psychological and medical problems are encountered. Required interventions are reproductive and STd information. , in various settings, adolescent clinics, and social Multiple approaches to assistance.

title: Socioeconomic factors, health behaviors, and mortality: results from a nationally representative prospective study of US adults.
abstract: Context.Â¡Âª A prominent hypothesis regarding social disparities in mortality is that the higher risk among socioeconomically disadvantaged people is largely due to the greater prevalence of health-risk behaviors among those with lower education and income levels. Objective.Â¡Âª To investigate the extent to which 4 behavioral risk factors (smoking, alcohol use, sedentary lifestyle, and relative body weight) explain the observed relationship between socioeconomic characteristics and all-cause mortality. Design.Â¡Âª Longitudinal survey study investigating the impact of education, income, and health behaviors on the risk of dying in the next 7.5 years. Participants.Â¡Âª A nationally representative sample of 3617 adult men and women who participated in the Changing Lives of Americans survey. Key Outcome Measure.Â¡Âª All-cause deaths confirmed through the National Death Index and death certificate reviews. Results.Â¡Âª Educational differences in mortality were fully explained by the strong relationship between education and income. When controlling for age, gender, race, urbanity, and education, the hazard ratio ratio of risk to death was 3.22 (95% confidence interval [CI], 2.01-5.16) and 2.34 (95% CI, 1.49) for those in the lowest income group. -3.67) for those in the middle income group. Considering health risk behaviors, the lowest income group (hazard ratio, 2.77"; 95% CI, 1.74-4.42) and middle income group (hazard ratio ratio, 2.14; "95% CI, 1.38-3.25). Conclusion.Â¡Âª Although reducing the prevalence of health risk behaviors in low-income populations is an important public health goal, socioeconomic differences in mortality rates are due to a wider set of factors and will therefore persist even with improved health behaviors across populations. disadvantageous.

title: Sources of Variation and Bias in Diagnostic Accuracy Studies
abstract: Background: Diagnostic accuracy studies are subject to different sources of bias and variation from studies evaluating the efficacy of an intervention. Little is known about the effects of these sources of bias and variation. Purpose: To summarize the evidence for factors that may lead to bias or variability in the results of diagnostic accuracy studies. Data Sources: MEDLINE, EMBASE and BIOSIS, and methodological databases of the Center for Review and Dissemination and the Cochrane Collaborating Center. Methodological experts were contacted during the diagnostic tests. Study Selection: Studies investigating the effects of bias and variation on measures of test performance were eligible for inclusion evaluated by one reviewer and checked by a second reviewer. Inconsistencies were resolved by discussion. Data Extraction: Data extraction was performed by one reviewer and controlled by a second reviewer. Data Synthesis: The best documented effects of bias and variation were found for demographics, disease prevalence and severity, partial confirmation bias, clinical review bias, and observer and instrument variation. The amount of evidence for other sources was limited, such as skewed participant selection, incomplete or inappropriate reference standard, differential confirmation bias, and review bias. There was no evidence for other features, including inclusion bias, treatment paradox, arbitrary threshold selection, and dropouts. Conclusions: Many issues in the design and conduct of diagnostic accuracy studies can lead to bias or variability";" however, empirical evidence on the extent and impact of these problems is limited.

title: Detection of malignant melanoma
Stability of Attitudes towards Ethical Issues Raised by Return of Incidental Genomic Research Findings in Children: A Follow-up Study
abstract: OBJECTIVE: We investigate the stability of parental attitudes towards ethical problems posed by the return of genomic research results. METHODS: A 19-item questionnaire was mailed to participants in a large genome research consortium 18 months after a baseline questionnaire. We describe the stability of parental attitudes regarding (a) sharing of genomic research results, (b) validating children in genomic research, (c) researchers' responsibilities, and (d) responsibilities to the extended family. We also explore their experience in getting results. RESULTS: Of the 170 original participants, 154 (91%) responded. Most respondents expressed a positive entitlement to receive incidental genomic research findings (85%), including when curative treatment was unknown (85%). Only 3% found the decision to return the results to an independent committee acceptable. Researchers with parents (42%) or physicians (17%) were considered responsible for transmitting research results to children when they reached adulthood. Most respondents (74%) indicated that the results should be shared with the potentially affected extended family. These results are very similar to the results of the basic survey. All participants who received genomic results would do this again and report actions similar to the attitudes they expressed. CONCLUSIONS: Parents' views on genomic research remain stable over time. Guidelines for returning results should include these findings.

title: Progressive diabetes management: computerizing a disease state management program
abstract: Recently, the Diabetes Control and Complication Trial (DCCT) and other similar studies have shown that near-normal normalization of blood sugar in diabetes will reduce complications by up to 75%, but these results have been difficult to put into practice. In an attempt to help patients with diabetes achieve the best possible control, we have produced a new disease state management system for diabetes called "Progressive Diabetes Management". (SDM) has been implemented at more than 100 sites worldwide and has developed a computer program to simplify its use. Designed to change the way we deal with patients with diabetes, SDM is based on five principles: (1) community involvement in setting care guidelines; (2) negotiating goals with patients; (3) appropriate timelines for therapeutic success; (4) flowcharts for medical decisions. and (5) program evaluation. The SDM is designed to be modified by a community to meet its needs and resources. It encourages primary care physicians to use a team approach to provide better diabetes care and refer patients with diabetes to specialists as needed. Communities, individual healthcare providers and has a complete set of materials for patients SDM has been tested for changes in structure, process, and outcomes A meta-analysis of seven clinical studies with over 500 patients showed a time-weighted mean decrease in hemoglobin A1c of 1.7 points (mean about 3.5 mM or 60 mg/dL'l in blood sugar equivalent to one drop). Preliminary pharmacoeconomic analysis shows a lifetime cost savings of over $27,000 per patient. A computer program has been developed for the Microsoft Windows environment that includes a DiabCare-based client-server database for the data file structure.

title: Standard operating procedure changed the behavior of prehospital intensive care anesthetists: a quality control study
abstract: INTRODUCTION: The ability of standard operating procedures to improve prehospital critical care by changing prehospital physician behavior is uncertain. We report data from a prospective quality control study on the effect on the behavior of prehospital intensive care anesthetists to perform a standard operating procedure for prehospital controlled ventilation. MATERIALS AND METHODS: Anesthesiologists from eight prehospital critical care teams in the Central Denmark Region prospectively recorded prehospital advanced airway management data according to a Utstein-style template. We collected pre-intervention data from February 1, 2011 to January 31, 2012, followed the standard operating procedure on February 1, 2012, and collected post-intervention data from February 1, 2012 to October 31, 2012. We included transplanted patients of all ages who needed controlled ventilation. It is treated with prehospital endotracheal intubation or insertion of a supraglottic airway device. The aim was to evaluate whether the development and implementation of a standard operating procedure for controlled ventilation during transport could change the behavior of prehospital critical care anesthetists and thereby increase the use of automatic ventilators in these patients. RESULTS: Implementation of a standard operative procedure increased the overall prevalence of automatic ventilator use in transplant patients requiring controlled ventilation from 0.40 (0.34-0.47) to 0.74 (0.69-0.80), with a prevalence ratio of 1.85 (1.57-2.19). (p = 0.00). The prevalence of automatic ventilator use in transplant traumatic brain injury patients requiring controlled ventilation increased from 0.44 (0.26-0.62) to 0.85 (0.62-0.97), and the prevalence rate was 1.94 (1.26-3.0) (p = 0.0039). The prevalence of automatic ventilator use increased from 0.39 (0.26-0.48) to 0.69 (0.58-0.78) in transplant patients after return of spontaneous circulation after prehospital cardiac arrest, with a prevalence ratio of 1.79 (1.36-2.35) (p = 0.00) . CONCLUSION: We showed that the implementation of a standard operating procedure for prehospital controlled ventilation can significantly change the behavior of prehospital critical care anesthetists.

title: Standards for Implementation Reporting (StaRI) Statement
abstract: Implementation studies are often under-reported and indexed, reducing their potential to inform initiatives to improve healthcare. The Standards for Implementation Reporting (StaRI) initiative aimed to develop guidelines for transparent and accurate reporting of implementation studies. Aware of the findings of a systematic review and a consensus e-Delphi implementation, an international working group of application science experts discussed and adopted the 27-item StarRI Checklist. It leads researchers to define both the implementation strategy (techniques used to promote the implementation of an underutilized evidence-based intervention) and the effectiveness of the intervention being implemented. The accompanying Explanation and Detailing document (published in BMJ Open, doi:10.1136/bmjopen-2016-013318) details each item, explains its rationale, and provides examples of good reporting practices. Adoption of StaRI will improve reporting of practice studies, potentially facilitating the translation of research into practice and improving the health of individuals and communities.

title: State of the science: beta-blockers and reduction of perioperative cardiac events
abstract: This article reviews the available literature on the use of perioperative beta-blockade to reduce cardiac events, in the hopes that it can guide clinicians or illustrate medical knowledge gaps, revealing suitable areas for future work. The current standard of practice for the use of perioperative beta-blockade in preoperative patients is outlined in the American College of Cardiology (ACC) and American Heart Association (AHA) guidelines. Findings regarding the risk and benefit of using perioperative beta-blockers to reduce cardiac events differ. More research is needed to support ACC/AHA recommendations. It is essential that the decision to use beta-blockade be made on a case-by-case basis with adequate risk stratification as part of the criteria.

title: Adhering to minimum standards: implementing antibiotic management in the ICU
abstract: BACKGROUND: In Australia, antimicrobial management programs are a mandatory component of hospital accreditation. Good documentation on anti-microbial prescribing aids communication and can improve prescribing practice in multi-decision makers. OBJECTIVE: This study aims to develop and implement an intervention to improve antimicrobial prescribing practice in a 24-bed intensive care unit in a tertiary adult hospital. METHODS: We conducted a prospective collaborative quality improvement study in four phases (observation, reflection, application, evaluation). Key audits and surveys of antimicrobial prescribing practices identified barriers and enablers to good prescribing practices. A customized intervention was then administered for 6 weeks and included a yellow drug registration label, quarterly training sessions, and ICU-specific empirical antimicrobial prescribing guidelines. After administration, effects were monitored for 1 year with serial antimicrobial prescribing audits. Primary outcomes were start date, planned end date or review date, and clear documentation of an antibiotic indication. All of these were considered 'minimum standards' for an antimicrobial prescription in the drug registry. RESULTS: Documentation of minimum standards specifically addressed by the improved label (start date (72% to 90%, P < 0.001), end date (16% to 63%, P < 0.001), antimicrobial indication documented in drug chart (58%) up to 83%, P < 0.01)). Overall, adherence to all three minimum standards (start date, end date, and indicator) increased from 41/306 (13%) to 306/492 (63%) (P < 0.001). A year after implementation, the yellow tag was embedded in the daily practice. CONCLUSION: A systematic approach to quality improvement combined with the implementation of a tailored, multifaceted intervention can improve antimicrobial prescribing practices.

title: stimulant drugs
