abstract: Stimulants are an important element in the treatment of ADHD. Carefully designed stimulant trials found a significant improvement in ADHD core behaviors in 65-75% of subjects with ADHD. Most standard stimulants are rapidly absorbed, with behavioral effects appearing within 30 minutes, peaking in one to three hours, and disappearing within five hours. Despite the risk of peer teasing and additional adult supervision requirements, doses are often required at school. The mechanism by which stimulants reduce hyperactivity is not fully understood, but they improve impulsivity and activity levels. Few controlled evaluations over a period of more than one year show a clear persistence of drug effects over time. A carefully tailored treatment program with methylphenidate is more effective at reducing symptoms of hyperactivity than an intensive behavioral and cognitive intervention program. The combination of stimulants with psychosocial interventions in ADHD offers several advantages over drug therapy alone. It is difficult to recommend undisputed practice guidelines that would be appropriate everywhere. It is imperative that clinicians prescribing stimulants monitor drug use appropriately, ensuring that the drug is not abused by the child's family, peers, or school dispensers. Polypharmacy should only be initiated by a specialist service and the combination of methylphenidate and clonidine should be used with caution. Apart from ADHD, stimulants are helpful in narcolepsy, resistant depression, and partial attention and hyperactivity syndromes. Big gaps in knowledge persist";" The pharmacokinetics, pharmacodynamics and pharmacogenetics of stimulating effects need further study. The details of stimulant administration regimens appear to have a major influence on the response obtained. More research is needed, comparing different forms of combination with psychological interventions, preferably in realistic practice settings, investigating effects in groups of children outside the core of school-age children with typical ADHD: preschoolers, adults, those with partial syndromes (such as inattention) and those with co-morbid disorders. .

title: drown the future
Strategies for rehabilitation professionals to put evidence-based knowledge into practice: a systematic review.
abstract: RATIONALE: Rehabilitation clinicians need to stay up-to-date on best practices, especially because adherence to clinical guidelines can significantly improve patient outcomes. However, little is known about the benefits of information translation interventions for these professionals. OBJECTIVES: To examine the effectiveness of single- or multi-component information translation interventions to improve rehabilitation clinicians' knowledge, attitudes, and practice behaviors. METHODS: A systematic review of 7 databases conducted to identify studies evaluating information translation interventions specific to occupational and physical therapists. RESULTS: 12 studies met eligibility criteria. For physical therapists, participation in an active multi-component information translation intervention resulted in improved evidence-based knowledge and practice behaviors compared to passive dissemination strategies. These gains did not translate into a change in clinicians' attitudes towards best practices. For occupational therapists, there are no studies examining the use of multi-component interventions";" Studies of single interventions suggest limited evidence of efficacy for all measured outcomes. CONCLUSION: Although this review recommends the use of active, multi-component information translation interventions to improve physiotherapists' knowledge and practice behaviors, additional research is needed to understand the impact of these strategies on occupational therapists. Serious research gaps remain as to which information translation strategies positively impact patient outcomes.

title: Strengthening general practice
Strengthening the Reporting of Observational Studies in Epidemiology (STROBE): Clarification and Elaboration
abstract: Most medical research is observational. Reporting of observational studies is often of poor quality. Poor reporting hinders the assessment of a study's strengths and weaknesses and the generalizability of its results. Taking into account experimental evidence and theoretical considerations, a group of methodologists, researchers, and editors developed the Strengthening the Reporting of Observational Studies in Epidemiology (STROBE) recommendations to improve the reporting quality of observational studies. The STROBE Statement consists of a 22-item checklist for the title, abstract, introduction, methods, results and discussion sections of the articles. Eighteen items are common to cohort studies, case-control studies, and cross-sectional studies, and four are specific to each of the three study designs. The STROBE Statement guides authors on how to improve the reporting of observational studies and facilitates critical evaluation and interpretation of studies by reviewers, journal editors, and readers. This explanatory and detailing document aims to improve the use, understanding and dissemination of the STROBE Statement. The meaning and rationale for each checklist item is presented. For each item, one or more published examples and, where possible, references to relevant empirical studies and methodological literature are provided. Examples of useful flowcharts are also included. The STROBE Statement, this document, and the associated Web site (http://www.strobe-statement.org/) should be helpful resources to improve reporting of observational research.

title: Stress as a cardiovascular risk factor
abstract: Stress is an organism's response to a stressor with various adverse health consequences, including the development of atherosclerosis. Stress can cause myocardial ischemia, rhythm disturbances, platelet stimulation, increased blood viscosity through hemoconcentration, as well as endothelial dysfunction and coronary vasoconstriction in the presence of arteriosclerosis of the coronary arteries. Psychosocial risk factors may also lead to the development and clinical consequences of arteriosclerosis. The five most important psychosocial risk factors are: depression, anxiety, personality factors, social isolation and chronic life stress. Various components are responsible for the fact that life events or certain psychosocial factors can lead to a stress response. Psychosocial risk factors have direct pathophysiological implications, but they also affect lifestyle and behavior. A variety of stress management intervention programs have proven effective. It has been shown that psychosocial intervention together with cardiac rehabilitation programs reduces cardiovascular morbidity and mortality.

title: Stress echocardiography in heart failure
abstract: Echocardiography is capable of noninvasively investigating hemodynamic variables during pharmacological or exercise stress testing in patients with heart failure. In this review, we detail some of the important potential applications of stress echocardiography in patients with heart failure. In patients with coronary artery disease and chronic LV dysfunction, dobutamine stress echocardiography can distinguish between viable and fibrotic tissue to make adequate clinical decisions. Exercise testing together with echocardiographic monitoring is a method of obtaining accurate information in the evaluation of functional capacity and prognosis. Functional mitral regurgitation is a common finding in patients with dilated and ischemic cardiomyopathy, and stress echocardiography in the form of exercise or pharmacological protocols may be useful to evaluate mitral regurgitation behavior. It is clinically useful to investigate the presence of contractile reserve in non-ischemic dilated cardiomyopathy, such as to screen for or monitor the presence of latent myocardial dysfunction in patients exposed to cardiotoxic agents. In addition, in patients with suspected diastolic heart failure and normal systolic function, exercise echocardiography may demonstrate the presence of such dysfunction and determine that it is sufficient to limit exercise tolerance. Finally, in aortic stenosis, dobutamine echocardiography can distinguish severe stenosis from non-severe stenosis in patients with low transvalvular gradients and depressed left ventricular function.

title: Structured follow-up by GPs after intentional self-poisoning: a randomized controlled trial.
abstract: BACKGROUND: General practitioners (GPs) play an important role in the follow-up of patients after intentional self-poisoning (DSP). The aim was to examine whether structured follow-up by GPs improves treatment content, adherence to treatment, and satisfaction with treatment after discharge from emergency departments. METHODS: This was a blinded assignment multicenter randomized trial. Five emergency services and general practices in the collection area participated. 202 patients discharged from the emergency department after DSP assignment. The intervention is a structured follow-up by the GP over a 6-month period with at least five consultations to motivate patients to follow treatment, to assess personal problems and suicidal thoughts, and with written guidelines for GPs. case of suicide crisis. Outcomes were data from the Registry to control and pay reimbursements to healthcare providers (KUHR) and through questionnaires sent to patients and GPs. After 3 and 6 months, the frequency and content of communication with the GP and adherence to GP consultations and treatment in general were recorded. Satisfaction with the general treatment received and with the family doctor was measured with the EUROPEP scale. RESULTS: Patients in the intervention group received significantly more consultations than the control group (mean 6.7 vs 4.5 (p = 0.004)). The intervention group was significantly more likely to spend more time listening to their GPs listening to their personal problems (93.1% vs. 59.4% (p = 0.002)) and GP involvement in medical decisions (87.5% vs. 54). was satisfied. 8% (p = 0.009)). The intervention group was significantly more satisfied with the treatment overall than the control group (79 vs 51% (p = 0.026)). CONCLUSIONS: GP guidelines and structured, improved follow-up after discharge of the DSP patient increased the number of consultations in general practice and satisfaction with aftercare. Consistent with previous research, interventional studies are still needed. TRIAL REGISTRATION: ClinicalTrials.gov Identifier: NCT01342809. Registered April 18, 2011.

title: Structured smoking cessation training in cardiology wards for healthcare professionals: a prospective study.
abstract: Background: Smoking is an important cardiovascular risk factor and smoking cessation is mandatory in patients hospitalized for a cardiovascular event. This study aimed to evaluate a systems-based approach to assisting hospitalized smokers to quit and to identify implementation barriers. DESIGN: Prospective intervention study following qualitative analysis of staff interviews. METHODS: The prospective intervention study evaluated the effects of applying standard operating procedures (SOPs) for the provision of counseling and pharmacotherapy to smokers admitted to cardiology services on counseling frequency. In addition, a qualitative analysis of staff interviews was conducted to examine determinants of doctor and nurse behavior";" this sought to understand barriers in terms of motivation, ability and/or opportunity. RESULTS: A total of 150 smokers were included in the study (75 before and 75 after SOP). The proportion of patients who reported receiving cessation counseling from doctors and nurses before the implementation of the SOPs was 6.7% and 1.3%, respectively. Following the SOP implementation, these rates increased to 38.7% (p < 0.001) and 2.7% (p = 0.56), respectively. Qualitative analysis revealed that lack of motivation, for example role mismatch, appeared to be a major barrier. CONCLUSIONS: The introduction of a set of standard operating procedures for smoking cessation advice was effective for doctors, not nurses. Analysis of the barriers to implementation highlighted a lack of motivation rather than talent or opportunity as an important factor to be addressed.

title: Study confirms value of STD therapy in preventing HIV transmission
abstract: PIP: An intervention was conducted in the Mwanza Region of Tanzania to determine whether improved treatment in rural health centers and dispensaries for non-HIV/AIDS sexually transmitted diseases (STDs) could reduce the incidence of new HIV infections. Medical assistants and nurses at six rural health centers were trained in the syndromic management of STDs, and health center staff were encouraged to counsel their patients, offer them condoms, and seek referral of sex partners for treatment. The centers received the cheapest effective drugs to treat the major STD syndromes. Healthcare workers trained as supervisors visited each center every 8 weeks to control drug supply and patient records, provide refresher training, and ensure compliance with syndromic management guidelines. In addition, a cohort of 1,000 adults in communities served by six health centers was interviewed and tested for HIV at the start of the study and 2 years after the start of the intervention. Next, the number of new cases of HIV infection occurring in the cohort was compared with those occurring in another cohort selected from communities served by health centers where advanced STD treatment was not provided. During the 2-year study period, 11,632 cases of STD were treated at the centers. The intervention was found to reduce the number of new HIV infections occurring during the study period by 42%. This reduction was seen in both sexes and all age groups, but was particularly evident among women aged 15-24. Survey results suggest that the reduction in HIV incidence is the result of improved STD treatment rather than changes in sexual behavior. Preliminary calculations show a cost of approximately US$300 per HIV infection prevented.

title: new curriculum study on electronic communication in family medicine residencies
abstract: Electronic communication between physicians and patients is common, but can carry risks for users, both for patients and physicians. Little is known about electronic communication between physicians and patients, and even less about electronic communication during residency. We examined knowledge and practices before and after controlled testing of a new curriculum that teaches e-mail communication with patients using residents and faculty at 16 family medicine residencies in the United States. Both faculty and residents demonstrated a lack of knowledge of privacy and encryption prior to curriculum delivery, little familiarity with published guidelines for doctor-patient email, and non-compliance with documentation requirements. Posttests revealed greater improvement in knowledge and appropriate behavior regarding patient-physician email in the intervention group compared to the control groups (mean intervention increase 13 points [t=-4.065, P<.01], mean control increase 5 points [ t=-2.015, P<.05]). The increased uncertainty among intervention assistants about comfort with patient email is an interesting result that may result from increased awareness of the issues but limited time devoted to assimilation. Recommendations for the implementation of the curriculum are presented.

title: Study protocol for a randomized controlled trial: Applicability and impact of cardiovascular absolute risk assessment in Australian general practice.
abstract: BACKGROUND: Although cardiovascular absolute risk (CVAR) assessment has been recommended for use in Australian general practice for several years, there is ongoing uncertainty about its application and impact. Our previous work had developed a versatile application model. This study aims to explore both the feasibility of using this model and the impact of CVAR assessment and management on general practice clinical processes and patient care. STUDY DESIGN: This cluster randomized controlled trial will be conducted to include general practitioners (GPs) in Sydney, other practice staff, and patients aged 45 to 69 years without pre-existing cardiovascular disease. METHODS: A total of 32 practices (40 general practitioners) and 1320 patients will be recruited. Randomization will be done at the application level. The intervention group of family physicians will be trained to use a CVAR delivery model, while the control group of family physicians will continue with usual care. Study outcomes include clinical processes, patient risk, use of lifestyle intervention, and prescribing of antihypertensive and lipid-lowering drugs. Data will be collected and analyzed using mixed methods. Study results before and after intervention will be compared and the 2 groups will be compared after adjusting for baseline difference and clustering factors. CONCLUSION: This trial will be the first study in Australian general practice and one of the few international studies to evaluate the impact of implementing CVAR assessment and management. The results of this study will help improve primary prevention of cardiovascular disease and inform guidelines for clinical practice and implementation of other health interventions.

title: Examining practice abolition in health: an analysis of funded research grants
abstract: Background Here, the study of practice removal, defined as the reduction or cessation of use of a healthcare service or practice provided to patients by healthcare professionals and systems, has gained interest in recent years. Elimination of ineffective, unproven, harmful, overused, inappropriate and/or low-value healthcare services and practices is important to reduce harm to the patient, improve care processes, and reduce healthcare costs. A better understanding of the state of science is needed to guide future goals and funding initiatives. To this end, we identified decommissioning research grants funded by the United States (US) National Institutes of Health (NIH) and the Agency for Health Services Research and Quality (AHRQ). Methods From fiscal 2000 to 2017, we used systematic methods to search for, identify, and disclose decommissioning research grants funded at all 27 NIH Institutes and Centers (ICs) and AHRQs. Research grants in the NIH Inquiry, Imaging and Reporting (QVR) system. Two coders identified eligible grants based on inclusion/exclusion criteria. A codebook was developed, pilot tested and revised before coding the final sample full grant applications. Results A total of 1277 grants were identified through the QVR system";" After removing the duplicates, 542 remained. After the multi-stage conformity assessment and review process, 20 grant applications were coded. Many grants were funded by the NIH (n?=?15), fewer by AHRQ, and the majority funded between fiscal years 2015 and 2016 (n?=?11). Grant proposals focused on de-executing a range of health services and practices (eg drugs, therapies, screening tests) in various health areas (eg cancer, cardiovascular disease) and distribution settings (eg hospitals, nursing homes, schools). Grants proposing to use a variety of study designs and research methods (eg experimental, observational, mixed methods) to achieve study objectives. Results Based on a systematic portfolio analysis of NIH and AHRQ-funded research grants over the past 17 years, relatively few have focused on removing ineffective, unproven, harmful, overused, inappropriate, and/or low-value health practice. services and practices provided to patients by healthcare practitioners and systems. Strategies for raising the profile and expanding the field of research on decoupling are discussed.

title: Success after periprosthetic joint infection treatment: A Delphi-based international multidisciplinary consensus.
abstract: BACKGROUND: The lack of agreement on what constitutes successful treatment of periprosthetic joint infections (PJI) makes it difficult to compare the different management strategies used in clinical practice and research studies. QUESTIONS/OBJECTIVES: The aim of this study is to establish a consensus definition for success after PJI treatment and to provide a universal, multidimensional framework for reporting studies on PJI treatment. METHODS: A basic two-step Delphi method was used to arrive at a consensus definition. We invited 159 international experts (orthopedic surgeons, infectious disease specialists, and clinical researchers) from 17 countries to participate"; 59 participated in the first round and 42 in the second round. The final definition consisted of all statements that reached strong agreement. (80% or more of respondents considers a criterion for defining success) RESULTS: Consensus definition of successfully treated PJI: (1) eradication of infection characterized by a healed wound without fistula, drainage or pain, and absence of infection relapse caused by the same organism species; (2 ) no subsequent surgical intervention for infection after reimplantation surgery; and (3) the absence of PJI-related deaths (due to sepsis, necrotizing fasciitis, etc.). The Delphi panel agreed to define medium-term outcomes as those reported 5 or more years after definitive PJI surgery, and long-term outcomes as those reported 10 or more years after surgery. Although there was no consensus on the definition of short-term outcomes, 71% of respondents agreed that it was acceptable to define it 2 years after definitive PJI surgery. CONCLUSIONS: This multidimensional definition of success after PJI treatment can be used to report and compare outcomes of treatment for this catastrophic complication. EVIDENCE LEVEL: Level V, therapeutic study. See the Guide for Authors for a full description of the levels of evidence.

title: Successful implementation of a guideline with peer comparisons, education and positive doctor feedback
abstract: The purpose of this study was to determine whether peer comparisons, an educational intervention, and positive physician feedback would reduce the rank of knee X-ray studies. To encourage the use of the Ottawa decision rule for knee radiography, we prospectively examined the sequence of knee X-ray studies for patients presenting with knee injuries before and after an education program. Doctors were able to specifically compare their individual baseline X-ray usage data with those of their colleagues. Although acceptance of the rule was optional, both verbal and written feedback encouraged consideration of the rule in clinical decision making. Percent Abnormal Results (PAR is defined as the percentage of X-ray studies showing a fracture or effusion), as well as the percentage of knee injury patients who received X-ray studies were calculated before and after the training meeting. The results of the study showed that the percentage of patients presenting with knee injuries who received X-ray studies decreased by 23%. In addition, PAR increased by 58.4% between the two study periods. As a result, physician behavior can be changed in a positive way with reinforcement. Peer comparisons, education, and positive physician feedback reduced test ordering by physicians, even if they did not mandate the use of a protocol. The PAR is a useful outcome measure for monitoring physician use.

title: Successful implementation of neonatal pain and sedation protocol in NICU
abstract: OBJECTIVE: To evaluate the application of neonatal pain and sedation protocol in 2 intensive care units. METHODS: The response began with an assessment of local practices, problems and staff satisfaction. We then developed and implemented the Vienna Protocol for Neonatal Pain and Sedation. The protocol included well-defined strategies for both non-pharmacological and pharmacological interventions based on regular evaluation of a translated version of the Neonatal Pain Agitation and Sedation Scale and titration of analgesic and sedative therapy according to target scores. Healthcare personnel were trained in assessment using video-based training and bedside instruction. We also performed reassessment, retraining and random quality checks. The frequency and quality of assessments, pharmacological therapy, duration of mechanical ventilation, and outcome were compared at baseline (12 months before administration) and 12 months after administration. RESULTS: Cumulative median (interquartile range) opiate dose (initial dose 1.4 [0.5-5.9] mg/kg vs. intervention group dose 2.7 [0.4-57] mg/kg morphine equivalent"; P = .002), per person pharmacological interventions sustained episodes of sedation/analgesia (4 [2-10] vs. 6 [2-13]; P = .005) and overall staff satisfaction (doctors: 31% vs 89%; P < .001; nurses : 17% vs. 55%; "P < .001) increased after administration. The duration of mechanical ventilation, length of stay in the ICU, and adverse outcomes were similar before and after administration. CONCLUSIONS: Implementation of the neonatal pain and sedation protocol in 2 intensive care units resulted in an increase in opium prescription, pharmacological interventions, and staff satisfaction without affecting the duration of mechanical ventilation, length of stay in the ICU, and adverse outcomes.

title: Successful reduction in catheter-related urinary tract infections: focus on nurse-directed catheter removal.
abstract: Background Despite the use of sterile technique for catheter placement, closed drainage systems, and structured day care plans, catheter-related urinary tract infections (CAUTIs) occur regularly in acute care hospitals. We believe that a significant reduction in CAUTI rates can only be achieved by reducing the use of urinary catheters. Methods We used an interventional study of a hospital-wide, multidisciplinary program to reduce urinary catheter use and CAUTIs in all patient care units at a 300-bed community teaching hospital in Connecticut. Our primary focus was the implementation of the nurse-guided urinary catheter removal protocol. This protocol was linked to the doctor's instructions for catheter insertion. Three additional elements included physician documentation of catheter insertion criteria, a device-specific chart module added to the physician's electronic progress notes, and fortnightly unit-specific feedback on catheter use rates and CAUTI rates in a multidisciplinary forum. Results Over a 36-month period, we achieved a hospital-wide 50% reduction in catheter use and a 70% reduction in CAUTIs, but there was wide variation in catheter reduction efforts, ranging from 4% (delivery) to 74% from unit to unit. % (telemetry). Conclusion Urinary catheter use, and ultimately CAUTI rates, can be effectively reduced by diligent implementation of relatively few evidence-based interventions. Aggressive implementation of the nurse-guided catheter removal protocol was associated with lower rates of catheter use and lower infection rates.

title: Suicide: procedure in an emergency
abstract: Emergency physicians (APs), paramedics, and emergency room personnel play an increasingly important role in the medical and psychological emergency treatment of patients after a suicide attempt, as well as in the crisis response of people with acute suicidality. This article aims to provide an overview of the prevalence rates, methods of suicide or suicide attempt, and the problems faced by ES when treating these patients. In addition, concepts that allow for an adequate risk assessment for suicide and primary crisis intervention options are presented. Paramedics and intensive care clinicians are increasingly confronted with this complex process, which has social, personal and medical aspects. Clear guidelines are a prerequisite for treating people in suicidal crises and/or after suicide attempts and to provide safe and optimal care for this often heterogeneous group of patients. The initial assessment of the acute danger of suicide is particularly important because of the consequences and a clear approach to dealing with suicidal people has been demonstrated. In addition, legal principles are presented.

title: Evaluation of suicide and violence in psychiatry
abstract: Psychiatrists are expected to increasingly anticipate and prevent their clients' suicidal and violent/murder urges. This article reviews the available literature and research in these areas. While debate continues about whether the clinician can successfully predict violence or suicidal behavior in their patients, the weight of studies indicates that predicting suicide and individual violence may not be possible with currently available information. To compensate for the limitations of foresight, conservative clinicians deliberately exaggerate suicide or violence to help ensure the safety of their patients and the larger communities in which they live. In addition, clinicians need to perform comprehensive assessments and make sound clinical decisions consistent with perceived risks. Preventive measures for violence remain complex, but clinicians can maximize treatment effects by following specific intervention guidelines. As a minimum, violence-related documents should focus on the rationale for whether treatment interventions are implemented. The chart does not require lengthy notes, but should include a reasonable risk assessment and a description of a prudent course of action.

title: Summary of practice parameters for the assessment and treatment of children and adolescents with suicidal behavior
abstract: These guidelines review what is known about the epidemiology, causes, management and prevention of suicide and suicide attempt in young people. Detailed guidelines on the assessment and emergency management of children and adolescents presenting with suicidal behavior are provided. The guidelines also offer recommendations on how the clinician can interact with the community. Crisis hotlines, method restriction, training programs, and screening/case-finding suicide prevention strategies are reviewed, and the clinician is advised on media counseling. Community intervention after suicide, minimizing the transmission or imitation of suicide, and training primary care physicians and other gatekeepers to recognize and refer potentially suicidal children and adolescents are discussed.

title: To support clinical practice at the bedside using wireless technology.
abstract: Objectives: Despite studies showing improvements in both standards of care and outcomes with judicious application of clinical practice guidelines (CPGs), their clinical use remains low. This randomized controlled trial examined the use of a wireless networked mobile computer (MC) at the bedside by physicians who have access to the emergency room information system, decision support tools (DSTs), and other software options. Methods: Ten volunteer emergency physicians were each randomized using a matched pair design to work five shifts in standard style (desktop [DC] access) and five shifts with a wireless networked MC. Work pattern issues and electronic CPG/DST use were compared using end-of-shift satisfaction surveys and a CPG/DST database review. Repeated measures analysis of variance was used to examine the shift differences. Results: A total of 100 eight-hour shifts were evaluated"; 99% compliance with post-shift questionnaires. Using a seven-point Likert scale (MC values first), MCs were graded as fast (5.04 vs 4.54; p = 0.13) and fit ( 5.08 vs 4.14; p = 0.07) as DCs overall, physicians rated MHs as less efficient (3.18 vs 4.30; p = 0.02), but encouraged more frequent use of DSTs (4.10 vs. 3.47 vs. p = 0.03) without affecting doctor-patient communication (2.78 vs. 2.96; p = 0.51) During the study period, physician's use of the intranet Web application (eCPG) during shifts assigned to the MC, DC (uses/shifts eCPG, 3.6 vs 2.0;" p = 0.033). Results: MC technology allowed doctors to access information at the bedside and increased the use of CPG/DST tools. According to the doctors, patients seemed to agree to use information technology to aid in decision making. The development of advanced computing technology can address the main limitation of MC portability.

title: Supporting insulin initiation in type 2 diabetes in primary care: results of the Stepping Up pragmatic cluster randomized controlled clinical trial.
abstract: ObjectiveÃ To compare the efficacy of a new model of care ("Steping Up") in normalizing insulin onset for type 2 diabetes with normal primary care, resulting in improved glycated hemoglobin (HbA1c) levels. Design Cluster randomized controlled trial. Primary care practice with a practice nurse and at least one eligible patient (maximum HbA1c â€°Â ¥7.5% with oral therapy) in Victoria, Australia. Participants were 266 patients with type 2 diabetes and 74 treatments (mean cluster size 4 (range 1-8) patients), followed for 12 months. Intervention The Elevation model of care intervention included theory-based change in systems of practice and a reorientation of the primary care roles of health professionals. diabetes team. Key ingredients were a role developed for the nurse practitioner in leading insulin initiation and mentoring by a registered nurse with diabetes educator credentials. Main outcome measures The primary endpoint was change in HbA1c. Secondary endpoints included the proportion of participants who switched to insulin, the proportion of those who achieved target HbA1c, and a change in depressive symptoms (patient health questionnaire, PHQ-9), diabetes-specific distress (diabetes scale problem areas, PAID), and overall health. status (quality of life assessment, AQoL-8D). Results� HbA1c improved in both arms, with a clinically significant arm difference (mean difference -0.6%, 95% confidence interval -0.9% to -0.3), favoring intervention. At 12 months, 105/151 (70%) of participants started insulin in intervention treatments compared to 25/115 (22%) in control treatments (odds ratio 8.3, 95% confidence interval 4.5 to 15.4, P<0.001). Target HbA1c (Ã7% (53 mmol/mol)) was achieved by 54 (36%) intervention participants and 22 (19%) control participants (odds ratio 2.2, 1.2 to 4.3, P=0.02). Depressive symptoms did not worsen at 12 months (PHQ-9: -1.1 (3.5) v -0.1 (2.9), P=0.05). A statistically significant difference between arms in mean change in mental health was found (AQoL mental component summary: 0.04 (SD 0.16) v -0.002 (0.13), mean difference 0.04 (95% confidence interval 0.002 to 0, 08), P=0.04) support intervention, but no significant difference in physical health (AQoL physical component summary: 0.03 (0.15) v 0.02 (0.13)) nor diabetes-specific distress (5.6 (15.5) v -2.4 (15.4)). No serious hypoglycaemia events were reported. ResultsÂ The Stepping Up maintenance model was associated with increased insulin initiation rates in primary care and improvements in glycated hemoglobin without worsening emotional health. Trial registrationÂ Australian and New Zealand Clinical Trials Registry ACTRN12612001028897.

title: Supporting mid-level health workers in Malawi: lessons learned during the implementation of the PALM PLUS package
abstract: BACKGROUND: The Malawian government is committed to the broad dissemination of antiretroviral therapy in Malawi in the public health sector";" however, one of the main challenges has been the lack of trained health workers. The Lung Health Plus Practical Approach to HIV/AIDS in Malawi (PALM PLUS) package is an innovative guidance and training intervention that supports middle-level primary care workers to provide front-line integrated primary care. The purpose of this article is to explain the lessons learned in implementing the PALM PLUS package. METHODS: A clinical tool based on algorithm and symptom-based guidelines was adapted to the Malawi context. For the implementation of the PALM PLUS package in 30 health centers, a training program based on educational access principles targeting clinicians, medical assistants and nurses was developed and a tiered training approach was used. Lessons learned were identified during program implementation through collaborating partners and program participants and through review of participation and program evaluation findings. CONCLUSIONS: Key lessons learned for successful program implementation of the PALM PLUS package include the importance of building networks for peer-based support, providing adequate training capacity, linking with continuing professional development accreditation, and maintaining modest in-service training budgets. The main factors limiting implementation were staff turnover and the desire for financial training allowances. CONCLUSIONS: The PALM PLUS approach is a potential model for supporting middle-level healthcare professionals to deliver front-line integrated primary care in low- and middle-income countries and may be useful for future reassignment initiatives.

title: Surgical decision making and behavior. Social psychology explanations and research perspectives
abstract: Social psychology is the discipline that studies thought processes, emotions, and behavior in an interpersonal context. There are three broad subject areas: understanding oneself and others, interpersonal relationships, and group influence. The most important method is experimentation. The value of the social psychological perspective has been demonstrated in relation to the following surgical research questions: How do surgeons arrive at their decisions? How do surgeons confirm their decisions? Why are decision aids (computer support, instructions) so little accepted? How should patients be informed? Which group processes play a role in the operating room? What are the determinants of patient outcomes? Social psychology can expand surgical research in three aspects: better understanding of daily events in the clinical and surgical field, methodologically refined and stronger patient-focused study designs, and new perspectives for better patient outcomes.

title: Surgical treatments for men with benign prostatic enlargement: a cost-effectiveness study.
abstract: OBJECTIVE To determine which surgical treatment is cost-effective for lower urinary tract symptoms suggestive of benign prostatic enlargement. DESIGN Care pathways defining reliable treatment strategies were agreed upon by consensus. Cost-benefit analysis used Markov modeling and Monte Carlo simulation. DATA SOURCES Clinical efficacy data came from a systematic review and an individual-level dataset. The utility values came from previous economic assessments. Costs have been calculated from the National Health Service (NHS) and commercial sources. METHODS The Markov model included parameters with associated uncertainty measures describing the health states in which individuals could act at quarterly intervals over 10 years. Consecutive annual cohorts of 25,000 men were included in the model, and the likelihood of cost-effectiveness of treatment strategies was evaluated using a Monte Carlo simulation with 10,000 iterations. RESULTS There was an 85% probability that endoscopic holmium laser enucleation of the prostate following initial diathermy vaporization of the prostate would be cost-effective at a willingness to pay 20,000 pounds (euro21) if there was no benefit or subsequent recurrence. ,595, $28,686)/quality-adjusted life year (QALY) gained. Other strategies with diathermy vaporization as initial therapy were generally less expensive and more effective than the current standard of transurethral resection, repeated once as needed. The use of potassium titanyl phosphate laser vaporization resulted in higher costs and was less effective than transurethral resection, and strategies that included microwave thermotherapy and initial minimally invasive treatment were not cost-effective. Findings did not change with extensive sensitivity analyzes. CONCLUSION Due to the limitations of the data used, the result of this economic model should be interpreted with caution. The finding that holmium laser enucleation after initial vaporization for failure or recurrence may be advantageous for both men with lower urinary tract symptoms and healthcare providers requires confirmation in a good quality prospective clinical trial before any changes to current practice are made. Potassium titanyl phosphate laser evaporation was unlikely to be cost-effective in our model, opposing its unrestricted use until further evidence of effectiveness and cost reduction is available.

title: Surrogate decision making for research subjects with severe cognitive impairment: ongoing debate.
abstract: As research on Alzheimer's disease and other dementia disorders becomes more complex, risky, invasive, and mundane, the need to discuss the ethics of involving people with dementia in research, particularly those with greater than minimal risk and no direct benefit expected, intensifies. subject. (It is beyond the scope of this article to consider ethical issues related to research participation of children with cognitive impairment or children or adults with intermittent and/or reversible cognitive or psychiatric disorders. For such discussions, see references in note 1–. 6.) analysis pushes our traditional analysis tools to their limits. Balancing and prioritizing core ethical principles such as respect for those who serve us well, benefit, and fairness in our review of the vast majority of studies is insufficient when reviewing research for ethical complexities, such as studies with obvious risks and no expectation of direct benefit to subjects. cannot consent or withdraw. Raising to the level of theory, embedding these principles in widely practiced consequentialism, deontology, or virtue ethics frameworks does not get us any closer to reducing the tensions that such research creates between promoting individual autonomy and advancing the need for society to learn how to treat and heal. these devastating diseases. What is needed is the introduction of more contemporary moral analysis. Specifically, we need to make the diversity of value perspectives of our general citizenship more inclusive. In more theoretical terms, as we rush to step ethically into this rapidly expanding field of medical research, we must elevate a societal perspective and a feminist ethic with an emphasis on relationships and context to a more central role.

title: Adherence to survival care plans and lifestyle recommendations among breast cancer survivors
abstract: OBJECTIVE: The effectiveness of survival care plans has not been widely tested. We evaluated whether one-time brief lifestyle counseling as part of a broader survival care plan was effective in changing diet and lifestyle patterns. METHODS: A diverse sample of women with stage 0-III breast cancer were randomized to control or intervention groups within 6 weeks of completing adjuvant therapy. Both groups received the National Cancer Institute's publication "Looking Ahead: Life After Cancer Treatment." The intervention group also met with a nurse (1 hour) and a nutritionist (1 hour) to receive personalized lifestyle recommendations based on national guidelines. Diet, lifestyle, and perceived health were assessed at baseline, 3 and 6 months. Linear regression analyzes evaluated the effects of intervention adjusted for covariates. RESULTS: A total of 126 women completed the study (60 controls/66 interventions, 61 Hispanic/65 non-Hispanic). At 3 months, the intervention group reported more information on a healthy diet (P = 0.047), the importance of physical activity (P = 0.03), and appropriate use of dietary supplements (P = 0.006), and reported a lower frequency of alcohol drinking (P = 0.03) than controls. by. At 6 months, more information on a healthy diet only (P = 0.01) was maintained. The intervention was more effective among non-Hispanics than Hispanics in improving attitudes towards healthy eating (P = 0.03) and frequency of physical activity (P = 0.006). CONCLUSIONS: The intervention changed lifestyle behaviors and knowledge in the short term, but the benefits were not permanent. APPLICATIONS FOR CANCER CAUSES: Culturally competent long-term behavioral interventions should be tested beyond the survival care plan to facilitate long-term behavior change among breast cancer survivors.

title: kwashiorkor-like syndrome after partial gastrectomy
Systematic Review: An Evaluation of Major Commercial Weight Loss Programs in the United States
abstract: Background: Millions of Americans enroll in commercial and self-help weight loss programs each year. Healthcare providers and obese patients know little about these programs due to the lack of systematic reviews. Objective: To describe the components, costs, and effectiveness of major commercial and organized self-help weight loss programs that provide structured face-to-face or online counseling in the United States. Data Sources: Review of company Web sites, phone call with company representatives, and search of the MEDLINE database. Study Selection: Randomized trials of at least 12 weeks enrolling adults only and evaluating interventions as generally provided to the public, or case series 1 year or longer that include an ongoing follow-up evaluation, specifying the number of enrollees meeting these criteria. Data Extraction: Data were extracted regarding study design, attrition, weight loss, follow-up time, and maintenance of weight loss. Data Synthesis: We found studies on eDiets.com, Health Management Resources, Take Off Pounds Senssible, OPTIFAST, and Weight Watchers. The largest of 3 randomized controlled trials from Weight Watchers reported a loss of 3.2% of baseline weight at 2 years. One randomized trial and several case series of medically supervised very low-calorie diet programs found that patients who completed treatment lost approximately 15% to 25% of their baseline weight. These programs were associated with high costs, high attrition rates, and a high probability of regaining 50% or more of the weight lost within 1-2 years. Commercial interventions and organized self-help programs available over the Internet produced minimal weight loss. Limitations: The results reported are probably the best-case scenario, as many studies did not control for high attrition rates. Conclusions: There is insufficient evidence to support the use of major commercial and self-help weight loss programs, with the exception of the Weight Watchers 1 trial. Controlled trials are needed to evaluate the efficacy and cost-effectiveness of these interventions.

title: Systematic Review: Elective Induction of Labor and Expectancy Management of Pregnancy
abstract: OBJECTIVE: Labor induction and elective labor induction rates are increasing. Whether elective induction of labor improves outcomes or simply leads to greater complications and healthcare costs is widely debated in the literature. OBJECTIVE: To compare the benefits and harms of elective labor induction and the anticipated management of pregnancy. DATA SOURCES: MEDLINE (until February 2009), Web of Science, CINAHL, Cochrane Central Register of Controlled Trials (until March 2009), bibliographies of included studies and previous systematic reviews. STUDY SELECTION: Experimental and observational studies of elective labor induction are reported in English. DATA DRAWING: Two authors summarized the study design"; patient characteristics; quality criteria and outcomes, including cesarean delivery and maternal and neonatal morbidity. DATA SYNTHESIS: Of 6117 potentially relevant articles, 36 met inclusion criteria: 11 randomized, controlled studies ( RCT) and 25 observational Overall, expected management of pregnancy was associated with a higher odds ratio (OR) cesarean delivery (OR, 1.22 [95% CI, 1.07 to 1.39]; absolute risk difference, 9 RCTs' than elective induction of labor). 1.9 percent points [CI, 0.2 to 3.7 percent points]. Women at or beyond 41 weeks of gestation who were administered as expected had a higher risk for cesarean delivery (OR, 1.21 [CI, 1.01 to 3.7 percent points]). 1.46)), although this difference was not statistically significant in women less than 41 completed weeks of gestation (OR, 1.73 [CI, 0.67 to 4.5]). was more likely (OR, 2.04 [CI, 1.34 to 3.09]). LIMITATIONS: Recently, there were no RCTs of elective induction of labor below 41. gestational weeks. The 2 studies conducted below 41 weeks of gestation were of poor quality and could not be generalized to current practice. CONCLUSION: RCTs suggest that elective induction of labor at and after 41 weeks of gestation is associated with a reduced risk of cesarean delivery and meconium. - stained amniotic fluid. There are concerns about the translation of these findings into actual practice; therefore, future studies should examine elective induction of labor in settings where most obstetric care is provided.

title: Systematic Review: Long-Term Effects of False-Positive Mammograms
abstract: BACKGROUND: Although abnormal screening mammograms may adversely affect women's psychological well-being during the period immediately surrounding testing, their long-term effects are not fully understood. OBJECTIVE: To characterize the long-term effects of false positive screening mammograms on behavior DATA SOURCES: English studies to August 2006 from MEDLINE, Web of Science, EMBASE, CINAHL, PsycINFO, and ERIC databases. STUDY SELECTION: the effects of false positive results of routine screening mammography on women's behavior, health, or beliefs. DATA DRAWING: Two researchers independently coded study characteristics, quality, and effect sizes. DATA SYNTHESIS: 23 eligible studies (n = 313.967) were identified. The random effects meta-analysis showed that US women who received false positive results on screening mammography were more likely to return to routine screening than those who received normal results (hazard ratio, 1.07 [95% CI, 1.02 to 1.12]). The effect was not statistically significant among European women (hazard ratio, 0.97 [CI, 0.93 to 1.01]), and Canadian women were less likely to return to routine screening due to false-positive results (hazard ratio, 0.63 [CI, 0.50 to 1.01]). 0.80]). Women with false positive results performed breast self-exams more frequently and had higher but not pathologically elevated levels of distress and anxiety and thought more about breast cancer than with normal results. LIMITATIONS: Relational study designs, small number of studies, lack of clinical validation for many measures, and possible heterogeneity. CONCLUSIONS: Some women with false positive results on mammography may have differences in whether they return for mammography, occurrence of breast self-exams, and anxiety levels when compared. with women with normal results. Future research should examine how false positive results on mammography affect other outcomes such as trust and healthcare use.

title: Systematic Review: The Value of Periodic Health Assessment
abstract: Background: Periodic health assessment (PHE) has been a core part of medical practice for decades, although there is no consensus on its value. As MEDLINE and the Cochrane Library, review of reference lists and hand search of journals up to September 2006. Study Selection: Studies (English only) evaluating the delivery of preventive services, clinical outcomes, and costs between patients receiving PHE and patients receiving PHE. persons receiving ordinary care. Data Extraction: Study design and settings, descriptions of PHE, and clinical outcomes associated with PHE. Data Synthesis: The best available evidence evaluating the benefits or harms of PHE consisted of 21 studies published from 1973 to 2004. PHE had a consistently beneficial association with patients receiving gynecological exams and Papanicolaou smears, cholesterol screening, and stool occult blood tests. ting. PHE also had a beneficial effect on patient “anxiety” in 1 randomized, controlled trial, but had mixed effects on other clinical outcomes and costs. Limitations: The descriptions of PHE and results were heterogeneous. Some trials were conducted before the US Preventive Services Task Force guidelines were issued, limiting their applicability to modern practice. Conclusions: Evidence shows that PHE improves the delivery of some recommended preventive services and can reduce patient anxiety. Although additional research is needed to clarify the long-term benefits, harms, and costs of taking PHE, the evidence of benefits in this study justifies the application of PHE in clinical practice."

title: Systematic reviews that examine the implementation of the research and its impact on population health are needed.
abstract: OBJECTIVES: To examine the research translation phase focus (T1-T4) of systematic reviews published in the Cochrane Database of Systematic Reviews (CDSR) and Database of Abstracts of Reviews of Effects (DARE). Briefly, T1 includes reviews of "basic science experiments"; T2 includes reviews of human trials that led to guideline development; T3 includes reviews that examine how guidelines can be brought into policy and practice; and T4 includes reviews that describe the impact of changing health practices on population outcomes. SETTING: A cross-sectional audit of randomly selected studies from CDSR (n = 500) and DARE (n = 500) was performed. The research translation phase of studies was coded by two investigators according to general and communicable disease, non-communicable disease, and injury subgroups. RESULTS: A total of 898 reviews examined a contagious, non-infectious, or injury-related condition, of which 98% of examinations in CDSR focused on T2 and the remaining 2% on T3. 8.7 focused on T1, 2.5% on T3, and 1.3% on T4: infectious (CDSR 100%, DARE 93%), non-infectious (CDSR 98%, DARE 87%) and injury (CDSR 95%, DARE 88%) Almost all reviews were T2 focused. CONCLUSION: Few reviews exist to guide practitioners and policy makers in implementing evidence-based treatments or programs.

title: Systemic inflammatory rheumatic diseases competency network
abstract: Funded by the "Bundesministerium für Bildung und Forschung" (BMBF) since 1999, the foundation of the rheumatology competence network has succeeded in creating a unique research structure in Germany: medical doctors and scientists from six university rheumatology centers (Berlin, Dusseldorf), Erlangen, Freiburg , Hannover und Lübeck/Bad Bramstedt), at the Deutsches Rheuma-Forschungszentrum (DRFZ), works closely with scientists engaged in basic research with rheumatology hospitals, rehabilitation clinics and rheumatologists. They jointly explore the causes of systemic inflammatory rheumatic diseases and seek to develop treatments with a nationwide and interdisciplinary approach. The main purpose of this collaboration is to transfer new scientific insights faster to develop methods for diagnosis and patient treatment.

title: Systems of care for ST-segment elevation myocardial infarction: a report from the American Heart Association's Mission: Lifeline
abstract: BACKGROUND: National guidelines require participation in systems to rapidly diagnose and treat ST-segment elevation myocardial infarction (STEMI). To characterize STEMI reperfusion systems currently in practice and to identify common applications in system organization, the American Heart Association surveyed existing systems in the United States. METHODS AND RESULTS: A STEMI system was defined as an integrated group of separate entities focused on reperfusion therapy for STEMI within a geographic region that includes at least 1 hospital and at least 1 emergency medical facility performing percutaneous coronary intervention. Systems meeting this definition were invited to participate in a 42-question survey based on expert panel opinion and knowledge of existing systems. Data were collected through the American Heart Association Mission: Lifeline website. Between April 2008 and January 2010, 381 unique systems including 899 percutaneous coronary intervention hospitals in 47 states responded to the survey, of which 255 (67%) included urban areas. The predominant sources of funding for STEMI systems were percutaneous coronary intervention hospitals (n = 320, 84%) and/or cardiology practices (n = 88, 23%). Dominant system characteristics identified by the questionnaire included: STEMI patient admission regardless of bed availability at the percutaneous coronary intervention hospital (N = 346, 97%); one-phone activation of the catheterization laboratory (N = 335, 92%); laboratory without emergency physician cardiology consultation activation (N = 318, 87%); data logging engagement (N = 311, 84%);" and prehospital activation of the laboratory with emergency department notification without cardiology notification (N = 297, 78%). The most common barriers to system implementation were hospital (n = 139, 37%) and cardiology group competition (n = 81, 21%) and access and financing of emergency health services (n = 99, 26%). CONCLUSIONS: This survey broadly describes the organizational characteristics of collaborative efforts by hospitals and emergency health services to provide timely reperfusion in the United States. These findings serve as a benchmark for existing systems and should guide healthcare teams in the process of organizing the care of STEMI patients.

title: Specific information fuels patient/physician discussion about colon cancer risk and testing: Cancer Risk Taking System trial
abstract: Evaluate whether custom printouts generated by the Cancer Risk Intake System (CRIS), a touchscreen computer program that collects data from patients and creates printouts for patients and physicians – result in more reported patient-provider discussions about colorectal cancer (CRC). more risk and screening from obtaining non-private information. Physician randomized, cluster-randomized study among 623 patients with data collected via a 2-week follow-up telephone survey and CRIS prior to visit. Patients aged 25-75 years with primary care visits who are eligible but currently not following CRC screening guidelines. Patient-reported discussions with providers about CRC risk and testing. Private recipients were more likely to report patient-physician discussions about personal and familial risk, stool testing, and colonoscopy (all p < 0.05). Custom recipients were more likely to report discussions about: probability of having cancer (+10%)"; family history (+15%); stool test (+9%);" and colonoscopy (+8%) (all p < 0.05). CRIS is a promising strategy to facilitate discussions about testing in primary care settings.

title: Special skills training for practitioners to improve assessment of prognostic factors for persistent and disabling back pain: four quasi-experimental single-subject studies.
abstract: The well-known gap between behavior in guidelines and clinical practice requires effective behavior change interventions. An example illustrating this gap is physiotherapists' under-evaluation of psychosocial prognostic factors (ie yellow flags) in back pain. This study aimed to evaluate a training model by performing a specific skills training intervention for caregivers and examining changes over time in physiotherapists' assessment of prognostic factors in telephone interviews. A quasi-experimental single-subject design was used for 36 weeks, with repeated measurements at baseline, intervention, and post-intervention stages. Four physiotherapists in primary health care recorded a total of 63 interviews with patients. The specific intervention included individual goal setting, skills training, and performance feedback. The primary outcome was the number of prognostic factors evaluated (0-10). Changes were seen in all four participants. The amount of prognostic factors evaluated was between 0 and 2 at baseline and increased to 6 to 10 after intervention. Time spent assessing psychosocial factors increased and time spent discussing biomedical pain symptoms decreased. Knowledge and biopsychosocial attitudes towards back pain were consistent with guidelines when included and did not significantly change during intervention. Self-efficacy for assessment of cognitive and emotional prognostic factors increased during the study phases. The results show that a specific skills training intervention using behavior change techniques such as individual goal setting, skills training, and performance-related feedback is effective in producing changes in certain clinical behaviors in physiotherapists.

title: Targeted intervention programs: establishing a customized practice model to improve the treatment of allergic rhinitis in a managed care population
abstract: OBJECTIVE: To develop an intervention program to improve health outcomes in patients with allergic rhinitis in a managed care setting. STUDY DESIGN: The Departments of Care (EOC) team at Lovelace Health Systems selected allergic rhinitis for an intervention program as it was identified as one of the top 10 reasons for visits to primary care clinics. The intervention program was based on a multidisciplinary team process designed to create a customized provider and patient education program to address inconsistencies or deficiencies in allergic rhinitis treatment. PATIENTS AND METHODS: The EOC team searched the literature and current practices and then identified inconsistencies in diagnostic and treatment patterns. Based on this research, the team developed guidelines and a provider training program. Intervention strategies were structured around decision points in a treatment protocol. More than 500 patients were followed during the allergy season using written and telephone questionnaires, symptom diaries, and encounter data. Measurable outcomes for provider and patient behavior were determined. Patient outcomes were derived from an index of preventive behavior and administrative data reporting the use of 5 drug classes. RESULTS: Approximately 50% of providers changed their delivery model as a result of the intervention program. Patient outcomes showed a decrease in the use of rescue medications, particularly antibiotics, and an increase in preventive measures in the treatment group compared to the control group. CONCLUSION: The EOC model resulted in positive changes in provider and patient behavior. The multidisciplinary approach resulted in broad provider engagement.

title: Targeting cognitive deficits in schizophrenia: reviewing the development of a new class of drugs from the perspective of community mental health researchers.
abstract: INTRODUCTION: Schizophrenia is a chronic disease associated with positive and negative symptoms and widespread deficits in neurocognitive functions. Neurocognitive deficits are considered the main pathophysiological symptoms of the disease. Neurocognitive deficits are also closely related to functional outcomes. Currently, cognitive deficits remain one of the most important unmet therapeutic needs in schizophrenia. AREAS COVERED: Neuroscientific discoveries over the past decades have enriched our understanding of the neurobiological mechanism underlying cognitive deficits in schizophrenia. This research has identified novel molecular mechanisms and processes as promising pharmacological targets. However, despite intensive efforts to develop a new class of cognitive-enhancing drugs for the treatment of schizophrenia over the past 5 years, no new pharmacological agents have received the necessary regulatory approvals by the Food and Drug Administration. Efficacy and safety results from selective Phase II clinical studies were reviewed. EXPERT OPINION: Current guidelines for the evolving concept of neurocognition and the design and methodology of clinical trials of cognitive-enhancing drugs for the treatment of patients with schizophrenia are being critically reviewed. Future directions in the development of cognitive-enhancing drugs for the treatment of schizophrenia are discussed from the perspective of clinicians and researchers from community mental health settings.

title: Task force VI: Self-monitoring of blood pressure
abstract: BACKGROUND: It has become increasingly common in recent years for patients to self-monitor blood pressure at home or in other non-clinical settings. This phenomenon has been fueled, in part, by the increased availability of automatic sphygmomanometers, which are now both affordable and easy to use for patients. BENEFITS OF SELF MONITORING: Self-monitoring of blood pressure can be an important aid in the management of hypertension. The technique allows patients to become more involved in their care. Self-measured blood pressure values are more likely to represent mean daily blood pressure than clinical measurement and may be better associated with target organ hypertensive involvement and cardiovascular morbidity than clinical blood pressure. Finally, blood pressure self-monitoring has the potential to reduce the costs of hypertension-related care. LIMITATIONS OF SELF MONITORING: There are several issues that prevent the more widespread use of blood pressure self-monitoring in clinical practice. Devices originally marketed for use by patients were technically advanced in the 1990s, but most have not undergone rigorous clinical validation for accuracy and reliability (for example, in terms of Medical Instrumentation Association and British Hypertension Society guidelines). It is recommended that devices used by patients to measure blood pressure at home undergo the same validation processes as those applied to ambulatory recordings. Second, while the upper limits of normal for self-monitoring blood pressure in a general population can be defined statistically (approximately 135/85 mmHg), it is not yet possible to determine normal self-monitoring blood pressure because these values are mandatory. should be linked to classic clinical cardiovascular endpoints or outcomes. Third, associations between self-monitored, clinical, and ambulatory blood pressures have been described for some populations, but their behavior by age, gender, ethnicity, and treatment status requires further study. Fourth, several different programs have been used to self-monitor patients' blood pressure in clinical research and practice. When patients self-monitor blood pressure, it will be necessary to determine the number of records required and the optimal schedule. Fifth, self-monitoring of blood pressure is certainly possible in clinical trials of antihypertensive treatments, but is typically not included in their design by either researchers or pharmaceutical sponsors. Sixth, there is data showing that self-monitoring of blood pressure reduces the overall costs associated with hypertension care on an annual basis. However, as most studies on the economic impact of blood pressure self-monitoring have been conducted in managed care settings in the USA, it is unknown whether this reduction in healthcare costs will apply to other types of practice settings. on a worldwide basis. CONCLUSIONS: Self-monitoring of blood pressure is currently useful as an adjunctive measure in the management of hypertensive patients and may benefit clinical trials of antihypertensive therapy. However, the available data on blood pressure self-monitoring are not sufficient justification for clinicians to make primary diagnostic or therapeutic decisions and should not override blood pressure obtained through clinical measurement or outpatient monitoring.

title: Teaching appropriate interactions with pharmaceutical company representatives: the impact of an innovative workshop on student attitudes
abstract: BACKGROUND: Pharmaceutical company representatives (PCRs) influence physicians' prescribing habits and professional behavior. However, the skills to interact with PCRs are not taught in traditional medical school curriculum. We examined whether an innovative, mandatory workshop for third-year medical students had immediate effects on knowledge and attitudes regarding interactions with PCRs. METHODS: Questionnaires conducted before and after the workshop intervention asked third-year students (n = 75) for opinions (five-point Likert scale) on the degree of bias in PCR knowledge, the impact of PCRs on prescribing habits, the acceptability of certain gifts, and GPs alike. as well as the educational value of PCR information for students. Two faculty members and a PCR moderated the workshop, which highlighted typical doctor-PCR interactions, the use of samples and gifts, the validity and legal limits of PCR information, and related ethical issues. Roleplaying with PCR has shown appropriate and unsuitable strategies for interacting with PCRs. RESULTS: The majority of third-year students (56%, 42/75) have had more than three personal interviews with a PCR about a drug product since starting medical school. Five percent (4/75) claimed no prior personal experience with PCRs. Most students (57.3%, 43/75) were unaware of current guidelines on PCR interactions. Twenty-eight percent (21/75) of the students thought that none of the aforementioned activities/gifts (lunch access, free stethoscope, textbooks, educational CD-ROMs, sports activities) should be restricted, while 24.0% (8/75) ) said that students should be restricted from only sports activities. The perceived educational value of PCR information for both GPs and students increased from 17.7% to 43.2% (chi-square, p = .0001) and 22.1% to 40.5% (p = .0007) after workshop intervention, respectively. . Student perceptions of the bias of PCR information decreased from 84.1% to 72.9% (p = .065), but the perceived impact on prescribing increased (from 44.2% to 62.1% (p = .02)). RESULTS: Students are exposed to PCRs early in their medical education. A single workshop intervention can affect students' attitudes towards interactions with PCRs. Students were more likely to acknowledge the educational value of PCR interactions and their impact on prescribing after the workshop intervention.

title: Teaching hand washing to hospital health personnel
abstract: Purpose To increase the frequency of handwashing of healthcare personnel. Design A prospective study of hand washing before and after patient contact. Setting up a pediatric intensive care unit in a tertiary hospital. Participants 61 intensive care unit health personnel and visiting health personnel. Interventions A five-stage behavior modification program: (i) four weeks of unobtrusive observation to achieve a basic handwashing rate"; (ii) five weeks of open observation (advance written advice); (iii) performance feedback; (iv) ) all observations and feedback were suspended for seven weeks;" and (v) five weeks of unobtrusive observation to obtain a residual rate. Results 939 patient contacts were observed. Baseline handwashing rates before and after patient contact were 12.4% and 10.6%, respectively. During open observation, the respective rates increased and remained stable at 32.7% and 33.3%, but increased further (to 68.3% and 64.8%) during the performance feedback period. Residual handwashing rates inconspicuously observed seven weeks after cessation of performance feedback were 54.6% before patient contact and 54.9% after patient contact. Results Performance feedback is moderately effective in training hospital health personnel on handwashing.

title: Breaking down the 'complex web' of the impact of policy dialogues: lessons from a dialogue case study on health reform options for Canada
abstract: Background The knowledge exchange literature suggests that policy dialogues aim to develop the short-, medium- and long-term capacities of individuals, organizations, and health systems to use evidence to inform policy-making. Key features of effective dialogues have been proposed, but the links between these features and the realization of enhanced capacities for evidence-based policy-making among dialogue participants and the subsequent impact on policy-making activities are not well understood. Methods In 2011, we conducted a series of qualitative case studies in Canada on health financing and financing-related issues, consisting of a series of four policy dialogues that brought together national, regional and regional stakeholders. Data sources included videos of participant perspectives captured during or immediately after each. Event and follow-up key informative talks between dialogue participants in 2015, 4 years later. The three conceptual frameworks for (i) policy dialogues and capacities for use of evidence, (ii) factors that shape policy making throughout the policy cycle, and (iii) the factors that shape the application of evidence guided the thematic analysis. We then synthesized the findings in three frameworks. Conclusions The results show that the potential benefits of policy dialogues described in the literature are developed among the participants in these dialogues. The informants explained how the features of dialogue during the agenda-setting and policy-making stages of policy-making affect their capacity to use evidence, ideas, interests and institutions, and how policy options for implementation are affected by characteristics of individuals, organizations, the external environment. and processes. Conclusions We present a conceptual framework that enhances our understanding of the potential impact of policy dialogues on the content and mechanisms of policy development, and illustrates the pathways of impact on various phases of the policy cycle, from agenda setting to formulation and implementation. The Framework highlights important factors to consider in designing and evaluating policy dialogues and supporting post-dialogue information exchange efforts.

title: Teleconference training detailing: diabetes education for primary care physicians
abstract: INTRODUCTION: Formal didactic continuing medical education (CME) is relatively ineffective for changing physician behavior. Diabetes mellitus is an increasingly prevalent disease and interventions are needed to improve adherence to clinical practice guidelines (CPGs). METHODS: A stratified cluster randomized controlled trial design was used to evaluate the effects of a teleconference educational detail (TED) CME on glycemic control (hemoglobin [Hb] A1c) and family physician compliance with national diabetes guidelines. TED used sequential, small-group, case-based education using CPGs delivered by a diabetes specialist. Medical record audit data from baseline to the end of a 12-month post-intervention period were compared for the control and intervention groups. Satisfaction with the intervention was assessed. RESULTS: Sixty-one physicians provided 660 medical records. The intervention did not affect the mean Hb A1c levels, but significantly changed the distribution of patients by glycemic control category (p = .04), less in the intervention group in the inadequate control (15.8% vs. 23.9%). More patients in the intervention group received insulin (alone or with oral agents) (12.0% vs. 21.2%, p = .03), and more patients in the control group only received oral agents (82.9% vs. 82.9%, p = .3). 005) . More patients in the intervention group had body mass index (7.8% vs 1.9%, p < .02), eye examination (12.1% vs. 5.1%, p = .02), and treatment plan (43.5% vs. 23.6%). , p = .01) and used a flowchart (14.6% vs. 7.7%, p < .03). Despite general satisfaction with the teleconference format, specialist educators found the format more challenging than family physicians. CONCLUSION: Teleconferencing CME was feasible, well attended, well received by participants, and improved some key diabetes management practices and outcomes.

title: Telehealth for patients at high risk of cardiovascular disease: a pragmatic randomized controlled trial
abstract: PURPOSE Â To assess whether non-clinical staff can effectively manage people at high risk of cardiovascular disease using digital health technologies. DESIGN Â Pragmatic, multicenter, randomized controlled trial. SETTING Â 42 common practices in three UK regions. PARTICIPANTS Between December 3, 2012 and July 23, 2013, 641 adults aged 40 to 74 years with a 10-year risk of cardiovascular disease of 20% or greater, no previous cardiovascular event, and at least one modifiable risk factor (systolic blood pressure) were recruited. ¢â€°Â¥140 mm Hg, body mass index â€°Â¥30, currently smoking) and access to phone, internet and e-mail. Participants were individually divided into intervention (n=325) or control (n=316) groups using automated randomization classified by site, minimized by practice and baseline risk score. INTERVENTIONS - The response is the Healthlines service (besides usual care), which consists of scripts generated by interactive software followed by regular phone calls from trained lay healthcare professionals. Counselors facilitated self-management by encouraging participants to use online resources to reduce risk factors, and sought to optimize drug use, improve adherence to treatment, and promote healthier lifestyles. The control group consisted of usual care only. MAIN OUTCOME MEASURES Â The primary outcome was the proportion of participants who responded to treatment after 12 months, defined as maintaining or reducing their cardiovascular risk. Results were collected at six and 12 months after randomization and analyzed masked. Participants were not masked. RESULTS 50% (148/295) of participants in the intervention group responded to treatment (adjusted odds ratio 1.3, 95% confidence interval 1.0 to 1.9"; number required to treat=13), compared to 43% (124/291) in the control group; possibly a random difference (P=0.08) Intervention was associated with reductions in blood pressure (difference in mean systolic -2.7 mm Hg (95% confidence interval -4.7 to -0.6 mm Hg), mean diastolic -2.8 (-4.0 to -1.6 mm Hg) Hg);" weight -1.0 kg (-1.8 to -0.3 kg) and body mass index -0.4 (-0.6 to -0.1) but not cholesterol -0.1 (-0.2 to 0.0), smoking status (adjusted odds ratio) 0.4, 0.2 to 1.0, or overall cardiovascular risk as a continuous measure (-0.4, -1.2 to 0.3) Intervention, diet, physical activity, adherence to medication and access to care, received associated with satisfaction in coordinating treatment and care. A relevant serious adverse event occurred when a participant was hospitalized with low blood pressure. CONCLUSIONS Â This evidence-based treatment The lehealth approach was associated with small clinical benefits for a small number of people at high cardiovascular risk and no overall improvement in average risk. However, the Healthlines service was associated with improvements in some risky behaviors and perceptions of access to support and care. Trial registration - Current Controlled Trials ISRCTN 27508731.

title: Telephone Care Management to Increase Cancer Screening in Low-Income Women
abstract: Background Minority and low-income women receive fewer cancer screenings than other women. Purpose To evaluate the effect of a telephone support intervention to increase screening rates for breast, cervical, and colorectal cancer among minority and low-income women. Design Randomized, controlled trial conducted between November 2001 and April 2004. Identification of community and immigrant health centers in New York City11. Patients, 1413 women overdue for cancer screening. Women over 18 months assigned to the intervention intervention group received an average of 4 calls from preventive care managers and women assigned to clinics. control group received usual care. Follow-up data were available for 99% of women and 91% of the intervention group received at least 1 call.
