Measurements Medical record documents of mammography, Papanicolaou test, and colorectal cancer screening according to US Preventive Services Task Force recommendations. Results "women with mammography increased from 0.58 to 0.68 with the intervention and decreased from 0.60 to 0.58 with usual care"; the proportion of those who had the Papanicolaou test increased from 0.71 to 0.78 with the intervention increased and did not change with usual care, and the proportion of those undergoing colorectal screening increased from 0.39 to 0.63 with intervention and from 0.39 to 0.50 with usual care. The difference in screening rates between groups was 0.12 (95% CI, 0.06 to 0.19) for mammography , was 0.07 (CI, 0.01 to 0.12) for the Papanicolaou test and 0.13 (CI, 0.07 to 0.19) for colorectal screening.With the intervention, the proportion of women up-to-date for the 3 tests increased from 0.21 to 0.43. and had access to a regular source of care.Medical records may not have caught all cancer screenings.ConclusionsPhone support can improve cancer screening rates among women visiting community and migrant health centers.The intervention helps health plans, large medical groups, and increasing cancer screening rates It seems well-suited to children and other organizations trying to address inequalities in care.

title: Telephone screening for depressed workers, outreach and care management, and its impact on clinical and work productivity outcomes: a randomized controlled trial.
abstract: Context Although treatment for depression in line with the guidelines is clearly effective, treatment often lags behind evidence-based recommendations. Organized depression care programs significantly improve the quality of treatment, but employer recipients have been slow to adopt these programs based on a lack of evidence of cost-effectiveness from their perspective. Purpose Evaluating the effects of a depression outreach program on workplace outcomes is of concern to employers. Design, Environment, and Participants A randomized controlled trial involving 604 employees under a managed behavioral health plan was identified as having significant depression in a 2-stage screening process. Patient treatment allocation was concealed and assessments of depression severity and work performance were blinded at 6 and 12 months. Employees with lifetime bipolar disorder, substance disorder, recent mental health specialist care, or suicidal tendencies were excluded from the study. The Intervention Telephone assistance and care management program encouraged employees to seek outpatient treatment (psychotherapy and/or antidepressant medication), monitored the continuity of treatment quality, and sought to improve treatment by advising providers. A structured telephone cognitive behavioral psychotherapy was offered to participants who did not want to undergo treatment. Main Outcome Measures Depression severity (Quick Inventory of Depressive Symptomology, QIDS) and job performance (World Health Organization Health and Productivity Questionnaire [HPQ] is a validated self-report tool that assesses retention, time off work, job performance, and critical workplace events) . Results Combining data at 6- and 12-month evaluations, the intervention group had significantly lower QIDS self-report scores (relative probability of improvement, 1.4"; 95% confidence interval, 1.1-2.0; P = .009), significantly higher job retention (relative ratios, 1.7; 95% confidence interval, 1.1-3.3; P = .02) and significantly more hours of work (ÃŸ=2.0; P=.02;"2 weeks of work equivalent to one year's impact) between intervention more than usual care groups. Results A systematic program to identify depression and promote effective treatment significantly improves not only clinical outcomes but also workplace outcomes. The financial value of the latter for employers in terms of recovered hiring, training and salary costs suggests that many employers will experience a positive return on investment from benefits and better treatment of depressed workers.

title: Telephone Collaborative Care for Post-CABG Depression Treatment
abstract: Context Depressive symptoms often follow coronary artery bypass graft (CABG) surgery and are associated with less favorable clinical outcomes. Purpose To test the efficacy of telephone collaborative care for post-CABG depression versus usual physician care. Design, Environment, and Participants Single-blind efficacy trial at 7 university and community hospitals in or near Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania. Participants were 302 post-CABG patients with depression (150, intervention"; 152, usual care) and a comparison group of 151 randomly sampled post-CABG patients without depression recruited between March 2004 and September 2007 and treated as outpatients through June 2008. Intervention. Collaborative care by telephone, provided by nurses who worked with patients' primary care physicians and was supervised by a psychiatrist and primary care physician from this study. 36 MCS) at 8-month follow-up; secondary outcome measures included assessment of mood symptoms (Hamilton Depression Rating Scale [HRS-D]), physical HRQL (SF-36 PCS) and functional status (Duke Activity Status Index [DASI]), and hospital readmissions Results Intervention patients reported greater improvement in mental HRQL (all P = .02) (SF-36 MCS: ?, 3.2 points; 95% confidence interval [CI], 0.5-6.0), physical function (DASI: ?, 4.6 points; 95% CI, 1.9-7.3) and mood symptoms (HRS-D: ?, 3.1 points; 95% CI, 1.3-4.9); and from normal care patients (P < .001). Men with depression were likely to particularly benefit from the intervention (SF-36 MCS: ?, 5.7 points; 95% CI, 2.2-9.2;" P = .001). However, the mean HRQL and physical functioning of intervention patients did not benefit. Reaches that of the comparison group Outcome Compared with usual care, joint care by telephone for the treatment of depression after CABG resulted in improvement in HRQL, physical functioning, and mood symptoms at 8-month follow-up.

title: Telepractice in the evaluation and treatment of individuals with autism spectrum disorders: A systematic review.
abstract: OBJECTIVE: Studies involving the use of telepractice in service delivery to individuals with autism spectrum disorder (ASD) were reviewed to inform the practice and to identify future research areas. METHODS: Systematic searches of electronic databases, reference lists, and journals identified eight studies that met predetermined inclusion criteria. These studies were analyzed and summarized in terms of (a) the characteristics of the participants, (b) the technology used, (c) the services provided through telepractice, (d) the research methodology, and (e) the results of the study. RESULTS: Telepractice has been used by university-based researchers, behavior analysts, psychiatrists, and psychologists to assist caregivers and educators in the delivery of services to 46 participants with ASD. Services offered included behavioral and diagnostic assessments, educational counseling, guidance and supervision of behavioral interventions, and coaching/education in the implementation of a comprehensive early intervention program. CONCLUSIONS: The results show that telepractice is a promising service delivery approach that warrants additional research in the treatment of individuals with ASD. Directions for practitioners and possible directions for future research are discussed.

title: Test ordering guidelines can change ordering patterns in an academic emergency room
abstract: An observational, pre- and post-study was conducted at a university tertiary referral center and Emergency Medicine (EM) residence to determine the impact of an educational program designed to change test sequencing behavior in an academic Emergency Department (ED). Test sequencing standards were developed by EM faculty, RNs, and NPs based on group consensus and published data. The standards were issued to all emergency room personnel from February 1996 and were included in the evidence-based medical orientation and training program for all residents and medical students prior to the start of rotation. No restrictions were placed on the actual test order. The number of laboratory tests (total and individual) ordered per 100 patients decreased significantly after the training program for total testing, complete blood count, and liver function testing (LFT) began. In addition, decreases in individual months were statistically significant for these tests. Prothrombin time and blood culture testing did not show a significant decrease in test sequencing frequency. The chemistry test sequencing frequency showed statistically significant increases. Overall, around $50,000 was saved by reducing the test order. Test sequencing behavior can be modified by a training program and can have sustainable and significant economic implications.

title: Testimony of LeRoy Walters

Testing the effectiveness of an innovative pack of information on practitioner-reported behaviors and beliefs: UK Chiropractors, Osteopaths and Musculoskeletal Physiotherapists Low back pain Management (COMPLETE) trial [ISRCTN77245761]
abstract: BACKGROUND: Low back pain (LBP) is a common and costly problem. Interventions designed to assist practitioner and patient decisions about appropriate health care for LBP include printed evidence-based clinical guidelines. Three professional groups of chiropractic, osteopathy and musculoskeletal physiotherapy in the UK share common ground with their approach to managing LBP and are among those targeted by the LBP guidelines. Even so, many seem unaware of the existence of such guidelines. Also, the behavior of at least some of these practitioners differs from those recommended in this guide. Few randomized controlled trials evaluating printed information as an intervention to change practitioner behavior have used a no-intervention control. All these trials used a cluster design, and most have methodological flaws. None specifically focus on practitioner behavior towards LBP patients. Studies investigating other strategies to change practitioner behavior with LBP patients have yielded conflicting results. Although a large number of LBP guidelines have been developed around the world, there is little data on whether their dissemination actually changes practitioner behavior. Sending printed information to large numbers of practitioners is an attractive dissemination and implementation strategy, primarily because of its low unit cost. The effect size of such a strategy at the individual practitioner level is likely to be small. However, if large numbers of practitioners are targeted, this strategy can yield meaningful population-level changes. METHODS: The primary aim of this prospective, pragmatic randomized controlled trial was to test the short-term efficacy (six months following the intervention) of a directly published information pack on the UK's reported clinical behavior (primary outcome), attitudes and beliefs. chiropractors, osteopaths and musculoskeletal physiotherapists. We tried to randomly allocate a pooled sample of 1,800 consenting practitioners to receive the information packet (response arm) or to receive no information obtained above during normal practice (control arm). We collected survey data at baseline and six months after intervention. Analysis of the primary outcome will evaluate for cross-arm differences in the proportions of responses to questions regarding recommendations for activity, work, and bed rest that fall into the categories previously defined by an expert consensus study as "consistent with guideline" and "guideline". -inconsistent'.

title: Testing the application of clinical guidelines
Texas Child Drug Algorithm Project: Update from the Texas Consensus Conference Panel on Medication for Childhood Major Depressive Disorder
abstract: OBJECTIVE: To review and update consensus guidelines for drug therapy algorithms for childhood major depressive disorder based on new scientific evidence and expert clinical consensus in the absence of evidence. METHOD: A consensus conference was held on 13-14 January 2005 involving academic clinicians and researchers, practitioner clinicians, administrators, consumers and families. The focus was to review, update and include the most recent data to inform and recommend specific pharmacological approaches and clinical guidance for the treatment of major depressive disorder in children and adolescents. RESULTS: Updated drug algorithms for major depression (with and without psychosis) and comorbid attention deficit disorders, with consensus. These revised algorithms also included approaches that address suicide, aggression, and irritability. Phases 1, 2 and 3 of the algorithm consist of selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor and norepinephrine serotonin reuptake inhibitor drugs, the use of which is controlled by acute clinical studies and clinical experience. Recent studies support that selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors in addition to fluoxetine are still promoted as first-line interventions. Emphasis is placed on the need for additional assessments, precautions and monitoring as well as continuation and maintenance therapy. CONCLUSIONS: Evidence and expert clinical consensus support the use of selected antidepressants in the treatment of depression in youth. The use of recommended antidepressant medications requires appropriate monitoring of suicidality and possible adverse effects, and consideration of other evidence-based treatment alternatives such as cognitive behavioral therapies.

title: ACC/AHA 2013 guideline on the treatment of blood cholesterol to reduce the risk of atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease in adults: good, bad and uncertain: a comparison with ESC/EAS guidelines 2011 for the management of dyslipidemias
abstract: Atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease is the most important public health problem of our time, both in Europe and the rest of the world, and is the largest expenditure in most healthcare budgets. It is the task of various guiding committees around the world to ensure consistency of clinical care, to incorporate new evidence and its synthesis into practical recommendations for clinicians. Therefore, any change in a set of guidelines can have far-reaching consequences, especially if they differ from existing guidelines. This article discusses the latest American College of Cardiology (ACC)/American Heart Association (AHA) guidelines on blood cholesterol control to reduce the risk of atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease in adults. Compared to the 2011 ESC/EAS guidelines on lipid modification, the 2013 ACC/AHA guidelines differ significantly. Specifically, (i) coverage is limited to only randomized studies that exclude a substantial amount of data and mainly support a statin-centered approach only”; (ii) favor abolition of low-density lipoprotein cholesterol (LDL-C) targets 30% in LDL-C We believe that specific statin regimens that provide a reduction of -50% will confuse many physicians and miss the opportunity for adherence and patient engagement in self-administration; (iii) target LDL-C levels not too high High-risk patients with high absolute risk or residual risk factors; will encourage clinicians to consider the addition of lipid modification therapies and to individualize patient care; (iv) a reduction in the treatment threshold in primary prevention will result in more patients being ill. prescription statin therapy that will result in a prescribing recommendation; and (v) primary pre- The mixed pool risk calculator used to assess CVD risk in treatment guidelines has not been fully evaluated. This article discusses the potential implications of adopting ACC/AHA guidelines on patient care in Europe and beyond, and concludes with the view that the ESC/EAS guidelines from 2011 are the most comprehensive, pragmatic and appropriate choice for European countries.

title: aggressive boy
abstract: The acute assessment and management of an aggressive or violent child or adolescent is a challenge for clinicians. Early recognition of signs of impending violence and a clear understanding of the progression of violent behavior are crucial to ensuring the safety of patients and staff. Management of violent and aggressive patients using behavioral interventions tailored to the stage of violence or aggression is critical to reduce the likelihood of the child or adolescent attacking staff or harming themselves or others. Indications and risks of chemical and physical restrictions and hospital standards and guidelines governing the use of behavior and experience regarding prevalence, presentation and differential diagnosis of psychotic disorders in children. The clinician must quickly distinguish which elements of the clinical presentation represent actual psychotic thought processes versus those that represent misunderstood developmentally relevant phenomena, symptoms of non-psychotic disorders, or precursors of an underlying primary medical illness. A thorough evaluation is necessary before appropriate treatment can be initiated.

title: AHCPR guidelines for heart failure: comparison of family medicine and internal medicine practice with guidelines and an educational intervention to change behavior
abstract: OBJECTIVES: The objectives of this study were to apply the Health Services Policy and Research Agency (AHCPR) guideline for heart failure to the measurement of outpatient quality of care, to compare the results of the two major applications, and to design a training design. intervention for the two applications under review. METHODS: A retrospective chart review was performed on a random sample of 50 patients with heart failure selected from each of the two outpatient practices, the general internal medicine practice and the family practice practice, at a large academic medical center. Five medical review criteria were developed from the AHCPR heart failure guideline to compare the two practices with each other and with the guidelines. An educational intervention has been developed to change physician behavior for compliance with guidelines. RESULTS: Evaluation of left ventricular function occurred in 79% of all cases. 68% of eligible patients were treated with angiotensin converting enzyme inhibitors (ACE-Is). 30% and 12% of patients treated with enalapril and captopril, respectively, were receiving the target dose as defined in the AHCPR guidelines. None of the patients who were ineligible for treatment with ACE-Is were treated with hydralazine and nitrates. When ejection fraction was less than or equal to 40%, 81% of eligible patients were treated with ACE-Is, while 59% were treated with ACE-Is when ejection fraction was greater than 40%. Calcium channel blockers were used in the treatment of 42% of the patients. A statistical difference (P = .05) was found between the two applications for documentation of left ventricular function, the use of ACE-I in patients with an ejection fraction of 40% or less, and the use of calcium channel blockers and beta. blockers. CONCLUSIONS: In the practices reviewed, there was insufficient use of documentation of left ventricular function, ACE-Is in eligible patients, target doses of ACE-Is, and hydralazine and nitrate use in unsuitable patients. A higher proportion of patients receive ACE-I therapy when the ejection fraction is less than or equal to 40%. Some patients may have inappropriate use of calcium channel blockers. There are unexplained clinical differences between the two practices studied.

title: The altruistic medical researcher: gone and forgotten?
abstract: With increasing economic, political, and bureaucratic participation in research, little focus is placed on the idealistic and benevolent intentions of the medical researcher. Charity is a pillar of ethical human-subject research, and altruism is a form of philanthropy that is difficult to measure. It is an interest in the welfare of others without self-interest. This article examines the dimension of altruism in medical research from philosophical, psychological, and practical perspectives. With the advent of experimental human trials in the first half of the century, the reputation and recognition of doctors greatly hampered altruistic motivation. Philosophically, altruism is at best an optional moral principle. Ethical rules are not clear. In the scientific process, altruism can only exist in ethical and properly designed research. Egoism, scientific misconduct, and conflicts of interest undermine it";" but altruism is also a potential solution to these problems. Research is not globally focused and has an unequal distribution. In an evolutionary model, especially in the economic environment of today's science, altruism cannot evolve due to a lack of reward and feedback. Anonymity is decreasing, selfishness is increasing. Research has become an industry, and virtuous ideals are a romantic concept. If we use altruism as an indicator, its rarity and fragility indicate the unhealthy state of research.

title: American Society of Clinical Psychopharmacology Study of Practice Patterns of Psychopharmacologists for the Treatment of Mood Disorders
abstract: BACKGROUND: Optimal sequential treatment decisions after initial drug unresponsiveness in major depressive disorder or bipolar disorder are not well established. While practice guidelines offer expert consensus-based treatment recommendations, little is known about the "real world" pharmacology decisions that practice psychopharmacologists. MATERIALS AND METHODS: We searched the national affiliation of the American Society for Clinical Psychopharmacology (ASCP) via the Internet to examine the preferred pharmacotherapy strategies and factors influencing drug choices in patients with mood disorders. RESULTS: Surveys were returned by 154/752 ASCP members (21%). After a lack of response to a serotonin reuptake inhibitor in major depressive disorder, participants equally preferred switching within or between antidepressant classes. After a partial response, supplemental bupropion was the preferred intervention, followed by switching classes of antidepressants. Although moderate or significant efficacy was perceived with olanzapine, aripiprazole, and quetiapine in most cases, atypical antipsychotic augmentation was only considered in line four. Responders preferred to avoid antidepressants in bipolar I patients with mixed/cycle features or previous antidepressant-related mania/hypomania. In rapid cyclers, they advocated discontinuation of the antidepressant and favored the use of atypical antipsychotics and lamotrigine. CONCLUSIONS: Participating psychopharmacologists treating adults with mood disorders report that they prescribe medications that largely reflect the evidence base, with only a few notable exceptions, taking into account the characteristics of identifiable clinical subpopulations.

title: Expected clinical and economic effects of 90-90-90-90 in South Africa
abstract: Background The UNAIDS “90-90-90” global treatment target aims for 73% virological suppression among HIV-infected persons worldwide by 2020. Objective We estimate clinical and economic value, using a microsimulation model of HIV detection, disease, and treatment. Achieving this ambitious goal in South Africa. We Model by Design: Current Velocity strategy, which simulates current scale-up efforts and gradual increases in overall virological suppression from 24% to 36% over 5 years; and UNAIDS Target strategy, 73% suppression simulation over 5 years. Data Sources Published estimates and Southern African survey data show HIV transmission rates (0.16–9.03/100PY), HIV-specific age-classified fertility rates (1.0–9.1/100PY) and costs (ART: $11––“100PY) 31/month, routine care: $20-157/month Target population South Africa HIV-infected population, including case infections in the next ten years Perspective Modified societal perspective, excluding time and productivity costs Time Horizon Five- and ten-year Interventions Aggressive HIV case detection, effective linking to care, rapid treatment scale-up and adherence to UNAIDS Target strategy/containment interventions Outcomes HIV transmissions, deaths, life years saved (YLS), maternal orphans, costs (2014USD) and cost-effectiveness i Comparative Baseline Analysis with Current Above Rate (5-ve) In 10 years, the UNAIDS Target strategy (873,000) will prevent 2,051,000 HIV transmissions, (1,174,000) 2,478,000 deaths and (726,000) 1,689,000 maternal orphans; and (3,002,000) will save 13,340,000 life years. The additional budget required for the UNAIDS Target strategy ($7,965) will be $15,979 billion, with $1,260/YLS per capita ($2,720/YLS) an incremental cost-effectiveness of <20% of South Africa per capita (<50%). rate (ICER). GDP. Results of Sensitivity Analysis Results generally varied <20% from baseline results when we changed key input parameters within reasonable ranges. Limitations The several pathways examined in the sensitivity analysis can lead to an overall 73% suppression. Results Achieving the “90-90-90” HIV suppression target will be costly, but in South Africa it will be both extraordinarily effective and cost-effective. Global health policymakers must mobilize political and economic support to make the 90-90-90 aspiration a reality.

title: Implementation of an occupational health guideline reduces sedentary behavior and increases fruit intake in the workplace: results of an RCT
abstract: OBJECTIVE: To evaluate the effectiveness of a draft occupational health practice guideline aimed at preventing weight gain on outcomes related to employee physical activity, sedentary behavior and dietary behavior, and body weight. METHODS: A randomized controlled trial comparing guideline-based care with usual care among 16 occupational physicians and 523 employees in the Netherlands between 2009 and 2011. Occupational doctors in the intervention group followed the draft guide, advising employers on how to evaluate. intervened in the obesogenic work environment and conducted five face-to-face behavior change counseling sessions with employees to improve their lifestyles. Employees' data were collected through questionnaires and physical measurements at baseline and at 6-month follow-up. Linear and logistic regression analyzes were performed to determine the effects. RESULTS: Intervention on sedentary behavior at work (beta -28 min/day, 95% CI -2 to -54) and fruit intake (beta 2.1 parts/week";" 95% CI 0.6 to 3.6) showed significant effects. No significant intervention effects were found for outcomes related to physical activity, sedentary behavior during leisure or weekend days, snacking, and body weight. CONCLUSION: Guided care increased a more positive sedentary behavior at work and fruit intake, but did not improve employee physical activity, snack intake, or body weight outcomes. Trial registration number ISRCTN/73545254 and NTR/1190.

title: Evaluation of attention deficit/hyperactivity disorder in rural primary care: portability of American Academy of Pediatrics guidelines to the "real world".
abstract: Aim. To examine the implementation of a protocol for the assessment of attention deficit/hyperactivity disorder (ADHD) in rural pediatric practice. The protocol is designed to provide an effective tool for pediatricians to learn and use the ADHD guidelines set forth by the American Academy of Pediatrics (AAP). Methods Primary care personnel (doctors, nurses, etc.) from 2 rural pediatric practices were trained to use the ADHD assessment protocol. Medical records of 101 patients were reviewed 1 to 2 years prior to protocol implementation and for the next 2 to 3 years for 86 patients to assess compliance with AAP guidelines. In addition, 34% of the scales scored by the staff were re-scored to check the scoring accuracy. Results. Prior to the availability of AAP guidelines and implementation of the assessment protocol, no primary care provider was able to consistently collect the comprehensive information currently recommended for an ADHD assessment. Parent and/or teacher rating scales were collected for only 0% to 21% of ratings on sites. Provided brief instruction and supporting materials, medical records reflected a significant improvement in detecting clinically necessary ADHD information, and parent and teacher rating scales deliver 88% to 100% of the time. Staff demonstrated the ability to score rating scales with a high degree of accuracy. The integrity of protocol collection and management was maintained 2 to 3 years after training. Results. An efficient system for conducting ADHD assessments according to AAP guidelines in rural pediatric clinics can be initiated and maintained in integrity. Additional research is needed to determine whether this system improves diagnostic decision making and patient outcomes. Pediatrics 2005";115:e120–e126. URL: www.pediatrics.org/cgi/doi/10.1542/peds.2004-1521;" attention deficit/hyperactivity disorder, assessment, guidelines, pediatric

title: Behavioral Economics of Health and Healthcare
abstract: People often make decisions in healthcare that are not in their best interest, ranging from not signing up for health insurance to which they are entitled, to engaging in highly harmful behavior. Traditional economic theory provides a limited set of tools for improving behavior, as it assumes that people make decisions rationally, have the mental capacity to deal with large amounts of information and choices, and have distinctive tastes and are not open to manipulation. Behavioral economics, which mixes economics with psychology, recognizes that people often do not act rationally in an economic sense. Therefore, it offers a potentially richer set of tools for understanding and influencing behavior than that provided by traditional economic theory. It has only recently been applied to healthcare. This article provides an overview of behavioral economics, reviews some of its contributions, and shows how it can be used in healthcare to improve people's judgment and health.

title: The behavior change wheel: A new method for characterizing and designing behavior change interventions.
abstract: Background Improving the design and implementation of evidence-based practice depends on successful behavior change interventions. This requires an appropriate method to characterize interventions and link them to analysis of targeted behavior. There are numerous behavior change intervention frameworks, but it is not clear how well they serve this purpose. This article evaluates these frameworks and develops and evaluates a new framework aimed at overcoming their limitations. Methods A systematic search of electronic databases and consultation with behavior change experts were used to define frameworks for behavior change interventions. These were evaluated according to three criteria: comprehensiveness, consistency, and a clear link to an inclusive behavior model. A new framework has been developed to meet these criteria. The reliability it can be applied to has been studied in two areas of behavior change: tobacco control and obesity. Results Nineteen frameworks were identified covering nine intervention functions and seven policy categories that could enable these interventions. None of the frameworks reviewed covered all intervention functions or policies, and only a minority met the criteria for consistency or linkage to a behavior model. At the heart of a proposed new framework is a 'behavior system' that includes three key conditions: ability, opportunity and motivation (we call it the 'COM-B system'). This forms the center of a 'behavior modification wheel' (BCW) around which nine intervention functions aimed at addressing shortcomings in one or more of these conditions are 'centred' around which seven policy categories that can make these interventions happen. BCW, UK Department of Health 2010 tobacco was used reliably to characterize interventions covered by the control strategy and the National Institutes of Health and Clinical Excellence's guidance to reduce obesity Results Interventions and policies to change behavior can be usefully characterized through a BCW that includes: intervention functions at the center and then policy Research is needed to determine how far BCW can lead to more efficient design of effective interventions.

title: Black report on socioeconomic disparities in health 10 years later
The Brave Word Project: a system change in primary care to support cardiovascular risk screening
abstract: OBJECTIVES: To develop a set of system changes in primary care to facilitate cardiovascular risk screening of all eligible patients identified according to the current New Zealand Cardiovascular Guidelines (NZGG) and to provide the ability to measure and monitor the clinical management of high-risk patients. METHODS: Various system changes have been developed in primary care practice management software to identify the appropriate patient cohort for cardiovascular risk screening, calculate cardiovascular disease risk (CVR), and extract data for reporting on high-risk status screening results and clinical management indicators. patients. Following the baseline audit, system changes were piloted over 12 months in three general practices with a total enrolled patient population of 30,963. RESULTS: A total of 6570 NZGG eligible patients were identified";" Of these, 20.1% were Maori and 19.7% Pacific people (mostly of Samoan, Tongan, Niuean or Cook Islands descent). Over 12 months, screening rates for cardiovascular risk assessment increased from 4.7% to 53.5% for the cohort. Cardiovascular disease was detected in 482 (13.7%) of the 3516 patients screened. Another 230 (6.5%) had diabetes without CVD and 646 (18.4%) had a 5-year CVD risk > or = to 15%. Of those with CVD, 232 (48.1%) had Management data, 74. 65% and 79% were using aspirin, statins and blood pressure lowering medication, respectively. Fifty-five percent exceeded the low-density lipoprotein (LDL) target of 2.5 mmol/L, 62% had systolic blood pressure (BP) above the 130 mmHg target, 18% were still smokers, and only 9% met all clinical targets recommended in the manual. Management data was available for 347 (53.7%) of 646 with a 5-year CVD risk > or = 15%. Only 34% were prescribed aspirin, 40% were prescribed statins, and 57% were prescribed blood pressure lowering medication. Of this group, 40% had systolic blood pressure >140 mmHg, 36% had LDL >3.5 mmol/L, and only 7% of patients met all guideline clinical targets. CONCLUSIONS: System changes involving this intervention have significantly increased cardiovascular risk assessment rates in primary care and will facilitate appropriate targeting of intensive cardiovascular prevention measures to bridge the observed treatment gap.

title: The challenge of preventive cardiology

The challenge of transferring an implementation strategy from academia to the field: a process evaluation of local quality improvement collaborations in Dutch primary health care using the normalization process theory
abstract: RATIONALE, OBJECTIVES AND OBJECTIVES: A quality improvement strategy consisting of comparative feedback and peer review embedded in existing local quality improvement collaborations has proven effective in changing the test ordering behavior of general practitioners. However, implementing this strategy has been problematic. We targeted large-scale implementation of an adapted strategy that encompasses both test ordering and prescribing performance. The purpose of this study was to identify and analyze the challenges of the transfer process, as we were unable to achieve large-scale implementation. METHODS: In a qualitative study, 19 district health officers, pharmacists, laboratory specialists, and general practitioners were interviewed within 6 months of the transfer period. The interviews were audio-recorded, transcribed and coded independently by two authors. The codes are matched to the dimensions of the normalization process theory. RESULTS: The overall idea of the strategy was broadly supported, but generating the feedback was more complex than expected, and the need for external support after strategy delivery remained high as participants did not assume responsibility for the distribution of work and incoming resources. With this. CONCLUSION: Evidence of effectiveness, a national infrastructure for these collaborations and a generally positive attitude were not sufficient for normalization. When planning complex quality improvement strategies, thinking about managing large databases, responsibility for tasks, and allocation of resources should start as early as possible. It is not enough to simply discover the barriers and facilitators experienced in a previous attempt. While the versatile implementation strategies for changing professional behavior are attractive, their inherent complexity is also a pitfall for large-scale applications.

title: Clinical efficacy and cost-effectiveness of low-intensity psychological interventions for secondary prevention of relapse after depression: a systematic review.
abstract: BACKGROUND: Depression is the most common mental disorder in community settings and is a major cause of disability worldwide. The goal of treatment is to achieve remission, or at least adequate control of depressive symptoms," but even after successful treatment, the risk of relapse after remission is significant. Although the efficacy of low-intensity interventions to treat primary symptoms has been extensively evaluated, the use of these interventions as a relapse prevention strategy OBJECTIVE: To systematically review the clinical effectiveness and cost-effectiveness of low-intensity psychological or psychosocial interventions, as the broader definition of 'low-intensity' psychological intervention has been somewhat contested, the review was conducted in two parts: A, para-professionals, a systematic review of all evaluations of 'low-intensity' interventions performed by peers. Promoters or psychological well-being practitioners to the Improved Access to Psychological Therapies program as defined by; and B, qualified mental health professionals. A coverage review of relevant assessments of interventions involving health professionals (eg, psychiatrists, clinical psychologists, cognitive behavioral therapists) with < 6 hours of contact per patient. DATA SOURCES: Developed extensive literature reviews; electronic databases were searched from inception to September 2010 (including MEDLINE, MEDLINE In-Process & Other Unindexed Citations, PsycINFO, EMBASE, The Cochrane Library), internet resources were used to identify guidelines for the treatment of depression, and related reviews, guidelines, and included studies examined. REVIEW METHODS: Two reviewers independently scanned titles and abstracts; data were extracted independently by one reviewer and checked by another using a standardized data extraction form. Inconsistencies were resolved by consensus, with the involvement of a third reviewer as needed. Inclusion criteria, population - adults or adolescents treated for depression; intervention - Part A, low-intensity interventions, specifically unsupported psychological/psychosocial interventions or supported interventions not involving highly qualified mental health professionals, and Part B, interventions performed by qualified mental health professionals and lasting less than 6 hours per-patient communication; comparator - any including treatment, placebo, psychological or pharmacological interventions; outcomes - relapse or relapse recorded where other outcomes (eg social function, quality of life) were reported; and study design - randomized, semi-randomized, and non-randomized studies with concurrent control patients for clinical efficacy. Full economic evaluations comparing two or more treatment options and considering both costs and outcomes for cost effectiveness. No studies met main part A inclusion criteria. RESULTS: For clinical efficacy review, 17 studies (14 completed, three ongoing) reported in 27 publications met Part B inclusion criteria. These studies were clinically and methodologically diverse and reported varying degrees of efficacy for the interventions evaluated. A randomized controlled trial (RCT) evaluating a collaborative care-type program was potentially relevant to part A; this study reported no difference in depression recurrence over 12 months between patients who received the intervention and those who received normal care. For the cost-effectiveness review, two studies met part B criteria. One of these was an economic assessment of the above RCT, which was potentially relevant to part A. This assessment evaluates the intervention's resources as compared to usual care; however, it was unclear how valid these estimates were for the NHS. LIMITATIONS: While any definition of "short" is likely to be somewhat arbitrary, a touch-inclusion threshold of 6 hours per patient was used to select short high-intensity intervention studies. Most excluded studies explicitly evaluated resource-intensive interventions, but occasional studies were excluded on the basis of only slightly more than 6 hours of contact per patient. CONCLUSIONS: There is insufficient evidence to determine the clinical efficacy or cost-effectiveness of low-intensity interventions to prevent relapse or relapse of depression. A comprehensive review of short-term high-intensity therapies shows that some approaches show promise in some studies, but the findings are inconsistent. Many uncertainties remain and more primary research is needed. The scope of such research should be carefully evaluated; It is important to evaluate the broader patient pathway that takes into account the heterogeneous patient groups of interest. Future RCTs conducted in the UK primary care setting should include adult participants in recovery or recovery from depression and, where appropriate, assess the quality of the intervention and consistency of practice among practitioners. Relapse or occurrence of relapse should be measured using established methods, and functional outcomes as well as symptoms should be measured; Data on quality of life using a general tool such as the "European Quality of Life-5 Dimensions (EQ-5D) FINANCE: National Institute for Health Research Health Technology Assessment program.

title: Clinical Efficiency and Cost-Effectiveness of Screening for Anal Squamous Intraepithelial Lesions in Gay and Bisexual HIV-Positive Men
abstract: Context Gay and bisexual men infected with human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) are at increased risk for human papillomavirus. Objective To estimate the clinical benefits and cost-effectiveness of screening HIV-positive gay and bisexual men for anal squamous intraepithelial lesions (ASIL) and anal SCC. The design Cost-effectiveness analysis was performed from a societal perspective using reference case recommendations from the Health and Medical Cost-Effectiveness Panel. A state transition Markov model was developed to calculate lifetime costs, life expectancy, and quality-adjusted life expectancy against various screening strategies for ASIL and anal SCC using the anal Papanicolaou (Pap) test at different intervals. Values of incidence, progression, and regression of anal neoplasia"; effectiveness of screening and treatment; natural history of HIV; health-related quality of life;" and costs are obtained from the literature. Setting and Participants Hypothetical cohort of gay and bisexual HIV-positive men living in the United States. Key Outcome Measures Life expectancy, quality-adjusted life expectancy, quality-adjusted life expectancy, lifetime costs, and increased cost-effectiveness ratio. Results ASIL screening increased quality-adjusted life expectancy at all stages of HIV disease. Beginning in early HIV disease (CD4 cell count >0.50Â¡ 109/L), screening with anal Pap tests every 2 years resulted in a 2.7-month increase in quality-adjusted life expectancy for an increased cost-effectiveness rate of $13,000. . per life-year adjusted for quality recovered. Screening with annual anal Pap tests provided the added benefit of an incremental cost of $16,600 per recorded quality-adjusted life-year. If screening was not initiated until later in the course of HIV disease (CD4 cell count <0.50Â¡109/L), annual Pap test screening was preferred because of more common anal disease (less cost-effectiveness). More than $25,000 saved per quality-adjusted life-year compared to no screening). Screening every 6 months provided little additional benefit over annual screening. The results were most sensitive to the rate of progression of ASIL to anal SCC and the efficacy of treatment of precancerous lesions. Results Screening HIV-positive gay and bisexual men with anal Pap tests for ASIL and anal SCC offers quality-adjusted life expectancy benefits at a cost comparable to other accepted clinical preventive interventions.

title: Clinician-researcher: inevitable but manageable tension
abstract: The "differential position" argues that clinical research and therapeutic medical practice are sufficiently different activities to require different ethics and principles. Instead, the "location of similarity" argues that clinical researchers should adhere to the same fundamental principles that govern therapeutic medicine, specifically the task of providing optimal therapeutic benefit to each patient or subject. Some proponents of the similarity view argue for this because of the overlap between the role of the attending physician and the role of the researcher in a research trial. This overlap is maximum when the same physician takes on both roles relative to a particular patient-subject. We address the ethical tensions inherent in this role conflict and argue that the tensions are real but manageable. The difference position provides a solid ethical framework for managing these tensions, while the similarity position is unsatisfactory as it tries to deny the existence of tensions.

title: The CLUES trial: a cluster randomized clinical trial to evaluate cardiovascular guideline practice in primary care
abstract: BACKGROUND: Appropriate care for people with cardiovascular risk factors can reduce morbidity and mortality. One strategy to improve the care of these patients includes the application of evidence-based guidelines. To date, very little research has been published on the impact of such implementation strategies in our environment. purposes. To evaluate the efficacy of a multifaceted tailored intervention compared to usual practice in the implementation of three guidelines on cardiovascular risk (hypertension, type 2 diabetes and dyslipidemia) in primary care in Basque Healthcare. METHODS/DESIGN: A two-year cluster randomized clinical trial in primary care in two regions in Basque Healthcare. All primary care units are randomized. Data from all patients with diabetes, hypertension, and susceptible to coronary risk screening will be analyzed. Interventions. The control group will receive standard practice. The experimental group will receive a versatile tailor-made practice strategy, including a dedicated web page and workshops for family physicians and nurses. Endpoints. Primary endpoints: annual demand for glycosylated hemoglobin, baseline laboratory tests for hypertension, cardiovascular risk screening (women 45-74 years and men 40-74 years). Secondary endpoints: other process and clinical guide indicators. ANALYSIS: Data will be extracted from central computerized medical records. ANALYSIS will be carried out at the level of a primary health care unit weighted by cluster size. DISCUSSION: The main contribution of our study is the attempt to identify an effective strategy for cardiovascular guideline implementation in primary care in our setting. TRIAL REGISTRATION: Available Controlled Trials, ISRCTN88876909.

title: Colorado Asthma Toolkit Program: a practice coaching intervention from the High Plains Research Network
abstract: INTRODUCTION: Asthma is often underdiagnosed and undertreated in primary care. The Colorado Asthma Toolkit Program was initiated to create a method for primary care practitioners to (1) provide coaching, education, and support for evidence-based asthma diagnosis and treatment, and (2) improve asthma care so that patients are effectively educated and activated. self-management of diseases. METHODS: Initiated a joint program involving 2 academic medical institutions and the High Plains Research Network, a primary health care-based research network in eastern Colorado. Focus groups were held with rural Colorado patients and health care clinicians to assess need and identify the most effective intervention strategies. Later, two nested training programs or "toolkits" were developed, one for healthcare clinicians and one for patients. Clinicians received 3 coaching sessions conducted by 2 nurses in practice, which included guide-based methods for the assessment and treatment of asthma, coaching to assist practices in the implementation of these methods, and training in communication techniques to promote asthma self-management. Applicants were also given a spirometer and trained in its use and interpretation. Patient self-management toolkits were provided to clinicians trained to use materials to educate patients and increase adherence to treatment. Assessments are based on practice interviews 1 to 3 months after coaching. RESULTS: Coaching took place in 57 of 58 primary care offices in eastern rural and semi-rural Colorado. Practices reported changes in asthma management behaviors: (1) 40.4% of practices increased use of inhaled corticosteroids, the median percentage of patients receiving inhaled corticosteroids increased from 25% to 50%”; (2) 53.2% of practices, increased use of inhaled corticosteroids. use of asthma action plans in which the median percentage of patients with an action plan increased from 0% to 20%;" and (3) 78.7% of applications initiated or increased the use of spirometry, resulting in an increase in median usage from 0% to 30%. CONCLUSION: The Colorado Asthma Toolkit Program has successfully extended asthma care education to most rural health care practices. Acceptance by practices can be attributed to the provision of flexible, in-office coaching and spirometry. Significant changes in asthma management practices are likely to reduce hospitalizations and emergency room visits.

title: Community Physicians Network (CPN): an academic community partnership to address inequalities in healthcare
abstract: INTRODUCTION: Inequalities in healthcare are perpetuated by three main factors: 1) patient factors including multiple risk factors and comorbidities"; 2) healthcare practitioner factors, including inconsistent application of practice guidelines due to a limited clinical trial database of effective treatments in African Americans and insufficiently other underrepresented minorities; and 3) barriers in the healthcare delivery system that result in inadequate access to care.The Morehouse Medical School Community Physicians Network (CPN) was established to address inequalities in healthcare by focusing on provider-specific strategies OBJECTIVES: 1) To identify treatment gaps between CPN practices and use disease-specific registries to facilitate quality improvement processes; 2) develop practice-specific and guideline-based educational messages to promote quality care; 3) involve and train CPN-physicians to: participation in clinical clinical protocols; and 4) develop a repository for all CPN-sponsored clinical trials involving significant numbers of African Americans and other underrepresented minorities. METHODS: Disease-specific outpatient records will have the following characteristics: 1) data structures and data items will use standard database codes and a data dictionary; 2) HIPPA compliant data abstraction and data transfer tool; 3) basic graph review to create application patterns and provide application-specific feedback; 4) annual registration update; 5) data record and repository held on secure servers of Morehouse School of Medicine; 6) record releases will only contain aggregated data without identification of contributing applications; 7) An electronic medical record platform will be promoted as the ultimate data management tool for CPN applications. Additionally, national speakers will take part in up to three continuing medical education (CME) programs each year and will support evidence-based practice guidelines. RESULTS: Eighty-five primary care and subspecialty practices are actively enrolled in CPN with a total of 385,000 annual outpatient visits. Structure of insurance status: HMO/PPO (45%); Medicare only (19%); Medicare HMO (11%); Medicare plus (8%); Medicaid (6%);" Uninsured (11%). RESULTS: The Community Physicians Network will address specific gaps in healthcare for African-American and other minority patients by promoting quality care among its members and facilitating participation in approved clinics. Trial protocols Unique academic community partnership is consistent with the NIH's roadmap goal of eliminating inequalities in healthcare.

title: Compensation for patients injured in clinical trials
abstract: The issue of 'perfect' compensation for patients suffering adverse effects as a result of their participation in clinical trials is discussed in the light of our recent experience in reviewing guidelines and protocols published by the British Pharmaceutical Industry Association (ABPI). submitted to the local ethics of the surgical research subcommittee. We have found several competencies practiced by pharmaceutical companies that do not fit the spirit of the guidelines, let alone the patient's interests, and we propose a way in which patients can be assured that fair treatment will be provided in the "no" situation. fault' injury.

title: Context of Antibiotic Overuse
Cost-Effectiveness and Population Outcomes of Extended HIV Screening and Antiretroviral Therapy in the United States
abstract: History Although recent guidelines call for expanded routine screening for HIV, resources for antiretroviral therapy (ART) are limited and not all eligible people are currently being treated. Purpose To evaluate the effects of extended ART, HIV screening or interventions on the US HIV epidemic to reduce risk behavior. Design dynamic mathematical model and cost-effectiveness analysis of HIV transmission and disease progression. Data Sources Published literature. Target Population High-risk (injection drug users, men who have sex with men) ) and low-risk individuals aged 15 to 64 years at USTime Horizon20 years and lifetimes (costs and QALYs). Perspective Societal. InterventionsExtended HIV screening and counseling, treatment with ART, or both. Individuals adjusted life years (QALYs) and increased cost-effectiveness rates. Results Baseline Case Study Annual screening of high-risk individuals combined with one-time HIV screening of low-risk individuals can prevent 6.7% of the predicted 1.23 million new infections and 20% reduction in sexual activity after screening Assuming that it is, it could cost $22,382/QALY earned. Extending ART use to 75% of eligible individuals prevents 10.3% of infections and costs $20,300/QALY. A combination strategy prevents 17.3% of infections and costs $21,580/QALY achieved. Results Sensitivity Analysis Without reduction in sexual activity, extended screening prevents 3.7% of infections. Earlier initiation of ART when CD4>350 cells/mL prevents 20%Â¨C28% of infections. Additional efforts to halve high-risk behavior can reduce infections by 65%. Limitations Simplified model of disease progression and treatment";" Exclusion of acute HIV screening. Conclusions Concurrent expansion of HIV screening and treatment provides the greatest health benefit and is cost-effective. However, even substantial expansion of HIV screening and treatment programs is not enough to significantly reduce the US HIV epidemic without significant reductions in risk behavior. Primary Source of Funding National Institute of Drug Abuse, United States National Institutes of Health (R-01-DA-15612) and United States Department of Veterans Affairs.

title: Costs, Clinical Benefits, and Cost-Effectiveness of Cervical Cancer Screening in HIV-Infected Women
abstract: Background: HIV-infected women are at higher risk of cervical squamous intraepithelial lesions than non-HIV-infected women, and the optimal regimen for cervical cancer screening in these women is uncertain. Objective: To evaluate net health outcomes, costs, and cost effectiveness of various screening strategies for cervical neoplasia and cancer in HIV-infected women. Design: A cost-effectiveness analysis from a societal perspective using a state transition Markov model. Values of incidence, progression, and regression of cervical neoplasia"; effectiveness of screening and treatment; progression of HIV disease; mortality from HIV infection and cancer; quality of life;" and costs are obtained from the literature. Setting: Clinical practice simulation in the United States. Patients: HIV-infected women representing the US population. Intervention: Six main screening strategies No screening, annual Papanicolaou smear, annual Papanicolaou smear after two negatives Smears taken 6 months apart (recommended by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention), semi-annual Papanicolaou smears, annual colposcopy, and semi-annual colposcopy taken into account. Measures: Quality-adjusted life years (QALYs), lifetime costs, and increased cost-effectiveness. Results: Annual Papanicolaou smear scan at 2.1 months in quality-adjusted life expectancy at an incremental cost of $12800 per QALY saved. It resulted in a profit. After two negative smears taken 6 months apart, annual Papanicolaou smear screening provided an additional 0.04 QALY at a cost of $14800 per QALY saved. The semi-annual Papanicolaou smear scan provided an additional 0.17 QALY at a cost of $27,600 per QALY saved. Annual colposcopy costs more, but offers no added benefit compared to semiannual Papanicolaou smear screening, and semiannual colposcopy has cost more than $375,000 per QALY recorded. The results were most sensitive to the rate of progression of neoplasia to invasive cancer. Conclusions: In HIV-infected women, screening for cervical cancer with annual Papanicolaou smears after two negative smears 6 months apart offers quality-adjusted life expectancy benefits at a cost comparable to: other clinical preventive interventions.

title: Current state of health research and ethics in Sudan
abstract: At the turn of the twentieth century, health research in Sudan developed primarily as a function of colonial British rule. Ethical issues in the medical profession in Sudan are governed by the Sudan Medical Council. To address these issues, the Sudan Medical Council published the Guidelines on Forensic Medicine and Ethics in 1967. This important document focused mainly on ethical issues arising in clinical medicine. It is very difficult to find any reference to research ethics throughout the history of health research in Sudan. However, few attempts have been made to articulate ethics in health research. In 1979, Sudan witnessed the establishment of its first ethics review committee, which was set up on the initiative of a group of doctors and scientists from the national health research laboratory. This committee was neither politically nor institutionally recognized. For this reason, it could not be developed and ended shortly after its beginning. However, in 2000 FMOH established an ethics review committee (ERC). The functions of this committee were to review health research proposals to be conducted in the country for ethical issues, regardless of funding agencies. Unfortunately, the committee devoted all work only to reviewing externally funded health research and research conducted by expatriate researchers or international organisations.

title: Demonstrate a theory-based approach to the design of localized patient safety interventions.
abstract: Background There is evidence of unsafe care in healthcare systems globally. Interventions to implement the proposed practice often have modest and variable effects. Ideally, the selection and adaptation of interventions to local contexts should amplify the effects. However, the means by which this can happen are rarely systematic, theory-based, or made transparent. This study aimed to demonstrate the feasibility, feasibility, and acceptability of a theoretical field framework application (TDFI) approach to co-design patient safety interventions. Methods We worked with three hospitals to support the application of evidence-based guidance to reduce the risk of feeding into misplaced nasogastric feeding tubes. Informed by key principles from TDF and practice literature, our step-by-step process included "involving stakeholders"; identifying target behaviors; identifying local factors (barriers and levers) influencing behavior change using a TDF-based survey; working with stakeholders to create specific local address key barriers Exit interviews and audit data collection were undertaken to assess the feasibility and acceptability of this approach Results Implementation teams for each Trust, following audit and discussion, Use of nasogastric tubes before feeding as the main targeted behavior. showed differences in key barriers between organizations.Focus groups introduced innovations to overcome barriers such as awareness activities, screensavers, equipment changes, and interactive learning resources. The worker created generalizable and adaptive strategies. rcs. Exit interviews identified themes regarding the benefits, challenges, and sustainability of this approach. Time trend control data were collected for 301 patients over an 18-month period for a Trust, suggesting clinically significantly improved use of pH following intervention and documentation of practice. Conclusions TDF is a viable and acceptable framework for guiding the implementation of patient safety interventions. The cascading TDFI approach involves healthcare professionals and facilitates contextualization in identifying target behavior, uncovering local barriers, and choosing strategies to address these barriers. This approach can be beneficial for implementation teams and policy makers, but our promising findings confirm the need for more rigorous evaluation; “A balanced block assessment is currently underway.

title: Design and evaluation of a graphical display for laboratory data
abstract: Purpose Advances in health information technology have provided opportunities to present data in new and more effective ways. In this study, we designed a laboratory display with small, data-intensive graphs called sparklines, which have recently been promoted as effective representations of medical data but have not been well studied. The impact of this new display on physicians' interpretation of data was investigated. Design Twelve physicians spoke aloud as they evaluated laboratory data from four patients in a pediatric intensive care unit using a graphical display and a traditional table display. Measurements Verbalizations were coded based on the abnormal values and trends identified for each laboratory variable. The appropriateness of the interpretations of the variables in each representation was evaluated and patterns were searched among the participants. Evaluation time was also analyzed. Results Physicians completed assessments with the graphical display significantly faster (4.6 versus 4.4 minutes, p=0.042). Compared between screens, 37% of comments did not match. Graphs were more useful when visual cues in tables did not provide trend information, while slightly abnormal values were easier to identify with tables. Results Data presentation format can affect how physicians interpret laboratory data. Graphic displays have many advantages over numerical displays, but they are not always optimal. User, task and data characteristics should be taken into account when designing information screens.

title: Development of an intervention to promote compliance with national guidelines for suspected viral encephalitis
abstract: OBJECTIVE: Central nervous system infections can lead to devastating clinical outcomes if not diagnosed and treated promptly. There is a documented gap between proposed and actual practice and limited understanding of its causes. We identified and explored the causes of this gap, focusing on the most relevant points of change in the patient pathway and the development of a tailored intervention strategy to improve diagnosis and treatment. METHODS: Using theoretically informed semi-structured interviews, we searched for barriers and facilitators to diagnose and manage patients with suspected encephalitis, specifically performing lumbar puncture and initiating antiviral therapy within 6 hours. We deliberately sampled UK hospitals and hospital staff. Before the frame analysis, we audio-recorded and transcribed all interviews. We placed the identified barriers and facilitators on the patient path. We matched behavior change techniques targeting clinicians with the most prominent barriers and facilitators and placed them in an intervention package. RESULTS: We interviewed 43 personnel in six hospitals. Clinical staff expressed uncertainty about when and how to perform lumbar punctures and highlighted the practical difficulties of performing them in busy clinical settings. When the need for treatment was triggered, clinicians often felt they could take appropriate therapeutic action, albeit within organizational and resource constraints. Paired behavior modification techniques largely targeted treatment precursors. These included decision support for rapid recognition and practical support for lumbar punctures, emphasizing the consequences of missed diagnoses for clinicians and patients. We then designed an evidence-based package that included 'essential' interventions and 'optional' interventions to allow local flexibility. CONCLUSIONS: We identified several points in the patient pathway where practice could be improved, the most critical being clinical suspicion and initial investigation. Interventions that targeted professional beliefs and behaviors while optimizing clinical settings were among the most promising approaches to improving the treatment of suspected encephalitis. TRIAL REGISTRATION: Controlled Trials Randomized trial registered with ISRCTN06886935.

title: Development of an intervention to promote compliance with national guidelines for suspected viral encephalitis.
abstract: Background Central nervous system infections can have devastating clinical consequences if not diagnosed and treated promptly. There is a documented gap between proposed and actual practice and limited understanding of its causes. We identified and explored the causes of this gap, focusing on the most relevant points of change in the patient pathway and the development of a tailored intervention strategy to improve diagnosis and treatment. Methods Using theoretically informed semi-structured interviews, we searched for barriers and facilitators to diagnose and manage patients with suspected encephalitis, specifically performing lumbar puncture and initiating antiviral therapy within 6 hours. We deliberately sampled UK hospitals and hospital staff. Before the frame analysis, we audio-recorded and transcribed all interviews. We placed the identified barriers and facilitators on the patient path. We matched behavior change techniques targeting clinicians with the most prominent barriers and facilitators and placed them in an intervention package. Results We interviewed 43 staff members at six hospitals. Clinical staff expressed uncertainty about when and how to perform lumbar punctures and highlighted the practical difficulties of performing them in busy clinical settings. When the need for treatment was triggered, clinicians often felt they could take appropriate therapeutic action, albeit within organizational and resource constraints. Paired behavior modification techniques largely targeted treatment precursors. These included decision support for rapid recognition and practical support for lumbar punctures, emphasizing the consequences of missed diagnoses for clinicians and patients. Next, we designed an evidence-based package that included 'essential' interventions and 'optional' interventions to allow for local flexibility. Conclusions We identified several points in the patient pathway where implementation could be improved, the most critical being clinical suspicion and initial investigation. Interventions that targeted professional beliefs and behaviors while optimizing clinical settings were among the most promising approaches to improving the treatment of suspected encephalitis.

title: Development of evidence-based psychotherapy for use in alcoholism. a review
abstract: The past decades have made tremendous strides in the development and validation of evidence-based approaches to psychotherapy for alcoholism. While psychoanalytic and early behavioral techniques were the original foundation of psychotherapy in this field, evidence-based approaches are now built on the principles of motivational interviewing and cognitive-behavioral therapy. Different techniques have been developed to modify previous and ongoing conditions that favor problem behavior, eg coping/social skills training and the community empowerment approach. According to the results of the MATCH project, one of the largest treatment trials, the "cognitive-behavioral intervention" combines motivational enhancement therapy, the 12-step approach, and cognitive-behavioral therapy to provide new and even more effective psychotherapy. for alcohol dependent patients. These extremely promising developments are surrounded by major problems, as few of the new evidence-based treatment approaches are accepted as standard treatment in Germany, plus only a fraction of all alcohol addicts in the country find their way. Early detection and facilitating access to the various treatment options available may be a future task for GPs as well as for corporate/industrial medical schemes.

title: The dirty dozen: 12 sources of bias with mitigation pathways in forensic neuropsychology.
abstract: The ever-expanding role of the forensic neuropsychologist in civil litigation has rightly led to a higher level of expectation for this specialist in areas such as clinical and courtroom knowledge, objectivity, and work product utility. It is the responsibility of forensic neuropsychologists to ensure that these expectations are met. Recognizing that bias is inherent in clinical and forensic work, in high-risk situations such as forensic neuropsychological assessment, it is imperative that the evaluator be proactively conscientious in recognizing and minimizing the effects of these biases. This article highlights 12 of the many common biases that the prudent forensic neuropsychologist should always consider during evaluation, as well as providing testimony or trial testimony. Role, cognitive, and practice biases are identified and illustrated. Specific recommendations have been drawn from both the empirical literature and forensic experience on how to recognize and reduce these biases. The information contained in this article aims to provide robust and practical strategies that may be useful to forensic neuropsychological practitioners. Lawyers will find the content useful when working with such experts, including preparing for testimony and cross-examination. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2017 APA, all rights reserved)

title: The UK economy-wide impact of pandemic influenza: a computable general equilibrium modeling experiment.
abstract: OBJECTIVES To estimate the potential economic impact of pandemic influenza, associated behavioral responses, school closures and vaccination on the UK. DESIGN Using published data, a computable overall equilibrium model of the UK economy was determined for the various combinations of mortality and morbidity from pandemic influenza, vaccine efficacy, school closures and prophylactic absenteeism. SETTING 2004 UK economy (the most recent available with appropriate economic data). KEY CONSEQUENTIAL MEASURES The economic impact of various scenarios including different pandemic severity, vaccination, school closure and preventive absenteeism in terms of gross domestic product, output from different economic sectors and equivalent variation. RESULTS Disease-related costs alone range from 0.5% to 1.0% of gross domestic product (£8.4bn to £16.8bn) for low-fatality scenarios, and 3.3% to high-fatality scenarios. It ranged from 4.3% (£55.5bn to £72.3bn). and even greater for an extreme epidemic. School closures increase the economic impact, especially for mild outbreaks. If widespread behavior change occurs and there is large-scale prophylactic absence from work, the economic impact will increase significantly with few health benefits. Vaccination with a pre-pandemic vaccine can save 0.13% to 2.3% of gross domestic product (£2.2 billion to £38.6 billion); a single dose of a matched vaccine can save between 0.3% and 2.3% of GDP. could save 4.3% (£5.0 billion to £72.3 billion);" and a two-dose matched vaccine could limit the overall economic impact to around 1% of gross domestic product for all disease scenarios. CONCLUSION Balancing school closures with "business as usual" and maintaining an adequate stock of effective vaccines are more important factors in determining the economic impact of the influenza pandemic than the disease itself. Protective leave from work in response to fear of infection can contribute significantly to the economic impact.

title: EDUCATE Study: An example of continuing education for the Implementation of Clinical Practice Guidelines
abstract: Cancer care is evolving from a stand-alone practitioner care delivery system based on tradition and anecdotal experience to a multidisciplinary, collaborative, science-driven paradigm. Evidence-based practice facilitates optimal quality of care for patients with cancer and influences for medical and nursing practitioners through the application of clinical practice guidelines. Clinician education based on adult learning principles is a method of applying clinical practice guidelines in clinical practice. But research shows that traditional static training methods do little to change behavior";" instead, effective training includes interactive forms, providing feedback, and strategies for reminders and reinforcement. The EDUCATE (Educating Clinicians to Achieve Treatment Guide Effectiveness) Study provides a model for clinical practice guideline implementation using training methods. A faculty of nurse educators, along with champions of practice, conducted an intensive educational intervention consisting of multiple teaching/learning activities over a 12-month period in community oncology practice in the United States. An overview of clinical practice guidelines and training methods that can be used to implement clinical practice guidelines, as well as obstacles encountered and lessons learned through the EDUCATE Study, are presented along with recommendations for practice in the practice setting.

title: The effect of computerized reminder system on the prevention of postoperative venous thromboembolism
abstract: Purpose of the study To measure the effect of a modified care process guided by a computerized reminder system on rates of symptomatic postoperative venous thromboembolism. Design Comparisons of pre-intervention and post-intervention measurements. Establishing a university-affiliated community hospital in Utah. Patients Two thousand and seventy-seven consecutive patients undergoing major operations in four surgical departments between January 1, 1997 and October 31, 1997 (pre-intervention) and 2,093 consecutive patients undergoing the same procedures between January 1, 1998 and October 31, 1998 (post-intervention). Intervention A program to prevent venous thromboembolism developed from the American College of Chest Physicians guidelines and a modified study process guided by a computerized reminder system. Measurements Mortality attributable to symptomatic, objectively confirmed deep vein thrombosis (DVT), pulmonary embolism (PE), and venous thromboembolism occurring within 90 days of surgery. Results Pre-intervention and post-intervention cohorts did not differ in age, disease severity, number of risk factors for venous thromboembolism, or individual risk factors for venous thromboembolism. The overall prophylaxis rate increased from 89.9% before application of the computerized reminder system to 95.0% after application (p < 0.0001). The combined 90-day symptomatic DVT, PE, and mortality rate attributable to PE remained the same (pre-intervention, 1.0%; post-intervention, 1.2%; odds ratio, 1.21; 95% CI, 0.67 to 2.20). Of the 46 venous thromboembolic complications, 40 (87%) occurred despite administration of the American College of Chest Physicians recommended measures to prevent venous thromboembolism. Conclusions Computerized reminder systems combined with modified care procedures increase the rate of prophylaxis against venous thromboembolism without reducing the rate of symptomatic venous thromboembolism when the baseline prophylaxis rate is high. There is a surgical patient population resistant to the prophylactic measures recommended by the American College of Chest Physicians against venous thromboembolism. New strategies are needed to address prophylaxis-resistant venous thromboembolism.

title: The effect of mobile clinical decision support system on obesity and overweight diagnosis in acute and primary care treatment encounters.
abstract: The aim of the study was to compare the proportion of obesity-related diagnoses in clinical encounters (N = 1874) documented by nurses using a personal digital assistant-based diary with and without obesity decision support features. In the randomized controlled trial, experimental group encounters had significantly more (P = .000) obesity-related diagnoses (11.3%) and a significantly lower false-negative rate (24.5%) compared to the control group (1%). against 66.5%, P = .000). The study findings provide evidence that the integration of a decision support feature that automatically calculates an obesity-related diagnosis increases diagnoses and reduces missed diagnoses, suggesting that such systems have the potential to improve the quality of obesity-related care.
