OBESITY AND OVERWEIGHT are challenging public health challenges and are the target of public health prevention goals in the United States.1 Obesity and overweight are underrecognized conditions that cause many obese patients to fail to receive appropriate interventions.2,3 Prevention and management of obesity and overweight weight encompasses a number of complex and dynamic processes4 and the integration of relevant evidence into practice is necessary to improve obesity management.5,6 Clinical practice guidelines can serve as a tool to enable evidence-based practice”; however, few studies with nurses have been conducted and methodological issues have caused the consequences of 7 Although advanced practice nurses have the potential to play important roles in the prevention and management of obesity and overweight, research is needed to explore effective strategies that support their application and therefore the application of the guideline.8 The aim of this study is to introduce personal digital assistant The aim was to compare the proportion of obesity-related diagnoses (obesity and overweight) in documented clinical encounters using predominant clinical judgment. Support system compared to personal digital assistant-based clinical registry without obesity decision support features.

title: Impact of patient-centered care package intervention on pressure ulcer incidence (INTACT): A cluster randomized trial.
abstract: BACKGROUND: Hospital-acquired pressure ulcers are a serious patient safety issue associated with poor patient outcomes and high healthcare costs. They are also seen as an indicator of the quality of nursing care. OBJECTIVE: To evaluate the effectiveness of a pressure ulcer prevention care package in preventing hospital-acquired pressure ulcers in patients at risk. DESIGN: Pragmatic cluster randomized trial. SETTING: Eight tertiary referral hospitals with more than 200 beds each in three Australian states. PARTICIPANTS: 1600 patients (200/hospital) were recruited. Patients: >/=18 years old"; at risk of pressure ulcer due to limited mobility; expected to stay in hospital for >/=48 hours and who can read English. METHODS: Hospitals (clusters) were divided into groups according to their last pressure ulcer rate and within strata randomized to either a pressure ulcer prevention care package or standard care. The care package was theoretically and empirically based on patient engagement and clinical practice guidelines. It was multi-component, contained three messages for patients. participation in pressure ulcer prevention care: keep moving, look after your skin. and eat healthy Educational aids for patients Includes DVD, brochures and posters Nurses in intervention hospitals are trained to collaborate with patients in pressure ulcer prevention care Statisticians, recruiters and outcome evaluators were blind to group breakdown and interventionists to study hypotheses, both at the cluster and patient level tested. vel. The primary outcome, the incidence of hospital-acquired pressure ulcers, was measured by daily skin examination, applied at both the medical and individual participant levels. RESULTS: Four clusters were randomized to each group and 799 patients per group were analyzed. The intraclass correlation coefficient was 0.035. After adjusting for clustering and prespecified covariates (age, pressure ulcer present at baseline, body mass index, reason for admission, place of residence, and number of comorbidities at presentation), the hazard ratio for new pressure ulcers was developed (relative pressure ulcer prevention care package versus standard care). RESULTS: Pressure ulcer prevention care package was associated with a large reduction in the risk of ulceration, although no adverse events or harms were reported. , there was a high degree of uncertainty in this estimate, and the difference was not statistically significant. Possible explanations for this non-significant finding include that the pressure ulcer prevention care package was effective but the sample size was too small to detect it.

title: Effect of adding Pap smear information to a mammography reminder system in an HMO: results of a randomized controlled trial.
abstract: While Background Reminders may promote cancer screening in primary care, little is known about the potential interaction between multiple reminders. Methods: We conducted a randomized controlled trial to compare the effect of Pap smear plus mammogram reminders and mammogram-only reminders among 2471 women aged 40 years and older enrolled in a health care facility serving a predominantly Medicaid-eligible population. Reminders included both a mailed letter for the woman and a medical record request. Results Intervention assignment was not associated with differences in FP or internist visit rates or mammography completion during the study year. Compared with women assigned to mammogram reminder therapy alone, those assigned to the combined Pap smear plus mammogram reminder intervention were more likely to visit a gynecologist (34% versus 29%, adjusted odds ratio = 1.33, 95% CI 1.08–“1.63) and Pap smear (30% vs. 23%, adjusted odds ratio = 1.39, 95% confidence interval 1.07-1.89). Conclusions In the workplace, adding Pap smears to mammography reminders has a procedure-specific effect, increasing nor decreasing gynecology visits and Pap smear use, but neither increasing nor decreasing other primary care visits or mammography. We find no evidence of reinforcement or competition among these reminders.

title: The effect of computer reminders on GPs' prescribing behavior: a cluster randomized trial.
abstract: OBJECTIVE: Despite the development and distribution of guidelines, it is difficult to control drug prescribing behavior in general practice. The aim of this study is to evaluate the effect of applying prescribing guidelines via the reactive computer reminder system (CRS) on drug prescribing behavior. DESIGN: Cluster-randomized controlled trial with incomplete block design in the south of the Netherlands: 25 GPs (7 GP practices) received reminders about antibiotics and asthma/COPD prescriptions, 28 GPs (7 GP practices) received reminders about cholesterol prescriptions. Prescribing instructions are integrated into the computerized GP information system. MEASUREMENTS: Both performance indicators and prescription volumes were calculated as main outcome measures. In addition to individual volume measurements, total scores were generated for volume measurements per drug group (antibiotics, asthma/COPD, and cholesterol). RESULTS: The difference between doctors turned out to be larger and more skewed than expected. No differences were found between groups for indicators and volumes regarding recommendations advocating certain drugs. Although there was a trend towards clinically significant outcomes for prescription volumes that needed to be reduced, the overall score difference between the groups was not significant. For antibiotic prescriptions that needed to be reduced, the overall score for the intervention group was 28.2 (95% CI: 20.8-44.5) prescriptions per 1000 patients per GP versus 39.7 (95% CI: 29.7-64.1) for this control. group (p 0.2). For asthma/COPD prescriptions that needed to be reduced, the overall score for the intervention group was 1.1 prescriptions per 1000 patients per GP (95% CI: 0.6-2.6) versus the control group (p 0.1). Significant differences were found in the three specific recommendations (about quinolones for cystitis, corticosteroids for CPOD, and antibiotics for acute sore throat). CONCLUSIONS: This study turned out to be unsatisfactory due to high inter-physician variability in prescribing behavior. However, computerized reminders sometimes have a positive effect in restricting certain drugs that are no longer indicated or no longer indicated in general practice.

title: The Effect of Educational Intervention on Medical Diagnostic Records of Residents
abstract: INTRODUCTION: Research shows that using interventions, including education, can improve medical record documentation and reduce missing files. As physicians play a crucial role in medical record documentation, the researchers aim to examine the impact of educational intervention on physicians' performance and knowledge of medical diagnostic record principles among residents at Hormozgan University of Medical Sciences (HUMS). METHODS: This quasi-experimental study was conducted on 40 residency students (in internal medicine, obstetrics and gynecology, pediatrics, anesthesiology and surgery) at Hormozgan University of Medical Sciences in 2010. During a workshop, guidelines were taught for recording diagnostic information related to a particular specialization. Five medical records were selected from each resident to evaluate the physicians' performance on chart documentation before and after the intervention. Using a questionnaire, physicians' pre- and post-intervention information was searched. Data were analyzed with one-way ANOVA test. RESULTS: The change in physicians' knowledge before and after education was not statistically significant (p = 0.15). The occupants' behavior did not change statistically significantly over the three phases of the study. CONCLUSION: The diversity of relevant factors contributing to documentation quality necessitates a portfolio of strategies for improving medical charts. A combination of best practice efforts, including educating physicians from the start of the internship and applying targeted strategy to problem areas and existing gaps, can improve physicians' behavior on chart documentation.

title: Impact of external feedback on the management of medicare inpatients with congestive heart failure
abstract: The aim of this study was to compare the effect of 2 feedback strategies on compliance with congestive heart failure (CHF) guidelines. Thirty-two hospitals in 4 states were randomized to receive either a written feedback intervention (low-intensity intervention [LII]) or an intervention that included feedback, physician contact, and quality improvement tools (high-intensity intervention [HII]). CHF quality indicators were evaluated and quality managers were interviewed at baseline and remeasurement. There were no significant changes in quality indicators as a result of both interventions. Seventy-eight percent of quality managers indicated that hospital project implementation did not begin until shortly before re-measurement. HII quality managers perceived the CHF project as significantly more successful than LII quality managers (63% vs 13%, P < .01). Evaluating the effects of external feedback on practice behavior requires sufficient time for organizational and individual clinician change to occur. Physician contacts can play a role in facilitating this change.

title: The effect of mobile phone text message reminders on the compliance of Kenyan healthcare workers with malaria treatment guidelines: a randomized cluster trial.
abstract: Background Health professionals' malaria case management practices often differ from national guidelines. We evaluated whether text message reminders to healthcare workers' mobile phones could improve adherence to treatment guidelines for outpatient pediatric malaria in Kenya. Methods From March 6, 2009 to May 31, 2010, we conducted a cluster randomized controlled trial in 107 rural health facilities in 11 counties in coastal and western Kenya. In a computer-generated sequence, healthcare facilities were randomly assigned to either the intervention group, where all healthcare professionals received text messages to their personal mobile phones in malaria case management for 6 months, or the healthcare worker control group. do not receive any text messages. Although patients were unaware of whether they were at the response or control facility, healthcare workers were not masked to the response. The primary outcome was correct management with artemether-lumefantrine, defined as a dual composite indicator of therapeutic, dispensing and counseling tasks in line with Kenyan national guidelines. The primary analysis was with intent to treat. Trial registered with Current Controlled Trials, ISRCTN72328636. Findings 119 healthcare workers received interventions. Case management practices were evaluated for 2269 children in need of treatment (1157 in the intervention group and 1112 in the control group). Therapeutic analysis showed that correct artemether-lumefantrine administration improved by 23Â·7 percentage points (95% CI 7Â·6–40Â·0"; p=0Â·004) and 24Â·5 percent immediately after intervention. 1â€“41Â·0;" p=0Â·003) 6 months later. Comment In resource-limited settings, malaria control programs should consider the use of text messages to improve case management practices of healthcare professionals.

title: The effect of orthodontic referral guidelines: a randomized controlled trial
abstract: OBJECTIVE: To develop and evaluate the effectiveness of referral guidelines for referral of orthodontic patients to consultant and specialist general practitioner orthodontists. DESIGN: Single center randomized controlled trial in which referral guidelines to general dentists for orthodontic treatment were randomized. SETTING: Hospital orthodontic departments and specialist orthodontic practices in Manchester and Stockport. SUBJECTS: General dentists and patients they refer for orthodontic treatment. MAIN OUTCOME MEASURE: Eligibility of referral, defined as whether the patient is accepted for orthodontic treatment. RESULTS: Redirect directives did not reduce the number of inappropriate redirects. CONCLUSIONS: Referral guidelines for orthodontic referrals did not affect the behavior of general dentists. Further research is needed on the optimum dissemination and implementation of referral guidelines for use in the general dental service.

title: Effect of registry-based performance feedback via short text messages and traditional mail letters on parenteral steroid prescribing by general practitioners - A randomized controlled trial
abstract: Background Providing feedback on physicians' prescribing behavior is predicted to improve the quality of drug prescriptions. However, the effectiveness of providing feedback and the way it provides feedback is not well understood. The aim of this study was to evaluate and compare the impact of traditional paper letters (TPL) and short text message (STM) feedback on the behavior of general practitioners prescribing parenteral steroids (PSs). Methods In a single-blind, randomized controlled trial, 906 general practitioners (GPs) with at least 10 months of prescription were randomly assigned to two interventions and a control study arm, stratified by percentage of prescription, in a 1:1 allocation. The intervention was to provide 3 feedback messages containing prescribing indices in the TPL and STM (first two arms) against the control arm (CG) with a 3-month interval between these messages. We calculated the PS Defined Daily Dose (DDD) for each GP each month and compared between the 3 arms before and after interventions. The primary expected outcome was a reduction in parenteral steroid prescription by participants. The study was conducted at the Kirman Social Security Institution in Iran. Results A total of 906 GPs were selected for the trial, but only 721 (TPL = 191, STM = 228, CG = 302) were recruited for 1st feedback. The average age of general practitioners is 44 and 59% of them are male. The parenteral steroid DDDs prescribed at baseline were similar (TPL = 121.62, STM = 127.49, CG = 115.68, P > 0.5). At the end of the study, DDDs in the TPL and STM arms were similar (TPL = 104.38, STM = 101.90, P > 0.9), but DDDs in each intervention arm were statistically significantly lower than CG (CG = 156.17, P < 0.0001). Being in the TPL and STM arms resulted in a reduction of 36.1 and 41.7 units in DDD compared to the control arm (P < 0.02 and P < 0.005) after one year of the study, respectively. Conclusion Feedback on prescribing performance of TPLs and STMs effectively reduced GPs' prescribing PS. An inexpensive and fast tool, STM is potentially powerful and effective for rationalizing drug prescription.

title: Impact of the Vermont Diabetes Information System on inpatient and emergency room use: results of a randomized trial.
abstract: Objective To describe the impact of the Vermont Diabetes Information System (VDIS) on hospital and emergency room use. Data Source Statewide evacuation database. Study Design Randomized controlled trial of a decision support system for 7412 adults and 64 primary care providers with diabetes. Data Collection/Data Extraction Fees and dates for hospital admission and emergency care in Vermont during a median observation period of 32 months. Data from New York hospitals were not available. Results Patients randomized to VDIS were hospitalized less frequently than control subjects (0.20" vs. 0.17 admissions; P = .01) and generated lower hospital charges ($3113 vs $3480; P = .019). also had lower emergency services (0.36 vs. 0.27 visits; P <0.0001) and fees ($304 vs. $414; “P <0.0001). The intervention was particularly effective in males and older subjects. Conclusions Despite data limitations that tend to reduce the apparent efficacy of the system, this randomized, controlled trial demonstrated that VDIS reduced hospital admissions and emergency room use and expenditure.

title: Efficacy and cost-effectiveness of dark chocolate consumption as prevention therapy in people at high risk of cardiovascular disease: best-case scenario analysis using the Markov model.
abstract: OBJECTIVE To model the long-term efficacy and cost-effectiveness of daily dark chocolate consumption in a population with metabolic syndrome at high risk of cardiovascular disease. DESIGN Best-case scenario analysis using a Markov model. ADJUST Australian Diabetes, Obesity and Lifestyle study. PARTICIPANTS 2013, persons with hypertension who met criteria for metabolic syndrome, had no history of cardiovascular disease, and were not receiving antihypertensive therapy. MAIN OUTCOME MEASURES Treatment effects associated with dark chocolate consumption from published meta-analyses were used to determine the absolute number of cardiovascular events with and without treatment. Costs associated with cardiovascular events and treatments were applied to determine the potential amount of funds required for dark chocolate treatment to be considered cost effective. RESULTS Daily consumption of dark chocolate (polyphenol content equivalent to 100 g dark chocolate) can reduce cardiovascular events by 85 per 10,000 treated subjects over 10 years (95% CI 60 to 105). $40 (£25"; â€šÂ¬31;" $42) per person per year can be spent cost-effectively on prevention strategies using dark chocolate. These results assume 100% compatibility and represent a best-case scenario. CONCLUSIONS The blood pressure and cholesterol lowering effects of dark chocolate consumption are beneficial in preventing cardiovascular events in a population with metabolic syndrome. Daily consumption of dark chocolate may be an effective cardiovascular preventative strategy in this population.

title: Efficacy and cost-effectiveness of lay counselor-provided psychological treatments for harmful and addictive drinking and moderate to severe depression in primary care in India: PREMIUM study protocol for randomized controlled trials.
abstract: OBJECTIVE: The leading mental health causes of the global burden of disease are depression in women and alcohol use disorders in men. The main obstacle to the implementation of evidence-based psychological treatments in primary care in developing countries is the lack of qualified human resources. The purpose of these trials is to evaluate the efficacy and cost-effectiveness of two psychological treatments developed for the treatment of depression and alcohol use disorders in primary care in India. METHODS/DESIGN: This study protocol is for parallel group, randomized controlled trials (Healthy Activity Program for moderate to severe depression, Counseling for Alcohol Problems for harmful and dependent drinking) in eight primary care centers in Goa, India. Adult primary care participants will be screened by the Patient Health Questionnaire for depression and, in males only, the Alcohol Use Disorders Identification Test for alcohol problems. Screen positive participants will be invited to participate"; men who screen positive for both disorders will be invited to participate in the Counseling for Alcohol Problems study. Those who approve will be allocated a 1:1 ratio to receive relevant psychological treatment plus enhanced usual care or primary care only Ordinary care developed by the center and using a computer-generated allocation sequence for depression classified by gender Advanced ordinary care involves the provision of contextualized World Health Organization guidelines and screening results to primary care center physicians for treatments, for a period of up to three months, to the layman. will be given by counselors.Primary outcomes are the severity and remission rates of the disorder at three months after enrollment, and for the Counseling for Alcohol Problems trial, the effect of drinking and drinking on daily life.Secondary outcomes are the severity of the disorder and remission rates at 12 months. Includes disability, disability. scores, suicidal behavior and economic impact, and cost-effectiveness at three and 12 months. 500 participants with depression and 400 participants with harmful smoking will be accepted. Primary analyzes will be for therapeutic purposes. CONCLUSION: These trials may offer a potentially scalable new approach to the treatment of moderate-to-severe depression and alcohol problems in primary care, as they rely on a single pool of lay counsellors. TRIAL REGISTRATION: Both trials are registered with the International Society for the Register of Clinical Trials (Wellness Program registration number ISRCTN95149997; "Counseling for Alcohol Issues registration number ISRCTN76465238).

title: The effectiveness of a published information pack on the beliefs and behavior of musculoskeletal practitioners: UK Chiropractors, Osteopaths and Musculoskeletal Physiotherapists Low Back Pain Management (COMPLETE) randomized trial
abstract: STUDY DESIGN: Randomized controlled trial. OBJECTIVE: To explore the impact of a printed information package on the beliefs and reported behaviors of musculoskeletal practitioners (chiropractors, osteopaths and musculoskeletal physiotherapists) across the UK regarding low back pain (LBP). SUMMARY OF BACKGROUND DATA: A significant proportion of UK musculoskeletal practitioners do not follow current LBP guideline recommendations. METHODS: A total of 1758 practitioners were randomly assigned to one of the 2 study arms. One arm was sent a printed information pack (n = 876) containing guidelines recommendations for the management of LBP, and the other arm received no intervention (n = 882). The primary outcome measure consisted of 3 "quality indicators" (activity, work, and bed rest) related to the sketches of a patient with LBP; here the responses were split into "guide-inconsistent" or "guide-consistent". The secondary outcome was practitioners' beliefs about LBP, as measured using the Healthcare Providers Pain and Disability Association Scale. Results were measured at baseline and at 6 months. RESULTS: The 6-month follow-up was 89%. Changes in behavior reported in the quality indicators were as follows: activity, odds ratio (OR) 1.29 (95% confidence interval, 1.03-1.61) and number to treat (NNT), 19 (15-28)"; work , OR 1.35 (1.07) -1.70) and NNT 19 (14-29) and bed rest, OR 1.31 (0.97-1.76) and NNT 47 (33-103) Consistent behavior in at least 1 of the composite NNT - 3 quality indicators for transition from guideline inconsistent to guideline 10 ( 9-14) Beliefs about LBP were significantly improved in those sent information packets (P = 0.002), but only to a small extent (mean difference), scale score of 0.884;" 95% confidence interval, 0.319-1.448). CONCLUSION: Printed educational material may shift beliefs about LBP and reported behavior of musculoskeletal practitioners towards practice that is more in line with guideline recommendations.

title: The effectiveness of an intervention in increasing the provision of preventive care by community health clinicians: a study protocol of a nonrandomized, multi-base trial.
abstract: BACKGROUND: The primary behavioral risks for the most common causes of mortality and morbidity in developed countries are tobacco use, malnutrition, risky alcohol use, and physical inactivity. Evidence, guidelines and policies support the delivery of routine clinician care to prevent these risks in primary care settings. Despite the potential provided by community health services to provide this type of preventive care, the limited evidence available indicates that it is provided at suboptimal levels. This study aims to evaluate the effectiveness of a very strategic practice change intervention in increasing the clinician's provision of routine preventive care through a community health service network. METHODS/DESIGN: A multiple baseline study will be conducted covering all 56 community health institutions in a single health region in New South Wales, Australia. The facilities will be allocated to one of three administratively defined groups. A 12-month practice change intervention will be implemented at all facilities in each group to facilitate clinician risk assessment of eligible patients and clinicians providing brief advice and referrals to those identified as 'at risk'. The response will be implemented in a non-random order among the three facility groups. Repeated, cross-sectional measurement of the provision of preventive care by the clinician for the four distinct risks (smoking, malnutrition, risky alcohol use, and physical inactivity) will be made continuously for all three facility groups over 54 months via telephone calls. Interviews will be conducted with randomly selected clients who have visited a community health facility in the past two weeks. Data collection will begin 12 months before the intervention was administered in the first group and will continue for six months following the completion of the intervention in the last group. As a secondary data source, pre- and post-intervention telephone interviews will be conducted with randomly selected samples of clinicians from each facility group to assess reported preventive care delivery and the acceptability of practice change intervention and implementation. CONCLUSION: The study will provide new evidence of the clinician's ability to increase the delivery of routine preventive care through a network of community health facilities. TRIAL REGISTRATION: Australian Clinical Trials Registry ACTRN12611001284954 UNIVERSAL TRIAL NUMBER (UTN): U1111-1126-3465.

title: Effectiveness of computer reminders to improve quality assessment for point-of-care testing in general practice - A randomized controlled trial
abstract: Background Computer reminders are increasingly applied in efforts to improve quality and patient safety. However, research is still needed to determine the effectiveness of different types of reminders in various settings. This study aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of computer reminders to improve adherence to a quality assessment plan for point-of-care testing in general practice. Method The study was conducted as a randomized controlled crossover trial between general practices in the Danish Capital Region. The intervention consisted of sending computer reminders (ComRem) to applications that did not follow the guideline recommendations of the split test for hemoglobin and glucose. The applications were randomly divided into two groups. During the first follow-up period, one group received the ComRem intervention along with general practice activities (GIA), while the other group received GIA only. For the second follow-up period, the intervention was alternated between the two groups. Results were measured as adherence to the split test procedure. Results A total of 142 treatments were randomly assigned to the early intervention group and 144 treatments to the late intervention group (control group in the first follow-up period). During the first intervention period, the average number of split tests performed in the group receiving the ComRem group increased from 1.22 to 3.76 (out of eight possible tests), while the average number of split tests increased from 1.11 to 2.35 in the group targeted by the GIA alone. . (p = 0.0059). A similar mnemonic effect was observed after crossover. Also, improvements in outcome measures over time have demonstrated a strong impact of computer reminders beyond intervention periods. Conclusion Computer reminders had a significant impact on adherence to the quality assessment plan for point-of-care testing. Therefore, computer reminders seem useful to support the implementation of relatively simple procedures for quality and security.

title: The effectiveness of computerized clinical guidelines in care: a systematic review.
abstract: BACKGROUND: Clinical practice guidelines have been developed aimed at improving the quality of care. The implementation of computerized clinical guidelines (CCG) has been supported by the development of computerized clinical decision support systems. This systematic review evaluates the impact of CCG on the course of care compared to non-computerized clinical guidelines. METHODS: Specific properties of CCG were studied through an extensive scientific literature search and querying electronic databases: Pubmed/Medline, Embase and Cochrane Register of Controlled Trials. Multivariate logistic regression was performed to evaluate the relationship between the properties of CCG and its positive effect on the care process. RESULTS: Forty-five articles were selected. The logistic model showed automatic recommendation provision in the electronic version as part of the clinician workflow (Odds Ratio [OR]= 17.5"; 95% confidence interval [CI]: 1.6-193.7) and Year of Publication (OR = 6.7;" 95%). . CI: 1.3-34.3) were statistically significant predictors. CONCLUSION: From the research we can conclude that significant improvements have been shown in the care process after the application of CCG. Our findings also suggest to clinicians, administrators and other healthcare decision makers what features of CCG could improve the structure of the computerized system.

title: The effectiveness of interventions to improve laboratory demand patterns among primary care physicians: a systematic review.
abstract: Background Laboratory testing is an integral part of daily primary care practice, with approximately 30% of patient encounters resulting in a request. However, research shows that the majority of cravings do not benefit patient care and are preventable. The purpose of this systematic review was to comprehensively search the literature for studies evaluating the effectiveness of interventions to improve primary care physician use of laboratory tests. Methods PubMed, Cochrane Library, Embase, and Scopus (baseline to 09/02/14) search were conducted. The following study designs were considered: systematic reviews, randomized controlled trials (RCTs), controlled clinical trials (CCTs), pre- and post-study controlled (CBAs), and interrupted time series analysis (ITSs). The quality of the studies was assessed using a modified version of the Organization for Effective Practice and Care (EPOC) checklist. The population of interest was primary care physicians. Interventions were considered if they were intended to improve laboratory testing in primary care. The result of interest was a series of laboratory tests. Results A total of 6,166 titles and abstracts were reviewed, followed by 87 full texts. Of these, 11 articles were eligible for inclusion in the systematic review. This includes four RCTs, six CBAs and one ITS study. The types of interventions reviewed included education, feedback, instructions, training with feedback, feedback with instructions, and changing order forms. The quality of the included studies varied, with seven studies deemed to have a low risk of bias, three considered to have an uncertain risk of bias, and one considered to have a high risk of bias. All but one study found significant reductions in the volume of tests following intervention, with effect sizes ranging from 1.2% to 60%. Meta-analysis was not performed due to heterogeneity. Conclusions Interventions such as training strategies, feedback, and changing test sequence forms can improve the efficient use of laboratory tests in primary care", but the level of evidence is very low and of low quality. The reproducibility of findings from different laboratories is also difficult to establish from the literature. To enable formal meta-analysis Some standardization of both interventions and outcome measures is required.

title: Efficacy of SPARX, a computerized self-help intervention for adolescents seeking help for depression: randomized controlled non-inferior trial.
abstract: OBJECTIVE To evaluate whether a new computerized cognitive behavioral therapy intervention (SPARX, Intelligent, Positive, Active, Realistic, X-factor thoughts) can reduce depressive symptoms more or more than usual treatment in helping adolescents seek help. DESIGN Multicenter randomized controlled non-inferiority trial. IDENTIFICATION 24 primary health care facilities (youth clinics, general practices and school-based counseling services) in New Zealand. PARTICIPANTS 187 adolescents aged 12-19 years seeking help for depressive symptoms, without significant risk of self-harm, and considered in need of treatment by primary care professionals: 94 allocated to SPARX and 93 to usual treatment was done. INTERVENTIONS Computed cognitive behavioral therapy (SPARX) consists of seven modules delivered over a period of four to seven weeks, with treatment consisting of face-to-face counseling, as usual, delivered by trained counselors and clinical psychologists. RESULTS The primary outcome was the change in the revised score of the children's depression rating scale. Secondary outcomes included the revised response and remission of the children's depression rating scale, the Reynolds adolescent depression scale-second edition change scores, the mood and emotions questionnaire, the Kazdin hopelessness scale for children, the Spence children's anxiety scale, the children's pediatric quality of life enjoyment and satisfaction questionnaire, and treatment ratings. overall satisfaction. RESULTS 94 participants were assigned to SPARX (mean age 15.6 years, 62.8% women) and 93 participants were assigned to treatment as usual (mean age 15.6 years, 68.8% women). 170 adolescents (91%, SPARX n = 85, treatment-as-usual n = 85) were evaluated after intervention, and 168 (90%, SPARX n = 83, treatment-as-usual n = 85) were evaluated at the three-month follow-up point. Per-protocol analyzes (n = 143) showed that SPARX was not inferior to treatment as usual. After intervention, children's depression rating scale revised raw scores had a mean reduction of 10.32 on SPARX and 7.59 on treatment as usual (group difference 2.73, 95% confidence interval -0.31 to 5.77"; P=0.079) Remission rates in the SPARX arm (n = 31, 43.7%) were significantly higher than in the normal treatment arm (n = 19, 26.4%) (difference 17.3%, 95% confidence interval 1.6% to 31.8%; P = 0.030) and response rates were significantly higher in the SPARX arm ( There was no significant difference between 66.2%, n = 47) and usual treatment (58.3%, n = 42) (difference 7.9%, -7.9% to 24%; “P = 0.332). ). All secondary measures supported not being inferior. The intent to treat analyzes confirmed these findings. Improvements were retained at follow-up. The frequency of intervention-related adverse events classified as 'likely' or 'likely' did not differ between groups (SPARX n = 11";" treatment as usual n = 11). CONCLUSIONS SPARX is a potential alternative to usual care for adolescents presenting with depressive symptoms in primary care and can be used to address some of the unmet treatment demands. TRIAL REGISTRATION Australia New Zealand Clinical Trials ACTRN12609000249257.

title: Effectiveness of workplace interventions to increase physical activity and reduce sedentary behavior in adults: a systematic review protocol.
abstract: OBJECTIVE: A physically active lifestyle plays a preventive role in the development of various chronic diseases and mental health conditions. Unfortunately, very few adults engage in minimal physical activity and spend excessive time sitting. Developing targeted interventions to increase active living among adults is an important public health effort. A reasonable context for reaching adults is the workplace. This systematic review aims to review the effectiveness of workplace interventions on increasing physical activity and reducing sedentary behavior in the workplace. METHODS: An advisory group will work collaboratively with the research team to inform systematic review and information mobilization. Fifteen electronic databases will be searched to identify studies examining the effectiveness of workplace interventions on physical activity and sedentary behavior. All experimental designs and observational studies (non-experimental intervention studies) meeting the study criteria will be included. Studies examining generally healthy, working, adult participants will be included in the review. Interventions will focus on increasing physical activity and/or reducing sedentary behavior from the individual to the policy level. Primary outcome variables, physical activity and/or sedentary behavior in the workplace will be reported or observed. Secondary outcomes will include variables ranging from return on investment to quality of life. Study quality will be assessed for risk of bias following the protocol described in the Cochrane Handbook for Systematic Reviews of Interventions and supplemented by guidelines developed by the Cochrane Organization for Effective Practice and Care group using RevMan. The quality of the evidence will be assessed using the Rating of Recommendations, Evaluation, Development and Evaluation approach. Studies using similar intervention strategies will use meta-analyses, forest plots and harvest plots where appropriate to assess the direction, extent and consistency of intervention impact. Follow-up knowledge mobilization activities and products will be developed to support the practical use of this knowledge. DISCUSSION: This protocol document describes a systematic review evaluating the effectiveness of various types of interventions in the workplace on increasing physical activity and reducing sedentary behavior in the workplace. Collaborating with an advisory group of potential information users throughout the process presupposes greater use and access by information users of the information gained from this systematic review. SYSTEMATIC EXAMINATION RECORD: PROSPPERO CRD42015019398.

title: Effects of a postgraduate course on opioid prescribing patterns of general practitioners
abstract: BACKGROUND: The aim of this study was to evaluate whether a single palliative cancer care workshop with information on drug prescribing has an impact on GPs' opioid prescribing patterns in daily practice. METHOD: The opioid prescription figures of 68 general practitioners participating in the workshop were collected from the computer system of the Regional Disease Fund. Prescription numbers one year before and one year after the workshop were compared and a control group that did not participate in the study was included. CONCLUSIONS: This study demonstrated the limited effectiveness of a palliative cancer care workshop on the morphine prescription figures of general practitioners in daily practice. This limited effect was not in line with the results of a pre- and post-workshop survey evaluating the attitudes of the same practitioners. CONCLUSION: A single workshop cannot make significant changes in prescription behavior. Possibilities for further reinforcement are discussed.

title: The effect of a theory-based training program on nurses' self-efficacy and behaviors towards smoking cessation counseling.
abstract: BACKGROUND: Smoking continues to put Americans at risk for serious health consequences and premature death. Nurses play an important role in disseminating smoking cessation interventions to hospital patients. However, nurses are not ready for smoking cessation counseling. METHOD: A quasi-experimental design was used. Fifteen nurses participated in the Clinical Practice Guideline "5A" brief intervention training program and completed a questionnaire in three time periods. RESULTS: There were few statistically significant changes in the dependent variables of self-efficacy and behavior for smoking cessation counseling. CONCLUSION: The results of this study support further research and theory-based education for nurses.

title: Effects of lowering LDL cholesterol with statin therapy in persons at low risk of vascular disease: a meta-analysis of individual data from 27 randomized trials.
abstract: BackgroundStatins lower LDL cholesterol and prevent vascular events, but their net effect in people at low risk of vascular events remains unclear.";" BackgroundStatins lower LDL cholesterol and prevent vascular events, but their net effect in people at low risk of vascular events remains unclear.

title: The effects of maternal depression, anxiety and perceived stress on preterm birth during pregnancy: A systematic review.
abstract: BACKGROUND: Experiencing psychological distress during pregnancy, such as depression, anxiety, and/or perceived stress, may increase the risk of adverse birth outcomes, including premature birth. Clarifying the relationship between exposure and outcome can improve understanding of risk factors for prematurity and guide future clinical and research practice. OBJECTIVE: The purpose of this review was to summarize the evidence for preterm risk associated with prenatal depression, anxiety, and stress. METHODS: Four electronic database searches were conducted to identify quantitative population-based, multicenter, cohort studies and randomized controlled trial studies focusing on the relationship between prenatal depression, anxiety, and stress, and preterm birth published in English between 1980 and 2013. RESULTS: Of the 1469 electronically accessed articles, 39 peer-reviewed studies met the final selection criteria and were included in this review following the PRISMA and MOOSE review guidelines. Received information about operating features";" depression, anxiety, and perceived stress were studied as separate and combined exposures. There is strong evidence that prenatal distress during pregnancy increases the likelihood of preterm birth. CONCLUSION: The complex pathways of important interactions between depression, anxiety and stress, risk factors and preterm birth have been indicated both directly and indirectly. The effects of pregnancy distress were associated with spontaneous but not medically indicated preterm birth. Health practitioners providing perinatal care to women, such as obstetricians, midwives, nurses, and mental health professionals, need to provide appropriate support to women with psychological distress to improve outcomes for both mothers and babies.

title: The Effects of Pay-for-Performance Programs on Health, Health Service Utilization and Care Processes
abstract: Background: The benefits of pay-per-performance (P4P) programs are unclear. Purpose: To update and expand the previous review that examined the effects of P4P programs targeted at the physician, group, management, or institutional level on the care process and patient outcomes in outpatient and inpatient settings. Data Sources: June PubMed" from 2007 to October 2016; MEDLINE, PsycINFO, CINAHL, Business Economics and Theory, Business Source Elite, Scopus, 1000 Faculty and Gartner Research June 2007 to February 2016. Selection of Study: In outpatient and inpatient settings Trials and observational studies reporting outcomes of care, health, or use Data Extraction: Two investigators extracted data, evaluated study quality, and rated strength of evidence Data Synthesis: Of 69 studies, 58 were in the outpatient setting, 52 were reported care outcome and 38 were reported patient outcomes. short-term (2 to 3 years) end-of-care outcomes, while data on long-term effects was limited. Most of the positive studies have been done in the United Kingdom, where incentives are greater than in the United States. The greatest improvements were seen in areas where fundamental performance was weak. There was insufficient evidence to characterize a consistent effect of P4P on intermediate health outcomes (low-powered evidence) and any effect on patient health outcomes. In the hospital setting, there was low-power evidence that P4P had little or no effect on patient health outcomes and a positive effect in reducing hospital readmissions. Pay-for-performance programs may be associated with improved care processes in outpatient settings, but have not consistently shown positive associations with improved health outcomes in any setting.

title: The effects of price information on physicians' test ordering behavior: ordering diagnostic tests.
abstract: This research evaluated the effects of providing physicians with information about the prices of diagnostic tests on their subsequent test ordering behavior. The study population consisted of 36 second- and third-year residents and 23 clinical faculty members at three family medicine centers affiliated with the Wayne State University School of Medicine Department of Family Medicine in Detroit, Michigan. Study participants were asked to review four case studies, each describing a patient with unclear symptoms, and specify the tests they would order for each patient in an accompanying test instruction. Subjects were randomly assigned to either a group that received test order forms (price-information group) with prices for diagnostic tests printed, or a group that received test order forms with no prices (control group). Study results show that for each of the four cases, the average number of diagnostic tests ordered was significantly lower in the price-information group than in the control group. Our findings also show an average reduction of 31.1 percent in the cumulative cost of tests ordered per patient in relation to providing price information. The feasibility of regularly providing price information to physicians is discussed and reviewed in light of other approaches developed to change physician behavior when diagnostic tests are requested.

title: The effectiveness of an automated feedback system for GPs
abstract: OBJECTIVE: An automated feedback system has been developed that generates comments about general practitioners' (GPs) non-compliance with accepted practice guidelines for ordering diagnostic tests. Before implementing the automated feedback system in daily practice, we evaluated the potential impact of the system on GPs' test ordering behavior. DESIGN: We used a randomized controlled trial with a balanced block design. SETTING: A group of six participating GPs five times in a computer lab setting. INTERVENTION: Family physicians reviewed a random sample of 30 request forms they had filled earlier that year. If they deem necessary, they can make changes in the requested tests. Next, the system displayed critical comments for their non-compliance with the guidelines, as evidenced by the (updated) claim forms. SUBJECTS: Twenty-four randomly selected practitioners participated. MAIN OUTCOME MEASURES: Number of diagnostic tests requested (17% [CI]: 12-22% with 95% confidence interval) and proportion of tests ordered that did not comply with practice guidelines (39% with 95% CI: 28-51%), automatic reversal decreased due to the comments of the notification system. Physicians accepted 362 (50%) of 729 reminders. APPLICATIONS: Although our experiment cannot predict the extent of the actual effect of the automatic feedback system in daily practice, the observed effect can be seen as the maximum achievable effect.

title: The effectiveness of computer reminders on external quality assessment for point-of-care testing in Danish general practice: rationale and methodology of two randomized trials.
abstract: BACKGROUND: Point-of-care testing (POCT) is increasingly used in general practice to assist general practitioners (GPs) in the management of patients with diseases. However, low adherence to quality guidelines for split testing procedures has been observed among GPs in parts of the Danish Capital Region. Computer reminders embedded in GPs' electronic medical records (ComRem) may facilitate improved quality control behavior, but more research is needed to determine what types of reminders work and when. The overall aim of this study was to evaluate the effectiveness of ComRem in improving GPs adherence to quality guidelines. In this article, the rationale and methods of the study constituting this research project are explained. METHODS/DESIGN: The study was conducted as two randomized controlled trials (RCTs) between general practices in two regions of the Danish Capital Region. These districts contain a total of 739 GPs in 567 practices and a total of 1.1 million patients allocated to practice lists. In the first RCT (RCT A), ComRem is compared to mail reminder letters. In the second RCT (RCT B), ComRem is compared to usual events (without reminders) using the crossover approach. In both of these studies, results are measured by the number of split tests taken by the laboratory. CONCLUSION: This study will contribute to information about the effectiveness of ComRem in primary care. As the study did not explore GPs' perceptions and experiences with ComRem, we will then conduct a qualitative survey focusing on these aspects. TRIAL REGISTRATIONS: Study A: ClinicalTrials.gov identifier: NCT01152151Study B: ClinicalTrials.gov identifier: NCT01152177.

title: Effectiveness of visual cues to improve hand hygiene compliance
abstract: BACKGROUND: Guidelines governing HCW hand hygiene (HH) behavior are well-structured. Despite the known dangers of healthcare-associated infection for both healthcare workers and patients, hand hygiene compliance (HHC) rates remain extremely low. To evaluate a possible solution to this ongoing challenge, we used a simulated patient encounter in a real hospital room to test the effectiveness of individual HH triggers. METHODS: One hundred and fifty healthcare workers (75 doctors and 75 nurses) participated in this study and were randomly assigned to one of five equally sized groups. Each participant performed a focused physical examination on a standardized patient and was expected to maintain HH before and after the examination. Various cues were used using two rooms in a medical-surgical unit in a tertiary teaching hospital and the effect on HHC was recorded before and after the examination. In the control group, the hand sanitizer box was in its normal position (Baseline). In one group, the dispenser was moved directly to the line of sight (Line of Sight) as it entered the room; in the other, flashing lights were attached to the dispenser in its usual position (Base Line and Flicker); and in a third group, the dispenser was placed in line of sight and flashing lights were installed (Line-Line). of-Sight & Flicker) In the last group, a large warning sign (Warning Sign) was affixed to the door, informing the healthcare facility that the room was under electronic surveillance and that failure to perform the HHC would trigger an alarm. analyzed using a model, P<0.05 considered statistically significant. RESULTS: In the control group (Base), the pre- and post-exam HHC rates were 36.7% and 33.3%, respectively. All interventions improved HHC pre-intervention compared to baseline (Line of View=% 53.3, Initial & Vibration=60%, Line of Sight & Shiver=66%, Warning Sign=93.3), but only Sight & Flicker and Warning Sign produced a statistically significant increase in pre-exam HHC (P=0.022 and P<0.001, respectively). Only the Warning Sign produced a statistically significant increase in HHC post-exam (P<0.001). RESULTS: Visual cues can improve HHC, but their effectiveness varies. A warning sign informing a surveillance system and subsequent non-compliance reporting resulted in the most significant improvement in HHC. Using a standardized patient in a real hospital room was a helpful tool in evaluating HHC and the impact of various interventions designed to improve patient safety.

title: Employment of ward opinion leaders for continuing education in the hospital.
abstract: Opinion leaders (OLs) are members within a social group who have significant social influence over others. A guideline for urinary catheter care was created in three groups (A, B, and C) of two randomly assigned wards. Two OLs per ward by nurses in groups A and B were determined using a sociomem'c method. For training, in-service lectures for 30% of nurses in group A and OL tutorials for all nurses were used; The training of OLs in B, lectures in C, and ward nurses were in turn responsible for the training of newly arrived student nurses. After the training program, the frequency of application of the guide was evaluated by applying a questionnaire to 30% of randomly selected nurses and making direct observations for misapplications. In addition, a knowledge contest was held for one student about the guide. The best results for all three measurement methods were group A, followed by B and C. ;" and differences were significant for the three groups (p<.05). This indicates that continuing education in the hospital can be conducted effectively with enrollment of ward OLs.

title: Increasing epidemics of obesity and sedentary lifestyle. A call to action for clinicians
abstract: Obesity and a sedentary lifestyle are escalating national and global epidemics that require greater attention from doctors and other health professionals. These intricately linked conditions are responsible for an enormous burden of chronic disease, impaired physical function and quality of life, at least 300,000 premature deaths, and direct health care costs of at least $90 billion per year in the United States alone. Clinicians are at the forefront of the battle, but little attention is paid to these conditions during a typical office visit. Clinicians often feel overwhelmed by these challenges and point to a lack of clear guidelines and means of implementation, minimal training in behavior modification strategies, and a lack of time to not confront them. This report provides a "call to action" with step-by-step directions specifically for the important role of doctors and other healthcare professionals in preventing these dangerous outbreaks. Requiring only a few minutes of a clinician's time to implement, this action plan will facilitate more effective intervention on obesity and inactivity and positively impact public health.

title: Esperance primary suicide prevention project
abstract: BACKGROUND: Suicide has been a major community concern in Esperance, a geographically isolated port on Western Australia's south coast. OBJECTIVES: To evaluate the impact of three evidence-based interventions for the primary prevention of suicide: (i) provide suicidality awareness sessions for staff in health, education, and social services"; (ii) limit the sale of over-the-counter analgesics (aspirin and paracetamol) to packages containing less than the minimum lethal dose. ;" and (iii) the application of Commonwealth media guidelines for media reporting of suicides. METHODS: Changes in knowledge, awareness, attitude, comfort, and use before and after each intervention were assessed using standard tools and proforma from previous studies, such as the Youth Suicide Prevention Training Manual and the Suicide Intervention Beliefs Scale. Percentage changes in the number of retail outlets selling over-the-counter analgesics for less than potentially lethal amounts (less than 8 g of paracetamol or aspirin) were also measured. Media representatives were interviewed to gain their perception of the Commonwealth Guidelines on suicide reporting and were encouraged to consult with the project team before reporting problems with suicide. CONCLUSIONS: The baseline survey showed that mental health staff and GPs were more aware of and more willing to raise the issue with a person at risk than staff in other services about the problems of suicide, risk factors for suicide, and professional and ethical responses. . Thirty-three subjects participated in the suicide awareness training, and 21 (66%) of them answered the questionnaire. There were significant increases in awareness of suicide-related problems and risk factors, as well as professional and ethical responses when assisting a person at risk, and reported levels of knowledge regarding comfort, competence, and confidence levels. Only three media representatives were aware of the Commonwealth Health Department's Guidelines for reporting suicide, and only one believed the guidelines had affected their reporting. Local newspapers then contacted the researchers to check whether their news complied with the guidelines. Regarding access to analgesics, one in seven retailers agreed to implement the strategy (awaiting agreement from other retailers), another claimed increased awareness of the danger of analgesics, and three claimed they would seek to monitor excessive quantities sold to an individual. CONCLUSIONS: Local initiatives can increase staff awareness and knowledge in assessing suicide risk as well as local media. These need to be complemented by State or Commonwealth level initiatives to change statewide media coverage or sell over-the-counter analgesics.

title: Ethical evaluation of innovative treatments: liver transplantation using living donors
abstract: Liver transplantation is the treatment of choice for many forms of liver disease. Unfortunately, the scarcity of cadaver donor livers limits the usability of this technique. To increase the availability of liver transplantation, surgeons have developed the ability to remove a portion of the liver from a living donor and transplant it into a recipient. Several liver transplants have been performed worldwide using living donors. Our aim was to analyze the ethics of liver transplantation using living donors and propose guidelines for the procedure before it is implemented in the United States. We used a "research ethics consultation" process that included a collaboration between clinical researchers and clinical ethicists. We concluded that liver transplantation using living donors in a small series of patients on a trial basis was ethically appropriate and published our ethical guidelines in a medical journal prior to the procedure. We propose this forward-looking, public approach to the promotion of other innovative treatments in medicine and surgery.

title: Medical Ethics: An Annotated Bibliography of Recent Literature
European Psychiatric Association (EPA) guidance on suicide treatment and prevention
abstract: UNLABELED: Suicide is a major public health problem in the WHO European Region, causing more than 150,000 deaths per year. Suicidal crisis: Immediate intervention must be initiated for the patient's survival. DIAGNOSIS: Up to 90% of people who complete suicide have an underlying psychiatric disorder. It has high comorbidity with depression, anxiety, substance abuse and personality disorders. Adequate diagnostic procedures and appropriate treatment for the underlying disorder are essential to ensure successful suicide prevention. TREATMENT: Available evidence supports the effectiveness of pharmacological therapy and cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT) in preventing suicidal behavior. Some other psychological treatments are promising, but supporting evidence is currently inconclusive. Studies show that antidepressant treatment reduces the risk of suicide in depressed patients. However, the risk of suicidal behavior in depressed patients treated with antidepressants exists during the first 10-14 days of treatment, which requires careful monitoring. Anxiolytics and hypnotics and short-term additional medications are recommended in case of anxiety and insomnia. Treatment with antidepressants for children and adolescents should only be given under the supervision of a specialist. Long-term lithium treatment has been shown to be effective in preventing both suicide and suicide attempt in patients with unipolar and bipolar depression. TREATMENT with clozapine is effective in reducing suicidal behavior in patients with schizophrenia. Other atypical antipsychotics are promising but more evidence is needed. TREATMENT team: Multidisciplinary treatment teams consisting of psychiatrists and psychologists, social workers and occupational therapists are always preferred, as integration of pharmacological, psychological and social rehabilitation is recommended, especially in patients with chronic suicidality. Family: The person who will commit suicide should always be motivated to include their family in treatment, regardless of age. Social support: Psychosocial treatment and support is recommended as the majority of suicide patients have problems with relationships, work, school and lack functioning social networks. SAFETY: A safe home, public and hospital environment without access to suicide tools is a necessary strategy for suicide prevention. Each treatment option, medication prescription, and patient discharge from hospital must be carefully weighed against the associated risks. Staff training: General practitioners' (GP) training is effective in suicide prevention. It improves the treatment of depression and anxiety, the quality of care provided, and attitudes towards suicide. Continuing education, including discussions on ethical and legal issues, is required for psychiatrists and other mental health professionals.

title: Evaluation of a specific intervention to improve the treatment of suspected viral encephalitis: protocol for a cluster randomized controlled trial.
abstract: Background Viral encephalitis is a devastating condition in which delayed treatment is associated with increased morbidity and mortality. Clinical audits show significant scope for improved detection and treatment. Improvement strategies should ideally be tailored to identified needs and barriers to change. The aim of the study was to evaluate the efficacy and cost-effectiveness of a tailored intervention to improve second-line treatment of suspected encephalitis. Methods/Design The study was a two-arm, randomized controlled trial allocated by the postgraduate dean's office. Participants were recruited from 24 hospitals in 12 postgraduate deanships in the United Kingdom (UK). We have developed a multifaceted intervention package that includes basic and flexible components with established behavior change techniques selected on the basis of identified needs and barriers to change. The primary outcome would be a composite of the proportion of patients with suspected encephalitis who received a timely and appropriate diagnostic lumbar puncture within 12 hours of hospitalization and acyclovir therapy within 6 hours. We will collect pre-intervention and post-intervention outcome data for up to 12 months from patient records. Statistical analysis at the cluster level will be blind to allocation. An economic assessment will estimate intervention cost-effectiveness from a healthcare perspective.

title: The evolution of current medical and popular attitudes towards ultraviolet light exposure: part 3
abstract: In the 1930s, attitudes towards ultraviolet (UV) light exposure in the medical profession began to change dramatically. UV radiation has been healthily promoted since the turn of the century, and especially after its role in vitamin-D metabolism was discovered. Increasingly, however, the focus will be on the risks of UV light exposure from sunlamps and sunbathing. During this time, the American Medical Association established guidelines for the approval of UV lamps and appropriate therapeutic uses of phototherapy. Findlay and other researchers' landmark experiments in which malignant skin tumors were induced in rodents after exposure to UV lamps or sunlight will lead to widespread recognition of the carcinogenicity of UV radiation. The role of sunlight in the etiology of skin cancer was increasingly mentioned in articles in popular journals in the 1940s and 1950s. There has also been rapid growth in the sunscreen industry, although product efficacy has been highly variable. In the 1950s, interest grew in the use of 8-methoxypsoralen ("sun pill") and dihydroxyacetone ("sun in a bottle"). Despite the known risks of UV exposure and attempts by doctors and other health professionals to educate the public and change behavior, tanning has remained stubbornly popular. Today, exposure to excessive UV light is considered the main cause of approximately 1.3 million cases of skin cancer each year in the United States.

title: The evolution of informed consent in American medicine
Expert consensus guide series. Optimizing the pharmacological treatment of psychotic disorders. Introduction: methods, comment and summary
abstract: OBJECTIVES: There is an increasing number of atypical antipsychotics available for clinicians to choose from for the treatment of psychotic disorders. However, a number of important questions regarding drug selection, dosing and dose equivalence, and management of inadequate response, compliance issues, and relapse have not been adequately addressed in clinical trials. To aid clinical decision making, a consensus survey of expert opinions on the pharmacological treatment of psychotic disorders was conducted to address questions that are not conclusively answered in the research literature. METHOD: Based on the literature review, a written questionnaire with 60 questions and 994 options was developed. About half of the options were scored using a modified version of the RAND 9-point scale to rate the relevance of medical decisions. For other options, experts were asked to write down responses (eg, average doses) or tick a box to indicate their preferred response. The questionnaire was sent to 50 national experts on the pharmacological treatment of psychotic disorders, 47 of whom (94%) completed the questionnaire. In the analysis of responses to items scored on a 9-point scale, consensus on each option was defined as a nonrandom distribution of scores by the chi-square "goodness of fit" test. We assigned each option a categorical rank (first rank/preferred choice, second rank/alternative choice, third rank/usually inappropriate) based on the 95% confidence interval around the mean rating. Guidelines showing preferred treatment strategies were subsequently developed for key clinical situations. RESULTS: The expert panel agreed on 88% of the options rated on a 9-point scale. Experts overwhelmingly approve atypical antipsychotics for the treatment of psychotic disorders. Risperidone was the best choice for first-episode and multiple-episode patients, and other new atypicals were rated first-line or high-second-line depending on the clinical situation. Clozapine and a long-acting injectable were other highly second-line options for atypical (where available) multi-attack patients. Expert dosing recommendations were closely aligned with drug inserts, and estimates of dose equivalence between antipsychotics followed a linear pattern. Experts considered 3-6 weeks to be an adequate trial of antipsychotics, but if there was a partial response they would wait a little longer (4-10 weeks) before making a major change in treatment regimen. Experts suggested trying to improve response by increasing the dose of atypical and depot antipsychotics before switching to a different agent";" Prior to the transition, there was less consensus on increasing the dose of conventional antipsychotics, possibly due to concern about side effects at higher doses. If switching is decided due to unsatisfactory response, risperidone was the specialist's first choice of switch, regardless of which drug was initially tried. Although there are some differences in expert recommendations on how many agents to try before switching to clozapine, the experts' responses suggest that switching to clozapine should be Clozapine, and it is the antipsychotic of choice for patients with suicidal behavior. Experts felt that cross-titration was the preferred strategy when switching between oral antipsychotics. When switching to an injectable antipsychotic therapy, experts stressed the importance of continuing oral antipsychotic therapy until therapeutic levels of the injectable are reached. Experts rated psychosocial interventions as the first choice strategy for partially compliant patients, and pharmacological interventions as first choice for patients with clear evidence of nonadherence. However, as it may be difficult to distinguish patients who are partially compliant from noncompliant, the editors recommended combining psychosocial and pharmacological interventions whenever possible to increase compliance. When patients relapsed due to compliance issues or there was any doubt about compliance, experts recommended the use of long-acting injectable antipsychotics and would choose an atypical injectable when this option was available. Professionals will also consider using an injectable atypical antipsychotic (when available) in many clinical situations that do not involve compliance issues. Experts emphasized the importance of monitoring health problems such as obesity, diabetes, cardiovascular problems, HIV risk behaviors, medical complications of substance use, excessive smoking and its effects, hypertension and amenorrhea in patients receiving antipsychotic treatment. Experts gave little support for either of these strategies, although most patients were prescribed additional therapies, multiple antipsychotics, and combinations of different classes of drugs (for example, antipsychotics plus mood stabilizers or antidepressants) to improve response. antidepressants for patients with dysphoria/depression, antidepressants or ECT for patients with suicidal behavior, and mood stabilizers for patients with aggression/severity. When asked about indicators of remission and recovery, while experts viewed acute improvement in psychotic symptoms as the most important predictor of remission, in multiple outcome domains (eg, assessing recovery. RESULTS: Experts had a high level of agreement on most of the key treatment questions in the survey. Within the limits of expert opinion and future future). With the expectation that research data will take precedence, these guidelines provide direction for addressing common clinical dilemmas that arise in the pharmacological treatment of psychotic disorders. They can be used to inform clinicians and educate patients on the relative merits of various interventions. It should be noted that sound clinical judgment based on clinical experience should be used when applying recommendations.

title: Expert consensus guide series. Treatment of behavioral emergencies 2005
abstract: OBJECTIVES: Because of the hazards and barriers inherent in research in emergency settings, little data is available to guide clinicians on how best to manage behavioral emergencies. Key constructs such as agitation are not fully defined. This lack of empirical data prompted us to conduct an expert opinion survey, the results of which were published in the 2001 Expert Consensus Guidelines for the Treatment of Behavioral Emergencies. Several second-generation (atypical) antipsychotics (SGAs) are now available in new formulations for the treatment of behavioral emergencies (eg, intramuscular [im] olanzapine and ziprasidone; "fast-dissolving olanzapine and risperidone tablets). Critical questions are faced on the field. SGAs differ significantly from FGAs and each other and, like FGAs, have not been studied in unselected patients. Can SGAs be considered as a class, do all antipsychotics have similar anti-agitation effects in different conditions, and if equally effective, what limits might their safety profile impose? Should benzodiazepines (BNZs) be used alone non-specifically, while should antipsychotics be used more specifically to treat psychotic conditions? Few data are available on combinations of SGAs and BNZs, and the findings for combinations of traditional haloperidol plus a BNZ may not be relevant to combinations with SGAs. Culture is also evolving with greater emphasis on patient participation in treatment decisions. An international consensus is developing that the appropriate endpoint of behavioral emergency interventions is sedation rather than sedation. We conducted a new expert opinion survey to update the recommendations from the previous survey. METHODS: Written questionnaire consisting of 61 questions (1,020 choices) was mailed to 50 experts, 48 of which (96%) were received. The questionnaire aimed to define the level of agitation at which emergency interventions were appropriate, the extent of assessment based on urgency and patients' ability to cooperate, guiding principles for selecting interventions, and appropriate physical and medication strategies at various diagnostic confidence levels. provisional diagnoses and complex situations. A modified version of the RAND Corporation's 9-point scale for rating the appropriateness of medical decisions was used to score most options. Consensus was defined as the nonrandom distribution of scores by the chi-square "goodness of fit" test. We assigned each option a categorical ranking (line one/preferred, line two/alternative, line three/usually inappropriate) based on the 95% confidence interval around the mean. The ratings were used to develop guidelines for preferred strategies in key clinical situations. This study received financial support from multiple sponsors, with the panel being blind to sponsorship to reduce potential bias. Drug ratings are based only on responses from participants who have direct experience with each drug. In reporting implementation models, the panel was asked to respond based on actual data rather than estimates. RESULTS: The expert panel agreed on 78% of the options rated on a 9-point scale. The responses suggest that physicians can make a tentative diagnosis with some confidence and that pharmacological and non-pharmacological interventions are selected differently based on diagnosis and other salient demographic and medical characteristics. BNZs are recommended when no data are available, there is no specific treatment (eg, personality disorder) or they may have certain benefits (eg, poisoning). A single SGA does not emerge as a non-specific substitute for haloperidol"; instead, different SGAs are preferred in a variety of situations, consistent with the available evidence. To the extent that haloperidol is recommended, it is almost always in combination with a BNZ; haloperidol alone is associated with this only. Conversely, use of SGAs alone is more often recommended, and the panel refrains from combining BNZs with some SGAs. Oral risperidone alone or in combination with a BNZ receives strong support in a variety of situations. Oral olanzapine is highly rated where studied. (eg schizophrenia, mania) similar to risperidone with slightly higher ratings than risperidone and slightly lower ratings where it has not been studied or where there may be safety concerns; there was less support for the combination of oral olanzapine with oral olanzapine a BNZ Schizophrenia or mania, olanzapine alone, alone or a BNZ combined with risperidone and halo-related agitation Peridol plus a BNZ for the oral treatment of rheumatoid arthritis is also a first line with strong support for combining divalproex with an antipsychotic for possible mania. Oral ziprasidone and quetiapine generally achieved similar second-line scores in most cases. If a parenteral agent is needed, im olanzapine alone has received slightly more support than im ziprasidone alone; however, there was greater support for im ziprasidone alone or in combination with a BNZ than for im olanzapine plus a BNZ, possibly reflecting safety concerns. For example, for the provisional diagnosis of schizophrenia, first-line parenteral options are im olanzapine or ziprasidone alone, or im haloperidol or ziprasidone combined with a BNZ. no data available or diagnosis includes medical comorbidity or intoxication When first response with risperidone, ziprasidone, or haloperidol fails, the panel recommended the addition of a BZD to antipsychotics. However, dosage is recommended when initial therapy with olanzapine or quetiapine has failed. Perphenazine has been consistently rated second-line and droperidol and chlorpromazine rec achieved overall third place ratings. CONCLUSIONS: Within the limits of expert opinion and with the expectation that future research data will take precedence, these guidelines show that SGAs are now preferred for agitation in primary psychiatric disorders, but BNZs are preferred in other situations.

title: Appropriate Family Challenge: Pilot Intervention for Primary Care Childhood Obesity
abstract: BACKGROUND: Childhood obesity has increased dramatically over several decades, and the American Academy of Pediatrics has recommended primary care practices as ideal places for the identification, education, and practice of therapeutic interventions. The aim of this study was to describe the implementation and outcomes of the Fit Family Challenge (FFC), a primary care-based childhood obesity intervention. METHODS: A single-intervention pilot project educating primary care practices in the implementation of childhood obesity guidelines and family-focused behavior change curriculum. A total of 29 family practice and pediatric community practices in Colorado participated. Participants included 290 patients aged 6 to 12 years with a body mass index (BMI) above the 85th percentile. The main outcome measure included the feasibility of implementing a childhood obesity program in primary care”; secondary outcomes were changes in BMI percentile, BMI z-scores, blood pressure, and changes in lifestyle factors related to childhood obesity. RESULTS: Implementation of the FFC is feasible, 9 Statistically significant changes were seen for decreases in BMI percentile and BMI z-scores for participants who completed 15 to 15 months of follow-up; lifestyle factors related to childhood obesity and food insecurity in Spanish-speaking families were associated with less follow-up time (P < .01) CONCLUSIONS: A primary care-based intervention for childhood obesity can result in significant clinical and lifestyle changes.

title: The future of mental hospitals in the UK
Gestational Diabetes Management System (GooDMomS): development, feasibility, and lessons learned from a patient-informed, web-based pregnancy and postpartum lifestyle intervention
abstract: BACKGROUND: Gestational diabetes mellitus (GDM) contributes to the epidemic of diabetes and obesity in mothers and their offspring. The primary objectives of this pilot study were to 1) improve the GDM Management System (GooDMomS), a web-based pregnancy and postpartum behavioral intervention, and 2) evaluate the feasibility of the intervention.
