METHODS: In Phase 1, ten semi-structured interviews were conducted with women with current or recent GDM Mellitus GDM to collect pilot data on the web-based response interface, content, and seek advice from women on improvements to improve the GooDMomS response site. Interviews were audio recorded, transcribed, and independently reviewed to identify key themes with Atlas.ti v7.0. In phase 2, a single-arm feasibility study was conducted and 23 participants were enrolled in the GooDMomS program. Participants received web lessons, weight and glucose tracking, automated feedback, and access to a message board for peer support. The primary outcome was feasibility, including recruitment and retention and acceptability. Secondary outcomes included the proportion of women who were within gestational weight gain (GWG) Institute of Medicine (IOM) guidelines and were able to return to their pre-pregnancy weight after delivery. RESULTS: Comments from the semi-structured interviews focused on 1) the availability of the online self-monitoring diary and monitoring system, 2) access to a secure, reliable social network for peer support, and 3) the antenatal clinicians' online diary for clinical management. Overall, 21 (91%) completed the pregnancy stage. 15/21 (71%) of participants were within Institute of Medicine (IOM) guidelines for the GWG. Sixteen (70%) completed the postpartum phase. 7/16 (43%) and 9/16 (56%) of the participants returned to their pre-pregnancy weights at 6 and 30 weeks postpartum. CONCLUSIONS: This study documents the feasibility of the GoodDMomS program. The results may have implications for web technology in perinatal care and inform the current care paradigm for women with GDM. The findings support further research by recruiting a larger sample of participants and comparing results with intervention and standard care. TRIAL REGISTRATION: The study was published May 15, 2012 on ClinicalTrials.gov with protocol no. NCT01600534 .

title: Effect of a body weight and physical activity intervention (BeWEL) initiated through a national colorectal cancer screening program: randomized controlled trial.
abstract: OBJECTIVE To evaluate the effect of diet and physical activity intervention (BeWEL) on weight change in persons with a body mass index >25 weight (kg)/height (m)(2) and at increased risk for colorectal cancer and other obesity-related comorbidities . DESIGN Multicenter, parallel group, randomized controlled trial. SETTING Four Scottish National Health Service medical boards. PARTICIPANTS 329 overweight or obese adults (aged 50 to 74 years) who had a colonoscopy and histopathology-confirmed diagnosis of an adenoma after a positive fecal occult blood test result as part of the national bowel screening program. 163 were randomized to intervention and 166 to control. INTERVENTION Participants were randomized to a control group (weight loss handbook only) or 12-month intervention group (three face-to-face visits plus monthly 15-minute phone calls with a lifestyle counselor). A target of 7% body weight reduction was set and participants were given a personalized energy prescription (2508 kJ (600 kcal) below what is required for weight maintenance) and body weight scales. Motivational interviewing techniques explored personal values related to self-assessed confidence, indecision, and weight. Behavioral strategies included goal setting, setting practice intentions, self-monitoring of body weight, and counselor feedback on reported diet, physical activity, and weight change. MAIN OUTCOME MEASURES The primary outcome was weight change over 12 months. Secondary outcomes included changes in waist circumference, blood pressure, fasting cardiovascular biomarkers and glucose metabolism variables, physical activity, diet, and alcohol consumption. RESULTS At 12 months, primary outcome data were available for 148 (91%) participants in the intervention group and 157 (95%) participants in the control group. The mean weight loss in the intervention group was 3.50 kg (SD 4.91) compared to 0.78 kg (SD 3.77) (0.19 to 1.38) in the control group (95% confidence interval 2.70 to 4. 30) has been. The group difference was 2.69 kg (95% confidence interval 1.70 to 3.67). The differences between the groups were significant in terms of waist circumference, body mass index, blood pressure, blood sugar level, diet and physical activity. No reported adverse events were considered to be related to participation in the study. CONCLUSIONS Significant weight loss can be achieved with a diet and physical activity intervention initiated as part of a national colorectal cancer screening program, offering significant potential for disease risk reduction in older adults. TRIAL REGISTRATION Controlled Trials Available ISRCTN53033856.

title: The effect of a nurse-led care program on events and physical and psychosocial parameters in patients with heart failure with preserved ejection fraction: a randomized clinical trial in primary care in Russia.
abstract: BACKGROUND: Disease management programs (DMPs) improve the quality of care for patients with heart failure (HF). However, only a limited number of studies have examined the efficacy of such programs in patients with heart failure with a preserved ejection fraction (HFPEF). OBJECTIVE: To estimate the impact of a structured, nurse-led patient education program and care plan in general practice on outcome parameters and events in patients with HFPEF. METHODS: Single-blind randomized clinical trial with an intervention of more than six months and follow-up for 12 additional months. Patients in the control group (n = 41) were managed according to Russian national guidelines. Patients in the intervention group (n = 44) received training on individual lifestyle changes and modifications of cardiovascular disease (CVD) risk factors, home exercise training and usual care, as well as weekly nurse consultations. RESULTS: Six months after inclusion, patients in the intervention group had significantly improved body mass index, waist circumference, six-minute walk test distance, total cholesterol, low-density lipoprotein, left ventricular end-diastolic volume index, quality of life and level. from anxiety. After 18 months, there were 11 deaths (25%) or hospitalizations in the intervention group and 12 (29%) in the control group (P = 0.134). After 6 months follow-up, cardiovascular mortality and readmission rate were not significantly reduced: hazard ratio was 0.47 (95% CI: 0.17-1.28"; P = 0.197). After 18 months this was 0.85 (0.42-1.73;". P = 0.658) . CONCLUSION: This primary care-based DMP for HFPEF patients improved patients' emotional state and quality of life, positively affected body weight, functional capacity and lipid profile, and reduced cardiac remodeling.

title: Effect of cost indicators on primary care physician laboratory test order.
abstract: BACKGROUND Physicians are under increasing pressure to help control rising healthcare costs, despite their lack of knowledge of the cost implications of patient care decisions. PURPOSE To evaluate the impact of real-time display of laboratory costs on the primary care physician's ordering of common laboratory tests in the outpatient setting. DESIGN Interrupted time series analysis with a parallel control group. PARTICIPANTS Two hundred and fifteen primary care physicians (153 interventions and 62 controls) using a common electronic health record between April 2010 and November 2011. The setting was an alliance of five multi-specialty group practices in Massachusetts. INTERVENTION The average Medicare reimbursement rate for 27 laboratory tests, including 21 low-cost tests (<$40.00) and six high-cost tests (>$40.00), was displayed in an electronic health record at time of order. KEY MEASURES We compared the variation in monthly laboratory order rate between intervention and control physicians over 12 months pre-intervention and 6 months post-intervention. We surveyed all intervention and control physicians 6 months after intervention to assess attitudes regarding costs and cost indicators. KEY RESULTS Among the 27 laboratory tests, intervention doctors showed a significant decrease in order rates for five (19%) tests compared to control doctors. This included a significant relative reduction in order rates for four out of 21 (19%) low-cost laboratory tests and one of six (17%) high-cost laboratory tests. The majority of physicians (81%) reported that the intervention improved their knowledge of the relative costs of laboratory testing. CONCLUSIONS Real-time display of cost information in an electronic health record can lead to a modest reduction in sequencing of laboratory tests and is well received. Our study shows that electronic health records can serve as a tool to promote cost transparency and reduce the use of laboratory testing.

title: Impact of evidence-based guideline publication for the assessment and treatment of major depression in a managed behavioral health facility
abstract: This study tests whether a managed behavioral health care facility influences adherence to practice guidelines for the treatment of major depression in a randomized guideline dissemination trial. Guidelines were distributed to mental health clinicians (N = 443) under one of three conditions: (1) a general mailing of guidelines to clinicians, (2) a mailing in which the guidelines were targeted at a patient starting treatment with a clinician, and (3) no mailing of instructions. The results showed no effect of guideline publication, as measured by patients' and clinicians' self-reports and episode characteristics derived from claim data, despite sentinel effects. The results also showed high clinician-reported rates of undertreatment for depression not detected in the claims data. The results suggest that mental health systems should look to other dissemination strategies to improve adherence to standards of care and improve the performance of self-employed clinicians.

title: Impact of guidelines, standards and economic constraints on clinical decision making
abstract: Guidelines aim to improve clinical decision making. Unlike textbooks and reviews that seek to improve medical knowledge, guidelines seek to influence medical behavior. Scientific models of clinical decision-making, such as theory of action and empirical data on the effects of guidelines, suggest that guidelines do not always achieve their goals and may instead lead to a deterioration in the quality of medical care. Therefore, controlled clinical trials are needed to investigate whether physicians exposed to the guidelines provide better patient outcomes than physicians unfamiliar with the guidelines. Guidelines should be accepted as evidence-based only if positive effects have been demonstrated experimentally.

title: Impact of computerized physician order entry antimicrobial management program directed by infectious diseases specialist targeting linezolid use
Effect of medication adherence on lung health outcomes in cystic fibrosis
abstract: PURPOSE OF REVIEW: Patient compliance is becoming increasingly important as new drugs continue to appear to improve health in individuals with cystic fibrosis (CF). Currently, compliance with pulmonary medications is approximately 50% for people with CF. There is recent research showing that poor compliance is linked to worse health outcomes. This review summarizes the latest research on the impact of compliance on lung health and highlights future research and clinical application areas to address this growing need. RECENT FINDINGS: Recent studies have shown that nonadherence is associated with increased hospitalizations and pulmonary exacerbations, lower baseline lung function, and longer lengths of stay. However, most of the research has been done using pharmacy refill records as an objective measure of adherence. Electronic monitoring of drugs provides more detailed information on patterns of use that can directly inform clinical care. In addition, there are few published clinical studies evaluating behavioral interventions to promote compliance. SUMMARY: Given recent research linking compliance with lung health outcomes, there is a growing need to measure and evaluate compliance in clinical care. As new drugs are approved for CF, methods for monitoring compliance also need to be developed and approved. Clinicians need to continue to assess barriers to compliance in order to individually tailor interventions to a patient's needs.

title: The effect of supported telemetric monitoring in people with type 2 diabetes: study protocol for a randomized controlled trial.
abstract: BACKGROUND: The prevalence of diabetes is increasing and current management methods are unsustainable. Effective approaches are needed to support self-management. The purpose of this randomized controlled trial was to determine whether assisted telemetric monitoring of glycemic control and blood pressure results in reductions in glycosylated hemoglobin (HbA1c; “primary outcome of long-term glycemic control) and secondary blood pressure outcomes. and weight in people with poorly controlled diabetes compared to a control group receiving regular care. METHODS/DESIGN: Design: multicenter, randomized controlled trial embedded qualitative study. Setting: Primary care in the UK in the Lothian, Kent, Glasgow and Borders areas. Participants: persons with type 2 diabetes and confirmed HbA1c>7.5% (58 mmol/mol). Intervention/comparison: randomization to intervention or control groups will be carried out by the Edinburgh Clinical Trials Unit. Participants in the intervention group will be shown how to use scales and blood glucose and blood pressure monitors that use Bluetooth wireless technology to transmit readings via a modem to a remote server. These participants will be asked to take morning and evening blood glucose measurements and weekly weight and blood pressure measurements at least twice a week. Measurements will be checked at least weekly by practice nurses, who will contact patients to adjust treatment according to guidelines and reinforce lifestyle recommendations. Participants in the control group will receive usual care. Individual training will be provided to all participants. Follow-up: measurements will be made at practices 9 months after randomization by research nurses blinded to separation. The primary outcome is HbA1c and the secondary outcome is daytime systolic and diastolic blood pressure, weight and quality-adjusted cost per life-year. Analysis: Treatment-oriented analyzes will be made. The sample size of 320 participants allows for a 20% cut-off to detect a 0.5% absolute (6 mmol/mol) reduction in HbA1c in the intervention group and has 80% power at 5% significance. The qualitative study will explore the experiences of patients and professionals using the intervention. TRIAL REGISTRATION: Trial registration number ISRCTN71674628.

title: Importance of cardiovascular risk management in the treatment of hypertension: the role of ACE inhibitors and ARBs
The importance of doctor-patient communication in somatized patient care
abstract: The term "somatization" refers to the manifestation of multiple somatic complaints that are not explained by organic changes. According to the literature, 15-25 percent of all medical visits are related to somatization. Because medical education does not place enough emphasis on the assessment of the possible psychological background of certain somatic symptoms, doctors may feel powerless and make unfair diagnosis and treatment efforts. Patients may also feel helpless and frustrated, and their anxiety and complaints may increase in intensity. Since stress is an important factor in the somatization process, reducing stress and improving coping are essential elements of chronic disease treatment guidelines. Evidence-based interventions range from brief counseling and medication to cognitive and behavioral psychotherapy. Reassociation, a short (10-30 minutes) structured intervention that can be applied in primary or secondary care, can in some cases result in significant reductions in somatic symptoms and anxiety.

title: Curative care study in chronic obstructive pulmonary disease study: CAROL improving care processes and quality of life of COPD patients in primary care: study protocol for a randomized controlled trial
abstract: BACKGROUND: The Swiss ministry of health launched a national quality program, 'QualiCCare', in 2011 to improve healthcare for COPD patients. The aim of this study was to determine whether participation in the COPD quality initiative ('QualiCCare') improves adherence to recommended clinical treatment. processes and demonstrates the impact of patients on COPD care and the impact that COPD has on a person's life. METHODS: CAROL is a clustered randomized controlled trial with randomization at the general practitioner (GP) level. Thirty GPs will be randomly assigned to an equally sized intervention group or control group. Regardless of the reason for the current consultation, each GP will sequentially approach patients aged 45 years and older with a smoking history >/= ten pack-years (PR). Patients with confirmed (by spirometric evaluation) COPD will be included in the study. General practitioners in the intervention group will receive 'QualiCCare' training that addresses aspects of knowledge, decision-making and behavior, as well as the delivery of care according to COPD quality indicators and evidence-based key elements. In the control group, no educational intervention will be applied and COPD patients will be treated as usual. The working period is one year. The primary outcome measure is an aggregated score of relevant clinical processes that define the elements in the care of patients with COPD: smoking cessation counseling, influenza vaccination, motivation for physical activity, appropriate pharmacotherapy, patient education, and shared care. Given a 90% power and a 5% alpha significance level, 15 GPs each recruiting eight patients in both arms would be required. With a default dropout rate of 20%, 288 patients will need to be included. CONCLUSION: The development and implementation of interventions that add value to COPD care is important for quality and effectiveness. Ways of care that change physicians' knowledge and behavior have the potential to improve care by transferring knowledge to clinical practice. TRIAL REGISTRATION: ClinicalTrials.gov: NCT01921556.

title: Impact of a physician and patient intervention program on dietary intake
abstract: BACKGROUND: There is a need for effective dietary interventions for patients with hypertension in clinical settings. OBJECTIVE: To evaluate the separate and combined effect of a physician intervention (MD-I) and a patient intervention (PT-I) on the dietary intake of patients with hypertension. DESIGN: A 2x2 nested design, randomized controlled trial conducted over 18 months. PARTICIPANTS: A total of 32 physicians and 574 ambulatory hypertension patients. INTERVENTION: MD-I included training modules for the Seventh Report of the Joint National Committee on the Prevention, Detection, Evaluation and Treatment of Hypertension, hypertension management guidelines and lifestyle change. The PT-I included lifestyle coaching to adopt Dietary Approaches to Stop Hypertension (DASH) eating patterns, reduce sodium intake, manage weight, increase exercise, and reduce alcohol intake. MAIN OUTCOME MEASURES: Dietary intakes were measured with the Block Food Frequency Questionnaire. Compliance with the DASH diet model was estimated by a DASH score. STATISTICAL ANALYSIS: The main effects and interactions of MD-I and PT-I were evaluated using analysis of covariance. RESULTS: After 6 months of intervention, MD-I participants significantly increased their intake of potassium, fruit, juices and carbohydrates"; decreased their fat intake;" and improving overall diet quality as measured by the Healthy Eating Index. The PT-I intervention resulted in increased intakes of carbohydrates, protein, fiber, calcium, potassium, fruit and juices, vegetables, dairy, and Healthy Eating Index scores, and decreased intakes of fat, saturated fat, cholesterol, sodium, sweets, and added foods. oils/oils/sweets. Additionally, PT-I improved the overall DASH compliance score. The change in DASH score was significantly associated with changes in blood pressure and weight at 6 months. At 18 months, most changes were back to baseline levels, including the DASH score. RESULTS: Both MD-I and PT-I improved eating habits at 6 months with some lasting effects at 18 months. Although all observed dietary changes were consistent with DASH food targets or food group guidelines, only the PT-I intervention was effective in improving the overall DASH adherence score. This finding confirms the role of medical nutrition therapy in long-term intensive interventions for hypertension risk reduction and weight management, and highlights the need to develop care strategies. Additionally, this study highlights the importance of collaborations between physicians, registered dietitians and other dietetic practitioners and lay health counselors when helping patients make healthy behavioral changes.

title: The effect of patient characteristics on the appropriateness of surgical treatment in patients with breast cancer. Progetto Oncology Feminine
abstract: BACKGROUND: As part of a multi-annual educational intervention supported by the Ministry of Health and regional health authorities, patterns of care for breast cancer patients in Italian general hospitals were followed to identify areas of practice where quality is needed. improvement. DESIGN: Information on diagnostic and therapeutic procedures at 63 general hospitals in eight Italian regions, performed on 1724 consecutive breast cancer patients, was collected retrospectively from medical records. Quality of care was assessed with a diagnostic and therapeutic score based on the observed degree of adherence to predetermined action plans. RESULTS: The median value of the overall diagnosis and staging score was 60%. Approximately one-third (38%) of surgical operations were inappropriate: one-quarter (24%) of patients with stage I-II disease underused radical surgery (ie Halsted mastectomy) and patients with small tumors (ie, < or = 2 cm). Chronological age influenced the behavior of doctors: older patients, regardless of their general condition, were more likely to have less intensive diagnostic examination and less appropriate surgical treatment (with more frequent use of an unnecessary radical operation and less use of limited surgery). health situation. The presence of one or more co-morbidities was associated with failure of axillary clearance and lower use of conservative surgery regardless of age. CONCLUSION: Consistent with other studies, this study confirms the existence of a clinically significant effect of patient age on diagnostic and therapeutic behavior and the use of unnecessary radical surgical procedures. The article discusses the implications of these findings for the next phase of the educational project where practice guidelines will be developed and implemented to improve the quality of care for breast cancer patients.

title: The intellectual structure and essence of the information use domain: A longitudinal analysis of author co-citation, 1945 to 2004
abstract: Background It has been argued that science and society are in the midst of an extensive renegotiation of the social contract between science and society, with society becoming a much more active partner in knowledge creation. On the one hand, new forms of knowledge production are emerging, on the other hand, both science and society experience a rapid acceleration in new forms of knowledge use. Simultaneously, since the Second World War, the science that underpins the field of knowledge use has grown exponentially. There are few in-depth reviews in this area and no comprehensive analyzes using bibliometric methods. Methods Using bibliometric analysis, specifically first author co-citation analysis, our group undertook a field analysis of the information use domain, tracing its historical development between 1945 and 2004. Our aim is to map the historical development of knowledge use as a field and to identify the changing intellectual structure of scientific fields. We analyzed more than 5,000 articles using citation data from the Web of Science. The search terms were combinations of knowledge, research, evidence, guidelines, ideas, science, innovation, technology, theory and use of information, use and uptake. Conclusions We provide an overview of the intellectual structure and how it has changed over six decades. The area was not wide enough to be represented by a common citation map until the mid-1960s. Our findings show strong growth from the mid-1960s to 2004, as well as the emergence of specific areas reflecting diverse collectives of intellectual activity and thought. Until the mid-1980s, the main areas focused on innovation diffusion, technology transfer and knowledge use. Evidence-based medicine emerged in the mid-1980s, a fourth scientific field that began slowly and then grew rapidly. For decades, the field has been ruled by one person, Everett Rogers, and a single paradigm, diffusion of innovation. Conclusion We conclude that the accepted view that social science disciplines are in a state where no accepted set of principles or theory guides research (that is, they are pre-paradigm) cannot be supported for this field. Second, we document the emergence of a new field in the field of information use, evidence-based medicine. Third, we conclude that Everett Rogers was the dominant figure in the field and, until the advent of evidence-based medicine, his representation of the general diffusion model was the dominant paradigm in the field.

title: Irritable Bowel Syndrome Outcome Study (IBSOS): rationale and design of a randomized placebo-controlled trial with 12-month follow-up versus clinician-administered CBT for moderate to severe irritable bowel syndrome
abstract: Irritable bowel syndrome is a common, often disabling gastrointestinal disorder, all of whose symptoms do not have satisfactory medical or dietary treatment. One of the few experimentally validated treatments, if available, involves a specific type of psychological therapy called cognitive behavioral therapy, which is typically administered over several months by trained practitioners in tertiary care settings. There is an urgent need to develop more efficient versions of CBT that require minimal professional assistance but retain the efficacy profile of clinical-based CBT. The Irritable Bowel Syndrome Outcome Study (IBSOS) is a multicenter, placebo-controlled randomized trial to evaluate whether a self-administered version of CBT is at least as effective as standard CBT and more effective than an attention control at reducing core symptoms of the gastrointestinal tract. IBS and its burden (eg, distress, deterioration in quality of life, etc.) in moderately to severely affected IBS patients. Additional goals are to assess the durability of treatment response over a 12-month period at three-month intervals; identify clinically useful patient characteristics associated with outcome as a way to understand subgroups of participants for whom CBT is most beneficial; theory-based shift explaining how and why CBT works Identify the mechanisms (active ingredients) and evaluate the economic costs and benefits of CBT Between August 2010, when IBSOS began recruiting subjects, and February 2012, IBSOS randomized 171 of 480 patients. Findings revealed the social and economic costs of improving the health of IBS patients. It has the potential to reduce health care costs, conserve scarce health care resources, and inform evidence-based practice guidelines.

title: Italian Diabetes and Exercise Study 2 (IDES-2): a long-term behavioral intervention for adopting and maintaining a physically active lifestyle
abstract: BACKGROUND: Physical activity (PA)/exercise has become an integral part of the management of type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM). However, current guidelines are difficult to implement in this population due to a number of barriers, particularly the lack of acceptable, feasible, and validated behavioral intervention strategies. This manuscript reports the rationale, study design and methods, and design considerations of the Italian Diabetes and Exercise Study (IDES)-2, a randomized controlled trial that tested the efficacy of a behavior modification strategy in increasing total daily FA and reducing sedentary time. SED time) in patients with T2DM. METHODS/DESIGN: From January 7, 2014, IDES_2 began enrolling 300 patients with known T2DM for at least 1 year at three tertiary outpatient diabetes clinics in Rome. Additional requirements are age 40 to 80, body mass index 27 to 40 kg/m(2), sedentary lifestyle, and at least 6 months of physically inactive, unassisted walking 1.6 km and fitness after cardiovascular assessment. Patients are randomized to intervention or control groups by center and by age and type of diabetes treatment at each center. Patients in the intervention (INT) group (n = 150) receive annual theoretical and practical exercise counseling consisting of collective behavior change techniques (one individual theoretical counseling session plus eight individual theoretical and practical exercise counseling twice weekly). 3 years. Patients in the control (CON) group (n = 150) receive standard care, including general physician recommendations for daily PA. Primary results are total daily PA and SED time as measured objectively using an accelerometer. Secondary outcomes include physical fitness, modifiable cardiovascular risk factors, musculoskeletal disorders, well-being/depression, and health-related quality of life. DISCUSSION: The behavioral intervention strategy tested in IDES_2 is based on solid theoretical foundations and employs several behavior modification techniques, two of which have been found to improve the effectiveness of behavioral intervention. In addition, physicians and exercise specialists are specifically trained for PA/exercise counseling/prescribing and monitoring, respectively, in subjects afflicted with metabolic disorders. Finally, the large sample size, long study duration, and objective measurement of PA allow statistically significant and scientifically sound conclusions to be drawn about the feasibility and efficacy of this intervention in T2DM patients. TRIAL REGISTRATION: ClinicalTrials.gov"; NCT01600937 ;" 10 October 2012.

title: information sickness
Lack, need, and opportunities for decision-making and information tools to educate primary care physicians and women about breast cancer chemoprevention
abstract: Vogel et al. (from page 696 in this issue of the journal) reviews tamoxifen and raloxifene prescription patterns and why these agents are underused in breast cancer prevention despite their effectiveness in definitive research, Food and Drug Administration approval, and the American Society of Clinical Oncology Guidelines Committee. consent for this purpose. The complexity of weighing the pros and cons of drugs and estimating net benefit, and the need for information resources such as interactive Internet-based tools to allow better individualized decisions about chemoprevention options, are discussed.

title: Legal position of local research ethics committees

The LIFESTYLE study: costs and implications of a structured lifestyle program to reduce the need for fertility treatment and improve reproductive outcomes in overweight and obese subfertile women. A randomized controlled trial
abstract: BACKGROUND: In the Netherlands, 30% of subfertile women are overweight or obese and there is currently no agreement on fertility care for them. Data from observational and small intervention studies suggest that reducing weight will increase the chances of conception, reduce pregnancy complications, and improve perinatal outcomes, but this has not been confirmed in randomized controlled trials. This study will evaluate the cost and effects of a six-month structured lifestyle program targeting weight loss followed by traditional fertility care (intervention group) compared to traditional fertility care only (control group) in overweight and obese subfertile women. We hypothesize that the intervention will reduce the need for fertility treatment, reduce pregnancy complications associated with overweight, and improve perinatal outcomes. METHODS/DESIGN: Multicenter randomized controlled trial in subfertile women (18-39 years) with a body mass index between 29 and 40 kg/m2. Exclusion criteria were azoospermia, use of donor semen, severe endometriosis, premature ovarian failure, endocrinopathies, or pre-existing hypertensive disorders. In the intervention group, the goal can be achieved by a combination of at least 5% to 10% weight loss, diet, increased physical activity, and behavior change over a six-month period. If, after six months, she has not conceived, these patients will begin fertility treatment according to Dutch fertility guidelines. In the control group, treatment will be started according to the Dutch fertility guidelines, regardless of the patient's weight. OUTCOME MEASURES AND ANALYSIS: The primary outcome measure is a healthy single born after at least 37 weeks of gestation after vaginal delivery. Secondary outcome parameters including pregnancy outcome and complications, percentage of women requiring fertility treatment, clinical and ongoing pregnancy rates, body weight, quality of life, and costs. The data will be analyzed according to the goal-to-treat principle and a cost-effectiveness analysis will be made. conducted to compare costs and health effects in the intervention and control group. CONCLUSION: The trial will provide evidence for the costs and effects of a lifestyle intervention aimed at weight reduction in overweight and obese subfertile women, and will guide clinicians in the management of these patients. TRIAL REGISTRATION: Dutch Trial Registry NTR1530.

title: Management of "psychogenic" orofacial pain
Management of patients with nicotine addiction - the role of general practitioners
abstract: Gatekeeper needs disease management of his smoking patients. The questionnaires will help identify the diagnosis and extent of nicotine addiction, as well as fingerprints of patients with a smoking career. The ICD-10 Code and the Fagerstrom Nicotine Dependence Test are used. There is no specified treatment without the optimal motivation of the patient. Prochaska and DiClemente's transtheoretical model is widely accepted for dividing the motivational stadium into precontemplation, contemplation, preparation, and action. Many other factors such as previous experience, disaster scenarios, self-efficacy and therapeutic modality selection are important for optimal outcome. 90% of a gatekeeper's job is minimal intervention. This means individually tailored arguments to shift the patient's motivation to quit smoking. The concept is defined in the rules of the five Rs with relevance, risks, rewards, roadblocks and repetition. Following these criteria, the gatekeeper achieves up to 60% positive change in motivation with just one minimal intervention. Smoking cessation guidelines around the world are very similar and indicate an A-level rating for nicotine replacement, behavioral therapy via bupropion or varenicline, and drug synergy. The choice of any other regimen is either less efficient or anecdotal and results in a further reduction in the smoker's life expectancy. The gatekeeper has the infrastructure, knowledge and confidence of his patient to act as the disease manager. A successful treatment is possible with approximately seven consultations over six months, and the success rate is expected to be even higher than the values in drug research. Smokers should be informed by health institutions to avoid self-therapy and expert help should be sought. The gatekeeper is an ideal candidate.

title: MAURO study: key features and compliance with guideline objectives
abstract: BACKGROUND: The Multiple Intervention and Control of Renal Diseases to Optimize Care (MAURO) study was a cluster of randomized controlled trials in 22 renal clinics that aimed to evaluate the efficacy of a multimodal quality improvement intervention to improve adherence to guidelines recommendations for the prevention of chronic kidney disease. disease (CKD) progression and cardiovascular (CV) complications. The trial aimed to test whether this multimodal intervention improved adherence to recommended targets for a range of surrogate indicators related to blood pressure (BP) control, sodium intake, proteinuria, dyslipidemia, anemia, and calcium-phosphate changes. The trial also tested whether the same intervention could slow CKD progression and prevent CV complications in CKD patients. METHODS: Twenty-two kidney clinics were randomized into 2 arms: an intervention arm performing a multi-method quality improvement intervention and a control arm providing standard care. Surrogate indicators were measured to assess changes in blood pressure (BP) control, sodium intake, proteinuria, dyslipidemia, anemia, and calcium-phosphate. RESULTS: Although the vast majority (95%) of patients enrolled in this study were treated with antihypertensive drugs, baseline BP targets (proteinuria level and specific for diabetes) were found in only 45% of patients without proteinuria and 14% and 18% of patients with Proteinuric and diabetic only, respectively. 'I. In hypertensive patients, the use of diuretics was less than necessary, and approximately 80% of patients had a salt excretion of >100 mmol/24 hours. Total and low-density lipoprotein cholesterol levels were off-target in over 40% of patients, but only 60% of these were on statins. The vast majority of CKD patients were obese or overweight. The proportion of smokers was relatively small (13%), and 37% of patients had quit, indicating that patients are aware of the health risks of smoking. CONCLUSIONS: In our cohort, the management of modifiable risk factors for CKD progression and CV disease can be significantly improved.

title: McMaster curriculum: a critique
Medical office of the 21st century (MOXXI): effectiveness of computerized decision support in reducing inappropriate prescribing in primary care.
abstract: Background: Drug-related adverse events are common in the elderly, and inappropriate prescribing is a preventable risk factor. Our aim was to determine whether inappropriate prescribing could be reduced if primary care physicians had computer-based access to information on all prescriptions and automatic alerts for potential prescribing problems. Methods: We randomly assigned 107 primary care physicians with at least 100 patients aged 66 years and older (12 560 in total) to a group receiving computerized decision-making support (CDS) or a control group. Doctors in the CDS group were able to access information on current and past prescriptions through a dedicated computer link to the state's seniors' drug insurance program. When any of the 159 clinically relevant prescribing problems were detected by the CDS software, the physician received an alert describing the nature of the problem, possible consequences, and alternative treatment. The rate of initiation and termination of potentially unsuitable prescriptions was evaluated over a 13-month period. Results: 2 months before the study, 31.8% of patients in the CDS group and 33.3% of patients in the control group wrote at least 1 potentially inappropriate prescription. During the study, the number of new potentially unsuitable prescriptions per 1000 visits was significantly lower (18%) in the CDS group than in the control group (relative ratio [RR] 0.82, 95% confidence interval [CI] 0.69–0.98) but potentially unsuitable Differences between groups in non-prescription discontinuation were significant only for drug interactions caused by therapeutic relapse (RR 1.66, 95% CI 0.99–2.79) and prescriptions written by the study physician and another physician. study physician (RR 2.15, 95% CI 0.98–4.70). Comment: Computer-based access to complete drug profiles and alerts about potential prescribing problems reduces the initiation rate of potentially ineligible prescriptions, but has a more selective effect on discontinuing such prescriptions.

title: The moderator effect of interventions promoting compliance with clients on evidence-based practice for children and adolescents with mental health problems.
abstract: Poor adherence of children and adolescents to evidence-based psychosocial interventions remains a major barrier to treatment effectiveness. To maintain patient engagement, researchers and clinicians have used a range of engagement-promoting strategies, from phone calls and letters to providing transportation costs and childcare motivational therapies. However, the effect of adherence promoters on intervention outcomes has not been reported. This study examined the modulating effect of strategies promoting adherence in a survey and meta-analysis of randomized clinical trials on cognitive behavioral treatments, interpersonal therapy, and psychoeducation for children and adolescents with mental health problems (k = 33). The results showed the type and intensity of moderated study effect sizes of loyalty promoters by client characteristics (age, gender, diagnosis). Preliminary findings suggest that men have higher effect sizes when more intense commitment development efforts are used. Efforts to increase adjustment have been associated with lower effect sizes for youth diagnosed with externalizing disorders. The results of this study suggest guidelines for future research to clarify clinical guidelines for maximizing persistence in evidence-based psychotherapy.

title: myADHDportal.com Improvement Program: An innovative quality improvement intervention to improve the quality of ADHD care among community-based pediatricians
abstract: Although the American Academy of Pediatrics has developed and disseminated clear evidence-based guidelines for ADHD care, community-based pediatricians often have difficulty applying these guidelines. New strategies are needed to improve the quality of care that children with ADHD receive and to improve the use of AAP consensus guidelines by pediatricians. An evidence-based quality improvement intervention has been developed that effectively improves the quality of ADHD care delivered by community-based pediatricians. To facilitate dissemination of this response model, the entire response has been modified for online distribution. The intervention is called the myADHDportal.com Enhancement Program. The full functionality of this online intervention is described, including the collection of online ADHD rating scales from parents and teachers, and online communication between parents, teachers, and doctors. In addition, the web portal features several innovative quality improvement features, including an online wizard to map ADHD patient flow, an online report card to monitor quality of care, and an online wizard to guide practices via Plan-Do-Run-Act (PDSA). integrates. ) loop process. The combination of clinical utility and quality improvement tools facilitates the delivery of quality ADHD care and reduces many of the barriers to implementing AAP-recommended practice behaviors. Initial results of this intervention model are reviewed and dissemination targets defined.

title: International ban on prosecution of Nazi doctors and medical intervention in torture
The need for research designed to support decisions in the delivery of mental health services
abstract: MEP Seligman (1995) argued that traditional approaches to mental health services research fail to provide useful information to consumers and practitioners, especially in an environment where managed care is increasingly dominated. The authors propose 4 guidelines for designing a research program so that the results can support the decisions of key stakeholders (clients-families, practitioners, service managers, and policy-makers): "complementary studies of effectiveness, effectiveness, and cost-effectiveness"; (b) study design and selection of measures, should be sensitive to identifying which intervention serves best for whom and in what context; (c) design stakeholders, the type and amount of effort required to reach a behavioral criterion; and (d) strategy should be about how information will be formatted to best support the decisions of key stakeholders. should inform researchers.

title: NIH report of its review of the Baby Fae case
Nuremberg Code and medical research
abstract: It addresses the tensions between religious discourse and bioethics. Accessibility and meaning issues";" To address different moral language and concepts.

title: Nuremberg Law and the Nuremberg Case. reassessment
abstract: The Nuremberg Rules contain 10 principles to guide physician-researchers in experiments involving human subjects. These principles, especially the first about "voluntary consent", were based primarily on legal concepts, since the medical ethics existing during the Nazi atrocities did not address consent and other safeguards for human subjects. The US judges presiding over the proceedings did not intend that the Rules apply only to the case before them, to be a response to the atrocities perpetrated by Nazi doctors, or not to be applicable to research as was customary in medical institutions. . Instead, a careful reading of the decision shows that they wrote the Code for human experimentation practice each time it was conducted.

title: Potential for asthma compliance management to improve asthma guidelines
abstract: OBJECTIVE: Expert Panel Report 3 Guidelines recommend that physicians use compliance management strategies", but the evidence for these interventions is weak. Clinicians need effective, proven compliance interventions, as approximately 50% of patients with asthma do not follow physician medication recommendations. unnecessary morbidity This review DATA SOURCES: A literature review was conducted in the following areas of asthma management: guidelines, cost; morbidity; compliance, monitoring, and communication skills STUDY CHOICES: Psychoeducational, behavioral, studies examining outcomes from monitoring and communication interventions CONCLUSIONS: Studies using individual interventions by themselves were moderately effective in increasing adherence Two uncontrolled studies on children with severe asthma With both inpatient and outpatient rehabilitation settings He used 4 intervention strategies to achieve significant reductions in morbidity, cost, and cost of treatment. These strategies included: (1) monitoring of objective compliance; (2) determining the cause(s) of the non-compliance; (3) providing specific strategies for each cause" and (4) using motivational interviewing communication skills to improve strategy implementation. CONCLUSION: Non-compliance remains a major problem. is guaranteed to increase the evidence for compliance management for future asthma guidelines.

title: The power of clinical trials and guidelines and the difficulty of conflicts of interest
Implementation of ethics committees
abstract: KIE: A short news note welcomes the publication of a helpful report, Guidelines for the Practice of Ethics Committees in Medical Research, by the Royal College of Physicians, London, in September 1984. An important recommendation in the guide is that any adverse or unforeseen circumstances arising from a study should be notified to committees and abstracts or reprints of publications should be sent. If it turns out that clinical trials have been conducted without ethical review concerns, the committee should report the facts to the agency they serve.

title: Problem with '5 reasons'
abstract: The “The Problem with” series covers controversial issues related to efforts to improve healthcare quality, including widely suggested but deceptively difficult improvement strategies and common problems that seem to resist resolution.

title: The problem with survey research.
abstract: The Survey Research Question makes a case against survey research as the primary source of reliable information. George Beam argues that all survey research tools, including surveys, face-to-face interviews, and focus groups, produce unreliable and potentially inaccurate results. Because those who rely on survey research only see the answers to the questions, it is impossible for them or anyone else to evaluate the results. They do not know whether the answers correspond to the real behavior of the respondents (objective phenomena) or their true beliefs and ideas (subjective phenomena). Reliable knowledge can only be obtained through observation, experimentation, multiple data sources, formal model building and testing, document analysis and comparison. In fifteen chapters divided into six sections - The Ubiquity of Survey Research, The Problem, Question Tools, Question Environments, Soldiers and Appropriate Methods and Research Designs - The Questionnaire Research Problem, the environments in which questioning tools, questioning and answering occur, and the survey researchers themselves distorting the results. makes the answers unreliable. The last two chapters and appendices examine observation, other methods of data collection, and research designs that can produce true or accurate information, and show how reliance on survey research can and must be overcome. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2016 APA, all rights reserved)

title: 1900 Prussian regulation: early ethical standards for human experimentation in Germany
QICKD trial protocol: a randomized cluster trial to compare low systolic BP with quality improvement interventions in primary care chronic kidney disease (CKD).
abstract: Background Chronic kidney disease (CKD) is a relatively newly recognized but common long-term condition affecting 5% to 10% of the population. Effective management of CKD with emphasis on tight blood pressure (BP) control reduces cardiovascular risk and slows the progression of CKD. Currently, there is an unprecedented increase in referrals to specialist renal services, often found in tertiary care centres, which are inconvenient for patients and waste resources. National and international CKD guidelines include quality targets for primary care. However, a rigorous assessment of strategies for implementing these guidelines has not been undertaken. This study aims to test whether quality improvement interventions improve first-line treatment of high BP in CKD, reduce cardiovascular risk, and slow kidney disease progression. with the usual practice. The two interventions include: prompt and supervisory education and the provision of clinical practice guidelines. The study population will be all individuals with CKD from general practice across eight sites across England. Randomization will occur at the general applications level. The intended sample (three arms of 25 treatments) powers the study to detect a 3 mmHg difference in systolic BP between different quality improvement interventions. An additional 10 applications per arm will receive a questionnaire to measure any change in confidence in CKD management. Follow-up will take place in two years. Results will be measured using anonymized routinely collected data extracted from practical computer systems. Our primary outcome measure will be reduction of systolic blood pressure in subjects with CKD and hypertension at 2 years. Secondary outcomes will include biomedical outcomes and quality markers, including practitioner confidence in CKD management. A small group of practitioners (n = 4) will be involved in an in-depth process evaluation. We will use time series data to examine the natural history of CKD in the community. Finally, we will make an economic evaluation based on a comparison of the cost-effectiveness of each intervention.

title: Quality of diabetes care for Gullah families in South Carolina
abstract: Empirical evidence from the Diabetes Control and Complication Study (DCCT) suggests that maintaining normal glycemic control can prevent both microvascular and macrovascular disease in people diagnosed with type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM) (DCCT, 1993). Adults with T2DM are also more likely to have hypertension (73% [HTN]), and patients with both are 2 to 4 times more likely to develop diabetic complications compared to the general population (CDC, 2005). The purpose of this descriptive study was to 1) describe the quality of diabetes care received by Gullah families participating in the Project Sugar research study; and 2) compare Gullah's quality of care with the national sample in the Centers for Disease Control (CDC) Diabetes Report Card, using two blood pressure and HbA1c indicators. was a secondary analysis from a main study comparing selected data with the CDC Diabetes Report Card, the National Health and Nutrition Examination Survey (NHANES III), and the Behavioral Risk Factor Surveillance System (BRFSS). Socio-demographic and clinical data from 1,057 research participants (N = 1,057) Overall, compared with the national sample in the CDC Report Card, HbA1c greater than 9.5% mg/dL was higher among Gullahs (18% versus 30.2%) and blood pressure above 140/90 mmHg was lower (29). Almost half of the gulahs (45.9%) had foot pain, claudication and kidney infection, and renal complications of dialysis (7.3%) He reported neurovascular complications such as Gullah study participants are at risk for diabetes-related complications. The results reveal a quality gap in diabetes care and health disparities in outcome measures. Optimal care in line with clinical guidelines can have a significant impact on reducing complications and health disparities.

title: The rational patient and beyond: The effects of adherence to treatment in persons with psychiatric disabilities.
abstract: Objective: Many people with psychiatric disabilities do not benefit from evidence-based practices because they often do not seek or fully comply with them. One way for psychologists to make sense of this rehabilitation and health decision process and subsequent behavior (whose commitment may be seen as one) is to propose a "rational patient"; that is, decisions are made deliberately by weighing the perceived costs and benefits of treatment. intervention options However, social psychological research suggests limitations for a rational theory of the patient influencing health-related decision-making patterns. Design: The research literature was reviewed for studies of rational patient models and empirically supported alternative theories. Special focus is on models. Outcomes regarding decisions regarding rehabilitation strategies for psychiatric disability: Rational patient concepts have evolved from a variety of psychological models, including the health belief model, the protection motivation theory, and the planned behavior theory. Various implementation strategies have evolved to encourage rational decision-making. However, research also suggests that it is limited. ions to rational negotiations of health. (1) Rather than being thoughtfully and consciously considered, many health decisions are implicit and potentially occur outside of awareness. (2) Decisions are not always planned; Often, it is the immediate needs of a context that have the greatest impacts, rather than an earlier balance of costs and benefits. (3) Cold cognitions generally do not dictate the process; "emotional factors play an important role in health decisions. Each of these limitations suggests additional implementation strategies that facilitate a person's health decisions. Conclusion: Older models of rational decision making need to be replaced. With multiprocess models that explain supra-negotiable factors in health decisions and behavior (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2016 APA, all rights reserved)

title: Organizing gene therapy research in competent adult patients, today and tomorrow: implications of EU Directive 2001/20/EC
Results of major clinical trials: critical evaluation, information circulation and media coverage
abstract: The roundtable chose to focus its discussion on trials that are likely to change medical practice and behavior in terms of their importance. Such trials may be pre- or post-marketing studies. For a study's findings to result in a change in practice, they must be reliable and meet basic methodological criteria. However, it is appropriate to complete this dual assessment using an assessment checklist appropriate for each category of users, ie doctors and patients who are sometimes directly informed by the media, and the prescribing Regulatory Authority. Roundtable members proposed the 'Giens 2003 checklist'. It consists of an interpretative semi-quantitative assessment checklist based on simple messages about the application. Critical evaluation is a necessary prelude to the process of distributing results to the various interested parties (healthcare professionals, patients, patient organisations, the media and the general public) and informing these parties in easily understandable but accurate terms. Behavior change and/or the publication of guidelines and practical application of the results are the next steps where a certain lag time is inevitable. Evaluation of implementation programs, together with an accurate analysis of the barriers to changing medical practice, should improve and accelerate the implementation of important results in the future to optimize patient management.

title: The right things for early intervention in psychosis: time, attitude, location, intensity, treatment and cost
abstract: This article shares information about an exciting new approach to psychiatry. Over the past 12 years, the authors have worked with young people experiencing their first episode of psychosis. It is clear that intervention in the earliest stages of psychotic illness allows clinicians to make a significant difference in the lives of young people and their families. This article summarizes current intervention strategies that are considered best practice guidelines for early treatment.

title: Increase in care in private hospitals
The role of the clinical pharmacist on lipid control in dyslipidemic patients in northern Jordan
abstract: OBJECTIVE: The aim of this study is to investigate the effectiveness of providing clinical pharmacy services in achieving the target lipid profile in dyslipidemia patients in Northern Jordan. The study was conducted in a primary health care facility in northern Jordan. METHODS: One hundred and fifty-two dyslipidemia patients were randomized to intervention and control groups and followed for 6 months. Intervention group patients were followed extensively by a clinical pharmacist who worked closely with physicians in controlling their lipid profile, according to the third edition of the National Cholesterol Education Program Adult Treatment Panel, while control group patients were provided with standard medical care. The main outcome measures the percentage of patients on the low-density lipoprotein cholesterol target in the intervention group compared to the percentage of patients on the low-density lipoprotein cholesterol target in the control group at the end of the study. RESULTS: One hundred and twenty-five patients completed the study period. After 6 months, 94.5% of intervention group patients and 71.2% of control patients had their target low-density lipoprotein cholesterol levels (P value < 0.001, Pearson Chi-Square) compared to 24.7% and 28.8% at baseline, respectively. test) reached. Most of the pharmacists' recommendations (90.4%) were followed by physicians, and total lipid-lowering agent use increased to 91.8% for intervention group patients and 86.5% for control patients, compared to baseline 69.9% and 78.8%. CONCLUSION: Implementation of clinical pharmacy services in Jordan has improved the lipid profiles of dyslipidemic patients.

title: The role of GPs in increasing compliance with colorectal cancer screening: a randomized controlled trial (Italy)
abstract: Objectives To evaluate the effect of the provider (GP vs. hospital) in reversing the stool occult blood test. To analyze the characteristics of GP associated with high cohesion among its beneficiaries. Methods A questionnaire about screening attitudes was sent to 1192 GPs working in 13 counties of the Lazio region. We asked GPs to participate in a randomized trial, we sampled 130 GPs, and about 1/10 (n = 3657) of GPs 50-75 year old beneficiaries were invited for screening at the GP office, and 1/10 (3675) were at the nearest gastroenterology centre. Results 58.5% of family physicians completed the questionnaire and 22.7% agreed to participate in the study. Concordance was 50% in the GP arm and 16% in the hospital arm (RR 3.4";" 95% CI: 3.13–3.70). There was a high variability in the fit achieved by the GPs. GPs visiting more than 25 patients per day and incorrectly recommended colorectal cancer screening had lower agreement (OR 0.74, 95% CI: 0.57–0.95 and OR 0.76, 95% CI, respectively: 0.59–0.97) . Conclusions Involving GPs in colorectal cancer screening can be very effective in increasing compliance, but effectiveness depends on their willingness to be involved.

title: The role of nurses/social workers in using a multidimensional guideline for diagnosing anxiety and compulsive behaviors in people with intellectual disabilities
abstract: OBJECTIVES AND OBJECTIVES: This study aims to (1) investigate the impact of the implementation of the 'Diagnostic Manual for Anxiety and Compulsive Behaviors in Mentally Disabled Clients' on the knowledge and self-efficacy of nurses/social workers"; and (2) nurses/social workers during the diagnostic process while applying the manual. BACKGROUND: Nurses/social workers are in intense contact with clients with intellectual disabilities. Despite this key position, the contribution of nurses/social workers to the diagnosis of mental health problems and compulsive behaviors is quite limited. They developed the Diagnostic Guide. This article evaluates the application of this guide on the knowledge and self-efficacy of nurses/social workers and the role of nurses/social workers in the diagnostic process DESIGN: A comparative multi-case study design was used in this study. heat METHODS: Qualitative and quantitative research methods. RESULTS: Studying the 'Diagnostic Guide for Anxiety and Compulsive Behaviors' resulted in a statistically significant increase in knowledge and self-efficacy among nurses/social workers in the experimental condition compared to nurses/social workers in the control condition. Nurses/social workers and psychologists appreciated the more active contribution of nurses/social workers in the diagnostic process. CONCLUSION: Working with the guide increased the knowledge and self-efficacy of nurses/social workers, and enabled nurses/social workers to participate more actively in the diagnosis process. RELATED TO CLINICAL PRACTICE: After following a training program, nurses/social workers can contribute effectively to the diagnostic process in clients with anxiety and related compulsive behaviors.

title: The role of relationship-based developmentally supportive neonatal intensive care in reinforcing outcomes for preterm infants.
abstract: This article details the conceptual framework, clinical application and effectiveness of a relationship-based developmental supportive approach to neonatal intensive care, called NIDCAP (Neonatal Individualized Developmental Care and Assessment Programme). The results of the approach are reported in relation to infant health and development, reduction of hospital costs and family cohesion. The approach is driven by a neurodevelopmental framework for understanding preterm infants and relies on the capacity of professionals to collaborate with each other and with families to support infants' medical, developmental and emotional well-being. The primary tool for clinical practice is detailed behavioral observation with subsequent recommendations for individualized care based on the infant's current functioning and clear developmental goals. A number of key components of developmental care delivery have been identified, including strategies for coordinated discharge planning and linkage to community services. Voices of individual clinicians highlight the transition from protocol-based to relationship-based care.

title: The role of stimulants in the treatment of preschool children with attention deficit hyperactivity disorder.
abstract: Symptoms of attention deficit hyperactivity disorder (ADHD) can begin early, starting before age 6. Despite the significant number of preschool-aged children who can be diagnosed with ADHD, there is limited controlled data on pharmacological interventions increasingly used in this population. A 1990 review showed that 34% of pediatricians and 15% of family physicians prescribed psychostimulant drugs to preschoolers with ADHD, and pharmacoepidemiological studies show that stimulant use in preschool children increased in the 1990s. Unfortunately, only six controlled trials with a total enrollment of less than 200 have been conducted using these drugs in preschool children. While these small studies provide some evidence of some benefit from the use of methylphenidate in preschool children with ADHD, more data is critically needed. The practice parameters developed by the American Academy of Child and Adolescent Psychiatry and the American Academy of Pediatrics provide some guidance on the diagnosis and treatment of young children with ADHD, but are primarily based on research in elementary school-aged children. The ongoing PATS (Preschool ADHD Treatment Study), funded by the National Institute of Mental Health, will provide important clinical guidance for diagnostic considerations and intervention strategies for children 3-5 years of age with ADHD. Until the release of data from the PATS study, clinicians must rely on developmental assessment skills, standardized rating tools available, reports on the child from multiple sources of information, and information on the risks and benefits of available pharmacological and behavioral treatments to treat preschoolers. children with ADHD effectively

title: The role of surveillance in the treatment of small renal masses
abstract: Incidentally detected small renal masses (SRMs) have increased significantly in recent years due to the widespread use of advanced cross-sectional imaging. A significant number of incidental SRMs are diagnosed in older patients who are more likely to undergo imaging for other medical problems. The natural history of SRMs has not been well understood historically because most masses are surgically removed soon after diagnosis. Several reports on surveillance of SRMs have been published in the last few years. According to a recent meta-analysis, SRMs have variable growth rates with an average of 0.28 cm/year when followed conservatively with serial imaging. Larger series with longer follow-up are needed, but a significant number of small tumors appear to have a lazy behavior with slow growth rate and limited progression tendency. The standard of care for augmenting SRMs is surgery. Up to one-third of surgically removed tumors <4 cm are histologically benign. The results of current surgical treatment of histologically confirmed, <4 cm, renal cell carcinomas are excellent, but this has not resulted in a reduction in mortality. Based on these considerations and the available data on the natural history of SRMs, it seems reasonable to think that we may be overtreating these lesions. This is especially true for elderly or unfit patients with reduced life expectancy. In these selected patients and patients who refuse active therapy, it seems reasonable to recommend an initial period of active surveillance for incidental SRMs and delayed intervention for tumors that will exhibit rapid growth during follow-up. Percutaneous needle biopsies of renal tumors can be performed safely using modern techniques and have the potential to characterize SRMs in histological diagnosis, thus allowing better selection of the most appropriate conservative or active therapy for each individual patient.

title: Role of theory in research for the development and evaluation of patient safety practices
abstract: Theories provide a way to understand and predict the effects of patient safety practices (PSPs), interventions to prevent or mitigate harm from healthcare, or the risks of such harm. Yet most published reviews make little or no reference to theory, thus hampering efforts to generalize findings from one context to another. Theories from a wide variety of disciplines are potentially relevant for research on PSPs. The theory can be used in research to explain clinical and organizational behavior, guide the development and selection of PSPs, and evaluate their implementation and mechanisms of action. An important recommendation from an expert consensus process is that researchers should define the theoretical basis for selected intervention components or provide a clear logic model for "why this PSP should work." Future theory-driven assessments will increase generalizability and a cumulative understanding of the nature of change.

title: Social worker and nurse roles in case management: Application of the three Rs
abstract: There are different skills that nurse case managers and social workers need to achieve a good patient outcome. The problem is that there is a gap in the relationship between social workers and nurses, and that gap is built on factors that can and should be addressed. This gap can be minimized through conscious effort, by addressing the issue, and by a willingness to maximize the energy expended in professional relationships to improve patient outcomes. The professional experience of each practitioner is equally important. Intervention is based on the Three Rs: Reciprocity, Responsibility and Respect.

title: SPHERE Study. Secondary prevention of heart disease in general practice: protocol of a randomized controlled trial of specific practice and patient care plans with parallel qualitative, economic, and policy analyzes. [ISRCTN24081411
abstract: BACKGROUND: The purpose of the SPHERE study is to design, implement and evaluate personalized practice and self-care plans to improve the course of care and objective clinical outcomes for patients with coronary heart disease (CHD) located in two different health systems in general practice. Irish island. CHD is a common cause of death and a significant cause of morbidity in Ireland. Secondary prevention has been proposed as a key strategy to reduce CHD mortality levels, and general practice has been highlighted as an ideal setting for secondary prevention interventions. Current indications show substantial room for improvement in providing secondary prevention for patients with established heart disease on the island of Ireland. The review literature recommends structured programs with continued support and follow-up of patients; providing training tailored to practice needs to access evidence of the effectiveness of secondary prevention; structured recall programs that also take into account individual practice needs; and patient-centered consultations accompanied by attention to disease management guidelines. METHODS: SPHERE was a cluster randomized controlled trial that recruited 960 patients from 48 practices at three study centers (Belfast, Dublin and Galway) with administration-level randomization to intervention and control groups.Primary outcomes were blood pressure, total cholesterol, physical and mental health status ( SF-12) and hospital readmissions. Intervention takes place at two years and data is collected at baseline, one-year, and two-year follow-up. Data are derived from medical charts, GP consultations, and patient mail questionnaires. SPHERE intervention, general practice It involves the implementation of a structured, systematic care program for patients with CHD who go to It is a multifaceted intervention developed to respond to barriers and solutions to optimal secondary prevention identified in preliminary qualitative research with practitioners and patients. General practitioners and practice nurses attend training sessions on drug prescribing guidelines for facilitating behavior change and secondary prevention of CHD. Patients are invited to attend regular four-month consultations for two years, during which goals and objectives for secondary prevention are set and reviewed. The analysis will be strengthened with economic, political and qualitative components.

title: Standard of Care: A Case Report and Ethical Analysis
abstract: Increasingly, doctors are allowing their perceived legal responsibilities to supersede their clinical judgment. Misunderstandings surrounding the term "standard of care" have fostered fears of responsibility and led to defensive medicine practices. Physicians may view the standard of care as a technical or legal requirement, but the optimal standard will be one based on detailed knowledge of the patient's medical history and personal situation. It will include the clinical judgment of the physician combining specific technical and legal knowledge with clinical experience in the care of patients. Sometimes, such judgment may conflict with a court's judgment that takes into account technical and legal information without the benefit of clinical judgment. Physicians must be prepared to advocate for their patients, especially when legal actions are flawed or harmful. Systematic review and analysis processes, such as those used by ethics consultants, can help resolve questions about the standard of care.

title: The state of office-based interventions for youth tobacco use
abstract: Tobacco use is a serious pediatric health problem, as most tobacco users begin to depend on it in childhood or adolescence. Primary care settings offer enormous opportunities for young tobacco users to provide tobacco treatment. While evidence-based practice guidelines for treating nicotine addiction in youth are not yet available, current clinical practice guidelines for professional organizations and adults offer expert opinion-based recommendations. This article reports on current tobacco treatment practices by pediatric and family medicine clinicians, discusses the similarities and differences between adolescent and adult tobacco use, summarizes and presents research efforts to date and the latest research that can ultimately help inform and guide clinicians. Current recommendations on the treatment of tobacco use in youth. Finally, recommendations are made for the primary care clinician, professional organizations, and health care systems and policies. Pediatricians and other clinicians can and should play an important role in the treatment of tobacco addiction in youth.

title: Early Life Asthma Research Working Team (STELAR) consortium 'Asthma e-lab': team science bringing together data, methods and researchers
abstract: We have created Asthma e-Lab, a secure web-based research environment to support the consistent recording, identification and sharing of data, computational/statistical methods and emerging findings across five UK birth cohorts. e-Lab serves as a data repository for our combined dataset and provides computational resources and a scientific social network to support collaborative research. All activities are transparent and the resulting findings are shared via e-Lab in conjunction with the explanations of analytical methods, thus enabling knowledge transfer. eLab facilitates iterative interdisciplinary dialogue between clinicians, statisticians, computer scientists, mathematicians, geneticists and basic scientists and captures the collective thinking behind interpretations of findings.

title: Systematic effect of gain and loss framed messages on interest and use of different types of health behaviour.
abstract: Systematically framing health messages in terms of gains or losses influences the behavior people adopt. Rothman and Salovey hypothesized that the relative impact of win-loss-framed messages depends on people's perceptions of the risk or uncertainty associated with adopting the proposed behavior. Specifically, messages with a loss-frame are more effective at promoting behavior that detects (screening) disease, while messages with a gain-frame are more effective at promoting behaviors that confirm (preventing) health. Two experiments provide direct testing of this conceptual framework. In Experiment 1, participants' willingness to take action after reading about a new illness depended on how the information was framed and the type of behavior encouraged. Experiment 2 replicated and extended these findings with the real health problem of gum disease. Leaflets with earnings-frames increased interest in a plaque-fighting mouthwash, while brochures with lost-frames increased interest in a plaque-detecting mouthwash. Research on message framing provides a theoretically based guide for the development of effective health messages.

title: The time is now: organization of training and services
Tools of an evidence-based culture: application of clinical practice guidelines in an Israeli HMO
abstract: OBJECTIVE: Although clinical practice guidelines (CPGs) are implemented with the assumption that they will improve the quality, efficiency and consistency of healthcare, they generally have limited impact in changing physicians' behavior. The aim of this study was to design and implement an effective program for formulating, publishing and implementing CPGs to promote the development of an evidence-based culture in an Israeli HMO. METHOD: The authors implemented a four-phase program of step-by-step collaborative efforts with academic institutions that consisted of developing quantitative tools to evaluate prescribing models, updating CPGs, collecting input from MDs through focus groups and quantitative surveys, and conducting a two-person randomized controlled trial. . - gradual, multi-faceted intervention. The test case of this study was the development, dissemination and application of CPG for the treatment of acute uncomplicated cystitis in adult women. To improve the rate at which physicians prescribe nitrofurantoin, the first-line drug, and in the absence of nitrofurantoin, interventions in the form of a conference call and a letter with personalized feedback were administered, both individually and in combination, adhering to the following. The recommended three-day course of treatment with ofloxacin. RESULTS: The tools and data generation capabilities designed and created in Phase I of the project were integral components of all subsequent phases of the program. Personalized feedback alone was sufficient to increase the rate of adherence to guidelines by 19.4% (95% CI = 16.7, 22.1). CONCLUSIONS: This study provides a template for introducing the experimental component necessary to foster an evidence-based culture. This process of collaborative efforts between academic institutions and a managed care organization can be beneficial for other health systems.

title: US training institute for dissemination and application research in health
abstract: Background Dissemination and application science (D&I) develops the knowledge base on how to best integrate evidence-based interventions into clinical and community settings and reshape the nature or conduct of research to make them more relevant and actionable. settings.
