While the field is growing, there are only a few training programs for D&I research”, which is an important way to help build the capacity of the field. To increase the United States' D&I research capacity, the National Institutes of Health and Veterans Health Administration has recruited postdoctoral-level students who want to advance this science. collaborated to develop a five-day training institute for candidates.Methods Health Dissemination and Application Research (TIDIRH) Results TIDIRH used a five-day residential immersion method to maximize interaction opportunities for trainees and faculty. retake own institutions to increase further investment TIDIRH curriculum, structured large group discussions and interactive small group sessions Thirty-five of 266 applicants for first annual training institute, psychology (12 trainees); medicine (6 trainees); epidemiology (5 trainees) ; health behavior/health education (4 trainees); and any A maximum of two people from any institution and 1 intern from the fields of education and human development, health policy and management, health care research, public health studies, public policy and social work. The institute was rated very helpful by participants, and six months after the institute, a follow-up survey (97% response rate) revealed that 72% had initiated a new grant proposal in D&I research; "28% had received funding, and 77%' TIDIRH has used TIDIRH's skills to impress multidisciplinary peers about D&I research by establishing local research networks, holding official presentations and symposia, teaching, and managing interdisciplinary teams to conduct D&I research. plans are planned to continue and expand TIDIRH in the coming years. Strengths are seen in the layout format, the quality and flexibility of the faculty, in adjusting the content to meet trainee needs and highlighting concrete examples of D&I that change annually by the local host institution Lessons learned and for the future plans TIDIR H trainings are summarized.

title: UPBEAT depression and coronary heart disease programme: using the UK Medical Research Council framework to design a complex nurse-led intervention for use in primary care
abstract: Background: Depression is common in coronary heart disease (CHD) and increases the incidence of coronary symptoms and death in patients with CHD. Interventions that can be used in primary care are needed to improve both mood and cardiac outcomes. The UPBEAT-UK research program has been funded by the NHS National Institute for Health Research (NIHR) to explore the relationship between CHD and depression and develop a new intervention for use in primary care. METHODS: Using Medical Research Council (MRC) guidelines to develop and evaluate complex interventions, we conducted a systematic review and qualitative research to develop a nurse-led intervention in primary care to improve mood and cardiac outcomes in patients with CHD and depression. Iterative literature review was used to identify evidence and theory to synthesize our empirical work and inform intervention. CONCLUSIONS: We developed a primary care-based nurse-led personalized care intervention that uses elements of case management to promote self-management. Following the biopsychosocial assessment, a personalized care plan is created. Nurses trained in behavior modification techniques make it easier for patients to address issues that are important to them. The identification and use of available resources is encouraged. Nurse time is protected by phone monitoring. CONCLUSIONS: The application of the MRC framework for complex interventions allowed us to develop an evidence-based intervention informed by patient and clinician preferences and established theory. The feasibility and acceptability of this intervention is now being further tested in an exploratory trial.

title: Use of computerized birthday greeting reminders in diabetes management.
abstract: BACKGROUND: Although mailed reminders have been used for prevention among general populations, few studies have evaluated their effectiveness among chronically ill populations. OBJECTIVE: We evaluated the effectiveness of mailed reminders in improving diabetes management. The reminder included a letter from the individual's primary care physician (PCP), a self-care handbook, a preventative care checklist, and specific recommendations for routine monitoring and receiving screening. METHODS: Of 195 PCPs working in a large group practice, 111 agreed to randomize adult patients with diabetes to either reminder (n=1,641) or usual care (n=1,668). Using data from automated databases, we fit generalized estimation equations to evaluate the effect of reminder receipt on fasting lipid profile and glycosylated hemoglobin test, expanded retinal exam receipt, and frequency of visits and glycosylated hemoglobin and cholesterol levels at 6 and 12 months following randomization. In the year following randomisation. RESULTS: Reminder and usual care recipients did not differ in sociodemographic, clinical, or prior test characteristics. At 6 months following randomization, reminder recipients were more likely to receive a retinal exam (odds ratio [OR], 1.29"; 95% confidence interval [95% CI], 1.12 to 1.49) and a diabetes visit (OR, 1.28; 95). %CI, 1.12 to 1.47. At 12 months following randomization, reminder recipients were more likely to receive a glycosylated hemoglobin test (OR, 1.21; 95% CI, 1.03 to 1.43), retinal exam (OR, 1.23; 95% CI), 1.07 to 1.41) and diabetes visit (OR, 1.25; 95% CI, 1.09 to 1.29). During the follow-up year, reminder recipients also tended to have a glycosylated hemoglobin test that did not reflect poor control (<9.5%). CONCLUSIONS: We found small but significant improvements in the management of patients with diabetes who received a computerized mail reminder.

title: Use of laboratory intervention to stop the flow of fresh frozen plasma
abstract: Four laboratory intervention methods were tested by the hospital blood bank to replace the use of fresh frozen plasma (FFP). Over a one-year period, a usage audit was serially initiated with feedback to physicians, a recurrent training program was introduced that defined guidelines for the use of FFP for home workers, a form was submitted requiring justification for FFP orders, and a policy was established that required pathologist approval for normal or coagulation work. Overall, when comparing the period following all forms of intervention (February 1986-October 1986) with the baseline period before any form of intervention (July 1984-March 1985), FFP use decreased by 52% versus an increase of 17%. red blood cell use. It was concluded that blood bankers could significantly change the use of this product by using established methods to change doctor ordering behavior.

title: Using simulation for training teamwork skills in healthcare: how low can you go?
abstract: High fidelity simulation has become a popular technique for training teamwork skills in high-risk industries such as aerospace, healthcare, and nuclear power generation. Simulation is a powerful training tool because it allows the instructor to systematically control the program of practice, the presentation of feedback, and the introduction (or suppression) of environmental distractions in a safe, controlled learning environment. Unfortunately, many in the education community have come to use the terms simulation and high-quality simulation almost synonymously. This is unfortunate because doing so puts an undue emphasis on instructional technology to the detriment of more important issues such as the aims, content and design of education. It also perpetuates several myths: simulation accuracy is one-dimensional, or higher levels of simulation accuracy lead to increased training effectiveness. The authors propose a typology of simulation accuracy and provide examples of how different classes of simulation have been successfully used to train teamwork skills in high-risk industries. Guidelines are also provided to maximize the utility of simulation for training teamwork skills in healthcare.

title: Use of nicotine inhalers to quit smoking
abstract: OBJECTIVE: To raise awareness of nicotine inhaler among nurse practitioners (NPs) by providing clinical and practical information on the use of nicotine inhaler as a treatment option for smoking cessation. DATA SOURCES: This included data-driven and review articles in the medical literature, tobacco use and addiction clinical practice guideline, and Medline and Cinahl search engines. The criteria for the search keywords were "nicotine inhaler" and "nicotine replacement therapy". The first survey was conducted in December 2004. RESULTS: The nicotine inhaler was tested to be safe and effective in tobacco cessation treatment. Clinical trials show that the nicotine inhaler is useful alone or in addition to other pharmacological treatments. Current national guidelines recommend the use of a nicotine inhaler for smoking cessation treatment. APPLICATIONS FOR APPLICATION: The nicotine inhaler is suitable for many different smokers, including certain types of heart patients. NPs may incorporate a nicotine inhaler into a group of nicotine replacement therapies to enable smokers to be successful in quitting tobacco.

title: Use of appropriate osteoporosis drugs improves following a multifaceted educational intervention: Canadian quality circle project (CQC)
abstract: OBJECTIVE: Osteoporosis is a serious but treatable condition. However, the use of appropriate treatment of the disease remains sub-optimal. Therefore, the aim of the study was to change the therapy practice behavior of physicians according to the Osteoporosis Canada 2002 guidelines. METHODS: The project was a two-year cohort study consisting of five Quality Circle (QC) phases, including: 1) Training and Baseline Data Collection, 2) Initial Training Intervention and Initial Follow-up Data Collection 3) First Strategy Implementation Session, 4) Final Training Intervention and Final Follow-up Data Collection; and 5) Final Strategy Implementation Session. A total of 340 family physicians formed 34 QCs and participated in the study. Physicians evaluated a randomized total of 8376, 7354, and 3673 patient charts at baseline, follow-up #1, and final follow-up, respectively. The patients were divided into three groups";" high-risk, low-risk and fracture-free low-risk groups. The generalized estimation equations technique was used to model the variation of physicians over time. group followed by 1.15 (95% CI: 0.97, 1.36) and 1.16 (95% CI: 0.93, 1.44) and 1.20 (95% CI: 1.01 1.43) and 1.23 (95% CI: 0.97) , 1.55) in the low-risk group, respectively. #1 and in the low-risk group with no fracture at final follow-up. CONCLUSION: Quality Control methodology has been successful in increasing physicians' appropriate use of osteoporosis medications in accordance with Osteoporosis Canada guidelines.

title: Value of 'kind reminder' in safe medical behavior
abstract: Background We introduced the 'Gentle reminder' based on knowledge and methods derived from cognitive psychology and behavioral economics. This procedure requires public planning of safety norms and the agreement of all team members to help each other to comply with this plan. Methods Team members agree to kindly remind their colleagues whenever they deviate from safety norms. For the study, we observed the use of gloves during intravenous insertion and blood collection. Results and discussion During the 2-year observation, safe behavior increased 55% in a ward before the “soft reminder” was applied; After 2 months it was over 80%; After 2 months, it was 83% and 90%;" and eventually fixed at 90%. A similar pattern was documented in all wards. This is a recommended way to overcome unsafe behavior.

title: Theory and practice in the management of depressive disorders
abstract: Scientific, professional, and government agencies have intensified their efforts in recent years to formulate guidelines for the treatment of depression so that medical practice meets these standards and thereby improves patient care. 'Evidence-based medicine' demands that medical practice make explicit reference to the best available scientific knowledge. Empirical data on the epidemiology of care show that there are large differences between guidelines and routine practice. Undetected mental disorders vary between 45% and 90%. Only 1 in 10 people suffering from depression receive adequate treatment. Treatment is inadequate because up to 50% of treatments are terminated prematurely and patient non-compliance prevents appropriate treatment, as the doses prescribed are routinely too low. Psychological treatment is provided in only 60% of cases who need it and is often non-specific, ie listening or giving advice. In addition, there are large regional variations in prescribing patterns, indicating that treatment is influenced by many non-medical factors. Empirical studies show that informing physicians and even measures to improve recognition alone are not sufficient to change treatment behavior. But better disease outcomes can be demonstrated, at least for more severe cases, if measures are taken to directly improve treatment interventions. If he is to understand that the therapist is not following treatment guidelines, he must first understand the medical decision-making process. Action theory provides a model that combines theoretical and empirical knowledge, goal setting, medical and emotional assessment, and operational procedures. On the basis of this theory, future guidelines should specify the context in which they claim to be valid, be empirically tested for their applicability and impact on patient outcomes, and appropriate attention should be paid to non-medical factors that have a major impact. about medical practice.

title: Therapeutic improvement: Nursing intervention category for patients diagnosed with Readiness for Therapeutic Regime Management
abstract: OBJECTIVES: To introduce a new category of nursing intervention called therapeutic empowerment. BACKGROUND: Less than half of North Americans follow their doctor's recommendations for diet and exercise, even if it's crucial to their health or recovery. It is imperative that nurses think of new ways to promote healthy behaviors. Therapeutic healing aims to provide such a new approach. Traditional intervention techniques that focus on education, contracts, social support and more frequent interaction with physicians are not effective when used alone. Successful strategies have been multidisciplinary";" and interventions by professional nurses who help patients understand their illness and disease process and help them develop their disease management and self-management skills. Therapeutic improvement includes Theory of Change Phases, Theory of Engagement, Motivational Interviewing techniques and tools specifically designed for process evaluation of health-promoting interventions. METHOD: This is a critical review of approaches that have not been synthesized in a single published article so far. CONCLUSIONS: Based on the commonly used Phases of Change model, therapeutic augmentation is beneficial for patients who are in the action phase of change. By using therapeutic reinforcement along with therapeutic strategies described in the Stages of Change Theory, such as emergency management, helping relationships, counterconditioning, stimulus control, and Motivational Interviewing techniques, nursing professionals can significantly increase the chances of patients moving from action to the maintenance stage of change. for a particular health behavior. RELATED TO CLINICAL PRACTICE: Using the nursing intervention category, therapeutic reinforcement can increase caregiver success in helping patients maintain healthy behaviors.

title: Treatment and supportive care of alcoholics: guidelines for practitioners
abstract: BACKGROUND/OBJECTIVE: Alcoholism is a common disorder in our societies. However, only a small percentage of alcoholics appear in certain psychotherapeutic treatment programs. The vast majority are seen by general practitioners or other medical specialties, where they are treated extensively for their alcohol-related comorbidities. However, alcoholism itself, which is the cause of these comorbidities, is rarely treated. This article provides a guide for experts and non-experts on how to properly treat these patients and increase motivation to abstain in non-specific treatment programs. In addition, the concept can be quickly and easily integrated into the daily routine of any therapy team. METHODS: Literature on therapeutic modalities of brief interventions, motivational interviewing, and pharmacological relapse prevention was reviewed in PubMed for the years 1991-2005. CONCLUSION/CONCLUSION: The burden of alcoholism and alcohol abuse as primary disorders is quite significant, but is often underestimated, even by therapists from various medical disciplines. Systematic studies of the brief intervention method, motivational interviewing, as well as pharmacological treatment with acamprosate, have shown that these are powerful methods that can be easily used to increase the duration of abstinence and the motivation of patients to engage in further specific treatment.

title: Thoughtless design of electronic health record leads to overuse, but purposeful design can improve patient care
Three- and 4-dimensional ultrasound in obstetric practice: does it help?
abstract: OBJECTIVE: The purpose of this article was to review the published literature on 3D ultrasound (3DUS) and 4D ultrasound (4DUS) in obstetrics and to determine whether 3DUS adds diagnostic information to what is currently provided by 2D ultrasound (2DUS). ) and if so, in what areas. METHODS: A PubMed search was conducted for articles reporting the use of 3DUS or 4DUS in obstetrics. Seven hundred and six articles were identified, of which 525 were actually related to the topic of this review. Articles describing technical developments, clinical studies, reviews, editorials, and studies on fetal behavior or maternal-fetal attachment were reviewed. CONCLUSIONS: Three-dimensional ultrasound provides additional diagnostic information for the diagnosis of facial anomalies, particularly facial clefts. There is also evidence that 3DUS provides additional diagnostic information in neural tube defects and skeletal malformations. Large studies comparing 2DUS and 3DUS for the diagnosis of congenital anomalies have not yielded conclusive results. Preliminary evidence suggests that sonographic tomography can reduce the examination time of obstetric ultrasound examination with minimal impact on the visualization rates of anatomical structures. CONCLUSIONS: Three-dimensional ultrasound provides additional diagnostic information for diagnosing facial anomalies, evaluation of neural tube defects, and skeletal malformations. Additional research is needed to determine the clinical role of 3DUS and 4DUS in the diagnosis of congenital heart disease and central nervous system anomalies. Future studies should determine whether the information contained in the volume dataset alone is sufficient to evaluate fetal biometric measurements and diagnose congenital anomalies.

title: through the carpal tunnel
thyroid disease during pregnancy
Tics in the Pediatric Population: Pragmatic Management
abstract: OBJECTIVE: Primary tic disorders, especially Tourette's syndrome, are very common movement disorders in childhood. However, the management of such patients still poses great therapeutic challenges for medical professionals. METHODS: Based on a synthesis of existing guidelines and newer therapeutic developments published in Europe, Canada, and the United States, the authors provide a pragmatic guide to assist clinicians in deciding when and how to treat patients with primary tic disorders. . RESULTS: After a systematic evaluation of tics and common neuropsychiatric comorbidities (primarily attention deficit hyperactivity disorder [ADHD] and obsessive-compulsive disorder [OCD]), the first step in treatment is comprehensive psychoeducation of patients and families addressing the multifaceted phenomenology. tics and related behaviors, coping mechanisms, prognosis and treatment options. Hierarchical assessment of treatment goals (ie, tics versus comorbid behavioral symptoms) is crucial when more active intervention beyond careful monitoring is indicated. Behavioral treatments for tics are limited to older children and are not readily available in all centers, particularly due to the scarcity of well-trained therapists. Antipsychotics for tics, stimulants for ADHD, and pharmacological treatments such as atomoxetine and alpha2A-agonists for children with tics plus ADHD represent widely available and effective treatment options, but safety monitoring must be provided. Combined polypharmacological and behavioral/pharmacological approaches as well as neuromodulation strategies have not been adequately explored in this patient population. CONCLUSION: The treatment of children with tics and Tourette's syndrome is multifaceted. Multidisciplinary teams with expertise in neurology, psychiatry, psychology and pediatrics can help meet the complex needs of these children.

title: Tobacco brief intervention training for chiropractic, acupuncture and massage practitioners: CAM access study protocol
abstract: BACKGROUND: Tobacco use remains the leading cause of morbidity and mortality in the United States. Effective tobacco cessation aids are widely available but underused. Tobacco cessation brief interventions (BIs) increase quit rates. However, BI training has focused on traditional medicine providers, ignoring other health practitioners who have regular contact with tobacco users. The 2007 National Health Interview Survey found that approximately 20% of provider-based complementary and alternative medicine (CAM) users were tobacco users. Thus, TAT practitioners represent a large, untapped community resource for potentially promoting tobacco cessation and the use of effective quit aids. Current BI training is not well suited to the background and practice patterns of CAM practitioners, as it assumes a traditional foundation of biomedical knowledge and philosophical approaches to health, healing, and the patient-practitioner relationship. There is an urgent need to develop and test the effectiveness of BI training that is both based on Public Health Service (PHS) Guidelines for tobacco addiction treatment and is relevant and appropriate for CAM practitioners. METHODS/DESIGN: The CAM Reach (CAMR) intervention is a tobacco cessation BI education and office system intervention tailored specifically for chiropractors, acupuncturists, and massage therapists. The CAMR study uses a one-group one-way crossover design to examine the impact of CAMR intervention on tobacco-related practice behaviors of CAM practitioners. Primary outcomes included CAM practitioners' self-reported tobacco use screening and BIs. Secondary outcomes include tobacco smoking patients' readiness to quit, attempts to quit, use of guideline-based treatments, and quit rates, as well as actions by non-smokers to help someone else quit. DISCUSSION: CAM practitioners care for a significant number of tobacco users. Practice patterns and philosophical approaches to health and healing are well suited to providing BIs. The CAMR study examines the impact of the CAMR intervention on practitioners' tobacco-related practice behaviors, CAM patient behaviors, and documents the factors that are important for conducting practice-based research in real-world CAM applications.

title: Tobacco cessation in primary care: maximizing intervention strategies
abstract: The most effective preventive intervention a clinician can provide to patients who use tobacco against heart disease, cancer, cerebrovascular disease, and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease is an empathetic, personalized smoking cessation intervention program with extended assistance and follow-up. The goal of the intervention should be to quit smoking completely. Reduction does not provide direct health benefits to the individual smoker. Interventions are readily available but underused, in part due to a lack of clinician training and institutional support. This article summarizes current guidelines for smoking cessation interventions as a framework to get started. The guidelines include the Transtheoretical Model of patient behavior change and the "Five A's": Ask, Advise, Evaluate, Help, and Edit. Pharmacotherapeutic tools are being evaluated, including nicotine replacement therapies (nicotine gums, patches, nasal sprays, inhalers, and novel therapies) and non-nicotine therapies (bupropion, clonidine, nortriptyline, and other antidepressants and anxiolytics). Compliance verification methods, new approaches to tobacco and addiction treatment that have emerged in the recent research literature are reviewed. Beyond this framework, specific consideration should be given to certain tobacco users (including smokeless tobacco users), cultural and ethnic minorities, adolescents who use snuff and bidis, women, Medicaid recipients and users of multiple types of tobacco. With this framework and the modifications that may be necessary for certain patient categories, practicing clinicians can incorporate a successful tobacco cessation intervention program into daily practice with quit rates approaching 20%.

title: Quitting tobacco at the dentist's office
abstract: Evidence-based tobacco cessation guidelines, when used by clinicians, are effective in reducing tobacco use and enabling patients to quit successfully. Dentists are encouraged to provide instruction and intervention on tobacco cessation in the dental practice. The dentist is in a unique position to relate oral findings to the patient and advise patients who use tobacco to quit smoking. In addition, dentists can assess patients' self-dependence and readiness to quit tobacco use. With this information, dentists can help patients quit tobacco use by providing appropriate pharmacotherapeutic assistance, thereby improving their oral and general health.

title: Tobacco Cessation Education for Complementary and Alternative Medicine Practitioners: Results of a Practice-Based Trial
abstract: INTRODUCTION: Brief behavioral intervention (BI) is a well-known tobacco cessation best practice among traditional health practitioners. Complementary and alternative medicine (CAM) practitioners treat a significant number of tobacco users, but do not systematically receive BI training. The CAM Reach study developed and evaluated a tobacco cessation BI training program/practice system intervention specifically tailored for CAM practitioners and evaluated in real-world CAM applications. STUDY DESIGN: Single arm response. Data were collected in 2010-2014 and analyzed in 2015. SETUP/PARTICIPANTS: Private practices of 30 chiropractors, 27 acupuncturists, 42 massage therapists (N=99) in Tucson, Arizona. INTERVENTION: Eight hour tobacco cessation BI continuing education workshop, in-office BI skills implementation/assessment, and systems intervention. Tailored to the TAT practice environment, the training addressed tobacco cessation best practices in the US Public Health Service Guidelines. MAIN OUTCOME MEASURES: Seventeen items (which assess the practitioner's behavior, motivation, and self-efficacy with tobacco cessation) consisting of three factors: Tobacco Cessation Effectiveness, Tobacco Cessation Motivation, and Out-of-Glass Comfort were evaluated at baseline, and 3, 6, from training according to the Practitioner's self-report. 9 and 12 months later. Research staff visited practices at approximately the same intervals to directly observe changes in clinical practice systems. RESULTS: At 3 months, there were significant increases in practitioners' tobacco cessation activities, motivation and confidence in helping patients quit, and comfort in providing information and guidance for guideline-based tobacco cessation aids (p<0.0001). Practitioners significantly increased the rates of discussing cessation medications with patients (AOR=3.76, 95% CI=1.84, 7.68) and routinely asking questions about tobacco use in clinical practice (AOR=2.62, 95% CI=1.11, 6.20). Increases occurred in all three types of practitioners and continued at 12 months despite heterogeneity in vocational training, practice models/organization, and practice business models. CONCLUSIONS: The results demonstrate that CAM practitioners are willing and able to deliver BIs and an important, but overlooked, channel to promote tobacco cessation and the use of evidence-based quit aids.

title: Tobacco addiction treatment guidelines
abstract: Tobacco addiction causes one in six deaths in the Czech Republic and is associated with whole-body diseases. Treatment of tobacco addiction should be a standard part of clinical care in the current timeline, from brief intervention to intensive treatment at each clinical contact with patients. It includes psycho-socio-behavioral support and pharmacotherapy. It should apply to all professions in clinical medicine, as recommended by WHO, in particular doctors, nurses, pharmacists and dentists, and should be covered by health systems. Economically, it is one of the most cost-effective interventions in medicine. About 30% of our population over the age of 15 smoke (approximately 2.2 million people), the F17 diagnosis concerns about 1.75 million people (approximately 80% of smokers).

title: Tobacco intervention practices by licensed psychologists
abstract: Tobacco addiction is a serious public health problem. The U.S. Department of Health and Human Services has published a practice guide on best practices to encourage all healthcare providers to respond to tobacco addicts they encounter. Psychologists may be ideal for implementing brief tobacco interventions because of their expertise in behavior modification strategies and interpersonal counseling skills. This study aimed to explore current tobacco assessment and intervention practices and perceptions of responsibility for tobacco intervention in a regional sample of licensed practicing psychologists. The results show that the majority of psychologists lag far behind the ideal best practices recommended in the practice guide, and many are unaware of the availability of the guidelines. Also, the psychologists in this study perceived that tobacco intervention was a greater responsibility of doctors and other health care providers rather than psychologists and other mental health professionals.

title: Tobacco use in individuals with attention deficit hyperactivity disorder: epidemiology and pharmacological approaches to quitting
abstract: Co-occurrence of attention deficit hyperactivity disorder (ADHD) and nicotine addiction is common. Individuals with ADHD are more likely to start smoking and become addicted to nicotine than those without ADHD, and recent evidence suggests that they may have more difficulty quitting smoking. Little is known about how best to approach the treatment of these comorbidities to optimize clinical outcome. Clinicians treating individuals with ADHD or nicotine addiction should be aware of their common occurrence and the need to address both in treatment. This review of ADHD and nicotine addiction provides an overview of the relevant epidemiology, bidirectional interactions, and implications for pharmacological and adjunctive psychosocial therapy. Combining the existing evidence base and clinical experience, the authors propose a stepwise approach to treating patients with comorbid ADHD and nicotine addiction. Given the potential for ADHD symptoms to interfere with smoking cessation success, the first priority is to stabilize ADHD. The first-line pharmacological approach should be a long-acting psychostimulant. Upon ADHD stabilization, motivational techniques should be used to promote readiness for a smoking cessation attempt. Within the scope of behavioral cessation interventions sensitive to the patient's needs and developmental stage, pharmacological intervention for smoking cessation can be initiated. The authors recommend varenicline as a first-line agent, given the superior effect size among current drug therapies. Nicotine withdrawal and craving symptoms, as well as ADHD symptoms, should be closely monitored during an attempt to quit and, if necessary, adjustments in treatment considered. The authors concluded that while current treatments may be potentially effective for comorbid ADHD and nicotine addiction, more research is needed to debunk the complex relationships between these disorders and to prospectively examine combined treatments.

title: Tobacco-nicotine education and training for healthcare professionals and practitioners: a systematic review.
abstract: Introduction: The purpose of this systematic review was to explore what education and training features prepare and support health care professionals (HCPs) in providing competent and effective care to tobacco-nicotine users. Methods: Eight bibliographic database searches for peer-reviewed publications in English from January 2006 to March 2015. Studies were included if they met the a priori inclusion criteria of: 1) quantitative study design and 2) focus tobacco-nicotine education or training for HCP students and practitioners. All studies were independently screened by two reviewers for inclusion. Data from the included studies were extracted for study characteristics and key conclusions, and then critically evaluated for methodological quality. Results: 59 studies were included for narrative synthesis. Two categories emerged: 1) curriculum features (n=10) and 2) education and training interventions (n=49). The curricular studies included identified the following themes: content, intensity, assessment of competences and barriers. Study findings on education and training interventions were grouped by education level (pre-graduate, post-graduate, and faculty education), teaching method, health discipline, and relevant HCP and client outcomes. Conclusion: This comprehensive review shows a lack of consistency in HCP tobacco-nicotine education and training specifications. This article provides a valuable categorization of the most commonly used components of the academic curriculum and discusses interventions related to HCP and client outcomes. Gaps in the literature are highlighted and the need for standardization of tobacco-nicotine education qualifications and assessment is discussed. Future research exploring the most effective approaches to education is needed. Trial Record: PROSPERO - protocol number: CRD42015019219 Available at http://www.crd.york.ac.uk/PROSPERO/display_record.asp?ID=CRD42015019219. APPLICATIONS: This systematic review summarizes current tobacco-related curriculum components (content, intensity, competency assessment, barriers) and educational interventions for healthcare professionals worldwide and shows that they are associated with positive outcomes (knowledge, attitudes, behaviors) of healthcare professionals. , skills) and client outcomes (quit attempts and smoking cessation).

title: Tools for applying an evidence-based approach to public health practice
abstract: Rising disease rates, limited funding, and the ever-growing scientific basis for intervention require the use of proven strategies to improve population health. Public health practitioners must be prepared to apply an evidence-based approach in their work to achieve health goals and maintain necessary resources. We explored easily accessible and time-saving tools to implement an evidence-based public health (EBPH) approach to improving population health. A variety of tools have been developed to meet EBPH needs, including free online resources in the following subject areas: education and planning tools, US health surveillance, policy monitoring and oversight, systematic reviews and evidence-based guidelines, economic assessment, and gray literature. The core elements of EBPH are to involve the community in evaluation and decision making; use data and information systems systematically; make decisions based on the best available peer-reviewed evidence (both quantitative and qualitative); apply program planning frameworks (usually in health-behavioral theory). ); make a solid assessment;" and disseminate what they have learned.

title: Topical intranasal corticosteroids in children aged 4-11 years with persistent bilateral otitis media in primary care: a double-blind randomized placebo-controlled trial.
abstract: OBJECTIVE To determine the clinical efficacy of topical intranasal corticosteroids in children with otitis media with bilateral effusion. DESIGN Double-blind randomized placebo-controlled trial. SET 76 Medical Research Council General Practice Research Framework, UK-wide practice between 2004 and 2007. PARTICIPANTS 217 children aged 4-11 years with at least one episode of otitis media or related ear problems in the last 12 months, and verified by a research nurse using otoscopy plus micro-tympanometry (B/B or B/C2, modified Jerger types) with bilateral otitis media with effusion. INTERVENTION Mometasone furoate 50 microg or a placebo spray is given once daily in each nostril for three months. MAIN OUTCOME MEASURES Proportions of children treated for bilateral otitis media with effusion as assessed by tympanometry (type C1 or A) at one month (primary endpoint), three months, and nine months"; side effects; daily symptoms at three months. Results 41% of the topical steroid group. (39/96) and 45% (44/98) of the placebo group were treated in either one or both ears at one month (difference 4.3% in favor of placebo (95% confidence interval -9.3% to 18.1%) Poisson regression, four prespecified common adjusted for the variable (clinical severity, P=0.003; atopy, P=0.67; age, P=0.92; season, P=0.71). The adjusted relative risk at one month was 0.97 (95% CI 0.74 to 1.26) at three months , 58% of the topical steroid group and 52% of the placebo group were treated (relative risk 1.23, 0.84 to 1.80). Diurnal symptoms did not differ between the two groups and no significant harm was reported. unlikely. general practice with an effusion. High native resolution rates occurred between 1-3 months. TRIAL REGISTRATION Controlled Trials Available ISRCTN38988331; National Research Registry NO575123823;" MREC 03/11/073.

title: Hard-spoken magazine editor faces accusations of indulgence
Toward criteria for pragmatic measurement in practice research and practice: a stakeholder-focused approach using concept mapping
abstract: Background Practice research and development of practice requires valid and reliable measures of practice determinants, mechanisms, processes, strategies and outcomes. However, researchers and practice stakeholders are unlikely to use the measures if they are not pragmatic at the same time. The aim of this study was to create a stakeholder-oriented conceptualization of the areas that make up the pragmatic measure structure. It was built on a systematic review of the literature and semi-structured stakeholder interviews that established 47 criteria for pragmatic measures, and aimed to further refine this set of criteria by defining conceptually different categories of the pragmatic measurement structure and providing quantitative ratings of the criteria. ¯ clarity and importance. Methods Twenty-four stakeholders with expertise in implementation practice completed a concept mapping activity where they conceptually organized the initial list of 47 criteria into different categories and rated their clarity and importance. Multidimensional scaling, hierarchical cluster analysis and descriptive statistics were used to analyze the data. Results The 47 criteria were grouped into four different categories: (1) acceptable, (2) compatible, (3) easy, and (4) useful. Average degrees of clarity and importance will be presented at the level of category and individual criteria. Conclusions This study advances the field of applied science and practice by providing clear and conceptually diverse areas of the pragmatic measure construct. Next steps will include a Delphi process to develop consensus on the most important criteria and the development of measurable pragmatic rating criteria that can be used to evaluate metrics.

title: Towards Evidence-Based Medical Statistics. 1: P Value Misconception
abstract: There is a major problem in interpreting modern medical research data: Biological understanding and previous research play little formal role in interpreting quantitative results. This phenomenon manifests itself in the discussion sections of research articles and can ultimately affect the reliability of the results. The standard statistical approach has created this situation by promoting the illusion that results can be produced with certain "error rates" without considering information from outside the experiment. This statistical approach, whose core components are P-values and hypothesis testing, is widely perceived as a mathematically consistent approach to inference. There is little recognition in the medical community that the methodology is a mixture of discordant elements, the utility of which for scientific inference has been the subject of intense debate among statisticians for almost 70 years. This article introduces some of the key elements of this discussion and traces the appeal and negative impact of this methodology to the P-value fallacy, the misconception that a single number can capture both the long-term results and evidential meaning of an experiment. a single result. This argument was made as an introduction to the suggestion that another measure of evidence should be used - the Bayes factor, which appropriately separates long-term behavioral issues from evidential power and allows background information to be integrated with statistical findings.

title: Toward a common terminology: a simplified intervention framework for promoting and integrating evidence into health practices, systems and policies
abstract: Background There is a wide variety of and inconsistent terminology in the field of Knowledge translation. This limits the execution of evidence syntheses, hinders communication and collaboration, and undermines knowledge translation of research findings in a variety of settings. Improving the uniformity of terminology can help address these challenges. In 2012, we convened an international working group to explore the idea of developing a common terminology and an overarching framework for information translation interventions. Findings Methods included describing and summarizing existing frameworks, assembling a subset of these frameworks, and bringing together a multidisciplinary group to begin work towards consensus. The group evaluated four potential approaches to creating a simplified framework: combining existing classifications, creating a framework of intervention mechanisms rather than intervention strategies, using a consensus process to expand one of the existing models/frameworks used by the group, or developing a new consensus framework. Conclusions The working group chose to design a new, simplified consensus intervention framework to integrate and support evidence into health practices, systems and policies. The framework will include four key components: strategies and techniques (active components), how they work (causal mechanisms), how they are delivered (delivery mode), and what they aim to change (intended objectives). The draft framework needs to be further developed through feedback and consultation with the research community and tested for its usefulness through implementation and evaluation.

title: Toxic hepatitis during ketoconazole therapy
Tracheostomy and weaning
abstract: No hypothesis regarding respiratory care in the ICU has been more difficult to examine objectively than the popular belief that tracheostomy accelerates weaning from respiratory support. Tracheostomy may facilitate weaning by reducing dead space and reducing airway resistance, improving secretion clearance, reducing the need for sedation, and reducing the risk of aspiration. Current evidence suggests that dead space and airway resistance are actually reduced, but whether the magnitude of these reductions explains the clinical observation of faster weaning after tracheotomy is less certain. Most of the data on this topic comes from laboratory experiments and short-term physiological studies in clinically stable patients, and the available evidence from clinical studies using weaning as the primary endpoint is insufficient. A large multicenter study showed no advantage of early tracheotomy, but showed how difficult it is to get clinicians to manage their patients with regimens that contradict their strongly advocated views. The most recent clinical study found that percutaneous dilatational tracheotomy performed in the first 2 days in patients predicted to need ventilatory support for more than 14 days greatly reduced ventilator and ICU days and reduced both the incidence of pneumonia and overall mortality. Tracheostomy was performed after the 14th day. Conducting such trials is difficult due to investigative and clinician bias, the inability to predict which patients will actually need prolonged mechanical ventilation, and several other factors discussed in this article. Tracheotomy probably helps to relieve some patients from respiratory support, but this may be from any physiological effects as well as from its impact on clinician behavior.

title: Tracing the foundations of a conceptual framework for patient safety ontology
abstract: Background In the work done on research methods and measures for the World Alliance for Patient Safety and on defining key concepts for the International Classification of Patient Safety (ICPS), it has emerged that it is necessary to try to understand what it means and how it underlies patient safety. The concepts relate to existing safety and quality frameworks commonly used in healthcare. Objectives To explore the concept of patient safety and how it relates to the safety and quality frameworks commonly used in healthcare, and to monitor the evolution of the ICPS framework based on electronic capture of the component elements of patient safety. Conclusion The ICPS conceptual framework for patient safety has its origins in existing frameworks and an international consultation process. Although the class 10 and its semantic relationships can be used as reference models for different disciplines, it must remain dynamic in the ever-changing world of healthcare. A progressively deeper interdisciplinary approach will be developed to address the complex, resilient problem of reducing harm associated with healthcare, by examining data from all available sources and expanding the ICPS with tight compliance with the latest informatics principles.

title: Training GPs on opioid prescribing for chronic pain based on practice guidelines: a randomized pilot and feasibility study.
abstract: UNLABELED: This study is a pilot and feasibility study comparing 2 training experiences to develop appropriate opioid prescription for chronic pain. Both training conditions included training on opioid guidelines. Following the training, 1 condition included training to develop psychological flexibility and the other included training in practical knowledge and skills related to pain management. Eighty-one general practitioners (GPs) participated in the study and each was randomly assigned to one of the training conditions. Training GPs has been easy. Overall, GPs demonstrated increased knowledge of opioid prescribing for chronic pain and decreased concerns about prescribing after training. However, no changes in reported prescribing practices or secondary well-being measures were observed. There were also no significant differences between the training conditions, except for a greater increase in intention to use prescribing guidelines in the psychological flexibility condition. The applicability and acceptability of the training methods were generally evaluated as high. The psychological flexibility condition scored higher than the comparison condition in terms of interest and satisfaction. Finally, pre- and post-training psychological resilience processes are significantly associated with measures of GP well-being and provide partial support for the relevance of these processes as a focus in GP training. PERSPECTIVE: An education intervention for GPs, including opioid guidelines for chronic pain and psychological resilience training, increased prescribing knowledge and reduced anxiety, but did not change prescribing behavior or well-being. The training was quite acceptable to GPs but may have been too short to have any other effects.

title: Training on internal fixation of fractures
Educating Physicians to Provide High-Value, Cost-Aware Care
abstract: Importance Increasing health expenditures are challenging the sustainability of the health system. Physicians must be prepared to provide high-value, cost-conscious care. Purpose To understand the conditions in which the provision of high-value, cost-conscious care is learned to inform the development of effective educational interventions. Data Sources PubMed, EMBASE, ERIC, and Cochrane databases were searched from baseline to September 5, 2015 to identify students and cost-related issues. Study Selection Studies were included on the basis of relevance, administration of the intervention, evaluation of the intervention, educational components in the intervention, and appropriate target group. There were no restrictions in the study design. Data Extraction and Synthesis Data extraction was driven by a combined and modified version of the Best Evidence in Medical Education abstraction form and the Cochrane data coding sheet. The articles were analyzed using the realist review method, a narrative review technique that focuses on understanding the underlying mechanisms in interventions. Repetitive patterns were identified in the data through thematic analyses. Emerging themes were discussed within the research team until consensus was reached. Key Outcomes and Measures Key outcomes were factors that encouraged education in the delivery of high-value, cost-conscious care. Results Initial search identified 2650 articles; 79 met the inclusion criteria, of which 14 were randomized clinical trials. Most studies were of a pre-post interventional design (58.2%; minimum) in North America (78.5%). They focused on 1619 participants), GPs (36.7%; at least 3448 participants), resident doctors (6.3%; n?=?516), and medical students (15.2%; n?=?275) clinical trials, 12 Addressed knowledge transfer, 7 reflective practices, and 1 supportive environment; 10 (71%) concluded that interventions were effective. Data analysis suggested that 3 factors aid successful learning: (1) effective transfer of knowledge, relevant, for example, to the general health economics and health care prices, guidelines, and scientific evidence regarding the benefits and harms of health care, and patient preferences and personal values (67 items); (2) facilitating reflective practice, e.g. ordering labs to give trainees insight into their past and present behavior or to provide feedback or ask reflective questions on decisions about prescribing (56 articles); and (3) creating a supportive environment in which the organization of the health care system, the existence of high-value, cost-conscious care delivery role models, and a culture of high-value, cost-conscious care reinforce desired care. educational goals (27 articles). Results and Relevance Research on training physicians to deliver high-value, cost-conscious care shows that learning for practitioners, resident physicians, and medical students is supported by a combination of specific knowledge transfer, reflective practice, and a supportive environment. These factors should be considered when developing educational interventions.

title: Physicians' Education to Provide High-Value, Cost-Aware Care: A Systematic Review
abstract: IMPORTANCE: Increasing health expenditures are challenging the sustainability of the health system. Physicians must be prepared to provide high-value, cost-conscious care. OBJECTIVE: To understand the conditions in which the provision of high-value, cost-conscious care is learned to inform the development of effective educational interventions. DATA SOURCES: PubMed, EMBASE, ERIC, and Cochrane databases were searched from inception to September 5, 2015 to identify students and cost-related issues. STUDY SELECTION: Studies were included on the basis of relevance, administration of the intervention, evaluation of the intervention, educational components in the intervention, and appropriate target group. There were no restrictions in the study design. DATA ATTRACTION AND SYNTHESIS: Data extraction was driven by a merged and modified version of the Best Evidence in Medical Education abstraction form and a Cochrane data coding sheet. The articles were analyzed using the realist review method, a narrative review technique that focuses on understanding the underlying mechanisms in interventions. Repetitive patterns were identified in the data through thematic analyses. Emerging themes were discussed within the research team until consensus was reached. MAIN RESULTS AND MEASURES: The main outcomes were factors that encouraged education in the delivery of high-value, cost-conscious care. RESULTS: Initial investigation identified 2650 articles"; 79 met the inclusion criteria, of which 14 were randomized clinical trials. Most studies were in North America (78.5%), with a pre-intervention design (58.2%; at least 1619). participants), GPs (36.7%; at least 3448 participants), resident doctors (6.3%; n = 516), and medical students (15.2%; n = 275). Among 14 randomized clinical trials, 12 address information transfer, 7 reflective practice and 1 supportive environment; 10 (71%) concluded that interventions were effective. Data analysis suggested that 3 factors aid successful learning: (1) effective transfer of knowledge, eg relevant, to the overall health economics and prices of health care services, guidelines (67 items); (2) facilitating reflective practice, ordering labs to give such trainees insight into their past and present behavior or to provide feedback or ask reflective questions on decisions about prescribing (56 articles); and (3) creating a supportive environment in which the organization of the health care system, the existence of high-value, cost-conscious care delivery role models, and a culture of high-value, cost-conscious care reinforce desired care. educational goals (27 articles). RESULTS AND RELIABILITY: Research on educating physicians to provide high-value, cost-conscious care demonstrates that learning by practitioners, resident physicians, and medical students is promoted by the combination of specific knowledge transfer, reflective practice, and a supportive environment. These factors should be considered when developing educational interventions.

title: Training practitioners to provide opportunistic multiple behavior change counseling in primary care: a cluster randomized trial.
abstract: OBJECTIVES To evaluate the impact of primary care professionals' training in behavior change counseling on the proportion of patients reporting changes in four risky behaviors (smoking, alcohol use, exercise, and healthy eating). DESIGN Cluster randomized trial with general applications as the unit of randomization. SETTING General applications in Wales. PARTICIPANTS: 53 GPs and GP nurses (each but one) from 27 general practitioners recruited 1827 patients who screened positive for at least one risky behavior. INTERVENTION Behavior change counseling was developed from motivational interviewing to enable clinicians to increase their motivation to change patients' health-related behaviors. Clinicians were trained using a blended learning program called Talking Lifestyles. MAIN OUTCOME MEASURES Proportion of patients reporting beneficial changes in at least one of four risk behaviors at three months. RESULTS 1308 patients from 13 interventions and 1496 patients from 14 control treatments were approached: 76% and 72%, respectively, agreed to participate with 831 (84%) and 996 (92%) eligible screenings for an intervention. Primary outcome (beneficial change in behavior) at 3 months (362 (44%) v 404 (41%), odds ratio 1.12 (95% CI 0.90 to 1.39) had no effect on biochemical or biometric measures at 12 months. more patients consulted, a health behavior (724/795 (91%) v 531/966 (55%), odds ratio 12.44 (5.85 to 26.46)) and intended to change (599/831 ( 72%) v 491/996 ( 49%), odds 2.88 (2.05 to 4.05). More intervention practice patients attempted to change (328 (39%) v 317 (32%), odds ratio 1.40 (1.15 to 1.70) ), reported a persistent behavioral change at three months (288 (35%) v 280 (28) %), odds ratio 1.36 (1.11 to 1.65)), and slightly greater improvement in healthy eating at three and 12 months and also reported improved activity at 12 months. The training cost is £1597 per app. DISCUSSION Training primary care clinicians using a short blended learning program in behavior change counseling did not improve patients' reporting of beneficial behavior change at three months or a biometric and biochemical measure at 12 months, but increased patients' recall that they discussed behavior change with them. clinicians, intentions to change, attempts to change, and perceptions of making a permanent change in three months. Permanent behavior change and improvements in biometric measures are unlikely after a single routine consultation without additional intervention with a clinician trained in behavior change counseling. TRIAL REGISTRATION ISRCTN 22495456.

title: Transforming assertive community care into an integrated care system: the role of nursing and primary care partnerships
abstract: Despite the high rate of co-occurring medical conditions experienced by individuals receiving ACT, this comprehensive service model continues to be recognized primarily as a mental health intervention. Without compromising adherence to the model, ACT can serve as an ideal platform to provide both primary and behavioral health care to those with complex service needs. Using a case example, this article discusses the transformation of the ACT mental health care model into an integrated healthcare delivery system by establishing nursing and primary care partnerships. Specifically, by expanding and clearly redefining the role of the ACT nurse, well-developed care models such as Guided Care can provide additional guidance and training to ACT nurses who are uniquely trained and oriented to serve as leaders and coordinators of health integration. efforts.

title: Transfusion Medicine
abstract: The evolution of transfusion medicine into a clinically oriented discipline emphasizing patient care has been accompanied by challenges for professionals as they look to the future. Emerging issues affecting blood safety and blood supply, such as pathogen inactivation and stricter donor screening questions, place new pressures on the availability of an affordable blood supply. Nearby alternatives, such as oxygen carriers, for the treatment of anemia show great promise, but will require close surveillance, if any. Current estimates of HIV or hepatitis C viral (HCV) transmission put minimal bacterial contamination (one in 2000) and transfusion errors in platelet products approaching an estimated one in 800-1000 units. Assume ˆ000 death rate, great urgency. Finally, the serious challenges of blood safety and availability for poor, developing countries require innovative strategies and a resource commitment.

title: Translating Clinical Research into Clinical Practice: The Impact of Using Prediction Rules for Decision Making
abstract: Clinical prediction rules, sometimes called clinical decision rules, have proliferated in recent years. However, very few have undergone formal impact analysis, which is the standard of evidence to assess their impact on patient care. Without impact analysis, clinicians do not know whether using a prediction rule would be beneficial or harmful. This article reviews standards of evidence for developing and evaluating prediction rules"; key differences between prediction rules and decision rules; how to evaluate the potential clinical impact of a prediction rule before it is translated into a decision rule; methodological issues critical to successful effect analysis, definition of outcome measures and estimating sample size; the importance of close collaboration between clinical investigators and practicing clinicians before, during and after impact analysis; and the need to measure both efficacy and effectiveness when analyzing the clinical impact of a decision rule. should inform its future development, evaluation and use.

title: Translating evidence-based fall prevention into clinical practice in nursing facilities: results and lessons from a quality improvement collaboration
abstract: OBJECTIVES: To describe changes in the care process before and after a collaborative evidence-based decline reduction quality improvement in nursing facilities. DESIGN: Natural experiment in which non-participating facilities act as a control. SETTING: Community nursing homes. PARTICIPANTS: 36 participant and 353 non-participant nursing facilities in North Carolina. INTERVENTION: Two face-to-face learning sessions, monthly teleconferences and an email discussion list for 9 months. The amendment package emphasized screening, labeling and risk factor reduction. MEASUREMENTS: Compliance was measured before and after the intervention using the facility's own report and chart abstraction (n = 832). Rates of decline measured using the Minimum Dataset (MDS) were compared with those of non-participating facilities as a result of an exploration. RESULTS: Self-reported agreement on screening, labeling and risk factor reduction approached 100%. Graphic abstraction, screening (51% vs 68%, P < .05), risk factor reduction (4% vs 7%, P = .30), and drug evaluation (2% vs 6%, P = .34). There was a significant increase in vitamin D prescriptions (40% to 48%, P=.03) and a decrease in sedative-hypnotics (19% to 12%, P=.04), but no change in benzodiazepine, neuroleptic, or calcium use. Chart abstraction (28.6% vs 37.5%, P = .17), MDS (18.2% vs 15.4%, P = .56), or self-report (6.1-5.6 drops/1,000 bed days, P = .31). CONCLUSION: While multiple risk factor reduction tasks are rarely implemented, scanning tasks seem more easily interchangeable in a real-world setting. Significant differences between self-reported practice and medical record documents require the use of additional data sources to evaluate processes of change in care resulting from quality improvement programs. Interventions to improve interdisciplinary cooperation should be developed.

title: Turning guidelines into practice: findings from a multidisciplinary preventive cardiology program in the west of Ireland
abstract: OBJECTIVES: The purpose of this observational, descriptive study was to evaluate the impact of an intensive, evidence-based preventive cardiology program on medical and lifestyle risk factors in patients at high risk of developing cardiovascular disease (CVD). METHODS: Patients at increased CVD risk and their family members/partners were invited to participate in a 16-week program of professional multidisciplinary lifestyle intervention with appropriate risk factor and therapeutic management in a community setting. Smoking, dietary habits, physical activity levels, waist circumference and body mass index, and medical risk factors were measured at the initial assessment, at the end of the program, and at 1-year follow-up. RESULTS: Adherence to the program was high, with 375 (87.2%) participants and 181 (84.6%) partners completing the program, 1-year data were obtained from 235 (93.6%) patients and 107 (90.7%) partners. There were statistically significant improvements in both lifestyle (body mass index, waist circumference, physical activity, Mediterranean diet score, fish, fruit and vegetable consumption, smoking cessation rates), and psychosocial (anxiety and depression scales and quality of life indices). Medical risk factors (blood pressure, lipid, and glycemic targets) between baseline and end of program and these improvements are maintained at 1-year follow-up. CONCLUSIONS: These findings demonstrate how a holistic model of CVD prevention can improve cardiovascular risk factors by providing healthier lifestyles and optimal medical management.

title: Translation of alcohol screening and brief intervention guidelines to pediatric trauma centers
abstract: BACKGROUND: As part of the American College of Surgeons' verification to become a Level 1 trauma center, centers must have the capacity to identify and respond to trauma patients with risky alcohol use. Despite the supporting scientific evidence and national policy statements promoting alcohol Screening, Brief Intervention and Referral to Treatment (SBIRT), barriers still exist that hinder the integration of SBIRT into clinical care. The study objectives of this multisite translational research study were to identify best practices for integrating SBIRT services into routine care for pediatric trauma patients, to quantify changes in practice through the adoption and implementation of an SBIRT policy, and SBIRT services in pediatric trauma centers. METHODS: This translational research study was conducted at seven US pediatric trauma centers over a 3-year period. Changes in SBIRT practice were measured through self-report and medical record review at three different study phases: adoption, implementation, and maintenance. RESULTS: Based on medical record review, at baseline, 11% of eligible patients were screened and had a brief intervention (if needed) at all facilities. After completion of SBIRT technical assistance activities, all seven participating trauma centers effectively developed, adopted and implemented SBIRT policies for injured adolescent inpatients. Additionally, across all facilities, 73% of eligible patients received SBIRT services after both the implementation and care phases. Opportunities and barriers to successful integration have been identified. CONCLUSION: This model can serve as a method for implementing SBIRT services in pediatric trauma centers.

title: Translation of eligibility criteria into practice guidelines: application of decision table techniques to RAND criteria for coronary artery bypass grafting.
abstract: The process of creating clinical practice guidelines from the evidence gathered is not well defined. We have developed a technique for translating a comprehensive set of eligibility criteria into a usable set of practice guidelines. The criteria are derived from a formal consensus process conducted by RAND and relate to indications for coronary artery bypass grafting in acute myocardial infarction. Clinical indications defined by the expert panel are entered as conditions in a decision table. The recommended action for each combination of relevant clinical findings is defined from the median ranking of the Rand panel. The fully constructed table is then compressed using traditional decision table techniques and sorted to facilitate parsing of the information. All in all, 8 narrative expressions were derived from 51 rules. Augmented decision tables allow detailed data to be viewed in the pivot table and accessed as needed.

title: Translation of obesity practice guidelines: interprofessional perspectives on the impact of public health nurse system-level intervention.
abstract: OBJECTIVE: The purpose of this study was to explore the perceptions of administrators and clinicians regarding a collaborative approach to facilitating public health that supports the implementation of the Institute for Clinical Systems Development (ICSI) Adult Obesity Guidelines. DESIGN AND EXAMPLE: This qualitative study was conducted with 10 healthcare organizations participating in voluntary, interprofessional obesity management collaborations. A purposive sample of 39 participants included two to three clinicians and an administrator from each institution. Interview analysis focused on how the intervention affected the participants and their practices. RESULTS: The four themes that defined the participants' experiences with obesity guideline translation: (1) the shift from powerlessness to positive motivation, (2) increased awareness with increased responsiveness, (3) personal ownership and use of creativity, and (4) increased sense of the importance of interprofessional collaboration. CONCLUSIONS: Exploring interprofessional perspectives illuminates the clinician and manager participants' feelings and perceptions regarding obesity practice guideline translation. These themes suggest that positive motivation, enhanced capacity, personal creative ownership, and interprofessional collaboration can aid successful evidence-based obesity guideline implementation. More research is needed to evaluate these findings with regard to translating the ICSI obesity guideline and other guidelines into practice in a variety of clinical settings.

title: Translation of obesity practice guidelines: measurement and evaluation
abstract: OBJECTIVE(S): A public health nurse (PHN) in the Midwestern United States (USA) spearheaded a systems-level collaborative intervention to transform the Institute for Clinical Systems Development (ICSI) Adult Obesity Guidelines into interprofessional practice. This study (1) evaluated the extent of guideline translation across organizations and (2) evaluated the Omaha System as a method for translating system-level interventions and measuring outcomes. DESIGN AND EXAMPLE: This retrospective, mixed methods study was conducted with a purposive sample of one administrator (n = 10) and two to three clinicians (n = 29) from each organization (n = 10). MEASURES: Results Omaha System Problem Rating Scale for Knowledge, Behavior and Status (KBS). KBS ratings collected from semi-structured interviews and Omaha System documents were analyzed using standard descriptive and inferential statistics, and participant citations and triangular findings were used. RESULTS: KBS ratings and participant citations demonstrated intervention effectiveness in creating sustained system-level changes. Self-reported and observed KBS ratings improved across organizations. There was moderate to significant agreement within organizations to achieve benchmarking. On average, self-reported improvement exceeded observer improvement. CONCLUSIONS: Systems-level PHN practice facilitating interventions have successfully translated clinical obesity guidelines into interprofessional use in healthcare settings. The Omaha System Problem Rating Scale for Outcomes reliably measured system-level outcomes.

title: Trend trap for statistical significance: probability of near-significant P value becoming more significant with extra data
abstract: When faced with a P-value (usually P<0.05) that fails to reach a certain threshold, authors of scientific papers may imply a "trend" towards statistical significance or otherwise suggest failure to fail. This was due to insufficient data to achieve statistical significance. This article provides a quantitative analysis to show that such disclosures give a misleading impression and undermine the principle of correct reporting. P values that do not reach the traditional significance level of Pâ€°Â¤0.05 are reported regularly as if they were moving in that direction. Phrases like "almost/approaching statistical significance" or, most obviously, a "trend" toward "statistical significance" continue to find their way into articles. journals with high impact factors.1 In this article, we examine the mathematical basis for this assumption and evaluate the extent to which a near-significant P-value can predict future movement towards a significant P-value by adding extra data. We also explore the probability that the extra data will result in a truly significant result, and finally, the confidence that a repeated experiment will independently yield statistically significant results. The most obvious context in which to consider the correct interpretation of a P-value is a randomized trial. Fisher explained how “the simple randomization measure would be sufficient to ensure the validity of the significance test. it tells how much it can explain the difference and acts as a “snapshot” measure of the strength of the evidence at the end of the trial. As the evidence accumulates, the conclusions become more well-founded. The AP value can be easily imagined as follows:

title: Treating alcohol problems: making a living
HIV "medical home" depression treatment: a guided algorithm for antidepressant management by HIV clinicians.
abstract: People living with HIV/AIDS (PLWHA) suffer from an increased prevalence of depression compared to the general population, negatively impacting antiretroviral (ART) adherence and HIV-related outcomes leading to morbidity and mortality. Yet depression in this population is often undiagnosed and untreated. The current project aimed to design an evidence-based approach to integrate depression care into HIV clinics. The model chosen, measure-based care (MBC), is based on current guidelines and the largest randomized trial of depression treatment. The MBC was adapted to the clinical realities of HIV care for use in a randomized controlled efficacy trial of depression management at three academic HIV clinics. Adaptation takes into account drug-drug interactions critical to continued ART efficacy and can be achieved by a multidisciplinary non-mental health team. A treatment algorithm has been developed that enables clinically supervised, non-physician depression care managers (DCMs) to monitor and monitor antidepressant tolerability and treatment response, while supporting non-psychiatry prescribers with antidepressant selection and dosage. Quality of care is ensured by weekly supervision of DCMs by psychiatrists. Key areas of flexibility that were important in practice included flexibility in the timing of assessments, regulating differences between algorithm recommendations and provider decisions, and regulating delays in the implementation of treatment plans. This adaptation of the MBC model to HIV care has elucidated critical antidepressant-antiretroviral interactions and facilitated the delivery of quality antidepressant management in the HIV medical home.

title: Treating obesity with a new handheld device, computer software program and Internet technology in primary care: SMART motivational trial
abstract: OBJECTIVE: The aim of this study was to evaluate the short-term motivational impact of a technology-based weight loss program for obese adults. METHODS: One hundred and eleven obese (37.0+/-5.8 kg/m(2)) middle-aged (45.5+/-10.8 years) adults (62% women) were randomly assigned to a usual care or trial (SMART: self-monitoring) and resting metabolic rate technology) group. The usual care group received a standard feeding schedule in accordance with national guidelines. All participants received a comprehensive weight management program consisting of motivational interviewing (MI) sessions and automated email behavioral newsletters. Body weight, arterial blood pressure, and psycho-behavioral structures were evaluated over 12 weeks. RESULTS: Supplementary analysis (n=80) showed significant improvement in body weight (-3.9%), systolic arterial pressure (-4 mmHg), and all motivational constructs (p<or=.05) after 12 weeks of study. However, there was no significant difference between groups at any time period. CONCLUSION: Based on these data, a comprehensive 12-week weight reduction program of MI and automated email behavioral newsletters with or without SMART is effective in treating obese adults. PRACTICE PRACTICES: Although both treatment programs are equally effective, clinicians should consider a treatment program that meets the patient's needs. This study is registered on ClinicalTrials.gov NCT00750022.

title: Treatment and prophylaxis of recurrent urinary tract infections
abstract: Recurrent urinary tract infections are typical diseases of sexually active young women. Only elderly women show significant rates of underlying, mostly urological, diseases. Along with behavioral changes, long-term antimicrobial therapy is the mainstay of both prophylaxis and treatment. This report provides information on the etiology of recurrent urinary tract infections. Prevention strategies are shown. The real importance of organic medicines and antibiotics is discussed respectively";" ineffective treatments are identified. It also provides an overview of promising new therapeutics, namely vaccines that have already been tested in clinical trials.

title: Treatment of anxiety disorders in primary care practice: a randomized controlled trial.
abstract: OBJECTIVE: Anxiety disorders are common in primary care. Psychological treatment is effective but time consuming and there are waiting lists for secondary care. Therefore, there has been increased interest in the development of treatment guidelines that can be applied in primary care. OBJECTIVE: To compare the effectiveness and feasibility of guided self-help, Dutch College of General Practitioners' Anxiety Disorder Principles and cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT). STUDY DESIGN: 12-week randomized controlled trial for primary care patients with panic disorder and/or generalized anxiety disorder, with follow-ups of 3 and 9 months. SETTING: The first two treatment modalities were administered by 46 GPs randomly assigned to a form. CBT was administered by cognitive behavioral therapists in a psychiatry outpatient clinic. METHODS: Participants (n = 154) were randomly assigned to one of three treatment modalities. The main outcome measure used was the status subscale of the Spielberger Anxiety Inventory. RESULTS: All three treatment modalities showed a significant improvement between pretest and posttest, and this improvement remained stable between posttest and follow-up. Results with the three treatment forms did not differ significantly over time. The applicability of the Anxiety Disorder Guidelines was low compared with guided self-help. CONCLUSION: Our results show that primary care patients with generalized anxiety disorder who do not see referral to the GP as necessary can be adequately treated by the GP. Referral to the psychiatry outpatient clinic does not yield superior results. Guided self-help is easier for the GP than a less structured treatment as outlined in the Anxiety Disorder Guidelines.

title: Treatment of childhood memories: theory and practice
abstract: With the increasing interest of cognitive behavioral therapy in precocious psychopathology such as personality disorders, there is a growing need for therapeutic methods to treat pathogenic schemas more directly. Exploring and reinterpreting memories of early childhood experiences that are presumed to contribute to pathogenesis is increasingly seen as a promising way to change core schemas. Experimental methods seem to be the most effective. This article discusses two main forms of these methods: (i) descriptive imagery and (ii) both role-playing childhood interactions with key figures. Protocols for both are provided as a guide for clinicians and to encourage standardization so that this new field can be opened up to experimental research.
