Theoretical views on why these methods can be so effective in the treatment of chronic problems arising from childhood are discussed.

title: Treating common 'life event' traumas
abstract: BACKGROUND: General practitioners are confronted every day with patients who experience distressing 'life events'. Assisting patients in this process can be a significant challenge. OBJECTIVE: This article points to the reactive symptomatology and subsequent reactions that are evident or hidden in a stressful event, sets the goal of restoring one's functionality and self-resources, and gives guidelines on what counseling can do for a patient. DISCUSSION: Individuals coping with a distressing 'life event' or trauma can be effectively assisted with early short-term counseling. While this task may not appeal to the busy GP, many accessible interventions can restore a person's coping capacity and prevent the possibility of an ongoing and deepening pathology. Many symptoms do not fit into the diagnostic categories often associated with stress disorders. Some may show impaired social participation and social phobia";" others may identify low self-worth, ill-health states, relationship dissatisfaction, and mismatches in core behavioral domains. The task is to help the person gain a different perspective on the upsetting event, his own capacity, and the supportive influences around him.

title: Treatment of Myalgic Encephalomyelitis/Chronic Fatigue Syndrome: A Systematic Review for the National Institutes of Health Ways of Prevention Workshop
abstract: Background: Myalgic encephalomyelitis (ME)/chronic fatigue syndrome (CFS) is a debilitating multisystem condition that affects more than 1 million adults in the United States. Objective: To determine the benefits and harms of treatments for adults with ME/CFS and to identify future research needs. Data Sources: MEDLINE, PsycINFO, and Cochrane databases (January 1988 - September 2014)"; clinical trial records; reference lists and manufacturer information. Study Selection: English-language randomized studies of efficacy and adverse effects of ME/CFS treatments. Data Extraction: Participants, study Data on design, analysis, follow-up, and outcomes were extracted and validated Study quality was double-rated using predefined criteria; discrepancies resolved by consensus Data Synthesis: Among 35 treatment studies that enrolled primarily participants, meeting 1994 Centers for Disease Control and Prevention and Oxford case definitions of CFS the immune modulator rintatolimod improved some measures of exercise performance compared to placebo in 2 trials (low strength of evidence), fluoxetine and various complementary drugs were inconclusive (insufficient evidence). gray graded exercise therapy and graded exercise therapy; counseling therapies also improved quality of life (low to moderate strength of evidence). Harms were rarely reported across studies (insufficient evidence). Limitation: Trials were heterogeneous and limited in size, number, duration, feasibility, and methodological quality. Conclusion: Trials of rintatolimod, counseling therapies, and graduated exercise therapy have shown benefits for some patients who meet the case definitions for CFS, while the evidence for other treatments and harms is inconclusive. More definitive studies comparing participants meeting different case definitions, including MI, and providing subgroup analysis, are needed to fill research gaps.

title: Treatment of seasonal affective disorder
abstract: Seasonal affective disorder (SAD), the winter type, is characterized by the onset of regular annual major depressive episodes in the fall or winter, followed by spontaneous remission, and sometimes by hypomanic or manic episodes in the spring and summer. SAD is clinically significant because approximately 2-5% of the general population in temperate climates is affected. Since the syndrome was first described, researchers have attempted to elucidate the pathophysiological background of SAD. Bright light therapy has been suggested as the treatment of choice for this disorder. However, numerous studies have also investigated appropriate psychopharmacological treatments for SAD. This report aims to provide an overview of clinical management and available therapeutic options for SAD.

title: Treatment services for children with ADHD: a national perspective
abstract: OBJECTIVE: To summarize information on treatment services for children and adolescents with attention deficit hyperactivity disorder (ADHD), trends in services from 1989 to 1996, types of services provided, mix of services, and barriers to care. METHODS: A review of the literature and analyzes from 2 national physician practice questionnaires are presented. CONCLUSIONS: Major changes have occurred in stimulant prescriptions since 1989, with prescriptions now accounting for three-quarters of all doctor visits by children with ADHD. Between 1989 and 1996, related services such as health counseling for children with ADHD increased 10 times and diagnostic services tripled. However, the provision of psychotherapy decreased from 40% to only 25% of pediatric visits over the same time period. Follow-up care also dropped from over 90% of visits to just 75%. Family practitioners were less likely to prescribe stimulants and use diagnostic services, provide mental health counseling, or offer follow-up care than pediatricians or psychiatrists. About 50% of children with ADHD seen in real-world practice settings receive care that corresponds to the guidelines of the American Academy of Child and Adolescent Psychiatry. Doctors reported significant barriers to service delivery for these children, including a lack of pediatricians, insurance barriers, and long waiting lists. CONCLUSIONS: Trends in treatment services and physician differences in service delivery point to large gaps between research base and clinical practice. Clinical differences may reflect differences in education, inequality in the availability of specialists and the location of services, and changes in health care incentives.

title: Trends in the social control of medical and psychiatric research
Triggering anti-smoking advice by GPs: how an intervention promotes GPs smoking cessation advice works
abstract: OBJECTIVE: To evaluate the mode of action of an intervention (GP desktop resource, GDR) that increases the frequency of GP recommendations for smoking cessation. METHODS: Analyzes were made to distinguish between three hypotheses regarding the course of action of the GDR. By: (1) changing the attitudes of GPs, (2) regardless of their attitudes in encouraging GPs to intervene with smokers, or (3) changing the relationship between attitude and behavior. RESULTS: GDR was an independent indicator of the number of patients recommended to quit smoking (beta = .345, p < .001). Concern about the doctor-patient relationship was the only attitude variable that negatively predicted independent advice in this situation (beta = -.465, p < .001). Having a GDR did not change GPs' views on whether intervention with smokers harmed the doctor-patient relationship, but weakened the association between this attitude item and the number of patients advised to quit smoking (beta = .595, p < .001 for interaction). CONCLUSION: This is the first study to show that concern about the doctor-patient relationship is an independent predictor of giving advice, but in other studies this has been noted as something that only GPs voiced concerns. A simple device designed by GPs to trigger action seemed to work by mitigating the negative impact of a behavioral action barrier. It would be interesting to explore this phenomenon more generally in relation to the health promotion activities of health professionals. PRACTICE PRACTICES: Recommendations for GPs to engage in health promotion activities with their patients should take into account that GPs' concerns about damaging the doctor-patient relationship may deter them from taking such interventions. The GDR appears to be effective in getting GPs to advise their smokers to quit smoking, and its widespread distribution to GPs should be considered.

title: Tumor boards: optimizing the structure and increasing efficiency of the multidisciplinary management of cancer patients worldwide
abstract: Multidisciplinary management tumor boards are now run worldwide for the management of patients with cancer. Studies evaluating its effects on decision making and patient outcomes are limited";" however, single-center studies have reported significant changes in diagnosis and treatment plans. A survey from Arab countries showed that tumor boards are widely used and relied upon for decision making. A recent multi-institutional study of veterans employment (VA) hospitals in the United States found limited association between the presence of tumor boards and care and outcomes. The Cancer Care Outcomes Research and Surveillance Consortium looked at the relationship between tumor plaque characteristics and measures of quality of care. Overall survival outcomes among patients from these physicians who attend tumor boards remain, but this article summarizes preliminary results, along with a recent ASCO study among international members, on the existence, use, and impact of tumor boards. Tumor boards allow for the application of clinical practice guidelines and can help capture cases for clinical trials. Efforts to improve the preparation, structure and functioning of tumor boards, research methods to monitor their performance, teamwork and results are also summarized in this article. The concept of mini-tumor boards and more efficient methods for MDM in countries with limited resources are also discussed. In suboptimal settings such as small community hospitals, rural areas, and areas with limited resources, the limits in diagnosis and management can be overcome or at least improved with tumor boards, especially with the use of videoconferencing facilities. Research from the UK has shown that tailored training of multidisciplinary teams (MDT) leads to better team dynamics and communication, increased patient satisfaction and improved clinical outcomes. The weight of benefits versus time and effort spent improving efficiency, patient care, and better time management in the United States and the international oncology community is also reviewed in this article.

title: Turning knowledge into action at the point of care: the shared experience of nurses facilitating the implementation of evidence-based practice.
abstract: BACKGROUND: Facilitation is considered a way to enable clinicians to put evidence into practice by solving problems and providing support. App development is a well-established movement in the UK involving the use of facilitators, but in Canada the role is broader. Few research has observed the facilitation process described by those experienced in guideline implementation in North America. OBJECTIVE: To identify the tacit knowledge about facilitation in the experiences of nurses putting the evidence into practice. METHODS: Twenty nurses from across Canada were consciously selected to participate in an interactive symposium on information translation to examine what worked and what didn't in applying the evidence. This study is an additional in-depth analysis of data collected at the symposium with a focus on facilitating as an intervention to increase evidence uptake. The critical incident technique was used to elicit examples to examine nurses' facilitation experiences. Participants shared their experiences with each other and completed the initial data analysis and coding collaboratively. The data were further analyzed thematically using the qualitative inductive approach of continuous comparison. RESULTS: A number of factors, at various levels, emerged related to the success and failure of participants' efforts to facilitate evidence-based practice. Successful implementation: (a) focus on a material issue, (b) relevant evidence, (c) developing strategic partnerships, (d) using multiple strategies to effect change, and (e) facilitating characteristics and approach. Negative factors affecting the process were: (a) poor participation or ownership, (b) resource gaps, (c) conflict, (d) contextual issues, and (e) lack of evaluation and sustainability. CONCLUSIONS: Factors at the individual, environmental, organizational and cultural levels influence facilitating evidence-based practice in real situations at the point of care. With a better understanding of the factors that contribute to successful or unsuccessful facilitation, future research should focus on analyzing tailored facilitation interventions to address barriers and improve those that facilitate evidence retrieval.

title: Two cheers or three for treatment guidelines? Pushing prescribers in the right directions
type 2 diabetes in young people
abstract: In the United States, the incidence of type 2 diabetes mellitus (DM) in children and adolescents is increasing at an alarming rate. Early diagnosis and intervention can delay the onset of type 2 DM and prevent long-term complications. School nurses have an important role in implementing the screening guidelines recommended by the American Diabetes Association (ADA) to identify youth at high risk for type 2 DM and in implementing student health programs that positively focus on the importance of physical activity and healthy eating habits. The purpose of this article is to provide an overview of epidemiology, pathophysiology, complications, diagnosis and treatment, as well as recommended screening guidelines for type 2 DM in the pediatric age group. The information provided will raise awareness, promote screening and empower the school nurse to more effectively promote healthy lifestyle education.

title: Undergraduate medical education: current status and future needs
Understanding and preventing recidivism among adults with psychotic disorders
abstract: The high prevalence of adults with psychotic disorders in the criminal justice system has received much attention recently, but our understanding of this problem has been marked by divergent views. Mental health experts point to deinstitutionalization and our fragmented mental health system as the root causes. Criminologists minimize the role of mental illness and argue that people with and without mental illness are arrested for the same reasons. Meanwhile, practice guidelines offer clinicians little guidance on how to address the problem. Drawing on contemporary principles of crime prevention, as well as up-to-date information on psychotic disorders and their treatment, this article provides a conceptual framework for understanding and preventing recidivism. The framework highlights the importance of individual and service system risk variables and highlights the central role of treatment nonadherence as a mediator between modifiable risk variables and recidivism. Based on the conceptual framework described in this article, three essential interventions are offered to prevent recidivism among adults with psychotic disorders: competent care, access to services, and legal leverage. Research is needed to further define and test these intervention elements as foundations for future service delivery efforts.

title: Understanding and promoting smoking cessation: overview and guidelines for physician intervention
abstract: This section outlines the requirements for successful smoking cessation and effective treatments. It provides practical guidelines for physicians and allied health care providers, with specific advice on how to motivate and assist patients to go "on their own" and, if necessary, choose more intensive supportive care. Useful guides, references and resources are suggested along with advice on optimal use of nicotine gum.

title: Understanding the diagnosis and management of dementia and applying guidelines in general practice: a qualitative study using the theoretical domains framework.
abstract: BACKGROUND: Dementia is a growing problem that places a significant burden on patients, their families and society. General practitioners (GPs) play an important role in diagnosing and managing dementia", but gaps exist between recommended and current practice. The purpose of this study was to explore and theoretically explain the reported practice of general practitioners in diagnosing and treating dementia in terms, evidence-based Suggested explanations for practice that are consistent and inconsistent with guidelines METHODS: Semi-structured interviews were conducted with GPs in Victoria, Australia. The Theoretical Domains Framework (TDF) guided data collection and analysis. 13 factors that hinder and enable the implementation of the recommended behavior. Data content and thematic analyzed using a validated instrument. This article provides an in-depth description of the factors influencing two behaviors, such as assessing comorbid depression using a validated tool and conducting a formal cognitive assessment. Using a validated scale RESULTS: A total of 30 practitioners consulted with the physician. Evaluate co-occurring depression using an approved tool according to recommended guidelines. Barriers include the belief that depression can be adequately assessed using general clinical indicators and validated tools provide little additional information (the theoretical domain of 'beliefs about outcomes'); possibly due to limited education and self-confidence ('Skills'; 'Beliefs about abilities'); discomfort in using approved tools ('Emotion'); limited awareness of the need for a depression assessment and forgetting to do so ('Information'; 'Memory, attention and decision processes'). Most reported practice consistent with the recommendation to undertake a formal cognitive assessment using an approved scale. Key factors for this are being aware of the need to conduct a cognitive assessment ('Knowledge'); have the necessary skills and confidence ('Skills'; 'Beliefs about abilities');" and have adequate time and resources ('Environmental context and resources'). identified key factors that could explain physicians' adoption of the dementia guidelines currently being evaluated in a cluster of randomized trials.

title: Understanding how evaluation of doctors produces its effects: a realistic review protocol
abstract: INTRODUCTION: UK doctors are now required to participate in revalidation to maintain their license to practice. Valuation is an essential component of revalidation. However, objective evidence that assessment changes physicians' behavior and directly leads to improved patient care is limited. In particular, it is unclear how the evaluation process will change physicians' behavior and improve clinical performance. The purpose of this research is to understand how and why physician evaluation produces its effect. METHODS AND ANALYSIS: Realistic review is a theory-based interpretive approach to the synthesis of evidence. It applies realistic research logic to produce a descriptive analysis of an intervention, such as what works for whom, under what circumstances, and in what ways. A theory of the evaluation program will be developed using a realistic review approach, consulting key stakeholders in the evaluation of physicians in expert panels (no ethical approval required), and reviewing the literature to identify relevant existing theories. The search strategy will have a number of stages, including a combination of: (1) electronic database search, eg EMBASE, MEDLINE, Cochrane Library, ASSIA, (2) 'cited' article search, (3) citation search, (4) with authors communicate and (5) gray literature review. The search for evidence will be expanded and refocused over and over as the review progresses. Studies will be included based on their ability to provide data enabling program theory to be tested. Data extraction will be carried out in different review phases, for example note-taking and note-taking, consistent with the realistic approach. Evidence will be synthesized using realistic logic to challenge the ultimate program theory of the impact of assessment on physicians' performance. Synthesis results will be written according to RAMESES guidelines and distributed through peer-reviewed publication and presentations. TRIAL REGISTRATION NUMBER: Protocol registered with PROSPPERO 2014:CRD42014007092.

title: Understanding the implementation processes of clinical pathways and clinical practice guidelines in pediatric contexts: a study protocol
abstract: BACKGROUND: Canada is among the most prosperous countries in the world, but the health and wellness outcomes for Canadian children are surprisingly poor. There is some evidence to suggest that these poor health outcomes are due in part to clinical practice variation, otherwise known as information translation (KT), which may be due in part to a failure to apply the best research evidence available in clinical practice. Surprisingly, clinical practice differences are common even for common acute pediatric conditions. Clinical practice variation results in unnecessary medical treatments, increased pain and increased healthcare costs. This study focuses on improving health outcomes for common pediatric acute health problems by evaluating strategies that improve KT and reduce clinical practice variation. DESIGN/METHODS: Using a multiple case study design, qualitative and quantitative data will be collected from four emergency departments in western Canada. Data sources will include: "pre- and post-implementation focus group data from multidisciplinary healthcare professionals"; individual interviews with local champions, KT response providers, and unit/site leaders/managers; Alberta Context Tool (ACT) survey data; and aggregated patient outcome data. Qualitative and quantitative data will be systematically triangulated and matrices will be created to make cross-case comparisons. Based on cross-case comparisons, statements will be made about the success or failure of uptake of clinical practice guidelines (CPG) and clinical pathways (CPs). will generate new insights into potential causal mechanisms and factors Future studies will monitor the impact of the administration of CPG/CPs on children's health outcomes and health care costs.

title: Understanding nonadherence to colorectal cancer screening: a case-control study nestled in a randomized trialÂ
abstract: Background The main limit of colorectal cancer screening efficacy is generally low compliance. We examined the reasons for non-compliance with stool occult blood tests and the predictors of compliance in Lazio, Italy. Methods This is a case-control study built into a trial that tests the effect of test type and provider on colorectal cancer screening compliance. Non-conforming trial subjects were classified as cases, and compliant subjects were classified as controls. We sampled 600 cases and 600 controls matched by their general practitioners, half of whom were invited for screening at the hospital and the other half were invited directly to the GP's office. Subjects and controls answered the following questions: distance from testing provider, logistical issues, perceived risk of colorectal cancer, confidence in screening effectiveness, fear of results, family history of colorectal cancer, and gastrointestinal symptoms. Results Approximately 31% of cases did not receive the letter offering free screening and 17% of the sampled population had already been screened. The first reported reason for non-compliance was "lack of time" (30%)";" The main determinant of compliance was distance from test provider: odds ratio >30 minutes vs <15 minutes 0.3 (95% CI = 0.2 – 0.7). The odds for the lack of time were 0.16 (95% IC 0.1- 0.26). The effect was stronger if the provider was a hospital (0.03 95% CI = 0.01–0.1) rather than a general practitioner (0.3% 95% CI = 0.2-0.6). Twenty-two percent of the controls were accompanied by someone in the test. Conclusion To increase compliance, screening programs should include testing providers geographically close to the target population.

title: Understanding doctors' acceptance of mobile technology: insights from two phone calls in Finland
abstract: This article aims to explore doctors' perceptions and use of a new mobile medical information system in a pilot trial in the Finnish healthcare sector. Two datasets were collected via telephone interviews in June and October 2003. The interviewed physicians had positive opinions about the mobile system and started to use it frequently in their work. They showed very few negative experiences of using the Nokia Communicator. They chose to use mobile technology as a way to improve the dissemination of medical information. The main content of the system, Evidence-Based Medical Guidelines and Pharmaca Fennica (pharmacopeia), was crucial to the use of the system. Some differences in the behavior of doctors over time were also found. The implications for system improvement are discussed.

title: Understanding practice: factors influencing the management of mild traumatic brain injury in the emergency department—a qualitative study using the Theoretical Domains Framework.
abstract: OBJECTIVE: Mild traumatic brain injury is a frequent cause of admission to emergency services. Despite the availability of clinical practice guidelines in this area, there are differences in practice. One of the aims of the Neurotrauma Evidence Translation program is to develop and evaluate a targeted, theory- and evidence-based intervention to improve the treatment of mild traumatic brain injury in Australian emergency departments. This study is the first step in the intervention development process and uses the Theoretical Domains Framework to explore the factors perceived to influence the uptake of four main evidence-based recommended practices to manage mild traumatic brain injury. METHODS: Semi-structured interviews were conducted with emergency personnel in Victoria, Australia. The interview guide was developed using the Theoretical Domains Framework to explore current practice and identify factors perceived to affect practice. Two researchers coded the interview transcripts using thematic content analysis. RESULTS: A total of 42 participants (9 Managers, 20 doctors and 13 nurses) were interviewed over a seven-month period. The results showed that (i) prospective assessment of post-traumatic amnesia is influenced by: "knowledge"; beliefs about outcomes; environmental context and resources; skills; social/professional role and identity; and beliefs about abilities; (ii) use to inform appropriate use of CT scanning The criteria or decision rules developed by the guideline were influenced by the following: knowledge; beliefs about outcomes; environmental context and resources; memory, attention, and decision processes; beliefs about abilities; social influences; skills and behavioral regulation (iii) oral and written patient information about discharge provision was affected by: beliefs about outcomes; environmental context and resources; memory, attention, and decision processes; social/professional role and identity; and knowledge; (iv) briefing practice, routine follow-up on discharge were affected by: environmental context and resources; social /professional role and identity; information corner; with results Relevant beliefs" and motivation and goals. RESULTS: Using the Theoretical Domains Framework, factors thought to affect the management of mild traumatic brain injury in the emergency department were determined. These factors offer theoretically based targets for a future intervention.

title: Understanding the neurobiology, assessment and treatment of substances of abuse and addiction: a guide for the intensive care nurse.
abstract: What do I do as an intensive care nurse? Because nurses are trained in health promotion and also interact with patients, their families and communities, they have first-hand opportunities to play an active role in primary prevention practices. Assess community need, assess facility needs, and identify potential risk to prevent the first occurrence of substance abuse. Determine the size of the problem. Intervene early on youth and at-risk populations. Refer patients and their families to mental health professionals. Provide education to patients, families, communities. Implementing secondary prevention to reduce substance abuse incidents requires immediate action at the earliest moments to recognize a problem and refer patients to early intervention and rehabilitation. Screening your patients, providing short training and prompt referral constitute early intervention. To delay disease progression, implement tertiary prevention by providing education, counseling and support to victims in achieving and maintaining sobriety through medication adherence and rehabilitative group and counseling work. The purpose of intervention in the lives of substance abusers is to stop drug use, prevent relapse, and maintain recovery. After years of research, NIDA has identified 13 key principles for effective drug addiction treatment. 1. Addiction is a complex but treatable disease that affects brain function and behavior. 2. No single treatment is suitable for everyone. 3. The treatment must be ready. 4. Effective treatment deals with multiple needs of the individual, not just drug use. 5. It is very important to stay in treatment for an adequate period of time. 6. Counseling—individual and/or group—and other behavioral therapies are the most common forms of drug addiction treatment. 7. Medication is an important element of treatment for many patients, especially when combined with counseling and other behavioral therapies. 8. The individual's treatment and service plan should be continually evaluated and modified as necessary to ensure that it meets their changing needs. 9. Many drug addicts also have other mental disorders that require treatment. 10. Medically assisted detoxification in the first phase of addiction treatment and alone does little to change long-term drug use. 11. Treatment does not have to be voluntary to be effective. 12. Medication use should be continuously monitored during treatment, as treatment delays may occur. 13. Treatment programs should assess patients for the presence of HIV/AIDS, hepatitis B and C, tuberculosis and other communicable diseases, and also provide targeted risk reduction counseling to help patients change or modify behaviors that put them at risk of contracting it. or the spread of infectious diseases. To truly impact this disease, improvement in identifying risk factors and early diagnosis and early intervention with children and adolescents is needed. The future of neuroscience is in objective brain scans and genetic testing. Of these approaches, more objective measures of addiction and addiction can be made using brain scans and genetic testing. These measures will potentially allow for the development of vaccines for certain drugs of abuse and addiction, as well as increasingly selective and effective pharmacological approaches to treatment and a new consensus on the standard of care for substance abuse.

title: Understanding the performance of community health volunteers involved in the delivery of health programs in underserved areas: a realistic synthesis
abstract: Background Recruiting community health volunteers (CHVs) to support the delivery of health programs is an established approach in underserved areas and particularly where there are inequalities in health due to scarcity of trained human resources. However, there is little evidence of what works to improve CHVsÂ¡Â¯ performance. This review aimed to synthesize the available literature to explain why, how, and under what conditions intervention approaches to improve the performance of CHVs may be more successful. Methods We carried out a realistic synthesis. We identified candidate theories relevant to our review questions and then guided the selection, evaluation, and analysis of primary studies. Publications of interest from 2008 to 2012 were identified by a systematic search in PubMed and IDEAS databases. We found appropriate all study designs that examined various aspects of CHV performance in the context of formal organizational settings and excluded studies that did not explain the performance of CHVs either in the findings or in the discussion section. Data were organized by context, interventions, outcomes, and mechanisms to identify interactions between them. The synthesis of the data allowed us to identify explanatory patterns within or across studies. Results We identified broad intervention approaches within the 23 articles included in the review: positioning CHV in the community, establishing clear roles, providing skills-based and continuing education, incentives, supervision, and logistical support for deployment and implementation. The findings provided insight into which mechanisms (self-esteem, sense of duty, self-efficacy, sense of fair treatment) should be targeted when applying such approaches and which contextual factors (stable and supportive cultural, political and social context and intervention are closely related). . linked to local health services) creates optimal conditions for these mechanisms to occur and ultimately contributes to better performance of CHVs. Four main explanatory models around these mechanisms emerged as the basis for better performance. Conclusions The assumptions about how such interventions are expected to work, combined with the models identified, designersÂ¡Â¯ and other stakeholders¡Â¯ can be tested through empirical studies to provide useful information to be used by program practitioners, policy makers, donors. and community.

title: Unemployment and death rate in Denmark, 1970-80
abstract: The relative death rate for the period 1970-80 was studied among Danish men and women who were unemployed and working on the day of the 1970 census. The population of the research consisted of the total workforce between the ages of 20-64 on November 9, 1970, that is, approximately 2 million workers and 22.000 unemployed. Relative mortality was analyzed with a multiplicative hazard regression model (as a natural extension of the standardized mortality rate) and a multiplicative regression model with extra Poisson variation. After adjusting for occupation, housing category, geographic region and marital status, a significantly increased mortality rate (40-50%) was found among the unemployed. An analysis of the five major causes of death showed increased rates of death from all causes, particularly suicide or accidents. In regions with relatively high local unemployment rates, the relative mortality rate among the unemployed was lower. The increased mortality rate among the unemployed has been interpreted as a result of increased sensitivity linked to the psychosocial stress of unemployment as well as health-related choice.

title: Unequal protection for patients' rights: the distinction between university and health ethics committees
abstract: Despite the recommendations of the Cartwright Report, ethical review by health ethics committees continued in New Zealand without having to acknowledge the dual role of health practitioners as health practitioners investigating their own patients. On the other hand, universities define doctor/research-patient relationships as a relationship that can potentially lead to role conflict problems. This is due to the acknowledgment within the university sector that faculty/research-student relationships are full of such conflicts. Although similar unequal relationships appear to exist between health researchers and their patients, the patient/subjects do not receive the same levels of protection as students/subjects. In this paper, we argue that the difference between universities and health research is a result of the Operational Standard Guidelines for Ethics Committees failing to openly acknowledge the patient's vulnerability and conflict of interest in the dual roles of the health practitioner/researcher. We conclude the article recommending the Ministry of Health to rewrite the Operational Standard Rules for Ethics Committees, specifically section 26 of the Operational Standard Rules for Ethics Committees. We also identify the value of comparative ethical review, and the New Zealand Health Research Council's tripartite relationship with Australia's NHMRC (National Health and Medical Research Council) and Canada's CIHR (Canadian Health Research Institute) is a useful tool for such a process. We recommend it as a starting point.

title: Unhealthy drinking habits and the receipt of preventive medical services by older adults
abstract: BACKGROUND: There is insufficient use of preventive services among older adults. Unhealthy drinking can be a risk factor for not getting these services. OBJECTIVES: To determine the association between unhealthy drinking and receiving recommended preventive services among older Medicare beneficiaries by applying the existing framework of alcohol consumption guidelines. DESIGN/METHODS: Data source is the nationally representative 2003 Medicare Current Beneficiary Survey. The sample includes community-dwelling Medicare beneficiaries aged 65 and over (N = 10,523) who receive a fee per service. Based on self-reported drinking, participants were categorized as nonsmokers, regular drinkers, exceeding monthly limits but not daily, or severe intermittent drinkers. Influenza vaccine, pneumonia vaccine, glaucoma screening and mammogram receipt were determined using questionnaire and demand data. Bivariate and logistic regression analyzes were performed. RESULTS: Overall, during the year, 70.3% had flu vaccination, 49% had glaucoma screening, 66.8% had pneumonia vaccination, and 56.2% of women had mammography for 2 years. In logistic regression, severe episodic drinking was associated with a lower likelihood of service enrollment compared to drinking within the guidelines: influenza vaccine (OR 0.75, CI 0.59-0.96), glaucoma screening (OR 0.74, CI 0.58-0.95), and pneumonia vaccine (OR 0.75, CI. 0.59-0.96). Nonsmokers were less likely to receive mammograms (OR 0.83, CI 0.69-1.00) compared with those who reported drinking within guidelines. CONCLUSIONS: Heavy episodic drinking is associated with less likelihood of receiving few preventative services. Practitioners should be encouraged to screen all seniors for alcohol intake and consider older people reporting heavy episodic drinking at higher risk for not receiving preventive services, in addition to appropriate intervention.

title: Adverse effects of a computerized physician, nearly stop warning input to avoid a drug interaction: a randomized controlled trial.
abstract: Background The effectiveness of computerized physician order entry (CPOE) systems has been modest, in large part as clinicians override electronic alerts. METHODS A randomized clinical trial was conducted at 2 academic medical centers in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania to evaluate the effectiveness of a nearly “hard stop” CPOE prescribing warning aimed at reducing co-orders for warfarin and trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole. A total of 1981 clinicians were assigned to either an intervention group that received a near-stop warning or a control group that received standard practice. The run time was from August 9, 2006 to February 13, 2007. Results The proportion of desired responses (ie, no reordering of the stimulus-triggering drug within 10 minutes of firing) was 57.2% (111 of 194 hard stop stimuli). 13.5% (20/148) (adjusted odds ratio, 0.12; 95% confidence interval, 0.045-0.33) in the intervention group and control group. However, the study was terminated early due to 4 adverse outcomes identified among patients in the intervention. group: delay of trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole therapy in 2 patients and delay of warfarin therapy in the other 2 patients Results An electronic hard-stop alert as part of the inpatient CPOE system appeared to be extremely effective in changing the prescribing intervention, clinically significant in the 4 patients requiring emergency drug therapy resulted in treatment delays.These results demonstrate the importance of formal evaluation and monitoring for unintended outcomes of programmatic interventions aimed at improving prescribing habits.

title: Update on interventions focused on symptom clusters: what has been tried and what have we learned?
abstract: PURPOSE OF REVIEW: Although clinicians and researchers have acknowledged clusters of symptoms, the focus has been on the relief of a single symptom. This review summarizes the recent literature on interventions focused on alleviating symptom clusters in patients with cancer. RECENT RESULTS: Twelve intervention studies that met the inclusion criteria were published in 2011-2012. The time frame was extended to 2009-2012, and 24 studies met the criteria: 18 in early-stage cancer and 6 in advanced-stage cancer patients. A variety of cognitive behavioral therapy, complementary therapy, and exercise interventions have shown positive results in alleviating various clusters of symptoms in various types of cancer. Most psychoeducational interventions using traditional formats or combined with automated clinician prompts have shown to be effective in reducing various clusters. Clusters including fatigue and anxiety or depression were reduced by exercise in early-stage patients and methylphenidate in advanced-stage patients. Current NIH R01-funded studies have confirmed trends in the types of interventions tested. SUMMARY: Few interventions have been tested and found to be effective in relieving specific clusters of symptoms in patients with early and advanced cancer. Future research needs to expand our understanding of the mechanisms that initiate co-occurring symptoms. Mechanism-targeted interventions need to be identified and tested in homogeneous samples with specific symptom clusters. Interventions need to be repeated before guidelines can be created.

title: Update on pediatric hyperlipidemia
abstract: PURPOSE OF REVIEW: The purpose of this study is to review the National Heart, Lung, and Blood Institute (NHBLI) guidelines on the screening and management of hyperlipidemia in children and to discuss critical concerns about universal screening. RECENT FINDINGS: Data from the National Health and Nutrition Examination Survey showed positive trends in serum lipid levels among 6-19-year-old children and adolescents between 1988-1994 and 2007-2010. Mean total cholesterol (TC) decreased from 165 to 160 mg/dl and the prevalence of high TC decreased from 11.3% to 8.1%. However, between 2007 and 2010, approximately 20% of 9-11 year olds had either low high-density lipoprotein cholesterol (HDL-C) or high non-HDL cholesterol. This warrants additional evaluation according to NHBLI guidelines. SUMMARY: NHBLI guidelines offer physicians a balanced perspective for screening and managing hyperlipidemia in children. These guidelines provide a schematic approach to help primary care physicians make treatment decisions. The hope is that this will lead to reduced health system costs and overall improved health through early detection and intervention.

title: US medical researchers, Nuremberg Doctors Trial and Nuremberg Law. Review of the findings of the Human Radiation Experiments Advisory Committee
abstract: The Human Radiation Experiments Advisory Committee (ACHRE), established to examine allegations of abuse of human subjects in federally sponsored radiation research, was tasked with setting appropriate standards for evaluating the ethics of cold war radiation experiments. One of ACHRE's key questions was to determine the role (if any) the Nuremberg Law plays in the norms and practice of US medical researchers. Based on the evidence from ACHRE's Ethics Oral History Project and extensive archival research, we conclude that the Code had little impact on mainstream medical researchers engaged in human subjects research at the time of publication. Although some clinical researchers have raised questions about conducting research involving humans, the medical profession did not pursue this topic until the 1960s.

title: Use and impact of health information exchange: a systematic review.
abstract: Background: Health information exchange (HIE) is on the rise in the United States and is encouraged by government policies. Objective: To systematically review and evaluate the evidence for the use and impact of HIE in clinical care. Data Sources: Selected databases from 1 January 2003 to 31 May 2014. Study Selection: English-language hypothesis testing or quantitative studies of various types of data exchanges between independent organizations for use in clinical care that address health outcomes, efficiency, utilization, costs, satisfaction, HIE use, sustainability, and attitudes or barriers. Data Extraction: Data extraction was done in duplicate. Data Synthesis: Low-quality evidence from 12 hypothesis-testing studies supports the impact of HIE use in the emergency room on reduced utilization or costs. Direct evidence of use of HIEs by providers was reported in 21 studies involving 13 different HIE organizations, 6 of which were located in New York, and generally showed use in less than 10% of patient encounters. Findings from 17 sustainability studies show that about a quarter of existing HIE organizations consider themselves financially stable. Findings from 38 studies on attitudes and barriers showed that providers, patients, and other stakeholders value HIE, but barriers include technical and workflow issues, costs, and privacy concerns. Limitation: Publication bias, possible selective reporting of results, and lack of reporting on context and implementation processes. Conclusion: The use of health information exchange probably reduces emergency room use and costs in some cases. Effects on other outcomes are unknown. All stakeholders claim to value HIE, but there are many barriers to acceptance and sustainability. A small proportion of operational HIEs have been evaluated, and more research is needed to identify and understand their success factors.

title: Use and prevention of isolation and restraint: a consensus statement of the American Emergency Psychiatric Association project Beta isolation and restraint working group.
abstract: Issues of reducing and/or eliminating periods of isolation and restraint in patients with behavioral problems in crisis clinics, emergency rooms, inpatient psychiatric units, and specialized psychiatric emergency services remain an area of concern and debate among mental health clinicians. An important principle underlying the BETA Project (Best Practices in the Evaluation and Treatment of Agitation) is non-compulsive tension reduction as the preferred intervention in the management of acute agitation and threatening behavior. In this article, the authors review the Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services guidelines governing their use in medical behavior settings, the negative consequences of this intervention on patients and staff, and the risk management strategies that are effective in reducing their quality improvement and use in a variety of treatment settings. An algorithm designed to help the clinician determine when isolation or restraint is most appropriate is introduced. The authors concluded that specialized psychiatric emergency services and emergency services may not be able to completely eliminate the use of segregation and restraint events because of their treatment primarily for acute patients, but that these programs may adopt strategies to reduce the rate of use of these types. interventions.

title: Use and care of animals in research and teaching: MMA policy statement
Methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus: Use of a Clinical Decision Support Tool to improve compliance with guidelines for the treatment of Skin and Soft Tissue Infections.
abstract: Abscessed Skin and Soft Tissue Infections (SSTIs) are common in the Emergency Department (ED) setting. Given the increasing prevalence of abscesses associated with methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus-aureus (MRSA), appropriate evidence-based judgments are required to ensure successful treatment. Provider adherence to clinical guidelines for the treatment of SSTIs with putative MRSA remains inconsistent with prescriptive practices regarding patient discharge recommendations regarding antibiotic selection, wound culturing, and use of infection control techniques. Evidence shows that the use of Clinical Decision Support (CDS) tools is valuable in improving provider awareness and adherence to clinical guidelines. This study was undertaken to examine whether the development of a CDS tool for the treatment of MRSA-related SSTIs to guide order entry and embed it into the electronic medical record program would improve provider adherence to the North Carolina Consensus Guidelines for the Management of Suspicious Community. Acquired MRSA Skin and Soft Tissue.

title: Using computers to detect and respond to clinical events: impact on clinician behavior.
abstract: prospective, randomized study of a primary care diabetes clinic used a computer to prospectively detect and recommend responses to simple, drug-related events as reflected in a computerized registry. There were two categories of events/recommendations: when the last observation of a test required for drug control was too old, the computer suggested a repeat", and when an abnormality with therapeutic implications was detected, the computer suggested a specific change in therapeutics. Clinicians accounted for 36% of the events in the first category. responded with reminders and 11% responded without computer reminders (P < 0.0001);" they responded to 28% of the events in the second category with computer assistance and 13% without (P < 0.026). For the most clinically significant of these second category events, the difference was even greater: 47% with computer assistance and 4% without computer assistance (P < 0.0004). I believe that computer detection and response (in the form of reminders) to simple clinical events will change clinician behavior.

title: The use of a computerized guideline for glucose regulation in the ICU improved both guideline adherence and glucose regulation.
abstract: Purpose: To measure the effect of a computerized manual for glucose regulation in an intensive care unit. Design: A randomized controlled trial with an open-closed design. Methods: We implemented a paper glucose regulation guideline in an intensive care unit during the first study period. During the second semester, the guide was randomly applied, either on paper or on a computer. In the third period, the manual was only available in paper form. Measurements and results: We analyzed data from 484 patients. During the intervention period, the control group consisted of 54 patients and the computerized intervention group consisted of 66 patients. Two outcome measures for the guideline consisted of (a) glucose measurement timing recommendations and (b) adherence to insulin dose recommendation. We measured the clinical effect as the proportion of time glucose levels fell within the target range. In the first (paper-based) study period, 29.0% of samples occurred with optimal timing"; in the second period this increased to 35.5% for paper-based protocols and 40.2% for computerized protocols. Third study period timeliness scores returned Late (non-optimal) sampling occurred for 66% of glucose measurements in the first study period, 42% of the paper-based protocol samples and 28% of the computer-based protocol samples in the second study period. In the period, compliance with insulin dosing guideline was 56.3%; While it was 64.2% in paper-based protocols and 77.3% in computer-based protocols in the second period, it decreased to 42.4% in the third period. For the second study period, the time a patient's glucose levels fell within the target range compared to the first study period (44.3%) and the third period (42.3) for both the control (52.9%) and computerized groups (54.2%). improved by comparison. %). Conclusion: Implementation of a computerized version of a guideline significantly improved timely measurements and glucose level regulation for critically ill patients compared to implementing a paper-based version of the guideline.

title: Using a decision aid with information on overdetection to support informed choice about breast cancer screening: a randomized controlled trial.
abstract: Background Mammography screening can reduce breast cancer mortality. However, most women are unaware that minor diseases can also be detected through screening, leading to overdiagnosis and overtreatment. We aimed to explore whether including information on breast cancer overdetection in a decision aid could help women aged around 50 years of age make an informed choice about breast screening. Methods We conducted a population-based, parallel group, randomized controlled trial using a random cohort of women aged 48–50 years in New South Wales, Australia. Participation in the study was by telephone"; women were eligible for women who had not had a mammogram in the past 2 years and did not have a personal or strong family history of breast cancer. We randomly selected 879 participants with a computer program from either intervention decision assistance (over-detection, breast cancer mortality reduction, and contains evidence-based descriptive and quantitative information about false positives) or a control decision aid (including information on breast cancer mortality reduction and false positives). defined as adequate knowledge and consistency) Primary outcome analyzed in all women who completed relevant follow-up interview questions complete This trial is registered with the Australian New Zealand Clinical Tria ls Registry, number ACTRN12613001035718. Findings 44 to intervention group from January 2014 to July 2014 0 women and 439 women were assigned to the control group. 21 women in the intervention group and 20 controls dropped out; Ten women and 11 controls assigned to the intervention did not answer all questions about attitudes. Therefore, 409 women and 408 controls in the intervention group were analyzed for primary outcome. Of the 409 women in the intervention group, 99 (24%) made an informed choice (difference 9%, 95% CI 3–14; p=0Â·0017), compared with 63 (15%) of 408 women in the control group. Compared with controls, more women in the intervention group met the threshold of adequate general knowledge (122/419 [29] vs 71/419 [17%]; difference 12%, 95% CI 6–18; p<0Â· 0001), fewer women expressed positive attitudes towards screening (282/409 [69%] vs 340/408 [83%]; 14.9–20%; p<0Â·0001) and fewer women (308/419 [74%]) seeking screening and 363/419 [87%]; 13.8–19%;" p<0Â·0001). Considering only conceptual information, 203 (50%) of the 409 women in the intervention versus 79 (19%) of the 408 women in the control group ) made an informed choice (p<0Â·0001) Interpretation Information on overdetection of breast cancer provided in a decision aid has increased the number of women making an informed choice about breast screening Being more informed may mean that women are less likely to choose screening.

title: Using a fall prevention practice guideline for seniors living in the fall-risk community: a feasibility study
abstract: Background: Falls occur frequently in the elderly and are a common cause of physical and psychological morbidity and healthcare use. The problem can be attributed to a complex interaction between health, behavioral and environmental factors. To provide a uniform and evidence-based approach, a practice guideline for fall prevention in community-dwelling elderly people at risk of falls has been developed. OBJECTIVE: To test the feasibility of integrating a fall prevention practice guide into the daily practice of the 4 core health disciplines, namely general practitioners, nurses, occupational therapists and physiotherapists. METHODS: This was a descriptive study conducted by 10 local health networks across Flanders. Subjects included in the study were 99 primary care workers and 1,142 community-dwelling elderly patients (65 years or older) who were able to get up from a chair and move independently. For 6 months, primary care workers followed our fall prevention guideline, which consists of 3 parts (case finding, multifactor in-depth assessment and interventions). After the 6-month trial phase, participating primary care workers were asked to complete a semi-structured questionnaire to assess the feasibility of using the guideline in daily practice. RESULTS: The average time spent implementing the guideline was 32.0+/-14.0 minutes. Health professionals from all 4 disciplines saw case finding as their responsibility. The picture was different in terms of the evaluation of risk factors and interventions. Although 87.5% thought fall prevention is an important issue, healthcare professionals from different disciplines disagreed on how to integrate prevention guidelines into daily practice. Perceived barriers to the implementation of the guideline were lack of time (57.3%), low motivation of the target audience (53.3%), and insufficient cooperation among healthcare professionals (37.3%). CONCLUSION: A guide can be used to initiate the integration of prevention strategies into daily practice. Case finding is possible for all disciplines. Multifactor assessment and interventions require specific assignments, multidisciplinary collaboration and open communication.

title: Using action planning to increase the delivery of smoking cessation care by general practitioners: the role of plan specificity and implementation
abstract: Background Strategies are needed to help general practitioners (GPs) promote smoking cessation as recommended by guidelines. This study examines whether the quality of action planning among GPs improves smoking cessation care. Methods The effectiveness of a 1-hour training program was examined in a cluster of randomized controlled trials involving 49 GPs. The GPs who followed the training (intervention group";" n?=?25) developed action plans to i) question smoking, ii) advise on smoking cessation, and iii) organize the follow-up of smokers who were motivated to quit. GPs also created a coping plan to encounter smokers who are not motivated to quit. The quality of these plans (plan specificity) were graded, and GPs reported on the performance of these plans 6 weeks after training (plan enactment). Multilevel regression analyzes were used to examine the effects of plan specificity and plan enforcement on patient-reported smoking cessation activities in the intervention group (n?=?1.632 patients) compared to the GPs control group (n?=?1.769 patients). . Results Compared with the control group, GPs who devised a highly specific action plan during training asked their patients to smoke more frequently after training than before training (OR 2.11, 95% CI 1.51–2.95). GPs were more likely to ask patients about smoking after training than before training when they enacted a highly specific formulated action plan (OR 3.08, 95% CI 2.04--4.64). The effects of the specificity of the GP plan and its enactment on asking patients about smoking were most evident among GPs who initially aimed to provide smoking cessation care. Conclusions A highly specific action plan formulated by a GP for when, how, and by whom patients should be asked about smoking has a positive effect on GPs asking patients about smoking, especially when they report that they have also implemented the plan. he had. This effect was most pronounced among GPs seeking to provide smoking cessation care prior to intervention. Training in designing personalized coping plans is recommended to further enhance GPs' advice on smoking cessation and to arrange follow-up support for smoking cessation.

title: Using an Internet portal to improve community-based pediatric ADHD care: a cluster randomized trial.
abstract: OBJECTIVE: To determine the effectiveness of a quality improvement program to improve pediatric physicians' adherence to existing, evidence-based, attention deficit/hyperactivity disorder (ADHD) practice guidelines. METHODS: A cluster of forty-nine community-based pediatricians across 8 practices participated in a randomized study. Practices were matched by the number of pediatricians and the proportion of patients receiving Medicaid. Medical charts of a random sample of ADHD patients were reviewed at baseline and at 6 months for each of the participating pediatricians. 4 sessions attended the training, including all practices, didactic lectures and office flow modification workshops. The apps were then given access to an ADHD Internet portal that allowed parents, teachers, and pediatricians to enter information about patients (eg, rating scales), after which the information was scored, interpreted, and formatted in a report style that was helpful for assessment and evaluation. Treatment of patients with ADHD. Physicians evaluated practice behaviors quarterly and addressed underperforming areas. RESULTS: Pediatricians in the intervention group showed significantly higher rates in many ADHD care practices recommended by the American Academy of Pediatrics, including parent (Cohen's d = 0.69) and teacher (d = 0.68) assessment, compared with those in the control group. Scales for assessing children with ADHD, use of the Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders, Fourth Edition, criteria (d = 0.85) and use of teacher rating scales to monitor treatment responses (d = 1.01). CONCLUSION: A widely disseminated quality improvement intervention using Internet-based information technology has significantly improved the quality of ADHD care in community-based pediatric settings.

title: Antibiotic use. septicemia
Use of evidence in WHO recommendations
abstract: WHO regulations dating back to 1951 emphasize the role of expert opinion in the development of recommendations. However, the organization's guidelines, approved in 2003, emphasize the use of systematic reviews for evidence of effects, processes that allow the explicit inclusion of other types of information (including values), and evidence-based dissemination and implementation strategies. We examined the use of evidence, particularly the evidence of effects, in recommendations developed by WHO departments.";" WHO regulations dating back to 1951 emphasize the role of expert opinion in the development of recommendations. However, the organization's guidelines, approved in 2003, emphasize the use of systematic reviews for evidence of effects, processes that allow the explicit inclusion of other types of information (including values), and evidence-based dissemination and implementation strategies. We examined the use of evidence, particularly the evidence of impact, in recommendations developed by WHO departments.

title: Discharge Use of Warfarin in Acute Ischemic Stroke Patients with Nonvalvular Atrial Fibrillation in China
abstract: BACKGROUND AND OBJECTIVE: Guidelines recommend oral anticoagulation for ischemic stroke patients with atrial fibrillation, and previous studies have shown inadequate use of anticoagulation for these patients in China. We sought to explore the underlying causes and factors that currently affect warfarin use in China. METHODS: From June 2012 to January 2013, 19 604 patients with acute ischemic stroke were admitted to 219 city hospitals voluntarily participating in the China National Stroke Registry II. Multivariate logistic regression models using the generalized estimation equation method were used to identify patient/hospital factors independently associated with warfarin use at discharge. RESULTS: 19.4% of 952 acute ischemic stroke patients with nonvalvular atrial fibrillation were discharged with warfarin. Bleeding risk (52.8%) and patient rejection (31.9%) were the main reasons for not prescribing anticoagulation. Larger/teaching hospitals were more likely to prescribe warfarin. Older patients, heavy drinkers, and patients with a high National Health Stroke Scale score at presentation were less likely to receive warfarin, while patients with a history of heart failure and an internationally normalized ratio of 2.0 to 3.0 at time of hospitalization were significantly associated with warfarin use. at discharge. CONCLUSIONS: The rate of warfarin use remains low in patients with ischemic stroke and known nonvalvular atrial fibrillation in China. Hospital size and academic status, as well as patient age, heart failure, excessive alcohol consumption, international normalized rate in hospital, and stroke severity at admission were independently associated with warfarin use at discharge. There is much room for improvement for the prevention of secondary stroke in nonvalvular atrial fibrillation patients in China.

title: User satisfaction and frustration with a hand-held, pen-based guide delivery system for asthma
abstract: OBJECTIVE: To assess clinicians' satisfaction and frustration with the use of a handheld computer system implementing a guideline for the management of childhood asthma exacerbations. SETTING: Nine primary care pediatric practices. DESIGN: Questionnaire component of a randomized, prospective before-after trial. INTERVENTION: Newton MessagePad equipped with proprietary software (called "AsthMonitor") that assists in documenting clinical findings and provides guideline-based recommendations. RESULTS: Overall, 3 users gave a strongly positive overall rating, while 6 users were unbiased. The majority used the documentation functions sparingly at the same time. Other than recommendations for oxygen administration (not supported by evidence), users found the recommendations appropriate and appreciated the reminders. Seven out of 9 respondents believed that documenting with AsthMonitor took more time. CONCLUSIONS: Handhelds are acceptable for some office-based practitioners to make guideline-based recommendations in the context of the clinical encounter.

title: Using “nudge” principles for order set design: before and after evaluation of an electronic prescribing template in critical care
abstract: Objective Computerized order sets have the potential to reduce clinical variation and increase patient safety, but the effect is variable. We sought to evaluate the impact of changes in the design of an order set on the administration of chlorhexidine mouthwash and hydroxyethyl starch (HES) to patients in the ICU. Methods The study was conducted at Bristol NHS Foundation Trust University Hospitals in the United Kingdom. Clinical information system (CIS) is used in our intensive care unit. All medications and fluids are prescribed with the CIS, and medication and fluid charts are stored in a database. Chlorhexidine mouthwash was added as the default prescription to the prescribing template in January 2010. HES was removed from the prescribing template in April 2009. Both interventions were available for manual prescribing throughout the study period. We performed a database review of all eligible patients for each intervention before and after changes to the configuration of options in the prescribing system. Results It was determined that 2231 ventilated patients were suitable for chlorhexidine treatment, 591 were pre-intervention and 1640 post-intervention. Chlorhexidine was prescribed for 55.3% before and 90.4% after the change (p<0.001). In the HES intervention, 6199 patients, 2177 before the intervention and 4022 after the intervention were evaluated. The mean volume of HES infused per patient decreased from 630 mL to 20 mL after the change (p<0.001), and the percentage of patients receiving HES decreased from 54.1% to 3.1% (p<0.001). These results have been well preserved over time. Results The provision of options within an electronic prescribing system influenced the predictable delivery of evidence-based interventions, and the impact was well sustained. This approach has the potential to increase the effectiveness of computerized order sets.

title: Using a taxonomy of behavior modification techniques to identify active ingredients in trials of practice interventions for diabetes care
abstract: BACKGROUND: Methodological guidelines for intervention reporting emphasize the detailed disclosure of intervention content. Despite this, systematic reviews of quality improvement (QI) implementation interventions continue to be limited by the lack of clarity and detail on the intervention content being evaluated. We aimed to apply the recently developed Taxonomy of Behavior Change Techniques version 1 (BCTTv1) to trials of practice interventions for diabetes management to evaluate the capacity and utility of this taxonomy to characterize active ingredients. METHODS: Three psychologists independently coded a random sample of 23 trials of healthcare system, provider, and/or patient-focused practice interventions from a systematic review of 142 such studies. Intervention content was coded using BCTTv1, which identified 93 behavior modification techniques (BCTs) grouped into 16 categories. We have supplemented the general encoding instructions in BCTTv1 with decision rules and examples from this literature. RESULTS: Less than a quarter of the possible BCTs in BCTTv1 were identified. For practice interventions targeting providers, the most commonly identified BCTs included: adding objects to the environment, directions/cues, instruction on how to perform the behavior, reliable source, goal setting (outcome), feedback on the outcome of the behavior, and social support (practice) . For practice interventions that also targeted patients, the most commonly identified BCTs included: warnings/cues, instruction on how to perform the behavior, information about health outcomes, restructuring the social environment, adding objects to the environment, social support (practice), and goal setting. (behaviour). BCTTv1 is well matched to practice interventions that directly target clinicians and patients, and can also be used to examine the impact of system-level interventions on clinician and patient behavior. RESULTS: BCTTv1 can be used to characterize active ingredients in trials of application interventions, providing content specificity beyond those given by broader intervention labels. Identifying BCTs can provide a more useful tool for accumulating information about the content used in trials of practice interventions, and it can help better inform replication efforts. In addition, the prospective use of a taxonomy of behavior modification techniques to develop and report intervention content will further assist in establishing a cumulative science of effective practice interventions.

title: Using planned behavior framework theory to explore hand hygiene beliefs at '5 critical moments' among Australian hospital nurses
abstract: BACKGROUND: Improving hand hygiene among healthcare workers (HCWs) is the single most effective intervention in reducing healthcare-associated infections in hospitals. For healthcare professionals with the most patient contact (nurses), understanding the cognitive determinants of hand hygiene decisions is essential to improve compliance. The aim of this study was to investigate hospital-based nurses' beliefs about performing hand hygiene under the guidance of the World Health Organization (WHO) 5 critical moments. Using the belief-based framework of Planned Behavior Theory, we examined nurses' attitudinal, normative, and control beliefs that underpin their decisions to perform hand hygiene according to recently implemented national guidelines. METHODS: Thematic content analysis of qualitative data from focus group interviews with hospital-based registered nurses from 5 wards in 3 hospitals in Queensland, Australia. RESULTS: Significant advantages (patient and self-protection), disadvantages (time, hand damage), references (supportive: patients, colleagues";" unsupported: some doctors), barriers (too busy, emergencies), and facilitators (accessibility) sinks /products, training, reminders) were detected. There was some doubt about the relative importance of hand washing after contact with the patient's environment. CONCLUSIONS: The belief basis of the planned behavior theory provided a useful framework for systematically investigating the beliefs underlying nurses' hand hygiene decisions based on 5 critical moments, and allowed comparisons with previous belief studies. Nurses' commitment to improving hand hygiene practices during the 5 moments should focus on individual strategies to distract from other tasks, peer-based initiatives to foster a sense of shared responsibility, and management-focused solutions to tackle staffing and resource issues. After touching the patient's environment, hand hygiene continues to be reported as the most neglected opportunity for compliance.

title: Using Appreciative Inquiry to promote evidence-based practice in nursing: the glass is more than half full
abstract: It is now understood that successful implementation of evidence-based practice (EBP) requires a focus on the context of the care setting. While limitations and barriers have been the focus of many reports, this article proposes a new approach to "making EBP happen." Appreciative Inquiry (AI), both a social research method and an organizational development or change intervention, is a new tool to elicit enthusiasm and support for EBP in nursing. Readers will be introduced to the "4-D Model" of artificial intelligence, as well as its theoretical foundations and assumptions. The advanced practice nurse (APN) is recommended to be in a key position to promote and support this intervention in healthcare settings to promote the successful implementation of EBP.

title: Use of computerized clinical decision support for screening for occult tuberculosis infection.
abstract: Past Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) has published guidelines recommending screening of high-risk groups for latent tuberculosis infection (LTBI). The aim of this study was to determine the effect of computerized clinical decision support and guided web-based documentation on LTBI screening rates. Design Non-randomised, prospective, intervention study. Setting and participants Participants were 8,463 patients seen in two primary care, outpatient, public health center clinics in late 2002 and early 2003. The intervention CDC's LTBI guidelines are coded into a computerized clinical decision support system that provides an alert that suggests further advice. Assessment of LTBI risk if certain guideline criteria are met (birth and age <40 years in a high-risk TB country). A guided web-based documentation tool is provided to facilitate proper adherence to the LTBI screening guideline and to encourage accurate documentation and evaluation. Baseline data were collected for 15 weeks and study phase data for 12 weeks. Key outcome measures Appropriate LTBI screening according to CDC guidelines based on table review. Results Of the 4135 patients enrolled in the post-intervention phase, 73% had at least one CDC-defined risk factor, and 610 met the warning criteria for potential screening for LTBI (birth in a high-risk TB country and <40 years of age). . Adherence to the LTBI screening guideline improved significantly from 8.9% at baseline to 25.2% during the study phase (183% increase, p < 0.001). Conclusions This study demonstrated that computerized clinical decision support using alerts and guided web-based documentation increases screening of high-risk patients for LTBI. Such technology could lead to an improvement in LTBI screening in the United States, and also shows promise for better care for other preventive and chronic conditions.

title: Using practice intentions to teach practitioners: changing practice behaviors through continuing education
abstract: OBJECTIVE: This study evaluated the effectiveness of practice intentions to increase the use of practice behavior among mental health practitioners attending a one-day continuing education class. METHODS: Seventy-eight practitioners were randomly assigned to one of two classes on psychiatric progression guidelines. One class included instruction (N=40) in the implementation objectives and the other class (N=38) did not. Practice intent training included consumers describing the best time and place to use a practitioner-guided procedure to help them complete a psychiatric advancement directive. Use of the practitioner-guided procedure was the dependent variable in this study. The practical use of the procedure was assessed with an electronic self-report questionnaire three months after the course. RESULTS: There were no statistically significant differences between the two classroom conditions in participant characteristics or intentions to use pre- or post-class information and procedure. Fifty-four participants (69%) responded to the three-month follow-up questionnaire, stating that they used the practitioner-guided procedure. The results of the follow-up survey showed that class participants that combined their intention to practice used the practitioner-guided procedure significantly more often than those in the other class overall (80% versus 58%). The influence of practice intentions on the use of the practitioner-guided procedure was evident among practitioners with high post-class intentions but below the median for the overall sample (chi(2)=7.1, df=1, p<.01). Implementation rates among practitioners with the highest post-lesson intent were equivalent across the two classroom conditions. CONCLUSIONS: The inclusion of practice intentions in continuing education classrooms can increase the use of practices taught in these classrooms among well-motivated practitioners.

title: Using practice intentions to teach practitioners: changing practice behaviors through continuing education.
abstract: Objective: This study evaluated the effectiveness of practice intentions in increasing the use of practice behavior among mental health practitioners attending a one-day continuing education class. Methods: Seventy-eight practitioners were randomly assigned to one of two classes on psychiatric progression guidelines. One class included instruction (N=40) in the implementation objectives and the other class (N=38) did not. Practice intent training included consumers describing the best time and place to use a practitioner-guided procedure to help them complete a psychiatric advancement directive. Use of the practitioner-guided procedure was the dependent variable in this study. The practical use of the procedure was assessed with an electronic self-report questionnaire three months after the course. Results: There were no statistically significant differences between the two classroom conditions in participant characteristics or pre- or post-class knowledge and intention to use the procedure. Fifty-four participants (69%) responded to the three-month follow-up questionnaire, stating that they used the practitioner-guided procedure. The results of the follow-up survey showed that class participants that combined their intention to practice used the practitioner-guided procedure significantly more often than those in the other class overall (80% versus 58%). The influence of practice intentions on the use of the practitioner-guided procedure was evident among practitioners with high post-class intentions but below the median for the overall sample (?2=7.1, df=1, p<.01). Implementation rates among practitioners with the highest post-lesson intent were equivalent across the two classroom conditions.
