Conclusions: Including practice intentions in continuing education classrooms can increase the use of practices taught in these classrooms among well-motivated practitioners. (Psychiatric Services 59:747–752, 2008)

title: Use of paper chart-based clinical reminders to improve guideline adherence to lipid management
abstract: RATIONALE, OBJECTIVES AND OBJECTIVES: The aim of this study was to implement a paper-based clinical reminder to improve adherence to lipid guidelines. METHODS: Patients with coronary heart disease (CHD) not receiving lipid-lowering therapy (LLT) were recruited and medical records were reviewed. Eligible subjects were randomized";" A clinical reminder stating current standards and local insurance policy is stamped on the paper table in the study group, but not in the control. The primary outcome was new LLT subscription at 6-month follow-up, and the secondary endpoint was the combined outcome of LLT or lipid profile control. RESULTS: 92 patients were assigned to the study group and 102 patients to the control group. The primary outcome showed no difference at 6 months (OR: 1.70, P = 0.248, 95% CI: 0.69-4.19). The secondary endpoint was significantly higher in the reminder group (OR: 2.81, P = 0.001, 95% CI: 1.57-5.04). CONCLUSION: A paper chart-based clinical reminder that provides up-to-date clinical recommendations can change the physician's behavior and increase attention to lipid levels. However, its effect cannot be translated into an increase in LLT or a decrease in low-density lipoprotein due to local policy constraint.

title: Using pathology-specific lab profiles in clinical pathology to reduce inappropriate testing requests: two completed audit cycles
abstract: BACKGROUND: Systematic reviews have shown that Consensus Guidelines, despite being well prepared, have failed to change clinical practice. In the Castelnovo ne Monti health region (Reggio Emilia, Italy), it has become necessary for GPs and Clinical Pathologists to work together to define laboratory profiles together. METHODS: Observational study in a primary care setting with two loops of retrospective checks on test request forms. The aim of the study was to develop pathology-specific laboratory profiles and increase the number of preliminary diagnoses in laboratory test request forms. The Multi-Professional Multidisciplinary Interhospital Working Team developed pathology-specific laboratory profiles for more efficient testing demand. After 8 training sessions using a combined strategy with multiple interventions, 23 GPs in the trial region (Castelnovo ne Monti) tested the profiles"; 21 GPs in the Puianello region were the control group; both GPs Districts surveyed For both health regions All laboratory tests are performed in the Laboratory located in the research area. An initial and 1-year audit has been carried out on the GPs request forms in both districts. RESULTS: Laboratory profiles have been developed for the seven pathology-specific outpatients Year after the first audit cycle: 1) in the trial area the number of tests requested was significantly lower than in the previous year, with a decrease of approximately 5% (p < 0.001), 2) the prediagnosis on request forms was 52.8% in the trial region and 42% in the control region (P < 0.001); 3 ) the reduction in the number of tests in each request form was much more pronounced in the t-rial region (8.73 vs. 10.77; "p < 0.001). RESULTS: The first inspection cycle showed a significant decrease in the number of tests ordered in the trial zone only. The combined strategy used in this study improved the prescriptive compliance of most of the GPs involved. The presence of a clinical pathologist is seen as an added value.

title: Using Second-Generation Antidepressants to Treat Depressive Disorders: A Clinical Practice Guide from the American College of Physicians
abstract: Description: The American College of Physicians developed this guideline to present the available evidence for the pharmacological management of the acute, ongoing, and maintenance phases of major depressive disorder; dysthymia; subsyndromal depression; and anxiety, insomnia, or neurovegetative symptoms, using second-generation antidepressants. Methods: Published literature on this topic was described from 1980 to April 2007 by MEDLINE, EMBASE, PsychLit, Cochrane Central Register of Controlled Trials, and International Pharmaceutical Abstracts. - Language studies in adults over 19 years of age. Search keywords included terms for depressive disorders and 12 specific second-generation antidepressants bupropion, citalopram, duloxetine, escitalopram, fluoxetine, fluvoxamine, mirtazapine, nefazodone, paroxetine, sertraline, trazodone, and venlafaxine. guide notes t Evidence and recommendations using the American College of Physicians clinical practice guidelines rating system. Recommendation 1: The American College of Physicians recommends that when clinicians choose pharmacological therapy to treat patients with acute major depression, they choose second-generation antidepressants based on their side-effect profile, cost, and patient preferences (Grade: strong recommendation; moderate-quality evidence). Recommendation 2: The American College of Physicians recommends that clinicians regularly assess patient status, therapeutic response, and side effects of antidepressant therapy, beginning within 1 to 2 weeks of starting treatment (Grade: strong recommendation; moderate-quality evidence). Recommendation 3: The American College of Physicians recommends that clinicians change therapy if the patient does not respond adequately to pharmacotherapy within 6 to 8 weeks of initiation of treatment for major depressive disorder (Grade: strong recommendation; moderate-quality evidence). Recommendation 4: The American College of Physicians recommends that clinicians continue treatment for 4 to 9 months after a satisfactory response in patients with a first episode of major depressive disorder. An even longer duration of treatment may be beneficial for patients who have had 2 or more episodes of depression (Grade: strong recommendation; "moderate-quality evidence").

title: Using shared goal setting to improve access and equity: A mixed-method study of the Good Goals intervention in children's occupational therapy
abstract: Background Access and equity in children's therapy services can be improved by directing clinicians' use of resources towards specific goals that are important to patients. An application change response (titled Â¡Â®Good GoalsÂ¡Â¯) has been designed to achieve this. This study investigated the uptake, adoption and possible effects of this intervention in children's occupational therapy services. Methods Mixed-method case studies (including n?=?3 services, 46 therapists and 558 children) were conducted. The intervention took place over 25 weeks through face-to-face training, team workbooks, and Â¡Â®change toolsÂ¡Â¯. Data were collected before, during, and after the intervention on a range of factors using the intervention, focus group, case note analysis, routine data, document analysis, and investigator observations. Results Recruitment and adoption factors were: the way the intervention was delivered, the competing demands for therapists' time, and the service manager's leadership. Service managers and therapists believe that the intervention: helps therapists establish a common rationale for clinical decisions; reported increasing clarity in service delivery and improving interactions with families and schools. During the study period, the behavior of the therapists changed: the rate of setting goals, probabilities 2.4 (95% CI 1.5 to 3.8); agreement on goals, 3.5 (2.4 to 5.1);" assessment of progress, 2.0 (1.1 - 3.5). Children's IoT decreased by two months across services [95% CI ?8 to +4? months]. Cost per therapist trained ranged from Â¡Ãª1.003 to Â¡¡1.277, depending on service size and therapistsÂ¡Â¯ salary bands. Results Good Goals is a promising quality improvement intervention that can be implemented and adopted in practice and may have benefits (i) Further research is needed to evaluate the impact on patient outcomes, efficacy, cost-effectiveness, and (ii) transferability to other clinical contexts.

title: Using standardized patients to measure the professional performance of physicians
abstract: OBJECTIVE: To determine the nature of potential errors when using standardized patients (SPs) to measure physician behavior and to evaluate the potential impact of these inaccuracies on estimates of physician performance. DESIGN: Secondary analysis from a randomized controlled trial. ENVIRONMENT: Family physicians' offices. STUDY PARTICIPANTS: Eighteen individuals, each describing one of the two patient scenarios, made a total of 179 visits to 92 family physicians who participated in a separate randomized controlled trial to evaluate the impact of a training workshop on implementation of preventive guidelines. MAIN OUTCOME MEASURES: The accuracy of SPs' descriptions of assigned scenarios and the accuracy of coding of physician performance are determined on the basis of audio tapes of visits and correlated with indicators of physicians' preventive practice. RESULTS: The accuracy of the depiction of the patient scenario was 84.8% for male CPs and 93.5% for female CPs. Inaccuracies in resuscitation had no effect on physician performance scores. The coding accuracy of physician performance was 90.5% (kappa = 0.66) for female CPs and 90.1% (kappa = 0.68) for male CPs. Coding errors occurred most frequently in the assessment of alcohol consumption and advice against smoking. CONCLUSION: CPs can provide valid information about the professional performance of physicians. However, the standardization of their activities should not be taken lightly. It may be more difficult to obtain standardized coding for consulting activities; this is one aspect of doctor visits that is particularly appropriate for TUs.

title: Using the Theoretical Domains Framework (TDF) to understand adherence to multiple evidence-based indicators in primary care: a qualitative study
abstract: Background There are accepted gaps between evidence and practice in general practice, which raises particular enforcement challenges. We screened previous clinical guideline recommendations to derive a set of Â¡Â®high-impactÂ¡Â¯ indicators based on criteria such as potential for significant patient benefit, improved scope of application, and eligibility for measurement using routinely collected data. Here, we explore the perceived determinants of healthcare professionals' adherence to these indicators, examining the extent to which the determinants are either indicator-specific or potentially generalizable across indicators. Methods We interviewed 60 GPs, practice nurses and practice managers in West Yorkshire, United Kingdom, about adherence to four indicators: “risky prescribing”, treatment goals in type 2 diabetes; blood pressure goals in treated hypertension; and anticoagulation in atrial fibrillation. Interview questions Theoretical. Based on Domains Framework (TDF) Data analyzed using framework analysis Results Professional role and identity and environmental context and resources were prominently featured across all indicators, while the importance of other domains, such as beliefs about outcomes, social influences, and knowledge, differed between indicators We identified five meta-themes representing the more general organizational and contextual factors common to all indicators Results TDF helped uncover a wide variety of reported predictors of adherence to Â¡Â®high-impactÂ¡Â¯ indicators in primary care. It was more difficult to determine which determinants would maximize change if The meta-themes highlight the need to align the design of interventions targeting general practices with higher-level supports and broader contextual considerations. However, our findings suggest that it is possible to develop interventions to promote the uptake of different evidence-based indicators that share common features, including context-specific adaptations.

title: Using the Research into Practice (TRIP) database: How do clinicians actually search?
abstract: OBJECTIVES: Clinicians and patients are increasingly accessing information through Internet searches. This study aimed to examine clinicians' current search behavior while using the Turning Research Into Practice (TRIP) database to examine search engine usage and how it could be improved. METHODS: A blog analysis of the TRIP database, a meta-search engine covering 150 health resources including MEDLINE, The Cochrane Library, and miscellaneous guidelines, was conducted. The connectors for terms used in searches were examined and observations were made on the search behavior of 9 users while working with the TRIP database. RESULTS: Most of the 620,735 searches used a single term, with 12% (n = 75,947) using the Boolean operator: 11% (n = 69.006) "AND" and 0.8% (n = 4,941) "OR". Of the elements of a well-structured clinical question (population, intervention, comparator, and outcome), population was most commonly used, while fewer searches included the intervention. The comparator and the result were rarely used. Participants in the observational study were interested in learning how to formulate better searches. RESULTS: Blog analysis showed that most searches used a single term and not Boolean operators. The observational study revealed that users are interested in making efficient searches, but do not always know how. Therefore, better training or better search interfaces are required to assist users and enable more effective searching.

title: Using theory to improve low back pain care in Australian Aboriginal primary care: a mixed-methods single-cohort pilot study.
abstract: BACKGROUND: Low back pain (LBP) care is often inconsistent with research evidence. This pilot study evaluated changes in LBP care following a systematic, theory-informed intervention in a rural Australian Aboriginal Health Service. We aimed to improve three aspects of care", reducing inappropriate LBP radiological imaging referrals, increasing psychosocially focused patient assessment, and increasing the provision of LBP self-management information to patients. METHODS: Three interventions were developed to improve care using four steps. systematic implementation approach Mixed methods pre-cohort/ post-intervention design evaluated changes in three behaviors using a clinical audit of LBP care over a six-month period following administration before and after the intervention (GPs) Qualitative analysis was guided by the theoretical domains framework RESULTS: Proportion of patients receiving guideline-inconsistent imaging referrals (GICI) , increased from 4.1 GICI per 10 patients to 0.4 (95% CI for reduction in ratio: 1.6 to 5.6 ) among GPs involved in the intervention Among GPs who were not participants (starting post-intervention) locum/part-time GPs) GICI rate 10 patients increased from 1.5 to 4.4 per a (95% CI for rate increase: from .5 to 5.3). There was a modest increase in the number of patients who received LBP self-management information from participating GPs, and there was no significant change in psychosocially oriented patient assessments by any of the participants," although GPs did report qualitative changes in their behavior. Environmental and resource factors, including clinical tools embedded in the software, were identified as future strategies. CONCLUSIONS: A systematic intervention model resulted in partial improvements in LBP care. Determinants of practice change among GPs Increasing knowledge of clinical guidelines, one recognized as a reliable source of information awareness of the negative consequences of education and inappropriate practices, particularly radiological imaging, on patient outcomes and inconsistent and evidence-based practice among Locum practitioners Problems are an emerging problem that will be a major challenge in the future. The systematic approach used applies to other services interested in improving LBP care.

title: Use of Wearable Devices and Smartphones to Track Physical Activity: Initial Activation, Continuous Use, and Step Count Across Sociodemographic Characteristics in a National Sample
abstract: Background: There is increasing interest in using wearable devices and smartphones to monitor daily health behaviors such as physical activity (1, 2). Many large employers use these technologies in their workplace wellness programs (3). The precision medicine initiative explained how the data collected by these technologies can be used to better target interventions. However, the characteristics of the people who use these devices are not fully understood. Purpose: To describe initial use of activity trackers, rates of continued use after 6 months, and step counts across different sociodemographic characteristics from a wellness program offered in the United States. Methods and Findings: Data on activity tracker use, average daily step counts, and sociodemographic characteristics between 2014 and 2015 for policyholders with access to HumanaVitality (now Go365), a wellness program offered throughout the United States, were obtained from Humana. Median household income from US Census data correlated using ZIP code. Data were taken as undefined and deemed exempt from review by the University of Pennsylvania Institutional Review Board.

title: Validation of the SF-36 health survey questionnaire: new outcome measure for primary care
abstract: OBJECTIVES To test the acceptability, validity and reliability of the short form 36 health questionnaire questionnaires (SF-36) and compare with the Nottingham health profile. DESIGN Postal questionnaire using a questionnaire booklet with a letter from the general practitioner. Those who did not respond received two reminders two weeks apart. The SF-36 questionnaire was retested on a subsample of respondents two weeks after the initial mailing. SETTING Two common practices in Sheffield. PATIENTS 1980 patients aged 16-74 years randomly selected from two application lists. MAIN OUTCOME MEASURES Scores for each health dimension in the SF-36 questionnaire and the Nottingham health profile. Responses to questions about end use and sociodemographic characteristics of health services. RESULTS The response rate of the SF-36 questionnaire was high (83%), and completion rate for each dimension was over 95%. There was substantial evidence for construct validity in terms of reliability of the SF-36 (Cronbach's alpha greater than 0.85, reliability coefficient greater than 0.75 for all dimensions except social functioning) and in distinguishing groups with expected health differences. The SF-36 was able to detect low health status in patients who scored 0 (good health) on the Nottingham health profile. CONCLUSIONS The SF-36 is a promising new tool for measuring health perception in the general population. It is easy to use, acceptable to patients, and meets strict criteria for reliability and validity. Its use in other contexts and with different disease groups requires further research.

title: Variations in GPs' decision to investigate suspected lung cancer: a factorial experiment using multimedia vignettes.
abstract: Introduction Lung cancer survival in the UK is low and relatively poor. Patients with symptoms suggestive of lung cancer often present to primary care, but it is unclear how general practitioners (GPs) distinguish which patients require further investigation. This study examined how patients' clinical and sociodemographic characteristics affect GPs' decisions to initiate lung cancer research. Methods A factorial experiment was conducted among a national sample of 227 British practitioners using vignettes presented as simulated consultations. A multimedia interactive website simulated key features of consultations using actors ("patients"). GP participants made online management decisions for six "patients" whose sociodemographic characteristics systematically varied at three cancer risk levels. In low-risk vignettes, investigation (i.e., chest X-ray requested, CT scan, or respiratory consultant referral) was not specified"; investigation may be appropriate in medium-risk vignettes; investigation was strictly indicated in high-risk vignettes Each "patient" had two lung cancer-related symptoms: one volunteered and Others emerged if GPs wanted. Variations in trial probability were examined using multilevel logistic regression. Results Doctors decided to investigate lung cancer in 74% (1000/1348) studies. The probability of trial did not increase with cancer risk. however, he was more likely to seek information when he requested information about involuntary symptoms (adjusted OR (AOR)=3.18; 95% CI 2.27 to 4.70) ), however, GPs in 42% (570/1348) of cases neglected to seek information. GPs were more likely to seek older "patients" (AOR=0.52; 95% CI 0.39 to 0.7) and lower than blacks. more 'patients' than white (AOR = 0.6 8;" 95% CI 0.48 to 0.95). Results GPs were not more likely to investigate high-risk 'patients' than low-risk cancer symptoms. Also, they equally treated everyone with the same symptoms. Inadequate data collection may be responsible for missed opportunities in diagnosis.

title: Venous thromboembolism risk and prophylaxis in the acute hospital care setting (ENDORSE study): a multinational cross-sectional study
abstract: Background Information on variations in venous thromboembolism (VTE) risk and prophylaxis practice worldwide is scarce. The ENDORSE (International Epidemiological Day for the Evaluation of Patients at Risk for Venous Thromboembolism in the Acute Hospital Care Setting) study was designed to assess the prevalence of VTE risk in the acute hospital care setting and the proportion of at-risk patients receiving effective prophylaxis.";" Background Information on variations in venous thromboembolism (VTE) risk and prophylaxis practice worldwide is scarce. The ENDORSE (International Epidemiological Day for the Evaluation of Patients at Risk of Venous Thromboembolism in the Acute Hospital Care Setting) study to assess the prevalence of VTE risk in the acute hospital care setting and the proportion of at-risk patients receiving effective prophylaxis.

title: Violence and Aggression: Short-Term Management in Mental Health, Health and Community Settings: Updated edition.
abstract: Â This guide has been developed to provide advice on the short-term management of violence and aggression in mental health, health, and community settings in adults, children (12 years and younger), and youth (13 to 17 years). This guide updates Violence: The Short-Term Management of Uncomfortable/Violent Behavior in Patient Psychiatric Settings and Emergency Rooms (NICE clinical guide 25), developed by the National Nursing and Supportive Care Collaborative Center and published in 2005. With the publication of the 2005 guideline, there have been some significant advances in our knowledge of the management of violence and aggression, including service users' views on the use of physical intervention and seclusion, and the efficacy, acceptability, and safety of drugs and their dosages. For quick calming. Previous guidance was limited to persons 16 years of age and older in adult psychiatric settings and emergency departments";" this update has been expanded to include some of the previously excluded populations and settings. All areas of the NICE clinical guideline 25 have been updated and this guide will replace it. The guideline recommendations were developed after careful consideration of the best available evidence by a multidisciplinary team of healthcare professionals, individuals with mental health conditions who have personally experienced the management of violent or aggressive behavior, their caregivers, and guideline methodologists. The guide is intended to be helpful to clinicians and service commissioners in the delivery and planning of high-quality care for the management of violence and aggression, while also emphasizing the importance of the care experience of these service users and the experience of their caregivers. (see Appendix 1 for more details on the scope of the guide). While the evidence base is expanding rapidly, a number of important gaps remain. The guide makes a number of research recommendations specifically to address gaps in the evidence base. In the meantime, it is hoped that the guide will assist clinicians, service users and caregivers by establishing the basis for specific treatment approaches for which evidence from research and clinical experience is available.

title: Violence in general practitioners: a survey of general practitioners' views.
abstract: OBJECTIVE To investigate the extent of abuse and violence against general practitioners during their professional duties and to classify the characteristics of this type of aggression. DESIGN Retrospective survey of the views of a large sample of general practitioners using a piloted postal survey. SET All medical practices in the West Midlands. SUBJECTS A total of 1093 GPs who answered the questionnaire (40.6% of the total sample). MAIN OUTCOME MEASURE Number of cases of aggression experienced by GPs and incidence of various triggering factors over a 12-month period. RESULTS Although the response was low at 40.6%, this study is the largest published database on aggression towards family physicians. In total, 687 (62.9%) respondents had experienced harassment or violence in the previous 12 months, 191 (17.5%) experienced some form of harassment at least once a month, and 11 (1%) every time. suffered verbal abuse. day. Even assuming that all non-responders did not experience any form of violence, patient aggression affects 25.5% of GPs in the west central regions. For practitioners experiencing patient aggression, the annual incidence of events per GP is 2.42. Of these general practitioners, 96 (14%) thought that aggression was increased. A total of 1520 (91.3%) of all incidents involved threats without verbal abuse or direct physical action. Surgery was the place where aggression was most common with 942 (56.6%) events";" however, 90 (62.5%) of the injuries and assaults occurred during home visits, and 22 (66%) occurred during night calls. Relatives were aggressive in 668 (37.6%) cases, anxiety in 435 (25.7%) cases, and long waiting in 183 (10.8%) cases. CONCLUSIONS Violence against GPs is common and may be on the rise. Some of the triggers of aggression are potentially avoidable, and applications must make extensive attempts to identify such factors and correct them. Training of staff in interpersonal skills and recognizing anxious or intoxicated patients is essential and should be supplemented with consideration of operative order and repair. Physicians should avoid delays for patients by rearranging reservation policies or surgery times and lengths. Victims of aggression should be pursued. A prospective study or centralized registry of events should be funded.

title: 'We can only do what we can do' for general practitioners' views on primary care for older people with complex health problems
abstract: BACKGROUND: Due to demographic change, general practitioners (GPs) are increasingly required to care for older people with complex health problems. Little is known about GPs' subjective assessment of the requested changes. Our aim is to explore how general practitioners view their professional mandate and capacity to provide comprehensive care to older people with complex health problems. Does geriatric education or experience affect their perspective? Can the barriers to implementing changes in primary care for the elderly with complex health problems be identified? METHODS: Prior to a controlled intervention study on case management for elderly patients in primary care (OMAHA II), this qualitative study included 10 general practitioners with varying degrees of geriatric qualifications. Semi-structured interviews were conducted and audio recorded. Full interview transcripts were analyzed on a case-by-case basis and starting with open coding in case descriptions. The resulting thematic structure was enriched with comparative dimensions through repeated inter-situation comparison and transformed into a multidimensional typology of views. RESULTS: Based on the themes emerging from the data and presentations by the GPs interviewed, we were able to identify three different types of views on primary care for older people with complex health problems: 'manoeuvring across the boundaries of competence', 'Herculean task' and 'collaboration and networking' '. Types of views differ in role perception, self-perception of professional space, and patterns of action regarding cooperation. One species shows strong correspondence with a geriatrician. A common concern across all groups is the availability of adequate resources to meet the challenges of primary care for older people with complex health problems. CONCLUSIONS: Limited financial resources, lack of cooperation networks and attitudes appear to be barriers to providing better primary care to older people with complex health problems. Geriatrics education is likely to have a positive impact on overcoming these barriers, but needs to be supported by reimbursement regulations. First of all, general practitioners' care for older people with complex health problems needs a conceptual framework that provides guidance on their specific roles and contributions and help networks. For example, it is essential that general practice guidelines be made clearer on managing older people with complex health problems.

title: Web-based computer adaptation for practice nurses aiming to improve adherence to smoking cessation guidelines: A study protocol for a randomized controlled efficacy study.
abstract: BACKGROUND: Dutch practice nurses are insufficiently committed to evidence-based smoking cessation guidelines. Web-based computer adaptation can be effective in improving their adherence to the manual. Therefore, this article aims to describe the development of a web-based, computerized program and the design of a randomized controlled trial testing its (cost) efficacy. METHODS: A web-based, computerized program was developed that included three modules with tailored advice and an online forum, theoretically based on the I-Change Model and The Theory of Self-Determination, and based on the results of a qualitative needs assessment among practice nurses. , up-to-date information on smoking cessation, Frequently Asked Questions (FAQs) and modules with project information and a consulting checklist. Program impacts are evaluated by comparing an intervention group (access to all modules) and a control group (access to FAQs, project information and consulting checklist only). Adherence to the smoking cessation guideline and behavioral determinants (i.e. intention, knowledge, attitude, self-efficacy, social impact, action, and coping planning) are measured at baseline and at 6 and 12 months follow-up. In addition, the indirect effects of the program on smokers' quit rates and attempts to quit after the 6th and 12th months are evaluated. DISCUSSION: This article describes the study design of a randomized controlled trial that tested the (cost) efficacy and development of a web-based, computerized compliance support program for practice nurses. This program potentially contributes to improving the quality of smoking cessation care in Dutch general practice. If proven effective, the program could be adapted for use by other health professionals, increasing the public health benefits of improved smoking cessation counseling for smokers.

title: Web-based interventions for ulcerative colitis and Crohn's disease: systematic review and future directions.
abstract: Behavioral intervention technologies (BITs), the application of psychological and behavioral interventions through the use of technology, provide clinicians with the opportunity to deliver care in a way that transcends a range of treatment barriers. Web-based interventions are a subset of ICTs that are emerging as promising alternatives to in-person treatment delivery and monitoring for patients with ulcerative colitis (UC) and Crohn's disease (CD). A systematic review of the literature resulted in five empirical studies of web-based interventions for UC and CD. Additionally, an informal search by a popular search engine provided limited, currently available web-based interventions for patients with UC and CD. Despite being an ideal population for the development and dissemination of online interventions, patients with UC and CD have far fewer treatment options compared to other behavioral health problems. However, given the growing body of research that includes web-based interventions for other conditions, researchers and clinicians targeting the management and treatment of UC and CD have the advantage of being able to use the BIT model, an existing conceptual framework for web-based development. Interventions for both conditions. The BIT model is presented and applied to the treatment of UC and CD, as well as a technology development program, Purple and usability guidelines to guide clinical researchers in the future development, evaluation, and dissemination of BITs for patients with UC and CD.

title: Weekly Email reminders influence emergency physician behavior: A case study using the Joint Commission and Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services Pneumonia Guidelines.
abstract: OBJECTIVES: Improving physician compliance with evidence-based guidelines is difficult. The authors wanted to determine whether weekly email reminders to emergency room (ED) personnel improve compliance with Joint Commission and Medicare and Medicaid Services (CMS) community-acquired pneumonia quality measures. METHODS: A nurse administrator reviewed weekly records of all adult patients admitted to the hospital from the emergency department with a working pneumonia diagnosis. An email was then sent to all emergency room personnel stating the percentage of patients who were scheduled for antibiotics less than 4 hours after arrival. The names of people who administered antibiotics in less than 1 hour were highlighted. This study compared time elapsed with antibiotics 11 months before and 11 months after the start of this intervention. RESULTS: The control cohort had 281 patients, 37 meeting the exclusion criteria, leaving 244 for analysis. The intervention cohort had 342 patients, of whom 40 met the exclusion criteria and left 302 for analysis. The median time from arrival to chest radiograph order was significantly reduced from 61 to 47 minutes (p < 0.001). The median time interval from the time of chest radiography to administration of antibiotics did not change significantly (92 to 88 minutes, p = 0.294). The overall median time from arrival to antibiotic administration was significantly reduced from 162 minutes to 146 minutes (p = 0.018). The percentage of patients administered antibiotics within 4 hours increased from 77.5% to 86.1% (p = 0.009). CONCLUSIONS: Weekly email reminders listing performance on antibiotic administration recommendations are associated with increased compliance with a clinical guideline.

title: Weight Care Project: Attitudes and skills of health professionals to assess body weight status - study protocol
abstract: BACKGROUND: Health professionals working in primary care and public health have opportunities to address body weight status issues through face-to-face contact with their patients. The aims of this all-Ireland project are to: 1. Evaluate the attitudes, current practice/behavior and knowledge of key health professional groups on body weight status"; both adults and children. Health professional groups are: (a) community public health nurses; (b) school public health nurses; (c) general practitioners and practice nurses (primary care);" and (d) occupational health nurses (workplace) from both Northern Ireland and the Republic of Ireland. METHODS/DESIGN: This Irish multidisciplinary project follows a mixed methods approach using both quantitative and qualitative methodologies and consists of four components: 1. Literature review - to explore the role of health professionals in the management of obesity through spontaneous intervention in a variety of health promotion settings. 2nd. Phone interviews and focus groups - to gain an in-depth insight into healthcare professionals' views in assessing body weight status.3. Questionnaire (primarily online but also paper-based) - to determine the attitudes, current practice/behaviors and knowledge of health professionals in assessing body weight status. Online assessment study - an online interactive program will be developed to assess the ability of health professionals to determine the body weight status of adults and children. DISCUSSION: This project will evaluate and report on the attitudes, current practice/behavior and knowledge of key health professional groups in Northern Ireland and the Republic of Ireland on body weight status and their ability to determine body weight status in both adults and children. The results of this project will generate recommendations for clinical practice in obesity management that can inform policy guidelines.

title: Weight maintenance: challenges, tools and strategies for primary care physicians
abstract: Obesity is considered a chronic disease and one of the biggest health problems we face today. Weight loss can be achieved through lifestyle, pharmacological and surgical interventions, but weight maintenance remains a lifelong challenge for individuals with obesity. Guidelines for obesity management have emphasized the role of primary care providers (PCPs). This review examines the long-term results of clinical trials to identify effective weight maintenance strategies that can be used by PCPs. Due to the broad nature of the subject, a structured PubMed search was conducted to identify relevant research articles, peer-reviewed reviews, guidelines, and articles published by regulatory agencies. Trials have shown the benefit of sustained weight loss in managing obesity and co-morbidities. It is known that maintaining 5-10% weight loss for >/=1 year improves many comorbidities. Maintaining weight through lifestyle change is possible—though difficult—but requires long-term support through diet, physical activity, and reinforcement of behavior changes. Adding pharmacotherapy to lifestyle interventions promotes greater and more sustainable weight loss. Clinical evidence and recently approved pharmacotherapy have provided PCPs with advanced strategies to support their patients in the maintenance of weight loss. More work is needed to evaluate the translation of these strategies into clinical practice.

title: Weighty topics - an approach to childhood overweight in general practice
abstract: BACKGROUND: Childhood obesity in Australia rivals asthma as the most prevalent chronic child health condition. The past 20 years have shown that the prevalence of childhood overweight and obesity is rising rapidly, and there are no signs that this trend is going to flatten out. Primary care is recognized as a forum to address this growing public health issue. OBJECTIVE: This article discusses the epidemiology of childhood overweight and obesity and their associated physical and psychosocial morbidities in Australia. Discusses the current evidence base and resources for the definition, research and management of childhood obesity and outlines an approach in the primary care setting. It also reports that a recently developed GP intervention to reduce excess weight in primary school-aged children - the Live, Eat and Play (LEAP) project. CONCLUSION: Clear clinical practice guidelines are now available for the assessment and management of childhood overweight and obesity in primary care. The applicability of these guidelines and the availability of resources to deliver them are not yet clear. The LEAP project proposes an effective intervention delivered by general practitioners to address this vital and complex issue.

title: Well-balanced: 8 steps to healthy living for adults with mental illness and diabetes
abstract: Serious mental illness places an enormous burden on clients, their families, and behavioral and medical healthcare providers. The co-occurrence of diabetes with mental illness can further compromise daily functioning. Psychiatric nurses can make a significant difference in improving the health and medical outcomes of this client population. A partnership has been developed between the University of Rochester School of Nursing and the Western New York Care Coordinating Program to evaluate a new nursing model for adults with both severe mental illness and diabetes. The Well Balanced program combined health promotion, disease management, nursing care management, and evidence-based practice guidelines in 8 Steps to Wellness for a community-based mental health population. During an intervention period of 16 visits, psychiatric nurses interacted with 74 clients. As a result of the program, customers experienced improvements in their health risk status and hemoglobin A1C and reported high satisfaction with the Well Balanced program.

title: WellDoc mobile diabetes management randomized controlled trial: change in clinical and behavioral outcomes and patient and physician satisfaction
abstract: BACKGROUND: Less than 63% of individuals with diabetes meet the professional guidelines' hemoglobin A1c target of <7.0%, and only 7% meet the combined glycemic, lipid, and blood pressure targets. The aim of the primary study was to evaluate the impact of a mobile phone-based diabetes management software system on A1c, used in conjunction with web-based data analytics and treatment optimization tools. Secondary objectives examined healthcare provider (HCP) adherence to prescribing guidelines and evaluated HCPs adoption of technology. METHODS: Thirty patients with type 2 diabetes were recruited from three community medicine practices for a 3-month study and were equally randomized. The intervention group received cell phone-based software designed by endocrinologists and CDEs (WellDoc Communications, Inc., Baltimore, MD). The software provided real-time feedback on patients' blood glucose levels, displayed patients' medication regimens, combined hypo- and hyperglycemia treatment algorithms, and requested additional data needed to evaluate diabetes management. Patient data captured and transferred to secure servers were analyzed with special statistical algorithms. The system sent computer-generated logbooks (with recommended treatment plans) to the HCPs of intervention patients. RESULTS: The mean reduction in A1c for intervention patients was 2.03% compared to 0.68% for control patients (P < 0.02, one-tailed). 84% of intervention patients had drugs titrated or changed by their HCP compared to controls (23%, P = 0.002). Intervention patients' HCPs reported that the system facilitates treatment decisions, provides regular data, and reduces registry review time. RESULTS: Adults with type 2 diabetes using WellDoc's software achieved statistically significant improvements in A1c. HCP and patient satisfaction with the system were clinically and statistically significant.

title: What are the attitudes of specialist mental health clinicians towards guideline recommendations for the treatment of depression in young people?
abstract: OBJECTIVES: As part of an initiative to implement evidence-based practice in the service, we sought to examine possible barriers to the use of evidence-based guidelines for youth depression in a tertiary specialist mental health service. METHODS: This is a qualitative study that adopts a social constructivist perspective using focus groups. Focus groups conducted with all clinicians (medical and allied health) were audio-recorded, transcribed and thematic analysis was performed. Clinicians were asked about barriers to implementing four key recommendations from the National Institute for Health and Clinical Excellence (NICE) guidelines. CONCLUSIONS: Barriers (i) at the individual clinician level; (ii) at the clinical level in terms of youth presentation; and (iii) service level. A key hurdle at the individual clinician level was the expressed belief that the guidelines were not relevant to young people applying for services and that there was little evidence to guide practice. The main barrier to relevant, clinical presentation was the severity and complexity of this presentation, often making it difficult to deliver interventions such as cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT). At the service level, the lack of integration with primary and secondary care meant that it was difficult to rank interventions according to guideline recommendations. CONCLUSIONS: The development of an evidence base is a clear imperative to enable research and dissemination of effective treatments for young people up to 25 years of age with serious and complex disorders, including co-morbid conditions, risk of suicide and psychosocial difficulties. Furthermore, this study underlined the need for greater investment in care models that enable integration between existing primary and secondary health care services and advanced specialist early intervention mental health services for youth.

title: What do GPs think and do about prostate cancer screening in Australia?
abstract: BACKGROUND: Men seek advice from their general practitioner (GP) about the benefits of prostate cancer screening. This study aimed to examine how GPs' knowledge and clinical experience affect their position in prostate cancer screening. METHODS: A total of 13 focus groups were formed with 77 general practitioners. Focus group interviews were audio-recorded and transcribed verbatim. Transcripts were analyzed by two researchers through thematic analysis. RESULTS: Doctors were evenly divided between those who proactively screened men for prostate cancer and those who only did so at the patient's request. GPs had limited knowledge of the recently published evidence from studies on prostate cancer screening. CONCLUSION: To encourage evidence-based decision-making by GPs and their patients, effective methods of increasing GP knowledge about evidence-based recommendations and potentially changing clinical behavior are required.

title: What do patients and their families know about problems and failures in care?
abstract: Purpose To understand what patients and family members know about health care problems and failures. Qualitative, semi-structured open-ended interviews were conducted with 39 design patients and 80 family members about their experiences with events in tertiary health care. More than one participant took part in nineteen interviews and a total of 100 interviews were obtained. Participants were recruited by advertisements in the national wide-page and tabloid press (43%), with the help of health services where the events occurred (28%), invitations sent by two internet marketing companies (27%), and consumers (27%). organizations (2%). Setting The interviews were conducted at the participants' homes or by telephone. One participant sent his answers to the questionnaire by e-mail. Results Analysis of interview data revealed: (1) substantial knowledge of patients and their relatives about healthcare risks, problems, and events"; (2) interviewees' insights into care improvement opportunities;" and (3) the difficulties faced by patients and family members when trying to negotiate their knowledge and understanding with healthcare personnel. Conclusion Patients (and family members) need access to structured processes that enable dialogue with healthcare personnel about perceived risks, problems and events. This type of dialogue will raise questions and information from patients and family members about improvement opportunities and minimize the risk of their questions and information being ignored.

title: What do people with mental illness need to quit smoking? Mental health consumer and provider perspectives
abstract: OBJECTIVES: Forty-one percent (41%) of people in the United States who have reported recent mental illness are also smokers. In this population, tobacco use is associated with up to 25 years of reduced life expectancy and excessive medical comorbidity compared to the general population. Although research shows that tobacco interventions can be effective for people with mental illness, they are not widely used in clinical practice. The current study explored how to adapt evidence-based tobacco cessation interventions to meet the unique physiological, psychological and social challenges faced by people with mental illness. METHODS: Ten focus groups were conducted using a semi-structured discussion";" 5 for adult mental health consumers (n = 62) and 5 with mental health clinicians and administrators (n = 22). Content analysis was used to categorize themes. RESULTS: Five thematic categories were found: (1) Barriers to treatment, (2) Resources and infrastructure, (3) Adverse effects on smoking behavior, (4) Lack of knowledge, and (5) Treatment needs. CONCLUSIONS: These findings guide the development of appropriate tobacco cessation services for this population. Specifically, these data were included in a mental health provider toolkit for smoking cessation and informed the development of a tobacco cessation intervention study.

title: What am I going to tell the Royal Commission? Our neglected wasteland
Which implementation interventions increase cancer screening rates? a systematic review
abstract: Background Appropriate screening can reduce the mortality and morbidity of colorectal, breast and cervical cancers. However, effective implementation strategies are warranted if the full benefits of screening are to be realized. As part of a larger agenda to create a practice guideline, we conducted a systematic review to evaluate interventions designed to increase breast, cervical, and colorectal cancer (CRC) screening rate. Interventions considered were: client reminders, client incentives, mass media, small media, group training, one-on-one training, reduction in structural barriers, reduction in out-of-pocket expenses, provider evaluation and feedback interventions, and provider incentives. Our primary outcome, screening completion, was calculated as the overall median post-intervention absolute percentage point (PP) change in completed screening tests. Methods Our first step was to conduct an iterative scope review of the research area. This provided three relevant high-quality systematic reviews. We've made an official update, serving as our evidence base. Randomized controlled trials and cluster randomized controlled trials published between 2004 and 2010 were searched in MEDLINE, EMBASE, and PSYCHinfo. Results The update provided 66 studies with 74 comparisons and new eligible studies. The new studies varied significantly in quality. Client reminders, small media, and provider supervision and feedback appear to be effective interventions to increase screening uptake for the three cancers. One-on-one training and reducing structural barriers also appear to be effective, but their roles in CRC and cervical screening, respectively, are less established. More work is needed to evaluate customer incentives, mass media, group training, out-of-pocket reduction, and provider incentive interventions. Conclusion New evidence is generally consistent with evidence and conclusions from the original systematic reviews. This review served as an evidence base for a practice guide. Inadequate reporting, lack of precision and consistency in describing operational elements, and inadequate assessment of context and differences between populations are additional areas of research.

title: What is the role of the general practitioner versus the family carer of a relative with dementia living in the community? A systematic literature review
abstract: OBJECTIVE: To determine the attitudes and perspectives of family physicians towards the caregivers of their relatives with dementia and to define the satisfaction of the caregivers. DESIGN: Systematic review. SUBJECTS: The population studied consists of the dementia family and their practitioners. MAIN OUTCOME MEASURES: Outcome measures were the general practitioner's duties and skills to improve home care from the family caregiver's perspective. Caregivers were assessed for their satisfaction with the care provided by their general practitioner. CONCLUSIONS: The GP is aware of the skills and limitations of his role in all aspects of dementia care and towards the family caregiver. They also recognized the importance of an adequate diagnostic process, but were uncomfortable explaining the diagnosis to both the patient and caregiver. They reported that they relied more on treatment issues rather than diagnostic stages. Caregivers' reports of their general practitioner's attitude during the diagnostic process were rated from helpful to inadequate empathy. General practitioners found themselves highly involved in home dementia care, but caregivers found their involvement insufficient. The general practitioners' lack of appropriate communication skills was also not appreciated by the caregivers. Lack of time and reward was recognized by the GP as a major barrier to dementia care. CONCLUSION: The key role of general practitioners as care providers and care planners is reinforced by their confidence in the skills of family caregivers. Clear guidelines, from early detection to adequate referrals, should enhance the GP's ability to support these time and energy consuming home care situations. Intervention studies that address gaps in general practitioners' skills in dementia home care management can be helpful in supporting the family caregiver.

title: What is the value of routine use of patient-reported outcome measures to improve patient outcomes, processes of care, and healthcare outcomes in cancer care? A systematic review of controlled studies
abstract: OBJECTIVE: The systematic use of patient-reported outcome measures (PROMs) has been advocated as an effective way to standardize cancer practice. Still, the question of whether PROMs will lead to real improvements in the quality of patient care is still a matter of debate. This review examined whether the inclusion of PROM in routine clinical practice is associated with improvements in patient outcomes, processes of care, and healthcare outcomes during active anticancer therapy. METHODS: Randomized and nonrandomized controlled trials of patients receiving active anticancer therapy or supportive care regardless of cancer type. RESULTS: We included 26 articles reporting on 24 unique controlled studies based on predetermined eligibility criteria. Wide variation was evident in the design and use of the interventions presented, the evaluation of outcomes, and the cancer- and modality-specific context. Healthcare outcomes were rarely included as endpoints only. Overall, the number of statistically significant findings was limited and intervention effect sizes of PROMs were predominantly small-to-moderate. CONCLUSION: The routine use of PROMs increases the frequency of discussion of patient outcomes during consultations. In some studies, PROMs are associated with improved symptom control, increased supportive care measures, and patient satisfaction. Additional effort is required to ensure patient engagement as well as additional support with open system guidelines to guide their responses to clinicians who will respond to the patient's concerns and problems. More research is needed to support the cost-benefit of PROM in terms of patient safety, clinician burden, and healthcare utilization.

title: What will we teach undergraduate students?
abstract: The opinions of 600 randomly selected doctors about what should be taught to university students in clinical years were analyzed. Respondents gave high priority to general medicine, pediatrics, general surgery, casualties, and gynecology, while low priority to forensic medicine, plastic surgery, radiotherapy, anesthetics, radiology, and rehabilitation medicine. Doctors thought these should be taught to graduate students. The two large groups of doctors - GPs and counselors - gave essentially the same priorities. Undergraduate curricula may not include all major specializations, so the results of this analysis can provide a useful basis for selecting the most appropriate courses. The criteria for inclusion of other specialties may be the talent and enthusiasm of teachers and well thought out and academically sound teaching programs.

title: What's in a setting?: The impact of organizational culture on provider adherence to clinical guidelines for the treatment of tobacco use
abstract: BACKGROUND: Organizational culture is an important but under-researched feature of the work environment that can influence provider behavior, including adherence to clinical practice guidelines. There is substantial evidence that medical assistance to smokers can lead to significant reductions in tobacco use. However, this evidence has not translated well to practice, as only a small proportion of smokers receive the recommended treatment during medical visits. OBJECTIVE: This study examines organizational culture as a contextual feature of primary care clinics and its impact on adherence to evidence-based guidelines for the treatment of tobacco use. METHODOLOGY: Cross-sectional survey data were collected from 500 primary care providers at 60 community clinics located in New York City. Relationships between provider compliance with "5A" clinical guidelines and both provider and institutional covariates were described, as recommended by the US Public Health Service. We used hierarchical linear modeling to examine the relationships between clinical culture and provider treatment models. RESULTS: Providers in clinics with stronger 'group/clan', 'hierarchical' and 'rational' culture types compared with 'developmental' culture reported greater adherence to 5A guidelines (p < .05). System-level structures and maintenance processes were positively associated (p < .01), while the number of ongoing quality initiatives was negatively associated with 5A delivery (p < .05). Provider familiarity with guidelines (p < .01), confidence in cessation counseling (p < .05), and perceived effectiveness in helping smokers quit were associated with more frequent 5A interventions (p < .01). PRACTICE PRACTICES: Findings suggest that institutional culture can influence provider adherence to cessation treatment guidelines, even when controlling for other factors known to influence practice patterns. Specifically, cultures that emphasize human resources and performance standards are conducive to integrating the 5A guidelines into routine practice. Understanding the role of organizational culture enables health managers and practitioners to be strategic when applying and maintaining the use of evidence-based guidelines.

title: What's on your Facebook profile? Evaluation of an educational intervention to encourage appropriate use of privacy settings on social networking sites by medical students
abstract: BACKGROUND: The rise of social media has led to growing concerns about the potential impact of 'unprofessional' posts by doctors and medical students on individuals, institutions and the medical profession. Relevant and effective guidelines have been difficult to develop and implement, and students and physicians need to consider how their online activities may be perceived in the context of their professional roles. The aim of this project was to examine the online presence of a Canadian medical school graduating class by scanning the students' public profiles on the social media site Facebook, to incorporate this knowledge into an educational activity for professionalism and social media, and to evaluate the impact of this. Activity on student behavior. METHODS: A systematic search was conducted for the public Facebook profiles of each member of the class and data was collected on the types of material that anyone could see. These were presented as part of a training session on social media and professionalism. A month later, the Facebook search was repeated. RESULTS: The profiles of 121 (79.8%) of the 152 students in the class were found. Most students used appropriately restrictive privacy settings";" however, a significant minority had publicly visible information, including comments, photos, location, and medical student status. The educational innovation was well received, with over 90% of students agreeing that this topic is important and well handled. A follow-up study found that many students changed their privacy settings to make less information public. CONCLUSIONS: A small but significant proportion of students share potentially unprofessional content on social media. An interactive educational intervention involving private disclosure of how participants appear to others on social media resulted in a significant change in student behavior.

title: When is it cost-effective to change the behavior of healthcare professionals?
abstract: Because of the way health care systems work, new, important, and cost-effective treatments sometimes do not become routine care, while well-marketed products of uncertain value are widely adopted. Should policymakers seek to influence clinical behavior and correct these inefficiencies? Implementation methods provide some level of behavior change, but are costly to enact. These factors can be combined with the cost-effectiveness of treatments to estimate an overall policy cost-effectiveness. In general, policy cost-effectiveness is always less attractive than treatment cost-effectiveness. As a result, trying to improve the uptake of underutilized affordable care or reduce the overuse of new and expensive treatments may not always make economic sense. In this article, we present a method for calculating policy cost-effectiveness and illustrate this with examples from a recent trial of educational access conducted by community pharmacists to influence physician prescribing in England in 1997 and 1998.

title: When pharmacotherapeutic recommendations may adversely affect physician decision-making
abstract: Long-term medical literature has shown that patients do not always receive appropriate care, including pharmacotherapeutic treatment. Physician-focused interventions are implemented internationally to apply evidence-based medicine in the routine daily practice of medical practitioners to achieve improved patient care. The pharmacy profession has taken an active role in providing evidence-based prescribing and intervention strategies aimed at improving the quality and safety of drug use. However, the medical literature also supports the idea that current clinical care recommendations do not always have the desired effect on physician behavior. We argue that the established theory of psychological response may at least partially explain situations in which doctors do not act on such recommendations. Response theory posits that when we are offered to take a certain action, a motivational situation compels us to react in a way that affirms our freedom of choice. We often choose to do the opposite of what the advice suggests we do, or simply settle into our first position. The core concepts of psychological reactance are universal and likely to be applicable to the provision of advice to physicians. Advice on clinical care, including pharmacotherapy, may carry tacit threats, as it may be perceived as an attempt to restrict one's freedom of choice, potentially as efforts to reactance and avoid them. By identifying and taking into account factors likely to increase reactance, physician-focused interventions can become more effective.

title: When the branch breaks: rethinking treatment strategies for perinatal depression
abstract: Awareness of depression among OB-GYN physicians has increased, with more than 13% of pregnant women in the United States receiving prescriptions for antidepressant medications. However, the safety and efficacy of these compounds have been exaggerated while the efficacy of psychotherapy has been overlooked and distorted, and various medical guidelines for the treatment of perinatal depression have been underestimated or ignored. This article addresses common fears and misconceptions about treating depression during pregnancy and after childbirth. The efficacy of hypnosis-enhanced strategic cognitive-behavioral therapy offers excellent results without the risks associated with these drugs. Goals for focused intervention are set and discussed.

title: When to start dialysis: impact of recommended US guidelines on survival
abstract: Background Recent guidelines from the US National Kidney Foundation Dialysis Outcomes Quality Initiative recommend starting dialysis treatment earlier than common practice. Their implementation will have a significant impact on patients' daily lives and increase costs. The guidelines are largely opinion-based, as there is still no evidence.";" Background Recent guidelines from the US National Kidney Foundation Dialysis Outcomes Quality Initiative recommend starting dialysis treatment earlier than common practice. Their implementation will have a significant impact on patients' daily lives and increase costs. Guidelines are largely opinion-based, as evidence is still lacking.

title: Where will John go? Newfoundland
Who wrote the Declaration of Helsinki?
Why are clinicians not embracing results from major clinical trials in severe sepsis? Bayesian analysis
abstract: BACKGROUND: Five major clinical studies (Intensive Insulin Therapy"; Recombinant Human Activated Protein C [rhAPC]; Low Tidal Volume; Low Dose Steroid; Early Targeted Therapy [EGDT]) have demonstrated reduced mortality in patients with severe sepsis and in specialist guidelines. has recommended them to clinical practice. However, adoption of these therapies remains low among clinicians. OBJECTIVES: We selected these five studies and asked: Question 1--What is the current probability that the new treatment will not be better than standard?Care for my patient with severe sepsis Question 2-Relative death for my patient with severe sepsis What is the current probability of reducing the risk (RRR) with significant clinical thresholds (RRR >15%; >20%; >25%) METHODS: This study applied Bayesian methodologies Odds ratio (OR) for Question 1 and RRR for Question 2 Effective sample sizes of other relevant clinical studies (negative evidence) Background distributions, prior distributions, and data from key studies (positive evidence) was calculated by merging. MAIN RESULTS: Answer 1--The previously mildly skeptical analysis showed beneficial results with the Intense Insulin, rhAPC and Low Tidal Volume trials, but not the Low Dose Steroid and EGDT trials. The results of all trials become unacceptable by analyzes using moderate or severely skeptical priorities. Answer 2--If we are targeting RRR>15%, mildly skeptical analysis shows that the current probability of reducing death with this clinical threshold is 88% for Intensive Insulin and 62-65% for Low Tidal Volume, rhAPC. , 17% for the EGDT trials and the Low Dose Steroid trial. Moderate to severe skeptical analyzes do not show a clinically significant reduction in the risk of death for all trials. If we target the RRR >20% or >25%, all benefits are less likely, regardless of the degree of suspicion. CONCLUSIONS: Our clinical threshold analysis offers a new bedside tool to be applied directly to the care of patients with severe sepsis. Our results show that the strength of evidence (statistical and clinical) is weak for all trials, particularly the Low-Dose Steroid and EGDT trials. It is crucial to replicate the results of each of these five clinical trials in confirmatory studies if we are to provide patient care based on scientifically sound evidence.

title: Why do doctors treat relatives? Exploring the impact of social psychology
abstract: Doctors often receive requests for treatment, medical advice, or other intervention from relatives. Most doctors are asleep. Reasons for compliance can be categorized according to doctors' relatives, colleagues, themselves, ethical guidelines, and attitudes towards the problem. Adaptation can also be influenced by elements of social psychology. Social exchange theory, techniques of persuasion, attribution, conformity, desire for approval, and the principle of affinity can all cause interference. Future research should explore physicians' attitudes towards relatives, the environment in which requests are made, treatment outcomes, changes in the relationship following treatment, cultural or familial norms, and changes in clinicians' beliefs or behaviors when faced with conflicting wishes and guidelines. Being aware of these effects can help physicians make objective decisions about intervention.

title: Why don't even good doctors wash their hands?
Why are there no guidelines for behavior change?
abstract: This article reviews guidelines for behavior programs published by the National Association for Children with Disabilities. The review discusses several reasons why guidelines for behavior change should not be specified; for example, behavior change procedures are not more or less subject to abuse and need no more or less ethical regulation than intervention procedures derived from any of them. is a set of other principles and is called by other terms. The review proposes alternative methods to protect the rights of clients participating in behavior programs. Specifically, behavioral clinicians, like other therapists, should be guided by the ethics of their profession";" furthermore, the ethics of all intervention programs should be evaluated in terms of a number of critical issues.

title: Why do providers transfuse blood products outside of recommended guidelines despite integrated electronic best practice alerts?
abstract: BACKGROUND: Best practice advisories (BPAs) provide point-of-care clinical decision support (CDS) to reduce unnecessary blood product transfusions, but substantial transfusions continue outside recommended guidelines. OBJECTIVE: To understand why providers order blood transfusions outside of recommended guidelines despite interrupted warnings. DESIGN: Retrospective review. SETTING: Tertiary hospital. PARTICIPANTS: Health care providers receiving inpatient treatment. INTERVENTION: Provider-BPA interaction data was collected from the hospital's electronic medical records from January 2011 to August 2012. MEASUREMENTS: Provider's (free text) responses to blood transfusion BPA requests were independently reviewed and categorized by 2 licensed physicians, assessed by agreement chi(2) analysis and kappa scoring. RESULTS: The rationale for voiding blood transfusion BPAs was quite diverse, the most common being acute bleeding (>34%), followed by protocol-bound behavior in specialized services (up to 26%), to "symptomatic" anemia (11-12%). . . Many providers transfused in anticipation of surgical or procedural intervention (10-15%) or imminent hospital discharge (2%-5%). Resident physicians represented the majority (55%) of providers interacting with BPAs. CONCLUSION: Providers that interact with BPAs (primarily residents and intermediate providers) often do not have the negotiation power to change order behavior. Prototype behaviors that are unlikely to be affected by BPAs are among the most frequently cited reasons for transfusion outside of the guidelines. Symptomatic anemia is a common, though subjective, indication for blood transfusion. With a wide range of individually uncommon justifications for transfusion behavior, the secondary use of electronic medical record databases and integrated CDS tools is essential for efficiently analyzing common practice behaviors.

title: Why we still do arthroscopy in knee osteoarthritis: a multi-method study
abstract: BACKGROUND: Knee arthroscopy has historically been a common treatment for knee osteoarthritis. However, multiple Randomized Controlled Trials, combined with a Cochrane review, have led NICE to recommend that arthroscopy not be used in the vast majority of patients with knee osteoarthritis. These recommendations have been replicated internationally. The use of arthroscopy in knee osteoarthritis has decreased";" but still common. This study examines the factors thought to influence decision making using a theoretical framework (The Theoretical Domains Framework) developed for behavior change research. This work will allow future studies to develop and evaluate an intervention that specifically targets identified barriers. METHODS: A multimodal approach was used, including survey research and semi-structured interviews with physicians of all degrees providing knee arthroscopy services at the Primary Trauma Center in the West Midlands, UK. Focus groups were also held with patients. Descriptive statistics were used for quantitative data, and thematic content analysis and mixed method analysis were used for qualitative data. RESULTS: A total of 26 surgeons answered the questionnaires with 6 semi-structured interviews. All surgical grades were represented. Two focus groups consisting of six patients were applied. Results identified 13 beliefs across 12 domains (some beliefs were represented across domains). The belief that there is pressure from patients to do something, other options are limited, surgeons want to meet patients' expectations, and time pressure in the clinic emerged as dominant barriers. CONCLUSIONS: Using the Theoretical Domains Framework, this article identified relevant barriers and facilitators in the implementation of the NICE guideline on the use of arthroscopy in patients with knee osteoarthritis. The next step in this process is the development of a targeted intervention, and we discuss the barriers most likely to change practice if targeted through an intervention, and what such an intervention might look like. Such an intervention will require evaluation in a clinical setting.

title: Why don't women ask for information about pre-pregnancy health? a qualitative study
abstract: BACKGROUND: Preconception care includes health promotion to reduce risk factors that may affect women and couples of childbearing age. Risk factors for adverse reproductive outcomes include family or individual recognized genetic diseases, previous congenital diseases, miscarriage, preterm birth, fetal growth restriction, infertility, chronic maternal diseases, lifestyle, and occupational or environmental factors. Effective preconception care includes a range of preventive, therapeutic and behavioral interventions. Although there are national recommendations for preconception care for the general population in Italy, they are often promoted informally and only for single risk factors. There is currently a growing interest in offering a global response in this area. The aim of this study is to examine the attitudes and behaviors of Italian women of childbearing age and health professionals towards pre-pregnancy health. METHODS: We conducted a qualitative study among women of childbearing age and health professionals between February 2014 and February 2015. Five focus groups were conducted: 2 with non-pregnant women aged 22-44 and 3 with healthcare professionals. Discussion topics are women's questions about pre-pregnancy health, concerns and barriers to pre-pregnancy care interventions, attitudes and behaviors of women and health professionals towards pre-pregnancy health, and women's information resources. In the analysis of focus groups, priority was given to what women said, supported by information from focus groups of health professionals. RESULTS: 14 women of childbearing age (8 nulliparous and 6 multiparous) and 12 healthcare professionals (3 nurses, 4 midwives, 5 doctors) participated in the focus groups. The results demonstrate the existence of many barriers to women, health professionals and policy and the lack of pre-pregnancy health awareness. The knowledge and attitudes of women towards primary pre-pregnancy care information are explained. For Italian women, the main source of information in this field seems to be obstetricians and gynecologists. CONCLUSIONS: The study shows that various barriers affect preconception care in Italy. There is also a lack of awareness of pre-pregnancy health and care among Italian women of childbearing age and health professionals. The findings may contribute to strategies for implementing preconception care guidelines.

title: Perspectives of WIC providers in offering smoking cessation interventions
abstract: OBJECTIVE: To examine the perspectives of WIC clinical providers on offering smoking cessation interventions to pregnant women. STUDY DESIGN AND METHODS: Four focus groups of WIC nurses, dietitians, and social workers (N = 25) were conducted at WIC clinics in eastern Iowa. The researchers developed discussion guides to determine how WIC providers currently approach pregnant women who smoke and what they consider barriers to providing effective smoking cessation interventions. Code matching was used to analyze focus group discussions. RESULTS: Factors influencing the ability of WIC staff to provide smoking cessation interventions for pregnant women included time available, clinical priorities, staff approaches to clients, and staff training. Additionally, providers have expressed concerns about additional customer issues that prevent smoking cessation alongside educational materials for customers. The absence of mechanisms to monitor clinical outcomes related to smoking cessation was also noted. CLINICAL APPLICATIONS: WIC providers have time limits that may require minimal or low-intensity interventions to quit smoking, but did not know such approaches were truly effective. WIC providers need more education on the whole topic of smoking cessation to be more proactive in their attempts to help pregnant women quit. To motivate staff to intervene, training should be initiated to increase self-efficacy and understanding of the impact of smoking on mothers, infants and children. Another strategy to motivate WIC staff could be to monitor clinical outcomes in helping women quit smoking or prevent relapse.

title: Will mothers of sick children help their husbands quit smoking with a brief intervention from nurses? Secondary analysis of a randomized controlled trial
abstract: BACKGROUND: Secondhand smoke is a serious health hazard for children. Clinical guidelines recommend that nurses advise smoking parents to stop smoking when accompanying their sick child to pediatric settings, but the guidelines do not mention what nurses can do if the parents are not present. This study examines the effectiveness of a low-intensity, nurse-led health education initiative in motivating non-smoking mothers to take action to help their husbands quit smoking. METHODS: This was a randomized controlled trial and enrolled 1,483 non-smoking women living with their sick children while on admission to the general pediatric wards/outpatient departments of four hospitals in Hong Kong. Women were randomly assigned to intervention and control groups. The first received brief health education consultations from nurses, a purposeful health education booklet, a "no smoking" label, and a phone call a week later";" control group received usual care.
