The primary outcome was women's action in helping their smoking husbands quit smoking at 3, 6, and 12-month follow-ups. husbands quit smoking at 3 months (76% vs. 65%, P < .001), 6 months (66% vs. 49%, P < .001), and 12 months (52% vs. 40%, P < .001) Women who received the intervention, had better knowledge of the health hazards of smoking, had higher intention to take precautions, and perceived their husbands' willingness to quit/reduce smoking had previously advised their husbands to smoke. The smoker was aware of her husband's smoking history and that her husband had tried to quit before and aimed to help them quit smoking in the follow-ups. It can be effective in motivating mothers of sick children to take action to help their husbands quit smoking. It recommends adding the following to clinical practice guidelines on the treatment of tobacco use and addiction: 'Nurses should provide concise advice to every non-smoking mother of a sick child to encourage their husbands to quit smoking'. TRIAL REGISTRATION: Current Controlled Trials ISRCTN72290421.

title: Words matter: increasing the application of clinical guidelines.
abstract: Objectives: To determine whether writing clinical guideline recommendations in behaviorally determined "plain English" language increases the likelihood that they will be implemented by service users (patients). Design: Randomized controlled trial in which participants received either the original text of the National Institute for Clinical Excellence (NICE) general guidelines on the management of schizophrenia or a behaviorally determined text with the same content. Setting: Mental health service user networks and voluntary sector organizations in two inner London boroughs. Participants: 84 mental health service users recruited by mail or face-to-face communication at service user meetings. Intervention: Section of public guidelines on psychological and pharmacological treatments for schizophrenia has been rewritten to improve style and behavioral specificity by applying evidence-based and psychologically informed principles of good written communication. Outcome measures: As indicated by the evidence-based theory of planned behavior, cognitive predictors of behavior constituted the primary outcome as it was not possible to measure the actual behavior of guide application. The predictors were behavioral intentions to implement instructions, attitudes towards implementation, and perceived behavioral control over implementation. Satisfaction with the guidelines and perceived understanding were also measured. Results: Behaviorally specified “plain English” directions led to stronger intentions to follow directions, more positive attitudes toward them, and greater perceived behavioral control over their use. There was no difference in satisfaction or perceived understanding. Conclusions: Writing guidelines with high behavioral specificity combined with the use of "plain English" can be a simple and effective way to increase their implementation. Evaluation with a behavioral outcome is now needed.

title: Working to improve hospital hyperglycemia care through statewide collaboration: Georgia Hospital Association Diabetes Special Interest Group
abstract: OBJECTIVE: To review the efforts of the Georgia Hospital Association Diabetes Special Interest Group (DSIG) to develop and disseminate exemplary clinical guidelines on the management of inpatient hyperglycemia. METHODS: Beginning in February 2003, a consortium of doctors and allied health professionals from across the state of Georgia began meeting frequently to formulate a plan to improve the care of hospitalized patients with hyperglycemia. The immediate goals of DSIG were the identification and organization of relevant stakeholders, the development of consensus model clinical guidelines, and the dissemination of information. RESULTS: Since its inception, DSIG has accomplished: the development of 7 consensus sample clinical guidelines, the creation of a Web site that publishes these clinical guidelines and other useful relevant information and educational materials, and sponsorship of workshops across the state of Georgia. CONCLUSION: As the importance of glucose control in the hospital setting is increasingly recognized, institutions must find ways to apply the results of clinical trials to "real world" hospital settings. DSIG is an example of successful collaboration that can serve as a model for other public hospital organizations that want to develop programs to improve the care of inpatients with hyperglycemia.

title: World Medical Association, statements on various issues, etc. adopts
Declaration of the World Medical Association of Helsinki. Recommendations to guide physicians in biomedical research involving human subjects
Xenotransplants: proceed with caution
Yoga for chronic low back pain: a randomized trial
abstract: Background: Previous studies show that yoga can be an effective treatment for chronic or recurrent low back pain. Purpose: To compare the effectiveness of yoga and usual care for chronic or recurrent low back pain. Design: Parallel-group, randomized, controlled trial using computer-generated randomization from April 2007 to March 2010. The results were evaluated with a postal questionnaire. (International Standard Registered Randomized Controlled Trial Number: ISRCTN 81079604) Setting: 13 sites in the UK that do not have a ¨CNational Health Service. Patients: 313 adults with chronic or recurrent low back pain. Intervention: Yoga (n = 156) or usual care (n = 157). All participants were given a back pain training booklet. The intervention group was presented with a step-by-step yoga program with 12 classes given over 3 months by 12 teachers. Measures: RolandÂ¨CMorris Disability Questionnaire (RMDQ) scores at 3 (primary outcome), 6, and 12 (secondary outcome)"; pain, pain self-efficacy, and general health measures at 3, 6, and 12 months (secondary outcomes) Results: 93 (60%) patients offered yoga for at least 3 of the first 6 sessions and at least 3 other sessions. Yoga group had better back function than normal care at 3, 6 and 12 months Adjusted mean RMDQ score was 2.17 in yoga group at 3 months score (95% CI, 1.03 to 3.31 points), 1.48 points (CI, 0.33 to 2.62 points) at 6 months, and 1.57 points (CI, 0.42 to 2.71 points) at 12 months , had similar back pain and general health scores at months 6 and 12, and the yoga group had higher pain self-efficacy scores at months 3 and 6, but two of 157 usual care participants and 12 of 156 yoga participants had side effects, mostly increased pain. Iteration: Missing data for primary outcome (yoga group, n = 21;" usual care group, n = 18) and difference for secondary outcomes There were missing data (more in the yoga group). Conclusion: Offering a 12-week yoga program to adults with chronic or recurrent low back pain improved back function more than normal care.

title: Young people receiving orthodontic care are not immune to poor diet and overweight: a call for dentists to join prevention efforts
abstract: OBJECTIVES: While obesity is prevalent in the United States, inequalities exist. It is assumed that orthodontic specimens are wealthier than the general population and do not need assistance in developing or maintaining healthy lifestyles. This article evaluates the need of the orthodontic population for intervention by examining the diet and weight status of a sample of orthodontic patients and describes the role of dentists in obesity prevention efforts. METHODS: 552 patients, 54% female, 51% non-Hispanic white, 26% Hispanic, aged 8-14 years, were recruited from orthodontic practices in Southern California to participate in a clinician-provided randomized controlled trial of health promotion. Height, weight, demographic information and diet were recorded. Chi-square analyzes were used to test for baseline differences by gender, age, ethnicity, and income. RESULTS: 13% of the sample were overweight and 9% were obese. The obesity rate in men was higher than in women. The proportion of low-income youth was higher than that of high-income youth. The proportion of Hispanic youth was higher than that of non-Hispanic white youth. Non-compliance with national dietary guidelines was common and differed significantly by demographic group. RESULTS: In a sample not typically thought to need help, about 25% were overweight or obese, and the majority did not meet dietary recommendations. While most patients could benefit from the intervention, male, Hispanic, and lower-income groups were the ones most in need of help. Dentists who see young people frequently and discuss nutrition in the context of oral health have the opportunity to contribute to the prevention of obesity.

title: Systematic Scoping Review of the Choice Architecture Movement: Toward Understanding When and Why Nudges Work
abstract: In this paper, we present an overall coverage review of the nudge action domain, reviewing 422 choice architecture interventions in 156 empirical studies. To review the current state of the nudge movement, we report the distribution of studies across countries, years, domains, sub-areas of applicability, types of interventions, and moderators associated with each intervention category. We also highlight certain features of studies and experimental and reporting practices that may hinder the accumulation of evidence in the field. Specifically, we found that 74% of studies were primarily motivated to assess the effectiveness of interventions in a particular setting, while only 24% of studies focused on investigating moderators or underlying processes. We also observed that only 7% of the studies applied power analysis, 2% used guidelines aimed at improving reporting quality, no studies were pre-registered in our database, and the intervention terminologies used were not comprehensive and often had overlapping categories. Based on our current observations and proposed solutions from other fields, we provide directly applicable recommendations for future research to support the body of evidence on why and when impulses work.
